text:
I am alway leery of places the trade on schtick. I should have known better, but on our recent trip to Portland, we decided to give the place a try.

Open 24 hours a day, there is always a line. We dutifully got in line which seemed to me should take about 20 min, given the fact that they are just handing you a product and there are multiple cashiers. Well, after an hour, we were finally inside the place. It is obviously garish with plenty of primary colors, goofiness, and double entendres. It is part of the whole schtick, so it's to be expected.

The displays showed their wide range of donuts which are designed to have visual wow factor, mainly via toppings like breakfast cereal or various icing patterns. We ordered four doughnuts to sample, one of which is their famed Bacon Maple Bar. The cashier was nice enough and we headed outdoors to picnic tables for sampling.

Boring. Or I should say: ordinary. We are basically talking Dunkin Donuts with "unusual" toppings and cute names. The Bacon Maple Bar is an ordinary maple bar with a couple of slices of decent bacon on it. I suppose since Dunkin Donuts has both maple bars and bacon slices you could probably bribe them to make you an equivalent for the $2.50 price tag.

The only donut that was in any way noteworthy was the Arnold Palmer, which was a cake doughnut with vanilla frosting and lemonade/iced tea powder. It was tasty enough.

The bottom line is go to Dunkin Donuts or any other decent local place and get doughnuts. Embellish them at home with bacon, cocoa puffs, or fruit loops and call it good. The schtick is simply not worth wasting an hour in Portland.

Innovative types of donuts but a bit priceyy (~3 per donut) Moreover, I think they make a lot of donuts ahead of time to meet demand but I'm partial to warm donuts and I couldn't get one of those here..

Voodoo definitely is something that is on your list for anyone visiting Portland, especially if you love doughnuts. At this location, be prepared to wait in line. On a Saturday morning, I waited maybe 15 minutes to get 6 doughnuts. Definitely try their Portland Cream and make sure you have cash handy as they do not accept card!

one word: HYPE.

Long line, which was to be expected so whatever. The employee's were super rude. But the worst part about my "voodoo" experience was that the bacon on my maple bar tasted old and funky. I dont even know how to describe it, but it was not good. (Im not picky either, usually bacon is bacon, but bleh!) Im not a fan of writting negative reviews but this place earned it.

Good, solid donuts. My major qualm is that the gentleman helping us feigned using a tissue to pick up the donuts. Saw him then use his hands. Which then grabbed my money. Sure he did that before and after us. Why try to use a tissue at all at that point?

Just your average donut. We came because we were visiting and had to check out the hype. The line took about 10-15 minutes. The ambiance was definitely Portland weird and it was a good stop to see what all the fuss was about. I wouldn't make it a must stop if I returned.

Ok. Yes.... yes. Eating donuts that look like voodoo men, have cereal on them, or that has bacon on it is fun.... but really it's like eating a 5 year olds creation. It looks funny, it tastes... well alright. 

There are hundreds of better donut places. My work used to get these on a twice monthly basis, they never tasted good. I would have been happy with Safeway, Fred Meyer or other donuts... they taste the same. 

In my opinion: go once for the fun factor, and promptly look elsewhere.
Okay donuts. They claim their "vegan" donuts are vegan but i have a dairy allergy and their donut still made me sick.

I was only in town for three days, and everyone was like "YOU HAVE TO GET VOODOO DOUGHNUT". Well, apparently everyone else's friends told them the same thing because the first time I went, the line was literally two blocks long. I would have felt like such a fat kid if I waited in a two-block line for a doughnut.

So then I tried to go after the bars, as I had heard Voodoo is 24 hours. It was closed. The universe did not want me to have these legendary doughnuts.

As I was leaving town I finally got one, but the selection was so overwhelming that I freaked out and just picked the first one that spun past me on that little rotating doughnut display, a Tang doughnut. It was unique, a little dry, nothing particularly special, but I'm glad I got to experience it, and wish I could go back to give it another try. I think it really does all just depend on what you get, so next time I'd spring for a dozen to sample a few more.
Man, whatever. It's sweet and carbtastic and I'm stumbling out of the tube. Go time.
Sadly overrated in my book. Nice staff and service though! We tried the Vicious Hibiscus, Blueberry Cake and one with oreos and caramel. Not bad, just didn't taste super fresh.
Just decorated "weird" or "fun" but the actual donut itself is NOT that great
They're good.  I've had better, but always fun to wait in line for Captain Crunch covered dough.

Nothing special, in my opinion. You get to wait in line out onto the sidewalk for who knows how long, have to pay cash... don't get taken by surprise by that. One guy in line got all the way up there and then didn't have cash for his doughnuts (and God knows they are expensive). (I would have covered for him but I couldn't.) And I don't find them to be anything special, other than some funny frosting.

Anyway, what's all the excitement about? You shouldn't be eating doughnuts anyway....  ;-)

A mediocre bunch of doughnuts mainly known for the unique and odd flavors.

Want fruit loop coveted doughnuts?  Check.  Doughnuts in the shape of make genitalia?  Check.  A giant Jerome Kersey doughnut created the day after his passing?  Check - though I'm sure this last one mentioned wasn't intended as a cash in and was more of a tribute.

The lines at both of the store front locations are ridiculous as well as perplexing.  Perplexing because you can find far better doughnut places within a mile or two of both store front locations.

The food cart at Cartlandia has not had a line anytime I have been to Cartlandia but the one time I tried to get a couple of doughnuts for the kids, they were out of stock of the few I was interested in.

The novelty of voodoo doughnuts is great and fun for the out-of-towners, but the locals have other tasty options to consider.

When you visit Portland, it's a place you need to stop by just to say you did so. But a return visit, for me, will not be necessary. I enjoy the quirky names, but the donuts are just average. I decided to try something new since I had already had the Bacon Maple Bar before. I had the Easy Peasy Lemon Kesey, which coincidentally I found out later a portion of it goes to the University of Oregon to do this: 

http://library.uoregon.edu/tools/blogs/scua/voodoo-donuts-ken-kesey-together-at-last/

A noble cause of which I was happy to play a small part in helping. Definitely if you're a lemon fan, this is the donut for you.

Also, I tried the famous Voodoo Doll complete with raspberry "blood" filling. I enjoyed this only because I'm a sucker for a filled donut. 

Consider this a place I've checked off my list.

I actually enjoyed their old fashioned glazed donut and didn't spend more than 10 minutes in line.  However I am not a fan of the hard metal music blaring inside or the greetings you receive when trying to enter or leave from the local homeless.    I never been to a place where there are 12 men and their dogs camping in front of a tourist spot waiting for customers to come out to wave their signs in your face as if they were teen girls at a Justin Bieber concert.  I heard people in line being concerned for their cars parked outside.  Not for me I guess.

I understand this a place to visit for doughnuts when you go to Portland but I found the doughnuts to be stale and way to sweet. I couldn't even finish one. Personally I think Psycho Donuts in San Jose is much better if you want the weird and wacky donut experience,

The donuts aren't really anything special, other than the fun toppings. There are better places around without the long lines. But for an experience when you're in town, Voodoo doughnuts is a must stop!

Taste wise - the doughnuts are average, often not the freshest, don't always have everything on their menu to choose from.

Experience wise - Not a friendly staff, classic Portland snobbery. Don't go late at night (downtown) due to long lines.

Novelty wise - some creative designs and the must-go junk food stop for drunkies and tourists.
Touristy and too much hype but if you are doughnut fan, this is definitely a place to go to when you are in Portland. I came, I ate and I saw....end of story.

I mean.. It's fine. Don't worry about the line it actually does move fast. Are the donuts good? Sure. Are they worth the price? Eh...

Honestly, blue star was better.

Voodoo is probably Portland's greatest attraction but do you really want to wait an hour for donuts?

We came here on a Sunday afternoon to a wave of tourists sprawling around the corners under the heated sun. No way you'd be a local Portlandian and wait an hour for a donut, even if it's Voodoo. 

We got a Voodoo Dozen which was pretty cheap because they are pretty filling. But other than the artistic representation of donuts, the donuts taste every average. Oh but they do have their special Voodoo Doughnot flavored beer...interesting.

I guess as a tourist, it's nice to check out but wouldn't come here again.

Voodoo Donuts it's a fairly known donut shop and a prime facet of Portland tourism, but arguably overhyped. The lines are always long just to get inside, but the real inconvenience is that they are cash only. You would think that as time progressed that they would adapt to accepting checks as well as credit or debit. So what's stopping them?

As you wait in line, you may find yourselves harassed by street characters who will ask you for money. I was once standing in line and this one homeless guy berated the whole crowd because nobody would give him a quarter. One of Old Town's problems is the homeless population which is quite neglected by the City of Portland. There's also a strong police presence in Old Town, so it'd be both nice and convenient if they could send more patrols to pass by Voodoo and through Ankeny Alley. That way patrons could feel a little less bothered.

To top it all off, the donuts are not really all that good. I mean, they're not bad, but they're not all that great either. They're more colorful and creative than they are delicious. I'll still give Voodoo props for being original and helping to put Portland on the map, but that is about it.

I go into Old Town quite a bit and actually pass by this donut shop a lot, but ironically, in the past several years I've only been to this shop three times. I'm still willing to give them a chance because they are an unquestionable slice of Portland, but I wish they would make some serious improvements. I mean already they've made their sidewalk much more pedestrian-friendly and added a whole outdoor eating area. Hopefully, there will be more patrols in the area and fewer vagrants harassing customers.

Here's hoping that maybe someday they could hold a candle to their competitors, such as Blue Star Donuts. But that day is still to come.

It's a good donut, but I didn't think it was out of this world. It's creative. The old dirty bastard was a huge donut with peanut butter and oreo cookies on top. Good, but not mind-blowing. It's next to a theater that shows anime porn. Interesting.
Overcrowded with tourists, doughnuts will be stale around 7pm... definitely a niche "Portland" Spot... doughnuts themselves are over sugared and mediocre at best

Voodoo is a must try if you're visiting Portland or new to Portland. Lines are usually out the door, so be prepared to wait. The doughnuts are okay, but in a city filled with delicious food, especially doughnuts, Voodoo isn't my first choice. They do offer vegan options, so that's a plus.

I take Voodoo for what it is; an experience. It's one of those things you get to say you do, but it was much better before it was super touristy. I'm actually greatful that they shove you in and out the door because you will get harassed by bums and passing drunk people while waiting in line (I've been yelled at and witnessed fights in line). The products aren't as unique as they used to be (partially because other places copied their flavors) and the price is meh...

I recommend it at least once, but if you want to enjoy your doughnuts for flavor or variety, there are a number of other places to explore. 

They also make some dough by only accepting cash - they can rack up some service fees on their ATM machine conveniently located in the entry area in addition to doughnuts. Another warning is that they do sell older doughnuts at the same price. They won't be gross or anything, they just aren't as fresh.

Avoid the hype.  Some exotic flavours but more of a gimmick than actual quality. Crazy lines for no apparent reason, donut's are really not that great. Even my buddy that loves donuts and junk food was a bit disappointed after travelling across Portland just to check this place out while in town and standing in an abnormally long line.    

Strangely mixes their donuts with politics?  All restaurants would fare better not mixing personal opinions with their food.
These donuts are okay. Go there once for fun. Then head to Pip's for the best donuts in town!

Definitely a touristy stop.  Lines are sometimes ridiculous and the doughnuts are OK but not the best I have tasted.(I prefer Blue Star)   My favorite at Voodoo is the maple bacon donut.  

If you visit Portland, it would not be complete without braving the line at Voodoo.

First attempt was on a Sunday afternoon, line was out the door.  It was over 90 degrees and so I didn't want to stand in that line.  So we drove to the second location and there was no line!  Of course I had the maple bacon.  I like maple and I like bacon - together, it was pretty good.  Next morning we were craving for another one so we went to the original location on Monday at around 9am and there was no line.  I like that their donuts aren't very sweet and when fresh, they're good.  Best donut I've ever had?  Probably not.  They're just decent donuts, nothing special.  Tried the donuts the next day and they were already drying out big time.  I wouldn't go overboard on loading up on donuts if you weren't planning to consume them on the day they were purchased.

Voodoo is one of those infamous places where everyone in line is probably from out of town and the food is expensive but you'll probably go for the experience of it all. I gotta give credit to this chain for their creativity and weirdness. From the minute you walk by the pink brick wall, you can't help but gravitate towards the lineup to see what all the fuss is about with these pink boxes. I ended up trying the voodoo doll and the dirty old bastard. Both were mediocre at best but IMO worth the experience. 3 stars for keeping things weird.

Excited to try two huge boxes of a variety.  Waited in line, spent a lot of money.  I'm just a classics woman; not a fan of weird, soggy cereals and icings, but had to try the experience.  The grape one was particularly bad, and for our crowd, lots of "bites" taken but nobody felt it an OMG experience.  I guess the mistake is not eating these drunk, high, and late at night.
Over priced and over rated, just like Blue Star.  Ya go there because its trendy, not excellent.  Better and cheaper donut shops abound throughout Portland. Give those a try.

It's ordinary tasting doughnuts but presented in a very creative way. Flavors are good. They have fun names and how the doughnut looks like. The  doughnuts are on the pricey side in terms of doughnut pricing. This place is very iconic here in Oregon, it's a must to try at least once. The doughnut shop is typical of Oregon which have fun bright colors, but need to be a bit neater/ cleaner. Can also get busy at night.

This is probably the most famous donut place in Portland. I had a very high expectation but was deeply disappointed by the service. The staff was so impatient and yelled at the next customer in the waiting line. I don't know why the cashier kept shaking his head in a negative way, looking like he didn't want to sell donut to me. TBH the donuts are just average except the design. Definitely not worth the line!!!!!!!

Ok, Voodoo,  I finally made it across the river to see what all the hype was about.  All I had been able to think about for hours was maple and bacon.  I was prepared to eat three doughnuts, minimum (I didn't have dinner, get off me).  AND YOU WERE CLOSED. WTF, Voodoo?  Your website says you're open 24/7.  Are you just messing with drunk people?  Not nice, Voodoo, not nice at all.  For shame.

I really wish I could give Voodoo Doughnuts a better review, but my experience here was sub-par at best.  Portland was one of the many stops on roadtrip of the Pacific Northwest, and with not much to do on a weekday night, we ventured into old town Portland.  It was late and most people were shuffling out of closing restaurants, but our attention was caught by the line spilling out of Voodoo.  After seeing the storefront, I remember seeing this on the Amazing Race and I was really excited to indulge in these unique delicacies.

To our disappointment, the doughnuts we tried weren't anything special, and tasted stale like they had been sitting out all day.  The gimmicks weren't able to make up for the lack of quality.  Maybe it was the time of day that we checked this place out, but with each bite, I kept thinking, "overrated".  Not worth the 20 minute wait.  The concept is there, but the execution needs improvement.  One star for the variety of wacky creations and interesting ingredients.  

I'm glad we randomly discovered Voodoo Doughnuts just to say we've tried it, but it didn't live up to all the hype.

Line up out the door on a Wednesday afternoon.  While in line another customer took on the challenge of attempting to eat a giant donut in a 80 seconds.  It was so exciting.  The staff does such a good hyping everyone up. 

The donuts were interesting.  Numerous flavor's I've never heard of or seen before.  After tasting a chocolate crueler and another cream filled one I didn't understand all the hype.  They were okay tasting, nothing special.
I prefer classic donuts and voodoo has so many over the top doughnuts.  The doughnut tasted yummy but I wouldn't visit often.  I can get just as tasty a doughnut elsewhere without standing in line.

Save yourself money, calories, and time - this place is a tourist trap with long lines known for their ridiculous names and crazy concoctions. I've tried numerous flavors on different occasions and their donut is just MEH. Also, their toppings look cool and fun, but are wdiabetes inducing and don't taste good. 

What a miss!
It's better than Kripsy Kreme but it's still doughnuts. This turned out to be a hipster place. Long line for doughnuts shows us that Oregon has health issues

Hmmm.. I don't know what the hype is about this donut place. My friend insisted on going here and she got the phallic shaped donut, but only tasted like a regular chocolate donut to me. The only cool thing about it was it's shape.... A waste of $6 I think.

this place has kitsch and fame.  it also has a line around the block, and donuts that aside from "interesting" are handily beaten by a number of other donut shops (blue star, tonalli's) in town for "best taste".

Listed as a pitstop for tourists . Well the names are funny and can get a chuckle or two. but the donuts are average. Nothing amazing .  
Portland cream turned to be the best of the ones we tried.
Memphis mafia, Chocolate donut, vegan -ok.. --
mango tango - not that great. 

Long wait times . Cash only.

Sorry VooDoo.  You have fallen prey to the tourists and Food Network/Travel Network fans.  You just are not worth the wait anymore.  I shall miss the Maple Bacon Bar, the Marshall Mathers, the Ol' Dirty Bastard, and Triple Chocolate Penetration.  Oh, how I have longed for some Triple Chocolate Penetration with a Maple Bacon happy ending.  Sorry VooDoo, the lines have reduced you to doo-doo.  I have no problem hopping down the block for a sweet/salty fix during the day now.  Rest in peace.
Overrated donuts cashing in on its reputation and tourists. I'm not saying the donuts are bad but it's just not worth waiting in line for.

I wanted to try this place just because it's what you hear/think about whenever someone mentions Portland. 

Granted, I'm not a huge donuts people, but I still wanted to try it. We came on a Sunday night and the line wasn't too long. I would say we waited about 30 minutes. I ended up deciding on the voodoo doll, the ODB, the lemon crueller, and the triple chocolate penetration. They were all okay tasting and I didn't feel like it was anything special (about its taste). Cost wise, it's decent, but it (Voodoos itself) does seem a bit overhyped.

I was really disappointed when I was told they ran out of the mango tango. It was the one thing that I actually wanted to try. Maybe next time.

Walked here from Deschutes Brewery so I wouldn't feel too guilty about eating my chocolate cake doughnut with chocolate frosting, the next morning.  Microwaved it for 10 seconds in the hotel room and enjoyed it with coffee.   Tom got an apple fritter and said it was good.

Definitely something worth doing once, but I wasn't blown away by the taste.  Its exciting to see all the choices including a lot of vegan options.  And I can imagine this would be especially fun for kids.  However, I thought the donuts themselves were just ok (tried maple bacon, chocolate orange vegan and the blueberry cake).

Voodoo Doughnuts, the novelty doughnut. 

Basically you can't visit Portland and not try a Voodoo Doughnut.  The place is weird, quirky and innovative which is what Portland is about.  The Doughnuts are fun to look at but when you eat one they can be a bit much. So if it's your first time in Portland do as tourists do and get in that long line, have enough cash ready (they only take cash and the doughnuts are pretty pricey), take a picture eating your doughnut, and post it on Facebook or Instagram.  However, if you are looking for a better quality doughnut that leaves you wanting more then I would suggest Blue Star Donuts.

Why these stupid tourists wait in line, for hours on end, to get this garbage is absolutely beyond me.
There is absolutely nothing "Weird" or "Portland" about Voodoo Donuts.
NOTHING.
And there isn't one self-respecting Portlander that would eat this tourist-trap rubbish, much less stand in line for it.
Pro-Tip: You can find the EXACT same cereal coated donuts and pastries at Safeway (NW 12th and Lovejoy).
Blue Star Donuts are a dozen times better.
(SW 13th and Washington).

I would actually be embarrassed to be seen here. This is not Portland and the donuts suck.
The wait was over an hour. I just couldn't see waiting an hour for a donut. :(  We came back early the next day. The donuts are good...but not an "hour-wait good".
Ick.. Artsy donuts, but ick... Too much for me. I'll take a basic cake donut over some art project any day.
Not a big fan donuts are to sweet, crowded, and unfriendly staff. My teeth hurt after taking my first  bite.

The Keep Portland Weird sign is located across the street on the brick building from this location. 

I guess they expect long lines because all the bar railing were up and ready for the crowd. Stop by in the morning, before 9am (I arrived at 8:45am) and maybe less than a handful of people will be in front of you. 

I got a chocolate, glazed and sprinkle donut. I think it was 95 cents per donut. Personally I only think they're alright and slightly dry. There is room for improvement. So I don't understand the rage for this place. UNLESS you Portlanders never had a taste of Krispy Kreme or Donut Time (in San Francisco) which can explain this hype. (:

Everyone hyped this place up so much that I had such high expectations only to be let down by the long wait and the overly sugared doughnuts topped with stale cereal.  

My friends and I ordered almost one of each doughnut in order to give each one a fair shot.  The Maple Bacon Bar would have lived up to it's reputation only if the bacon hadn't tasted old.  None of the other doughnuts called out to me because everything was so dense and super sweet.  The cream-filled ones were even more difficult to swallow.  And speaking of swallowing, the Cock-N-Balls one was the most entertaining of them all.  haha

They definitely get an A for creativity and variety but taste-wise, this place isn't for me.  I like my doughnuts light, airy, and fluffy.  I am glad that I stopped by though to experience this voodoo magic that Portland has to offer.
Big hype for mediocre kinda crappy doughnuts. Its fun to say you went but I would've taken a calorie refund at the end
Not remotely worth waiting in line for an hour and a half. Go to the blue star donuts instead. Or go to Safeway or something, Nobody needs a donut in the shape of a cock. 2 stars

Wish I liked this place like everyone else! After having dinner, we headed over here for desserts the day we arrived. Heard so many good things about it but when we arrived in our hotel with our box of "doughnuts (or is it donut?)" and took a bite, we weren't at all impressed. We got the glazed, the maple and bacon, and the voodoo doughnuts/donuts. Tasted like any regular donut we've had

But it could be that we aren't really doughnut fans but I was hoping going here would change our mind. ORRRR we just got the wrong ones? But I thought the maple and bacon and the voodoo one were the ones to get? Oh well.

I pass.... but definitely glad we went here so I can say that I've been. When in Portland right?
Overrated.  The fritter was a joke.  Tourist hipster trap.  CASH ONLY BTW.
Blue star all the way! This place really sucks. Their chocolate donuts have, what looks to be, cake frosting on them. If you want to feel like crap, eat here.

Portland's answer to New York City's infatuation with the fancy-schmancy "cronut" (croissant-doughnut) are the hardly edible but always enjoyable presentation of the ubiquitous Pepto-Bismol pink box filled with assorted novelty donuts, not always fresh.  The hype is hilarious, the prices accessible for celebrity fried dough and hey, there are even velvet ropes for the long lines separating curious tourists and aggressive panhandlers at the downtown location.  If you are serious about providing something memorable for those out-of-twon clients or family, that pink box of doughnuts is always good for laughs.  If you are a local, you know to head over to the inner NE location, that sick pink building just off NE Sandy Blvd.  Sad but true, after Powell's Books, Voodoo Doughnuts is the #2 spot for visitors to our city, forking over gobs of cash that are stored in laundry bags somewhere, hopefully as bonuses for their hard-working grease-stained employees.
I'm not a fan of doughnuts, so this may not qualify. Voodoo's claim to fame are the funky shapes of their doughnuts. Otherwise they taste like any doughnut I've had at dunkins.

Nearly any donut place in PDX is better than Voodoo.  Overrated, the donuts aren't that great, and definitely not family appropriate.  Oh and cash only- how charming.  Welcome to 2016.

If the donuts were great, maybe, but they're just Safeway-quality donuts with funny toppings.

Fun environment, definitely worth a stop if you are visiting in from out of town. A great tourist spot with some fun and weird donuts. The voodoo doll is REALLY good. I gave this a three star rating only because if I was going for a good donut in Portland, I would go somewhere else.

I have tried the old dirty bastard, voodoo doll, the one with fruit loops, and the one with captain crunch. Don't get me wrong. the donuts are good donuts, but they aren't Portland's best.

Get ready for a line if you are showing up during the busy hours (Saturdays and Sundays)

Look, I don't want to be that super-judgmental local but people.... seriously.... it's a damn donut. Interesting toppings, but really not even that good. Why you would wait in that long of a line for what has become, at best, a ridiculous tourist trap run by hipsters that more often than not can't even understand your order due probably to the huge cloud of pot smoke coming out of the back? Go to Tonali's or  Blue Star instead.

And yes, this is ranked "pricey" because why the hell would you ever pay that much for a flipping donut?

Voodoo doughnut is interesting because of the style of donuts that they provide. 
The way the donuts are styled I think is what interests people the most. They do have pretty cool donuts like the voodoo donut, which is Pretty cute. 

The flavor of the donuts was nothing spectacular to me though. I honestly liked blue star donut a little more. 

The service at voodoo is a lot nicer than blue star.

This is more of an iconic tourist experience centered on novelty donuts. If you're looking for a quality, delicious donut, then this is not the place for you. The donuts are average and the lines are long--but the originality is out of this world. If you think of your experience as more like a visit to a donut museum you might enjoy it more.

I was underwhelmed by this (probably too) popular hipster hangout in downtown Portland, partly because of the hype, partly because we waited in the ubiquitous lineup outside for over 40 minutes, but mainly because, well, the doughnuts I had weren't all that good.

My first pick, a glazed doughnut covered in Fruit Loops, looked promising enough, but the cereal itself was beyond stale - an unforgivable sin given my lifelong affection for that particular bit of junk food (not to mention it's the main feature here).

My second doughnut, though less stale than the first, was no more successful at giving me Voodoo religion.

But the point of Voodoo, I suppose, is not to achieve culinary excellence; rather, it's to partake in culinary counter-culture, and to "keep Portland weird." And at that it certainly succeeds.

When in Portlandia ... long lines are the norm here and it can be a bit of a dicey atmosphere depending on the time night (they're open 24/7 except major holidays which includes Groundhog Day).

The allure is "good things come in pink boxes" with some naughty thrown in for good measure.  Voodoo Doll donut is a visual delight and who can resist the nostalgia of sweet cereal (think Fruit Loops and Cap'n Crunch) topped donuts?

I know there's a lot of folks moving in and out the doors, and your shifts are difficult due to all the people asking questions and testing your patience. But it wouldn't hurt to try and be kinder to your customers.

This is a great place to take out of towners.  The doughnuts are a little dry but the service is horrible!!!!!! They are so rude and don't really seem to care.  Also it would be really helpful if they had printed out menus of what the doughnuts are so you didn't have to point and ask, "which one is that, what does it have in it." over and over and over.

I don't get all the positive reviews on this place. Granted there exists few donut places these days but Voodoo's so overrated. It's just one big gimmick that the masses are eating up (pun intended). Around $25 for a dozen w/ the added bonus of waiting in line for what are mediocre donuts at best is nuts. Skip this place if you visit Portland as there has to be better donuts in the city. 

I've yet to find a place in the NW as good as Pao's in Tacoma, WA which is just a little local business that makes them how they were made in the past. If you know of others let me know!

But, if you're still not convinced and you want some Voodoo-like donuts, here is what you do. First, pull a few kids into your kitchen. Ages 4-7 should work. Find a local place w/ decent donuts and pick up a dozen or two. Next, empty out your pantry and place anything w/ sugar in it on a table along w/ the donuts. Seat the kids around the table and let them go to town on putting toppings on the donuts. Voila! You now have some Voodoo Donuts!

Dear Voodoo Doughnut,

I've heard the story so many times. Your founders got high and walked around a grocery store and came up with your donut ideas. They then found a piece of commercial real estate in the once-defunct Old Town district next to a hentai theater in the 90's and got really lucky with the way that Portland decided to expand. Their silly little donut shop now lives at the heart of Portland's tourism industry. A cheap product that can be made in mass and delivered to a cheap consumer. The McDonald's of bakeries. It's a win-win situation for anyone hoping to consume 500 calories for under $1.

But oh, Voodoo, oh how I despise you. I hate your long lines regardless of the day or season. I hate the way that everyone who visits me in this city insists on going to Voodoo while they're in town, and how I have to stand their with my rolling eyes and crossed arms and pretend to be happy to take them to your establishment. I hate your tired "pink boxes" jokes. I hate the way you've made "maple bacon" a thing now. I just hate you, and you don't deserve it, but I still hate you.

You get two stars, though, for having an excellent reputation as an employer. You provide those who work for you with a livable wage and health care options. Even though it's one of the busiest food spots in town, your employees always seem to be happy to call Voodoo Doughnuts their place of work. Serious high fives for you.

But your doughnuts are still worse than the ones at Safeway. 

Sincerely,
Sara

It was honestly alright, the line wasn't as long when I went, it was probably a case of "showmanship" type of donuts, I should've took the other route and had bluestar in which they probably had quality donuts that had a minimal style but good tasting batter forsure, however, voodoo was decent and had a good bang for my buck, got the voodoo assortment box which mainly was having the staff pick which donuts, for $16 it wasn't bad, I think I'll come back here when I ever go back to Portland but for a smaller amount.

I really didn't find anywhere super amazing about this place. I guess if you really want some interesting ingredients on your donut, then this is the place for you. It's a bit weird but cool at the same time. I think there's too much hype. If the line is too long, get out! Come back another time. It's not really worth it. Then again, that's my opinion. I'm an old-fashioned donut kinda guy. Occasionally a cinnamon twist but that's about it for me.

I really don't get it. I think I eat voodoo donuts like, maybe once a month. If that. Every 6 months? And I live down the street from voodoo. Idk. I just don't get it. They're super sweet and almost unenjoyable sometimes. The Portland cream is really the only one I can stand.

Thanks to Anthony Bordaine and all the other Food Network stars, Voodoo Doughnuts has risen to fame for their strange combinations and unique toppings (bacon, captain crunch, etc.).

These doughnuts are decent but aside from the unique toppings that almost every doughnut has, the execution of the actual doughnut seems just ordinary. Like Safeway doughnut ordinary. It's the toppings that make them shine.

Note. The new location (literally a block down the street) is awesome. Bigger in size and has tons of outdoor seating (tables) against the awesome glittery brick wall. Which I could seriously stare at for hours. 

Definitely a tourist attraction. Lines expected.

Disclaimer: I am not a huge doughnut person, but if all the locals and tourists like it, I'm definitely checking it out.

I can see why this place is so popular. They've really got their niche and branding down, from their neon sign to their pink gate fences to their togo boxes. I love that they'll give you a box even if you only ordered two doughnuts. (P.S. I totally took the pink doughnut box home with me.)

I ordered a Portland Cream for myself. Nothing specular. Tasted like your stand doughnut to be honest. But they have a lot of interesting looked doughnuts and their names are pretty funny and unique.

Cliffnotes:
- $$ cash only $$
- You can order them by the dozen.
- Vegan donuts available (yay!!).
- Almost always a line, but they're pretty efficient.
- "Keep Portland Weird" mural / wall is across the street.
- Pine Street Market and other fun places are nearby.

Would totally recommend people to come here. It's a known Portland spot!

It's open 24/7, so don't trip, chocolate chip, you can avoid the lines by going later in the night (midnight munchies anyone?). Frankly, I'm not sure what the big deal is though. The donuts are good, but not THAT good. I'm sure there are local bakeries that have better donuts. Just ask the locals. They don't even come here! More than anything, it's a tourist spot and a must, just so you can say you tried it. 

P.S. it's cash only.

One of Portland's slogans is "keep Portland weird."  If you have no idea what that means, then you gotta check out Voodoo Donuts - one of the city's famous attractions, for tourists and locals alike. When I was there a couple years ago, the whole place was painted black.  Harsh goth.  Since then, gone are the black walls, a couple of them knocked down to allow natural light to brighten up a different decor:  eccentric and kitschy.

Donuts range from the odd and controversial: Voodoo Doll, Cock-N-Balls (yes - literally shaped as such), Gay Bar, Old Dirty Bastard;  to the funky:  Captain My Captain, The Loop, Bacon Maple Bar (topped with 2 real strips) and for those who prefer to stick to the basics, fear not -- there are "normal" flavours on the menu:  cinnamon sugar, regular glaze, chocolate glaze, toasted coconut, to name a few.  

Not a sweets fan in general and especially not donuts to begin with, but in judging the taste and texture of the donuts themselves, without the scary icing and toppings, Voodoo is leaps and bounds better than places like Krispy Kreme (too lardy) and Tim Horton's (bone-dry) for Canadians.  So far I have tried cinnamon sugar, glazed, toasted coconut and buttermilk bar.  Why so boring?  I like to taste the real deal, without all the weird jazz.  Too much noise to distract from the basic goods.  Besides, all that funky artificial food colouring makes my stomach churn so no thanks.  

Figured that once is plenty previously as all donuts are way too sweet for my taste but I still managed a repeat on my recent trip to Portland.  For all donut and sugar fiends, as well as anyone else who has never been there, I would say Voodoo is worth the trip.  Lineups during the day can be long but being 24-7, going there during non-peak hours is recommended.

Oh, and Stumptown is just a stone's throw away - literally a very short block.  Talk about hitting two of Portland's must-visit spots with one stone!  ;0)

I was really excited to try this place after hearing so much about it, but now, having tried it... I'm kind of disappointed. Voodoo donuts has an excellent marketing scheme with its whole darkly magical, fantastical theme and its 24/7 convenience so that you can satisfy your fried sugary goodness cravings any time you heart (or your stomach!) wishes. Having said that however, it just wasn't worth the hype, atleast when I went. The donuts themselves were a let down for the most part. The classical four donuts we got were recommended by the guy behind the counter as some of the most popular: chocolate coconut, neopolitan, butterfingering and raspberry romeo. With the exception of raspberry romeo, they all had a dry, thick cakey texture with stale, cracked glaze/frosting. It has a huge let down and nobody ended up finishing them. The raspberry romeo was somewhat soft and chewy and was the best out of the classical four. We also got Maple Bacon Donut and the Memphis Mafia Donut which are larger and more atypical. The Maple Donut was my favorite donut for the delicious combination of textures (real bacon on a maple syrup glazed donut) and flavors. The Mephis Mafia Donut was more of a fritter than a donut and was also good but being covered in chocolate frosting, peanut butter, peanuts and chocolate chips, it was a little too much for me. Overall, I think you should definitely try Voodoo Donuts but if you buy into the buzz surrounding it, you're setting yourself up for a little disappointment. THREE POINT FIVE STARS.

Yeah, they have unique offerings and flavors. But underneath the frosting,  cream, and flavored sprinkles is a pretty sub par donut. Way too thick for a human mouth, extra doughy. I suppose maybe my disappointment was a product of the extreme build up of waiting in line for 30 minutes and everyone raving. I am curious if people actually like these donuts or if they just agree for fear of not fitting in. Will not be sitting in that line again.

It's a little pricey for donuts but they are huge so I guess it's not too difficult to justify. My friend and I also ordered hot chocolates to accompany our cock donuts (dual purpose as it would keep us warm in the freezing cold outside. There is a lack of seating inside because everyone is congregated in line for the wait). The hot chocolate was incredibly watered down. Disappointment - I've made better hot chocolate myself using those instant packets at home..

All in all, the quality of the donuts was pretty mediocre. They have some cool names and funky additives but I probably won't come back. I'd recommend checking Blue Star instead if you are looking for slightly smaller but also slightly better quality donuts.

Seriously. I just don't understand the draw because I thought the donuts tasted old. 

My friend Troy and I stood in line because he wanted to try it. I decided to purchase a box of Voodoo donuts with a variety of flavors, and seriously we weren't spellbound. 

They put so much sugar in their donuts and were far too sweet. 

So sweet you can get a toothache! I really did not like them. 

I tasted one of the donuts and tossed it in the garbage can. 

I gave the rest of the donuts to my co-workers. 

Don't expect to get the "cocks and balls" or "the gay bar". They always run out of those. 

Plus did you know that there are mounting evidence suggests that flooding your system with sugar can play a role in corpulence, heart illness, and sarcoma? It can also impact how you look or feel, doing destruction to your skin or shifting your mood to cause melancholy. Surely the work of an evil entity. They even have a devil donut.
Very tamasic. No thank you!

Cool donut shop, I give it props for the creative flavors and snazzy decor. However, I was surprised to find a line outside the door on a Saturday night around 10pm. We waited about 15 minutes, and although the line went by pretty fast, I could feel the pressure at the register. The cashier was pretty snappy and not pleased to answer my questions about donut flavors. When I asked what the blue and pink donut on display was, she said it was called Miami Vice and tasted just like the drink. I told her I didn't know what the drink tasted like, and she gave me a 'wtf' look and described as 'artificial berry'. Not sold. I ended ordering the famous voodoo donut and a blueberry cake donut. They were both good, but not any better than the donuts from local convenience stores in California. I think going to Voodoo was a good experience, but I would not come back solely for the donuts. It's also in a sketchy neighborhood surrounded by lots of bars and rowdy people at night.

PS: CASH ONLY. ATM was broken on day of our visit.

A competent doughnut made by the best marketer on the planet.  Your local doughnut is probably better but they aren't made in a variety of shapes including the signature voodoo doll complete with a pin in it.

The flavor is delivered via frosting not the dough.  We stood in line for 20 minutes while were waiting for a table around the corner.  By the time we left the store, the line had ballooned to over an hour.

If you're into touristy things, as I am, you must buy a doughnut.  Just don't expect an existential experience.  It is, more hokum than anything else, in the vein of the bearded lady at the carnival rather than a statue of David.  A shining beacon for doughnut eaters everywhere it is not.

Unlike Blue Star where I thought the offerings were poor and not worth the money, these doughnuts are not worth the time in line unless of course you really need an anatomically correct cream filled doughnut.

All hype!  It's one of the highlights of Portland when you're a tourist, so of course we stopped by.  We went to the one near Burnside around 2pm and there was a small line but it moved fast.  The inside had a fun and artistic feel to it with a giant donut hanging from the ceiling, artwork and rotating donut displays.  I ordered the voodoo donut man ($2.50) and blueberry cake donut ($1.00).  I was disappointed with the design and taste of the voodoo man.  First, the design wasn't the funny face one, it was two dots with a blue icing triangle.  Hard to make out what it really was suppose to be, but the blueberry cake donut was good.  The voodoo man donut was filled with jelly inside but the dough itself was a bit tough, thick and old tasting.  Not the best donut I've ever had, but the experience was cool.

Not the one for bad reviews, so sorry VooDoo! Your donuts did not satisfy my taste buds at all. 

I came later in the day, which may have contributed to the staleness and poor taste-but I don't think that should be an excuse considering the late open hours. 

Donuts shouldn't be sitting out that long anyways! 

None of the flavors I got (captain crunch, lavender, bubblegum, fruit loops) were any good. 

Good if you want to snap a fun picture, otherwise, it's a no go! 

Oh and I forgot to mention, a group of "suspicious" people like to hang around the area, and repeatedly ask for money. Creepy!

Tried to get into this place twice.  Waited in line for hours.  Not sure what is going on with this place.  Does anyone actually get in the front door?  What day must people go to get in?  Line runs clear up the Burnside bridge.  Since I have waited in line and never progressed forward, I assume it is not real.  Don't waste your time, you'll never get in.
I'm not sure what all the fuss is about.  I had the maple bacon donut and the dirt one. The donuts were super sweet. I'm no donut guru, but I don't think it's worth enduring the long lines.

This is my second time coming to Voodoo donuts. The first time was in Denver, Colorado. Though the donuts I would say are good. Not sure if they are good enough for the price point. They are very, very sugary as well. I'm a huge sugar person & it's even a bit much for me. Totally brought my box home from Portland to Detroit & I've never had so many people talk to me at the airport lol. Overall they are decent I would say.

Big Disappointment! Over-rated!
We were a group of 25, traveling for a sports tournament and were hoping for a fun experience!
Not only were the donuts sub-par, the people who worked there acted put out by our orders.
Skip this place and save your money AND your sweet tooth for better donuts!

Tourist trap.. The doughnuts were good but I'm
Not sure it was worth the one hour wait. They had lots to choose from and unique flavors but honestly so does our hometown bakery. I think if I didn't have to wait so long it would have given it more stars.
Been here many times and this was no different. More a novelty than anything else. A stop on the Portland tour bucket list.
Voodoo is good.  Also try Annie's Donuts in NE Portland.  They are great!

Not all it's cracked up to be. The doughnuts have a variety of names, but NO DESCRIPTION, making it nearly impossible to order....and the girl at the register was NO HELP AT ALL AND VERY UNFRIENDLY. And the place was empty!!! Ended up having to try and describe to her what we wanted from the case. And when we finally got them...they were nothing special, and certainly not fresh. Skip it.

Definitely overhyped-- people just want to take a picture with the pink box. Blue star is alot better! Came on a Sunday night around 10pm and there was almost no line (only 2 people ahead of me). Ordered a glazed donut and the voo doo donut. Nothing too fancy

Waited in line for 45 minutes during my brief trip to Portland while returning from a road trip. Honestly it wasn't worth it. To be fair, I don't have much of a sweet tooth but I still like the donuts at top pot in Seattle a lot more. 
The plain glazed was by far my favorite of the custom dozen that we picked. The portland cream was excellent as well albeit way too sweet for my taste. My wife really enjoyed it though. Some of the other flavors that were pretty good were the lemon powder and the voodo doll. All the others that we tried were just ok.
I'd recommend going here once just for the novelty experience but definitely not worth the wait twice.

Came here because we were bored waiting for our food from a nearby restaurant for burger week.

I tried the Miami Vice, which was too sweet and artificial tasting for me. Captain My Captain was decent and will be your favorite if you absolutely love Cap'N Crunch cereal.

Overall, Voodoo is super sweet for me and too gimmicky and colorful, which turns me off. LOL Also, the line is always super long whenever I pass by here, which is totes not worth the wait. 

Cash only!

they have a few great donuts...however, i do feel they are a bit overpriced and sloppy for what they are.  that being said, there is no denying that this is a must for tourists.  i would suggest the banana fritter, only when it's warm, otherwise go with the chocolate donut with crushed oreos and peanut butter drizzle.

Who woulda thought the place would be packed at 4pm!? So we had to stop in early the next morning on our way out of Portland. The donuts were pretty good and different than the usual at Dunkin Donuts. I didn't like that the overhead menu didn't say what kind of donut it is. I got one with filling, I was thinking it would be whipped cream-ish filling, but it was raspberry jelly. It was good, but not was I was hoping for. I guess I should have asked.

Tourist trap.  Some interesting and creative combinations, but the quality of the donut itself - average.  Have had much better donuts in places not trying to get fancy.  Def not worth a wait for more than 5 minutes.

I'm all about extravagant decorated sweets, and this place is the place for me. I showed up on National Donut Day and what better place to go to than Voodoo Donuts? Those pink boxes that these donuts come in were in everyone's hands in the city, and there's no question to why! So much to choose from, it's almost overwhelming. 

Three stars because the service was a little on the irritated side. I get it, you're being bombarded by a ton of people standing in a long line waiting for a sugar rush. I just figured it was way too early for people to be that annoyed already! You work in a well known and over hyped donut shop; maybe just accept it or get another job. This is a pink walled shop, at least show a smile or something with walls that pink. Great place to try at least once.

They're basically Dunkin Doughnuts with "wacky" toppings. Often stale, very busy.

I hate to go all hipster, but I lived here 15 years ago when it was a hole in the wall with no signs. It was a fine option for staving off an Ash St. Saloon hangover. I feel like it's been turned into disneyland, and there are just better options in town. 

Keep sending the tourists there, though. Good for the ol' economy you know.

The moment I mentioned to friends I was going to Portland I was told I must, must stop by Voodoo Doughnuts. When I got to the shop the line was out the door, but it was moving quickly so I didn't mind. Especially since it came so highly recommended. The store has a very quirky look including but not limited to a giant donut hanging from the ceiling. It's a cash only spot and their prices are on the relatively cheap side for novelty doughnuts. We bought half a dozen doughnuts for a little less than $10.

The reason for the 3 star rating? The staff was so rude, I don't know if it's different in the morning or if this was just a one-time occurrence. (Doesn't seem like it.) Like I said we were waiting in line in the freezing cold, it was getting a little packed inside but it's to be expected when it's 30℉. Two of the cashiers kept yelling at people telling them to wait outside because it was getting crazy in there; it wasn't, people were just chit chatting and waiting patiently. I don't  mind squeezing in so folks can stay warm. One of the soon to be customers said something, I'm not quite sure what but one of the male cashiers said well you can wait outside or just leave in the most snarky tone I've heard in a while, instead of being empathetic and still conveying your message. 

Overall the doughnuts were alright nothing out of the ordinary. The service wasn't very nice. Would I go back? Ehh, probably not, not worth the wait or attitudes. The best part was the decor to be quite honest.

Edit: Changed their star rating to a two. Three stars was to generous.

Been a few times since we moved to Portland, as hubby likes doughnuts and is keen to try other flavors. Good variety of flavors that's for sure! :) The doughnuts aren't as fresh and fluffy as I would like though. Good work on the marketing and popularity of this iconic Portland spot! Cash only.

Crazy creative, colorful doughnuts. My eyes exploded when I saw the variety of toppings. Familiar sweets, like Orea cookies and colorful cereal. 
However, looks were deceiving. All of them tasted average, some too sweet except for the one with Rice Krispy chocolate frosting, peanut butter drizzle. That was scrumptious, something to write home about. 
The Oreo cookie crumbled topped one was average.
If you like mango and lots of sugar you might like the one with mango jelly filling. 
My friend really like the ghost-shaped one with brown icing. I thought it was meh.
The doughnuts also tasted denser than your standard doughnut. 

Fresh, colorful, more satisfying to the eyes than stomach. VD is conveniently open 24 hours for your cravings or curiosity. I'm glad someone got them so I didn't have to wait in line.

I stumbled upon this potentially amazing find from the long line of buzzed Portlanders late one night. Intrigued by the line, and the raving approval from people in line, we decided to hop on the bandwagon to see what this place was all about. The wait was about 30 minutes, which went by pretty fast once you get into the cozy place. 

There are a lot of interesting things to look at, from the wall decor to the fliers to figuring out actually what you want to order. Their menu is huge, with some very unique names that make you wonder if you might pick up some venereal disease eating here. But I'll admit that it added to the whole eclectic vibe of the donut shop. 

The reason for the two stars is because the donuts were frankly pretty crappy. I think I could've gone to my local supermarket and had a more fresh donut at 11PM than the one I ordered. It wasn't just mine either. All 4 donuts we ordered had the same stale taste. I threw my donut only half eaten, and  I ALWAYS finish my food. 

This place has hype, but its all show and no go. If your looking for a good place to eat fresh donuts, go somewhere else.
Long line. Big doughnuts, decent prices. Cool athmosphere. Nothing notable about the doughnut itself.

It's nothing too special aside from the unique design and toppings. All around it's just aiiight.

I understand there are long lines due to popularity, I think they could be a little faster here. Not really a need for all of the waiting considering other donut shops have figured out being efficient.

For me it wasn't worth the hype.

Very cool place but definitely overhyped. I'm pretty sure everyone has heard of Voodoo doughnuts and I was very excited to try it when visiting Portland. A group of us got there early on a Friday morning and didn't need to wait in line at all which is apparently unheard of! We got a box of a few different flavors so we could all try them. The assortment included the Captain Crunch, Chocolate Coco Puff donut, Maple Bacon, and a classic old fashion. While the donuts looked pretty and colorful, I didn't particularly think the flavor was all that amazing. They were SUPER sugary and sweet and it was hard to compare to Blue Star Donut which had fresher tasting ingredients. I definitely think it's worth going once for the experience but I don't feel the need to go again.

More hype than anything!
Every since I knew I was going to Portland I couldn't stop thinking about those donuts! The day we arrived it was a Wednesday late at night and there was no line! Yes! However when we stepped in no one greeted us. They were rude and when it was time to order they gave me the "hurry up look." Why? there was no one there! I mean, have to pick the right donut don't rush me! When I ordered my donut the guy just tossed it at me as I tried to grab it and ended up getting frosting on my hand. Don't know if they're just plain rude or two "cool" guys who think they're hard core punk rockers and live a sad life. I will probably never go again and tell everyone I know to go to blue star instead! The review on the donut itself: My boyfriends maple bacon bar was stale and mine was just okay. Meh

I knew Voodoo Doughtnut would be all hype, but if a place has almost 7000 reviews, you know I can't not go!

My friends and I came on a Friday night around 11:30pm and were surprised to find only about 10-15 people ahead of us. The line moved fairly quickly. Once inside, you see revolving cases with all the colorful donuts being displayed.

We got:
-Old Dirty Bastard (chocolate frosting, oreos, peanut butter)
-Triple Chocolate Penetration (chocolate donut with coco puffs)
-Bacon Maple Bar 
-Blueberry Cake
-Apple Fritter

We all agreed that Old Dirty Bastard was our favorite. It reminded me of a Butterfinger candy bar but in donut form. The Trip Chocolate Penetration is not as awesome as it sounds.... and it's even more meh the next day. The Bacon Maple Bar was decent, but only when you had a bite of bacon with it. Without the bacon, it's just way too sweet. As for the latter two, I have very high standards for those. The blueberry was just whatever. The apple fritter was good but not amazing. 

The donuts were very cold and soggy. I don't regret coming here, but in hindsight, I think I would have enjoyed it more if I had it with some hot coffee to balance the overly sweet flavors.

After hearing all the hype (arguably Voodoo is the most widely known donut shop from Portland) it was time to see what it was all about.

Free Parking is available in front of the store on weekends before 1100.

Service is friendly and very efficient.  There are hordes of people outside after all.

The donuts honestly aren't that great.  Yes they're pretty hilarious to look at, but taste-wise they're mediocre.  My biggest complaint is that most of them are way too sweet, to the point that it masks the other flavours the donuts are supposed to have.  With that said, the tradeoff is that the prices seem much more reasonable.

Oh well, off the bucket list.

Do not plan on ever going back to this donut shop. Had to experience what all the hype was about and I just don't understand what people see in Voodoo Doughnut. Standing in long line for 30 min and dealing with dirty, smelly, rude, and frankly scary people and then getting to the less then friendly and impatient employees was not all that fun. The donuts were good but I have had just as good of donuts at Safeway without the circus going on around us.I would recommend going to a different place this place paints a very bad portrait of Portland.

THE Portland doughnut landmark with a cult following.  Tons of people taking photos of this little joint.  Endless line 21 hours a day.  20 minute wait get THE doughnuts.  Survey says?  C+.  Not bad, but no wow factor.  Tried about 7 varieties and the Butterfinger was the only one worth talking about.  That one hit the spot - not too sweet, with just the right amount of icing and candy bits. They ran out of their famous maple bacon bar and it was only noon on a Saturday.  Voodoo did a doodoo on my expectations, but I would give it another chance and stand in line to try that bacon bar!  Cash only.

I just don't need bacon on my food. However if you're out and about and feeling peckish, VooDoo might be your best bet as, there's little else within walking distance. I personally think it's gimmicky and overpriced. To be honest though, it might just be what some with a cranky inner child might need. You know cap'n cruch maple bar, or as I like to call it "the mouth cutter sugar fluff power combo.

I thought the donuts were okay. I guess we got lucky  in the matter that we got there early = no lines. What is unlucky was that since it's open 24 hours, donuts aren't always going to be fresh since they don't sell out around the clock. The donuts weren't that great. Given all the hype about it, I wanted that melt-in-your-mouth oh-so-good doughnut that everyone talked about. I guess we didn't get a fresh batch cause it tasted like regular, cold doughnuts to me.

We ordered 2 donuts - the old dirty bastard and another one with raspberry creme filling and a couple of coffees for the homeless people outside. Walking here from our hotel in downtown to Old Town was about 0.7 away you would see a lot of homeless people sleeping on the ground and on the sidewalks asking for change or coffee. They were extremely polite - I come from California and most of the homeless people that I have encountered approach me like they are entitled to my money ugh! ... but I digress.

I did like the way the doughnuts looked, with pretzels as "needles" stabbing into a gingerbread man shaped bar, etc. It is very creative. I would probably return to give this place another try when I'm in Portland again as I felt like I didn't get the "right" experience. I WANT THE YUMMY EXPERIENCE AS OTHERS DAMMIT! LOL

Why go here if you really love good donuts when Portland has Blue Star? 
The line of tourists waiting to get in is a real deterrent, but the poor quality of the donuts is even more important a reason to avoid the place.
I don't know why everyone is up in arms about this place. The doughnuts are okay, i mean a doughnut is a doughnut.... If you want a good one, then go to Blue Star!
I was very disappointed that voodoo Donuts does not offer gluten-free options. Maybe they will one day.
Had the experience. It was fun. Donuts creative in their form and toppings. Some inappropriate for kids. Parking was a hassle. Not sure I would bother again.

I'm not really a sweets fan but I'll have a donut here and there. My friends and I drove from Seattle to Portland and what better place to go other than the famous voodoo donuts I've heard about on tv.  

I got here around 10 so the line wasn't too long. There were a lot of people hanging around the shop outside. My friends and I got the bacon maple bar, cock and balls, and the Oreo one. 

I think if I were to eat everything I would've been on a sugar craze and get super hyper. I just tried a little bit of everything and frankly, they were just ok. Mind you I don't really like sweets that much 

The cock and balls are hugeeeeee and it just tastes like a regular chocolate glazed donut. The bacon maple bar was good with a mix of sweet and salty. The Oreo one was ok, it was kinda too sweet. 

I wouldn't care to come back since it's not the best donut I've ever had in my life. But at least I can say I've been there !!!

** btw I think it's CASH ONLY

Their donuts are what Portland is all about.  They are kitschy and fun and kind of weird.  I am not crazy about a donut shop that sells adult themed donuts, but the kids love the kind they have had a parties that are smothered in sugared kids cereal...  Kind of like crack for kids.

That being said, I did not find the flavor any more amazing than other donut shops, its just all about the ambiance and theme.

Sorry Voodoo Doughnut fans, but this place is not for everyone.  Yes, the sexual innuendos are hilarious.  Yes, the toppings are endless and creative.  Yes, the toppings are in fact delicious.  But sadly no, the doughnuts themselves are not any better than your hole (get it?) in the wall strip mall shop, and I don't have to overpay for those nor wait in a long line.  The one exception would be the apple fritter that I tried, which was delicious, but then again I think the only apple fritter I've had that wasn't amazing was form 7-11.  Glad I tried it though...

MUCH HYPED?
I don't get why is the line so long. I mean, the donuts at this place aren't half good compare to Donut Friend in Highland Park, CA. You have to be kidding. Their donut is really old-fashioned (the dough, of course, not the "dick and balls." Well, now I think of it. That's old-fashioned too). 
I got the portland cream and the voodoo doll. The icing for the voodoo doll turns out to be way too sweet. And the cream in portland cream needs to be creamier and less sugary, since the sugar gives it a crystallized texture.
Average donuts glazed with hype.  Coco donuts is way better, although sometimes it's nice that Voodoo is open all night.

Nooooooo..... what a way to butcher donuts. Look amazing.. tastes like rubber. Dense dough not light and fluffy. Overdone with toppings I had no idea what I was eating. Cool concept but not my thing. Took a bite and threw out the rest, both myself and my husband. So sad

First time in Portland and of course,  we had to find out what ask the hype is about.   But sadly, that's all it is.   Hype

Great marketing concept though. ..gotta give them that.  Nothing special.

Cool store, I find my self ending up there more often than i'd have imagined, mostly leading first time portland visitors to pay homage. Nothing spectacular about the donuts, but waiting in line outside the paris theater in questionable part of town makes for a uniquely portland experience.

Overrated as hell. Safeway makes the same quality of donuts, but for a lot less $$$.

Of course, the storefront is overrun by tourist and hipster dipshits who think its so "kewl" and "zany" and "keep portland weird maaaaan" (ugh). The donuts are hardly anything special and are extremely overpriced for what you get. Seriously, Krispy Kreme tastes just as good, but for a whole lot less (and you get your donuts a lot quicker).


But voodoo is a great representation of Portland itself-overrated, rude, expensive and extremely pretentious.

Voodoo's doughnuts are okay, but nothing I would ever wait in line for. I don't really understand why every tourist feels the need to come here. If I happen to be walking by late at night and see no line, I might pop in for a maple bacon doughnut, but that's about the extent to my affinity for Voodoo Doughnut.
Great for tourists. Average for residents who expect and can get more out of our artisan doughnut shops.

A very average donut - bolstered by a legendary reputation, a long line, and cutie patootie names like The Gay Bar ("white" glazed donut with rainbow fruit loops) and other such clever concoctions. I waited, and the line that looked long took no time at all. And, the line gives you a chance to read over the huge list of donuts on the menu and eye them all in the glimmering glass, rotating case. I had a kruller, which was good...but it wasn't warm or out of the oven, and it tasted just as delicious as one from any other shop I've ever been to.
In addition, my problem with this excursion, is that it's in a somewhat sketchy downtown area, that could easily be avoided. I parked my car and was told by a local policeman to take out *everything* from the car, or the car windows would be broken into if I left a hairbrush in it. I loved Portland, but this was a very touristy, not worth it bend in the road. People, just go to the microbreweries, corralled food trucks, or gorgeous nature everywhere, and get a donut from the 7-11 and douse it with cereal.

Wanted to come since it had so many reviews. Waited in line for an hour for okay doughnuts (boyfriend had the bacon maple bar, I had the devils food diablos rex). Nothing really spectacular. Seems to be more about the novelty than anything. Liked they had vegan options, but I don't think the wait is worth it. The shop itself is decorated pretty cool though.
So I wanted to see the hype of this place. The best doughnut was thr maple bacon. But other than that they are just doughnuts with some creativity. The cocopuffs doughnuts were stale...... not good.

Love the vegan options very tasty doughnuts. Always a line but you are in store for a freshly made treat. I love the vegan maple bar and the cereal topped ones. They are certainly on the sweet side. 

Location is tiny and there's lots of bums that ask for change when you are in line. There's no seating. Otherwise I prefer going to their other location. Less of a line outside in the mostly cold Portland weather and no bums at all. 

Cons: Most of the filled doughnuts are way too sweet

I gave VD two stars because it's still fun to see silly donuts, but they're not fantastic, they tend too be too sweet (I didn't just say that, did I?) and the apple fritters are Greazy- with a capital G! I'm required to wait in the long line every time we have out of town guests, but for my money and tastebuds, Portland has some much better donuts, I'm probably still stuck in line though. But a line for good donuts us time well spent.

So, I like the character of this place. But the doughnuts I had were okay.  I mean, if I had tried many more varieties, then maybe I would have struck gold.  The problem is that there's all these funky names, but no description.  You can look in the case and see a lot of unusual looking doughnuts, but just because you put cereal on top doesn't mean they taste good- just that they look good.

After everyone and their mom hyping this place up, I was trying not to get my hopes up in case I was disappointed. We came mid-afternoon to a line that went across the street so we decided to try again later. After dinner we stopped by and thankfully, the line was much shorter and only wrapped around once. 20 minutes later, we were inside and ordered their famous voodoo shaped donut and the maple bacon donut. Inside is so cute and kitschy. I wish we could've spent more time inside. They have the rotating display case of different donuts. I think it's for display purposes only and not for consumption. But they all looked good. We took our big pink box back to our hotel to try. Along the way, 3 different people asked us how the line was. I guess it is the most popular thing in Portland. After taste tests, the verdict is that while the donuts are cute both cute and unique, it wasn't the best tasting donut I've ever had. They felt a little bit NOT fresh. You would think that because they're so busy, they would be constantly churning out donuts and they would be fresh. But whatevs - I'm glad I tried it and didn't have extremely high hopes because I wasn't super disappointed. Also it's about 3 bucks per donut.

The idea of this place is better than the donut.
I wish they put the amount of creativity that they did on the outside of the donut into the quality of the donut itself. 
Its a basic donut. With a super sugary glaze.
Kinda like the donughts that you'd get at a truck stop. 
Fresh & soft yes, unique in flavors? Well...
Some have a sh!tload of sugary cereal on top.
Some have cute & creative designs.
Some have catch phrase-y names like "cock-n-balls" (its shaped like a penis. Post that selfie to Facebook "look everyone! Im at Voodoo eating a donut that looks like a dick!')
ITS ALL THE SAME DONUT
WITH DIFFERENT TOPPINGS

The place is crazy. One counter where everyone is trying to look into & take pictures with/of the towering & rotating display cases. Lots of "trailer park" type decor... old & dusty looking.
But hey if you like chaotic & superficial donuts then by all means... stand in line for an hour.

The doughnuts are pretty good. The choices are endless and the flavors super original. I always judge a doughnut place by how good their plain old glazed doughnut is and it's not that great. Honestly a fresh crispy cream doughnut is better but the options are why people head to voodoo. It's cool but not fantastic.

Most overrated doughnut in the entire universe. People take boxes of these to California on the plane. Out of towners practically move here to eat them. It's totally ridiculous. They aren't good. 
I will give them props for innovative flavors, and to be the first people to do it, but...... the doughnuts are the same doughnuts you can get anywhere. Literally.
Very mediocre doughnuts. Not worth the wait. Let me be clear. Not worth the wait. Not sure why they are so popular with tourists.

sorry folks, I think this donut shop is over rated. Just because a place gets a spot on network TV (not sure how) doesn't mean its the hottest place in town.  Much like other tourist traps, this place is a gimmick and that's why people flock to them.

These donuts are not really worth it, but at least somewhat for the photos. I was semi-nauseous all day after eating just the one "Ball" from the "Cock and Balls." This is basically a Bavarian Creme (Boston? I never get it right... but this one has the custard inside not the white creme) donut BLOWN up to the proportions of the size of my upper body and shaped into a penis and testicles. Probably not consistent from donut to donut, but I had to push through layers of dough with my fingers to see where the hidden treasure of custard was. At least the woman customized it for us and wrote a personalized message all over the front of that thing and then doused it in sprinkles. 

We also had the zombie donut (jelly and chocolate icing) and an oreo-peanut-butter one. All overly sweet and NOT the way to start your day, unless you're into self-torture. Then again, its the experience. The line, the ambiance, the over-the-topness. Despite all the excitement, remember to get some strong Stumptown coffee to wash it all down.

Tourist trap!

AMBIANCE: hipster donut shop.

LOCATION: right downtown, easy fine because of the golden bricks and voodoo sign.

SERVICE: quick, only cash once you get to the counter. waits can be up to an hour at certain times.

FOOD: it's just like any other donut, maybe on a lesser taste level that they've just piled different toppings on it. Some of the designs are cute, like the actual voodoo donut shaped like a voodoo doll with a pretzel sticking out of its heart. Overall, not worth the wait. If you get lucky and the line is short, go get a donut and snap a picture just to say you visited

PRICING: regular donut prices. I am glad they do not hike the price because of its name. Priced just like any other donut. $1-3/donut.
We waited in line for 30 minutes and the donuts were just okay. It was an experience, but I wouldn't do it again.
Expect a long line. Donuts are good. I had the maple bacon and it was delicious. It's a Portland institution worth stopping by.

Very much below my expectations. They get one star for their creativity and well-established brand name or maybe because Yelp won't allow 0 stars. Their doughnuts are mediocre at best. You do get a variety of funny shapes, but that's all.

Service is by far the worse part of it. These guys are literally on "island time". I would even suggest that the whole scheme is based on making people wait. I tend to skip anything with a long waiting line, but the line was very short when I got there,  so I decided to go for it. With only 6 people ahead of me, I still had to wait 20+ minutes. By the time I had my doughnuts the line was already going around the building. 

Overall, I think this is a tourist trap, many locals recommended Blue Star Donuts instead.

Doughnuts taste normal but this shop is so hyped up by the different shapes of'Doughnuts. Attached pictures. Some of the varieties are 'Cock and balls', 'Doughnuts in coffin'......
When I went to buy a doughnut in the morning on the long weekend, there were atleast 200 people waiting in line. So I decided to come later in the evening. Even, my tour guide mentioned, this doughnut shop is the number 1 attraction in Portland. It took almost an hour to get this weirdly shaped doughnut.

It saddens me that so many people flock to voodoo from out of town based on their reputation alone.   Don't get me wrong.... It takes a good entrepreneur to build the fan base that they have.  The problem is that people often wait here for about an hour for donuts that taste worse than Krispy Kreme.   The best donuts to be had are available at Blue Star Donuts.

Voodoo Doughnut is the Hot Topic of doughnuts. Takes itself way too seriously for a place that looks like an 8-year-old was let loose in the back to put all of his favorite cereals, candies and Tonka trucks on everything in sight.

Yeah - they put about every cereal imaginable (aside from anything by Kashi, but don't tempt them...) on their doughnuts. Crazy, right? There's also a litany of other totally wacky creations involving things like Dubble Bubble, Tang mix, and M&Ms. The kitsch MIGHT be charming if they didn't act as if James Joyce wrote "Ulysses" right there next to the case of Cock-N-Balls doughnuts. 

But aside from that, the doughnuts themselves are just average. That should be obvious by the fact that they feel the need to mask their often dry/stale doughnuts with Halloween candy. 

I feel absolutely no need to return and discover that they've started adorning their goods with game pieces from the family of Milton Bradley board games.
sooooooooooooo over rated! Leave this place for the tourists!!
I'm not a huge donut fan, and they weren't crazy exceptional, tasty but nothing SUPER amazing that I would go back and have again

All hype - the line piques your curiosity - once you get in you feel like a kid in a candy store - i think I bought six because I didnt want to miss out on experiencing something Ive heard about for no less than four years.  My first bite was like eating a rice cake for the first time - i wasnt sure what to do with my words. I knew I needed to feel something - I mean its Voodoo Donuts.  In a way I felt like when I went to NYC and told ppl I didnt love it - it was okay.  I felt like I had to love this donut because everyone does (right)? Oh wow - all I can say is - im glad CoCo donuts is here  - they saved the day - I took a bite from two more of them and tossed the rest in the trash where they belong.  I did like the customer service though.

First time trying Voodoo donuts since last time we were in Portland the line was crazy.  Great selection and variety.  The apple fritter was better than average as were the chocolate donuts and maple bars.  The filled donuts were okay but not spectacular.   The reason why I am giving 3 stars and not 4 is that the hot chocolate tasted like dirty water.  I even opened the lid to make sure it was hot chocolate.   Ended up in the trash.

Highlights:
1) They only accept CASH only.
2) Expect waiting in line.
3) The dozen box of doughnuts come with regular, but colorful doughnuts like frostings covered in coco puffs, fruit loops, sprinkles and etc. It does not include their specialties like the voodoo doll or cock-n-balls. You can request those in your dozen, but the prices will vary.
