I've heard about Voodoo Doughnuts all the way from San Diego and I was able to finally check during my visit to Portland. 

The place is quirky and wacky. Pink colored stuff everywhere (reminds me of Luche Libre back in San Diego). There are usually long lines. I came around 10:00 am on a Thursday morning and I was at the cash register in 15 minutes. I must've got lucky because around 10:30am, the line was much longer.

I'll give it to them that the doughnuts appearance are fun and creative. However, the taste of the doughnuts are mediocre. They're dense and average tasting. I got a dozen of the regular doughnuts and the cereal on a few doughnuts were stale.

It's a must visit if you're from out of town visiting Portland for the first time. For me, I'll probably only visit it again if I wanted to show family and friends around Portland. Would I want to buy their doughnuts again? Probably not. It's one of those things you must try at least once in your life.

Have some doughnut with your frosting. Our family waited for approximately 30 mins and the only fun we got was watching this other family doing the doughnut eating contest and laughing at the "cock and balls" (actually just T shaped) doughnut. After looking forward to having a delicious, juicy, tasty selection of doughnuts, we left with a box full of grease dripping, sugar overloaded and extremely fake- colored doughnuts. Taste-wise they are dry and they all actually taste exactly the same. We are even afraid of giving them away since we don't want to be responsible for any heart attacks.

Voodoo Donuts

So what can I say about this place. Voodoo donuts is a place where they sell really interesting and odd donuts you don't normally see. These are the donuts that are sold in those famous pink boxes. They also have very inserting names for there donuts. They really sweet and some are really big. I think this place is more like a tourist place now then a regular donut shop. It fun to go to, but not all the time. I think it a once in a while kind of place for me. 

So there always a big line here, at night time when people are drunk or people want something sweet after the club this is the place they go to. I would recommend it if you just want to be where everyone is at and willing to stand in line and if you really like sweet stuff.

the donuts eeeehhh not THAT great the TOPPINGS they use ....those were good.  I liked the cock n balls and the no name.  I kinda liked the captaincaptain but you have to eat it right away or else the cereal gets stale super fast.

We waited on line for 25 min, which isn't terrible but considering the quality of these doughnuts, it is. When we got in, our server's blue hair was hanging in her face and a strand ended up underneath a few of our doughnuts. Upsetting. 

We got a dozen, but realized when we got home that our server also forgot to add in one of our doughnuts so we ended up with 11 total. Upsetting. On top of that, she piled the doughnuts on top of each other so they were all messed up when we got to them. 

I will give them props for a cute store and doughnut names, but our experience and doughnuts were sub-par. These doughnuts have the same quality as Dunkin donuts. So, overall, this place is a tourist trap and is absolutely overrated. Just go to blue star instead.

I like the place ocassionaly, if there is no line, but I've had better donuts. The donuts are big, and of the yeasty variety. For being a "cool" novelty donut they are reasonably priced. 
The donuts taste good, but when you pour chocolate or maple glaze and add a pound of candy toppings all over fried dough of course it's gonna be good. Yes, they're colorful and fun shapes. 
If the line is more than a couple people out the door it's really not worth the wait. I've seen the line get pretty long. If it's more than a few people out the door you're looking at a 45+ minute wait. Maybe it's worth it if you're a tourist. If not and you still want a Voodoo-ish donut just buy a plain one from the grocery store and shove a Snickers bar in it.

I always wanted to try this place after numerous posts I saw on Instagram. My hubby and I finally went to Portland for solar eclipse and decided to grab some donuts & coffee before headed to Salem. We got there around 5 am and didn't wait too long in line. (I'd say around 30 mins). They have a lot of flavors to choose from, but To be honest, i think crispy cream is better.

Every donut my family had was good there but the diablo Rex,I mean really,a pentagram on a donut what the hell why! They should remove that item because my baby brother tried to order it but my mom saw it and got mad.
The flavor are unique and the service is wonderful, but the doughnuts are overall just okay. I've feel they were the same as Dunkin donuts except with crazier things on top

The Bacon Maple bar was really yummy, but I don't think I will wait another hour for it :/  The donuts are really bright and fun to look at (with really funny, clever names), but flavor wise it's "whateve" (I think).  The crazies outside of the place are not fun to be around either :/
Not sure their donuts are really worth waiting in line for.  Yeah, they've got some interesting choices, but fried bits of sugar are available at other donut shops which are just as good.
Right in front of a bunch of dirty, filthy homeless people. The best place in Downtown Portland to be stabbed to death. Is a cock-shaped doughnut worth getting stabbed for? Of course it isn't!
A bit of a tourist trap. Donuts worse than average.

i do not think this place lives up to the hype. sure you can get wacky donut toppings in a sketchy part of town but it's still just a donut with cereal or bacon on top. thankfully we didn't have to wait in a line at 9am on a thursday. i really wouldn't recommend this overpriced option. even though it seems everyone does.

Mleh. They're okay. I've had them a couple times and they're mostly mediocre. The line is for the woah-factor.
They have vegan donuts though, several - and that earns them an extra star :)

It was decent but I'm still scratching my head trying to figure out what the hype is all about. As an out-of-towner, I felt compelled to stop by because this is one of the first and sometimes only thing that people tell me about when I mention Portland. 

The long line does move more quickly than it looks but it was still about a 20 minute wait. When you finally get there, you have about ten other anxious donut-hungry people tapping their feet behind you so you feel compelled to not ask a lot of questions. We ended up hurriedly just pointing at a dozen donuts we thought looked good on the rotating display box. 

For the most part they were pretty good but nothing I couldn't find in the Bay Area. The apple fritter was probably my favorite despite all of the other "crazier" donuts.

Let me start out by saying... Try the signature VooDoo doughnut. It was worth the experience.

I stopped by for a bag. This is an interesting place. It's in a rough area that was reminiscent of downtown LA- urine on the sidewalks, drunk/stoned hippies selling lemonade on a box with black marker scrawl across it that said, "Lemonade Stand," people pandering for change, and very high parking costs. 

If you can get past that, and find your way into the line, you will be waiting a while. But you can people watch (which is quite a show there), and listen to a DJ that is entertaining. Thus, I didn't mind the wait.

There is no inside eating, but they have tables outside with a security guy that is also the DJ. With all the hype and wait, I thought that I would be in heaven taking the first bite, but... The doughnuts were ok. However, their signature voodoo doughnut was pretty dang good. I'd be tempted to even replace the word dang with an expletive.

Almost all gimmick, very little substance. The donuts are fine at best, stale-ish at  worst. You probably will never hate anything you order, but you'll probably wish you had spent the calories elsewhere. The hours are pretty fantastic though, in a town where even the sidewalks shut down at 5 pm.

TL;DR  if you are wondering why the 2 stars:

+ Variety of donuts
- Long wait
- Cash only
- Under cooked donut - memphis mafia's center was still really gooey and doughy, semi-raw
- Really bad guitar playing hipster kids hanging out in front of the shop while you wait in line singing dreadful emo songs - and because you are waiting in line, you are the forced audience

Boo. This was a letdown. I was looking forward to having a couple of good donuts during the trip - unfortunately, it didn't turn out that way. Ridiculous long line to get into the shop on a Saturday afternoon - if you are thinking about trying it out, I suggest to not go on a Saturday afternoon unless waiting is your thing.

Multiple people in line were asking if this place was any good. Everybody's in line is a tourist it seems. Not that it's a bad thing but I kind of get suspicious when no locals are willing to go to a place. Not only the line was long but there were a group of kids singing horrible mopey songs horribly in front of you. You can't get away. You must endure. The only clapping and applauding after each song is coming from their own group. Picture a dog licking its butt - yeah, now you're with me.

The long wait failed to mask the penultimate disappointment when we finally got the donuts. The voodoo doll was average - the filling was really over the top. The Memphis Mafia wasn't fully cooked. The middle of the donut had semi-raw dough. Ugh.

First things first My boyfriend and I are from Las Vegas and on our way to Washington. I have heard how awesome Voodoo doughnuts are from a friend of mine that used to live there as well as others and from Tv (foodnetwork i believe) of course. So i made it a must to stop by Portland just to have these doughnuts which were very good. 

The customer service experience wasn't a good. There was no line but two very unhappy irritated looking girls are the counter both with black hair a slightly "chubby" one and a thin girl with a Septum piercing.
When we walked in we stood off to the side to look at what we hand wanted before going to the counter there was NO line btw.
When we asked started picking out what we wanted the girl was clearly annoyed. She asked us if we had been here before and we had said no and she gave us an annoyed look and said "you havent been to Voodoo before" with the tone as if we were completely mentally challenged. We said that 1 dozen will do and began picking out what we thought would be cool to try. She then said the Voodoo dozen is the best way to go but we couldnt pick out any doughnuts (right away a bell went off in my head thinking shit im going to get the cheapest thing here) but she assured us that it was the best way to pick variety so i reluctantly agreed, seeing as all the doughnuts were unique. I had specifically asked for multiple maple bacon bars. she grabbed the dougnuts from a speed rack and handed us the closed box and gave us the total. 
we walked out feeling majorly disappointed with how rude their workers are.

Got the car and what appeared in the box was VERY average looking doughtnuts not worth the extra time to go and certainly not the rude employees. Not one Maple Bacon Bar was in that box, I wouldn't have cared to pay more for them if she had just pulled her head out of her ass and said their are none in the box. 
They were soo rude i didnt even want to go back inside to buy the six additional maple bacon bars that i was excited in trying. The only doughnut that looked unusual or an "VOODOO" assortment was a glazed doughnut with captin crunch and another with coco puffs.Two doughnuts out of 12!! best way to get an assortment my ass !

Doughnuts tasted GREAT!!
BAD customer service !!!
3 stars based on taste !

Over rated and over priced and any line you have to wait in isn't worth it. A tourist trap. Only raised donuts, though not all raised donuts are bad. I love bacon and I love maple bars but the bacon topped maple bar is NOT the mind blowing experience people say it is. Its just another alright donut. Don't believe me? Okay, take a bite...see told ya. And that thing covered in fruit loops is just a gross sugar bomb.
If you are looking for novelty and are an out of towner that wants to tell your friends that you have been there, then OK.  If you are looking for the best doughnuts in town, go to Blue Star.
I'm not a fan of Voodoo.  Every now and then people bring them into the office.  They're just ok. I like more traditional doughnuts like maple bars sans the bacon.

As a native Portlandian, I DON'T GET IT!!! They are donuts covered in cereal and cookies served by gross, hairy, hipsters in dirty conditions. Yet the lines don't stop!!! I can only assume its all tourists......FYI if you like their donuts, you'll probably like their day old donuts too...just sayin.....you can buy them at a discount by the bucket load, just ask....grossssss!!!

3.5 Stars

I guess it's a must if you're in portland. I have to admit though, I only tried a few bites of the blueberry glazed donut. It's a bit overpriced and expect a line all day long. Our hotel was just down the street, and so we would eye the line whenever we pass, and there's always a line! We waited an hour for donuts (but we also chose the day with the longest line). Our intention was to purchase a dozen donuts before we head to the airport so we can share with fam and friends. They seemed to enjoy them. 

They carry a unique variety of donuts - maple bacon, vegan, voodoo, etc...it's worth a try if you're ever in the area. I recommend going during the weekday....a lot less packed then the weekend.

- long waiting line
- no place to sit 
- insanely sweet 
+ It was beautiful inside 
+ The music was good
I'm disappointed that we came here. Go to Walmart and get a donut, throw some fruit loops on top. Same thing.

HIGHLY OVER RATED!!! i had these doughnuts before and i thought they LOOKED creative but I hated the taste of both doughnuts I tried. I thought I would be fair and gave em another chance  on a recent trip to Portand. I decided to stop in and give em another chance. I forgot which one i tried because that was the  low point of my night but i can guarantee you it was disgusting! the next day i went back to get a dozen for a co worker that like one of their doughtnuts but the line was out the wazzoooo. so all and all skip it!!!!!
Voodoo is great, if you want to wait in long lines for mediocre donuts.
This is not the place you go for doughnuts. This is just a gimicky place for out of town tourists.

Great visit for the ambiance.... not so great doughnuts.

It's a long wait if you want to get in to take a few pictures and say you've been there but most likely you will be disappointed by the doughnuts.  Also if you decide to get any of the ones with cereal topping, the cereal gets soggy and stale overnight, so eat them on the day you bought them.

The maple/bacon bar was probably my favorite one and its no different than if you went to safeway, bought a maple bar and added a couple of strips of bacon on it, really.

My advice, go once, take a few pictures, buy a couple of doughnuts, tell your friends about it, then don't go back.

Decent doughnuts. It lived up to the expectation of a doughnut. Definitely could have had more filling. Would not go back for this doughnut but worth the experience. Coffee was terrible and not worth the cost of use if my hand to hold it.
Clever concept, sugary stuff on subpar Dunkin Donut quality donuts. The lines are too long, the help is surly and you get way way way better no nonsense quality donuts at CO CO donuts!!!

I guess if you like poisoning your body with sugar and white flour while you're already shitface drunk at 2am.
No different than any other god-awful donut place, except for some reason it's a Portland icon.

This was on my list of things to do in Portland, and while I'm not overly impressed, I'm glad I experienced it! The experience cost me $28 for parking, 6 doughnuts and 4 postcards, and let me give you a piece of advice... If you're not eating the doughnuts until the next morning, don't get the cereal topped doughnuts!  The doughnuts themselves were pretty run-of-the-mill, but seeing all of the different types is worth it.
Good place to take tourists, but the donuts themselves aren't that good and the wait times are ridiculous.
Fun the first time. Donuts taste average, even sickly sweet compared to other donut shops. It is a novelty that isn't really a go to place for the product they sell.

The best thing about this is the cool box. The doughnuts are slightly novel but not nearly as cool as the pictures or website portray. They are decently priced but are cold and aren't any better than Safeway doughnuts. Not worth the wait... Its just a doughnut!

I don't know why the line for this place wraps around the corner.  I have never been a fan of their donuts.  Stale cereal on a donut?  Overpriced donuts?  Rude creepy staff?  Everything pink?  This place is weird, unsanitary, and overall just a bad vibe in general.  The donuts I have eaten here are overpriced, stale, and just better everywhere else.  I will never understand why this place is so popular.
Waited more than 30 minutes in line, and the donuts were not worth the wait. Lacked flavor, tasted a bit dry, and were not nearly as creative as Blue Star. Would not recommend this spot.

This was one of my must-see destinations whenever we went to Portland. Coming from Texas, I knew that there had been one that opened in Austin, but I wanted to wait until I had come to one of the original ones in Portland. 

Granted - I came at 5 AM after I picked a friend up at Greyhound, so there was absolutely no line whenever I got there; however, I have heard about the crazy lines that can happen with Voodoo so just beware. My experience is more based off the donuts themselves rather than the store experience. 

My friend and I came in and ordered ten donuts for us to share amongst our group of 5 college friends. Here are the donuts that we ordered. Anything with an asterisk is one that I would order again. 

Mexican Hot Chocolate - not enough cayenne kick for me, but it was a delicious chocolate cake donut. 
Glazed 
Bacon Maple Bar 
Portland Cream* 
Raspberry Romeo* 
Voodoo Doll 
Memphis Mafia
Viscous Hibiscus*
Lemon Curd Filled 
Old Dirty Bastard*


These donuts are creative and fun, but a little too sweet and not chewy enough for me (and I have a tremendous sweet tooth) - so the donuts for me are a 4 star. However, for me, they're not necessarily donuts that I would go out of my way for or wait in an insane line for, but if I'm in the area and there's a Voodoo donut without a line, I'll probably stop by - hence the 3.
Voodoo is quite the tourist trap, we've had it a few times and I have found better donuts around the city.

I've never found anything special about Voodoo.  They have a lot of gimicky donuts, but they're not super high quality, or even that delicious.  I would put them on par with Dunkin' Donuts or Krispy Kreme.
Maybe it's just that I am from Portland and have had my fill of voodoo.  But this place is alright.  Worth visiting if you're from out of town.  But otherwise, the lines are a bit much.

Voodoo, I still love you, but you have changed, and I have changed, I just feel like we are growing apart. Sure, you have delicious donuts, but you just refuse to change. Sometimes I feel like you are trying to hard to be weird with your blaring music that is so indie, it is even indie in the indie scene. I know you are busy, but you could move faster if it weren't for the "we're too cool to give a damn because we work at voodoo" attitude I get sometimes. Could you maybe accept credit cards now that you have made it big? Your quality is hit and miss, so at times you are amazing and other times you are a totally different doughnut shop than the one I once frequented. I just feel like you are letting yourself go, but I just don't know if I'm ready to let you go yet. It is never too late to change. 

Forrest

2 stars for creativity. And that's it.  They are far from the best I have ever had. In fact I wouldn't say there any better than Albertsons doughnuts. Way over hyped.  

Just my two cents

I finally made it to Voodoo Doughnut on my third trip to Portland. We managed to avoid the long line by arriving on a weekday afternoon. What I liked about this place was that it was quirky, unique, and had punk music blasting, adding to the overall vibe of the place. 

The donuts looked really cool (we couldn't even figure out which ones to get because we were overwhelmed) so we did the voodoo dozen, where they choose for you. We got a nice mix of everything, from the cereal topped ones, to a cinnamon one with sprinkles, to an oreo one. I'm glad we came here just because it's something that you have to do when visiting Portland, but I do agree with many people that Blue Star has the better donuts - Voodoo's were dryer and less flavorful. If you do want an instragrammable photo of awesome looking, decent tasting donuts, definitely go to voodoo at least once though :)

The donuts at Voodoo are quirky and eccentric, which makes this a prime stop for out-of -towners.  It's a good place to experience at least once.  My boyfriend took me there as the first 1/3 of our first date, which I enjoyed simply because I had never been there before.  Of course, there was a long line, but that was to be expected.  When we finally made our way to the front, I only had a moment to make my decision, as there were several people behind us.  I ended up getting the little voodoo man, which made for cute pictures and fun to eat, and my boyfriend got the Ol' Dirty Bastard, his favorite.  
The donuts are overpriced (and be sure to bring cash to avoid ridiculous ATM fees!!!) and the people behind the counters can't be counted on to be too friendly, so don't set your sights too high when you stop in.  If you don't want to be rushed, check out http://voodoodoughnut.com/doughnuts.html to look over the menu ahead of time.  
If you've never been, it might be worth checking out.  If nothing else, you made memories stopping in on a donut shop that appeared on the Food Network.

After a night at the bar, my friend brought me here for the first time. I can't believe I'd never heard of it after living here for a while. You walk up to this bright yellow door and glance up at their sighn "Voodoo Doughnut: The Magic is in the Hole" and don't know what to expect. So...onto the doughnuts. We were there at about 2 a.m. and I think most of the doughnut supply was already taken. I had a frosted doughnut sprinkled with tons of colorful fruit loops cereal. The problem: the cereal was stale. Yuck. The most creative doughnut: a maple one with a strip of bacon on top. My friend said it tasted like eating breakfast. Interesting. This place is worth a try, just make sure you ask for what was recently prepared cause stale doughnuts suck.

It is a meh baked good. The cake donut is flat out not good and their raised yeast is ok. They legit just deep fried cake... Yeast donuts are so big they were almost under cooked.  Not anything special except for the novelty. And the really really long line. Plus side the staff aren't a bunch of douchebags, they are hipsters. I'm more into the store kitsch and merch.  Great branding.

Quality dip.  I used to go to Voodoo back in 2004 and for a minor finding a place to hang out on a late night, Voodoo was the spot.  Their donuts tasted great (we used to split the gigantic Boston Creme 4 ways and it still filled us up), prices were good,and yeah we laughed at their signature quirky-ness and giggled at the adult humor. It was also fun watching people getting married there.  I know we tend to be more picky and "our palettes refine" when we get older, but I just remember the freshness, the smaller lines/being able to actually hang out inside with room to breathe, non-stale cereal, and the non-burnt pieces of bacon on the maple bacon bar.  Go for quirky, but not for quality or if you're in a time constraint.

Two words aptly describe this place: hype and kitsch.

I never had to stand in line at Winchell's or Dunkin', and not only were their donuts not any worse, they were often better --  because one thing they both were was consistent. Not here. You never know just what you'll get at Voodoo in terms of quality; I've gotten stuff from here that Albertson's would have thrown in the garbage hours ago!

And, seriously, potty humor-themed food? How old are we in this town? I'll stand in line for an Iron Maiden concert, not for some vulgar and over-priced culinary effrontery -- I could do that at the Union Gospel Mission for free.

Just like whoopee cushions, the novelty wears off. Unless you've artificially arrested your development at some point in the teenage years.

We went there with some friends 2 weeks ago. The friends had never been there and NONE of us will return. After purchasing our donuts we noticed cockroaches climbing all over the walls. Our appetites were ruined and we were stuck with our donuts. The cashier said "well I can't reach thm up there." And went on about her business. We were highly disappointed.

Never encountered such rude employees. Arguing with the customers and kicked them out for no good reason! Whoever owns this place should be ashamed of themselves for allowing employees to be so disrespectful to customers! 10 people in line walked out because of your employees horrendous behavior.

The doughnuts are good, but not out of this world.  Let's face it, it's a tourist destination. 
It's a fun place. That's for sure. I've been three times while visiting Portland and never had to wait too long. 
The staff is cool and friendly. Funny too. 
I tried to be discreet about ordering a particular masterpiece there, and the staff member filling my order yells it out loud. Ha! I got caught. Haha. They have many unique creations worth trying. The voodoo little man is always a must. Maple and bacon was good.  
Parking can be a challenge but not impossible. There is street parking and public lots.  
I've taken the little pink boxes home with me. Flying to LAX is never as much fun as when I'm carrying the pink boxes. Everyone wants the doughnuts. Some have joked about tackling me for the box. 
Just a warning!

Sorry bro, I don't care how good your donuts are. When you make fun of me to
your coworker and act like a pretentious ass while rapping along to Big Sean, I'm not gonna care about anything else from my trip to your shop. Customer service comes before any food. Piss off.

Voodoo donuts is really not much more than a tourist attraction. For anyone who is visiting Portland for the first time, definitely check it off your bucket list. In fact, for a one-time, bucket list visit, I'd give Voodoo 5 stars. It's quirky, and when you take all the tourists out, perfectly Portland weird. But for everyone else who lives here, 2 stars at best. 

You can't go wrong with the bacon maple, or old dirty bastard, but otherwise the donuts are mediocre. The cereal donuts are guaranteed to taste stale. And absolutely nothing in the shop is worth the line if you actually just want a doughnut. 

Luckily, the tourists will keep this place in business for all eternity so I don't feel bad saying any of this.

Went here on a recent trip to Portland. It was conveniently blocks away from my hotel so I was able to wake up at 7 am and avoid any lines. Grabbed a couple donuts (cereal and the signature Voodoo) and a cup of coffee.  I liked the coffee but the donuts were just ok. I can see how this generation that loves their over the top food combos adores Voodoo doughnut but I can't really say that it was any better than any winchell's or krispy creme I've ever had. It's definitely gluttony of doughnuts at it's finest if you're into that. It's not worth the line but if you're up early enough it's worth it when it's hassle free.

Voodoo Doughnuts is good but how good is the question... $13 a dozen good? Not really. If you are going there to be like one of the tourists and wait in line for an hour in the rain then ok, maybe it's worth it. I prefer to go at times of the day/week when I know there won't be a line. I have a few I really like though. The McMinnville Cream, The No-Name, and The Voodoo Doll are my 3 faves. If you are looking for basic donuts go with the Original Glazed or the Buttermilk Bar, those are great too. Usually they are blaring heavy metal so loud that I literally lose track of what I'm buying and have a headache by the time I am walking out. Don't bring plastic, they only take cash but have an ATM available if you don't have any. 3 out of 5 times I go here the people working are rude, Rush me along (even when there isn't anyone else in line), and are frequently out of at least one or two of what I wanted to buy. These things over time have made me not want to go anymore. I mean if I wanted a chick covered in tattoos and piercings to give me dirty looks while I put money in her till I would just go to a local strip club... Not a doughnut shop. I really wish they would turn the music down a touch and maybe be a little friendlier. It would make all the difference. Unfortunately, that's not going to happen because just enough tourists watch the Food Network and cannot wait to go and spend their money at this hometown famous Doughnut shop. They are so in awe of their first time being there that they are oblivious to the crappy service and average doughnuts that they won't complain, therefore making the establishment think the way they run business is acceptable.

After always hearing people rave about Voodoo doughnuts, we felt like it was something we couldn't miss on our trip. The line was long, but moved fairly quick. The donuts were pretty average-have had a lot better. A large part of the reason I'm giving a two star is because of the attitude of the guy who rang us up. Not helpful at all and a little snarky. Would not visit again and would not recommend wasting your time with it.

Honestly, despite the rave reviews I've received from some friends, Voodoo doesn't make that good of doughnuts. Sure, as a novelty item, it's maybe a fun trip. 
The dough itself is rather dense and not fluffy and airy as a doughnut ought to be. This, coupled with stale toppings (this is what I've experienced personally, not saying it's the status quo) has left me wanting more. 
Finally, the prices are too high for what you get above. My final act of sacrilege is to state that Heavenly Doughnuts on Glisan has better donuts for the dollar; are they fancy? No, and that's the beauty. They don't pretend to be anything they aren't. 
Skip voodoo. There are better places.

Number one place you have to visit when in Portland. Pretty cool that they're open 24hrs! And their funny donuts are always worth the IG pic. 

What I tasted here:
Blueberry Donut 
Portland Cream 
Regular Glaze 

All basic and all hyped. Nothing I would go out of my way to get. Nothing really to say either. Also a pretty SKETCH NEIGHBORHOOD @ NIGHT. So come during the day if you can! Cash Only!!

Voodoo Doughnut is seriously overrated.  Sure, top a mediocre doughnut with bacon and of course it's better.  But the other doughnut shops in town are ten times better.  Tonalli's on Alberta?  Now those are totally worth it, but i never see a line stretched out the door there.  How about Annie's on Sandy?  Voodoo is just good marketing.  And it gets a nod 'cause it's open later than most (though Tonalli's is open till midnight, and the doughnuts at that time are warm and fresh and heavenly.)

A bit too gimmicky for me - Voodoo was full of judgmental teens and the service was grumpy, which I guess is their thing. I had their chocolate peanut butter rice krispies doughnut, which was good, but nothing outstanding. I can now say with confidence that Blue Star is superior to Voodoo.

It's a whole lot of hype for some pretty mediocre donuts. The donut quality is masked by silly names, marketing, and novelty toppings. I guess if you care more about appearance than substance, by all means, stand in line.

Was expecting a magical experience but I'm feeling generous giving a 2-star to Voodoo. The cashier/face of the company was grumps and not helpful at all for a first time customer. My donuts really weren't that amazing and they sent me off with a huge gaudy pink box for 4 donuts, in attempts to make me a walking billboard for their disappointing donuts. Maybe I just got unlucky but I'd say that was a bust.

These are not the finest, most elegant donuts ever made, nor are they meant to be.  What Voodoo serves up is an immediate sense of Portland, nonsensical mishmashes that at times are greater than the sum of their many parts.  The Memphis Mafia is one example, and I am sure there are other scattered among the mistakes.  The good news is Voodoo doesn't take itself too seriously, and neither should you.  These are donuts, after all, so wait in line for 30 and stuff your face with a Cock-N-Balls.

I think it's the hype about this place that makes it worth going. We went in the afternoon and the line had doubled in on itself, and we ended up waiting for almost an hour. That was definitely the con. (Luckily there was some interesting people to talk to, so having a conversation made the time go by faster!)

I had looked at the menu online, but I am such a sucker for oreos that even if I had *wanted* to try something new (Cock and Balls doughnut, I'm looking at you) I probably would have switched at the last minute. 

The oreo doughnut was awesome. Best I've ever had? Well, no. My boyfriend got the Captain Crunch one and liked it, but both were just so big and sugary that we ended up not finishing them. Still, I'm glad that we tried it, and I'm sure that I'd go here again, but only if the wait was under 10 minutes. I'm sure there are better doughnut shops around Portland. We just didn't have time to check them all out.

One thing I loved immediately about Voodoo Doughnut upon entering their tiny storefront during my recent trip to Portland, Oregon, is that they spell "doughnut" correctly. Over here in Dunkin' Donuts territory, I sometimes feel the word is in danger of losing its silent letters forever, à la the commonplace and ridiculous spelling of "drive-thru." 

Grammatical considerations aside, I was excited to go see the selection of vegan doughnuts at Voodoo, a mecca for hip kids and drunkards (as it's near a lot of late-night bars in downtown Portland) as well as for vegans tired of missing out on fluffy, sticky, delicious sweetness.  Midday on a Thursday (Christmas Eve, actually) the line for Voodoo snaked not quite out the door and the air was thick with the scent of sugar. 

Now, Voodoo is the kind of place you go for the novelty, really. With a bacon-draped maple bar and doughnuts festooned with Fruit Loops and crushed Butterfingers, the point here is as much the entertainment value as it is the flavor. My brother and mom selected six regular doughnuts (although there's nothing much normal about a giant chocolate doughnut dredged in Oreos) and I asked for an assortment of six vegan ones. 

We spent the next couple days sampling the doughnuts little slices at a time, because there's really only so much fat and sugar that's appealing to an adult before you start craving an apple or some nice steamed broccoli. In general, I'd say the vegan doughnuts were so-so. My assortment included cake and glazed varieties, one with what tasted like grape Pixie Stix powder on top, a couple with blah vanilla glaze and sprinkles, one with what appeared to be (and tasted like) orange crayon shavings, and one maple-glazed (with which you can never go wrong!). Maybe Voodoo puts too much emphasis on the sugary glaze and toppings and not enough on the taste and consistency of the dough itself. Or maybe I'm just not a sweets fanatic. 

Still, I definitely recommend stopping by Voodoo if you're in the Portland area.

Fun experience, but totally lackluster doughnuts, as far as taste is concerned. You can find a better tasting doughnut at practically any other shop in town, and this place has become pretty much strictly reserved for tourists. Never been much of a fan of pink boxes anyways....

I have heard the hype about this place, I have seen the lines wrapped around the building down town, but I have never made the trip in the store to try it out.  But luckily I was at a wedding where they served a whole bunch of different kinds of Voodoo Donuts.

Now, I do love donuts.  I really, really love donuts.  But only good donuts, not crappy donuts.  These donuts didn't look great, the frosting seemed slim.  There was all sorts of crap on them that don't belong on donuts (bacon, cereal etc.)  They didn't look appetizing but I figured I might as well give them a shot since I had the chance.  I think that it was the first time in 20 years that I did not finish a donut.

When did donuts become food for kids?  When did we decide to put things on donuts that look like they are going to a classroom full of 2nd graders?  Why is there a kid's cereal on a donut, and why do we do we accept it, and eat it.  Instead of thinking of the next crazy thing to put on a donut, why don't you just focus on making a really good donut?  

But Voodoo will not do that, they will continue to make bad donuts will stupid stuff on them, that people will continue to line up outside because they want to follow the crowd because it's the cool thing to do, and I will continue to have to listen to people praise this place, and I'll have to argue with them for either following the crowd, or for just having really bad taste.

Brandon
www.totalepicness.com
It's not for me. Poor quality, and overpriced. I don't know why a lot of people would stay on the line to get it. I rather go to  krispy Kreme.

Fun place, but make sure you bring cash. 
Very Portland quirky; they always give change in gold-dollar coins.
The line can be long during peak hours, but it's one of the those must-do experiences when in Portland.

Don't play it safe if you're just visiting, get one of the odder choices. I personally recommend the "Dirty Old Bastard" a chocolate covered donut crusted with crushed Oreos and topped with a peanut butter drizzle.

Greeting- no
Vibe/ place to be
Parking- street
Price- nice
Service-fast
Food
Still love the snickers donut and the voo doo doll. $2.75 each. Large sized donuts
WIGB? Yes

It must be the Voodoo because it sure isn't the donuts here. I've had better from a grocery store, and the clones stand in line for up to an hour here to pay high prices for these dumb-idea donuts. This place proves once again the comment credited to PT Barnum - 'Nobody ever went broke underestimating the intelligence of the American (read Portland) public.' 
there are so many good bakeries in this town, why bother with the stupid, pink boxes!!

Okay, I had to go since I saw that they have a maple bacon bar.  It sounds like the kind of thing that you can't go wrong with.  But the store itself is pretty creepy.  It looks like they haven't cleaned in ages and the girl behind the counter must have been stoned.

I asked her if they had a hot donut, she grabs the largest apple fritter I've ever seen in my life and tells me it's still warm.  When I get it I realize it's not.  Not even close honey.  But the maple bacon bar is a winner as far as donuts go.  If you can get past the looks of the place, the donuts are what you expect.  Crazy flavors and deep fried sweetness.  I can throw 2 pieces of bacon on a local maple donut.

This was one of the few places on my hitlist because of Tony Bourdain. I went to the new location because of the renovations. There was a line but what's waiting 15 min. The food experience was awesome!! The service experience is something for them to work on. I wish Yelp had a two phase starring system... one for Food and one for Service. I would give 4 Stars for Food, 2 Stars for Service.

FOOD:
The Bacon Maple Bar, the Apple Fritter and the Mango Tango were all awesome! Damn good at 1am and what's left over is perfect for breakfast.

SERVICE: 
The donuts are double the price they should be (the novelty of it.. just like those ultra high-end cupcakes that exist). The Donut Nazi taking the orders can learn to be a little nicer, especially for someone who has never been there before and you want to ask a question.

DRUNK PEOPLE WATCH OUT!!!!
They take advantage of people by giving $1 coins as change. I witnessed this while standing in line... and the guy tried to pull it on me. You should have seen his face when I didn't drop any change in the tip jar and pulled out a dollar bill instead. If I would have dropped the change like I normally do they would have taken $4+ more dollars from me.

I'm poor so when someone tries to play me for a fool, I don't like it. Drunk people watch yourself!!!
Theyre just donuts. Not worth the wait. Go to Coco or even a grocery store. Tourist trap.

I have been to their cart in Pioneer Square a few times and the items they offer are not truly original. Imagine buying a doughnut from Safeway and covering it with gummy bears. It is childlike imagination that seems to give the business popularity and appeal. I would rather have cake and tea than eat one of their doughnuts again!

I just don't get it. The doughnuts are not bad but.... for gods sake they are not that good. Sure they are kind of fun and creative but I think their doughnuts are kind of dry. I never really review any business unless I can give them + 4 stars because I own a small business and don't really like how Yelp works if you don't buy their service (karma and all that) but.... my lord this place is WAY over hyped. And if you can't stand a hipster vibe never ever go there.

If your from out of town you have to stop by voodoos and pick up that mable bacon bar at least once to get that portlandia experience...but once is enough.. most locals will go to blue star to get that really good fresh donut..not worth the huge line if your at downtown location- but those big pp donuts are fun to bring back to your friends as souviners

When visiting family from out of state, they ALWAYS ask for me to bring them a box of this stuff. FYI: if you do not like attention, don't bring this box on an airplane. People will gawk and make really obnoxious comments to try and get a donut from a complete stranger. I personally prefer Heavenly Donuts to Voodoo. Voodoo is definitely more novelty than food.
Like waiting in line for an hour for a doughnut? Me neither. This place is more hype than anything else. However, if their mobile doughnut Van shows up to a community event near you, DO IT!

Everyone was telling me to go to Voodoo on my trip to Portland so I had to go and check it out for myself. Every time I passed by, there was a huge line outside and since they're open 24/7, I decided to come back around 11 PM so there wouldn't be a crazy line.

The interior of the store is very interesting (gothic, hipster, punk, etc...) and there's even a rotating glass case full of donuts to give you a look of what their donuts look like. There is a wide variety of donuts to choose from so you'll be sure to find one that suits your desires. 

Instead of opting to get a donut to enjoy, I decided to do the Tex-Ass Challenge after hearing and seeing about it. WOW. The Tex-Ass Challenge is where you have to eat a Tex-Ass donut (basically a HUGE glazed donut equivalent to 6 normal glazed donuts) in under 80 seconds. If you succeed, you get a pin and Voodoo pays for your donut, roughly $5. I totally underestimated the size of the donut. In photos, the donut doesn't look too big but once you start shoving it in your mouth, it's sooo thick. I failed miserably...I only ate half of the donut in 80 seconds. I was so disappointed in myself...luckily there was no one else in the store!! I took the rest to-go and after taking a few bites, the donut wasn't the best I ever had. It's a decent donut and I would tell anyone to check out Voodoo on their trip to Portland since it's so famous.

The donuts were good. There was no line on this Sunday morning (9 a.m.) Only 3 stars because the customer service was Horrible. He acted like it was an inconvenience to serve us. It would have been nice to have a donut menu.
I don't know what the hype is about.  It's just OK.

I love the bacon maple bar. I've tried other stuff and a lot of time they are stale and I don't like that they are cash only and kind of over priced.

The last 3 times I've gone here everything seems stale and crusty...my rating is more like a 2.5

unconventional yet totally underwhelming.
i tried a couple of different donuts but found them to be totally average.
definitely not worth the hype.

Hmm...
Lined up for about 30 minutes on a Saturday night at around 10:30pm. I tried their Oreos donut. I really am not sure what the hype of this place is. Is it because of a lot of unique flavors? Or because it is open 24/7? Their staff were rude, donut was wayyyy too sweet, the line takes forever...
Anyways, not gonna happen for me again!

As a native of the Portland area I've found these doughnuts to be more hype for visitors to PDX than of quality. Yes, there are some good doughnuts and I've received decent service, but I've had better doughnuts elsewhere. If you do visit though, make sure to bring cash instead of using your card.
Vastly overrated. I suggest Helen Bernhard's (I'm not associated with either, just a customer.)
The taste of the donuts are nothing to write home about, but this place wins for two reasons: (1) it's open 24 hours a day usually (2) it's unique as fuck.
Over priced disgusting donuts. Leave this for the tourists. If you want an amazing donut go to Annie's on 72nd and Fremont or Tonalis on Alberta
They are just too busy keeping Portland weird. Overpriced and gooey sugar laden. Not going back. Great place for the gullible hipster doofus's of Portland.

Ah, Voodoo Doughnut! All hype and little substance. Yes the Doughnuts are "good", how can a fresh doughnut be anything else? But other than the name, the incredible hyperbole, and the design of the box you are left with an average doughnut shop.
The most amazing thing is that a cash-only business with an open till with no electronic record keeping is able to stay in business!

The doughnuts are scrumptious, but think they are over-rated. The only thing is they have ones that other places dont. So if you get the munchies at 2 am, you can count on them being open to provide you with the artery clogging goodness.

They'll never have a gluten free donut (I've asked). I've only had a bite here and there, and from what I remember, it tasted just like a regular donut. I'm obviously not their target consumer, and it's not worth the time in line for me, but I know some people just can't get enough of this place.

Voodoo donuts is an iconic donut shop in portland OR. It's cash only and always has a line. ** don't worry it moves fast** The yeast donuts are light and fluffy. Don't get any ones with crazy toppings and strange names. They won't be good. Regular donuts are reasonable though, they are stingy on the filling for their Portland cream and blueberry donuts. Honestly, I expected more for a craft donut. Prices are reasonable and donuts are large in size so 2 instead of one star but I probably won't be back.

Protip: Cash only

Tried this place out with my buddy visiting from out of town. Their donuts are creative, but I've had better doughnuts. The doughnut recipe needs improvement, slightly on the tangy side. This seems more of a novelty then a place to go for a quality doughnut.
Fun experience, brilliant names/marketing - but a little overrated from a donut perspective. Everyone should try once - locals and tourists.  Likely won't go back  though.

This place is extraordinarily overhyped. 

There is usually a very long line outside of this place, since this is the original location, and barely any parking. You're either running through traffic or running through the rain. Either way, once you stand in line, they're real sticklers about making sure that the door that is the entrance stays closed and the exit stays clear. I guess that makes sense.

I think the other location is a bit bigger so can accommodate more diners inside. This place doesn't have any "inside" areas to eat or hang out in. 

The donuts are all a little crazy for me. To be honest, I am like a plain, glazed, simple donuts kind of girl. All this jazz doesn't do much for me. Definitely a recommended visit to say you've been here. Otherwise ... meh.

Maybe it's just all the hype that got to VooDoo.  But, I feel their donuts have become dry, rather blah, and totally not worth waiting in a line for.

Sorry VooDoo you no longer doo that magic you used to Doo so well.

Hmm not sure why this is a must-go-to place... I think we wasted our trip time lining up and trying this place tbh I forgot the name of the donuts we got, but we got the one w the maple glazed + bacon and the one w the oreos. It was too sweet and the oreos were too stale that my sis and I took a bite and threw them out. Meh... would not go back~

If in Portland you are told to go to Voodoo Donuts. A bit hyped up but you must experience it at least once. Donuts were average. Considering we bought a dozen, they stuffed them in a small box and put one on top of another and then a big with 2 donuts. When we took them back to our rental, the top donuts melted the bottom frosting. The too in the bag also melted as it was a hot day. For the price of each donut, they should have put then single layer in 2 boxes.
Don't waste you time and money. It's all a big hype because they put crazy things on their terrible donuts.
I would have loved to eaten some doh!nuts here....but spouse put the kabash on that when she pointed out how dirty the display cases where the food is kept. So creative here tho.

It's ok. It's gone too touristy and I won't wait in line for it anymore. Of the donuts we've brought to work, Voodoo is probably the least favorite of folks. Generally, the complaint is the donuts are too sweet / gimmicky. Most folks avoid the cereal / candy coated ones.

We're an old fashioned / cake / buttermilk kind of crowd.

That said, the 'Mexican hot chocolate' donut has to be one of my favorite cake donuts I've had. Ever. A perfect dunker for coffee.

Don't get your hopes up. Voodoo is serving novelty donuts. These are normal donuts topped/ filled with cereals, cookies, etc. The catchy name is the finishing touch. With all that being said, standing in line for $3-5 donuts is just part of being a tourist in Portland.

Humm, well I have to admit I love their donuts - though for the most part they taste like Rosauer's donuts in Spokane (which is not at all a bad thing though it is a grocery store chain).  But... the place is just dirty - I know it's cool and all to have these crap shacks for spaces but sanitation is still a concern. The location downtown is semi-excusable because it's downtown in a gritty neighborhood. Their second location, Voodoo Donuts (too) - is trashy. That Voodoo is doodoo.

This donut taste pretty good, not voodoo one those maybe i don get used to have jelly inside a donut so that my personal point of view. Got there at 3 am , no line no wait best time but a lot of homeless people around the area, dont worry they wont ask you for money, they ask you if you can give them a donut only.
Absolutely horrible. Much too sweet. Better doughnuts are served at 7-11. A new cart called Donut Byte Labs serves immeasurably better donuts and is located across the street from voodoo.

nothing to write home about - tourist hype as usual. 

nothing bad to say ... nothing good to say either... its a donut

If you want quality, delicious doughnuts do not come here. If you want fun, silly, novelty doughnuts then this is the place for you.

The doughnuts are nothing special taste wise. I thought some of them were a little dry and if you get the cereal topped ones eat them right away otherwise they get soggy and gross. To be honest, I think that I've had better doughnuts from Safeway. The colors and "odd" toppings are the only things that make these stand out from other doughnuts. 

If you really must get these doughnuts, go to the other location where the wait isn't nearly as long.

We were visiting Portland so this was an obligatory stop. The vibe was pretty cool and definitely different than any other donut shop I've been to. I think we got lucky because the line wasn't too bad. Of course it was 10am on a Monday morning. What we had:

Neapolitan- definitely tastes better than it looks but I'm a sucker for anything that has strawberry in it 

Memphis Mafia- one of the best fritters I've had, a little dense and sweet but worth it 

Pothole- this one was my favorite hands down

3 stars because I like Blue Star better

Gave this place another try 5 years later. Still do not like. The donut is dry and not fluffy and the toppings make them cloyingly sweet.

Cash only. Long lines outside.

I've been here twice and the first time I was here there was no line and the maple bacon bar made a pretty good drunk food. The second time I was here, there was a long line and we waited about 30 minutes. I got the maple bacon bar again and I enjoyed it but it was just too sweet for me. I can only eat half and save the other half for another time.

The donuts are average and overrated.  Not worth standing in line for them.  

Why tourists continue to do it, I'll never know.  But they've expanded to Denver so they clearly are doing something right, which I'm clearly missing.

I appreciate that they are a "Keep Portland Weird" type of place, but seriously, it's not worth waiting that long for them.

I mean, when in Portland you definitely have to stop here. But let's be honest, the donuts themselves are not that great. They taste like your regular donut shop donut, but the different toppings are awesome. My family went on a Monday afternoon and the wait wasn't long at all (prob about 10 min). Cash only so just be prepared!

Voodoo Doughnut, A short history: 

The concept of Voodoo when it opened was hilarious and intriguing but that was many years ago now. When they first opened they had toppings like NyQuil and crushed up Pepto. "YES!" everyone said in unison. Then the FDA or someone decided that wasn't okay and that they had to go with stale cereal instead. We all thought Voodoo was doomed except somehow the masses thought this was GREAT, especially people from other parts of the country. The word spread until there was no soul left wondering what Voodoo Doughnuts was. Me myself? I like the doughnuts alright if you scrape off anything they put on top of them.
If you like sugar and lard and other poor quality fat and food coloring and cheaply made over sweet junk, go to Voodoo.  Their prices are high and the donuts are pretty, but it ain't worth it!

I tried 5 doughnuts and liked only 2 of them. So I guess I'll give this place 2 out of 5 stars.

The maple bacon and plain glazed are the only ones I would recommend. The maple bacon has a great balance of sweet and salty, and the plain glazed had a delicate flavor of a buttered croissant. 

The others I tried were overly sweet. Specifically, the voodoo doughnut was too sweet where there was no jelly, but too tart where jelly was. 

I went at 10pm and there was a line of about 40 people. There were also panhandlers outside the shop, but I'm not going to factor these into the star rating. 

This place is definitely overhyped, but it won't break the bank to try this place if you're very curious.

If you want to identify yourself as a tourist, walk around town with the infamous pink box...the locals will tease you. We knew that, but went anyway. What the hell, why not. 

Honestly, the doughnuts themselves aren't that great. The shop is fun, painted in glitter and pink. The doughnuts have great names, like Gay Bar, Cock and Balls. It's fun if you want the experience. But they were too sweet, not very flavorful, and kind of stale. But I still couldn't pass up some Cock and Balls...

Voodoo Doughnut rose to the top with gimmicky doughnuts (Pepto-Bismol doughnuts, Robitussin doughnuts, Nyquil doughnuts) until the FDA said they could not sell them anymore. They stayed at the top by appearing on popular shows on the Food Network and now they are a Portland icon.

The doughnuts here are not bad but neither are the doughnuts at Safeway, Fred Meyer or Albertsons.  Don't be fooled by the lines wrapping around the block, they are all tourists too.  

Yes, the doughnuts have funny, clever names.  Yes, the bacon maple bar is good, almost as good as going to the grocery store, buying a couple maple bars and some bacon and making them yourself (yes, we've done this.)

If you want a truly amazing doughnut go to one of the many fantastic doughnut shops in town; Annie's, Blue Star, Pips Original to name a few.

Voodoo Doughnut is a must if:
a) You want a picture in front of the sign to show your friends back home.
b) You want to get married in a doughnut shop (yeah, for real.)
c) You're craving a good fritter.  To their credit they do make some pretty good fritters but be prepared to pay for it, they are not cheap by doughnut standards.

One more thing, if you get some doughnuts to go make sure you eat the ones with the kiddy cereal on top right away because that cereal will be stale by tomorrow morning.

Oh, and if you happen to be driving by on your way to some late night after party you can stop here (when it's way late) and often get a 5 gallon bucket full of day old doughnuts for about $5, the only real deal at Voodoo.

Voodoo is a classic and iconic must try spot if you are in Portland visiting.  Overall the hype is the best part of your experience.  Everyone needs to try it once and get a selfie holding their signature pink boxes.  As far as the donut itself it's subpar and never really is "fresh" tasting in the multiple visits I've had to both Voodoo and Voodoo Too.  Also, as of my last visit it's "cash only" which is really annoying since everything is card based nowadays.   Why they don't have the technology to take debit is beyond me.

Meh is right.  Stale fruit loops (this can ruin one's day people).  Not the best doughnut base either, have had better from some grocery stores.  Staff not exactly the friendliest of people.

Meh.

We had to stop by and see what all the fuss was about.  Long line (to be expected).  The selection was pretty creative and we ordered about a dozen different types of donuts between the 4 of us.  Unfortunately, we dont have a big sweet tooth and these were just way too sweet.  Like the atmosphere and kudo's on the PR.  We can now say we tried it, but most likely wont be coming back next time we are in town.

Honestly, I don't see what the big hype is. Maybe it's cuz I'm not really into sweet things. I thought it was a bit overrated. I got the Kruller, Old Dirty Bastard and the Maple Bacon donut after waiting in line for 30 min. I loved the glittery brick wall and the pink boxes. But I thought the donuts were way too sweet but I can see why people who have a big sweet tooth would love these doughnuts. All in all, it's not for me but it may be perfect for you. If you don't have a big sweet tooth, I don't recommend this place. If you do, then you probably will like it. They are cash only.

Gross, overrated, over-priced, unhealthy! If you are hitting Portland and you think visiting this place will make your tour complete, then you are mistaken and wasting your time. As someone who grew up here, I feel it is disgraceful to see that this hole-in-the-wall represents anything about our town to people passing through other than a good way to waste 5$ and consume 500 calories in dirty grease and sugar.

A short visit to Portland required the obligatory visit to VooDoo donuts. I haven't had a donut in years and was looking forward to trying one from the infamous VooDoo donuts, even if the reviews weren't that great. We went around 2:00 am and the choice was very limited. I hate to say it, but I agree with the previous reviews; either I've lost my taste for donuts, or these were not that good. They were very greasy and left a film in my mouth, and the Bavarian cream tasted like pure sugar. 

Oh well, no more donuts for me for the foreseeable future, I'm sure my waist and hips will be grateful. 

They got three stars for managing to build a huge following with crappy donuts, offering vegan options, and for being open 24 hours.

Very creative but average in the taste category. Waited in the ridiculous line to buy overly priced donuts but what the hell that's why I was here. Occasionally there are entertainers outside to entertain the crowd as they wait in line. This place is crazy touristy with prices to match, t-shirts are crazy expensive. Also, if you have kids and are waiting in line with kids they have some donuts that are for adults in the glass case, so be prepared.

Don't want to be harsh but my donuts were stale within a couple of hours. Bought a dozen to bring to Washington for my boyfriends grandparents and aunt and when we got there 4 hours later, the donuts were stale and by the next day they were just falling apart and nasty to eat. Pretty disappointed.. the donuts aren't even in closed cases. They're all out on baking trays. Probably why my donuts went stale so quick.

Exceedingly average donuts.  Their fillings and icings are the standard pre-made stuff that everyone else in the bakery industry uses. The donut dough is not anything spectacular, neither for the regular nor the cake donuts. 

Yes, there is some originality in combinations, but not enough to justify the wait and the popularity.  

A tourist trap and nothing more.

Wish I could say I loved the doughnuts here, but they just weren't really my favorite. I actually prefer Dunkin Donuts to this, but that could just be my preference. I tried four different types of doughnuts here and all of them were quite heavy, dense and too sweet. Also the filled doughnuts were lacking in filling (noticed on the Portland Cream, Voodoo Doll and Raspberry Filled). The line moves quick enough though and we only waited about a half hour on a Sunday evening. Prices are reasonable and though I am glad I tried this iconic shop once, I don't think I need to go back again.
If you want a gimmick doughnut that tastes alright, then this is the place for you.  If you just want a delicious doughnut, there are other places you can go that don't have such a huge line.

bad bad bad.
not what portland is about and i think they only exist because its been established as a tourist trap.

Overly sweet, overpriced and people are very rude! No explanations, not even a decent hello... dirty location... this was our first time to Portland and to voodoo.. not worth it.. it's just a hype.. Safeway donut if even that...

I came here to visit Portland and heard about this from all source of media. We walked here from our hotel and got in line. I had a decent expectation, not to over hype but hold it to high standards. We got the dozen because we had no idea what to other. Here are my take aways

Pros- nice deco, interesting donut shapes

Cons- taste regular, cash only, long lines 

Overall, it's just fancy looking donuts. I tried blue star and it was much better if u care about taste.

I got the mango tango doughnut and it was totally inedible. I took a few bites until I got to the filling and then I put it down and never picked it up again. If you are hoping for a genuine mango taste in the mango tango doughnut, you will be disappointed. It tasted artificial, almost lemony, and had a harsh chemical aftertaste. Nothing about it reminded me of a mango. The dough had the consistency of a hamburger bun but did have good flavor. I can't speak for other doughnuts, but I do NOT recommend the mango tango under any circumstances. Plus it was extremely overpriced.

I love donuts, so I had to try this place when I visited. CASH ONLY. Waited for about 1hour in line on a Sunday (mid morning).  

It somewhat lived up to the hype. We got the flyer dozen because we wanted to try as many different ones as we can, and we were able to substitute a couple of them to our liking. I think the dough is definitely superior than your neighborhood donut shop, and some of the flavors taste really great/unique. But I found the donuts overall to be a little too sweet for my taste. With that said, the next time I'm in town I would stop by for a couple of donuts.

I realize that this is a touristy spot but it really is over-hyped. 

Firstly, it's in a pretty sketchy area. Walking in and out of voodoo doughnuts, we were approached 3x by homeless asking for money - one asked to take my donut? 

Anyway, back to the donuts - we ordered two items that were in their glass case. We went around lunch time so I would've hoped these were reasonably fresh but they tasted a little stale, as if they were next-day donuts. Not only that, but they were way too sweet. I realize I'm saying a dessert food is too sweet but honestly, there wasn't balance between the doughnut itself and the toppings. And for me, that's strange because I have a sweet tooth. 

Honestly, I wouldn't recommend making the trip to this location if you want to try Portland's donuts. If you happen to be in the area, sure. But no need to make it a point.

I've heard so much about this place but I wasn't extremely impressed after all I've heard.  In Voodoo doughnuts defense I was slightly intoxicated when I went in so I can't remember everything they had to offer.  My friend ordered the Bacon Maple Bar, although hesitant at first, it was awesome! In fact I kind of want another one right now.  The reason I only give it 3 stars is because I also tried a frosted doughnut with fruit loops on it and a chocolate frosted doughnut with butterfingers crumbled on top, I was not impressed with the last two doughnuts.  I plan on trying it again when I am sober and I'll review after that.  Overall, I expected something a little more special and different and only one doughnut filled that expectation.

Don't know what the hype is about. I had the voodoo doll doughnut and it was average. Though I'm not big on pastries, I definitely had better doughnuts from chains like Krispy Kreme (Pittsburgh location). Even locally I would definitely head over to Cupcake Jones if I wanted to satisfy a sweets craving.

Perhaps I need to try this place in the wee hours of the morning when starving. Until then, just two stars.

Best part about this place is that it's open 24/7.  There's usually a long wait outside with a fairly small inside store area.  Workers of course get through the line as quickly as possible so don't be scared by the long line.  As far as variety of options goes, Voodoo has it all.  They even have some oversized fun donuts to experience.  The taste, I thought, was nothing special.  After all, due to the numbers they move, the donuts are mass produced.  It's a fun place to check out if visiting Portland, especially if you have donut cravings late at night, but I don't think I'll re-visit Voodoo on my next trip to Portland.

Two years after the move I finally made my way to Voodoo.  It's a must see if you're from out of town...if only to say that you did.  The donuts are all right...just all right.  Waaay too sweet for my taste.  I guess if you think of Voodoo as an old run down museum and have no intention of actually eating the displays, it's awesome!  Not sure I'll be back.  One visit will suffice.

The only donut I liked was the voodoo man donut... other than that this okay. If it weren't for its Colorful/artistic decors, funny donut names and the location this place is just meh.  Definitely a "do it for the gram" kind of spot

Average average average.  

I won't repeat the endless reviews of this place, so here are my thoughts. 

If you come to Portland and you like donuts it's worth going for the "experience".  If you are someone who loves going to different donut spots, you will find this place overpriced and overrated like I did.  

If you want to spend 8 bucks for donut that looks like a blunt or a penis then I guess have at it.  I tried the grape ( too sweet), maple bacon ( bacon was old, look up Friendly's in Orange as a way to make it), and a lemon donut ( I actually liked it). If I come back here I would try the basic donuts only. 

I come up to the Northwest 1-2x a year and will try a different place next time ( I'm hearing about Blue Star), for now I will stick to the Donuttery for my donut fix.   Thanks!!

61/2016

Just a fun place to visit.  Not a big deal.  It was fun to actually eat a voodoo doughnut. Service was great.  Very helpful with recommendations.  We were lucky to wait less than 10 mins to order.  Every time we walked by, the line was outside the store and around the corner.  Maybe the best time to visit is after 9 p.m. when we were there.
Overhyped. Good donuts but too trying too hard with toppings. Sometimes simpler is better.

Of course I couldn't leave Portland without making a stop at voodoo donuts... I was excited all the way to the checkout, until I opened my bag of donuts to find my voodoo doll upside down, face smeared on the inside of the bag... Overall, the donuts are average but very fun. The location itself is a little grimy but again, fun. I purchase three donuts: a voodoo doll, lemon chiffon, and the Mango Tango. I would go back to try a couple more... Probably not the same location though. Maybe I'll give Denver a shot

I get it...if you're coming for a visit you have to go because you saw it on the food channel or Portlandia or whatever...that said their doughnuts are "Meh". The cereal ones are always stale, and everyone does the maple bacon ones anymore. If you do go here the Mango Tango and the Arnold Palmer (the cream filled one is ok too) are really the only ones worth getting in my opinion.
My recommendation is to skip Voodoo altogether and hit Blue Star instead.

You wait in line, excited for donuts while simultaneously freaking out about the fact that the brick wall outside the place is shiny and covered in glitter. You slowly approach and look into the pepto bismal colored place with names on the board such as 'Miami vice'. You try to think about what you might order but are too distracted by the names of the donuts and the cases of spinning donuts inside - can you say visual stimuli?! When you finally enter you're bamboozled by the pink walls, loud punk rock music playing, men with beard nets at the front and the kooky designs everywhere. So when you get to the front you freeze and you shout to the guy with the Beard net that you and your friend just want like a dozen of their most popular donuts. Little did we know a dozen donuts is really like 2 dozen donuts since these are no ordinary donuts but huge mega donuts half the size of your face with cereal and cookie crumbs onto of them! You get the donuts and quickly leave to escape the pink and punk music. We sat outside and both ate one and a half donuts. They were delicious!! However, we didn't prepare for the donut-coma to come next. You eat the donuts then you need like a solid 30 mins before doing anything else cause these things will knock you out and make you feel like a full sleepy baby. We tried really hard to finish the donuts the next few days but had to share them with friends because it was too much. 

Overall, I probs wouldn't be back. It was great to check it out as someone who was visiting Portland for the first time. If you're visiting it seems like it's something you have to check out, just if you do go don't get bamboozled like I did and order a dozen...

They're ok. It's a tourist mecca. I take visiting friends there (if the line isn't wrapped around the building like a snake).

If you want novelty donuts with naughty names or weird toppings, this is your place. If you want just good, straight-ahead donuts (glazed, old-fashioned, maple bars, etc.) this might not be the place to go. The quality is highly variable in my experience, ranging from quite good to so stale that you wonder why they're still serving them.

There are better donuts in Portland-- Tonalli's on Alberta, Pip's on Fremont, and Coco in SW are all excellent. Even Heavenly is good if you stick to the basics. Check it out, but please be aware, oh lovely tourists, that there is much more to be had in the way of fried pastries in our fair town. By all means, grab a Portland Cream (very good, IMHO) from Voodoo and take a walk down the waterfront park. But also head out into the neighborhoods and try some other options.

First of all, the donuts aren't really that tasty. They are just donuts, and I've had better at lots of places. So, if you are going for the flavors, think again. However, if you are looking for an experience, it is a 5 star place. The prices are reasonable, the line is long, the decor, and scene are hilarious. A funny thing about writing this review, It started as a 1 star, moved up to 2 and settled at 3. Who knows, if I kept typing, it might move up to 4. But I stopped.

I read/heard all the hype about this place and saw this place on Diners, Drive-Ins and Dives so my wife and I decided to check it out since we were in the area.  Luckily, we did not have to deal with long lines since it was on a Tuesday afternoon.

We got the Portland Creme, Maple Bacon, and the Voodoo donut.  Honestly, I have no idea what the big hype was all about.  It tasted just like any other donuts I have tasted.  They all tasted like the way a donut should taste...very sweet.  To say that this is the "best donut shop ever" is definitely an overstatement.  However, at the same time, I can see why so many people flock to this place.  The funky/fun decor inside and various toppings on the donuts make this place pretty cool compared to others.

Its funky and very Portland.  It makes you feel super accomplished to have survived the line.  It is a great way to shock and surprise visiting coworkers with a box of unusual.  The donuts are okie dokie, but not really cravable.  We are glad the pink box is here, but as a local, I'll stick with some of the other delish options around town for a donut fix.

So sadly disappointed. Visiting Voodoo was going to be the highlight of my trip to Portland- it most definitely was not. The experience was a major thumbs down, starting from the moment we walked in. It was hot and muggy inside the shop and it smelled like a mix of donuts and armpit- super gross. The line wasn't long at all but took forever. The employees were busy with their own conversations and didn't acknowledge guests as they walked in. The donuts available at the time were causal donuts, nothing special like I've seen in Photos. We ordered our donuts and took them back to the hotel. They were totally simple nothing special at all.

Although Voodoo has unique donuts, they are a little overrated. The doughnut itself was not spectacular. I would suggest visitors check it out only if the line isn't too ridiculous. They really aren't work waiting more than 15 minutes for.
The people were nice.  The store was interesting to look at.  The doughnuts left more to be desired.  Reminded me of Dunkin Doughnuts with extra frosting and crunchy things.
Lots of choices. But I prefer Blue Star donuts which do not leave the oily taste in your mouth.

I was expecting this place to blow my mind. Seeing it on tv, reading rave reviews, i thought this place was going to change my life. It didn't. Got the old dirty bastard and strawberry lemonade. Typically i would have just ordered the one but the cashier was adamant i try the newly created strawberry lemonade. Lets start with the one i came for. 

Odb. Round glazed donut topped with oreo, peanut butter and chocolate. Dount was a bit soggy but with all those toppings, im not surprised. 

Strawberry lemonade. Now, i LOVE lemonade. That is my go to drink almost every time a place doesnt have orange fanta. This donut was sweetness to 11. No tartness, wth? Major disappointment.

So this place is just ok...

They have cool looking sh*t, but I could go to krispy cream and get a better tasting donut. 

Came here after the bars during my last visit line wasnt too long (20 min max wait), and when I stepped away for two seconds while my friends stayed in line, to take a call and came back, some douchebag tried telling me to go back to the end of the line, I flipped...dont remember too much of what my drunk ass said to dude but he got the point...

The counter girl was a b*tch and I clearly wasnt part of the hipster crowd with my LA style...

overall I liked how the sh*t looked but the taste was average...

Oh and worth mentioning, watch out for the tweekers or meth heads pan handling right outside, as well as all the creepers...

4 donuts almost 5 bucks...tasted like whatever...will not go back again...

Seriously, not even worth the review.  It's popular because it's hip.  It smells of bacon when you walk in.  None of the doughnuts looked appetizing and what evilness is there when and old fashion is glazed! IS THERE NO GOD!  

Honestly, I was going to give it 1 star to balance for all the bull ratings on here from all the hipster kids who think bacon donuts are the thing.  But in all reality, it's not horrible, service is fine, and there is a lot of space.  If you want a traditional type doughnut, don't go here.
Not sure what the hype and long line is about, they put interesting toppings, it doesn't taste much like anything different. Not worth the long line

Overhyped, of course. Still a perfectly okay doughnut, though.

Major gripe is with the cash-only policy. It certainly makes sense for smaller businesses that need to cut transaction costs. However, Voodoo does enough business to afford a card reader. This is pure pretentiousness.

Props for offering many vegan options, which I hear do not suck.

If you've never had one, you must. It's a right of passage whether you're a tourist or a local. And if there's not a line around the block,  come back when there is one! That's also part of the experience. And if you're not treated like an idiot by the staff, then that is a rare occurence indeed. But hey, people don't go to Voodoo for the sweet-as-pie staff. And if you do you'll be sorely disappointed. 

Now on to the goods. They make a decent donut here, and while I'm not huge on donuts I think theirs are pretty high up on my list. Not too greasy, fluffy dough. And they aren't famous for their weird toppings for nothin'. I'm partial to the cereal-topped varieties ( Captain My Captain and the Loop), but you may want to go for the bacon maple bar, voodoo doll, or the always a good time cock-n-balls. 

Of course you have to go here! Take in the sights and sounds of the seedier side of Portland and enjoy!

The line is WAYY too long for a donut that has cereal on it. On a weekend day you can expect to wait about 45 minutes if not more which isn't worth the effort unless your a tourist. The maple bacon donut tastes the best out of all the selections.

Sorry for being a hater but this place is not worth the hype.... 

We waited in line for about 30 minutes which is fine. I've waited in longer lines for food.... However, when you get inside there's only 3 cashiers and 3 registers... with a line that long why not have someone take orders while the other person rings. Would be much faster...
