On top of that their customer service sucks. The guy we ordered from was too busy singing along with the music to worry about guest service. Also instead of bagging or boxing our doughnuts, brought each one and tossed them on the counter or on top of each other. 

In terms of the doughnuts we ordered 1 bacon. maple bar, 1 old dirty bastard, 1 voodoo man and 1 mango tango. They're nothing special as far as doughnuts go. They taste like regular doughnuts ... maybe a bit sweeter. The voodoo man is only filled half way with the raspberry filling which left a bunch of dough left over. The mango tango was a weird combination of tart and sweet filling. The only thing that's special about their doughnuts is they're shaped nice. They also do not last very long, they start getting stale the next day. 

Not worth it. would rather eat krispy kreme

The donuts are interesting and as a commodity it's pretty funny. However, for the quality they aren't the best donuts I've had. I get that donuts are deep fried bread and sugar but mine have been to the extreme here.

In my opinion...I hate touristy things; Pats vs. Geno's, Modern Pastry or Mikes Pastry, Duckboat tours, Ben and Jerry Ice cream Factories...all of these having one unifying factor...they're actually kinda mediocre, but there's so much hype that not doing it when you're visiting the area that you are unofficially obligated to wait in line for something that's stands against all of my foodie natures.

So...for someone who doesn't eat donuts, I waited in line for 45 minutes at 10am, while harassed by ...not so talented street performers... to get a taste of donuts that do not inspire beyond their unique physical attributes. They tasted, at least to my simple tongue, the same as every dunkin' donut pastry that I've ever had. The only reason why this place didn't get 1 star is that their donuts are fairly cheap and not over priced, which they definitely could get away for. As a result, since Voodoo Doughnut is a Portland special and there are some unique flavors and shapes, it deserves 3 stars for recognition. But I strongly recommend Blue Star donut if you're actually into great tasting doughnuts.

Food: 2 stars
Price: 3 stars
Uniqueness: 3 stars
Doughnuts are good. But are they waiting in line for 45 minutes good? Methinks this is an impossible standard to meet.

Look, I love donuts. Who doesn't? That being said, no donut is worth waiting 2 hours in line for. I used to live in Portland and I've eaten here before, about half a decade ago, and remember just walking in and getting a donut. It was a good time had by all.

Now, there is just a crazy line constantly around the corner and it makes it no fun. I mean, it's just a donut. It should be fast, easy, and delicious. 4 star donuts with a 1 star wait and so we've leveled out at the 2 star area.

It's really too bad, because if this was my former self I would be giving it 4-5 stars.. but now.. the wait is just not worth it. It's really too bad.

I'm really sorry to say this but I was let down by my experience here.  I bought 3 different donuts and didn't think that they were better than any other donut shop in the Portland area!  Sure the combinations are off the wall -- but really, at $1.50 - 3.00 per donut, I'd rather get my plain raised donuts elsewhere.
Way over-rated.  The donuts with cereal on them always have STALE cereal.  Nothing here is worth waiting in the always present line.

This place obviously has a lot of hype, and well i honestly have to say that it's more hype than anything else.

They have some intense ideas and some nutty ideas, but really the execution is just pretty mediocre. The doughnuts themselves (crazy toppings aside) are really just average, in texture and taste. 

It's definitely something to check out at least once, because it is an experience. But even if i lived in Portland (i only visited while on a trip) I don't think I'd actually go here more than once except maybe to take out-of-towners to.

I don't usually like to give a single star for places; however, this establishment was a huge disappointment - particularly because my friend and I were treated poorly because of our ethnic origin.  After my experience, I feel that "Voodoo" stands for "Very Overtly Obvious Discrimination Of Other."

Doughnuts: They have a wide variety of interesting combinations ranging from sugar-rush-inducing cereal or candy toppings to your run-of-the-mill cream/jelly filled doughnuts . The taste of the doughnut itself is typical, nothing special - it's the toppings that make their doughnuts unique.  If you go, I would recommend the Bacon Maple Bar doughnut (there are two slices of real bacon). Overall, nothing to write home about, and certainly more hype than yumminess.

Ambiance: Located in a less... delectable part of the city, be prepared to see some establishments not suitable for young eyes.  It's a small location that serves its purpose.  There's a small small standing table along one of the walls where you can eat your doughnuts if you don't want to walk around them.

Service: Insulting. I had read that sometimes the servers can be terse, but my friend and I were treated differently because of the color of our skin.  Our encounter: My friend told the brunette woman behind the counter that this was our first time in Portland in hopes of hearing a little bit about the menu, but we received a stony stare.  I thought to myself "maybe she's having a long/bad day," and asked what were her favorites.  She pointed to a couple with lackluster effort, and my friend and I just ordered three doughnuts to try.  Our server then proceeded to give us our doughnuts in those little parchment paper slips.  I thought it was weird because other people had gotten little baggies, but maybe it's because we only ordered three. What I saw afterwards made my blood boil.  The two women who were behind us - who were Caucasian - were treated COMPLETELY differently.  They were chatted up (by the same server) with friendly smile and fanfare (and no, I don't think they were the server's friends), and while they only ordered two doughnuts, they received each one in a separate bag (without being asked).  When I went up to ask for a bag, I got an impatient look (there were no other customers) and a reluctant one bag.  While Voodoo probably doesn't need to care that much about customer service due to its large patronage, I would hope they would at least catch up to the 21st century and not practice discrimination.

Pricing: Reasonable.  Cash only.  

Hours: You can roll in at any time, day or night.
Sorry that PR trumps quality. Average doughnuts, bad service.

first of all this place is more about the hype then great doughnuts i was here 2 days ago and bought 4 dozen of donuts it cost almost $80  REALLY?  when i got home i let all my friends have some most said they have had better.. so why the hype? i think what draws people here is the great creativity they have in coming up with the different doughnut flavors  that part i give them a 5 star  the taste is just not there to meet the looks .. and that is why it gets a 2 star ... i would not go out of my way to go there again to go to a hipster trap

I was really excited to go to this place after years of seeing it on Instagram posts so when I knew I was visiting Portland, I made it a priority to go. It was a bit busy when I got there, but nothing too crazy. I went in the evening with my bf. The atmosphere of the place is what I expected it to be and it was pretty cool I have to say. The staff was very friendly as well. I do have to say though that this place is a bit over hyped, and maybe I over hyped it for myself. I ordered their signature voodoo doughnut. I have to say as someone who has a weird obsession with sweets, (I sometimes eat cake frosting straight out of the jar) that it was way too sweet compared to the doughnut places I've tried before. My bf got the guava colada doughnut which he also said was too sweet, but he did like the coconut topping on it. On our way back from Portland we did go back to try their other doughnuts and bring some home. From the others that we tried though, the apple fritter, chocolate coconut, old dirty bastard, and bacon maple doughnuts were the ones we liked the most.
This is a fun place to take out of towners, but there are better doughnuts in Portland.

I give the place about 3.5 star. A for effort though. I'm from St. Pete, Fl. One place in Pinellas park area called Frays is more fresh in my opinion. The golden graham cereal on top of donut wasn't too bad. The cereal was a little stale. The eclair was good. All random.

I'd say it's worth a try, just for their interesting flavours/choices. The only one I really would do more than once is the bacon maple.

If you're looking for an amazing doughnut, it's probably not here, as there are far better quality & better tasting ones. However, it's still worth at least one try for the experience, in my opinion.

It's one of those places 'you have to go' when you visit here but it's only because it's unique. The donuts are always old and dry. I think you can get lucky and score a fresh donut, so i've heard. It's certainly a fun experience but if you go, you're not going for the actual donut!

The employees have never been friendly but the doughnuts are a tasty novelty when I visit. Last nite was diff, it was like we were irritating and bothering her by being there our Voodoo Virgin asking about the product since the racks behind her were full and not in the case and hard to see since she's short. with an attitude of buy it and GTF Out!  The 3 gals I was with last night work for a huge charity and are very very polite, pleasant, cordial and are very likable from the moment you meet them.  To make a long story longer if you're attitude is bad and you cannot deal with even the easy customers you probably should be working the counter. Put her in the back washing dishes where she can frown, scoff and treat the dishes bad...

1 "Scar" -   Sour Employee Attitudes  
4  Stars - taste
5  Stars - creativity
Not worth the huge hype. Basic donut with yes, I will say interesting and creative toppings on it. However, not worth the long line for a grungy basic donut.

Honestly, I don't know what all the fuss is about?  
My husband, son and I were walking around Portland and found Voodoo doughnuts during our walk.  The wait in line was ONE HOUR which I would not even dare wait more than 10 minutes for doughnuts especially with our cute baby boy. 

My cousin and I decided to go super early on Sunday and we waited no longer than 2 minutes.  The doughnuts were OK really and I've had so much better in San Francisco.  

Definitely not worth the wait.
Not a bad doughnut! I just prefer blue star! But it's a good experience. If you have a craving at 3am, you know the place to go!!

Oooooh - good publicity doesn't make up for the fact that this place is nothing more than a donut shop that makes pretty donuts.

Skip the lines of selfie-taking tourists at the downtown location, head over to their Eastside location (Voodoo Too).  No lines there!

Any Portland trip must contain the obligatory pilgrimage to Voodoo Doughnuts. Where else will you find wonderful pieces of fried dough bedazzled with every topping that you can possibly imagine?

Did I even mention that it's so cheap? There's nothing stopping you unless you're dating Jenny Craig.
I love it that Voodoo is successful and has become a Portland icon, but seriously, the donuts are pretty average. Support your local baker....

Underwhelming. 

Dude at the counter who's "worked here for so many years" was rude and off-putting. 

Good tip: go before 10am and there no line!

Be warned, cash only!

I went to Voodoo Doughtnut while visiting Portland beause it seemed like the thing to do. I can understand why it is a Portland tradition -- where else can you get doughnuts with cereal and chocolate and peanut butter all over them, but frankly, I thought the doughnut was not good, and the toppings way way way too sweet -- to the point where my doughnut was almost inedible. I was surprised that in a city that I consider kind of earthy and health conscious, there weren't any doughnuts that used fresh fruits, whole wheat, etc. -- which I think I would have prefered. I also would have prefered a not stale base.

I will pretty much echo what Kim D. said a few days ago.  

Do I recommend tourists in Portland visit Voodoo?  Yes, but because it is a pretty cool experience, not because the doughnuts themselves are particularly remarkable.  It is worth it for the menu, the signs replete with sexual innuendo, and the rotating display of eclectic treats you get to choose from.  It is even more worth it if you visit at a time when you don't have to wait 30+ minutes to order.  Just by luck, I only had to wait about 5 minutes when I went during a mid-afternoon.

That being said, the doughnuts themselves really aren't that great.  For really, really good doughnuts in Portland, go to Blue Star.  Fewer choices, not quite as eclectic (although they also have a maple and bacon sometimes), but absolutely delicious.
A Portland institution. Go to the Eastside one to avoid the lines. I have barely ever experienced Voodoo in any form other than buckets of day olds, that is the best way to get them.

Sadly disappointed by Voodoo, but still worth a visit if you're coming from out of town just for the crazy colors and toppings that they have. As someone who doesn't have a major sweet tooth, I found all of the doughnuts from Voodoo to be overly sweet, and lacking any special flavors. We assumed the donuts were great due to all the people we saw leaving with filled boxes, but we soon realized that it was mostly because everything was so cheap (approx. $1.50-$2 each). 

To make your own Voodoo donut: buy a Krispy Kreme donut, sprinkle rice cripsies on top, and voila!
Tried quite a selection of donuts here. They're fine, and the names/flavors are creative, but really they're just slightly above average donuts.  Don't really see any reason to return.

It's been a few years since I first tried Voodoo, and it's not quite as good as I remember. 

I came here while visiting Portland a few weeks ago not because I particularly wanted a donut, but because I felt like I should get one since I was in Portland only for a few days. 

The line wasn't as long as it typically is; we waited about 20 minutes. We planned ahead and brought cash, and thank goodness we did, because the ATM inside was out of order. The poor folks in front of us waited all that time and couldn't even take cash out. A sign outside would have been nice. 

I had the Portland Cream and my husband had the Maple Bacon. He enjoyed the Maple Bacon although took about half the frosting off because it was so darn sweet. Mine was also sweet but not too sweet. I know they claim to make their donuts fresh each day, but mine was actually pretty stale under the frosting. 

We left feeling silly for going out of our way to get cash back at 711 and then waiting in line for these donuts that we didn't enjoy that much. I think it's a place everyone should go to once, but I will probably skip it next time I'm in town.
You're better off going to any supermarket and getting donuts there. These donuts are way too greasy and aren't very good

Not sure what all the hoopla was about.  Went on a Wednesday afternoon.  Four people in line ahead of me.  Great names for donuts, unique toppings, but I didn't find anything special about the raised dough or the cake dough.  Coffee (from Stumptown) was good to wash down all the sugar.

If you eat the Texas donut in 80 seconds it's free.

BTW: DOES NOT ACCEPT CREDIT CARDS.

I had to see what these donuts were all about. It's pretty small inside once you get in but there's 4 registers going if I recall correctly. Hard to decide until you got closer to see what was available if you are a newbie.

Definitely came here just because it's a must-try if you're visiting Portland. The line was out the door and wrapped when we came here on a Sunday night, but it wasn't unexpected. It moved pretty fast though so it wasn't bad to wait. We just got a plain glazed donut...I know, kind of boring, but the others seemed like a bit much. There are definitely a lot of different flavors and combos, but their glazed one seemed the best to us at the time. It was alright at best. Not very fresh and kind of blah...right away I thought to myself "I'd rather have a Krispy Kreme." If you want to get a fancier donut though, then I recommend coming here just for the experience. Heir decor is super interesting and fun to look at while you wait in line inside so that's a plus.

I'm normally good at weeding out tourist traps but respected sources said I'd like it. Nope. Short line (5 man strong). Ordered two. Took a bite. Threw it out. Took a bite. Threw it out. 

Excessive? Mean? No, I'm being honest. It was dry, hard and dense and not worth another bite. I'm somewhat self-conscious saying this because I'm sure there are slew of people ready to fight me on this. After all, on my way out of the city I saw about 20 people carrying pink boxes.

Voodoo and their trademark box and what's inside is like buying a jar of maple syrup at the airport when visiting Canada. Don't do it. Ever.

Alright. I get that it's super trendy and some kind of tourist mecca type of spot. But...let's get over it...it's a friggin' donut people! Some of their creations are pretty tasty but more than anything I give it 3 stars because my kids find it incredibly cool that I can take them there and get a donut literally as big as my head. I imagine that as my children get older this place will lose some of it's appeal and that's OK with me because the lines get stupid stupid long.

This was our first stop in Portland. At 6 am, my group found cold donuts to be absurd and gross. We felt like we were being handed yesterday's left-overs. I guess the novelty is the variety of toppings and controversial forms, which could be easily recreated in one's home. Give me a hot Krispy Kreme any day!

Voodoo Donut is itself an "experience" you must for sure try at some point, but after that, it just lacks.  There are three things in particular that get me about these donuts

1. They are a sugary nightmare or a sugary dream depending on how you see it.  Most of the donuts are overly sweet.  While unique and often tasty, the sheer amount of sugar can send anyone's sugar levels off the chart.

2. They do not accept debit/credit cards.  I get it, you pay a transaction fee as a business everytime someone swipes their card, but by not accepting cards you basically force the poor out of towner who has never been to your shop to pay an ATM fee so they can try your donuts.  Thats bad business in my opinion.  There are great solutions like Square that charge 2.75% per swipe.  So that $3 that your customer just bought with their credit card, you lost 8 cents.  Where with your ATM, if you get half the fees back that it charges the customer, you just made an additional $1.25 on that $3 donut.  Again bad business.

3.  To go along with the extra money that you are extracting from customers who do not bring cash, the donuts here are not cheap.  If you try to chose your own dozen, expect to pay at least $20.

So all in all, try it once for the experience, but just make sure you bring cash.
Fun for tourists to visit, I guess. Not really a place I'd want to wait in line at. The donuts are okay.

Wow! Talk about a sugar high. Everything has a lot of frosting. The maple long John with bacon on top is unique & flavorful. I think this place is over rated due to all the sugar. Kids may enjoy the Captain Krunch raised donut.

Try to catch at off hours - people go a little nuts for this place. We went mid-day, mid-week, in the winter and there was still a line out the door. It moved pretty fast, but still. Wow.

We steered clear of the novelty doughnuts, instead opting for two massive apple fritters and a maple bar. Very satisfying and the prices were reasonable. Our choices were promptly confirmed when chatting with other customers in the cute alley courtyard - they wished they had ordered more conservatively as they were not happy with their doughnuts.

Worth a stop to gawk and check off your list. Just go for the ol' reliables.
Way overpriced for mediocre doughnuts. Nothing but hyped. We are not going to return for sure. Don't waste your time and money.

I love that they have vegan options, but they only take cash, which is ridiculous. Also, the music was up WAY too loud. I thought I was going to have a seizure. Still, great variety and I will take my tourist friends here, if they want to go. I will probably never go on my own accord, though.

Donuts are ok. But NOT worth waiting for in line.  The lines get crazy here, and I get it...it is a touristy spot and all...but they are not that great.  Besides, I already get hassled enough by homeless people, I don't need them hassling me the whole time I am in line. Lol.

Cash only! Don't forget to bring some!

I discovered that much of the hype surrounding Voodoo doughnuts is based on their creativity more than anything else.  As far as quality and taste goes, their donuts are not a whole lot better than what you would find at most of your other neighborhood doughnut shops. Other "boutique" doughnut places such as Dynamo Donuts in San Francisco are a leg up in terms of taste.  But the doughnuts here are an absolute visual feast.  Take for example, a doughnut that Food Network did not mention in DDD - the Cock n Balls doughnut.  

If you easily get offended by things that are sexual in nature please do not read any further as I am going to describe the best way to eat this doughnut.  If you easily get turned on by things that are sexual in nature, please remember that I am only talking about eating a particular doughnut and nothing else should be construed concerning my sexual orientation, occupation, or what I would do for crack.

The first thing that you will notice with the aforementioned doughnut is that it is a rather large and unwieldy monstrosity. It really requires that you handle with both hands otherwise you will just have a mess ending up all over your face.  If you are into that, then you may proceed to do so by all means.  Carefully cradle it by the base and start with the elongated portion and taste the chocolatey goodness.  This way you can start off light.  As you get toward the base of the doughnut, you will notice a shift in the weight distribution - this is because you have already gone through about a good 8 inches and what you are left with is the portion that is the true reward - the cream filling. You need to be extra careful here since just chomping for the cream will have it squirting out everywhere.  If you don't get that initial portion, don't worry, just give the base a light squeeze and you will eventually have some of that tasty filling in your mouth.  Then as your confidence builds, you can continue to eat the rest, all the while, being careful not to let all of the cream out.  If you just can't wait to get to the cream portion, then go straight for the base.  Ultimately, you will then be filled with ecstasy or guilt (depending on your upbringing) at the realization that you ate the equivalent of two doughnuts - a chocolate bar and a chocolate covered eclair!  Of course, you can always share and even eat the thing simultaneously.

As far as the other doughnuts were concerned, I thought that the Oreo doughnut was the next best as the glaze tasted just like the cream filling of the Oreo, and had crushed Oreos all over.  I found their fritter type doughnuts a bit too greasy and heavy.  The maple bar with bacon is decent, but the large strips of bacon made it a bit unwieldy and would have been better if they were cut into smaller pieces. So go here for pure entertainment and curiosity value and you will not be disappointed.

What we had:

Him: Maple Bacon Doughnut, "Captain my Captain," [Captain Crunch, vanilla frosting,] and I think, "Memphis Mafia," [basically ginormous thing, covered in all manner of chocolate chips, peanut butter, nuts, etc...]

Me: Maple Bacon Doughnut, "Old Dirty Bastard," [chocolate frosting, Oreos, and peanut butter,] and a plain glazed old fashioned cake doughnut.

Plus milks all around. And no we did not eat all of that in one sitting.

Love: 
* The doughnuts, all of mine were genuinely great doughnuts. I don't even like raised doughnuts. 
*The staff, we had a genuinely friendly person help us, asked if we'd been there before, steered us in the right direction, helped us very quickly, but without rushing us.

Not so love:
* There is ALWAYS a line.
* You have to stand outside in the line.
* We felt lucky we had only a 40 minute wait.

So why 3 stars? This is not a place I would spend 40+ minutes waiting for very often. But if you ever think to yourself, I'd like a doughnut in about an hour, and I just feel like standing around for the same amount time. This is a really great place to go! Plus you should try an icon like this at least once.
The line was the 1st turn off. Cash only was the 2nd. The ridiculous price for a mediocre fried gut bomb was the final.

The bacon donut was great. But do not come here at night the neighborhood gets real shady quick past 7. Their is a lot of bums and junkies around the block. Besides that the place did have a lot of selection

Long, long lines since VooDoo took over the Berbati's Pan space and became a tourist attraction.  But if you're willing to wait in line, get a Miami Viceberry donut to soak up your drinks before heading to the next spot.

Just disappointing. If this were in any other city, I would give it 2 stars, but this is PORTLAND. The new rising star of american cuisine! Unfortunately, Voodoo was just hilariously named doughnuts, with ingredients that had my hopes high. The taste was genuinely disappointing. We gave our remaining donuts to a homeless person a few blocks away...sorry portland, I loved your food. I was let down by your donuts.

really? Waiting in a line around the corner for a donut with fruit loops on top? I don't get the frenzy about this place. I also have met a few former employees and they had NOTHING good to say about management and their experience as a donut whore.  
oh year, if you buy a dozen I hear they pick them out... allergic to coconut... too damn bad

Cash only. I paid with a $100 bill. Was shorted $5 when the smug hipster chick gave my change. She even counted one of the 5s twice! It was NOT an honest mistake. That's so SHADY. I even tipped! Booooo! C'mon Voodoo! 
Ok. Must admit...The donuts were very good. We waited for 30 minutes in line, which is CRAZY unless you really, really like donuts. We loved the funky vibe. Loved the donuts. 

Count your change!  Be aware!

Bad customer service, but pretty good donuts. Blue Star has wayyyy better customer service. I'm from Seattle and Mighty-Os will
Always been my favorite.

Doughnuts with a gimmick. I like their branding but the doughnuts are just okay. They are more dense, cakey than most doughnuts you'll encounter and the frosting is usually very sweet and gluey. Nothing delicate or subtle here.

average doughnuts. 
a definite tourist trap. up to a 4 hour wait for doughnuts. which is ridiculous. a cool 1 time thing, but you're better off with krispy kreme

This was probably the most hectic place I've ever been to. I would find out what time is the least busiest because when the employees are busy and stressed out, they're mean. It's a very cute shop with hilariously named donuts and would probably be more enjoyable if you go when they're not as busy.

I don't understand the hype. Line was way too long for a donut. We tried 3 different kinds and all the toppings were stale (especially the fruit loops one). The donut itself isn't that great. tasted kind of dry to me.

This made me miss Timmie's Honey Dipped and Strawberry filled. 

I would bring a friend here to take pictures, but not line up for their donuts.

Good , but kinda hypie. 
The staff is super trendy Portland folk and almost kinda stuck up- ish.... Just over all not so impressed, plus, they need to offer more vegan and GF options, or do they?! Maybe I just won't go to them for my vegan pastry desires with their lack luster staff and SO many great other pastry and treat shops to go to in Portland. 
Overall I think the majority of people go to voodoo doughnuts because it's trendy.

We queued up on a Saturday for a good 15min (nothing too ridiculous) for our first taste of voodoo donuts. It has a festively decorated interior, with three rotating display cases showcasing their selection of donuty goodness, all topped off with friendly staff behind the counter. So far so good. We ordered the voodoo and pothole with much anticipation. While the donuts were obviously fresh, the raspberry jelly filling in the voodoo donut was awkwardly gelatinous and cloyingly sweet. I really couldn't taste anything else. The cream filling in the pothole donut had the jiggle and texture of generic middle school lunch vanilla pudding. The crunch of the Oreo on top was great, but aside from that nothing short of ordinary. I hate to say it but Psycho Donuts, an obvious mimicry of Voodoo, is significantly more memorable.

This place has contributed to my weight gained so it deserves 1 star.  If you are on a diet or have to watch your blood sugar, please stay away from this place. Donuts were overrated here, just loaded with sugars! I only came here because of my so called relatives were visiting from Boston, they did leave with new clothing due to weight gain from eating too much doughnuts.

I've found better donuts in a box on a grocery store shelf.  Voodoo is great at selling kitch and snark and sexual innuendo.  But the actual donuts?  Overhyped, often stale, and way more about "shocking" combinations than actual good taste.  Save the times you'll wait in line and go to Heavenly Donuts or Tonallis.

I would say that Voodoo is overrated. Don't get wrong, the shop and the environment is cool looking, but with taste it was okay. The doughnuts looked really cool but I thought the cream and jelly could have been better. It's a nice spot to say you have been. I also bought a cool mug.
tourist trap waste of time if you ask me. people! they are doughnuts!
Stale. That's the best word to describe every doughnut I've ever gotten from this location.

I don't get it? Why does everyone love this place?? The doughnuts are cute but the flavor is grocery store quality!! Hello? Just because it comes in a pink box doesn't make it good.. Get out of that ridiculous line and go find a really good doughnut when you want one in Portland there are at least 4 other shops that really rock your
Craving for fried dough and sugar;)

I look around at the reviews and it seems as if most are right on. This is more for people like me passing through who have heard about this place on the Food Network. Who is crazy enough to wait in the sun outside for 45 minutes just to get some donuts? This guy did. They are not much more spectacular then your average donut shop. it's more for the crazy tourists.

We came on a Sunday night and the line only took about 5-10 minutes. The only thing good about this place was the marketing. I liked the way they decided to decorate their donuts to portray taboo things, such as cock and balls, but it was nothing fancy. A 5 year old could've helped with the icing and decorations. We ordered the voodoo doll just for the sake of trying this place out and it was too sweet - I got a toothache from one bite. 

If you want good tasty donuts, Blue Star Donuts is the place to go. But if taboo is your lifestyle, then try this place out. I heard they do weddings here...

So.. I don't really get it? What's with all the hype? I've read and heard about Voodoo Donuts for YEARS so I was really excited to finally have the opportunity to try it out. Surprisingly the line was shorter around 1am on a Saturday night compared to noon or any time in the afternoon, so I was thankful for that. We waited for about 30 minutes and once you get through the front doors the place is hoppin! Pretty fun environment, funky decor and a long menu to drool over. They have the craziest toppings, different types of cereal, cookies, bacon.. we ordered the voodoo dozen where your cashier picks random donuts for you - we kinda felt jipped because he gave us some of the boring ones.. we asked for the maple bacon and ended up with a maple bar, but minus the bacon. bummer!!!! The donuts were alright, but really... i just don't get the hype? Go to the local grocery and get any type of donut, a box of cereal and there you have your very own voodoo donut. 

Tourist trap for sure.

One star because you are a tourist attraction and take cash only.  Hey VooDoo donuts...1950 wants their method of payments back...

I'm a small business too and I take credit cards...it's not that hard to set up a merchant account.

Get with the times...

I was told this is on the list of places you must go when visiting Portland. The donuts were very tasty but the staff was pretty unfriendly. Felt like they were too cool to be friendly, which is pretty ridiculous for a donut shop employee.

I visited here as a tourist and for the wait the donuts are literally just MEH. REALLY sugary sticky sweet and nothing that exciting. Go to DD if you want a donut of this quality. If you want REALLY good donuts hit up Blue Star!

If you're looking for quality donuts and a classic donut shop setup,this may not be right for you- but if you're looking for quirky donuts and an eclectic atmosphere full of aesthetic oddities,VooDoo donuts may be worth the trip. The lines are usually fairly lengthy,though the inside of the shop is compact and a bit chaotic given the cramped space. The menu is pretty simplistic,with a broad range of donut types for customers to choose from. The cream filled donuts are worthy of your tastebuds and time,and there's a vegan donut section of the menu as well. However fascinating and quirky the shop itself may be,the donuts are just average at best. I've definitely had better,given the wait and the not-so-friendly staff. There is outdoor seating,complete with your local Portland homeless and pigeons begging for scraps. It's an interesting visit,however touristy,not necessarily a Portland gem.

So brand new to Portland and here's my take....
Voodoo Donuts. Awesome, you get to watch weird people as you watch in line and yeah, its smells pretty damn good and its open 24/7. Overall if you want crazy creative Portland feel vibe with interesting donut concoctions that are probably a 3 out of 5 on the taste scale that kinda taste stale (not like 7/11 stale, but close....) I'd wait 5-10 minutes if i'm craving for a donut but I wouldnt wait more then 15. 
For better tasting, more classic, fresh donuts, I'd go to Blue Star which is about a 4.5 out of 5. Downfall with Blue star is their hours but...I've never had to wait more then 5 minutes...lol. So all and all, it really does depend on what kinda donuts you're looking for.
Don't go here unless you're a tourist looking to get your mouth cut on sugary cereal. This isn't even on my top ten list for donuts in Portland.

Voodoo Doughnuts is known for their trendy, out of the norm, adult version donuts. It's a small donut shop decorated with voodoo décor, sexy chandelier, and lots of pink. It's a weird mixture. However, their line is always extremely long. Might need to go earlier in the day. I have tried almost every donut there. It's fun to try out their variety donuts that comes in pink boxes. In my honest opinion, I feel like their donuts are more on the way sweeter side for me. It's worth to try it at least once.

Long lines, poor service, and the donuts are MAYBE half as good as they used to be.
Ever since Anthony Bourdain (Food Critic) featured Voodoo on his show the place has been SWAMPED.
This was once one of Portland's many unique facets, but, now it's a kitschy, overrun, tourist stopover.
It's almost impossible to get a donut without an hour long wait.

5 years ago the place was run by an eclectic combination of young punk-rockers and (genuine) Portlandians who knew the neighborhood and the characters that made it what it was.
One of the last times I was there I went in for a donut one night (right before close) a few days before Christmas. The kids behind the counter were bagging up several large bags of donuts. I asked what it was for and they said they were extras. So, they were going to pass them out to the homeless around the neighborhood.
I ended up helping.
I gave my bag to a woman sleeping beneath the Burnside bridge with her husband.
I don't think I will ever forget that Christmas or those two kids.

The next time my friends and I went in it took us 35 minutes to get a couple of donuts and some coffee. The obnoxious hipster girl behind the counter was curt, pointlessly rude, and I swore I would never go back.

This place was cool 5 years ago.
It's not 5 years ago anymore, and this isn't Voodoo.
They made a name for themselves. It's Starbucks now.
Total fun, but the donuts are not actually that good.  It is more of a great experience- even waiting in line is fun.

Waited in line for over half an hour and had part of the Portland Cream (Bavarian Cream), O Captain My Captain (Captain Crunch topping), and the Memphis Mafia (fritter with peanut butter and chocolate all over). While the ideas were all somewhat cool and the variety interesting, none of them seemed particularly tasty or noteworthy other than that I had never had Captain Crunch on a donut. I would much rather visit Doughnut Plant or Dough for just as inspired donuts in flavor but with far better execution and taste.

Let's be perfectly clear about what these donuts are, lacking all hyperbole: these are grocery store-quality donuts covered in stale cereal and/or cardboard-y bacon and/or filled with caustic syrup-y jellies.

There are so many great donuts to eat in this city. It's one of the great tragedies of human pleasure that hundreds of thousands of hours every year are wasted standing in line for some of the most mediocre, undeservedly-trendy food that can be bought ... when you could wait a minute or two at Blue Star for a creme brulee or at Pip's for some fresh-fried donut holes, legitimately great pastries. Walking by Voodoo and seeing that line of people who just want to be able to say they held a pink box is like seeing a line of people waiting an hour to buy Folger's  with a Coava next door, or seeing movie stars waiting in line to hug a wet dog when they could be at home making love to their beautiful spouses. It is deeply, genuinely, bewilderingly sad. I pray for the day when holding a pink box is a mark of disgrace and dishonor rather than the repulsive rite of initiation it is today.

Ahh..whose donuts reign supreme?  I actually braved the lines at Voodoo at 7am on a Sunday only to return to catch another line at Blue Star at 8am.  I got four donuts from each so I can compare!

I think just based on sheer donut quality, I'm giving Blue Star the edge.  However, I found plenty to like about Voodoo too with their creative selections, cool store design and decorations, and yes the fact that they seem to open 24/7.  Listed below are my faves from the four I picked, from high to low:

1. No-Name: They tied this donut to that Man of Bravos (Jaqen H'ghar) from Game of Thrones and it was my fave.  Raised donut with chocolate, PB, and rice crispies for crunch. 5 stars.

2. Portland Creme: Supposedly Portland's official donut and its a chocolate layered, Bavarian Creme donut with a soft and light cake.  I like it better than Dunkin's Boston Creme Pie. The wife ended up eating most of it.

3. Mexican Hot Chocolate: The cake was a bit heavier and denser than expected, and man that cayenne pepper really puts a number on your lips!

4. The Champ: Decorated like a baseball, it is a lemon-glaze donut filled with cherry filling. Guess it was too much to expect fresh cherries or a compote at least to add some texture.  Sweet and not too bad.

Overpriced average doughnut....  The place is cool and worth a visit, but the fritters (the ones we like the best) are now a little greasy and not as flavorful as they once were.  I think they have slipped a little in my opinion.

If you're trying to get doughnuts and diabetes in the same day, then look no further than Voodoo Doughnut. A Portland landmark, tourist initiation site, and young homeless person hotspot, every doughnut here is coated and/or decorated with enough sugar and calories to nuke your insulin levels, and make your heart stop working for at least one minute. But make no mistake. Waiting in this long ass line may psychologically trick you into buying more than you should. I mean, you wouldn't wait 30-45 minutes in line to buy less than six, would you? It wouldn't be worth the wait then.

Honestly though, they're an okay treat, but I don't think the hype meets the reality as much. They're just gimmicky doughnuts- really nothing that special. I hardly see any major difference between these doughnuts and any other basic doughnut place. Then again, I just don't value doughnuts as much as the next person. 

Cue the stupid puns. Oh, and this place is CASH ONLY, so doughnut say I didn't warn you.

I love a good doughnut, but I don't know what makes this place so special?  Is it because it's near nudie places?  Not very cool to take a kid here. It's in a fairly seedy area with what appears to be a lot of drug dealing.

The place looks rather grungy and unclean.

The doughnuts don't seem that spectacular, unless you think a couple shapes and fright colors and uninspired toppings make it special. Placing Cap'n Crunch M&M's and Fruit Loops isn't revolutionary or even creative.  There are maybe three or four which could be considered "interesting".  

To be honest, I've tasted better, and healthier. I am concerned about the lack of cleanliness.  To me, they fall far short of the hype.  Though my wife loves them, I was underwhelmed and a little grossed out by the store condition and drunks/druggies loitering outside.

Maybe I'm too much of a doughnut snob. That must be it.

I just relocated to Portland and found Voodoo donuts on a "things to do" website. Normally, I'm not one to follow the masses unless I know and trust the source. But since my tech guy wanted to meet there, I thought I'd go ahead and sample their sweet delights.

Sorry to say I was so disappointed in my Bavarian cream filled/chocolate iced donut. I had to eat over a third of my donut before I reached any of the creamy filling and found nothing particularly special in the dough itself. Don't get me wrong, the donut was good, but not spectacular as all the reviews led me to believe. Tang sprinkled donughts? Donuts topped with stale looking fruit loops? Thick, hard looking bacon slapped on maple bars? One bite and off comes the bacon. Why not dice the right bite-size bacon pieces and top the maple bar so we can enjoy bacon with every bite and bake some right into the dough? And nothing looked fresh. I felt like I walked in on "baked" teenagers, mashing bits of dough together and concocting their idea of great munchie treats... (I'll take a joint with my donut thank you). 

What Voodoo DOES right is their marketing and branding strategies! And their logo isn't even that great yet the masses can't get enough of their over priced merchandise. The best part is how even my not-so-great review will only contribute to their internet and social media presence... GENIUS!

All hype and nothing more. 

We went against a former Portlander's objections and still proceeded to check Voodoo out to only regret the decision later. 

Even with the cute shapes and over-the-top toppings, it was mediocre at best. I'm sad we wasted our time in line and money here instead of going somewhere else, like *ahem* Blue Star..

I was visiting Portland and never really intended to try Voodoo Doughnut due to the reviews. However, someone had shared a dozen doughnuts so I gave it a try. It was just OK, as many previous reviewers had stated. There was a large line almost every time I passed this place. I wouldn't be willing to wait very long for these doughnuts. The only time I would buy them is if there wasn't a wait. There is another place in the area that is much better.
I know Portland is weird and Voodoo Doughnut by far has the weirdest sweet fried dough that I've eaten. I just can't get into it. The doughnuts aren't very good despite it being different.

I understand that this place is an institution. I've been here a couple times and it's always been a letdown. I've had much better doughnuts for much less wait. I love doughnuts and if you do too, I'd advise you to pass on these unless you're going there simply because it's an authentic Portland thing to do.
The line is too long. Nothing really unique about the donuts to out weight the waiting factor.

The atmosphere is quirky and fun. The donuts are good, not great. I was a little disappointed that they didn't knock my socks off. I thought it would be fun to get the cock and balls donut, but it only comes with the chocolate frosting. If they had maple also, I'd be all over it lol. 
Having homeless watch you eat and ask for money isn't the greatest thing to experience.

I think I ordered a triple chocolate penetration (a chocolate donut, with chocolate frosting and coco puffs)... was it worth the 40 minute wait? Definitely not. Not sure if it was because I left the donut out overnight, but I felt that I could easily buy a chocolate donut from any donut shop and just put coco puffs on top. 

I really wish they had a menu outside or something, because I felt so rushed when we got to the front that I just chose anything with CHOCOLATE in the name. Yes, their donuts do look pretty darn cool but if you don't know what you're ordering you could end up with just a plain regular looking donut...

Perhaps I had somewhat unreasonable expectations after reading the reviews, and although the donuts looks really cool they don't particularly taste that great.  It was fun to try it once, but I probably wouldn't bother waiting in the long line again.

What's with all the hype? The donuts are interesting but the taste is not special or anything to rave about. We concluded that the allure is due to the Pink box, the catchy name, and smart advertising.


The food: we ordered the Voodoo Donut, Apple Fritter, and Mango Tango. Everyone raves about the classic voodoo donut or maple bacon but if there was anything to rave about it would have to be MANGO TANGO. The flavors of voodoo donut are all around us down to gas stations and maple bacon bars are sold everywhere. The voodoo donut was way too sweet. It was slathered with chocolate and inside was stuffed with jelly. It was so overpowering. The apple fritter was disgusting. One bite and some kind of liquid oozed out of it. Is it supposed to do that? Was that grease or apple sauce? Overall, we would only go back for the Mango Tango

The service: it was average. The servers didn't look enthusiastic or friendly. We were in the shop and out.

Voodoo is a fun place to bring friends from out of town who are in it for the novelty factor, but as far as the taste factor goes, it's reeeeally not worth it. It's not bad, but it's also not great, and most certainly not worth queueing up for if you've been there before. Pretty generic, honestly, other than (obviously) the funkiness of the combinations and appearances. There are so many better quality doughnuts around town, why would anybody opt to come here instead? It's a fun, quirky place to bring first-time tourists or new transplants, or even bring a box to a study group or a work meeting, but it's not somewhere most locals will go to just because they actually want to eat it.
Staff is snippy, lines are too long (open some extra registers maybe?), doesn't take credit cards.  Product is amusing, but mediocre in quality.

I visited Voodoo this past spring. It is what it is, but you should stop in  while you're in Portland if you have time. Make sure to bring cash, as they don't accept cards.

I think that voodoo is popular because of the  unique names and ingredients in/on the doughnuts.  Every one says "try the maple bacon bar" and I agree. If you're patient, you can even customize your donuts.  

During the weekends the lines can get crazy, so try to go on a weekday or in the AM because It's not like Dunks which is always packed in the early morning for people headed to school or work.
Gross.  Expensive.  Not worth the hype.  Honestly Krispy Kreme makes a much better doughnut.  You're paying for hipster atmosphere in a tourist destination at Voodoo.  Nothing more.

I can honestly say that 'It is just a donut!'. True, they are better then krispy kreme, but they are just a donut as well. Quality is a little higher then kripsy kreme but, all-in-all, it is still just a donut. There are other shops (Heavenly Donuts, Sesame Donuts) that have better taste and quality. Plus, you don't have to wait outside in a line for as long as an hour (who DOES that... for a donut?).

I'm always skeptical about tourist traps when I travel because it's hit or miss. Voodoo Doughnuts was a disappointing, overrated miss. Boo. I love donuts, but this just wasn't worth waiting in line for... Even to visit for the sake of saying that I did. My boyfriend and I waited around 20-25 minutes to get inside. At least the weather was relatively nice.

None of the donuts in the glass window seemed appealing, but I got one anyways. I selected the iconic voodoo doll, but there was something off about it... The nasty icing, jelly filling, or the soggy pretzel stabbing the donut. I had an upset stomach afterwards, which made for an unhappy last day in Portland. They have some weird donuts, but I guess that's what they're known for.

I do like that there's benches to sit on right outside, but they're not the cleanest, especially with all the beggars and homeless people around. Overall this was my least favorite Portland experience and definitely not one I would recommend to anyone creating their bucket list of eateries to explore here.

Ok so I have not written a review on this place yet, so here we go. The donuts taste just the same as the donuts you would get at safeway, nothing special. They do have unique donuts, but always seem to be out of apple fritters. They are open 24/7 so if you have a sweet tooth after a night of partying down town, check it out.

It was a great experience coming here but the line can be very long. We went at a non busy time (after 10pm) and didn't have to wait. We got an apple fritter, blueberry cake, voodoo doll and grape ape. You can't go wrong, there are a ton of options including vegan, etc. Is it touristy, yes. But it's a cool experience and the doughnuts are good.

The first time I went to Voodoo, I was not impressed. All of our donuts were completely stale! I've decided to go back multiple times and the donuts have never been stale again. I general seem to go at a good hour where the line isn't wrapped around the corner (usually bar hopping at 12 am and need a donut for my drunk belly). My favorite is the Grape Ape. Its got some sweet and sour sugar on it that makes your tongue tingle! Must try! I once saw a girl get a huge bucket of donuts.. not sure how much she payed but seemed like a good deal for a ridiculous amount of donuts. I will go back again, but do prefer Blue Star! They never let me down!
Not sure it's really worth the wait, but the donuts are cute and the staff are really friendly.  The unique flavors sound better than they taste.  Many of them were too sweet for my taste.
Cool doughnuts, definitely a must-try on your first trip to Portland. But, honestly other than cool designs I don't think the doughnut itself is enough to bring you back.

My sister brought over some Voodoo donuts that her friend picked up. When we were just about to dig in, we saw Voodoo Donuts on "Man versus Food." What a coincidence. At least I know what the owner looks like.

I had been craving a donut for a long time so this was a nice retreat. The donuts were a Mango Tango and a Memphis Mafia. I was surprised to find that these donuts were still really fresh even all the way from Portland.

The Mango Tango is a raised yeast donut so it's really fluffy. The insides are filled with mango jelly while the top is frosted with white vanilla frosting and another layer of orange frosting. It kinda looks like a Krispy Kreme donut with an orange toupee. When I first tried the donut I thought it was apricot filling. I was quite surprised that it was supposed to be mango. I would bypass the purchase of this donut unless you're a big fan of sweets. The insides feel like a huge glob of corn syrup or simple syrup with artificial flavorings. The dough itself is good but I don't think it needed vanilla frosting on top. It's more like decoration than additional deliciousness. The insides are sweet enough.


The Memphis Mafia, according Voodoo Donut's website is "Fried dough with banana chunks and cinnamon sugar covered in a glaze with chocolate frosting, peanut butter, peanuts and chocolate chips on top!" I'm pretty surprised at how many ingredients there are because I only tasted a few of them. Maybe because the donut suffers from the same problem as the Mango Tango? TOO SWEET. I couldn't taste the peanut butter, cinnamon, peanuts, chocolate chips, or cinnamon sugar. I did however like this donut a lot more than the Mango Tango. Since the dough is fried and glazed it has a crunchy shell while the dough still has a softness to it. The banana is a savior although there is not enough of it.

If your taste buds are maximized to 100% sweetness, it's really difficult to taste anything else. Adding more is actually getting less. The quality of the donuts and ingenuity at Voodoo Doughnut is awesome; still, the execution and balance of flavors is hardly anywhere near impressive. Please balance those flavors and control the sweetness.
You should try it at least once because of it being an icon and all but there are far better ma and pa doughnut shops that could use the money. I recommend the bacon maple bar!

Fun and novel the first time. Quality and taste certainly don't warrant a return. There's much better doughnuts to be had. Especially avoid the downtown location due to the presence of aggressive homeless people who hang around there specifically because Voodoo only accepts cash.

Sorry, for all the hype and the long line, big disappointment.  I'd rather go to Krispy Kreme.  Voodoo have donuts that are unique because they combine different things together, but the donut itself is so dense.   I prefer my donuts light and fluffy.    If you like unique flavors, which I have no problems with, this is the place for you, but not for me.  Some of the donuts are so sweet, you might as well eat sugar straight up.  Not worth the price or the wait.
Its good. Its not worth standing in line in the rain for hours but I would say, this is a PDX staple, and if you are visiting I can see the nostalgia of checking this place out.

I was in the area and of course, watching the Food Network, had to give this place a shot. Glad we only got a couple donuts because they really weren't that special . They come in crazy shapes and stuff but the flavor is pretty standard as any other donut shop across the nation. 

Glad I crossed this place off the list. Probably will never return to be honest.

It's worth visiting once for the novelty (phallic shaped donut, anyone?), but I wouldn't go back.  The doughnuts themselves were okay, maybe even leaning towards the stale end, but it was the snotty attitude I got from one of the staff that really turned me off to this place.

I do appreciate that they sell a decent variety of vegan doughnuts (my favorite happened to be the chocolate glazed, topped with oreos and drizzled with PB, hotel microwaved, to boot!).  Otherwise, I'll be going to Sweet Pea Bakery next time for my sweets...and suggest you do, too.

This is a one-time stop for when guests are in town. Wait in line for 30 minutes to order punny-named donuts. These are not gourmet donuts. These are not even better tasting donuts than Safeway (imo). But go ride the ride and then you    never have to come back again.

I saw the funniest thing at the location in downtown. This happy family is sitting outside--indulging in their long awaited treat..the father took one bite and as he is holding his beloved doughnut--a random street kid comes up, takes it straight out of his hand,and eats in front of his face...and walks away. I was weak. 

If you want to wait 2 hours for a regular ass doughnut-go for it. Their donuts are more about how they look rather than how they taste. I'll stick to Krispy Kreme.

I don't get it.  I'm not sure how these are popular,  maybe just the novelty of them? ? They are pretty spectacular. .. to photograph.  Not to eat.  The cereal on top was so stale and the doughnut tasted like 2 days old. We tried a variety. The best of the worst was the Voodoo guy with raspberry filling but the filing is the only good part and is only in the belly portion. Lots of homeless people outside asking for money, since it's a cash only place. If you're in the mood for a real treat I recommend Blue Star Donuts,  hot, fresh and delicious or Salt and Straw Ice cream unique flavors and homemade waffle cones!
They have fun and funny donuts! I don't think they're that yum, but it's a must visit place whenever I have people in from out of town! They also have vegan donuts, which is super cool!
They have OK doughnuts. Nothing to write home about. I'm not a fan of the kookie flavors. It would be nice to get a normal Boston Creme that's neither a cock or a ball.

PURE HYPE!  Seriously!  And NOT worth it.

We waited in a line that was at least 50+ people deep.  The line moved fast because they have a lot of workers.

Service is beyond rude.  When it came our turn, the tall, surly bearded guy basically bit our heads off.  It was our first (and last) time, once you see the donuts it can be difficult to decide.  He was obviously irritated that it took us more than 30 seconds (but less than a minute) to tell him what we wanted.

The donuts?  Oh my gosh.  They were greasy and expensive.  All 3 family member who ate them had stomach aches and intestinal issues within an hour.  We hadn't eaten since the evening before, so we know it was the donuts.  

If you are someone who likes to say, "Been there...done that," then you'll probably want to give this place a try.  If you are someone who could care less (like us, only we had heard such great things, we decided to go) and want a good donut,  skip Voodoo and go elsewhere!

Really disappointed in this place.  Tried the Mexican hot chocolate,  chocolate glazed,  Portland cream, pumpkin buttercream, maple crueller. Only one we really enjoyed was the Mexican hot chocolate. Everything else was pretty plain and simple. No craft or creativity involved here. Putting other people's creations on top of normal Doughnuts doesn't qualify. Take away the crude humor and your left with below average Doughnuts,  we both said they tasted like dunkins and we would have preferred dunkins.

I think I was there at the same time Allison R was there....the "Donut Nazi", as we came to know her, was SO INCREDIBLY rude. The line was long, the night was cold. People were just trying to get in out of the cold and apparently there was some kind of "system" regarding the line...a system that only the Donut Nazi understood. She YELLED at everyone in line to back up, and when we all looked at her with somewhat confused faces, she yelled again! Drunk with power that only novelty donuts can wield, she implied she would hold our donuts hostage until we met her demands. 

So, like good like boys and girls we backed up a few feet and the donuts flowed once more. This would have been all fine and good had our donuts tasted anything even remotely related to the concept of freshness. I've had MUCH better donuts at...oh, just about any donut shop anywhere. My husband and I got the maple bar with bacon and the bacon looked like it had been in the refrigerator for about a week, the bar itself tasted as though it was already a day old. I had a few bites and tossed the rest...and I NEVER throw out a donut. Ever. 

The next day I got a maple bar from a quaint little bakery on the other side of town...no line, helpful staff and guess what? An awesome donut.

It's just donuts, people! I understand this place was on tv so everyone flocks to it but there is nothing special about it. On the contrary actually, both places are disgustingly kept (I swear everything is sticky and it looks like they never clean) and the one right off Burnside is always packed. Seriously lines around the corner all the time. The donuts aren't great anyway. Yeah, they're kinda weird but they're mostly stale and the service sucks. The hipsters that work there think they're famous or something because they work at VooDoo so they are smart-asses if they even say anything at all. Not to mention the location of the one downtown. It's right across from tent city. You get people panhandling while you're waiting in line then if you sit down to eat outside then the bums ask you for food. Not exactly where I'd take my family visiting Portland for the first time.

CASH ONLY.

This place is just a hype. The donuts are weird and fun but that is just about it. There are plenty of other places that are at par or even better than this place.

The line was huge and it took about an hour to get through it. 

But I checked it off my bucket list of places to check out, so there's that...it is just one of those places you can tell people you've been to.
The staff is kinda rude to get you in and out as fast as possible even when there's not really a line

Personally, there was too much hype about the donuts. I had never had a voodoo donut before but had heard so much about them and was extremely excited when I saw the building. I ordered a Oreo donut, the voodoo donut and a fruit loops donut. Unfortunately, the cereal and Oreo on top of the donuts were stale. The donuts also didn't taste as fresh as I would have liked them to be. I wish I could say that I loved the donuts but I would be lying.

I'm no donut expert, so this may negate my review, but I don't get what all the fuss is about. Plus, it makes the experience that much worse when you have to wait an hour to get a box of donuts. 

It's good, don't get me wrong, but being a Seattleite, I can go to Top Pot Donuts or Frost and NOT wait and get a donut almost as good. Maybe someone in Portland can explain to me what the deal is. Maybe there aren't a  lot of donut shops in the area.
It's a donut, but a lot more expensive and with attitude, and cash only.  But the donuts at Heavenly donuts, and put your own Cap'n Crunch or Peanut butter on it.

I came to Portland to see what the hype of these doughnuts were all about, but I didn't see what was so special besides the cereal and bacon toppings. It was a sugar overload and they dry out so fast since I bought a dozen and had to throw most of them away. I prefer the original glaze Krispy Kreme doughnuts way better!!

You really come here for the looks/hype.
It is not fresh and taste is subpar. You're better off going to Blue Star Donuts.

Weird! Yes, it's pretty much marketed that way but who's the high one that comes up with those doughnut combinations? And the decor... it's weird.

The hype is a bit overrated. It's one of those "do it once" places. A must see, but not a must do. 

It's also hard to know what doughnut is what. They don't really have a menu that corresponds to the sugary creations going 'round in the case. What I thought was a  S'mores doughnut actually was tang...

Ended up with a plain ol birthday cake. Husband tried the maple w/ bacon. Friend had Oreo with peanut butter. All were delicious and put us to sleep.

Clever Doughnuts created by people who enjoy making a spectacle of themselves as well as their doughnuts, along the line of circus freaks. Thereby offering more entertainment and less of a tasty pastry. If you are a sociologist or want to be one, start here before the fad wears out.
Its ok, the lines are ridiculous!  Save yourself the wait and go for the winner (BlueStar Doughnuts)  I've only been to the one on Hawthorn but WOW!  Best doughnut I have ever had!

I like donuts & these are pretty darn good. Love the one covered in M&M's & the Voodoo doll donut, but some of the other ones with cereal as toppings just seem stale, it's probably the cereal lol, but I'll still eat them! Just hate that the line is always so long, & they only take cash. It can be pricey too, but the experience is fun for a special treat!

Voodoo is fun for about five minutes.

As a Portland local, I enjoyed Voodoo a couple of times; these were usually late night stops, when there wasn't an abhorrent line--how people are willing to stand in line like buffoons for novelty items involving cereal is baffling (then again, most of these people are from Vancouver or out of town).

IF YOU LIKE DONUTS, and you're looking for unique, quality donuts, I highly recommend Blue Star Donuts. They don't treat their employees like shit (i.e. like what Voodoo puts in their donuts). Their offerings vary depending on the day, but every time I've been there they have refreshing, unique combinations, with classic standbys as well.

If you can't make it to Blue Star, at least go to Tonalli's or Heavenly Donuts. Be original, for fuck's sake.

Overrated? Yeah. As a tourist to Portland was it worth the stop? Yeah!

We went in the middle of the day and lucky for us the line wasn't too long. Still we waited nearly 30 minutes until we were able to get out of the rain and order inside. Once inside, it was surprisingly small. A counter with 3 cash registers and 2 spiraling display cases full of all unique creations was basically all there was. There was plenty to look at on the walls. I felt like I was in a doughnut themed Amoeba record store. 

The cashiers are very friendly and surprisingly quite patient considering the line of anxious customers that is likely non-stop throughout their shifts. Prices of the doughnuts are not cheap considering they are doughnuts. The actual taste of the doughnuts was quite tasty and very fresh (almost too fresh because some of the chocolate frosting smeared on most of the other doughnuts) although the uniqueness of the doughnuts are merely cosmetic. Still you'll get a good chuckle out of some of their creations.

All things considered, as a tourist Voodoo Doughnuts was worth the visit. The price and the wait are some of the biggest deterrents to this Portland attraction. 

*Taste ~ 3.5 stars
*Value ~ 2 stars
*Novelty ~ 4 stars
*Customer Service ~ 4 stars

Its tourist-ee, and a great spot to take visitors that are new to the Pacific Northwest.

The staff may be happy, but they do not act like it.  I don't think I have seen any of them smile or be (at least) pleased or happy to help someone...I've been there three times, always with guests.  

Lines do not justify the quality of the donuts...as it's a weird donut shop, in a weird part of town.

Donuts are average, but edgy (a bacon maple bar..).  They don't take credit cards, so have your CASH ready....WTF?  Why no credit cards?  Curious.

I'm glad I'm not the only person that felt this way, judging by the numerous reviews posted.
Crazy named and flavored donuts- tons of varieties. Pretty fun place decorated in pink and neon green. There's usually a line out the door stretching around the block, so come early.

This is a fun place but I think overrated but we had to try it as it is one of the tourist things to do in Portland,  I had a lemonade doughnut- others had tried various unusual ones.  I enjoyed my doughnut but it was the icing that made it good the doughy part was just like any other doughnut.  We liked the decor of Voodoo Doughnut and how people lined up to go inside to make their selection.  Frankly after the experience I would pass on Voodoo Doughnut if in the vicinity.  But like being a tourist you have to experience it once.

I was really glad I got to try this place out while I was in Portland. Luckily, I came here when the line was really short. Thank goodness. I kept hearing about the long lines and was not really in the mood to wait a really long time. 

If figured I would get one of the crazier ones and one normal donut to compare. I got the old-fashioned donut and the donut with the captain crunch on top. The old-fashioned donut was the best old-fashioned I've had in a really long time. There was lots of flavor and it was not dry! The captain crunch one was really sweet (almost too sweet). I could only eat it in small pieces because of that. 

The next time I'm in Portland, I might come back if I have the time, but I will also try out the other donut places in town.

Totally based on hype. There's no doubt the doughnuts are tasty and creative. However, considering you have to ward off the homeless beggars while you indulge is kind of a downer. I will say it was one of the only cream filled doughnuts that didn't leave me feeling bloated. Would only recommend if you happen to be in the area but not worth a trip just for Voodoo.

I've been wanting to try this place ever since I saw the episode of Bourdain's show on the Pacific NW.  The donuts look cool but are just okay tasting.  I tried the maple bar with the bacon on top and it was okay, nothing special.  The donut was just too sweet for me.

The line wasn't too long and the selection was fun and interesting. Overall the donuts are good and something different than the norm. The neighborhood is a bit seedy so I wouldn't suggest going alone at night.
This place has a super long wait time. The donut names are clever and crazy, but donuts taste kind of stale.

it's a portland tradition - they have unique donuts that you will have a very tough time finding anywhere else.  The donuts are good, but the crazy lines outside of their store in downtown portland is ridiculous. There are other Voodoo places that have parking, the same donuts and yet are pleasantly missing the maddening crowds.  You should visit vodoo as part of your time in portland.  I recommend the maple bar with bacon (now a staple in many places), the donuts dipped in koolade mix (haven't seen other places).
The prices reflect the demand vs. the experience. (a little on the high side)

I had the following:
-Blueberry
-Buttermilk
-Triple Chocolate Penetration
-Portland Cream Pie

Overall, I thought these were good...I don't think it's really worth the long line, but I do appreciate the creativity.  My favorite one was the Portland Cream Pie and the Blueberry...unique and tasty.
The donuts Ive had here were good, but this is definitely a tourist trap.

Unbelievably overhyped. The 25 minute wait in line is definitely not worth these tasteless and dry doughnuts. Sure, the quirky shapes and addition of cereal might be fun, but does that really make a good donut? No. It comes down to the flavor and texture, and that is certainly lacking at Voodoo.
long line + stale donuts = not fun experience.  go to blue star instead

Long line outside so we just had to check it out. 40 minute loop around & we finally made it near the door & we still gotta wait inside but a shorter wait, about 10 minutes...

We ordered 6 donuts & we got the cool pink box so we felt special walking out the door. Lol! We took bites of the donuts right outside the door. There is benches and tables. We ordered the Triple Chocolate Penetration (chocolate cake doughnut, chocolate frosting and coco puffs) for $1.25, Miami Vice Berry (vanilla frosting, blue raspberry powder, pink sprinkles) for  $1.50,  Dirt Doughnut (vanilla frosting and oreos), Old Dirty Bastard (chocolate frosting, oreos and peanut butter) for $1.75

The donuts had super sweet frosting that I dislike cause I feel a diabetic attack coming on. The dough didn't taste fresh. So all in all it was exciting standing in line with the others but I'd probably do it again NEVER...

If u go its Cash only so bring cash!! Btw the line got even longer when we walked out.

Date: Sunday Febuary 20, 2012 @ 1 pm

I went to Voodoo doughnuts in the evening and maybe the donuts were stale? It was a nice thing to do and see since it's a novelty in Portland but a donut is a donut. I had the maple sugar bacon donut which was tasty but I only enjoyed half of it since it's a lot of sugar and salt in one pastry.

One of many tourist spots in Portland. I was lucky enough that when I went, there was no line. I honestly think it's just like any other donut shop that I've been to. There's just some donuts with different toppings. I got the voodoo doll, dirt (oreo pieces on top), blueberry and old fashioned. I liked it all. It wasn't too sweet for my taste which was a plus. The price is very affordable (around $2 for a donut). 

There's parking on the street. It can be a little tricky though. I parked a block away and just walked to the shop and all around downtown. Overall, it's a must when you're visiting Portland but I wasn't too impressed.
The lines suck- but it's part of the novelty. The donuts are okay- some are better than others. My favorite is the maple bacon bar.

Definitely a creative place and of course I had to check it out since we don't have Voodoo in Cali, but I was a tad disappointed in the actual product's taste and quality.

We waited in line for about 30 minutes.  The girl that helped us was overworked and not overly helpful.

We got a maple donut with creme filing, a fruit loop one, Oreo with peanut butter drizzle and cocoa puff one.  Hands down the maple one was the best, but none of them were the best donut I had ever had which is what I expected from all the hype.

I am glad I went, but I doubt I will ever go back.

Good but not the best. They're very cake-y and way to sugary, they have cool designs on their donuts and it's awesome that they're open 24 hours but the quality is probably a 6/10 compared to other places. Still a staple of Portland and worth trying and checking out.

Voodoo Donuts is a Portland tourist experience. The Disney Landish line and bizarre donut concoctions (they literally have a jam filled voodoo doll donut that comes with a functional pretzel stake) are all part of the charm of this well known fried dough market. That being said, outside the novelty, the donuts themselves are just OK. Still the anticipation while in line and fun picking out your custom dozen make it a must visit.
I had the no name and captain crunch.  They both had great appearance and the actual doughnut part was good, but the cereal on them is stale unfortunately.

Done with downtown pdx location- clearly just for tourists and apparently waiting in line is an experience. Went to other one on Sandy.  Much faster.  But seems quality of donuts is suffering.  Flavor is still there mostly, but they're starting to look less and less like the donuts advertised.

everytime i attempted to go here, the line was r i d i c u l o u s l y long. are you serious?! for a donut!? there were other great places in portland to see and try, i didn't waste one more second here. it's over-rated!

My husband is a big fan of doughnuts and he enjoyed the Voodoo doughnut.  I would say it's more of a novelty. A little overrated. I've definitely had better doughnuts before although it was fun watching my husband stab his voodoo doughnut as it gushes out with fake blood made from raspberry filling. I would get some if I'm in the area but I won't be going out of my way.
One word...overrated! I was looking forward to this place for years and sooooo disappointed. Donuts were not great, not warm and overall just bland. Save your time and effort
I mean, it's a donut. Don't buy the hype.

RUDE! 

Damn you travel channel!!

The service here sucks!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!

Never again.

Oh, we arrived around 2am...NO VOODOO donuts? How the hek is this place called Voodoo donuts and they don't have the dang voodoo donuts available!!! My goodness what a disappointment!

The place is tiny. serious HOLE in the wall, literally!!

It was good, but a little too much going on for me,,, If I have a visitor from out of town, I may take them to Voodoo just for fun experience, but if I would like to eat something 'delicious', I choose somewhere else.

Donuts are not the best tasting in the world, they are "Fun" if that means anything.  I buy them for the novelty no the taste.
Locations are dirty, but its part of the ambiance..

I've tried this 'hot spot a few times" Now the spell is broken. $2.50 for ONE small round over priced cereal /peanut butter laden donut? , I felt like all i was paying for is the Hype and the legend. Yeah, i used to be a believer, but last night i tried a mouthful of overly sugared, dried out HYPE. 
the tide is turning....lower your prices before the public catches onto this Voodoo
FAD. Thank god, i think i broke the spell last night. Back to Sesame' donut in Raleigh Hills where the prices are fair and there is no half hour or hour and a half lines.....

Voodoo definitely achieved its fame more for its creativity in donut design than for its execution. While there are plenty of interesting choices like Cap'n Crunch, Cock-n-balls, Maple bacon bar, and of course the classic Voodoo, none of the donuts taste particularly amazing. I prefer airy donuts like those at Krispy Kreme to the denser cake versions. Plus, we bought our donuts closer to closing time so none were particularly fresh and the cereal-topped ones in particular had stale toppings. Nevertheless, carrying the pink box on the Maxx attracted plenty of attention and several people asked if they could buy a donut from us. If you're looking to honor a classic Portland tradition, stop by Voodoo. As for me, I'll be at Krispy Kreme.

long lines. total tourist trap.

it's definitely a unique place, i'm glad i went to see what all the hypes about. the donuts? meh. i've tried the voodoo donut and bacon maple bar. they were on the stale side. not fresh, no unique taste, quite ordinary. it's so interesting to see such ridiculous lines and people taking boxes of them on their flights at pdx!!

Honestly, I don't know what the hype is all about in regards to this place.  I've heard about it from so many people who have visited Portland.  I've seen it on the Food Network.  I guess I had high expectations but I thought their donuts were way too sweet and not that good.

First off there is a long line that is out the door.  It goes by pretty quick so you don't have to worry if you see a long line.  The inside of the place is really small.  They have cashiers who can help you but it's hard to tell which donuts are which unless you ask.  The menu is also displayed on the wall but it's hard to match each description to the exact donut in the display case.  I felt like it was almost too much for me to keep asking the cashier what each of the donuts were in the case and what was inside each of the donuts.  

They definitely have unique flavors and pretty much anything sweet that you can slap on a donut.  We ordered a regular chocolate donut so we could compare a regular donut to a regular donut shop back at home.  And we also ordered another chocolate donut that had peanut butter and rice krispies on top.  

The rice krispies were stale and the donut itself was not good.  The regular chocolate donut was okay but overall, both donuts were super sweet.
