I guess we should've ordered the Maple Bacon Bar but overall, I think this place has really super heavy donuts that are too sweet and too rich.  It's also not worth the hype of actually ordering and eating one of these.  It's good to go take pictures but I probably would've skipped out on the donut saving me some more bites of food elsewhere.

I think this place is just okay (but let's keep in mind that I'm not a donut fan and I don't really care for it). Way too overhyped and I would not wait in the ridiculous long lines for it. The only reason why I got to even try it was because we were out drinking late at night and decided to stop by since there was no line. PERFECT OPPORTUNITY especially since they're open 24 hours!!! 

I got the captain crunch which was recommended to me by a staff member. He was nice and actually had a lot to recommend me but was quite indecisive himself..lol. Even though it tasted good to me at the time (probably because I was not really coherent), I thought it tasted like a regular donut with captain crunch cereal on it. Now thinking back about it, Voodoo donuts isn't something that I would have a craving over. I probably only wanted to try it cuz I wanted to say at least I had voodoo donuts while in Portland when I was there. I think their donuts are cool, interesting, and unique in terms of look but did not win me over in terms of taste. I had a couple bites of my donut and left the rest in my hotel with the intent that I would finish it the next morning but I never did.. oops :X

P.S. Cash only :((( and I probably wouldn't have been able to try it if one of my co-workers didn't spot me!
It's all about the customized cock n ball cream filleds for me,

I gave an extra star for the decor and overall fun of the place. Donuts went in the trash and I thought I'd never meet a donut I didn't like. On to try Blue Star Donuts. Our Lyft driver recommended last night.

I made the trek here from Seattle, so after about 2 hours me and my friend were craving doughnuts, craving them. But no, we had to stand in a line that wrapped around the corner, we stood in line for an hour before we even got to the counter...an entire hour!

I knew I wanted to try to the voodoo man doughnut, but other than that I was whatever about it all. We opted to do the voodoo dozen (where they pick 'em) because the line was long and didn't want to be in there much longer. 

The shop itself is small, very cluttered with various things, kinda makes it *shrugs*, I can't think of the word, but whatever. Inside the shop it smells like old Halloween candy, mainly old tootsie rolls. Also, it reaks outside, probably due to the garbage and the whatnot, but it stinks. Do I want to smell garbage before I eat doughnuts? Not really. 

The doughnuts weren't that good, more over-hyped than anything. The voodoo man doughnut was alright, the most notable doughnut I had was the oreo one, but other than that everything was pretty unspectacular. 

Bottom line:  voodoo is not worth the wait or the drive.

I'm kind of torn on Voodoo doughnut. The long & to be expected line moves at a decent enough pace and provides pretty good people watching. I wouldn't bother in the rain or cold, but on a nice day it's a decent enough wait. I love that the doughnuts are so creative and fun, but I wish they were better executed. They are definitely just average donuts in the quality department, made special with creativity in the ingredients & naming department. I still like Voodoo & find myself at least considering making a stop by on every visit to Portland. But I would LOVE them if they could make really high quality AND creative donuts. I just feel like when you specialize in one thing, you should be able to get that one thing really right. I find myself wanting to ask my local bakery to recreate Voodoos donuts. 

They're good, just not great. Definitely still worth a visit for a true sugar aficionado.

Highly overrated. Saccharine sweet and over-worked. When I think of the MANY delicious dessert options in Portland, this place is not even on my list. It only comes to mind as a destination for tourists who have seen Portlandia, and stoners fixin' for a sugar high.

for those who want the box i guess it's worth the wait? I live just down the street and pop in during the off time to satisfy my sweet tooth and it usually does just that. I love getting the plain glazed, the blazer blunt and the Apple fritter. Though i often forget that their plain glazed is not up to standard anymore...........The other standard that I have been met with on numerous occasions are the employees attitudes that work behind the counter. there must be some voodoo doughnut protocol before hiring one of their counter-clerks because they all look the same (i shop at the same stores yet i am weird look!) and are always consistently rude. I am not sure if they have just worn thin dealing with the tourist or the crackheads which surround and even enter the building begging for money but it is completely unacceptable. I guess it must be the "i don't give a f*** attitude" that keeps me coming back for more. I know it isn't the blaring obnoxious music that no one likes. sometimes it even seems like the employees can't stand the facade of this place. Did the owner supply his two donut shops with obscure noise rock compilations for the patrons and employees to be subjected to?  Is there a set decibel level that both shops must keep the music on at? 
regardless of how annoying I find this place to be I will still come here when there is no line for a donut.
 
tip: Coco's donuts is just down the street (Morrison and sixth) and their donuts are amazing without all the frills, they even have a lavender donut that is beyond description. their prices also are not so obnoxious. oh yeah it is quiet and they have good coffee wow!

Meh, over hyped and a great big slap of carbs smothered in colorful things. I used to laugh when I'd see all the Voodoo Doughnut boxes being carried by travelers heading back home from their big trip to Portland. Are they tasty.. sure.. worth the hype .. not unless you need HUGE COLORFUL DONUTS.
This place is a joke, not worth the time, and the donut are crap at best. Workers are rude and font give a crap. And who has a donut called "The Cock & Balls" better shop out there than this place

I can see where the hype is about Voodoo Doughnut - their presentation is insane and they have a lot of cool choices. This is definitely a great place to check out. The donut itself tasted pretty underwhelming and the frosting was way too sweet.

When I mentioned to friends that I was going to Portland everyone said "You HAVE to go to Voodoo Doughnuts. It's unbelievable." Being someone who really likes "donuts" (imho the proper spelling...) I prepared myself for what I thought was going to be the best of the best.

As I pulled up, I was lucky to snag parking space right outside just as someone was leaving. Given how popular this place is, this was probably just a freak miracle. My guess is that usually finding parking there is tough. It's in a slightly dodgy area with more than its fair share of crazy homeless people. But with a downtown location that's par for the course. Some of the best places I've eaten have been in sketchy neighborhoods so that doesn't phase me.

The line was really long. Out the door with ropes set up to zigzag the line back and forth. "Man", I thought, "This place must be absolutely AMAZING!"

My wife and I settled into the back of the line getting ready for a long wait. Surprisingly it wasn't bad at all. The line moved much faster than I expected. That's certainly a big plus.

Once inside I immediately realized why the line was moving quickly. The crew working that day was fantastic. They were laser focused and extremely efficient at moving customers though. The server who helped me was friendly and offered good advice as to which donuts to try. He was also sincerely patient when I took a while to make up my mind.

The donuts themselves look incredible. Goodies pilled high. Definitely an avant garde design sense that pushes the limits of what a donut can be. 

We ordered a large assortment of different types and headed to the picnic benches. Ready to have my taste buds blown.

They weren't.

I tried a bite of each one and frankly I didn't love any of them. Don't get me wrong they are ok. Just not "the best donut you've ever tasted" Most of them were way too sweet. Some were too messy to enjoy. Others seemed weird just for the sake of being weird.

So overall I probably won't go back again. And I wouldn't kill yourself trying to cram a visit there if you are visiting from out of town.

Lots of fun weird different styles of donuts.  Line was a little long but part of that is because it just isn't very efficient.  They have the names of the donuts on the menu but I want to see them before I buy them.  So I have to wait until we get to the front of the line and can see them in the round display case.   I prefer most donut shops with the bigger case.  This little thing made it difficult to decide quickly which in turn causes long lines.   The donuts we tried were good but mostly because of the fun stuff on them.   They have got to figure out a better selling system before we try again.

Bottom Line at the TOP: Its nice to know PDX can get on the national sugar coated fried batter map with the offerings from VooDoo, but I am not sure they would take the top prize in Portland if we were to have a taste test. 

They are good, the Memphis Mafia gets solid marks for inventiveness in name and ingredients plus being enough for 2 (or 3 small people). The whole range of cereal toppings has never intrigued me but the other signature items are fun such as the VooDoo itself, or the one that a friend of mines little girl said "Daddy can I get the one shaped like a 'T', please" (in reality turn the T upside down and remember it has a cream filling)

What is toughest part of VooDoo is the line to wait in to get one esp after midnight on a weekend. Go there just about any time and you will have a wait of 10 to 20 min but I have to admit to stopping in once because when I drove by there was no line. 

My test of any doughnut shop is the Old Fashioned my standard is with glaze but sometimes go with a chocolate topping. I am not to concerned about what oil is in the fryer as long as its changed on a regular schedule. To get high marks in my book the "shell" of the old fashioned should have a crunch to the ridges then a solid inside the teeth can cut with ease without it breaking apart or so tight you have to pull. (Having any heat left from the fryer is an added bonus if found) 

The marks above is my overall impression of the Old Fashioned's I had here, one glaze one chocolate. One had the ridge crunch and both needed to be pulled a bit, flavor of the dough seemed a touch off but that could always be just the batch or oil so will edit next time I go in if something changes.

Absolutely. Disgusting.

As a tourist, I felt the need to stop by this place like worshiping an old temple. So on a rather toasty Sunday afternoon, I waited about 20 minutes to get one donut. I got the Voodoo Doll, which seemed iconic and what could go wrong with chocolate. 

I ate one arm. BLEH. I ate the other arm because I already bought it. I couldn't finish the rest and the two arms already gave me a bad sugary taste in the mouth for 10 minutes. I don't know how could it be that bad. Did I choose a wrong flavor? I was going to give it to a homeless person but I was too scared. I offered to give it to my Rental Car guy, but he doesn't want any. Cause. the. locals. know. it. is. a. hype.

I mean, 2 stars, because it's not breaking my wallet for one donut and the line went by fast.

But really, GO TO BLUE STAR!! OH BLUE STAR HOW I MISS YOU! Or come down to San Diego for some good ones - Nomads, Donut Bars... we actually have a pretty good donut scene down here.

I live in Portland and used to love this place, but now it's just become a tourist trap. With an ever present line, who, but a tourist can afford to wait 45 minutes for a doughnut. Would love it if this place would come up with a register for people who just want to order one fucking doughnut instead of having to wait in line behind 20 people who have to gotta have a little pink box to show all their friends how cool they are.
That said, best doughnuts I've ever had. Too bad I don't get to enjoy them anymore.

Voodoo Doughnut is a landmark for Portland. I'm not a huge doughnut (or donut for Americans)  fan, but this place is worth visiting once. Yeah, it's hype, but so was the  Portland strip club and you probably still visited them and gave them a lousy review too! I spent about $5 here. I can also say I ate a Guinness doughnut.

Back in the day(yeppers I'm almost 40) this place was a kitschy fun place.  The donuts with the silly names and crazy toppings were fun to look at a debate amongst a group of friends of who was going to get what.  Even back then, if you didn't go there close to when they made a fresh batch, well, you ended up with a deflated, sugary brick that made you more depressed than happy.  Again, I have happy memories from way bavk when, and I shall keep them in tact by avoiding the lines and not going back.

Donuts are just ok, nothing great. Just normal donuts. Their cereal donuts that we bought were stale. The Cream filled donuts were the best part of our order. I do have to say that the decorations on the donuts are the awesome part of coming to this place, picture perfect. Don't go on a weekend if you're going with family, it's next to a bar with some fun wild peeps. A lot of crackheads roam around as you're waiting in line which keeps it interesting and makes time go by faster as you're waiting in line. Voodoo donut is definitely a place to stop by when you're ever in Portland! Just don't go with high expectations due to the hype. It's a fun weird experience bc it's a one of a kind donut shop due to the theme. Enjoy your visit and look out for some muns (man nuns) that pass out condoms and mints on weekends! Lol oh and the people that work their have a cool unique style! I dig it
Ok it wasn't all that. I definitely was not worth 30 min wait in line. It seems like one is obligated to atleast try it if u r in Portland but it's really not all that

We got the voodoo doll donut and the old dirty bastard. 

The voodoo doll was super sweet, but still pretty tasty with the raspberry jam.

The old dirty bastard tasted like a regular donut, just with peanut butter on top.

It was a nice experience. If you love donuts, this is the place to go.

They're really nothing special honestly. A maple bar with a slab of bacon on top? I could just as well make that myself. The voodoo doll shaped donut is probably the best thing about this place simply because it's fun and quirky. Otherwise, the long lines are simply not worth it and makes me scratch my head wondering why all these other people think so.

When this place starts getting cleaner, friendlier, and more consistent, I'll update this review.

Stood in line forever for something I could have easily gotten at Tonali's or any of the other Donut shops in PDX.

I wanted to check this place out for awhile since I've seen on tv a few tunes.. the time we went the line wasn't to busy and the line kept moving.. they only take cash only and they don't take pennies.. the doughnuts itself it's about average but they do have a lot of variety so u can't go wrong on any of them
Just a novelty.  Unless it's on your bucket list, go somewhere else.

We've seen Ace of Cakes. We've seen creative cupcakeries. If you're going to make badass creative donuts, for the LOVE of Papa Legba, Make 'em look appetizing!!

Visiting Portland, we were taken here around 3 am by a good friend showing us the sights.

I didn't get the hype. Maybe it's because I lived in San Francisco & am unfazed by kitsch and attitude. Maybe it's because I'm a visual artist. Maybe it's because the donuts were smeared in frosting, half smushed, and had sprinkles thrown willy-nilly on top. 

They tasted good. But all's I'm sayin is make them LOOK as good as they taste!

Worth the stop for the kitsch factor.  We had two late night donuts, lets all say 24-7 hours are awesome!  They were tasty and fresh.  The favorite was the maple/ bacon.  Total tourist trap.  On a Thurs. at 11:00pm there was no line.  We had better donuts during our time in Portland but the kitsch factor would make me reccomend it to others visiting Portland.  Cash only.

Voodoo Doughnut?  What is all the hype and long lines I always see about?

The family (Wife, kids, Brother) and I decided to venture into Portland for the afternoon to be "tourists for a day".  We opted to hit up both Voodoo and Big-Ass Sandwiches truck which are across the street from each other.

I already knew the line for Voodoo would be an hour or more long and I kept telling the family, no doughnut is worth an hour wait.  I don't care, it's not worth an hour wait.  

It just so happened the wait at Big-Ass was the same today (around 1:00 p.m. arrival) but we split up and luckily received both orders at the same time.  

We sat down at the picnic tables Voodoo offers and other than the homeless guy digging through the trash can eating previously eaten doughnuts, the stay was comfortable.  A nice couple from Indiana joined us, which made for some nice conversation.

I ordered the Maple Bacon Doughnut and the "Cock N' Balls".

For those of you who decide Bacon on a doughnut is something you cannot stomach and shouldn't be on doughnuts and verbally make it known on Yelp, I say your palate isn't refined enough to post reviews to begin with.

Also keep in mind, Have you ever had breakfast consisting of Pancakes with Bacon and Eggs?  If so, then why are you against a a Voodoo Bacon Maple Doughnut.  Afterall, doesn't the maple syrup you put on your pancakes, sometimes run over onto your bacon?  Enough said!

I found my Maple Bacon Doughnut to be Heavenly.  This yeast raised doughnut with a sweet maple glaze and two strips of smokey bacon to be perfect.  The doughnut was soft, the glaze not overly sweet and the bacon cooked nicely.  The whole doughnut was creamy and buttery.  I will definitely order this again.  The saltiness and smokiness of the bacon complimented the maple glaze perfectly.  This is a must have if you visit Voodoo.

My "Cock N' Balls" err I mean Voodoo's Cock N' Balls doughnut is about the size of two "log" doughnuts covered in chocolate and filled with a triple cream filling.  I was too stuffed from the Big-Ass sandwiches (you can find my review on their Yelp page) and the bacon doughnut to dig into this, but I will enjoy it later and will post more.

**Update** Just dug into the Cock N' Balls.  Chewy, Chocolate goodness with triple cream oozing from the sides when your mouth bites down.  I'm not a huge chocolate fan, so curious how this would be with a different frosting, hmmmmmmm.

I didn't try any of their other doughnuts, but future visits will change that.

The only thing keeping me from giving Voodoo 4 or 5 stars is my lack of trying their other doughnuts and the Hour Long Wait.  However I understand they are open 24 hours a day and have another location across the river which is not as busy, so I may venture over to the 3rd Ave location during the Midnight hour and if the lines are short and the other doughnuts are tasty, I will update with 4-5 stars.

The amount of people lined up every day here to eat stale cereal cemented to a dry excuse for a pastry is truly depressing. This is supposed to be a food town! Go get an apple turnover at Tonalli's Donuts and Cream on Alberta and call me in the morning. Sheesh.

i want to give more stars but i just wasn't that impressed with the donuts i had. i had the mc minville and the chocolate frosted cream filled donut. they were good, but the frosting was too sweet. i had a taste of the old dirty bastard which was pretty good and not as sweet as i thought it would be. i like the idea of the place and definitely will give it a try again the next time i'm in portland.
Got theme to it and unique decord . But I like my Krispy Kreme better.  Nothing special about the dough, I find all of the topoing they put in overpower the simple donut.  Just a personal taste.

Voodoo is an experience. The doughnuts don't melt in your mouth, and you won't be begging for the recipe. Still, the pink box is probably the most notable container in town--and the suggestive nature of the goods that go into the pink box...you catch my drift. 

Again, if you are waiting in line there is a reason. I don't get it...but there is a reason. 

If ever I had a craving for a donut--the golden painted store--with Winco quality doughnuts obfuscated with pure and perverse artistic liberty...well that's where I'd be!

I agree wholeheartedly with all the 2-3 star reviewers.  This place is all about hype and is on the 'must-go' list as a tourist, but there isn't anything super special with the donuts.  It's a super funky place, I'll give them that, but the donuts themselves aren't spectacular.  They are just ok-good.

My husband and I drove down from Vancouver, Canada on a long weekend and met another couple that were going down the same time.  We decided to get some donuts on our last night there because we've heard so much about Voodoo.  There was a pretty long line-up outside that went down the block, but decided to wait anyway because we were there anyway.  The line took about 30-40 minutes which is pretty ridiculous to me for donuts, but again, we were with friends and chatting so it didn't feel that long. 

Both couples ended up getting a random dozen to eat and bring back home.  In this random box, you get a dozen (I think) donuts and they make the assortment for you.  They do have a great variety of donuts, but the dough in the donut isn't anything different than, say, a Tim Horton's donut if you're from Canada.

I'd say save your time if the line-up is long, and try it out if the line is short.  It's more of a novelty to take pictures and say you've been.

Been wanting to visit this place for a while.  The place is cool but my counterperson seemed a little edgy in not a good way. It was my first time there and I ordered a powdered mango donut and I meant to order the mango sugared one with mango filling.  When the girl brought it to the counter and I had asked for the wrong donut  she said, "The powdered mango sugar is what you said." Then she said,  "You can just have it." and then she curtly got me the one I meant to order. I guess putting the wrong donut back into the cool revolving display case would make the donut lose its voodoo mojo. I kinda felt like I was with the Soup Nazi. 

Otherwise, I enjoyed their donuts. But this kind of attitude is what kept me from giving Voodoo 4 stars. I like patronizing places that appreciate me as a customer and not on how efficiently I can order a donut.

So yes, Voodoo does have fun doughnuts. However, really the only time I've found to get fresh doughnuts is after the bars have closed. I've tried 9am and by then they already taste on the stale side. And you can never NOT have a line. There are a number of other doughnut shops in town that have fun and delicious doughnuts. Its fun to go when you have out of town guests who have heard and want something good out of a pink box...but it's only ok in the long wrong.

OK, so I was skeptical about the dang bacon maple bar, until someone made me take a bite.  

OH  MY  STARS!!  

It's a dang good thing I live on the other side of town.

It's a bit weird, normally over-crowded, not a lot of space to sit and have Ur doughnut and coffee, but it's a MUST GO, at least once.  

AND HEY, if U ask nice, they will actually MARRY U there and build a doughnut wedding cake!

A lot of hype but unfortunately the donuts weren't very good. The novelty of having so many toppings on a donut was cool to see, but the actual dough was a little dry. I tried the Oreo and peanut butter donut which was pretty good but take away the Oreos, and it would be a very lackluster donut. The chocolate donut with cocoa puffs was a little better, but the same issue with the dough was present.

This place was neat when we first visited as tourists. Now that I'm a local and know how they treat the employees, I refuse to go back. The donuts are neat, but as far as taste goes... there just okay. It also bothers me that they only take cash, so all the homeless people beg outside while we you wait in line knowing you have cash on you. It's an awful experience!

This place is centered around the unique experience, not the product.  For me, the unique experience was largely an uncomfortable one.  They literally have switchbacks outside their door for you to fill in, much like an amusement park ride.  Also much like an amusement park ride, you wait in line for an hour, have about 2 minutes of excitement, and at the end of it think "was that really worth it?".  Add in the fact that you are surrounded by homeless people, street "artists" and what other eclectic and obnoxious bunch happens to camp out next to the line.  The donuts, while fun and unique, were only a small step above what you'd find at a Dunkin Donuts in terms of taste and quality.  If you are into that kind of crowd and experience, knock yourself out, but my trip there was my first and will be my last.

Really love the atmosphere and magical feeling of this portland landmark.  My most recent experience was not for the kind hearted. I was yelled at multiple times to move out of the doorway or get out of the way for other customers. 

This was my brother and sisters first experience going here and we waited through the long line excited to see all the doughnuts. Once we were done i heard them ask why was that one black lady yelling so much? 

That whole experience was unfortunately an experience i do not want to live again. Though the doughnuts were great being yelled at is not something i deserve  I will never be back.

What a disappointment. I absolutely love doughnuts. Surprisingly, this place was more sugary than Krispy creme and psycho doughnuts. I didn't like it at all. I felt like my teeth were instantly rotting and my blood pressure spiked up. 

This place is super hyped. Also, there's a ton of homeless people that literally get in your face asking for money.

We got a few donuts this morning because we're tourist from Southern California, and seemed like we just had to visit Voodoo donuts while in Portland. I really loved the place, the atmosphere, the people, and the variety of donuts... that being said I thought the donuts were just ok. We got the voodoo donut, bubbly gum and grape ape. They all tasted like expected with their flavor but the actual donut seemed dense and dry. I still think it is worth a visit, but don't plan on having a delicious breakfast. It's just a fun thing to do.

VOODOO!!!!! This is one of the must-see places to check out if you are visiting Portland. They have two locations and pretty much it's the experience of visiting the donut shop.  They have different names for all of their different concoctions of donuts. My favorite is the Maple-Bacon Bar! Yes I said it Maple and Bacon. It sounds kinda extreme but the salty and sweet  together is heavenly.  Apparently you can get married at the  place. Info on their website. The donut shop has been featured on the travel channel.  Overall, come here for the experience.

So overrated!   The donuts are fine, average donuts that you'd fine in any bakery.   But combined with the long lines and massive hype, I was not expecting an average donut.   Apparently, a trip to Portland is not complete without a stop to this famed donut shop.   Being a tourist here myself, totally feel like I was conned into stopping by.   We sampled the bacon maple, chocolate glazed and plain donuts.   When trying a new junk food spot I always order and bite into the most basic item first, as this is usually a good test of the quality of the establishment.   The plain donut can be described as, ordinary.   After all, it's just a donut, nothing more, nothing less.   The famed bacon maple was pretty bad in my book.   Way too much maple.   I mean, the place does have variety going for it.  Literally, there must be like 30 different donuts to choose from.    But the real issue I had with the place was being such a famed tourist stop, Voodoo,  after 6pm becomes a mad house.   Line stretching down the block, homeless people loitering around and alot of drunk idiots waiting to gobble up some donuts.   If you do plan to stop by Voodoo, either go in the daytime when the lines are reasonable, or be prepared for the madness in the evenings.  My opinion, just go to Crispy Creme and save yourself the hassle.
These donuts are too sweet and taste stale. Yuck.

This place is a must for anyone new to Portland.  The bacon maple doughnut is my favorite here!  Although very unique, most are very rich (too rich for my taste), but an experience worth venturing.  This place only takes cash, but there is an ATM located inside.  Be prepared for a line due to the popularity of this place!
Not sure what the hype is about. I tried both their cake and raised donuts and they are average, and, in fact, over-priced. Friendly staff and colorful display makes it fun to shop there though!

I like Voodoo. The variety is fun. I always go when I'm in Portland. What I have learned is that if you want a fresh doughnut go early, like when they open. I went in the later part of the afternoon and waited for about 20 min in line. When I got inside I felt as if I had to order fast and get out so that the next group of Voolovers could get their fix. I strongly recommend getting milk cause theres alot of doughnut going on.

Overrated. Overhyped. Overpriced. 

Here's the Voodoo breakdown:
1. Stand in a 30 minute line squished between crying babies and inpatient 16 year old girls. 
2. Order a box of mediocre donuts topped with stale candy and cereal. And you'll do it quick - your cashier will be pushy, rushed and not willingly helpful.
3. Overpay for a donut that may or may not induce a heart attack. 
4. Attempt to enjoy your donut until you realize that the donuts in the Safeway bakery are of better quality. 

I like the concept of Voodoo, don't get me wrong! It's a fun place to visit if you're a first timer in Portland, but my advice would be to check out Blue Star Donuts instead.

Seriously not worth the wait. Donut taste like Safeway donuts. People who worked there obviously don't care. They stack all the donuts in one box. By the time you get home all the frost on top of each donut is all over the place. I specially order a voodoo doll donut so I can take picture. She put it on the bottom.
5* for donuts, 1* for crazy waits.  You will probably go once and then forget about it for 6 months.  Life is too short to spend one hour in line for a donut.  Terrific variety and great fresh taste.

I have being there around 3 times. The place is great, doughnuts are great. The thing that they need to fix is the customer service. I understand the place is always busy and need to move fast but you need to take care of the customer and be helpful without long and mad faces. I'll be thinking twice before going back again just for this reason.

I was told this place was a must when visiting Portland, but wasn't told about the wait. We went on a Saturday morning and stood in line for an hour up against a dirty wall that my son couldn't resist touching repeatedly. When first getting in line, I told my boyfriend "no donut is worth this wait." But we had driven there and found good parking, so we went for it. When we finally got inside, it felt dirty and we were overwhelmed with choices (none of which looked good to me, but I'm not big on donuts). My son could hardly contain himself. Rather than stress over all the options, I just ordered a Voodoo Dozen for $15. Beware, they take CASH ONLY. The chick took my money then went to the back to select my dozen. I had to remind her to give me my change when she came back. I grabbed my pink box and went back to the car where we would "see what we got." 

Now, I always thought that a dozen equals 12. I have heard of a "baker's dozen", which is 13. But I had no idea that a "Voodoo Dozen" equals 8 (eight). I don't know if this is normal, or if our cashier didn't know how to count, but I wasn't going back in to correct it (most of them went in the trash anyway). 

My son took a huge donut with fruit loops on top, he only eats sugar willingly, so this was right up his alley. He ate about 2/3 of it. My daughter got a chocolate donut with pink frosting and marshmallows on top, this was her first donut and she was happy and ate about half of it. My boyfriend got a huge donut with peanut butter, which he said was too sweet (but he still ate it). I got what I thought would be the safest choice, a donut with white icing and shimmery purple sprinkles. It was so sweet, I took a few bites then threw the rest away. 

We closed the box up, and the next day the donuts were stale so into the compost they went. 

So, we came, we saw, we won't come back. I stand by my statement that "no donut is worth this wait." Personally I like the plain old-fashioned donuts at 7-11 better, and its cleaner there too.
Incredibly over rated.  Their claim to fame is the weirdness of the donut combinations. NOT worth the ridiculous long line.

Go here for the funky atmosphere and to get ONE donut. The donuts are too sweet. I never thought I'd say that because I have a major sweet tooth, but dang it's so sweet. The actual donut is not nearly as good as some other local shops. (blue star.) going here is more for the crazy flavors and toppings than the actual donut.

as creative as before.. slightly more crappy.
i'm surprised that people are excited about mediocre doughnuts.
i guess people like what they are told to like

I was really excited to get the bacon maple donut and it was a great combo to have the salty bacon on top of the sweet donut.

the variety and creativity is awesome, but the actual donuts aren't that good. If they worked on improving their ingredients and cooking of the donuts, it would be out of this world

Oh, and not taking credit is just annoying
I'm not much of a doughnut person, but I must admit it was good. Not 40 minute wait good, but I can say I've been and conquered.

One of the Top 10 things to see or do in Portland. Finally, after 4 tries of getting in line we finally made it this time. The line was about 20 minutes long but better than an hour maybe due to the fact that we went on a Friday evening (6:30pm) . Who will eat donuts at this time? But for us we bought it to be consumed the next day. 
The place has tons of donuts to choose from. We had the  voodoo dozen since we really don't have any idea what to choose from, so they picked it for you. 
To cut the long story short, it is a donut shop for tourist. It tasted like the donuts I've had before ( years ago), with extra flavors depending on what topping you choose. 
Just an experience to see it and check off the list of things to do in Portland.

Portland's classic, open late, and with crazy donuts.

That said they're more into the overly sweet, crazy side with sprinkles, Oreos, ridiculous amounts of frosting, etc. If you prefer something more elegant, you'll want to go somewhere else.

At the late hour we showed up there wasn't much left-- a mango-filled option was the best one left. It actually might have been pretty good but there was waaaay too much filling for me. Just tells me I need to show up earlier!

The donuts here are pretty creative.  Tried the maple honey donut, gingerbread man, double chocolate. They even have a c**k and b*lls donut.  That was a huge donut in the display case.  Its very touristy and there was a long line waiting. Despite that, its taste pretty good, not great. And the price is pretty decent. Great to go if you're a tourist.

I've lived in Portland my whole life, so I am not as taken as I used to be with voodoo. But if you are looking for portlandia type things and a good giggle at some funny looking donuts, go here!! The lines are pretty long all the time, but hey.. They are just a cool place to be!! Make sure to bring cash!!
I tried the voodoo doll, bacon maple, and portland cream... they were all doughnuts and they were all A-OK. Not really sure what the big deal is though.

Obsessed with doughnuts myself I was a little disappointed. Voodoo doughnuts was good but nothing more unique than a doughnut from the grocery store. We ordered the blueberry (good), voodoo (good), homer (fine) and the fruit loop (stale). This was a tourist trap. I realized most tourist do this for the experience and for the frosting styles, but I wouldn't waste the calories OR recommend wasting your time driving into Portland and waiting 45 minutes for a mediocre doughnut. I would give this place 2 stars but DJ VoodDoo is the man, so I gave them 1 extra star for his performance.

My shortest review ever.

Idea of Voodoo? Great.
Presentation? Fantastic.
Unique Factor? A zillion.
Sense of humor? Laughed so hard I had an aneurysm.
Cool factor: Fuck you, James Dean, you creeptard.
Creativity: Ready for the Paris runways.
Donuts: Ehhh. I've had better.

As long as you're not looking to eat donuts, this place is the best.

Scrambled out of bed earlier on Sunday than we would have to avoid standing in line = got there bout 8.20a and we were second in line just outside the doors. As there became more room inside we attempted to go in but were rudely barked at by crabby doughnut cashier named Paul. Really could have done without being yelled at first thing on a Sunday IN A DOUGHNUT SHOP! He could have asked us nicely to just wait outside, but no he BARKED loudly at us. The doughnuts are okay, got a couple of the fun shaped ones and glazed (which was nice and moist and cakey). They did not have any plain old glazed chocolate fried cakes which was a bit of a disappointment for us. Overall, if you're looking for a touristy thing to do, this is it., complete with crabby workers. The doughnuts are fine, but glad we didn't have to wait in line, otherwise it would not have been worth it.

when voodo first opened and it was a little hole in the wall just off w. burnside, i loved the doughnuts, especially the bacon maple bar.  then it slowly became some sort of portlandia thing, before portlandia the show ever existed. then anthony bourdain featured them in an episode and it has been all downhill from there.  even the east side store. doughnuts are mass produced, often taste stale, the bacon isn't worth eating (yes, i just said that) and most of the folks behind the counter are impatient and have too many dreadlocks to be serving food. i USE TO LOVE them, but now i avoid them. but, if you are a TOURIST, then you better go pick up your pink box.  and, don't worry you can get them in the airport.

The Hard Rock Cafe of doughnuts.  Where tourists go to wait in line for truly mediocre donuts that theoretically are catapulted to greatness because they are topped with Froot Loops or Oreos.   This place is definitely style over substance. There are too many amazing bakeries in town to waste your calories on this overhyped hipster hole.
Touristy. Exactly as expected. Nothing out of the ordinary but glad we made the trip. Need to offer coffee with the donut !

We didn't plan on coming here after getting coffee. We had time to kill, so why not try doughnuts that is over rated! 

We got some basic ass doughnuts! It's average at best. Compare to a known doughnut place like Krispy kream  doughnuts, I would rather pick Krispy kreams over voodoo any day. 

They were good the next day for those who are a fan of stale donuts for breakfast!
It's OK, had two donuts and I definitely had better! Really not amazing!

They're donuts.  They're not remarkable.

But hey, they're unique and have an interesting schtick.  But give me a good ol' fashioned raised donut from any Mom & Pop donut shop anytime.

The BIG plus to Voodoo is they have a killer VEGAN selection that taste EXACTLY like non-vegan donuts.

Visited this place on our family Thanksgiving Holiday vacation after seeing this featured on Guy Fieri's "Diners, Dives and Drive-in's" and loved the pink building and the crazy decor showcasing prices for marriage ceremonies and t-shirts. Also enjoyed the display of the HUGU Zues sized doughnut.
The doughnuts were just okay but the coffee was good (especially on a cold winters day in Portland) but I guess I wanted more. maybe seeing the hype on the show ruined it for me.

3 because it's iconic and was on TV so that's cool. 

But honestly, the quality of the donuts was pretty average. Nothing too mind blowing, and things didn't taste as fresh as other donut places I have been to. 

The people working there should smile more and offer suggestions other than just staring. 

Definitely expected more with the hype it gets.

fun, super sugary doughnuts
always a line - sometimes fun, sometimes infuriating
if you're in portland, just go

Saw a non-stop long line outside of the shop when we were in the area, out of curiosity we stopped by and bought a box togo! I've never seen that many varieties before! Very colorful with icings, decors, fillings, and different shapes, and they have a huge one that is even bigger than my head! I personally like the simple ones, maybe just a little icing, definitely not the ones with fillings, kinda gross me out. And if you are planing to buy a lot at one time, please make sure you eat them right away or within 2 hours the most, or don't stack up cuz they melt pretty fast and would stick to each other. Overall nothing special, guess just the colorful and funny looks make them really good in pictures.

Total tourist spot to go. They are well prepared for long lines. When you step in, you are amazed of the list of donuts that they have. You can see the donuts displayed and you want to try them all. 

I got the voodoo's choice, where they pick the dozen for you. You get a good variety and cheaper than choosing your own dozen.

The guys there aren't the friendliest, by if I were open 24/7 and serving donuts all day, I might not be that cheerful.

Voodoo Doughnut is only good the first time around. It loses a lot of its quirky charm pretty quickly. Anyways, I dropped by with friends from out of town because they wanted the experience so I can't say that I was in any way excited to wait in line for 30 minutes for a couple of doughnuts. The quality is regular - nothing that blows your mind. At least it's has a great location next to the Saturday Market.

Hmmm there is good doughnuts and poor doughnuts. This place worths a stop to contemplate the store, but that's it. People are lining up all day for this... Yeah, I did too...
Doughnuts are as huge as greasy, using just all the unhealthy ingredients they found.
Not very hygienic neither, while lining up, saw trays with the doughnuts from the oven just next to a dirty and dusty facing the street.
I didn't follow Yelp this time... it could not be that great with only 3.5 stars, and it was definitely not!!
It's just a tourist trap recommended everywhere

The doughnuts are ok, nothin to write home about, they sure have some origanal ideas like bacon doughnuts or doughnuts that are shaped like a penis and testies. At the end of the day however it is just a gimick to get people to line up around the block and pay way too much for avarage quality junk food. But hey... it works...

Have I stood in that stupid long line before, yes. I get the tourist hype but not sure why a local would ever intentionally stand in that line more than once. The donuts are "meh" at best and the frosted donuts are so sickeningly sweet that even as a sugar fiend I can only eat one without regret. Blue Star is a good alternative and no line or rude hipsters working there.

I can sum up my experiences with Voodoo in one word: YUCK.  As much as I want to support local businesses, I just can't give Voodoo a thumbs-up.  I've tried their doughnuts a few  times, and each time, I took a couple of bites and threw the remainder away.  Once I had a cruller (sp?) at the Sandy location (it was stale and flavorless), once I had a breakfast cereal sumpthinsumpthin doughnut at Back Space (again, stale and icky), and once I had something chocolatey marshmallowey at the downtown Voodoo (yet again very very stale, tasteless and bland, which I find miraculous cuz how can you go wrong with chocolate & marshmallows)? Sigh. I've finally given up on Voodoo. Honestly, I'm baffled by the around the block lines.

So listen. I am a native Portlander. I have lived here for a long, long time. I don't need a bunch of transplant hipsters serving me attitude when I am ordering donuts that look 100 times better than they taste. Drop your attitudes, kids, and remember that no matter what else, you're just a cashier.

I visited here 5 years ago (2010) and never made a review of it. They serve good donuts, heavy and filling. You really only need ONE but feel compelled to buy 12 because the line is so long. It's hyped, donuts in a pink box which the local homeless will request instead of money if they see you walking with that pink box. I say try it once and pass all other times. The city has many donut spots to offer. There are always people carrying them home on flights to LA and its like "Really? We have funky donuts in LA too". This spot may have been one of the early pioneers of unique, innovated donuts but now every city has their own variation of Voodoo

A 100% just a tourist destination aka I wouldn't eat here if I lived in the area, but it's super cute and worth a visit. I had a lot of fun looking at all the different doughnuts and loved the vibe of the place. 

We got the Bacon Maple, Voodoo Doll, Captain My Captain, and Dirt (Oreo).

Bacon Maple was probably the best, but I wish they crumbled the bacon to get it in every bite. The other ones were pretty decent but a tad too sweet. All were super adorable though.

It's worth the trip if you're in town, but probably not if there's a ridiculous line. we went on a Friday around 11 and there was only maybe a 10 min wait. Would also make good gifts - to others in Portland since they can't deliver - as they're at least cute to look at.

P.S. Cash Only

Giving Voodoo three stars because the donut experience was pretty average. Good, not great. They had a fun store front and funky donut names and flavors, but most newer donut stores have similar gimmicks. 

Glad I got to stop by and see what it was all about. I would suggest you go if you've never gone, but you shouldn't feel bad if you missed it or leave it off your trip itinerary.
The unique toppings and quarky themes make them fun, however I don't find them to be that much better than a dunkin in overall tast and quality. Def. a Portland staple though!
Good stuff. Over hyped for sure. Always a great place to bring out of towners. Liked it but unless Im in the neighborhood (never am), I wouldn't make a special trip on my own.
Used to be great when it was dingy and a small shop. Now it's a tourist trap. Better donuts all over this city. Blue Star and Coco for starters (though Coco...seriously, sell some doughnut holes).

These are good doughnuts, don't get me wrong. But the cult-like following is one I'll never understand. I guess irreverent desserts are pretty awesome, but not wait in line for 45 minutes awesome. And while captain crunch and bacon and stuff are fun, you're probably better off sharing a normal fritter--albeit, the size of your face.

Ok, so this might be worth 2 stars, but really its very below average on the doughnut front. The bacon maple bar was stale and the bacon tasted like it was precooked prepackaged possibly not really bacon. The overall quality of the doughnuts is comparable to your average supermarket variety. I recommend you grab doughnuts from your local grocer and put your own bacon on it, if you are desperate to try it. 

The voodoo doll was the only saving grace to bring this above a 1 star rating.

Voodoo is more about the experience and the crazy creations than about a good quality donut. If someone asked me for suggestions for a really good donut, I wouldn't steer them here. But I do recommend it to anyone who is looking for something touristy to do in Portland. It's a long wait for an okay product.
They're dooughnuts. Plain and simple. Worth the wait? If you're into novelty-shaped doughnuts, sure.

I was super excited to try this place since it was so wildly known and this is one of the situations where a place was overhyped. We waiting in line for probably 30 minutes to pick up two donuts. I had the maple bacon and my friend had a donut that looked like a voodoo doll. I thought mine was at most ok and he didn't even finish his. LAME.

Came here stoked and ready to try the Maple Bacon Donut...

They never had it... :(

I don't understand why they wouldn't have their main donut or maybe I just think that and it's their worst seller.  IDK

Line was long but it moved quick enough.  And they only take cash.  There are tables outside for people to sit down and eat.

Make sure if you park in front of the shop to feed the meter, couple cars fot tickets while we were there.

During my first visit to Portland, VooDoo Donuts was pretty much #1 on places to check out. So we waited in line for a half hour, no problem. When we finally got inside we were overwhelmed with decor. It was cool and different. 

When we got to the counter, the employee was as unfriendly as could be. They have a rotating display of the doughnuts but the flavors aren't listed. I asked the employee what the purple donut was, she said with so much attitude "ummm it's probably the grape one." I smiled back at her and said "sorry! It's my first time here. Guess I'm a little unprepared!" And she rolled her eyes at me. Really nice way to treat a paying customer. 

I ended up picking a few that looked good and that I thought could be enjoyed between me and my two friends. One had oreos, one had peanut butter and Oreos, one was raspberry, and one was a plain chocolate. Each of them were so big. None of us were impressed with them... we ended up having to throw most of them away because they were just too much for us. 

I guess it's fun and all to check out if you're visiting Portland but that's all it was - a check off the ole bucket list. Definitely wouldn't come back if I was in the area again after the way we were treated. Also, it's cash only.

Hyped hard. Tourist destination that has seriously lost it's charm due to it's "oh wow, that's SO PORTLAND, gotta go there." Not that great. Try Annie's on NE Sandy.  Downtown location reminiscent of the red light district scene in Total Recall. I got food poisoning from there once when i had a peanut butter and chocolate gross bomb a few years ago. I guess these donuts taste "awesome" if you're wipe-out drunk or starving and living on the streets. Or from out of town and aren't accustomed to confections made by alcoholics and puuuuunkz.

I have been told about this place by a number of former Portlanders and my wife felt it was a must. My wife and I got there at after dinner around 6:30pm and there was a 30 minute wait in line prior to ordering these donuts. Afterward since there is no interior seating we trekked to the bus stop and waited till we hit the hotel before partaking. The location is middle of downtown in a very sketchy area of the neighborhood so if you plan on taking a family then you might want to take your own transportation so that you have a quick escape from the area; this was one of the only areas that I truly feared for my own safety. The donuts were just okay. To be honest, they were better than a supermarket donut but not as good as the donuts I get at my local donut shop so I was somewhat disappointed. If you are not a big donut person then this is a perfect tourist trap for you because they have a number of unique and oddball/gimmicky donuts in which to experience and to overpay for. But if you frequent your own donut shop, don't waste your time or money here unless you would like to partake in an apple fritter which is larger than a pancake; or one of your favorites which has been contorted into an abstract expression of culinary hipsterdom.

My friends, I am going to remove a smidge of the air from the balloon! I hereby jot my heresy against the indomitable pink landmark of Stumptown.

Voodoo is just... a donut shop!

I have nothing against them. I ate their donuts. They're... donuty. 

I will probably in the course of living my life be handed one of their donuts again by some good-natured compadre who has dropped by with a dozen, and I will eat it. But can we return from the stratosphere and be done with inhaling the gas from the whipped cream cannister? It's JUST a donut!
The idea is great... but the donuts tasted like they had been sitting in the shop for weeks. No flavor at all. Just major disappointment.

Doesn't seem clean at all and lines are extremely long.  Don't bother with the one downtown. Go to the eastside one.  You'll spend less time driving there than you will standing in line.
Extremely greasy and sugar coma waiting to happen.  Definitely a tourist trap.  
My kids like to get the $10 bucket of donuts to take to friends parties.  Even so, they never all get eaten.  Even teenagers can only handle so much grease.
The attraction is how weird it is inside and how weird so many of the donuts are.  Weird being a good thing in Portland I can see why it's popular.
Don't be fooled into thinking it's "Mom and Pop". Local owned, yes, but if you've ever run across the owner, he is no version of any pop I've ever known.
Good Marketing and feature on DDD is the only reason they are popular.
If you want good donuts there are other places you can Yelp in Portland.

Wow, open 24/7. If you go after dinner, around 9:30pm, there's pretty much no line. Cash only.

Voodoo has a vibe of young, hip, fun. Fun decor, fun donut names. For the price of one donut at Blue Star (the more sophisticated, elegant donut shop), you can get 2-3 donuts at Voodoo.

If we are talking about the quality, consistency, and flavor of the donut/dough itself (not the toppings or glazes), I think the two shops are pretty comparable. I have a slight preference for Voodoo because it has more cake/old-fashioned options (well, it has way more options in general), including the simple chocolate glazed one (nothing is simple at Blue Star).

You take kids to Voodoo. You take mom and dad to Blue Star.

Like Katy says, if you're not bringing a newb through Portland, there's no point in really coming here.  

No, the doughnuts are not the tastiest, but they definitely are the weirdest, which is why it earned a few spots on the Food Network and why most of us flock to it when we're in town.  This place is purely about the novelty and sometimes the novelty means standing in line in the cold and/or rain for a really long time before you get a few bizarre doughnuts.  I remember when this was the only place that did the maple bar bacon thing but now that's old news, and unfortunately so is Voodoo in my book.

If you MUST have a pink, "magic is in the hole", voodoo doughnut box and you're stuck in line, head on over to Voodoo Doughnut Too on Davis, it has indoor seating space which means a roof when you have to wait.  It was also the one my (I wish!) future husband Adam Richman went to. Hell, I'll just say it. he's the only reason I go!

Why do people line up for this place?? The donuts here are sugar overload. Maybe it's because I lost my sweet tooth, but the donuts here taste like straight up sugar. I only bought 2 donuts to try and was only able to eat half, before tossing the rest away. If you love sugary donuts then definitely give this place a try. If not, stay far away.

I don't get it.  Tourist trap.  Long ass line.  Not worth it.

Had the obligatory maple bacon bar.......good.

Lemon chiffon cruller......also good.

Both were too sweet for my liking and they gave me donut tummy like NO ONE'S business.  

They are just doughnuts with colorful toppings and sexual innuendos in their nomenclature.  

I would normally give this place three stars, but given the hype and long lines, it harbors a sense of inconvenience which, frankly, isn't worth it.

Personally I ate off the food truck version, and found it just ok.

Nothing special other than the unusual combinations.

The service was...servicable, but I've had much better doughnuts in my day.

It may be better after waiting in a line at the location, or getting them 'fresh' (hot)

Two stars for creativity, but that is about all they have going for them.  The doughnuts are just terrible.  My maple bacon bar was so sweet that it literally made my teeth ache.  All of the doughnuts we tried had a funky taste and did not taste fresh.

TOURIST TRAP!

Yeah... not so much a fan as the hordes of reviewers on here.. 

Yes, they were indeed featured on the Amazing Race. Sure, they're about funk, perform weddings, keep hours well suited for goths/vampires, will shape some dough and chocolate n make it all phallic fun, but somehow, the actual taste of these donuts is lacking!!!!

We used to stroll downtown enough to be almost a lot....and having passed it dozens of times, have only really frequented it (less for the pizazz than for the want of real donuts) and left kinda irresolute on the matter. Was that really it? errrR

Someone please confirm that their oversized popularity is more about oversized personality and eccentricity than taste of every diabetic's kryptonite?

I have to say I have never been to a landmark joint and given such a low rating (check my reviews I'm not kidding) 

It's not that I don't understand the novelty or the rarity of what voodoo is trying to accomplish but everything from the experience to the actual doughnut is tasteful. The dough is bland, to thick and nothing special. If they didn't later this doughnut with colors and shapes of inappropriate nature no one would buy two let alone 12 at a time. Even with all toppings in the world that they put on, it doesn't make it taste any better. It's sAd I had such high hopes. 

So to wait in line in the cold and in a part of town where the homeless harass you knowing you have cash on hand, it's not worth going to again. It's a unique landmark for sure and I would not shame someone for experiencing the disappointment like myself. 


**** but if you are going to stand the line order the bucket of previous shifts assortments. It's $8 and you get like 40 doughnuts lol. Wish I would have known that earlier and trust me the extra hours those doughnuts sit out don't change their flavor. ****

Meh. If you're an tourist, then absolutely go for it! If you love sugary cereal and frosting in a variety of combinations all on a shitty doughnut: absolutely. But if you're looking for a quality treat then move along.

Definitely overhyped place but if you'll in Portland, you are required to try Voodoo Donuts at least once! Lines are extremely long but if you know a local, they will most likely tell you when to go to avoid a line. 

My friends and I basically got one of each donut to try. After trying them all, they were definitely overly too sweet for me and the only one that I liked was the Cock-n-balls donut! It had bavarian cream and chocolate.

Candybar in San Francisco showcases Voodoo Donuts' famous pink box in their restaurant! Every time I see the box, I get excited because I know where the box is from!

Apparently as I get older, I find myself acquiring more of a sweet tooth. Up until a few years ago, I would've opted for a pork chop for dessert. And forget about ever having anything sweet for breakfast. Savory all the way, baby.

So now I know why seniors retire, move to Florida, and always have to eat pie for dessert. It's because they're stuck in an old folks home with no visitors, wearing Depends, gumming mashed peas and green Jell-O, and playing Bingo with an old geezer named Gomer. 

Sugar has become their only joy in life.

As this epiphany dawned on me, now I also know why I'm not as choosy with my sweets and why I can actually tolerate waiting in line for a freakin' sugary artery-clogging, muffin top-inducing doughnut (or two) for breakfast. 

It's because of bacon. Yes, the bacon on the glorious Bacon Maple Bar. No longer is it just a sugary doughnut, but now it has become a savory-salty-sweet meal. The savory-salty always cancels out the sweet, and thus we have zero calories and zero guilt (especially when you eat standing up). 

So kids, today's lesson is:

a) Don't move to Florida.
b) Don't get old.
c) Don't make friends with an old geezer named Gomer.
d) Always eat standing up.

The correct answer is:
a) Don't move to Florida.

You go here once for the experience, but that's about it.  There are far better donuts elsewhere in town, and without the long line.  Skip them if you have any kind of dietary consideration.  While they do have vegan options, there is no ingredient segregation-- great if your dietary restrictions are a personal choice, not so great if you're trying to have a day out and one of your kids has an allergy.

They're a classic part of the Portland experience, and a tasty snack after Dante's Sinferno Cabaret lets out.
It's such a touristy place and when I get them I spend the whole day burping them up. I don't find them to really be that special but I do enjoy that they're open 24/7
This isn't a great donut, and it's a weird tourist thing. All-around gimmick.

Two stars for the experience, great job building up the hype!!!  We tried voodoo, hibiscus, dirty old bastard and a coupe of others, they all taste the same!!! Just swallow a lb of sugar, same thing...  if you want real flavor, just go to blue star donuts, so much better quality and taste!!

Was on a trip from out of town. We were warned by a local friend not to go there, that it's just an overhyped donut store that isn't even that good.

We didn't know where else to go, so we just thought "eh, lets try it out. it was on the top food list on tv and the donuts online look pretty awesome". So, lame. Line took forever, which I didn't mind until we got in. The prices are through the roof ($5 for a donut with a few ingredients?). They didn't even have any Oreo donuts (which I had made my mind up on before we got in).

The service was terrible. Way too rushed. No excuse for the workers to be anything but super friendly, they get hired on knowing exactly how busy the place gets and that it's mostly tourists.

Not worth it.

I don't understand the attraction. These are the worst donuts around. Seriously. Most of the time they are stale, or taste like they've been dropped on the ground -- probably outside -- where the local denizens barf, sleep, shit and piss.

Hey, there's an idea: a piss-soaked doughnut! What do you say boys? Fire up the oven and turn 'em out by the truckload. It'll probably be a big seller because, let's face it, when you wait in line for over an hour, you'll eat anything.

Suckers!

I've been to Portland multiple times but have never been to Voodoo - partly because every time we drive by or walk by there's a long ass line that I don't want to wait on.Luckily, one of my friends woke up early and decided to get in line. I tried some of the doughnuts and I didn't think there was anything special about them. Yeah sure, they look cool but they look better than they taste.

Eh. Overrated. The ambience of this place is obviously super cool and so are all the combos of donuts you can get, but really the dough is not that great. The donuts don't feel super fresh and fluffy like I think they should. I've had way better simple donuts at hole in the wall joints. I think the dough is one of the most important parts of the donut! You gotta do it right and keep it fresh. Not only that, but all the toppings like chocolate and maple cracked when a piece of the donut was torn off. This to me screams old donut! It shouldn't be hardened. I'm glad I tried it out, but I would probably skip out next time. We tried 7 different ones and the hibiscus donut was definitely my favorite.

This donut shop is a cute little place with a sitting area on  the outside of the store. There is no sitting area on the inside. It has tons of cute decor on the inside and a rotating glass tiered stand of donuts. 

I went with a group of 8 girls. We got in and out super quick. I was pretty happy with my voodoo donut in the shape of a doll with a chocolate too and jelly center. There is definitely a huge selection.  Some of the other ladies were not as pleased or impressed.  I think we had hyped ourselves up too much about it. 

It is a good spot for the experience when visiting Portland. But it isn't a place I feel like I HAVE to go back to when I return to Portland.

A place for ass clowns and name droppers to stand in line for mediocre doughnuts.  If you are a vapid and silly dipshit, you'll love this joint.

If you just like doughnuts, go to a local doughnut shop and buy their stuff.  It's better.
the bacon maple doughnut is very good, but this place is basically a tourist trap and not worth the hype.

The place is kitschy and is famous for it, but the hype isn't really worth it beyond the kitsch and a decent doughnut. 

If you're a Dr. Who fan, you're familiar with the phrase "it's bigger on the inside;" well, this place is the opposite of that. It's tiny. You wait outside in a long line with the other tourists [raises hand - yep - me too], and you can read the menu along the outside wall, sort of. It's not exactly organized and it's kind of hard to see the descriptions. We ended up looking on our phones and got the better details that way. 

The staff is less-than-friendly, which honestly I can understand, given that, at least on the day we were there, it was record-high temps, and there didn't seem to be much air conditioning inside (or maybe because the door was constantly open, it was hard to tell). 

Then when you get up there, you've got to know exactly what you want, so hopefully you read and figured out the menu because you've got a ginormous line of people waiting behind YOU. Tick tock, my friend. They don't give the impression you can ask questions... it reminds me of the Soup Nazi from Seinfeld (wow two TV references in one review... do I win a prize or something?!). Walk up, make your order PAY IN CASH ONLY - move along. 

Yep -- they ONLY accept cash. They have an ATM on the spot, but just bring your cash with you. 

And the doughnuts? They were good. We took ours in their signature pink box and went home to our family's place. Generally they were extra sweet (cloying I'd say), and creative flavor combos for sure. 

It's something to see once, but we won't go back the next time we visit. Definitely not worth the hype, but it was something I wanted to do because I'd seen them on my favorite shows and now I can say I did it.

I waited 45-mins along with all other tourist. I heard mixed reviews about this and was not sure If I should waste 45-mins and couple of dollars and this is Cash Only. I thought why not since I'm here in Portland for 1-more day. Now on to the doughnut. I ordered regular glaze and other weird name doughnut that had cream inside and chocolate. Long review short. It tasted like your regular mom and pop doughnut shop! The taste is mediocre and I only enjoyed the Glaze. I was not all that disappointed because others had said the same thing and I tasted the why and how. Will I come here again. Only if the line is short and I'm hanging out with who never had a Voodoo doughnut to show them its not all that and its hype!

Eh. Nice to say I've been there. I was extremely fortunate (so I hear) that the line was short. Definitely not worth the wait if the line is long, though. 

PS: I have never really understood the attraction of fancy doughnuts: I love a perfect, warm from the kettle, raised and glazed doughnut, so I'm definitely not in the target demographic for this operation.

Theyre dirty old bastard doughnut is my favorite, good for chocolate and peanut butter lovers. They line is long so expect to wait. Good place to go if you've never been. Not the best doughnuts ever but you go more for the experience than anything else.

Have to say we did wait along time and we got in and got ourselves a donut.  That it, we had a donut.  Guess nothing more to say, I ate it and it was gone. No more donut, 

Its unique and alot of choices but if you want standard chocolate covered or maple donut why go to the trouble.

Five stars simply for bucking the trend of generic plain doughnuts. Five stars for novelty. Three stars for actual taste. Three stars for price.

Blueberry, bubblegum (with bubblegum in wax paper attached), voodoo doll, raspberry filled, Portland creme, plain sugar, tang orange dipped and dusted. Total cost for seven doughnuts? Over $15 dollars. Not to say that's expensive but in comparison to every other doughnut shop from boring to boutique, that's on the high end of price spectrum.

Enjoyed these in the morning with a tall dark coffee with an extra espresso shot. The voodoo was great for novelty, raspberry for blood, the pretzel stick for a dagger through the heart. But the problem is the novelty wears off and you have to actually eat the doughnut sponge bread. That was the problem. Of course, the plain glazed classic is the defacto basic comparison, where the breading is evaluated. It tastes like it should but is dry and waxy, and the texture is like wonder bread that has gone stale. This is where a standard glazed from Krispy Kreme rules over all other doughnuts and the reason it does. 

The best of the bunch was the blueberry, which had a crunchy sugar glazed exterior (like an old fashioned) and a gooey soft interior with blueberries - it looked totally different than the rest of the doughnuts breading. The second best was the Portland creme which is chocolate coated, custard filled, with 2 dots of white frosting. The orange tang with 3 marshmallows on top and gum flavored glazed were strictly novelty and were not eaten after the first tasting bite. The plain glazed was awful and worse in every way than your generic 35 cent local grocery store offering.

CASH ONLY at their shop, keep that in mind. Loud boombox makes it hard to order food but is quite fitting to the eclectic interior, doughnut selection and staff.

In conclusion, the novelty and experience and effort to make doughnuts appealing through novelty earns Voodoo Doughnuts a must-see while in Portland. 

3/5 stars: A-OK!

Ridiculous shit hole. Please stop with your over-priced, overly sweet, poor excuse for a doughnut and run, don't walk, to either Helen B's or Sesame Doughnuts for some real, delicious, perfect treats.

Seriously! Don't waste your time on the hype! Not worth it!

How disappointing. I LOVE donuts, so naturally I ordered the Voodoo dozen for the family to experience the full effect of Voodoo's best. Half of the dozen were regular donuts, we had to order a voodoo as an extra. The mascot isn't even part of his own dozen. I have yet to taste a donut I would drive over 1,000 miles to crave. I was excited for the voodoo experience and even made it part of our family vacation, but the small cramped space, underwhelming donuts and unfriendly service made for a lackluster experience. The abysmal traffic caused by an inch of snow in Portland made it the worst decision of the journey.

In this day and age, if an independent business wants to get ahead, they have to either accept multiple forms of payment or have a readily accessible ATM. They should also probably make a product better than the national chains (i.e., Krispy Kreme).

I've been to both Portland locations and I just can't seem to see what the hype is all about. Sure, they are creatively named with interesting flavors, but they are still just a mediocre doughnut.

Long line is painfully slow, if you just want to try their donuts, go to the East side location, its fairly vacant most of the time. If you're lucky, you'll catch a wedding there too!
Just bad donuts here. Good to have for novelty or if they are free or something. But not worth it to wait in any sort of line for these very dry donuts

The doughnuts here are creative, but I do have to admit they're way too sweet for my liking. On top of that, I'm not too big on the prices for the doughnuts since they didn't taste too fresh (seemed like they were sitting there for a while). Honestly, I can say that this is just a tourist attraction we're all bound to visit.

The doughnuts are overly sweet and if you take away all of the toppings and bite into a simple glazed doughnut there is little left to be said. Ordinary at best. 

I understand why people come here though: Food Network, hype from other people, the long lines out the door, the name, the inventive combinations, etc. but when it comes down to the actual doughnut and taste, it is not mindblowing. In fact, I've had a lot better. Their fruit flavors are artificial which is such a disappointment and I was hoping they would use some better quality bacon on top of the maple bacon doughnut. I feel that if you're going to put a piece of bacon on top of a doughnut then you should use a really good high quality maple applewood smoked bacon.

Gonna keep it short and simple.

Worth trying out for the novelty factor and entertaining doughnut creations.  It may have been all the hype leading up to it, but my actual enjoyment of my treat was only meh.  

I would be willing to try again, but I am in no rush to do so based on my first experience. Your mileage may vary.

Honestly, I think Voodoo is all about the novelty of its cool/funny/weird shaped donuts. It's great that it's open 24-hours but the donuts themselves aren't mindblowing, and I don't think it's worth a wrap-around-the-store long wait. If there's not much of a line, I'd definitely swing by because it's such a quintessential Portland attraction, but don't come expecting uhhhmazing donuts here. (If you're looking for delicious donuts, go to Blue Star!)

"Now go do that voodoo that you do so well." as Harvey Korman as Headly Lamar once said in Blazing Saddles.  I finally got into Voodo on a rainy Tuesday night (the last time I visited Portland, the lines were around the block, and we never go to try them).  So, this time, the line was only 3 people, so I had to go all in.  I bought a dozen to bring into work the next day choosing the "They Pick" option so the worker just through in the best-ofs into the signature pink box and I was on my way.  I enjoyed the atmosphere of the store with the crazy things all over the walls and the "carousel" of donuts parading in front of you in the cases.  Sure they have some crazy looking ones, I wanted to try a bite of several.  My willpower held out on the MAX light rail back to my hotel, and I managed to bring the box in for my coworkers to enjoy the next morning.  Between 6 dudes, we were able to polish off the box before lunch, so that is saying something, but not saying a whole lot as they would eat anything for free.  I got to try the butterfinger donut which was pretty good.  And between mouthfuls, the other guys enjoyed the M&Ms, Cookies and Cream, Maple Bacon bar, Fruit Loops, and other cream filled delights.  I found the actual donut I had to be just regular/normal and not super exciting in terms of cake flavor, thus my 3 star rating on the actual product.  I definitely think this is a cool place to visit and one of Portland's treasures, but I would not wait in line for more than 10 minutes to enjoy their product.

As a tourist in Portland, this was one of the stops that we were stoked about.  After walking by 30 or so "urban outdoorsmen" down the streets of downtown Portland, we finally got to this hole in the wall doughnut shop.  The line was out the door, but moved surprisingly fast (+1 star).  The menu was really trendy and had a creative assortment of doughnuts ie. cock n balls, maple bacon bar (+1 star).  My friend and I tried the giant oreo peanut butter, maple bacon, and buttermilk bar.  They were overwhelmingly sweet and I was only able to eat about a couple bites at a time (+1 star).  

If it's your first time in Portland, I'd say check it out.  But, if I lived nearby I would probably not be a regular.   

CASH ONLY. They have an atm in the store.
The experience may be five stars, for the revolving doughnut display and interesting neighborhood.  The doughnuts are a disappointment,  I bought three and ate only half of each,
Meh.  Iconic and great at the novelty? yes.  Tasty? no

Couldn't believe that I had never been to Voodoo Doughnut! Luckily the line wasn't that long, but it's hard to make a choice when you feel like you have to get in and out that quickly. I settled on the tasty-but-boring jelly doughnut, while my companion got the trusty maple bacon. She loved it! Mine was good, but honestly nothing to write home about.
Good doughnuts but not worth waiting in the looooong line.

the doughnuts are good but not wait in line forever good...
more of a tourist trap

I personally think the doughnuts are too dry. Perhaps, I just never had the opportunity to get'em fresh. I just think I've tried better. The best part about this place is the pink boxes the doughnuts ride in on the way home.

I do not know the reason or the excuse to why this place is always dirty! I've been here several times and the dirt looks as if it never left. Sure, it gets dirty from the customers but I'm also talking about the walls and the display case by the cashiers. I would feel more comfortable ordering if the place were a little cleaner.

I'm enough of an old Portland hipster to remember when this place was only open after 11:00. Back then, my high school friends and I would go here as part of a late-night adventure.

Now it's open 24 hours a day and it can be impossible to get into the restaurant. Some of the donuts are very good, but others are to be consumed only for the novelty (Tootie Fruity doughnut, anybody?). It's not that the doughnuts are bad, but doughnuts are one of those foods where even bad doughnuts are easy to eat. It's just sugar with more sugar. If you're a Portland native, just go to Sesame Doughnuts or Heavenly Doughnuts. Better prices and shorter lines are found elsewhere.

Had no desire to come here but I was awake super early and had time to kill. 5 person line at 730am took 15 mins. I got a half dozen to sample. Very creative but these are definitely not anything special. Peanut butter oreo and other oreo one were the favorite. i know this place may have started the maple bacon donut craze.....but a lot of places have it now and it tastes the same almost everywhere. 

Had a beer in the area later that day and saw a 200 person line. I laughed. Retarded.

Donut quality is the worst.  It is overrated. I feel like if this is one of the things that makes Oregon unique, well then we are in trouble.  I understand people mostly go there for the experience, but when an employee sexually harasses a customer, I don't think that should be a unique experience. So if sexual harassment is ok, and being rude to a customer is considered expressive, excuse me I think not.  It just shows to me the distance a person is willing to go to show their ignorance.

I was highly disappointed with the donuts considering all the hype it had. The taste is good but short of fantastic. Make sure to get only the newly baked ones to save yourself the same disappointment.
