Honestly, their donuts taste better than your average target or Walmart donuts but not as good as the hype(as usual). Yes I enjoyed the donuts and the line wasn't that bad when we went but what really ticked me off was the customer service. NOT WORTH THE DONUT. The workers did not look welcoming or friendly and were not helpful what so ever. The whole time I was there(about 20 minutes) I only saw ONE worker smile ONCE. I just shook it off as they were tired or something. When it was our turn to get our donuts, the cashier we had just stared at us so we just decided to point out the donuts because most of them didn't have names. This was our first time and didn't know how they work. My mom was trying to point out the donuts and the girl just kept staring at us and my mom thought it was because it was too loud in there to hear so my mom raised her voice a bit and the girl just kept staring at us(I learned after that they just type in the donuts then go back and pack them). After about 5 minutes of struggling, my aunt went to the next cashier who was open and asked for help which we received finally. This girl honestly wasn't much better. She got our orders in but she didn't look like she wanted to help. I'm usually not picky on customer service. Please just smile or at least help clarify things and I'll be perfectly happy. Customer service here ticked me off big time.
Definitely only successful because of it's attraction to tourists. There are so many better doughnuts out there.
I'm not sure what the hype of waiting in line for 30 minutes is all about for donuts that are just ok. They're funny, yes. Tasty, not so much.

I recently went to Voodoo and got the classic dozen doughnuts for work. I had no trouble getting to my order filled save not realizing that it was a cash only establishment. the doughnuts were very very sweet. A coworker noted that her doughnut was very doughy and did not  care much for it. The counter staff was pleasant enough though perhaps slightly on the curt side. Hey it was Saturday morning it happens.

Meh. Got half a dozen to share with friends... only really liked the Dirt (Oreo with vanilla frosting) & butterfinger (chocolate cake donut)... and get the voodoo doll bc it's the most original. Cereal ones were the least fav of the group. Go once for the experience, but not a repeat spot

Yes it's a pretty good doughnut. The dough has a good texture and the raspberry filling, very tasty. If you didn't have to wait for hours just to get your hands on one, I'd say this place was four stars. But it's really a lot of hype.

Kudos to the shop for being really creative with their donut recipes. Lots of cool ideas.

Err, definitely overrated. I am sorry! 

I would skip the line, skip stumptown, skip errthang and go to a more Pip's or Blue Star. The line goes by pretyt fast, but it was at least a 30 minute wait for us. The outdoor seating was not the best view. 

I got the maple bacon, this is the first time, I did not like bacon. Although it is fresh, it tasted something like I can find at any local doughnut shop minus the crazy colors and designs. My friend got the the actual voodoo doughnut/freaky looking ginger breadman. She said it was out of the ordinary.

The novelty of the shop is better than the quality of the donuts, but it's worth a one time stop. The line was really long, but the wait was not bad at all; maybe 25 minutes.  

We tried nearly all of the donuts on the menu. Some of the best were The Loop, the chocolate French Crueller, and the Raspberry Romeo. 

They accept cash only, so stop by the ATM first. There's one nearby but the service fee is $3.00.
Great doughnut selection but nothing to write home about except the many unusual types of doughnuts offered.  Expect to wait in line for a while if you do on a weekend.

Thanks to the Food Network and other exposure the whole world seems to think this is some sort of awesome doughnut place and putting Oreos on a relatively stale fat conveyance is worth a 40 minute wait.  It's like the soup nazi from Seinfeld but without the good soup.

My suggestion: Find ANY fresh doughnut just about anywhere. Go to Safeway and buy yourself some cereal or pre-cooked bacon. Apply and eat.

This place is to Portland as Fisherman's Wharf is to San Francisco. Complete and total tourist trap. If there was a Joe's Crab Shack and someone selling shot glasses the trapping would be complete.

Voodoo is a appropriate name for the creative yet barf like "donuts" that this scary not-so-cool-HOLE-IN-THE-WALL is serving!  
I've lived here in Portland for almost three years now and I recently went in for dessert, (also part of the reason I have temporarily given up eating sugar altogether), after a wonderful and expensive meal at Kincaid's and BOY WERE THOSE DONUTS DE-CUSS-TING!!!
They seriously had me "Driving the Bus" and or "Worshiping the Porcelain Goddess" ALL NIGHT LONG!!!  I can't remember the last time I puked so much and it really bummed me out since my girl and I had had such a delicious meal with great service over at Kincaid's only to see it all come right back up!  Yep, that place is perfect for unsuspecting tourists who want to see the weirder side of Portland but I'll never do that to anyone I'll without first warning them BIG TIME!!!

Decent doughnut, good price.  A little too hyped up, and the staff attitude reflects that.  Still, as a Portland tourist for a couple of days, a trip to Voodoo was necessary.  

Cash only, so be warned.
Overpriced, stale, touristy. Go to a real doughnut shop if you care about quality. Anyone can put a piece of bacon on a maple bar.
Donuts were good, but the leaking roof and buckets of brown water on the floor gave us pause to wonder how clean the baking was.

I really don't understand why this place is popular. I was one of the many people that was suckered into coming here because of mainstream media. The donuts were cold and tasted stale. Luckily we came in the morning so there was no line. Do yourself a favor and go to blue star instead. 

Giving it 1 extra star for their marketing skills as they are able to attract customers while still serving a mediocre product

I gotta say I don't give two stars very often, but the service here is unbelievably bad! Being a tourist to the place I thought I'd check the place out, the donuts are ok, gotta say not the best. However the service! oh my god I've never experience such bad service, the people are just plain RUDE! The lady keep screaming at people at the doors, huddling people close together in line, and the guy who helped me at the cashier didn't even want to listen to my order! Was a request for separate boxes too much when you saw there was TWO of us ordering??? He did not even wants to listen to anything we say or help us with anything. I will NEVER recommend this place to anyone! and would NEVER come back!

This place is legendary although I unclear why. Long lines most hours of the day. We were staying across the street at Embassy Suites and our window overlooked their store. It was about 730AM and low and behold there was NO LINE so decided to stop on in to see what the fuss was about. Yes, the place has funky,/cute decor,the donuts  have hip and catchy names and a few of them (like to voddo doll) are unique but it all ends there. At the end of the day these are run of the mill DOUGHNUTS and its all in the presentation. Not worth the time or effort to fall in line for. Certainly go if the opportunity arises when it is devoid of customers. Caution to the gentrified- this is close to the area where a lot of riff raff hang out.

Tourist donut shop often with a line of out of town-ers looking for famous Portland donuts. You would be better of and one of the other better tasting donut shops in Portland. II have been more than once due to it being close to me but otherwise avoid.

So overrated. So crowded. So basic. I had the pleasure to try it first in LA before trying it in their original hometown.  I've tried their ODB, specialty voodoo donut and their Portland cream.

Luckily I've only waited in line at this location for about 15-30 minutes. Thanks goodness for perfect timing otherwise I don't know what's the hype. The only that got me is the bread part of the donut. It's like a donut. Sadly they just put random stuffs on their donut and call it "get weird" Portland. Haha! Sorry guys, go to Blue Star Donut!!!

So you've come to Portland to check out this 4 star 2000 review joint.

Regardless of what the nay sayers say you will still check out this place but really wasn't worth my time (5 min wait on a Thursday morning) nor the space it wasted in my stomach. Portland being a big foodie town, I'd rather have some thing else.

But go ahead, follow the herd just to say you've tried it.

It's just okay. Cash only. Cramped. A rite of passage for Portland, it seems. The donuts aren't hot and made on the spot like Pip's. They're actually diabetic inducing with the amount of sugar atop! They're cold and just typically breaded inside. I cannot say it was fluffy. It's hard to eat a whole donut. We all shared a bunch. 
They didn't have any plastic knives there, so we all put our grubby hands on there and took a bite!

It's one of those things to try when in Portland .
Allow extra time to find a parking spot and expect at least a half hour or more wait in the queque and bring cash ( it's cash only)
I got the crafty, Voodoo Doll (Raised yeast doughnut filled with raspberry jelly topped with chocolate frosting and a pretzel stake)-  I find it too sweet to eat more than one. 
Won't be back.

This may sound like sacrilege to some but this place is the epitome of Mehhhhhhhhhhhh.  The donuts are OK, but I just dont get the worship Voodoo Doughnuts gets. 

Perhaps its just a case of over-hype or maybe the hipsters just get down here because of admittedly cool vibe and counter culture under-currents but the quality of the donuts receive is essentially the same as what you receive at any neighborhood doughnut shop. 

Avoid the 45 minute wait in the rain and go somewhere else.

Heard a lot about voodoo doughnuts and honestly they are highly overrated. I tried four different doughnuts and all of them were mediocre. They were sickeningly sweet and not that flavorful, so i gave my leftovers away. I liked the metal playing in the store but that's its only redeeming quality.

Not as big of a thrill as I expected. But I guess it would be tough to live up to the hype of this way over-hyped doughnut shop. Yeah, they do some wacky things to carb cakes. Adding cereal as a topping has almost become a genre with them. The doughnuts themselves are a-okay fine.

Too sweet, even though I have a sweet tooth.

I happily dissected the VOODOO DOLL as it turned into a GRAPE APE, holding a BACON MAPLE BAR in its hand so it can MCMINNVILLE CREAM me with a MAPLE BLAZER BLUNT. Those DIRTY OLD BASTARDs were plain fun to play with. ok. I guess I can deal with the hyperglycemia in this case.

Make sure you consume 'em asap, too, as the doughnuts are heavenly when fresh but their godliness depreciates exponentially every other hour.

And honestly, do they really have an "off-hour" on the weekend? I enjoyed the one-hour wait with Mr. K, yet being able to get what I want within 5min on a late weekday morning was probably more efficient use of my time.    

I came here to see the naughty doughnuts twice, but I couldn't spot them anywhere! (disappointment...)
These are basically grocery store donuts. Very inefficient ordering system means huge lines.  Bunch of hype.  For a real donut go to blue star.

Ew. Why is this place famous? None of the donuts in the display case looked remotely appetizing. We ordered the craziest flavors for fun, and everything tasted as disgusting as it looked.

Avoid the captain crunch, the coco puff, and the shredded coconut + peanut butter donuts. *Barf*

It's more about the theatrics here. It's a fun place for sure but the donuts are really not that great. I did enjoy picking out fun donuts from this establishment but I was expecting more from the actual taste of the donuts. Fun place, definitely worth checking out just got get too excited if you're a donut aficionado.

I feel like this shop was not bad but, mostly hype. 

We waited in a long line with the midday sun beating down on us. We didn't mind, however, because we were getting doughnuts that people swore would make it worth the wait. 

We both got the Voodoo doll and a few others. The jelly filling was a little overkill for us but, it was still delicious. Our biggest concern was the toppings, including chocolate M&Ms and crushed Oreos, were very stale. That took away from the experience for us A LOT. 

Other than that, these were really tasty and we both appreciated the doughnuts with vanilla icing. Yum!

I would still recommend this shop to others, especially if visiting from out of town, for  the novelty alone. It's a Portland must-see.

Great place to take friends from out of town. Not the best donuts I've had, but they definitely have some really creative variations (think bacon, breakfast cereal, candy). Often has a long line on the weekends.

The donut was fantastic. I got an Oreo donut that was perfect in every way. The service however was terrible. I dealt with two separate hosts and neither one provided any sort of customer service other than taking my money in exchange for pastries. Both hosts were young, tattooed and seemed to hate their jobs. Don't misunderstand me, I have tattoos too but I understand the value of customer service.
Not a doughnut fan to begin with and I thought maybe it would change that about me.  I split one with a friend, ate half of my half and tossed it out.  Not all it was made out to be.

I did not eat here. Hence the neutral rating.

The line was worse than a new rollercoaster ride at Six Flags. 

But, helpful hint - did find Voodoo Doughnut Too across the river! Same donuts, no line, hehe suckers!
It's fine, but I just don't feel any compelling reason to go back. There's just too much better stuff out there
Overrated. They just don't taste good. They LOOK interesting and enticing but we had both the yeast and the cake donuts and they were really sub-par. Blue Star is way better.

Went by 5 times this last weekend.  It's UTTERLY overrun with tourists.  You simply can't get in under a 1 hour wait - and it's NOT worth it.  

All the cool stuff that used to make this a neat place are now killed by all the out of towners gawking and taking 20 minutes each to pick out the 5 donuts they want.  The staff looks like they want to kill themselves, and I don't blame them.  I'd want to kill myself too after watching grandma try to figure out what that d*ck-shaped doughnut is supposed to be and some clueless 'tard from New York tries to figure out which ones will look coolest in his facebook update photo.

Time for me to head to Heavenly Doughnuts.
Yuck! Highly over-rated "dough nuts" that have a doughy consistancy. Love the box though, and see so many of them at PDX.

3 stars for originality, but seriously, the doughnuts are not that great. And definitely NOT worth the line wrapped around  the block. I've never personally had to wait in this line, but I've seen it, it's there every day, I've heard it's an hour long at least! I've had there doughnuts on a few occasions and tried a fair variety, I'd say the voodoo doll was my favorite. Some of the other ones with tons of toppings are just too much to handle!

Nah. Just nah. A tourist thing, and sure, the first time, a doughnut in the shape of a penis is funny? But I'm not crazy about donuts, and after you've had breakfast cereal on a donut once... well you don't really need it again, but it's just my opinion...

First time visiting Portland so I knew I had to try VooDoo Donuts. Honestly, I don't really understand what all the hype is about. The donuts taste like any other donut I've ever had... nothing special. The only thing I can say is that I enjoyed the assortment of flavors and designs. The shapes and designs make the donuts fun to look at but the taste was anticlimactic. I'd recommend Blue Star over VooDoo any day but it's worth a one time stop. In my mind VooDoo = Dunkin and BlueStar = Krispy Kreme.

great donuts!  it just sucked waiting in line for an hour to get them.  i guess if you're going and you really want donuts then its best to buy as much as you can.  i got the voodoo dozen where they pick the donuts for you, its all random.  i still got some good donuts in my box.

I've been here twice and I have to say both experiences was nothing special. I think a local donut shop may offer you a better doughnut. Long lines, dry and overly sweet = totally not worth it.  I felt as if this place is a tourist trap.
So don't get what all the fuss is about???  I waited 15 min in line for what was an average doughnut, just a cold dough ball with cold icing on it.  Never need to go back...
No reason to spend your retirement on a donut....sheesh folks...it's just fried dough.

I recently visited Portland, and had to try VooDoo donut since it made many of the "must sees" in the city.  They have a queue out front for the long line, which even at 11:00pm, was a 20 minute wait.  I ordered three donuts - a classic old-fashioned, the Voodoo donut, and a maple donut.  The old fashioned was the best one, and all of my donuts came to $5.60, which wasn't too bad.  

They are cash only, but there are no signs in the waiting line or front entryway letting you know that.  I waited in line for 20 minutes only to find out from the guy behind the register that it's cash only.  Thankfully my friend I was with had cash, otherwise I would have waited for nothing.  I think Voodoo could do a better job of posting signs at the end of the queue, or at least the entrance to the store.  If there was a sign inside, I missed it because there is so much to look at on the walls and so many other donut and Portland-related signs to read.

This is a great place to see if you're close to one of their locations.  Even looking at their donuts is fun, because they do a lot of neat things with them.  They were yummy, but weren't anything so amazing that I would wait in line for them again.

Why do people go here? Dear Travel Channel or whatever made Voodoo popular, do a piece on Blue Star...just kidding...don't. It's not much of a secret as it is. Voodoo, it is not your fault. You just got too big and you jeopardized quality for kitsch. I'm sure you're just rolling in the...dough.
This place is cool to got to as a tourist, but there are better donut places around.

An adolescent version of me would probably have enjoyed the humor and novelty of waiting in line for 20 minutes to purchase a phallic shaped donut named "Cock-N-Balls", and that seems to be the primary draw for Voodoo Doughnuts. I ordered the "Bacon Maple" and "No Name".  I can only describe the texture and flavor of both as that sticky, gooey texture that most bake goods get when they've been sitting out for too long.  The store itself has a really cool vibe, the décor is fun and the people who work their are cool. Go in expecting a long wait and fun experience to purchase fairly unremarkable, mediocre donuts.

Pshh. It's just a damn donut! They're okay? They out cereal on it. One is shaped like a penis. Yep, that is pretty much it. If you realllllly need a donut. Do yourself a favor and go to their location on Sandy Blvd. it's just over the river and will save you the trouble of waiting an hour in line. ; )

You can't go on a trip to Portland and not get these doughnuts. I'm not a huge doughnut person (or expert), but these were definitely good, and fun!  

The key is to go late at night, we never waited more than ten minutes. 

My favorite doughnut was the Memphis Mafia. It's massive but SO GOOD.  

I also tried: 
VooDoo Doll doughnut- alright, the design was fun, you can't not get one. 
Bacon Maple Bar Doughnut- yummy! We saved it for later and I think it would have been better fresh. 
Triple Chocolate Penetration - alright, nothing to write home about 
Diablos Rex Doughnut- I had high hopes for this one, but it's tiny and not that great. 
McMinnville Cream Doughnut- Love the maple frosting! 
Old Dirty Bastard- My second favorite! The peanut butter and oreo is a great combo
No Name Doughnut- I thought there would be more peanut butter, you couldn't taste it enough. The rice krispies gave good texture but made the doughnut more bland.

I like the concept, the crazy doughnuts, but they're not that tasty. The line is usually long because it's a touristy place but it does usually move fast. I do enjoy the maple bacon doughnut though! Definitely my fave.

SSSSSSSSSSSSOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOO OVERRATED!   

The donuts are fine and kind of creative but totally not worth the long lines.  IF you notice they are empty head on in, but Voodoo does not deserve to be the tourist attraction they have become.

Gotta say this is one of the things in life that is all hype. 
Bought four different kind of donuts. All were Very Dry and overcooked. Possibly instead of making phallic donuts and ones that look like blunts they should concentrate on making a soft melt in your mouth donut. 
Do Not waste your time in line. Go anyplace else. 
Tourist trap that I believe to be a big scam of Portland.

This is a Portland classic, as a tourist it's a must see! But since my sister became a local there are much better donut places in Portland than this.

With that being said, dirty old bastard is my favorite one here!

It's Voodoo Doughnut. If you are looking it up on Yelp! you should already know enough to know that you need to go there at least once and get yourself a maple bacon bar.

Pros:
-It's weird, it's Portland
-The maple bacon bar is the best donut I have ever had 

Cons:
-Lines, lines, lines (only experienced issues with this personally on the weekend and you can mitigate it by getting a cup of coffee from Stumptown down the street for your wait)
-Every other donut (besides the maple bacon bar) I have tried were okay/good, but nothing special
-Price (these are spendy for mostly average donuts)
-Cash only

Neutral points:
-The staff is not rude but not quite friendly, either (I understand, they are focused on getting that line moving)
-Some of Portland's homeless and less well-off citizens will wait outside the door asking for cash (since you MUST have it there) or food. I empathize with their plight and don't blame them.
I wasn't blown away. They looked cool but tasted pretty average. Not worth the line we waited in.

Dropped by this famous establishment from Washington on the way to California in the wee morning hour. The service was good, got myself a shirt as a souvenir, along with 4 donuts that weren't as tasty as they looked..just so-so. There were a couple fat people in line ahead of me with buckets they handed over to the cashier to fill with donuts. I guess them folks love their donuts!

Voodoo in Downtown I went to about 9 years ago. Picked out a doughnut and she told me the price. I gave her the money and she said "We do not take pennies!". I said well here is all my pennies in your tip JAR. Ten I let them know I would not be back. 9 years this week and I still have not gone back. 9 years and never had one. And I am fine with that. I wonder if 9 years later they take pennies now? (it was only 4 pennies for Gosh sakes)
Not good at all

Overrated, in my opinion.

Perhaps it was because I was just getting off a sugar-free existence so my taste buds were super sensitive? I have a sweet tooth normally, but I found Voodoo Doughnut's namesake donut to be cloyingly sweet. Too much so that I was discouraged from trying anything else from their selection.

The lines can be long, but we went around 2 AM so it was not as bad and the line moved quickly. The staff were nice and friendly but it really would be helpful if you used your waiting time wisely and figure out what you want. You would be doing yourself and everybody else after you a huge favor. 

I will try again next time I am in town just to verify that my taste buds were not just off that evening.

These aren't even that good. I think the hype comes from the weird stuff they put on them.   It's mostly a novelty thing.   Now if you want a mouth watering donut go to sesame donut.  They are delicious.
Also its like 3 -5 bucks a single donut... wtf

Meh. I've experienced better. 

Voodoo Doughnut is 100% hype. The line that you have to wait in during normal hours for a subpar doughnut is a sad waste of time. Yes they have a large menu of doughnut, yes some of the doughnut flavors seem original, yes this place is on a lot of "must-visit in Portland" lists, but do not believe the hype!

I came here around 8pm (Voodoo is 24 hour so you should stop by at off hours), and there was only a line of about 10 people, instead hundreds during the day time. My girlfriend and me ordered 5 doughnuts all together. The ones that were filled with jelly made both of us gag. The filling is so sweet, you are guaranteed to have diabetes after consuming a single doughnut. For the ones that were not filled with jelly, you could more clearly tell that the doughnut dough was not done well. Compared to a place like Blue Star Donuts, you can definitely taste that the doughnut is not fresh, and you get an oily taste in your mouth after each bite. Gross! Unlike Blue Star which convinced me to give doughnut a second chance since I actually hate doughnut, Voodoo reminded me again of why I hated doughnut so much in the first place. I would definitely NOT recommend stopping by here. If you want a photo, grab a photo off Yelp and claim it as your own instead of wasting your time here.

This place has "TOURIST TRAP" written all over it. Before going here, you must ask yourself one question: "Do I really want to wait in line for 45 minutes for a sub-par doughnut?". Don't get me wrong, this place is a definite go-to for the typical Portland tourist. However, I wouldn't go here regularly because I would prefer getting my doughnuts and pastries from a local neighborhood bakery in North Portland. If you want to avoid the line, go here during the off-hours (~ 12am - 6am).
the fun thing about this place is standing in line and watching the other donut-buyers.  don't recommend eating the donuts.

I think this place is wayyyyyy overrated!!!! its just doughnuts anyone can make looked like they came out of Susie homemaker kit. cereal on top was the most creative ha! the line is NOT worth the wait. The staff looked like trash like they just got out of bed, everyone had a miserable look on their face and had an attitude to match! no one was helpful or pleasant to talk with. Being it my first time it will definitely be my last! after i gave up trying to decide what to order because clearly the environment was unwelcoming nor did my cashier bother to suggest anything I gave her a $20 only to be accused on giving her a $5 becasue she was distracted by her friend/co worker in conversation. She responded rudely and argued with me saying she had "never been off of her register" i waited another thirty minutes to get my money that was rightfully due. The rude cashier Diana Prince never returned to apologize after such bold statements, another co worker apologized on her behalf but walked away from me before i could say anything... avoid this place your gonna get ripped off!


zero stars!

The ambiance of this place is the best part.  The bright colors, the fun decor and signs, and the doughnuts look great!!  I got lucky and got in Monday evening so there was no one in the place and walked right up to order.

I wish there were signs by what was in the rotating display case, because there were so many different kinds, but I had no idea what was what, and really I just wanted a fun one because that seems to be the point of going here.  I ordered the butterfingering because it sounded good (it was decent) but it ended up being just a plain donut with frosting & butterfinger crushed on top, looked very boring.

Still fun to go and see it and experience it, but really do not need to go back again.
This place is way over hyped fun place but the donuts are just so so... definatly not worth the line.
I honestly don't think that voodoo doughnuts are even that great, I guess its cool that it's one of Portlands iconic places, but those dough need some work
Slightly overrated and always long lines. I'd recommend going to their other location. Downtown is always packed and not worth the wait.

I'm still trying figure out what the big fuss is all about with this place. I don't see how dumping a box of cereal or crushed cookies on a doughnut makes this place special. The doughnuts themselves weren't bad, aside from feeling that I was about to go into a diabetic coma. Lastly, they keep the freshly made doughnuts near a gated door. Not a big deal, but when you have a hundred some odd customers lined up next to it, toking cigarets, one is liable to believe that some of the smoke and flys somehow make their way to the doughnuts. The juice is not worth the squeeze here.
Good doughnuts.  Unique flavors but the standard glazed and cream filled were nothing too special. I don't get the hoopla.
These people are real jerks, they wouldn't entertain a business opportunity. I spoke with the manager he was really transactional with me. No help!!!

I've hit them up thrice now, 1st time before moving to Portland, because well.. VOODOO!  The other two times after moving here a few months ago.  I think they are a good doughnut joint.  The treats are tasty and creative.  They aren't my favorite doughnuts in town, which is why I give them three stars.  Good, creative, but a bit too sweet and overpriced compared to what I can get elsewhere.  You're definitely paying for the experience with this one.
yuck.  Probably the shittiest donuts.  And full of tourists.  Stay away.  Or, better yet, go there and spare us waiting in lines at the good places.

Hubby and I tried this while visiting Portland - it's ok.. we got the famous voo-doo donut... it was fine.  Our son had the old dirty bastard (donut topped with oreo cookie crumbles and peanut butter - i didnt taste it, but he said it was good.  I shoulda tried the apple fritter - it was huge and I didnt want to eat that much.... lots of people coming in to try this place... we weren't that impressed... go if you must. :-)

Overpriced donuts with a side of drug deal.

My third trip to Portland and I finally get to try a damn donut here. I went around 8:30pm on a Friday night and was pleasantly surprised to see a very short line. Problem? No parking......anywhere for blocks!

The line moves pretty quick, do you want to know why? Because the workers rush you and pressure you to hurry the F up and make your decision. Just watching the people ahead of me gave me anxiety. I had to bust out my notepad and write a list of donuts I wanted and mark the  "ifs" in case they are out of the ones I picked. Cash only, there's an ATM machine inside.

It's a great place to try if you're in the area, but paying $$$ for fancy donuts isn't worth it after that. They are good but not blow you away good. The bacon maple was just okay.  

Great place to sit out, enjoy donuts and people watch. A drug deal went down literally 2 feet from me while I was standing in line outside. Can they be anymore obvious??!?!
A variety of delicious donuts, but a very long wait in line. Go to the one by Buckman field for a shorter wait

The donuts are always cold. You'd think that they could serve a warm donut once in a while with their volume. But no. I only really find myself at this joint when I need to entertain an out of town guest that has heard about this place on the Travel Channel or Food Network. There's a certain level of novelty with this place because of the original doughnut creations and the whacked out space. For a decent donut there are some other places I frequent in town over this one, especially if I don't want a street kid or cracked out old guy asking me for leftover donuts or money. DO NOT GIVE THE STREET PEOPLE MONEY!!!!

Are you a toursit? If so I think you will love this place, its weird, and fun, you have to stand in line for a long time, and you have to pay in cash, but compared to most places out there it has a charm its own and you'll certainly find something worth sharing with all your *insert popular social media site* followers.

Locals on the large however adopt a 'been there done that' mentality - if it isn't your first time the line feels awfully long for a cheap treat and with so many good choices in the city stale cereal on an 'ok' doughnut just loses the wow factor.

Vegan donuts are yummy,  but seldom do I go out of my way to go to Voodoo. Well, unless I know someone who just had a vasectomy. In which case, I'd buy a cock'n'balls treat and cut a few slices into the doughy "balls" as a tasty treat for a friend in recovery.
Waaaayy overhyped... total tourist attraction with stale donuts. Go for the novelty, not for good donuts.

Yes Voodoo's is a Portland institution, but let's face it, one really never goes to Voodoo's for the doughnuts. You go to Voodoo's to:
1. For the people watching
2. To say you've been here and cross it off your travel bucket list

This is a Celiac's worst nightmare, but damn it, sometimes I just want to feel like a normal person and have a damn doughnut. Voodoo's do have the typical traditional doughnut's, but they are truly know for their interesting combinations. 

I would seriously recommend checking out their website prior to going and have an idea of what you want prior to ordering, as this helps speed up the line.

I feel the best/worst time to try and get Voodoo's is right after the bars close. It eerily similar to the Vegas airport taxi line at around midnight. Just substitute the ropes for the pink bike racks that keep the line from over taking the sidewalk. If you happen to go in the daylight and at the right time, you could be serenaded by the one and only uni-cyclist, dressed like Darth Vader, wearing a kilt, and playing the Star Wars theme song on the bag pipes. This is seriously the highlight of waiting in line, because the guy has talent to be able to pull this combination of things off. 

They do offer seating outside if you wish to enjoy your sweets shortly after purchase. Also, if you plan to travel back home with any of Voodoo's goods, plan for this, especially if you are flying out of PDX. It takes extra effort to have the pink box make it on long haul flights.
 

**As always, they are 24/7 and CASH only. The do have an ATM onsite if you happen to be in need of cash.

It's really hard for a famous place to live up to all the hype.  The triple chocolate was ok, I thought the Oreo covered ones were great.  I would suggest Blue Collar bakery if you want better quality.

I don't know why people make such a big deal over VooDoo. It's good, but not great. But, to be fair, there really aren't many great donut places out there anymore. They definitely have some good, unique varieties. And it must be nice if you're vegan to have a place to get donuts. I brought some to an event in Seattle, making sure to get a few vegan donuts for someone who I knew would be there and is vegan... She was delighted. She hadn't had a maple bar in years. So, I guess it's great for that, but otherwise, it's just your average donut. Plus, who wants to wait in a line an hour long just to get a donut?

If I only had one word to describe voo doo, it's pretty overrated.  Long lines don't always mean spectacular food.

Granted, voodoo donuts is pretty good, especially when you want a donut fix.  Nothing can beat fried sugary goodness.  But I suppose the niche for Voodoo is all them crazy combinations and toppings.  But really, you can go to safeway, buy cereal and oreos and sprinkle it on top of a donut there.  Ig uess what I'm saying is for a standalone donut without all the frills, it's only okay for me.
Over rated, would not come back. We Tried three different kind in the afternoon and found them to be dry and too dense.

They are expanding, yet... The ONLY reason to come here is for the wonderful staff behind the counter, the decor, giving the tourists something to ogle over, the wacky "Keep Portland Weird" vibe - but NOT the doughnuts, which taste stale. Sorry, folks - fix the doughnuts and maybe I'll come back.

Also, I love doughnuts, so the fact that the quality is so poor makes my pastry-addicted heart cry.

2.5 star for the doughnut - not worth coming if you're expecting a donut better than the basic gas station donut. 
In California there's plenty of Mom and pop shops that have fresher donuts with a lighter consistency for the same or less price.
If you rarely get to eat donuts then I'm sure it will be a treat either way because it's sweet and deep fried. 
If you've had your fair share of delicious donuts from Sidecar, Blue Star, or any other well known places in NY and Chicago, then youll be disappointed.
They use the same base donut for every donut, meaning the batter is the same. (Excluding yeast vs. cake vs vegan) The donuts are not infused with their names-flavor. Just the basic icing on top has some of the flavor it's named after.
Nonetheless, glad I experienced it for $2 but I won't be back.

Over-rated.  Long line, pressure to choose, limited descriptions unless you go online to select.  Donuts were interesting,  but the flavors were not all there.  You have to visit,  just because it is an institution,  but temper expectations

Long line, tons of tourists and all for catchy donut names. I love sweets - but this was too sweet, too dry or too wet (some fillings made the donut mushy). 

Cash only!

If you want an unique, good flavor go to Blue Star Donuts.
Overpriced, overrated, and understaffed. This place is for tourists, which I was. The staff that was working were rude! At 10am they were out of 8 types of donuts.

I'm going to get quite a bit of flack for this, but I'm going to be honest; I'm not a big fan of this place. Let me preface this by saying, I'm not a huge doughnut lover in general, but occasionally, I will crave one. When that craving hits, Voodoo is the last place I will go. I just don't get it. They do make very creative doughnuts, but it seems like those toppings are there either to mask how bland the doughnut itself is, or just to create a hype, something that will be talked about. The doughnuts seem like a poorly thought out art project more than an actually amazing doughnut shop. Don't get me wrong, (most of) their creations are completely edible, but they are not anything that I would ever talk about with a guest from out of town, nor are they something I would go out of my way to get. I've lived in Portland for nearly 4 years, and have been there 3 times. The doughnuts themselves--minus the toppings--just aren't memorable.

My hubby, little girl and I waited 40 min in THE LINE to get into voodoos main location. The choices of donuts are very fun and creative. The quality of donut is decent but really nothing special. We enjoyed the experience but doubt we will brave the line again for a weird shaped or fun colored donut.
Just okay, a tourist spot, not the best donuts in town.

Voodoo Doughnut is interesting. It's an interesting cultural hub of Portland. 3 stars? The doughnuts just aren't that good. Maybe I just don't like doughnuts that much. 

If I was only reviewing the Portland Creme, I'd give it 4 1/2 stars. The other doughnuts were dry and faux-inspired. Not impressed with cereal on doughnuts. 

Go here for the ambiance and the experience. Not for a superior product.
This is an institution...the donuts were a bit over the top. Focus more on taste rather than the sizzle.

Tucci Restaurant in Lake Oswego: decor was pretty okay. The greeter was in a shirt that was bursting buttons at the bottom. His tummy was not the first thing we wanted to see. He had never seen us before so he sat us facing a wall. How lovely. Grudgingly and with a face he moved to another table when we said no thanks for the wall staring us in the face. Greeter did not offer to take our coats but when 'regulars' came in and were seated beside us he was happy to offer to take theirs. 

The so-called chef was less than mediocre! Plus when were seated and my wife noticed him staring at her, she smiled a greeting to him & all he could do was look away, but, he sure had time to chat with the hired help. His food was not close to authentic Italian food. It was just plain lousy.

The only bright spot of an evening when the two of wasted over a $100 at Tucci was our server, David. Friendly, efficient, welcomed us to Lake Oswego & who treated us to a birthday piece of very good ( I doubt made by the cooking staff) cheese cake, candle & all. So sorry, David, but we won't be back

This review is not just another plug for the bacon maple bar, though I will go as far as to call it genius because come on, we all know it is. There are certainly many creations found here worth mentioning, but my purpose in writing a review is not to praise the whimsical pastries spinning in their case like a donut-themed merry-go-round, but rather to comment on the celebrity of the joint. Fame has surely gone to the heads of Voodoo's employees, who seem to recoil from kindness the way an old, bitter crone might when presented with a daisy by her grandchild. Robotic and woefully thin for donut-pushers, Voodoo employees want no part in the joy you derive from their offerings. Like the filling from a jelly-filled donut, resentment oozes out of them as they try to ignore your enthusiasm, and you are forced to think yourself stupid for being so giddy in their presence. But how can you contain yourself in front of such an ostentatiously delicious display that SPINS for pete's sake? If I can't get that kid-in-a-candy store feeling here, where else is there to go? That's why people come here pal, for the outrageous donuts. So you're a tourist destination, accept it.  I'll take my penis-shaped eclair without the proverbial semen from now on, thank you.

unfortunately, i feel it's a little too much hype.  pretty much institutionalized now and overrated because of all the copycats.  quirky donuts without much care (except for the glass case ones for decoration).  for example, the voodoo doll donut icing all messed up (sloppy icing work).  not unique tasting.  bay area has a place like this -- psycho donuts.  as far as maple bacon donut, too bad it's played out.  for unique great tasting specialty donuts, i think of donut plant nyc.  this is one of those places you just need to get out of the way.

First-timers in Portland so we hit all the "musts" (must-sees, must-do's, and yes the must-eats). We braved ridiculously long brunch lines, walked in the rain to hit the coolest neighborhoods, and yes, we looked like complete gluttonous morons standing outside a doughnut shop in a line out the door for over a half hour at 11:00 at night. If you're visiting Portland this is one "must" that really shouldn't be at all. Go to a grocery store, any grocery store, and you'll get an equivalent doughnut. Standing in that silly line is especially stinging too when you learn there's another location, not just in Portland, but in Austin and Denver as well (and probably elsewhere that I don't know about). This was one disappointing tourist trap. 

I give one extra star for their blueberry cake doughnut, which was at least unique and not something you really see anywhere else. Otherwise, you're talking about a standard doughnut with some cereal or cookies stuck to the top and people are falling all over themselves for it.

Overhyped!

An average donut with lots of junk (oreos, cereal, bacon, etc) on top.

But if youre a donut fan like me, definitely recommend a visit here for the quirky ambiance.

Nationwide appeal, literal amusement-park-like queue, decent donuts.  Go once for the experience and then spend the rest of your life pitying the poor saps waiting 45 minutes in the rain for fruity pebble covered mediocrity.  Staff is cool though.

Cool ionic Portland place that offers a different spin on the "average doughnut". I really enjoy the cream filled and apple fritters....which are a must. The three star rating comes because of rude employees, and lines into these places are out of control. Little to no effort is made to speed up the line, in fact it's like they wear it as a badge of honor. Anyways good stuff for the most part.
Tourist trap. They are no better than Safeway doughnuts and you have to wait in line in a sketch part of town to get them. Nothing special about this place except it's famous for some reason.
Nothing special The taste is that of a regular donut at double and triple the price. If you are fascinated by shapes, you are better off buying dolls.
Bleh, it's a frick'n doughnut with excess crap on it.

I'm a huge doughnut fan, but I don't get the hype here. Is it just that it's a Portland tourist attraction?

Luckily, I visited during a time when the line wasn't completely around the corner. My friend and I got a half dozen mix, which included their signature cream-filled doughnuts, voodoo dolls, and Captain Crunch. The toppings are interesting, but at the end of the day, they are just normal doughnuts...and cold at that. As my friend says, "they are run by stoners for stoners," which makes sense if you think about it.

My overall impression is meh. But obviously, people need to experience it for themselves. Maybe there's something I am missing?

Who cares about the doughnuts. It's all about the experience. First you have the methheads swarming around the vicinity begging for dough, with the odd sprinkling of alcoholics sipping out of bags and also asking for spare change. The closer you get the more tbe excitement builds until you push open that door to reveal the palace of the unfortunate workers. All waiting with panting desire to serve you one of tbe many absurd combinations of donuts. Only problem is I think maybe the owners must have applied for a special grant to hire workers who were once beggars.  The one cashier/Donut retriever was part zombie. Yes that's right brain dead. Pointed/gestured  to donuts i asked about, couldnt carry on a conversation and seemed to be looking forward to hanging out with her commrades who circled the building asking for cash. Hey we all work, lets show a bit of enthusism when we have unique product. The street performers were way more interesting.

Sub-par doughnuts marketed mostly for the tourist crowd. As well, cleanliness of the facility is apparently not a priority. Pip's Doughnuts, Annie's Doughnuts, Rockin' Frogs... ALL much better doughnuts and without the tourist trappings of VooDoo.

RUDE. Terrible, stale doughnuts. Cash only?? It's 2013! I keep trying to like this place but... nope. There are so many delicious doughnut places in Portland- why waste your time here?? Stacacto gelato has a unique selection that's fresh an delicious- with wonderful customer service! Coco is downtown, also good. This place is NOT a right of passage- it's a waste of time and money- especially if you are waiting in line. I'm so bummed that this place keeps getting so much publicity.

Honestly, when I first tried these doughnuts - I bought into all their hype. But now having lived in Portland for 5 years now, I have to really let out the truth about Voodoo: SO OVERRATED. I've tried multiple different kinds of donuts, each time hoping for the experience everyone always raves about and each time finding myself sliding down into a terrible, sugar-induced coma. Not to mention, the service staff is always rude, despite having made multiple attempts to be overly nice. 

Overall? Not worth the wait or the price. 
You'll find better donuts in town with Coco's or Tonalli's.
It was dirty, staff was rude, the donuts were "meh".  I think they are trying too hard
I wish they had gluten free donuts! I hear they are amazing but I never get to try any :(

Only come here if you have people from out of town demanding to go here because they saw it on the Food Network or some shit. Yes, you need to placate your out of town guests and that's cool but why on god's green earth you would ever come here on your own accord is beyond me. The donuts are just donuts with cereal on them or bacon. Relax, it's not that cool and they are not the greatest tasting donuts. Heavenly donuts has better donuts, shit even Safeway donuts compare to Voodoo donuts. If you must go there go to the location on Sandy because the downtown location is the size of a Port O Johnny and you will be accosted by people demanding "spare change and/or cigarettes". The staff are good people though.

Great ndonuts!
I can see why this place is so popular. They've really got their niche and branding down, from their neon sign to their pink gate fences to their to go boxes.

Nothing is fresh. The toppings are completely stale. There's a huge line out the door and is not worth waiting in. I visited because I felt obligated to try it as a tourist, but it really was a waste of time. Blue star and other company's are galaxies better. These were the WORST donuts I have ever tasted. They need to learn a thing or two about QUALITY CONTROL.
A Portland classic. One of those things you need to do once but other than one time, just don't! Major problem is the line. Blue star much better quality but voodoo is a treat for sure.

Line was crazy long and the donuts are just ok. Doughboys in Reno Nevada make these seem juvenile in comparison, taste wise. However, the employees are super cool, the ambience is hilarious, and the experience was worth the time we waited. It is a great experience although the donuts are really not any better tasting than any other ma and pa place anywhere in the USA.

Stopped by on a whim while in the neighborhood one day. Saw something about Voodoo Doughnuts on Man vs. Food and figured I'd do the tourist thing.

Now, I'm not a fan of doughnuts (which is ironic considering my line of work). But were I a doughnut connoisseur, I might recommend this eclectic establishment to whatever doughnut loving peers I might have.  

All I know is that I saw a bacon maple doughnut. Perhaps it could be described as an evolution in culinary science. I simply called it bliss. There were many other doughnuts to choose from. I paid no mind to any of them. This was the target of my affection in all its gluttony. Calories be damned.

Doing three stars until I work up the courage to go back and "attempt" to try another varietal of sugar pastry goodness. Also three stars for forcing me to go to the gym. Damnit.
Buy a doughnut from anywhere else, sprinkle cereal or M&M's on it and you've got Voodoo. Why people line up around the block for it is beyond me.
No parking, No cards accepted.  Need I say more?

Warning: Portland tourist hot-spot. The line at the W Burnside will pretty much always be around the corner. The staff is quirky and spunky. The donuts are okay. They taste a little stale to me but to each their own.

If you go really early in the morning 3-5am you can get a bucket of donuts for $5.

It's a lot of hype. The experience was great. The look of the place and the service were top notch. We ordered the captain crunch, golden graham, and voodoo and they were definitely different and pretty good but also definitely not the best doughnuts we have ever had.
Great fun doughnuts for the kids... Nothing overly exciting, more just for the name. We will continue to buy when in the neighborhood.

So.....we were in Portland and figured we had to go because everyone has always said how good the donuts are. I've even had people tell me they were diving from Seattle to Portland to get said delicious donuts. Anyway, we decided to go and figured the lines would be shorter on a Monday. There was still a line but it wasn't too bad. 

We had never been so I asked the guy working behind the counter a question about one of the donuts and he did everything but roll his eyes so I knew when I asked if he had any recommendations it would be his worst nightmare and a very short list; he didn't disappoint. We were going to get a dozen donuts but his attitude was "hurry up, I don't have time for your questions or another moment for you to figure out what you'd like" so, we only got six. 

Honestly, I'm not sure what all the ruckus is, donuts were just meh. I wouldn't drive across town for them, seriously, don't waste your time.  The attitude of the staff doesn't help either. Go somewhere else. The locals told us later that the best donuts in town are actually to be found at Blue Star Donuts and there is absolutely no way their staff could be less friendly than what we encountered here.

I admit I'm one of the fools that lined up for donuts on a rainy Sunday morning.   First star deducted for the ridiculous line, second star deducted for the donut I got (maple bacon too sweet!)...keep the third and fourth star for the ambience/decor, very tasty lemon crueller and fifth was for the friendly people that work here.  Once is enough just to say we visited this very popular Portland bakery...unless family really want to visit (likelihood is high) so I'll be waiting down the street at Sumptons (yum!).
They're not the best donuts in PDX, but I suppose there's a demand for donuts from a small child's fever dream.

as a tourist experience, it is part of Portland, so OK.  but too, too sweet - especially the peanut butter drizzle they use.  the doughnut underneath was great, not too greasy.  next time something more plain.

The line wasn't that bad, maybe 20 minutes. The donuts are perfectly alright. No one nut stood out among the rest. I could go on, but let the brevity of this review stand for itself in honor of a place that's much better than bad and manages to satisfy as it fails to live up to the hype.

The line here is ridiculously long.

The donuts here are good, but NOT exceptional.  This place seems like a tourist trap and proves that consumers really do love nothing more than a good gimmick.  

The donuts are overpriced.

The only thing it really has going for it, is that it has a remarkably huge selection that always seems to be available.  Again, it's a huge variety, but nothing seemed to be exceptional to warrant the 30 minute wait in line.  

I had the maple bar w/bacon.  It tasted just like how you would imagine it to taste.  I don't remember the other donut we had, but I guess that proves that it just wasn't memorable. 

If you're visiting from out of town, I guess you have to come here just so you can tell the folks back home that you tried it.  Then proceed to do what I'm doing now...telling everyone it's overhyped!

Expensive. Taste is mediocre. We went to the one in downtown Portland that is in a questionable part of town. We took out of town relatives there thinking it would be fun. I was embarrassed! Portland is known for being weird, and that has to be the draw that gives this place its business. I will never go back.

While the donuts are tasty, they're not worth the long wait in line. They're much too sweet and lack the softness of my favorite places. 

The vibe and atmosphere are fun, and it's worth a stop for tourists but if you're actually looking for a delicious donut, maybe skip Voodoo.

Good. But not nearly what I expected. Tasted like a donut I could get at Dunkin' Donuts. Think most of the hype is around the names of the donuts as opposed to the ACTUAL donuts. HATE that they don't accept credit cards. Blue Star Donuts is definitely superior!
It's not what I expected The place is really neat the donuts were OK not crazy about the wait
Pretty average for taste, not sure what all the hype is about, but they do make some fun looking doughnuts, and interesting flavor combos

Dirty, filthy, sticky icky.  Cool looking doughnuts, very long line, but very overhyped!!!

Major dissapointment.

Maybe 2.5

Was it Portland over the weekend and heard the hubbub over this place, so we decided to go. It was an early Wednesday afternoon and there was about 8 people in line in front of us. Service is sloooooow. You can't see your choices until you get to the door and people hem and haw and take forever to decide. And the kid getting the donuts? He was putting them on the counter and then in the box, not sure why he didn't just put them straight in the box, but whatever.

As for the donuts themselves, meh. I had the voodoo donut which was just a regular jelly donut with a face and I've definitely had better. The same for the maple bacon one my sister got. There are definitely better donut places if you're going for actual taste and not visual effect.

I'm going to agree with the "nothing special" reviews. I'm not saying it was bad, if you like doughnuts I would recommend it; but it was just a doughnut. You can cover it with Fruit Loops or Oreos, or shape it like a huge cock, but in the end it's just a doughnut. If you want to consume 100 grams of sugar in 2 minutes, this might be the place for you. Or you could just go to a Fred Meyer and get the same quality doughnut (though admittedly without the selection).

If you are a fan of paying for the "atmosphere" or the novelty of a restaurant, you'd probably love this place. If you are just looking for great tasting food, there are other places you could go.

All hype. We got a dozen with my husband and they were under cooked. I just got the maple bacon and it didn't taste right.  My husband ate two and we got sick afterwards. We gave them away instead of saving them for later. The store looks dirty as same as the donut display. The atmosphere of the store was weird, that made us feel uncomfortable and the cashiers weren't friendly either,  the one we got seemed pretty annoyed.
Zero stars. They turned away a man in military uniform. The manager even told him that voodoo doesn't support the military.

The doughnuts were outstanding and the selection cant be beat.  That said they are not so good that it is worth a trip out of your way.  The building is intersting with lots of different things on the wall to look at and read.  

I was not prepared however for the aggressiveness of the homeless that surround the shop and in general fill this area; demanding doughnuts and screaming at people if they doid not give them any.  I am glad I went during my visit but the this one issue alone will probably keep me from going back.

I first heard about Voodoo Doughnut when the Portland Ranger contingent brought boxes of maple-bacon donuts to the Burning Man festival, many years ago. Since, from time to time, I've seen traveling Portlanders wearing Voodoo tee-shirts. So I was pretty excited to be in Portland and in the vicinity of this famed temple of the circular sweet.

The thrill was not to last, alas.

Voodoo was completely sold out of not one, not two, but **three** of the donuts on my to-eat list. Seriously? You're a famous bakery, with lines out the door, and you can't replenish stock? Big let-down. It's hard to do a taste-test when what's being popped into my mouth is completely different than what I imagined I'd be getting. Grrrrr.

Their customer service was cranky, whiny, self-important, and cranky. Yes, I said 'cranky' twice, that's how bad it was. Yes, I get that you're way hipster, and even hipper for working at Voodoo, and even hipper than that for pretending not to care by whinging and slouching and feigning indifference, but it wears thin quickly. We don't care about your personal issues, or how you choose to posture. Just take pride in the product you're slinging across the counter.

There are a lot of donut shops in a lot of places, from Boston's North End to Cape Town, South Africa. Makes Voodoo way less interesting, especially if I have to suffer the slings and arrows of the minimum-wage hipsters at the counter. I won't be darkening their door anytime soon.
fun enough to do once, but don't wait longer than 10 minutes here. they're just donuts, people.

The line is long but does move fast. They donuts are ok, I like its more the Hype then anything. Donuts are overly sweet and over priced. I took a few bites of my oreo cookie donuts and I had enough. It definiety wasnt worth the standign in the rain.
Very authentic place worth seeing and experiencing but in terms of the actual doughnuts, they were too sweet for me.

The homeless man outside of voodoo doughnuts had more personality than any of the workers, hence why he received a tip and they did not. Voodoo gets 1-star because their donuts are unique/somewhat tasty but their customer service was HORRID. For a business that attracts customers from all over the world AND on top of it makes you wait in extremely long lines (in the sketchiest part of Portland), the workers could not have been ANY less friendly. Save yourself the drive/walk through bum-city and just add bacon to a maple bar from your local grocery store.

Let's preface this is saying that I'm not a big fan of donuts.  But I had to visit this establishment because of all the hype.  I got the maple bacon donut and the voodoo jelly donut.  The maple bacon was delicious, a great melding of both sweet and savory tastes.  They give you two huge pieces of bacon!  The voodoo jelly donut was good, just your average donut filled with jelly with a cute decoration.  

I went on a Thursday afternoon around 3-4pm and only had to wait for 20-30 minutes.  If you go on a weekend, expect to wait double that time.  

FYI:  They only take cash.

Ok..what is the big deal about this place? I'm not from Portland and I was told I HAVE to go here. Essentially it's a novelty shop that sells doughnuts. Are they good? Yes.. Are they "different"? Yes (in look and naming) but remember, you're just getting a doughnut. No need to stand in a 30+ min line (even 15mins is too much) for this. Its a good place to go as a tourist if you have extra time to waste, but do not go out of your way to eat this. Remember....its a bedazzled doughnut at the end of the day.

Visited voodoo donuts while we were in Portland. The line took about 15 minutes. They have a wide variety of very unique, crazy donuts. The atmosphere and the experience is cool. Personally I felt the donuts were insanely sweet so I wasn't a huge fan. It would be good for dessert but it was not the best for breakfast (this is coming from someone who grew up eating donuts every day for breakfast as a child). It was just way too sweet. Prices were reasonable and they had vegan options too, which were pretty tasty!

If you're a tourist in Portland, you gotta go to voodoo right!?!?!  Its just what we did and had a great time being in line, ordering, and sitting outside eating while watching homeless,druggies fight.  Well worth the trip.

Cash only! And you can get Stumptown coffee here too (so you don't have to go to Stumptown coffee and THEN here).

Kind of overrated to be honest and the line is very long, but if you're a tourist then yeah it's just one of those things you have to try once while you're in town I guess. But if you're on a tight schedule, honestly just skip this on your itinerary. Their doughnuts are super sugary (I mean, what'd you expect?) and even though my friend and I only got 4, we went through like 2 and a half and threw the rest out. On the plus side it was surprisingly cheap!

Visiting Portland last weekend, it was recommended by several people that we try Voodoo Doughnuts. We stood in line for an hour and fifteen minutes. There were lots of interesting people around so we were entertained people watching. A bum pushed me out of the way at one point. When we finally got inside, we picked up a variety of donuts to sample. They certainly are good donughts, but personally don't think the wait is worth it.

I've lived in Portland all my life and about 6 years ago discovered Voodoo Donuts. This downtown location isn't like the other Portland location. No seating, always lines out the door. The employees are nice... To each other. 

Seems like this is more a tourist attraction then anything... Yes the donuts are good, but I'd rather go to the other location. Seating, video games, photo booth, and the people are all around a good time!

Oh please!
What a waste to stand in line.

Here is a business idea. Stand in line, buy in bulk after an hour and then sell tastes of it for 3x the price outside for folks in line. 

The lines will surely disburse.

Guys if you are a true donut lover try someplace else. This is a hyped up place - just that no one has taken advantage of the hype as i described above. 

Try krispy kreme or duck donuts - they beat this shitt!

Personally, these over-sweetened donuts absolutely disgust me. I don't even like sweets, so I especially don't like decorated sweets.

Giving 3 stars as a "meh". Can't give 4 cuz I can't be a fan of this food, and can't imagine anyone able to eat this on a regular basis - so it's practically just a tourist attraction IMO. But hey maybe that's exactly your thing.

Long lines and doughnuts really not worth the hype.  As the star of the order, I went with the maple bacon long john and it didn't taste very fresh (the bacon certainly wasn't). I can walk into any number of other, local doughnut shops that have the same or better.

(If anyone hits Lancaster, PA, I had a maple bacon long john at the Central Market that blew away Voodoo's.)

Well, run me out of town on a rail! I'm a Portland native and have never been to a brick-and-mortar Voodoo Doughnut store and I probably never will.  However, today a Voodoo Doughnut mobile truck unit was sitting in Pioneer Courthouse Square, and I decided to stop for a Sunday morning treat.  I was mostly enticed by the fact that there was not much of a line (three girls were just ahead of me) and I could get in and out in a matter of moments.  

I like fairly plain doughnuts (cake doughnuts, buttermilk bars, etc.), so I ordered a buttermilk bar.  You should have seen the looks of amazement on those girls' faces when I didn't order one of the fancy doughnuts.  The buttermilk bar itself was very fresh and light as a feather with a cake-like interior and nicely glazed outside.  I ate it with great appreciation and moved right along to hop on MAX to head for home.

So there you go - my first Voodoo doughnut.  Like I said, it was tasty and very well made, so I give three stars just for that alone.  The counter person in the truck was far from engaging, just took my money and silently handed me back my buttermilk bar, so one star off for customer service.  I'm not impressed by Voodoo Doughnut as a cultural icon for Portland, so one last star off for that, and have trouble believing that people talk about them all over the world, but they sure do.  The Voodoo Doughnut concept would have been truly revolutionary back in the sixties, so to me the funny names and interesting doughnut flavors are sort of old school and give me the feeling "we've been down this road before."  I would certainly order a good old-fashioned plain doughnut from them again if I found myself in the same situation (no line and mobile truck), but I think hell is going to freeze over before that happens again.

I feel like this place is a tad bit overhyped...I think I went more for the pink box than the actual donuts. The store itself has pretty interesting interior décor too. Lots of personality. The donuts are good, don't get me wrong, but they're not THAT good. So if the line is super long, I recommend skipping and trying Blue Star Donuts instead. My favorite donut here is probably the Maple Bacon. Again, not mind-blowingly good, but it is a great flavor combination. Prices here are reasonable-ish, and they do have some very interesting donut designs. But for someone like me who really just wants a simple glazed donut, this place doesn't quite hit the spot.
Nothing but a novelty. The novelty donuts are clever and unique, but if you're just looking for a donut , save yourself the wait in line and go to just about any grocery store.

This is a novelty doughnut shop. All tourists always come here. Locals rarely do.  While a novelty, the doughnuts are not terrible. You come here because it's a must-have, but for great doughnuts there are other options.

they try. really hard. there's a lot of new and exciting things to put in my mouth also vegan options also ping pong, pin ball, and one game cabinet which is awesome. also you can get married in there.

Had to try it to find out why there was this long line out of the store for hours?
It took me 20 minutes to get my donut log with maple and bacon-quite efficient service!
Well, it did taste pretty good. I just wish it was not soooo killing sweet! With all that sugary icing, I could only enjoyed couple bites and had to stop from finishing it.
There were plenty people came out with dozen or even dozens in their box! Wow!

Some donuts are very good, some are meh. Sometimes you will get a stale donut or two. I really love the creative aspect and the staff are generally really nice! The only annoying thing is that you have to pay in cash only.

My experience here was WACK. I'm from out of town and decided it would be nice to bring my family back some doughnuts that are unique to Portland. What a dumb waste of time. I'm not even that annoyed by the fact that they only take cash or that there are a million people begging for money outside, but I am annoyed by the fact that the girl working there was the rudest and most hostile person I've met yet in Portland. I walk in and ask if there are any specials for a specific amount of doughnuts, like for maybe a dozen or half dozen. Okay, no there isn't, but she gave me this "are you stupid or something?" look. Whatever. So I start picking out doughnuts, and apparently she couldn't hear me (well yeah, the music in there is so f-in loud) so she tells me, in the rudest way possible? Almost yelling. Nah. I said never mind and left after that. Check your employees, Voodoo Doughnuts.

TLDR; This place is trendy but terrible.

I made Voodoo Doughnut a destination. I was in Portland for a few hours, I'd already been to Powells and Pearl Bakery, but I needed something a little more kitschy.  I found it, but with this funkiness, I also smelled something funky. Now, it could have definitely been the weather or the adjacent bar/punk rock venue, but it was so stuffy and with a smell that made me feel sick in the head. 

I WAS going to try the maple bacon bar, but really didn't feel up to it when I noticed it sitting on the racks, all dry and unwarmed (might be better at 6am). I instead tried a McMinneman's creme, and my companion tried the Portland Creme. Portland's had a chocolate top, Mcmineman's was maple...both were averagely okay. REAALLYY sweet , and I'm kind of a donut fan, but this was over the top.

bleck, think its def a local flavor that i would go back to just to try the cereal bars and give it one more chance. but maybe not.

National Donut Day calls for great Donuts. So what better way to spend it by flying from San Diego CA to Portland OR just to celebrate.

Voodoo Doll
Old Dirty Bastard

With all the hype going around this place for years, I decided to finally try out this place. The overall dough was good which was crispy on the outside and soft on the inside. Both doughnuts were pretty large too. The Voodoo Doll was a little too much for me. I know it is all just food coloring  on top to decorate the Doll but I felt like it was a little too much. The chocolate frosting was decently smooth though. The other thing that I didn't like is the pretzel because it tasted a little stale. The raspberry filling added to the monstrosity of sweetness. The Old Dirty Bastard is extremely heavy with mouthfuls of Oreos, chocolate frosting, and peanut butter drizzle. Definitely not for the light hearted but tasted really sweet.

After wanting to come here for the past 5 months, my curiosity has finally been fulfilled. Great for the hipster feel but nothing outstanding (taste-wise) caught my attention. Definitely a tourist trap but I don't mind getting trapped every once in a while.

Official Review: 3+

We went at night and both our donuts were stale... They looked cool, sounded good, but not so much. That's good we didn't buy a dozen to bring home. I hate to say it but Dunkin' Donuts taste way better. 

Take a picture in front of the sign and then be on your way.

BTW... this place is CASH ONLY For the amount of business they do, they need to probably start accepting credit cards.

I have gone to this location once and actually got something. Line is usually way too long. The one time I did get through a six person line it took 40 minutes. The doughnut s are not anything amazing. If you do really want some go to the too location. Longer line but goes fast!!!
I just don't feel the quality in these donuts. Nor, do I feel the line :( I do enjoy Voodoo's creativity and passion for donut-making, but I think Blue Star is more my speed.

Went there for a maple donut topped with bacon...but also got a jelly filled voodoo man just to suck the goo outta him! Fun to visit once, but not worth waiting in line for 30 minutes...all in all they are funny donuts, but they are just donuts.

The doughnuts are delicious. As a local, I just wish I didn't have to wait so long in line to get them! I would go here more often if the line wasn't always so long. The doughnuts are so good that I do brave the line once in a blue moon. Try the mango tango and the bacon maple bar! Buttermilk bar is great too. It is a great place to take your out of town guests.

Had to go & gorge myself on 2 donuts! If I'm only going to be in Portland once...

Small place decked out in VooDoo stuff, pictures & donuts. Friendly staff (I was expecting a**holes, don't know why). Cash only. 

Old Dirty Ba*tard - raised yeast donut (fluffier than regular cake donut) with Oreos, Peanut Butter & chocolate frosting. Yes, indulgent. Yes, good for the 1st 3 bites, but then too sugary & taste-bud-numbing. On the larger side of the donuts. 

Chocolate coconut was fantastic. Tasted just like it sounds with every bite, the flavor never died out or got too overwhelming. Plus, it was a normal size donut (whatever that means!). Chocolate cake with chocolate frosting & coconut flakes on top. 

...But you already knew that & everything else myself & all the others have written...

Convinced by a buddy of mine to check it out. The wait at  11am on a Saturday was 10-15 mins. Overall, average donuts and def not worth the wait or hype. They do have interesting donut names :)

-Old Dirty Bastard ($2.50): apologies if you are offended, this was actually the name of my donut - Oreos and peanut butter cream on top. It was def sweet and kinda old to be honest. Maybe I was unlucky and didnt get a fresh one. Kind of sad there wasn't filling either

Overall, an okay place for donuts. Make sure your friend waits in line for you so you can try out other delish eats around.

I don't know what the big deal is.  Voodoo Doughnuts are just regular donuts with psycho toppings.  They are pretty greasy and overly sweet.  Everything here is sexualized.  I must be getting old, because I don't think a doughnut is supposed to be sexy?  Definitely not the voodoo doll doughnut.  The stained glass over the front door are cool though.

1 star off: Doughnuts are overly sweet
1 star off: I feel weird eating a doughnut in the shape of a voodoo doll.
1 star off: I feel weird biting into a penis doughnut, too.

One of the most overrated places in Portland. I confess to preferring Krispy Kreme or even Dunkin' Donuts (I'm a glazed doughnut kind of guy).

If you must have a donut, go where the line isn't so freakin' long. You're not missing anything if you don't get a Voodoo.
Overhyped, always insanely busy, and the doughnuts aren't the greatest, ever.  They have funny names and shapes, and a stop for every Portland tourist going for the hipster experience.
Tourist stop. Okay, if you want to say you've been here, but you're not missing much. I got the special Portland one, and I liked it. It's cream filled and has two cute eyes on it.

I don't think it's worth the hype. They make cool combos - which I guess is the allure - but the doughnuts themselves aren't that great. The doughnut tasted a bit stale - like it was out for a while, and the frosting I had was way too sweet. But yeah, it's a cool place to visit and you won't see these flavors anywhere else.

Voodoo Doughnut is the much hyped wacky Portland doughnut shop located just south of Burnside on 3rd.  They have doughnuts you won't find at most places like ones covered in frosting and various types of cereal, candy, drizzles and crunchy things.  Their infamous voodoo doughnut is in the shape of a voodoo doll with raspberry filling and a pretzel piercing its heart.

There will be a line around the block at any time of the day.  I've randomly walked by very early in the morning and been able to swing in for a doughnut without having to wait but this is a rarity.  The lines are mostly made up of tourists who were told this was a place you absolutely had to try when in Portland. 

In the end, the doughnuts are nothing special.  They're unique in that they're covered in all kinds of sugary bits you normally don't see on doughnuts.  Aside from that you can get something just as good as the 7/11 down the street.  I'd much prefer a Blue Star doughnut if I'm looking for flavor.  Heck, I'd even go for Krispy Kreme over these guys.

Anyway, when you're visiting you kind of have to get one so that you can tell your friends you did.  Try to go super early to avoid the ridiculous line.  Make sure you go to Blue Star as well to try a really great tasting Portland doughnut as well.

Eh. It was a fun experience, I guess. The long wait built anticipation, and the display was interesting and colorful. But the doughnuts themselves weren't the best I've ever had. They were a little dry, honestly. The place seems, in my opinion, to be riding on its tourist-attraction reputation and colorful toppings. But it was fun to go there and check it out in person, and the prices were surprisingly excellent. So, two stars for the good prices! One star for the quality.
The anti doughnut but unbelievably sweet and over hyped. They don't do dozens, which I find absurd. 2 dozen costs $48 bucks. What a waste

The store is sleazy, but I guess that is what I should have expected.  We bought doughnuts for family in Seattle as we drove through Portland and all the varieties made fun appetizers when we cut them in to small pieces.  I would recommend going, but only once for the experience.
Ain't no voodoo here anymore. Only doodoo.

Best doughnut I have ever had? Not really, but the place is a Portland institution so you have to go when you are visiting.

They have some very cool doughnut designs but get ready for a moderately long wait for a moderately delicious doughnut. Staff is always friendly.

My hubby and I went late on a Friday night, around 11:30pm. There was still a line out the door but it only took like 5 minutes until it was our turn. I saw that there was a menu on the wall, describing the doughnuts. But then the actual doughnuts were on a turning display. There was no correlation between the physical doughnut and the description. So we had no idea what any of the rotating ones were. We ended up pointing at one. It ended up being some kind of peanut butter chocolate doughnut. It was pretty big (and of course pricey for a doughnut) but it was only ok. I would still prefer a Dunkin Donuts boston creme filled doughnut. But it was a good one time experience to see all the silly looking doughnuts.

I waited in line for the legendary donuts. I pondered the misperception of sunk cost as my life ticked by for one interminable hour.
