I finally get to the front, recite my carefully rehearsed order, unwrap the hallowed orbs, and bite into... a donut. A regular ordinary donut, not good, not bad. There was literally nothing to distinguish this donut from any other donut available at any other donut shop anywhere in America (and probably the world at this point).

It's 24hrs! That's the main thing I like about it. The donuts aren't delicious but you'll go there because its trendy. The only one I like is the Portland Cream which I have no idea why its a "Portland" cream, I guess because there's a mustache on it?! They are marketed as unique flavors...which...I guess...if you think putting breakfast cereal on top of a donut is novel then, yeah. Knock yourself out! 

You'll go there at least once because you feel like you just have to and then you'll be over it. 

Another thing...its a cash only establishment which I can't stand. It's one thing if you're a fledgling cart, but after you have several spots and "Merch" on their online store...c'mon being cash only is not only ridiculous but also annoying.

I came here because of the great buzz about this place. If you are actually craving a great donut, don't come to this place. The donut is not great. It is huge, overly sweet, and staff looks miserable. Go to another donut shop in downtown.

Partly went just for the experience as many people post about this place. Lots of varieties to try, but it's as if they don't listen to you. My friend asked about the Gay Bar, but ordered a Voodoo Donut. They gave her a Gay Bar. Which of course, we didn't note until after we'd left and driven 10mi. My $9-something in change was a $5, several $1 coins, and change. I tried to tip one $1 coin and the change, but all the coins fell in. Basically almost $5. For $10's worth of donuts. I was still standing there, with receipt in hand, and told the guy who had helped me that all of my dollar coins accidenatlly fell in. His response? "Okay, thanks. Next customer in line?" SERIOUSLY? Wow. Opened my box of donuts and one is partially squished. Had one and it was pure artificial sugar. Not impressed so far.

When I started planning my trip to Portland, all I heard was Voodoo Donut,  you gotta go! Well I think this has just become a big hype thing, like visiting the walk of fame in Hollywood. You get there and realize, ok not that big of a deal. Lots of beggars outside, kind of seedy looking area, and the only thing special about the donuts is what else can they think of to put on a donut? Bacon? Check. Froot loops? Check. Call a donut "cock and balls?" Check. Just an odd little place but hey, I can say I went!

I made this a destination while I was visiting Portland. First of all, you need to be lucky when trying to park your car. After you park, expect to wait because there will be a line outside. I think my group waited about 30 minutes. Once inside you will notice a carousel of doughnuts and a sign that states "If you choose the doughnuts it will be $$, if I choose for you it will be $". 

I got a dozen doughnuts to share with my group and I let counter guy choose the doughnuts for me but asked him to throw in some of the things I wanted.  He was kind enough to do so.

We eat the doughnuts once we got to the hotel and the doughnuts are very good. I had the bacon maple bar which was something different. The doughnut by itself was fantastic but when you add the bacon it become something else. Your brain gets thrown off by the saltiness of the bacon against the super sweet maple bar. 

I have to admit that they are imaginative when creating  their doughnuts, they are tasty and very good eats. However, the bottom line is: a doughnut is just a doughnut. It is a sweet bread covered in sweeter frosting, the rest of the toppings can be your heart's desire.

This place offers a good treat, and I like their doughnuts but I think this may have been too hyped up. Waiting to park and waiting on the line is not worth the trouble for creative doughnuts. 

I am giving this place 3 stars for taste and 4 stars creativity. This is a place where you just go to say you've been there. I think this place is a step above a Dunkin Donuts but a step below a Krispy Kreme

I spent some time in Portland with my boy on our way up to Seattle, so we figured we had to try this place. With it's fun doughnut creations, funky decor, and wedding options, Voodoo gets a couple stars for ingenuity alone. Surprisingly, we didn't spend all that long in line, but there was only one employee working the counter and based on her demeanor, I can see that customer service isn't their focus. 

We ordered the Bacon Maple (self explanatory), the Portland Cream (chocolate iced with cream filling), the McMinninville Cream (maple iced with cream filling), and the Old Dirty Bastard (chocolate iced with crumbled Oreos and peanut butter on top). 4 doughnuts cost us about $8, so you obviously pay for the novelty of it all.

Boyfriend thought the Bacon Maple was pretty good and he liked his Portland Cream. I didn't try either of his, but my McMinninville Cream was tasty, but uber sweet to the point where I couldn't finish it all. The ODB was pretty dry, though the flavor combo was a good mix. I again didn't eat the whole thing. These were not the worst doughnuts I've ever had, but not the best either.

Verdict from boyfriend: "Good. Doughnuts are doughnuts...they're all good."

Verdict from more discerning me: Overrated for the quality of the product, but certainly fun and creative in terms of the store and ambiance.
More hype then it is about the donut. it's cool though, and real touristy.

The voodoo donut was gross haha but i expected it to be and so was the maple bacon bar. Next time I will go for something a little less experimental. Def worth the trip since it is one of Portlands signature spot. CASH ONLY!

A Portland staple they said, easily worth the wait they said.   Portland's "world famous" donut shop has turned from a quirky doughnutery, to an underwhelming gimmick.  No one who lives in Portland ever eats here, but who cares?  Tourists flock to this place to fulfill their food network/travel magazine fantasies.  

I could get mad at the big VD for feeding this madness, but who can blame them?  Why make cheap, delicious donuts, readily available for locals, when you could make buku bucks off of snaking lines of tourists? 

VooDoo I'm not exactly mad, I understand why you do it, I am just disappointed.  You feel like Redbull to me. Their drink tastes horrible, but they are widely popular due to their marketing. You are not buying a canned energy drink, you are buying a piece of their global brand.  Voodoo has grown to the point where most everyone will go bonkers over anything that is in one of their pink boxes, and I believe that is a dangerous notion.  

I fear that other Portland staples (we're looking at you Pok Pok!) will follow the Voodoo Model of selling out, growing complacent and catering to the first time tourists who are so excited to instagram their food that they can only taste the hype, not the actual flavors.   

Voodoo, if one night stands with droves of tourists with poor pallets is what will put your kids to college, I begrudgingly will allow you to carry on.  Just know that a truly Portland establishment would value food quality, service and fair treatment of their employees over witty item names and poor quality doughnuts.

I have heard about this place being raved about all the way from Southern California. Maybe I just had a rare experience, but my doughnut had definitely been sitting out all day in the display and it was kinda soggy but the flavors were pretty decent.  I'll give it another shot since it's so close to where I work.

A decent doughnut, with an amazing shop and backstory. Sadly with other shops popping up that offer a higher par of ingredients for the same price, they are either going to have to rely on being a "must-do" thing in portland, or start adding more than cereal and sprinkles to their doughnuts.

This place is not worth the long lines and the service is very slow to help encourage the long lines. By the time I got to the plate I had to order a dozen donuts just to make it worth my time. The donut are unique but average in taste. Krispy Kreme and several other local stores have more fresh tastier donuts without the long lines. I can see why the tourist like this place but i'm not waiting in line for fruit loops.

Customer service was lacking, a customer kept pointing to a donut and the worker did nothing to help the language barrier. Donuts weren't even that great. I'm glad I checked the reviews for this place because it led me to Blue Star donuts, which is where you actually wanna go.

I can honestly say that 'It is just a damn donut!'. True, they are better then krispy kreme, but they are just a donut as well. Quality is a little higher then kripsy kreme but, all-in-all, it is still just a donut. There are other shops (Heavenly Donuts, Sesame Donuts) that have better taste and quality. Plus, you don't have to wait outside in a line for as long as an hour (who DOES that... for a donut?).
Voodoo donuts are just basic donuts with an attempt to look creative...taste wise...mediocre.

Okay, I don't get all caught up in the whole "they have the best donuts" thing. They were dry, the chocolate wasn't good.  Anyone can put Capt. Crunch on a donut doesn't make it fabulous.  The employees were typical Portland very entitled and just hated their job.  And really a "cock & balls" donut.  I would put a local donut shop where I live up against voodoo doughnuts any day of the week. Hands down the best specialty donuts.  I think they should challenge each other would be nice to see voodoo get slammed.
Ok I re-tried these donuts. The vegan ones are amazing.  Much better than the gross greasy ones I tried last time

My husband saw this spot on Man V Food so of course we had to come here. We made the two hour drive down from Olympia in the pouring rain. We arrived pretty early on Saturday and found that the line was already wrapped around the outside of the building. Obviously, in this part of the country you can't let standing in the rain for 30 minutes stop you. 

We used our line time to scan the menu online and choose our flavors. The longer we waited the larger our wish list grew. We settled on a dozen donuts for the two of us.

The Maple Bar was the best donut of the bunch. The Grape Ape and Mango Tango were good too. I liked the sugar crunch and the flavor of the powders with the icing and donut. Everything with cereal on top was a disappointment since all of the cereal tasted stale. Cereal on top of the donut sounds interesting, but just doesn't work.

Keep in mind that they only accept cash so make sure to hit the ATM before visiting. I want to say that there was an ATM on site, but I wouldn't count on that. At the time I visited there was also only one table inside because most of the space is used for the line. Plan to have somewhere else to enjoy your donuts.

These aren't the best donuts you'll ever have in your life, but the donuts and the shop are unique. Would you really want to visit Portland and miss the iconic Voodoo Donuts?

It's clever.  It's funky.  It's jr. high funny.  It's a great gimmick to over charge for some fried dough.

I didn't hate it, just found it underwhelming.  But then, I wasn't high, drunk, or hung over.

I'll take my bargain Heavenly Donuts on Lombard and be more than pleased.

Four stars for originality, but only three for execution.  The donuts are baked in bulk, which means that when you come in at midnight, the cocoa puffs on your Triple Chocolate Penetration are gonna be stale.  The raised donuts aren't as fluffy and light and the cake donuts, a bit dry for my taste.  The confections are achingly sweet, but regardless, Voodoo is a must-see in Portland.  I recommend the ODB.

I've been to VD a few times over the last 6 years. They're okay donuts, nothing to call home about. Now the first time I ever went I found a hair in my bubble gum donut...ew. They don't wear hairnets or gloves when preparing the food. ...that was 6 years ago. Last night I went and once again no hairnets or gloves & definitely zero personality from the employee. And I found a hair in my ODB!!!!! Fuck this place, strictly for tourists.

Foul. This is why America's fat. Cash-only, with extra rude help is not what I'm looking for in any establishment. The doughnuts are disgusting, not fresh at all, and DEFINITELY not worth the hype. Forget this silly tourist trap, long line, and poor customer service. Go to some other spot for sweets...there's tons in Portland...seriously...you'll be happier. Voodoo doughnuts is a flat out GROSS tourist trap! Can't wait till they close when people realize they serve up health hazards...

The donuts here are more of a novelty item than anything else. Sure, its fun to get donuts named "Old Dirty Bastard" and "C*ck and Balls" but the entertainment factor only applies to your first time here because the donuts aren't very tasty.

One hour wait... only worth it if you're visiting for a few days and you're taking tons of touristy photos in line.
Good stuff.  Short wait on a Friday early morning.  Everything you read about it is true...in the 5min we were there and ate our doughnuts outside.  Worth a try but I don't like to wait in line.

You should probably go at least once. Then never again. It's a novelty thing. First time you go I guess it's a little fun to see all the different kinds of doughnuts with treats thrown on them, but then after biting into one of said doughnuts you realize that nerds on a glazed doughnut isn't exactly the most palatable thing in the word. Their doughnuts are fun to look at, but not so much to eat.
Donuts are creative, good.......went there for the experience ~ fun.  But wouldnt wait in line again just to get donuts

I know you really want that selfie with a kinky shaped donut but neither the donuts, nor the time spent waiting to purchase them, are worth the wait. This is a tiny shop in not the best area of Portland. The line is typically long and wraps and people need to know what they want ahead of time to keep pace. There are so many other things to do and see in Portland with these minutes you're never getting back again.
Tourist trap, with donuts that taste like stale cigarette smoke. Go to Blue Star or CoCo instead.

We've waited years to visit and left feeling ripped off. The doughnuts were stale (what a disappointment). The customer service was mediocre, and the cashier REALLY didn't enjoy waiting on children. She just complained about how little money she makes for how much she works. Don't waste your money and go to Blue Star Doughnuts instead.

Not really big on donuts, but when in Portland, u gotta buy into the hype. Of course there was a line, but it wasn't too bad. Apparently when we got inside, we went on the left side to wait to order which turned out to be the wrong side. We were standing there a good 5 mins and the chick at the counter could've told us we were on the wrong side cuz we were standing at the counter. That's just bad customer service on her end. We ended up having to get on the right side and waited some more. Maybe there should be a clear sign on where u need to go once u are inside. Where I'm from (NYC) popular places that ppl stand in line for have a very clear system and signs. Just sayin'. 
As for the goods, I can only base my review on the maple bacon bar which was pretty good. The bacon def cuts the sweetness a bit. I came, I saw, I conquered.

IFFFF there is a small line..then try this place.

Must visit here when in Portland, and if you live here and have not tried Voodoo Doughnut... you are not a true Portland-ite.

Must try Voodoo Doughnut and Bacon Maple Bar!

I'm torn between giving Voodoo 2 or 3 stars. The doughnuts were fine. We ordered the cock'n'balls, the maple bacon bar, and a coconut cake. The maple bacon bar was especially good. The cock'n'balls was fun but nothing special. My wife did like the coconut cake doughnut. So why the 2 star rating? The music playing in the shop almost drove me out before I ordered! I could not wait to get out of there. My son informed me that it was Punk Metal. It was LOUD. I had a hard time hearing the clerk. There was also this sense that you needed to hurry and order which I did not like. A friend of mine, native to Portland, had encouraged me to skip Voodoo, which he called a tourist trap, and try another doughnut store in the downtown area. I wish I had. Two good things is that the line was short, not the hour long wait that other reviews reported, and there was a nice sitting area outside. But the music totally ruined any chance of getting a good rating from me.

These donuts are hyped up, not because they are good per se, but because they look ridiculous and have crazy flavor combos. We ordered a half dozen to sample over the course of our stay because if I'm going to stand in line that long it makes no sense to only order one donut. They were way too sweet, which is saying a lot coming from someone with a sweet tooth. Not the freshest, and I for some unknown reason felt these donuts were erm, unhygienic while eating them. 

We stood in line for an hour or so in the hot August sun, which is normal by San Francisco standards. Some angry old man with a walker decided to plow over my husband and call him a "f-ing Jap" while we stood in line with others who were -partially- blocking the sidewalk. He's not even Japanese, ok?! Not the best experience.

So basically, "meh" donuts while being subjected to angry/smelly hobos who yell racial slurs at you, but HEY the glittery wall was cool!

First time out here in Portland so we came here to see what the buzz was about. I thought the place had a very cool look to it, but the first thing I noticed was it was extremely hott in there. We were there sometime around 9 pm too, and I felt really bad for their workers. Although it was hot, the cashier was very sweet to us and helpful. I think this place is big because of the oddness of the doughnuts but theyre very heavy in glaze, i would say half sugar/half bread and just a bit tooooo sweet. On the other hand I did want to try their big doughnut which was $4.50 fair price but i didnt think Id finish. Not ur average dougnuts, im not to big on heavy sugar but others may like it. If you have kids theyd love this place.
Tourist trap. Mediocre donuts. There are far better donut places in Portland.

These donuts ain't good. Oh, sure, the shapes and names are cute, but the 'nuts themselves are below par. The fillings are loaded with cornstarch and have that overly carbed vibe. Nasty! The glazes are pure corn syrup with flavorings and gross color added. Basically, their donuts are low-end supermarket quality. I mean, below a suburban Cash'n'Carry.

The best thing, I guess, about Voodoo Donuts is to watch the vacuous hordes thronging to buy these over-priced, sugary, verrrry unhealthy trendy treats. When my family and I were there, the two-block crowd was exclusively trend-wannabes, each glued to their personal electronic, mainly iPhones. Seriously? People should be told how absolutely uncool it is to be a sheep.
Not all that and in a very sketchy very dirty part of town. It's chaotic and not very sanitary looking. Idk plus the fact they're cash only, get with 21st century . I'm gonna pass on these.

Maybe I just got a donut that was average but I definitely could not justify waiting in line any longer than 5 minutes for these. They were just average, nothing that you cant get at any no name donut place.  Went on Friday night at about 8pm and there was no line. Would probably skip it and go for salt and straw inside the pine st market next time!

Definitely a tourist trap. Waited 15 minites in line on a super hot day. The menu is not easily visible while in line. Once we got inside we were rushed to order. The menu inside doesn't have pictures or descriptions so we ended up just pointing at random donuts in the twirling display case. Also, it's cash only which we were not expecting. On top of that they refused to accept our $50 bill. Once we got our pink box we immediately sat down at one of the tables outside to eat our treats. At first bite, I was already disappointed by the overly sweet frosting and stale bread. We ordered 4 different ones, and each one was worse than the previous.  There's nothing special about these donuts! They are by far the worst donuts I've ever had. Why people bother to bring boxes of these donuts home on the plane baffles me. Do not waste your time-- I would highly recommend you try Blue Star instead.

I've been to Portland more times than I can remember and the only reason I stopped by Voodoo for the first time was solely for the hype. It's one of those things that everyone says you must do when you visit a city. 

The reality is that you can find better doughnuts somewhere else in the city or your own for that matter. Now, don't get me wrong. They are tasty and "creative" but not worth the long wait. 

You can avoid the lines by going late at night. Or, a lot of hotels near by such as Embassy Suites have deal with them and you can get them deliver to you room as part of your hotel experience.

Doughnut wise they are not the best I ever had. Save that honor for the doughnut man in Glendora or San Diego Donut bar. If you're a tourist don't let your eyes write checks your stomach can't cash. They are so sweet! So just pace yourself.

We visited here on a trip to Portland, as everyone that had been here was raving about it. I suppose since I had such high expectations, I expected more! Its' location isn't exactly ideal, as it was a bit off the beaten track, and when we arrived there was a huge line. There were homeless people asking us for money while we waited. I think it was about a 30 minute wait (in the rain) before we got inside. When we did get inside we decided to get alot of different doughnuts, just to make the experience worth while. The prices are not too bad actually, and we did enjoy them very much - but, we have also enjoyed other doughnuts from other locations just as much! The decor suits the name of the establishment! We didn't really take too much notice of the staff actually, we just wanted our doughnuts and then get out again.

In summary, go there once for the "experience".....

Voo-doo makes a great doughnut. That being said, I'm not a huge doughnut fan and given the lines I see at the down town store nearly every morning I can't help but think "it's just a doughnut people". But if you're a doughnut person, they're about as good as it gets and the selection is pretty amazing.

This place is seriously a tourist trap. I've been wanting to visit after seeing it featured on the Food Network and Anthony Bourdain. Food Network has let me down on numerous occasions, but Anthony!? How can you say that this place is great?

First off, the line is ridiculous. I waited for 30 minutes just to make it to the door. I thought to myself, "ok, no problem...the doughnuts are going to be great and I'm sure this place has a line for good reason." Boy was I wrong. 

Service is terrible and the doughnuts didn't look fresh. I ordered a Voodoo dozen and the lady went to the back and just grabbed a box from who knows how long ago? Worst of all the doughnuts were stacked on top of each other so the bottom layer was squished and deformed (yuck!) - definitely not worth my $10.50. 

I also ordered the bacon maple ($2.50) which was overly sweet and the voodoo man which was okay at best. All in all I do NOT recommend unless you want to become a diabetic. The line, the service, the food, and the space were all below expectations. 

I am giving it two stars because I love the city of Portland.

Our last stop in Portland is always voodoo's to bring back home to Seattle. I love the doughnuts & that definitely earns a 5 Star. But, the only thing bringing it down is the staff--especially one particular chick. She happened to be wearing a black corset w/ black lipstick the day we visited the store. She's rude & a definition of BAD customer service. If you wanna live up to the brand, hire people that'll be fun, energetic & provides excellent service. She was a B****!! Y'all better sit her butt down & make sure she puts a smile behind the cashier if she's supposed to provide great service and bring guests back.  I'm not happy!

Wow, a pink box! Anthony Bourdain was here! It's next to Dante's!

Ugh, I get it if you're a tourist and you don't know any better but, seriously, there is a nigh infinite amount of better donut places in a town filled with culinary school dropouts. The chocolate is too rich/the toppings are too sweet, the donuts are sure to give you the runs, the service is poor, it's way too over-hyped and they're pricing according to their popularity, and the qUiRkY atmosphere is enough to make you want go to the protest across the street for #whatever just to be around better people.

Go to Sesame Donuts in Beaverton or Blue Star instead.

gimmicks supercede quality

Skipping all of the myriad flavors they have and getting down to the dough itself, it is mediocre and perhaps even substandard. It simply does not taste great, almost to the point of distraction. They try to razzle dazzle you with colors, wacky ingredients and coolness but it doesn't make up for the lackluster dough. 

I do like the "mythology" they have created and it is cool they experiment but Voodoo does not have any special caché with me. It's great that local businesses advertise they carry their goods but you'll have to lure me in with something else. 

Bonus for the pink van and hiring disadvantaged kids to run it. They ARE good for the community, undoubtedly. 

But the reputation for awesome quality is hype.

I can't believe this place has a long line out the door.  Its definitely a tourist thing, I myself being one of them, but you can't leave Portland without trying this place.  Thankfully we came early Thursday afternoon and there wasn't much of a wait or line. The donuts are ok. They have a variety of donuts, large donuts and loaded with toppings. They didn't taste fresh or fluffy maybe because they were loaded with tons of toppings and sugar. I recommend going early in the morning and on a weekday. If you come on a weekend the line is out the door and around the corner.  Also its cash only, they do have an ATM inside but come prepared with your cash.

We like the donuts as they are fresh with all the people buying them all the time. We didn't go crazy and buy a huge box but we did try a few like old fashion, old fashion with chocolates, and maple bacon bar, etc. We didn't do the over-the-top crazy concoctions. I give it a solid 3 stars. Aside from the hype, I see it just as another doughnut shop. I do see people stocking up on them and saw like 5 boxes of these things on the return flight which I don't get but whatever. As long as people are happy...

Sunday, we started our day at the famous Voodoo Doughnuts. It was around the corner from the car rental, since they weren't open quite yet we decided to see what the fuss was about. There was a line out the door that built up down the street. It took us just under a half hour to claim our prize of a half dozen doughnuts. We kept ourselves amused with the doughnut names while we waited. They accept cash only. You'd think the armored trucks would do pick ups hourly for the draw this place seems to have.

We drew all sorts of attention at the car rental with our pretty pink box. It was funny, that you would spot people all over the city at various times of the day with their very own pink box. Finally, we dug into our sweet snacks. 

The lemon chiffon crueller was my favorite pick. It was loaded with way too much icing, talk about a sugar rush! But it was damn tasty. Frank really enjoyed the Memphis Mafia fritter. It was a banana fritter loaded with chocolate and peanut butter drizzle and piled high with chocolate and pb chips. I'm happy we stopped to learn that "the magic is in the hole".

I don't get why this place is so famous or why some people consider it the best doughnut shop in America. It is just an average doughnut decorated in a silly way with funny names. Just more funny than delicious...

This is definitely a very touristy destination and as a result, the wait time can be forever.  It is a place you go once to say you've been there but not a place one would go twice. 

Too overrated...

Voodoo is pretty much the definition of 'overhyped'.  The line at the downtown location is almost always 30-40 minutes, and the one in SE often only takes 20.  However, let that sink in for a moment. You are spending the better part of an hour waiting for a DONUT.  A donut.  

But okay. Great things take a wait, right? The lines would be fine if these were the best donuts in Portland. 

However, the donuts really are mediocre.  They are overly sweet, overly greasy donuts piled high with cereal and bright-colored frosting.  

The donuts aren't 'bad,' but compared to the hype surrounding this place, I'm giving it three stars.

Eh.. I mean it's really just whatever. Sure, for a lot of people out of state, this may be something totally new and different but here in the Bay Area, we have lots of donut shops that are truly the same thing and MUCH BETTER. 

Voodoo is the first to create wild donuts that are topped with anything possible. It takes out the taste of it with all these things going on. Now I'm not hating, I just don't prefer all these toppings on a donut. I'm a simple guy! lol

This is a true staple of Portland so I do suggest coming here but I recommend just eating one. I loved the Portland Cream which is like a Boston Cream Pie. It's not too much and the filling is just right! It was priced at $1.75 which are most of the donut prices.

Everyone will tell you that Voodoo Doughnut is a must do while visiting Portland, and I won't disagree.  But it's more for the entertainment of the crowds of people that line up outside than for their doughnuts.  While waiting in line, we must have heard 5 different languages and seen some pretty interesting Portland locals pass by in the space of 20 minutes.  The weather was beautiful at the time, so it was actually a pretty pleasant wait.  However once you make it inside the tiny store front, the staff is obviously overworked and just want you to make a quick decision.  And the doughnuts themselves (a huge selection, I must admit) were nothing spectacular.  They tasted like...any other doughnut.  I suppose the interesting combos of ingredients were something new (bacon on maple), but I think the draw of this place must be the atmosphere.
The donuts were okay.  I expected better.  There are some interesting flavors and coatings.

ODB! Ol' Dirty Bastard...best doughnut in house.  If you are visiting Portland I recommend the wait.  It is a tourist must.  Flashy artwork and hipster staff make it a Portland signature.  The "Voodoo Dozen" will set you up with a perfect box of sugary goodness... to take back home with you.  


..."The Magic is in the Whole"!

I can only comment on the vegan doughnuts, but I've had two chances to visit Voodoo and try a few different doughnuts, and I'm just not impressed. Somehow the texture and flavor leave something to be desired. Sorry Voodoo, but the vegan doughnuts we have here in the Bay Area are worlds beyond yours.

Worth checking out once.

I was not overly impressed.  I mean, the doughnuts were neat, and they had a wide variety of variety, but these didn't satisfy any sort of doughnuty craving for me.  They tasted like the fast and cheap doughnuts you get from a grocery store bakery.  The 'novelty' of the doughnut was interesting, and they weren't bad doughnuts.  The service was excellent.   I guess after all the hype, I just walked away disappointed.  This is definitely a 50/50 toss up for me.  I want to give them a good review, because they're running a tight ship, and it is INTERESTING, but the doughnuts were just like eating a mountain of sugar fluff on a crisco pastry.  Definitely worth seeing, but you'll probably be more than happy with just one.  Maybe I'm just a doughnut snob, or my home town doughnut shop puts crack in the doughnuts, I don't know.

5 star service, 4 star orginality, 2 star doughnuts.

Good and reasonably priced donut but in my opinion somewhat overrated and very touristy. Opens late. The line may appear very long but it moves pretty fast. Cash only, there is access to ATM in the store but personally I find this pretty inconvenient as I tend to not like to carry too much cash on me.

Other than the unusual, there comes a point when rushed servers tending to be quite abrupt at times and a business that has become overly full of itself might hope that newbies keep hearing about this Portland "secret" no?!  I give it an extra star just because I am "portland" and do like creativity.

Super long line just to get some average grocery store donuts. Sure, some of them have amusing names, and others have cereal on top, but other than that it's nothing special. Generic frosting on bland donuts. If there is a line, don't waste your time.
The donuts actually have made both of my kids sick from too much grease. I appreciate the novelty. Annoyed no that they only take cash.
They're donuts with goofy crap on them.  Enough said, not worth the ridiculous line.

Meh. They're on par with a good grocery store donut, certainly nothing worth waiting for and something I'm glad we didn't really have to do. I guess it's popular because people like standing in lines? The raised donuts were a little dry and most are topped with an array of store-bought cereals or cookies. Tue cake donuts were OK but you can expect a similar donut anywhere. On the plus side they are impressively cheap, but at the same time who wants to pay anything for a mediocre pastry? I'd rather pay a dollar or two more for something tasty.

Good doughnuts.  There was a line, which seems to be the norm at such doughnuts places, but it moved quickly enough.  Surprisingly this place only takes cash but there is an ATM that is accessible from the line.  The doughnuts were reasonably priced, which justified the experience and would have me coming back.

Their donuts are alright. Had to wait in a long ass line outside in the rain and took forever to get my order taken. Most annoying part is they're cash only and they have an ATM that makes you pay $3 extra dollars yet they can't afford a credit card machine????? Underground business??? Wack.
Just ok.  I guess I am not a donut person. Long wait in line just remind me of going to club.

Don't get me wrong people this is a must stop one time tourist attraction in the heart of Portlandia.  Now that I've discovered higher quality bakeries in the area. This place is dead to me. 

Make sure you're paying attention when you get close to the front of line. Know which ones you want. If you can't decide, you can let them pick it for you. That's a thing. But you have to get the bacon maple bar. That's a give-me. 

You may have read the lines are long and the parking sucks. This is all true. 

In my most recent stop here to pick up some treats for people before I headed back to Seattle the employees attitudes here was appalling. When you spend almost $100 on donuts here you'd think the service would be a little better. Like you know, not ignore me when I turn around and ask for the keys to the gross restroom.

Maybe it's just me, but I wasn't too impressed with Voodoo doughnut. Their donuts are huge and to me it just looks like it is going to get me that closer to diabetes that much faster. They certainly are creative with some of their toppings but I think some of these can be shared by 3-4 people. I did see many people walking around with Voodoo donut boxes so maybe it's just me. There is a line that can form so be ready to stand in line.
The hype over this donut shop is way too extreme. The donuts were not as cool as I thought they would be.

VIBE 
The store is cool. It's weird. It's wacky. The magic is in the hole. Blah Blah Blah. The owners have a cool story though. 
Staff are kind of indifferent. 

I ATE
The Maple Bacon. I waited 5 minutes in line for that. The dough is good but the sweetness of the maple and the flatness of the bacon were not. 
Oh, and the Maple Bacon is $4 at their truck and $2.50 at the bricks and motar location. Come on! 

OBLIGATORY CATCHY REMARK
I was told it was overrated. It is. 

PS Doughnut allegiance is to Glory Hole Doughnuts in Toronto. She's doing the creative doughnut topping thing way better.

When I told friends / colleagues I was going to Portland, they either asked "are you going to Voodoo donuts" or said "you have to go to Voodoo donuts". 

So we went. Not that I'm a big fan of donuts. Wait was around 10 min, which was fine, though parking was a pain. 

Donuts tasted normal, but was really got to me was the crass / tacky / sleazy sort of marketing. I guess some would say I should not have come here if I felt that way - I agree. Won't be back.

Cash only!!! They have ATM machines but don't count on it. It was not working when I visited. I got the voodoo dozen which is a dozen donuts picked by the staff and costs 15 bucks. They taste alright but there tend to usually be a line to get in.

I knew when I wanted to come to Voodoo, it was solely for the hype, and yes I definitely wasn't expecting much since I had been fully warned by my dear friends. But really? I didn't know someone could possible make donuts worse than Dunkin Donuts. And how do you even mess up a jelly donut exactly? 

Came here around 11pm on a Saturday night just so I can be a tourist and take a picture with the Voodoo Donut sign but thought "I might as well just stand in line too because how many times will I really come here." The wait was roughly around 30 minutes (which is still insane!) and I ordered the infamous voodoo, a jelly donut in the shape of a voodoo doll covered with chocolate. The donut was extremely heavy and the dough was not airy or fluffy at all. On top of that, it was extremely sweet and just not very different from that jelly donut from your local donut shop (and honestly that one may even be better). 

Majorly disappointed and I am shocked that people still stand in line for an insane amount of time for this basic donut. #basic

WARNING: Doughnut coma will ensue if you try to eat the memphis mafia!

We stopped at Voodoo Doughnut while in Portland to see what all the fuss was about. It was a fun place to visit, but the doughnuts were just ok (a little dry and didn't seem fresh). 

My wife and I ordered 4 doughnuts to split (go big or go home!), and regretted it about an hour later. The doughnuts are filling and some of them are enormous! 

We're glad we stopped at Voodoo, but it will remain on the 'been there, done that' list.

Voodoo Doughnuts is known for its atmosphere and creativity more than just the taste of donuts and I would have to agree. While they have alot of different flavors to offer, in my opinion, most of the taste is from the frosting. There is nothing special about the donut cakes themselves. I'm a bit of a peanut butter fanatic so I ordered the Old Dirsty Bastard (with chocolate, oreos and peanut butter), the butterfinger, and the Neapolitan with strawberry frosting and marshmellows. The donuts were good, but I still don't think they compare to Pip's. Prices are very reasonable though. The one off Davis street has a parking lot, which is a huge perk.

Got there around 9am on a Friday morning. Luckily, there wasn't a long line, just a line long enough to let us debate whether we should get the Voodoo Dozen or just a bunch of doughnuts. I got the Mayan Doughnut (not sure if that's the name) and it was a moist, chocolate doughnut covered in cinnamon cayenne sugar. I also got a Portland Creme (a Boston Creme with a face). My fiance got a maple creme (mcmin-something, sorry I don't remember the actual name), and I liked that one the best. 

They have signs everywhere saying they only take cash, but there was a woman in front of us who ordered over $30 in doughnuts and then was shocked that they only take cash. She blasted them that they were lucky they had an ATM there, otherwise she would have just left without her doughnuts. Umm, it's not their fault you didn't take notice of the signs. 

By the time we left, there was a lineup out the door and down the street. I thought it was worth it for a doughnut. They tasted very fresh, but were more expensive than the average doughnut.

An okay place for donuts, we ordered the full variety (12 pieces) of the donuts, nothing remarkable, just like old stale ones from Albertson or something.

A long line, but mostly driven by hype and marketing.

Price is average.

The donuts look interesting, the store is pretty cool, but the wait in line is awful and the donuts do not taste good.  I've had better, for less trouble and expense.  Now that I've had the experience of Voodoo Donuts, I have no reason to go back.

Ah, the familiar bright pink box. Everywhere we went in the city, we saw people carrying a pink box from Voodoo Doughnut. I'm a sucker for these popular tourist traps, so this visit was mandatory to relieve my FOMO (fear of missing out). 

***Important tip for first timers- read the menu on their website! The chalkboard lists all the flavors with crazy names but no descriptions. No wonder the line is so long! People are debating whether to risk getting something solely based on the name (Cock 'n balls? Hmm...staggering or disappointing, could go either way), which makes them second guess. 

Yes, the donuts are overrated, but it's still worth a stop if you consider the experience as a whole. Voodoo is arguably the most famous shop in Portland, so if you're only in the city once, why not check it out? Honestly, the wait wasn't even that long on a Friday night at 9 PM (~20 min). On Saturday morning at  8 AM, the line was practically non-existent when we passed by. 

The bacon maple bar was yummy, and I'd eat it again and again. The voodoo doll is a safe choice- chocolate covered and raspberry filled. Bonus for the mean girls-  you can curse your frenemy or ex-boyfriend by stabbing the donut with a pretzel stick. 

The Old Dirty Bastard was less desirable. Nobody likes stale oreos, and there was WAY too much frosting even for a sugar addict like myself. I ate a couple bites and threw it away. Same issue with the Mango Tango- jelly filling was sweet enough without all that frosting. 

The employees are upbeat and friendly despite having to deal with a high volume of indecisive tourists and obnoxious drunkards. Props. 

My hometown team, the Houston Rockets, happened to be playing the Portland Trailblazers that night. They displayed a Texas-sized donut and encouraged customers to place a hex on the Rockets. I guess it worked. We lost. Heartbreaking.

It was pretty decent, not the best doughnuts in the world but very imaginative. I had a Lemon Chiffon which made my mouth pucker (it was very sour in some parts, in a good way) and the Dirt which was ok, a little too much sugary stuff piled on though.  It's pretty awesome that they're open almost all day and night.

I don't get it. Ok so there is some weird things on the donuts but how does that make it good? They are overpriced and not very tasty. In our group we ordered pretty much one of every kind and I gave them a lot of chances. Not one single one wasn't greasy and off balance with sweetness. I don't think they are much better than a twinkie and certainly a lot more trouble and $.

Voodoo Doughnuts was an okay semi tasteful experience. The best part about this place is how everything looks. From the standout Pink Store to the Crazy designed donuts stands nothing more but some average tasting donuts.

They have a huge selection of crazy creations such as Old Dirty Bastard, Voodoo Doughnut, Captain my Captain, Cock-N-Balls, Gay Bar, and many more priceless named donuts. I enjoyed the atmosphere of all the excited first timers like myself. I even made a friend which made the lengthy wait seem to go by fast. I just was disappointed when I took a bite out of a few of them. They tasted as if they were sitting around for hours. You'd think that something with so much sugar can overpower such a dry taste, guess not.

This place isn't horrible or anything like that, it is just too overhyped. I enjoyed this pit stop while visiting Portland though. Trying out new places is about the experience of both taste and atmosphere. Try this place out, just don't expect too much "Magic in the Hole".

yaaawwwwn. used to be sorta cool before they got so slick. Ive definitely had better donuts but voodoo was good and then there was the atmosphere...dark, sorta dingy, late nights, never knew when they'd be open for sure,  and you heard of voodoo donuts but walked around the block a couple times wondering if that door was really it, then there were the weddings (now it looks like a vegas chapel, now that I think of it or a shop on main street, disneyland) and the contest to see who could put the most donuts on their male member...those where the days. omg...now there are not just tourists but the kind that stand in line and talk about donuts in new york and l.a. and san francisco and wonder how voodoo will compare and take pictures and marvel at the glitter in the paint on the bricks...they are like the couples who collect mcmenamins hotel stays and the little coasters they get there... 

but sometimes you just have to show up somewhere with a pink box of voodoo donuts, you just have to. or better yet, you'll walk in and there will be a 5 gallon bucket of day olds....score

On a recent trip to Portland, we were looking forward to stopping at Voodoo Donuts because the Yelp reviews were so good.  Unfortunately, we felt like we had inadvertently stepped into an episode of Portlandia.  Apparently, we weren't cool enough for the uber hipster behind the counter or maybe she is rude to all the customers as part of the "appeal". In any event, when we made the mistake of asking her a question we were rewarded with some pleasant sarcasm and condescension. Love it.  Anyway, being as we are hicks from the small town of Seattle and assuming the rudeness was a trade off for a delicious donut experience, we went ahead with the purchase.  Yum. Just as good as the wonderful Safeway donuts we get at home. Well done, Voodoo Donuts.
the doughnuts may be vegan (pointless) but they taste like  shit.

Hyped.

We waited about 30 minutes in line for our donuts. I got the voodoo doll which was in the shape of Harry Potter, which was super cute. The boy got the Portland creme. 

We both agreed that it was nothing special. It tasted like a donut. Not bad tasting, but certainly nothing to wait that long for. The raspberry filling was a raspberry jam filling. It tasted like a donut that you'd get from anywhere, except it was cute.

Maybe I should had gotten the one with cereal on top? I don't know, perhaps I should had gone adventurous, but I really wanted the cute donut! And so maybe that was my issue.

Despite all this, the donut didn't taste bad. But I don't think I need the line or the extra calories.

I waited 45min in line for regular donuts.

When I say regular donuts... these are just normal donuts... same dough, same custards, same chocolates that all donut places use.

I ordered the ODB... regular raised donut with chocolate, oreos, and peanut butter frosting. The donut was... normal... just a regular chocolate frosted donut. The oreo was stale and kind of soft. I did like the peanut butter frosting and wish I had gotten this on a jelly filled.

All the hype and expecting it to taste something that wasn't like normal donuts was a disappointment to me. While the venue looked nice and wild, different and weird... i could experience this from the sidewalk. 

It was just OK, and the prices weren't crazy inflated, but still I can't believe I waited in line for regular donuts
Stood in a LONG line, only because we felt we had to do it because the place is kind of iconic, wasn't really worth the long wait. Want to try Blue star next time.

If you are twelve and want all the sugar, sure, go to Voodoo, stand in line with all the tourists and get your sugar on.

Personally, I will go 1 1/2 blocks down and chaw at the cart called Donut-O-Rama.  

The man is a freaking donut genius!
O.k. the variety of strange doughnut concoctions and flavors is impressive. The donuts themselves are not particularly tasty if you expecting "light & hot".. Mostly a dough-y consistency.
Many people consider Voodoo a staple in Portland, and it is definitely worth a visit, but not a repeat visit. The donuts are large, sugary, and served with the right amount of disdain. Try it out!

Ok, I have to admit I am not a huge donut fans. We came here because my coworker said this place is popular. Waited for 30 mins or so to order our donut. Cash only, dont forget to bring some cash with you. The donut we got was cold, the cereal on top of the donut was chewy, not sure how long it sat on the counter...little dispointed. Mostly a tourist thing. Is worth a visit as a tourist but probably I wont be back on my next trip.
You have to go because it's the Portland thing to do, but there are better quality donuts out there.  They have some fun and interesting choices and are fairly inexpensive.

During our visit to Portland, we were told we HAD to go to Voodoo Doughnut.  After seeing a line 50 yards long, we were told "that's not bad, the line is usually longer".  We thought ok, must be good.  After 20 minutes in line, we enter the tiny, sugary smelling (not in a good way) bakery.  While our ears are being abused by the way too loud Death Metal, we start reading the Doughnut menu.  We quickly see that the descriptions are "R" rated.  My mom-in-law then escorted our 13 year old to the t-shirt store across the alley.  We place our order and, because there is no seating, take our doughnuts outside.  They are huge.  They have unusual ingredients, but they are nothing special.  Save time and money by going to your local doughnut shop, order their biggest maple covered doughnut, put a piece of bacon on top, sit in your car and eat it while listining to very loud rock music in front of a tattoo parlor. Same effect.

great imagination but the donuts are awfully heavy and I have had better, you also wait for fucking ever in line - even at voodoo too on the east side. my favorite at this place is the trailblazer spliff or as it is more affectionately referred to, the "blazer blunt." cone shaped cake donut, dusted in cinnamon&sugar, with the tip dipped in maple and red sprinkles. oh captain my captain will tear your mouth apart but try the ODB. it is home to the famous bacon maple bar, which is strangely delicious but HEAVY! service is great, they tend to hire portland types - you know a little strange and sassy but real, down-to-earth, and kind. they sell all sorts gear too; voodoo panties for you ladies, t-shirts, stickers, etc. if you're a prude stay clear because these people have dirty minds (that's the best part). this place is a portland fixture but i don't think it really lives up to all the hype... plus they went and opened one in the Euge and that's just sacrilegious!

I wish I could give Voodoo no stars. This place sells day old donuts they unload from a truck the night before. DO NOT GIVE IN TO THE HYPE. So many other amazing donuts shops in Portland to check out.

VooDoo Doughnuts is a Portland institution. I do like that they have crazy flavors and amazing names of doughnuts, but really $3+ for an alright doughnut? I've had better doughnuts at a grocery store. Unless you are looking for something in particular, I would recommend the VooDoo dozen where they pick out a dozen doughnuts for you, which saves you a good $12. I also like that they have Vegan doughnuts (GAY BAR!) but overall this place is only busy because of the tourists and TV exposure. Interestingly, I found this original location to have a limited selection of doughnuts compared to the other location in NE Portland. Parking is a bitch here since it is downtown, so I would highly recommend going to the other location for FREE parking and a better selection of the crazy doughnuts.

First I have to state, I shouldn't be eating anything from this place or any donut shop for that matter....my physician would have a royal fit if he knew I'd had Voodoo Donuts back in 2007.  That said this place is way better for tourists than locals.  If I had a $5 for every pink Vodoo Doughnut box carrying tourist I've seen at PDX about to fly home I could greatly enhance my IRA.

Extremely sweet, excessively sweet and not so moist and doughy.  Sesame Donuts (again my doctor would have a fit....and I did consume these during my big promotion year 2010-2011) much better especially when fresh.  Both nowhere near my favorite donut place of all time Tasty Donuts in WeHo, Cali.  

But as a Portlander I'm glad people come here and add money to the economy by buying the things and lugging them onto their flights home!

First time visiting Portland with friends and we had to try Voodoo to see what all the excitement was about.  I have to say, I was unimpressed with the donuts.  They were average at best.  As we explored the city we walked by the doughnut shop several times and the line can be extremely long.  I was glad we went when the line was short because it would not have been worth the wait.  There are a lot of options with cereal or cookie toppings.  We tried the captain crunch, a lemon one and a maple bar.  All in all, I have definitely had better.  The doughnuts were slightly stale and so was the cereal on top.

Cash only so be prepared for that however they do have an ATM inside.
Thanks for bringing tourists to Portland and filling the overhead bins with pink boxes on the airplane. Not the best doughnut in town but it is what it is.
Overrated, tourist trap doughnut shop.  Not worth a wait or the price for the little giggle you get from the sexual innuendo.

Tourist Trap! I have lived in Portland my entire life, in the past 10 years, this place has turned from a funny little shop our city had, to an overblown must stop for tourists. The donuts are mediocre, but why people line up is they put crazy (at least it used to be considered crazy) toppings: Captain Crunch, Candy, etc. etc. 

If you want an actually GOOD donut, try blue star. If you want cereal on your donut and a long line... well you get the idea.

Meh. Not worth the hype, but a good donut is waiting nonetheless! We came as tourists (of course), and had heard of the long lines. Thankfully we decided to come at night around 8:00 PM, and we got right in!

We didn't have a ton of time to decide what we wanted between scrounging for cash (cash only). We walked away with a bubblegum, a voodoo, and a captain crunch donut. They were good, but WOW they were sweet. We couldn't even finish them because they were too sweet for us. 

Unfortunately spent more on parking than we did on donuts. Bring cash. Try to street find parking. Come at odd hours to avoid a line.

We ordered a dozen random doughnuts and by that I mean we let a staff member choose 12 doughnuts and surprise us. The doughnuts were fine. Pretty average. The crazy factor was really just putting random stuff on top of each doughnut (kids cereal, weird color frosting, M&Ms, etc) This place is really more of a fun attraction than anything else. The original location is cash only and parking is definitely limited out front. Also be aware if you go late at night, there are a lot of panhandlers around outside who will come up to you and ask for money if you sit outside to eat.

Just over-rated. If you want to wait in line for about 45 minutes, and be served an average donut, then this is your perfect place. Homeless always beg for money. The experience is just not worth the time, taste, or money.

When you hear about Portland, Voodoo Doughnuts come up, so I had to make it a point to go there. From my understanding the locals are indifferent, so you'll mostly see tourists there. Having friends know about the food scene in Portland is such an advantage because we got to the place and there was no line, we went straight to the front and stared at the carousal of doughnuts. Getting there around 9:30 AM was perfect too because it smelled super fresh.  Since we went with a group of friends we shared with each other. We got the Maple Bacon (the most popular), the Captain, My Captain, and the Dirt Doughnut. The Maple Bacon is one of those long donuts and cooked bacon on top of the maple, what a hit! The Captain, My Captain had Captain Crunch cereal on top, my boyfriend's favorite cereal, so he loved that one. The Dirt Doughnut had vanilla frosting with Oreo cookies on top, which are my favorites, good for those that may not be so daring to try new or different things but still delicious. If you're ever in Portland, check this place out, not just for the doughnuts, but as one of the images in the city.
[spoiler alert] there's captain crunch on the donut.
Was told it was a must try. I wasn't truly impressed. Tasted good but guess it was too hyped up and didn't meet my expectations. Cool to see the many different options

The Portland cream donut is 4 stars for sure, the rest I've had are more like three stars.  There are better donuts out there, there are worse, I'd say these were middle of the road.  Still tastey, just maybe not worth waiting in a line wrapping out the door in my opinion.

Fun place and good doughnuts, but too hyped up and filled with tourists.  Always fun to take out of town friends for pictures and such, but if you're looking for something to munch on for yourself, go somewhere else.

I have to say I'm pretty disappointed with the quality of donuts Voodoo bakes. 
My friends and I had one day in Portland, and decided that Voodoo Donuts was a must because of how much publicity it's been getting. The line isn't too bad in all honesty. You also don't pay attention to the wait time because you're distracted by everything around you: the photos on the window entrance, the pictures on the wall, and even the "Keep Portland Weird" mural across the street. When it was our turn to order, the lady at the cash register looked completely out of it; she didn't give us much direction or guidance as to which donut is most popular or which one we should try. From what I remember, we purchased 9 different donuts, and the only two that tasted "okay" was the bacon donut and the plain glazed donut. My friends and I were pretty upset and let down because we expected the donuts to melt in our mouth and/or be extremely flavorful. 
I'd have to agree with many of the comments other people have left here: Voodoo Donuts is overrated and overhyped!
Waiting in line for doughnuts? You would think these would be really, really, REALLY good, right? They're okay at best...save your time and money and just say you ate one. Not worth it
I ordered the hibiscus donut. It was a little too sweet for my preference personally, but looked super cool nonetheless. Also, not as huge of a selection as I thought there'd be considering the hype.

The roommate and I first walked by Voodoo Doughnut in the middle of the day on Sunday. Since the line was crazy long, we decided to skip it. Later that night, after hitting a club nearby, we walked by to see if there was a wait. Luckily, there was no line at all! We walked in on Monday, October 10th around 2:30am.

My friend from Portland actually ended up ordering two donuts for us: the Fruity Pebbles and the Captain Crunch. I love pink, so I added on the Homer doughnut. The roommate and I tried all the doughnuts once we got back to the hotel. I have to say, I don't get it. The donuts themselves were average. Just normal doughnuts with cereal on top. And one of the cereals ended up being stale! Out of all three, I think I liked the Homer the best cuz it was simple. I don't think the cereals really made either doughnut better.

I don't get the hype at all. I'm so glad we didn't wait in line at all as it would not have been worth it. Was going to give them three stars, but knocking down to two because of our stale cereal. There's no excuse for that!

My sister bought donuts back for me. And it wasn't like super fresh because she said she bought it at around midnight and driving back to Vancouver BC is like 6 hours. So I am not sure what it would taste like if I got it there. 

Anyways she bought a dozen back for me. I found them a bit overly sweet. But they are cute to look at. I don't think these things are any healthy with so many sweetness. 
For the price regardless if I liked it or not, I ended up eating the whole thing. And yes I had it everyday for lunch for a week and at home as well as snacks. After one week these things melt on its own.

Didn't quite live up to the hype, but it was a good experience!

We waited in line for about half an hour before finally getting into the building, and once inside decided to just get a big box of randomly chosen donuts. While the maple bacon bar was pretty outstanding, all of the other donuts tasted pretty standard despite being all dolled up in cereal, cookie crumbs, Pixie stick dust, etc.
It was definitely a tourist thing to do - when in Portland, eat Voodoo Doughnuts!

Stopped in, in a visit to Portland. I decided to walk in during non peak hours (check Google) with my girlfriend. They are cash only so be sure to have cash... Except... It's in a hobo den. Hobos know this place is cash only and case anyone who grabs money from machine inside... It is ridiculous... Very unpleasant experience... A hobo came into the bakery and was promptly screamed out, he growled in response. The doughnuts are pretty good and are more like mini cakes. Look to pay around 5 dollars a doughnut.. ohh yea.. they were short on ones so they shortchanged me like 4 dollars and I didn't have time to count the money because my GF was freaking out about the hobos staring at me counting my money. She forced me to put it away... Great... When you count the charge on the ATM, getting short changed, angry hobos outside... I think I would take a pass on this place next time. The doughnuts are not really that remarkable. If you live in Portland and generally have a mundane life and nothing to do ... I could see this place being just under the threshold of pain... and visiting... I don't blame you.
Super Fun and creative. It's worth the experience but the doughnuts aren't that good.

This is one of those places that I think the legend has taken over the reality.  We went super-early (6:30 am) on a Sunday morning to avoid all the lines.  Yep, we avoided the lines but we also missed out on a Memphis Mafia or any fritter.  The explanation from the guy behind the counter?  "We don't have those here."  Okay, your menu says you do.  Anyway.  It's a dirty place, the employees were too cool to be friendly (the guy outside begging for change was friendlier!) and the actual doughnuts aren't that great.  Good, but not great.  I had the maple/bacon, regular chocolate, voodoo doll, and something else.  Munched on them on my way back to Seattle and they made the ride go quicker (sugar high!) but, again, nothing spectacular.  Still, we wanted to say we'd been but we won't be back.

If you're looking for vegan junk food donuts made with low quality ingredients (that you would buy at Safeway or Fred Meyer's), you found the right place! Otherwise not a great product, we won't be returning. Enjoy!
dirty and rude. I have NO IDEA why this place is popular...only with tourist I guess? Never see local people standing in line

Went here today to see what all the hype was about.  Glad we tried it but would never go back.  Definitely not worth the price.  Tried the Neapolitan, lemon crueller, maple bacon, and butterfingering.  I almost threw the lemon away...no flavor and tasted underdone.  Neapolitan was good as we're the others.  But for $7.30?  I think not.

The line is always super long no matter what day or time you go.  The doughnuts are not fresh unless you go in the early AM.  They have been sitting out all day and taste like it.  The names of the doughnuts are fun though and unique.

Had to go to see what all the fuss was about.  I am not much of sweet fan and was put off by the fact this is only a cash only place (do not like to carry cash).  They do have an ATM inside the store.  I waited in line for about 10 minutes and the donut was good but I have done this and crossed it off the list and will not be back.
Good but overrated.  There's always a line and half the time the donuts are cold.

Donuts were okay but am unsure if they were worth waiting 20 minutes in line without ventilation and dripping sweat to get. Topped off by Cruella Deville sales girl with shortish curly dark hair and big gage earrings being very unfriendly and seemingly unhappy to have this job, we will not return and realize this place is mostly hype.
It's all hype folks! Over priced and under quality. At this point it's just a Portland tourist trap check off. You can do much better.

It's nice having so many choices for vegan donuts. The line hardly makes it worth it. But then you're rewarded with donuts. And then you leave confused with a pink box and wondering when you will do it again.

I'm not sure I understand the hype of voodoo donuts. I got 2 donuts with cereal on them and the cereal was stale. I wasn't impressed with the mashmallow stuffed one, and their only saving grace was just a basic sugar raised piece. I walked through the snow to get these donuts and they were just OK. Not sure I need to go back. Cash only too and a line to boot.

Didn't have a bite -- I'm gluten free.

But, to sum up three guys' experience -- "not as good as Krispy Kreme, but the maple bacon donut was real good."  Was it worth standing in a line, in not best neighborhood late at night, with a bunch of young, homeless dudes holding up signs that they will take donuts instead of cash? Yeah, probably.  Just to say we did it.

I was curious enough about the experience, that I went and got a Kinnikinnick chocolate gluten-free donut and put some bacon on top.  I think it loses something when you don't have to wait 30 minutes for it.

If my memory serves me correctly, I think it's cash only.

Was it worth waiting in line for the voodoo doll, Portland cream, homer, Marshall Mathews, or bacon maple? For a first timer? Sure! Would I do it again? Definitely not. Interestingly, of all the donuts we tried, the classic buttermilk was our favorite.
Very overrated now.  Five years ago, they had good doughnuts. Now, not so much. It's mostly a novelty. Most of the time the doughnuts are dry and sloppily put together. They've lost their appeal.
Lines were crazy long, the donuts weren't that great...It is definitely a tourist trap.

Voodoo Doughnut has been getting a lot of attention, not just in Portland but nationwide. I actually watched an actress have some flown in to L.A. to share some Voodoo doughnuts with Jay Leno on The Tonight Show. 

When we were just on vacation in Portland I waited in their long line for a half an hour just to get up to the front and realize that they only accept cash. Who even carries cash nowadays? Anyways, the curiosity got the best of me so the next day my wife and I decided to go there to finally find out what the hype was all about, again, the lines at their downtown location were too long so we decided to go to their Northeast Portland location. The line was not much better there but went by fairly fast. Luckily I had cash in hand this time since this location is cash only as well. We started by trying to order their most famous doughnut and they were all out, the doughnut with the most hype, because of its shape, they were all out of. So we started going down the list and every other doughnut we tried to order they were out of as well.

We basically ended up getting any flavor at this point and the doughnuts did NOT match all the hype. Isn't a super hyped doughnut place at least supposed to serve warm, or at least fresh doughnuts? Well these weren't. They were completely average tasting, another review I read was accurate when it said that they tasted like Safeway doughnuts. We didn't even get ours in a box and the one we took home for our daughter that was shaped like a doll was put at the bottom of a bag beneath the other doughnuts and was all smashed up.

Anyone who wants to have the best doughnuts in Oregon should go to Joe's Doughnuts in Sandy, Oregon on the way up to Mt. Hood.

Fun concept, but the doughnuts were so so.  I bought the voodoo ones (super cute, but dry) and my husband got the old fashioned maple.  We were not impressed.  Maybe the other varieties are better?   I think a good doughnut stands on it's own without a lot of toppings.  Maybe this place is popular because of the toppings.  There was a line when we got here at 8pm, but it went fast.

It's all about the experience here - waiting in line, the oddly shaped and risque' named donuts, and unfortunately listening to hard metal music too.  It's very rush-rush - you better know your order when you get to the front of the line.  I went there twice - will not be back unless someone is visiting from out of the area and wants to check it out.
Honestly, not good. They don't make their own doughnuts and pile globs of junk on top.

A Tourist Trap!! I heard about Voodoo Donuts from friends and decided to give it a go. I was a little overwhelmed by the plethora of donuts sitting on the rotating carousel. So many - cake, old-fashioned, speciality, where do I begin?

We decided to try the chocolate cream donut, maple old-fashioned, double chocolate cake, red blaming blunt, and blueberry cake donut. We should have just gotten one - the  Blueberry donut. It was sweet and tasty. We just took a few bites of the other donuts - they weren't worth the calories. The maple and double chocolate cake were both a bit dry. I like the bavarian cream in the chocolate cream donut, but it was nothing special. The red blaming donut is nothing more than a cinnamon donut with some sprinkles. The donuts are a notch above Dunkin' Donuts. The locals go to Blue Star - I can see why. 

The donuts aren't worth the wait. Luckily, the line wasn't too long when i was there at 10pm on Sunday. It's much longer during the day and in the evening. While waiting in line, be careful! The donut shop is in a shady area and plagued with homeless people. This guy came right up to my boyfriend in the parking lot and scared us as we were walking towards the donut shop. The parking lot across the street is very expensive, I recommend street parking a block away. No better way to wait in line than people asking you for money! It was so bad that we didn't even bother to sit down and nibbled on the donuts when we got to the car. 

If you're really curious about the donuts, I recommend going to the other location - Voodoo Donut 2 or not going to the Chinatown location at night. I think you'll be more impressed with Blue Star.

Ok, seriously now, if I have to stand in line for a doughnut, it better be orgasmic.  Needless to say, these were not.  My hopes were quite high, based on the popularity of this place, and the looks of the things in the display case.  We ordered the mixed dozen, and received a box of doughnuts topped mostly with breakfast cereals and candy.  Clever, pretty, but not really that tasty.  The toppings seems to be the focus, and unfortunately, the actual doughnut isn't very tasty.  It was dry and bready, not light and sweet.  It left me wishing for Krispy Kremes... My husband insisted that we exact revenge on these overhyped doughnuts by introducing them to the back tire of our rental car.  Pictures of their fate wil be posted soon.

I don't regret going here ONCE for the cute doughnuts, hipster pink boxes and quintessential Portland experience. But after biting the doughnuts and tasting nothing but sugar, I've figured that once is enough. They'd hit it all if only the taste was as good as the concept.

So I got there about 6:30 pm on a Friday night. There was a line out the door and it took about 10 minutes to get in; not too bad. I was in a mood for a vanilla cream donut but had to settle for custard since they don't have vanilla (or chocolate) fillings. The donut was good but not great. As someone used to the great Amish donuts available in mid Atlantic, I can tell you that these are just average. Creative yes (if you like to pay more to have a donut covered with fruit loops), but not worth the wait or the premium for the donut. Delicious Amish donuts back east, about $1, average but trendy Voodoo donut, generally about 2. Another thing, there was hardly any custard in the donut. If you gotta have it, go for it; it should hit the spot.
Pretty good donuts here, but a looooong line and it's cash only so come prepared. I really liked the Grape Ape, Maple Bacon Bar and Maple Blazer Blunt.

Such a disappointment! Only came because it's a Portland staple. Wasn't even at least decent. Breaking tasted like it's been made two days ago. Pricing wasn't bad but the donuts were either really bland or really really sweet. Ended up throwing them out.

Plus, we went at around 9 pm. No lines which was great but so many bums bugging customers for change. Guess that's expected in downtown at night but didn't feel safe eating there. Go to blue star instead. This place sucks.

It's a solid donut, but does a pentagram made of icing on top make it worthy of standing in line for an hour? 

The voodoo doll donut is pretty tasty with a raspberry filling and most donuts are pretty dang cheap.

I'm glad I showed up on a good day and the line was only about 15 people deep. If I had to wait any longer, I would have regretted venturing inside for a dry cake donut. 

Donuts are handed to you in a big pink cardboard box, which is great for the novelty of it all, but every trash can outside of the place was overflowing with those boxes. In a city like Portland, that seems like a huge no-no.
Fun place but a total tourist trap. Donuts are overly sweet and not worth the wait. I've had better donuts at Safeway without all of those stale tasting toppings.

A great place to visit with people from out of town, who really seem to get a kick out of it, but there are far better doughnut joints in town.

The line during peak hours can be annoying and I kind of feel like saying (to both the clientele and the proprietors), "We get it, the doughnut's shaped like a dick. Let's move on already."

That said, the donuts are pretty good and you can't beat the huge boxes of day-olds for a great value. I once scored a box of three dozen plus vegan donuts for $4. That weekend I went on a sugar binge that ended with me as a junior camper.

My three favorites, Portland Creme, Blueberry and Ol' Dirty Bastard.

Why why WHY would you go here instead of the location on the east side?  You can literally walk over the Burnside Bridge to the east side location, get your donuts, eat them, and walk back before you would get through the line at this place.

The times I do go to Voodoo, its filled with out of towners lookin for photos, which is fine cause this place is known around the country....bout the only time Im willin to wait in line is with visitors from out of town...other than that ill head down to the saturday market...theyre donuts are darn good though.

Guys: The donuts aren't that great. The waning aura of hipster unicorn magic has been trampled by the lines of drunk frat bros and bridge n' tunnel bachlorette harpies wrapping around the block. Plus they are shitty to their employees.

Go to Pip's or Blue Star. If you're in SF, go to Bob's; that's what a fresh, hot donut should taste like.
Not sure what the hype is about this place but was disappointed when I bite into one. Donut taste like a pack of sugar was dumped on top, that I feel like I can make a better one.

Its a doughnut, a very good doughnut.  But really dont understand the hours in line for..  did I mention its a doughnut.   I don't stand in lines so visit the Eastside location the wait will be less. OR try one of the many other wonderful doughnut shops in Portland.

It's an iconic location, but the donuts are pretty average in quality and flavors... there are some interesting combinations that are specific to them, so if you're into trying a maple bacon, then check them out.. I didn't find them to be the freshest donuts, but maybe it was an off day or i went at the wrong time..  I'll try them again sometime for sure if the opportunity presents itself, but I wont go and make a special trip for them...
Wait line was crazy. 45 minutes. I did it once for the experience but not sure if I would go back. Of course they had some cool looking donuts but they tasted just average.
An over-rated tourist trap.  There are several other donut shops in the city with just as creative and much tastier donuts where you don't have to wait outside in the rain for an hour.

Went to Voodoo Donut to check it out and although the donuts are appealing to the eye...NOT THAT GREAT!!!! As for the staff, one word RUDE!!! Very impatient and not very helpful at all. Won't be recommending and won't be going back.

This place was pretty darn cool. It was definitely worth the wait for the doughnuts the BF and I got. Me, glazed with some sort of white frosting and Cap'n Crunch on top. The BF, Maple glazed with bacon on top. Yes, bacon on top of a doughnut! A-MAZ-ING. 

Yes, the line out the door isn't the most fun thing to wait in...but it was fun to see the wacky decor and smell the fabulousness of the doughnuts within! We definitely enjoy being tourists.

Portland, thank you for Voodoo Doughnuts. :o)

P.S. The price was pretty sweet as well. $3.50 for 2 doughnuts? Yes, please!

This is a Doughnut shop. I feel like that's all you need to say. 
It's hugely popular as a tourist attraction, but aside from the fun shapes and bacon, it's still just a doughnut shop.

Went here while on vacation, and was excited about the birthplace of the wacky donut. The line was long, and the donuts were good - not great. I'm not sure if Voodoo has lost its touch or if other places have caught up with the shop in creativity and surpassed it in quality. Over-hyped in my opinion.

If you're into hygiene and just the normal appearance of somewhat clean do not go to this VooDoo donuts, go to the one in Eugene Oregon. Before you even get to the line you have to fight your way through all kind of throw up on the floor, spit and loogies, piss and bubble gum on the floor, and like a video game you get to the end and fight the evil boss. Just before the evil boss their ends up being a barrage of bums in all shapes and sizes nationalities and different levels of smells, which none of them smell like donuts by the way. Once you get in the main boss is some short Asian lady with a shaved bald head with a very rude attitude that is playing loud obnoxious punk music way too loud as she's trying to take your order and every other word that she yells to you is huh, huh. The reason I gave them 2 stars is because the donuts is what saves them, some of the donuts seems like somebody that was high out of their mind created some of them and is just way too much. It's almost like they let a bunch of kindergartners go back there and go to town on some of these donuts. The almost normal ones and the normal ones are very good, but I must warn you before hand DO NOT USE THE REASTROOM.
