You might want to use it to wash your hands before you eat your donuts and drink your coffee because everything you touch has either gonorrhea, syphilis,or AIDS, but you're better off using some hand sanitizer. If the owner and the city of Portland took a pressure washer and pressure wash the whole area,sidewalk, street, walls benches, and anything you can lean up against this place wouldn't be so bad. At the end of the day if you want to have a good experience do not go to this one.
Yes....its good donuts...but I think it's a bit of a hype.

Not impressed. I was warned by friends who had come before that I shouldn't have high expectations and they were right. Nothing special about these donuts besides being pretty pricey for a donut IMO. Wouldn't wait in a long line for these but brownie points for Voodoo being open 24/7.
I have tried Voodoo several times. Each time I've gone in there, the doughnuts were old and dry. And putting Fruitloops on top of a doughnut is not inventive; its terrible.

Definitely a tourist must go since EVERYONE raves about it, celebrities and commoners alike. 

The place is on the corner of some random area and homeless people definitely are smart in roaming around this spot. I heard one man say, "Boy! I sure wish I could have a donut before I start my day!" Good job, bro. You keep workin' it.

The place itself is kinda cool I guess. It's very hippy-ish. They have their donuts on display so you can gawk at the crazy heart-attack desserts you're about to devour. 

I think the donuts itself were just okay. I mean, I give it to them that they created some unique donuts and gave them cool names....but all in all, it's just a donut with hellllllla stuff on it. 

I probably won't come back again but hitting it up at least once was good. If you're craving a donut, sure...come back here.

Voodoo, thanks for helping me doo doo. (Sorry, that was really childish)

Good solid doughnuts but for the life of me I can't figure out what all the hype is about. Wide selection of weird concoctions. I tried the no name, Memphis mafia,  and the lemon filled powdered sugar. Memphis mafia was the best by far.

A good place to take the inlaws or friends and coworkers from out-of-town. The novelty is nice, but the quality of the donuts themselves often tend to be dry and the cake bland. Sure, a drunken bacon maple can hit the spot, but it's rarely worth the wait behind tourists and suburbanites.

Despite the long line, cash only, their doughnut is pretty average for me. If anything it's a little too sweet for my taste. I got chocolate glaze and other two with creme filled. The chocolate glaze one taste great, just like you can get it from other mainstream brand, the other two with creme filled were way too sweet. I didn't finish both of them. Cute store though.

I'm sure all the Voodoo donut followers will be appalled, but these really are not the best donuts. Yes, they have funky, zany, fun flavors, but that does not equate to a great donut. A conversation piece maybe, but outstandingly good donut... no. Any I have ever had were  greasy and dry at the same time. The contradiction of texture was as funky as the flavors. 

Until there is an actual food shortage, I'm not waiting in line for it. The lines are silly, but apparently that makes some folks feel like they are "in the know". I know I don't recommend Voodoo donuts to anyone wanting quality treats.

When considering writing any review, you have to weigh the overall value against the product. And considering we spent an hour in line for these donuts, I would have to say they are definitely not worth it. All they are is a bunch of decent (not great) donuts, that someone threw cereal and other junk on top of. Its another level to the American obsession with all things gluttonous.

We arrived at 11am on a Sunday (yeah, our fault), and waited in line for an hour, then ordered a Voodoo Dozen, which lets them choose what goes in the box. We ended up with a maple donut, one with Coco Puffs on it, one with Oreos on it, a blueberry cake one... You get the gist. I personally ate the maple one, a toasted coconut one, and one with chocolate frosting, peanut buuter, and rice krispies. They were good, but not great, and certainly not worth an hour's wait.

Their overall schtick is cool, but honestly, I'll take Top Pot any day over this.

This place is the biggest disappointment in all of Portland. 
Not only are the donuts not delicious but the whole whole experience is extremely stressful. The customers service is horrible. The employees yell at and pressure the customers.  And I didn't even eat the whole donut. 
10/10 would not recommend.

In town, so we sucked it up and stood in line to get a taste of voodoo. The neighborhood is a bit dicey and it was awesome getting harassed while we waited in line. Also, we kept getting alternating wafts of delicious sweet doughnut smells and trash. Great start.

I get it, voodoo sells quirky weird donuts. That's their thing. Are they the best doughnuts I've ever had? No, but after a 30min wait, the maple bacon bar was pretty tasty. 

Keep Portland weird, ya'll!
Cool. Creepy. As to be expected. The donut (apple fritter) wasn't anything special, but the atmosphere was different and pretty neat.

The line looks intimidating but it moves kinda quick. I think we were in line for about 25 minutes.  I picked some up for my friends and some for myself. Ordered bacon maple bar, chocolate cake, sprinkles cake, the homer, old dirty bastard, viscous hibiscus, memphis mafia and voodoo doll. I tried voodoo doll and it was too sweet for me. I like the tanginess of the viscous hibiscus. I was disappointed as nothing was really special about these donuts.

So I didn't go to this store but my friend gave 2 Voodoo donuts to try, the one with the M&Mns and the twirl donuts with chocolate topping. 
They were just ..."really? People wanna wait in line for these?!"
My friend was saying she had to wait in line for 30mins, wth?? But my friend was a tourist so it makes sense for first timer. 
But I know people have been going here many times. 
I was pretty surprised how ppl can wait for these donuts, it was kinda hard, too thick, it isn't that yummy. 
I have another friend who are friends with a Portland local, she didn't even recommend Voodoo. 
I think the name was intriguing so ppl always wanna buy them.

I wouldn't bother to go to this Voodoo. It is not great or okay donut . it is less than okay. So go figure.
Objectively, the Wait-to-Doughnut ratio is hard swallow. There's a point of diminishing returns, and an hour for some donuts is well past reasonable.

Another stop on the Disneyland ride known as the Portland food scene.  There are better donuts.  Unless you're really, really, f-ed up and it's late at night.  Then there is nothing better than the Captain Crunch doughnut.

I simply can not remember coming here but I guess I did because I checked in??? The donuts must not have been that memorable or just not worth reviewing.  According to hubby, it was ayte.  If it was ayte to him, then it must have been blah for me. All I remember is that their donut was way too soft just not what a donut is suppose to be

The donuts here are a great novelty for someone like me who came from out of town = 1*.  I love the marketing and eclectic style of both the establishment and the donuts themselves = 1*.  The donuts themselves weren't anything grand.  In my opinion, they were too doughy and far too heavily frosted.  My family however, did appreciate that I hand carried a baker's dozen back home on the plane with me back to California = 1/2*.

I'm glad I went to check this place out, but I'll pass the next time I'm in town.  One more off my to-do list in Portland.

Cheers!
The doughnuts were creative but not tasty at all.   It's a tourist stop and if you want to see their infamous voodoo doughnut then this place is worth a visit but that's about it.

I do not know that I have ever been to a bad donut shop.  This place is no exception to that statement.  It is a bit overwhelming after waiting in the line to feel pressured to pick a donut so quickly.  I felt so rushed.  Basically, they need to make you feel welcome and not like someone they need to shove out the door.  I am glad we came here as a snack rather than missing out on breakfast at the amazing restaurants in the area.

So, two other people and I decided to go to Voodoo Doughnut because I heard about great things about them. I also, heard great things about Voodoo Doughnut from my friends and how they enjoyed eating their donuts. However, it wasn't what I expected.

The line was incredibly long and it was a hot day, so it was really frustrating to see that if they were having great business, they should of expanded. But, hearing all the great things about Voodoo donuts and from the commercials on T.V., we decided it was well worth the wait. 

By the time we get into the store, the store is small and looks  very ghetto. We finally got our turn to order and we decided on getting a dozen of the voodoo donuts and 6 personal donuts we ordered. 

Some of the donuts weren't even unique in its entirety. I mean, come on, Captain Crunch on donuts? The only thing I was impressed with was the Voodoo man. It had some creativity in it's shape, but still was overly saturated with sugar. The sugar in these donuts were overwhelming and very difficult to eat. 

I also tried one of their Cruellers since they are my favorite type of donuts. Unfortunately, I had one with frosting and 2 marshmallows on top. It wasn't what I expected.

I give this business 2 stars because from the amount of people that like Voodoo Doughnuts, they need to expand their store to be bigger. Also, they overly saturate their donuts with sugar that overwhelms the taste of the donuts.

Tldr: Go to Blue star donuts.

Not sure why there was a long line for these donuts. Ordered three different flavors and could only manage to take a few bites from each of them. If you're looking for overly sweetened donuts packed with overloaded flavors, you'll like this place. If you're looking for quality donuts with refined flavors, skip this place.

I headed to voodoo doughnut as if drawn there by magic. I got there at 8am, already there was a long line in front. 45 mins later I got to the cashier and ordered a double chocolate and a mcmineville cream. Thankfully, the spell was broken with my first bite. 

With as much of a line as there was, I expected the donuts to be warm. Unfortunately they were cold and stodgy, and the icing tasted too sweet.

Very ordinary doughnuts, v. v. disappointed.

I want to write a good review, I do... Fun place, fun (if average) donuts... Until I encountered "doughnuteer" E. D. A hostile hipster girl who after the exhausting job of boxing up a whole 4 doughnuts gave me my change in the form of dollar coins, when I asked for a dollar bill, she refused, said she didn't have any, right, in a cash only business... I know the idea is so I will leave it as a tip, no sorry, you didn't wait on me, you pulled 4 donuts off the rack and put them in a box..a task you apparently thought was worth a tip... Understand, I tip, servers who make my visit to a restaurant pleasant by bringing me food and being attentive, you didn't, by making me a drink, you didn't, by making me feel welcome, you didn't... For being a bitchy hipster no, sorry... So yes, I exchanged the dollar coin for a bill out of the tip jar you nodded to, mainly to piss you off as much as as you pissed me off... Here is your tip, Find another job that doesn't involve customer service... I will never return to voodoo.

Let me first say these doughnuts are not bad, they are good. But are they great? 

There are 3 things that i didn't like... 
1. Cost - the avg. cost for a single doughnut $1.75?  Are they using 
"gold" to bake these doughnuts? For $1.75 i could buy at least 3-6 elsewhere.    2. Cold Doughnuts - as we bought them, we noticed these doughnuts were cold. Warm doughnuts would have been nice. Mircowave it at least.    3. Long Line - we waited over an HOUR for these special doughtnuts.  No doughtnuts are worth an hour wait. It's like if I was waiting to buy U2 tickets.

The bacon-maple donut is very good. The others we tried were just so-so.  Located near the Saturday Marketplace, which was cool.  Located in a sketchy area, so just be aware of where you're wandering.

lololololololololololollllllllllllllllllll to me ever standing in line for one of their mediocre doughnuts!!!!! maybe if they were phenomenal i would but they're basic af!!!! with that being said, get anything other than their cereal doughnuts, they're stale garbage.

Definitely overrated doughnuts.  Yes it has some funny names like Cock-N-Balls and Old Dirty Bastard, but as for taste, I wasn't impressed.

I bought five different ones to try and paid about $15 I think.  I felt that the doughnuts were a bit heavy and too doughy for my taste.  I'm more of a fan of Krispy Kreme where their doughnuts are light and airy.

The line was out the door of course, but that's because the store is very small so only a few groups are inside at a time.  I stood in line outside for about 20 minutes before I got through the door, so the line moves relatively quick.  

CASH ONLY

It's a fun, local, overly hyped donut shop.  Yes, they have crazy combos that are yummy.  The bacon maple and the Dirty Bastard are my favs.  However, they aren't the BEST in town.  Anytime we've gotten the larger donuts, they have been raw inside. So stay clear of them.  Unless you like raw donuts...  Still a fun place to visit and get a sugar rush.
A waste of 45 mins spent queuing for a box of doughnuts that all tasted the same - of sugar with artificial coloring!

If I see you walking around downtown Portland with a Voodoo Doughnut box on a weekend, it lets me know you're a schmuck.  It's like the Scarlet Letter of schmuckery.  You just waited in line for potentially hours for a frigging donut served to you by someone who couldn't have more of an "I don't care if you die or not" attitude.  Don't get me wrong, the donuts are tasty, but they're donuts.  Sure they've got fun names and gimmicky designs but they're donuts.  Would you wait in line for an hour for a $1.50 food item anywhere else on Earth?  Not likely.

To max out the schmuck levels, there's a 2nd location a 5-minute drive away with probably 3 people in line.  But you knew that.  You're mad smart.

Like most of the locals will tell you, Voodoo is overrated. Pretty standard doughnuts but it's worth checking out just as a Portland landmark and to say you tried it. I ordered the voodoo doll doughnut (chocolate icing with jelly inside) and it was nothing special taste-wise but cute for taking photos of. I recommend going at an odd time when the line isn't an hour long. And make sure to get a picture of the iconic Keep Portland Weird sign nearby!

Make sure you go when you are really really hungry!

Not sure if its the norm, but we had to wait in the line for 1 hour to get the donuts.  Only to find out that what we wanted was out.  But anyways a very interesting shop and some cool variety.  

Don't want to be hated by all the locals but just the wait and then not finding what i wanted was a bummer.

OK, so they're GOOD donuts, but they're not the best I had in Portland, so what's the big deal?  Good decorating?

I got the Memphis Mafia and the Ain't That A Peach, both of which were fritters and HUGE.  And they were good!  But they weren't great.  I have had truly great donuts, and Voodoo donuts didn't live up to them.

The line thing - whatever.  I went as a tourist and considered it a Portland experience.  It was kind of fun.  I'm amused by sparkly things, so I had fun looking at the glitter-sprayed exterior brick wall, and also status-ing about the grump in back of me who was grumping to his girlfriend about waiting in line and it's stupid and blah blah blah.  It's a Portland thing, man!  Deal for your girlfriend!

Anyway, I also have to note that the prices are pretty high - I payed $4-ish each for two gigantic fritters; I'm not going to complain, but I did the Voodoo Doughnuts thing and I wouldn't go back again.

On one hand, it fills me with a sort of silly, useless, and of course completely unrequited civic-minded pride that a local-grown business has blown up like Voo-Doo has. Bully for you guys. No, really!



On the other hand, candor and good taste compel me to say that I am simply not capable of recommending Voo-Doo to anyone on the basis of their actual product. As that great American patriot Don King might say, "Only in America" could you see huge success and financial windfall, simply from pouring stale cereal, bacon, and plastic army soldiers, etc, etc, on top of a quality of dough-nut that make Albertson's deli/bakery seem genius by comparison. The axiom widely attributed to H. L. Mencken  is completely applicable here: No one EVER went broke, under-estimating the intelligence of the American public....


My rating is not based on any particular negative experiences, per se..... most of my exposure to Voo-Doo is owing to dastardly cretins in the workplace, who insist on bringing those incriminating pink boxes, chock full o' Voo-Doo doo-doo in for yet another round of group self-sabotage. Admittedly, one almost cannot help but get a certain, twisted satisfaction from watching certain work-mates (and this type exists in almost every work place, you may be very sure) complain gratuitously at the first sight of the donuts--It is herein requested that these beasties be more properly called "do-nots"--- only to inevitably behold the same co-workers shortly thereafter set upon said "do-nots" and cram them into their seldom-closed pie holes w/an alacrity suggesting the long dreaded Apocalypse, w/the attendant looting, rioting, and mass starvation is imminently at hand. 


This rating is most assuredly not simple-minded contrarianism nor envy of the afore-mentioned success.... in fact, I wish the fine folks @ Voo-Doo ongoing, delirious levels of success. As long as nit-wit tourists are willing to continue lining the sidewalks waiting to fill their coffers for something as mundane as Voo-Doo donuts, there is hope, gentle reader, for you and I, likewise. Perhaps we might even join forces to create and attract more intergalactic nit-wits w/our very own trendy product(s), served up of course by only the smuggest and most pretentious of world-famous Portland-brand Hipsters (patent pending). How hard can it friggin' be? So long as we never forget the Cubic Zirconium Rule: People care about what's hip, what's popular, what's NOW---do not annoy them with questions of whether or not "it" is actually any good. The trendiness is what makes it so doggone good, hellloooooo.....

I really only suggest this place for the ambience. Very cool, hip place to check out if your in the city. Doughnuts are not that great. Definitely unique in their topping but way to sweet. I always go and just get one for all of us. Plus the person handling my doughnuts with his hands by the way was also handling the cash register. Boo

It gets a lot of press but might be the worst donut shop in Portland. If you like stale cheap breakfast cereal glued onto a donut then this place is for you. No Portlander in their right mind eats here. There are many better donut shops throughout the city.

I will start off by saying I really love donuts...
As for voodoo, they have a couple of locations and you will generally stand in line for a while, maybe an hour or more. Having grownup in Los Angeles, we have some local donut shops that have long lines, such as Randy's near LAX or Donutman in Glendora.
Now, back to voodoo.... they have weird donuts... weird flavors, weird shapes, weird colors.. which doesn't mean a bad thing, but unfortunately, they were more hype than anything. They are not cheap, expect to get a half dozen donuts and spend about 15 dollars or more. Other problem, they aren't really great.. some are actually not really good either. Last problem, both my wife and I noticed a touch of heartburn after eating them....Not normal for me, as I've been known to each a few donuts in a few minutes with no regret. My suggesting is just find a  good ol mom and pop donut place and give them your business. Enough with hipster places that don't live up to the hype.
Silly tourist thing, however very unique and trend setting :)

Stopped by here because it's a "must" in Portland. We came by on a Sunday morning around 9 am and lucked out. No line.

Ordered a few donuts to take back home, and enjoyed one outside with a hot cup of coffee.

The actual donut, the actual bread of the donut is pretty darned good. But some of the donuts just had too much frosting. 

The donuts are okay. There's better places around without the huge line.
Better than your average doughnut. The atmosphere earns it an extra star, but the quality of the doughnuts doesn't live up to the hype. That said, the maple bacon bar is my favorite.

I tried the Memphis Mafia doughnut... it was very sweet to say the least. Hubs tried the Bacon & Maple doughnut, and he liked it. I also had the Maple Blazer Blunt doughnut, but only sampled half of it (the half that the guy's hand that was serving up doughnuts didn't touch). lol.. This area can be a little sketchy late at night. When I visited, there was a guy standing outside asking for money. I guess it was a good place for him, since this place is cash only. Of course patrons are going to have cash. Also, the donuts were so-so. Very creative, but beyond that, I've definitely had tastier donuts. Womp.

There is a line outside but really its just weird donut combinations. like bacon maple bars. the donuts they gave us tasted like it was made early in the morning and was seating around for a while. ill just go to a regular donut place

It's. Just. A. Doughnut. 

If you come to Portland, you have to get one-- it's not an option. However, don't be surprised if, after waiting in line for an hour, you receive a doughnut that tastes a lot like a doughnut. But, whatever-- it's quirky and fun and should be taken as such.

Tip: Did captain crunch shred your palate as a kid? You can experience that two-fold when it's on top of a doughnut.

Pro-tip: Go to the one on Sandy blvd. instead, to avoid waiting outside for an hour.

Over rated. Long lines for doughnuts that really aren't that great. We went early in the morning to avoid long waits and still waited about 15mins. D's are about $2 to $6. Regular, cake and filled. We tried the triple chocolate penetration. I didn't like it at all. It was the worst cake doughnut I have ever had. Chocolate fondant on top, nothing special and   a topping of Count Chocula pieces. Really I expected more! Where exactly was the penetration?? Triple Chocolate Penetration..... boring chocolate and cereal. Service was fine. Prices okay. Store was cool and eclectic. I have talked to some Locals and this is straight up an tourist attraction. No locals eat here. We will consider trying "Pips Original" doughnut shop, based on a recommendation from a tourist.
These are not good tasting donuts.  I don't know what's up with them. Stomach ache every same time.  I'll stick to Heavenly Donuts
It's fun to look at the different toppings but the donuts themselves tasted ok.  The toppings are stale.  The only good ones are the mable top with bacons.

It's fine... But really you are paying for hype, clever names, and strange designs... Taste wise, the doughnuts are just "ok". I highly prefer Sesame Donuts for taste. Voodoo is for shock value and tourism.

Longest line ever but we had to check out the hype. We got the voodoo doll, the maple bacon and the fruit loops. Donuts are donuts so I didn't see what was super spectacular about it but yeah? Cool experience

While your going to have to wait in a line it's definitely worth your time.
The doughnuts are fluffy but can be a little overly sweet.  They're  not the best doughnuts I've ever had but if your in the area and have some time to wait in line it's definitely worth a try. 
The bacon maple doughnut was unique and very tasty!

Disappointed! We were expecting better donuts, being waiting in line for 15 minutes, but the donuts were cold and not as fresh. Just very ordinary donuts, don't understand why so many people recommend it.

Ever since discovering the perfect cake donut in Denver, Colorado, I've been on the hunt for a repeat experience. Based on the number of reviews for Voodoo, I had high expectations. But alas, I was disappointed. I didn't get any of the specialty donuts, but opted instead for a chocolate glazed old fashion donut and a chocolate glazed cake donut. Instead of melting in your mouth, I found the cake of the cake donut to be a bit on the stale side. The old fashioned donut had too much chocolate glaze, giving it an odd crunch at every bite. Maybe my expectations were too high, but for a dollar a donut, I thought they would be better. I would also recommend passing on the coffee because I didn't think it was anything special and even witnessed one of the Voodoo workers walk down the block to Stumptown instead!
solid donuts but not worth the wait. just show up at odd times when there is no line and dig in:)

Yes indeed they do carry a voodoo doll shaped doughnut and all sorts of oddly shaped/named doughnuts. But in my opinion the doughnuts are no better then any other shop's. I honestly prefer a small "Ma and Pa" place where all of the items are baked with love. Because of the off-beat names and ingredients, Voodoo still holds a small interest of my curiosity. What will they come out with next, the maple bacon was -hands down- a great discovery to all man kind. 

- Voodoo Dough Nuts-

The doughnuts are a little funky, but taste basically basic. We got the Voodoo Doll, the Bacon Maple Bar and the Grape Ape. The Bacon Maple was my favorite. 

The lines are long. Like really long. Because of this, know what you want by the time you get to the cashier. They get SUPER annoyed by the oohing and awing, the twiddling of thumbs and asking for their opinions on "what's best here?" Just choose five different doughnuts that look interesting and sample them all!
With all the hype I was disappointed.  I waited in line for quite a bit and my doughnut was stale and counter staff less then pleased to be working that day. Clever doughnuts with original flavors.

Voodoo Doughnut. A Portland icon. But, uh, it was kind of a disappointment. 

Went for a dozen on spouse's birthday. Sure, we waited in line. It was somewhat expected. A bit longer than desired, but expected. Finally, we're ready to order our assortment. But, WTF, they were out of the Voodoo doughnut?!?!  WHAT? I wanted to stab the little man and see the filling ooze out. But no. It was especially disappointing after the wait. So, we picked a dozen. 

Look, I don't have high standards for doughnuts, but Matt M. is right, stale tasting doughnuts first thing in the morning=FAIL.

Ok so the line is long. The donuts are good, but they don't blow every other donut place out of the park. Still, a PDX staple so you sort of have to check it out if you come for a visit. Conveniently close to a lot of other PDX things like Stumptown and other great coffee. I suppose there is a reason you will see people bringing a big pink box of donuts onto their flight out from PDX, but you won't see me with one.

I am from Cali and heard about this place and decided to check it out with my family while we were up. The 15-20 minute wait on a weekday morning was worth the amazing-almost-too-sweet donuts...what was not worth it was the appallingly rude girl at the register. I have an issue with people thinking that because their business is popular, they can treat you like crap - because hey, even if they lose your service they have a huge line. My sister, who had been looking forward to this for weeks, was so stressed out because the girl ROLLED HER EYES and sighed because my sister didn't know what she wanted the moment she got to the front of the line - even though the line is OUTSIDE so there is no time to really look before you hit the register. It was horrible, she was to scared to ask her if they had bavarian filled donuts after that and so she left without one. I wont be recommending this place. She ruined our whole experience.

The doughnut varieties and flavors are unique and pretty exciting. It's definitely a fun place to bring out-of-state guests. But the taste of the doughnuts is nothing to scream about. They're just so-so. Also, they don't take credit cards so make sure you bring some cash.
Honestly I think this place is overrated and the donuts are not worth the wait. They are just donuts after all and I think you can get very similar donuts pretty much everywhere.

Enjoyed the experience.  It is definitely something to check out if you're visiting or new to the area.  It is SO Portlandia!  Donuts were good, unique, funky and something to experience but I can't see myself going back.  Definitely check it out.

A few stars for being open late, but no more since the donuts where stale both literally and figuratively.  They coast on their popular name with tourists and hipsters, but those in the know go elsewhere for really great 5 star donuts.

Of all the things to visit in Portland - this one took the cake in terms of anticipation. So when we finally tackled the line at 9pm on a Sunday (which was still around the corner), I was so excited. I asked for 6 doughnuts and it came out to be $10.25 - expensive for doughnuts but well worth it.

Cash only, so we had to run to the ATM to grab money (read: a lot of effort for doughnuts). We were so excited to taste them at our hotel. Imagine our surprise when we find that we only had 5 doughnuts in the box instead of 6. It must have been a mistake, but seeing as how it was the Triple Chocolate Penetration (a more expensive specialty kind and the one we were looking forward to the most) that was missing, I was very disappointed.

The donuts were delicious but we hope that this just happened to us (and not a regular occurrence). Suggested donut: maple bacon bar!

Come for the experience, not the donuts. It's sad to have to say that out of all their flavors and options, the best donut they have is original glaze. It's a fun shop, and I love the coffee mugs I got from them, but their donuts themselves are vastly overrated and underwhelming. So do yourself a favor and go to Blue Star instead. Less crowded there too (although the line went fast at voodoo!) Voodoo is cash only (ATM inside) and reasonably priced. Ordered a giant glazed donut and it was only $4.50-$5.

ポートランドで一番有名だけど一番美味しいわけではないドーナツ屋さん。

行列がいつもある人気店だが金曜日の５PMぐらいに行ったら全く列が無かった。ユニークなデコレーションが目立つデザインだがすべてあまり「トレンディー」ではない。すべてがちょっと昔に流行ったようなテイスト。列が無かったので選ぶのに時間がなくて困った。
「どれにしようかな？」と困って選んだのはお店の入り口にある看板と同じ形のドーナッツ。人の形でプレッツルが差し込んである。中はストロベリージャム。

味：普通。ジャムは間違いなく美味しく無かった。列に並んでこれを買っていたら怒りだったかも。

Yelpの魅力をまたもや感じた瞬間だった。
6000以上のレビューがあるがEliteのレビューを読むとイマイチなことがよく分かる。見た目が可愛いので写真投稿サイトにはバツグンだ。でもYelpは文章のレビューサイト。見て楽しむものだったら写真サイトでいいけど食べ物は味が大事だ。ネットで味を送るテクノロジーができるまでは言葉の口コミが便利だ。

結論：写真だけ写して食べない人にはオススメのお店。美味しいスイーツを求めている人はパスした方がいいお店。

these are not amazing doughnuts, but they are fun... for tourists and just-moved-to-towners, and, I guess, office parties since boxes of these tend to show up around mine.

if you can get the absolute freshest doughnuts, they're not so bad.  not worth the prices or hype.

This is the most disappointing, overrated, and over hyped food place I have ever been to and experienced. It is a tourist trap! And I fell for it. I have seen Voodoo Doughnuts everywhere, from the food network and the travel channel and food blogs. I have always wanted to visit and try their donuts for as long as I can remember. The premise and unique donuts were just enticing. I was excited and hyped to finally try it after years and years of seeing it. However, it is just the biggest disappointment ever. 

We went on a Friday afternoon and the line was just inside. Thank goodness there was not a long line because I would have been even more upset for standing in line for this. It is cash only and there's an ATM before reaching the counter to select your donuts. The menu was tough to read and I had no idea what was going on. It was not cohesive at all and too much going on. So I had to rely on the spinning case of donuts to see which one we would get. Once we got to the counter, the employees were rushing us to select donuts. I get that they're trying to get the line moving, but a) there wasn't even a line and b) we have no idea what to get because of the hot mess of a store it is. We eventually got the fruit loops donut and the coconut with guava filling. 

The donuts are not good at all. At all. The fruit loop donuts was unnecessarily massive. The donut itself was alright. The frosting was disgusting and too sweet. Frosting should not be put on donuts. It wasn't even good quality frosting. It was a bit runny and too thin. The fruit loops were stale and hard and didn't even taste like fruit loops. We only ate like 25% of it. The coconut guava was not as bad, but still not good. Again, frosting should not be put on donuts. There was way too much frosting on this one and had to scrape it off. The guava filling was good, but it tasted artificial. 

I understand that this is a novelty item and a touristy thing. But it was just awful and disgusting. The hype surrounding it makes it even worse. I didn't even take pictures because it wasn't worth it. I'm extremely disappointed. If there's a line, don't bother. You can try it still, but don't expect anything good.
Totally overrated.  Maybe right out of the deep fryer, they are to die for, but on an average Saturday morning, it wasn't worth the trip.

We went to Portland to eat around town for my birthday last year.  I am only reminded of this place because a new on in my area in California just opened up and my cousin was so excited.

There was a long line which is fine when a place is popular. When we got to the checker we had normal questions about flavors and what not. We got rolling eyes and no real answers. Whoever hired the rude staff that is the face of the business should be fired because multiple people working there could obviously not hold a job that cares about costumer service.

The donuts were not special. They were too thick and doughy. What a disappointment for an over hyped place. We threw about half of the leftovers away. Portland was pretty cool otherwise.

Well - they certainly have their followers - and they are tasty - but honestly - seems just okay to me.  I will say, I travel to Portland quite often for work - often morethan twice a month and i have NEVER been on a flight leaving there on a Friday night that at least one person is not carrying their signature pink box.  And no overhead for these treasures - they always ride on the person's lap.

Maybe I'm just not trying the right flavors?

The donuts are ok, but I would not wait in a long line to purchase them.

I'd heard from several friends that the donuts at Voodoo are overrated and not as good as donuts from other places in Portland (i.e. Blue Star), but when I saw the super short line outside of Voodoo, I had to see for myself. This place has a very large selection of donuts that look very cute/creatively decorated and are pretty inexpensive. 

Definitely check this place out if you think you can get in and out in 10 minutes, but I wouldn't wait much longer than that.

This was our last stop in our adventure/first night out in Portland. After getting dinner at the Mediterranean food cart, we walked down here to get the famous Voodoo Doughnut. The line from the outside was ridiculous as it went out the door and hugged the side of the building. This doughnut shop is located in a very active and electric part of downtown where people are out and about, friends hanging out and families/tourists are grabbing doughnuts for the night. 

We got in line and waited for about 20 minutes or so. Once at the cash register, we ordered a box of doughnuts. I kept my eyes on the blueberry cake doughnut (although  I should have just went with the old fashioned cake doughnut now that I think about it). I like blueberries though and I've had blueberry doughnuts so I thought this would be good too. The doughnuts were cheap. Good prices. Service was okay. The donut shop is quite eclectic in decor and "in-your-face" with doughnuts. Some were decorated with cereal (I don't care for) and others were plain like chocolate frosting or sprinkles. There was a really large doughnut too. I didn't get to eat my doughnut until the morning because we were just all too tired once we got to the place we were staying.

Then next day, I tried my doughnut. It was alright. The other blueberry doughnut I've had at another place did it better in terms of flavor. I mean keeping it in it's box couldn't have changed the flavor much, right? It was cake-y, soft in the middle and had a blueberry flavor. Tasted really artificial though. Unfortunately it was the only doughnut I tried from Voodoo but at the point I wasn't really craving doughnuts or really sweet things anymore. 

Con: CASH ONLY. D'OH!
Make sure you know this before stepping in that long line. Have cash ready because they did not accept card when we went. It's a hassle really.
Although a great novelty. They use the worst doughnut flour and is the worst tasting doughnuts.

Doughnuts - Good!!
Service - BAD!!

In Seattle we have some asskickin' good doughnuts, so I was excited to learn of this wacky doughnut heaven from the food network. 

While these doughnuts are quite tasty and don't leave that gross grease film in ones mouth, they aren't anything to write home about besides their use of strange toppings.

Upon arrival we were uber, yes uber, excited to enter this doughnut realm of wackiness. After stepping in there was some sort of death metal blasting from all corners as if we were in a headbanging metal night club. Not a good start. We decide on some treats and proceed to order from the lady who seemed to good to be serving us but was forced to, maybe that is why there was nothing in her tip jar...

If you are in Portland and have a hankerin' for a sweet treat and don't care if you are treated with a smile, then stop by and try a strange creation.

Got there early, had to wait in line...had high expectations....BUT I come from a city where we have quite a few great doughnut shops.... The donuts here were cold, and i felt like I was paying for the name and the quirky concept...I felt that the taste is masked by all of the gimmicky toppings, not necessarily a great doughnut though....and the staff was to busy trying to be cool vs just give great service...I think Portland needs more doughnut competition if this is considered the best....BUT I did buy a great T-shirt because of the name sake....BUT eh the simple apple fritter I had was cold, and unimpressive.... My husband had a more exotic kind and he LOVES most donuts but was also just not that impressed....Felt again I was paying for the concept not the real quality...... AND had to pay like $2.00 in parking just to run in and get the donuts.... I wouldn't go back...BUT if your visiting Portland it's worth going to just for the namesake and seeing the quirky look....  But they were cold and kinda stale in my opinion.

Not that great.  But, I had the Portland doughnut; custard filled chocolate doughnut.  There are other doughnuts that probably garnered most of the positive attention this place has received.  So, with that said, take my review with that in mind.  I simply think that this place has made a name because of a t.v. show and....literally, a good name.
They don't taste good at all. I prefer any other doughnut chain. Cash only. Definitely not worth the wait or the calories
I'm not a fan of Voodoo Doughnuts. It's too gimmicky...and I judge a donut shop on their old fashioned and raised doughnuts. 'not my go to.
Overrated. ..why would anyone stand in line for doghnuts.   Only visitors.  Good, but not worth the wait or higher cost
It's not worth the wait, and definitely did not live up to the hype for me.

Just don't. A gimmicky, obnoxious hole-in-the-wall found in the seedier, junkie-friendly part of Portland. VD peddles tasteless, overly-sugared doughnuts and couples their lame crullers with even worse service. Perfect for tourists who want to wait in line for an hour to get an 'experience,' but not for anyone who actually wants to enjoy their doughnut. I like punk rock and I like doughnuts, but I like 'em separately. You're better off finding a Safeway and getting your doughnuts there.

These are terrible donuts with stuff stuck too them. Lucky Charms? Just go buy lucky charms. Maple bacon? Go anywhere else and get a maple bar then go get good bacon and just eat them together. Just a tourist trap.

This place does not need a review, it has line ups every day, tourist high season or not.  Having said that, if you are visiting Portland, it really is a must try.  Great donuts, interesting array/selection.  I agree with other reviews in that it would serve them well to have more than one cashier.
If there is a line I would roam about and try later, as if you are in the neighborhood keep an eye on the place and pop in and try it when it seems more quiet.

Soooo not worth the fake lines. (they need to serve faster, lol).
The doughnuts are fair at best.
Only tourists go here that feel cool walking around town with a stupid 
pink box in their hand. Trust me, most other doughnut shops in PDX are better.

I am writing this review for the out-of-towners, not the locals. 

It's a donut. It's got junky nostalgia cereal on it or bacon. It tastes as good as any three ounce 600 calorie thing sold for a dollar could taste. If there's no line or a short line, by all means indulge.

Don't wait in line out in the rain for an hour. Seriously, if you are only in Portland for a couple of days, you are really missing out on so much other stuff you could be doing.  The networks have their own agenda for promoting places and it isn't necessarily based on your quality experience but rather what sounds flashy and "weird." If you google "voodoo" it will fill in the donut part. It's not a conspiracy, it's good marketing.  But good marketing does not make for a payoff for standing out in the rain for 45 minutes.

Definitely iconic and fun, but overhyped and not very tasty.

Imagine lining up with a bunch of drunk people at 2am under a flashing neon sign. Except instead of waiting to get into a club, you are waiting to buy donuts. 

The magic is in the hole.....but there was definitely not too much magic experienced by my tastebuds.

Normal stop for visiting friends and family only. If you are actually looking for good donuts without the "touristy marketing", there are several better alternatives in the Portland area including donut byte labs, blue star, donut day. Donuts are solid but don't expect to be exceptional.
Interesting flavors, but way overhyped... Even major chains like Dunkin donuts serve better tasting donuts.  What's a donut place without quality glazed donuts?
Sure Voodoo is something fun for tourists, but literally only tourists go there. If you want real portland donuts try pips or blue star
I guess for me it wasn't worth the wait.  The donut was fine, but not spectacular.  Fun to take family or friends from out of town just for the experience.

can you get worse donut without going to Salem?  
Don't want to give this place any lip service beyond that.

We visited Voodoo Doughnuts late at night during a visit to Portland. Voodoo is a small independent doughnut shop that's known for it's imaginative doughnut toppings and creative combinations. 

+The "Blood filled" doughnut was tasty
+Lots of fun/unique doughnuts to try
+Open 24hours (except on Sundays)
+Inexpensive

-The location is a little small and cramped
-Not the best area to visit late at night

This was a fun place to visit and you can't really go wrong stopping here for a late night dessert. If you are lucky you might see someone take up their challenge in which you must devour a huge doughnut in like 80 seconds. If you accomplish this feat, the doughnut is gratis!

I should add that while this is a fun place to visit, don't expect gourmet doughnuts, this isn't that type of place. It's really just a place where they sort of experiment with different toppings. For instance the Maple bacon is just a maple doughnut with a strip or two of bacon on it. I had a bite and it was tasty enough, but not what I'd call imaginative. On the other hand, I purchased the "Blood filled" and really liked it. It was sort of a chocolatey doughnut with a small pretzel and raspberry filling, good stuff!

I completely agree with Katy H. on her  review of Voodoo Doughnut. 

Adam Richman glorified this place for the donuts and it seems that because of this everyone says that you have to go. Plus it seems like Voodoo Donuts is like Cocaine to people in Portland. I carried that well-known pink box into the shopping mall and eveyone's head turns in jealousy. Employees ask if they can hold your box while you shop. They just want a whiff or even a taste.

When we got there in the afternoon the line wasn't long, but it was extremely hot outside and even with air condiitoning in the building, you can feel everyone's body heat. When we get to the counter we order a ton of stuff:

The Voodoo Doughnut - donut covered in chocolate and filled with raspberry jelly. Shaped like a person and stabbed in the heart with a pretzel. Has the VD initials on it, though I think that shouldn't be there cuz VD stands for something else in the health field. 

The Peach fritter: Peach fritter covered with a white (cream cheese?) icing and sprinkles. 

The bavarian creme: Donut stuffed with bavarian creme and topped with maple icing.

The raspberry donut: Donut with raspberry filling and lightly glazed

The Old Dirty Bastard: Chocolate Donut with Peanut Butter and Cookie Crumbles

The Maple BAcon Donut: Donut topped with Maple Bacon Icing and Bacon. 

The Mango Tango: Donut filled with Mango Jelly and topped with white icing and sprinled wiht Orange Tang.

The only donut that I liked was the Maple Bacon Donut. What I like about VooDoo Donuts is that the Donut itself is not laden with sugar. It is perfectly cooked and it isn't dry or too sweet. There also isn't this residual fat taste that you get in your mouth after you eat a donut. The icing on all of the VooDoo donuts are all very sweet and in my opinion intolerable. That's why the saltiness of the bacon counterbalances the super sweetness of the icing. I think that I would have liked the other donuts had the icing been not prepared too sweet. 

I think everyone should come here at least once to try the donut and see the huge array of designs. Otherwise, I probably won't return. I'd like to spare my teeth the cavities.
Yup I ate two, one right after the other. They were delicious but bad move on my part, I barfed!!! I would do it again tho.

I have never experienced a more overrated place than Voodoo Doughnut in Portland, Oregon. The wait during peak times can be in the hours. And for what? If they were the most amazing donuts I'd ever had then I'd forgive the wait. If they were even mildly great I could make an argument. But no. The donuts are barely average. Yes, they have original toppings (is maple and bacon even original anymore?), but the donuts themselves are average. Maybe even below average. They're not fluffy, they're too sweet, and worst of all they're stale. With their volume, each batch should be hot and fresh, but instead they feel like the leftovers from yesterday. The best donut we tried was the Captain Crunch, and that's simply because adding Captain Crunch makes desserts taste better. Don't believe me? Throw some on your frozen yogurt next time and I'll accept your apology via Twitter or Instagram.

The only redeeming quality about Voodoo Doughnut is that it's right next to Stumptown Coffee, so you can grab a coffee or three during your marathon wait session. I'm clearly not the only person with this brilliant idea, since every other person in line also had a cup in their hand.
Not sure what the hype is here. They're really just pretty donuts, that's about it...

Sorry but this Entertainment Donut thing is getting boring now that everyone is making their version of "psycho", "Diablo", "Crazy" or in this case "voodoo"...(we have Psycho here in San Jose, same product).  My experience was underwhelming.  I was visiting Portland, we had a break and I made my coworker walk to this place with me.  When we arrived we were greeted by a SEA of Portlands finest homeless stoners and drunks all camped outside the front doors asking for change, food, pot, etc...it got obnoxious.  Then after standing in a line that I expected since this place is famous I was asked by the cashier what I wanted, I ordered the little voodoo man with the pretzel stuck into him to take to another coworker who craps herself for stuff like this so she can do selfies with her food and post it all over Yelp for feedback..I wanted to stick a pretzel in the cashier girl who didn't ONCE look me in the face, her dead angry eyes darting all over the place EXCEPT at me...I'm not THAT ugly am I?  perhaps I am but man was she and the cashier girl next to her completely OVER their jobs.  Wrapping this up this place sells donuts with toys and tricks on them.  If you need the tricks and the toys and marketing then Pshycho donuts is for you...I'll take a plain chocolate/maple Krueler any day over something with crap stuck all over it.  Experience it once I guess...the indifferent service and the pushy homeless drug crowd outside made my mind up for me on never needing to return.

Looks over flavor. It is the tourist trap so beware! I wanted to tried once since it was my first time coming to Portland. I kept my expectations low but they still weren't met. If you want cute voodoo donuts for its decorations then stop by otherwise, save yourself the time and money!
We thought it was over hyped via food channels and didn't meet expectations. Sorry but nothing special. Unless we ordered the wrong sugary snack...

This place is overrated. I'm from Los Angeles and heard that this place is the place to be when it comes to donuts... the hype??? What hype.... I come to understand that this place is all about marketing. I was talking to a lady outside the place as she ate her donut and told me she was a food blogger in oregon and she also told me that she felt let down about this place. We ordered the maple bacon, and old dirty bastard? These donuts were not fresh at all. We came at 10am. They tasted old and the dough was hard. There's a better place where I live in Los Angeles... absolutely horrible here. It's funny... I talk to locals in portland and they swear about "blue star" to be the better donut shop out of the 2. Damn.... I chose the wrong place to eat for donuts.

The line was crazy, absolutely insane. I stood in it for 5 minutes, wanted to play Rock Paper Scissors to make the call on whether we stay or go, but we just walked away donut-less. That line was not moving so we guesstimated about a 45-50 minute wait. I just can't wait that long for something that will probably shave a good year and a half off my life expectancy. Oh well, maybe next time when I'm in town... Because I might kinda need that captain crunch donut...

the lines are ridiculously insane, did not stand in line and boy am I glad I didn't ! I really did want to try voodoo before leaving Portland. Was getting bummed that as my vacation was ending I had yet to go there. While on a walking tour of Portland we stopped @ voodoo and our tour guide surprised us with a box of donuts. Donuts were mediocre , don't understand why the line is hours long. I had the peanut butter chocolate donut, Was good but not worth waiting for hours. Try blue star donuts not too far from there !
100% not worth the wait. Tastes like bodega donuts with crap on top of them. Nothing special at all.

Voodoo is a Portland trademark, and anyone visiting the city should check it out. You will get a kick out of the names of all the doughnuts, and the pink building will make you smile.
But, for the record, Portland locals don't really frequent voodoo. There are WAY better doughnut shops in the area with no lines and affordable prices.

Portland's most famous and popular Doughnut shop. Known for their extremely crazy and unique donuts.

When you hear about Portland, you often hear about Powell's bookstore, The Rose Garden, and especially Voodoo Donuts. Voodoo Doughnuts is Portland's biggest and most popular doughnut shop. Being so famous, I knew I had to visit it at least once. There are several Voodoo Doughnut locations but I visited the main Voodoo Doughnut location near Old Town/ChinaTown.

My friend and I visited Voodoo's at around 10:17am and boy was the line long. The sheer amount of people waiting for the line was so long, it could even rival Disneyland lines!

We ended up waiting around an hour until we got to the register. There is a giant menu outside the store and a variety of donuts inside, but I had my game plan for doughnuts ready. One thing that I really loved was the sheer amount of creativity and uniqueness 

My friend and I ordered:
Old Dirty Bastard (Oreos & Peanut Butter), Fruit Loops Doughnut, Voodoo Doughnut (A Chocolate Donut with frosting made to look like a Voodoo Doll and jam filling with a pretzel stick in the middle), and Maple Bacon. And a nice refreshing carton of milk to go with all the awesome donuts.

The Old Dirty Bastard was personally too much for me since I don't enjoy peanut butter. My friend who really likes peanut butter thought that this donut was good but not amazing.
The Fruit Loops Doughnut was so disappointing. The fruit loops on top were stale, and the doughnut itself was sort of plain.
The Voodoo Doughnut was arguably the best doughnut out of my box. The jam inside was a nice addition to the doughnut, and the shape of the doughnut made it fun to eat! I'm also just a giant fan of chocolate doughnuts.
Last but not least, the Maple Bacon. The Maple Bacon is a maple syrup with bacon doughnut. A sweet and salty experience. I personally thought the doughnut itself was good, but the bacon on top was too inconvenient to eat. It was just a giant piece of cold bacon that wouldn't break into pieces easily.

Overall, Voodoo Doughnut is Portland's most famous doughnut store. I think Voodoo's is easily the most unique and creative doughnut place around, but in terms of quality and time I spent waiting in line for these doughnuts, makes this place a visit once and done.

Tourist trap. Doughnuts are not really that good. Maybe because i got a doughnut that has been sitting around all day long. But nothing special. I may go back to see if the hot fresh doughnuts are better. one would thin that they would be. If they are i will change my review. Also there are a lot of creepy people outside that place asking for money. So be safe and go in a group if you go at night.

Voodoo donuts is not my thing, but lots of people love the novelty of foot loop donuts and such, but as far as delicous donuts go they are not on my top 3 list, but as a company it does lots of wonderful things and is at the heart of Portlands unusual side which makes Portland the place it is.

Voodoo donuts is good for novelty, but the donuts themselves taste pretty basic. 

My best friend and I came here on our way back from Washington. There was long line outside, but the wait time was short. 

We purchased the Voodoo man, Diablous Rex, Old Dirty Bastard, and the Cock and Balls. The voodoo man and diablous rex tasted the same. The c & b was huge, and it was cream filled. The old dirty bastard had a lot going, including Oreos and peanut butter. It was a bit much for me. 

The price is very reasonable. For two coffees and four donuts I paid about $10.00.

This place is a hit it once and quit it for me. I tried it once and that's enough.

Okay, guys, let's be clear. THEY'RE DONUTS. It's fried dough. It can only be so good or so bad. 

Locals don't come here for damn good reason: they know they can get donuts where there's not wrap-around lines and surly, stressed-out cashiers. (I found this article particularly illuminating: http://www.wweek.com/portland/article-21767-the_hole_story.html) People come here for the name and for the gimmicks. If you're into penis-shaped donuts with cream fillings, by all means mosey on over.

That being said, the donuts are fine. Because, like I said, you can only mess up a donut so much. I wouldn't recommend getting the fritter--in my experience, it's 90% congealed oil. Not pleasant.

Meh. Not that great. Granted there is a lot of variety and for donuts, they are blingy. But the quality of the donuts and the flavors - not overly inventive or refined. Worth going for the first time, but otherwise, it's just a pile of sugar for a 30 minute wait.

Day old donuts at a grocery store taste better. The prices are triple than most bakeries because of the reputation for weird. However, their most creative idea is putting crushed cold cereal on the frosting. No regard for being sanitary, the workers look like they never clean anything. Don't be caught in the tourist trap. Cash only

So... I'm not sure why there's a line constantly outside this place. Seems like if you're in Portland, it's a thing you must do. The donuts are not warm or fresh from the oven. They are huge sugar bombs so be prepared for that. The bacon fell flat on the maple bacon donut and just tasted sweet and greasy. Also the Portland cream donut is just a rip off a Boston cream pie. There are better donuts out there!

I don't know why people like this place.  There's a long ass line, but it moved really fast. The donuts just taste like pure sugar.  Absolutely way too sweet.  The designs on the donuts are unique and very Halloween themed, but really do not taste very good. Took a couple bites and felt like complete crap after.  Extremely too heavy. We got 4 donuts, took a few bites of each and just threw away the rest.  Great design, but not great flavor/quality.  Maybe fun for kids??? Would not get again though.  Blue star donuts all the way!

It was kind of a let down honestly. Nothing was fresh when I got there. A staff member gave me her "I'm vegan gluten free and allergic to chocolate" attitude, so she could not recommend anything. I had like a snickers donut or something. A big "meh..." for me. Just not great. I wanted to love this thing. Everyone said I had to go, so I went.
Voodoo doughnuts...its the line that kills me. I can't justify standing in line for a Krispy Kreme donut with Kool-Aid sprinkled on it.

No cards!!!! Cash only spot. 

Passing through Portland had limited time for culinary experiences. Voodoo Donuts was for shir an experience. We went at 6pm on a Monday and had zero line. 

Pros: hip; parking; decor; vegan options; display for vegan options; Apple vegan fritter; creative use of cereal toppings; awesome pink boxes 

Cons: lack of restroom; cash only; adult humor [both my kids bought "cock and balls donuts" was horrified that they were also cream filled]; lack donut descriptions on menu; donuts just okay 

We told the kids for being good for the 5 hours drive to Portland they could each pick 1 donut, anything. They have donuts that are like two chocolate bar donuts making a 'T' but because of fluffy roundness the resemblance is closer male anatomy so the name is apt. In the spinning clear displays there are decorated donuts with words & art. The cost of these huge donuts because of decor is $7.50 each. And as aforementioned there is no description of items so I was surprised to find these donuts, the cock and balls donuts are filled with white cream. 

I ate a vegan apple fritter. Most Fritters are not vegan and it didn't rock my world but it was a good vegan donut for shir. Plus it was only 2 bucks. 

Hubs had a voodoo donut & blueberry flavor. His donuts were $5 bucks combined. 

5 donuts & 4 people total= $22 

Overall memorable but not in a rush to go back.

Voodoo Doughnuts is quirky, vibrant, and a fun place to take out-of-towners.... but if there is a line (which there almost always is), forget it.

We went to Voodoo early morning on a weekday and there wasn't a line to our surprise. The decor and menu is funky and the staff is very friendly. 

The donuts are good, but nothing to write home about. We tried the bacon maple bar, which literally was a donut with a slab of bacon on it. My sister likes the Voodoo donut, which was decorated like a Voodoo Doll. 

Creative? Yes. Delicious? Meh.

If you really want and mindblowingly good donut, I hear Bluestar and Pips are better choices (I still need to check them out for myself!)

So sad. I came here all the way from San Diego and was really excited to try voodoo doughnuts especially the lemon filled powdered one. I got back to the place I'm staying on my last night to find that my doughnut wasn't even filled. Completely dry  NO LEMON FILLING! NO FILLING AT ALLLLLL!

I don't buy into all of the hype of this place.  I am a major donut fan, and would have had a stack of donuts for my wedding instead of cake if my husband would have been on board with that.  If you want good donuts, go to Joe's in Sandy, Oregon.  Hands down the BEST donuts in the metro area!  Voodoo is creative however..I'll give them that.   Where else can you get a cream-filled donut shaped like male anatomy?

The experience of Voodoo is cool. But each time I go I'm a little less satisfied. 

Takeaway the hype and the lines and it's just an a-ok doughnut that looks better than most.

If you've never been I recommend going and getting an assorted dozen. If you've been before maybe check out Blue Star Donuts.

Voodoo donuts is a place everyone is told they must visit when they at in Portland. I dropped by voodoo in the evening, though not late night when I'd have to wait forever. 

The place is 24/7 and cash only. The donut selection is pretty extensive and has many of your standard types alone with interesting options. 

I went with and old fashioned and blueberry cake. Old fashioned donuts should be solid at a good donut shop. 

The verdict? Decent donut for the price but If I'd have waited a while for it I'd be disappointed. Blue star is more expensive but blows this place out of the water.

Are you kidding me? These donuts are just like Dunkin Donuts. I don't understand the hype or the long lines. They are definitely not worth the wait or money. Okay, their box is cool. If you want a REAL artisan bakery, try Maggie's Buns in Forest Grove. They are worth the trip.

Tourist trap - for those of you who want to witness a homeless guy peeing on the line that you have to wait on to get into this dingy little place - then by all means - this is your place! Panhandlers are all over this block. 

But inside isn't much better. The Donuts are tired. The selections are geared more toward kids or stoned college kids. Fruit loops, Oreos jammed on top of a dry donut etc. The service is consistently rude and unfriendly - and honestly the place is so dirty. After bringing yet another out of town friend here - we've decided to stop coming even for that - the place has lost all of its portland charm. (And Blue Star makes way better donuts!).

Honestly, I don't get the hype.
Don't get me wrong, they are good donuts....but they are just donuts. Fun paint on the walls and you can get married there....but the donuts are average.

Meh.  It is just a doughnut.  but the place is iconic and must go at least once in your life.  seems like every time I go by one of their locations, there is always a line.  Not worth waiting in line for 30 minutes for a doughnut that is covered in a kids cereal.

The doughnuts here are good.  They have a few unique options that are definitely worth trying at least once.  I enjoy taking visiting friends from out of town here if I can.

That said, I can't stand the lines.  If I happen to be in the area and the line *isn't* out the door, I might pop in for a visit.  The other thing that keeps me from visiting is the fact that they ONLY accept cash.  They do have an ATM inside, but.. meh, it isn't worth the fees to me.  I'm not a cash carrier.  If you are, this won't matter to you.

I gave 3 stars because the doughnuts are pretty good and I enjoy the unique offerings the place has.  However, the lack of parking, long lines, and required cash make it rather inconvenient for me.  The doughnuts are not SO good that they make up for these things.  Still, go at least once - especially if you're just in town visiting.  My favorite is the Old Dirty Bastard... Don't try to eat more than one of these at a time.  Even one could be pushing it - it's large, rich, and filling.

Blah blah blah.

BLAH BLAH BLAH.

BLAHBITY BLAH BLAH.

Sorry. I was just trying to spare you from having to read the same ol' same ol' type of review that's probably already been written about Voodoo. Yeah, this place is freaking famous, so no wonder it's got over a thousand reviews! Everyone wants a piece of the pie! Er, donut!

Anyway, this place does have insanely novel donuts, all cuckoo and crazy and lots of fun. Yet, unless I was a tourist, I would not be okay with standing in line for an upwards of 2-hour wait. There's something very... un-natural (and un-Voodooey) about that. 

I've really only been here 2 times, both of which were with family from out of town. The other times I was really hungry (and the hours were so weird that there really wasn't much of a line).

Yes, I do love me a classic Voodoo donut, but at the same time my cravings for sweet, friend and fatty can be satiated by other means (and note: by MUCH FASTER means).

Coming cross-country from Florida, I had to see what the buzz was all about. Of course when we arrived there, the lines wrapped around the block and decided we should come back at a later time. After a couple of tries, at around 2pm, the wait looked bearable and we decided to get in line. 

The donuts are really good but not the best I've ever had. Though their crazy donuts are what they are known for (Bacon Maple Bar, Voodoo Doll, Cock N Balls) I preferred their more "basic" ones, especially their cake donuts. My favorites are the Glazed Old Fashioned, Blueberry Cake, Maple Bar and the Chocolate Cake.
 
Took off a star because the lines are just crazy at this particular spot. The donuts from the voodoo van or the shop in Orlando are just as good. That being said I do think you have to check this place out at least once if you visit Portland even just for the experience and photos.

Original product and fair prices, not bad. It didn't seem like the donuts were super fresh or intoxicating but customers do love with a donut craving well-satisfied. Wish they had gluten-free donuts!

My fave here is the original lovely pink box the donuts come in, never seen anything like it. Lines do get long so come around 7pm before the after dinner rush and you're good to go with no line on a Saturday night!

While Voodoo has done a great job marketing itself for tourists their product isn't the greatest. Yes they're fun and gimmicky but they don't make up for the long line and mediocre donut you end up with.
Meh. I've experienced better is right. A donut is a donut. Honestly all this place should be known for is being open 24/7 selling odd donuts. All I'm saying is there are other donuts.

Tourist-trap-alert!!
Huge lines, wait times go into hours during peak times. They sell donuts, in fun(& weird) colors and shapes. The donuts, the shop, the decor-- would make for nice instagram posts but that's about it.
The donuts taste like plain simple donuts nothing more, nothing extra ordinary. You just spend an hour standing in line to get a funnily shaped donut, thats all there is.
The donuts are not bad by any standards but nothing that would blow away your mind.
Do check it out if the lines are not crazy( maybe early morning), more for the experience than for the  food, otherwise just a tourist trap--better avoided.

I found the variety of donuts here fascinating and overwhelming.  I'm weird, I don't really like sweets that are super sweet so I had a hard time choosing here.  Some of the items sounded good until you started asking and seeing them and then I was like no!  So apple fritter wise they have many options, like one with bananas and what not but when they explained they had layer upon layer of stuff on them I ended up with just a traditional one, nothing extra on it.  They also had doughnuts with captain crunch, fruitloops and gobs of other stuff on them, just not my cup of tea.  I think its one of those places to go in for the experience and maybe grab one to go but otherwise I would stay clear from it.  I went at night around 8pm or so and there was no wait.
best donuts in town but the wait is ridiculous
Worst doughnut I have ever had!  Dry and tasted like grease.  I'll stick with Krispy Cream.

This is the only place we go for doughnuts and tends to be a must for our out-of-town guests.  My only question for the folks at Voodoo is, "why not clean a little?"  Just a little--doesn't have to be sterile--just enough to not inspire a question about what might be going on behind the counter.
I like their creations, but I think the donut base is so-so.  There are definitely better donuts in Portland, but it's fun and can't knock it for putting Portland (more) on the map.

It was fun to stop in to see what all of the talk was about....but honestly, the doughnuts weren't spectacular.  They were good.  Apparently, you should get there early to get the one you want.  They didn't have my first choice, so I ended up with something else.  I don't even remember what it was.  That's how memorable it was.  It was a doughnut and that makes it good in my book, but it's not the best doughnut.

Don't kill me, people... but this place was just ok. It's not that the donuts were not good. They were. They are just not standing-in-line-for-an-hour-must-go-out-of-my-way-to-get-them good. We were fortunate to stop by at night and there was only maybe two other people in front of us. We got a pretty big variety of donuts to try them all- from regular glazed ones, to specialty ones like the Old Dirty Bastard. The dough was good and the concept  of shapes/names is what makes this spot unique. 

I'd say if you get lucky and find this place semi empty as I did. Go! it is a sign. But don't waste your lovely day in line. 

Also.. don't find out the hard way that this place is CASH ONLY (rolls eyes).

Donuts for drunk people is what I think of voodoos donuts. The donuts are very sweet but the folks that work there seem to work very long shifts. I would take out of town friends there only if they really requested it.

All hype. Cute nonetheless. I hate overly sweet desserts so this was not for me. Everything's either covered in frosting or filled with jellies. I do however bumped up a star for making a gray fluffy original glazed donut. If it was fresh and warm, it'd be fantastic.

the maple bacon bar was incredible. the rest of the doughnuts were just OK. not worth the wait, or the exposure to indecency. I get that they're rude and crude and bordering on obscene, but that's not why I go to a donut shop...

Good luck getting to it!!! Parking is a beast! And not in a good way, very cool place though, someplace different in kind of a shady/trendy part of town. They only accept cash, but have a huge assortment of doughnuts not found at any old bakery.

This was on the short list of places my husband wanted to try while visiting friends and family in Portland.  He loves donuts.  He loves bacon.  A maple bacon donut?  Just try to keep him away.

Surprisingly, the maple bacon donut really did have good flavor, but I wouldn't want to eat a whole one.  In general the donuts are way too sweet here, though the cake ones are better than the raised donuts.  We had a big group so I got to taste several.  The grape ape was atrocious to me, it tasted like a pixie stick.  The Portland Creme (Bavarian, my usual favorite) was too sticky sweet.  

My 14 year old nephew nearly finished the giant glazed.  We were very impressed.

It's worth a visit (and a wait in line) just for the novelty of it.  In fact, two separate tour groups came through during our visit.

I think my husband would give this place five stars, and he's a donut fiend.  I give it three, and I am not a big donut fan.  So take that information for what it's worth.

Decent enough standard donuts. The specialty donuts look great and may sound great and quirky, but there's really nothing fantastic about stale, three-day-old tasting fruit loops on a mediocre glazed donut.

The cashiers are snippy more often than not and can be quite rude.
Busy place with many characteristic on donught...  bit pricy on doughnut.  Good for one time for fun...

Atmosphere is great! Long lines but moves very fast. Selection of donuts and names are great. 

Flavor....okay. Not bad but also not going no back. 

We tried the : double bubble, grape ape, dirty snowball and captain crunch. The captain won out

Here is a word puzzle for you:

Voodoo Doughnut 
Rated

See if you can figure it out.

Came here on a Thursday night around 12:30am and waited amongst the drunk crowd spilling in from the local bars. Must have been the right time to go because there were only 6 people ahead of us and soon after 15 people behind.

Captain crunch donut - definitely the best one of the three, but tasted exactly as you'd think it would taste...glazed donut with vanilla frosting with captain crunch cereal. You can't go wrong with captain crunch on anything can you?
Something with oreos and peanut butter? - Not that great. Wasn't amazing, wasn't terrible.
Voodoo man - Of course I had to try the voodoo man for voodoo donuts. Chocolate glazed donut with rasberry filling and a pretzel for a voodoo stick. If you start from the top, you won't reach the jelly for quite a while. 

All in all, this place is a novelty donut shop. Unique donut names, but doesn't seem like anything special. Good to try to say you've tried it, but I'm glad I didn't have to wait more than 15 minutes. Very friendly cashier as well!

To be honest, i really want to know why its so famous but definitely not the taste of the donut.

Its sooooooooooooooo sweet, all i tasted was sugar and flour. I think i will go bk to krispy donut, light, fluffy and soft
Totally overrated. Donuts are too sweet, dry and i just don't get why people spend so much time waiting in line for these...plenty of better sweets in Portland!
They make some good donuts, but you've got to wait in line for about 45 minutes...  Nope, not worth it because in the end they are just good donuts.
Not great donuts, super sugary. Just a tourist trap that's not worth it.

I would give you zero star if I could but can't. I have been here multiple times before. This time around, my friends and I got 18 donuts and they got our order wrong and to add on to that, the girl that was helping us missed one dount I wanted and she turned around to talk shit about me and my friends. What the fuck is that? Is that how you do business? When people come down to you from the north to give you business? We drove a few hours for donuts NOT FOR YOU TO LOOK DOWN ON US AND RUN YOUR MONTH, YOU CAN'T WAIT TO GO INTO THE BACK? I WAS RIGHT IN FRONT OF YOU. I'm piss and very disappointed in you! I guess I'll just go to another one.

Over rated ,but fun . They have a large selection of vegan doughnuts,
the grape Kool-aid is my fave . 
I never feel good after eating here.
Go figure .
Yes and though its a bit of a novelty especially for tourists I still think that Mighty O is better.

The creative side of these donuts is that each donut on the menu has a cool design to it.  The donuts were colorful.  The line was actually alright on a Thursday morning and took about 30 minutes.  There's a giant sprinkled donut on the ceiling inside the shop.  There are 2 cash registers now, I assume this really sped things up for the line outside.  We ordered 8 donuts of a variety.  These are not gourmet donuts, they are average donuts with creative names made with cool toppings and colors.  It is definitely an experience, but I would not expect 5-star donut standard.  Come here and see what all the fuss is about, grab a few donuts, and form your own opinion.  Have fun!
Whether a local or a tourist, Voodoo Doughnut is a definite Portland Bucket List item for everyone.  Experience it for the experience itself, not so much for an extraordinary doughnut.

The donuts are pretty good and the customer service was great as well. I went here really late at night on a weekday, because I had seen the long lines and I really wasn't going to stand in line that long for a donut. And I'm glad I didn't. While they are yummy (specially the Oreo cookie one) they aren't out of this world good.
Donuts are more of a novelty than a good donut. Thick, too-sweet frosting. But they have a "cool" factor - fun designs, names, toppings. At least try it once and decide for yourself.

Go for the tourist experience but not worth the long line if you just want a doughnut. 

On a Friday night at 8pm, we waited about 20 min. in line.

Fresh donut piled high with funky toppings but way too much frosting so it is not balanced and a sugar overload. The cake is as good as any fresh donut at almost any donut shop.

A friend bought us some Voodoo donuts with an array of options. She got a blueberry cake donut (which is all I need in this life), M&Ms, smores, grape, and I don't remember the last one. I don't know the price point and I haven't stepped foot in this location. I just know based on the taste of the donuts. The blue berry cake donut was good but everything else was okay. I would be more careful picking which donut to get next time because they look good but the ones I tried were just meh.

Voodoo Doughnut was a must-visit on a recent trip to Portland - it's quite the tourist attraction. And while I'm glad we tried it, I would not return if I find myself in Portland again. If you ask me, the doughnuts themselves weren't very good. Both the taste and texture of the yeast doughnuts were unimpressive. The only thing I really liked about this sweet treat were the unique toppings. My favorite was the 'Oh Captain My Captain' - a regular yeast doughnut with icing and captain crunch cereal on top. If I could combine the delicious toppings of Voodoo Doughnuts with the to-die-for yeast doughnut of my favorite Cincinnati bakery - Holtman's - I'd be in heaven (and fat!)

Overrated and overpriced, granted the donuts look do unique as if a 5th grade class had a baking workshop. Customer service can suck their own cocknballs delight. It was not worth the wait as the voodoo dozen , is the worst donut selection, and the al la carte is double the price. 2 dozen plain tasting donuts came out to be $33. Voodoo man, FAIL! Maple Bacon FAIL! Blunts donuts FAIL!  :-(

We were tourists so we indulged.  Our group (2 donut enthusiasts included) found voodoo options to be too over the top -- very dense, very sweet.  We got a dozen variety but found they all kinda tasted the same.  On our next trip to Portland, I will skip voodoo....
Some of the dozen or so we bought were above average, but most were just average in quality.  I'm not sure they currently live up to their reputation.

Great place to go if you don't mind waiting in line for a doughnut.  They are interesting to say the least but the doughnuts aren't light and airy like a doughnut should be (my opinion).
