They can be a little on the heavy side. Everyone who comes to PDX want to go there, i usually just ask people sitting on the outside patio if we can look at their doughnuts, it saves on standing in line.

Unique, yes. Overrated, yes. Service, horrible. Soup Nazi experience. Be sure not to step a foot inside the door unless one of the grouchy bored with their jobs cashiers extends the personal invite to do so or you will have to endure a full 70 second lecture on how their line ( of NINE people total) works before you have to interrupt them with a very squimy toddler in your arms and flatly say "can I just get a doughnut." then wait another 2 minutes while they go talk to a co-worker and re-tell the story of how we walked up to their register after the previous customer walked away. Seriously it killed the joy. At the end of the visit, all I got was a HUGE sugar rush and letdown on what had been hyped for so long, by so many. Captain crunch, Oreo, and maple bacon were treats indeed, but the experience was HORRIBLE! :/

Couldn't say much about the food because the line that wrapped around the building was a HUGE turn off. 
I "guess" they're good...judging by the line.

Before arriving to Portland, I did a little research on the MUST DOS and Voodoo Doughnuts were one of the suggestions. Coming from Chicago, I was willing to give anything a chance and waiting in long lines isn't anything new to me. When we came to Voodoo Doughnuts around noon, there was already a line but nothing too extreme because the line was moving fast. When it was our turn, the lady who was helping us was really rude and to me, customer service is everything. She seemed really impatient when I didn't even take long to pick me donuts.

Captain, My Captain - The dough was nothing out of the ordinary. I picked this one because I thought it was going to be good with captain crunch but to my disappointment, it was extremely sweet with the cream that held the captain crunch to the doughnuts. Also, the captain crunch was stale!!

Voodoo Doll - This was definitely better than Captain, My Captain. I really enjoy the jelly inside. Although the cream on top was still a bit sweet. The creation of the character is pretty cute. 

Like most places, it's overhyped for an average doughnut and I'm glad I checked it out to know, not to come back.

So I'm rolling down Burnside, thinking about sideburns, and I hang a left on third and I see the line at this here Voodoo location. And there is the line. Long. Cordoned off with a rope. Full of folks hoping for doughnut glory. I'm going to try to stick to my "don't be a hater" principle here while I stick to my personal likes and dislikes about this joint. The rancor of the crowd won't sway me this day. 

Good: This was the first place I ever had bacon on a maple bar. It was novel and gorgeous this first time that shock of maple sweetness met the salty smoke of cured pork belly in my oral cavity. It's been done to death since then. I could probably write a decent academic piece that strongly correlated the "bacon on EVERYTHING!!!" movement with this place, but I'll take up that work another day. For this day, this doughnut is unmitigated good. 

Good: last time I checked, you could still get a bucket of older doughnuts from the night before in a 5 gallon bucket for like $10. The first time I tried this I was a minor hero when I showed up to the office with a bucket of goodies that was sorta commingled, sorta smashed in places, and sort of like a food-grade garage can (in a good way).  If they still do this and you have lots of hungry folks, get this. If they don't do this anymore, then join me for a moment of silence for the joys of the past deals no longer with us. Amen. 

Bad: Cereals on doughnuts is a gimmick that results in a fine doughnut with stale old crap all over it.  I see what the idea is. It doesn't work unless you throw some of Clark W. Griswold's high gloss cereal varnish on there. That doesn't really exist. Neither does a good cereal doughnut. Stop. 

Bad: cash only. It's not 1985. 

Good: The Old Dirty Bastard.

Honestly, I don't think this place deserves the accolades or the hate it gets. It makes good doughnuts, bad doughnuts, and some are in between doughnuts. If you wanted a consistently better doughnut in downtown, I'd march yourself up Burnside to Blue Star. If you want to cross it off your list in PDX I won't begrudge you that feat. Just skip the cereal.

They're donuts. Average donuts. If you're visiting Portland please don't waste your precious time in the insane line-up for this place. I stayed at a nearby hotel and passed this place a few times and was shocked by the line winding up and down around the block, especially on a Friday night. Worse was that the homeless people in the area had to watch this consumerist spectacle. Eventually on the last night of my trip, I saw that the line was relatively short, and I just had to know what the big deal was. Lined up for 5-10 minutes and got a maple cream donut, and my boyfriend got the Homer Simpson and an Oreo donut. They were definitely good, but nothing remarkable. They didn't taste that much different to Tim Horton's in Canada. By all means if there is no line, you may as well stop in this place to check out the fun decor and grab a tasty donut. But good lord is it really worth half an hour of your short life?
Lol, this place is a weak, overpriced tourist trap. When I want real delicious donuts, I go to tonalis on Alberta.

Had to visit since I've heard so much about the place.  The line wasnt long when we got there which was nice.   Don't expect this though - I'm sure it's crazy long in the morning.   I love the donut options and the store itself was pretty cool!   I had the 'No-Name Donut' (with the rice krispies and peanut butter drizzle) which was yummy! I would have given a slightly higher rating, BUT, as we were taking pictures of the store, the girl at the register rudely said, "Don't take my picture..."  Ummmm noooo, we aren't trying to take your picture, we are trying to take a picture of the donuts - you just happen to be IN the way!!  I also used their restroom and it was filthy - smelled like an outside public bathroom rather than an inside one.   They also only take cash - this bugs me, as I'm not one to carry cash on me often.  

Aside from all that, still check this place out, even if it's just to get pics of the brightly-colored location.

Overrated, especially if you are from a city that is larger than Portland. Yes, there are "clever" donuts that are a touch irreverent, but there's also absolutely nothing special about the taste.

The dough was tough, dense, and tasted as if it had been fried 7 hours ago. This is probably because when you're standing in the line 40 minutes deep, you actually stand next to the vents where you can see the donuts waiting to be covered in various toppings. That in and of itself isn't a problem, but when the vents open to the sidewalk, which smells like urine, then it begins to all make sense. Perhaps that is why Voodoo needs to lather on toppings:  to mask the essence of Portland.
I just don't get all the hype. I've tried them on several occasions, like when someone at work brings in a box. I don't think they taste good. Safeway has better donuts.

A tourist stop if you are looking for something unique to Portland. But if you are looking for flavor, find another donut shop. This place is hyped up for it's fun donut shapes and unique mash-ups. Cereal, cookies, peanut butter, m&m's and more all topping these donuts. It's fun but too much and too heavy. The donut themselves are not that great either. Don't waste your time waiting in line if you're goal is to get a great donut. If you're here for a gimmicky donut, then this is the place for you.

This place is such a classic Portland Hype type of joint. The doughnuts, while possibly a step above gas station ones (but maybe on par with Grocery store doughnuts), are just as average tasting as you can get. The only plus is that they're gimmicky and have silly names. Cash only.
I didn't think that the taste of the donut was amazing enough to go there again, but at least I got to meet the celebrity pastry, voodoo doll.

I knew that the doughnuts probably wouldn't be quite worth the wait in line, but glad I did so just for the visual appeal (and resulting photo op). As someone who's lactose intolerant, it was great to have vegan options on the menu! Glad I went the once, but next time I'm in Portland, I'll just head to Blue Star.
Basic Greasy donuts, I do not understand why Portland celebrates this business.
If you want donuts with a lot of stuff thrown on them, knock yourself out. Its a cultural experience I guess.

Growing up in Portland, I went to voodoo donuts a few times a year as a teenager. They're definitely not the best donuts in Portland, but it's always a fun experience, and a very "Portland" experience if you're a tourist. These donuts are very heavy (I mean physically heavy too - carrying a box around is very tiring) and pretty sweet, so if you're sweet averse I would recommend getting a flavor like maple bacon or the Old Dirty Bastard, and not one with candy or cereal on top. Have fun picking out fun flavors, but don't expect a great culinary experience.

Since they're so heavy, they're much better when they're (relatively) fresh, so if you take a box to another city for your friends, by the time they eat some, they'll probably think you're crazy for dragging those donuts around the US. Maybe you can just eat the whole box for yourself while traveling. Note that these donuts are not expensive, but they're definitely not cheap and you won't feel like you're getting a great deal on them. 

There's going to be a line pretty much whichever location you go, so bring some friends or talk to people in line. Portlanders are friendly (though you might not find many in line)! If you go to the location in SW, you can visit the "Keep Portland Weird" sign, and if you go to the NE location, you can sit in their coffin chair or lie in the dentist chair and have your friend pretend she's fixing a cavity for you (I have weird friends).

OVERRATED, sadly. 

My couchsurfer warned me not to go, but then someone else said NO YOU SHOULD GO FOR THE PORTLAND EXPERIENCE. So we just went for the shameless picture of the voodoo doughnut. 

Even in line, these older women were hyping up the voodoo doughnut saying it was so good especially with the jam inside. 

My voodoo doughnut looked really messed up and it was blue/orange frosting (SUCH UGLY COLORS, sorry if those are Oregon colors ha). It just tasted like a basic chocolate donut with jam. Wish I would've tried another flavor like the oreo one, or maple bacon. It was only like $2 and the line went pretty fast so oh well. It's also cash only.

Wow. I can't imagine thinking that just working for a place that sells pretty ok and gimmicky donuts makes me somehow above being nice, friendly or helpful even though I work in the food service industry. Donuts are good, the people who work here are rude. Grab a coffee down the street and enjoy the nicer folks of Portland. Skip the Voodoo.
I think it just over hyped. They are okay but not really that good to make me wait for 45 mins.

I'd give this place a zero if I could. Even though it's a Portland novelty, I advise any real donut enthusiast to avoid this place. Waited about half an hour which I expected and then ordered only 4 donuts. The shop itself stunk like urine (smell came from the washroom it turns out) and everything looked really grungy. I get it, that's kinda the look anyways but is it sanitary? I think not. I took one bite of 2 of the donuts and couldn't go on. The most sugary awful things i've ever had. I have had way better donuts at Tim Hortons (which isn't saying a whole lot) and there's no way I'd even look at another Voodoo again.

I liked this place better when it was a tiny hole in the wall, for some reason it just made it better. The best doughnut you can eat is the orange tang though. It sounds weird but it is truly amazing.

The donuts were good - tasty and unique, but Voodoo Doughnut was not as incredible as all the hype led me to believe.  Yes, I did enjoy my orange tang sprinkled donut, but it wasn't one of my favorite ones ever, nor was my husband's selection.  And the store itself was completely underwhelming - dark, tiny, and boring.  This place would do well to have less hype, and thus new patrons would have less heightened expectations.

In my opinion, not the freshest tasting donuts.  We are tourist and were told by many people that we had to try this place.  Staff was not friendly or helpful.  It's hard to order donuts from a revolving display case.  Since we went midweek, we did not have to wait in line.

I feel as though this place is just hyped up by everyone and in reality it wasn't that great. I heard about Voodoo from so many people and was excited to try it. However, I do not like donuts that are overly sweet and Voodoo had really sweet donuts. I couldn't get through one.

I also was really disappointed with the service. I had asked the worker at the counter what she could reccomend and she was not friendly towards me at all. It was as though she didn't care and wasn't enthusiastic about helping me. Does it really hurt you to just give me a reccomendation?

As a doughnut shop it's so-so. As case study for professional marketing it's a MUST. 

As others have mentioned, I'm not sure how fairly average doughnut shop has managed to become associated with the very fabric of Portland's being just by throwing some glitter on the wall and selling over-sized boxes.

They have one infamous cream doughnut that looks like a dong, but I think they missed the boat for that being shocking by a good 15-20 years. I'm pretty sure there are erotic bakeries in Chelsea (Manhattan in New York City for the West-Coast lifers) that have reached the point of willing to depict full hardcore pornography on an apple strudel if that's what you want...

Speaking of hard numbers: I waited 40 minutes in line to spend 28 dollars on 13 doughnuts.

As I typed that sentence I gradually became more and more disappointed with my life. 

And yet there were suckers who didn't beat rush-hour and had to wait way longer than I did. 

Spoiler Alert: it's not worth it.

Are the doughnuts bad? I wouldn't go that far. If you gave VDD one star for quality I'd love to read your reviews of a Dunkin Donuts. 

On the other hand, were they great? Not really. Definitely not good enough to go there regularly and deal with the winding line of tourists / adult-onset diabetes.

I do applaud them for being one of the only truly 24-hour businesses in PDX (maybe you can actually avoid the line at 2am?), but at the same time I boo at them for running a cash-only business. Seriously? You're crumbling up an Oreo onto a doughnut (God Bless America) for a 250% markup and I can't earn some frequent flier miles by swiping the plastic? 

You could say it would make the line worse, but no, what makes the line worse is people fumbling at the ATM who can't believe VDD has the same payment requirements as Lucky Devil Lounge. I guess to be fair, both are similar in that you'd be ashamed for your significant other to see the withdrawl statement if you'd gone without them...

At the end of the day though, the most shocking thing about VDD is the blandness. There's nothing magical, nothing that defines Portland, just OK doughnuts sprinkled with an amazing amount of hype and marketing.

See what I did there with the sprinkled reference? That was for you.

I don't like carbs.


Voodoo doughnuts has lots of carbs.


Therefore I don't like Voodoo Doughnuts.

As a food person who enjoys a good donut, I was very excited to try a donut from Voodoo.   As a native of Portland, I felt an obligation to try one of the famous places - and be able to share it with visiting friends and family. 

After waiting 45 minutes, we were greeted by a person who didn't know what donuts came in the "favorite dozen" pack even though the picture and the donuts were at the front of the register.    She then proceeded to pull out donuts after touching the prior person's money.   She handled our money, and then went to pull more donuts.    It is amazing they have passed health inspections.   The counter and display cases were filthy - inside and out and the back room had three or 4 employees just standing around.   

The donuts were stale - from the cereal crusted topped ones to the buttermilk bar we purchased as an additional donut.    We tried a bit of all the dozen, with none really standing out as exceptional.    I think the donuts at our local Safeway are better - and they are substandard at best.

Voodoo is a place that has so much hype in portland. And although the style and ambiance is cool, their donuts leave you feeling stuffed and sick. They certainly aren't the best donuts in portland. More of an experience than quality food.

Too sweet, long lines and a bit pricey. 

They have a variety of odd concoctions that would make your dentist shake their head. 

I felt like I would get a toothache. It would be good for those who love sweets or for a first timer in the area. I can check this off my list.

OOOKAY seriously, I'd much rather get a heart attack from a fatty piece of prime rib than a sugar overkill from one of these doughnuts. I know that this is the thing in Portland, but I dont think I can handle. I couldn't even do half of one. 

So knowing I'm not much of a doughnut fan, I asked my friend if she wanted to split one. She had another agenda in mind. She wanted each of us to get one and split it. (Good Lo**!) I agreed as I am a people pleaser. I opted for the Dirt Doughnut (oreo topping) And she had the Cap'n Crunch. Both we're pretty good but by the time I got to the first bite of the Cap'n Crunch I was done. 

Good experience as it is a Portland thing, but I'll have to pass the next time around!

Disappointed in this donut shop, the 6000+ reviews seems like a hoax. There is nothing delicious about the donuts.

Maybe the cool decor and the mass amounts of frosting in each donut are luring people in.

Voodoo doughnuts is strange. The donuts are not that great, but since they are creative, it makes it fun. I get the appeal of having a small, funky storefront but when you get extremely successful, its honestly kind of dumb to stay in a tiny place; the workers here yell at people to step back outside in a mean way, but I don't really blame them because they probably have to do it hundreds of times a day. Overall, I think this place is pretty over-rated, but it's a fun place to bring out of towners, and it has some sort of weird charm....hmmm...
You have to have it once to be a true Portlander...ok so I am on my 3rd visit and I don't understand why.  This was the last stop on our pub crawl..is Voo Doo a pub.  The Hot Sign was not on at KK.

It's not all that, they just add a lot of toppings the doughnut itself is dry.
Try "everything Bundt".  Hope it comes to the neighborhood soon.

I'm not buying into the hype here folks.  Honestly, I just don't care for the quirky donuts Voodoo is offering up.  I realize that here in Oregon we don't have a huge selection of quality doughnut shops.  I've lived most of my life in So. Cal where doughnut shops are on just about every block, so I've tried more than my fair share.  Voodoo is great at selling a niche and I'm pleased at their success.  Other than that, I wouldn't say they are epic doughnuts just because they throw some cereal, cookies, or candy bar crumbs on top.  Give me a quality Cinnamon roll or Apple Fritter and I'm good to go.  Hold the bacon please.

I just don't get it.  I've heard the hype and tried it on 3 separate occasions just to try and understand what folks rave about.  While the confections are certainly creative (maple bar + bacon = win), the quality is just low.  All the ingredients taste stale and just unpleasant - at or below what I'd expect from a supermarket. For baked goods freshness is key.

Doesn't live up to the hype. I guess it was cool to go once just for the experience, but after that I'm not tryna wait in line again for mediocre tasting doughnuts just cuz they come in novelty shapes and flavors. We read other reviews and decided to get the Homer, Grape Ape, McMinnville Cream, and Voodoo Man. The Homer was probably the best one out of those.


I'm told that the line is long here during most normal waking hours. We went at around 10:30 on a Monday night and it was still pretty crackin, but at least we didn't have to line up outside in the cold. Right after us though the line filled up quickly and by the time we left it was packed. Staff is friendly and accommodating of whatever questions you have. Cash only.
totally overrated, tourist trap.  for a good doughnut go to tonalli's on alberta...

This doughnut shop is for amateurs and out-of-staters. Dry, overly sweet and expensive. Don't know why anyone stands in line for these things. There are many shops in Portland that produce a much better product that this stuff.

If you see anyone carrying around their pink boxes you might want to ask if they need directions because they must be from out of state.

On our way to the Airport we stopped by. It was 3:00 a.m no wait!! (But who's really out and about at 3?) there were a few homeless people wondering. It felt a little creepy. But the street is light up. We wanted to bring some back home (Hawai'i)  Never got the chance to really look around the shop. We were in a rush. The doughnut expert wasn't the friendliest. I felt like he was irritated with me asking 21 questions of the doughnuts.

We ordered 6 old dirty bastards , 1 Loop , 1 oh captain my captain, 1 Raspberry Romeo, 2 Chocolate Old fashion, and 2 cinnamon sugar crueller. Old dirty bastard we're our favorite. Shareable size doughnut. I can't imagine eating a whole one to myself. Raspberry Romeo was very tasty.  When you order any doughnuts with cereal topping, it should be consumed asap! Tends to get stale fast. Voodoo doughnuts are moist and everything a doughnut should be!

@ $2.00 a donut,plus a long line into the place,I feel these donuts are highly overrated. Nasty menu names,certainly ain't no place for children..Truth be told,your local donut store/grocery store donuts are just as good if not better. The bums bumming plus  needing to pay for parking.. I certainly can't understand how Portland can call this a "main attraction"!

Being a iconic spot in Portland, took a little trip on Saturday afternoon and there was a line, took us about 15 minutes to get into the store. It's very vibrant and filled with all kinds of posters, pictures.

Their donuts are not the best but if you want to try some weird flavors then it's a spot to visit, although some of them are very light and not extremely sugary.
This place serves up pretty poor donuts and the customer service is very hipster.  Meaning they don't really look at you if you are brown.  If being cool is worth money then go here.

Yes- I realize I may be the only Portlander who is not a fan-but I am not. I thought I would love them for all the reasons everyone else does, but the employees are rude and the doughnuts are not good. I am not sure what all the hype is about. Really people???!!!
It's just a regular old donut as far as the flavor goes. Not worth all the hype it gets.
Goood donuts.  Went here to say that we had while on vacation. Line moves fast, fun atmosphere.

I came here after all the hype on IG and FB early in the morning. We beat the long line of people and was able to order within 5 minutes of waiting. We ordered the Voodoo and other variety of donuts. I did not know what to expect but after tasting all of them, I feel like there was nothing special about the taste. They all were very sweet just like other ordinary donuts from a regular donut shop. The "unique" flavor was not super different from what I have tried before from places like CA donuts in LA. The price was alright for the size of donuts and you pay for the hype too I guess. I think it's good to try once but I probably won't go back.

Overall
Taste 3/5
Service 4/5 pretty fast but they don't rush you even with the long line
Parking 4/5 on the street, meter
Price 4/5 normal price

I have had them a few times. I have never been to a location, someone has always brought them to me. I dont know the names of them, but I always like the custard cream filled one topped with chocolate. I  have had a taste of some of the others as well. The ones with cereal on them are pretty gross. The cereal is very very stale. Over all the donuts are good, but I dont think they taste so much better than other places to where I would be willing to wait in the long lines they have.

Not worth standing in line for 15 minutes. I wouldn't recommend it even with no lines. I am not a big doughnut fan. Just visited this place for the hype on the web and expected something especial. Didn't happen.

good donuts, expensive for donuts. they need to hire more cashiers to get the line moving faster.a few times i thought  about buying then changed my mind a donut with cereal on it, is not worth waiting in line for that long

I have not missed a trip to Voodoo Doughnut on each occasion that I have been in Portland, but I have to ask myself why? It must be the fun atmosphere and the catchy advertising, not to mention how delicious the doughnuts look, Ultimately, they don't taste that great; I have definitely had better.

Every part of the inner (and outer) chubby-me wanted to love this place. Certainly my chubby-maxi-me's inner voice was the reason why I stood in line for an hour to get a couple of doughnuts. That said, when I matriculated to the front of the line, I was a bit disappointed in my purchases. 

I ordered: 
The chocolate penetration (coco-cake with coco-puffs) and was surprised how small it was and how stale the coco-puffs were - at midday no less. 

The bacon-maple bar, which was nice, was same as I have had elsewhere (see my All-star doughnut / yellow brick cafe review. Except those were cheaper and had no line). 

Lastly I had the Arnold Palmer. A goofy vanilla cake with a dusting of lemon iced tea powder. This was interesting but not great. Kind of reminds me of being a kid when you dip your fingers into the mix powder instead of making the drink. 


All in all, I would go back if there was no line. It is NOT worth the wait. Its also really not that special, but then again chubby-maxi-me loves his fried cakes.
Fine maple bar and blueberry cake donuts, but far from worth the hype. At least we didn't have to endure a line.
I had the hibiscus and old dirty bastard... both didn't excite my palate.  Just way too sweet for me.  I guess two stars for creativity?

Huge disappointment. Heard all the hype so I ordered bride and groom donuts to take back home as a souvenir for our daughter who's getting married next weekend. Got there early so we waited 1/2 an hour in line only to be told they didn't make up our order. No compensation offered for their mistake.
To be honest, they are completely over hyped. Pretty disappointing. While they do look cool, they are not worth the prices.

Good solid doughnuts, we tried the maple bacon and chocolate with peanuts. Came by on a Saturday morning and luckily avoided the crazy lines, was able to just walk straight in. 

Definitely some creative concoctions here, would probably give it a higher rating if we tried and liked a more adventurous one!

If you're in Portland and you've never been here, you need to go.  It's a very "Portland" experience.  And the french glazed cruller is just absolutely phenomenal.

That being said, while the doughnuts are certainly good, they are nothing to write home about.  Just generally decent doughnuts.

Go for the experience, but don't go expecting the most incredible doughnuts ever.
Got a variety of donuts from orginal to Oreo topping.   Everything was alright maybe it was over hyped for me.  Out of everything Oreo one was the best.

Yes, you should go here once, it's a Portland legend. And the day olds are a good deal (not from the main location I believe?). But honestly, the donuts aren't great and covering something in cereal (while cool) still feels childish

Make sure to bring cash!

Honestly, the doughnuts were okay. They taste like regular doughnuts just garnished with different types of cereal/cookies with some drizzle of peanut butter or chocolate. It's a bit pricey, 2.25 for almost doughnuts. If you want doughnuts, avoid going on the weekend, the line was ridiculous.

Cool concepts for the toppings but donut quality is just ok for me. Sometimes the cereal ones are stale. I prefer Blue Star and Annie's donuts. Unless you're just going for the novelty, this place is over rated and not really worth the wait!
Good donunts, crazy variety. There are better donuts in town, but you cant beat the atmosphere, people, and crazy concoctions. Whatever you do, eat the ODB, just because of it's level of awesome

We got there early, so although there was a line out the door, it was only just out the door, and we got in fairly quickly.  

I had two of their more or less unusual doughnuts.

First was a bacon maple bar.  I just wasn't that impressed.

OTOH, the Mexican chocolate devil's food cake doughnut was delicious.

I find that the lists of doughnuts don't adequately explain their unusual doughnuts, especially the names ones.  I'm pretty sure I'd still have chosen the two that I tried had they had better explanations, but maybe not...who knows?

Voodoo Doughnut is a cool experience but definitely overrated.  The variety of doughnuts is awesome but the flavors are really all about the frosting and decoration.  The classic voodoo one with the jelly inside is delicious and the pure fact that you can buy a COFFIN of 3 dozen is to die for.  I got two coffins for a company get together and it was a huge hit!  But besides the presentation and the novelty of it all you're left with regular doughnuts.

Not a donut fan, but this place is so famous and just had brunch in mother's bistro and it's close to here. Waiting for around 30min and got the beautiful pink box. The shape is so funny but just little bit too sweet to us. Love the one with jam inside. If you decide to go and grab some sweet from this shop, don't forget voodoo doll, it's also good!!!

Totally over rated and the donuts are way too sweet and leave you feeling sick! I wouldn't recommend waiting in the long lines for these donuts! The staff are really nice and the place is unique but their product is not worth the wait or the hype!
overrated.  yes, you have to go with your tourist out-of-town guests, but go to pips if you want real doughnuts.

Expectations were too high. Id say it's an ok place, good price. On their defense the vegan Apple critter was really good. Even so, i Was going to buy a box to take home but I don't think it'd be worth it. Sorry guys.

I think the whole ambiance of the place is amazing, but the donuts are just ok the novelty of them ( flavors, design ect....) is what makes this place cool. I felt like I was at a MAC/forever 21/ vintage pin up girl store where the girls sell donuts instead of makeup and clothes. Overall fun place if you like put pics on the gram or snap and be a foodie! If your inpatient then you won't like standing in line because it gets super busy!
Just remember you are going here for the hype and you'll be fine.  The doughnuts are okay, but nothing to rave about.  It's a 'cooky' name for crazy looking doughnuts and that is what you are buying.

In a word, OVERRATED.  As a fat guy,  I know donuts. After a great meal at Imperial, we spent the evening walking around downtown Portland and stumbled upon VooDoo.  We weren't planning on visiting but kept running into people carrying pink boxes.  So when in Rome...

After waiting in a huge line that took 45 minutes to navigate, here's the rundown:

Maple bacon bars:  I'll pass on the two huge strips of bacon.  The maple bar by itself was solid.  Their donuts are dense and very filling.  I've had maple bacon bars with the bacon crumbled on top. 

Glazed raised for junior.  A classic donut.  Very well done.  Again a dense donut.  But I've had just as good at other donut shops.

Portland Cream.  Official donut of Portland and they make a donation for each sold.  Done deal.  I like the Portland rose icing décor.  Not a real fan of cream filled(or filled donuts for that matter).  Nice donut with creamy center and chocolate icing to balance the filling.

Sadly, I don't think I will return.  I've had many a great donut here in the LA area at local Mom&Pop donut shops usually run by super nice Cambodian families.

They are not that good, just a porly made doughnut with Trix or some other garbage on it. Nothing to write home about. No flavor just too much sugar. Best doughnuts in Portland was XL doughnuts on 82nd avenue their dough had flavor and the texture was incredible however, they are long gone. I think people just want the Voodoo for the name the hype and the pink box... It is a shame that most people want pablum.. they grew up on mass produced chemical treated food tasteless over salted food, the really good places are gone or going. People you missed out on what a doughnut should taste like. Enjoy the sugar coated  insipid tasteless fare (very Soilent Green)

Definitely a tourist spot. Are the doughnuts worth the 20+ minute wait and 10+ block walk from our hotel through the midst of vagabonds and homeless? Probably not. We were in town visiting a friend, we did a search on the "go to" portland spots and this place popped up. At the time, it seemed like a good idea seeing that I was 7 months pregnant and the random doughnut options were tempting. 

Got a few of the populars. Although the doughnuts were cutely made and pretty "original", they didn't taste spectacular. I agree with one of the other yelpers, the theater of the line is why you should visit for sure lol

After reading various reviews about Voodoo Doughnut, I could not wait to go when I visited Portland.  What did I miss??!?  Besides waiting in line for almost an hour, the doughnuts were dry, and not nearly as eccentric as I originally thought they would be.

Yes, I was surrounded by individuals mmmmmm-ing and ahhhhhh-ing as they were eating the doughnuts; but my friend and I ended up tossing our four doughnuts, because we decided to use our "empty" calories on red wine.
Mediocre to sub par donuts at best, more for novelty.... very sad that dunkins would have better dough..... sad ain't it

Came here on a trip to Portland and the line was out of control. I was not a fan of waiting an hour for anything. Their donuts are fun, colorful, and you will have a sugar high eating it. It's a fun place to try different toppings on donut but it was too sweet for me. Got the voodoo, captain crunch, and fruit loop donut.

If you love donuts, this should be one of those places to see before you die.  Sure, the ridiculous line with a dozen tourists taking photos (I was one of them) might take away some the street cred, but once you battle your way inside, the crazy concoctions make it worth it.

But if you just want a donut, the basic glazed, chocolate, and frosted varieties here are unremarkable and heading to one of the other local donut joints in the city might make more sense.

When I first came here, I really love the donuts. But, at finally realized that this donuts is too sweet :(
However, I still think that this place is one of the best place in portland.
Reccomendation:
Maple Bacon!
Do Donut Land in Tualatin Oregon...Voodoo is DooDoo

Sugar all dressed up, with nowhere to go but down. I'm really really not sure what all the hoopla is about - that stuff doesn't even taste good, even if it's interestingly off beat.

The lines are insanely long - totally not worth the wait if you're not a sugar fiend (and apparently, according to the fabulous Clover, it's not worth the wait even if you ARE a sugar fiend). 

Thumbs down.

OK, this place was a complete tourist trap.  Waiting more than half an hour for a doughnut was just silly, and cost this place a star.  That said, I bought a whole range of doughnuts to taste (and then discard because I didn't want to develop diabetes on the spot) and they were pretty cool.  The highlight was taking a photo of the "Portland Stay Weird" sign on the building opposite.
A great place if you enjoy waiting in line while dodging meth-head vagrants in order to eat not-very-good donuts. The only positive is that it's pretty cheap.

I suggest that you go here earlier during the day when the line is not as long (it is a 24 hour shop). You definitely go to Voodoo more for the aesthetics of the donut over the taste of the baked goods. They have so many interesting and "instagrammable" donuts, the box that it comes in is also pretty nice!

I'd heard nothing but bad news about the new incarnation of this spot from its humble roots.  I was out in Portland for a wedding and some members of the party really wanted to stop by here.  

I'm not a huge fan of sweets in general, specifically not the over the top sugar rush of most of these doughnuts.  After having one doughnut I realized that the doughnut itself just isn't very good, or perhaps I just got a stale doughnut out of the revolving case. 

It reminds me a lot of the cupcake craze in DC, people waiting in 40 person deep lines for mediocrity.  

Ther service and the prices were actually not that bad but they are cash only, fyi.  I also like that they sell cartons of milk.  

The other obnoxious factor are the tourists, it takes even longer to get a doughnut due to the hordes of large groups taking pictures of anything and everything inside.  I also saw another dozen giant pink boxes at the airport on the way out of town.  The street kids next door and the ominpresent homeless scouring the line for change don't do anything to enhance the experience either.  

Kudos for the owners of this place who have rode the hype train to great profits, others in my party were really happy with their doughnuts but I still don't understand the draw.

I stopped by Voodoo while visiting Portland because well, that's whats you do. After all the hype I was let down. I don't even care that I had to wait in a long line outside in the rain or that they only take cash..so what. What I do care about is that I visited one of the most over hyped donut shops in the nation. The actual donut itself taste like one I would get at a gas station. Throwing a bunch of over sweetened frosting, candy, and cereal on them didn't help...not to mention they were all stale (leaving cereal out for hours at a time isn't a great idea).

Is it the worst donut in the world? Probably not. Is it the most over hyped? Probably so.

Donuts were good but this place was over hyped. I was expecting something amazing from all the talk I've been hearing about this place. 

If you haven't been here before I'd recommend to go for the weird vibes the restaurant gives off.
It tastes like normal doughnuts except you have to wait in line for an hour to get to order any and they are overpriced for being regular doughnuts. Really jsnt worth the hype

Tourist trap.  Other than crazy toppings the donuts aren't any bit better tasting than what you would find at a grocery store.    Most people carrying off boxes of their donuts are headed to the airport it seems like.  Not that I'm into donuts but after one of these I get that "Oh! I do miss Dunkin' Donuts so badly" feeling.  And I never thought Dunin' Donuts were any good either!!

If you're a tourist doing touristy things and you're in Portland, you should find the time to go to Voodoo. Yes, it's true that there probably is a doughnut place right in your hometown that has better baked goods, but c'mon, this place has a doughnut shaped like a voodoo doll. What's more fun than that? And you get to stand in line with a crowd of like-minded folks all excited about the same thing. Sort of like back in the 1980s when you had to stand in line to get concert tickets for that group everybody was excited to see live, except that the Voodoo line moves faster. And none of the people in it are smoking weed.

It is true that they toss the doughnuts into those pretty pink boxes in a manner that causes the glaze to rub off onto the thin wax-paper they use to separate the doughnuts, as some other reviewers have noted. And that is a bummer because, as a tourist, you really wanted to instagram that voodoo doll back to all your friends at home. But it looks too unappetizing with half the glaze smeared off. So they lose a star for that.

Tourist trap with mediocre doughnuts.  I was in the area with my family and my sister really wanted to try this place since it is always featured on some Food Network or Travel Channel show.  I've been to Portland a handful of times and had never been so I figured we'd give it the ol' college try.  

The line wasn't bad, we waited about 5 minutes.  The doughnuts were simply okay.  Honestly, mine was way too sweet.  I got a raised doughnut with fruit loops on it and, while it was tasty, I could barely even eat half of it because the frosting was just over the top sweetly rich.  I thought the prices were pretty good though, considering the touristy aspect and how over prices similar places are.  

Coming from Seattle and Top Pot Doughnuts, I have to say Top Pot is way better.  Voodoo is worth going to once but I won't ever try it again when I am in Portland.

These are just OK donuts, and speaks more to Portlanders obsession with being trendy, or tragically hip - would make a great Portlandia episode! Try Coco Donuts for a much better donut w/o the the dbl lines and frantic hype!
Not worth the hype. Made the stop here during a road trip from LA to Portland and stood in a long line to try all the popular, most recommended donuts. Honestly, it was nothing special.

Cool joint - actually just found it by mistake while walking around and remembered it from some tv show. 

It's probably more of a novelty place, but the donuts we sampled were good, chocolate old fashioned and a maple bar. We had no interest in the ones with fruit loops or what not.

If you happen to be in the area, it's certainly worth checking out, but I wouldn't go out of my way to go back.

My review of this place is rather mixed. It's definitely worth coming here at least once to try out their donuts, but I found them too sweet for me. I'm not sure what flavor I bought, but my donut had white frosting and purple sprinkles on it. It tasted like a sweet tart candy or maybe a pack of nerds?  

On a more positive note, the variations of donuts that you can find here are pretty awesome and definitely unique from other donut places. They're also open 24 hours so they get credit for that!

It's a donut. I just heard about this place last year and I didn't have time to come here so we just came this past trip, 10/30/2011. I got the voodoo dozen and 3 voodoo dolls. I didn't like the service, I didn't like the store, the cashiers are just yelling at people looking at the menu from the entrance. I couldn't see a PDX native come for these everyday, but I definitely can see why people that are from out of town come here (I'm from PDX but just heard of this place and live out of town). You won't be disappointed but I felt that the voodoo doll donut didn't do a good job of distributing the jelly well at all. It was all in the lower portion of the doll. Obivously, I ate the head first and then as I worked my way down, I had the fullsize amount of jelly for half of the donut. :(

Won't come here again, but will take friends here. It's an easy time killer for out of towners.

Are you freaking kidding me? We stood in line and it never moved. We went there in the morning, came back in the afternoon and in the evening and the line never died down. I'm sorry, but I don't care how good their doughnuts are, my crazy ass is not going to stand there all day just to buy a freaking doughnut. I think Voodoo Doughnut is all hype and no substance. If you want something sweet, try Ja Da's dessert at the Saturday Market. Their red velvet cupcakes are divine!

First things first - I love Voodoo doughnuts. The actual doughnuts, that is. I think they're delicious and unique and definitely worth a try. That being said, this location has gotten craaaaazy and I'm not entirely sure it's worth it anymore, given that they've expanded. 

Located in downtown Portland, the line for this place is basically always wrapped around the block. The location itself is the original one - it's a super tiny corner of a building with not a lot of room. If you reeeeeally feel the need to do the touristy thing and buy doughnuts from this location, okay, go for it. If you're just craving a doughnut, there are plenty of equally good doughnut places around - OR I'd suggest hitting up Voodoo Too (they have their own building outside of downtown) or coming at some weird hour like 3am. 

Some people get weird about it and say that the original location has better doughnuts or what not - I don't really agree, as I think the other locations are just as good. And if I'm just hanging out in downtown and want a doughnut, I can't say I'd come here first. 

I really do love me a good Dirty Bastard, but man, the line is just not worth it anymore. I'm super stoked that it is doing so well, but with all the popularity, I think I'll stick to the other locations to get my Voodoo on. 

Visiting Portland? Definitely stop by and check it out at least, as the "KEEP PORTLAND WEIRD" sign is right across from it - but remember, cash only if you decide to brave the line.

bacon maple bar - don't get anything else. if you like bacon, you won't be sorry. I had 4 of them over course of 6 days. 
lines are too long, but coffee is cheap. I think they deliberately have too few employees to enhance the mystique of place -- people lining up, We were there early and there was one employee. If there were two, there would mean no lines. But lines to people must mean they are good; hence, less employees to service customers.  Nonetheless they are good.
 Go early, before lines are really out of control.   If they had enough employees they would have gotten 5 stars from me. Also, no rest room which is crazy as YOUR CUSTOMERS HAVE BEEN WAITING AND ORDERING COFFEE. DISRESPECTFUL!!

This place is hyped up because of their eccentric style and creativity. The doughnuts themselves are barely better than what you might find in a grocery store bakery... but with unconventional toppings, like cereal and bacon.... in quirky shapes and themes. Really wish this place was better, because their atmosphere/personality is awesome. But the doughnuts always fail to impress.

Not worth the wait!  It was a tourist thing to do and we saw so many people walking around with the famous pink boxes so we thought we would do as they do, bringing some home for our family at home.  When we arrived, which took a couple of buses to get there, we had to wait in line for at least a half hour.  The vegan doughnut was a reason to come for us, along with the voodoo doll doughnut, which has a pretzel stuck in it and raspberry jam inside (cute).  Once we got to the front of the line, the grouchy server had no time for our questions (btw, they take only cash but an ATM is inside!) so we quickly ordered.  They were OUT of the vegan doughnuts, except for a chocolate one, and so we got voodoo doll doughnuts (yes, they were creative) and glazed.  Cock 'n' balls looked funny but a waste of money unless you were buying for a bachelorette (or bachelor, haha) party.  The glazed were not nearly as delicious as others I have had from other places (like Meches in Lafayette, LA for example, not even close in fact!) but it was fun and they have definitely attracted a crowd.

Voodoo Doughnuts is great but the lines are NOT at downtown location.  If you want to stop by for a quick doughnut pick-up try somewhere else, however if you can withstand the 30 minute to sometimes one hour and a half wait then I recommend their bacon maple bar and there mango tango, both are my favorites!

Overrated. 

If you walk on Burnside, you can smell pee mixed with the odor of fresh donuts. There are nineteen year old blonds in hotpants next to 60 year old, toothless drunks. Someone is screaming over at Dantes. This donut appeals to the clientele that prefers this scene, or else, can withstand it in exchange for a donut topped with bacon after a forty minute wait. 

Then, when you eat the donut, you think, so what? Someone paid six dollars for this? If you buy a box of donuts here, some spanger will ask you for a donut within five minutes. 

I went to Voodoo the first (and only) time with a wedding party, where the two evangelical kids tying the knot queued up happily, while I eventually lost interest and went home. The fact that church kids celebrate weddings here tells you a lot about culture in Portland at this moment, although just exactly what, I'd need more space to outline.

I am tired of seeing trendy teenyboppers, may of them from Idaho, with the pink boxes. Stop already, just stop. 
Stop.

What a novel place this is. Typical Portland "justifiably weird joint". Not worth the wait nor taste. The amount of panhandler harrasment outside is a bit high. Tried it once, shame on you voodoooooo.
Stale cereal isn't worth the novelty.  Blue Star is way better---much cleaner, and not near the wait.

We had to get a donut based on the reviews since we were in Portland only one weekend. Though the donuts are too sweet for our taste, you should go just to experience it. Get ready go wait in the freezing line outside!

FYI: the cock and balls donut is huge, so consider sharing.

I was looking forward to this place for months, and it was underwhelming.  first off it was really hard to find, and none of the locals knew how to get there.  They have one of the best slogans, " The magic is in the hole"  genius.  This place is open 24 hours, its kinda in a rough area.  as for the dougnuts, i had the dirt, which has white icing with orea on top.  The icing was way too sweet, i scraped most of it off and juts had the doughnut.  choose the most basic doughnut for best results.

Honestly I don't understand the hype! We waited in line for 30ish mins which wasn't too bad but the donuts are incredibly sweet and mask any chance of the donut having flavor. I got the Arnold Palmer--lemon filling with strawberry frosting. The icing was thick and gummy kinda like toothpaste. The donut part was okay in terms of moisture and texture and all that. I couldn't get through the donut without wigging out from the sugar high. My sister liked her coco puff donut though! We went back the next day to give it another chance and were equally disappointed. My friends and I tried the Portland creme, old dirty bastard, and few others.

I don't think the doughnuts here are anything special. Good? Yes. Amazing? No. I guess I'm just not that impressed by a doughnut with cereal dumped on it. I am not personally vegan but I do appreciate the fact that they have vegan doughnuts and that is worth all three of my stars. 

None of the staff has ever seemed even remotely friendly and I think the bacon on the maple bacon doughnut looks like it has been sitting around for a few weeks. 

I dig on the atmosphere and the line always goes pretty quickly so don't let it intimidate you. 

There's a lot of hype so go for the experience, I guess but don't expect some magical melt in your mouth super doughnut.

Living in Portland I hear about about Voodoo Doughnuts all the time. They are ok. But it's 90% hype. They are extremely overly sweet, the dough tastes similar to grocery stores donuts. Blue Star Donuts is the way to go.

If you're looking for a review of Voodoo, you know what you're looking for. 
But here's the take from a local, go to a Krispy Kreme. 
Sure you could wait in a long line for a doughnut, sure you could then overpay (CASH ONLY) for that pastry and sure then you could tell your friends when you were in Portland, you got Cheetos on a doughnut.
It's a pretty sad state too as I don't usually care about the food quality, but since the service is non existent, the food is all there is to comment on and at the very best, it stinks. 
Save your time, save your money, go to Freddies and buy a pack, then lie to all your friends. 
You have better things to waste your time with than waiting in line for 8 hour old doughnuts while you're here.

As donuts go, they're mediocre to just ok. Leave this joint for the tourists. Get better donuts for half the price and no wait at Tonalli's on Alberta, or have your tastebuds completely blown away at Blue Star or NOLO in L.O.

The other Yelp Elites are right- the hype is not justified and 3 stars is definitely fitting.

Honestly, you'd go here just because many people would recommend it, and Portland is known for this place.

Bacon maple, any of the cream-filled ones, and the blueberry beret.  Try those.

I mean, yes the donuts are very cheap, but they're not worth waiting in any line that's more than 15 minutes.

At other places, I've had donuts topped with bacon and sriracha, donuts with lavender-infused dough, really crazy donuts.

Voodoo has.. cereal-topped donuts.  Wow.  Ground-breaking.

I am a lover of donuts and grew up on Dunkin.  These are overrated and a dissapointment.

I get the thrill of the fun and new, but really it's a waste of time to stand in line when the donuts you get are stale and the flavors are so fake as to make your mouth hurt.

The only halfway decent donut is the maple bacon, and even that tastes like they use fake maple flavoring and the bacon is so tough from sitting around that you can't even bite into it properly.

For my money, and time, and tastebuds i'm sticking to Dunkin Donuts, aka Sesame Donuts.

Look, I get it. Everyone loves funny doughnuts, but I feel like Voodoo sometimes takes it too far. For me, a doughnut is what it isn't. Plain glazed? Give me 20. Tang flavored? Give me none, and apologize for even offering it. I realize this place is very famous, and yes, it is a lot of fun to go here. In all honesty, I've had doughnuts from here that I enjoy very much. But... waiting in line? For who knows how long? For subpar, overrated doughnuts? No thanks. If you're visiting, and you want to wait in line because you saw Anthony Bourdain eat here, go ahead. Overall, I think Voodoo knows what they're doing and will not lose any sleep by my review, but please know that there are other doughnut stores in Portland, and they are just as good (aka better).

Finally came here after much encouragement to do the "portland" thing. I ordered the Mexican Hot Chocolate and of course the Maple Bacon Bar. I was very underwhelmed by the Maple Bacon Bar. I thought it was going to be really really good since people I knew hyped it up so much for me. I would rather have a Bacon Waffle because the bacon on the doughnut was so so...dry..and tough. Bleh. The Mexican Hot Chocolate on the other hand was really good! It wasn't overly sweet like some of their other chocolates (tasted my friends) and it had a spicy kick to it. Don't get it if you don't like cinnamon though, cause it does have it on top.
Living in Portland, and tasting everything this amazing food mecca has to offer, I can't figure out why on earth people wait in line for these over priced day old stale donuts.

overrated suger pit adored by Portland trendies in love with the Portlandia mythology.  Save
your money for a really good bakery.

There are WAYYY Better doughnut shops in Portland. I got a HUGE box of a multi variety (ranging from grape-ape to their fritter) One bite of each told me all that I was going to know; Subpar and OVERHYPED. Go to Lee Farms and get yourself an apple cider vinegar donut and a view or Annie's Donut Shop and experience way better. This place is a Voo-Don't.

If you own a business that focuses on one particular product, you'd want to make sure that product was damn near perfect, right?

Or as my pappy used to say, "Just 'cause you pour syrup on sh*t--don't make it a pancake."

Now replace "pancake" with "donut."

Didn't like the looks of any of the donuts, but I went ahead and fell in the five minute line with the rest of the SUCKAS....just to say I tried one. I got a cream filled raised donut with chocolate frosting. The frosting was thick and good, but the donut was doughy and bland. Ugh.

Kudos to Voodoo for the great success they have had all these years. They have managed to take an average product and make it edgy and cool...not an easy thing to do.

3.5

Worth the line? meh... THOUGH, if a friend was willing to wait in line for diabetes, I'll throw them a few bucks (since they're cash only) and get either a voodoo doll, bacon maple or a Cock-N-Balls. The doughnuts are good, yes. However, I personally would not wait in line for sugar and carbs.

If you're visiting Portland on the other hand... this place is AWESOME! Portland has a lot of quirks and waiting in line for doughnuts is one of them. The street entertainment that you get to witness while waiting in line is great!
Donuts were great but the staff treated us  terribly. Twice. Probably wont return to this location ever again.

Not really a fan.  Was excited to try since everyone said it was a must when visiting.   Coffee was disappointing and the peach fritter had no taste of peach but a lot of cake frosting, making it extremely sweet. Tried the lemon powdered donut and that was decent.  

Just not my thing.
The donuts are OK.  Nothing exceptional.  It is a nice gimmick, so worth a visit.

A novelty. Great for tourists. Nothing special about the doughnuts except that they are somewhat creative, very colorful, sometimes funny/zany/over-the-top, and appealing to the eye. 

They don't taste awful or anything, they are perectly decent doughnuts... but perhaps not worth the price.

I had to go here because I heard so much about it and everyone that knew I was going to Portland said... "You gotta go to Voodoo Doughnut!!".  After waiting in line for almost 45 minutes, maybe I expected heaven in a doughnut.  Yes, their flavors are like no other doughnut shop I've been in, but the taste wasn't matching the looks.  I tried the Apple Fritter, Oreo, Cap'n Crunch and regular glazed (had to do a boring one!).  I guess I was looking for a bit more - but now I can check this off the "Portland to do" list.

Visiting Voodoo Doughnut's is a must if you are a first-time visitor of Portland! It's like a tourist's right of passage into the city, and I experienced this as I waited for an hour for a box of donuts. Never waiting again in my life, but I was obligated to on my first trip there. 

They do have funky flavors and designs, but I think the quality of their donut is not up to par of even a neighborhood donut shop or Blue Star donuts (their competitor). The consistency of the donuts are almost bread like, which means I got full after taking two bites of my donut because of how heavy it was. Overall, I'd opt for other donut places in Portland, but definitely visit if you are as intrigued as I was.

I have been to this tiny room a couple times. There is often a line out the door, so one would think it was the bees knees.

Sure there are really creative doughnuts and the names are fun, but the customer service is absolutely HORRIBLE! I don't think I have ever seen these people smile. Or even treat me like I'm a human being. Obviously, they don't need to, so they don't need my money.

The doughnuts were ok, not the best, not the worst.  Perhaps if the doughnuts were better I would tolerate the abuse more.
It was ok. The line moved quickly. All donuts are large in size and very sticky sweet.

There's a lot of hype around this place! Yes, it's good. However, the doughnuts are only good fresh. They won't last more than 12-24 hours and still taste the way they should. 

The only reason I take 2 stars off is because the service can be up and down. I've had really poor service about a handful of times. The service and attitude of the people working up front is usually pretty average.

I feel since there are a lot of people visiting Voodoo from out of town, therefore the service and attitudes could be a little more inviting and nice.
Donuts are imaginatively decorated but don't pass muster on crispiness of doughnut and overall flavor.

I know its UBER POPULAR and all the press and the HUGE lines and all that jazz.  Its delicious but so is 99% of all the other donut shoppes in the world today.  Never had a bad Dunkin' Donut .  Guess what I am trying to say is that VooDoo is excellent, hardly worth the LONG ASS LINES and that I don't know what all the hype is about.

If there were not the wait, I would say hell yeah go there.  Anyway, its yummy.  Try the Bear Claws for certain !!!

Why go to Voodoo? Honestly, just to say you went. They are good. Not great. It's whimsical. Get yourself a clunky, inappropriately named donut. Bring a friend to share half as required so you don't die of diabetes, or ask the guys that bum around right outside the door asking for handouts if he/she wants the other half.

1. Don't go on the weekend. The line is 75-people deep. Go at a rando time. 
2. If you find yourself in a 75-person line, go look online and see what donut you would like. 
3. Indecisively wait for everyone else to order.
4. Cash only!

It's okay. Good donuts, hellacious line, cash only. I'd honestly rather skip the line and go to Krispy Kreme, but guess they're not welcome in Portland till they get gender neutral restrooms. In case you're wondering, Maple bacon was the champ. Biggest disappointment was the voodoo doll.
So not worth it. The line was super long after getting there a 3 in the afternoon!! The donuts were way too sweet and a bit overprice. The place is basically a tourist trap, I suggest avoid it.

I understand the appeal of novelty doughnuts but if I'm going to put something in my mouth I want it to taste good! We picked up about two dozen for our beach house vacation expecting them to be devoured in minutes but they ended up just getting picked at. They already tasted dry and stale and the creative toppings just didn't live up to my expectations. They do provide one great service though - you can try all those crazy things that sound like a good idea when you're drunk or stoned without actually having to do the work yourself.
Open 24 hours, standard doughnut with unusual toppings. Cool to see once or twice and try different ones but not the best doughnut in town.
It is loud inside, accept cash only and is a must see when visiting Portland, but people who live here know else where to get a quality doughnut!
Overly hyped, and as usual lines were out the door. Total tourist trap.

Despite all the hype, these donuts were not good. We ordered two and they were just meh, at best. Dry and uneventful, not anything like I was expecting. We stood in line (had to come back as the first time we tried to go, there were waaaaaay too many people in line) for about 20 minutes then selected our donuts - the maple bacon bar donut and one with oreo and peanut butter on top. Sadly, I've had better at Krispy Kreme. The atmosphere inside is fun and the racks of endless decorated donuts and the signature pink Voodoo boxes are cool but overall,  just 2 stars.

I visited Portland for the first time last week and had to see what the fuss was about. I tried the Captain Crunch, Old Fashioned, and a purple sprinkled doughnut. They were good but not the best doughnut Ive tried. I would choose Blue Star over Voodoo anyday.

I came for all the hype and the cool environment. I'm not a huge fan of doughnuts but it is a must in Portland so I was willing to stand in line for 20 minutes. Doughnut was underwhelming. The maple glaze on the maple bacon doughnut is way too thick and too sweet. The bacon's saltiness was not enough to help the sugary glaze. Lavender is very fragrant but once again thick glaze and way too sweet. My favorite is the blunt which is a cinnamon-ie donut. Overall disappointed but now I can say I've tried Voodoo doughnut

If you are a trend follower, and feel that the only way to express yourself and be unique is to wear the hipster uniform, you might like it...  oh, also, you need to have EXTREME tolerance for refined sugar

Everyone was telling me that I must go here during my visit to Portland, so I put it on my list. I've seen to many people carrying the infamous pink boxes at the airport and around town, that I didn't care if it was all hype. I just wanted to try it anyway... plus my friend requested a couple doughnuts for me to bring back. 

They currently have 5 locations and one of them was within walking distance to where we were. To my surprise, there was a really long line, so we decided to come back on a different day. We came back one night and I was glad it wasn't as busy as during the day. They're open 24/7, so I recommend coming during non peak hours, so you don't have to wait.

They have doughnuts rotating in a glass case and more donuts in the back to choose from. I got my friend the captain crunch one and I ended up getting the cock and balls doughnut. Mine was huge and shaped like a penis! It's equivalent to about 2 donuts, so it's more expensive than the other flavors/shapes. My other friends got the Voo Doo doll doughnut and we thought it tasted okay. I think people like this place because they have over 90 different variations/shapes of donuts. Even though I only bought two doughnuts, I got a pink box to take home! It is definitely all hype, but worth a visit if it's your first time in Portland.

Okay....waiting in line in the cold for 30 min is so not worth these donuts!  Yes, the names & shapes of these donuts are different....I like the Peanut Butter and Jelly the most and the Powder lemon filling. But the rest is just...donuts! PB is spread on top and jelly was the filling. That was delicious. Maple bacon had no filling....just alright. the voodoo doll had I think rasberry filling just in the middle...not enough filling!  Waiting in line for that amount of time would be a one time deal. If there's no line then I would get something from here.

I have to admit, this place was a little over-hyped for me. The location left little to be desired (a lot of homeless people hanging around) and could use a face lift, and I think the long line was getting to the staff, who barely cracked a smile  by the time you got up to the register. I chose the chocolate peanut and the Homer. While I wouldn't recommend the Chocolate Peanut - it's literally an old fashion donut with chocolate glaze and chopped peanuts on top - the Homer was really good. All in all, it was "fine" but not out-of-this-world good by any means.
Bacon maple bar is great, otherwise just ordinary doughnuts with different gimmicky topings or shapes.

We were visiting Portland and had heard this is super touristy, but since we're tourists we figured we should go. There was a line outside, but it moved pretty quickly for its length. We got a maple bacon bar, old dirty bastard, pothole, and Memphis Mafia. The Memphis Mafia was my favorite of the four, followed by the old dirty bastard. I didn't find the maple bacon bar (their best seller) to be particularly special. The taste was overall okay, so I think you go more for the experience than anything. It's hard to mess up donuts and they don't, but it's not amazing either.

Cash only!

Note to self: cash only, parking on the street, long lines, busy staff, adult movies theater next door and homeless hanging outside panhandling. Those are the upshots. 

The doughnuts are okay. Not the worse but not the best I've ever had. A little to heavy on the sugar in the frosting. One step under Kristy Cream on the amount of sugar, but the doughnut quality is a whole lot better. 

I had the chocolate raised glazed and the chocolate old fashion which I believe are the golden mean of doughnuts. At Voodoo Doughnuts they were okay. I would give them a dead center of the road.

Now on specialty doughnuts Voodoo is way a head of everyone else. The Oreo Cookie doughnut is a diabetics nightmare. The Fruit Loop Doughnut is simply trying to push the edge of sugar high. The Diablos Rex, Voodoo Doll and Cock-n-Balls are simply creative spins on traditional doughnuts. 

Creativity along doesn't make for a great doughnut shop, hence the 3 star rating. Voodoo is an average doughnut shop with hip facade, creative doughnuts and a staff with attitude. It is an aspect of Portland personified.

This place is completely hyped up.  

Pro: 
1. Decent Donuts, light and fluffy
2. Different flavors of filling/topping combo 

Cons:
1. Long line, around a 30-40 minute wait
2. There is NOTHING special about the donuts.  No unusual flavors. No unusual textures.  Just different fillings and toppings and all of it too sweet.

Come for the experience of the wait, the grungy room filled with voodoo paraphernalia but don't come for the donuts.  We didn't finish ours.  Also, this is not in the best area of town, saw at least two methheads as we walked around.

Ordered:
Mango tango- regular filled raised donut. The mango filling had good flavor but overall sweet.
Guava toasted coconut - raised donut with guava filling and frosting topped with toasted coconut. Nice to see something different.
Pink lemonade - not special at all. Regular lemon filing.
Lemon chiffon crueller - light and fluffy but the bottom was a bit hard/stale
Cakey with m&ms - my son took forever to eat this... the whole walk back to Whole Foods and through Whole Foods and to the car. I suspect it was too sweet for him but he didn't want to throw it out.

Bottom Line: been there, done that. Not coming back.

More of a touristy place than a place for an excellent doughnut. That's not to say it isn't incredible and everybody should go there at least once. Just saying if you're looking for the best doughnut in Portland, you likely won't find it at Voodoo.
I lived in Portland for many years. There are better donuts there. This place is way over hyped. If you're going anyway, get the Old Dirty Bastard and the Memphis Mafia.

Overrated donuts. If you want good donuts, go to Blue Star. 

Voodoo donuts is a place where tourists go just so they can say they went and get a picture with that pink box. 

The donuts are huge and look funky, which is probably why there's so much hype. There's a blunt donut, a penis donut, a ghost... All Instagram worthy I'm sure. But I honestly can't tell the diff between these donuts and the ones you can buy at 7/11 lol. 

Oh and don't be intimidated by the line that wraps around outside, it goes by pretty quickly. 

Ps. It's CASH only.

Super excited to visit Portland for the first time and try some of the famous restaurants. Went to Voodoo Doughnut this morning and was greeted with a not so smiling face. We were rushed to order and pay  and got home with the wrong doughnuts and an incorrect amount. LAME! Hope the taste makes the wait in line and unhappy employees worth it.

What hype.
I have no idea what the rage is about?
Cereal on donuts? Woooo!

Anyways, the line is almost always huge, the donuts are just donuts. Not good ones.
Save yourself some time and skip it. Try Blue Star instead.

They closed the store and didn't give a heads up! I came from out of state to try them only to find the place was all dark! I tried calling, no answer, checked their Facebook page no answer. 3 hours after I posted on Facebook asking why they are closed( it's supposedly a 24 joint) they did post an update saying they were closed to fix their floors. Thanks for the heads up, by then I had already flown home! I guess I just expected better customer service

Lines are long, donuts are mediocre (though fancy looking), and I always get hit up for cash by homeless people due to the location.  It's a cool shop and I still stop in occasionally if I'm in the area late at night, but there are much better tasting donuts in Portland.

I'm really surprised that people are so crazy about this place. I've been there a few times, and the donuts are okay at best. It's always insanely busy, so it's difficult to enjoy factors of the business that make it unique. Compared to Blue Star or Co Co Donuts, their donuts are never as fresh, so it doesn't really make the extra wait worthwhile since those other two never have such a crowd.

They're constantly making donuts, too, and put the fresh ones down on the bottom, serving the oldest ones first. Unless you're ready to push for a fresh donut, which can be hard too if you're getting one of their more odd specialty flavors, you're likely to get one that's cold.

It's still a fun establishment, and the maple bars are worth a try. I love the staff and aesthetic, but I don't get the hype, and I feel like other places in Portland have better donuts with a pleasant environment to enjoy them in.

Before I visited Portland several of my friends said, "Skip Voodoo Donuts, it's a tourist trap."  So what did I do on my second day?  Of course, I stood in the rain for 30 minutes for a damn donut.  I don't even like donuts in general.  It was close to the hotel and there's something about a line of people waiting that suggests something good is going on.
What made the wait particularly vexing was that it wasn't slow service inside, it was customers too busy taking pictures and jack-assing around instead of reading the menu and realizing they only take cash.  Countless people made it to the counter only to be turned away with their credit card.
The interior is kind of fun, there is a giant, ugly donut and they were playing death metal.  The employees are definitely part of Portland's hipster elite.
As for the donuts themselves, the very item behind all the waiting and silliness?  They were simply okay.  I had a plain raised with chocolate that was the definition of 'A-OK', and then I told the guy to surprise me and got 'The Ol Dirty Bastard', which is a raised donut with peanut butter and smashed oreos on top.  It was delicious, but almost anything covered in peanut butter and oreos is delicious.
I suppose I would only recommend this place to someone looking for a somewhat fun, inexpensive (and unhealthy) diversion.
Blue Star -- I can bring the Girl Scout there and the donuts are amazing.  Glad it is there for tourists, though. I like that it helps keep portland weird.

It's Voodoo, it's become a commercialized tourist trap. Locals cringe every time we see a pink box being carted around by a 13 year old kid and their family from Phoenix who saw the place on a Food Network show. But the bacon maple bar is pretty damn good, and it is pretty interesting people watching in there. But the constant lines and snarky employees pretty much suck and don't make it worth the wait.
Not a big doughnut fan and tend to like more traditional varieties.  That being said Voodoo Doughnut needs to be experienced at least once.

I went there my first night in Portland about 10 years ago and the doughnuts were stale. I've had them a few times since then and they've always been stale. Hopefully, there will be a day when I have a doughnut from them that isn't stale.
Voodoo is ok. If you are from out of town or have never been there before, it's definitely worth the experience.  However, as a Portland-er there is no way I'm waiting in that line for a donut.

Sorry to say, but this place really is overrated! 

I think the 'cock and balls' is what makes them ever-so-popular! Nevertheless, if you're in the area and there isn't a line - sure, try it! But would I make a trek out and battle parking for this establishment? No thanks! The donuts are cute and creative, but average.

So i had conflicting thoughts of this place.  First this place was highly recommended by friends whom visited Portland and one whom on the regular.  

Of the three of the four doughnuts that i had bought, three of them were too sugary and too overpowering for my taste buds.  My favorite one was the gay bar, oddly I didn't know what i was thinking. I should of taken a hint and expect the surprise in the middle of the long doughnut (cough cough).  Over all i think it still an experience worth doing regardless on how i felt on the doughnuts. i still recommend coming to Voodoo for a doughnut or two.  For its uniqueness in style of doughnuts and taste.
Way over-rated. Three stars may be too kind. But since I'm a doughnut fan, I'll give them the benefit of the doubt.

Eh. I wasn't impressed. After the long line, and all of the praise, to me, the doughnuts weren't great. I like the eclecticy (sure, that's a word) of the doughnuts and the shop itself, but I wasn't blown away by any of the sweets I tried. The area is also seedy, but then, I'm not a huge Portland fan, which may be seeping a bit into my review. Even so, it's probably worth going once just to see what it's all about, but I wouldn't recommend a twice.
Not sure why people get excited. Donuts were not good. And you wait in a long line. I can say I did it now.

So not sure what all the fuss is about.  Donuts here are average at best, kind of greasy (not in a good way) and you have to step over homeless individuals and put up with being harassed while waiting in the line outside.  There are simply too many other great options of the donut variety to explore in Portland.

Wasn't impressed. Stopped in on our way home and grabbed an assorted dozen. I had heard so much about this place that I couldn't believe we were finally there. Decided to save the doughnuts until we got home...so we could relax and enjoy them after our long road trip. After trying several of the doughnuts we determined that while they looked cool, we could get better at the local doughnut shop. The names of the doughnuts were amusing and the toppings inventive but the quality of the actually doughnuts and their ingredients were just so so. I'm glad I went but wouldn't go out of my way to return.

As we walked up to the long line, a man came out of the store to play a game called Guess the Doughnut, where you guess, name verbatim, what doughnut on their menu he is describing. If you win, you get a free t-shirt. After winning one, I thought to myself, "Well, this is going to be fun!" 

A menu gets passed back to us, and I start to read all of the names of the doughnuts to my party. With doughnut names like Cock 'n' Balls, The Gay Bar, and Maple Blazer Blunt you'd think, "Man this is such a fun place!!"

But then you walk inside, and the girl behind the counter thinking she's hot shit with her mini skirt and mismatched socks shrieks "NEXT!" at you. You walk up to the counter and order your, although very entertaining, overly-sweet and, as someone below me said, "Safeway quality" doughnut. 

After terrible service and a mediocre doughnut, I will not be back. Go for the novelty of the experience, but if you want to be treated with respect or get great doughnuts, you should probably go somewhere else.

Life pro-tip for the girl behind the counter: you work at a doughnut shop. I also work in customer service. You're not better than the people you serve. If you want to work with the public, you need to be less of a bitch. You'll make more tips. Oh, and tie back that mop on top of your head. No one wants a strand of greasy-ass black hair nestled in their Maple Bacon Doughnut.

Well being in Portland this weekend it was mentioned to try Voodoo Doughnut. I'm not a huge doughnut person, and normally wouldn't stand in line for one... but when in Rome right?
