Well I tried their signature maple bacon bar and another doughnut with chocolate frosting and nuts. The bacon was a little over cooked but otherwise it was pretty good. The doughnuts themselves were really good and seemed fresh for doughnut standards,

If you are in the neighborhood and want a doughnut definitely give them a try. I wouldn't travel a long distance just for one though.

The explanation of two stars says it all for me: "meh. I've experienced better."

Not worth the long wait- but if you find a short line, the names and designs are colorful and creative, though the employees were grumpy and not helpful. Also I thought they were overpriced and remember it's cash only!
Stale oil, creative doughnuts, tourist trap. Go for the experience but not the doughnuts. Try Blue Star or Coco doughnuts instead. - *Doughnut Addict in Recovery

Really disappointed. This place is insanely overhyped. The wait is out the door, but the donuts are really average. Yes, the toppings and concept is awesome, but the toppings sit on a less than stellar base. We got 3 doughnuts to share: banana chocolate (I think it was called mafia?) fritter, bacon maple bar, and the rocky road. I had a bite of each and had enough. For sure a place to visit to see and try once, but not a go back for me.
One person waiting on a line of 30 people. Doughnuts are mediocre at beat. Don't waste your time.

i have no idea why this place is so popular...  it's like if beanie babies were a food, voodoo doughnuts would be that food - they really aren't appealing yet somehow they became super popular. honestly, i'd rather just get a doughnut from safeway.
average doughnuts. more gimmick than anything else. stale cereal on average doughnuts. good place to go if youre stoned and dont really care

When in portland this is the go to spot. You gotta get a picture with the voodoo donut and the pink box of course! Line wasn't to bad when I went, but overall there was nothing that stood out to me. Unique designs and flavors but just an OK donut place.
They have some really neat ideas and the mega doughnut it good but overall i find them a little dry.  doughnut nook up in vancouver is vastly superior

I wouldn't even review this place one star. Donuts are dry overpriced the wait is ridiculous there's nothing rewarding about the taste of their donuts what a crock of  crap! Anyone local knows they're are way better donuts in the city!

Hrm I really do not know what the fuzz is all about at this place? Sure, the donuts are weird and funny looking, but that does not make them any different than any other place. Although I'm not fond of Krispy Korean, but I still prefer them to this. I suppose that's just my opinion. The donuts were alright, but I would not come back as I preferred Blue star. Nevertheless, it was a pleasant experience.

Obviously, VD has its cult following.  We've been there twice, and there are a wide variety of unique donuts.  If I'm in the area, I'll stop by just for the heck of it (it's a Portland thing to do), but wouldn't go out of my way to go there.

Could probably do without the penis-shaped donuts though...

I wasn't impress with Voodoo Doughnut. The line was long and they ran out of many of the donuts, so my options were slim. I ordered the donut with Froot Loops and the PBJ donut (peanut butter on top and jelly filling). I surprisingly enjoyed the PBJ donut better than I thought. Nevertheless, the donuts were way too sweet.

I did appreciate the shimmery brick on the side of building. If you want to say you went, it's worth a visit. Otherwise, you can pass. 

I most likely will visit Portland again so if you have recommendations for another donut spot that is great, please feel free to drop a note. :-)

The doughnuts are really nothing special; in fact, I think chain grocery store doughnut quality is better. The novelty of the decorations is OK and I've been there once or twice, but standing in that ridiculous line more times than that...no thanks.
more of an experience than an actually amazing donut.... go here once or twice to say you tried it, that's about it

I would say you go for the experience and not the doughnuts. Having said that, the experience consists of waiting in line for an hour and a half and then placing your order in a place that is about as big as a walk in closet. The doughnuts aren't bad - just not mind blowing.

Crap. Crap. Did I mention crap. OVERRATED. Not worth the time or money... nor the line. I understand it's a Tourist Trap... but how many more people WARNING people not to go here... does it take. I'm embarrassed to have this be a Portland Institution! The doughnuts are always dry and stale. With the amount of business you'd think they'd be fresh. Instead, they taste like they make them once a week and keep them around, uncovered for days. One of my least favorites places in Portland.
Its a fun place to go and experience the interesting doughnut creations, but they aren't the highest quality tasting doughnuts.

The wait was very long! 
The donuts were LARGE! 
Lots of variety and a must do at least once in Portland.

A must visit? Hmmm, maybe!

We had such a late lunch, we weren't hungry for dinner.  It was approaching 8:00 pm, and I suggested skipping a proper dinner for Voodoo Doughnuts instead.  I didn't hear any complaints from Stephen or mom, so we googled the address and made our way to the famous doughnut shop.

The place is open 24 hours, and its cash only.  It's in the sketchy part of town, near Chinatown, and there's a lot of pan handlers and homeless looking people begging for money.  We found parking off the street behind Dante's pizza, and also found the line to get into Voodoo.

The line didn't take that long... I'm estimating 20 minutes.  The store had 4 people working the counter.  Since it was cash only, some customers had to get out of line to use the ATM machine located by the door. There's also plenty of ATM's located on the same block of the store should that machine run out.

We didn't get that many doughnuts... just 5. We got the Portland Cream Doughnut (the official doughnut of the city) as well as the Voodoo Doughnut, an Apple Fritter, a Chocolate glazed, and Stephen's favorite, the Buttermilk Bar.. setting me back $9.00.  Since it was cash only, I broke my $100 bill for this purchase.

Was it the best doughnut I've had? Oh god no. It was too sweet for me. But, at least I can check off the place.
Eh. Not worth the wait... the girl at the cashier was rude and this place wasn't worth the wait. I say blue star donut is so much better and much better quality and service.

A very popular place in north downtown area.  Youll know you are getting close when you see everyone carrying pink boxes of sugary deliciousness.  We went in the evening (they are open 24 hours)  around 7 and the wait was 15 minutes to order.  Interesting selection,  would recommend the Memphis Mafia and the Dirt Doughnut,  take note the special doughnuts are double the size of the average.  Overall the Doughnuts are average and probably a little overpriced, but a unique place to go if you have the time to wait in line.  Also they sell doughnuts by the bucket, didnt have the stomach to try this but was amazed when a guy walked up to the register next to us asked for "the bucket" and recieved a 5 gallon bucket full of a mix of donuts.  Take a camera as youll get some interesting shots including my favorite the "Keep Portland Weird"  wall art to the northeast a half block.

Honestly came here last year after driving around for 30 minutes at 7 am on a Monday like the newbie to the area I am (my folks live across the border in Washington) and after finding the joint - I was excited to order the Famous Maple Bacon bar ANNNNDDDD...they didn't have it, yet the place was dead.  

Bummer, right?  Yeah...

Anyways so we pick up two of the Voodoo Doll Donuts and ate them on the way back to LA.  Dude, really.  The best?

Uh nah.  They do have style though no doubt.  I personally like Cali Cambo Donut spots the best.

Two Stars for the experience.  Sorry it seems like the Food/Travel Channels really kill the dope spots huh?
Beavis and Butthead open a donut shop. More-or-less normal doughnuts with playground-naughty names.

I've had their donuts a few times. It's honestly not the best. More of a tourist trap or a place to go if you're drunk. And they definitely don't have gluten free so stay far away if you don't do gluten.

Shame on you Voodoo.  This place is ghetto and way too much kitsch.

Over priced donuts based on the length of the line and hype.  The "voodoo doll" . . . is an eclair shaped like the muffin man with a pretzel stick in its belly.  The cock and balls . . .a 5 dollar eclair in the shape of a circle with an eclair bar attached . . .super lame.   There are no descriptions of these doughnuts that I was able to see, so you really don't know what you are getting unless you ask . . . so shame on me I guess.  I also ordered the maple bacon bar.  Folks - it was just a maple bar with a skinny crusty-ass piece of stale-dry bacon strip laid on the top.  I've never experienced buyers remorse from a doughnut shop so thanks Voodoo!

I think the challenge is that to keep up with the volume, they make these doughnuts two days ahead of time, so when it finally reaches you, it is dry, stale and uninteresting.  I gave an untouched doughnut to a bum nearby and I even saw HIM give it to somebody else.  No joke.

Somehow yelp and locals have warranted this place a must see,  After my experience it's a "Must suck if you're a local and this is the only place you can get a donut"

I'd skip it.  You're better off getting a sugar doughy health ring at Safeway.  Oh, one more thing, it is CASH ONLY.  But they do have an ATM inside.
Cool toppings on crappy doughnuts. Super over-rated.

Visiting from out of town - shop itself was disgusting, tons of flies coalescing and buzzing around. In a pretty terrible part of town too, and I felt kinda bad that I was creeped out waiting in line outside. I'm used to homeless population in Chicago, but it wasn't like this part of town. Which is tough to knock the restaurant for, because of larger social issues, etc. but still, not somewhere I'd recommend a visit.

Only reason not 1* is that the Voodoo doll was pretty great, I liked the chocolate frosting they use and actually liked the jelly. Also got a donut covered in Oreos and peanut butter drizzle - meh. Just tasted like a bunch of processed sugar rather than good donut taste.

It could be being a bougie Chicago native, but every place from my hometown does it better. Next stop- blue star! Hopefully they live up to my expectations mode.

Long wait times to enter a loud environment. Difficult to determine what doughnut is which in their rotating display cases unless you ask directly. I've had better doughnuts, will not be coming back, and not worth the tourist hype.

Over-rated tourist trap!! I can't believe people think this place represents Portland. Nothing about it lives up to the hype. Donuts taste bad, too sweet, flour is not soft and overall cheaply made (Blue Star donuts and Pips are 100 times better). No creativity at all in terms of flavor varieties - just giving donuts a funny name or shape doesn't mean creativity! Very disappointed. If you want to take on the donut calories, make sure every calorie counts for joy. There are other much better donut places in Portland that I am proud of.
Had to go see what the hype was all about. We had the bacon donut and vegan chocolate donut! They were great but nothing that knocked me out of my seat!
we said we wouldn't but we did since there wasn't a line. plus it was walking distance from stumptown. the donut was okay, but their apple fritter was the da bomb especially with coffee.
Was really excited because of all the videos and tv shows that say how good they are, but to be honest it tasted like bread with frosting on it :/
Great donuts, terrible service. Visited the old town location and the guy who got our donuts acted like a jerk. Oh well there are lots of other donut shops that would like my money.

No, thank you.  They're edible, but I grew up in Kentucky tainted by the delicious creation known as Krispy Kreme.  I realize that's comparing a corporation to a local business... but they're a national chain for a reason:  consistency and quality, two things I have often found lacking at Voodoo.

DO (pro):  sugar, many options, inevitable hipster kitsche factor
NUT (con):  everything else, I really don't understand the craze.

Like many other reviewers, I liked Voodoo, but found the whole process a bit over the top and not really worth the end result.

The wait, in spite of the huge line, was maybe 20 minutes. No big. Prices were absolutely reasonable, which surprised me (some of the giant, elaborate things were $2-$4 each, many were in the $1-$2 range). For people complaining about the price, I think they don't recognize that you're not coming here to buy your standard plain dozen for your family visiting from out of town- you're ordering a specialty breakfast, so no, a dozen donuts will not be 10 bucks.

One caveat- just as we stepped up to greet the cashier, a woman from outside shoves through the line to ask the cashier "a quick question". She steps in front of us and spends, literally, 5 solid minutes asking him questions that sum up to the greater inquiry of "how do I not have to wait in line in the future". He was very polite to her, and very apologetic to us after she left, but once it became clear she wasn't just asking for a napkin or something, I would preferred if he'd been a little more forthright and asked her to stand aside while he helped people in line, or asked another staffer behind him to assist her. He was a nice kid though, not a huge deal.

And, of course, the donuts. They were quite tasty (bacon maple, blueberry cake, lemon creuller, some over-the-top peanut butter chocolate syrup explosion), but nothing I felt compelled to eat.. While the flavor options are interesting, I think you can get a pretty hearty variety of tasty donuts at most chain places, sans the line. I'm glad we went, but wouldn't go out of my way to go back.

Take my review with a grain of salt, because I did not actually try the donuts.  It turns out that they only accept cash, and I did not have cash on me, so I didn't get to try any.  However, the donuts are kitschy and gorgeous, and the whole space smelled heavenly.  Too bad I didn't get to sample VD's creations!

Overrated by far. The lines not worth it. The donuts are subpar, and the only thing that you get out of going there, is their unusual donuts. I've been there twice, only because I'm not from Oregon. The price is decent for the donuts, but Blue Star is definitely better in terms of quality.
Really an average at best donut. Pretty long wait and caught a bunch of attitude from the girl at the counter. Plenty of other places to get much better donuts without the wait.

I dont get all the hype between all the donut places in portland that everyone says you should go to but then they aren't very good. I only think tourists go here, never heard of a local that likes them

the donuts are awesome, the line is stupid and i hate waiting in line for ANYTHING. 30 minutes on a weekday in the afternoon standing in the sun or the rain waiting for a donut. i guess I don't like donuts enough...

Voodoo will always have hoards of loyal out-of-towner fans, so I don't think my low rating of them will hurt them much.  To me, they are quite a tourist trap.  Yes, they have some fun, creative donuts that are pretty okay (not amazing)... but are they worth the 45-minute wait in line?  Absolutely not. 

Note:  CASH ONLY (with ATM inside the store)

This is not to say I don't suggest going there for a sugar fix.  If you're visiting from out of town, then... sure, it can be a fun thing to add on your to-do list.  It's just not quite worth it for me.  There are better donuts in town without the horrendous lines (check out Blue Star Donuts)

Voodoo Doughnuts didn't work its magic on me and I don't think it will - ever. We were greeted by the long lines that everyone keeps telling us about and when we reached the front of the line......well...

After 4 boxes (2 of which were filled with the ever-popular cock and balls) and 37 agonizing heat-filled minutes later I left as an unhappy camper. These doughnuts weren't as great, delicious, voodoo-ed out as most people claim they are. They were just....OK.

The reason I give VD 3 stars is because of the experience OUTSIDE of the doughnut shop, not what I experienced inside. We were sandwiched between a Seattle transplant and a couple were just got married and were traveling the 50 states in a just-about-to-die 1994 Ford Taurus- and their stories were sweet and admirable. Surely, if i wasn't for our ambitious adventure into Voodoo Doughnut-land we would not have met them.

I'm glad we had a chance to say "been there, done that"- but next time I'm going down to Portland it won't be because I'm dying and craving one of their unusually odd-named, bizarrely concocted doughnuts.
Great toppings, sup-par cake.

Voodoo has certainly cast its spell over swarms of people bc every time I passed by there have been lines wrapped around the block. My first trip to Portland I just gave up (I came on a Saturday and couldn't fathom standing in the cold waiting for a donut - no matter how magical or how much that said donut was shaped into male genitalia). 

But my second work trip there this last month I went on a Monday night, saw no lines and had to hop in. We got the No Name (raised donut with chocolate and peanut butter frosting and rice krispies) & Memphis Mafia (fried donut, banana chunks, glazed with chocolate frosting, peanut butter, nuts and chocolate chips). As you can imagine, it was sugar overload! My 5 year old self would have thought these donuts were God's gift to the world but my adult self just couldn't get into it. There was just too much sweetness going on especially in the Mafia donut -  I mean it's a glazed fritter with more frosted sugar all over it - my taste buds went numb processing all the different levels of sugar.

Plus, the donut itself was very thick - I tend to like more airy, lighter donuts (so I can cheat myself into thinking it wasn't THAT bad....).

All in all, this is clearly a Portland institution and it's one of those "Gotta try it once." And while it was far too sweet for me - this could be your new joint so give it a try for yourself and if possible, go on a weeknight or at really odd, early hours (they're open 24/7)!
It's a doughnut shop. The decor and ambience is cool. I tried the Portland doughnut. Maybe I should have tried a different "specialty" doughnut.

Over-hype much??

I finally gave in and checked this place out. Stood in line for gawd know how long. I ordered 3 donuts to try out: the voodoo doll, grape, and captain my captain. The girl at the counter placed a sheet of paper on top of the doll donut, and just carelessly jamming it into the bag, ending up smooshing it! Suffice to say I didn't get to take a picture of the cute looking donut.

Taste-wise it was mediocre at best! Nothing special about the dough or the icing/filling/topping. Ok so they're creative with their flavors, I'll give them that. But can't a shop with better donuts slap some bacon on their maple bar or sprinkle some cereal on top of another? If so then they'll give Voodoo a run for their money. 

No amount of voodoo will bring me back to this place.

Meh, they're just donuts. They taste fine, but they're nothing special. It's more about enjoying having been there than wanting to go back because it's great. That being said, the donuts (much like most food) increases exponentially in flavor as you drink. So basically drink at the bars around there and you'll be happy they exist as you drunkenly stumble to your Uber at 1:30am.

I don't understand what the big deal is about voodoo's donuts  I waited an hour which was fine because the reviews said the donuts are worth it. The yelp  reviews said  they are amazing so I happily  waited. YOU KNOW WHY BECAUSE LOVE WAITS AND I LOVE DONUTS. All I can say is the donuts are not even close to what I thought they were going to be. The donuts are heavy and with bad texture did I say they are heavy like dense gummy not good at all. I get the extravagant topics on top are meant to look more appeling and fun or whatever I just cannot understand why donuts are already festive and happy! It just feels like they just decided to put all kinds of cereals and other sweet things (cookie crumbs gum) on top  of the donuts and to be honest they look straight up grotesque and don't even make any sense or taste good. I guess I took it off my list of things to do in Portland. I just have a feeling that this is basically a tourist trap I just don't see anybody from the area shopping at this donut shop. Just because everybody else is getting them and everybody else is talking about them DOES NOT  mean they are actually good. LESSON LEARNED.

Nothing impressive about the donuts here. It's just another donut shop that happens to have a lot of hype around it (and long lines).  The donuts look pretty and good but they are just Mehh in taste and texture.  No desire to go back.

Voodoo Doughnut has hit the Portland meme nail on the head. They have creative names, and donuts. The service is across the board bad, and the donuts are just so so. Definitively a must try when you visit Portland, but for a local, meh.

We got a glazed, Portland cream and mafia. The glazed was average, the Portland cream was average as well but the chocolate didn't taste quite alright. The mafia was giant and probably the best of the bunch. 

Agree with the other reviewers - the place is hyped and it is pure marketing/branding at work. The line was long when we went there and it moved fairly quickly. But not worth the effort of standing in line for an average donut. Go there for the fun donut names, not for an exceptional donut.

I went to Voodoo Donut in NE PDX late on a Monday morning.  No line,  empty parking lot, and only a few other customers.

Frankly I don't understand all the fuss.  The bacon maple bar was okay but no more than that.  The combination of tastes was interesting and creative, I'll give them that.  The lemon chiffon wasn't bad but was too sweet.  Both were made from a good tasting but too fluffy dough.
  
To be fair the donuts I prefer are the ones which used to be called "sinkers".  Solid, gut bomber pastries.  The frequently raved-about Krispy Kream are way too light by my standards and these were only a little better.

Voodoo donuts coffee is nothing to write home about either
Overrated and the lines are way too long.  Nice place to get a picture doing something crazy like waiting an hour for a donut, otherwise, go to a local bakery.

I may get bacon covered donuts thrown at me for not being a huge follower of a Portland institution, but this place is overrated. I'm sorry, I said it. Don't get me wrong, I really like the unique nature of this place, the cool interior design characteristics, and obviously the really great list of unique dining options are truly remarkable. Also, I cannot count the times that I chuckle when I see nice little families walking out of there and their little children carrying a box that says "good things come in little pink boxes" on it. So satisfying...
But all things aside, I just don't think the donuts taste that great. It's fun to go to Voodoo once in a while to get a donut that is different, but if I want one that actually tastes really good, I go elsewhere...
Not worth the hype - Blue Star Doughnut was WAYYY better. Not even close. Shocked that there was such a long line here. I had the classic doughnut with chocolate topping - very average.

I posted a new review, too, but something is amiss is maple bacon bar land. The bacon was wrong, the icing too thick, the donut too thick....  Please go back to perfection or fix the production issue if this was just an error.  Still delicious but trending towards average.

So, I can't really hate too much because I literally rolled in at 130 am, hoping for a few maple bacon bars (they were of course out) and a whole load of etceteras. I ordered a dozen and basically got a box full of random, way too sweet to really enjoy, crapshoot of what was left. The majority of which I unloaded on the walk back to the hotel, although even the homeless did NOT seem interested. Worth a trip but don't expect to be blown away.

I've been here before and tried some of their selection, but nothing really stood out to me so I decided to give it a try again since all my friends rave about how great this place is and etc. FAIL! 

The line at the door was a good 30+ person long, the cereal on some of the doughnuts were ordered were stale as previously mentioned in other post and to top it off some of the people that were waiting in line was EXTREMELY RUDE! On three different occasion I came very close to yelling at an older woman, punching a guy in the face for being too loud and obnoxious and another couple that was undecided with what they wanted to order even though they were in line for a good 20 minutes prior! 

Thanks but no thanks Voo Doo Doughnut, YOU SUCK! 


Oh yeah, the maple bacon bar sucks too! Ok, I lied. That was probably the only doughnut I liked out of their GINORMOUS selection.

Plain good donuts.  Nice and soft, sweet like as donuts should be.  I just think it's fun to get in the long line and see all sorts of different donuts and different people waiting to eat voodoo.  It's like being a kid at the candy store.  I give 3 stars because I don't eat enough donuts to say what is the best and worst taste of donuts.

Funny names, interesting concept, but overpriced and below average donuts with stale toppings. Maybe worth one trip for the experience (just look around and buy one donut -- don't get suckered into paying 30 bucks for a dozen), but that's about all. I really don't understand the hype with this place.

I used to intern across the street from this one and i would get there early before the mad lines started. They doughnuts are really just so-so. the place is tiny and old and dirty. so it makes it less appetizing.

Seriously so OVERRRRATED! It's just a donut with a buncha sh*t piled on. Yea, flavors and toppings are unconventional, but piling on cereal, cookies, peanut butter, different color glaze DOES NOT necessarily make for a better tasting donut. 

If you're an out-of-towner, I would say it IS worth making the stop and maybe even waiting in line just so you can people watch and get the experience. Don't expect anything mind blowing. My local donut shop does a better job than Voodoo.

First of all, don't go here after sunset as the area is inhabited by the homeless crowd and you'll be asked for hand outs. The amount of smoking of all types is pretty intense as well so this is not a kid friendly area. The donuts are fine and look very homemade and are a bit sweet for my taste. We got a few to try and only had a few bites of each.

I've wanted to try this place for years and was looking forward to stuffing my face full of donuts. I should've looked at the menu online before coming here because it was a crazy way to order donuts. I really liked the bored woman at the register gazing off into the distance while my wife and I were trying to pick our donuts. The donuts were good but nothing like I had built up in my head. I'd come here just to say I've been, but you should drop whatever you are doing and go directly to Blue Star donuts...now.

Meh. A bit underwhelming, I'm afraid. It's cool in the kinds of donuts it offers (I mean, where else are you going to get donuts that have phallic shapes or utilize kids' breakfast cereal?) but the actual taste of these donuts are somewhat lacking. Fun to try at least once, but not quite worth the walk through a sketchy part of Portland for a return visit, in my opinion.

We stopped here to take in the experience after seeing Voodoo on a Travel Channel series.

We waited in line for about 15 minutes to get inside. It's clever how they've branded themselves and the names of their donuts, but the donuts are way too rich for my taste - we ordered almost every donut they make, and walked out with 3 boxes - I could only finish 2 of the donuts I tried - the rest were just too rich.

It's a fun experience, and the shirts are clever, but a no-go on the donuts EXCEPT for the maple bar topped with a slice of bacon - now that donut is genius and it tasted great. If it weren't for that donut, it'd be a 2-star rating.

Maybe my expectations were too high based on the TV show.

First time visiting Portland, I got to hit up the hyped voodoo donuts as a must try donut shop. When we arrive, sure enough, there was a long line waiting on the outside (really popular place). 

The pink sign was very bright and visible, stands out from other shop around the area. The donut shop is located at downtown Portland, area around the shop looks very sketchy, dirty street and many pan handlers wondering around the shop, I am not sure how safe is the area. 

We waited about 25 minutes to get inside the shop to order, got a dozen donuts including cock n balls, captain my captain, old dirty bastard, bacon maple bar, aren't that a peach, voodoo doll, tex-ass, all the special naming donuts that you can get on their menu...etc

Packed in huge pink box with voodoo donut logo. Open the magic voodoo box, and the donuts were huge! Especially the balls on the cock n ball donut, Lol!

The decorative donut designs were so interesting, I had to push myself on taking a bite. What I taste in most of the donuts is SUGAR OVERLOAD, they are extremely sweet, sweet oozing out from the inside (jam filling donuts), sweet frosting cover on the outside with extra sweet sprinkles and drizzles. I think I was going on a sugar high after a few bite, and down them with water. I enjoy the peach filling donut, old dirty bastard and maple bacon bar. The dough were soft, and sweetness melts with it. 

If yelp has 0.50 rating increments, I gave this place a 3.5. The hype magic was there for a short time, then  it disappears. The attraction is for the shape and design of the donuts, and for its naming logistics. The donuts tasted good, but way to sweet for me.

My friend's statement while we were eating our donuts pretty much sums this place up.. "You guys may or may not get upset with me, but this is just a regular donut." 

It's good, but overrated.

Meh... Did not live up to the hype. The donuts look very creative and interesting but taste like nothing special. I guess what makes the donut look cool is all the colors and whatnot which means an insane amount of frosting. Way to sweet for me. The line was incredibly long also. Not worth the wait.
Above average donuts but not spectacular and a bit overpriced. Not bad by any means, just a tourist trap. Lines do move fast though.

Well, it's Voodoo Doughnuts.  It's more about the experience than anything else.  The doughnuts are tasty, but I'd say its more about the whole package.  Just go, at least once, you won't regret it :)

If you have a conservative slant, you may have issues with some of the menu items.

Visiting Portland, Oregon - of course our hosts said "we have to go to Voodoo donuts!" and yes, I agree. It's an experience, a "thing to do" - I mean, people actually ask "did you go to Voodoo donuts" if you visit.

For me, the strangest part was as I was on the Trimet light rail headed into town from the airport, a man sat across from me clutching a pink box. Yes, a dozen Voodoo donuts. He was with his young daughter, but he seemed to be protecting the box. They left a couple stops later, but that stuck with me.

SO - when we get to downtown and have dinner - we're told "time to visit Voodoo donuts!" - Luckily it is late, so the line is ONLY about 20 minutes wait time.

We get to the front of the line - what do we want? Too many choices, and actually the donuts don't look that fresh. We get a "dozen" - so suddenly we have our own precious pink box.

We eat them over the next two days - and they are "ok". If I had a favorite, it was the peanut butter and jelly donut. But overall - hey - they're donuts.
You all know about these donuts.  But please please please. Make more vegan ones!!!!!!
Tourist trap. Donuts the same quality as Safeway. Some are interesting shapes. Line around the block only because tourism made it a 'thing'. Locals never go here.

We went to this place late at night and cannot believe they were still open. They had a case of dough nuts on display and had baking racks behind them with diff. varieties of doughnuts. They had a great and "interesting" variety. Of course I got the voodoo doughnut and it wasn't bad. They all had good flavor but sorry to say not rememberal. Almost taste like any other doughnut. The only difference was what was on top of the doughnut. If I go back to Portland, I will try them earlier in the day and see if there was a difference.

Their donuts taste like the underside of an emaciated donkey's scrotum.

Go with Blue Star Donuts instead: http://www.bluestardonuts.com/

Wow.  I don't get it.

Walked in when there wasn't a line (very rare) and saw the selection.  Almost got diabetes just from seeing all the sugar on one doughnut.  Yes, they are fun to see, but most look like they were made by 3-year old kids.

No thanks!
How about we don't wait in line for cereal on top of a dough nut? idiots... tourist... republicans... those are the only people that go to VooDoo Doughnuts... #bluestardoughnuts for me

oh how i wanted to avoid this place but lo, i went. i waited on line, late at night. like a cow, like everyone else.  buuuuuuuut, the vegan donuts were good. yep, they were. a novelty. i'm a donut addict so i have to avoid these joints anyway.

I'm not a donut aficionado. In fact, I'm not that crazy about them. But my wife loves them and we both agreed, Voodoo Donuts is ok, but nothing spectacular. I got the double chocolate cake donut. The flavor was mild without that oily aftertaste that most donuts have. Not bad but I've had much better. My wife got a mixture and not a single one made her say yum. The peach fritter was a standard Apple fritter with what tasted like canned peaches in a few spots. The maple bacon was large, but heavy and unfilled with standard maple frosting and some bacon on top. Overall, we were not impressed. We went more because it's an icon than anything else and that's why we won't go back.

3.5

It looks like exactly what it sounds like:  a maple doughnut with crispy bacon strips on top.  A nice, warm caramel colored icing with 2 strips of fatty bacon laid out nonchalantly on either end of the doughnut.  Like someone just left it there and forgot it.

Sure enough, it also tasted exactly like what it sounds like:  sweet and salty, soft and crunchy.

I wasn't sure whether to expect fireworks coming out of my mouth or to be utterly grossed out.  I liked it, but I didn't love it.  Maybe the bacon looked a little stale, or maybe because the guilt factor in my brain wouldn't let me finish it.  But I had it and I survived!  My friend and I also had the Mexican hot chocolate flavored doughnut, which had a nice rich and spicy flavor.  

Voo Doo is a tiny doughnut shop that flaunts its attitude & sexual brazenness, whether it be from the penis shaped doughnuts to names like "cock and balls."  I love that their display case is chock full of doughnuts sprinkled messily with cereal or other strange shapes and colors.  These certainly aren't the best doughnuts in the world, but they are the most fun to eat.  It's a place to visit, if you can stand the huge line and shock factor.

Yeah, sometimes the line is too long. Unless your heart was really set on it - go somewhere else if the line is that long. Don't be mean to them, but don't give money to the dudes asking you for money. They will use it for drugs, and will not leave.

My favorite donuts are the Butterfingered and Diablo Rex. I often go to Ground Kontrol, then hit Voodoo on the way home, so I can have breakfast donuts the next morning. 

A Portland classic, better than the Bay Area's Psycho Donuts. I have one of the purple ringer shirts. I love wearing it when people don't know what the hell Voodoo is, and are forced to comprehend a woman willfully wearing a shirt saying "the magic in the hole."

I really dont get the hype.  That being said, it is very 'Portland'-  they have funny and cute offerings and I can see why its been written up and is so popular.

The service is good, they are helpful.  Back in my younger days it was nice to go grab a doughnut after a night of drinking downtown, so being open 24 hours is pretty cool.

Unfortunately their doughnuts just arent that great.  There are much better doughnut places in Portland, so its hard to give a doughnut shop a high rating when their actual product is more show than substance.  Add a long line and I just dont see the point.

The doughnuts here are really good,after the wait outside, through the sea of poo scented hobos (not loveable tramps). 
The waiting area is packed with sour faced, entitled tourists, I wanted to chin check the people in line next to me (1 inch of personal space is okay, you'll still get to order, we don't have to touch, get out of my bubble) .  
Do not even attempt to use the bathroom, don't even approach it, I believe it may be a local custom to do a handstand completely naked and spin around as you defecate.
Overall, the doughnuts were worth the quick stop, but I am also up to date on my tetanus shot.

Eh. The doughnuts are OK, and they're best enjoyed at 3:00AM on a weeknight when you don't have to wait in a fiendish line.

I know a lot of people like them, and the customer service is fantastic, but they're just too damn sweet for my taste.
Not a fan at all.  Doughnuts does not taste good at all, taste just like Safeway 50cents donuts.  Don't waste your money and time.

This place had about a 30-minute long wait outside the shop but being that we were visiting, we had to see what the hype was all about. There were so many doughnuts to choose from and we got quite a few. I remember we had the Oreo one and the bacon one.. and also the one with fruit loops and then another crazy looking one with a bunch of chocolate and caramel. At the end of the day, a doughnut is a doughnut, especially if it's loaded with a bunch of crap. The doughnut itself tasted very good and fresh, but not worth such a long wait in my opinion. 

I have yet to try "Psycho Doughnuts," which we have here in Cali and reminds me much of Voodoo Doughnut.
Great doughnuts, bad customer service and wait times.

This is a "when in Portland" type stop. I've heard so much about this place and if you know anything about me, you know I'm a sucker for doughnuts! It was late in the evening, so I'm sure they didn't have their full menu of doughnuts, but I still wanted to try a couple!
I ordered the Portland Cream and the Cinnamon Sugar Crueller. They didn't have their original Portland Cream but they had a vegan version so I decided to just get that. And honestly, I could not tell the difference! I love cream filled donuts, and vegan or not, this was a good choice! It was on the heavier side, however. The Crueller was lighter and tasted great too!
I highly recommend getting a bunch of donuts and just sharing them with other people. For the amount of hype Voodoo has, I wasn't impressed with the doughnuts I received.
Also, just an FYI, this place is CASH ONLY, so be prepared - but if you forget, they do have an ATM inside!

Ok, they're not bad, but I don't see what the fuss is all about? Maybe it's the quirkiness and the way it represents the city. The taste? It's how I expect a donut to taste. I've tried bites of 4 different kinds, but nothing that knocked me off my feet. The staff seemed simply annoyed and didn't really contribute to a great Portland experience. Oh well...
the donuts were alright. I'm sure other people really love it, but to me it was just alright. I fell in line for 30mins and did the whole tourist thing... but wont do it again.
line was hecka long. donuts were eh, but the staff was cool af.  probably wouldn't go back.

So my husband and I kept hearing about this place and so we had to go being from out of town. We waited in line for almost an hour, thinking this place would be the bomb. I guess i was just a bit disappointed, expecting tastier doughnuts. But the service was great and the place was pretty funky. the doughnuts were ok but I guess with waiting all that long, I had higher or just different expectations. All in all an OK experience.

This place has style and charm coming out the wazoo, but the doughnuts... meh. There is absolutely nothing special about the way these doughnuts taste. Apparently a great logo and some quirky marketing (this donut is shaped like a dick and balls!) is all you need to be the talk of the town. You've got to wonder what the line of out-of-towners think 30 minutes later when they finally get their unremarkable treat. 

Of course, you go to Voodoo Doughnuts because people go to Voodoo Doughnuts much like people go to Blow Pony because that's where the people go (eventhough the djs can't mix two songs together and all the music is ironic in the sense of "isn't this funny, we listened to this in the 80s!!" but they're playing the very worst crap from the 80s). A much tastier doughnut can be had at Acme over on SE Powell.

I am happy that this place just keeps going strong. It is essential to the weirdness of Portland. That said, this is gimmick cooking at best. If you feel compelled to buy a fruit loop encrusted donut you must not really trust the base. You should. The plain donuts actually express the art much better than the gimmicks.

This was a painful experience. We went at 6:45am on a Sunday morning. The place was fully staffed but only one register was open. There were three people in front of us but we still waited over 20 minutes for 2 overrated donuts. Not worth it!

Waaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaayyyyyy over rated. I have eaten here a few times and yes, the donuts are good. Yes, the donut names are fun. Yes, they have a fun logo. But they are NOT worth that line! I waited in the line only once and now I only order when there is no line. The servers are rude and rush you. The people are obnoxious. The boxes are pink and full of treats. But I can get fantastic donuts in many places. You have to try them for yourself, at least once. Then you can decide if you think they're worth the line.  I loved the apple fritter and the blueberry. I'm not into the real freaky stuff with bacon and cereal and phallic donuts.

The biggest and most-creative doughnut names and toppings I've seen anywhere. I opted for a simple glazed donut and it was tasty. For the more adventurous there's a maple bar with bacon as well as a glazed doughnut that probably measures 10 inches across. People were lined-up around the corner at 9 p.m., but the next day around 1 p.m. the line didn't reach the corner and the wait was only about 15 minutes. The place is small so you'll probably notice it first by the line outside before you see the signs. Get a few doughnuts to go in their trademark bright pink box, and you'll be stopped in the streets by curious locals as well as tourists asking about the donuts and directions to the shop.

I am not a fan of donuts and Voodoo Doughnut was not on my list of places to visit in Portland but omg, we kept passing by it that we just had to stop by and check out the hype. There was a parking spot that was open right in front of the store so we pulled up and put in about an hour worth of metered parking.

The line was fairly long, wrapped around the railing and extended down the street...I think we waited almost an hour for it. I keep seeing people coming out with boxes on boxes of donuts but it was just me and my bff so we got 2 donuts and shared. We tried the Portland cream (too sweet to my liking) and the blueberry one (I think it was blueberry, and it was mediocre). The donuts itself were pretty expensive too considering the fact that I picked two of the less popular ones and it was still ~$4-5/donut...

I think it is only worth it if you have a big party and are willing to share all the crazy decorated donuts for a photo op. Other than that, the quality of the donuts is nothing close of spectacular and definitely not worth an hour wait. But, it is part of the tourist experience so if you have the time while exploring Portland (which I am sure you will since there isn't much to do around here..), then stop by and check it out. I believe it is cash only but there is an ATM machine nearby. And they are open 24/7 so if you don't wanna wait in line, go during non peak hours.

It's a decent doughnut, and if you can show up when there's no line, go for it. 

It's also just a doughnut with cereal on it, in most cases. And whenever I've gone, the cereal's been slightly stale. Or maybe they stuck a pretzel in it. 

Woo. 

It's definitely not worth the line.

The doughnuts are different than any other doughnut shop. Had to wait in line for about 20 to 30 minuets. There is four order takers and a menu of most of their offerings. Which helps the line keep moving. As far as price I don't remember. All i remember is ordering s bunch of doughnuts. Snd getting some change back. Yes I would do it all over again

This place is pretty original during it's time & it's been copied all over the country.  The donuts were decent, but the shop is more of a gimmic than anything.  It's in a prime location so it's super busy at all times of the day.  I guess if you're looking for a penis shaped donut, come here but of you're looking for super delicious donuts look else where...

standard donuts with maybe extra creativity. 
Most of them are so sweet and I can barely eat more than one at a time.
Not a frequent go-to place for me.
It's a bit overrated. The cereal they sprinkle on some donuts usually tastes super stale.
This place is over rated,Over crouded,old doughnuts,Cool shapes but not worth the time.

While these are certainly not the best donuts you could eat in Portland, they're definitely the most fun. Choose from plain old sprinkles to captain crunch, tang, bubble gum, voodoo doll, maple blunt, m&m and Oreo and sooo many more. Hey if you're really up for it, you can even getting married at their shop! Watch for long lines at this location, but it moves fast! If you want yummy donuts and don't want to wait, head to Coco donuts or Blue Star donuts.

Heard all about Voodoo Doughnuts from friends who visited Portland in the past. All said I had to try it at least once. Sadly, I was not impressed.

I ordered 3 doughnuts, Peach Fritter, Maple Bacon Bar and a Glazed doughnut. The glazed doughnut was not good - it had an oily / greasy taste; slightly better than a standard supermarket doughnut. The Maple Bacon Bar while good could have been better with some sort of filling and a little bit less sweet frosting. The Peach Fritter was very good - crispy on the outside, and loaded with peaches. The only issue there was too much frosting on the doughnut itself. Overall, if you want to try it for the experience go for it - but do not think you are going to get an awesome doughnut.

This is not my type of store. Worn (dirty), gaudy, and paraphernalia everywhere. Actually, I'd be okay with gaudy paraphernalia if it weren't so dirty feeling but those seem to go hand in hand? Plus the donuts just don't look appetizing.

So I admit, I didn't eat the donuts that we bought. But apparently the apple fritter is good, maple bar just okay, voodoo doll donut has too much raspberry filling.

There you have it.

I don't understand at all but there you have it.
Soooo gross. Greasy doughnuts with lots of sugar on top to hide the terrible lack of taste.

It's fine, but if you want a really good doughnut, I prefer Blue Star.  Voodoo is more about the gimmick. The doughnuts are decent, and gimmicks are fine, but I just think the gimmick sometimes overshadows the doughnut itself.  That being said, I often choose the very plain doughnuts here, as I think they are way better than those that have so much theme to them.  Just my preference maybe.

It may practically be a sacrilege to write a less-than-stellar review of Voodoo Doughnuts, but I've tried a variety of their flavors, three times over the past couple of years, and never found a doughnut I could rave about.  I love doughnuts in general, but I think Voodoo has traded flavor for gimmicky style with a lot of hype. You'll wonder what the buzz is all about.

Even hailing from Seattle, that pink box is unmistakeable. At the stroke of midnight, the line was at a constant roar with eager, carb-crazed people. When I came back around the area 12 hours later, it's like the line never stopped. Madness, utter madness. 

Note that I'm not much of a doughnut lover but their unique (and mostly weird) toppings, gold flecked brick walls and funky chandeliers did give it street cred. 

Had the maple bacon bar and 1/2 way through, the sugar high was just too much and I picked off the crispy bacon pieces to devour instead. From Fruit Loops to "Voo doo" doll shapes, their doughnuts definitely each have a distinct personality. However, I wasn't impressed with the bread itself. Sans toppings, could they have stood alone amongst other doughnut contenders? Kind of doubtful. The maple bacon wasn't as airy and fluffy as I had hoped. 

This isn't really the place to go when you want a more simple doughnut of times past but a fun place to visit at least once.

I wanted to see what the hype is all about. The donuts are good. I like the voodoo one the best. There was a line to get in and the staff yell on top of their lungs to say ' NEXT ' I thought that was rude.

This place is about hype, fun and the absurd.  It's not a place about making good donuts.  Just about every other donut place tastes better than Voodoo but Voodoo is fun.  You're buying fun donuts, not great tasting donuts.

On a road trip up the coast, I knew this had to be a place to check out.
Unfortunately, we went to the shop that did not offer seating or milk.  We waited patiently in the long line, admiring the eclectic art of the wall, accompanied by the vulgar names of the donuts.  When we got to the front of the line, we order 5 donuts and they were good, but not great.
The maple bacon bar was exactly how it sounds.  I was hoping the bacon would taste a little more "cooked today" rather than "cooked last week" but it still was decent.
My favorite was the huge fritter called the Memphis Mafia.  On top of this Sasquatch Size fritter sat peanuts, chocolate chips, peanut butter, and chocolate sauce.  It truly was an experience in itself.
The voodoo donut was dry and the jelly tasted a bit sour.
Definately a place to visit, but don't expect out of this world donuts, it looks like they are focusing more on delivering huge quantities at a time, because I saw their van twice leave with a huge load.

When you come to Portland, you have to think of Voodoo Donuts more like an attraction, than anything else. If you haven't been, you have to check it out. 

- There is a designated, roped off line at all hours of the day. 
- The wait can be 30 minutes or more. 
- Donut names are funny and crazy. 
- There is a gigantic donut hanging from the ceiling and other kitschy stuff. 
- The donuts are not as good as Blue Star, but funner! 
- Decently clean tables to enjoy your grub. 
- Donuts range from $1.50-$3.00

Tip: While everyone takes these to go, don't take any cereal ones home. The cereal becomes pretty soggy over time.

A bunch of old, stale, dried out doughnuts that look like they were made by Cub Scouts at day camp!  Dry, chewy, stale fruit loops on a maple bar?  REALLY!???  Just plain nasty.  I can't figure Portland's hype of this place other than it's open really late and it's in a neighborhood where you could probably buy just about any drug... just outside the front door.

People around here just don't know any better.

On our last day in Portland, my friends and I decided to try out these famous doughnuts. The line wasn't too bad. We waited maybe 20 minutes before being served. The guy that took my order seemed really angry and annoyed. He was kicking boxes and cursing while he was putting together my box of doughnuts. That was weird. What I also found weird was being harassed by drunks while us tourists waited in line. People would walk by and say "that place sucks" and "their doughnuts aren't even that good" and "enjoy your f***ing doughnuts". But, I guess they were kind of right because the doughnuts we got were pretty basic in taste. How they were decorated was really fun and unique, but the taste was just ok. It was an interesting experience overall, and if I'm ever in Portland again, I will probably never come back to this doughnut shop.

there's a line. there's donuts. i'm a fan of a good donut now and then and i certainly have my favorite spots but i wouldn't say this is one of them.  the names are kitschy and cool...great marketing for sure but overall i'll save my donut calories next time and pass.

I'm sorry, it just doesn't live up to the hype.

I got 6 of their best sells:

Purple sprinkle donut: 4/10
Voodoo: 4/10
Rainbow cereal thingy: 5/10
Chocolate covered: 7/10
Bacon maple: 7/10
Oreo crumb: 8/10

These donuts... just aren't that good..

Donuts are donuts no matter where you go, well most of the time. But when you go to Portland, you go to Voodoo, it's just a must! There is always a line out the door, no question. The first time I went, we picked up a mixed dozen...they lasted for days because there were so many and they were so sweet. They pick a random 12 too, so it's difficult to get what you want. We had to take the rest of the box back to San Diego, lol. 

This time around I decided I was just going to get one donut. I waited in line, took a lot longer. The register girl was sneezing and helping people...uhh gross. There was a picture of the actual voodoo donut next to a particular type of donut, can't remember the name. I ordered that particular type and then she came with it and I was mistaken...and i said Oh i thought that was the voodoo...and she was pissed cause she had to do it over. Well THANKS FOR YOUR HELP. Whatever, it's just a donut. I ate the top of the voodoo, and i enjoyed it until i realized it was jelly filled. Watch out for a gooey insides that may spill!
You go here for the weird factor, uninterested counter staff and notoriety, you don't go here for the donuts. They are basically grocery store quality with odd food items stuck to them.

Super fun atmosphere...crazy donuts.  My fav is the grape vegetarian...raised donuts with white frosting and sour grape candy powder dusting the top.  The donuts are standard stick to your gut with immediate regret though.  All the ingredients seem to be the same stuff that they sell in 5 gallon buckets for any other grocery store.

So overrated. The lines are insanely long and filled with tourists. Did this place just get popular because there is a phallic donut?

Sure, it's an experience that you should have once, and I get the appeal of a place that puts weird toppings on their donuts, but the donuts themselves are too dense and too sweet. Spend your daily calories elsewhere!

I am a man of plain and basic donuts. Round cake donut with white icing. Kruller. Shit like that. I got a blueberry cake donut here that was pretty good. Only problem was it cost a dollar. A dollar? 

Think about that. Next time someone says something crazy like, "You know, I really think Croatia could win Euro 2008," are you going to be able to come back with, "Well I bet you dollars to fucking donuts they don't!"? No, you will not be able to say that, cause a donut costs a dollar now.

I just don't get it! Over priced, stale doughnuts with stale toppings.

It pains me outsiders automatically think of Portland for these crappy gimmicky doughnuts when we have so many mom & pop shops that make fresh tasty doughnuts. Krispy Kreme even makes a better doughnut and I don't have to wait in a long line.
Umm the doughnuts were good but I can tell they've been sitting there all day next time I gotta remember to go early morning when they open and hopefully I get fresh ones
I get a stomach ache every time I eat there. Plus the smell is terrible. The last time I had a good donut there was 8 years ago before it really became the tourist trap it is today.

Girl with the red hair behind the counter, are you the door natzi? Your mean and rude. Can we get some customer service and some training......!
Donuts rock! Red hair girl get a new job
ALWAYS stale. I don't know how they do it, but their donuts always taste stale! That's the real voodoo.

We got there around dinner time and found a line out the door.  But the wait was not bad.  We bought a voodoo doll, a bacon maple and a Portland cream.  I was a little disappointed because besides being unique, they tasted just like a regular donuts if not drier.  I guess going there for the Portland experience is ok.

OK, we do go here often, especially with out of town guests, but really I don't quite get it.  The staff is, shall we say, different.  The "cash only" policy which seems so "Portland" is really to avoid the 5% vendor fee they would have to pay.  
When you step back and look at it, your paying top dollar for a donut, after waiting in line and making sure you went to the cash machine first.  You are getting food from a place you would not normally want to get food from....

But hey, I can't go thru the airport without seeing a pink box...

And in Vegas there is an actual business called Pink Box doing the same thing.
Meh, Donuts are ok, the wait around the block is absurd. I'd rather spend my time elsewhere.
Sub-par. Cold and old even at 7:30 in the morning. Ate half of the "buttermilk bar". Not much buttermilk to be had.

I really want to rate Voodoo higher than this but I really just was not impressed. I think I'm even being a little charitable with three stars. I felt obligated to visit and withstand the long line out the door because I live so close to Portland, but it definitely was not worth the hassle. I got the "Portland Cream" (apparently portland's official donut),  the bacon maple, and peach fritter. The dough tasted typical for all the donuts- not bad, just not special. The cream in the Portland cream tastes like jello vanilla instant pudding and the peach fritter was a big disappointment as it had a thick pink frosting on it and little peach. The bacon maple was alright if you're into that kind of taste. Sorry Voodoo, I get why you're a hype but you're just not my type. Basically, Voodoo donuts is a tourist trap and a generic donut shop hidden behind a silly reputation.

They had "employees" outside saying that you could get 20% off by putting a good Yelp review. But when getting to the register she had no idea? Well how about enforcing  people saying that right at their front door. I got a dozen of they pick them and she gave me all the smallest and boring ones. Cool.

Came here to see what the rave is about. Basically the doughnuts are similar to Dunkin' Donuts just bigger and different flavors and shapes and more expensive. The lines can be long. We went around 9pm and the line was not too bad. They are open 24 hrs. And cash only

Mediocre doughnuts made with the same mass-produced ingredients that are supplied to Safeway.  But you get to wait in a line to get them.  They're a lose-lose proposition.  

Their one positive is that they keep the tourists away from the better shops (Blue Star) since they're now a Portland "institution".

I used to work in the area so i've probably been here a dozen times and eaten my way through their doughnut selection.  I get the appeal I suppose, they're quirky, they sell doughnuts, very Portland.  
The problem is while quirky is good, the donuts just aren't very good.  There are other donut places that do a much better job but don't require waiting in line to grab a donut.

I gave an extra star for the decor and overall fun of the place. Donuts went in the trash and I thought I'd never meet a donut I didn't like. On to try Blue Star Donuts. Our Lyft driver recommended last night.

Voodoo Donuts definitely does not live up to the hype.
The donuts here are just "okay" and deserve nothing more than a picture saying "yeah, I've been there."
I mean, yes, the donuts are tasty, but you're mostly paying for the design.
My family and I went late night during the club scene and it was moderately crowded. The wait wasn't too bad though and the customer service wasn't too bad either. I got the buttermilk bar (which was really small) and everyone else got something different. Mostly chocolate donuts though, and I don't even bother taste-testing them.
If you're not from the area and don't have one in your state (like Hollywood Studios, California), then I suggest coming here at least once in your life to try the hype.

if you want to get your picture taken at a tourist spot that is not a chain, go ahead and go to Voodoo donuts.  However, the reason their donuts are popular is due to the unconventional toppings and the name.  Do you really want Tang powder on your donut?  or Captain Crunch with Pixie stick dust?  methinks not!  When people have brought a box of Voodoo donuts to an event, there is literally nothing in the box that looks appetizing...except maybe the maple glazed bacon one.  and i hear that's the only thing people order when they are ordering for themselves.  So if you are the type of trendy person who likes to think they are being original, out-there, "weird" and unique, even though literally thousands of people and tourists are lining up right behind you, then go ahead and go to Voodoo donuts.  It reminds me of the Monty Python movie Life of Brian when everyone in the crowd is shouting "We're all individuals!" and one guy says "I'm not!"   That guy heads to Krispy Creme.

Don't really understand why everyone takes people from out of town here.  There are about a million other places in Portland I would rather spend my money at and eat delicious things. 

The great thing about this location is that while you wait in line for over an hour to get a doughnut, the homeless bums that live right outside, entertain you with their drunken/drug induced brawls. 

I am being funny, but when the homeless people outside were fighting, it was actually scary.

Want a goofy looking doughnut come here, want a partially undercooked doughnut come here as well. Great tourist location and plenty of interesting looking doughnuts to take pictures of but as a local I've probably had 3 undercooked and doughy doughnuts from them in the last 3 visits. Literally raw dough in the middle each time. The bacon maple bars are delicious but they never seem to have them the few times I've come in.

I know this place is hot but for the life of
me, I don't know why. The donuts are mediocre at best and covered with stuff like day glo cereals that could hardly be considered food, let alone food grade chemicals. Even sadder, one has to wait in line just to buy their near-toxic products. Portland has much higher quality donuts avail in the city, no need to go to VD
Sadly, very disappointing. The doughnuts were not very fresh.  They tasted as tired as  they looked in the display case.  Not impressed.

ok donut place. the quality of their donuts is average or below (perhaps i was unlucky in my timing). what makes them unique are the unorthodox toppings, but theyre not particularly clever in terms of flavor. i wouldnt wait in line for these donuts a second time.

Three star for average donuts. 
There is something to say about originality tho, so they are cool for that. However, Each time I have had Voodoo, the donuts have been covered way too much with frosting/toppings, and they are always STALE. Not to mention, they are very pricey (in my opinion) for a donut. Voodoo is cool to try once though, and I think it is cool that they have somewhat put Portland on the map in the food world. I have thought about going again, when craving sweets, but they couldn't pay me to stand in a ridiculous line for a bleh donut. Too much hype.

Go for the novelty, not the doughnuts. 

We recently ate at Voodoo Doughnuts for the first time--inspired by some out of town visitors who desperately wanted to try this Portland landmark. Of course, everyone has read or heard about Voodoo Doughnuts. There are the fanciful names, and the unusual decorations. 

Sadly the doughnuts themselves were disappointing. They tasted like average commercial doughnuts. The cake doughnuts were really heavy. And the traditional doughnuts reminded me of Dunkin' Donuts. Nothing tasted spectacular. In fact, I would even say that the doughnuts were too sweet.

So I repeat, go for the novelty, and don't expect a great doughnut.

Everyone said "go to voodoo doughnuts in Portland! It's the best doughnut ever!" We got a dozen doughnuts and let the staff pick them.  We were there at 5am there was no line yet. We were the first ones. We took out voodoo dozen back to the hotel and sampled each and every one. We could old take one bite out of each. The were the most dry doughnuts I had ever had. Put some stale cereal on top and its even worse. I don't understand the hype and really can't understand why people stand in line for hours for the crappiest doughnut. Seriously go to the grocery store, buy a glazed doughnut, put it in the microwave for a few seconds, sprinkle fresh cereal on top and I guarantee it will be 100 times better than voodoo.

You got to admit, they have the best marketing strategy. I suppose they paid a lot of folks to stand in line for a few weeks to kick it off. Their doughnuts are O.K. but , without the junk on top, nothing to rave about. It reminds me of when the Union Pacific Railroad built Sun Valley Idaho. They paid movie stars full contract fee to just hang out at the lodge and pretty soon the "little people" started going there. Or, when the "Cabbage Patch Kids" boondoggle began with all the false reports of their scarcity.

I give 'em an "A" for marketing. Cleaver bumper stickers and everything else very trendy and counter-culture.

Voodoo doughnut ? Wait all that time and pay extra for someone to put breakfast ceral or some other commonly available topping on your pastry?   Maybe it's just me but I can get as good or better at Safeway.

3stars for being open at 3am while I was jet lagged. So ask what's fresh and eat that. The chocolate raised doughnut at 3am was good. The other stuff was ok. Really just ok. The voodoo doll doughnut was clever but taste was alright, dough wasn't great. Luckily there's no line at 3am. Just post-bar crowd, some homeless peeps and other sketchy characters but it was safe enough.
Some of the other doughnut shops are better - do Blue Star, insane!

Finally got around to trying this place. We went to the one on Davis and was pleasantly surprised that it was not at all crowded. NO waiting!!   

I personally thot it was just OK.  Very sweet doughnuts and wow the flavors on some are really intense like a purple one hubby got. He liked it. I did not.  The grandkids enjoyed theirs a lot but hey they are kids. Fun shapes and sizes. Prices are surprisingly cheap.  

I will not go back unless my hubby wants to.  I think it is a lot of hype from the media.

While I appreciate the art in icing, VooDoo is, to me, more known for the touristy visitors who have seen this quirky doughnut misfit on tv. I've been there and was not impressed. The doughnuts themselves taste like day old grocery store leftovers - Nothing fresh, cake-like or moist about them. Mr. Yuck. And the obviously-bothered nonchalant hipster who appeared bothered by our asking about doughnuts, acted like WE were strange when he told us, on a Saturday evening, they were out of all but the bacon adorned and shriveled up "doughnut." Nope, sorry.

Interesting place, and decent to good donuts depending upon what you get.  The Maple Bacon roll sounds terrible but is actually awesome.  The negative is the long wait to get in and get served................best time to go, 5:30 am since they are open 24hrs!
Line was ridiculous but to be expected. Decor was great quirky all the things you expect. Donuts are unique and pretty good. I would recommend the experience.

Voodoo doughnuts is good for what it is--a Portland icon. It has been around forever and is a perfect reflection of Portland's quirky, irreverent, naughty character.

So if you've never been to Portland, yes, try it out. BUT, know that you are not going for an amazing doughnut. You are going for its bachelorette-party creations and its historical status. 

If you are looking for a delicious, artisan doughnut, go to Blue Star (downtown or on Hawthorne) or Pip's Doughnuts on Fremont. Those will change your life. Voodoo is simply for the experience--or when you've been out until at 4am and just really need some cock-n-balls.

Overrated Overhyped Overpriced

If you are one of those "Painfully trendy" people who must have the latest trend... this is the place for you.

The rest of us, those of us who do not want to wait in a TWO BLOCK LONG LINE for a doughnut... will eat elsewhere.  

Is the quality of the doughnut worth the wait , not to mention the outrageous prices they charge here? I think not.  There are other far better doughnut places in Portland.
It's a good doughnut, but despite being a local, I'm still not sure what all the fuss is about. They've certainly ridden a nice wave of publicity.

Pros: Unique & flavorful selection, can be a fun experience with friends, decent pricing, Portland culture.

Cons: Rude staff, long lines from time to time, too frequent sub-par quality, seems dirty, ghetto location.

It's a Portland thing. They have a pretty awesome selection of unique doughnuts like the maple bacon bar (not so unique but delicious), fruit loops, cap'n crunch, mango tango, Memphis mafia... I could go on... but the quality isn't consistent. Sometimes the doughnuts are stale, other times they're a real treat; it really depends on the time you go. There are vegan options for those vegans out there who once read or heard somewhere that they should be vegan, so that's a plus for them.

From time to time, the staff can be extremely rude. I get that the employees put up with a lot of crap, but customer service should never harm your business or offend people. The lines on a Friday or Saturday night are terrible and the customer service declines even more.

In reality, this place is a lot of hype with some really unique doughnut selections. It's a tourist attraction. Why wouldn't it be? They have a penis shaped doughnut. Going there with your friends while out on the town is a lot of fun, though. It's definitely worth trying more than once. I still make the suggestion to go there when I'm out on the town with friends and a sweet tooth.

I ordered the Maple bacon, it was delicious! The bacon was crunchy and there was tons of maple! It's definitely a tourist attraction though, something to try once. The lady who helped me out wasn't friendly at all so the experience wasn't that great. But the place was pretty cool looking and they do have a large selection for everyone.

Ew. Felt like I was in line for the methadone clinic. Tweens and tweekers nervously twitching for a doughnut, made me want to curl up and hide. Despite the commonly held belief that Voodoo has the greatest donuts on Earth, these confections were heavily laced with hype. Plus, the cleanliness factor in the place makes you keenly aware of the fact that you're doing very bad things to your human organism.

I have no idea what all the fuss is about.  Yes they have some creative doughnuts, however, the line and the homeless problem surrounding this PURE tourist attraction is so sad.  

I came here because it was featured on shows like Anthony Bourdain among others.  The doughnuts are not all that great.  They really are not.  They are good, but not great.  In a blind taste test Krispy Cream would win but it is this nostalgic uniquely Portland experience that needs to be de throned.  

Not worth the long lines.

Meh. The hype doesn't pay off. The snooty staff combined with mediocre donuts shaped like penises....well, I won't ever go out of my way to stand in a long a** line for a donut. Plus, did you really just charge me 27 bucks for a dozen donuts???? They better do more than just taste....ok.
Blue star will come through and the line? Less long.
I've had better donuts before. Waited in line for about 30 mins in the freezing cold and the donuts didn't taste fresh.

overrated and not really worth the wait.   

This place is good to try maybe one donut to tell people that you have gone there while in portland.   

I would not buy a dozen and try to bring it back b/c the donuts are pretty sweet and don't really last all that well on the plain.  

1) Maple Bacon Donut which was more expensive $3 which was probably my favorite 
2) Blueberry donut was okay but i have better! 
3) Cereal Donut was okay but SUPER sweet and the cereal was bland! 
4) Rice Krispie with peanut butter was okay but again too sweet 

Remember, it's CASH only so make sure you bring some dinero!
Pure gimmick for tourists. Visit Blue Star instead.

Terrible. Overhyped. Dry. Three words to describe my experience at Voodoo Doughnut. My chocolate cruller and my friends maple crullers were overcooked, dry and disgusting. My friend also purchased a bacon maple bar which was cooked better and tasted ok. However the bacon was burned. 

Maybe we went on an off night or maybe everyone in this city is just stoned. Perhaps Portland doesn't know what a good doughnut is with all the granola hipsters walking around. If you find yourself in Portland, save yourself the trip. I wish I had.
Over rated. Line is long as hell. Not really worth the long line. Go down the street for better doughnuts. Tourist trap.
Not bad, but not worth the wait. Donuts were not spectacular in taste or quality. Still, a donut is a donut so if it were in front of me, I would enjoy it. Just wouldn't wait for it.

You know the drill.  This is a Portland landmark and I recommend it for first timers.  Once is enough, though, and it's worth checking out the other doughnut spots in town once you're over the kitsch.

Pretty standard donut. More artificial flavored than Blue Star. However, this is Portland and it's pretty much required that you have a Voodoo while you're here. The shop was smaller than I thought it would be and the donut selection was interesting. I'm glad I got to experience it while I was here.
I wouldnt recomend waiting in line but its not bad if you need a sugar fix and i like their albums for sale

These are just doughnuts! Maybe it's so popular because people want to relive their church days of coffee and rolls after Mass? Hmm.  I don't remember the after church doughnuts having a near constant huge line on cement that reeks of urine. I don't remember the after church doughnuts being next to an anime porn theater (Okay, that is a plus for Voodoo). The doughnuts are perfectly fine and yes the maple bacon is pretty dang good. But unless if you're in the mood for a treat to go with your X-Rated anime, perhaps this block really isn't worth the visit. I've tried five or so different doughnuts from there and am always left wondering, is that it? The Fruit Loops one was especially not good. It's not Voodoo's fault they're so popular, but do keep in mind that it's just a doughnut. Enjoy your film!

I like the idea of maple bacon, but I don't like the overpowering maple taste, so I sort of picked off the bacon and ate that.  The bacon was delicious, but the hype really left me feeling disappointed.

The line is ridiculous at this place.  I didn't enjoy the doughnuts that much the first time, but we had to go there again to get some to bring back for our friends and families.  That time we waited in the rain and it was just really shitty.  

The person at the counter on the second day had a bad attitude.  She couldn't pick the doughnuts up or it stuck to the paper and she just threw it really hard against the wall to hit what I assume is the garbage can.  I get that she's under a lot of pressure, but it was frightening.  

I got the Voodoo dozen, which is when they pick the doughnuts for you.  How the hell did I not get a single doughnut I wanted?  That was epic fail.  Thankfully I did enjoy the filled doughnut with cream and chocolate glaze on the outside.   Still, I prefer the texture of Krispy Kream doughnuts.. they're a lot more fluffy and don't taste all doughy.  

Go here at like 2 am, the line isn't as ridiculous, and it will taste better because you're probably going there after a night of drunken debauchery.

Yes they have a great variety ... and yes, it's a great spot for tourists ... but once you use your tongue to experience the donut and not just your eyeballs, it is a bigger let-down than McKayla Maroney on the vault in the 2012 Olympics.

Came on a Saturday around 1pm.  Line was about 20 feet out the door, took about 20 minutes to get inside, so not too bad. 

Cons: cash only, too sweet, donuts were on the hard side as if they'd been out for a day. 

Pros: uh....  ?  

Area:  a few homeless people around the neighborhood.

Bottom line:  overrated.  Got the Voodoo dozen. After picking on and sampling 3 of them, I realized they all started to taste the same - sugary.  Even my kid, who loves all things sweet and donuty,  didn't finish one. We didn't touch six of them and gave the box away the next day. 

Tip:  if ever in Colorado, look up Amy's Donuts in Colorado Springs.  Every donut is $1.  They have 3 times the selection of Voodoo, and they actually taste the way they look.  Donuts were soft, fresh.  Those I could not stop eating and still tasted fresh the next 2 days.

After waiting 15 minutes in the rain, this place was a let down. Maybe it's because it's so hyped up and everyone tells you to go here, but it's not worth the wait. I got the viscous hibiscus donut and was extremely disappointed. The frosting was peeling off the donut and was very very sweet.

This place i must say it's all about the hype. Nothing really special about this donut here. Just the names of the donuts and the shapes.. lol. The reason why I gave this place a 3 stars is because of their bacon maple donuts. Must try it! They make this perfectly! I wish they have more delicious donuts..

The doughnuts are good, but how wrong can you go with freshly fried cake batter?  I was expecting more from a place with such hype.  The shtick is 'clever doughnuts,' which somehow makes it OK for people who wouldn't usually eat doughnuts to do so.  But they weren't that clever.  Don't get me wrong, they taste good, but they are just doughnuts.

Above average line. Below average clientele. Average doughnuts. Waited in queue with what appeared to be the millennial dregs of humanity. I shouldn't have. While waiting in line one can read their vulgar sexist advertisements like "good things come in a pink box". What an ingenious little pun. Wow. Certainly didn't "wet" my appetite. Or their other one "the magic is in the hole."  It's a very short walk from Powell's bookstore, but a very long distance.

Meh. This place is extremely crowded and whenever I have family come over, they always want to visit VooDoo Donuts since it has become such a tourist attraction. The donuts aren't very good.
