I have had them numerous of times and there are much better donut places around Portland. The donuts somehow always taste a little stale to me.

Before you read my review, here is my disclaimer:  my family owns a doughnut shop.  My co-workers suggested that I must go here when I visit Portland.  I listened to the hype and went.  I ordered a blueberry doughnut and a triple chocolate doughnut.  They just tasted like your average doughnut.  I did not find them to be any different than any other place I tried or even my family's place.  In fact, I found the cocoa pops cereal on the triple chocolate doughnut to be soggy.  I felt I was eating an old doughnut.  I will not be a returning customer.

I'm blessed to have gotten a job close to Voodoo, and so the doughnuts often make an appearance in the office kitchen.  I'm not one to turn down food, especially donuts.  So no matter what, those rings of goodness make me happy.  But I must say that the magic/novelty of the Voodoo doughnut has worn off.  I'm not super impressed by the "let's pile 15 kinds of sweets on a doughnut" anymore, and find myself going more the traditional route.  And even those come in at mediocre.  But, hey they're still donuts, so a solid 3 stars.  

Please note, this review does not pertain to the maple bacon bar, which still remains king of the donuts.

Immensely overhyped.
Staff aren't particularly rude but they are disinterested and aloof.
It's basically a tourist trap.

This tourist trap is not worth the wait. I went there once just to try it out in my first year of living here and found their doughnuts to taste no better than a grocery store bakery's. I am too old to find the concept of a "cock and balls" doughnut that amusing unless the flavor is better than its namesake. 

I will give them props for their customer service, however. My partner decided to cheer my teenage sister up by prank calling them and asked for a "fecal doughnut." Suprisingly, the employee didn't hang up but instead calmly explained that no, they don't make fecal doughnuts, but they do have some chocolate coconut doughnut he might like instead.

It's ok...too much TV hype is driving all flock to come here for their donut fix. I thought it was too sweet and some of them in just a gross shape...not appealing and I am not talking about the "D" either. haha. anyways, i went to the location downtown and was semi grossed out by the bakers, front staff etc by the amount of facial hair that WAS NOT covered...ughhhh nasty!!! i wont come back not worth the wait or the $$

What is special about this place are the creative donuts here. There are some coated with cereal, kool-aid, and even bacon. They aren't very fresh, even in the morning so that is a bit disappointing.

The donuts are fun, the quality is mediocre. 

... and I'll probably be hunted down for saying so.
Overrated, doughnuts did not taste fresh at all and the guy taking care of us was very impatient and rude
Always too long of a wait in line to get served but the doughnuts are not all that much to brag about other than the selection of varieties made.

Grocery store doughnuts with cereal ontop.  There is nothing culinary unique or significant about anything here.   7eleven has the same doughnut quality and diversity.   You are just reading this because voodoo is a hype machine.

About the most overrated place I've had food or drinks in a long time. Very pedestrian donuts. Tim Hortons is better and no ridiculous long lines. Great marketing. If you like pink boxes and clever names, fine - but if you are coming for a tasty donut, don't waste your time in line.

I've been hearing about this place for sometime now, I was really looking forward to trying Voodoo Doughnuts. It was a bit of a letdown. The signature Bacon Maple Bar was disappointing. A mediocre maple bar with 2 half strips of dried out bacon on top in the frosting. What's the big deal? The cruller was OK but I've had better. Our lofty expectations weren't met.

Lived in Salem for 14 years always heard how wonderful VUDU donuts was never had the opportunity to try them until recently when I came back to town with completely and utterly disappointed for $40 worth of donuts..... Girl with bright red hair was very rude as to my questions on variety since it was my first time at this time there was no line behind me only one person that I allowed to go in front of me so I didn't keep anyone waiting. once we got our donuts I was trying to make sure we didn't get two that were the same she ended up putting three of the same in there all of the ones with cereal on top where completely stale. I went out and put them in the car came back into use the bathroom and was told I could not use the restroom  unless I made a purchase, once in the restroom it was worse than a septic tank smells atrocious dirty as a sewer.

The experience was very cool as I have never been to Portland before yet alone a Voodoo Doughnuts. To say the least, the experience was joyful. The staff was friendly and nice as I explained I'm a tourist. :) The doughnuts themselves didn't taste very good and they didn't serve coffee.  Outside of the store are a lot of homeless people which sort of kills the experience.

I went to Portland for a weekend with my gfs and we decided to check this place out. I LOOOOVE donuts, so I was excited to try it. After seeing all their crazy, heavy creations, I decided that a plain 'ol chocolate glazed donut is all I need to satisfy my cravings. 

The cashier was also a little bit rude. We ordered 4 donuts to-go and it was raining outside so it was a little shocking that she didn't bag them for us. She picked out the donuts and placed them in front of us, we asked for a bag and she rolled her eyes. Then we asked for napkins and she rolled her eyes again. Am I missing something here? Oh well.

This place is a bit overrated, but it seems to be on a tourist's list, so check it out!

Donuts are nothing to write home about.   It was nothing less than a tourist attraction.  Aside from unusual combinations of ingredients, that's about it. On the unpleasant note, while waiting in line, they had their donuts next to a window (behind a thick wire screen) that looked like a cooling area.  I could have  breathed, cough, spit, all over the freshly baked donuts and some poor soul would never know. How that is not s health code violation is beyond me.

Donuts were okay. In my opinion, over priced for mediocre "fancy" looking donuts. It was definitely a fun experience and worth checking out, but the line was too long for me to ever want to do it again.

Really cool location but my simple, chocolate glazed donut was not good at all which is odd since it's such a common flavor.  I feel like you are paying for the hype and the witty names and odd combo recipe of the donuts.  Not really worth it in my opinion.

noveltynoveltynoveltynoveltynovelty.  

sorry guys, but a good doughnut doesn't need sugary kids breakfast cereal on it to taste good.  oh right, that's the point.  this is portland, etcetc.

whatever, i'm down any time for novelty food, but if that's all you have going for you...

seriously, the popularity of voodoo doughnuts makes me wonder if i could open, say, a crepe shop, and just put crap like tootsie rolls, starburst, jelly beans, and marshmallows (with of course, the token bacon something-or-other crepe) in the crepes and it would be a huge success.  i love you portland, i do.  but sometimes you try too hard.

Overhyped. Overrated.

That is all I have to say.  Came here on a Friday night and it wasn't too crowded.  Remember, buy donuts that look like they will taste good.  Do Not buy donuts that look so dressed up because you will die from diabetes!! Foodies definitely buy food that look cool and will look amazing in a picture but that is all you will get, a cool looking picture with a toothache.  I bought a variety of donuts that look super crazy such as the captain crunch but oh man, once you take a bite into it, you will not want it.  The majority of the donuts that was purchased was just okay.  The plain ones are a lot better such as your glazed and chocolate donuts.  I hear Blue Star is way better but it was closed by the time we got there so we settled on the touristy spot for donuts.  Never coming back here.

Picked up some donuts before heading back to NYC and I have to say that they were just "okay".  Perhaps it was overly hyped with the long line that formed outside but these are nothing to write home about.  They're pretty average in taste/quality but they are pretty cheap so I guess we just broke even.

Also, I tried to pay using pennies (5 to be exact) since I didn't have any nickles and they would't accept it -- pennies still count as money and that was really irritating since I was trying to get rid of the change in my wallet - not add more.

not really sure what the fuss is about- maybe its just the hype that keeps bringing people here. In my opinion it certainly is not the doughnuts. Heavy, overly sweet, and cooked in oil that gave up the ghost a long time ago- where are the light non-oily ones- elsewhere I guess.

Mmmm, dog nuts. I recommend Voodoo Dog Nuts for creativity not for taste. One night in mid-March 2010, I bought one of everything they had. Sadly, they were out of Cock & Balls and Nyquil, but I had everything else they had on the menu. My favorites: After Eight, Maple & Bacon, Cap'n Crunch and Memphis Mafia.

Not all doughnuts were thoroughly cooked. You'd bite into them and some grease and batter would ooze out of little shiny pockets. The doughnuts taste best when they're fresh, but they remain sufficiently edible for a week before they turn into clay pigeons.

None of the doughnuts struck me as The Most Delicious Doughnut I Ever Had. Not even the homeless of Portland wanted them. If the starving won't eat Voodoo Doughnuts, then who will? Tourists... and some diehard local fans of novelty. Keep Portland Weird.

This place is definitely hyped up. I got the homer donut and it was pretty dry. The taste was okay, but not the best I've tasted. The cashier also rushed us on our ordering, which wasn't pleasant. The interior was interesting to look at. They had a lot of posters and other neat things. Overall, the place is definitely worth a try to go to because it is only found in Portland, but for tasty donuts I would not recommend.

On vacation so we had to stop in to try the madness. Waited in line for about 15 minutes which is reasonable considering its popularity. Voodoo is smack dab in the middle of a downtown portion with all walks of life. We had some bar patrons smoking weed to our right, homeless 'performers' to our left, and Police officers to our front as we waited. 

We purchased a classic donut dozen which is picked by staff. Pretty boring selection for a whopping 12 bucks. Donuts tasted fine but can find a much more colorful selection elsewhere for 4-6 bucks less. 

We bought a sprinkle and maple bacon donut which were good. Overall it's what you expect, they taste like donuts.

Dirty place where the gutter punks hang.  Kind of dangerous late at night.  Their donuts are mediocre although creative.  I'd give this place a higher rating if there was no line, but sadly, it has become so popular it is rare to not see a line.  I'll take a maple bar from Safeway, thanks.

Thee most over-rated bakery in the history of bakeries. Have some stoned12 year old boy name a few doughnuts, shape one like a penis , and Presto ! You have a very average tasting doughnut , shaped like a penis. How very original... I won't mention the cartoonishly sized bathroom key that has made infinite visits to the bathroom floor, and gets passed around the same area that the food is.

**CASH ONLY!!"**

I found voodoo to be over hyped, the line is always so long as people are still deciding what to get after they get to the front. Our cashier wasn't very attentive she kept dancing with the music and we had to repeat our choices multiple times.

If you have a sweet tooth this is great choice they have a wide range of selections. If you don't like it to sweet and want a place that doesn't have lines up that are as long go to Blue Star  - highly recommend.
It's just ok. If you're a tourist, I guess it's a must to say you've been there. Not particularly clean inside. Better doughnuts all around the city.

EXPENSIVE DONUTS.  I believe in paying for quality, especially with food, but that's pushing it. I'm an out of towner, and I kind of got the tourist trap vibe.   $5 for two moderately tasty donuts is ridiculous.  One maple bacon and one custard filled.  Seriously, voo-doo?  Let me guess, they must have been organic, free range, farm to table donuts.  I've gotten tastier donuts in the 'hood for half that price.  To top it off, the donuts were "aight."  If I go back, it won't be my $5 bill sliding to the register.  One and done, Voo-Doo.

One of the places you have to try when you're visiting Portland just because of the hype and popularity of the doughnuts for their colorful and crazy designs/combos. The actual donuts are very sweet and after a few bites, I couldn't continue and had to save the remainder for later. 

To avoid the long lines, come later in the evening. They also have multiple location in Portland and one at the airport. If you are looking for an alternative place, recommend Blue Star for their blueberry doughnuts.

For sheer fun factor, Voodoo deserves the highest marks.  Featured on nearly every episode of every travel show ever to hit Portland, Voodoo serves up good donuts with a heaping helping of pink-boxed whimsy.

Between the two of us, we ordered 6 donuts to sample...gluttonous, I know!  We placed our pink box on the picnic table outside and got to tasting.  On the whole, I found the decorations killer but the taste largely average.  My one exception was the Bacon Maple Bar, which was bomb ass fantastic!  Our favorites for taking classy vacation photos were the Voodoo Doll and the Maple Blazer Blunt.  The prices were pretty reasonable...at least compared to other gourmet donut shops like the Doughnut Plant in NYC. 

PARTING THOUGHT: The line tends to stretch during normal times, so try to hit up Voodoo on the early or late side.  I believe it is open 24 hours, so this is pretty easy to do unless you require 10 hours of beauty sleep a night.

This place was very interesting. I don't know how to feel about it still, but a doughnut is a doughnut. The service was actually very good. The person behind the counter got us our doughnuts and even let us choose a few (they don't usually let people choose). So that was nice.

The doughnuts were just okay, though.

Every time I get a doughnut here it's dried up, they are always out of coffee and you have to step over homeless and meth people to get to the front door.  This place is definitely only for tourists and after the bar.  Nothing but hype.
This is a touristy spot that most people who are not from Portland, however it isn't the best place to get donuts in PDX.

It's not about the donut here.

It's about waiting in line because of the hype, seeing all the crazy decor in the shop...and telling everyone that yes, you went to voodoo doughnuts on your trip to portland.  Becaaaauuse, the actually donuts are not that good.

Expect interesting flavors and combinations, funny and kitchy names, unenthused cashiers and a line out the door.

Lemon chiffon crueller- dry and blah
Dirty old bastard- HUGE chocolate peanut butter concoction with oreos all over.  Yup, it's calorie laden but when in Rome.... The dough is dry and the oreos on top are a little stale.  This is definitely more of a quantity over quality place.

So here's the tip- not worth the calories or the time.  Just skip it and make your way over to Blue Star donuts instead.  

I will say, there are a couple of pros: (1) stumptown coffee and (2) they don't overcharge for the donuts-- prices are still cheap at $1.50 for the crueller and some of the more plain ones at less than $1.
A tad overrated in my opinion, Blue Star donuts taste better, and it is a little rediculous that in 2014 they don't accept credit cards!
Great atmosphere, great concept...so so donuts.  Its worth going to if you are from out of town, but if I lived in Portland, there has to be better donuts.
Average donut place. Don't really understand the hype except for the colorful toppings the taste is like any other decent donut joint!

While here for work I figured I would check this place out. I was overwhelmed by the small interior. Lots of options but I felt like the staff wanted to push people in about so I didn't get to ask them for recommendations. 

I had the Portland Cream and an Oreo doughnut. They were okay. The Portland cream was like any cream doughnut that you could find anywhere. The Oreo one was better and the doughnut itself was tasty. It couldn't even finish the frosting. 

I'm not sure I get the hype but it was cool to visit while in town.

If you are into healthy foods don't come here.  Creativity and sugar are the main sales points.  The actual donuts are just average, but if you have a sweets or donut craving the variety of unusual toppings and taste combos is outstanding.  Bought a dozen for a group of 5 for the weekend.  Could not eat it all, way too much sugar for one weekend!
I agree with other comments on the lines and the pressure to make up your mind with so many choices.  But that should tell you Voodoo Doughnuts has its fans.
For me, it is fine for the occasional novelty treat.

This place always has a line outside, but dont let the lines scare you, they are fast moving. We went there on a Saturday night. Good thing is, its open 24/7. When we had our turn, the server at the counter was too rude. The bad part here is, there are lots of donuts on display, but none of them is attached to a name. Being a first timer, I asked her a couple of questions and she assumed that I wanted those donuts and since she placed them on the counter for me, they cant be returned! I thought it was a little ridiculous. Despite of great donuts, the service is really poor.

Although, the donuts were really good. The place is different. Must try out if in Portland.

So I finally had the opportunity to try some Voodoo donuts during a recent trip to Portland. I was extremely impressed by the offerings... where else can you find bacon-topped donuts? Not to mention a whole vegan section of donuts. Uber cool. I think it's something everyone visiting Portland should try at least once. While it was a fun experience, the donuts I tried were a bit blah. I was much more impressed by the ambience of the place and the creativity of the offerings than the actual donuts themselves. I really wanted to like them but doubtful I'd eat them again.
Just good, nothing that I would write home about! The sign was the best thing there for me. And my girlfriend of course! xo

The bacon maple doughnut does taste like breakfast but I have got to say that the cash only thing, the neighborhood it is in and the utter lack of seating did kind of put me off.  The customer service was decent though and the doughnuts of course were great, who doesn't love fried dough covered in sugary toppings?!

Good things come in pink boxes.... or not. I've been three times, and still don't get the hype. I guess their success shows you what good marketing, a unique business concept, and LOTS of coverage from the Food Network will get you.

I've had better doughnuts at chain store.

I want to give them another star. I really do... but... I... just... can't. 

They're fun. They're creative. The staff are sweet, smiling folks who seem to have a great time at work. People enjoy these oh, so zaaaany donuts, with the quirky name and cute Voo Doo Oooooh! image, but covering an average-tasting doughnut with way too much glaze and sugar, or Froot Loops®, or Cocoa Puffs, or making it in the shape of the male genitalia (or boobs, for that matter) doesn't make it good food: 

It just makes it a gimmick. 

They get a half-star each for the individual categories of: fun, hip, edgy, adorable. 

They get minus-three stars, however, for nothing-special flavor, just 'meh' texture, overuse of sugary glaze (there is such a thing as too much, even on a doughnut) when we're talking about "food." Donuts aren't car dashboard decorations (though these could do the job). They're still food. Dessert food. Why can't they be car dashboard decorations =AND= be over-the-top delicious? They are better than, say, the abomination of Krispy Kreme, or Dunkin', or even Annie's, but not nearly as good as, say, Blue Star or Pip's. I've heard Helen Bernhard is good, but I've not tried them yet. 

I would love to see Voo Doo "doo" more in the way of gourmet flavor and texture with their dough and toppings. But it probably isn't what they were going for. They're great for what they are. I'd rather look at them, or make a mobile out of them, than eat them. 

Not hating: just stating. Thanks for reading. :)

What can I say??  I am weak...I fell for the hype and waited almost an hour in line for some average tasting donuts.  I gave it two stars for the mango tango donut just cause it was different and I had never tried a mango flavored donut .  I even took some home for the fam to try and they didn't get it either.  Lesson learned-stop being a sucka!!

tried the voodoo doughnut, the triple chocolate penetration, and the maple bacon bar. the voodoo doughnut is essentially a chocolate covered raspberry jelly doughnut. the maple bacon bar is just a maple bar with cold cooked bacon on top - good because it's a maple bar, but i think the bacon could've been incorporated better to achieve salty sweet perfection. the triple chocolate penetration was a chocolate cake doughnut with chocolate icing and cocoa puffs. the most interesting addition to a regular doughnut that we tried - probably didn't need the chocolate icing along with the cocoa puffs - chocolate overload. maybe better with a regular glaze.

anyway... this place's popularity is unexplainable and if you've never been here, you need to try it once. probably wouldn't come here on a regular basis though.

VooDoo carries some of the best doughnuts around. But unfortunately, their employees are incredibly rude and snotty. They had this pretentious  "we're too cool" attitude. I visited Portland for a couple weeks for a national tournament and everyone from the tournament who went said the same thing. Great doughnuts, but shitty people.
A donut is a donut. I don't understand the long lines for funny shape or a colorful frosting. It's a donut. It still just tastes like a donut.

The only difference between a Dunkin' Donut and a Voodoo Doughnut is that one has stale cereal on top and the other doesn't. This needs to be said. 

Crap coffee, crap doughnuts and even crappier employees who are snotty, rude and would be better off working at McDonalds. It's just a lame gimmick with no real quality, feeling or love for the art of the donut. 

Seriously, stop giving these twats your money.
So overrated hype.  Stale donuts dipped in frosting and cereal.  How do you spot a tourist in Portland?  They are carrying a pink Voodoo donut box.
Its a doughnut place. There's nothing truly special about the actual taste of the donuts, certainly not worth waiting in line for them.  Yes, they are kind of fun, but really, just average doughnuts.

I guess that if you are a tourist in Portland you may be required to visit this place. Don't get me wrong, the doughnuts are good but they're not exactly "voodoo" doughnuts, so, unless you are in the area you can skip the place, you won't miss out on anything.

Like i said, the doughnuts are good but in the average - average+ range. They do have some crazy creations and designs if you are into that... but even those are regular tasting.

If I may have a suggestion it is this: early in the morning, grab you doughnuts to go, walk south a block, grab a coffee from Stumptown roasters, then 2 more blocks to the south grab breakfast at Mother's Bistro and Bar. That right there should pretty much take care of eating for the day. :)

Really a fun place to visit once.  There was a line to get doughnuts.  There was no place to sit inside.  The neighborhood was sketchy.  Once we got inside to the counter, we were back out again within 30 seconds.  Not much of "an experience".

The vegan doughnut was great.  But I can't see any reason to go back.  It wasn't like you could sit down, have a cup of coffee, and enjoy the doughnut.  We ate our doughnuts outside in the blowing wind and enjoyed the company of street people arguing with invisible persons.

The two best things:  yummy VEGAN doughnut selection and the name.  VOODOO DOUGHNUTS.  Isn't that great?  Isn't that creative?

Voodoo doughnuts are the equivalent of one step above Safeway grocery store doughnuts, only being marked up in price due to voodoo doughnuts unique (not unique any more because everyone is following their footsteps) designs and flavor combinations. Even if I were a tourist, I don't think the constantly long line is worth it.

The service is ok. The donuts are ok. I enjoyed the experience though. We waited 45 minutes and got 1 dozen donuts. I wouldn't wait in that line ever again. I would say go if you're in Portland for sure. I like Krispy Kreme donuts though so if you like dunkin donuts i'm sure you will like these but they have more character, way more! THEY ONLY TAKE CASH!
Variety of choices. Taste of donut is okay. Sweet toppings and bready donut but nothing spectacular. Cool visit. Long line to grab donuts

Came here around 8 pm on a Friday night, line was quick, maybe 10 minutes or so. We ordered  4 Doughnuts, of which one was called Old Dirty Bastard... HAHA.. Loved the name.-;) Customer service was great with Aaron who rang our order up, and I am sure for the 1 million  time had to explain what they all were. However he was FUN and super good looking.. -;)  Do you all have a Doughnut named "Eye Candy" ? 
So all in all in and out in less then 15 minutes with 4 doughnuts and  then ate them on Saturday night cold.. My best Favorite one was the Chocolate Vegan one!!

I went in knowing that the quality of Voodoo wasn't going to be the best, but that I was visiting mainly for the experience of crossing my visit off my Portland bucket list. I was also intrigued by their unique and creative flavors. Yes, you will have to wait in line, but it's all part of it. they have a menu of their top flavors outside on display- however, they don't list what is in/on the donuts. We ordered the voodoo doll (chocolate frosted voodoo man with jelly filling), triple chocolate (chocolate donut topped with chocolate frosting and cocoa puffs, a frosted donut with fruit loops and the "dirty old bastard" (chocolate frosting with oreos and peanut butter). The cereal toppings tasted stale which was unpleasant. My favorite was the triple chocolate. Wash it down with some Stuptown down the street!

the pedal bike tours office was right by voodoo, so once our ride was over, and we were dropped off, we came by to grab some donuts.  the line was the shortest i had seen all wk, and it went by fast.  if it wasn't for the funky flavor combos, i wouldn't have even come here, since i'm not a big donut eater.  i tried the ODB donut, which was tasty but definitely not worth waiting in line for.
Good but Blue Star is better. Probably more hype here than a great donut.

I didn't wait at all, as I went late on a weekday.  And, the staff was friendly and helpful.  The problem is that each of the many donuts I and my friends tried was mediocre.  They get an A for effort but a B- for execution.  Sorry Portland.
They are decent, but I think they are a little overrated.  It's a decent doughnut place, but not great.  I like their maple bacon doughnut, though!
Good the first two or three times you visit, but after a while it's just another doughnut shop? Good for tourists.

Everyone said "You have to get voodoo doughnuts" So I did. I got there around 10 am on a Saturday and didn't have to wait in the atrocious line. They have a variety of specialty doughnuts with fun names. I got the Cranky Old Bastard - it was humongous. Around the size of my face and very filling. If you haven't been to a doughnut shop that does a variety of flavors, might as well check it out. But if the line was any more than 20 min... nah.

On a Sunday morning, I felt fortunate to only have to wait a half hour to get to the front of the line.  I'm not a big donut eater, but let's be real, this is quintessential Portland. I like the art inside, it's really creative and unique, let's put it that way. Anyway, ontot he donuts. We got a bacon maple bar, apple fritter, old fashioned with glaze, and an orangutan, which had vanilla frosting, tang, and orange sprinkles. We split all four. I have to admit eating those donuts just made me smile. The bacon maple was by far my favorite. The old fashioned was just ok. I liked the apple fritter since it had nice big chunks of green apple and plenty of cinnamon. But I wish they had a simple raised donut with granulated sugar; that is by far my favorite kind of donut. Or even cinnamon sugar.

I think the place is just overrated. I went over there because my co-workers recommended it. I tried the oreo something something donut and it was just ok. We also tried different donuts and I found nothing exciting about them. It is quite expensive and the employees look like a bunch of hippies working in a place that, again, is quite overrated. They act like big stars and maybe think that the rest of the mortals (the ones in line) do not deserve them. Maybe donuts is not my thing and I don't even know why I am wasting my time reviewing this place. Not planning to come back in the near future.
Overrated donuts. I always go simple, Bacon Maple.  Most donuts are too sweet for me. Love the toasted coconut too

I'm not sure how to approach a review of Voodoo. Their donuts are just fine. You can get the same donut basically at any other place for 1/3 of the price. I suppose it's what you do when you come to Portland. Certianly interesting people watching and of course the status of a pink box. I guess a few of the donuts are memorable but it's really a tourist trap. I can think of 5 donut places in town with better donuts and less time waste to stand in line with annoying selfie taking humans. Go if you want to say you went but don't expect a great donut.

I tried Voodoo Doughnuts because every time we visit Portland, we have excited questions like "Did you try it? Did you try it?" Now I can say I did. My triple chocolate treat was tasty, and I thought the staff was very friendly and cool. So yeah, I've tried it. My hubby tried the maple bacon treat and thought it was tasty. We have fulfilled our mission.

Possibly the most overrated stop in Portland. 

Donuts are NOT fresh. Overly sweet. Strong, not always complimentary toppings. Do your research, Portland has far better bakeries to offer. Ahem. Blue star.

Gosh, I feel horrid being one of a few bad reviews...but really 2 stars is all I can manage.
The donuts are fantastic, this is true...but after seeing where they are prepared I don't know that I could ever go back.  Now don't get me wrong, I frequent food carts and dingy taco stands...but Voodoo is dirty in a whole other shade yet unsurpassed.  I have no idea how they pass city code and inspections.
The service was exactly what i have come to expect at many trendy Portland stores...the "I'm soooo cool i don't have to be friendly or polite" attitude abounds.  Really is it too much to ask for a smile or a thank you for shopping here and helping me be employed?

Sorry Voodoo, I know my review won't hurt your business, but it has to be said.

Edited:  Star added for donut purchased at coffee shop (from voodoo), it was fantastic.

Now that i finally have a yelp account I can tell the world what i really think about voodoo doughnuts.  In a word OVERRATED.   I seriously do not understand the country wide love affair with this place.  I've eaten here several times and haven't been impressed with the quality.  The douhnuts taste very dense and on several occasions have been stale.  Just because it's a doughnut shaped like a penis doesn't mean that it's worth waiting 45 minutes for.

Voodoo Doughnuts is an incredibly popular place to visit when you're in Portland. They have several locations throughout Oregon as well as a few others around the US. Given that we've visited their stores in LA and Denver, it was time to visit their original location. 

Voodoo Doughnuts is located in the heart of downtown Portland, Oregon. Parking is available on the streets, local parking garages, or in pay for the day lots. You'll notice a line outside of the store with pink metal barriers set up to guide people inside. It's a small shop so only a small number of people can be inside at one time. Also, the entrance and exit doors are adjacent to each other and so people often experience difficulties when trying to leave the store. The exit is usually blocked by people who are standing in line and employees are not that great at keeping that doorway clear.

When we made our way inside, we saw all of the familiar items on the menu. They were all visually appealing with all kinds of creative toppings and ingredients. I love how this location has a bit more than their LA shop because you could see the full range of what they really have.

When it was time to order, I honed In on my favorite doughnut, bubblegum! The sprinkles taste just like bubblegum and it comes with a piece of gum placed in the center of the doughnut. Now Voodoo is famous for their C&B doughnut that is shaped like the lower region of the male anatomy. Being an elementary school teacher, I will not state the actual name of  the doughnut but the abbreviation should give you a big hint as to what it's actually called.

Anyway, as my husband placed his order for two C&B doughnuts, they told us that they ran out of them. They said that they only had the vegan  version of this dessert. So when they went to get the doughnuts from the back, they came back and said that they only have one vegan C&B left. Since we wanted two C&B doughnuts, they said that they could sell us the other one that was revolving around in the glass display case. I asked if it was fresh and they said, "Not really, but we'll give it to you for free." We  were cool with that because we ended up with one vegan doughnut and the other one that had been on display for a bit. I can't attest for how the C&B tasted because we picked them up for family members who live in the area.

In general, I absolutely love the creativity behind this establishment. They are definitely ahead of the game when it comes to marketing. Their line always stretches out the door and it's because of customer loyalty and the novelty of this place. I think that we will check out Voodoo Too next time that we are in town.
Gross, a donut with stale cereal???  So damn sweet, you don't taste anything but sugar and artificial crap.  Everyone's in love with the concept.

Not impressed.  Not that it matters :)

If I ever get the urge to go to voodoo again I'll just go to the grocery store and buy some captain crunch, mix it with cake frosting, and call it something wacky and slightly pervy, like sweet ball sacks. It'll be the same thing.

They've got a lot of varieties of doughnuts but I feel like the main attraction of a doughnut place should be the doughnuts themselves, and they tasted average, kind of like the variety you'd get at a supermarket.  The lines are super long too.  Blue Star is a far superior quality doughnut!

I'll admit it.  I was a sucker for the Maple Bacon Bar hype.  Shit, I don't even LIKE maple bars, but the bacon made me want to try.

So, on an overnight visit we wandered past about midnight on a Saturday.  Holy bejeezus!  The line was a block long and not moving.  We went into Dante's intead.

Next morning I told my man we had to try again.  The line didn't look so bad.  He waited in the car while I joined the queue.  Holy bejeezus! The line is STILL not moving.  Seriously, I thought it would be 15, maybe 20 minutes max.  Nope. 1 hour, folks.  1 hour.  AND on top of that, once I got into the rabbit hole-sized store I noticed it was CASH ONLY.  Thank GOD I got that $20 out to play video poker the night before.  AND, if I hadn't had cash, I couldn't call my man waiting in the nice warm car because my phone died a half hour earlier!!  ON TOP OF ALL THIS the gal at the counter announces -- 3 people ahead of me -- that THEY ARE OUT OF MAPLE BACON BARS.  o.m.g. It's the only reason I came here.  But I wasn't about to have wasted an hour.

Even though there's something like 60 different donuts to choose from, I had NO idea what any of them were besides the aforementioned Bacon Maple Bar.  They all had crazy imaginative names, but no description anywhere of what they were made of.  Sure, there was a rotating case of the selections, but no signs on the rotating sweet doughs to let me know what I was looking at.  Grrr.  Lest I hold up the already anxious line, I decided to just start throwing out donut names to the oh-so-helpful-and-happy-to-be-of-service gal (not).  I ended up with an Old Dirty Bastard, Captain My Captain, and Grape Ape. Finally. Donuts were in hand and a cheer erupted from the line as I exited the rabbit hole.

I gotta say though. The donuts were pretty tasty. Nice doughy chew. Sweet, but come on, it's a cake covered in stuff like Oreos, Cap'n Crunch, Peanut Butter, and grape sugar. Expect sweet, people!

Bottom line. I'd never wait in line for an hour ever again. Ever. If anything I'd go check out the other location and hope it's run a bit more efficient.  Then maybe, just maybe, I'll get my lips around that frackin' Maple Bacon Bar.

I actually didn't like the donuts. However, I didn't eat them fresh on the spot, which I'm sure makes a difference. It's a little hard to do though, when you've got a dozen and you're standing in a small room crowded with people. I went for the experience, but I wouldn't go back on my own.
The place does not seem very clean.  The people who take care of you are wearing cut off t-shirts, no gloves, long hair not covered.  I was really turned off

I mean, what can I say? Donuts are donuts. The unique names, flavors and vegan options are what set this spot apart from others. Most definitely worth the wait in line, especially if you're in town visiting.

My only complaint (and it's a minor one): no gluten free options.

the place is dank, small, loud and its filled with a lot people with even more attitude. Its also filled with doughnuts. Wacked out, sugary, vegan, cereal covered doughnuts. They're real good.  If it wasn't 1 am and I hadn't just had kamikaze shots, I'm not sure I'd be able to handle the place. None the less, my favorite is the voodoo man and their is also a gigantic glazed that awesome to share. They're only open at night - something like 10 pm - but now they sell to some local coffee shops and they even deliver so you can get your fix in the morning too.

My girlfriend and I happened to be visiting Portland and spotted this donut store with a huge line up outside. At first, when I saw the banner outside and peeked at the inside of the store, it looked to me rather unappealing. But my girlfriend (being a fan of food shows on TV) suddenly remembered having seen this place featured on TV as a must try, so we decided to give it a try.

For the amount of time on the lineup and all the fuss people seemed to be doing about this place, I was expecting to try the best doughnut I have ever had in my whole life. When we finally reached the inside of the store (which can probably fit no more than 12 people at best at a time), we were greeted by a menu that listed funny names of their doughnuts, but absolutely no description of what each of them is - as if we were expected to know what a "dirty bastard" doughnut or contains. 

The service was not a strong point of this shop. The staff at the counter was not extremely helpful. The guy at the counter had an indifferent business-as-usual like attitude towards us, and he provided little to no answer to our questions. We ended up getting the voodoo doll (human shaped donut topped with chocolate and filled with strawberry jam), a donut topped with Oreo and peanut butter, and a glazed donut with sprinkles on top.

The donuts were big in size and visually interesting, but the taste and quality of the product was about average. We found them comparable to donuts available at any Safeway or Tim Hortons: Acceptable, but far from memorable.

Voodoo donuts might be an iconic shop in Portland, but certainly one that is enough visiting once in a lifetime for the sake of telling "I've been there".

I have been there twice.  Once after a date on my birthday and another time after a concert with my nieces.  My date loved the place. He loves the oreo cookie donut.  My donut was way to sugary.  I think I have had better donuts but it is such a Portland staple.  Waiting in line was the best.  There was such a quirkly group of folks waiting in line with us.

The experience was a bit odd, but worth going to. The doughnuts were good but they tasted so bad after 12 hrs after being out of the shop. I don't suggest getting more than you can eat within the next 2 hours. There are also too many flavors and they are not described, how am I supposed to know what I'm getting! The people were also a bit wierd, like entering a tattoo and piercing shop. It's only about the experience not about the doughnuts. The doughnuts are not comparable to a Krispy Kreme... Although I might be doughnut spoiled.

Would we stand in line for 40 minutes in the rain again for a voodoo donut? Probably not. The donuts are good, and it's fun to try the different combinations, but we can go to the grocery store and buy a chocolate donut to put fruit loops on. :)
Meh donuts. Overpriced and hyped. Go find a smaller less busy, less tourist filled donut shop. Really not worth the wait.

One of those over hyped touristy places that everyone should go to once but really isn't more than a small shop with stale donuts topped with cereal. If you want real donuts try Pips Original or Bluestar. At least those are fresh, shorter lines, take payments other than cash, and have a more memorable taste.

I think a lot of people confuse quality with uniqueness.  This place is definitely unique.  Its got so much character it doesn't know what to do with all of it.  Case-in-point, their maple bar which has bacon on it.  Their Maple Bar alone is what earned them a 3rd star.  If it had been based on taste alone, I would've given them only 2 stars.  I agree with others' reviews that say that their doughnuts are too sugary.  Some may argue that this is what they're going for, but that doesn't take any talent.  I can dump sugar and candy and frosting on a fried piece of dough, but it doesn't make for a 5-star doughnut.  The Maple Bar was pretty awesome to take pictures with, but again it tasted like a more sugary version of your average grocery store bought maple doughnut with a piece of old bacon on top.  So again, unique but not quality.  Great for tourists but not for regulars.  Sorry to all you loyal customers, just trying to be honest.

i guess i have to be the bad guy and say that voodoo is NOT all that. my very first voodoo experience was in the form of the voodoo doughnut itself.   the namesake was given to me as a gift complete with my nemesis initial chicken-scratched on top. (an extra BUCK, mind you!) 

since then i have made the effort to return and try of course the famed bacon maple bar. i also got some other goodies, but funny nothing was so great about any of these doughnuts. i just don't get it. there was nothing spectacular about these doughnuts besides the fact that they are funky creative (hence the two stars, vs. one) but seriously, i've had doughnuts at smaller shops that are wayyy better. the doughnuts didn't melt in your mouth like some i've had. it almost tasted stale to be quite honest. 
it's funny how people get all excited over something that is remotely 'different.' maybe i'll start a new craze...rice with peanut butter or something...it'll be the next best thing. AND, i'll hand draw a stick figure on it for FREE.

shocked. Shocked!!!

hate giving negative reviews but jeez louise - VD has huge, sloppy donuts that I wish were tasteless. Instead, they were just bad.

I used to think bacon - like vicodin - makes everything tasty. Wrong!!!

Boyfriend got some lavender purple monstrosity that tasted like one big mushy bastard cousin to the sweet tart. and we like sweet tarts.

Besides the Waste of Bacon, I also got a plain old cruller. How do you mess up a cruller???? That's a basic!! Its like effing up a stick figure!!

And despite the gross taste (boyfriend who NEVER throws out food, tossed his pastry out after 2 bites), the donuts look like whoever baked it, didn't give a shit about what it looked like. God, I dont need my doughnut to look like a Cranium clay project, but come on, care a little and make it look like, I dunno, a doughnut

And the place is dirty. 

Its irritating because they have a good concept and good PR and I wanted to buy their sweatshirt because, frankly, it looked cool. But I just can't support an establishment that vomits on effort. If I wanted to support sub-mediocrity, I'd watch an episode of the Kardashians.
Cool variety of doughnuts, but I've had tastier.

Save yourself the wait!  The donuts are worse than the ones you buy at a grocery store. We waited about 45 minutes and bought a variety of donuts to try. We thought the toppings were interesting, but most were cereals (eg. Captain Crunch, Rice Krispies, etc). The maple bar with bacon-well the bacon was good but the maple bar donut was not good. This is a tourist trap. From talking to the people waiting it was mostly out of town folks.

The queue was around the block, but they lay on entertainment.  This place is located at one end of the CBD, just past the famous Portland Grill.  It is a relatively seedy area, but I like that.  Reminded me a bit of the unfortunately no more inner lanes of Christhchurch, New Zealand.

I picked up 3 cakes. French cruller (meh ... almost euuw).  A Voodoo doll, had to really; and an almost plain by comparison to its peers lemon item.  They were not half bad.  :)

I'll begin this by saying that I don't eat donuts.   However, many of my staff do, so I frequent this place often.

The fact that it's in an area widely considered Portland's a---; uh - 'armpit' is more than a bit off-putting.  If you can get past the legions of homeless and druggies which frequent this part of town, you'll find this an oasis-of-sorts for sugary treats.

Warning:   If you get there anytime later than opening time on a weekend, or anytime during tourist-season, count on a L-O-N-G line.   You'll be like water-buffalo on the Serengeti; easy targets for panhandlers.   Mainly, they'll take 'no' for an answer.   Sometimes not.   That's why you're glad Portland has bicycle-cops cruising the area.

Inside, another disappointment - they don't take plastic, of any sort.  They are probably the last eatery in Portland not to do so (even the food-carts which have sprung up all over Portland like mushrooms after a fall rain take credit cards), so please be prepared with plenty of cash - another disquieting thing, because the ne'er-do-wells in this area likely know that, also.

You'll be greeted by someone who wants your order, now, and who wants to sell you trinkets - t-shirts and other baubles as 'souvenirs of your visit to Voodoo' - it turns out that the management actually assigns a sales quota to the counter-staff, and if they don't meet it, there are dozens of applications from recent college grads looking to pay down their student-loans.  Don't expect conversation from these folks - just a 'get to it and get out' attitude.

That said, everyone I know says the donuts are good - so; hey.....

This is a tourist trap. I came at 1 am on Monday and there was a 5 min line!

Some of their flavors are good. However, for good doughnuts try blue star

We have heard so much about this place and everyone raves about it. It's a normal doughnut. No different then anything else. We came from seattle to get some and we could have just went to our normal bakery.

I feel as if this place is a little over hyped. Most people say that they love this place but I would say that it's okay. The donuts here are definitely unique though. There are tons of different types of donuts to choose from. I'm not really a big fan of donuts but the captain crunch was pretty good.

Whenever I am driving past and see a line of 50+ tourists wrapped around the building....I laugh and laugh.

Why the laughter?

1. These doughnuts are on par taste-wise with any doughnut I have ever tasted in an Albertsons or 7-11

2. There is another Voodoo location that is a 10 min drive away with no line!

3. 2 minutes on Google will direct you to much better doughnut shops within a 3 mile radius. 

4. They haven't done anything new or interesting since I have lived in Portland (10+ years now). Oh you put cereal on a doughnut......how interesting (sarcasm). Cereal on a glazed doughnut tastes a lot like....cereal on a glazed doughnut.

The long wait is not worth the pink box you will have to balance on your lap for the entire length of your flight home. 

Go to your local grocery store, buy a doughnut and smash some cookies on top. Voila, Voodoo in your own home.
Still a fun experience even if it's a little tired.  Not worth the line if you're a local but good for taking out of town guests.

Meh.

I'm glad I can finally say I've been here and I got some good pictures. However, I really don't think this place is any better than any other crazy donut places I've been to before.  Overly sweet Donuts with Fruit Loops, Fruity Pebbles, Bacon, Coco Puffs, Oreos? I've seen that all before. I will say that the bacon maple donut was pretty tasty because it neutralized the sweetness and the bacon was thick and crispy, but I don't think id wait in line for it. I'm sure a lot of donut places have copied the concept, but the only thing that really sets Voodoo apart is the cute/funky decor.
It's a donut.  Why would anybody wait in line for a donut?  Sure, it's a good donut, but not the best in town and definitely not worth waiting for.

One of the so called major attractions to do and see in Portland is Voodoo Doughnut.
I got a dozen doughnuts to bring to a party we were going to.
The doughnuts are extremely tasty and reasonably priced.
The biggest negative is this Voodoo Doughnuts is so busy that it is almost not worth going.
My daughter and I got there and the line was about 50-60 people deep.
I left my daughter on line and went to get car that was about 3/4 of a mile away.
By the time I got back and parked it was about 30 minutes later and she was just coming up to the door.
Once we got into the store it took like 15 minutes to get to the counter.
Doughnuts are extremely delicious and unusual.
I would of given it 4 stars if I did not have too wait so long to get a doughnut?????

Honestly this place is amazing! Amazing for what? Pictures! That's about it. Just taking pictures, otherwise there is 1000 places that are so much better than voodoo! I mean seriously! I live in Portland and people visit here and this is the first place they go! But this is not really Portland food like I KNOW FOOD!!!! I live in Portland for gosh sakes! You want ideas on where to go for doughnuts umm try Pips Original, Blue Star, 180 which is Churros, or just google it!

Sorry guys... I'm not the biggest fan of this place...at all. The only thing this place has going for it is it's massive variety of donuts, but besides that I really, really, don't like this place. I can eat at the dingiest places, food carts, backyard restaurants, garages, basically anywhere, but I just find this place so dodgy feeling. I don't think they ever mop or wipe down tables. I didn't experience too bad of customer service, but it definitely could've been friendlier. My biggest complaint though has to be the overrated hype about the taste of the donuts here! We had a total of 6 or so donuts and each one had the same french-bread like consistency, some I swear they just slapped some sugared frosting on a loaf of stale...bread and called it a donut! Oh yeah, I hate beggars in shops.

Be careful your elbows might stick to the table and you'll never be able to leave this place!
A doughnut is a doughnut. Is a little convoluted inside, especially late a night.

Do you love waiting in line?
Do you love fads that have lasted too long? 
Do you love watching crackheads eat your leftovers?
Do you hate quality donuts?
If you can say yes to any of these things then Voodoo is for you!

Old Dirty Bastard and Voodoo Doll doughnuts were good. The quality of taste is not any better than donuts from a grocery store or an independent doughnut shop. 

Being there was more for the Portland experience as a visitor and for the creative decorations and combinations of ingredients on and inside the doughnuts.

Come for the atmosphere, but get your donuts somewhere else.  While Voodoo earns some props for allegedly inventing the maple-bacon donut, there are any number of mom-and-pop donut shops who make better donuts for better prices.  Must-have advice:  steer clear of the cereal-studded donuts (unless you like your Cap'n Crunch soggy)

I was in Portland for one of my girlfriends bachlorette weekend getaway.
We decided to check it out since we were here anyways, why not? 
The line wasn't as long as we imagined but keep in mind that we were there at 2am. The line was moving pretty fast so whatever.

The music was BLASTING when we got there.

I give it 3 stars only because the doughnuts weren't that impressive.
There was so much to choose from but I chose "Miami Vice," SUPER SWEET! But that's how I like my doughnuts.

I tried the maple bacon bar but I think I could've done waaaaay better. the bacon was burnt & the doughtnut itself was dry.

But like said people go there for doughnuts you can't find anywhere else.
NOVELTY =]

If you are into hype and sugar overload, this is your place!!
A half hour wait, in a long but friendly line, resulted in an opportunity to choose from a vast selection of decadent donuts. 
I got the bacon  maple  bar. Delicious!
Would I do it again?  Been there, done that!
I know that voodoo is a Portland thing , but it's so very kitschy.  I like sesame waaaay better honestly. It's just an over glorified sugary doughnut.

The doughnuts are decent enough and some are quite creative and "fun", but they're really not worth lining up around the block for. If this is the best Portland can do as a tourist trap, then I would advise against tourists coming here.
The donuts are more fun than tasty.  It's really the experience you go for.

The donuts are good. But they are way, way over priced. And depeding on which Voodoo store you visit in the Portland area, you may end up standing in line for donuts that are too expensive, and taste average.
The donuts really do suck here.  There service is bad.  Do yourself a favor and pass.  The donuts were no fresh and I think they microwave their coffee
Overpriced Hipster nosh. Cool Pink Boxes and fun for visitors, but there are better doughnut places in town without the lines and the hubbub.

I was really excited to go to VDD and I'm sorry to say that I was a little disappointed. I got the cock n balls (yeast doughnut with chocolate icing and filled with cream but sorry folks, in the balls only), arnold palmer (cake doughnut with icing and powdered iced tea), the marshall something (cake doughnut with m&m's) and the maple bacon bar (yeast rectangle doughnut with maple icing and slabs of bacon on top). The most anticipated of these was the arnold palmer but it really didn't taste like iced tea. It was tangy for a second and then the taste went away and it was basically a vanilla doughnut. Sadly, I didn't get to taste the others because I handed them out, but everyone really liked the maple bacon bar. The cock n balls was pretty mediocre, but I did enjoy the texture of the doughnut. 

Definitely a must when in Portland, but next time I might stick with the more extreme versions like grape and fruit loops just because you can't be disappointed with something so creative. 

Beware that the line can be long (and it's rainy and chilly) and that there aren't any descriptions for the doughnuts. I would suggest going to the website and writing things down that you want then asking them to pick a surprise one. Also, they're pretty cheap. My items came out to $10.50.

Very overrated and I would NEVER wait in line for these donuts. I've been wanting to try these donuts after many trips to Portland b/c of all the hype but when I see the line .. I don't even bother .. I'm not a huge fan of sweets .. but I love me some krispy kreme from time to time :D 

My most recent stay in Portland I got to stay in Downtown .. so we walked to a lot of places .. including Ground Kontrol on a Sunday .. unlimited free play yes please .. anyways on our way there we noticed Voodoo was still open and there was no line (btw they're open 24 .. didn't know that) .. so upon our return at 1 or 2am we bought a box of random popular picks by the lady at the counter.. who looks like she hates her job b/c she gets asked by so many people for recommendations im sure .. but sorry I can't tell what the donuts are just by looking. 

The only donut I actually enjoyed was the oreo peanut butter one .. idk what it's called .. they have difficult names. I'm glad I was finally able to try it .. but I would've been pretty sad/upset if I had to wait in a long line just to try these donuts. I'd recommend going late at night .. after midnight. Even at nine when we were having dinner at Portland Grill (our view was of Voodoo donuts) there was still a line.
Interesting flavors and combination of choice of doughnuts. Just not the best in taste. Definitely worth a visit for a tourist for the experience.

Voodoo doughnuts, have to come here if it's your first time in Portland.  That was my friend, so I had to take her here and give it a try.  I think they're the first donut shop to have exotic donuts with crazy phallic creations.  Sometimes I think they just dump random stuff on there and give it a name, hey kudos to you guys!  Some are actually cool and hilarious.  Cock'n balls!  Of course with great things, there is always a line.  The line wasn't too bad for us, maybe 20-30 mins?  Dropped my friend off and I went to look for parking.  Parking is cray cray, so park near Chinatown or something.  We went on a Sunday, so parking was free till 1pm.  Do give yourself time though, you never know!

Oh before I forget CASH ONLY!!!!

We freaked out because we totally forgot about it, but luckily we had enough to buy three!  Since I'm there, I got the Voodoo doll donut and she got a regular since she's not really a donut person, but had to try it out!  

Like a few other's said, zero taste + flavor.  I couldn't even finish my little devil voodoo doll, but it's because it's from Voodoo and it's a trend.  My friend said the same thing, but her sister think otherwise.  So it's up to you whether it's something you love, it's ok, or no, but if it's your first time in Portland, just do it!

WHY!!! I wanted to love you, but I just couldn't...

I was so excited to visit VooDoo Doughnuts when I came to Portland. I am all about donuts, and I thought this was be the crown jewel of all my donut adventures. Sadly, it was not.

The line wasn't that bad when my girlfriend and I visited. Maybe that was the problem. I do hear the wait can be pretty ridiculous though.

The workers are all crabby, like they're upset that you came in for food. I wasn't about that.

There are so pretty unique donuts, but, in the end, there all variations of the same thing. Donut covered in _____, topped with _____ cereal. Worst of all, they weren't even fresh. I should have just stayed in Cali...

I was hoping for some of that ingenuity that I heard so much about. I hope your experience is better than mine.

I've been here most times I've come to Portland from Seattle, if nothing else to see what the hype is about and because either one of our three kids wanted to have donuts or we were spending the weekend in Portland with friends or family from the East Coast and they wanted to try a Voodoo donuts. Sure, it is fun to see the crazy creations and try one of their less over the top creations, but I'm not blown away by the donuts. The decadence and sugar stuffed creations are just a bit much for my taste and style. Sure it is a must stop if you've never been before, but now that our children are older (19, 16 and 13), they feel the same way. We just came down for a weekend in Portland and no one had any interest in grabbing donuts here as they said they were over-rated and too sugary.

I like the unique variety but definitely doesn't live up to the hype. Not surprising that the locals have stopped coming here and it's 95% tourists and drunks nowadays.  I miss the old days when grabbing a quick donut here was possible, not a 30 mi process.

Waaaaaay too sweet. I spent a week in the northwest and Portland was one of my earlier stops. This place ruined my appetite for the rest of my day and basically ruined sugar for me for the entire week.

Any time of day you go, there will be a line. All the tourists in Portland stop by this place, so yes there will be lines early in the morning too. You'll have to deal with people asking a million questions about what's what, asking for samples, and taking photos with their donuts, especially those brave souls who buy the phallic-shaped ones.

Since I'm an engineer and I fix roads for a living, it seemed fitting to try the pothole donut (chocolate, cream filling, Oreos). I couldn't even get through half of it without running out of coffee to balance out the sweetness overload. I also made the mistake of buying a second donut (Portland creme) which I couldn't finish either. Between the two, I struggled to finish what amounted to one full donut.

You'll see lots of people buy entire boxes. I saw a group of four tourists each walk out with their own individual boxes, and they attempted to eat them in the table area in the alleyway. Those poor souls...

One final HUGE complaint: all their coffee stuff (creamer, sugar, etc.) is on top of the trash can. They can't even spare a little bit of counter space? How does this place not get shut down from this alone? Get your coffee across the alley instead.

Decent donuts?  Yes for the most part. 

Worth waiting in line for an hour?  Not a chance. 

My biggest gripe is that the donuts themselves aren't great. The toppings are the toppings and anyone can add bacon or Reese's to a donut, and we know they will be delicious regardless.  I've just had much better plain or chocolate donuts than the ones they offer piled with sweets. 

That being said I do think they have a unique marketing strategy all the way down to the pink boxes they give you. We had several people come up to us on the street asking about the donuts and the line because of the pink box. 

All in all, if you want to try them I suggest you check out there menu online to save time ordering at the counter. Also go on a Sunday morning when the donuts are fresh and there is very little line.

I think for out of towners Voodoo has become such a "portland thing".  As a local, the donuts aren't that good, they're not bad, but the lines and the cost certainly are huge detractors.

If you're looking for a tourist trap, go here.  If you're looking for good donuts, go elsewhere, pay less and don't stand in line.

I don't want to blame the annoying tourists on the business itself, so I can't give it a bad review just because it's over hyped. Plus if you come here at 1am like you are intended to do it's about the same as it ever was. Tourists tend to think of it as a breakfast or dessert destination, despite all the decor clearly indicating that it's a late night hangout. If you ever want to elope with a pole dancer and don't have an officiant or want witnesses it's a good option for marriages! (um, from what I hear...)

OK, if it were not for all the hype and build up I might give this place three stars but the fact that everyone calls it the best donut shop in the Northwest, if not the planet, I am expecting something truly extraordinary. I have been to this place about four or five times, not by choice, but because friends, from the area, insist on stopping here when in Portland,  so being the good sport that I am I go along. I will say this, that they have found a niche and they are original and their donuts look very interesting but after standing in a long line for some 20 minutes or more I decided to order like eight or nine donuts and give everything a try. I think I like the old dirty bastard and maybe the bacon maple bar the most but honestly the donuts were not very fresh and they just kind of had a staleness to them and not just this occasion but every time I have gone there it has been that way. I think it's just a trendy spot and I understand that. Why go to a normal donut shop, even if the donuts are better, if you can be in the crowd and say you went to the popular spot? If you have not been here, I highly recommend you going at least once just to try it out and be your own judge and I would love to hear your opinion on them.
Long wait... you'll see people bringing these donuts back to share with others. But, they arent worth the hype.
Creative but honestly not that great. The doughnuts are fresh because it's such a popular place, but there are much better doughnuts in Portland than those at Voodoo.

Try Annie's on 72nd & Sandy as it's much better. Voodoo is over-hyped and not worth the wait.
Annie's apple fritter is incomparable.
Voodoo, is a tad overrated. I do like their fun designs and originality, but there is another place in Portland that I see is the true Star doughnut of Portland. ;-)

I heard sooo much hype about this donut place so I did whatever I could to make sure I came here while I was in Portland. After waiting in like for over half an hour I finally got my box of donuts. I wasn't even that hungry but I wanted to try all the signature donuts so I got the voodoo, maple bacon, and penis shaped donuts. After taking a bite, I realized it just tasted like any other donut I've had but I guess it was more creative in the design and presentation of donuts. The voodoo is pretty cool with the jelly filling and pretzel stick as the needle and each voodoo donut was decorated differently to give it its unique donutality. The maple bacon just tasted like a maple donut with a piece of bacon on top nothing too special. Really, the donuts don't taste any different but the presentation is worth a visit.

This place had been hyped to the hilt, but I found it to be more style than substance. The donuts were visually appealing, but just ordinary tasting. They had fancy names and ornate designs for the donuts, but that meant nothing to me. Krispy Kreme has better tasting donuts, even your local coffee shop may have better donuts. They've seduced consumers with slick marketing, but the product is mediocre.

Overrated-- really only for tourists. Portland natives don't eat donuts from Voodoo because they aren't good, they're gimmicky. Most fresh donuts in town will be at least as good if not better, they just might not be shaped like a cock or Texas.

Typically, all Voodoo donuts is good for is walking past the lines of tourists, standing in the rain-- and laughing at them for waiting on mediocre donuts.
Disappointing.. Long line and the donuts weren't any better than dunkin donuts or other chains. They make for a good picture and the price was super reasonable.
Absolutely disgusting. If I could give zero stars I would. How the heck does this place get any business let alone have a line out the door????!!! Grow some real taste buds, people! AWFUL.

So two stars for the cool concept but that's all this place is. The donuts are overly sweet and nothing special. The service was especially bad. The girl who served us was so rude to us and the customers before us. 
I won't be going back!

Fun experience. Our cashier didn't seem very excited to be there and wasn't the friendliest but we enjoyed the visit anyway. We purchased 6 donuts because let's face it, we probably won't be back. Of all the unique selections, our favorite was the Texass donut. Some of the other combinations are just too much but hey, you have to try them, right!?

Not sure why this is a tourist must-see location. It has average, overpriced, doughnuts. They do have cool designs, but if you buy one with toppings, the toppings are soggy or stale, having sat in the frosting for too long.

Came by because it was one of those "must try" things in Portland. First time we came by, the line was so long we gave up. Came back again on a weekday around 1pm and the line was pretty short (30 minutes long) probably because it was raining. Once we got in, we ordered a dozen donuts to split. We let the employee choose for us. Service wasn't particularly nice, just kind of grab and go feeling but I understand that it's busy.

The donuts were not good at all. They were dense and besides the "crazy" toppings, weren't special in any way. I know the flavors are supposed to be "wacky" but honestly they weren't that out there.  The cereal donuts just tasted like normal (if not sub-par) donuts with stale cereal on top. Most of the other ones were just too sweet. On top of that, I'm a bit upset that the employee didn't give us a single one of their voodoo donuts. I know it's "their choice" but honestly you'd think they'd include the specialty... Literally I cannot emphasize how bad they are. I tried every single donut of the dozen me and my friend got and I did not find a single one I liked. There are so so so many better gourmet donut options.

I been there as I was told this is the place for Doughnut lovers. It was quite disappointing. Huge lines for a very average tasting Doughnut. The fact that you put all kind of weird and funky looking toppings does not make the Doughnut good. Presentation is nice selection is nice but flavor is very average.

Portlands most famous donut shop.  Known for their quirky flavors like NyQuil or pepto. Try anything with bacon on it. Moderately high pricing and decent donuts. You should at least go and get a pic of this place but then ask the locals for some other options to check out!

I don't understand all the hype! I do believe they are good but the prices are OUTLANDISH LIKE SERIOUSLY IT IS A joke some one is making way more money then they should be for a slightly above average DONUT and portlanders come running its sad!

Congratulations. You're about to eat a regular tasting donut. Nothing special going on here and the hype has never been so wrong. Wanna taste a real gourmet something-to-write-home-about donut, visit California.  Portland... I am very disappointed and pretty spoiled. You have fooled me.

Doughnuts are good, but nothing special. It is a great tourist spot, but the locals know to stay way because of the lines. 

Still, a great spot for some tasty treats!

Good donut, but don't see all the fuss and definitely wouldn't wait in a long line to get one of these. It's more of a novelty snack than anything else. They have a spot at Cartlandia and there's hardly ever a line, way better option than going directly to the store.

I can't give this place a negative review, because it is really fun and unique. The donuts are very clever and the atmosphere is over the top weird which makes it really fun. However, it loses 2 starts because of the quality of the donut. Biting into the donut I could instantly feel my teeth falling out. Just get them for pictures and to laugh and then throw them away.
Totally overrated and gimmicky...not worth the 45 minute wait!

Voodoo donuts is a PDX 'thing' that has become a tourist attraction.  The natives basically wait for the summer/holiday's to end and then partake in the unique flavor combinations.

Look folks, you eat Voodoo donuts because of their novelty (been accosted a few times by TSA when carrying the pink box with maple bacon bars through PDX or SEA security).   I have had Stan's Donuts (Westwood, CA), Randy's (off 405 Fwy, LA), Blue Star (PDX), as well as other's but none come close to the novelty combinations of Voodoo donuts.  They are all unique and everyone is unique (shape, flavor, combinations).  So a Voodoo donut is what you get when you want a real sugar fix and meet some 'interesting' folks . . . 

So if you are waiting in line for a Voodoo donut, you also probably also waited in line for an ice cream from Salt & Straw . .. need I say more.

Native's go the SE Davis location to avoid the long lines on SW 3rd (now I am in trouble).

Fun, creative flavors (oreo, fruit loops, etc.), open at all hours.

The wait in line isn't always worth it for me.

Its open 24/7 making it an easy destination to stop by when in Portland. They also only accepts cash but has an ATM in the store. If you're not a fan of overly frosted donuts beware. I'm not but decided to give the hype a try. I only liked my blueberry donut (which is decent because it did not have frosting on it but I've had better) and took only bites of the other overly sweetened choices we got. They are literally just donuts with frosting decorations and an interesting name for the store. The decorations were entertaining though, but I Went, tried, and am over it.

It's a doughnut...some are topped with stale cereal... service is nothing to write home about...it is definitely not the place to bring your younger kids!
The maple bacon is yummy, but beyond that it is not worth waiting in line for one hour or more to experience these.
I guess this is the place to be for tourists...

I don't know what is the hype about this place, but the doughnut was not that good. I got the voodoo doll OMG it was so sweet if you into super sweet diabetes doughnut then this is the place for you! Anyway this is a tourist trap, definitely recommend Blue Star over this!! 2 stars for they open 24/7 and open during a winter storm, but trust me the doughnuts is not worth 2 stars

Look, Voodoo is tasty, and the donuts have funny names, but it's not going to change your life. It's not even the best donut place in town. Don't get me wrong, they're good, and if you're staying in a hotel downtown you might as well see what all the hype is about... but if the line is crazy long then hit up Blue Star, which makes better donuts.

Tourists annoy me. An hour + wait in line for a f-ing over priced doughnut? As Cartman would say: "Screw you guys, I'm going home."

BTW it smells like cat piss and used condoms out there.

I would humbly consider myself a donut connoisseur.  I have grown up with them in Texas where I personally knew the owners of several dozen shops.  The shops I know stuck to the traditional stuff where Voodoo elevated the donut game and added some jazz to theirs.  I would have liked Voodoo more if the oil they used was fresh and their toppings added more depth of flavors rather than just more sugar.  I think the concept had potential but the execution fell short.  The draw is mostly hype but I guess it keeps with the theme of Portland in that it's weird.  I liked the overall experience of waiting with people in line, the anticipation of getting an out-of-body experience with a voodoo donut, chatting it up with other patrons eating their donuts outside but the actual taste of the donut left much to be desired.

This is one of those not quite sure how you became so popular places. Maybe it's the name, maybe it's the gaudy pink, maybe it's the tourists. Whatever it is this place is bustling. We were visiting some friends and stopped off here to pick up some doughnuts, most of them just do not look like something I would ever want to eat. The cereal on top, the colours, flavours...I asked the guy if I could get a dozen with more simple flavours which is pretty much what "the classic" box is. So he made sure not to put any weird ones in. Really these are just run of the mill, nothing amazing about the flavours, textures etc. nothing tastes bad except the Mexican chocolate one :/ I wouldn't go back - do yourself a favour and go to a local favourite instead BlubStar Dounuts (albeit much more expensive, they taste and look way better in my opinion.)
Great people working at this place ....but donuts are look great but taste terrible and would not wait in line

Not exactly too sure why this place is so popular. I've been here a couple of time, on nights when you have to wait in line for 20 minutes and days when you can just walk right in. Every single time I've been here my doughnut was stale and quite frankly stale doughnuts are tasteless, no matter the crazy concoction you've made. I'm not impressed by this "oh so popular" place at all. You think they would at least have fresh doughnuts with how busy they always are. 

Side Note: The alley next to Voodoo doughnuts is so nice but unfortunately it's always  crowded with trashy people.

Worth checking out, however the donuts have gone down hill since last visit. The maple bacon bar use to be worth the evil it does to your health, however this last trip it was way too sweet, like they started using pancake syrup instead of maple syrup and the bacon had some undercooked fat, not the crispy death it use to be. Mr speed metal (or was that Rob Zombie) had no personality and was irked I wanted a bag for a half dozen 2 dollar donuts. Oh and the underage drunken people (including a young woman in voodoo that was on some hard drugs and was falling over where nobody seemed to care) from the bar next door were a pain when standing in the line that was around the corner. 

Place was 5 star a couple years ago, has really gone down hill..

OMFG, I went back, Why?? I dont know.. This time I got just a plain 'ol apple fritter. It was HUGE and delish. My friend's all ordered some random donuts and they thoroughly enjoyed them as well. 

The service still sucked though. I think thats part of the whole experience. Just gotta go with it.
Not bad, but it's a tourist attraction. There are MANY other offerings of higher quality in this town. Don't let the line fool you.

They are doughnuts with weird names. Not a big deal. Be prepared for a gut bomb. 

If you want good doughnuts, go to Blue Star. Those are fresh, real ingredients, and delicious. You can watch everything being made in front of you.

Say it ain't so!! Three Freakin' Stars for what I easily put high on a pedestal since the first bite??  It was just last September at Universal Studios in California when our party of 10 decided to get a snack. Man, I went down the rabbit hole riding that pink strawberry frosting!  I was hooked!  Had to try the Portland as Bavarian Cream is a lifelong favorite of mine. The doughnuts were light, airy, and at the same time chewy. The BEST doughnuts I have tasted in my Life. 

Fast-forward to a month ago. I live in Southern Oregon, but blessed to have my Son and five grandchildren living in Portland. So, we have gone to their flagship store four times in the last Apx. six months. 

So here comes the three stars (which should maybe be two, but they hooked me, and I'm like a battered wife...I keep going back for more!).
