The way we get the doughnuts is to get maybe 8-12 at a time on our way home (a 5-hour trip) and we m-a-y-b-e will eat one in the car. So we did on our first take home. And they were good but not great.  it was such a bummer. They tasted like day-old doughnuts from a grocery store. 

Ugh!!  Sad as we were, we went back a second time with the same result!!  What say you, Voodoo Doughnuts?!? But we called the next day and gently 'complained' the way you might go to a garage sale and 'complain' to the owner that Barbie doesn't have any shoes. 

You know, we were glad handed, and yada yada yada...we went there Again!! (I mean, seriously, could you see my eyes rolling?). So this time, we made sure to ask if the doughnuts were fresh. We were assured they were 'Very Fresh!'  Got down 1-5 past Salem and decided on a doughnut, and they were The Wrong Doughnuts. 

I mean, are they just screwing with us?  Are they doing a weird Candid Camera spin off and we'll get our first residual check any day now!?!  And by the way, we didn't like the ones they gave us. I'm Very persnickety. 

So yes, say it with me... 'We Went There Again'!

So these ones were good. The ones we didn't eat that day were kind of Stale, but you know, we got the doughnuts. So the three stars should be five inasmuch as they have the capacity for greatness. 

Can't wait to go again!!

This is CASH only and expect a line. 

I heard when in Portland, give this place a shot! Well, I did and ordered 3 donuts of which 2 I forgot already what I ordered with 1 that left a faint memory - The Voodoo Doll only because it was their store front signature iconic donut. 

The Voodoo doughnut contained some type of raspberry filling covered with chocolate frosting. The frosting was good but towards the end, I just felt like the sweetness was too much for my palette. BUT, this was the best donut of the bunch that I ordered. 

Here's my suggestion: Give this place a shot but don't expect some high quality donut. Given that everyone raves about this place, you might as well just make the effort to try it out and then check that off your list that you've been here and tasted it. Then move on...

If you have some time left on your schedule, I would highly recommend visiting Pip's Original Doughnuts & Chai off of NE Fremont Street to get a better feel of amazing doughnuts that Portland has to offer.

It's just mediocre donuts with a lot of attitude. I don't get it. But people get into it, so have at 'em... I just... I've eaten a lot of donuts at a lot of donut shops and I don't get why people get emotional about these ones. They're novel, but I don't find them very tasty.
They're not the most amazing doughnuts although they are beautiful, get a pic for instagram sure but, its just a go here once experience.

I like their selection and their random-ass doughnuts with crazy frostings and toppings. Cannot beat a unique 'nut! I think this is a great place to come with your tourist friends and family. Living here I have only eaten it twice. I tried it and I get it but I'm not one to drive out specially for them.
I don't know a single native Portlander that understands why tourists stand in line for maple bars with M&Ms. It doesn't make sense.

The doughnuts are good here but their customer service could get kicked up a notch.  I didn't drive 3 hours to get a dick server trying to get me in and out. I want to know what I'm buying, what's inside, how much it is and what discounts apply.  Lmao.

Can anyone say "beard nets?" I took my 11 year old daughter here last night with a bunch of her friends. I whipped around when i heard them squealing "Dad that mans beard is touching the doughnuts!" I guess that's part of the Voodoo experience. Anyways, The cashiers are totally rude and the donuts are average at best, but the kids seem to love them, then again, I caught my daughter eating a spoonful of sugar before, and she loved that too.

I think it's a 5 stars for tourists and a 2 or 3 star for locals. Blue Star and Coco have much better donuts, but everyone has to try it out. I work a few blocks away and it's easy to run in (at the right time) and grab some for the office. On the weekends I prefer the less murder stab location of Voodoo Too.

Take some real mediocre donuts and put stale cereal or candy on top, wait for a half hour in a sketchy line, and that's Voodoo Donuts in a nutshell. 

After waiting in line forever, and coming from a city with a strong donut scene... I left very disappointed. It's clear that Voodoo was probably once a great place but with the extremely high volume of traffic they deal with 24/7 and the general demographic, it's a total tourist trap, plain and simple. 

The two stars here are for the AMAZING staff who process an insane line around the clock with a great attitude (and also excellent taste in blaring music). But the donuts are okay at best and have boring to stale toppings. 

TLDR; great staff, it's an institution, but core product line needs a lot of work.

Their donoughts are good, but there's better doughnuts, but they certainly get full points on creativity. Also, ask about their day old bucket of doughnuts. Keeps me coming back :) And the banana fritter is my favorite.
too sweet   well they have a unique design and flavor.The  lines too long too but  for tourist it might be  interesting

I was visiting Portland this weekend to see a friend and saw a line coming out the door.  I guess they have been featured on TV and are known to have the best doughnuts in town.  For me this place just wasn't my style.  I got the voodoo dozen where the cashier picks the dozen for you.  I tried a few of them and each one I felt a sugar overload and nausea following shortly after.  The worst one was the bubble gum doughnut, omg I nearly barfed.  Krispy Kreme is wayyyy better than this place by far.

Nothing special, super long line, most donuts are too sweet and have half an inch of regular cake frosting on them. Not enough jelli filling. Most of the donuts you can get at a grocery store just without the gimmick. Go to Blue Star instead.

SERVICE WAS UNBELIEVABLY WORSE THAN ANYTHING I'VE HAD MY WHOLE LIFETIME IN LA. The gay boy in the front whom we asked to see the vegan donuts from, was a complete douchey DIVA WANNABE. My gf wanted to buy a dozen donuts but only walked out with 2 because of his stank attitude and I ended up getting nothing. He literally ROLLED his eyes when she asked to see the donut tray again. It is clearly stated to ask for options on their menu PLUS he works in a service job that serves a high amount of tourists. REHIRE YOUR STAFF, They're too busy trying to get people in and out to even say hello welcome it's just "who's next!?" FUCK THIS i dont even get service this bad in LA and BELIEVE I WILL NEVER RETURN OR RECOMMEND THIS ESTABLISHMENT TO ANYONE I KNOW OR ON SOCIAL MEDIA.

Not sure what the big deal is with this place.  It's unique, to be sure, but the few times I've eaten here, the doughnuts were pretty stale and didn't taste fantastic.  Now I admit that I'm not a huge doughnut fan, but any fresh decent doughnut is at least on par, if not better, than these.  It's like a joke that's only funny the first time.  I guess most cities are so bland and boring that something different is cool, but this kind of thing is so common around here that I really don't get what the big deal is, and I'm certainly not willing to wait in that hellish line that usually forms when I go by.  I tried the location on Davis a couple times, hoping for a better experience, but it's just blah to me.  I've even seen people take limos to this place, strange.  But visitors seem to have fun so I'll still recommend it to outsiders.

I went here when I visited Portland and heard all the hype about it.  I gotta admit the doughnuts are pretty damn good, but the line is really long so expect at least a 45 min wait.  I only got one doughnut, Old Dirty Bastard, which I regret for not getting more after waiting for so long.  They do not accept cash, there's an ATM machine.  Its a really small spot, so not much room for indoor seating, but they have benches outside for patrons.  They charge .10 cents for a cup of water (free refills) don't ask me why.  I would def go here again.

Very large selection of unusual doughnuts.  I opted for the most popular Bacon Maple Bar.  It was out of this world.  Don't bother getting the coffee, it lacks flavor and is 1/8 grounds.  The worst thing about this location is the junkies that take over the seating outside the restaurant. They cover the tables with their possessions and dogs and prevent others from siting to enjoy the doughnuts they just purchased.  The odor from them would keep you from enjoying your purchase anyway.  They sit around and talk about where the best place to score heroin is and the best way to get people to give them money for their drugs.  Not a safe location for families.

To all the people standing in line outside the downtown Voodoo Doughnut at 11:30 a.m. on a Tuesday in July, do yourself a favor: walk across the Burnside Bridge and turn right on Grand St, there you will find Delicious Doughnuts!! 

Yes, Voodoo Doughnuts are famous, but they are more well known for their variety than their flavor. Sure, you can get married at Voodoo, but how many of you are actually gonna do that??  As for their flavor??? It's fine.  They make a decent doughnut, but not even close to the best doughnut you will ever have.  For that you will need to travel to New York city and try the Doughnut Plant (also on Grand St, coincidence, perhaps). That is all.

As a local, I can't stand this place. The staff doesn't even look at you and can't count change. The donuts are stale and the flavors are so fake it completely destroys your palette.

It's fun for out-of-towners to see something that doesn't really exist anywhere else. The in your face attitude of the menu, the shocking aspect of a cream filled cock 'n balls, it's all an experience. 
If they cut the menu down to 10 items or so, and started caring about their product, it might be a worthy place to eat.

We waited in line for about 45 minutes. I thought their donuts were good, but not great. They have a picture menu posted outside so you can see what they are offering while waiting. I thought it was a good idea since the menu board with prices can be hard to read and trying figure out what you want. They also have a display case inside the store showing the actual donuts as well.

Come for the hype. Stand in the long lines if you must. Tell all of your friends that you went to Voodoo! But...don't expect good donuts or friendly service. There are other places in Portland that have better donuts, hipper hipsters, and shorter lines.

Stopped by around 8am on a Sunday, so there was no line.  Huge selection, and the draw is definitely the cereal and candy-coated donuts because the rest are all variations on a donut you could get anywhere (the Portland Creme is basically a large scale Boston Creme and several are simple sprinkle and glaze topped).  The toppings made most of our selections overly sweet and I found the cake donuts too dry.  The standout was their devils food donuts, which hit a perfect balance of sweetness.  Definitely would not wait in the line wrapped around the block I saw later in the day.
Pretty neat flavors. I tried the maple bacon and the flavor/consistency was decent. I did like how it had strips of real bacon, but not sure if ALL the hype is warranted. Cash only as well.
They're donuts with random stuff on it.  I don't understand the rave over it, just buy a normal donut and put what you want on it, haha.

A tourist trap. With all the hoopla on just about every "travel and food" show out there, I suppose you might feel the need to cross it off your Portland bucket list. That said, some of my guests brought some home one day and the donuts are, without a doubt, the worst tasting things I've ever had. Yes, they come in funny shapes. Ha. Take a picture with the donut. Story over.

Certainly a fun place to visit if you're a tourist. Charming and Cute.  Take the pictures. Pick out the funky donuts and eat to your heart's content. Then go home and puke it up because you don't need the calories and fat.

Really cool concept and the donuts were amazing. I didn't enjoy having to weave through the homeless crowd lurking outside the door begging for a donut though, nor did I enjoy the druggie flailing around on an acid trip circling me and my friends. So...I would say that the atmosphere was a little sketchy. But I really enjoyed the donuts. Cash only!

Don't get me wrong, the donuts here are good, several reasons for the rating.  Kam Bakery is in my hometown of Honolulu has better donuts without the long wait.  It was worth to try this, won't be coming back again unless the line is reasonable.  Another suggestion a trusted local gave me is Joe's.

One, this place does not match the hype, there are long lines night and day and you see people bringing out boxes and boxes of this stuff.  I was able to get actually inside the store by coming in just past 7:00AM and still had to wait 25 minutes!  The gal in front of me just left and couldn't wait.  I can't imagine how long the wait is when you are outside with a long line.  The staff was not friendly at all and didn't give any suggestions, or good descriptions of the donuts, like I was bothering them.  The staff is also slow, one of the reasons I can see why there is a long line.  A big disappointment.

For the donuts, ordered the Portland Creme, Raspberry Romeo, and the Maple bar.  All of the donuts were good but too sweet.  The Portland Creme was the best out of the bunch, the filling was just the right amount and  the donut doesn't collapse when you bite into it, a big plus.  A big minus is that the donuts was not fresh and hot when I got it... why not?  Another minus, no credit cards.

Honestly, I think this place is totally overrated.  I had seen this shop featured on the Food Network and I was super intrigued.  Bacon on a maple bar? Genius!!  My friends and I decided to come here around 8 p.m. and this place was bustling.  It was really hard to find parking in the nearby vicinity so we ended up paying $10 to park for about 30 minutes.  Ridiculous.  

When we arrived at the store, the line wrapped around the corner.  The line didn't take super long but I thought that it was kind of silly to wait in line of donuts.  I picked out the maple bar with bacon and a jelly filled donut.  Seriously, the donuts weren't all that spectacular, taste wise.  It was okay...  In fact, the inside of the store is kind of grungy and dirty looking.  Perhaps this is because so many people frequent this store.  I didn't think this donut store was all that special.  

However, the outside patio area was nice.  It was well lit and there were picnic benches where you could plant yourself while enjoying your donut.

No gluten free. Long line. I waited in line for an hour to get a gluten-free donut because my dummy friend reassured me that they had them there. They don't. I know my waiting in line for an hour isn't Voodoo's fault. But come on! No gluten free options? Isn't it 2014?

Meh. Extremely tourist trappy. Actually walked past at a time when the lines were minimal so i said "when in Portland" and what the heck. 

My bacon maple donut was okay. My buddy got the stick man and his was undercooked. Kind of a doughy slimy mess. 

I wasn't impressed but was only out $6 and can say i've been. 

On the other hand i did get a donut and coffee earlier in my trip at Blue Star and i can say i was pretty happy with that combo. Go there. No long lines, and better services / food. 

When in Portland i guess. So now I know. 

Don't do-doo that Voodoo that you do.

personal feelings on voodoo... they do the originals well.  but in the bigger picture i'm not going to wait in line for an hour for an okay doughnut with a bunch of sugary crap on it.  they are doughnuts for tourists.  if it's off hours i'm happy anytime to stop and grab some from their smaller east side location so that would be my only recommendation.

if you're in town sure it's fun and cute to take home a box of pink on the plane.  go for it.  but know that portland has FAR better things to offer!  go explore :)

After an evening out on the town, we stopped at Voodoo Doughnut to complete our Portland experience.  The wait wasn't bad at 1:45am, although we did wrap around the side of the building.  Being on vacation, I wasn't feeling as impatient as I normally would...  The shop is kitschy and decorated amusingly, and I was happy that there was a hefty selection of different donuts, even that late at night.  

Once we made it to the counter, the cashier who took our order introduced himself by saying, "Duuuude, one of my customers tonight tipped me with a joint..."  Clearly.  Here's how the conversation then played out:

Me: "I'll take the Portland Cream donut and two small coffees, please."
Stoned cashier: "Riiiiight.  That'll be (I don't even remember how much because I was stunned he was high!)"

***pay the cashier with cash only - no credit cards***
***stand there waiting...***

Me: "So I'm going to need my donut..."
Stoned cashier:"  Riiiiight, donuuuuuuuttt...."

***stand there waiting....***

Me: "So, I'm going to need my coffees..."
Stoned cashier:"  Oh, yaaaaaah, the coffee....."

OMG.  

The donut was huge, greasy, overly sweet, and I've had better custard filled donuts at convenience stores.  The coffee was diner-grade coffee.  I am unimpressed, and the only thing that makes me smile is that I got a check-in and selfie at a place that somehow has become iconic in the food world and gives me a hilarious story to share about this pothead cashier.  Not worth another trip though.

Slightly overrated in my
Opinion but a must if you go to Portland. 

I love donuts just as much as the next guy so I was excited to finally try this place. The flavors are delightfully creative but the execution was not as good. This place is popular more for the hype rather than the product itself. To be honest I think that Bluestar donuts actually has better donuts. And the best part about Bluestar is that there are no lines unlike voodoo donuts. Even though I was not that impressed by this place compared to most people I must say, I have to give them credit because they are the ones that started this whole donut trend in the first place.

OK, everyone has been here or had a voodoo... But when it comes down to it, they are just doughnuts... In some cases they are not very good. If you want to do the tourist thing then go, get one, say you went. But don't go nuts, there are better things in life. 

Remember there are two locations, one is off Sandy on the east side, sometimes a shorter line or no line at all.

Usually choosing doughnut isn't that hard but voodoo is making your head spinning around with excitement. So many variations to choose. I have to thank Man vs Food for introducing me to this place and so far, I have been lucky in avoiding those crazy lines. There are few names that you can't say them out loud at work unless you want to deal with HR :) 

But apart from all the hype and craziness, which I had to admit I was one of their junkies before I sobered up, their doughnuts are just so-so. Local grocery stores would probably have better taste doughnuts than voodoo. 

I tried their maple bacon and it was just too sweet. one bite was enough to last the rest of my life... 

If you want to grab voodoo, go to the second location (voodoo too) to avoid the lines and the second location also has parking lot that can save you a lot of hassle in looking for street parking in downtown portland. Grabbing the doughnuts at off hours (evening or morning) really help too (in terms of waiting)!
Overrated -- but as a tourist, screw it why not. Also do not get the donuts with any sort of cereal on it, they suck.
The long lines typically keep me from going here but the doughnuts are fun, fresh and very tasty. I also like that they offer vegan ones.

It's a decent donut shop with many yummy varieties and waaay too long of a line. Not sure how they managed to get so much far-reaching hype! If you love donuts, it's worth the stop but try the SE location to skip the line.
Unbelievably rude. Literally wouldn't answer questions with words, just pointing and grunts. Zero exaggeration.

I want to give a four star, but since I was there last they've expanded. Which I can understand as its a growing business, but seems doughnut quality has gone down with the need for quantity. Still a freak show of a doughnut selection and the gal helping me was very nice at 10pm, so I'll go 3.78 stars.  

Be prepared as there ALWAYS seems to be a line. Stop talking about what you might have, and get ready to order!! Standing at the till still 'thinking' irritates everyone!!  Just sayin'.....
Maybe I don't get it but these are pretty basic and nothing special. I think it is all hype.

Stopped by Portland on my way up to Seattle. A friend of mine really wanted to come and eat a donut from here cause she saw it on tv or something like that.

PROS: 
- very interesting selection of donuts as you probably can see (c*ck and balls? LOL)
- donuts have more goodies to add extra fat to your stomach
- awesome staff
- perfect easily accessible hangover food

CONS: 
- 15 minute wait on a Sunday morning
- line is outside.. Had to wait in the rain
- the menu is not too descriptive of what's in it
- parking here is so weird 


I had the bacon maple donut and the captain crunch berry donut. Both were pretty damn good. The one thing that kind of bugged me was that there wasn't descriptions of the donuts in the menu, or maybe I just didn't see it somewhere. I didn't want to ask our donut guy to tell me every ingredient to every donut.. So I chose the ones which were pretty obvious in what you were going to eat.

Not to take away from their overall creativity, but this place is a little overrated. As much as it sounds good and looks good, I would rather have a fresh out of the oven original glazed Krispy Kreme donut. I would still recommend everyone to come at least once just to check out their spinning presentation of awesomeness when you're ordering.

The donuts were just kind of okay. This place seems to thrive on the hype. The donuts were very creative, but not worth waiting in line for an hour just to have a marginally good donut with a pretzel sticking out of it.

My one and only experience with Voodoo doughnuts was so annoying that I will not be repeating it.  The doughnuts are no better than most other doughnuts but the noise level when I entered the store SO DEAFENING that I had to ask the young woman at the counter to turn it down as I could not hear a word she was saying.

Why would any establishment make it difficult for customers to hear as well as exposing their employees to permanent hearing loss, is beyond me.

Of all things Portland associated, I really don't understand the fascination with Voodoo Doughnuts. The doughnuts themselves aren't of the best or freshest quality and there's always guaranteed to be a line out the door since everyone that visits Portland somehow hears about Voodoo. Sure, there are some more unique shapes and decorations that you won't see in many places, but it's definitely not worth standing in line for. Of the different doughnuts, the cereal topped ones can be a bit stale depending on the time of day, so be warned. If you really want the Portland tourist experience or really like eccentrically  doughnuts, by all means go for it, but otherwise it's a better idea to skip Voodoo if you just have a craving for something sweet.

Super overrated, it's great that they have vegan options, but the donuts are just super average with crazy toppings and names. Not worth the line or the hype. Better off at smaller donut shops. It is a cool experience to go but only once is really necessary, just to say you have.

I don't get the hype. Got a dozen donuts and have tasted the maple and bacon donut. It was like your run of the mill maple donut, just added bacon. My bar for donuts include Randy's Donuts and Donut Man in SoCal.  Those places are worth waiting in line for and has way less hype. The donut designs here are cute, but the taste wasn't anything to write home about.

I haven't had a doughnut in years but the hubs wanted to try this out.  I don't get why people line up for this place....nothing special, except for the fact that there were doughnuts with crushed whatnots on top (Oreos, fruit loops, etc.). I'm sure there's better out there...

I am disappointed in Voodoo doughnut. I had been told how great they are and when I got one it was a mountain of frosting on a doughnut. If I where under twelve I would have maybe loved it, but as an adult it is to rich and sweet, and when I asked to have a plain Bavarian filled with the two dozen I was sent in for it was too much trouble said could only purchase what was and had been sitting in the cases.

The donuts are great, yeah. The line is long for a reason. Every time friends come into town, they want Voodoo. The Memphis Mafia is the stuff dreams are made up, but honestly, once you've been there five times, ten times, twenty times you just kind of /shrug. The doughnuts are good and creative. The people are nice. The coffee is okay, but not my favorite. It's fun to go there after a bar crawl, for sure, and I tend to stumble over from Bailey's Taproom quite often.

Pretty standard as far as doughnuts are concerned. There is always a long line. Inside it's an experience that is almost worth it. We enjoyed the doughnuts we got, but it's nothing we can't get anywhere else. Thanks for the experience, but we see no need to return.
Gross! We had glazed and chocolate donuts, and they were stale and bland on a Friday morning. We make better donuts here in the Midwest. Voodoo Donuts is a tourist trap, and not worth the time.

Had to stop by here on my trip to Portland despite having an uber driver spend a whole 20-minute car ride trying to convince me not to go. After trying it, I can see why..

We tried the Old Dirty Bastard and the Portland Cream Doughnuts.  Maybe it was because we went in the middle of the day, but the doughnuts tasted stale and old despite there being a constant line of customers; this was so different from the fresh, soft doughnuts we had from Blue Star the day before.

This place is good to go to if you're going to check it off your travel bucket list, but if you want an amazing doughnut definitely head to Blue Star.

I wanted to write a review sooner, but I've been in a diabatic coma since eating one of their doughnuts 13 years ago. On the upside, Voodoo Doughnut has figured out how to make doughnuts out of pure sugar. A feat!

This has been my least pleasurable voodoo experience. I went over after work as I didn't realize there was a location so close to me. I love their doughnuts and thought I'd pick up a dozen. The outside is typical voodoo decor with glitter brick and a neon sign, pink rails etc. The line wasn't very long. Inside was a little dirty looking, but I tried not to let it bother me. I knew what I wanted so I walked right up. The guy was wearing a cut out tank top that showed his sides and underarms. Not exactly up to health code I don't believe  He didn't seem to want to look at me and could not for the life of him remember my order. What was so distracting I don't know. I kept asking about different types and he kept responding nope, sold out. Kind of disheartening. I know that wasn't his fault. Anyway I ended up walking away with 8 donuts and as always they were good. I just won't be visiting this location again if I can help it.

I must be one of the few that doesn't understand the hype for these doughnuts ... AND I LOVE DOUGHNUTS. Maybe it's just not for me to understand?

Their lines are fairly long, which is understandable. But personally, I think most are very comparable to other doughnut establishments. 

There were a few that did stand out to me, 
- The Grape Ape Doughnut
- The Mexican Hot Chocolate Doughnut.
- The Mango Tango Doughnut
- The Voodoo Bubble Doughnut
- The Memphis Mafic Doughnut
- The Bacon Maple Bar Doughnut

Other than those, everything else I could probably find at other doughnut hot spots. 

Besides that, their people are very rude. 

Therefore, really was not too impressed with Voodoo Doughnuts. 
Like I said, maybe it's not for me to understand.

If you like long lines for donuts raise your hand!! If your going just to get your hashtag, sure go and wait excess of 20+ min, the donuts don't get me wrong are very eye appealing, but sadly other then that they are not worth consuming, sampled the donut with maple and bacon because of course who doesn't like bacon, heavy, sweet, meshed with salty bacon, good but not great, would I wait another 20+min for this donut? NO!!!

I also ordered one of their fancy donuts decorated with capt'n crunch with berries, it was over the top, it was heavy, for diabetics stay away, but once it hits the lips though haha, the sugar high on some of there choices are unreal, definitely a place you want to hit up if you have had a salt lick for dinner or something close to it, again eye appealing yes, hashtag worthy yes, taste wise not so great, waiting in that line definitely not fun when it rains haha

donuts ***** for eye appeal ** for taste
price $
service *** the line crawls not due to staff but patrons either being to drunk to know what they want or not sure what would taste good (they all have sugar, pick one and move along) haha
ambiance ** line wraps around the block at times, getting to front door is great then it does this weird bend of a upside down S formation only to exit by the small door next to the entrance

For my first time being here I had to end up with the goth broad with the lisp that seemed to be on her period.  Not very nice.  Felt very rushed.  Crazy because all the other servers seemed to be super nice.  My doughnut Nazi even yelled at someone outside for being on the wrong side of the entrance.  Donuts are okay.  I think Blue Star is better.

I am a donut freak with Pa Dutch blood/ raised in Philly-- so, I know a good donut. VooDoo is not that good.  Too greasy. Not a place worth waiting in line for as far as I am concerned. Sorry. The apple fritters are good but greasy and heavy. I am not opposed to different kinds of donuts-- but they have to taste good. Can someone out here please make a cream donut? NOT custard-- cream. White fluffy delicious cream-filled donuts. I digress.  Voo Doo is fun and funky looking but that doesn't help me when I want a donut fix. Go to Blue Star if you want to buy an expensive donut. At least they taste good.

It was alright... long line to get in... i think this place it's overrated... We ordered a mango tango and a Marshall matters ... and they were fine but definite rely not worth the wait ...I guess since it's on the listing "to go places" people just crowd the place ‍.. anyway stop by only when there's not a big line, otherwise you'll may be disappointed
The donuts were very unique. Crazy topping.Super sugar rush. The donut we had was good but not great.
not the best donut in town. if what you want is an overpriced, not great donut but a weird Portland vibe, this spot is for you. That said, it is on on "B" tour list when out of towners visit

It was ehhhh ok, I would not stand in line again.  The maple bacon and grape ape were  good.  Double Bubble, dirty old bastard, Marshall Mathers, and vanilla sprinkle were nothing to write home about.  If you want some good people watching and in the area go for it.  Don't make a special trip.

I'm a donut expert - I shit you not.  I've scoured the earth for the best donuts in the world, and only recently terminated my 2 donuts-per-day habit because my physician told me I will die if this continues.  I kid you not, my cholesterol test has indicated my blood may actually be Ragu spaghetti sauce.

You only live once though, and if I'm going to have a heart attack, I want to be holding either a donut or a churro.  After finding myself in Portland - Voodoo donuts was a must-try since the internet seems to have ejaculated unicorn sperm all over this joint.

I ordered a dozen BY MYSELF, with the intention of taking one bite of each to determine if this is better than Stan's donuts (Santa Clara).  While the donuts were good, they were tolerable when it comes to the taste department.  While I love the novelty of it all, I probably should have hit the bong prior to eating these - which would  have easily bumped up my rating to 4 stars.  In my sober state however, shit isn't happening.

Tourist trap? Yes. Just OK donuts? I'd say so.

Just came back from Portland and finally tried the world famous Voodoo Donuts.  Surprisingly, there was pretty much no line at 9p on a Friday.  Maybe everyone is too busy at this time prepping to party, but I'm not complaining. Got in and out of there in 15 minutes with a few donuts.  Since I was stuffed from eating dinner, I opted to get one and eat one the next day.  We got a few donuts including the berry crunch, voodoo doll, maple bacon and neopolitian.

My girlfriend and I ate them all and we came to the conclusion that they were just alright.  There's nothing extremely special about them, although we cannot say they were bad donuts.  They were just.... OK.

The pricing isn't cheap, so be prepared to drop 2 to 3 bucks on a donut.  Go once to check it out but that's all you really need I'd say.  You know someone is going to ask you if you went anyways after you come back from Portland.  Don't be that asshole who didn't go cause you "wanted to live like a local" LOL.

They run out of the donut you want quick. The lines are always really long. The donuts aren't really even that great. Cool ideas for donuts though. Nice people work there. I'd rather go to a krispy Kreme though.

The doughnuts were tasty...but so are the others I tasted at other doughnut establishments. Went here to see for myself what the hype was all about but came out neutral. There were 20 or more people in line when I arrived and the place was surrounded by a lot of homeless (or looked homeless) people. They pretty much minded their own business so don't let that stop you from trying it out. Staff here was nice but you would think they are doughnut makers in the morning and rock/grunge band performers at night (as they dressed the part). Would probably go back if I was in the area but would not seek it out if not.

OK so let me say the Doughnuts are great but still over priced after all it is still a doughnut.  I can't believe it but I actually loved the bacon maple bar, and the No-Name is my favorite.  I have never visited a coke dealer, but I bet I would get the same vibe I got after leaving this place.  You get something Delicious and fun, but you have to deal with some scummy A-hole to get it.  I have stopped in this place the last 3 times I have been in Portland and every time I have hated the record store reject employee they have working the counter.  Doughnuts:Good, Attitude: F-off.

After a concert, I was taken to Voodoo doughnut.  Is this a club or something?  There was a long line to get into this place.  A doughnut place! Okay, let's see what the hype is about.

Once we made it in, I must admit, I had a whirlwind of mixed feelings.  This place was very unique.  It had a strange, eerie, but interesting vibe to it.  I immediately noticed the odd doughnuts with oreos, bacon, and fruit loops as toppings.  I had to rub my eyes.  Am I seeing correctly?  My friend ended up getting me the Cock-N-Balls doughnut with creme filling.  That was funny.

This place is definitely more so for the experience than the actual taste of the doughnuts.  You go here to see some wacky concoctions, that's for sure.
naw thank ya! I'll take a glaze donut that wants to be a glazed donut or a Jelly donut!! Stop the insanity!!
too much hype.  dry and texturally lacking.  If you like lucky charms on Safeway frosting......Get in the que and wait for 35 min to get ya some!

The doughnuts are amazing.  The service is hit and miss. Ive only been twice.  The first time the service was a miss, but the second time they were great.  Always a long line out front with plenty of Portland entertainment to pass the time.  My sister was up from California ,so we took her in to grab a box to bring back for her and her husband to share.

Two stars for creativity and variety. Otherwise, just go to blue star (seriously, blue star is amazing). The doughnuts are stale and the lines are long.  Fortunately we arrived at 9pm on a Friday, which is apparently a slow time. The price is fair for a decent doughnut, but not for the quality of these. 

I wouldn't even file this under "places to experience once". Look in the window, see the pretty pastry, keep walking.

Ok, I get it: Voodoo is a novelty and kind of interesting.  The donuts themselves are not good at all, though.  The line is long, so I'd only go if: 1) it is really nice outside and you want to stand around in the sun, or 2) you have visitors in town that you have no idea what to do with, so you kill an hour standing around.

I don't know whether waiting in line for 40 mins.+ made the doughnut good, or if it was good on it's own...but I did enjoy my doughnut. 

Of course I got the Voodoo Doughnut man, but I also got one with sprinkles and a Neapolitan one. They were all very sweet and yummy!

They are closing this location on April 10th and won't open again til sometime in May?

Mostly a touristy place, if you actually want to try the doughnuts go to the Sandy Blvd location.  Downtown is always crowded.  But interesting if you don't mind waiting.  They are good but slightly expensive

They have a blueberry glazed donut that is absolutely delicious. I'm not huge into doing things everyone says you HAVE to do, but if you have guests in town that insist on trying it whats the harm in "convincing" them to get a dozen so you can eat some (and the leftovers after they've left). I'm just sayingg....

it is a great place to visit, there is no doubt.  The varieties of doughnuts are
incredible.  The only thing is, beside the lines, is that the doughnuts aren't that fresh and good.  

If you are like me, who likes doughnuts warm, soft, airy, and sweet, (okay maybe not always warm) you might just not like these.  They tend to become a bit dense and topped with whatever you happen to pick up.  

It is always fun to visit Voodoo.  Late at night, standing in line, meeting new people, there is nothing better.

I have been here several times and it is never worth it. Never worth the time waiting in line or paying for an overpriced doughnut just because it's a Portland thing. The doughnuts really a not as fully as other small local options that are also much cheaper. The doughnut are not bad tho and they are very creative. The downtown location is super cute, but parking definitely sucks and you will most likely wait in line.

Well, a must-see for any visitor.  They have the craziest donut combo's and names, and the line is ALWAYS 20-30 people deep...24/7.  HOnest!  The donuts are decent, but it's mostly about the crazy kinds...like the VooDoo Doll shaped one that is a signature...must do when in Portland!

Don't forget your tetanus shot for the Old Town location. It's not the food that's the threat here, it's the aggressive panhandling that can get out of hand at this high-profile tourist hot spot. The kitschy donuts are deliciously worth the wait, in the same ways that porn on dial-up used to be. You'll meet people from all over the planet while waiting in the line. My advice is to take your prized treats away, in the requisite Pepto pink box, and enjoy them elsewhere cleaner, like under the Burnside bridge? The filth and mayhem that surrounds this location are as jarring as they are fixable. The upshot is, that you'll likely end up on 1,429 Facebook pages as a photobomb, and you just might get to meet one of Portland's finest while filing a police report about being pick-pocketed. Three stars for the food and brand. Two stars lost for the horrific location.

This place sells donuts.

They can only be fresh, considering the line outside the store.

They are very good but I will not wait 45min for a donut again. 
The line is at the sidewalk with no canopy (Portland/Rain???) and full of homeless people harassing you for money the whole 45 f**ing minutes.

45minutes of my life I will always regret losing....
I should not complain though....Because, as the people that drive by say "It's a F*ing donut you idiot, hahahah....." 

I was one of the idiots.

Never again!

I have lived my whole life in and around the Portland area, so of course I have been to Voodoo more than a few times. The doughnuts are good and they have good vegan options, but honestly, I am not going to wait hours in line behind tourists to get a doughnut. That is the only reason they get 3 stars. The Blazer Blunts are off the hook!

If you are in Portland and love Quality donuts please check out BlueStar donuts.  Voodoo donuts are funny and cute and they are fine donuts for a reasonable price but you can much much better.   All the frostings are much too sweet and thick.  The flavors are mild at best and quality of ingredients does not seem to be a priority. Even what looked like a short line took 25 minutes to get through.   We tried 15 donuts and between 6 donut lovers none of found a donut we could love.  That's a sharp contrast to our experience yesterday at BlueStar where we bought 8 donuts and everyone of us found a few favorites.   If you like a wide variety of cute, cheap donuts and don't mind a 20 minute wait then this is the place for you.

Love their attitude, wish their product matched the standards that Portlanders have become accustomed to.  I always encourage visitors to visit Voodoo, but I prefer to spend my calories on other Portland delights.

Having lived in Portland for quite a while and being a fan of doughnuts, I've tried a lot of different doughnut shops. Though these doughnuts are good, and certainly win on on the fun factor, there are better doughnut to be had. I do not believe that it's worth the obnoxiously long wait.

Meh is right. As a Portland native, I've been dragged here when friends are in town quite a few times. There are better Portland experiences, and there are way better, cheaper doughnuts. Even Safeway has better maple bars. 

Get drunk somewhere fun, go to Petite Provence in the morning, have a way better time. The Travel Channel/Food Network dickriding is insane for somewhere that's solidly mediocre.

This is definitely for the tourists.

Over priced and NOT worth the wait in line.

Walk across the street to Donut Bite Lab for a better experience. Better yet, find your way to a Blue Star Donut

If you are a tourist, stick it out...  you can tell your friends you ate a maple bar with bacon on it.

Meh... this is more of a Portland novelty than really good doughnuts. Don't get me wrong, I've definitely brought home my fair share of pink boxes, but usually it's for a house full of teenagers. We host a lot of family and friends from out of town and they inevitably always want to go here... ok. We oblige. But we take them for the experience... to say they've been to VooDoo Doughnuts. There's nothing inside that's worth waiting in that monstrous line for... it's just meh. If you want to say you've been... great. If you want to feed a bunch of young people who don't have a discerning palette, ok. If you want really incredible doughnuts, skip VooDoo and head to... (I won't call out another business in my review of this). Let's just say there are better doughnuts in town... Google it!

If you are looking for the best donut in town - don't go  here.  If you are looking for short lines and good prices - don't go here.  Voodoo Donut is a staple in Portland and it's definitely a must-go place if you haven't been at least once.  It's hard to beat their creative donut concoctions.  Where else can you get the "Old Dirty Bastard"?  A donut cakes with oreo bits and peanut butter?  Or the "Grape Ape" whose name speaks for itself?

Those who love a simple, pure donuts will not like this place (Go to Annie's instead) but if you are looking for a unique experience and original recipies, this is where you should go.  Expect long lines and not so friendly service.  Prices aren't cheap either.  It's all about managing your expectations before you go!
I'll make this short. Parking fees, very long lines, overrated doughnuts, I'm good. Worth visiting once.

Ehhh....doughnuts were so-so.  We didn't really go for those, though so...  The line moved quickly and it was all about the experience. The place was pretty interesting inside and the employees scream "Portland"  That part was fun!  I do think the guy who took our order didn't give a crap and clearly is over the crowds of tourists cycling through the shop all day.   A twenty minute wait was cool, but I wouldn't wait much more beyond that.

The ambiance at Voodoo Doughnut is amusing--a voodoo theme and loud music. They have a variety of vegan doughnuts, and I've always found something I like. It's a good local place to take out-of-town visitors.
They're quirky, but overall okay... Not worth waiting in line for. Go to blue star instead!
Genial

One of those places you need to stop by and check out when here in Portland but meh.. sorry guys... 

The names are hysterical 
The voodoo doughnut with pretzel needle was therapeutic for one of my kiddies... 
The bacon maple bar was a disappointment *cringes for doughnut being thrown at head* 

For folks from the San Jose, CA area it is like Psychodonuts but less PC (yes such a place exists). 

Maybe I got the wrong thing or maybe getting them in the earlier part of the morning is better than the night... *shrugs* 

Cash only!

Tourist trap with mediocre donuts and usually poor service too. Not worth it even if there isn't a huge line. Portland has much better donut shops, like Blue Star, that are much more deserving of your patronage.

The Disneyland of donuts, this place usually has a 1 hour line for a 5 minute ride.

I love shops that have a lot of character and originality and this place fits the bill.  Donuts are extremely creative but the level of taste didn't necessarily meet the level of creativity.  Still worth visiting at least once though.

We had some time to kill waiting for the Farmer's Market to open so  decided to wait in the long line. I got a donut. It didn't taste fresh and I felt that back home, Judy's donuts are a thousand times better. I took one small bite of the Vooddoo donut I waited so long for and threw it away b/c it wasn't worth the calories --it's tasted so old & blah. I read a review before going to this place that said basically this is a long wait for just a donut and that is very true. I wish I'd listened, but I got sucked into the hype.

I was so excited to have a doughnut from VooDoo Doughnut. I had seen people with their to-go boxes throughout Portland. I'll blame it on the overrated hype but I was not impressed at all. In fact, I threw some of mine away. I thought Krispy Kreme has had VooDoo beat on their worst day, in fact I think I might even prefer Dunkin Donuts.
I don't get what the hype is about. Huge doughnuts. Big deal. The interior of this place is lacking all things usually associated with doughnuts. Whatevs....
Great tourist attraction. Tourist's love this place. Lines of tourist's often go around the block!
Wasn't a huge fan, the ideas behind the donuts are fun but the flavor and freshness could use some revamping. Fun for out of towners though.

The doughnuts here are okay, lots of topping choices and flavors but they really aren't THAT special as all the flavors are something you've had before but they are just on a doughnut.  At the same time, you almost have to visit because it's practically a landmark of Portland and it's nice that it's open 24/7.  If you can, go during off hours to keep the wait at a minimum and the area isn't as bad as some people make it out to be; those bums that are sometimes around are probably vegan... they wouldn't eat a fly.

SO overhyped and gimicky. I don't understand why people like these doughnuts... I would much rather go to Dunkin Donuts than ever come back. It is most definitely NOT worth the wait. I got the voodoo doll, glazed old fashioned and old dirty bastard. All of them were super dry and tasted weird. My bf and I both took one bite of each and didn't want to even take another bite. I normally love old fashioned doughnuts but this one had a weird medicinal taste. What a disappointment.
Have you eaten a good donut before? Politely move along. This is not worth your time.
Low quality. Don't waste your time. Have gone to a few locations and just generally don't reccommend it anymore.

Visited Portland for the first time and had to go to Voodoo. Had heard amazing things about this place and the long lines outside suggested that these doughnuts would be worth the wait. Honestly, after all the hoopla, they didn't really live up to the hype. Doughnuts were above average for sure but I went in expecting something  mind blowingly delicious. I would take Top Pot or Krispy Kreme over these any day
Most overrated donuts on earth. Stale crappy quality donuts that all the tourists fawn over because they have cereal on top or a slice of nasty, old bacon.

Don't see what all the fuss is about.  I've had better doughnuts at Dunkin'.

Ok, so let me preface this review by saying that I've had couture doughnuts in Chicago; at both Doughnut Vault and the now defunct City Provisions, so my expectations were in line with those when I heard about Voodoo Doughnuts.  I also gave my self a reality check by telling myself that even though they are open all night, this is a Portland institution that Portlanders love, so it couldn't be worse than Dunkin'.

So we went in the morning.  Like 8-9am.  I expected that the doughnuts be at least fresh and warm and delicious.   But I was wrong.  Doughnuts were in a carousal, all cold, and plunked on a napkin.  Luckily, I got a vegan doughnut which used pumpkin and banana instead of eggs but was way too sweet. That was original and deserves a solid 4 if it was only fresh.  

But the sticky point is that my friend got the only doughnut that came "fresh" from the oven.  He had eaten only half  before finding the center wasn't cooked.  To his horror, by the end of the day, he started to throw up. 

Yea, this place has the 24 hour thing going for them.  It has the trendy cereal as toppings going for them.  But let's not get overly carried away saying this is any better than the chain donuts shop.  Its a "fast found donut shop," not a true taste pushing doughnut shop.

My first time visiting Portland and I was recommended to check this place out. Was fascinated by the long line, glitter brick walls and pinkbox packaging. The long line went by fairly quickly so that was cool.  Donuts are super affordable and definitely appreciate the pricing is what a donut is expected to be. The donuts are very elaborate and have amazing personality but after the bite, not much can be said. Decor is awesome, service is okay but sad to say, one is lured in by classic commericial hype. One donut was fine... No need to return for more. Recommended for kids given it is a colorful and elaborate environment with sugary goodies all around! But for parents - have one and your done.  Many thanks!

Really, the only thing we knew about Portland was Voodoo Doughnuts and the quirkiness shown in Portlandia. Sorry, we're from Chicago, but those were the only two things we even knew about Oregon in general. So when we got to Portland, the number one thing on the list was Voodoo Doughnuts. We knew it was a tourist trap going in, but I didn't expect it to be this bad.

The line was not tremendously long, but we did have to wait in the rain for about five minutes before we were allowed inside. That's understandable- it's hyped up, and there has to be some wait even on an early Sunday morning. When we got in, we saw what we had seen on the shows before: the decor, the atmosphere, and, of course, the doughnuts.

The service was nice, and we got out quickly despite the immense wait we saw. We didn't really know what we wanted, but we picked whatever we saw that looked appealing to some groggy travelers.

Fast forward to the hotel, where we started eating the donuts. The first thing that overcame our senses was staleness and loads of sugar. The shop is open 24/7, so the donuts were clearly about a couple days old. They had the texture of about a day old munchkin from Dunkin Donuts, not so hard as a rock but just hard enough to make anyone be like "woah, this is stale." The sugar was another big problem. One donut alone probably had all of the sugar recommended in a daily diet. The recipe must have called for one bag of sugar per donut. To top it off, the donuts gave me E-Coli, not a fun thing to have when you're driving down the 101 South through the redwoods.

So, I guess it boils down to "Would I come back if I was back in Portland?" And that answer is a definite no. Maybe I'm being a bit biased because of the fact I got sick from the batch of donuts I ate, but the donuts were NOT worth the hype or money spent on them. Their aesthetic is pleasing, and I can see why it got popular, but something went drastically wrong when we were there. Overall, I give a 1.5/5, but I rounded up to be nice!

This is a well known institution so I came in with high expectations.  The dough and frying are not exceptional, but they do have some inventive combinations and risque donut names.  The donuts themselves are sweet and reasonable, but in terms of the basics, Krispy Kreme is better.  The clerk is helpful and friendly, and the location is trendy and convenient.

Spent the weekend in Portland and had heard Voodoo Doughnut had all these crazy donuts, one of which was a bacon maple bar.  I had to see what all the rage was about.  I went on a Sunday late morning and there was a line snaking along the front.  After standing and waiting in line for about 20 min watching customer after customer come out of the store with a large pink box of doughnuts and smiles on their face I realized the signs that read CASH ONLY.  Seriously?  This was a surprise to many as they came close to entering.  Luckily there is an ATM, so you can eat the bank fees on top of your treats.  

Once inside, the cashier was simply not in the mood to be there. The doughnut options are spinning in displays but nothing to indicate what they are exactly.  Luckily there were a few floating menus out front, none of which made it to me, and an app online to read the selections beforehand.  The list is long, the options are so bizarre they require serious study, and frankly my memory is not THAT good.  I refuse to pay ATM fees and limited my order to whatever cash we had on hand the few doughnut options I was able to remember.  The price tag is appropriate for an over-sized popular novelty at the level of your run of the mill tourist trap.  

The result, good doughnut.  Seemed fresh from that morning, they were nice and doughy inside.  I'm glad I came, but I don't need to return.  I come to Portland often and this will not be a regular stop.  The parts that stuck with me the most: long line; poor customer service; high price tag; and a business more interested in avoiding taxes than offering the convenience of accepting credit cards to their customers.  I know for me, I would've bought way more than necessary and charged it rather than work within the limits of cash in my pocket.

The pricing is what saves them. I got the Miami Vice donut which is basically a plain glazed donut with some colored frosting and I believe a total was around $2.75. The "traditional old fashion" donuts are heavier than expected so they definitely aren't light and fluffy like Krispy Kreme, but they are not as heavy as cake Donuts. It's a good mix and will keep you full for at least more than 8 minutes if you're trying to hold yourself over until your next meal. The batter itself isn't super sweet which I can appreciate a lot of the sweetness comes from the icing only.

 It's a cash-only establishment and they have an ATM. The line is always at the door so be prepared to wait and keep in mind the line waiting are is outside and uncovered so if it's raining you're doomed. I found the donuts at Blue Star Donuts to be a lot tastier but they're also more expensive.

Have heard about Voodoo for years. We finally stopped by to see what it's all about. We bought a box and needed to leave with one each for the road. 1) Voodoo man w/jelly filling and 2) fruit loop donut. 

It was a creative and unique donut. However, aside from the creativity I didn't feel it lived up to the hype. If your looking for something fun to eat. I would definitely recommend checking this place out. If your a foodie you will probably move on to the next place.

Totally over-hyped and I can't believe I actually waited an hour to get 3 donuts.  We got the Portland Cream, McMinnville Cream and the bacon maple bar.  The highlight of the trio was definitely the bacon maple bar, which doesn't come cheap at $3 a piece.  This is one of those places that you go once, just to say you did.

Voodoo Doughnut is one of those places where you'd take your out of town friends to visit. The doughnut itself is okay. There's nothing spectacular about the quality of the donuts. The wait for a single doughnut is not worth my time. You are essentially paying for the artwork. With that being said, here are other reasons WHY I would go to Voodoo: 1) Instagram worthy, 2) open late, 3) satisfy the drunk cravings.

(First timer tip): I don't particularly enjoy stale cereal on my doughnut, so I avoid everything with cereal. Other than that, pick something that is worthy of Snapchat/Instagram.

I brought a family member here during their visit to the NW- as it is of course an 'iconic' Portland establishment.  It was my first time trying Voodoo too.
Let's just say that the donuts were so sweet we both found them nearly inedible.  
And, there was a nice little bug baked into the batter of my donut.  
If you are having a donut craving, there are much better donut shops in town.  Try Blue Star donuts for starters.

In all was just ok.  The unusual doughnuts were too strange for my taste and most were too sweet.  I would have given a third star, but the customer service sucks!  The line was super long and when I finally got there, the hippy looking, grunge dude with the tattoos helped me.  He was impatient cause I didnt notice he said, "next".  Then he rolled his eyes at me cause I was asking him questions about the doughnuts,  no smile, no thank you, just handed me the doughnuts and that was it!  Not sure if it was cause I seemed like a tourist, which I was or maybe he was racist cause im asian, but for whatever reason, he was very rude!  Wouldn't go back, unless there was a different guy and no line.  I only liked one out of the many doughnuts I tried.  The peanut butter, Oreo doughnut was not bad, still a little too much though.  Could have been a better experience.

Voodoo is fun but overrated! It's best with a group of friends and at night. They're a bit expensive but what do you expect? They are a legend. Overall, they're something everyone has to do a couple of times, but I'll personally stick to Krispy Kreme.

Not the best donuts I have had here.
Lots of sugar, and fun designs.
Long lines and mildly pricey.
Definitely a tourist point.

Definitely a popular place that you can tell by the long line of people in front.  A cool place and they have some unique donuts but that's about it.  Although they have a great presentation the donuts themselves taste below average. They must have been sitting on the shelf for a while because the donuts were stale and same goes for the cereal on top.  Total bummer.

Good donuts but a little overrated in my opinion. The maple bacon bar and cock-n-balls are favorites but the line is always ridiculous. 

One time a guy I was with had to use the restroom and the employee insisted he wait in line and buy something first (even though he was with a group that was in line and he was planning to buy a donut). I understand the policy, but when the line is crazy long I feel like exceptions could be made for well-meaning people. He definitely didn't deserve the level of rudeness he received. 

Basically, if you really like donuts or don't get to Portland much it's worth a visit. Or you could just go buy a normal donut and buy some cereal to stick to it and call it a day.

Quite honestly, I'm not sure why people wait in line for 30 minutes for the donuts. I just picked up a dozen today, and was not that impressed. They throw on unique toppings like M&Ms, oreos, etc. but that doesn't make them exceptional. Note that they are cash only also, which could be annoying for those who have credit.

I think that they have so much volume that they try to cycle people through quickly. They try to rush your order through to move the line, which is understandable, but not a great experience.

I'd pass next time I'm in town, but am glad that I got to stop by and experience the hype.

Go if it is your first time in Portland. But there are far better local options, like Blue Star and Pips, where they actually care about your questions and customer experience. Server was super rude last time. I feel like the place has gone downhill in the last few years in terms of service and inventiveness, and I used to be a fan.

I debated on giving this a two or a three. I've always wanted to go to Voodoo's doughnut that everyone talks about. I even expected the long wait which to my surprise was none! But the service was terrible. The guy giving us the "voodoo picks" was rude and we got mostly doughnuts with stale cereal toppings. Not even the voodoo doughnut or any good toppings like bacon I see a lot of online. Make sure you pick your own selection when going.

Not really worth the line,  I got a Oreo doughnut and the oreas  were stale,maple bacon doughnut was good but everything else had too much frosting.  I asked for a gay bar doughnut and I they gave me a Christmas one instead.  People seem to like it so if you have never been worth going to at least once just for the experience, after that to me it gets old.  I rather just eat a doughnut because it taste good it does not have to be and special shapes or colors.
Like Powells, it's part of Portland. The donuts are okay. Usually the staff is very nice.

Came on Christmas Eve when it was lightly snowing and there was no line. Walked right in and got to order immediately.

The server was so rude. We just asked if he could make a recommendation but he told us just to get the mystery dozen and he would pick them. He wouldn't tell us what the donut prices were, and when I asked him to tell us what he put in the box, he just opened the box and asked us if that was good. I asked him again if he could tell us what each was (maybe I wasn't specific enough??) and he said that the donuts are what they look like. .... ok, jerk. Happy holidays to you too. 

The donuts are good but if I'm not in a position to learn about them because of dietary restrictions we have, I'm not comfortable coming back again.

Real conversation #1, waiting in line:

Jasmine L.:  Do you know what you're going to order?
Julie:  We're going to order the c&b to share.
Jasmine L.:  What is it?
Julie:  It's a big doughnut shaped like c&b, covered in chocolate and filled with thick triple cream
Jasmine L.:  .....  Oh, I see... [provocative voice] Do you usually share?
Julie:  No, but this time we will.  I couldn't finish one.
Shun:  [provocative voice]  Me neither.  I've never had a black one before.  Sharing will make it interesting.
Scott:  [quietly laughs]


Real conversation #2, opening big pink box:

Julie:  Whoa this is HUGE.  It's like... 10 inches... It looks delicious!  I like them big.
Shun:  It's so big I don't even know where to start.
Julie:  [starts at the tip]  Mmmmm... this tastes soo good!
Shun:  [takes a bite out of the base]  Mmmmm... this does tastes good!
Jasmine L.:  Scott would you like some?
Julie:  Scott is new to this.  This is his first time.  Scott are you open minded enough to try?
Scott:  [quietly laughs]


It's hard to not have a sexually charged conversation when "enjoying" the c&b doughnut...  Now, I have a hard time typing it out in my review, but others have not been shy to spell out what c&b really is... and if you're "creative" enough, you probably already figured it out.

Overrated trash served out of a tourist stuffed cubbyhole. Nothing but trite dull designed and dick jokes here. Stank willows through the air as several dozens of sweaty tourists, stale stagnating half eaten doughnuts, and some of the gnarliest hobos of the waterfront all mix into one endless black pit of sorrow.

Not sure what the hype is about.  My objectivity here is that I did not actually visit the Voodoo premises.  This review is based on the doughnuts Artie schlepped from PDX to Gresham for Vero's birthday.   

Yes, the doughnuts have a creative (some folks might say odd) appearance (e.g. sprinkled with Oreos or Fruit Loops), but are no better in flavor and texture than doughnuts from Krispy Kreme.  

And they are not as good as those from the Spudnut Shop in Richland.

While I love a cock and balls donut as much as the next person, these are not my favorite.  A little too heavy and sugary for me.  That said, I get it.  Voodoo Doughnuts exists for a higher purpose than just cranking out doughnuts.  They are a great social equalizer, they give people something to laugh about, and provide visitors to Portland with a mission.  I know they will never be gluten free, vegan health food, but they make me laugh.  So while I don't eat them on a day to day basis, I am invested in their continued existence. So if you are visiting Portland- stop in, have a snickers doughnut, it is definitely an experience!

All the hype...all the hoopla..and the people saying this is a must. I didn't mind the 15/20 minute wait. Good things come to those that wait. I made sure to go early in the morning for an out   the oven taste. I give them credit for trying to be creative but can it at least be fresh!!! I came early for a fresh doughnut and it tasted like it was made the day before. Doughnut Plant in NYC puts this place to shame...hell even krispey kremes got that melt in your mouth goodness right. It was like dunkin doughnuts with stale cereal on it.

Okay, another blasphemous post. I honestly don't find this place amazing. Their doughnuts taste like any other doughnut you can find. Maybe even slightly less quality. They're fancy, yes. Maybe that's why they're famous. But the cuteness of the doughnuts don't justify the 30-40 min wait you do standing in line to pick out your overpriced goodies. I think they're overhyped and now every tourist needs to go experience it. And since all of their donuts are covered in cereal or pretty or shaped like penises, people get a thrill out of it.

But the quality just isn't there. I've only tried them once, however. I never have come back because that one experience didn't wow me enough to want to spend another half hour of my life in line for doughnuts that I could get with a better taste elsewhere. Or you know what? Just down the street there's a stand that sells delicious beignets as well. 

But I have to admit, the fancy doughnuts are a little legend and they are themed prettily enough that you should at least go try them once to see for yourself what the hype is about.

Fun looking place. Donuts are not any better than fresh donuts from any bakery that makes them fresh.  They have some unique donuts with sour candy powder or sugared cereal if that's what you want. They are known for their Maple Bacon donut, but I've had way better elsewhere.
Doughnuts are OK, Both Portland locations are always busy, we heard about them from a TV show a few years ago.

You really have to ask yourself why you're going to Voodoo. Katy H NAILED it in her review - if this is your first trip to Portland, if you watch a bunch of Food Network shows or Anthony Bourdain, or you just like waiting in line for 15 minutes for donuts, then Voodoo Donuts is a can't miss. Otherwise? Meh.

This place is all about the experience, from the loud punk music playing while you wait to  a cherry-filled voodoo doll with a stake in his heart to the "Good things come in pink boxes" to go box. The donuts are creative, but really aren't spectacular. The maple bacon bar has had dried out bacon each time I've gone, the Fruit Loops on the Fruit Loop donut were on the stale side and buttermilk donut was, uh, a buttermilk donut. The only thing I really thought was extraordinary was the chocolate/peanut butter/fried banana fritter creation I got. Toss in fresh Stumptown coffee and you've got a sugary caffeine high for the morning, but meh.

Did I mention it's cash only? Go do it once, post pics on Yelp, Instagram and Facebook, and then go explore the wonderful neighborhood breakfast places that make Portland AWESOME.

This should be a one time only experience. It's kind of like the local thing to do and seeing penis donuts is pretty fun. The downside? They aren't fresh whatsoever. I can get better quality donuts at a gas station, truly. The interior is funky, they aren't that expensive but expect to wait in a line for at least 30 minutes for one of the most sub-par donuts of your life.

If you like your fried sugar bombs with a side of Satanism than this is the place for you.  Very loud, heavy metal music, vulgar anatomical doughnuts, employees were cranky &  the day we visited was sporting an upside down pentagram on his shirt.  Refused to give us a plastic knife or  to cut our doughnut in half.  The doughnut itself was ok, but the atmosphere, not so much.  Not going back.

This is definitely a tourist place.  The surrounding area alone is "interesting".  We had to wait about 45 min and were able to do some people watching.  The donuts were ok.  I think they were over the top sweet but the experience of going to this place was the best!  We ordered the Mafia donut, Portland cream, and the apple fritter.  The apple fritter was good and the Portland cream was good too.  The Mafia was too sweet & I like sweet but this was just too much!

Okay, these donuts aren't like phenomenally good. I think primarily these donuts are gonna satiate your drunken state in the middle of the night after the bar has closed. At night, there's barely a wait. Not sure when the donuts are made but they were still fresh! But they aren't gourmet donuts. These donuts are just gimmickly designed and I love that -- but not like, "I gotta have these donuts," donuts. You know what I mean?

I really like their designs and coming from out of town, I got just that. There's several locations, so I say still check them out cuz they put Portland on the map of places to visit by being Voodoo Doughnuts. And they were the ones who started the pink donut boxes. They're still revolutionary donuts and now everyone else is following in their footsteps.

I don't get the hype (as far as taste in concerned) but they do have some creative (read unique looking) doughnuts.  We ordered a box and they were soggy by the time we got home 2 hours later.  The doughnuts themselves were dense; I personally prefer fluffier doughnuts.  It's decent but would not be my first choice.
Somewhat above-average, frequently gimmicky donuts beloved by tourists and dismissed with a sarcastic eyeroll by natives.

It's just an overhyped donut shop, definitely not work the half hour wait. 

Their donuts are regular donuts, but with sensationalist names like "Cock and Balls" and unconventional toppings like Fruit Loops. 

Their staff were kind of rude too. When I asked for recommendations, the lade just spurt out 5 different names in 1 second, with absolutely no intention of me understanding anything she said. I think my response was "umm... the first one you said."

If you want a REAL gourmet donut, come to San Francisco's Dynamo Donuts.
Wow. Don't believe the hype. Mediocre doughnuts that are way more interested in "wacky" combinations than in quality or taste.

Tasty donuts worth eating, but certainly not worth waiting in line for. Instead, check out any of the other doughnut shops in town...there are so many to choose from that there's no need to waste your time waiting in line. After all, it is just a doughnut.

This is more of a tourist destination than an actual place you would want to have really good donuts. Had to go see it for myself but they did not appeal to me and I would not wait in that line. I recommend you go and take your pics and then head to a real donut shop.

Our walking tour ended across the street from VooDoo Doughnuts, and while we weren't too hungry, decided we needed to try one, especially since the line wasn't wrapped around the block like usual. We ordered the Dirty Old Bastard - it was inexpensive, better than your average donut, but nothing out of this world.
Tasted like glorified safeway donuts

Though I hardly have a sweet tooth, I wanted to order their donuts for the first time specifically because of their dessert idea and presentation. Even their exterior building had a unique and slight sinister appearance which made it somewhat enjoyable to look being the fact that the wait was ridiculously long. However, I don't think I would go there again as my first experience was ample and their donuts were adequate.

Tasted like regular donuts , don't know what the hype about this place is? The line was pretty long and there was a homeless dude singing and whistling about donuts outside and some very nice people gave him a donut. Being from the bay, some locals talked trash about us "tourists" while we were waiting in line. 
I don't think I'd try this place out again. The downtown location was kinda gloomy and it wasn't  worth the wait and they only took cash.
Overall, the employees were very nice and patient with everyone. Good experience to try once.

If you're ever in Portland, make sure to stop by Voodoo's. It was more of an attraction in Portland for me to visit just to say "I've been there". Although each donut looks unique, personally, I thought the donuts were all hype. The quality of donuts are definitely lower than the quality of donuts at Blue Star, but Voodoo's does have a selection of donuts that you don't find at your typical donut shop. Prices of the donuts are $2-3 each and some of the flavors of donuts available are maple bacon, "grape ape", bubble gum, and mango. 

I probably won't be going back to Voodoo's if I were in town but I think it's definitely worth a visit for those who have never been there. It's a pink themed donut shop with its own super unique character and I think it's worth the new experience because you don't find a donut shop like this one just anywhere!

This place makes sub par donuts and names them after demons. The owner is an affirmed pagan who admits to those who ask, which I did while I was there waiting in a two hour line for a donut, that he enchants donuts with magic spells. Psycho. The employees are no less insane or rude.

Long lines and crazy donuts. I only came to pick some up for a friend and waited about 20 minutes, any longer and I would've left. I guess it's cool to try, but it isn't that great. The donuts are Wayyyyyyy too sweet!!! You would have to have a low threshold for sugar or something not to think so. I picked up a dozen of the assorted donuts, tried the bacon and maple one and that was probably the best one. I prefer Krispy kremes over this any day

Is this place a tourist trap? Yes. Is it worth the stop by ? Yes. Generally the donuts are overly sweet, however the plethora of options is impressive. I've  tried many  but the BEST are the Old Dirty Bastard (oreo and peanut butter), Memphis Mafia (banana, peanut butter, cinnamon sugar,) and the Maple Bacon Bar.

Today's date is the 4th of February. I was in there today around 1:30. I took a friend from Utah to experience one of Portland's treasures. Well so called treasures. We were yelled at and treated like total shit by a women with short black hair running the cash register.  I've never been treated to rudely before in my life. We waited in the rain for a stupid doughnut that wasn't that great anyway. Almost all the workers in that shop was rude. I was embarrassed to even bring my friend there. I will never go there ever again and I will not send anyone there. She was the biggest bitch to ever work in the food service industry and her male counterpart with the ring in his nose was not much better. Plus he was sick and coughing everywhere. What a joke of a place.

I had to visit the "Famous" doughnut shop during my latest visit to Portland.  After all, there really isn't much to do when in Portland anyways, so why not binge on sugery fried dough!

Food:  The variety of doughnuts is interesting and unique.  I really like how they had a mix of re-invented classics and some unequal ones.  I picked up Voodoo Dolls, Portland Creams, and a few Bacon Maple Bars.  The taste combinations of each were good, but way overly sugary and sweet.  The Voodoo Dolls are your basic bar doughnut with chocolate icing and raspberry filling.  The filling was too sweet and I ended up squeezing out about half of it to make it more palatable.  The Portland Cream had more of a sugary icing filling (I was expecting more of a custard, pastry-cream type of filling) that was also too sweet.  After a few bites of it, I squeezed just about all the cream out of it.  The Bacon Maple Bar has potential with some tweaking.  The doughnut itself was good, the maple icing was too sweet, and the bacon was not "bacony" or salty enough.  There just was not that strong sweet and salty contrast I was expecting.  The gimmick of the different types of doughnuts is fun, but the regular donuts you find at Krispy Kream or at any regular coffee shop would probably be more palatable.

Price:  Overpriced considering its doughnuts, but you are paying for the novelty of it.  I bought 9 doughnuts and paid about $20 for them.  The price is reasonable if you are a onetime visitor who is into the gimmick and novelty of the strange and unique doughnut combinations, the definitely too expensive for your daily "doughnut and coffee" breakfast.

Atmosphere:  Super touristy, but fun.  I went on a cold, rainy afternoon midweek and the line was out the door.  Once you got inside, the pink walls are covered with voodoo-related posters and other touristy looking things.  There is a huge menu board up front, and two turn table displays that have donuts displayed on them.  The glass turn table units look very dirty and disgusting (I hope they don't actually serve the doughnuts that are in them.)  The glass was covered with all sorts of different substances, as if it has not been cleaned in quick awhile.  Since this is one of the first things you see when you walk it, Voodoo Doughnuts should take more care of keeping it clean.

Staff:  Pretty basic staff with not much personality or friendliness.  Yes, they were covered with tattoos and piercings, but looking physically interesting does not make up for the lack of a simple smile.  The cashier by the door was constantly yelling at people to keep the front door closed.  When it was my turn to order, I was greeted with a "what do you want?"
