Being cheery as I am, I smiled and said hello to the cashier, which normally invokes a smile in return, but that didn't happen this time.  The cashier was accommodating though when I requested to have all my doughnuts placed in a smaller box (I'm traveling and don't have the room to carry the bigger box around.)  She did warn me that the doughnuts will get smashed a bit, but I said that was fine.  She did look like she took some care putting them in the box to minimize smashing.

Over all, it was an experience visiting Voodoo.  As a first timer to Portland, it is definitely a place to visit just to say you have been there.  If the lines were not too long, and the doughnuts where not so sweet I might visit it again (but only if I am really craving a doughnut.)  If I return to Portland I would probably not go out of my way to visit Voodoo again, but definitely a spot to visit as a first timer.

Donuts with stale cereal on it really isn't worth the wait or the ATM fee. Do not get me wrong, in college this was so great for midnight Portland runs. However as a city dweller now, I am embarrassed for people that set foot near this place. There are so many great donut joints in Portland. This one is not one of them. Let the tourists and suburbanites wait it out so they can get the picture with the pink box. Everyone else go to Coco Donuts, Blue Star, or Pip's. Heck go to your local grocery store, they probably have fresher options.

this place is the definition of 'hyped up'. 
always a line.
the donuts taste normal other that crazy designs made of extra frosting. too much if you ask me. ill stick to my normal donuts.
i liked the normal glazed. and the oreo cookie donut.

This shit is fucking stupid. I'm tired of the bullshit. It actually pisses me off. Novelty donuts piss me off. I normally don't give a shit about much, but this really does bother me. When I get looked at like an asshole for asking for a simple cake donut with white icing then fuck it. Fuck fancy donuts. I don't think they are special, cool or good-tasting. And I wouldn't care except that the emphasis on bullshit seems to have the effect of crowding out the delicious basic donuts that I want (or maybe those are the ones people actually buy while all the yeah-we're-weird-and-in-Portland-and-have-been-on-TV-so-we're-cool-cool-enough-in-fact-to-feel-warranted-acting-real-high-and-mighty-just-cause-we're-standing-at-this-particular-minimum-wage-counter-all-day novelty ones end up in the day old bargain bucket). Fuck you for making me choose between a cake donut with white icing and coconut on it or no donut at all. Forget those toppings! 
Donut. Icing. Done. That's it. Leave the cereal in the bowl and the attitude anywhere else. I hope someday you figure out what's holding you back from being an actual human being and start behaving with some god damn decency.

the donut I got wasn't very good. it was purple and I picked it because I felt rushed and the girl who had a short pixie cut and black lipstick, didn't explain a single thing and didn't help whatsoever. she just stared at me as if I was supposed to know what I wanted, and when I asked she was very rude. my boyfriend got the Homer Simpson (and we only knew the name because it was labeled) which was very good. so basically, my donut was gross, his donut was good but the service sucked.
Crazy toppings, but just normal donuts underneath.  On the plus side, with so much turnover they always seem very fresh.

What an overrated place. Other than our stop at Voodoo, we had a great time in Portland. The reason we stopped by was we were at the Saturday Market next block and my wife saw this big line. Both of us are Donut fans so without much thought we joined the big line.

Our first shocker came at how rude the serving lady was. She was the only rude person we met on our entire trip. I am personally very impressed by how fun and laid back Portland people are. My wife told her that this was her first time at Voodoo and asked what their most famous donuts were. The server just made a very fed up face as if she would rather be somewhere else before giving a very generic 'depends on what you like' response.

Anyways, after we bought the donuts, we were shocked to find them completely cold. Who goes to a donut shop to eat cold donuts?! Also, both the donuts we tried (Portland Cream and Raspberry Romeo) were absolute rubbish even though we were starving. 

We loved Portland and every other restaurant or food-cart we ate at. Voodoo was the only and surprising disappointment given the line. Maybe they were just having a bad day. But we are never going back. 

Sidenote - the best Doughnuts we have had were at Gourdough's Donuts in Austin, Tx
Donuts are on the sweet side.  Service is not particularly good.

A tourist stop if you are looking for something unique to Portland. But if you are looking for flavor, find another donut shop. This place is hyped up for it's fun donut shapes and unique mash-ups. Cereal, cookies, peanut butter, m&m's and more all topping these donuts. It's fun but too much and too heavy. The donut themselves are not that great either. Don't waste your time waiting in line if you're goal is to get a great donut. If you're here for a gimmicky donut, then this is the place for you.

It's okay but I WILL ADMIT ONE THING THAT THESE ARE INDEED UNIQUE DONUTS. I think it's just the appearance though. 

Just cuz it looks differently designed doesn't make it any better than a lot of donut shops. 

If they do a crime brûlée one, then yes I'd get my ass down there in a second but since you don't. Naw. 

The apple juice you got there was pretty good though low key

Hype is one thing.  Unjustified hype is something else entirely.

My parents live in Portland, and so when I went to visit them, I was told to go try Voodoo Donuts.  I have to admit, I'd actually heard of the place from random people saying how great it was and all that.

So I went, and while the shop itself was very eclectic-looking and had a nice hipster vibe, the donuts were just whatever.  My gf and I got some donut with cereal flakes and stuff on it.  Not good at all.  The cereal part seemed a little stale and the donuts themselves were oversweet.  I thought maybe I just caught them on a bad day, but when a friend of mine went months later and had the same experience, I knew it wasn't just me.

I don't even know if I'd go so far as to call the donuts even 'good'.  Granted, I'm not much of a sweets fan in the first place, but I do enjoy a good donut from time to time, but I'm sure any mom & pop donut shop on any corner in America could probably serve you up a better donut than the ones you get at Voodoo.  Sure, Voodoo's got some weird flavor combinations and stuff, but who gives a crap if none of them taste any good?
Good donuts. Not worth the wait in line though. Not sure what all the hype is about. Worth trying once.

The Dish: I might be a bit biased because I don't have the hugest sweet tooth, but the 1-hour wait was not worth it. I think the voodoo doll is worth it but the Voodoo dozen - no. First of all, don't be stupid like we were - don't try to split 13 donuts (dozen + voodoo doll) between 2 people. Also, if you are, be ready to eat them so you don't throw them all away after 4 days because you can't finish them. The flavors are interesting, but nothing that made me like donuts any more or less. My friend warned me that it wasn't anything special - I wish I believed her.

Ambience: It's really hip and hipster (just like the rest of Portland).

Overrated, overrated, and overrated.
Doughnuts are just doughnuts. They look colorful and unique but there's nothing special when it comes to flavor. 
One star is for their ghetto cashier. She was playing a game with her smartphone while we're paying.

I went to Voodoo Doughnut after reading all the hype and reviews over the years, since it's been on Food Network and Travel Channel.

People in the long line were ecstatic and acting like we were going to eat some heavenly treats..

I came in after about a 20 minute late that went down the street, I went through the menu items (bacon on donuts, cereal on donuts, funky frosted were some of their novelty donuts).

I honestly thought there  was something super special about their donuts, at least they offer vegan donuts - however I honestly don't think besides being super thick and well-glazed donuts (I got a dirt donut, marshall mathers, / rapper's delight with  some vegan donuts). I liked the amusing names and a twist on several donuts.

I felt like it was over hyped, I won't say overrated since it's a unique experience. I feel like I should of went to one of their other locations to avoid such a long line. You would think for being such a famous donut shop they'd accept credit cards.. It's Cash Only.

I think the sign down the street from Voodoo Doughnuts explains it best, PORTLAND IS WEIRD.
Eh, a good place to trap the tourist who come to visit Portland.

"the tourist thing to do": in otherwords overrated and overcrowded.   People wait in line hours for these donuts which are sugarbombs.  The flavors are more kitchen-sink than subtle.  Yes I tried one and it was tasty, but I had to come back a few times to avoid the mobs.   Surrounded by homeless asking for change, you will feel guilty for dropping $ on these unhealthy items while everyone starves outside the window.   There is another sophisticated donut shop in town that far better impressed me, this place is for flash.  However it is something to do if you don't have to wait more than a few minutes.

Voodoo Doughnut is a lot more fun than it actually is good. For example, the excitement of waiting in line for your Old Dirty Bastard Doughnut outweighs the actual taste and quality of the doughnut. It's definitely still something I recommend doing once in your life because how fun the actual store is. For me, the feeling of the bakery is better than what you're actually buying. The theme got this place it's second star.

I'm not sure if this is the best donut shop ever, but it definitely gets 5 stars for being the coolest donut shop ever. The place itself is extremely small. Basically, it's order your donuts and get out. There isn't any room inside to chill and have a donut. When it comes to donuts, I'm old fashion, so I tend to like the classics. That is why I decided to try the Portland cream donut, which I found out was the official donut of Portland. The donut was pretty yummy.

If you're going to go here, go on a Saturday so you can at least enjoy the Saturday market after waiting almost an hour in line for these donuts  we came here on a Saturday afternoon and the line was about an hour long. We couldn't decide which voodoo location to go to but decided to go to the original one. The donuts were good but I wouldn't wait an hour to get these again. There are just too many good donut places in Los Angeles where I don't have to wait this long. It's also quite dirty inside but the workers were so great! They are genuinely friendly and try to make the best of your experience with them. While waiting in line though it just smelled like trash and weed. I'd recommend ordering some food or drink at the food carts across the street so you can munch on something while you try and get through this line.

Most of the people who have been here have instead recommended Blue Star donuts (which they have insisted is far better and recommended by the locals). Maybe we'll try this place if we ever come back here.

I know this is will come off as anti-Portland, but Voodoo is not that great. I get it, they have really off doughnuts. However, they're not that good. The batter isn't anything to write home about and I don't want a doughnut covered in fruit loops.

I will say, the Bacon Maple Bar is okay. I guess check it out if you're not from Portland.... but don't be shocked when it's not the most amazing doughnut of your life.

It is an average baked good. The cake donut is flat out not good and their raised yeast is ok. They legit just deep fried cake... Yeast donuts are so big they were almost under cooked.  Not anything special except for the novelty. And the really really long line. Plus side the staff aren't a bunch of douchebags, they are hipsters. I'm more into the store kitsch and merch.  Great branding.
Not good, pretty basic donuts overall.. don't really understand the hype. The time that I went, the person at the counter was very rude and rushed me.

The donuts are nothing special... tried 3 different donuts. They tasted like your basic donut, with a lot of toppings. 

Definitely a tourist spot. I would say it's worth the try (if the line is short) for the touristy experience but wouldn't be something I would ever go back to.

This is a really cute shop, I love all their decorations! That and clever doughnut names (the ones I tried were the voodoo doll, cock-n-balls, dirty old bastard, & buttermilk bar) earns this place 3 stars. Unfortunately, beyond that I'm not sure what they hype is all about; the doughnuts LOOK great, but I've had way better Safeway doughnuts.

At first, I tried them all on an empty stomach and thought they were spectacular, but then I decided to save them for dessert after lunch proper, and then none of them seemed that great. The only part of the dirty old bastard that was at all appealing was the topping, which is made of Oreos and - duh - tastes good, like Oreos. So they were only good when I was hungry! Maybe that's the real reason why everyone seems to love them: they fast before going there. Everything tastes good if you're hungry enough. I dunno. 

If you're in town, it's definitely worth checking out the decor, if not the doughnuts. If you do end up buying some, try to hide the box when you're in the streets - the homeless people will try to take them!

Fun place to try once! I am not a huge donut fan in general, so this review probably doesn't mean much, but overall I didn't think they were special, other than the fun names and designs. Just fine for a donut shop, just don't expect to get something mind blowing.

This is the kind of doughnut shop you go to after all the bars close. You're also probably drunk. 

It's the kind of place you go to because it's popular, and not because the doughnuts are good.

I found myself saying, "Hmm, these doughnuts are kind of dry...and why is that one covered in cereal? Also, our cashier is dressed like Dorothy. We should totally come back here sometime."

I'll probably be back.

Theres a lot of line, a lot of tourists, a lot of sugar. 

Sugar rush extraordinaire. If that's your thing, cool. Check this place out. Me? I'll pass. 

Came here with some out of town visitors who had to check this off the bucket list. I had already visited the one in Eugene and got some mediocre vegan doughnuts with another out of town visitor. 

They have a seating area in the alley next to the shop which is nice, but that's always full.

VooDoo was always a fun way to end a night out on the town when I was younger. The donuts are still great, but currently this location is incredibly crowded. It's a big tourist stop now, and that's great for their business, but the lines are intense.

Tooth achingly sweet and yet with each bite it tastes less cloying as your tastebuds become dulled.  The chocolate peanut butter doughnut was my favorite.  The lemon jelly filled with frosting  -- blech.  No line, early Sunday morning but I see how lots of folks who do end up in line justify the wait by buying a big pink box of them -- I even saw someone bring a box as a souvenir on the plane.

I do not understand why this place is famous. You wait in line for overpriced donuts and the workers just yell at you if you don't follow their confusing line directions. The donuts are good but the wait and customer service weren't worth it.

Don't usually eat donuts much, but this place makes some odd lookin' donuts that just makes you want to try them. 

I actually liked the venue better when it was a hole in the wall. It definitely added to the experience that is Voodoo donuts. Now it just feels like another corporate dunkin donuts chain (with a twist).

Ok we queued up for a doughnut hoping to be surprised and impressed. The verdict? I wouldn't mind seeing this place taken off the Portland guide maps and replaced with a place or two that are actually breathtaking  and impressive. A place or two that deliver, as this place did not. 

Admittedly, and as noted by hundreds of other yelpers, it's fun. The decor is weird and funky, and sure they have some unusual items, but the basic glazed and filled doughnuts, two of which we got, could have come from one of any old doughnut shops. The dough for my Portland Cream, was not fresh, and it was underwhelming. 

I'm in no rush or a second visit.

6:00 am. 
Wandering around the streets. 
Near Chinatown is a big neon sign. 
You have been hexed. 
Donuts.
Funky decor and menu so high it overwhelms you.
Portland Donut -Cream filled with chocolate on top.
Pink box.

Results - Sweet but I've had better donuts. At the same time, I wouldn't mind coming back if I'm in Portland.

The donuts are ok, there was no line on Saturday around noon. For some reason all of the donuts taste like peanut butter, I thought it was just me, but everyone else that tried them also thought that. Probably won't go there again though.

Worth trying.

I got a voodoo doll, and it was surprisingly good. The donut was soft and fresh, the icing was really good...I was happy. 

Even though I came as a 'tourist' too, it became pretty apparent that tourists seem to really clog this place up, due to not knowing how the line works, not being aware enough to move out of the way when they're done ordering, etc etc etc. 

Oh yeah, and no credit card machine? This is a brick-and-mortar business that does pretty damn well from all the hype. NO excuse to shun technology that has been around since oh...the 1960s. Unless of course, you have a shady ATM machine right inside that you make money in fees from...

I'm going to start this off by saying that maybe I just don't get it. I can't understand the hype surrounding Voodoo Doughnut for the life of me. I ordered a Old Dirty Bastard and well....it tasted old and dirty. The doughnut wasn't stale perse, but it certainly didn't taste fresh by any means. I grew up just outside of Chicago and maybe it's just because of what I've been exposed to, but nothing about Voodoo Doughnuts screams "HEY! Wait in line for over half an hour for a doughnut that probably won't come close to the greatest thing you've ever had". Voodoo is way too overhyped and it's sad how much people build up this place. Their doughnuts are mainly all unique and have clever names, but Voodoo Doughnut is nothing more than gimmicky crap. 

If you want to wait in a long line for a doughnut that is loaded with sugar, tastes subpar, and has a gimmicky name then be my guest.
Doughnuts are okay.  Captain crunch one was completely stale.  Not sure why there is so much buzz about this place.  The shop itself is dirty and nothing special

These donuts are your basic donuts you might expect from any donut shop around the nation, but at voodoo doughnut they decorate them to look fantastic. I myself am not a big fan of paying the prices that they charge for their donuts, but with a line out the door at almost every location most of the time, I have to think that most people would disagree. 

Access and value -2 stars

Alright... I'm a doughnut fan. And this was totally overrated. My expectations must have been other worldly because I found voodoo's doughnuts just mediocre.

On top of that, there's the out of this world LINE to get the doughnuts. Honestly, the names of doughnuts were clever, but they're mostly basic glazed with various toppings. Almost like a froyo shop and doughnut shop collided. 

We tried top pot in Seattle and I was much more satisfied with that shop.

It's a cute little shop, I would say more of a tourist attraction than a foodie attraction. We lined up for almost an hour with our friends - I can see what the hype is when you see tons of other suckers lining up but I didn't think it was worth it. The donuts are cute to look at and have fun designs and are definitely artistic but again nothing out of this world in terms of taste or quality. The people were nice and friendly, cute little seating area out back where you can enjoy your donuts. Probably wouldn't visit again now that we've tried it once.

We took our Portland friend who happens to be 92 and had seen the lines going out the door for years but wasn't sure what it was all about.  He wasn't too impressed but he doesn't eat a lot of sugar...probably why he's still alive. And he absolutely would have none of my maple bacon doughnut....another reason he's probably still tickin' away at almost a century.

I liked my doughnut but preferred the bite of the signature Portland that is filled with crème and topped with chocolate. Would have preferred the bacon be chopped up on top of the maple to disguise the big strip of fat. Oh I know I'm deluding myself...it's still bacon....so how can you go wrong? 

Great selection...I'd be tempted to go back if I lived in Portland. Plus, the doughnuts were still solid fresh at 2pm on a weekday.

Everyone likes a fancy, shiny objects.  In this case it's a pink box filled with eccentric fat pills.  I guess I understand the appeal, but I find their doughnuts to be not much better than average.  In most cases, their product is a doughnut, cake or yeast, with a flavored icing and one or more excessive components added -typically cereal or oreo cookies, which in our case were stale!  I also found the apple fritter to be lacking in both apples and cinnamon.  Further I was disappointed that they were out of their flagship voodoo doll doughnut.  I will concur the maple bacon bar is a nice sweet and salty combo.  Bottom line though, I don't think it's worth standing in a line that long, having to pay for parking and then they not accept modern payment methods nor provide more game changing doughnuts.
It's not about the doughnuts, it's the novelty. So, try everything weird, then don't bother waiting in line again.
If you haven't been, it's worth checking out because it's one of those staple things every visitor or newbe must try. BUT... once you've been, try any of the other much better places.

The guy at the register argued with me that old fashioned doughnuts are not cake doughnuts. The people are rude and stupid, and the doughnuts are stale.  Oh, and the crazy doughnuts with all the toppings...those toppings absorb moisture, get stale, and get gross fast.  And that's how they serve it to you. 

Also, let's not forget the ridiculous Charles Manson doughnut. This place isn't cool, it's out of touch and poor quality. Don't waste your money.
They are alright. I'm over the hype. Props for them for leading the charge in the creative donut game though. But there is another local spot that is better.

We visited as we wanted to do the Voodoo thing, like tourists. I don't like doughnuts much as they're usually much too sweet for me. I've tried doughnuts across the country and have never found one I liked except maybe those made at home with very little sugar and no dusting. But I wanted the experience of going Voodoo - if only for my teen who thought it would be 'crazy cool'. 

We drove by at 8 PM on a weekday, there was a CRAZY line outside so we decided to go wait and come back at 11:30. Major oops! The line was even longer! What! Still we parked for $12 for the night and went to Voodoo. There was a 200 person line in front of us with some street performance going on right in the middle. Most people were late teens or twenties and many were drunk. Didn't think I wanted to be in line with my kid, we had even brought our dog, so we sent the poor soul back to the car. My kid got a few cat calls as she was walking back and was upset but still determined to go in and try the doughnuts. 

We then had a few teenagers slam into us as they were being chased by cops for breaking into someone's car or store and then a few cops came running after. It was quite a commotion. A homeless dude then got up on a trash can, he seemed really high and started lecturing the general audience in the line. Another crowd of drunk people showed up and lit cigarettes. Most of the people who had kids or others who did not want to wait left at this point. 

We waited about 1.5 hours to get in. I had typed my order on my phone and handed it to the server who thanked me for that since I was buying a bunch of flavors. A lot of people were just staring at the board inside, lost as they seemed not to have a clue what they wanted, I think they were in the line just for fun. The place is cash only so some were scrambling to get money. The servers were friendly despite all this going on all the time. It's amazing that they sell so many doughnuts, all their racks were full and they were still making more!

So the visit was an experience, that lasted 3 hours to buy a few doughnuts! But I don't think I would have seen more people and more interesting sights in the space of those 3 hours anywhere else!

We got our legendary pink boxes and I tried a bite of each doughnut having got about 15-16 flavors. I wasn't very impressed, the only one I liked was the Buttermilk bar. I had not tasted one like that before and it was not overly sweet. The voodoo dolls were all different and fun to photograph but not to eat. Eventually, I ended up trashing most of the doughnuts. Out of the 24 we purchased we perhaps finished 4-5 over 2 days. And our dog helped too!

Recommended as a place to hang out if you're into that sort of thing. Not worth going to just for doughnuts!
Overrated and makes my stomach hurt. Don't wait in a long line for a tummy ache and mediocre donuts. Go to BlueStar instead.
Strictly for tourists, although I did have the bacon crawler once and it was pretty legit.

Overrated! Got the Voodoo doll. Expected the jam to ooze out when I stabbed him with the pretzel stick but it did nothing! Jam only found in the belly and super sweet. I recommend sticking to Blue Star Donuts!
Interesting on the inside, grungy on the outside. Donuts weren't that fresh and the flavors were uninspired. I'd highly recommend Blue Star over Voodoo.

Coming from out of town and hearing people rave about this place I had check it out. (Also having 3200 reviews and 4s also played a part)  these doughnuts are neat at best.  They are only worth the novelty of their notoriety.   They have pretty extreme topping for doughnuts and the fun voodoo man doughnut.   I wouldn't say they are worth more then 5-10 min wait. But with that said it was worth a one time visit.

Coming from California me and my bf were excited to try this... A big part of Portland's culture (obviously). Too be honest, my expectations were not too high because it tastes exactly like how it looks. The texture of the donut was fried well, the icing/frosting/glaze was too sweet (almost similar to cake frosting), and the toppings were exactly what was listed: m&ms, Fruit Loops (gaybar), Butterfinger (crumble), Oreos (old dirty bastard), and so on. We didn't have to wait long (15 minutes) but typically there are long waits. There's parking right in front and across the street in a prepaid lot. So, it was okay... Not amazing, but not bad.
Decent crazy Donuts, I like the non downtown location better.
While the texture of the donuts is chewy and wonderful, the frosting is straight-up Betty Crocker.

yep, yum. I got the Portland Cream. I was expecting more creativity on the foresting end, but delicious indeed. The line was long but we grabbed a coffee togo while we stood in line. I don't easily give out five stars (it's has to be over the top for five).

Fun place to check out. The donuts are not the best I've had but glad we checked it of our list of things to try while in Portland. The interior of the shop was cool & the variety of donuts is creative.
Boring, just sugar no flavors, and out of towners who think its amazing.
Played out. But go ahead, go on in once or twice. Whimsy, sexy, messy. Take a look. Stick around. Better doughnuts elsewhere, but there's genius behind this joint.

After hearing all the hoopla about this place my expectations were super high.  I waited for 30 minutes in line to get my box of a dozen and was it really worth it at the end of the day?  I'm not totally sure.  I think if I didn't have to wait I would have happily given Voodoo 4 stars but I say it's worth a try but not worth waiting in line for regularly.  

The cool thing about the doughnuts here is they aren't absurdly over priced like you would expect, if you let them pick a dozen for you it's only $13.00.  The doughnuts are good and they get bonus points for having inventive toppings.  Their cake doughnuts are fantastic and I think they're better than the yeast versions (I felt the dough was pretty standard and unremarkable).  Pro tip: Tip your cashier!
I think it is over rated and doughnuts are stale and tastes like cardboard boxes.  Cool looking gothic place!
get real, these are NOT the best donuts in the city. Seriously. go to Denver for this

I mean, it's fun sometimes, especially if you go with people from out of town to get the whole tourist experience. But, frankly, I prefer the doughnuts from the bakery section at Fred Meyer. Better yet, do yourself a favor and head over to Annie's Doughnuts - the best doughnuts in town! Unless, you like to wait in an incredibly long line to pay strictly with cash for a huge mess of a doughnut with a bajillion toppings that you'll most likely pick off most of in the end.
All Hype, but you can meet cool people while your waiting in line for cheap white sugar coated dough ;D
This place is alright. Seriously overrated. Every time I've been here, there's a line. It isn't even worth the wait, if it wasn't for the people I was going with.

I mean me and my girlfriend were visiting Portland,  and every Tourist said its a must, ( locals say blue stars bette, and trust me it is lol), but when we arrived there was a  line which hyped me up despite a heroin addict running in circles close to the line. LONG STORY SHORT we got a dozen the dirty bastard, was the best hands down but all of the donuts including the famous voodoo doll, were stale and average... maybe just get2 donuts and take a picture of the building... nothing special really.

This place is a real fad that caught on. There is even one in my home town of Eugene. I love the bacon maple doughnut however that is their one and only great success. The voodoo doll doughnut is also okay. However the majority of what they make is gross doughnuts piled on with fruit loops, coco puffs and other breakfast cereals. They even had a pepto-bismol doughnut at one point. No thanks! They could be good if they would focus on quality instead of strange gimmicks.

After spending 45 mins in line to get the donuts  i wasn't disappointed, as the donuts were pretty good but not worth standing that long in a line for. They are inexpensive, big  and yummy  but only go when there is no line.

After driving to Voodoo, saw the line, and left twice, we decided the third time, that we'd brave the line to try these donuts that seemed synonymous to Portland. The wait was surprisingly short (30 mins) for such a long line. The result? 12 odd-but-cool sounding donuts that tasted like well....donuts. I wish the donuts were warm - that would have helped but aside from the design, tasted like those I could get at (gasp!)...maybe Safeway? I wish they came out hot and fresh - like Krispy Kreme ones do (another gasp!). 

Quality: 3
Service: 3
Cost: 3

This place was alright. I stopped here because it was featured on a foodie show and we were just moving to the area so why not?  
The atmosphere has the Portland groove that we can all appreciate, the place is really cool and eclectic, but the donuts were just alright.
 They have jazzy names and interesting ideas (Cap'n Crunch donut anyone?), but I just wasn't too thrilled. Maybe because I hyped myself up for the experience, I don't know. I just expected more from a place that was widely televised and praised for thinking outside of the box. 
I say if you're a tourist go ahead and check it off your bucket list, but don't come if you're expecting melt in your mouth delicious donuts.
as a local- I think I'm kinda over it....not worth the line.
Theme crap for fun but not good, fresh donuts.  Great for teens.

It was my first time in Portland, so of course I had to see what all the hype was about. The donuts are delicious and I was very lucky to not have to wait in line. However, as far as the customer service portion, let me just say it was horrible. It was me and my family's first time here so we just had a few questions, but they were very impatient towards us, even though there was no customers in line after us. While we were deciding what to order, the guy behind the counter said "do you want some donuts orrrr..." I mean what else did we come here for! All I have to say is we traveled many hours full of excitement, to be presented with unsatisfactory customer service. I would give it one star for the service, but I'll give it a two because the donuts were good and cute.

There's so much hype around this place, but I didn't think it was all that great. The place is pretty dirty, too.  

Sure, the donut names are cute and all, but they just didn't taste that great.  We waited in line for over a half hour and while some of the donuts were okay, others were disappointing.  I bought one of their standard dozens and all the donuts with cereal got kind of soggy.  I honestly think Krispy Kreme is better.

I went here for I have heard a lot about it. If you are wandering around Downtown in Portland in the mornings, I am sure you will pass by a couple of pink Voodoo boxes. They have a lot of flavors but I wasn't fairly impressed with the donuts. They were good but not the best I ate in Portland. They also accept only cash. Overall they have a nice seating outside, and you will enjoy their pink boxes.

A decent couple of donuts but not worth the stupid wait you can find here. We went in because there was "no" line (7am). The inside is like a zombie movie collided with a cure album and someone threw pink everywhere. Watched a homeless guy try to fill a cup of soda that he was holding upside down then pretty much fell out of the front doors, that was a highlight.

Its a donut....

Maybe its because I'm a harsh critic, but there was really nothing that separated this place from most donut places.  No matter how they dressed it up, it was still just a donut.  Full of sugar and doughy goodness.  Actually, I thought these donuts were a little too sweet.  

Had the bacon one, the portland creme, and the voodoo donut.  Portland creme was the best because it wasn't as sweet as the others.  There was really nothing here that warranted the long line and amazing reviews.  You might want to come here to check out all the crazy donuts, but, at least for myself, no matter how they dressed it up, it didn't really change the taste all that much, so I won't be coming back.

Maybe I'm just a hater...
Long wait for ok donuts.  Could do a better job of labeling allergens and ingredients

This was highly recommended as a Can't Miss Must Go place in PDX.  Only 2 people in line ahead of us at 5 pm on Friday afternoon.  Many of the doughnuts were not in stock (Capn' My Captain, Fruit Loops, Voodoo Doll, Rice Krispies).  But many were and we ordered a dozen.   My mind went blank when it was our turn to order from the screamin' bangin' music and I completely FORGOT to order a Maple Bacon bar.  I found my brain and managed to order some regular and a few "special" doughnuts. In the box were a Mexican Hot Chocolate, a Cocoa Puff (very stale cereal), a Tang, two M&Ms, a Double Bubble, an Apple Fritter, a Peach Fritter, a Powdered Sugar Raspberry filled, a plain cruller, and 2 I will have to remember another time....
the M&Ms rocked!  the Tang was suprisingly great!
the Fritters were very disappointing - very little fruit, cake-like frosting on the peach one that did not make up for the lack of fruit, 

The shock of my life came when I bit into the Mexican Hot Chocolate and my mouth was on FIRE!  I am not a spicy food person.... I was not expecting ground chili pepper all over the donut - but rather cinnamon sugar on a chocolate donut... when I inspected it more closely while my mouth was in flames, I noticed the orange-red flecks all over the donut.... brought it home to my daughter and she said.... well Mom what did you expect?  and then took a bite and said it had a bit of a kick to it.

This place is always packed! But in the off chance you get in, the service is pretty friendly and the donuts are pretty good.  They are a little too large and sweet for my tastes, but they have most regular varieties available for your enjoyment as well.  I think it's more a novelty than anything else, but I would say if you're here, might as well get the signature voodoo (if you like sweet fruity fillings) as it's probably fun to play with a voodoo donut (it's supposed to "bleed" when you "stab" it with the pretzel).  I don't know if it's worth the wait as I stopped in early in the morning just to check it out.  Prices aren't bad, but they only take cash, so be prepared for a wait and have your dough ready!
Don't understand why people behind the counter are so rude, doesn't seem like they want to sell any donuts
They have unique doughnuts that's for sure. But as far as taste, its ok. I think people like it just for the oddity of the place AND to say they have been there.

This place isn't all that it's cracked up to be. Who in their right mind would want to wait in line for over two hours to have some quack making donuts I can make myself st home. Random concoctions I can do myself. Just because someone says you need to check it out doesn't mean you need to. Dumb. Everyone was in my way and everyone was scattered and there was no consistent greeting and people cutting. Awful just awful. Screw that place. Never going again. And you shouldn't either. Why would some stupid donut place be the A highlight of Portland. Dumb.

Honestly don't know why this place is so popular. The donuts have suggestive names and they put on unusual toppings that don't taste that great. There's always a line but it moves pretty fast. I heard the other location had a faster line and is nicer overall.

Save yourself the time. Skip Voodoo and go to a Blue Star Donuts!

There is a lot of hype around Voodoo and the iconic 'pink box' as a portland destination...it's one of the ones you can skip and honestly you're not missing anything.

In my opinion you're really paying more for the decorations than the actual doughnuts...they're gut bombs with not a lot of flavor, a huge kick of sweetness, and a lot left to be desired. There are so many other local places that really care about the doughnut itself first and the decorations second. The line is always really long and it's really cramped and dingy inside. First time I visited Portland I went to Voodoo, got a tshirt, the whole nine yards...and even after trying to get excited about it it's just meh. I have friends that swear by Voodoo and other people I know that really like it. Go you! It's a definite well-known PDX location that's cool to say you've gone. But pls follow real portland culture and go to a less-hyped but so much better local shop.
Didn't think it was anything special or amazing. Not worth the long wait... Although they do have cool/unique looking donuts.

This place is absolutely disgusting!  We took our two kids because everyone said we had to check out Voodoo Donuts. To start its next to a porn theatre and as soon as you walk in all you can smell is piss from the single restroom.  The restroom was worse than a gas station restroom. The donuts were over priced and didn't taste fresh. We went in the morning so not sure when they would be fresh. Tons of homeless people everywhere. Super disappointing! !

As far as flavor goes, this place is like every other donut shop I know - the donuts didn't taste fresh and the frosting tasted artificial. Plus, it didn't help that there was a man verbally harassing everyone waiting in line. I strongly recommend avoiding this place - please don't fall into this tourist trap like I did.
This place is a touristy overrated doughnut shop, yeah they're good... but not worth the lines.

Pass....total waste of time!! Thought it would be fun to check out and service was horrible. The girl that helped us was a total RAG and shouldn't be in the service industry!! Doughnut were good, but wouldn't go back.

Fun, kitschy, interior but donuts are Dunkin Donut quality.

Sampled the bacon maple bar, portland cream, and signature voodoo man donut (jam filled, chocolate frosted). All of them were only meh.  Don't feel the need to ever go back.

Would recommend blue star over voodoo.

Visited the evening of Labor Day.  Had to step over homeless people to go inside.  
I was clueless on how to order a doughnut.  Order by shape?  Order by color?  Order by location in the display case?  Staff was kind of rude, and no help.
Doughnuts were just ok.  Nothing special, and not worth the trip. 
If you're walking by, stop in, but don't go out of your way for them.

WAY OVERHYPED. One of my friends' roommate just moved here and was dying to go so I decided to tag along. I have lived in Portland my entire life and never understood what the big deal about this place was. There was a long line, as expected, but moved fairly quickly (~10 mins or so). We didn't notice that they only accept cash until we got closer to the front and the menu is pretty difficult to read. There are no descriptions of the doughnuts but instead just their quirky names and we ended up having to point to which ones we wanted in the spinning case. The doughnuts were too sweet for my liking and the toppings (Oreo and captain crunch) tasted quite stale. I'll give points for the interesting flavors that they created. But overall, I am not a fan and there are definitely better doughnut shops in the area, like pip's or blue star.

Ive been to/had vodo many times and its fine but i just dont see why people would go out of thier way to go here. Theres so many better places to get a doughnut in portland that have less attitude, no wait and accept debit/credit.
long lines for stale donuts. Let's go to Bluestar!

I went to a show tonight and my boyfriend and I thought we would walk down to Voodoo doughnuts and see if there was anything cooler about this one than the one in Eugene. We WOULD have gone in but there was a huge line of irritating tourists that I honestly did not want to stand in. I also didn't want to go into their tiny, little, cramped store thanks.
You end up standing in line, and then when you get up to the front you finally get to see what all the donuts look like and THEN you can decide. And then people start moaning and groaning that you're taking to long to order a damn donut.

To be quite frank, their donuts aren't all that great either, they've got a funky aftertaste. The only one that's even worth getting at all is the bacon maple bar because it's not super absurd, but it still has that funky aftertaste. Blech. 

Do yourself a favor, go to a regular donut shop and get some regular donuts. Get ones with sprinkles if you're feeling a little crazy. A regular donut shop will even give you donuts for cheaper, and they'll taste better!

The hype train is real.

How did this place get famous? I really don't know. If you like kitschy "hipster" things, or are a tourist, this is the place for you! I can't think of a single local who's a regular here.

PROS:
-Inexpensive
-Relatively fresh

CONS:
-No cash? Have I been transported to 1992?
-Lines at all hours
-sketchy area at night
-Nowhere near as good as competitors like Blue Star Donuts

It's donuts.

We didn't wait in line, but we did go at 4 in the morning before our flight. Not necessarily inconvenient since it was on the way, but wow that's early for some donuts. They are open 24/7 though! And they'll always have all the donuts in stock (or so they say).

The lady at the counter wasn't particularly friendly (for PDX), but it was also 4 am.

We ordered a BUTTLOAD of donuts to take home for the family.

My favorite is probably the maple bacon donut. They're all cooked very well and soft.

But a donut is a donut. This place is just a lot of hype!

I bought 8 different donuts @ Voodoo on SW 3rd and was disappointed in all. On average, the flavors and textures were a lesser quality than the donuts baked at my local, national chain, grocery store.  Why?  Because the apple fritter has no apples (I gave up looking half-way through); the maple bar frosting is achingly sweet; the choc. cake donut is slightly gummy; the two fruit fillings remind me of the fillings in pastries that are pre-packaged and processed for a very long shelf life.  If you take away the huge selection, unusual flavorings, and marketing hype, what's left is a mediocre and boring core product.

(I've eaten outstanding donuts, but they were from a donut bakery/cafe in Seattle; high quality ingredients and cooking techniques are clearly their top priority.  I'm not listing the name because I don't want you to think my low rating of Voodoo has a hidden agenda.)

Didn't get to try Voodoo on my last visit to Portland so I really wanted to check it out this trip. 

Its wayyyyyyyyy overrated. Sure they have a large and unique selection of donuts, but they really DO NOT taste all that great. 

Maple bar - yeast donut that you expect to be light and airy and it was really dense! 

Captain Crunch - yeast donut topped with vanilla icing and Captain Crunch cereal. The cereal pieces were soggy, soft and NOT crunchy. 

Blueberry - cake donut that actually had a good blueberry taste, but the overly sweet glaze just killed it. It would have been great not-glazed. 

Tourist spot that was on my list of Portland to dos. Been there. Done that. Will never go again.

Meh. Just meh. 

I wanted to visit voodoo after hearing from multiple sources and even MORE food network shows that I absolutely HAD to visit Voodoo Doughnut as a part of my trip to Portland. I consider myself a donut enthusiast, and unfortunately Voodoo did not live up to its hype. 

First strike- the line. We stood in line outside for legitimately 30 minutes on a Friday midday to even make it to the inside of the store. Sure, I know it's a tourist attraction, but the sheer length of time it took for us to make it inside was pretty shocking. Especially since it's not exactly in a great neighborhood (this is coming from someone who lives in Baltimore and has stood in line outside for less.). 

Once inside, the line continues and you are brought into a kitschy but weirdly sexualized lobby area that smells of cloying B.O. Not in a temporary way, but in a way where you can TELL everyone there just stinks. Not something you want when you're trying to eat a donut. We decided to just grab one donut - the old dirty bastard (which is chocolate frosted, with Oreo crumbles and a peanut butter drizzle). We also grabbed a cold brew (which was a "new featured item!!" But came out to be a literal milk carton of overly sweetened milky coffee) 

The donut itself was fine. But totally forgettable. For $1 I can get a donut from Dunkin and crumble some cookies on top of it and have the same experience. That's not something you want to say after paying double for a donut of the same size but like, maybe staler. It just didn't live up to the hype. There are better donuts in Portland!

OK so yes this is a "must stop at" tourist attraction in Portland, unfortunately it's all hype. Yes the donuts look really cool and have great cereal toppings and bacon etc..  Unfortunately when I crave a donut, taste is the most important factor and these just don't cut it. in fact the Albertsons near me has cereal and bacon covered donuts in their case and they taste fresher, softer, and sweeter than Voodoo. The donuts at Voodoo (and I have been there 3 times, and had the donuts from there (people bring to work etc) numerous times always seem a bit stale and hard and dry under those toppings. Sorry hipsters seek out better alternatives you don't always have to be a follower and gotta do what everyone else is doing (see your appearance wink).

Two stars because they have tons vegan choices. Other than that the taste is nothing special. The silly shapes are good for a chuckle. It's not particularly something special but just some thing different.

If u are really into donuts, i hate to say this, but crispy creme may win in a blind taste test.
They're donuts. Yes, they took the reigns on creating unique combinations and selections, but when I see a line out the door, I have to shake my head.

Great tasting doughnuts!  Fun to surprise out of town guests with them.  

Don't care for the line; does anyone need a doughnut so bad they will wait 30+ minutes for them?  There are many other great doughnut places in Portland were you do not have to line up for a bite.

I visited Portland and in tourist fashion made my way to this donut shop to see what the hype was about. I got 13 of the most popular flavors (chosen by the woman at the register) and most of these donuts were forgettable except the maple bacon bar, the maple cream filled donut and the Boston cream donut. I am glad I tried it out just to get it off of my bucket list but next time I visit Portland...I won't likely return here. The customer service was very poor and left a bad taste in my mouth...no pun intended. I was with my friend who is in a wheelchair and the woman was calling for the next person in line. Meanwhile, I was trying to maneuver the chair around other customers and the line posts. The rep was clearly not aware of her surroundings (even though we passed her and stood in front of her while moving along in line) because she shouted several times loudly and rudely for the next customer while we made our way to the counter. It drew attention to us in a way that almost caused me to turn the wheelchair around and leave to go spend my $30 (13 donuts and a coffee mug) somewhere else.
Save your time and money. Go to Bluestar if you want truely good donuts. The workers are snobs and the donuts are crud.
Bacon maple bar was best one in box.  The rest while very cool looking were too sweet.  Then again, I do not like Top Pot.  Am more of a Krispy Kreme fan.

I must say I love the concept of Voodoo Donuts because it is so very Portland.  I am not a fan of long lines so when I wait in one - I better get something EXTREMELY good at the end of it.  I will say - their fritters rock pretty hard but I still, to this day am not a bacon maple bar fan which is ok - enough people in this state are addicts so they do not need my help.  The rest of the donuts I have tried I also was not too into either - they just tasted too sweet and greasy for me.  But, their fritters....just sayin...

I came around 2-3 PM on a Saturday and there was a long line outside, even with the rain. It took about 1/2 an hour to get in and out of Voodoo Doughnut.

We got a box of assorted donuts and it cost about $18 total. I was really disappointed that they ran out of the Maple Bacon doughnut and a lot of the other kinds of doughnuts we wanted were sold out too.

The donuts are definitely made for sharing because each one is big and really sweet so it's hard to finish in one sitting. I really liked all the donuts with the chocolate and peanut butter drizzled on top. There was an interesting pink bubble gum doughnut that actually tasted like bubble gum, swallowing it seemed a little wrong..

Bottom Line: I was disappointed since the store ran out of all the flavors I wanted to try. The doughnuts are too sweet in it's entirety, so share with a friend!

I've been told it's not that great, and it's more of an attraction than a must-eat spot in Portland, and it's true.

We came on a Monday night so there was no one there. We ordered an assortment of donuts and they're basically all the same but with different weird toppings. Nothing special at all. And they certainly don't care about the aesthetics of the donuts (I guess that's part of their schtick) because boy, are these donuts ugly. 

Try it once to say you've tried it, then go get your donut fix at Blue Star.

beautifully designed doughnuts, just not very moist or tasty. The line wasn't too terrible when we went, but they do only accept cash. Luckily theres an ATM in the store. Cool place, definitely something everyone needs to experience once, but wouldn't consider it a favorite.

I have to admit... it being my first time in Portland, I was very excited to try this place.  I've seen it on the travel and food channels.  My husband and I were so giddy about going that we didn't mind waiting in line for about 1/2 an hour, and ordering a dozen weird donuts...of course including the maple bar with bacon. The overall atmosphere was fun.   
However, once the novelty of it wore off, I realized that this is a very overrated place.  The maple bar had too much maple glaze on it.  I could easily buy a maple bar and cook up some bacon and throw it on there.  We didn't even end up eating the rest of the donuts cuz we realized that there was just too much STUFF on them.  
So, I suppose if you're gonna be in Portland for about a week, it's fun to go and experience the vibe of the place.  But if you're going for just a few days, don't bother.

Ok so of course this is a tourist trap. If you're in Portland and would really like to try this place, make sure you come in the middle of the day on a weekday. Don't ever come on the weekend or a Thursday, Friday, or Saturday night because you will be in line for a long time and they will rush you. 
There are a ton of different donuts to choose from and they also have gluten free. 
This is a touristy place but when you're a tourist, you're supposed to try the touristy places. This place is good and very unique.

This place doesn't even deserve a damn star. I am so disappointed that I made a huge round trip and the first thing I told my boyfriend was "As soon as we get to Portland we are headed straight to voodoo's doughnut." I am so PISSED I even gave them my money away to this shit hole because that could've been gas money... doughnuts were dry and that wasn't the only thing that was dry the guy that served us had a dry ass attitude. First of all I am a tourist going to your shop happy as can be to finally arrive after hours of driving then I get sour ass eye rolls when I ask him certain questions. Keep in mind the questions I had were minimal. OH HELL NAH! When I got home my boyfriend apologized that my mission to this piece of shit doughnut shop killed everything for me. One bite guys... one bite and those doughnuts hit the bottom of my trash can. WHAT A FAIL GUYS. YOU SUCK. I'm done here, never again. Also ghetto as can be smelled like homeless piss.




ADULT ADVISORY:
I'd rather eat anus then to ever go here.
REPORT ME I DON'T CARE THIS PLACE IS TRASH TRASH TRASH.
Great novelty doughnut, worth a try. However once you get past the novelty it isn't the best quality doughnut.

This place is crazy over hyped. The lines are long if you come during peak hours. I came early in the morning before 8am and before the lines got crazy long. Bring cash but they do have an ATM machine and parking available across the street. I got the old dirty bastard, hibiscus, colada, Coco puffs and lucky charm donuts. I had the Coco puff donut first and it tasted days old. The next day I had the old dirty basatrd and that one was super yummy. I didn't get to try the other donuts bought because I have them away to the staff in the lobby of my hotel. Probably won't come back here and if I do I'll go to Universal Studios in Hollywood for the fix.

Touristy trap for sure. Donuts are good and creative but the fact that the place does not take credit cards is a turn down for sure. Also I was surprised how stale the donuts were. Overall blue star has much better donuts. Was in town for a few days for business and tried both vodoo and blue star. No questions blue star takes the prize for better donut.

Donuts are very fresh and definitely unique. I'm giving 2 stars because of the service :( I went around 11pm and maybe because it was late and she's been working all day but the girl was very rude!! Her name was Chelsea. She asked me what I wanted and since I've never been there I asked her "what's popular?" "What's voodoo dozen?" The girl have me short answers "yea" "no" and said smart remarks such as "why don't you look at the pictures?" I don't think I'll come back to this location. Just rude..!

Nice place to stop by, and I felt like it's one of those things that has to be done once.

I first came to this place around 8pm, and the line was about 1hr30min according to the person that was managing the line. Saw that the place is open 24/7 so I did other stuff and came back around 1am. Line was still about 15~ minutes wait.

Overall the donuts itself was good and satisfying. Toppings are generally unique. Stuffed donuts were full of flavor. Staff are helpful on selection, and quick. 

Not sure about waiting in line aspect, which is easiest the biggest detraction.

I would have loved to see this place years ago when it first opened because I bet it had an ambience.  It is one of the most popular places in Portland with a line always out the door but it gave me the assembly line effect.  The people behind the cash registers weren't particularly friendly.  They were just taking care of the business (Cash Only btw).  There wasn't much interaction between staff and customers.  It's a small cute little room with Voodoo-ish paraphernalia on the walls.  Very commercial I thought.  Now on the subject of their donuts.  They do them well.  They are huge, unique shapes and flavors and very pretty.  Little works of art.  I don't know Portland or downtown Portland at all but I would call that side of downtown seedy.

WOW was my family disappointed!! We have been DYING to go here (only located in Portland that we know of) we live in Ca. So while on vacation we visited this shop! The line was out the door for over an hour wait (not surprised because it was Memorial Day weekend). But for all the hype this place has; I expected some AMAZING customer service & even better looking donuts... unfortunately both SUCKED! I asked for the "voodoo guy" looking donut- he was cute with a pretzel stick in his tummy. Only the display one was cute- mine looked like it fell/lost an eye/someone who was drunk put the pretzel stick in because it was so low on the donut- just didn't look cute let alone appetizing. So I asked the guy if he could pick out a different looking voodoo man; he said "no". Packed up the rest of the donuts sloppy into the box & rung us up. I told him I was a social medial Influencer; if I post about these donuts it would be a big deal because I have a large responsive following - to please change the donuts for visually appealing ones- he literally said "I heard you, and I'm not getting you a new one they all look the same"... wow. I'll be sure to never return when we go back there for vacation and content. Too bad because they tasted super good (just looked like shit).
its cliché, dirty and mediocre.  Much better donuts elsewhere in Portland

We came here after a night of bar hopping on a saturday night. There was a line but service was quick. I don't know what everybody's talkin about with the mean man and bad service. Our service was fine, not rude or unfriendly at all. And it being in the bad part of Portland... I guess. Looks normal to me, I mean you have seen a homeless person before haven't you.. or a goth. Maybe I'm so use to places like Chicago?.. with it being rough around the edges and learning hey if you snooze you lose!! Maybe portland or westcoast peeps are too nice and squeaky clean.. It's a lil donut shop, do ya expect some cuddles with your donut too? geezus. I didn't feel scared walkin down the street here. I was expecting much worse. The inside of the shop can maybe use a scrub though. But I'd come back. I'd rather they keep it real and put the dirtiness out in the open rather than secretly dropping my donut on the floor and sneezing on it in the back which I wouldn't be too surprised.

The donuts are soft, and fluffy! BUT they were super sweet .. a little much for my taste but it was soooo doughy soft. I could only handle a few bites because it was so sweet. I was really wanting a Grape Ape but they sold out!!!!! That's my only complaint :( I was really wanting to eat the "chewable form or a grape soda"  mmmmm that sounds like heaven. If I ever run into a guy that would marry my ass, I'd do it here.. that or the drive through in Vegas. Yeah I'm a classy one. Don't try coming in here like a timid little lamb. Grow a back bone.
I went there just once and the donuts are grassy, probably a lot of coloring.

This placed was so hyped we had to get in line to get a couple doughnuts.  I would recommend the guava one and grape one since they were more novel flavors.  However they were not out of this world amazing unfortunately.  I have to admit it's very picturesque store inside and out if you are an instagramer or such.

I was looking forward to trying Voodoo donuts, but I was disappointed by the choices they had available and the actual donut that I ordered. I eventually settled on a chocolate covered custard filled donut, because I didn't want cereals on my donuts, I don't like jelly, and I don't like bacon on my donuts. Then my donut tasted (particularly the texture) like what I would get at a grocery store, which isn't terrible, but I wouldn't have to wait in line for a grocery store donut. So in conclusion, come here to check out the interesting shop and their decor, but head over to Blue Star Donuts for great tasting donuts.

Not worth the hype and sugar migraine that comes along with eating them. There are much better donuts in Portland, but I guess I am glad they exist to distract all of the tourists away from the real donuts. :)
not life changing and not worth the line. i guess its nice to visit this place for its novelty and for the nostalgia.

Not worth the wait (if you must wait)...

It was 3am and there was no line.
But they ran out of the bacon maple bar.

Workers are rude, i think they are trying to push the line as fast as possible.

Donuts look cool, but way too sweet (and i eat dessert at every meal).

Prices are not too high - they start at 95 cents for the plain.

CASH ONLY!

No offense to the Portlanders, but I just don't get what's the big deal here. 

I waited in an insanely long line, got the famous maple/bacon donut $3 and the Voodoo doll $2, took one bite each, disgusted @ how sugary they are and that's about it!

I think Krispy Kreme had more "crispy" donut, and I have to say, other than the idea of being avant-garde, there's nothing special here and not worth my stopping here next time. 

This is not to say that it's not for others who like this type, just like I don't see the point of Hostess sweets. Nothing again the establishment.

Overrated! 
All the wait in the line and all the hype ... and it tasted like just another donut with a few other options in each bite like Oreos, fruit loops, bananas, extra sugar syrup, extra-extra sugar syrup, etc.

After all that wait in the line, we didn't want to buy just 1 or 2 donuts. So, we bought 6. 
Oh, what a waste! 

Unless you are into donuts in general, don't bother wasting your time in those lines.

P.S.: Still wondering how this place became such a craze in a health-conscious city like Portland.

If you like gimmicks, waiting in line, and not the best quality product: this is the place for you.  Yes, Voodoo is cute and fun to experience and well marketed, however, the donuts themselves do not live up the the hype.  

I was lucky enough to experience a "short line" i.e. about 15 minutes.  I tried about 10 different donuts and none of them was particularly memorable.  I was really hoping to fall in love with the ridiculous fritters (they were huge and had a ton of icing and enticing ingredients), however, I took two bites of each and was underwhelmed.  My favorite donut was the voodoo as it was a well executed jelly donut.  Though, I certainly would not dream about it and need to get it again.  Skip the pain and just head to Blue Star where everything is good and I am still dreaming about  those donuts (just note: they are not 24 hours and they do sell out of stuff).

Went with a girlfriend and it seemed overpriced for the quality.  I felt as though I was paying more for the name on the box.  I won't be back.  The donuts, while creative and maybe exciting, still tasted like the oily donuts I would expect from an everyday donut shop.

OK, I will probably be permanently banned from Portland (my favorite city)for saying this, but I was not super impressed.  The concept is cool, and I thought the little voodoo doll donuts were cute, but I was disappointed in the concept's execution.  

I really wanted a bacon donut.  They did not have any bacon donuts.  I tried one with rice crispies, and it was OK, but rice crispies are not bacon.  The girl working at the counter seemed annoyed with life.  Also, there were a bunch of flies swarming around the donut case.

I'm gonna tell you straight. This place is disgusting. 

I've been there three times, and tonight's visit will be my last. Every time I go in there, the floor is filthy, the kitchen is filthy, with grime that has obviously sat there for days, layer upon layer of filth. But that is probably explained by the fact that the employees always look and act like they are coming off of heroin. 

The donuts are ALWAYS stale, greasy, unattractive as if someone just threw crap together without thinking about taste or quality, not to mention that they taste godawful, like sugar and crisco mixed with stale flour that's infested with boll weivels. 

I swore I'd never go back, but my brother told me to try the bacon donut, that my opinion would change. But guess what, they sold me a day old crusty donut, with a FINGERPRINT in the icing. Even the bacon was stale! 

It tasted like a sugar frosted, bacon grease slathered cardboard box.

Everyone has had a doughnut from various bakeries throughout their lives.  These are the worst I have ever had.  They taste like grease and sugar.  Its a diabetic sandwich.   They are unique in design, I will admit that, but in no way are these a delicacy to go out of your way for.  I laugh at the lines of lemmings wanting more.

This place sucks. Born n raised in Portland and this is everything I hate about Portland.

The service sucks, doughnuts are overrated, the lines are long, the music they play is horrible (punk music), and the employees are all dicks

BOYCOTT VOODOO!!'

Nope! The quality has gone WAY down over the years. Quantity over quality is not the best business model for repeat local business. It's all hype and not worth waiting in line for. Fortunately, there is no shortage of good quality donuts in the Portland area. If your visiting Portland, do yourself a favor and check out Doe Doughnuts, Annie's Donut Shop, Pip's Original, Tonallis Donut Shop, or Back to Eden Cafe! They all offer a much better product.

Voodoo Donuts is like the friend you know who's famous.  You wanna hang around them until they get obnoxious and have too many hanger ons.  Now I'm not saying Voodoo is obnoxious.  They get kudos for being on the leading edge of creativity.  And bonus points for the hours they're open.  And I do like them, but I don't think they're the best in Portland and vicinity.  I do get tired of the crowds however.  And if it's late at night, some of the drunken crowds can be a bit trying.  Still for creativity and getting world famous, well they are a-ok.
A tourist trap.  Wait an hour for a donut doused in captain crunch, too boot, that tastes stale... Just don't.  I beg you, please just don't.
Kind of over-rated but still fun for the occasional donut since they have a vegan option which is less heavy but totally pleases my craving for sweets.

I get it. I just don't like it. Not a doughnut fan, these ones are OK and kitschy for sure. The service is usually pretty ass-ish and I am just not that impressed. I give full stars for their Bacon, Maple bar though, that thing is awesome. (how I miss you meat!)

Come early to make sure you don't wait in line for an hour for donuts.

We had to get the maple-bar donut. It's a maple glaze on a donut...with pieces of crispy bacon stuck in the glaze. If you want donut opulence this is the place for you. 

Old Dirty Bastard doughnut was pretty epic it has chocolate frosting, Oreo's and peanut butter!

Buy some milk, because you're going to need it to choke these giant donuts down your gullet.

Good donuts. We got a they pick dozen and a few other. They do some funny donuts but pretty much just a donut shop with a long line. I would pass on some of the weird and get something you like the maple bacon and Choc old fashioned were my fav.

This place is quintessential Portland. Very quirky. I enjoy bringing people here because it can be quite the experience.  I like their doughnuts, but I am not as crazy about them as most people seem to be. However, I am not a big doughnut person in general, so I guess I wouldn't be the best judge.

Barf!! Gag me!

The donuts are made for tourists. Completely OVERRATED!
$30 for a dozen?? Hellllll no!

Every local that eats there is drunk after a night at the bar. We all know EVERYTHING tastes great when you're drunk and craving things.

The donuts are dry, and the concoctions they've come up with are really weird and mostly gross. I would NOT recommend this place.

In my opinion, Voodoo is a bit of a tourist trap. Sure, it's fun to visit the hole-in-the-wall spot downtown and get their funky donuts, but I don't think it ever merits a 45 minute wait in line, and there are much better donuts elsewhere.

Not the best doughnut in town these days, if it ever was. However, it still has the flair and imagination to make it a Portland staple. I like many of the flavors, but I gravitate to the ODB for some reason. The maple bacon is only best when fresh, so skip those when they're day old. Frankly, everyone should experience this place once, so you know what excess you'll be missing when you have a regular doughnut. Only then will it be clear which you prefer.
i do not get it-i see people carrying around pink boxes of donuts- all day and wow- a line around the block!!!
Have to give them a 3, mostly because we went to Blue Star first.  They were just okay and kind of over hyped.

I went to Voodoo Doughnuts  ONCE.  Was late at night, around 1:30am.  There were a couple of grimy, smelly, drunk bums in front of me  negotiating for stale donuts and coffee.  These guys took forever to conclude their business and then one of the drunk bums spilt his coffee on the counter, thereby wasting more of my time.  Although there were several other employees there, only the one was working at the counter.  Compared to others' waits, however, I guess I was fortunate only having to wait 10 minutes while the transients finished their business.

I noticed that the counter guy didn't even wash his hand after cleaning up the drunk bum's mess before grabbing my donuts, which didn't leave me pleased.

The donuts -- meh.  Yes, they got some weird toppings.  Big whoop.  I got the Memphis Mafia, which wasn't too bad, but it was nothing to write home about and wasn't that particularly fresh.  And they're fairly expensive as far as donuts go.

As others have said, the employees have a too-cool-for-school attitude about them, and take their damn time to wait on paying customers, although they really do go out of their way for penniless, drunk, cackling bums.

The place is painted black -- no doubt to cover stains of one and another sorts from a century or more of prior businesses, as well as the likely cockroaches crawling around.  It's in an old building in an old part of downtown, and I wouldn't be surprised if they have the highest protein content donuts in town, due to the indigenous bugs.

As a bonus, I had to walk past the aforementioned stumbling, cackling, wheezing, coughing bums on my way back to my car and demur on supplication for change on their part.

Unlike The Terminator, I won't be back.  And don't let Voodoo do you.  Don't believe the hype.

Shit coffee. Not drinkable. Apparently Stumptown went downhill or Voodoo blows chunks. I'd rather drink 7-11 coffee. Cafe Vita is next door... Go there instead. We also paid and waited to use the restroom but nothing was done when whoever was in there for a long time would not emerge. Donuts are ok, but with everything else, NOT  worth the wait.

I've always wanted to try Voodoo Donuts, and made a special trip on my only evening in Portland. I wanted to love them, I really did, but they were terrible. I got a few to try and they were all horribly sweet in a very bad way. I can drink pure maple syrup out of a jug, I have one of the biggest sweet tooths  out there, and they were just overkill. The sweetness has sort of an artificial sweet taste to it is the problem. They are adorable though and the shop is super cute, hence the two stars, but the donuts themselves just are bad.

This place is a total tourist trap.. the lines are atrociously long.. for what? I do not know. If the doughnuts actually tasted good then yes an establishment totally deserves a line but this place?? Get outta here! Ordered the their Capn donut... total let down.. tasted like a donut from hell.. they should consider renaming it 'sweet garbage' since that was it resembled.. looked like a buncha crap placed on a frosting caked doughnut.. 

I am by no means a donut connoisseur .. but i would say Krispy Kreme blows this place out of the water.. like seriously. 

+ 1star for the store decorations 
+ 1star for the friendly staff

My sisters and I were looking forward to seeing this place since it was talked about so much sadly we were very disappointed... The staff were the rudest people I've ever met and the doughnuts were undercooked and the design was sloppy. Wouldn't recommend to anyone.

Locals stay away: Normal donuts that take 45 mins to an hour to get, cost more, and have beard hair in them reeeeally make me miss dunkin donuts drive through. Seriously nothing special unless you need a dick-shaped doughnut for a bachelorette party.

First off: the cashier I had was very rude. I was rushed into picking a donut and picked the Gay Bar. It was pretty good (I'm a sucker for cream filled things) but the cereal on top was stale. 
I've heard about the lines for this place but I think we just got lucky because we walked in and out of the store. 
So my tip would be to come at an odd time so you don't catch the line

Don't understand the attraction to this place. My husband and I checked it out while visiting Portland because of all the hype about it. Yes the donuts were "different,"  but we both thought they weren't that good. He got the Froot Loop donut and I got the Habenero jelly filled. Mine was good but not anything great. They lacked freshness. Plus, the staff wasn't friendly and the area was very sketchy...Almost saw a fight break out and there were several panhandlers right outside the doors.

This place is an institution in Portland, but these donuts are customized versions of Winchell's donut - cakey in consistency, low on quality but open 24/7. We came here at 2am and the line was zero. Those who did come looking for sugar were mainly bar hoppers from nearby. We tourists grabbed the Voodoo doughnut with the pretzel pin in the body and filled with jam. It was cute, but nothing to write home about. 

The gourmet donut experience can be found at Blue Star Donuts. That's more my thing than Voodoo's community vibe.

Honestly, this place is so overrated and while there are a ton of options... there isn't enough to make me stand in line for upwards of a half hour. If you're going for the 'gram, then it's worth it, but don't waste your time for a second round.
I get that it's a tourist spot, but honestly the donuts are below average. Wacky flavors are cool in concept but don't taste good.

I don't get it. The wait is crazy, the people even crazier and the donuts are not the best. The idea is even a little strange. 

Lets focus on the quality of food. The donuts are the best that I have had. Their are lots of mom and pop do-nut places around the city that are far better. They are overly sweet without the savory doe. They seem really cheap and thrown together. Several really nasty flavor options. You must be a real idiot to come up with some of these nasty flavors. Shipley's in Texas makes this place look like the McDonald's of donuts. I also like Crispie Creme far better as well. I would not wait in line again for these donuts. Just not that good. The donuts at Safeway in the deli are probably just as good. Sorry Portland, this place is a real disappointment.

Fine donuts but nothing outstanding. They do have a lot of variety and the outlandish decor makes it an interesting experience. The line does move quickly and the staff are friendly. The chocolate glaze was the best part.
Brilliant and creative branding but quality of the doughnuts leaves something to be desired.

Always a good excuse to take a "field trip" over here, my classmates and I love walking over for a sugery sweet snack! They are pretty good, but not the cleanest or the best customer service I have received, but it's always fun to grab a certain cream filled dougnut for the classmate who chooses to stay behind ;)

Overall not very impressed with this doughnut shop. There is ALWAYS a line. I waiting to see what all the hype is about. It's mostly a huge tourist trap. I purchased a dozen doughnuts to sample a few and they were good. Not the best though. If I had to rank best doughnut shops in Portland I would rank in this order: 1. Pips 2. Blue star 3. Voodoo.

Don't get what the big deal is about this place.. There's a long line up almost all the time, the staff isn't friendly, the donuts are stale, and the loud heavy metal is just not inviting.. my whole experience here was terrible. We ate a few bites and had to chuck the rest of them, cause it was just like eating fructose syrup in bread format.. After a trip to Voodoo doughnuts you'll be one step closer to diabetes

It's a bit expensive for what it is.  Most doughnuts are much more over $1.  They do have really rich tasting and interesting doughnuts, but they are expensive.  Maybe I was lured into the allure of the bacon maple bar, but it was just a standard maple bar with a strip of bacon on it.  The maple was good, but the cake part was just a standard doughnut...

Great place to go once unless you really enjoy the touristy schtick, waiting in line, or you just LOVE donuts.

I always think  I LOVE donuts, but after a few bites I'm over it.

Apple fritters were the best.

CASH only though plenty of ATMS nearby.

Variety is the spice of life. If you are looking for unusual or specific flavors this is your place. Be prepared for the lines. Its Portland Trendy and it doesn't look to be going away any time soon. 
Out of town visitors will love the atmosphere and the visit to the funky store. In town people I am pretty sure will find a different donut spot and be content. 
Bring Cash.

Had to go up to Portland for work recently, and was told by a friend that I HAD to go to Voodoo Donuts.
