It was sprinkling rain out (in Portland, shocking!) but I decided that the short line was worth the wait being the huge fan of sugar that I am.  Got inside and was kind of overwhelmed by the menu, but went for the donut with the fruit loops on top.  I wanted a t-shirt too, but they didn't have my size =(

So...the donut was OK.  I mean, most of the options were your basic donut with icing and some sort of cereal/crumbled cookie/whatever on top.  The concept isn't THAT revolutionary.  I'm sure there were more interesting options I could have chosen, but there you have it.

It's worth checking out if you've never been, just so you can say you did.

The owners of this place have made a great name for themselves with a novelty.  The doughnuts served by Voodoo Doughnuts are the equivalent of a gas station doughnut; they have merely taken a mediocre product and slapped some cereal on top to make it into something marketable.  If you are looking for a good doughnut, skip this tourist-trap and head over to Heavenly Doughnuts.  
P.S.  If you want to see something hilarious, watch the Portland episode of DRUGS INC., where you will discover the downtown Voodoo location is below a heroin flop-house.  Seriously, there are drug deals going on right next to the line tourists stand in to get a taste of the trendy pastries.

I picked up 2 dozen doughnuts for my morning meeting and I rarely ever eat them because I travel a lot and try to eat on the healthier side.  I'm really sad that my first doughnut from voodoo had stale fruit loops on it!!  I plan on getting them for my morning meeting tomorrow as well and trying another one hopefully the 2nd one is better.  They are decorated great but so far I wasn't impressed.  Be cautious on the cereal topped ones because you might end up with stale cereal too!!

Meh. I don't understand what all the hype is for. That being said,  I'm no donut fanatic, so it tasted like any other donut. The location is bad with alot of transients hanging around. It's also next to an "adult" theater, which makes staring at the patrons as they come out entertaining.

Maybe it was just bad choices, but I was kind of underwhelmed.  I went with the Diablos Rex and the Portland Cream.  The Rex at least had some unique aspects being made of devils food cake.  The Portland Cream though was straight up Boston Cream though.  It seems like their thing is the variety of toppings they put on there.

Meh, I had high hopes because holy hell is there a lot of hype around this joint. It must've been every person I told I was going to visit portland who said I "HAD TO GO TO VOODOO DOUGHNUTS". 

My husband and I got 4 donuts to go because we needed to make a proper assessment of the inventory, you know, for research, and, and science! 

Typically my favorite donut on the planet is a maple bacon. Really, how can you possibly go wrong? Burnt, dry bacon is how, I guess. It made me so sad to see such a thing of beauty be so flawed. 

I think my husband liked his ODB best. I was more impressed with the name than the chocolate icing, Oreo crumbles (& I'm a woman who is borderline obsessive over her Oreos), and peanut butter spooge. 

Despite the aesthetically impressive display, my favorites were the old fashioned and the apple fritter. Who'da thought in such a creative space, the old tried and true would be the ones to make the positive impression.

Voodoo doughnuts: where the doughnuts are always stale, even when they're fresh!

The gimmick is good, but if you want your mind blown there are better shops in PDX.

I've been here twice now (tourist) & both times, my cashier wasn't particularly friendly. With a line constantly outside the door, I would expect at least some positive service from them despite the line. This place has a lot to live up to, & while the doughnuts all looked very cool, their flavors weren't too much better than your average local doughnut joint. I had a voodoo doll, Memphis mafia (yum), & a couple other cream-filleds. All great, fluffy, sugary doughnuts, just not the best doughnuts I've ever had. Also, prices are too high. Overall, overrated.

Voodoo makes a pretty ordinary donut but the toppings are wild and crazy dudes. I'm not a huge donut fan - my brother's kids wanted to come here - but it was fun to stand in line and people watch in the area.

A little overhyped in my opinion. If you're visiting from out of town you have to visit just because it's one of the places on your list. But definitely not a place I would go back if I'm ever in Portland again. Luckily when my friends and I came here it was like a 10 min wait but I can't imagine waiting over an hour for this and I will wait for good food. We got their Voodoo donut. vegan voodoo donut. Bacon maple. And fruit loops donut. All of them were good but personally there wasn't anything too special about them. The donuts aren't as greasy as other donut places but that's about it. Honestly sorry but it's overhyped.

Even though anything tastes good after a night of drinking and dancing, this place especially rocks since it's open all night. Next to Denny's, this will be our place to go for late night cravings. 

Be careful, though, it's easy to gobble several down before your tummy wakes up, and 10 minutes later you'll feel like you're going to explode. I picked one stuff with fruit loops. May sound kind of gross but it actually tasted really good. My friend tried a peanut butter crispy mix, and she loved it. I ended up snatching the rest of it when she went to the bathroom. So of course we had to order another one. Misson accomplished!  I'm not sure the doughnuts would have tasted as good sober, but at 1 a.m. they tasted like heaven.

Tip: Even though they're open all night, I heard that there's not much of a choice after 2 a.m. So if you want to try their best ones, head there a bit earlier.

I probably should've listened to people on Portland's Yelp Talk when they said to avoid this place. Not that it was horrible to go to at all. But, in the end, Voodoo Doughnut is still just a doughnut shop. And, honestly, not even that great of one at that.

I convinced Boyfriend that it was worth going to at least EXPERIENCE it -- after all, why go all the way to Portland to only then disappoint people when they ask if we had Voodoo? Luckily, we only waited about 20 minutes in line before we were walking up to the register (surprisingly, the line wasn't too long but it was probably because we went during a time most people are enjoying dinner). A good friend of mine had made a request that, if we went, to please please PLEASE bring her back some Voodoo, so we had a list ready to go to hand over to our cashier. Which he apparently really appreciated. He said it made his job easier!

We got a dozen doughnuts and the total ended up being $24 even (bless the lack of sales tax in Oregon). Still, that's a hefty price to pay for 12 doughnuts. We ordered a voodoo doll, a maple old fashioned, a Captain My Captain, a No Name, a Dirty Snowball, a Memphis Mafia (totally a fritter, not a doughnut and $5!!), a McMinnville, a Mango Tango, two bacon maple bars and two Mexican Hot Chocolate doughnuts.

I personally ate the Captain My Captain, bacon maple and Mexican Hot Chocolate. Not a huge fan of the Captain My Captain -- it was a regular doughnut, liberally covered in icing and cereal. I ended up picking the cereal off to eat and dumping the doughnut. The bacon maple bar was really good though! Savory and sweet, but not overly so in either spectrum. And I should've passed totally on the Mexican Hot Chocolate. It tasted kind of gross to me.

My friend who had requested six of the doughnuts in that list was pretty juiced that we managed to get them to her through security, TSA and flying. Too bad the cabin pressure made them kind of implode on themselves since we individually bagged them into Ziplocs before flying :( But she said they were overall pretty good, but, again, nothing too special.

In the end, they're just doughnuts. I kind of wish I had either a) not gone at all and saved my money, or b) bought a smaller amount. Definitely worth the try, and now I can say I've had Voodoo in Portland, but I don't think I'll be going for return visits.
I tried this place from all of the hype. The donuts were very mediocre & I disliked the long line and then rushed ordering. it was more of a hassle than a treat.

I mean, it's donuts. There are a million different choices, and it's a fun tourist destination, but who cares. I would never stand in line there again to get the donut I really like, the "Tex-Ass" which is just a gigantic glazed donut. I've always been more of a Krispy Kreme guy, I like their decadent, wet glazed donuts. bottom line, everyone should try Voodoo once, but then you've done it and there is really no reason to go to the trouble of doing it again. Enough said.

Donuts are donuts. And donuts are still donuts even when you throw cereal, bacon, Oreos or any other topping you can think of on them. Kudos for the creativity, portions and presentation. We tried the maple bacon bar, captain crunch, and blueberry donut. They were all good. Maple and captain crunch was very sweet. The blueberry donut was well balanced. There were other outrageous flavors but we weren't into them. Definitely a tourist spot more than a local favorite.

Alright, let's talk. If you're going to sell donuts, you have to make drinkable coffee!! The donuts were great- no worries there. They are an infamous donut shop for good reason. But their coffee was terrible. At first i just thought it was extremely watered down...and it was, but there was something else. Some strange, not-at-all coffee like taste coming from my coffee cup. Oregano? Probably not, but you get the idea of how foreign this flavor was- I'm not xenophobic here, but coffee should taste like coffee. And when it doesn't, I get a little bit worried. 
Coffee aside, my sister and I ordered 1 Cock and Balls, The dirty bastard one, and a simple chocolate coconut. This selection lasted us days!

Cash only. I'd give 2.5 stars because that's exactly average but that's not an option and so I remained on the slightly more disappointed side. I love donuts, and am not really a donut snob (I like grocery store ones just fine). With that said, I can still decipher quality. We stood in line for 20-30 minutes on a Saturday morning and the line moved fast, but I think it's about the experience (of hype) more than the actual donuts, which I didn't expect I would be saying. They weren't bad, just not mind-blowing for as long of a wait as you'll have. Also a little more expensive and prices aren't mainstreamed so you have to be careful with that. While we were walking around with the pink box, a local told us about some really good donut and pastry shops. So if you want a tourist experience, go here. If you want delicious donuts, ask a local for a recommendation.
Yes, I tried. I do not see why is so much buzz about this place. Probably fits this "weird" Portland picture. You can find better donuts elsewhere.

Voodoo is fun and creative donut shop that will charm you with its kitsch, fun flavors and unique ingredients. It is also an over-hyped tourist trap that will make your wonder why you stood in an hour-long line just to have a donut? 

Don't get me wrong. I like Voodoo. I just think the hype on the place has exceeded reality. My experience here reminds of the fervor that gripped the area back in the 90's when Krispy Kreme left its southern confines and start popping up in ever city in the US. Lines stretched for hours as devotees and wannabes waited patiently to experience donut nirvana. I joined in the fun and waited with them. And I felt then like I feel now... "Good donut, why is there a line?"

In all fairness, Voodoo's Chinatown location tends to attract larger crowds than its other two stores, so it is possible to get my favorite maple bacon without standing in a long line. But that said, these are just donuts. Creative to be sure, but really no better or worse than can be had in many fine donut shops in Portland and elsewhere.

Stand in line if you must for the experience, but let's put an end to the hype. Oh, and hit the ATM before you wait in line. Cash only folks.

Don't believe the hype. Voodoo donuts are NOT good. They are just "different" part of what keeps Portland weird but I've had waaaaaaaaay better frick'n donuts. Save yourself the 45 min wait and don't bother!

Voodoo Donut oh oh Voodoo Donut oh oh

PDX is where it's at 
Located it with my yelp app

Voodoo Donut oh oh Voodoo Donut oh oh

I be a tourist and checked this out
Tons of yelp reviews and word of mouth

Voodoo Donut oh oh Voodoo Donut oh oh

We arrived with a line eeeh somewhat long
People watched, found guys that looked like Cheech and Chong

Voodoo Donut oh oh Voodoo Donut oh oh

15 minutes later we were in
Read the menu board and OMG I felt indulgin'

Voodoo Donut oh oh Voodoo Donut oh oh

Loved the donuts with the homo flair
Gay bar, Big ass...where's the one for twinks and bears?!

Voodoo Donut oh oh Voodoo Donut oh oh

Saw folks with a dozen, oh hell no
That is super calorie overflow

Voodoo Donut oh oh Voodoo Donut oh oh

I at least got three
The mango cream one was the one for me

Voodoo Donut oh oh Voodoo Donut oh oh

Agree with the 2, 3 star reviews here
It's a tourist thing and I'd rather have a beer

But when in PDX you really need
To check this off your list indeed

And say yeah.. been there done that...Voodoo Donut oh oh Voodoo Donut oh oh

oooooooooohhhhhhhhhhh..................hollah atcha boiyaaaaaaa.....boom. YOLO.

This is a must stop spot on anyone's first trip to Portland. Its been all over Food Network and Travel Channel. They have lots of interesting doughnuts that you wouldn't see anywhere else.

Are they good doughnuts? They aren't bad I guess. I think its more about the experience than the actual doughnuts. 

If the line is super long, I wouldn't wait. But I would suggest going earlier rather than later. I went super late at night my first time and there were only a handful of doughnuts to choose from. 

I would go again, if I was in the neighborhood and there was no line. Its definitely an interesting place with interesting doughnut varieties. But overall, it was kind of a let down.

Over-hyped, over-priced, over-coated with sugar.  We four almost gagged after half of our individual donuts and did not want to see the rest of the pink box again. 
Been there, done that.  Lesson learned.

I wish it wasn't such an in-and-out format but it is. Like, it's literally 'get your doughnuts' and then 'get the hell out' but everybody knows how it works and nobody actually says "get the hell out". However, atmosphere and gimmick shouldn't make up for the quality of their food. I've had a few doughnuts there and they're just okay. Nothing special. But maybe I need to broaden my horizons and try some more. I'll definitely be back but if everything still taste bland then I'll find a new doughnut shop.

Came to Portland for the day and figure why not try these doughnuts since I've seen it on numerous tv shows.  Got there around 930 in the morning, there was a small line.  We ordered the bacon maple bar, the voodoo doll, and a couple of other doughnuts.  The bacon maple doughnut was AWESOME!!! All the other ones were good as well but the maple bacon was the BEST!!!

Every few years I stop in and ask if they have gluten free doughnuts and every single time I'm met with a serious attitude and an eye roll. I figure if they can do vegan they can do gluten free, like many PDX shops, but I was told that it would never be an option. It makes me sad because I hear such good things about these doughnuts but I can't support a business who's employees are so rude, even if they do decide to make GF options.

Voodoo is great for a kitschy and unique factor that keeps people visiting, and the donuts are great. Yet... they are still just donuts. 
That being said... the peach fritter is my favorite thing on the menu. It's a little heavy on the frosting, but it is as big as my head and full of delicious peachy bits that have led me to order it more than once. The voodoo man is fair, for novelty's sake, and the grape ape is interesting enough to make it worth a try.
Definitely not open 24 hours. Went there at 4am, stood in line for 5 minutes, then was told it wouldn't be open until 6am. I think they close to create a line and make it look crowded and popular.

2.5 stars for interesting decor an. Concept but donuts did not meet standards. Tried the maple bacon bar that was popular per our cashier. Bacon was good, crispy, an. Thick! They do not buy cheap bacon let me tell you that! Dough of the donut was slightly hard and wasn't too buttery as how a do night should be. Since we came at 8:30PM, I didn't expect these prized jewels to be pipping HOT but at least edible. I am a donut lover and even grocery store bought donuts taste better. 

I also got a glazed one because you  can judge a doughnut shop by eating it's glazed dough! If a doughnut shop fails on it's glazed donuts then it cannot be more than mediocre.

Oh how it failed me :( not only was it pretty dry with slightly melted glaze as though it's been sitting out all day, but the dough tasted like white pre-package store bought sandwich wonder bread. 

I came. 
I tasted.
VooDoo failed.

I'm rounding up from two and a half stars. I'm glad we checked out Voodoo Doughnut during our trip to Portland, but really, I've had better novelty snack items in my day. There were certainly a number of interesting sounding doughnuts to choose from, but ours were a little dry, and the frosting on both of the flavors we tried (maple and Oreo) were sickly sweet. Plus, I was pretty much over the "over it" kids working behind the counter. If you think tourists are lame, don't work at a place featured on Food Network.

Best part about this place is that it's open 24/7.  There's usually a long wait outside with a fairly small inside store area.  Workers of course get through the line as quickly as possible so don't be scared by the long line.  As far as variety of options goes, Voodoo has it all.  They even have some oversized fun donuts to experience.  The taste, I thought, was nothing special.  After all, due to the numbers they move, the donuts are mass produced.  It's a fun place to check out if visiting Portland, especially if you have donut cravings late at night, but I don't think I'll re-visit Voodoo on my next trip to Portland.

The first time I had ever gone here was with my sisters near midnight. The wait was like 20 minutes. Since I had heard a lot about how good the doughnuts were I was really expecting some out of the world donuts, but they were just ok. There wasn't anything that was that special about them. They are just donuts formed into many different shapes with what seems like unusual toppings. I would not wait in the long line that everyone does during the day for these donuts as they were nothing special, just overhyped.

Bookmarked this place before I got into town. Luckily there was no line outside when we went. So disappointing . Tried a cake donut and it was small and so dry. Also tried a regular chocolate glazed and it was nothing special. This location did not seem to be in a good part of town. Let's just say we saw some guys get into a major fist fight right near here.

A Massachusetts native whose hometown's ratio of Dunkin Donuts to Starbucks is 5 to 1, I have eaten enough donuts in my lifetime to discern a good doughnut from a bad one. Voodoo doughnuts is creative, but it lacks the taste or texture of best doughnuts out there. Eh, I'm not a fan of Coco Puffs or Captain Crunch anyway. On to the next doughnut shop!

One star for the creative designs.  Nothing else to see or taste here.  It's insulting to the city of Portland that one of the only things people will line up around the block for here is a doughnut that tastes like a fried milk carton.

I would give them one star for saving my shitty, broke Christmas one time but I am pretty sure those genuinely cool people don't even touch this place anymore.

For a place that supposedly is a must have, I don't think it is all that special. First things first, you don't get to choose your donuts, they chose it for you... so don't go there expecting to get your pick and choose of what you want. And the donuts themselves are good but you could go to any donut hop down the street and get a decent donut. So if you want to go there for the sake of getting a cool looking donut then go for it, otherwise save yourselves the trip of going through a sketchy part of town in portland.

I think it's more hype than anything, honestly!!!  I tried it because the line 
was short and glad I did because now I know there isn't much about it!

Although I enjoyed the store decorations and the customers (they are always waiting with great energy)...  I suggest you try it yourself!!!  You will have to get in line for 20 - 45 minutes, if you lucky to get a so-so donut for $3+ each.

Or you can just go to the local donut shop, get a 50cents donut & stick a pretzel on the center or dip in your own Captain Crunch!!!

In the future, I would like to try a few more times just in case, hahaha but I will never wait for 45+ minutes for an expensive donut! lol
A tourist stop. thats about it here. A place to go to once maybe but  the wait is definitely not worth it.
Most expansive dough in the World! The oil they use to fry the doughnuts in leaves thick & uncomfortable film in your mouth... shortening? Try to avoid this tourist, trap.
The lines are too long, they treat their employees like dirt, and their donuts are definitely not "heart-smart"
Meh.  I just don't think these doughnuts are anything to write home about.  Not bad.  Not great.  Just ok.  A-OK.

Yup, I went to Voodoo for the first time this past Spring break and I honestly don't know what the hype is about. Sure there is a doughnut called Cock and Balls which is quite silly but other than a few unique doughnuts and their characteristics, it's just doughnuts. 

It's the same thing as cupcakes being a super fad but cupcakes are cupcakes in the end and doughnuts are just doughnuts. 

Don't get me wrong, I am a huge fanatic of doughnuts, I crave them almost everyday but that doesn't mean I get to eat them everyday considering how unhealthy they are!!

I ordered a select variety to take back home with me in Tacoma (WA) and yea. Not that big of a deal. Since it is so popular, the prices are not the worth of the taste. I expected a lot more from them. But then again, my expectations for a lot of foods are high maintenance compared to other "foodies". 

It's alright but not worth the 30+ minutes wait in line outside with the rain and definitely the peer pressure of standing in front of the register for more than a minute looking at the doughnuts and figuring out which ones you want... not worth it.

Place has gotten so much attention on TV & other places that the staff don't give a flying frick about customer service anymore. This attitude may also go up to management. When you have a line out the door from open to close, why make any effort anymore? 

Not worth the 30 minute wait for the sour attitude at the end of the line. Bad attitude messes with the taste of food. Either that or the doughnuts really did suck.

ehhhh....living in Portland for all of my life. All the reviews that give it 4+ stars are either

1. New to Oregon
2. Visiting 
3. Havent tried anywhere else. 

I enjoy the doughnuts, but majority of the time, it s a long wait for semi stale doughnuts. Yea, its got some unique concepts, but other then that? Not much to be desired. I would recommend one time only, other then that...? Not much to fall in love with.

It's a gimmick, not a good product. I don't get why there's a line at this place, ever.

The icing is sickly sweet. Like disgustingly so. If you want a good donut, go to Sesame Donuts. Or Krispy Kreme, but I think Sesame is better.

Not impressed. Waited 45 minutes for donuts that were cloyingly sweet messes. The place is a tourist trap. Also the area is a bit rough as well. I was so disappointed. I had the dirty snowball which was coconut and peanut butter but the donut was dry. My hubby had half of a Oreo concoction and we gave the other two donuts away to the homeless. Go to blue star instead. The only cool thing at voodoo is the sign and decor.

I really don't understand what's the rave about this place. The lines are long. The donuts are stale. (I haven't been lucky enough to get ones fresh out of the oven yet.) I've been here a couple of times, always hoping just maybe it was a fluke. After four tries, methinks not.

Give me a Krispy Kreme over this anyday!

We waited in line for about 30 mins to get our donuts tonight. When we got to the front of the line the lady that helped us was extremely rude. She appeared to be unhappy because we paid for 2 donuts in change ($3.85). Since it is a cash only place that does not seem so unreasonable. She slammed the cash register and abruptly gave us our donuts. Overall I am sad to say it was a bad experience at Voodoo donut. I do not feel she had any reason to treat us as unkindly as she did.

The actual donut dough is really good. Unfortunately, the toons, even basic chocolate glaze, is really really sweet. I have Asian sweet sensibilities, so its quite a bit to much. Even compared to the average donut shop, voodoo is extremely sweet. For sweet lovers, might be fine.
Donuts are good, service is fair, no coffee, no forks, nasty outside. Don't waste your time.

Touristy, yes, but it also embraces all the weird that Portland is, and I thoroughly loved it. I agree with some of the other yelpers on here that they're not as weird and different as they claim to be (woo hoo, fruitloops on a doughnut...lets go wild, guys!) and can be on the sweeter side. But you know what? It's fun and something to be sampled at least once. Twice for us...but you know...

My boyfriend's take on it -- in his own words: "For me, the doughnuts were less about the quality and more about experience of eating creative doughnuts."

Also, they're fairly cheap. Go Oregon with your bad ass no sales tax awesomeness.

We ordered:
-Bacon Maple Doughnut -- I loved it. It is sweet, but it's freaking bacon and bacon is always a win.
-Old Dirty Bastard: Oreos and glaze. My boyfriend ate the entire thing before I got to try a bite but he said he seemed to liked it a lot...hence the eating all of it before I had a chance.
-Voodoo Doll? I think that was the name. I think it's their mascot doughnut. It's got chocolate glaze, frosting face, a pretzel sticking in it's heart and filled with raspberry and I'm a sucker for raspberry and chocolate so I enjoyed it.
-Miami: A freaking explosion of color and frosting. Super sweet. My friend ordered it so I had a bite and that bite was about all I could take.

If you're in Portland give it a try but just know it's for the novelty. It's a fun place to go with friends when you have a sweet tooth -- and believe me, they deliver on the sweet tooth.
Okay service, long lines, the donuts taste like regular donuts. Not sure what the hype is...

This is a tourist trap. The donuts were disgusting. I came here for vacation May of 2017. The donuts were fresh, but tasted like eating sugar. Super yuck! Don't bother. Go to a Blue Star Donuts instead.
overpriced racist tourist trap. everything that is shitty about portland deep fried and sugar coated. Pass

This place is one of the many things that make portland so popular. Voodoo is known for its eccentric donuts, decor and creativity. Lines are long but moves relatively quick. The have a large selection of donuts, from yeast, to cake, to you name it. A variety of flavors, toppings, fillings and names that make you just want the donut because of what it's called. That being said, donuts were ok. The flavors were ok. Seemed like there's a lot of pizazz but not much to back it up. The donuts just throw flavors at you but those flavors are not tried and tested. Gimmicky I suppose. Glad I tried it at least once though.
Donuts look great but taste is just ok. Cereal was stale not crunchy and customer service left a lot to be desired.

I guess I'm just the contrarian. I don't see what the big deal is. Their doughnuts are GOOD, but not great. Certainly not worth waiting in line for an hour. Certainly not worthy of international notoriety. For your $3, you'll get a standard, overly-sweet, Safeway-quality doughnut with kooky shit sprinkled on top. Enjoy.
I love the doughnuts, but refused to wait 1 hour plus so we went to Voodoo Too the next day with no wait.

I wanted to give these guys 5 stars. This has been one of the only reasons I agreed to be dragged to Oregon in the first place! 

The donuts are really good. They are thick and cakey, very fresh and wonderful. Their online customer service is wonderful! But alas- only 3 stars for you in the hopes that some day I will be able to give you a better grade.

When I found out I was going to Portland, I reached out to my foodie family and told them I was going to VooDoo Donuts. So we gathered around in the living room and everyone looked at the menu and we compiled a list of what to order. I called that evening and made the order because that way everyone would know I ordered their favorites and it was one less thing to worry about. I called and placed the order and was told it would be waiting for me on Thursday and I said great!

When we arrived the line was less than 10 minutes long...in fact, I was able to walk right into the shop. I gave the lady my name and she went in the back and returned with my huge box. I peeked inside saw that they had multiple levels of donut with waxed paper in between. I didn't doddle because the smell was driving me insane so I went to the airport and flew back to SFO. 

I have to say, I have never been leered at so much in my life. Toward the end, I was feeling I should have an armed guard. But I made it home. When I got home we discovered we had been shorted the VooDoo Doll Donuts! I mean, how do you come back from that? The chocolate I saw through the wax paper was just the Portland Creams. 

So a very heart broken me writes VooDoo, and I was told that they were sorry and next time I'm in Portland they will make it right...Next time I am in Portland? Really? I was really really disappointed and this is the reason for the 3 stars.

Everyone recommended Voodoo on our trip to Portland. We certainly thought it was over rated. I appreciate the selection and creativity of flavors and designs but the flavors were just not there. We ended up getting the blue raspberry donut, bubble gum donut and the voodoo. The bubble gum and blue raspberry were just vanilla(?) Glaze with flavored sugar it seemed like. You had tp really search for the flavor. I like my donuts light and airy and these were dry and dense. we went after dinner and didnt have to wait in line. It's  not worth the wait.

Being a native to Portland all my life I never would have ventured into this place had it not been for the long lines. Surely something this demanded had to be of good quality? Wrong. I've had better (and fresher) doughnuts from a grocery store bakery. 

The only reason for two stars is because they have made bacon maple bars revolutionary to other spots that I enjoy much better.

If you're into waiting in line forever for the experience of being rushed out the door quickly by overwhelmed staff and novelty, then by all means, this is what you've been looking for. The only plus side of this place is the dozens of drunk tourists and gutter punks who like to give out free eats from day old 5 gallon buckets if you happen to be passing by at night and are hungry. 
In reality there's only two words that come to mind when I see this place- tourist trap.
Mediocre product, super touristy.  If their donuts were as good as their marketing, they would rule the donut universe

I stopped in at the downtown Voodoo to celebrate today.  What I was celebrating was that it was Friday morning and there was NO LINE at Voodoo.  Not one person waiting.  Weird, huh?  

My usual experience is to coast by, observe the queue strung out down the sidewalk, mutter "Fuck it" and ride on.  But today, no line.  It must be some kind of celebration of specialness and therefore I had to stop.

I got the legendary bacon maple bar, the rice krispie peanut butter and just for color, the crunchberries donut.  Took the three to the office to divvy up with my office mates.  I have to say that VDs straight from the kitchen are far better than the bargain bucket o' day-olds that are known to turn up in the breakroom and at bike events.

And still, as fresh as you can get them, underneath the novelty toppings lurks a very average doughnut at a rather high price.

True, the bacon maple is an inspired combo once in a while and I enjoy the peanut butter drizzle on the rice krispies doughnut.  But then the crunchberries are embedded in a hypersweet white glaze that makes the whole thing a little nauseating and silly.  You could go to Safeway, get a fresh doughnut from the bakery, slap a bunch of canned frosting on top and smoosh a bowl of cereal into it and be pretty damned close without venturing past aisle 5.

I am mystified by the aura of awesomeness that surrounds this place when there are plenty of really great doughnuts in this town.  But there are many things that mystify me - why it is so scary to have national healthcare, how people do cyclocross racing on unicycles, the popularity of Coldplay.  It's all too much to contemplate.

Every non-local has seemingly heard of, and wants to visit. Typically too crowded to justify waiting in line for average (albeit creative) doughnuts. Worth the experience if you're passing by with no line, otherwise shouldn't be the sole focus of a downtown excursion.

Had family in town and a must was a trip to Voodoo Doughnut.  We waited in line over 30 minutes which was part of the experience.  The brunette that helped us was less than enthusiastic.  Her comments were rude and clearly did not have the personality to be working in such a high energy place.  We tried to be light hearted to no avail.  She wouldn't make eye contact with us and was sarcastic.  We were stunned by her demeanor.  We even put money in the tip jar before she helped us.  We were tempted to take it back. (but didn't)  We couldn't get her name but did complain to the guy outside greeting everyone in line.  I'm sure nothing was said to her.  If I was an employer I would want to know if one of my employees was rude and unfriendly to our customers.  She acted put out to be helping us.  We aren't going to let one person spoil future visits.  I have family coming next week and I hope she isn't there.

I really didn't get the hype here. Sure, they have lots of unusual toppings, but nothing that wowed me. The Carmel chocolate coconut crunch and the filled maple frosted were good. Other than the cereal and candy toppings, pretty much compared to DD in my opinion. Definitely wouldn't wait in a long line for it.

Where else does a dirty bastard taste so good?

You want it?  They have it.

I only stop in when a sweet tooth hits and there is no line.

Beware of long lines and CASH ONLY

What I sampled: Triple Chocolate Penetration, Dirt doughnut, McMinnville Cream
Visit date: September 4 (er...5 by the time we got to the front of the line), 2011
First time? Yes, everyone was recommending it!

O VooDoo, l I was so excited to meet you, but I was slightly disappointed. I do love a good doughnut, but VooDoo isn't that much more special than an average doughnut shop. I do give them credit for good basic flavors. And yes, they do have some crazy doughnut concoctions (pun intended) that are interesting to look at, but it was definitely not worth the hour long wait. It was more of an 'experiential' food event. On to the doughnuts: 

The Triple Chocolate Penetration: Chocolate cake doughnut, chocolate frosting, and coco puffs. This was my favorite doughnut of the three. I could do away with the coco puffs though. The chocolate cake doughnut itself was dense yet fluffy and went well with the sweetness of the chocolate frosting. I would have been happy with just the Double Chocolate doughnut.

The Dirt doughnut: Doughnut with vanilla frosting and crumbled Oreos. I appreciated how the frosting tasted like Oreo cream. This doughnut was a bit too sweet for my taste.

The McMinnville Cream: Doughnut with Bavarian cream and maple frosting. The cream was nasty, so I ate around it (the doughnut and frosting made a good pair).

More hype than substance I think.  Is it worth standing in line?  Well maybe if you are from out of town and checking off a bucket list item.  They sell doughnuts, just happen to have different toppings, weird names or shaped differently.  Don't get me wrong, it's fun and all, but at the end of the day, just doughnuts.  Worth going once for sure, but been there once, you've done it and can bring your out of town guests.  Now the kids on the other hand, seem to love the place and go whenever they can.

This place comes with a "Keep Portland Weird" mantra perfectly. Just over the corner from our hotel, always line, open 24 hours, cash only.
But at he end - it's still donuts, so I ordered  "The Homer" donut  (Raised ring dipped in strawberry flavored icing and a smattering of round sprinkles), don't remember my DW selection. We spoke with the owner Johnny, really spooky looking guy, asked him about the name, promised him one of our son's Video Blog You tuber to stop by. In any case took the donuts out, tried them later at the hotel, whoa what a sugar overload, could not finished them  up, too sweet.

Add the word voodoo in front of anything and it would make it a hit since we love a little mystery and darkness in our food, but is it worth the wait? I don't believe so. 

However, people will still come to this place because they want to find out for themselves what is a voodoo doughnut. The only voodoo I see them doing to these doughnuts is over stuffing it with way too much of other good stuff (peanut butter, jelly, chocolate, and etc).

We had the unfortunate hindsight of ordering 6 different voodoo doughnuts to share with friends and families. Each of these doughnut was sweet enough for 4 people to share and it stays with you for the rest of the day.

I ordered the Voodoo Doll. I was disappointed that it came out looking like a long bar of doughnut without any identifiable eyes or mouth, killed by a heart attack from its own sweetness instead of the pretzel stick in the middle. This was after a long wait that seemed like forever.

A funky place with a great selection of standard and very weird donuts. Frankly, though, they tasted about the same as donuts anywhere. But, since this is Portland, ya gotta go there. And wait. And wait. (Or, you can visit the new store in Denver and wait there, too, because a lot of folks have the "munchies" in Denver now.) FYI, no credit cards accepted, but there's a cash point in the corner.

Go when it's raining because the wait is not worth it.

I was expecting it to be fresh out the fryer--I'm krispie kreme spoiled.

I saw all the tourists there, waiting in line at all hours of the day. I rode my bike when in Portland and the line never seemed to get shorter. 

I like the transients that ask folks in line to buy them a donut. But the highlight are the teenagers buying two dozen donuts but always avoiding the "dick and balls" one. 

I've had better donuts in the Bay, but I like the atmosphere of Voodoo Donuts--no cops.

Cash only. ATM inside. Adult theater next door.

Not exactly the best donuts I've ever had... but definitely cute and worth the wait. Huge touristy destination. Don't worry, the homeless folks are harmless and nice. Expect a long, long line (over half an hour wait). If you can, look at the menu online and know beforehand what to order because it's hard to take your time once you're inside. And the selection is hard to read through when feeling rushed.

My favorites are the bacon maple bar and peanut butter oreo donut. Beware of frosting overload (to me is a bad thing, to you may be a good thing). More than not, I scrape half the frosting off my maple bar because it hurts to eat it. I honestly just like the donuts here because of the funky combinations. The fact that it was on food network slightly makes me like it more. Damn hipster blood coursing through me!

I was blown away by the creativity and variety of selection, however the taste not so much. It meets the average doughnut expectation, but if your asking of the freshness of the quality, it just wasn't there. It really is all about the hype here at Voodoo. If you haven't eaten a doughnut here, you aren't missing out on much. You can simply go to your local grocery store, pick up a box of cereal, grab a glazed or chocolate doughnut from your local doughnut shop, and throw everything together. Thats just how i feel. Overall, it was a good experience visiting both locations. 

Hungry and don't want to pay for a doughnut? Do the Tex-ASS doughnut challenge. Six regular doughnuts formed into one big Ass glazed doughnut! you have 80 seconds to finish it otherwise you pay for it. Fortunately for me, I DID IT!

Is there really a point in reading this review? Probably not, since a quick scan of all the reviews will indicate that you'll either love or hate this place, and that you really do need to go try it yourself. It would be un-Portland of you not to give it a try at least once, especially if you're from out of town.  Much like the Pike Place Fish Market is to Seattle, Voodoo is to Portland.  I'm sure someone will want to dispute me on this comparison, but let's just let it slide?

Personally, I think it's good if you're in the neighborhood and eat one right away.  Give it a few hours and the donut quickly goes stale.  I prefer the Vegan ones, even though that's not how I usually roll.

So if you're reading reviews to decide whether you should give Voodoo a try...I say go for it if you have an extra 2 dollars in your pocket, cause frankly, 2 dollars won't even get you an all zone pass on Tri-met anymore and it'll hardly buy you an hours parking downtown come July 13th.  Might as well get a little flavor of Portland weirdness with your dough. (ba-dum-ching!)

While in Portland, OR, took time to stop at Voodoo Doughnuts.   The line took all of an hour to get through on a Sunday morning.    Since the eclipse was next day, I was not surprised.   There were many choices available even with the number of people.  My favs were the raised cream filled donuts.   Cake reminded me of just that, cake.

It's cute, but they're just a sugary mess. Stale cereal on top of a doughnut is as underwhelming as it sounds, and the amount of stuff they put on their doughnuts (the peanut butter chocolate apple fritter comes to mind) always gives me a gut ache. If you want a GOOD doughnut that isn't a total gut bomb, head over to Tonalli's. 2 locations in portland, best old school doughnuts in town, period. Also, no line full of hipsters and basics. Plus ice cream and burgers.

Tons of variety and loaded with crazy, Voodoo Doughnuts are too gimmicky for me. However, if you haven't been, check this bakery out once. It's sort of a rite of passage when visiting Portland. I give them props for being open 24/7, but I wouldn't go back especially if there's a nearby Blue Star.

I got a box of 8...unfortunately, despite the uniqueness of the media, packaging and flavor topping combos...the doughnuts were mostly stale and less vibrant with freshness, texture and flavor than their rival I tried the same morning: Blue Star (DO NOT SLEEP ON BLUE STAR!).
I had two Memphis Mafias (banana fritter with chocolate and pb topping), a bacon maple, PB Oreo, cream cheese peach fritter, mango guava jelly, lemon iced marionberry filled, and an "eclipsicle" doughnut (chocolate iced with orange cream filling). 

-Memphis Mafias (banana fritter with chocolate and pb topping: banana chunks weren't very detectable, at all, which was a let down. I'm thinking they wee mashed and blended into the batter but don't expect to have sweet banana chunks. The peanut butter overwhelms the rest of the fritter flavoring. Would not rebuy again.
-Bacon maple: strips of bacon were stale and dry. Maple was less than mediocre. Wouldn't rebuy and didn't even finish eating.
-PB Oreo: cookies were stale and soft--obviously the doughnut had been sitting for hours. Total let down. I've had better from chain doughnut shots and would not rebuy from Voodoo.
-Cream cheese peach fritter: fantastic peach chunks with the blend of slightly salty and tart cream cheese. This was a win.
-Mango guava jelly: fun salty tang on top paired with the unique guava jelly. Would rebuy and was a fun twist.
-Lemon iced marionberry filled:fun and tart topping but the filling was lackadaisical and bland. Definitely a lack of clean punch to tie it all together. Wouldn't necessarily rebuy...
-"eclipsicle" doughnut (chocolate iced with orange cream filling) this was a fun take, but the mixing of flavors could leave you feeling ill as there's an essence of medicine flavoring that I can't place.
Overall: fun tourist experience...don't wait too long, TAKE CASH ONLY, don't have high expectations, and follow up for a better experience at Blue Star!!

This place is worth venturing to on these occasions:

You are drunk and downtown

You are downtown and drunk

You are drunk, downtown, and have friends in town who are Voodoo virgins.  

Otherwise, I see no point in making a special trip to Voodoo donuts.  True, those times I have partaken I have not been disappointed (read:  the donuts are delicious and my inner fat kid was happy), but the fare is, needless to say, pretty ridiculous (read: nothing you need to make a habit of).

Hmmm.....Ridiculous + Delicious= Ridiculicious?

The doughnuts themselves are not bad BUT they're no different than any other shop

I think VOODOO is just unique for the crazy flavor combinations they offer that makes them famous ...so expect LONG TOURISTY LINES but they go pretty quickly

no menu to look at while you are waiting in line.. we didn't get a glimpse of the menu until it was almost time to order.. what a stressful situation considering they have so many options

---Maple bacon doughnut: the bacon is not my cup of tea. We ripped off the bacon & were left w/ a maple bar that was good but again just like any other

NOTE: CASH ONLY & there's outdoor seating
Blue Star is much better. Doughnuts with stale cereal on top and a maple bar with a piece of bacon on top, how creative.

This place isn't what I expected it to be - I guess there's a lot of variety that's the bright side of it but besides that I find the donuts too sweet and the dough not as fluffy. The maple bacon bar was their signature donut and I guess the salty and the sweet combo makes it bearable - good but not to die for or to wait for - not worth the experience

I've gone to Voodoo Doughnuts twice. They have some unique creations and weird and dirty (I mean dirty, unsanitary) locations, other than that, nothing really special unless you're a hipster. Have had as good and better tasting doughnuts numerous times elsewhere.
Not really a fan. Donuts are WAY too sweet, and definitely not worth standing in line for.

Tourist trap. Go to the location closer to the airport. Wait in line in the heat for 30-40 minutes

Staff is just there to grab you a doughnut. Seemed to careless to suggest any types. 

Tried the Memphis mafia. If you like bananas then go for it. It was a banana fritters with chocolate and peanut butter on top. I Love for others but I did not care for this one

We also try the maple bar with bacon on it it was fairly good.

And I tried a couple other flavors. I prefer Blue Star Donuts.

It would've been a disservice to the fine city of Portland to pay a visit without coming to Voodoo Doughnut. And so we fulfilled our civic duty. 

***BACON MAPLE BAR - Raised yeast doughnut with maple frosting and bacon on top

Stunningly average, just your standard maple bar with a strip of bacon on top. And not that crispy oily "I could bite the you into a million pieces" type, but a dull, flat, thick, & chewy variety. As if they gave each other high fives for barely fulfilling the quota to "Keep Portland Weird".

***PORTLAND CREAM - Raised yeast doughnut filled with Bavarian cream with chocolate on the top and two eyeballs

Allegedly the official doughnut of Portland, I couldn't have been more bored. This was just about the most nondescript doughnut ever, pedestrian dough, a bit of standard chocolate glaze on top, and filled with an odd, almost clear, water-soluble solution that cried "Contains no actual milk solids". 

***MEMPHIS MAFIA - Fried dough with banana chunks and cinnamon sugar covered in a glaze with chocolate frosting, peanut butter, peanuts and chocolate chips on top

This was the closest thing to approachable that we tried--I could taste a bit of banana essence in the dough, and the chocolate and peanut butter combo on top had potential, but in the end the heaviness of this beast became the millstone around its neck. 

***OLD DIRTY BASTARD - Raised yeast doughnut with chocolate frosting, Oreos, and peanut butter

Basically the same as the above, but with no banana flavor, and Oreo chunks on top. 

ALL IN ALL:

The very best experiences I've had with doughnuts have involved eating them fresh out of the oven--this seems to magnify the deliciousness of even the most average doughnut. Unfortunately this isn't the rule of law around Voodoo Doughnuts, where doughnuts are served slightly chilled. And as the prime marker of a doughnut is its unhealthiness, it becomes incumbent upon the chef to disguise her creations with a light fluffiness--this is where Voodoo fails, for the meatiness of half of one of its doughnuts could choke a cow. It's not something where you could gobble three or four down and feel guilty about it--two bites in and you're in the depths of hell, longing for a raw carrot and an enema.

Not impressed with the taste of their donuts. Dots Donuts in Vancouver and New Seasons have much better tasting donuts especially the Apple and Blueberry Fritters at New Seasons. OMG are they Gooooooooooood!!!!
yeah....donuts are donuts...just the worst food on the planet. sorry..

Don't get me wrong, the donuts are good.  But there's nothing special about them.  The donuts here are way overhyped.  I can get this quality donut anywhere.  The only difference is that they put crazy toppings on it.  If you're looking for gourmet donuts, I highly suggest Blue Star.

As a tourist, of course I stood in line and waited 35 minutes to order my doughnut. But after the long wait, I was disappointed to find that the donuts here taste like regular donuts. Sure there are some crazy toppings like bacon, or fruit loops. Sure there is a huge vegan selection. But it's still a doughnut. What gives Portland?

3 stars for
-the very cool neon Voodoo sign
-the "Keep Portland Weird" mural across the street
Way over hyped for a purest from Boston. Too hipster. .in fact staff are rude ..never going back again. Live near

You're probably wondering if it's worth it to wait in line for 1/2 an hour for some donuts, Let me tell you now that the answer is no.  The bacon maple bar was pretty good (and really fatty too) but I personally didn't see the appeal of the rest.
It's was ok. It's hyped up. The line was way to long for me to get a mediocre doughnut with a x-rated name.
There are better donuts to be had in Portland but if I'm on Sandy Blvd I might stop in . The downtown location, never; there is no reason to stand in line for these donuts.
Quality has gone down but still enjoy the voodoo doll donut.  Tried the maple bar but not a fan of maple.  Will buy for others in a party.

Lame. Sugar and bleached flour -ah yumy not! This will result in a stomach ache every time! Also this type of food does nothing for your well-being. It's ok if you want to see some clever creations though

I like doughnuts. There....now that we got that out of the way we can move on. 

This place only thrives because of its gimmicky nature. That being said they do make an all right product. It simply doesn't live up to the hype and the price set. 

Stale cereal is a bad topping. The idea sounds wonderful. But having the roof of my mouth torn to shreds my stale Cap'n Crunch is not how I want to cure my hangover. 

Long lines, cash only, slow service and tons of hipsters to wade through makes for an ominous time. Having bums beg you for change the entire time you wait in line is also pretty lame. 

All in all they serve doughnuts....that's it. If you're in the area and craving one, stop on in. But don't expect to be blown away.
Just regular donuts with weird stuff on top, but it's worth the trip for the people watching

over-rated. Good, but not oh-my-god-foodgasm good. I wouldn't go out of my way. Too sweet half the time and not any better than deli doughnuts any way.

I do appreciate that it has vegan options. Sure, they have some interesting combos and they are very delicious, but it's not worth the line, crowd, or smell of said crowd. It's a nice closer to a long night and definitely is at a section of downtown that is depressing. I've suffered to avoid using their restrooms. Do not get the day-old bucket. My prof inexplicably loves it...but...it's exactly as tasty as it sounds.

I prefer its other location that's more like a cafe where you can actually hang out with folks.

Tourist trap. There's some unique stuff here, but quality is hit and miss, usually seems rather dirty and staff is apathetic at best. Plus, always with the long lines! There are so many better donut places in town, Voodoo is just not worth it.
So overrated!!  Donuts were comparable to grocery store donuts and pretty sure they win first place for worst coffee ever.  Wasted my valuable time - we literally threw the donuts in the trash.

Honestly, these doughnuts are fun, but I wouldn't call them necessarily "good." I understand that they're more symbolic of Portland's famed weirdness rather than a real harbinger of flavor, but I can still think of several pastry shops with better doughnuts than this. However, because it does stay open so late, I kind of think of it as the Taco Bell of doughnuts. I'm drunk; it's not exactly what I want, but it's still doughnuts. (Plus, that phallic one IS pretty great.)

I am not a fan of overly sweet stuff and these doughnuts are extremely sugary.  So if you don't have a five-pound bag of sugar handy to pour into your mouth, the doughnuts here will serve the same purpose.  

People watching, while standing in the inevitably long lines, is the real draw here.

This place was cool to check out on my visit to Portland. I appreciate this place for their unique donuts and fun atmosphere. The bavarian cream filled donuts were delicious, but the Cocoa Puffs on my personal donut were a bit stale. Glad I went but I probably won't go back. I definitely recommend experiencing this place though, just steer towards the non-cereal donuts !

Meh... 

Voodoo is all about the image. It is a great brand - very edgy and cultural. The products are colorful and whimsical, but the actual flavor of the dough is pretty plain.

Zak and I ordered a dozen doughnuts. (Voodoo's Choice) They were all good, and fun, but not worth waiting in line, like we had been told. (One bad one, though - it was a maple old-fashioned, but it seriously tasted like CURRY. What's that about?!)

It's a fun thing to do, if you're downtown, and don't mind waiting.

time: midnight
line: 20+ deep (40+ within 2mins)
wait: 30-40min
weather: 55*F
ages: 15-40
surroundings: Drunk Bum Central begging for everything but actual food 

inside: dim 'n dingy (which still really LOOKS like ding-E to me)
cost: didn't pay
taste: overly sweet and over-rated

The donuts are very special and very different no doubt about it.  As far as taste I'd say they're what you might expect with the goodies that come atop of them.  I do like they're donuts for some whacky and special but they wouldn't be my first choice for a solid, well mastered donut.  No doubt an experience and place every foodie HAS to check out though!

Been to voodoo too and had great service and received all of the donuts I ordered. Stood in line for a half hour at this voodoo (yes, I know that is fast, but it was 7:30 in the morning) and received exactly 3 donuts I ordered (out of a dozen) even after pointing to and naming the donuts. Now back in line, which has grown exponentially. Extremely irritated! I've learned my lesson about this location.
This is where we take tourists because it is a very Portland experience. Voodoo doughnuts are like the weird version of Krispy Kreme - very sweet - but with some added psychedelic flair.
Over rated spot for doughnuts.  The couple I have had were ok, but not great.  The staff had a poor attitude when I was there.

Recently visited PDX with some friends visiting from the east coast and was dragged here despite my protestations that this place just isn't worth it. Thankfully we went late and the line was super short. The Portland Cream, Dirt Doughnut (mmm Oreo's), and the Marshall Matters (mmm M&Ms) were all mediocre. Love the aesthetic of the Voodoo Doll, but the raspberry jam=no bueno. Quite frankly, these just aren't good donuts. Making a phallus donut isn't enough to warrant the line. Go to Blue Star for higher quality fried dough.

There's nothing that will make you feel more like a tourist than standing in line in the rain for a donut. Lining up for donuts is a completely foreign experience for me, but it's what getting a Voodoo Doughnut is all about. They're in hot demand and always popular, so deal with the lines and you'll be fine.

We got the stock standard Portland Cream, which was by far the best choice, and a triple chocolate penetration, which was unexpectedly dry. I also bought a fancy new pair of hot pants that I can wear to roller derby - no complaints there!

The crew at Voodoo are great at dealing with crowds and serve everyone fast and efficiently. I can't say I'll be doing too much lining up for donuts in future but at least I got to experience VD in PDX!

Meh, I don't get the hype about this place.  My buds had me visit due to all the buzz on foodie shows, websites, etc.  Alas, the long wait outside didn't really produce much oomph as a result.  My buds got the obligatory voodoo, and a few others.  I dared try the Tex-ass, expecting something worthy of poking fun of my former state of residence.  Alas, it was just a hokey gimmicky large donut.  (Ha.  Ha.  "Tex-Ass..."  Get it?)

On the plus side, the donuts are pretty darn good, and where else can you nab a non-dried-up-7-Eleven one at 1am in the morning?

I've tried these doughnut twice now. The first time was in CA and they were brought in to my work by a coworker who had them brought in from Portland that evening. They were alright, I thought maybe because of the travel time. 

The second (and final) time my husband, friends and I visited on a Saturday morning around 8am. The line hadn't started yet, so that was nice. I figured being there still fairly early they would be fresh. Not so much. We ordered the Captain Crunch, maple bacon, massive banana bear claw and a simple chocolate frosted one. Overall they were all very mediocre and tasted a little stale. They are definitely not worth the price for what you get. This place is way overrated and in my opinion isn't even worth it for the experience. Oh and they only accept cash. meh.

This definitely topped my list of things to do while I was visiting Portland. Don't hate me, but I think it was overhyped for me though! ): I really wanted to like it, but I just wasn't too impressed with it. I've had my fair share of bomb donut places in LA and I didn't really think it came close to it.  This is definitely a place that you try once just to say you've tried it, but I would not be a regular here if I lived here. Nice presentation of donuts displayed on spinning displays though! Really fun and cute!

Just a note, CASH ONLY. 


TEX-ASS CHALLENGE: This is a fun challenge. I came with friends and you know there's always that ONE friend that's willing to go for it haha! You have 80 seconds to finish this huge giant glazed donut. It's huge...pictures don't give it justice. It's equivalent to 6 regular sized donuts. If you eat it all by 80 seconds, it's free. If not, you'll have to pay for it haha. The lady who conducted the challenge didn't the most animated, but other servers did. They even rang a cowbell and shouted words of encouragement/ridicule to raise attention. Our guy friend almost gagged haha, but he only got through 2/3 of the donut. Fun thing to try though. 


VOODOO DOZEN: Since I came with five others, we decided it was worth it to get this. The voodoo dozen is perfect for tourists (like us) that wanted to try 13 of their most popular donuts. I think it was about $24 dollars. Of the ones we bought, I was able to take bites from most of them and these are the ones I tried:

-VOODOO DOLL: I was told that you're supposed to move the pretzel around and the raspberry filling inside the donut is supposed to ooze out. Didn't happen haha. Not a raspberry filling person, so this was a miss for me. 
 
-BACON MAPLE BAR: I love maple bacon bars!! So this one met my standards (: I'd get this again. 

-OLD DIRTY BASTARD: Loved this one! This donut came with chocolate frosting, crushed oreos, and peanut butter. If you love the traditional chocolate and peanut butter combo, this will win you over. I'd get this again, but definitely share because it's on the sweet side. 
 
-PORTLAND CREAM: A donut filled with Bavarian cream. The cream tasted like a light custard. It was whatevers to me. 

-CAPTAIN MY CAPTAIN: Donut with an overly sweet frosting and stale captain crunch. No thanks. 

-TRIPLE CHOCOLATE PENETRATION: Chocolate donut with overly sweet frosting and stale coco puff cereal on top. No thanks again. 

-DIRT: Donut with an overly sweet vanilla and crushed oreos on top. SUPER sweet, but it tasted as I expected it to.

-MARSHALL MATHERS: A very cake-y textured donut with vanilla frosting and covered with mini m&m's. Not my personal taste. 

-NEAPOLITAN: This chocolate cake-y textured donut with vanilla frosting, strawberry dust, and marshmallows.

The remaining one I didn't taste were GRAPE APE, DIABLOS REX, MAPLE BLAZER BLUNT, & MCMINNVILLE CREAM.
Waited 45 mins, donuts were nothing special. You're basically just trying the toppings on them. It's a dry donut with toppings.

I do think this is a tourist trap, the line was out the door in the morning but moved along fairly quickly.  The donuts were a little too crazy for me and if you're from SJ it'll be similar to Psycho Donuts.  Cool to visit plus the "keep portland weird" sign is outside.  I still had to check out what the hype was because Voodoo is such a Portland legend and now I can say I've been here.
I personally do not like the donuts here. Donuts are cold and more dense. I rather go to Donut plus, sesame donuts or Blue star.

First off, I am not a donut person...at all!  Although I do eat the occasional blueberry cake donut here and there.  I can say the bb cake donut at Voodoo was incredible, melt in your mouth sweetness.

The bf 'donut connoisseur' was in heaven. I started him off with the Cap'n Crunch donut, then the Oreo donut, then grabbed a Froot Loops donut on the way to the aeropuerto. They were all fantastic and I like that the icing tasted like milk.

I take two stars away b/c of the service. A half smile or perhaps a 'thanks' would be nice.
If cold doughnuts, long lines and selfie-taking tourists are your thing, be my guest.
Captain crunch and grapefruit vanilla are my favorite in here! This place is open 24/7. Rain or shine!

After hearing all the hype and seeing the place on countless TV shows I was really excited to try Voodoo Doughnuts but it was not worth the hype.  The line is really long and the doughnuts themselves are just okay with stale toppings.

OF COURSE I'm going to visit Voodoo Doughnut while in Portland. Yes, I will even wait 20 minutes in line. 

And if you are going to pry, YES... We got a dozen doughnuts and took a bite of each one... Should I not have admitted that?

Anyway, I really dig the funky vibe of this place, it is beyond unique. It is worth the visit in a just-to-say-you-did-it type of way. But honestly, the doughnuts were just "meh." I have had better. 

Now, I'm not saying don't go, because you definitely should check this cool landmark out. But I am saying that you may want to set your expectations a little lower.

Tuesday, 9am - no line! 
I went for the ordinary--an apple fritter--this time and it was definitely above average (3.5 stars). The dough itself was bland. However, a freshmade donut cannot disappoint its consumer. Huge too... well worth the $1.95; I didn't have to eat for the entire day.
My conclusion sticks with the fact that Berkeley's Kingpin donut beats Voodoo's. That is, I have had better. On the other hand, Voodoo's concept of fun doughnut creation does indeed deserve an applausive audience.
Meh.  Doughnuts are good, but they're no Top Pot.  This is apparently the #1 tourist attraction in Portland, so do your touristy duty and check 'em out.  I probably won't go back, though.

Had heard about this place numerous times and after spending some time at Powell's Book store, we walked over to the shop. There was a line which was impressive.  It moved quite fast though and we were inside in no time. Quite a selection of donuts, especially unusual ones. Prices seemed very reasonable.  Atmosphere was not to my liking but then it's called "Voodoo Donuts", so I wouldn't take any stars away for that.  Got our choices and headed out. But when I bit into my decadent-appearing donut I was heavily disappointed. Now I'm not some snobbish foodie, but I have to be honest. These donuts were not fresh or there was something very wrong with the way they were made. Sorry guys, Krispie Kreme makes a better donut by a mile!  Taste, feel, texture, you name it. Shoot, I've had better donuts from my local Safeway.  So here's my advice:. If you like a quaint shop with some edgy vibes go for it. If you want a great donut, go just about anywhere else.
These are ok doughnuts.  Some of the combinations are a weird but taste good.  I like the maple bacon and the memphis mafia.
Overrated. I just don't understand the fuss. Has nothing on Blue Star.

When I think of Portland, I always thought about VooDoo doughnuts, only because of an episode I saw from Food Network. So I definitely made sure we stopped by while we were in Portland. 

We went on a Tuesday at about 530 pm I would say and we were so lucky -- there was barely a line! We literally just walked right in and was in line long enough for us to decide what we were getting. 

We got the VooDoo doll, grape, dirt, glazed, maple bacon, a couple more that looked Instagram worthy. Honestly, I don't get the hype. The donuts were dry, too sweet. Just wasn't satisfying to me. I always try the glazed donut first -- to see how they compare with all the other donuts, and I definitely had better. 

Thank goodness there was no line. I would not have been happy if I had to wait an hour for this donut. I get it, I was happy I got to try it -- now I can say I've been there. But I definitely won't be back.

Well,I was a little disappointed! This was on my Oregon bucket list to visit. The building is so extremely tiny that we couldn't even get out after ordering. The donuts are fun to look at and tasted good. We got the basic pink frosted one. It had about 3"of bread with icing ...wasn't worth hype to us.

I am sure the donuts are delicious and everything you ever wanted in one... or two, but the wait is rather ridiculous. It's 7:20am and there is a line out the door that has not moved because there is only one girl working the counter and she has no sense of urgency.  Again, I am sure they are good but to wait 40 minutes because they don't have their staffing set up properly?  

I have to pick up these donuts for a client but the next time I come here, it will be when the newness of it dies out.

Long lines may be deceiving since they move fast. Voodoo is a "yeah, I was there" place, with fancy shmancy shapes, icings and toppings. But when it comes down to it, a donut tastes like a donut. And by the next day they are stale.

Didn't get to explore inside cuz we were actually on our way to Mother's Bistro & Bar (a wonderful place btw), so our group split up and I was part of the group that left to wait at Mother's. Anyways, so my friends who went inside Voodoo brought back a box for all of us to enjoy back at the hotel.

First off, the appearance of the box seems like a typical pink donut box, but it has a cool inked out design on the top. Simple, but I digged it. We got a wiiide variety of donuts... here's what sticks out in my memory:
- main Voodoo donut (jelly-filled-- my fav actually)
- Blueberry (hybrid of a bagel and donut)
- Cotton candy (awesome but too sweet. shrug, what did i expect)
- Oreo (self explanatory)
- and finally, Bacon-topped donuts.

The bacon-topped donuts remind me of a personal favorite of mine. Has anyone tried the Krispy Kreme donut sandwich w/fried chicken in between, typically sold at local county fairs?? Anyways, i LOVE those, and these bacon topped donuts remind me of them. It leaves this sweet and salty mixture of goodness to your tastebuds, while of course clogging your arteries.

After Mother's Bistro & Bar and exploring some more, we went back to the hotel and gorged on our Voodoo donuts. True, it's nothing special. But the creative variety of donuts just might coax me to return if I am ever in the Portland area.

Visiting Portland so this had to be on my list to do. The vibe of the place didn't feel as great as I thought, perhaps the charm got lost after it got too famous. There's a lot on their menu, which is a double edge sword. Lots to choose with amazing flavors but it's also confusing what to get. The cashier didn't seem too happy how me and my friend asked questions and being a tad indecisive  (it's our first time, what do you expect?) However despite that, the donuts are good and fun to eat. The line wasn't long when we were there, however when we went back during Saturday Market it was crazy.
A must for tourists, but the whole affair is much ado about little. Donuts are average, prices are high and the wait is usually significant.

I guess people come here more for the novelty donut than for the donut itself.

The donuts have unusual toppings and names, the place is really small with a line out the door, and they really want you to know what you want when it's your turn to order.

I think it was just to hyped for me by my Portland friend. It's like the Statue of Liberty, go once to get it out of the way but there's no real need to go again.

There are lots of comments about wait time. I waited 15 minutes in line, but walked past it a couple other times and the line was longer and even 1 time there was no one in line. The prices are good. You can get a doughnut for as little as $1.25. There are lots of varieties and dietary options (maybe not diabetic though). I got a big once and shared with 2 others. It was good, not the best ever, but we wanted the experience. 
The bad part is that there are lots of homeless people pestering you while you are waiting in line, and while you are eating it next door at picnic tables they have set up. A homeless couple with their dog were set up right at the front door asking for handouts.
If you are going to be in town for awhile, and you see a long line, I suggest you come back and keep checking. If the line up is even just 10 people, you are looking at about 15 minutes. Portland is small and walkable. We accidentally walked past Voodoo at least 2 other times and could have went in if we wanted to, but once was enough.

Definitely not a fan of the mediocre doughnuts and rude customer service we encountered yesterday. 

Not sure what all the hype is about but I won't be going back.

At first, I thought their donuts were pretty horrendous. But since then, I've realized that while their novelty donuts are pretty terrible, with thick frosting and stale toppings, their regular donuts like cake or raised donuts are actually quite good. Their cruellers are quite good as are cake donuts like mexican hot chocolate donuts.

It's OK. My friends liked it, but personally not my thing. 

Like someone else said: CASH ONLY. I wouldn't trust the ATM in there. There's panhandlers on the street (which you should be ignoring anyways) and long lines at night.

We got a Portland Cream and a Fruit Loop donut. Both are incredibly sweet and made me feel pretty sick after trying to eat them. 

If you have a major sweet tooth, this place is good for you. If you're someone who likes it only in small amounts, skip Voodoo.

I don't get all the hype.  I mean the doughnuts are good. But good grief.  Is it really that dificult to serve shitty doughnuts?.  I mean to have this place on the tourist guide is something that baffles me.  That and the lines.  Not a huge doughnut fan and if i wanted some I would probably go here... or heavenly doughnuts, or dunkin, or safeway or wherever.  I give them credit though for starting a movement and getting the other places to step up their game.

The dough is dry and the flavors are random... The dough should not hold in your mouth like a brick, I like light and fluffy (the frosting should not be everything). I would rather go to Krispy Kreme! Yum!  They do not have lines going down the block and have nowhere for customers to eat!  I would eat a Voodoo Doughnut if someone gave it to me free but I would never purchase one again.

I had an apple fritter and a maple bar at my visit to VooDoo donut last week. My rectangle maple bar looked the exact same as Safeway's maple bar, except Safeway's tasted better to me and had a thicker layer of maple on it. I had to wait in a long line for at least 15 minutes for what was overpriced and tasted mediocre. Safeway's maple bar is only around $0.50. I paid $1.20 for mine. It wasn't worth the price. The apple fritter was OK. I think Krispy Kreme is a better deal. Nothing special to me.
Overrated - the experience is cool and the donuts are clever, but I don't think they are the best tasting.

Where do I begin? Maybe this place is super cool for teeny boppers who get excited over a pretty donut with candy/colorful cereal on top? If the line is no more than 20 min (what we waited) and you've never been here then I guess it's cool to try (just so you can say you did, like us). It wasn't expensive (about $1.5-$2 per donut). I wish we would have tried Blue Star Donut instead (I guess it's a local place) that two people told us about. Sorry Voodoo.

Overrated tourist spot! Sure, the doughnuts have creative shapes and flavors but it's all just show. They do not taste great; sometimes they taste stale!

Other notes: Long lines, unfriendly cashiers, cash only, vegan doughnuts available

Not bad! I guess I was expecting worse seeing the amount of "this place is overrated" reviews/ The neighborhood it's located is a little run-down with packed street parking. We had to park right in front of a "lap dances on the 3rd floor!" Signs and homeless people which made me uneasy. 

There was no line considering it was a weekday afternoon and service was very quick.It annoyed me a little that there were no signs next to the doughnuts and only had a picture right as u got to the cashier so must research online the different fillings and flavors before going. 
Overall, taste wasn't bad. Someone compared it to Dunkin donuts but I thought I tasted much better than that! It was a great touristy thing to eat and would come back here if the lines were as short as they were. If it's as long as other people have said I wouldn't waste time unless it's your first time in Portland!

Absolutely terrible doughnuts. Stale day old doughnuts serving Portland's burgeoning hipster tourists. If you are native Portlander you should be ashamed to support this place. Annie's, Sesame, and Rocking Frog are all ten times better and cheaper.

Ok. I'm not a big fan of sweet things but I had to try the famous voodoo donuts in Portland, right?

Yes I did, and that's it. Don't get me wrong, I love the experience, but the donuts just weren't what I was looking for. Maybe if I was drunk one day and needed some post party drinks, the 24/7 joint will do it. 

At 10am on a Sunday morning, the line snaked for about half a block, took us about 20 minutes. I liked how orderly everyone was and how everyone came out with the PINK box!! Awesome. 

Such a cute decoration and all those merchandise! love it. 

Ok now down to business -
Bacon maple syrup - only saving grace was bacon. But maple glaze was WAYYYY too sweet. 
Maple mafia fritter - the only good one of the day. Love the crispy but chewy texture. And there was less glaze. But still could be less sweet. Peanut butter, chocolate and peanut bits. 
Voodoo doll - only good for looks and photos - thick chocolate glaze, thick jelly inside. What can I say? Sweet. 
Chocolate peanut - the most simple one. It was so recommended I thought I had to try. But SKIP IT. It's the same old sweet chocolate glaze. And there was nothing special about the donut itself. I can't tell what was good about it other than the experience of being in the store. 

So, don't expect anything amazing. It's edible, and the store experience is amazing. And bring cash.

Okay, I came to this place late at night and it was bustling with energy. I had a plain glazed doughnut, which was good, but I'm not sure why everyone raves about this place. I guess it's for the atmosphere or that's it's located next to the strip club? Anyway, I like the tables outside, it makes a great spot for people watching while you eat your doughnut. Would I return? Sure, but I wouldn't go out of my way.

We stopped by late on a weekend night. Line was to the door, but only took about 10 minutes to get through. Ordered the ODB, the Portland Creme and a couple others. I have to say: based on this experience, I would never go back. The donuts were very big, dry and tasteless... except for the frosting/toppings. They were cloyingly sweet, unsubtle, and probably more suited to the tastebuds of a 3-year-old than an adult. Imagine just pouring sugar on top of a donut and topping it with some sugary breakfast cereal... that's about the taste we got from most of these. 

The Portland Creme was undercooked toward the center. I could literally taste raw dough. The other donuts were as noted... and the frosting was dry and crackly, as well. Just... unsatisfying. 

Now I would go back one more time. I generally don't write off places forever unless it's a service-based issue. So I may try again here. 

However, I made a special run out to Pip's Donuts, and discovered the single best donut (and chai) experience of my life. If you're a real donut freak, try Pip's, too.

All that said, the experience of going to Voodoo was fun. The store itself is really cool. The pink boxes (that kinda scream "TOURIST!") were cool. The neighborhood is pleasantly sketchy (I think there's a strip club next door or something). I would not discourage you from trying it once, just to get the experience. But I would bet you won't return often based on my experience.
