I was lucky enough to be staying across the street from this place.  Every time we drove by there was a line out the door.  One night it rained pretty hard so my dad and I ran across the street to try it out (there was no line).  We only ordered a few to try.  I had the maple bacon donut.  While it was tasty I realized it was just a maple bar with two strips of bacon on top.  I think both my dad and I enjoyed our donuts but I wouldn't stand in line for them.  It was a tourist thing we had to try.
If you're not into bacon, this is just another doughnut shop....but a very good one, and friendly staff... expect a long line though!

Sadness. I had high expectations for this much-raved-about-sugary-goodness-joint. I even went back once more for a second chance at our relationship. I wanted to make sure it was ME and not THEM.

The donuts were unbearably sugary. Each bite sounded like a gnashing of sugar between my teeth, a future trip to the dentist. It was also a sugar rush that could go wrong. I tried their voodoo donut and maple bacon, and besides the cute smile on my donut doll, I was not too enchanted. I love them for their attempt at trying be innovative. 

I think the next I will give them another chance is when I'm drunk. But maybe not.

On my homepage yelp suggested I write a review for Voodoo doughnut, so a review I will write. In a word? Ugh. If you want a stale donut with some cereal on it, by all means wait in line for 2 hours. Voodoo Doughnut is not the end all be all of Portland kitsch, and this city is more than just a doughnut (I swear all the guidebooks suggest Voodoo and I don't get it). 

If you want a good doughnut, go to Blue Star and get the blueberry bourbon basil doughnut. You will think you died and went to heaven.

I would have attributed a solid 4 stars to Voodoo had I not have tried Blue Star Donuts the day before! However, (un)fortunately I didn't feel like waiting in line for ~1 hr the previous day and decided to give Blue Star a try (no wait!). 

Here are the pros of Voodoo: 
1. Creative concoctions with fun medleys of different flavors. Great variety of donuts as well
2. Fun names! And I'm quite a sucker for fun names
3. Overall quality of the donuts are better than the average donut shop with strong and delicious flavors (we ordered a dozen donuts so we can safely judge away!)

Here are the cons of Voodoo: 
1. Although the overall quality of donuts is great, no particular donut had a wowza factor. The texture was meh and not the kind of melt-in-your-mouth-ness that one would anticipate after an hour long wait. I literally cannot remember one particular donut that I loved out of the 12 different donuts that we ordered
2. I had tried the Bacon Maple donut at Blue Star the previous day and was left SO disappointed after trying Voodoo's version of that. Voodoo's version was soggier, overly-sweetened and literally had an entire piece of overly salty bacon in the donut. I'm not talking about little chunks of bacon - I'm talking about a massive slab of breakfast-style bacon. It was a bit much and the flavor was completely lacking 
3. The line. Thankfully, we didn't have to endure the notorious wait because we went at 7pm on Christmas Eve. However, I've heard that the wait can be quite arduous

Thus, if you're craving some delicious gourmet donuts and are trying to decide between Blue Star and Voodoo, I would highly recommend the former over the latter. Blue Star has less variety and less fun names but significantly better quality and more meticulously made donuts.
Interesting design, but a bit too sweet. Really long line here (~40 min) and I was told this is when it's not crazy.

i stood around 40 mins in line for donuts that were not round but of different shapes are kind of exotic. The doughnut's are okay IMO it is just over-hyped. 
i would still recommend the place, cause it is different from the usual doughnut places. but not worth the wait in line. 
Get there real early so that you can spend the rest of your time doing something fun, rather than standing in line.

It is definitely an experience, but not worth a wait in an extremely long line.

We stopped one evening after dinner and there wasn't a line so we decided to try.
Totally overrated, dry & over the top donuts. If you're going to queue, queue at Blue Star and at least get something fresh. Novelty factor only.
Voodoo has good donuts (who doesn't know that?), but I wouldn't go out of my way to get a donut there. I guess I'm just not enough of a donut person to go ga ga for Voodoo...

To say I wasn't entirely disappointed is the best I can do.

First: when we arrived, we got there about 5 mintues after a busload (litterally) of teens and there was no where to wait but outside because..
Second: there's no where to wait INside. No tables with chairs, just a tiny little CRAMPED room that...
Third: wasn't very clean
Fourth: We had driven up from Eugene and the bathroom was out of order-to which they were non-empathetic.
Fifth: All of the cereal-topped donuts had stale cereal on them.
Last but not least there was an abundance of inappropriate *ahem* things to look at and to read and we happened to have our kids with us.
Some of the donuts were tasty and very creative.
I suppose if you're going just to partake in crudeness-this is the place for you. 
I made a special trip because I thought they might have good donuts. Silly me.
Disappointing...sorry!! We were so excited @ bought 1 1/2 doz to share w/our office, until the first bite...greasy & hard..:/

Voodoo Doughnut is a gimmick first and foremost. The doughnuts are good, but nowhere near the Heaven-rending wonder that the hype suggests. Long lines and too-good-for-you attitudes are hardly compensated for by Voodoo's doughnuts. Sure, they are delicious and bizarre...just not enough to warrant the time and effort it takes to get them. Round-the-corner lines are rarely justified by edible products.

Best doughnuts: Peach Fritter, Grape Ape, CnB

voodoo doughnuts has been on my radar for years...more like 15 years. one of the main reasons for coming to portland. despite my dreams, i was a bit let down. the donuts are funny and playful, but to be honest..dont taste so good. even the appeal is a bit sloppy. i appreciate the creativity, but im someone who calls herself the flavor queen, and these donuts are pretty simple tasting or just have too many toppings to make them taste good. however, its still worth a trip for that fun photo opp.

Some of the best Donuts I've ever had, but there are honestly other bakeries in town who match or even exceed the quality of Voodoo. If you've never been, it's definitely worth checking out just to mark it off your list. It's a kitschy Portland landmark, after all, and that makes it worth doing at least once.

Not sure what all the hype is about. Original names (like maple blunt, cocknballs, etc) but the actual donuts weren't anything I'd wait in line for. If you want a donut covered in cereal or frosting, do it yourself. 30 minute wait is too much. At least they weren't overpriced.

Great late-night stop! Unique flavors and names, so the fun is in selecting your treat. It is definitely not in the ridiculously long line or tiny, cramped store. They need an awning badly, and should have a way to expedite the line, like menus posted outside, more staff, doughnut names written on the racks, etc. 

Definitely try the maple bacon bar, cock 'n' balls, and the Portland cream!
Obviously unique, but the staff always seems like they're trying to rush you out the door and the donuts aren't the best I've ever had.

Being from the Northeast, donuts too often mean Dunkin Donuts - they're omnipresent - in every town and on every corner. You're not missing much here, Portland. So, even though I've heard of Voo Doo, I've never bothered to seek them out. Remember, I know Dunkin Donuts. I stopped in today and they're quite good. I paid $1.50 for what Dunkin would call a 'Boston Cream' and it was a lot better than what you get from DD - much better, in fact. Would I go back? Absolutely and better yet, grab a cup of java from Stumptown down the street for the ultimate sugar and caffein high. Well done, Voo Doo.

Good donuts. Obviously people like them. 
Mostly pretentious staff. Come on now! Donuts should make you smile!

This place is packed during the day. You'll see long lines around the corner. They have fun flavors with unique toppings such as captain crunch. In my opinion the donuts are too sweet. Don't get me wrong I love sweets but I don't want to feel like I'm eating spoonful of sugars. I kinda like the old dirty bastard donut. I was gonna try their blueberry donuts cause I saw someone mentioned it on yelp but didn't get the chance. It's very colorful inside. It's worth a visit. Go at night time where theres less waiting.

They are pretty good but it is such a tourist attraction now. Is it really worth the wait??!!?
Go to Delicious Donuts on Grand Ave and Burnside. Every cop in town knows about this place. They have the best maple bars ever !!!   You won't be sorry.

When in Portland, Voodoo Doughnuts should be on your list of places to visit, in my opinion, mostly for the EXPERIENCE. Does it have crazy and out of this world flavors?  Yes.  Does standing in and long line behind the pink barricades with other tourist and locals build anticipation and excitement? Yes. Does talking to the friendly homeless guy selling newspapers to the people in line add to said excitement? Definitely. Do my girlfriends and I get a good laugh at ourselves and feel like complete dummies when we are first scolded for holding the door open, and then scolded again for blocking the door while standing in the exit? Yes, we are Voodoo virgins. Am I totally amused by looking at the crazy decor on the ceiling and walls once inside the surprisingly tiny shop? You bet. Was it stressful trying to decide which flavors I'm going to pick while staring at the craziest doughnuts I've ever seen? A little, especially since there was a long line behind us staring at me with vulture eyes hungry for doughnuts. 

And now the BIG question - did the doughnuts taste out of this world and blow my mind?? Sadly, NO. It was a doughnut, people. Yes, it may have had bacon on it, and it may have been one of the most clever looking doughnuts I have ever seen, but in the end, the doughnuts itself tasted quite ordinary. But the EXPERIENCE, my friends, was certainly memorable and a trip to Voodoo was the quintessential Portland experience! I'm so glad that I visited and can now say that I've been to Voodoo Doughnuts. But for actual great doughnuts, my friend swears that I should go to Pips. That'll be first on my list for my next visit to Portland, but for now, my morning at Voodoo will leave me with great memories for a long time to come. Everyone should experience it at least once :).

I actually came here on a Saturday night and didn't wait in line for an hour-- In fact, we got right in, got a donut apiece and left. The donut wasn't too bad either-- it was a plain glazed donut. I'm not a fan of overthinking and to me a donut with captain crunch is overthinking. Even the maple bacon donut (their most popular) is overthinking. Any advice I would give is to not wait in line ( their average wait time is about 50 minutes) unless you like cereal on your donut. Middle of the night is the best time to go as there is no line. Otherwise-- go to Blue Star

This place is fun to go to with out-of-towners, who may enjoy photo ops and catching up while waiting in the line that wraps around the corner. The doughnuts are mediocre tasting and overpriced, but the creative names and  combinations--Bacon Maple Bar, Voodoo Doll doughnut, and Loop doughnut, to name a few--add greatly to the hype. Worth going to at least once for the  experience.

I'd rather have Sesame doughnuts... I can pay how ever, they give me extra, and they actually taste good.  voodoo I walk past you every day. I also feel that the couple times I have been in there it felt unsanitary.
Decent donut but not worth waiting in line for. Typical Portland, it's more about being seen with your pink box than whats inside.
a doughnut is a doughnut...even if it's shaped like a penis or has Fruit Loops on it. And standing in line forever just to get this artery hardening masterpiece...for the tourists!

Voodoo Doughnut's plain donuts are pretty fantastic. And the novelty factor for out of town guests is pretty great as well. Got a visitor? Take them! Enjoy it! Soak up the weirdness. But the actual doughnuts themselves, beyond the plain and the maple bacon bar and the famed voodoo with the raspberry filliing are too sweet. They're kind of enough to make you puke, some of the sugar sugar sugar ones. So what you get out of here is what you're looking for. For shortest lines, counter-intuitively, go for breakfast, when the stoners are still fast asleep. As a regular Portland commuter though, if I just want to get a doughnut in and out, I'll go for CoCo Donuts, off the Max line.

I just do not get it. I have been a few times over the years here in Portland, but only because of visiting friends and family. I think without tourism that this doughnut shop would not stand the test of time. But luckily they have turned themselves into a must-do tourist item and good for them. Tourist on touristy folk :o) Help Us Keep Portland Weird!
This doughnut place is just okay.  They have a lot of interesting flavors, but the product isn't stellar.  Ours were kinda stale, and just underwhelming, but our son really enjoyed his.

If you're new in town check it out. If not, maybe stop by once a year. 

Doughnuts are good, but not mind blowing by any means. If you don't mind waiting in line for 45 minutes it's not bad. 

The place is good for wasting some time. The novelty is the real reason you should stop by. The service is straight to the point and fast, and the variety is pretty righteous. 

Eat that lil doughnut guy, he's good.

I waited in a long line on an 85 degree day for a doughnut I could have gotten at a grocery store and sprinkled lemon aid dust on myself. It is a lot of hype for something that isn't extraordinary. Was the doughnut good? Sure. Was it worth the wait and price? No. With that said the gal who helped us was very nice and they seemed very efficient at helping a TON of people daily.

I think Voodoo Doughnuts is a victim of it's own popularity in my case. The doughnuts themselves were as creative as advertised but ultimately they weren't much better than the other doughnuts I've experienced in my life.

Certainly not worth the wait and the price unless you are looking to add something else to your list of famous culinary conquests.

Damn you to hell, Travel Channel.......and you too Bordaine! 
And just to kick you in the balls even more, the one shop that made the best PBnJ doughnut ever has shut down.  Leaving this circus and a few other local unspoken of places around town.

Yea, I wish all my pastries were shaped like penis'. Grandma loves em on Sundays after church.

The doughnuts here are some of the coolest doughnut concepts ever...But! They aren't fresh, taste worse than any doughnut I've ever had, and you have to wait in line forever. :( These doughnuts made me want to cry.

Maybe their doughnuts aren't fresh in the morning? We went around 11 am on a Saturday. Could have been bad timing on our part.

It's popular as hell.  There's always a line.  The combinations and the names of the some of the donuts are funny. The staff is great.

However, The donuts were just so-so for me.  I had the bacon maple bar, and a little bit of the fams Apple fritters, voodoo dolls, and the one with pink frosting.  They were like i said, interesting ingredients, but for me, it was just...Meh.

I'm glad I went though.  I even bought a shirt!

This place was so hyped that I had high expectations, but, sadly, it didn't deliver for me. It seems like it's in a sketchy neighborhood and there was a street person waiting outside the door asking everyone for change. The small shop was busy and takes cash only (that's a pain!). They do have a well-used looking ATM in the corner of the waiting area. They had run out of maple-bacon bars so my husband was disappointed, but we tried other donuts. I got a blue raspberry (gaggy sweet) and a Portland Cream (nice, but nothing different from a cream donut I've had other places). I was hoping the donuts would be warm, but they were not. All in all I was just not impressed. They do have a large variety, but you need to really like sweet toppings on top of an already sweet donut to appreciate this place. Kids might this it's fun for the designs/colors.

Don't get me wrong- this place serves decent donuts.  But after standing in line for 20 minutes at 8 PM on a Friday night, I have to say this place is definitely NOT living up to the hype.  The donuts aren't very polished in their look- they clearly look hand made and the icing and glazing is not evenly spread on the donut.  The taste is really so-so, nothing great.  I don't understand why people are so gaga over this place.  It may be locally owned, not a large chain, and popular, but it does not compare to the local Krispy Kreme two minutes from my house.  I don't care how unhealthy either place is or how "rude" Krispy Kreme's staff is- the donut at KK is significantly better and doesn't involve waiting 20+ minutes no matter what time of day.   

Oh and after you enter Voodoo, you'll feel like you entered some run-down shack.  The staff look like they haven't showered in like a week, the place looks ready to crumble (the shop literally has a capacity of like 10 people), and you don't feel like you're buying from a "gourmet" donut shop.

Cool place and lots of seating outside. Tried this place since I've heard it's a must do if you are visiting Portland. 

The line was long but went by quickly. The service was great and fast. The donuts were just okay. I felt they were too sweet. I wasn't sure what all the hype was about but I'm glad I tried it and I took lots of cool pics.
Fun place to go. Donuts are average, except the specials are great. A great example of marketing mattering more than product.

Voodoo doughnuts is a tourist trap, plain and simple. If you think fried bread with cocoa-puffs is the food of the gods, then by all means get in line. However, there are so many amazing doughnut places in Portland I wouldn't give Voodoo a second thought. 

Just because something is unique doesn't make it good.

Even though this is a three star, I do suggest everyone who visits Portland stop by and visit this place. I don't know if I'll be going back as the two donuts I had didn't taste any better than something from Dunkin, but the place is still very cool and the collection of flavors is a sight to see. I went with the Arnold Palmer and the Marshall Mathers, neither was horrible nor great.

I'm not a weird, doughy, kind of donut person. I do appreciate their cake vegan donuts however!  Once in a great while I suppose.  If I have to get something though, I'm more of a cupcake person I suppose.

Not too happy with them after yesterday's visit. I bought a dozen (my choice of which donuts) with an extra or two in addition. They left out two of the donuts that I asked for and I was charged for it. My husband also purchased a dozen (their choice) for his coworkers to try. Sadly, we can't go back to complain since we live in CA.

Not sure if I'd come back next time I'm in town.

3 stars because I think the taste of VooDoo donuts is just average and it taste like donuts I could get a Dunkin Donuts back on the east coast. 
I'm not saying they're not good, but they are definately overhyped for the amount of people who line up to get these guys.

The concept is cool, the toppings are cool and I appreciate the very helpful and friendly staff. However, the donut itself is just....normal, average...
I know in portland, its probably one of the better if not the only place to get decent donuts, but I guess i'm being a bit biased as I like to compare them to places that i've tried in various other cities.
The wait is waaaaaaaay to long for the quality of the donuts.  Sure, they're good, but I've had better (way better).  Everyone was very friendly.

I feel this place is so overrated. Its biggest edge is the fact that it's a 24 hour spot and a haven for late night party-goers. Nothing in particular stood out. Don't get me wrong. I enjoyed the donuts, but it's nothing special in terms of taste (they are pretty).

People are obsessed with this place.  There is a lot to choose from, I will give them that.  Customer service is... meh.  Not awful, but nothing to write about.  I've never felt overly impressed with what I got.  The donuts are good, but not worth spending 45 minutes of my life waiting in line.

Voodoo Doughnuts is a Portland institution, so when visiting, it was somewhat required that along with all the breweries, we go for a round or two.  (Hey, get it?  Get it?  I crack myself up.)

Now, I know it's not their forte, but I judge the quality of a doughnut shop by their chocolate glazed old-fashioned.  It's what I had for breakfast four mornings out of five in my senior year of high school, so I have some familiarity.  And I have to disappointingly report that Voodoo Doughnut's was substandard: dry and insufficiently glazed.  

If that were all to be said, Voodoo would rate a two-star review, but of course, that's NOT what one goes to Voodoo for.  You go to Voodoo for their creativity.  I also had an "Old Dirty Bastard" with peanut butter and Oreo cookie crumbles, and it was a great combination of textures, both sweet and salty.  My lovely companion had the bacon maple bar, but as maple isn't one of my favorite flavors, it should have scored more points.

Overall, the execution and creativity balance out to a solid three stars.  Go elsewhere for the "perfect" typical doughnut, but come here for the fun doughnut.
The donuts do not match the hype.  The place is dirty as well.  I would not recommend going to this place as it was a big let down.

Can you visit Portland and not make a stop for Voodoo Donuts? On my first visit, my boyfriend and I were fat kids and got the Fryer Flyer dozen. Let me tell you - a dozen of these donuts is not a good idea.

THE GOOD:
Tons of variety. Really unique donuts. You're bound to find something you like.
My favorites: Portland Cream, The Voodoo Doll, Diablos Rex, and Old Dirty Bastard.

THE BAD:
The wait - on a Sunday morning around 10:30a, we waited an hour in line. There's really no donut in the world that's worth this kind of wait - but when in Portland, I had to try it.
Cash only - I get it, I just really like to use my credit card.
The donuts are very very sweet - I'm a plain donut girl so having candy + frosting + donut is a bit much for my taste.

I frankly don't know what all the fuss is about. We were there in the afternoon when there was just a few customers about. The donuts are just doughnuts, priced quite a bit higher than what you will find elsewhere, with a few creative twists thrown in. We could tell that earlier there had been a massive crowd, rope line area lengthy and littered with paper coffee cups and napkins, pretty much a mess. If you need a doughnut and don't mind a little squaller, you can check it out and at least be able to say you've been there.

Had to come to check it off the box, but honestly, if you're visiting like we were, it's not worth the wait in line. We were staying at the Embassy Suites and our suite overlooked the place, so if we didn't see a minimal line we would have skipped this place. Our donuts were meh. Considering they're open 24/7, I was surprised they ran out of anything let alone the 2 that I wanted. I settled for the guava stuffed and was a little disappointed. My wife liked her captain crunch, but that was just a donut with cereal piled on top. I love a great donut, but sadly didn't find it here. Also, bring cash, as its cash only, but not too much cash as there is a tribe of young homeless individuals outside asking you for it. Let's just say it's awkward. Everyone knows it's cash only, yet here you are, not wanting to give any of your cash to these people, but instead would rather pay for an over priced donut.

I guess I will venture forth and be review 1999 so somebody else can take the glory.  Coming here, I can just sense that these donuts were just going to be overrated and the long lines the product of great marketing.  I mean, there is just so much hype surrounding this place that that would likely be a foregone conclusion.  Be prepared to wait in line.

A previous reviewer mentioned that he/she didn't know what kind of toppings were on each uniquely named flavor of donut so I will describe what we ordered the best we can.  

OLD DIRTY BASTARD: This was probably my favorite one...it had chocolate frosting, oreo cookies, and peanut butter on top of a ring donut

NO NAME: Chocolate frosting, rice crispies, and peanut butter...2nd fave

MANGO TANGO: Some sort of fruit frosting on top stuffed with mango preserve (I think)

MAPLE BACON BAR:  Self-explanatory.  The bacon was very crisp though so that was nice

VOODOO DOLL:  Jelly doughnut shaped like a voodoo doll complete with pretzel stuck in heart.

These donuts aren't bad but for the wait time and how much you hear about these donuts these were somewhat of a letdown.  The dough wasn't as light or fresh tasting as other places.  They had some very interesting and delicious combinations though although the frosting and toppings made the doughnuts super duper sweet.  There is a coffee shop right next door (Caffe Vita) where you can order a coffee to balance the sweetness (which made it not so bad).

What do I add to the 7000+ reviews for Voodoo?  Probably not much.  

Is it the best doughnut you have ever had? Probably not.  
Does the long line make it more desirable?  Probably.  
Do they have anatomically inappropriate doughnuts? Yes. 
As a Portland institution, does it make it worth a visit at least once?  Absolutely 

What did I learn today?  My first Voodoo donut was way back in 2003 while working at OHSU.
Wrong person to ask about donuts. Whatever I had was good. I guess worth the wait for 20 mins.

While I'm very happy with the doughnuts I've had in silicon valley, the doughnut places I've been too around here suffer from a small problem: insufficient cursing and genital references on their menu!  I was hoping I might find a place without this weakness when I visited Portland, where I encountered Voodoo Doughnut.

Problem solved!  I can get the "cock-n-ballz" doughnut while their large sign reminds me that "good things come in pink boxes."  I can even enjoy a large chocolate doughnut with raspberry filling that features a centrally placed "voodoo pin" near crotch height.  Yes!

To sum it up, the donuts are super uneven with some great and some just OK... the successes: 
- old dirty bastard: covered in a variety of tasty chunky stuff including chocolate
- the chocolate frosted raspberry filled one with a "voodoo pin" in it (but skip the filling part - it's the chocolate that wins it)
- maple bacon! yeah, what it sounds like, probably my favorite.

Skip the cinnamon sugar one, the triple chocolate one that's dry, and probably the grape frosted one which is a little "too" jolly rancher like.

I suggest they eliminate the so-so donuts from the menu and name all the remaining good ones more after more esoteric genital sub-parts.

I liked the hype years ago and bought off on it. Several years later, the hype has worn off. People (visitors) dig the idea and fun doughnuts, but rarely do they go back a second time. 

It's nice that they are 24 hours, but it is kind of a downer when they say they aren't taking anymore pre-orders...What? Don't you want to be prepared?

I want to love them but just can't.  Love the creativity, the vibe and the passion of the place.  But, the donuts just are way too sweet, the flavors try way too hard and my stomach is always in knots well after.
This is a novelty stop off for sure. The donuts are cheap and quirky. But if you want a real donut don't waste your time and go to Blue Star, YUM.

They have a deal on their menu where the staff picks the donuts for around $12.  All of them were "ok", 4 were interesting and only 1 was worth returning for.

But--  it's not worth the wait.

This is a tourist trap!

So so incredibly overrated... 

Honestly, I would rather go buy a grocery store doughnut and sprinkle my own oreo/cereal/bacon on it myself.

Where else can you go late at night to get your sugar fix. Saw this on the food network so I had to stop in. To bad they were out of the bacon maple bar 'cause now I will have to go back next time I am in town to get one. I got the "Old Dirty Bastard". It was a good substitute.

Gimicks, Giicks, and more gimicks!  This place is not even a Portland original anymore. It is pretty much just a corporate chain!  They underpay and treat employees like crap (why do you think they are always so crabby), and they cater to tourists and not the local population.

This place used to be a cool portland staple, but has completely lost its soul.  The owners walk around like they are some sort of celebrities but really are just huge jerks. I don't know how many times I've seen Tres Shannon make an ass out of himself in public.  He is usually drunk or on cocaine or both.  I'm pretty sure Cat Daddy is a pedophile as well.  

Do Portland a favor and do not support this place and hopefully this eyesore will go out of business.
Long queue. Donuts are okay, nothing mind blowing. Jerk behind the counter was terribly rude. I could do without your eye rolls, impatient sighs, and overall condescending attitude. Not coming back.

The difference nuts were pretty good. They are dense and soft and very tasty. It's also a cool place to go and see just because of all the decorations. It's a fun tourist place but probably won't go there again just because it's so so so so expensive. I recommend going at least once because it is worth the experience.

So this is exactly what you think it is, a tourist spot that was highlighted on TV and became a phenomenon. I had to go, couldnt go to Portland and NOT go to Voodoo Donuts. I ordered the cap n crunch donut, it was massive and It was just that, a big donut with cereal on it. I get the allure but its a one and done.
I used to love Voodoo Doughnuts but my last experience there was lacking, customer service was 0
Doughnuts were ok. Definitely more marketing and hype. Price was reasonable. Be aware that the establishment is CASH ONLY!

More novelty than actual good tasting doughnuts. You get all sorts of crazy stuff like captain crunch, oreo cookie with peanut butter and maple bacon. The cereal and cookies are stale and the doughnut is pretty dry. When you are in Portland, you come here for the crazy but you go to Blue Star for taste. Also cash only, so come prepared.

Voodoo is all about image. The doughnuts themselves are just okay, or are actually just bad. Cereal on a doughnut? Prepare for stale yuckiness. The only doughnuts worth eating are the ones that are more "normal" -- but then, what's the point? There are definitely better "normal" doughnuts to be had elsewhere.

There are so many good donuts in Portland, I just can't see why people come here. I do like the decorations and the cleverly named donuts but for a long line that is roughly 30 minutes long, I will pass. Grab coffee for the long wait. Cash only. If you are here on the weekend, it's nice to walk about the Saturday market afterwards.

Most of their donuts are too tall so they end up not having enough glaze on them so they just taste doughy. I couldn't agree more about their workers. It obvious they aren't happy working there. We got to the car and saw that they didn't give us one of our donuts. After tasting them and remembering the mean worker neither one of us was brave enough to go tell her she shorted us one. We ended up leaving the uneaten box in the hotel

A true testament to the powers of zaniness! I've watched this place transform from a tiny 100 square foot hole in the wall to it's current line around the block doughnut juggernaut status. My friend won their first doughnut eating competition almost 10 years ago! The owners are genuinely cool dudes that have been around Portland for decades and I am stoked for them on their success. It is a fun place and my belief is that they give back to the community. 
That said, it's still just doughnuts...more power to them for creating a fortune 500 company based on zaniness and deep fried white flour. MMMM Deep fried white flour... I guess it's a "Portland tradition" for newbies, tourists and commuting suburbanites who want to get in touch with their edgy side. Doughnuts are a terrible thing to ingest. It is truly comical/annoying that people are willing to wait in line for what looks like eternity to end up feeling like shit. That chocolate voodoo doll you just ate is gonna put a hex on you! All the zaniness makes it seem healthy and shit "it's a Portland tradition" so it must be good for you!!!
I'll stick to my yogurt, fruit and nut parfait.

【Average】

Super touristy place. The lines can get long during peak hours. I ordered a dozen for $25. The donuts tasted decent but does not match the hype and the price. This is one of those places that you only line up once for. If you are ordering, must get the Voodoo Doll doughnut since that is their signature donut. The Voodoo Doll is a yeast doughnut filled with raspberry jelly topped with chocolate frosting and a pretzel stake! Very instagram worthy.

I was so excited to grab a doughnut from this Portland hot spot, but was disappointed by the quality of food and service. Everything on the menu was very creative, and if you get it fresh, I'm sure it's worth the wait. However, our doughnuts were slightly stale, and I was really grossed out when the guy helping us wiped his nose with his hand and then picked up our food.

A tourist's rite of passage.

If you're holding a pink box of donuts... it's a sign that you're from out of town. I was one of those said customers holding a bright pink box.

Voodoo is a novelty and is a must-go if you're visiting Portland. We came on a weekday and it was about a 30 minute wait. Right around the corner is Ristretto, so I recommend picking up some coffee and waiting in line with a cup of joy. Don't forget to save about half the cup to go along with your donuts ;)

There are a ton of different flavors so after some Yelp research while waiting in line, here's the cliffnotes:
- Voodoo donut: their signature. Personally, I do not like jelly donuts, but it's the traditional voodoo shaped donut and it's fun to see its jelly blood ooze out when you take a malicious bite.
- Portland Cream Donut: A must get if you like cream filled donuts. I really liked this one. It reminds me of Krispy Kreme donuts cream filled donuts, but better consistency and fluffier!
- Bacon Maple donut: My favorite!! I usually don't eat bacon but ate it especially for this donut. A must have. I would say this is their famous donut.
- Arnold Palmer: I like simple, lemon-y donuts. I highly recommend this if you like something on the tamer side.

I am not a huge fan of overwhelming flavors so I didn't try the ones topped with a ton of cereal or chocolate... so those four above are the ones I recommend you to get. 

Upon paying, the cashier gave me two free maple donuts on top of the four that I ordered.. d'oh. I felt sluggish the rest of the day. haha. that was oddly nice of him. I was also surprised to see the donuts are reasonably priced!

Side note: apparently Blue Star Donuts is better, but I didn't have time to swing by...

Voodoo Donuts has received a lot of national attention thanks to the likes of Food TV & Travel Channel. It's a novelty tourist stop while in Portland. The donuts are okay, but not worth standing in line that typically winds around the block. The over sized Texass donut is a treat if you want to spend your day in a sugar coma; the voodoo donut filled with raspberry jam is fun; and the glazed donut with orange Tang powder is indicative of the unusual toppings you wouldn't typically find at your local donut shop. Try it once and weigh in on whether or not "the magic is in the hole."
Great when you are drunk. Not great for breakfast. Very average as far as taste goes (which is the only thing that matters to me).

I am an east coaster, which means I am partial to Dunkin Donuts. So, I didn't expect a whole lot from Voodoo Doughnut, but I was pretty disappointed. I expected at least an hour wait in line, and enjoyed conversing with those near me and taking pictures of the area while waiting. But, then I got in, ordered some classics and some strange donuts and then returned to where I was staying. Fresh out of the oven, and yet the donuts were pretty crappy. Specifically, the donuts tasted more like fat than sugar. I know, donuts are fried and all that, but if you have had Dunkin Donuts, you know what I mean--it should taste like a donut, not like french fries with sugar. 

Bottom line: Not worth the wait, the weight or the cost! Go enjoy a local ice cream place (Salt and Straw perhaps, though I missed it unfortunately) or bakery (St. Honore Bakery, also missed but highly suggested).

Not sure what the hype is all about... Apparently you're not a real Portlander until you stand in line for some doughnuts that just taste like Krispy Kreme with a bunch of miscellaneous crap on top and graced with names that would give your grandmother a stroke? I do like the Old Dirty Bastard, but then again, I love chocolate enough to lick it off a McDonald's bathroom floor... 

Really, now... it's all about the trendiness/cool factor. Not worth the wait, money, or hype!

This place is a portland staple... and I'm not sure why, ha! Probably cuz it has weird food like Portland. But the donuts are just ok, not great, not bad. I would rather go to Blue Star donuts in Portland.
Ehhhh... it's more about the scene and marketing than the actual product. But it's creative, I'll give them that.

I dont understand the hype. My son and daughter absolutely love this place, but after staying in line for 30 minutes I was getting a bit tired.

I choose the crueller (check spelling) and it was alright, it definitely had a cream puff texture which was nice.

The kids chose very colorful doughnuts that were too sweet for my taste. Interesting experience but will not go again.

At the end of the day when going to Voodoo you are buying into the novelty of some of their crazier creations.  A donut is, largely, a donut.  What keeps the lines around the block are interesting takes on a classic staple.  
That being said, what they are able to do with something that is so fundamentally a part of our culture is sometimes quite impressive.  See the Mexican Hot Chocolate as a prime example.  Staples like the Voodoo donut are always tasty and novelties like the Pepto Bismol donut are absolutely interesting, but if you are looking for more than a novelty and really just want a good donut, you have more than Voodoo as options.

"Overrated" doesn't even begin to cover it. Simply put, this place is a tourist trap. It's an average-at-best place that for someone reason has become part of a checklist of places that people think they need to see when they visit Portland. Just as Magnolia Bakery has dry, flavorless cupcakes in New York City, Voodoo Doughnut has dry, stale donuts in Portland. Are they bad? No -- they are still donuts, after all. But are they worth standing in a long line for or going out of your way to get? No. I would recommend going to Blue Star Donuts instead -- unique, inventive and fresh flavors, without the lines and without the gimmick of donuts that look like genitalia.
Nothing special just decorated everyday donuts.
The donuts arent my favorite. The lines are really long too! Cool concept... just not my go-to

As an out-of-towner, everyone has highly recommended that I try Voodoo Doughnuts at least once. Seeing how long the lines were, I refused to wait an hour for a damn doughnut. But... I caved. I had to find out why everyone wouldn't shut up about it for myself.

But seriously, they're just okay. They honestly look better than they taste. The interior is nice and pink but the doughnuts are nothing special. 

This review was brought to you by a victim of a tourist trap. Save yourselves.

Would be good if the lines didn't look like they would take hours just to get into the place. EVERY time I go to Portland, I say "Hey- let's try the original Voodoo Donut just for fun". Then we get there and watch the line spiral all up and down the streets, across the streets.. it would take a few hours to get in. Seriously. And, it has nothing to do with the day of the week or time. I've been there at night time, morning time, evening, on week days and weekends. That's why it was good that they put one down here in the Eugene/Springfield area. I got to try their food. It's good, but definitely overpriced and not worth too much hype. They're creative, but half the time, the donuts are stale, and the other half they're okay. The donuts are super sweet, I like the oreo cookie one and my husband likes the maple-bacon one. Not worth a long wait, though. I definitely could not afford or stomach the pink box.

The lure is in the decorations, right? The donuts certainly aren't that amazing, especially compared to some other sugar pushers around town. As a resident, I refuse to wait in such a line unless I'm promised divine breakfast/brunch options, and voodoo just doesn't deliver.
They need to get those pierced nosed punks out of there! I don't want them handling my donuts.

All the foodies have heard of VOODOO donuts.  It's one of those things to try just to say you've tried it. Not really a place where a donut afficionado, like myself, would frequent. The donut were pretty dense. Felt and tasted like I was biting into a dinner roll with some sugar. There was no bounce to the dough. I really wanted to love their donuts because their shop was cute as is their donut flavors, but sadly I would not recommend. This was purely for experience. The line looked long, but went by fast.
It's VooDoo. The lines are long thanks to awestruck tourists spending more on T-Shirts than doughnuts. The food is ok, but it's a freaking Doughnut shop.

A Portland iconic shop.  Apparently it's been featured on channels like the food network and the travel channel and it's off beat decor / attitude is amusing to those from out of town e.g. their sign slogan of "the magic is in the hole" sets the tone for what you'll find inside.  In addition, the variety of donuts is amazing - vegan donuts and normal donuts side by side on the menu with some of their items being just as kooky as the decor.  Donuts topped cereal and the voodoo donut, a man shaped donut with raspberry filling and a pretzel stabbed through the chest, comes to mind.

Still, I don't really see what the fuss is about personally.  Their doughnuts are decent in flavor, but it's not 5 (or even 4 star for me) quality.  On top of that, 9 times out of 10 you're looking at a line that goes around the corner of the block - about a 20 to 30 minute wait sometimes.  Finally, the interior shop area is tiny so unless you've been there multiple times, you'll probably be a little flustered / bewildered about what to order especially with a line of people behind you.  

Tips - if it's your first time there and you're willing to be adventurous, try the "voodoo dozen" - a dozen donuts that are randomly chosen by the person tending the cash register.  That should give you a fair random sampling without having to figure out on the spot what to order.  Also, from what I can tell, midweek and midday during stormy weather seems to keep the line short.  I wonder why?  ;)
Surely there are better donuts in town, but vegan donuts are hard to find.  Meh.

Went to get voodoo donuts from the place for first time since the last time I have voodoo domuts I was 13 year and my step dad went there and gave me the captain crunch which I fell in love with. I came around 5 pm and it was really busy also it have a long line so that wasn't great. After waiting in line outside for about 20 minute, me and my friend finally got inside and it was small and crowded. All I can heard was staff yelling for the next person and yeah. The donuts are so freaking expensive and if you want to get dozen... You choose between classic or let the staff choose your donut... Or you can chokse your donut but it varies by the price... Which I find bit unfair, but at the same time I understand that their job. They seem to get impatient when someone having hard time deciding which donuts they want... After getting donut... I took a bite at captain crunch donut and the donut itself was soft... But the cereal was stale.... To fast forward.... I would of enjoy these donuts more if I was 13 year old and not picky about donuts... But other than... I would still come back there for gheir donuts, but at the same time... I would go to Blue Star donut since thwre customer service is best and so is their donuts also you don't have to wait in a long line so that a bonus.

This is a great spot to get a donut.  Walk up.  wait in a huge line,  Get an over priced very greasy donut that doesn't taste that good....that's what you said you wanted right?  oh but it comes is a pink box!

Was so excited after all we have heard about Voodoo and couldn't wait to binge on doughnuts during our trip to OR. Seems like expectations were too high since the one word that sums up our experience is: Eh. We got the Oreo doughnut and the Voodoo Doll which were good, but not mind blowing. I really expected to be back in line for a dozen more, fidgeting in a sugar induced craze, but instead I sat outside at those intensely purple picnic tables sad and well, disappointed.  Overall, the doughnuts alone would be 3 stars. The texture wasn't soft and fresh, but borderline stale and it was only about 3pm.  Poor customer service really underscored my dislike for this location and disappointment in Voodoo. Sad to see that other Yelpers have had the pleasure of experiencing this kind of treatment too. Poor service brings my rating for Voodoo to 2 stars. Getting the stink eye from an employee for asking a question about the menu is just not something I'd like to pay for, especially at this price.  Thanks for crushing my doughnut dreams.
Just mediocre quality donuts covered novel toppings like cereal or Oreos. If that's your cup of tea, and go for it!

Waited in line for 15 minutes with le huz and baby. Wasn't about to let the cold weather get in the way of our self-guided foodie tour of Portland! Baby seemed impressed by the sparkly brick exterior (the brick is glitter-covered) whilst I was amused by all the sexual innuendo peppering the joint. "The magic is in the hole..." Lovely!

Voodoo Doughnuts is known for its offering of fun flavors and combos. I really enjoyed watching the colorful selection spin in the display case as we waited in line to order. But le huz, baby girl and I ultimately decided upon some "tamer" options. A Classic Portland Cream (chocolate covered donut with custard filling), a Bacon Maple bar (exactly like it sounds, only rather than covering the bar with bacon bits, you actually get two short strips of bacon on top), and ooh, Cock n Balls. That's right. Cock n Balls. Think two Portland Creams (as the balls) connected to a twist version of the Portland Cream as the wiener - which is then decorated with a rainbow and the text, "TASTE THE RAINBOW"... wahaha. SCORE!

I wanted to love these donuts, but they were only just okay. Congdon's Doughnuts in Maine still reigns supreme in this doughnut fanatic's book.

As a non-native, I had no idea that Portland loved its donuts. When we rolled in to town, three places were recommended to us, Voodoo being the most consistently recommended. Blue Star being the second recommended and Annie's Donuts being the lesser known. 
The first thing to know about Voodoo is that you will wait. This appears to be a tourist trap that is fun, quirky, and in a convenient location. The homeless appear to know this and were practically camped outside of the place, bluntly asking for a donut or a $5. 
We waited about 30-45 minutes to get inside the place. 
The interior is equally fun, making the wait worth it as you have to read all the interesting descriptions for their donuts. If you like the famous: maple bacon or The Homer Simpson. The stranger ones that looked like they had fruit loops attached to the top of them. I'm a fan of classic chocolate glazed and really did enjoy it. Our overall impression of the actual taste of the donuts was mediocre/good. I don't even remember how they tasted, but this place was memorable because of the niche they built in Chinatown, Portland. 
My advice: if you're up for touristy, go for it. The donuts are all right and its a fun location. Skip Blue Star. If you're a serious fan of donuts go to Annie's Donuts. It's a bit further away and less explosive in creative flavors, but their recipe is AMAZING and were the best donuts we had on this trip.
Super long line. I was told it was a must stop place in Portland. I have to disagree. The donuts were extremely sweet. I don't feel like it was worth my wait.

Wow is this place overrated! I couldn't come to Portland and NOT check out Voodoo donuts...but my Goodness was it gross. My friends and I got a variety of donuts and the only one any of us could stomach was the plain glazed. Clearly they make an incredible donut, but it's so disgustingly overly garnished. I know the gimmick is this big overly done donut, but it wasn't worth the hype. 


The employees were very nice, which is the only reason I gave it more than one star...
i dont get the hype. just wasnt that great. tasted way too sweet. nothing any more special than other donuts.

Good donuts, but the hype is insane. I've had donuts everywhere I've traveled and these are good, but not great. We waited in line on a Saturday night for about 30-40 minutes, and it went by pretty fast. They were sold out of a few things once we got inside so that was definitely disappointing. It's certainly an experience but I wouldn't say that I would go out of my way to go back. Blue Star and Pips are just as good, if not better, but I understand why people feel the need to go just based on their image and marketing. It's certainly different, with an interesting and intriguing variety of custom and off the wall donuts, and because of that it's worth going at least once. 

The inside was TINY. I would think they could dish out a little cash to expand the storefront a bit or at least reorganize to make it less of a hassle for customers. I'll also say that it's not in the best area...so if you go later at night, be prepared to be bugged by bums and see some seedy people passing by.

Really, really really dissappointing. 

The doughnuts are like candy corn. Look delicious, sound delicious, mmmm tempted to eat it. But then, they really are just more dissappointing then anything. Lures me in but hten tastes like meh. What else can you say? Just looks better then they are. Ill take a plain looking delish doughnut over a fancy meh one. Maybe it was my fault, maybe I let myself get sooo talked up to this place. But when I tried it, I found the doughnut surprisingly bland and really lacking. Ill try it again before I give up.

A lot of hype but unfortunately the donuts weren't very good. The novelty of having so many toppings on a donut was cool to see, but the actual dough was a little dry. I tried the Oreo and peanut butter donut which was pretty good but take away the Oreos, and it would be a very lackluster donut.

Listen, if this is your first time to Portland, you probably need to go here just to say you've been. But after you've gone once, you don't really need to go again, unless you're entertaining out-of-towners. But props to having $2 cups of Stumptown.

Call me crazy, but I am not a fan. I would much rather consume the absurd amount of delicious calories from Krispy Kreme.  I have given them a few shots but the line during any "donut feasting" hour is ridiculous.  I once ordered a jelly filled donut, and was close to depressed biting into my donut which had no filling.  What a let down!

How sadly disappointing. I know that Oregon has it's share of personalitly-less inhabitants but why did they have to work here? 

My expectations were high, thanks Food Network, but apparently our family stopped at the wrong VooDoo doughnut..

I got out the van all excited like ooo this is gonna be fun!! Walk in and DAMN it's cramped.. am I in a coffin? It wasn't like this on tv... watch the guy behind the counter making stuff... alright... look at the boring doughnuts twirling in the display... and wonder where the hell is the little doughnut man w/ the pretzle impaling him?!?!?!

Mom orders some OrangaTang and the blue and pink and the purple ones.. All I wanted was the little freakin man, the MASCOT of the establishment... and he says "oh we don't have any".. It's not like it was the middle of the day or anything UGH! So annoyed.. I asked for something else (but this was a couple months ago so I dont remember what) but he didnt have that either.. what's with these people!?!

I walked out with a sad faced maple glazed custard filled doughnut. I bit his ugly little head and wanted to spit it out. I don't like maple. bleh. I'm not stopping back at this place ever again.. The VooDoo Too better not disappoint or I will swear off doughnuts forever.


 (forever = for a year at least)

PS. Kudos to whoever painted "KEEP PORTLAND WEIRD" on the back of a building across the street.

It's just a fucking doughnut, people. Get a grip.

It IS a mighty fine doughnut when it's midnight, your drunk and there is no line.

Exactly! Meh. I've experienced better.

Nailed it on the presentation, but doesn't taste like anything special.

However, entertaining for the kids.

We were visiting Portland for the weekend and read somewhere that Voodoo is a place to visit. Donuts were okay - not the best I've had. Best donuts ever are at the Fractured Prune in Ocean City, MD - they serve the donuts hot and they are sooo good. Voodoo donuts are cold and overly sweet, but creatively decorated. My son ate two (I don't know how he did it) and I was barely able to eat half of one. That said, it was an experience and I don't regret it. It's a total tourist trap, and donuts are so-so, but Voodoo proves the power of good marketing.

Holy cow this place is overrated. Does Portland not have a krispy kreme? I mean the doughnuts are decent, but they are too sweet for my taste. I guess there's some novelty in their signature voodoo doughnuts and the harry potter doughnuts, but overall it's not worth the wait.The doughnut quality is akin to what you can get at the bakery section of Safeway. I swear people come here just so they can take a picture of the stupid doughnut and post it on fb/instagram. Unless you are in the area and you have to experience the doughnut's 5 seconds of novelty, you can skip voodoo doughnut.

Crazy concoction doughnuts. Some are good like the ol' dirty bastard, m&m, oreo creme, voodoo doughnut man with stake pretzel, and of course the bacon maple. Some of the other varieties like the fruit loop, fruity pebbles, grape and orange filled covered in confectioners frosting and pixie stick dust are nasty. And there have been times when they taste stale and the toppings taste like they have been laying around all day. If your going there for a munchies mission you probably won't be disappointed. If you go on weekend nights expect long-ass lines and bring cash. They do have an atm that seems to be testy its only operational about 50% of the time.

Maybe their signature bacon maple bar or voodoo jelly filled doughnut would've made all the difference - but they were out of them - BOTH! So, not wanting to be THOSE people who held up the line due to indecision, we put all our faith in the worker before us, and ordered the "Voodoo dozen."  Out of 13 doughnuts handpicked by one of their workers, there has got to be something in there good enough to justify our parking ticket, right?  

The doughnuts certainly looked majestic, larger than most and decorated with a certain childlike ferocity.  But flavor-wise, I really wasn't that impressed.  I tried so hard to taste something amazingly fresh or revolutionary - that just wasn't there.  Short of the oddball toppings, they were just regular doughnuts.

I hear they sell buckets of doughnuts for cheap in the ungodly hours of night, so I could see how that could be cool for people who live around the area, but for all the hype that I heard about this place before I got there, I was disappointed.
Poor quality donuts. Hype is great for tourists. Try Safeway.

I bought into the hype of what is Voodoo Doughnut, and it left me disappointed. The place itself is very alluring -- you have a long line of people (usually a good sign) waiting to place their orders, there's neon everywhere and you're just like "whoa, neon," and then you see all of the available doughnuts spinning in the display case and you wonder which one is the "Cock and Balls."

I finally made my way to the front counter and ordered like six or seven doughnuts. One was a bacon maple bar for me to try, and the rest (an assortment of their most popular items) were to bring home to my girlfriend in NYC. Voodoo Doughnuts come in a huge pink box which you can't miss because it's large, pink, and has "VOODOO DOUGHNUT" written all over it. Everyone, and I mean EVERYONE (my client, my cab drivers, strangers on the street, TSA agents, flight attendants, the passengers on the plane next to me, etc.) took notice of my box of doughnuts and couldn't help but spark up a conversation about it. 

At this point, I had already tried the bacon maple bar, and I found it unimpressive. I mean unimpressive like I ate half of it and ended up tossing away the other half. I've had bacon doughnuts before, and I just didn't think the one from Voodoo Doughnut was good. As for the box I had brought home, the doughnuts in there weren't impressive either. I'd have to say that I found the offerings here more gimmicky than actually good, which overall was just a huge disappointment to me.

So, the doughnuts were just OK -- no more, no less.

Meh. I think these donuts are overhyped, but they're still pretty good. Also, it's open for 24 hours!

The line is pretty ridiculous, because of the tourist-y nature of the place, but it really goes by quite fast. 

I forgot which donuts my friends and I got, but we got a large variety.

The cereal donuts were good! The oreo donuts were pretty decent too!

The problem, however, I have with this place, is that the donuts are like, REALLY REALLY sweet. Like, excessively sweet. I feel like I'd get a cavity if I ate 2 of these donuts. I can't even handle eating one a day! Maybe I'm getting old.

If you can handle the huge, huge, HUGE amount of sweetness, I recommend this place. Otherwise, I wouldn't bother. There's other things worth getting in Portland.

I've tried for days to try to find words to describe Voodoo.  I've only come up with two: eclectic and strange, very strange.  For now, I don't have too much more to say other than that they have a door covered in news clippings about people dying (??).

Stars for creativity... but otherwise, these donuts aren't "to die for" good. I never liked jelly-filled donuts and the Voodoo doll donut didn't make me fall in love. The long line also makes me annoyed at this business... why can't they improve the efficiency? I think they just boast popularity by keeping the line snake long... it seriously moves at a pace of 1 ft per minute, with the line being at least 50ft long when it wraps around the corner.

The biggest negative -- they don't even have traditional donuts! Go get a pastry at Pearl Bakery instead.
its okay.  the Memphis mafia is yummy and of course the classic bacon maple.  but the goddamn lines...ugh.  id rather get blue star, pips or sesame donuts!

For how busy it is, it is absolutely overrated, if you're talking about straight donuts. 

You stand in line to say "I've been to Voodoo," to try to figure what to get, pay too much for donuts that really aren't that special, and someone has done some great marketing to sucker a lot of people into this insanity. 

Donuts with style but really lacking in substance. Sure you get interesting named, styled, sweetend donuts, but if your idea of fun is stuffing your face with an apple fritter as big as your face - talk to your toilet later ... 

I'm more a substance guy - which is why Krispy Kreme never took off with me either. 

This is a great place to visit once. Then the novelty of it wears off.

OK. Can we really call these doughnuts? Aren't they more like sugar-laden and diabetes-inducing fried calories, ready to prompt a massive heart attack after ingestion? Perhaps I'm being over-dramatic. I mean, Voodoo's toppings only consist of bacon, various cereals from my childhood, bubble gum, candy bars, and good ol' chocolate frosting. What is SO bad about that? 

Any tourist visiting Portland will have to make a trip to Voodoo Doughnut. It's almost sacrilegious if you don't. Like people will stare and judge you. Are Voodoo's doughnuts really that remarkable? Considering the ridiculous lines, you'd think so. I waited roughly 30 minutes and it was late afternoon...not really prime doughnut consumption time. 

My boyfriend and I decided to try three of their sugary creations. None of them were memorable-- in a positive way. They were all extremely sweet. I was disappointed that the doughnuts were not warm. I'm assuming with the millions of people who visit daily, their stuff is all fresh. 

Maple Blazer Blunt Doughnut - raised yeast doughnut dusted with cinnamon sugar. The tip is dipped in maple frosting and red sprinkles. This doughnut is supposed to resemble a blunt (how Portland), and is a nod to their basketball team, the Trailblazers. I love maple frosting and cinnamon so I thought this doughnut would be perfect for me. Yet, the sugar + cinnamon + sprinkles + maple frosting were too sweet for me. 

McMinnville Cream Doughnut - raised yeast doughnut filled with Bavarian cream with maple frosting. Two eyeballs and a swirly mustache are drawn on the top. The Bavarian cream was thick and rich. I would have liked this without the cream so I should have gone with the plain maple bar doughnut.

Old Dirty Bastard Doughnut - raised yeast doughnut with chocolate frosting, Oreos, and peanut butter. Sweet Jesus. This was TOO much. My boyfriend and I ended up throwing it away, half-eaten. I can appreciate Voodoo's creative and wacky flair but dang. I might as well have been shoving sugar straight into my mouth. The first bite was fine; however, every bite after that was arduous and the flavors just started meshing into one chocolaty mess. 

The doughnuts here aren't that decadent or to-die-for. I understand the concept of hipster doughnuts with crazy flavors, but they're average doughnuts that are just sugar bombs. Voodoo's infamous pink boxes are emblems of this sweet shop's prominent rise. However, you're not missing out on too much if you skip this "top" culinary destination.

It's worth mentioning that Voodoo Doughnut's neighbor is Paris Theatre, an adult movie theater. So as you stand in line waiting for your fried carbs, you have this classy establishment to keep you company.

It was cool to just go but the doughnuts were ehh. Good to try once. Let's be honest we lol just wanna go there because it's well known and they have cool voodoo shape doughnuts. But the actual doughnuts themselves were just alright.

Kinda disappointed, read numerous reviews and finally gave it a try on my first journey out here to the North West.

After waiting in line for an hour in a cashless society and being told that they only accept cash, the glazed over staff pointed me to an atm behind me that had an 8$ service charge to buy an equally expensive doughnut that tasted like it came from last weeks second quality bin.

The doughnuts I had been reading about in various foodie magazines for so long had been discontinued. I was a little bummed that the NyQuil Glazed doughnut and the Vanilla Pepto Crushed Tums doughnut were no longer sold. 

The disappointment I felt when trying this place for the first time was far from epic as many other reviewers have described.
I was disappointed, such as driving an hour out of the way to see the worlds largest peanut, knowing its a tourist trap only to get to it and see a statue and a plack.  

What a bummer!

Nice pink box and graphic artwork !

For all my family and friends that come to visit and just like reading VooDoo doughnut's vulgar and crass menu and seeing their faces for the first time that is worth three stars.

But for the doughnut themselves, I'll pass and go to the Pearl Bakery or get safeway maple bars instead.

My wife and I were travelling through town this week.  Voodoo Doughnut was one of the repeated suggestions from friends back home in San Francisco, so we had to try it out.  We drove up on Sunday night, around 11pm, hoping to get a crack at some of these so called delicious donuts.  This was a complete no go.   After finding a parking spot a block and a half away, we arrived to a lineup of ~50 or so people waiting for donuts, plus maybe another 10-15 vagrants who smelled really bad haggling folks for cash.  With no washroom, and no hope of getting out of there any time soon, we bailed and came back Monday evening.

Turns out that Monday evenings have a much shorter lineup, but the 10-15 bums were still hanging around.   Parking was a lot easier, so at least two aspects got better overnight.  We got inside and I was a bit shocked to see that these donuts were mostly just regular donuts with cheap crap thrown on them.  Really?  Captain Crunch on a donut?  Fruit Loops?  Rice Crispies?  How old is the target audience for these donuts?

I was happy to see that they had a bunch of vegan options, so I kindly asked for a dozen donuts, half regular, half vegan, letting them choose.  I was surprised to see their prices:  $7 for a dozen 'regular', $10.75 for a voodoo dozen (wtf does that mean?)  They also listed another *something* dozen, but that part of their menu was covered up by storage crap.

The guy at the counter, a douchebag hipster that looked like he *loved* his job, agreed and boxed us up the dozen.  "$15".   WTH?   I don't think I've ever paid this much for donuts.  Way to make me feel ripped off.

Fast forward to a couple hours later.  We're sitting in our hotel room with 10 donuts left, each with a single bite taken out of them.  I would have been better off going to Safeway and sprinkling cereal on them myself.

Maybe Top Pot Hand-Forged Doughnuts in Seattle will satisfy my cravings...

It's a lot of hype considering their spots on the travel channel and food network.  After all at the end of the day, it's just a doughnut shop.  

Their creations are pretty imaginative and some doughnuts there are big enough to have as a meal.  They are open 24 hours a day and I've been there at 10am and 10pm, there is always a line.  

The doughnuts at 10pm tasted much more fresh than the ones at 10am did though. 

My suggestion, try the raspberry filled.

Nothing special about the actual donuts. I knew this coming in but b/c I am from out of town, it was something I had to at least once.

The wait was about 25 minutes and it was still fairly early in the morning (around 930ish) so the piping sun was not out full throttle yet (4th of July weekend 2015) was so hot! 

I had the ODB (Ol dirty bastard); much love to Wu Tang on a side note. It was decent but the dough obviously didn't taste that fresh. 

It's over hyped and I doubt I will come back unless there is no line. But b/c there will always a line, hence I probably won't be back!
Decent. It's more about the experience than the quality of the donuts themselves.

I know this is a must do when you come to Portland, and I've been wanting to come here forever, of course, but I really think it's TOTALLY OVERRATED! 

I definitely give them props for the creative donuts they offer.  We waited in line for 1/2 hour so when we got to the counter, of course we had to order 6 to make sure we tried a variety. And I did like the Oreo cookie donut and the Kix one.  But, it's not somewhere that I would really crave or that I really feel the need to experience again.

Maybe my expectations were set so high from all the hype?  The donuts weren't actually even that moist.  I'd say, maybe do it if you've never been to Portland before, just to go. But otherwise, skip it and spend the money and calories elsewhere.
The doughnuts are good and it's a must stop once in your life but it is more of a place to go if you are visiting Portland.

The doughnut alone is good, but anyone can put cereal on a doughnut. 

I think they just sell the culture of Portland.
We visited Voodoo at 2 in the morning (about the only decent time of a day without a line). Donuts were delicious -- but not abnormally out of this world. Not sure what all the hype is?

As a Portland local, I kind of hate this place. It used to be a nice little spot for getting sugary donuts at 2AM after clubbing or drinking, but it's become bombarded by tourists who don't know any better. I would never wait in line for over 30 minutes for mediocre donuts that I can get at the gas station. This place is just plain OVERRATED.

They are OK. But honestly, I don't get the hype. Their product is not any better or worse than DUnkin donuts of any other donut shop. 

As for standing in line to pay a high price for an average donut..... I have better things to do with both my time and money.

I know Voodoo is a "cultural" thing in Portland, and it's considered blasphemy to speak ill of them, but..... I'm just not feeling the love for the place. 

Meh.

Overrated doughnuts. Go for the experience and to check it off of your list. If you want a better doughnut try Roth's grocery store or Blue Star. Just whatever you do...don't stand in line for 2 hours for a doughnut. That is rediculous.

The line was already out the door when I got to Voodoo, but that was already expected. The line was long, but it went by fairly quickly so don't turn around just yet!

There are is a huge selection of creative, gourmet donuts. I was kind overwhelmed by all the different fatty concoctions and knew I wasn't going to be able to eat more than one donut. I don't remember the name of the donut because I just pointed at whatever donut looked yummy haha. It was chocolate glazed with oreo bits and peanut butter drizzle. I enjoyed my first two bites and after that...I think I had a hard time finishing it. It was just a little too much for me.

I think the price for these donuts are solid. The donut itself was just alright. I had higher expectations for this place but I wanted to try it out because I was in Portland. I think next time I am back, I probably don't need to come back for Voodoo though.

This place has a glittery brick wall. Take a picture with the brick wall as the background. Instragram!!
It's more about the experience than the doughnut.  The east side location is less prone to long lines.

Not sure what the craze is about this place other than it's kinda vintage. We waited in line for a while to get a doughnut that was way too sweet for me and kinda of stale. The portions are huge (ok, that's not really something to complain about) but I just couldn't finish it. If you're looking for a good doughnut that is large then drive up to Seattle and go to Top Pot.

The donuts were good don't get me wrong and very reasonably priced however the experience as a whole was bad. It started when we got out of the car. We lucked into a front row parallel spot, and as soon as we got out we were harassed by homeless people. Voodoo is cash only and all the homeless knew that... once inside, no one seemed to know what a line was, they only had one person at the register and customers were taking their time placing orders. We finally got our donuts and we're headed to the car, only to be harassed again by homeless people. The donuts weren't good enough to come back.
Nothing special in terms of the taste of their donuts. It's a cool place to visit but that's about all. It's not worth the wait in line.

If you enjoy sugar upon glazed sugar upon deep-fried sugar, then classy lady, this joint is for you! Make sure you brought an extra size of pants along, because you will need it after consuming the sugar-laden treats of Voodoo Donuts. Not recommended for children, pets, or lactating females.

Came here to see what the craze was all about. 
Love the different and unique variety of doughnuts. The names are priceless. Definitely would enjoy a lot better if I were high too.

There's def a big sugar high from these doughnuts. 

We went in the early morning-- uno wait time. It's cash only & no pennies accepted. 

The girl recommended the Portland creme doughnut. Pretty ordinary. Voodoo person was pretty hilarious. The pretzel seemed a bit stale. There's jam in the inside.. "Blood" haha. There's a blazer blunt kind of doughnut we got a good laugh out of. Maple bacon bar doughnut was good. Definitely helped that it had that salty element to cut the sugar. The dough was dense. 

Nothing too exciting about the doughnuts except the names and shapes of them.

Decent donuts. There are better in town. Like pretty much everything in Portland these days, it's for tourists  - literal and figurative.

Props though for the abundant vegan selections.
The donuts were okay, but the Bacon Maple bar was good.
I hate this place. People only go here because it is on every TV show food network and travel chanel. Voodoo was cool back in 05' when there was a possibility of getting stabed.

I would give Krispy Kreme 4 star in the donut category, other average donut shops an average 3 star, and an average donut shop with freakishly long line round the clock 2 star.  

Also, I have never met any other Portland local who likes Voodoo.  None.

Voodoo definitely has some unique donuts to choose from - but they're all SO sweet and really more for the wow factor than anything. If you like massive pieces of cookies/cereal/candy/chocolate/whatever on your donuts then yes, voodoo is for you. We could barely finish a donut - it was just SO much. I fear I may have walked out of here with aching teeth. If you want something simple - don't come here.
Pretty good doughnuts but it doesn't live up to the hype. Not worth the line or price, just some new fad that caught on in my mind .

Hate to say it, but the place is overrated and did not match the hype. They were basically sugary donuts that mostly had unique toppings. Price is very good, lines are blah, and the donuts were mediocre. I would still say experience it at least once. However, I preferred Blue Star for donuts when I visited Portland.
Interesting place, but the donuts tasted like they were purchased from Safeway.

Yup, I know.  I'm gonna get it.  I'm sure this review will simply be added to the pool, filed by date and offer a mere .00005 star adjustment to the overall star score of Voodoo, but that's fine.  I will still have several incredulous friends who will have some choice words for my "treason," as if I just tattled to Cornwallis about Washington's Delaware River crossing.  None of that does anything to change the fact that Voodoo Doughnuts is, at best, a slightly below-par bakery with a few (admittedly amusing) gimmicks to support it.

Now, I have tried to love this place, I really have, but kitsch can only go so far in convincing me that what I am eating is of high quality when my tongue is relating a vastly different tale.  I am nothing but ecstatic for those people who have gone to Voodoo and had a great time...really, truly, I mean it.  I, on the other hand, am one of those "lucky few" who managed to get themselves a stale batch.

Wait, I mean batchES.  I have been to Voodoo on five separate occasions, each time hoping for a better experience - each time I was sadly let down.  It didn't matter what I had, it was always rough, dry, and in some cases brittle.  The cereal donuts are the worst offenders: awesome concept, but stale Captain Crunch is not what I would call good eats...using it as a topping for anything else just seems kind of pathetic.

I won't go into the store itself...I am trying to remain focused on the donuts themselves...it's just...

...

...well, damn.  I really wanted to like this place.  The concept is so great, but I can't keep putting on a mask of false exuberance when my friends say "let's go to Voodoo!"  I just don't have it in me anymore.

overrated and overpriced doughnuts with rude hipster employees who get mad when you don't know what you want the first second you come to the register.  the line is also insanely long. I went at night and my doughnut tasted stale. :(
But on the plus side the atmosphere is pretty cool, and they have bathrooms (for customers only) which is always a plus.

This place is a testament to the power of myth and media hype.  They serve completely mediocre donuts covered with all manner of gimmicky nonsense.  You can recreate the Voodoo experience at home by simply topping any old donut with a healthy pile of the stalest cereal you have.  Viola!

Seriously, 75% of what they sell at this store is a gimmick.  There's nothing good about stale Cap'n Crunch cereal, period, let alone on a donut.  Yet the crowds just keep on coming.

Yeah, the Maple Bacon Bar is good.  It's nothing but a more or less average maple bar with some thick-cut bacon on top.  I mean, how bad could it be?  Again, this is the kind of thing you could make at home if you were really craving it.  Their more traditional doughnuts are fine, but certainly nothing to write home about.

Joe's Donut Shop in Sandy is superior in just about every way.

it was ok.  

i understand the vodoo doughnut - stabbing it with a pretzel and red berry filling oozing out.  but it was just not a great doughnut.  points for the great novelty, minuses for the not very good product.

been there, done that, not going there again.  enjoy!

I don't get why people are fanatical about this place.. It's crusty and dry doughnuts that are mock- gormet, by dumping lucky Charms and Fruit Loops on top of them. They accept limited forms of payment and there's a mile-long line and it's PRICEY! Go to Bluestar doughnuts instead... yUMMY!
Very touristy these days.  There are better tasting doughnuts in Portland but none so entertaining.
Nothing exceptional about these donuts other various cereals placed on top. Would rather go to my donut shop down the street
Great assortment of donuts, but after going once I doubt I'll be going back anytime soon.

Ugh. Voodoo doughnuts. I'm just going to chime in here, and some people will undoubtedly resent me for this. But...

Voodoo Doughnuts is not good - rather, it's novel.

There are worse doughnuts, it's true. These are quite stomachable. But the only reason to go there is for the novelty of the blunt, Voodoo man, cereal kitsch toppings, etc. 

But when it comes down to it, these doughnuts are too sugary, too heavy, and the cereal is always stale, even if you actually go and wait in the too-long line at Voodoo doughnuts (instead of getting them at any of the myriad places around town that receive a delivery every day).
