Don't bother. It's a tourist trap with overly sugary doughnuts and things that are just over the top. If you want good doughnuts with interesting glazes and toppings that are way more "Portland" than this outdated spot... try Blue Star or Pip's Original.

Bitchin' donuts but the hydrogenated oil in them is killing us. I get it, NOBODY eats a donut thinking it's healthy but does it have to inflict so much permanent damage to us?

The owner is conscious of the affect of hydrogenated oil but could care less that it's so damaging. I'm not eating at a place where the owner couldn't give a sh*t about my well being. Luckily there is PLENTY of baked good around Portland that don't have all the cheap ingredients.
average tasting doughnuts, funny names and crazy decor inside and out

I will give this place 4 stars for marketing and creativity but only 2 stars for the actual donuts.  They were dense and heavy.  I like light airy donuts but these were not it.  We all got some good laughs from the names but I wouldn't come here for the donuts.

We went to say we had been there and, yes, we waited in the very long line!

Overall the donuts were just fun. Not particularly amazing or anything, but fun and a cool experience. Sad we didn't order a penis one just to say we did it. 

My husband ordered the maple bacon one and apparently loved it since I didn't get to try any. I boringly ordered a french crueller, yet it was one of the best I've ever had. We also got the Portland cream and the captain crunch one for the following day. I dislike crunchy food lately and yet I finished the whole thing with no complaints. They all tasted like grocery store bakery donuts, but the experience nearly made up for it. 

Just an interesting little spot that you kind of have bring your sweet tooth to while you're in Portland.
long line of tourists,waiting for donuts, every single day, all day. This place is a money machine. good job Tres. waiting in a line for a donut is really stupid.

The doughnuts in my opinion arent worth the 20-30 minute wait under the brutal summer sun. Also lame that they don't take credit card, especially since people were buying $30-40 worth of doughnuts... But i loved the decor and the photobooth.

Long lines and incredibly sweet donuts. That's what you'll expect at this Portland landmark of a doughnut shop. But don't worry, the lines move fast enough that you'll be able to grab something good within 15-20 minutes. 

Any time you go to Portland, you'll find that Voodoo Doughnuts is at the top of the list as famous food places to visit. Unique feel? Check. Interesting Vibe? Check. Food? Check. But what Voodoo provides is an interesting take on your average doughnut. With several different varieties from your classic filled doughnut (mango tango please) to the fritters (apple or banana), they try to please everyone. Their options are endless. I wouldn't say it's the best doughnut Portland but it's close to the top of a very short list.

If you're looking to add at least one doughnut shop to your list, I'd recommend a few others. But if you're looking for a place to say "Hey, I went there" then you might as well try Voodoo.

Keep Portland weird.

You guys. It's a fucking doughnut. 

Some creative toppings, but nothing to write home about. I've had some with toppings that were rather stale.

It's silly to see people wait in line for an hour for something they could have purchased for the same price or cheaper at some small neighborhood bakery.

Nothing really so great about the donuts. Had Portland cream and maple donut. Had to throw away maple one. Way too sweet for my taste buds. Now they serve you donuts in a coffin if you buy 3 dozens. So basically eat and die on sugar overdose!

Who makes a maple bar with no cream filling ? C'mon now. The voodoo doll came through in the filling dept, except it was way too sweet and I couldn't even eat it while intoxicated. The service was fast but I'm pretty sure the staff was in a bad mood...probably because it was hot as hell with the sun beaming in the window mid afternoon. I guess I went for the hype, but I'd be heading to Blue Star for a better tasting doughnut.

I personally didn't like this place. All I heard was "go check them out" so I did. Not impressed with them. Especially after a 1.5 hour wait. I get the idea that it's more about the experience and they have creative ideas but taste wasn't there for me.

I went there with really high expectations because of all the hype it was getting. It looked like all the donuts had been sitting out for a long time. They tasted like they gave us the display donuts. I tried practically all of them and they were okay but not the best. I would recommend somewhere else and definitely wouldn't go out of my way to eat here again.
It's fine. Gimmicky. Not really that tasty. Really more about funny decorations than taste. For real insanely delicious donuts Blue Star is so much better. But Voodoo is cute

I think that I was a little disappointed and it could be the fact that I have had Top Pot doughnuts that made it hard to compete. I think the other thing for me was the fact that we had to wait in line for forty-five minutes to get said doughnut. Maybe next time we are in the Portland area we will give them a try and see if my review will change...

I would actually give this place 3.5 stars if i could. Their doughnuts are pretty good. They carry classic doughnuts as well as their own creations. I highly recommend anyone who is visiting Portland to check this place out. Keep in mind, this place is a tourist destination so expect to wait in line. Overall their doughnuts are good, very creative, but can be a little overly sweet.

Honestly, when people say that it's overrated, I honestly think it's so true. But of course... being a tourist, I had to try it being that it's so iconic of Portland. After dinner, I stopped by late at night with my friends for a doughnut run. When I got there, the store was fairly empty, but there were people going in and out of the store. Most of them did seem like tourists, which was expected. 

Before I even went in, I knew that I wanted to go for the voodoo type doughnut, so I went straight for it. Being smart, I decided to split one with my friend. That was honestly the best decision because the doughnut was way too sweet. Even as a chocolate lover and a big sweet-tooth, I thought it was way too sweet that I ended up throwing away a majority of it. The voodoo doughnut also has jelly-type filling inside, which I'm not a huge fan to begin with. So overall, the doughnuts here are very sweet (all my friends would agree). But they are very unique and has the Portland-vibe. I would visit once just to try it and probably be satisfied with that.

The donuts are just so-so. I'd rather go to Heavenly Donuts or just about anywhere else. Having to pay cash only and wait in a long line of tourists is a pain. I did used to regularly pick up a bucket (yes, a bucket) of their day olds from the Sandy location for about $10 to feed my whole office, that was kind of fun. It's just a tourist trap, and if you read any articles about what goes on behind the scenes it's a complete turn off.

If you're a doughnut connoisseur, then this place is for you. If you can take it or leave it, it's probably not worth waiting in line. 

It's a Portland institution, and a must-do if you're in town, but the line was long (and apparently always is) and it's CASH ONLY. I knew this going in, but I'm sure most people do not. The doughnuts are tasty and eccentric, and there's something about walking out with the coveted pink box that gets you excited. Now that I have been there, I may not go out of my way to stop in there the next time I'm in town.

The place felt dirty. The girl who served my doughnuts had arm pit hair that seriously could've used hairnets. It was quite disgusting. The environment felt unclean and dirty. I've had better doughnuts, and especially in cleaner places. I did not eat my doughnuts after seeing the girls arm pit hair. It was disgusting. The employees were nice to a degree, but with a flat like personality; like decarbonated soda. You can see part of the kitchen at the back and it does not look like they are very clean. I'm surprised that OSHA and the Health Dept. have not audited this place much better.

Yes, their doughnuts are good.  Are they good enough to wait in a long line for?  A lot of people would argue with me, but I don't think so.  That being said, if someone else wanted to wait in line and get me a vegan vanilla coconut doughnut I wouldn't be mad.  Everything else is just a little too sweet for my taste.
It's just a damn donut with bs on it.....fresh Krispy cream is better...too expensive wayyyyy overly hyped

A Portland "cult" classic so close to my house that when the wind is blowing the right way, I can smell the maple bacon bars.   While Voodoo is not my favorite donut, they are still a "must stop" for all my tours for out of town guests.  I particularly like the buckets of day old donuts I pick up from time to time for staff meetings!

Came around late at night with all the other drunk folk flocking to grab a sweet thing to tend their hunger pangs. It was average at best I think. Someone else described it perfectly in an earlier review (a tourist trap) and I completely agree. The line was long for something you can get at some of the other great donut places around Portland. If you're just trying to grab an amazing donut, save your stomach and go somewhere else.

If its late out and this is the nearest option, I can see why you would come. Otherwise, you can skip this if you're sober.
got married at the 'Nut' house......it was fun! Of course the peeps are great to close it down for us to have the ceremony! Good times!

Flew in from Cali and my friend Pat was like "you have to try Voo Doo Donuts!"  Everyone said at least a two hour wait- so we go, not a long line at all, and it was around 8pm on a Friday.  Now doughnuts were creative, I have to give them that.  Very colorful and cute!  Crazy flavors-in a good way. The doughnuts were good- like a doughnut  should taste.  I do say it was an interesting stop in Portland, I'd go again.
Ok donuts .... I've had better....this is a good place to go after a late night of drinking

The most overrated thing I have ever had in my life. The places are worth waiting in line and this is definitely not one of them. If you need a sweet treat in a pinch this is not the place to go. However if you are in a first date and wanna get to know them than you are in luck. Sometimes the staff are nice and sometimes they are incredibly rude. Either way if you are gonna wait in line this long it might as well be at Blue Star.

This place is more of a novelty for out of town guests than a place I would frequent for a donut.  

Everything is overly sweet and you cannot eat a whole donut without going into a sugar coma after.

When I first came to Portland for nursing school, people told me to go to voodoo doughnut. It wasn't until my third semester, I tried the doughnuts. There just doughnuts with weird names and food combinations. Once was enough for me.
Whenever I go downtown, I past by voodoo and see that awful line. Sorry guys, but another way to get type 2 diabetes.

I would give this place 2.5 stars.  This place was totally overrated.  I came here after Saturday Market since it's nearby.  The line was long and we waited about 45 minutes in line.  My friends and I ordered the Mango Tango (Mango cream filled mango iced doughnut), Voodoo Doll (jelly filled chocolate iced doughnut), Diablo Rex (devil's food cake doughnut), and Guava Colada (guava jelly filled coconut iced doughnut).  All the doughnuts were super sweet.  Sure, they were cute and instagrammable.  I only liked the Voodoo Doll and the Guava Colada.  The Voodoo Doll was their signature doughnut and very cute.  The icing and the jelly wasn't too sweet.  The Guava Colada was a great combo of tropical flavors, coconut and guava.  Would I come back? Probably not, the wait was too long for mediocre doughnuts.  FYI - its cash only.
Meh.  I get the hype... but I dunno.  They Were OK.  Not the best...

i was told it was a portland must try places to i went during my visit!

line was reasonably long... waited about 15~20 minutes... got a dozen of donuts.
i think the overall taste of the donut itself is mediocre, but its just about the experience and the unique donut features they have. 

i recommend in the sense that its a place to try during the visit, but if you're looking for super awesome tasting donuts, not so sure.
Meh. It's donuts, sheep-people. Not worth more than about ten minutes in line. Go once so you can say you did. If you want a special donut experience, go to Blue Star.

If you love the donuts at Safeway, you can go here and wait in a long line and absorb the "hip" atmosphere and get a Safeway-caliber donut shaped like a dong. 

 (They literally use the same pre-manufactured Bakemark dough as grocery stores etc)
I was so excited to try them... after waiting 30 mins in line my excitement went down when I was biting a mediocre donut :(

So, we knew about this place on Man vs Food. We decided to hit up the shop. Just know, there will be periods of long lines out the door, but don't worry, it goes by pretty quickly.

It was very unique. They had a coffin size box that can be delivered to you with 3 dozen donuts for $100 to be creative! It was cute to come in to the shop to see 2 revolving pillars of different kinds of donuts. They have many different varieties but what really took us by surprise were their "cock'n'balls" and "tex-ass" donuts. You can only imagine what they looked like.

Besides the creativity, the donuts were mediocre. For being a donut shop that stayed opened much later than other places, their donuts were not top quality in taste and tasted pretty dry and old. Sorry, we definitely had better.
Good doughnuts, I don't see why someone would line up for an hour to get them though. They're just doughnuts.

Unfortunately these donuts are just ok. We had read the reviews but wanted to try for ourselves... now we know. Overrated, gimmicky donut shop. The flavor is just not there. Just sweet sugar taste and artificial tasting.

After hearing about Voodoo Doughnuts all these years, I was expecting so much more..

On the day we went, the Parking God was with us as we drove right up in front of the bakery and parked. The line snaked in front with about 30 people in front of me. I almost decided to leave, but decided to stick it out since we drove there special for doughnuts.

I ended up waiting in line for about 45 minutes. The decor was fun, doughnuts were pretty to look at, but taste was just ok. I was disappointed after waiting so long. My baby girl seemed to enjoy hers, so as long as she was happy, I was too.

After speaking to other people in Portland, I later found out that Voodoo is not the go to place for doughnuts. Next time I'll try Blue Star or Pip's and hopefully lines are not as long.

Not good, not good, disgusting donuts!
 
I know all of hipster Portland will hate me after this review. 
 
Check out Voodoo Doughnut for some artery clogging fried chunks of fattness! I didn't think their donuts were good. I ended up having the maple bacon donut, just to try it out. No need to repeat that experience.

They sell tubs of day old donuts for $10 for an entire tub, I believe. That's enough fattness to wipe out a whole town.

I am giving voodoo doughnuts a 3 star because of their originality however, their donuts are not anything special besides the crazy toppings.  Don't get me wrong they are still good tasting donuts but it is not something I would come back to on a regular basis.  

You do have to prepare yourself to stand in a long line. I went around 11:00 o'clock at night and the line was still pretty long. Also be prepared to bring your bills because it is cash only.
Honestly the donuts were good, but extremely overrated. They are literally just like every other donut anywhere else except more expensive, with a shinier design and a long ass line.

Voodoo is a fun place to visit once or twice for the experience. Also the maple bacon bar won't leave you in a sugar coma and is my go to if we visit with family or friends. 

Voodoo is more about appealing to the quirkiness of Portland rather than the quality of the donut. I've never been able to stomach the excessive sweetness of the multiple combinations of cereal, candy, frosting and jellies however it is worth trying as a novel experience.

I am no doughnut connoisseur but I thought these doughnuts were just alright. I came here on a Tuesday afternoon and there was a line. I ended up getting a dirty dozen plus the old dirty bastard. They tasted a bit stale, not fresh like I was expecting. I did like the dirty old bastard. That doughnut was good (probably thanks to the toppings). 

Is it worth the hype? No. Is it worth trying? Probably. It is a good tourist attraction for Portland.
eh... too much hype around the donuts.  they are pretty dry, at least the ones i've tried.  they are creative, i'll give 'em that.
Lines here are insane and full of tourists and out of towners. This used to be great before everyone and their dog knew about it. Thanks tour guides and everyone else for ruining a great spot!
Never have understood why people like this place, as it is dirty and the donuts are subpar.

I saw many reviews mentioning long lines, so I guess I was lucky coming on a Wednesday a little after noon, and walked right in the door with only a few people ahead. I ordered a voodoo doll and an old dirty bastard with chocolate icing, peanut butter, and oreos. They were pretty good, nothing to rave about. This probably happens a lot on Yelp, but I would choose Blue Star over Voodoo, any day. A lot of Voodoo's flavors were for the most part, flavor profiles I've already seen done before. The voodoo doll's raspberry jelly was pretty damn good, though. The old dirty bastard was kind of dry (lol) but I'm assuming it's because of the peanut butter. Make sure you have a drink at hand!

Location is prime. It's right across from the Keep Portland Weird Sign, and a short walk to Stumptown, the waterfront park, and Powell's. 

I'm kind of stuck between wanting to give them a 3 and a 4, so I'll give them a 3.5 because of the overall experience. It's a cool place to visit at least once to get the whole Portland experience if you're not local. It's one of those kind of things where you go just to say you did. Their donuts are kind of a novelty item. The voodoo doll was creepily cute and the atmosphere was edgy.

The revolving display cases were fun to see. The menu above was kind of hard to read, and it was a little difficult to read signs in the display as it was revolving, so it was kind of overwhelming trying to pick a donut. As we walked out we realized that there was a menu outside on the wall that we totally missed, so that was the only con of walking right through the door because there's not a long line. It's something I only would have noticed if we were waiting in line standing against the wall.

To my mind and tongue of course , dunkin donuts was better than this. I didn't see what the hype was all about. Maybe back then it was amazing I guess. No card , long lines , crazy picture on the wall make it bit of an event. Other than that there is really nothing much to it. It's always fun to experience the hype and mark it as done in the bucket list.

CASH ONLY!

I've read and seen the pictures of long line and when I went there wasn't a line thankfully.  I was able to park at the lot across the street for about 10 minutes and go in and out of the store.

I bought the Ape Grape, Voodoo, Butterfingering and Maple beacon.  The Butterfingering was my favorite because it's the chocolate on top of the doughnut.  The grape was interesting because I can't recall having a grape flavored doughnut.  The Voodoo is their signature doughnut for show.  The cool part is how each voodoo is unique, but taste like a chocolate doughnut.

3 stars because of the 40 min wait in line. The doughnuts are yummy so if the line isn't so massive, give it a try. I felt like it was a waste on my part though because of the long wait. We drove in from puyallup and we have a doughnut place that has the same type of doughnuts.

Fiancee demanded we try this place while in Portland. I resented the fact we spent an hour and half of one of our two days standing in line at Voodoo doughnut. The weather was nice enough though, and listening to the Street Beat guy solicit us for an hour became kind of humorous. 

The donuts: they're ok. Mostly too sugary though. I enjoyed the Ole Dirty Bastard with oreos and peanut butter glaze. The Mexican Hot Chocolate was a standout buttermilk traditional donut. As far as the highly-touted maple bar with bacon... I could pretty much go to my local grocery store and buy a maple bar and fry up some bacon, slap it on the donut and have it all done in less time than it takes waiting in line at Voodoo. 

I guess if you're a tourist, you have to stop by this place at least once if you love donuts. Bonus is that it's open 24 hours, so I suggest you go in the wee hours of the morning after drinking all night and get yourself a donut.

A really sketch place to be at night. While there are a lot of restaurants and people nearby, the street is dark and the donuts are mediocre. I like the texture of the donuts, but they were too sweet (trying to watch my blood sugar).

Guys, don't wait in line for VooDoo. It's Portland's biggest secret. Go to VooDoo at 4 a.m. on your way to the airport. Sometimes the guys are super nice and will give you free donuts they're about to throw out. I know it's cool to walk around town with your pink box, or share some treats at Stumptown down the street, but please don't wait longer than 5 minutes in line. Sure, you'll meet some cool people in line that will probably become your best friends.... but the long wait could be better spend in line for brunch. Now that's what Portland people wait in line for. 

Just go at off-times!

HAD to try this place: yes because of Anthony Bourdain, yes because of the funky looking doughnuts. OH SO disappointed. I've tried many doughnuts all over the country, mostly they're just regular, but I've had some really great doughnuts too. These are really just plain - tasting. I really don't want to knock this place because the actual store is soo cool looking, the idea of Voodoo and doughnuts, the wild pink color of their store and their boxes, the neon sign outside, but in reality these doughnuts are below par. The only reason I would recommend you to go is so can say that you've been to a world famous doughnut shop-if that's what you're into, because to me, that's all they were, cool to look at. But just like some world famous places, I left asking myself why it ever gained that reputation.

This review isn't based on the doughnuts themselves.  Rather the customer service that did not exist on 01/28/18.  Decided to finish my Portland trip with Voodoo, walked in and used the ATM.  I then proceeded to look at what they offered.  As well as two other customers that I was standing next to.  Then shortly after a female cashier yelled at us "I'm standing over here" in a very rude tone and rolled her eyes at us.  At that point the other guests walked out.  I walked out as well and decided not to give my money to this employee, she was the only one.  She even gave me a smirk as I walked out.  Was not impressed at all as I was excited to experience this place and it went terrible.  Also wasted $5 on parking for no reason.  Will definitely not come back to this location.
Not impressed. Mediocre tasting, albeit creative ideas. Too bad my butterfinger donut was way too sweet and stale tasting. Good idea though.

The line for this place can be quite long.  It is a Portland classic and a tourist destination so plan accordingly.  Still, I am not a particular fan of their donuts.  We tried a dozen different donuts and none of them blew my mind.  They were good but for me at least, they were not worth waiting twenty minutes for.
Certainly not the best doughnuts I have had, but not the worst either. I guess they are good novelty. We ordered a dozen to try and none of them were tasty enough to finish.

A friend from Florida wanted to go so we stood in line.  The doughnuts are like krispy creme gotta eat them fresh and hot.  The place, I felt, was dirty. Been there done that.  Cash only so they're making bank for sure

Visited here three times. 

First time was fun to see the creativity. The eye appeal and art is here, for sure. Ordered a dozen and thought the experience unique but not impressive flavor wise. 

Second time took a friend both of us felt this is overrated. 

Third time brought guests again. The lemon filled was so skimpy that one member of our party brought to the attention of the shop. (She felt after the long wait in line and considering the price and the great reputation the "wanting donut" needed to be mentioned. She only showed the scant filling and said nothing else.)  The young man behind the counter acted extremely "put out" and worked to make the guest awkward. He dramatically tossed the donut away and reluctantly replaced with the same (skimpy filled lemon).

Everyone in the third party agreed that there was nothing worth the rave here.

Won't be a fourth visit. Not when Every Day Is A Donut Day, in Hillsboro generously fills their donuts, has a variety of flavors, goes out of the way to make an experience positive, is priced so the experience is worth talking about.

Voodoo who do you think you are? I now look at people carrying their pink box with empathy.

I'm currently daydreaming about bacon...the kind that sits atop a maple long john in a far away city called Portland. Mmmm. The last thing everyone needs is another review shouting the praises of said doughnut...but I can't resist. I woke up with Voodoo on my mind and figured it's as good of place as any to get my Yelpin' started. 

I loved (most) everything about this place....the vintage-ee feel, the Johnny cash playing on the radio, the tattoo covered baker, the sexy doughnut names, the fact that I magically showed up when there was no line, and of course the plethora of heavenly goods just begging to melt in my mouth. 

What I didn't like, however, is that A: it's cash only. This means I spent all of my money on doughnuts (which are by no means cheap) and that the only way I could buy one of their cute t-shirts is if I paid yet another fee to the ATM and B: there were soooo many to choose from. I felt like the guy who helped me was hurrying me along, likely annoyed by all of my questions...but they had no names! I walked away feeling as though I may have missed out on some real goodies as a result, and definitely wasted some $ on a couple blaaah choices. Perhaps my fault for being an ill-informed newbie?

Either way, I like bacon. And assuming I can once again magically end up there on a day where there is little to no line, I'll be back :)
Put an early morning curse on your boss and co-workers!  If you like stabbing your food because you just waited a half an hour for a doughnut then this is your place.
There are much better doughnuts to be had in Portland. Voodoo seems to have a lock on the "weird" flavors and texture combo, but is not necessarily a good overall doughnut.

I con't figure out what makes people wait in line for a doughnut. Call me crazy but I couldn't get excited by the one I ate and was glad the line was short. Glad to hear they have now opened in Colorado, their going to need lots of doughnuts there now.

really? most reviewed place on portland yelp? really?...
seems like everyone from out of town feels the need to come check this place out...
it's ok..yea, it's creative and at times "ballsy".. and yes they do have a delicious maple bar with bacon that is way overpriced...but, the downsides are a few- night time line, cash only, and way too sweet (wayyyy...)
the novelty factor last only so long.

Fell for the hype and waited 20 minutes on a Saturday to get me some donuts. Had to stop here just to know for myself what this place was all about and left feeling unimpressed. Voodoo may have started the different donut craze from your standard donut, but flavor wise nothing stood out to me. Got a donut shop back home that offers a variety of donut flavors that taste better and cost less. Ordered the maple bacon bar, Portland cream, and grape ape. Maple bacon bar is pretty self explanatory. Portland cream is a yeast donut with a cream center topped with chocolate frosting. Grape ape is a yeast donut topped with vanilla frosting and purple sprinkles. All donuts were overly sweet. I will say the texture of the donuts were good consistency. Will I be back? Nope, but at least
I can say I've been there and can check it off my list of places to try.
Unique flavors which are fun.  Overall taste is a normal donut.

Hm, Doughnuts, well, DOn't go to NUTS about the Doughnuts! I don't know there is a big difference between these and the ones I have had in other fresh doughnut places. It's certainly become a tourist trap, and I was very disappointed in the attitude I was getting from the young man who served me at the counter. Like he was too good to work there and his time was too valuable to be taken care of me. Anyways, if you feel like standing in line for 20 minutes to have some doughnuts than "this is your place to be" :)

You have to come here when you are in Portland. But a bit overhyped for me. Fortunately we only had to wait 15 minutes to get in. 

I had the mango tango which was tasty. I like citrus flavor so this hit the spot. Intended to only eat half but I ate the whole thing. 

Also got the signature Voodoo donut. Reminded me of Mr Bill from SNL way back in the time. It was good with the raspberry filling. 

A litrle too touristy for me but fun nonetheless.

I'd say the line at voodoo donuts wasn't too bad.  I was expecting really long lines for such a touristy place.  The artwork was interesting however I felt the donuts were somewhat lacking.  I'm originally born in Oahu (land of malasadas) and I'm used to really fluffy donuts and good batter.  We ordered the hibiscus frosting and the voodoo donut chocolate, which was gingerbread shaped.  Not uber fluffy or fresh donuts but looked cool.  The t shirts were funny but not worth $25.   Hibiscus frosting tasted good and we went next door to eat them at Stumptown because it was raining.

They had a wide selection of their signature "voodoo" doughnuts. Being it my first time, I decided to order the voodoo dozen, where the workers choose the twelve most popular doughnuts for you. The girl worker that night wasn't that helpful and seemed to choose the old doughnuts instead of the "popular" ones. They were okay tasting. My favorite was the oreo doughnut, but that's about it. This place is a must visit for people visiting the Portland area for its exotic and weird vibe.
Overhyped, but good donuts... There are better places to get a donut in Portland. Goto Blue Star Donuts!

Being the ultimate tourist, I had to stop by voodoo doughnut and of course there was a line. Overall, the donuts were pretty mediocre. They tasted like any other donut you can get at a grocery store. The frosting was overly sweet but they do get pretty creative with the toppings.. with different cereals and whatnot. I don't think I would come back if I'm ever back in Portland.

This place has the most wild doughnuts I have seen. Someone suggested I visit this place when I went on my business trip to Portland. I didn't have much though into it before going. When I got there the line was super long! I had what felt like a million choice of doughnut to choose from. In my opinion it was just too much for a doughnut, but I can see why people rave about this place.

What is all the hype about? I've had better tasting donuts from groceries stores than here. Luckily when I went there was no line at all or I would have been pissed for waiting for something less than mediocre. The shop itself has a kind of funky hipster vibe, and the employees match that vibe. They all seemed like they hated their life.
I got this chocolate sundae type donut; chocolate frosting with peanuts and chocolate chips. It was incredibly dry and gave me an instant stomach ache. It must have been made the day before and was a left over or something. Nothing about Voodoo Doughnut's left me impressed.

Good but not great. Obviously tons of hype from being featured on network television but the donuts are pretty average- I've had better in my hometown for way less price-wise. Fun names and provocative shapes for the donuts adds to the fun but really don't think it's worth the 1 hour wait in the morning to get a donut here.

It's Voodoo Doughnut. It's a Portland staple and one of the tourist traps I felt like checking out for the hell of it even if a great majority of these reviews says it's A-OK. The reviews are on point, but I still checked it out anyways because I'm just another obnoxious tourist.

Brian and I wanted to check out this location the very first day we arrived in Portland, but before we even decided to check it out a bazillion of cops fled to the area to see whatever kind of illegal activity is going on. We waited until the next day, and we got pretty lucky with not running to a long line extending to the corner of the street. While we were chatting it up with some other tourists visiting this shop, we didn't realize that it was one of "cash only" places, but luckily, there were was an ATM inside and outside of the donut shop.

As far as the variety of donuts, it's just basically your standard donuts with some extra weird garnishes with pretty creative names. I tried one of the employee's favorite donuts and the maple bacon bar. For the maple bacon bar, I wished they would've garnish the bacons on top of the maple bar in to bits instead of strips. Even though the combination was satisfying, I thought it would be better if it were bits. On the other hand, the employee's favorite which was the Oregon Cream was real tasty. I liked the chocolate glaze on the outside with the light cream on the inside. However, the two random dots toward the edge of that donut was a bit odd for me and would be better if it was decorated more.

Overall, be aware that the donut shop you're about to enter is deep in the hood... Bring pepper spray or someone who has kick ass self-defense skills with you to wait line. Other than that, this shop is just another one of those overrated places where you can find some better quality donuts at your local grocery store.

A novelty only.  Stand in line for an hour and you get to say you've been there and you get to try the strange concoctions like a bacon maple doughnut or the voodoo doll.  Oddities aside, the doughnuts themselves are only mediocre.

Voodoo has a flair for the creative donut. The donuts have unique toppings, shapes and names. Are the donuts good? Yes, I'd say so. Are they worth the price and the line? Eh, probably not.

Their offerings are novel, but when you consider the basic donut quality (beyond the extra toppings and shapes), the donuts are actually quite average. IMO, the texture and taste of the standard glazed donut at Krispy Kreme is actually superior.

But it's still worth a visit. If you go, get the Voodoo doll and the Portland Creme. Those were my favorites.

They have a ridiculous variety of donuts, with some interesting combinations. It was around 9pm, and we  had to wait about 20 minutes in line, but the line moves fairly quickly. Highly advise browsing the menu on your phone while waiting in line. Only comment is that they don't list the prices for the donuts, and the prices vary depending on the donut. I got the Memphis Mafia, which tasted delicious. But it's one of the bigger donuts and cost $4.25, compared to the more mild $1.50 other donuts you might find. Overall good donuts, but a little overrated. Would go back again, but not too often to save my budget and my health.

I'm not sure I can give this place a neutral review.  Maybe the lists of 4 and 5 star reviews, and long line made me expect too much, but didn't live up to my grand expectations.  I'm not sure.  

The donuts are fun and createve, and there are several choices.  We ordered, the Portland Creme, glazed, old fashioned, maple bacon, grape, and mango tango.  The donuts were comparable, and in some cases less stellar than some less touted places I've been to.  

Surprisingly, I enjoyed the grape and mango tango.  Although the grape has a bit of an artificial flavor, it's so unique and has such a punch that I enjoyed it.  The mango had a lot of flavor as well.

It's certainly a place to go, to at least say that you have been.  In addition, their donuts are decent, and there are so many options that I may have missed the opportunity to taste their best ones.

This place was overly hyped up and it wasn't worth the wait for the donuts. They tasted just like any other donut with a bag of sugar poured on top of it. While the designs and decorations were impressive, it was not as delicious as I expected it to be.

Want to show off a purple tongue?  Wait in line for the grape ape.  You won't be disappointed.  Fresh, and read the descriptions of donut  before you get in there, as it is tough for them to talk with tongue and nose  piercings, as well as with 50 other people waiting it can be bad to shout over along with some great speed punk can really get you pounding.  The place is hard to find, so just look for the Keep Portland Weird sign, as it is in front of there.

I waited 2 minute in line for my cute Voodoo Doughnut... So I am not complaining...

It was kind of cute with it's big eyes staring at me while I chowing down his body. I was hungry and I have a few drinks. Can I say sweet and carb is one of my favourite drunk food too?!

I ate it in bed... and I got chocolate all over my hands... yes it was finger licking good.

RIP you mean looking Voodoo doughnut!

Overly-hyped!  Call me a food snob but these donuts are not the best.  There is always a line of tourists and although they have expanded the shop, the taste of the donuts are just okay.  Once is enough, and if you go again, you'll then quickly remember to never eat another again!  I would rather have a cupcake!
I think people come here for the fun, not for the food.... way to sweet and overpriced
Just regular donuts, really nothing extraordinary. They were good but not amazing enough to stand in line for.

a class in portland, but definitely too much hype.
donuts were good, but not great.  love the decoration and decor, however.  
get the classic voodoo donut with a shocking ghost who has a pretzel stabbed in the heart.  it is filled with raspberry jam.  pretzel was stale, however.

chocolate peanut butter oreo donut was decadent!! too sweet for my taste and loaded with oreo cookies.  

dough was soft but lacked an extent of chewiness.  didnt feel overly greasy but definitely very sweet.

How many people in the United States need to become addicted to sugar, obese, or eventually die of heart disease before we let go of the idea that over indulgence is a joke?

The body is not a sacrificial device for your business to succeed.

Overrated.

If you're from South Bay, Voodoo is essentially the same as Psycho Donuts in Campbell. I had their Captain Crunch donut, and we also got their bacon and maple bar, and a few glazed ones. They have super sugar-ified donuts with overly done designs that are sure to pack tons of overwired energy in them. 

Service was on the grumpy side, but hey...y'all have lines out the door all the time, so what's to complain about the money you're making? Each donut was about $2, and lines move quickly. This is definitely a tourist trap, but if you've never been to a crazy donut shop, then this is your stop. It's just not for me.

I would rather eat at Blue Star (another Portland donut place) because it seems more edible and unique in terms of flavor.

Ah, couldn't wait to visit the famous Voodoo doughnut on our trip to Portland. I tried the cap'n crunch donut that I've seen on TV a few times. I was pretty underwhelmed. It was OK, but didn't really live up to the hype at all, and not worth waiting in line so long only to be hurried along by the unfriendly staff when its your turn to order, while being overwhelmed trying to choose something. And they don't even have coffee! Everyone wants coffee with a donut, right? Plus, it's cash only. What year is it, people?

The best memory I have is a man in a bronze art-adorned van that showed up and started dancing in the street in a monkey mask, only for my grandpa to join him. If you're lucky, you'll see him too. I mean, I would probably come back to try some other donuts, but since I live 2000 miles away, that isn't going to happen anytime soon.

So much hype for this place! Watching the Travel Channel's Man v. Food, riding the train and having complete Portlandian strangers tell me "You gotta try this place", and seeing the ridiculously long lines outside the shop, you can see how the bar was set so high in my mind. 

Alas, crashing down to reality... We were fortunate to enough to come at a time where there was no line to speak of. We bought a dozen different doughnuts to share and try.

There were some stars that stood out - the classic Voodoo Doll and the Maple Bacon Bar. The Voodoo Doll was playfully delightful with it's raspberry filling combined well with the chocolate topping. The Maple Bacon Bar was a good play with the salt and sweet contrasting flavors. It wasn't overwhelming sweet either, which was nice. 

This would've gotten 4 or even 5 stars had it not been for a couple factors. Firstly, some of the doughnuts with the cereal toppings were a little stale. Secondly, the experienced I had heavenly bliss of Krispy Kreme doughnuts dampened any and all other places indefinitely. (Yes, it's that good - restaurants use this doughnut as buns for hamburgers for crying out loud!)

Also, I didn't recall seeing any other competing doughnut shops in the area to compare Voodoo with... 

3-Solid Stars

I appreciated the quirkiness but could have done without the long line and skipped the excess calories. Indeed, the Voodoo donut gave me a chuckle but can easily be described as a large chocolate icing slathered jelly donut with a small pretzel stick poked in its side. Sorry, Portland, you're sweet and weird too, but you got nothing on my Gourdough's (aka "your Austin donut rival")!

Voodoo Doughnuts is running on the fumes of its past gimmicks.  (They used to sell unconventional and controversial doughnut flavors like Pepto-Bismol).  I was initially drawn to its bright pink neon sign, but a closer look reveals that the shop is located in a sea of strip clubs and dive bars that gave it a somewhat seedy feel.  The doughnuts themselves had fun names and concepts, like the Voodoo Doll, but there was nothing special about the flavor combinations.  I'm glad I went once during my Portland visit to check it off my bucket list, but I will not be going back.
Great, great presentation. Great Portland icon, but the donuts just aren't good. Yes we will take out of town guests to try them, but we won't go for ourselves.

When in Portland, the rule is you MUST try Voodoo Donut, right?  I've been three now and I have yet to be blown away.  They win for creativity and shock value ("Yes, I like a Cock and Balls please) but taste-wise, it's really nothing special.  My favorite so far is the ODB.  Give it a shot but be prepared to wait in line for 30 minutes and have cash on hand.

My son and I visited like two weeks after the reopening last summer (they remodeled), and I can't even believe how disappointed we both were.  I got the same thing I always got, the banana fritter; not only was it smaller by at least half, but it was now a dollar more, and as my son and I walked to the MAX station eating our selections, I kept having to spit out mouthfuls of grease, literally!  It was disGUSTing!!  I forget what my son had, but he was gravely underwhelmed as well.  O.k., so their lobby is bigger, but gone is the cool ATM covered in all the graffiti that lent it character, and all the celebrity obits you used to be able to read while standing in line have been relegated to some Siberia of a hallway, and the plethora of illumination has washed away all the old counter-culture feel of the old lobby.  If you're a tourist and bound and determined to do Voodoo Doughnuts for the full Portland experience, well, knock yourself out I guess.  But if you're actually out for doughnuts?, do Sesame or Coco; they're both full of actual flavor, Sesame has hordes more choices (many of which could be addictive if you're not careful...), and they're both priced way more reasonably.  Sorry to say, I doubt I'll ever go back to Voodoo...
Line went quickly around 10:45 on a Saturday. They are cash only, but there's an ATM inside. Pretty hyped up yes, but definitely more unique than a grocery store doughnut.

I love the idea of Voodoo donuts. Fun and unique. However if you were ever lucky enough to be in Renton, WA. Look up chuck's donuts. They have the most amazing maple bar. I can scarf down 4 and I hate sweets.
I'll give it three stars because they do actually provide you with somewhat decent donuts. But all you fools lining up are suckers for marketing.

I was really upset to find that after YEARS of wanting to try out this famous doughnut shop, their donuts were VERY underwhelming, dry, and just tasted old.... I wish they cared more about their product. I'm only giving another star for creativity of donuts......very disappointed

Fluffy goodness + fun flavors and designs + doughnut freshness longevity... Voodoo is definitely a neat spot. I dig the vibe and all the sparkly gimmicky stuff. The doughnuts really are delicious, but I have not had one in a while so, I don't have much to compare it to. 

For such a popular spot it seems strange it is Cash Only, also their doughnuts are quite overpriced, but, hey- you are paying for the experience, right?

The donuts are old and stale in the evening.  It may be fresher in the morning.

The Arnold Palmer is just a glaze donut with lemonade and iced tea powder dusted on top--not impressed.

The bacon-maple overwhelmingly tasted like day old bacon, which I would rather eat separately from the donut.

The gorilla grape is just dusted with grape flavored powder which reminded me of dimatap cough medicine.  If you like that flavor, by all means...
This is the happening spot in Portland, as the line was quite long.  I found it to be just ok.

We went Sunday around noon...I was so excited about the maple bacon bar and they were out!!  I was so sad!  So we picked for others to try...to be honest...the donuts were not that great.  What makes them interesting and even greater heart attacks are are toppings that they put on them from cocoa puffs to chocolate and peanut butter sauce with chocolate chips and chopped peanuts.  Put a bunch of stuff on a mediocre donut and you still get a mediocre donut.  I will probably not make any effort to go back...maybe if I'm in the area, I'll check to see if they have the bacon maple bar..
If you are a local go to Pips or Cocos or Blue Star. But if you are from out of town you ought to stop by and see what Portland is all about.

To paraphrase the old expression, "Lardy, Lardy, Lardy!"

Voodoo Donuts is all about appearance.  Looks good, tastes... well, not to mine.

I've long called donuts "doughludes" because they taste like dough and act like qualudes.  These take that expression to new heights.  Prepare to be truly catatonic.

Been to Voodoo a few times as I work dt Portland. The quality of doughnut is on the better side of average. The price is about average. The wait stupid. And I only got hit up for money about a dozen times within a few blocks. It's far better than any standard grocery store but I have had much better quality of doughnut at some ma & pa places.

Way overrated.  It's in a crappy neighborhood and it smells like pee outside.  If that makes me want a donut, something is wrong with me.  I know it's a Portland staple but maybe the standards need to change.  Just an average donut from a well-known place.  You could probably get the same quality at 7-11.

Once upon a time there was a little bakery that produced the craziest doughnuts you'd ever imagine eating.

Unfortunately, that little bakery grew and grew, so much in fact, that it no longer resembled what it once was...

Are the doughnuts funk and fun, yes, but are they the most amazing doughnuts in the PNW, no. They aren't bad either, they just aren't "stand-in-line-for-45min" good.

If you are looking for a comparison, they are better than Blue Star... but not by much. The only redeeming factor here is at least there is more character here.

Given the amount of reviews and rave about this place I expected so much more!

I feel like doughnuts can only be so good and to me that limit is crispy cremes...THEN Voodoo. Don't get me wrong, the doughnuts here are good, but not THAT good. When I think of Portland, I don't think of Voodoo doughnuts, I think of NO TAX. I was obviously not from around the area and the lady that was helping me was not nice at all! She was being so impatient. My family loved the doughnuts though that I had brought home and I enjoyed them as well but will not be back.
Donuts. Long lines. Wow. I'm not a "doughnut guy", but surely this is the most overrated foodstuff on the planet, let alone in Portland. They're good, just like the ones at Fred Meyer.

My first time here was a little after 2am on a weekday night and shockingly- no line! Quick service although the staff wasn't super friendly. The doughnuts themselves were reasonably priced ($15 for a dozen). The oreo was my personal favorite but they were all pretty good. 

Second time here was on a weekend around 1am and it was a madhouse. Cops were called to escort out two guys that were fighting, while another guy felt up his girlfriend's dress while in line. Yikes! The staff was extremely rude during this visit but probably because they were over the wild animals they were serving. 

All in all, since I was on vacation I'm glad I got to experience the madness however if I lived here I would not be visiting this place often.

When in Portland... 

I can agree with the hype but there's other things that makes this joint standout from the rest. The location, the ambience, the community and its personality. 

The location is ideally located in a cultural melting pot of both savory and sweet. Walking around the 5 mile radius of the shop, its clear that there's a cultural transition and its not really a border per se but rather an ensemble of mixed theme shops and restaurants that is as diverse as its tourists. In return, it offers an ambience that caters to all walks of life. Its not mainly focused on the tourist trade but also offers a bit of Portland's weird personality in their dough. 

The shop offers a lot of appeal with its alternative and unique personality. Its a first and how else can you successfully introduce a sub rosa lifestyle through the public rather than through a sweet piece of cooked dough. Brilliant really, but not unique. 

To critique their donuts, its unique and has good ensemble. The idea is to buy a piece, enjoy it with your favorite warm drink and you carry on. Most of the negative reviews I read about it are from people who sugar-binge with a dozen and devour it all. Ever heard of Diabetes and Obesity? Yeah, America. 

Besides the hype, they deliver some of the unique combinations of Donuts that I haven't seen elsewhere. I may have heard it through the Food Network but their application is very spot on (Shout out to the Guava Donut). I just hope that they stay grounded with their ever expanding brand and possible franchise. Some joints lose their essence and gives in into corporate greed. 

Stay true Voodoo and continue to stay weird. 

PS. 
For everyone who complains about the staff... this ain't Disneyland. Get your sh-t together, order, pay and get out. Thanks (the guy next in line).

Over hyped to the point of ludicris.  They serve donuts.  Putting Fruit Loops on a donut is not creativity.  The donuts are mediocre, the toppings are overkill, and the constant line to get in is idiotic (in that it is idiotic to stand in a line in the rain to get an ok donut, just because it looks like a cock and balls).  HYPE HYPE HYPE
For all the hype Voodoo gets, the donuts are average at best. I've had way better in other places where I didn't have to wait in line for an hour or deal with impatient and unfriendly staff.

Great doughnuts. Maple bacon bar and apple fritter were excellent, glazed was alright. Really annoyed they gave me change including two dollar coins so I'd throw them in the tip jar. Realized only when I went to tip from my ones. Slimy move but I'm sure it pays. Enjoy! And count yo dolla bills ya'll.

Ok, I know a donut is a donut but everyone I know who has been to Voodoo tells me that I "must go". I went three kids in tow and waited for 35 minutes to be greeted (I am joking there is absolutely no greeting, the people who work there looks so unhappy) to a list of delicious looking donuts. They all sounded fun and unique which of course they kind of are but...they are just donuts. Do their toppings taste different? Sure. My son opted for a captain my captain (captain crunch) and triple chocolate penetration (coco puff topped) donut but cereal toppings were so stale he didn't want to eat them. I did a vicious hibiscus and it was certainly interesting. My girls ordered more standard sprinkle donuts and they ate them. Overall, it's a donut and maybe an experience? Go if you want to see the creative toppings but if you want a good donut I would stick to Krispy Kreme.

We waited in the POURING rain in a long line to sample these donuts. I wasn't disappointed with the experience; I can now say I've had a Voodoo Donut and I even got to order one of the more inappropriate ones. So that was fun. 

But if I came back to Portland, I'd probably skip doing the long lines again.

Ashamed to say that we stood in line for over an hour here, just to be able to say we did it.  Since we were walking around the Saturday market, we thought "why not?"  So..we were sheep, but I still refuse to buy an i-phone or do the black Friday nonsense.

Order the shirt on ebay, tell everyone you went, then take your ten dollars and 2 hours to (fill in the blank), get yourself a better donut, and then use the other hour and 45 minutes to do something that won't leave you with the feelings: "why is this such a big deal" and "I wish the roof of my mouth wasn't first cut by cereal, and then burned with tang".  Not my fave to say the least... I will say this though, better than Blue Star.

Tourist Trap!

The donuts are terrible and I'm sure no local would ever be caught inside. It could be a fun place to stop by to check out all the bizarre donut options, but you'd be wise to save your $2 for Pip's. You've been warned.
It's a must for all outsiders and first timers. The maple bacon bar is fantastic and the other donuts are average at best. A fun atmosphere and quite a experience waiting in line for the donuts.

The name of Voodoo Donuts was the best thing about this donut place. There were not enough black magic to justify the amount of time standing in line or the prices of a blueberry cake donut and mango filled donut. The blueberry cake ($1) tasted no better than the $0.50 one I buy at my local Mom and Pop back home. My wife said the mango filling of her mango donut ($2.25) tasted good, but there were too much of it and the mango icing.  She needed more donut dough to balance out all that sugar sweetness. She actually had to threw some of the filling and icing away. It will be fun to claim that we tried Voodoo when we get home, but we will not recommend it.

I was just there and I'd have to agree with some reviewers here. It's overrated. 
I mean it's essentially just doughnuts with bunch of toppings on it. I'm sure you can find similar doughnut shops around your town. I'm still baffled as to why this place is so popular. 
Don't get me wrong, the doughnuts were tasty but not amazing. I did enjoy my bacon maple bar, but I'd have to say the other cream filled doughnuts I had were too sweet. Felt like I'm getting a toothache just from one bite. 
Overall, it's just a hype but if you happen to be in Portland and happen to be craving some doughnuts then this would be the place to go.

Voodoo doughnuts (even though its an institution) is highly overrated.  Sure its unique, wacky, and it has a ton of variety, but as for the actual taste?  Meh...

I would say that you should visit this place if you've never been, just as a tourist would visit the biggest yarn in the world type of attraction... just not impressive.

Well, this place is overrated, but they have really fun creations that are fun to look at but not always as tasty as they could be.  What lives up to the hype is the bacon maple bar.  Salty and sweet has never been better.

Great designs but I've had better tasting donuts. Still a place to see for the Portland vibes and expect a line. I went before 10 and there was still a line but not too bad compared to in the afternoon
Cute doughnuts but kinda too sweet for me. You will have to wait in line for about half hour.

So we have been to the voodoo donut in universal studios as well as this location and I can say I prefer the one in hollywood. The place was cool and the donuts were alright but the staff is what made me dislike this place. The man in the front with like a half mullet or something was not very friendly and acted annoyed as we were placing our order. He had to keep saying what after every donut because the music was so loud. The donuts themselves are okay. They had a oily taste to them and plain aside from the super sugary toppings. The toppings were cool though.

My quest for the most epic donut in the world has finally brought me here after hearing about this place from a lot of people. 

I didn't expect there to be a line, take this into account when you pay for parking. Luckily the line moved quickly because I didn't put that long on my meter. 

I'm also glad I'd checked out their menu online and already knew what I wanted, but they all have funky names, but most of them don't actually tell you what the donut combinations are and if there's a line up behind you it's hard to ask what everything is, etc. 

They were out of crullers which was a disappointment, but the ones I did buy were fresh and huge and very tasty!  

Also this place is CASH ONLY! There's an ATM inside though. 

So final decision: The line, cash only and ordering being complicated if you don't already know what you want knock it down a star. The donuts themselves are 4 star, but are still not the best I've had in the (literal) world. So far I'd say they're in solid second place though!

For the full Portland experience, we were told to try Voodoo Doughnuts. We walked down and waited a half hour in line (which I hear is pretty good compared to the afternoon wait). The place is in kind of a crappy part of town. Run down buildings with strip clubs every 5 feet, not to mention anime night right next door to the doughnut shop. But it's part of the experience I suppose. 

They've got some silly named doughnuts. The chocolate ones are good. For the most part they are pretty standard doughnuts with some different things on top if you order those.

I'm glad I went. Did it, got it done with. I recommend it for tourists to go and try once.

**THEY ARE CASH ONLY**

Meh...I think this place is pretty overhyped. It is fun to take our out-of-town friends to so that they get the experience, but the donuts themselves really aren't all that great. Just because you crumble cereal or tang on top of a donut, does not mean that it is worth waiting hours in line for.

This being said, their Maple Bacon bar is pretty delicious if you happen to stop in.
Honestly, I can get a donut at Safeway that tastes a lot better but the experience is interesting.
Overrated and oversugared donuts. Try Blue Star Donuts instead!

The doughnuts here are very large and there is a wide variety to choose from. We ordered a bunch of different doughnuts to try. My favorite is still just a simple glazed doughnut. As for the actual fried dough itself, it wasn't as soft or fluffy as I would've liked. 

All the locals say they like blue star more but I actually still thought these were better.

Stale cereal topping mediocre donuts with street urchins all around you begging for change to support their drug habits.

What's not to love?

Go to Blue Star. Wayyy better.

Not only is this a must see but it's also a must try. I made a check list of things I had t come see for myself and this was definitely one of them. Luckily enough to people don't want to stop and by donuts when it's cold outside! So I had to wait in line for like 2 minutes. 

At first it's kind of scary stopping by since the neighborhood is very uncared for. 

But once your inside all walked of life blend together to try one of the signature donuts. 

I looked up at the board and was confused with their selection , but when it was my turn to order I asked for their signature voodoo doll and two donuts that had peanut butter. The gentleman recommended a few , and seemed annoyed about it . That kind of bummed me out because it's a popular place and I was expecting the full service . I guess he gets asked the same questions often. 

As soon as I got my donuts I had to try them. They are good. Not the best but the catch is their designs . Just looking at them makes you happy . I only ordered four and are 1 and a half . Super sweet but good. I probably won't come back but if your a first time portland tourist , make sure to check it out .
Used to enjoy this place a lot when I was younger but now I think the hype is too off-putting. I still enjoy their goodies, but the long lines and the tourists always send me away!

The place is very touristy and can take an extremely long time to get doughnuts. The doughnuts were "good enough" years ago when they were just a hole in a wall next to a popular concert venue and they suited the concert going community well. Now it's just the same crummy doughnuts without the original dirty experience that I loved it for.

It really depends on when you go and what you get. Voodoo donuts offer a variety of flavors that aren't typical, so come prepared with an idea of what you like and don't like. Also, BRING CASH because it's CASH ONLY!! Ordering becomes easy when you filter out the flavors and textures of donuts you're looking for. I can't do filing and fruity flavors, so I got the Triple Chocolate Penetration (chocolate donut, chocolate glaze, coco puffs on top). The donuts wasn't anything spectacular, but I still liked what I was eating. There were no surprises and nothing to dislike. My friend got the Homer (strawberry yogurt glaze on a regular donut with sprinkles on top), which again wasn't anything spectacular. The shop being 24/7 is very convenient, and my friend and I went at 9:45 PM which meant little line. So my suggestion would be is to come prepared, bring cash, and go odd hours. Overall, no wow factor about these donuts - it was just okay, but it's something to try when you're in Portland.

From my rating, you can figure I'm more in the "eh" camp on this one.  The line early evening on a Monday was only 15-20mins.  I ordered the maple bar with bacon, dirty old bastard, and the triple choco penetration.  I was most impressed with the  DOB.  But *gasp* I do like Planet Doughnut's tres leches doughnut better than all of these.  If you happen to walk by and there's only a small line, why not?  But with so much cheap, good food in PDX, I would not waste all your calories here.
The store is cute but the donut is nothing fancy and too sweet. Not sure why there are so many people
The donuts always seem to be stale here.  This place is more hype than it's worth.  If you have a favorite then please keep on eating here but there are much better donut shops in Portland
owned and operated by rapists, victims, and rape apologists.

I gave Voodoo Donut's a 3 star because the line was super long. The wait wasn't that bad, only because i had company. We bought the random dozen, which i think you should not do because we didn't get what we wanted. & in the random dozen there were a lot of cereal donuts, which the cereal was stale (was it supposed to be like that). 

It is a really cool place to visit, but it is really overrated.

& they only except cash.

The staff was nice. They guys helping us said that we were his longest customer, i think he was getting irritated with us, we did buy 4 shirts & 2 dozen donuts & a post card. Hey, we are supporting you.. But, if i'm ever in Portland again I don't think i will be coming back.

SORRY!!

I was only able to take one bite of the hibiscus donut because it was disgustingly sweet. That was about an hour ago - whenever I think of the donut the saliva in my mouth immediately retreats to the back of my throat to prep it for vomit.

It is overwhelming the amount of options you have here. We came here one morning for breakfast and the wait actually wasn't too bad. Probably waited about 10-15 minutes tops.

Ordered a Bacon Maple Bar, Aint that a Peach Fritter, Triple Chocolate Penetration, and a Portland Cream between me and my husband. Personally, they were all pretty sweet to me, and that's saying a lot because I love my sugar, but my favorite and probably the one I would most likely be able to finish is the Bacon Maple Bar. That bar had just the right amount of maple glazing + the saltiness of the bacon and if you pair it with some coffee, there you have a winning combo. 

Now that I've been here once, I don't feel the need to come back again. We have a similar doughnut place in my town, so I guess I don't see the uniqueness of it. But then again, I'd choose waffles over donuts any day, so to each their own.

Inexpensive novelty donuts. Found that most of the donuts were too sweet. Smaller sized donuts had more of a cake-like texture and density. It's a great place to try if you're in the area as it was featured on shows and recommended by lots of peeps. Lines move fast.

Voodoo doughnuts and blue star are the two big doughnut shops in Portland. I was surprised by the goth-esque ambience of the store upon walking in, and they have a lot of unique donuts on a rotating cabinet that you can pick from. The donuts were alright, but I get the sense that they were kind of "over it". I feel like it is something that you should do once, but definitely not if you live in the area or this is a second time. The quality of the donuts seemed a little subpar - it was a little dry, and for a shop that was open 24/7, it seemed as though the frosting had gotten a little hard. The flavors were interesting though!

Can't believe there's a wait for donuts. We did it  and I still don't know why. Contrary to other Yelper's I am going to say " If you're in PDX you do not have to visit Voodoo Donut" 
   I had the bacon maple donut, bacon is two large slices and super crisp. I really liked it, but felt there was way too much maple glaze on top. The mafia something was a fritter with banana, peanut butter, chocolate. It was tasty but huge and I think with all of the fillings the chocolate chips were unnecessary and kind of chalky IMO.
Well, I have been a couple of times now. IF there is no line, check them out. IF there IS a line, I wouldn't bother.

Visited Portland for 4 days and stopped by a few times to grab some of the delicious doughnuts.  While they are delicious that is not what earned them  my three star review..the customer service is crap.  The cashiers were extremely rude, rarely making eye contact with me while I was making and paying for my order, and yelling at customers for blocking the doorway.  While I understand it is a fire hazard and you're not allowed to block the doorway there are no signs or any sort of communication from the employees to the customers unless they are screaming at them for holding open open the door or blocking the door (they have a crap setup).  Also, the names and flavors are fairly overwhelming if you're visiting this place for the first time (be sure to check out the menu online so you know what to order and what is in each)...otherwise you're stuck staring at a rotating display of the doughnuts they offer having no clue what is in them...and the displays are at the register so inevitably it holds up the entire ordering process.

Voodoo is all hype. I finally went to Voodoo again after living here 9 months. Had the Bacon Maple Bar. It was mediocre at best. Oh ya, I almost forgot...I stopped by my neighbor's late one night after hitting some bars and he had this bucket full of Voodoo Doughnuts that some Voodoo employee had sold him for like eight bucks or something? So I had one then too.

7850+ reviews, what can I possibly add?  How about a ranking of notables:

1. Coco's Donuts: buttermilk and price
2. Nola's Donuts: very creative
3. Delicious Donuts
4. Blue Star: they have the ingredients, but creations just don't speak to me; and they're too big
5. Pip's: it's about the excellent chai and when I'm craving a healthier donut
6. Voodoo: out of towner "wow" factor
7. Annie's 
8. Heavenly

37. Starbucks

Good donuts. Tastes like other good donuts I've had. Cool atmosphere inside. Outside there are plenty of questionable people hanging out begging, shouting, or just waking up from sleeping on the street.

You're probably not reading this review unless you are someone visiting Portland, looking for all the best spots to try, and Voodoo doughnuts is no doubt on your list. It's so much hype! I don't know what it's all about. If you're coming here for a great doughnut- go anywhere else. If you're wanting to come for the experience or the novelty, that's different...and you might appreciate it for those reasons. As far as doughnut quality though, save your money and time and go to the grocery store for a doughnut. Portland has some great doughnut places, and this is not one that I would consider to be one of them... go to Blue Star or Pip's!

This is written from a Southern Californian's point of view

I waited about 1 hour 45 minutes for the donuts on a hot summer's day. The way wasn't that bad throughout because there were lots of things around me to look at. The shop is located in this awesome alleyway with restaurants and many people are there.

But let's get on to the donuts. I had bought a dozen of assorted VooDoo where you get to choose whatever donuts you want. I didn't really do comprehensive research before coming, but I knew the couple of donuts that I HAD to get that VooDoo was staple for. The cost at the end surprised me because it was about $28 for a dozen.. and i was dying. I didn't know how expensive it would be.

The taste: all these donuts to me weren't so special because you can find about 90% of the donuts at your typical hole-in-the wall donut shops down here in Southern California. I had a bite of all the 12 and I was not impressed by any of them.

VooDoo is good because there aren't a lot of donut shops up there in comparison to SoCal, but it's a totally fine donut shop to eat at. It just wasn't anything special to me.

Not worth the wait because I wouldn't have to wait down in socal for anything. BUT it's a fine donut shop :)

I'm not a big fan of donuts, so this review is probably a little bias. I was in Portland for some bussiness trip and visited this place to see what the hype was all about. I went on Monday night around 9pm and there's only 2-3 people in front of me. I got Mango Tango and Triple Chocolate Penetration. Both are good, nothing too spectacular though. The awful metal/punk/rock music they were playing hurts my ears and gives me headache... The place is a little ghetto and lots of homeless standing in front of the shop. Pretty scary...

The grape ape doughnut was pretty good- definitely a unique flavor. The voo doo doll was a bit stale- so I didn't finish. My husband didn't finish his maple bacon bar either.  Seems like the unique choices and hype are more important than the actual food.

The donuts here are actually pretty bad. You don't go to Voodoo for the donuts. You go for the "Portland experience" of standing in a long line, looking at silly-named items, and walking around with a pink box.

I saw a food show. I saw the donuts on the food show and I thought that was going to be great. It was good. But not great. Basically a bigger sized donut with lots of sugar. i do enjoy the voodoo theme. That's a fun element.

I feel like this place is more kitsch than anything.  Very overwhelming going in because everything is spinning around a carousel that you can't match up what the flavor is with what the doughnut looks like.  

In our confusion, we ended up just doing the "fryer flyer" -- one of each of the 12 best sellers. 

The doughnuts themselves are good if they are the more "basic" varieties, the wild ones seemed to be more for children or hype rather than anything else.  Definitely a must eat day of otherwise half the toppings are all soggy and sad (they use a lot of cereal).

Glad I went to see what the hype was about, but will probably save my delicious dessert-ing for another place.

Oh and cash only is a bit of a bummer :(
Crappy doughnuts, even worse service, super long lines. If you want a good doughnut go to Tonalli's on Alberta where there is very little waiting and they have ice cream too :)

go for the ambiance ( or lack there of,) not the donuts. I'm a fan of fresh, warm donuts, and they had nothing like that. The old fashioned chocolate was standard, but would have been so much better fresh. Sigh, I've been spoiled by King Pin in berkeley, I suppose.

To me, Voodoo Doughnut is one of those places where you go just to be able to say you have been. The store is very quirky and you can even get married there. There are tons of different doughnuts with all sorts of unusual toppings and sexualized names, haha. I'm not a big doughnut fan, but I thought they were pretty good. Not something I want to eat all the time, but it was fine to try. They even had a nice selection of vegan doughnuts. 

Basically, this place is very unique so I would say go for the novelty.....but once was enough for me.

Okay so the wait was like 15-20 minutes.  The donuts sounded amazing and very creative. Ordered a bunch of different ones and I was not impressed. I was disappointed with some of the basic donuts.   The donuts were pricey as well. $15+ for 4 donuts.

We expected a place that we could sit down and enjoy our donuts and/or coffee but there was no seating available. Small cool little place that is very original. We had no idea what we wanted since we had never been. We went around 9 and had to wait outside for a couple minutes, but it was also raining so that may have decreases wait time.

For donuts we had: the home Simpson (strawberry frosting), the double bubble (bubble gum frosting), a grape frosted donut and tons of sugar, apple fritter, and a blueberry cake donut. 

Customer service was lacking majorly. Not very welcoming at all. The person that took or our order seemed very annoyed that we didn't know what we wanted (since we've never been there). 

A good tip, their menu is posted online so you can get an idea before you get there
Fun variety and good when fresh. Over priced and touristy, these places are always packed. Always.
Good donuts, but kinda gimmicky. Take tourists here.

If you're in the mood for a dry, cakey, flavorless fried pastry adorned with colorful, quasi-creative toppings, then definitely don't miss Voodoo. The focus is entirely on the wacky accoutrements and not the donut itself.

Try putting a hot Krispy Kreme donut next to one of theirs. No contest. If you want Coco Puffs and bacon on it, go nuts.

Besides the food porn factor -- the doughnuts here are ok. I'd highly recommend the maple bacon bar and the loop, deeelicious, especially with a cup of coffee. 

I'd recommend it more but I think it's mostly overrated, due to features on the travel and food channels.

First let me start with why I only gave 3 stars: Bc this place is CASH ONLY 

Went here on a Friday around 6:30 and this place was PACKED! Line out the door and around the corner. We had no idea it was cash only until we got inside after waiting in line outside. Thankfully we had $6 on us, but hey it's 2016. Ever heard of Square? PayPal? Etc. 

The Doughnuts were good. Not the best I've ever eaten, but they looked cool and my 3 year old inhaled hers!! So, I'm not sure if it was the taste or the visual aspect that did that. Haha 

There's an abundance of seating next to the building in a well lit, clean alley. The alley also serves as entrances to other shops and bars. Beware: atleast one bar there is a strip club and another one is a demonic night club with loud rock/scream music. 

The doughnut Prices were reasonable, nothing too ridiculous. The most popular doughnut they sell, which looks like a voodoo doll is only $2.75 - which I was convinced was going to be closer to $7, but like I said it's only $2.75 

There's no free public parking. Only street pay to park parking & pay to park parking lots. Normal for any city.

There are homeless people who frequently ask for money and food out side of the shops. 

Kid friendly 
 
No indoor tables for eating inside 
Very little room inside

Cool place that is a must to see when it Portland. The donut combinations are crazy and fun.  Each donut is a hunk of deliciousness.  You see there pink boxes all over town.  

While the donuts are fun the staff not so much.  You definitely know that you are bothersome when making your decisions.  They are in a hurry to get you in and out so they can get back to their own crap--- even when you are the only customer.  The music is incredibly loud it hurts your ears.

Not much room to stand around but you wouldn't want to anyway.  Nice seating outside when not too cold.  The place is iconic but not so special.
Go just for the experience but no big deal.Overpriced diabetes pills hawked by hipsters.
Not a fan thay are creative but. The topping are stale. Fruit loops and cookies were stale. I was disapointed

Always love something a little different. Voodoo is just that very thing.

Unique donuts, flavors and names, Voodoo has it all. You want something funky, this is what you want.

Donuts are a bit sweet depending on what you get, but the donuts always taste fresh. 

I always visit when i'm in Portlandia.

The donuts here are really good.  I don't think it's just a tourist trap.  They are legitimately tasty.  The service though is not so great.  The last time we went, the guy at the counter was speaking loudly about how hungover he was, dropped one of our donuts on the counter, picked it up, wiped it off and tried to sell it to us.  Umm gross.  They have delicious crullers though and their maple bars are pretty darn good too.

I waited for 40 minutes in the intense summer heat for Voodoo Doughnut last weekend and was it worth it? Well, probably not. Me and my two companions ordered a 'voodoo dozen' without bacon of course (sorry folks, desert and meat should be kept on separate plates).
