I sampled a bite of seven of the dozen provided and have the following thoughts: the glazing/frosting was thin and had underwhelming flavor, many of the gimmicks they used ended up limp or soggy (limp/not crunchy breakfast cereal is a turnoff), and their raised Doughnut were oddly unsatisfying (can't put my finger on it yet, will add to this review when I do). The cake donuts were good however and would go back for them if the lines were cleared out. 

All in all I felt Voodoo was more hype than substance and all in all I wished that I hadn't waited in line.

To me, a (fresh) donut is a donut is a donut. I was a little surprised by the incredible fanfare surrounding this Portland institution. While the donuts do come in interesting shapes and sizes, the confections didn't seem a whole lot more elaborate or tastier than those of the other bakeries nearby. It's probably worth a picture and the prices aren't bad (about $3/ donut).
Not what i though it was.. a big line and they are just OK.  I like the buckets if you come early but that's it!

The ambiance made it feel like it was all hyped up for people. Very touristy. A lot of people, which I understand there are better times to come when it's not so busy but that meant we had to wait in a line for our food. I felt like the doughnuts had too much sugar. I could barely finish one. It tasted like dumping a huge spoon of sugar in my mouth. I prefer Star Donuts. I give them props to great marketing skill though. The way they have their menu. The ambiance of their shop. They make you want to have their doughnuts but I feel it's just too much. The first time we came on a  Saturday afternoon after strolling through the Portland market there was a long line. I felt confused since it was in the afternoon. Why would there be a long line for doughnuts? We came back the second time on a weekday  & the line was much shorter but the doughnuts still had too much sugar. I thought it was just that batch on Saturday that had too much. The wait was around 15 minutes which I felt was a little long to wait for doughnuts. The staff was very fast. I give them credit for working as quick as they did. I guess it's because they have too many customers to try to answer our touristy questions. We were just curious why their shops vibes was for tourists and wanted to ask if their owner liked to travel.

Delicious! But... honestly can't say it's too different from a grocery store donut :( Maybe more frosting and a bit more dense. 

However, I will say the decor is cool, they have a lot of interesting flavors and twists, and it's in a fun location. But I don't know if I'd go out of my way to try it.

I have never experienced a Voodoo donut that wasn't stale, no matter how "fresh" it was.  Something about their dough causes it to come out of the fryer tasting stale.

Their gimmicky donuts (cereal, etc.) do not add anything to their charm.

These seem more designed for comic effect on Portlandia, than actually food people would want to eat.  Just because you can have an ipecac syrup doughnut doesn't mean anyone should actually have to eat it.

After all the hype, I was not impressed. For a 20 minute line, I expected the donuts to be great, but in reality, they were stale and overly sweet. There are a lot of fun flavors, but they would be better if they didn't taste like they had been sitting out since the previous day. I would recommend Blue Star Donuts over Voodoo any day.

Average doughnuts prepared in a small funky spot.  Parking is difficult and the lines are huge.  We asked when was the best time to get a doughnut here without waiting and the staff at our hotel told us to go to Blue Star, then they said 8:00 pm.

We took both pieces of advice and had high quality doughnuts.

Here we got to see what all the fuss was about.

Want to buy the talked about doughnut? Come here.

I was somewhat disappointed to be honest.
Was expecting more but then again, there is only so you can do with a doughnut.
They do have a very large selection but the doughnuts themselves are about average.

This place is awfull! It is next to a Anime Porn theater. As we waited for our dayold stail doughnuts, it reaks of trash and sewer. We were standing next to trash cans while watching a pan handler ask for spare change as people exited the awful doughnut shop! The doughnuts were old and staile, they needed to change the grease out that they fry them in. I would rather eat weekold powdered doughnuts from a grocery store than subject my palet to these ever again! If I could rate it lower than 1 star TRUST ME, I would!!! Stay away from here eat a Krispy Kreme instead!
DO not go here! It's OVERRATED. Do NOT WAIT IN LINE. You are not a sheep. Trust me. This place stinks. I've been sucker once to many times to waste my time with this sad excuse of a donut place.

One of those places you just HAVE to go to...but only because it's so famous on Yelp.  

Maybe because I'm not in love with doughnuts, but Voodoo Doughnuts weren't really that different than any other joint.  Yes, there were some creative ones that you can't get at your local AM/PM, but let's face it, I'm not eating a Miami Vice doughnut everyday.  Overall, the taste and consistency was similar to any good doughnut shop.

Glad I checked it off my list.

We are not really sure why this is as popular as it is other than the niche decor and unique toppings and themes. For my wife and i we think the doughnuts are a bit on the greasy side and leave a film on our tongues. Therefor, we aren't dying for it.

In one word, overrated. 

We had heard of this place and all of the praise that surrounds it and were highly disappointed by just how lackluster these donuts were. 

I stood in line for 40 minutes, ordered several pastries and other than the fritter, they were all very, very dry. I emptied my water bottle trying to eat one doughnut! No thanks!

A fun novelty for sure... It might be worth going to once just to say you did, but other than that, I would steer clear:/ Much better donuts can be found just about anywhere:(

I do not get why this place is so popular. Fortunately, I did not have to stay in line too long to try it. I got the Portland original and Mango Tango. Neither were special, they were so sweat that I almost choked.

Voo doo Doughnuts were ok. They weren't bad but nothing special. I do give credit where credit is due. The actual voo doo doughnut was amazing. It was a doughnut in the shape of a voo doo doll . The outside was covered in chocolate and the inside was filled with raspberry filling. My husband and I came here on a visit to Portland. He found out about VDD by looking up places on yelp. Like most places popular in a city, there was a long line that we had to stand in. Once we finally got to the front to order we decided to get the following four doughnut flavors : Voo Doo Doll, Oreo (Dirty Doughnut), Captain Crunch (Captain my captain ; something like that), and M&M . The Oreo wasn't bad and was my 2nd fav after the voo doo doll. My least favorite was the M&M doughnut. It just didn't seem right to have M&Ms on a doughnut. I personably didn't like it. It was just a little to much for me. Overall it was good to be able to come for the experience.

I heard about this place so I went this weekend when I was in portland. The line wasnt too bad. I heard it could get line, but a 30 minute wait for donuts set my expectations high. As folks came out I would see these really cool donuts decorated really cool. Finally it was my turn. My mind was on overdrive! I was like a kid in a candy store. I ended up getting the sampler box thingy for $21. We left with box in hand and I couldnt to rip it open. I opened the box and let my kid get first pick. I picked one of my favorite donuts and bit into it. I was highly disappointed. Yes it was good, but was it worth standing in line in the freezing for 30 minutes? NOPE? we ended up eating a few of them and threw the rest out. My wife got real sick after eating one. Had to pull over so she could hurl out the door. Was it the donuts? Not sure. Standing in line for 30 minutes getting hounded by the meth head freaks ruined it for me. It wouldnt be so bad if there was no line and the price was cheaper. I really dont see what the hype was about.
I am from Indiana. Growing up, my hometown had a little place called DUNKIN DONUTS in the shady part of town.  These donuts are better than that place.

ehh I went here for my first time and it was okay... I don't get the hype about this place it really isn't that good. Personally I think my local supermarket bakery has better pastries and wouldn't drive downtown just for these again it isn't worth it. I guess Portland needs something exciting to talk about though LOL.

Long story short...

Long line and bad donuts.

I've had $1 donuts that are way better and no line.

Tourists come here and they were kind of rude cutting people in line. 

OVERRATED!!!

A fun place to visit in Portland. Creative decor and donuts. The donuts are not as good in the mouth as they are to look at. Two of three donuts I purchased for myself ended up in the trash after one bite. This was a destination for me on this vacation and I was totally disappointed.

I like the doghnuts as an art form, but i don't like eating them. And isn't that why you buy a doghnut. Most of the time I get them I'll look at it with joy and think "What an awesome doughnut!" Then I take a bite and think "Blagh". I usually end up tossing half of it which is hard because they look so cool.

When we moved here, we did the Voodoo thing.  I get sick if I eat a whole doughnut.  It's just too much of everything. The novelty wears off eventually and you get tired of waiting in line for a mediocre doughnut. Having to deal with "that part of the city" doesn't help either.

Don't bring your kids with you.  Outside they'll be faced with vagrants trying to touch them because they are "so cute" and then asking you for change, and inside you'll be faced with doughnuts whose names should not be spoken in the presence of children.

We found a new doughnut place on Washington and 13th that we like much better.  They sell out fast, but they are delicious and won't give you a belly ache.

Voodoo is a purveyor of totally fucking OK doughnuts, but I just can't go past three stars.  I've heard the maple bar with bacon is awesome, but I have not yet gotten one of those.  Last time I was there, I got a hugefuckin' peach fritter.  If size is everything, then you've hit the jackpot with this one, but the frosting was way too much; it's deep fat fried already with a heavy sugar coating, and an inch of frosting is overkill.  Oh, and I think they're fried in shortening, because I get the unpleasant greasy film on the roof of my mouth which I inevitably have to wipe out with a paper napkin, only to have the napkin fibers cling to the roof of my goddamn mouth.  Totally too much info... 

The raspberry filled with confectioners sugar is delightful, particularly because the raspberry filling doesn't taste like some can of raspberry shit that's been processed, sent through an expeller, and run through a radiation bath; It actually tastes like good raspberry filling inside an OK doughnut!  

There are some sexy patrons that visit Voodoo, so maybe you can land yourself a date on a visit.
The donuts are ok but expensive and the line is always way to long. If your a tourist I am sure this place is super exciting for your every day Oregonian not so much.

Got there at 8:30am on the long weekend. Waited about 1/2 hr in line before service. When we left, the line was twice as long. Not too bad of a wait except the fact that the donuts were not worth it. Service was awful. Vibe is that they know they're in such demand that they don't need to care about the customer experience, the bathroom was absolutely filthy. Way overrated.

The doughnut flavor is so-so. Blah. Whenever these are brought to the office, I take one then wonder why anyone craves them. Meh! A mystery to me. The lines on weekends are crazy long. Don't get why people are willing to camp out for them. It is a puzzle. However, this place DOES has its cult following (so did the Grateful Dead) and the place does have a distinctive scent of body odor wafting amid the fumes of frying oil. Yummy. Visually, the shapes of penises and voodoo dolls, tasty toppings like bacon or Froot Loops or M&Ms have made its reputation. Magical symbols and crassness sells, hippy dippy silliness works. Attracts street kids galore. You know, the f*** grownups crowd. Voodoo's image is the embodiment of rebellion in fried dough. Part of the Keep Portland Weird movement.
Really not that great.  Sort of funny but honestly there are better donuts.  Try Pips!

It's doughnuts.  I guess there was no way it could live up to the hype.  Seems like they have sacrificed quality for quantity. (These are BIG doughnuts)

Had the apple fritter. Not much apple to it.  Same for the peach one.
Also had the Portland cream and McMinnville cream.  Not much difference - chocolate vs. maple frosting.  Not enough cream.

All in all, an OK doughnut shop, but expensive, crowded, difficult parking and with an attitude.

Ya know its a cool theme that you guys rock. Even the Doughnuts are pretty decent and very well decorated. The slight downfall is...........you guys only make 1 kind of doughnut and dress it 500 different ways. It would be awesome for you to continue to think outside the box and find some new recipes.....

It had been a while since I paid a visit to this infamous Portland landmark, and I was SO excited because I remembered it being the bee's knees back in the day. I was disappointed after bringing out our pink box and taking a bite out of each of the doughnuts, hoping at least one would make me squeal in delight. Fortunately the wait was not long at all during a late Wednesday afternoon. Doughnuts selected were:

Maple Bacon: just like any maple doughnut you'd find elsewhere with 2 strips of bacon on top. Less bacon-y than I thought it would be

Dirty Old Bastard: my favorite out of the bunch. Decadent, chocolate and peanut butter all up in my mouth

Portland Creme: custard doughnut. A little too much filling that quickly became overwhelming

Voodoo doughnut (Christmas edition): cute little voodoo doll shaped doughnut with red and green icing plus a mint on the forehead for Christmas. I liked it better than I thought I would have, considering I'm not usually a jelly doughnut fan. Jelly tasted a more fresh than standard jelly doughnuts.

This place is definitely more about the idea/concept rather than the actual doughnut itself for me. They don't have a unique quality to the base and depend on the overload of toppings to mask it. I guess I remembered it being good because I hadn't experienced a doughnut that truly wowed me back then. Unfortunately, I just see it as a tourist trap now.

The donuts were just okay. 

3/5 Portland Cream ($2.25) - There was nothing special about this donut. 

3/5 Maple Blazer Blunt ($1.25) - This donut looked cool, but was only different from a regular maple bar in that there were sprinkles. 

1/5 Vegan Dirt ($2.45) - The oreos were completely stale. 

3.5/5 The Homer ($1.75) - This was my favorite donut. The strawberry icing was a little too sweet though. 

Overall, we didn't think these donuts deserved to be raved about. Voodoo Donuts is on almost every "Things to do in Portland" list out there, but when we tried them they were really underwhelming. Would not recommend.

So sorry but for me, this is a Voo-Don't. I think I spoiled myself by having Blue Star Donuts first. But I get it Voodoo. Your fun & quirky toppings & fillings is what makes Portland weird. And I do love that you're open late night as a drunk food option. For 1st timers its a great Instagram spot.

A bit overrated in my opinion. overcrowded. good for tourists but if you are a local this isn't really the place to go. This is the place you go to once and then find out about all the places around town that are better. The fun thing about Voodoo is the comical aspect to their donuts. They are known all over the US for their famous voodoo doll donut and maple bar topped with bacon. This iconic donut has since inspired other shops to expand their selection to mimic these popular fried balls of dough. Ambiance is very cheery and pink. You can buy gear here to go along with their donuts if you really like this place and want to advertise it on your clothes. Go here and check it out, then mark it off the list.

How did they turn this very average product into 1-2 hour lines?
Ok but mostly hype.

Whether you witnessed the construction of the famed voodoo doll on Man vs. Food or crave the unusual, Voodoo doughnut is not to be missed. If you find yourself at this location make sure you're gellin with your Dr. Schools because you'll be standing in a long ass line with the other sugar junkies. While chocolate penetration and peanut butter fritters sounded tempting I was here to seek out my holy grail of pastry prizes the maple bacon bar.

It's the only thing I can review because it's the only thing I have and ever will eat. All hail your smoky pig flesh, atop rich gooey frosting and chewy roll. It begs the question, is the magic really in the hole or does this doughnut raise the bar?

Every time I see someone carrying a Voodoo box I say, "Welcome to Portland! Enjoy your stay."

As far as doughnuts go, these diabetes bombs are not great. They're not even good. But I appreciate the gimmick and tourists seem to love them. If you don't want to wait in line and/or actually enjoy doughnuts, there are better options nearby.

There donuts are pretty good, but the lines are crazy and in the end it's just donuts. I've gone a couple times in the last 10 or so years. I don't think it's worth all the hype, but I guess you have to try it atleast once.

Do they have unique donuts? Definitely (and lots of them have names that'll make your immature self giggle)
Are they better tasting than regular donuts?  Not necessarily
Is it worth standing in line for over 45 minutes on an 85 degree Saturday?  We did... but I guess that depends on how much you love donuts. 

Conclusion: A fun place to check out if you've never been here - definitely a Portland staple with the "Keep Portland weird" sign right across the street. But not a place I'd frequent if I lived in the area - just because the lines are ridiculous and the donuts are a little overhyped. 

Note: Bring cash - they do have an ATM inside but you'll be charged a fee that could've gone toward buying another donut

Sadly, I was disappointed.

It all started with the long line. It was like waiting to get into a nightclub. Once we got up to the front, we saw the sign that said "Cash Only," but also saw one that stated that they had an ATM inside. Okay, cool. As we walked in (after waiting in line for 20+ minutes), we were informed by another customer that the ATM was broken. Apparently, they felt no need to inform us with a sign in the window. So my fiance headed across the alley to find another ATM as I walked up to the counter. I asked the cashier if I could place my order while my fiance grabbed the cash, and she literally stood there and stared me dead in the eye, silent and obviously not happy, for a good five seconds. Then she said, "Okay, fine," and was bitchy the whole time. My fiance was back in less time than it took for me to place our order, and even he noticed her crappy attitude. I wanted so badly to throw attitude back at her, which I would have done under any other circumstance, but I felt it would be a shame to waste all the time we spent in line. The donuts themselves are nothing special, though the chocolate frosting was pretty good. Also, they don't have bottled or even refrigerated water...you pay ten cents for a cup, and get your water from a giant plastic bucket that has been sitting there for who knows how long. And I am REALLY holding my tongue when it comes to how I feel about the chick at the counter. Go to the Voodoo in Eugene instead. There is no crazy tourist line and the attitude is MUCH better there.

If it was possible for a doughnut shop to be a brick-and-mortar embodiment of "The Emperor's New Clothes," this would be it. This place sells doughnuts that are mediocre-at-best, but people in Portland seem to believe they are AMAZING AND OMG HAVE YOU HAD VOODOO DOUGHNUTS BEFORE THEY ARE SO GREAT!!!

We got in a line with 50 other people and waited 45 minutes to purchase the  doughnuts. The doughnuts are wacky and creative, to be sure. There are some that have stale breakfast cereal on them, some that have M&Ms on top, one that actually had a piece of bubble game baked into the frosting (complete with inedible plastic wrapping and everything). These Voodoo people sure are wild and crazy! The problem is that the doughnuts these toppings are positioned on top of are dry, overly doughy, and bland. At least the doughnuts themselves are pretty cheap. 

Worth it only if there are no other options and there is no line.

I've hit them up thrice now, 1st time before moving to Portland, because well.. VOODOO!  The other two times after moving here a few months ago.  I think they are a good doughnut joint.  The treats are tasty and creative.  They aren't my favorite doughnuts in town, which is why I give them three stars.  Good, creative, but a bit too sweet and overpriced compared to what I can get elsewhere.  You're definitely paying for the experience with this one.
The wait is long, the doughnuts are mediocre and it's in an awful part of town. 2.4. Overrated. There are better options for doughnuts in Portland.

Just regular plain old doughnuts. Really nothing special about them and out of the 6 doughnuts I tried only one of them was really good. Kind of disappointinng... Even 7/11's doughnuts are better by a huge margin.

More hype than what it's worth because those line are ginormous to just get in. And then it's pretty much take it with you when you're in there as it's just always crowded.  The oddities of the donuts are what make it ''hip", and some flavors are pretty wild (and very very good). Other's are just so-so. Other than that, it's just another donut place but a good place to show visitors to Portland just how weird it can be here.

Being my first visit to Portland as an adult, I knew I had to take a visit to Voodoo Doughnut. Before going I read some reviews mentioning line ups, but I was not expecting as long of a line as there was! We waited in line for roughly an hour on a Sunday afternoon, in the rain. Once we reached the front of the line we were able to see the available choices. We chose 4 donuts- the voodoo doll of course, Portland cream, bacon maple bar and the loop. The donuts were good, but they weren't to die for. There is quite a bit of a hype for this place, but I think it is the large variety and odd flavours available that keep people coming back. Coming to Voodoo Doughnut is something that you must do when visiting Portland, but just once.

Interesting experience. Came here during Halloween and was totally unexpected to hear interesting chanting being played in their small lobby area while I was waiting to order my doughnuts. If they wanted to make it eery, they sure did the trick! Their doughnuts were very interesting, creative and artistic. I definitely dig the maple bacon bar but as a convert to try and eat healthier, the doughnuts were too sweet for me so don't listen to me too much on this, just go try it out for yourself.
Why anyone would wait an hour for a doughnut is ridiculous! This place will survive on tourism alone. Costco has better doughnuts.

They are donuts. They are extremely creative donuts, but they are donuts.

It is a fun experience, but don't expect to have any clue which donut is which. It's a guessing game with about 80 percent of the menu, and if you ask them what it is, they are pretty rude about it. Our person helping us acted like we were stupid for asking when we asked questions.

There are a lot of places in the world that become famous for their food items, some let it go to their head and treat people poorly. This place is one of them.

Butterfinger Donut - Very good. Moist. Good flavor. Better than most cake donuts.
Giant Peach - Way too sweet, but I don't think they are care. It's Portland. The donuts here fit the mantra of "Keep Portland Weird."

We ordered a bunch of others, and they are all tasty for sure, but I can't give a place a better rating when they are jerks to people.

I have to say, I'm not sure what all the craziness and block long lines are all about here. I just moved to Portland for the second time from San Francisco so we thought we'd try the most famous doughnut shop in town. PS, San Francisco has a doughnut shop every other block and most are pretty good. 

We caught Voodoo at a time when there was only 3 people in line so we jumped the opportunity. We decided to go with more basic choices cause after all voodoo, you are a doughnut shop, you should have basics down before you start putting bacon and frutty pebbles or grass and twigs or whatever the hell. I got a lemon ganache and my boyfriend got a glazed old fashioned (again, we're putting basics to the test). 

They were both dry and cheaply flavored. It just seemed that while they might be OK right out of the fryer, anytime after, they just don't hold up. At my favorite donut shop in SF (Bob's Donuts), you can literally eat their donuts at any time of the day and they are delicious.  Also, they way to f'ing expensive for a donut that tastes so dry. Donuts, unless they are special special or big, should always be less than a dollar in my opinion. These were both over a dollar. I would have enjoyed a $1.50 beer special more. 

So, in the end I guess try it but I wouldn't wait hours in line for these donuts...I really wouldn't.

It was fine, but I think the variety of donuts and the novelty are really why this place is so popular. The donuts themselves were good, but maybe not good enough to deserve the cultish following this place has.

Crazy fun flavors, totally! Bacon on a doughnut, cool dude.  Kitchy Portland vibe, awesome!!  Prices, average.  Long wait in the rain, standard.  Worth the wait, once and then again for out of towners that have seen Voodoo on TV.  Yes they are good, but I can't say they are great.  I feel bad, I went there so wanting to like the doughnuts, neigh, love the doughnuts, that I psyched myself out and was let down.  I still like Sesame Donuts better on the kamikaze corner of Beaverton.

It's a tourist trap.
I was told to try the maple bacon doughnut, as it was some kind of legendary
creation.
It was a your average maple doughnut but with an old piece of bacon on it.
I mean when you're stoned or drunk, of course it tastes legendary.
But otherwise I'd describe their doughnuts as sugary bagels with
stuff like oreos or chocolate syrup on top.

People definitely make way too big of a deal about this place. Aside from the different toppings and flavored powders, the actual donut itself tastes like something from the grocery store bakery.  It's all about the quirky idea of this place.  I do enjoy a grape ape and bubble gum donut every so often.  

If you don't want to stand in a long line make the trek over to the east side location. It's pink and fabulous and has tables to sit at. 

plus who wouldn't want to get married at a donut shop?!  I know I do.

Its a doughnut shop, with crazy formed doughnuts. Cash only place, Its to far out of our way to stop by frequently and there is always a line out the door. I see why people frequent this joint, its very Portland and quite different from anything else that is offered. Out-of-towners love it so Good for them to have the business they have, but this is a one and done deal us.

5000+ reviews?  Why even bother. LOL.

I'm not jaded but I don't see the big deal here.  I've tried 7 or 8 different doughnuts from the VooDoo Dozen and they are more or less made from two or three base doughnut recipes with different toppings. All things considered, only a very small portion of their menu is that creative and unique tasting.  Otherwise it's just a different flavored icing (and the flavor isn't that strong) with some different types of sprinkles.  So I'd recommend avoiding the tempatation to get the $9.95 Basic Dozen or $13 VooDoo dozen and choose your doughnuts individually and carefully.  You'll have plenty of time to decide standing in the ridiculously long line for a half hour or up to an hour depending on day and time.

I honestly don't think they surpass a freshly cooked Krispy Kreme or Top Pot but I get the cult following thing.  Not worth standing in line for more than 15 minutes in my opinion unless you're a tourist and REALLY into doughnuts, or just want to say you've gone there - just don't let your expectations get too high.

My hat goes off though to the business and how well they've hyped their brand but otherwise any level headed person I think would agree this place is overrated.

Doughnuts get a 4 star (I've had better), customer service, mainly the long wait in line gets 2 stars, prices get 3.5 stars = 3 star average.

Ehh...this place is for tourists. The donuts taste like donuts. They just happen to be covered with ridiculous amounts of sugary things. Not really my jam. They're a novelty item for those visiting Portland. For those from the Portland area, there MUST be better donuts somewhere.
For a 20 minute wait I was expecting something out of this world. There really wasn't anything special about my doughnuts, the pretzel on my voodoo doll was stale.

So not worth your time to wait around a city block to purchase a voodoo doughnut. I may be a little old fashioned but the chunky toppings, even bacon, on a dry textured doughnut just don't hold any appeal. Couple that with the service. When my turn at the old town location came a tourist behind me was asking a question and I got an air horn blast from the counter signalling me to hurry up and approach. I should have just left right then. I won't be back. Ever.

I didn't necessarily mind the 20 min wait, but the handwritten "cash only" sign would've been much more helpful OUTSIDE rather than inside after the wait. The $4 in cash in my wallet really cut down my spending power (I would've purchased a lot more had I known to bring cash). The gal at the register was rude, SO INCONVENIENCED to answer my questions. When I later opened my bag to get the donuts out, the receipt was wrapped around them. Disgusting. Congratulations, Voodoo Donuts. You have convinced me to never return.

I heard about this raving reviews of this place, so while in Portland I checked it out and ordered a selection of donuts, including the maple bacon, voodoo, captain crunch and fruitloop donuts.

I would have given this place four or five stars, but half the donuts I got were stale by the time I got them. 

It doesn't make sense, because they are so crazy busy all the time. Maybe they make them in super large batches, maybe they don't store them well, whatever, it was a little disappointing.

Wel we pretty much had to do it while we were in Portland. So we came pretty late in the afternoon to check the place out. The line was not that bad from what I was told and to be honest it moved pretty dang fast. So we got in and all the pressure of a first time hit me.  What do I get? What is good? How many should I get? Should I get one of each? 

So here is what I got, the Old Dirty Bastard, Butterfinger Donut and a Blueberry. So the verdict? I enjoyed them...but it didn't blow my freaking face off. In fact, it was almost too sweet. I know donuts are supposed to be sweet but man it was a lot to in \take and I hate each donut spread through out the day.  I liked the Butterfinger but there was a marshmallow fluff underneath that kind of threw it off. The ODB was just out of control, good but just out of control. 

If you are in town visiting Portland, you kind of have to come here. Its a right of passage just to say you did it. Would I go back? Sure I would, but I am not gonna wait more than 20 minutes for one. Im sure they have better donuts than what I got and maybe I got the wrong thing. But overall they were decent. Place has a lot of hype built around it and rightfully so, visually the donuts and the place is awesome. Not to sure about their beer collaborations with Rougue though. CHEERS!!!

*CASH ONLY ESTABLISHMENT*

After spending 5 days in Portland, I am convinced that Portland folks are much friendlier and nice than Californians. Came here at 2am in the morning on my last day in Portland to try the famous donuts. I've had them before by virtue of co-workers bringing them back on their morning flights out of Portland to Los Angeles and thought they were okay but the ideas they come up with are interesting. 

I was short on cash but the host was gracious in offering me a few free donuts to try out after making my first selections as I had waited in line for quite a while. I was very appreciative of that. As for the donuts, eat them when they are fresh. The apple fritter was my favorite and flavorful. Donuts were great, but I wouldn't say they were SPECTACULAR. Just creative and on par with my expectations. Taking a pink box full of these bad boys did turn a lot of heads at the airport though and even got me through security super fast. Therefore, the Voodoo name has some pull in this city!

Went there on a road trip to Seattle over Valentine's weekend. The old man and I made a special stop in Portland on the way since we'd seen this place on the food network and aforementioned man was pretty excited about the combinations of bacon, coco puffs, peanut butter, and mango he could get on fried dough. We waited in the cold line that stretched around the corner of the building, looking on yelp for what doughnut we should order once we got inside. 

Now, I should mention that I'm not really adventurous when it comes to doughnuts. I don't like peanut butter, jelly filled (when the jelly-dough ratio is too skewed in the jelly direction) or maple flavored doughnuts. So the "quirky" factor of this place is mostly lost on me. I do appreciate a good doughnut, but I don't need all the fanfare. When we finally got inside the front door, I really liked the way they had decorated the maybe 8'x10' ordering area - the art was funky and not your average doughnut shop decor. But when we got to the counter, the girl taking orders was really brusque. I get it, when you have to deal with hundreds of people shoving their way to your counter for 8 hours of the day, you're probably gonna be a little snotty. But this had more the vibe of someone who felt like I should have had the menu memorized, even though most of the ingredients weren't listed under the doughnut names on the tiny-printed menu above the counter. Sorry I didn't research the formula of the Memphis Mafia before I made the trip! I felt rushed and unsure of what to order, so I ended up getting just a plain chocolate glazed. Lame.

The doughnut was okay, a little stale. My boyfriend's Triple Chocolate Penetration had really stale coco puffs on top, but that didn't stop him from scarfing it down. All in all, it was a decent place for doughnuts, probably better if your tastes call for marshmallow glaze and froot loops. For me, I'll save the 10 hour drive and stick to Stan's.

Go once for the experience and Instagram photos but then don't go back. Voodoo is the younger step sister of the more sophisticated Blue Star Donuts. Voodoo is loud and obnoxious, craving attention through its bright fruit loop, sprinkle and chocolate-covered creations. Donuts are creative and tasted pretty good, but their is no donut passion running through the veins of Voodoo, it all seems to boil down to a marketing ploy.
Long line , good donut. Most of the other reviews are pretty spot on. The different donuts were visually pleasing. The experience is worth it but probably won't be back.
Do you like long lines and terrible donuts?  Then you should definitely go here!  Portland tourist trap.  Hit up Blue Star or Coco Donuts instead.
Presentation was nice, but the donuts were 'OK'. Would have been better if they were warm. Did not give me a reason to ever return.

I appreciate getting to live a famous experience and I am glad I did it and would do it again once per lifetime just so I could say I did. Also the glitter bricks were cool. But it's in a sort of sketchy part of town and the donuts are only normally good, not pants shaking lay good, so I donut need to go again.

I came to Voodoo only because my boyfriend has never been to Portland and I think you should at least try it once. After dinner, we decided to come here around 10 pm and no line at all. If the line was out the door, I would have said no, we will come back next time. I ordered the Portland Cream and my boyfriend got a donut covered with Nerds candy. I actually liked my donut and my boyfriend enjoyed his also. The best in Portland? No, I will pass the torch to Blue Star, but I give props to Voodoo for starting the crazy flavor donut movement.

My goodness, I thought the lines at Mike's Pastry in Boston were awful!  The owners at Voodoo have the place open 24 hours and they are just killing it.  The wait was ridiculous enough to make me and my friend try 3 times over the course of our weekend trip to make our way in.  Hint?  Try and come in the morning on a weekday if at all possible.

With limited space before lunch, we split several of the most popular ones including the Voodoo Doll, Bacon Maple Bar and Portland Cream.  While I enjoyed the fresh, crispy bacon and Bavarian cream filling, the doughnuts honestly weren't much better than your local run-of-the-mill doughnut shop in terms of textures and sweetness.  To draw a quick comparison, the yeast doughnuts at Doughnut Plant in NYC are worlds apart and worth the extra $1 or so compared to here.

Overall, worth at least one try if you're visiting...but like Mike's, Voodoo is a bit overhyped.

This place deserves kudos for creative donut flavor combinations and a kitchy atmosphere; however, the donuts themselves are pretty mediocre. 

We ordered the blueberry cake, banana cake with toasted coconut, glazed, bavarian cream, and mango tango donuts. None stood out especially, but I kind of felt like the glazed donut tasted like a grocery store donut. Sorry, please don't kill me. 

I guess I liked the blueberry cake donut the best, but I've definitely had better donuts elsewhere. If you're visiting Portland, then this is a neat place to visit; otherwise, I'm sure Portland has other donut shops that serve up better, hotter, and yummier donuts.

I don't get it. We waited in the line for about 15 minutes. Man, what a waste of my time. 

Menu was extremely difficult to read. They had a rotating thing with each donut but I didn't want to ask the guy at the counter every single thing that went by. We just picked what looked pretty. 

We have a donut shop here in Port Orchard that does a maple bacon donut that is to die for. We were excited to try Voodoo's famous maple bacon donut. YUCK! The bacon was burnt! 

Every donut we tried was overly sweet and just plain gross. Even people in line with us mentioned the donuts weren't that great but its just a thing you do when you visit Portland. Well I've done it once, won't be doing it again.

2 star doughnuts with a 5 star delivery and social scene.  Nothing really special taste wise, but they have the most creative concoctions.  OK, when passing through town, just go and see what all the hubbub is about, bub.

It's a donut shop, people! Unless there are no other donut shops in Portland, I really don't get why someone would stand in line for overpriced donuts. I had the bacon-maple bar (it's interesting, but not out-of-this-world) and the Portland Creme (too sweet).  Maybe because they give them crazy names? Or because a person would want fruit loops sprinkled on a donut?  I don't know.  Give me an apple fritter and I'm good.

To be honest, I think the hype exceeds the quality with Voodoo Donuts. It's the kind of place where you wait in line for 45 minutes, pay in cash, then go on your way. The donuts have a lot of "everything but the kitchen sink" appeal with a mix-mash of flavors in different varieties, but I couldn't say these are any better than a Krispy Kreme. 

If you want something that really blasts your tastes, go to Pips Original or Blue Star. You probably will only be here once.

If you're into donuts, this is a great place to get whatever you could possibly want. I'm not a fan, but had to see what the hoopla is about. Ok, got it. Still tasting it two days later. It was a Voodoo Man donut at the second Voodoo location (eastside). Out of town friends liked the vibe, and one glutted on a peanut butter-and-Oreo donut. Hope he made it home...

After all the hype settled all that was left were a bunch of dry non-delicious donuts.  I was looking forward to voodoo doughnuts every since I saw them on TV, but was really let down upon first bite.  We got a total of 6 donuts and they were all pretty dry.  I don't get how the donuts were so crappy with such a high turnover rate?  I waited in line for almost 30 minutes so I'd expect the donuts to be fresh, but they weren't!  oh well i guess I did the tourist thing but I won't try it again.

Cannot understand why people love this place so much. While I don't completely hate it here because I am grateful for the fact that they offer lots of vegan donuts, it's the decor that really ruins it for me. I know I'm supposed to leave a review on the donuts but I have to bring up the whole gore theme they've got going on! Why!?! Because keep Portland weird? I only come here when I'm absolutely desperate and Doe Donuts is closed.

Ok, you're a tourist so you know you're going here even if you don't really want a donut. 

The line is usually pretty long but it moves quickly. When we arrived, the line had about ~25 people outside and another 15 inside. The wait to order was only 15 mins. There were two people taking orders. 

If you've never been here before, you should probably do a bit of research because they don't really have normal flavors -- that's sort of the point. There's a big sign on the outside wall with the unusual names but it's not really self-explanatory. You can ask questions when you get inside but it's a little uncomfortable to hold up the line with so many people waiting.

There are two versions of donuts; so-called "raised yeast" and cake donuts. We tried four donuts:

* Triple chocolate 
Cocopuff cereal and chocolate drizzle on a chocolate cake donuts. This was my least favorite. I scraped off the cocopuffs. The donut itself is moist but I like raised yeast better. 

* Maple Bar 
Raised yeast doughnut with maple frosting. Pretty good but not the best maple bar I've ever had. 

* Portland Cream
Raised yeast shell filled with Bavarian cream topped with chocolate and two eyeballs. This was an enjoyable combination of flavors. 

* Guava colada 
Shredded coconut on a raised yeast donut with a guava/raspberry filling. Served with a umbrella. Sugary goodness without being over the top. The unexpected winner and only donut worth going back for. 

I did some research afterwards (reminder -- do it beforehand) and decided we should have gotten the Memphis Mafia. It's fried dough with banana chunks and cinnamon covered in glaze, drizzled in chocolate and peanut butter with peanuts and chocolate chips on top. Wow! It's also $6.

Not sure I will ever go back to Voodoo but I'm glad I went once.

It's a tourist destination that you must pay homage to. The quirky decor will distract you as you wait in line with the other 75 tourists who are here for a sample. Menu items are creatively named and some have unique ingredients but the classics are available too. Tastewise, it's a 3 out of 5 but if you're a first timer to the city you should definitely check it out.

Line is entirely too long but its a huge buzz about going here. I will say the line moves very fast.

The variety was not as great as i thought and the associates are cool but impatient.

Its a "Been there done that and ill pass next time."

Not impressed and wouldnt return.
Must visit for tourists and lovers of Count Dracula.  Very Small location but cleverly decorated.  Be prepared for a super long line after a Sunday night Timbers game.

Voodoo Donut is itself an "experience" you must for sure try at some point, but after that, it just lacks.  There are three things in particular that get me about these donuts

1. They are a sugary nightmare or a sugary dream depending on how you see it.  Most of the donuts are overly sweet.  While unique and often tasty, the sheer amount of sugar can send anyone's sugar levels off the chart.

2. They do not accept debit/credit cards.  I get it, you pay a transaction fee as a business everytime someone swipes their card, but by not accepting cards you basically force the poor out of towner who has never been to your shop to pay an ATM fee so they can try your donuts.  Thats bad business in my opinion.  There are great solutions like Square that charge 2.75% per swipe.  So that $3 that your customer just bought with their credit card, you lost 8 cents.  Where with your ATM, if you get half the fees back that it charges the customer, you just made an additional $1.25 on that $3 donut.  Again bad business.

3.  To go along with the extra money that you are extracting from customers who do not bring cash, the donuts here are not cheap.  If you try to chose your own dozen, expect to pay at least $20.

So all in all, try it once for the experience, but just make sure you bring cash.

Not bad, not amazing. Get the maple bacon bar and the captain crunch donut. They've marketed themselves well and it worth the trip as a tourist, but I wouldn't say it's as great as a lot of other donut places I've had.

Donuts are very unique looking.
But tasted like any other donut shop. 
I will not coming back here.
Way too overblown... Not worth the line. Donuts are decent but nothing special in contrast to the hype. I will admit, though, bacon on a donut is genius, but they need more pungent pork.

they're really not even that good but also the fact that it's becoming this disgusting represenation of portland, with a line down the block and a box in the hand of every other tourist at the airport, sickens me.

Donuts are just okay. The staff here are very unfriendly. The sole guy working here is rude and ought to go to customer service school instead of loathing his job (and possibly, life outside of work). Will not come again.

Interesting experience. I had to see what all the fuss was about. I guess if you like that trendy sort of PDX-hipster vibe, this will do you well. I'm sick of the Portlandia nonsense, myself, so I wasn't expecting to be overly impressed.

It was fine. I can't get over the feeling that I'm just as qualified as the next guy to sprinkle some Captain Crunch on a glazed donut and call it art, though. For me, the shtick has no impact. The hype has no game. The emperor isn't wearing clothes. So don't be fooled. These are just donuts, and no matter how you gussy them up, they're still just donuts and there's no additional magic in the recipe. 

I get what they're doing, though. They're not catering to me, they're catering to Portlandia, where trend is king. It's working for them. The lines go around the block. People seem giddy waiting in line for this stuff, especially once they've moved up toward the back kitchen door where the racks sit, the scent of fresh baked goods wafting out into the street level to drive us all crazy with food-lust. The pink box is loved and revered by many.

So I'll give it a respectable three stars, a quiet nod, and be on my way. Good for yoo, voo doo.

I honestly am not sure what all of the hype is about, but will be honest that my family thought they were the best ever! I've been to Portland many times and never felt compelled to wait in the long lines for calories that I don't need, but since my family was with me on this trip I decided to find my patience and see what everyone is talking about. So the wait began, made better by a small band playing for tips outside. We ordered a dozen doughnuts and were on our way. My family flipped for them. I thought they were good but I wouldn't wait in that line for them again and I wouldn't order a dozen again because the next morning they were not st all appetizing...so definitely best directly after purchase.

The donuts are creative and silly, but that's about it. They're really just normal-tasting donuts. In fact, I've had better donuts at 7-Eleven.

I came here because I felt like I couldn't be in Portland and not at least give it a try.

I walk in to a "cash only" sign, which to me is a huge turn-off. Not trying to come to conclusions, but most of the cash-only places I've been to do it because they don't want to pay the extra fee to the credit card companies, or they do it to speed up efficiency. Neither of which says to me "We value our relationship with our customers". But whatever, it's your business model.

So I walk over to the ATM machine they have inside (at least there's that) to get cash, and get a Maple Cruller, a Portland Cream, and a Voodoo Doll.

The only one that ended up entirely in my belly was the Maple Cruller. The other two, I took a few bites and thought "wow, this is very underwhelming..." so I didn't finish them. To be honest, for me, the candy and other zany toppings they put on the donuts just get in the way...

Sorry Voodoo Doughnut, I wanted to enjoy you, I really did!

If it's your first time in Portland, sure, come here for the novelty, but otherwise, you're not missing much.

This place is all hype. The only reason that I wouldn't give this place one star is due to the vegan options.

I went in the middle of the day and waited in a line that was inside of the door. What really bothered me was that some of the people that worked there kept yelling at everyone to clear space for the exit. My thought is, if you know that you're going to have a problem like that, plan for it. Create a way that the line will not be blocking the fire exit, don't continuously yell out. That's definitely not a great way to start off an experience before even ordering.

After getting a varied selection of donuts that seemed to be unique to Voodoo Donuts my partner and I were greatly disappointed. The donuts with the cereal and fun toppings were exactly what you'd think it would taste like. Plain donut and topping, nothing super spectacular there. We also got the maple donut, subpar. Finally, I got the Voodoo doll donut with raspberry filling which wasn't terrible. The frosting wasn't that good but the jelly inside seemed really fresh. I also ordered the hot chocolate and it just tasted like something that comes from a packet.

The service is nothing great either, not particularly friendly and not rude, just there.

The location is in a nice area to walk around especially when it's the Saturday Market but parking is pretty scarce.

I'm so surprised and disappointed going there. I've seen this place on the Food Network and many friends said that I needed to stop by here.

Overall, I can see why it's a tourist spot but it's nothing that I'd want to go to again. If you're really craving donuts there is a better one right around the corner.
Over rated shop and please do not stand in line for these.  There are better donut shops all over.  Blue star or the donut shop in Alberta district.

I've had better.  You can taste the lard after one bite.  I think the hype is more than the taste or worth the cost.  Definitely not standing in line for 45 minutes for a donut.  I'll try some of the other places.
It's cute, has lots of tasty and exotic donuts, great place for a sugar rush, affordable prices and great people. I wish it was bigger with seats but other than that, it's all good!

"EH" is the one description I have for this place. Me and some girlfriends were staying across the street and could see Voodoo from our hotel window, There was always a line! No way em I waiting in line for a freaking doughnut. After a night of drinking we noticed there was no line at voodoo so after some convincing from the girls we deiced  to give voodoo a chance. Again there was no line, And the lady taking our order was in a hurry still. Their menu is hard to read and their display case rotates/spins so you can't just easy point to one you want. it doesn't help that she was rushing us to pick out what we wanted. Not a friendly staff at all, but hey why do you need a friendly staff when there is always a line and over 5k reviews on yelp? right? We got a couple "Homer Simpsons" Some topped with cereal  and some maple bars. They were good doughnuts but nothing special, nothing you really couldn't get anywhere else. Half of them ended up in the trash.  Legendary doughnuts (in WA) are just as good maybe better and the store is clean and the staff is nice and helpful. I don't see what the hype is about.

Its a fun experience to try these unique treats, but I would highly recommend going to the second location in NE to avoid the crazy rush of people and long waits. They are expensive but its worth it once.

Scariest part of the Voodoo? ... the LINE!

Like, around the block several times, ribbon queue, people are probably gonna need a smoke break kind of line. I'm thinking, what in the world? Oh, right, a place that has becoming fabulously, insanely popular and crowded because of a niche market. Pentagram on the donut, classy, for sure. It looks like a... wow! Neat!

Better donuts to be had. Katy H. is on the money.. it's kinda a tourist trap.

I wouldn't bother coming here, bottom line. What's with $3 donuts anyways, when did that become okay? For me, not today! That's when!

Thanks for listening!

I love Portland. I forgot to leave a review for this donut haven. We waited in a line about 45 minutes to get in. Yeah, I know, I played tourist that day with the fam. My current photo is from right in front of Voodoo. 

We got a dozen of all kinds of donuts. For those who don't know what they are all about, the donuts have cap'n crunch, oreo, bacon and all kinds of odd toppings. Definitely pricey ($21.99 a dozen at 4 or 5 years ago) and pretty good. Definitely for tourists. The service was very good and friendly and the clerks answered all ?'s patiently even though the line was long. Portland peeps are so much nicer than Cali folks. I would move there but I can't stand rain, cold and bleek weather. 

Kinda cool is the interior is designed with crazy decor. You have to see it once. Some of the donuts were good and others were yuck. I'm giving them a score of 3 for their donuts. Worth at least a check them out drop in.

Wacky fun Portland factor:  High

Serenade by denizens of old town, this visit brought to you by the Stinky Pines, amusing yet fun and creepy all at the same time.

A must do as a visit?  Yes

A regular thing to do?  probably not.

Was the doughnut good?  The bacon and maple was good.  The base doughnut was actually very tasty and I certainly give them high marks for creativity.  But the mexican chocolate doughnut just didn't work on many levels.  Disappointing as chocolate and not even close to mexican chocolate flavors.  

Would I wait in line 40 minutes again?  Probably not.

Best bet, get your friend to wait in line and enjoy that they got.  But not really something I must do next time in portland, so just A-OK.

Definitely a tourist trap... doughnuts were mmmkay. Felt a bit rushed. Small building and cashiers have bad attitudes. Cash only and they give change back in dollar coins. The bag the girl put my doughnut in honestly looked like it was already used and a bit dirty. Signs posted about racism and discrimination is a bit of an eyebrow raiser. Not sure if they're racist or just have poor customer service. Save your money and go to 7 eleven.

This is one of those places they tell you you have to try.  So I do, every time I visit Portland with somebody who has never been.  I stand in a long line and watch donuts spin around and around and around.  They do have a lot of donuts with many unique flavors and toppings and a whole lot of vegan choices.  They also have coffee and stuff.  I get an upset tummy almost every time.  Cash only.
Its okay but dont see what the big deal is nor the long lines. If you come super early on a weekday NO LINES. otherwise avoid line at all costs.
I only go here when bringing guests through Portland. It's so touristy and overrated, just not worth the long lines and poor service when you want a good doughnut. I far prefer Pip's on Fremont.

These had to be the worst donuts I've ever eaten...I was so excited to finally get here.  Waited in a long-ass line.  Loved the cheeky concept and the fun donuts.

But, they were horrible.  Tasted like they were fried in bad oil, or something.  If you want a good donut, it's not here...

I am a complete sucker for doughnuts so I was ridiculously excited to check this place out. Unfortunately I wasn't super impressed by it. I happened to go at a time where there wasn't a long line which was great. However, despite the lack of a crowd, the service wasn't great. My friend inquired about the different flavors but the cashier didn't really answer her questions. I got a Powdered Doughnut with a Lemon filling and my friend got the  Hibiscus Doughnut. The first doughnut was good but I found the Hibiscus Doughnut to be too sweet. I think people tend to come here for the pictures but I found the doughnuts themselves to be average. I would still check it out just for the experience.
Long lines doughnuts that are well below average.  I say that as a doughnut lover who's tried Voodoo three times in an attempt to enjoy it.   It's all hype....

[Visitor from CA review]

Thankfully I didn't have to stand in any lines! The free walking tour that I went on, deliberately ends across the street from Voodoo Doughnut at a non-peak time, which is around 2 PM.

Since it just my one stomach, I modestly got 1 donut, the Voodoo Man.

This donut makes for great pictures, since each of them have a different expression but all have a heart with a pretzel stick to stab with. I had fun stabbing the donut until it bled it's raspberry jelly blood. :D 

The flavor itself wasn't anything too memorable, it was just the fun factor that amped it up. All of their donuts have fun/tongue-in-cheek names with some pretty wild flavor combinations.

I purchased a dozen from another Voodoo location to fly home with me, and I have to say the simpler ones, like the Portland Creme, tasted the best. 

Fun to try once for sure!

While the boyfriend and I were in Portland, we had to try Voodoo Doughnuts.

Sadly, I was disappointed.

Don't get me wrong - It was fried dough.  I was a fan.  But it wasn't anything special - I can get a better doughnut without the hassle of parking here in Puyallup.

I was very impressed with their selection and their prices, but overall, I think it's overrated and probably won't go back unless I'm in the area.
It's ok. Line took about 10 minutes. Strip joint and pan handlers outside. Shady part of town. Not family friendly.

The two stars is for wverything else besides the service. The doughnuts are okay. Like any other. When you first walk up you have to literally walk through homeless people who stop you for money before you even get inside. The enployees seem like they dont want to be there vut have to be. They still have half smiles on their faces. Its kinda grungy. Very Portland like though  growing up here I never came here.

Voodoo donuts food = creative, fun and delicious!!! A must experience place if just for the donuts.

Voodoo donuts merch, because you want to support such a delicious product, is mediocre at best. I ordered a 40$ zip up sweatshirt.  It has great graphics but the material is the thickness of a long sleeve shirt. Very light weight, so maybe for the California,  Arizona, Nevada,  Florida crowd but that's about it. It's disappointing that you hold your sweatshirt up and it's thin enough to easily see light thru the fabric. Again the graphics are great but for 40 bucks I think any customer would expect a higher quality product.

Voodoo really put Portland on the map and definitely embodies the weirdness of Portland (despite having franchises in other cities and overseas now). The pink boxes have become iconic and you see a lot of tourists carrying them around town. However the lines can be ridiculous and the donuts are a little overrated. Don't get me wrong, they're great and really creative but not worth an hour plus wait. However, if you come on rainy winter days or off times then the wait isn't so bad or even non existent. That's usually when I try to go. Forget about summer weekends. I like the Portland Cream, Voodoo Doll, and Maple Bar. The tang one is kinda weird. Cash only and be ready with your order. There's no where to sit inside but there's tables outside. Sometimes they have a minimum order to get a pink box.

I'm a native Portlander so I don't go to the one downtown-- I go to the one on Sandy. But even our Sandy location has gotten too touristy. Also I have gone here way too many times and realized that they only take cash. Don't forget to bring cash!

Out of the gate, I am not a huge fan of the donut. That said I absolutely had to give this place a whack, and a whack I did! Very good and unique donuts. I was afraid that the donuts would be "overly" unique taking away from the donut itself. Not the case. Truly they have just about everything you can imagine. My favorite was probably the maple bacon bar...but the voodoo donut was pretty darn good to. I did notice that some of the donuts were piled high with sugar; so if you are looking for a more traditional donut, I would probably skip those. All around you are going for the experience not that you are prepared to have the best donut of your life. Just a matter of opinion.

PORTLAND18 REVIEW #3

TL;DR: CASH ONLY, great doughnut variety, little under the hype

Ah yes, the Portland spot that almost everyone talks about. I couldn't ask anyone for suggestions without hearing about this donut place. Voodoo Doughnuts does have a lot of hype and the variety to back it up. However, I didn't find their doughnuts to be too out of the ordinary. Yes, I'm glad I went here, but I'm not sure it's something I'd go out of my way for.

I had the Portland Cream and the Viscous Hibiscus.

PORTLAND CREAM (4/5)
- Good filling, but not too filled
- Average chocolate doughnut taste
- Pretty good size for the price

VISCOUS HIBISCUS (3/5)
- Really sweet, but I don't know what else to expect
- Half sprinkles looks good, but kinda awkward to eat
- Huge doughnut!

I was a huge fan of the service! Even with the line, the cashier was really helpful and explained some of the doughnuts. We were able to order our doughnuts and get out of the store pretty quickly. We didn't know that this shop was Cash Only, but luckily, I had some cash on me. Important to know before you come. I think the novelty of this place is great, but I'm not sure I'd come back again. A good experience for a vacation, though!

I've heard so much about this place, all good. We tried it twice while in Portland and I was underwhelmed. It's definitely different and original  which is why so many like it. To me, it looks like a bunch of kids got together and decided to add the grossest most bizarre things on donuts. I'm more of a traditional donut gal I suppose. It's a pretty cool place in the end though.

Likes: I love the unique vibe in this bakery. They have an eclectic collection of decorations inside, the exterior brick is painted a sparkly gold color, the employees all seem pretty hip, and they always seem to have pretty cool music playing. I enjoy the variety of donuts here. My favorites are the mango donut and the bacon maple bar. The mango donut doesn't taste like it has real fruit in it but I'm honestly OK with that because it's so amazing! Besides, how healthy can you expect to be while eating a freaking donut?? I love how thick the bacon is sliced on their maple bar. Other bakeries tend to skimp on this so you don't get the contrast between sweet and salty like you do here.

Dislikes: I feel like the donuts at voodoo are pretty basic. In other words, they don't use many unique or creative flavorings. They just load their donuts up with a ton of sugar and food coloring. I would love to see some Cronut, turnoand flakier pastries here. Also, I feel like their donuts are a bit overpriced for what you get. And lastly, I hate having to stand in such a long line to get some pretty basic donuts.

Clearly I am one of the disappointed customers of the famous VooDoo Donuts. We were here at this place by around 10 pm hoping that we could pick up some donuts as we were making our way to Seattle. It was shocking to see the horrible wait line with around 100 people ahead of us. Because of the hype we decided to wait and trust it was the longest wait ever because the queue was hardly moving. Finally we got into the store were there was plenty of varieties to select from. We selected a few and then the next bummer was that they take ONLY CASH. Oh Gawd pleaseee don't want to get out of the line and start from 100 again. Luckily we had a $20 bill using which we got the donuts. When it comes to taste, I would say it was decent but definitely not worth the Hype. Another major problem here is the Parking. Because this place is always having the long queue, finding a parking is almost impossible. Personally I felt the Sunrise Donuts in Redmond tasted better than the VooDoo Donuts. Finally I would say that the only reason we should try this Donut place is because it is one of the important identities of Portland. If you are not bothered, just Skip it !!!

Went there for the first time ever today and the line was not long but was treated like I needed to rush... I asked about what I could order for a dozen and I received a rude response with an ugly remark as if I should already know what I could get for $20 cash since its cash only! Then I said you pick them since I'm NOT from here I am from Seattle make them good ones that nobody can get anywhere else... She touched every doughnut with her hand no paper and was rushed.... Again the lines was not long for all the rush!!! My total was $20 for crappy doughnuts that I could get at Safeway for $6 a dozen! Traditional doughnuts!!!! I got no voodoo I got not cereal no cookie doughnut nothing!!! Ontop of that I said something about her hand touching the doughnuts and she gave me a kill eye I was not about say anything else since I was running late for my bus ride back home to Seattle so I took the box and threw and gave it to homeless people!!! Worse service and took expensive not worth the hype at all GO to PETES which is before going to mt. hood! Or to your local grocery store 3x less the price and better service! Mind you I don't ever write reviews but this was just horrific! I don't know where her hands have been and the other guy had a beard hanging out.... NO WAY!!!
They're good, but don't live up to the massive hype everyone gives them. They're just unique, not the world's best doughnuts.

When friends come in from out of town and my wife and I ask them where they want to go, I am already cringing, knowing they are about to say Voodoo Doughnut.  
I tip my hat to the owners.  Their marketing plan has been nothing short of brilliant. Every time I turn on one of the numerous food channels there is about a 50% chance I am going to see Voodoo Doughnut in some ridiculous top ten list.   
When I drive by this place I always shake my head at the line stretching around the block and wonder out loud, "who the hell would wait that long for a bad doughnut." 
I have been to Voodoo about six times and though I am interested in the imaginative flavor pairings, I have always been let down when I actually take a bite.  I don't care if you want to put Tang on a doughnut, but if you want me to actually come back again, you need to make it taste good. 
If you are visiting Portland and you want a really good tasting doughnut, go to Blue Star Doughnuts. Get the Buttermilk.

Doughnuts were decent but nothing special. I had the cinnamon one. Although the place itself was something to see. Atmosphere friendly with wild colors. We must have been there on an off day as there was no line. It was worth doing once for the experience but probably not again

I'm not entirely sure why this place is so popular and has such a long line. I feel the 2 hour wait usually turned me off, but their donuts were just so so too. My boyfriend and I were visiting portland for a week and decided to walk by here every time we were near the area and every time there was such a long wait. It wasn't until some random Monday night at maybe 11pm when there was no line that we were finally able to try it. I got the maple bacon and I don't remember what he got, but it wasn't particularly tasty. I understand donuts are supposed to be sweet, but it just felt like the whole thing was entirely sugar and overwhelmingly sweet. 

I definitely prefer blue star because I feel they have a much better balance of flavor and the dough to frosting ratio.

If you buy donuts from here, you must either be a tourist or really really desperate for something sweet and greasy late at night.

That said, they have a killer PR dept that somehow manages to get their name in every single freakin food magazines/newspaper/media. And they lent their name to a line of Rogue Ales that's sold in many souvenir shops as well as the PDX airport. (sickly sweet bottle of beer for $15? Hmmm)

If only other more deserving donut shops could get that kind of publicity...
Honestly, there are MANY donut shops in Portland that sell much better tasting donuts. They don't have to hide their mediocrity and stale taste by using all these attention seeking nonsense toppings.

Stop the madness and don't line up to buy these subpar donuts. Just don't

When you say you're giving out free donuts for national Margarita Day, customers expect to receive what is advertised. Nowhere online or on social media does it say that "a purchase is necessary" for you to receive a donut. We had no cash on us and of course they only accept cash... So disappointing, we just left empty handed and annoyed by service and false marketing.

This is a definite tourist venture spot. If you have never tried Voodoo Doughnuts before, I would suggest attending. They have some fun specialty doughnuts where they are in unique shapes. That helps it to be fun.

The donut flavors were good. Nothing to special. It was fun getting a donut called a gay bar, they had two great filled donuts, and a peanut butter crunch.

I would suggest first timers wait in the line to get the goods. If there was not a line, I would probably go back here. But if there is a line (since I have already tried it), I would pass.

Original Downtown Location (Davis location is much less crowded)

* Warning to Tourists... the downtown location gives new meaning to the word crowded... if you're going to come here for their quirky kitschy doughnuts then bookmark the Davis location instead... TRUST!

We all know the main reason this location is so popular... noooooo... not because the recipe calls for some new crack like addictive ingredient created by the government, but because one wants to get something a little different than what he, or she believes is a good representation of Portland and that's VD.

VD is one of those "Tourist Traps" not because this location is small... well that's part of it, but seriously their line stretches down several blocks so visitors can get a taste of those deep fried delights that seemingly defy convention with quirky names like "The Blunt," The Eminem," Cock n Balls," The Memphis Mafia," The Orangutang," Bacon Maple Bar," Triple Chocolate Penetration," ODB," the famous Voodoo Doughnut," The Grape Ape," or the Miami Vice" to name just a few. Bright colored frostings and various ingredients like crushed Oreos, Captain Crunch, or real bacon are just some of the things that run amuck here.

I'm not going to lie... before I was in the "know" I also fell into the trap that is this location. Fortunately for my dining partner and I the line wasn't too bad on the day we went so we stuck it out. I had the Memphis Mafia which is a Peanut Butter, Banana, Peanuts, and Chocolate Chip Fritter: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/voodoo-doughnut-portland?select=fsdnsh5IiFJHxYT0nVOUjQ#kunnzOhuFVcfO2enI4xMCg I barely finished consuming this one... One because the size was so immense, but two because it kind of lacked any sort of assertive flavors. It sounds like this Elvis inspired doughnut would have been amazing, but not so much. I was more than underwhelmed. The person that joined me cracked me up by just having a regular frosted doughnut! She had me in tears more so than the thought of Hion cramming the shaft of the Cock n Balls in his mouth! So are their ridiculously long lines worth coming here? This guy says no way. Trust me when I say if you're going to make a stop by to a Voodoo location then go to their Davis location Voodoo Doughnuts Too. It's still cash only, but the venue is much larger, has plenty of parking, is less crowded, and features much more (indoor) seating and Pinball Machines!: http://www.yelp.com/biz/voodoo-doughnut-too-portland

Like I said though... this location is pretty tiny so there are no indoor tables at all (space would be way too cramped ya know and they could probably only fit like maybe one table if they were lucky.

They sell T Shirts, Sweat Shirts, Stickers, and Post Cards if you want to commemorate your visit.

Parking can be found with great challenge on any of the nearby streets.

Leave your cards at home Party Peeps cuz this place is CASH ONLY! Be wary... you will pay a premium on those fancier doughnuts.

Voodoo is a place you go to say you went. You get cred, then you move on. If I lived in PDX I probably would've found a doughnut shop I liked better by now.

All things told though, the doughnuts are fun, even if the cake for most of the ones I've tried has been drier than I would've liked. It's a good excuse to grab a bunch of friends and try something ridiculous. I'm not drinking the Voodoo fan juice, but I'm not against the place either.

I don't understand the hype. I came here when I first moved to Portland and after waiting in a ridiculously long line, my donut was so dry and stale that I couldn't even finish it. Neither could my roommate who loves chocolate. I took my parents here the second time as part of their PDX tour and again, the donuts were just not good. I always describe Voodoo's donuts as putting a ton of random stuff on a donut and then selling it for the novelty. With many other great donut and bakeries in Portland, skip the lines at Voodoo and try Blue Star or Tonalli's instead!

Yes I know it wasnt necessary to come here but that most reviewed with the 4000 reviews was just coaxing me to try to it. The line at night is long but it moves fairly quickly. I say it took about 20-30 minutes for donuts that arent the best quality but they are so colorful and over the top that you just have to try it. I got the maple bacon and I thought it was alright. I tried a real bacon donut at Blue Star and that is beyond better than Voodoo. I also got the peanut butter oreo..I mean how can you not. Those are the two best flavors you can put together. Yet again it was alright and I am positive this place gets visitors because it is open late and is near all the bars and stuff. This area is a tad sketch so make sure you are with friends at night.

- Good to go at least once if you are in Portland.
- Had the Homer Simpson or something and it was quite tasty.
- Staff is quite under-whelmed to be working there it seems.
- Prices are cheap.
- They seem to only serve cold brew coffee (none hot).
- Much better donuts out there.

Would have liked to hold a pink box and it smelled good but the line was 75 people deep. I have better things to do then to wait an hour for a donut. I will say the donut smell what they were cooking....smelled incredible. Wish I could have had one
I love Portland, and I know this is a Portland establishment (or so say many Yelpers), but I just didn't get the hype.   I wish I did.

For a taste experience, definitely over rated. For a cultural/artistic/creative experience, it's ok. The place is creative and fun... but the donuts themselves are not very good. My favorite is the McKinnleyville Cream (or something like that)  - it's filled with a maple-flavored cream so it's not dry. The  "old fashioned" and  the  "cake" donuts that we got were dry and tasted stale.  Personally, I'd take Dunkin' Donuts over these any day.

Vegan oreo peanut butter donut-awesome. 7am on Sunday before labor day-minimal line. We are on to a good start. The maple blintz was good. The Portland creme was what I thought would be my favorite. Instead it was raw on the inside....forgiving that offense, which I find to be a little hard, the taste of all the donuts and atmosphere was very good. I was afraid it would be widly innapropriate everywhere, but it is still a good place for kids. I could see me living in close proximity becoming a real problem...

Do I even need to review this place?! I didn't experience the line (thank goodness! I went in Monday afternoon) the donuts are good, the names of the donuts and creativity are better. I ordered and promptly consumed a Raspberry Romeo and ordered a couple of Voodoo dolls and Memphis Maria's...for a friend *ahem*. The romeo was delicious the voodoo and mafia were ok...I heard...because it was for a friend *cough cough* If I find myself in Portland again I probably wouldn't go again. But it was good to check them off of the list.

its good.  If I am in Portland, I would eat a Voodoo Doughnut.  

I was a bit disapponted to not love the Bacon Maple Bar.  I was hoping to just have that moment of light shining from the heavens.  I guess it was just overhyped and nowhere to go but down from there.  Especially since a maple bar is my favorite doughnut. And Bacon is my favorite way to eat pork.  

Not a fan of Portland Creme. Tangtastic lives up to its name. The Voodoo Doughnut is just a novelty.  

Overall good doughnuts but really is just Portland saying we don't need a big doughnut on our roof to get people to buy our doughnuts.

OK fine this place looks cool and has a killer cream filled donut, but it's seriously overrated.  Even Fred Meyer has stared to slap some old cereal on their donuts.  I want to see something else.  The nice thing about Voodoo is their hours.  A midnight donut is never a bad idea!

While in Portland, check out Voodoo Donuts! Haha, forreal the first thing everyone says to me when I told them I was visiting Portland. This place was definitely not for me. I am very plain Jane when it comes to donuts. Give me a plain ol' glaze and I would be more than happy. But hey, I'm in Portland! Of course I had to check it out and see what the hype is all about. 

Very cute, fun donut shop with a rock and roll theme. These donuts follow the "Keep Portland Weird" motto very well. All the donuts were pretty crazy, made with many different colored icings, cookies, cereals, candies, etc. To the point where it looks pretty unappetizing. Haha!

They have a Jones soda fountain! Never seen that before, so dope! I was all about the green apple jones growing up! Ahhh, the memories it brought me right when I saw it!
