TIP #1: I was told by a few Uber drivers that THE donut shop of Portland is Blue Star Donuts located a few miles away. They serve high quality donuts, made with fresh ingredients. 

TIP #2: Also, if the line at this location is out the door and around the block, come back or visit their other location! This one is located downtown so it's always busy. Luckily, my BF and I stopped by around 3pm and there was no lines! Yay! We got to sneak in, looked around for a bit, then head out to Blue Star!

"Now go do that Voodoo that you do so well!"  

Similarly, the Voodoo Doughnut cache continues as evidenced by the huge mid-day lines outside and the number of pink boxes I saw from fellow passengers on the plane back to Oakland a few Sunday evenings ago. 

My Son and I were at the Portland Saturday Market mid-morning and as the Voodoo Doughnut line was only on the inside of their establishment.  Please note the ATM in the alleyway, as this place remains a cash business. 

The Kid went for 2 types of specialty donuts (Grape Ape and Orangatang) and loved them. I ordered the relatively mundane chocolate old fashioned as I wanted to see what Voodoo could do with the basics. What I found was that like specialty coffee drinks, fancy sugary treats on top of a doughnut often dramatically improves off the average basics below.

My Advice?  By all means, "check the box" and give Voodoo Doughnut a go and a another go. At the same time, there's no place like Timmy's.

OK -  I get it... it's quirky. You can get a donut with bacon or cereal or heaven forbid bubble gum on it. But really - a almost hour long line just to get inside? You only take cash? The donuts taste about as good as any other decent quality donut shop?

Rockin - the flavors of donuts, the funny signs, the quirky decor

Tired - long line, average quality donuts, average service.

It's a fun place to go once when visiting the city, but I don't know that I'll be back.

So apparently this was a MUST STOP and try place when visiting Portland... We paid our dues by standing in line, got a few to try (maple bacon + Mango Tango)... plus a box togo to bring back to the office to share.

Verdict: Overrated.

The donuts (taste/texture) themselves were nothing to write home about. The novelty of this place are the crazy toppings they put on to make it different from your neighborhood donut shop.
Too much hype. Krispy Kreme donuts are a better, much better. No need to stand in line for so long to have this experience.
I don't understand why this place is so popular. There are so many better donut places in town. Try blue star donuts or joes in Sandy. The donuts here are just stale and not that good

Overrated. Since I saw it on the Food Network I made this place one of my first stops when I moved to Portland. Its not that the donuts are bad, they are fine, its just not as AMAZING as people say it is. They do have some awesomely creative flavors like bubblegum (yum!) and cotton candy (also yum) as well as the traditional flavors like glazed, chocolate and maple. The maple bacon bar is really good and the blueberry cake donut is, in my opinion, their best donut. They are open 24 hours but in the summer the line is out the door and down the block. The best time to go during the summer is very early in the morning like 5am or very late at night during the week.

I've heard lots about Voodoo Doughnuts and after participating in the Oyster Racing Series, one task involving eating the giant doughnut with my team and using no hands, we decided to stop by on our way to the holiday parade.  The doughnuts were okay but I thought it was too expensive for what we got.  Ordering four doughnuts and two containers of milk was $14!  A little steep for the public servants we are.  I'd go back if that's where friends wanted to go, but there are good doughnuts that cost less and are closer to where I am.
Everyone should try it once. Love the bumperstickers, they make me giggle everytime. Not a fan of long lines or sweets in general, but I've had better donuts.

I feel bad but...I don't get the hype.  Other than the fact that the donuts are beautiful, colorful, and huge....there isn't that much to like about them.  I tried 4 different donuts during my visit and all of them were terribly dry.  The Old Dirty Bastard and Butterfingering had great, delicious toppings...but the cake was just plain dry and/or bland.  The only one I tried that was relatively moist was a cherry fritter....which is not one of my favorite flavors.

Luckily, we didn't have to wait in much of a line so that doesn't really have an effect on my rating.  I'd be willing to try Voodoo again next time I'm in Portland, but I certainly wouldn't wait 30-60 minutes for what I think are subpar donuts.

Unique place, but nothing special. I didn't find the donuts tasted better than any other run of the mill donut place. The line was over an hour and we were less than enthused with our donut. I think it's more about the experience than the actual product. I could sprinkle stale cereal on a donut myself and have it taste better. Not rushing out to have it again.
Very long line for overrated donuts... Very sweet and sugary which is expected but it was an overload! I don't think I'd go back but a great experience for a first time Portlander.

Wait in line for over an hour for mediocre stale-tasting doughnuts with trendy names, served up by a hip person who couldn't care less.

I say Krispy Kreme is a MUCH better bet. Go to Voodoo for the touristy t-shirt, not the food.

Possibly one of the most over-rated places I have EVER been to..

I went here with my friends on a Sunday afternoon. The line was ridiculously long (30+ people) and I found it odd that a lot of people waiting in line had luggage with them. It seemed as if they were leaving town and they just HAD to get a box of voodoo donuts before they left town. This was very odd. 

I also noted that all the 5 star reviews of Voo Doo donuts originate from locals that live in the Portland area. As if they have all been collectively brainwashed to gravitate towards this place come rain or shine. 

We waiting for about 20 minutes to actually get up to the counter and as we were waiting we heard one of the employees tell a customer " I don't give a sh*t if you take an hour to select your donuts, these people can wait here forever for all I care" . Excellent, I thought! 

When we finally got to the register, we selected 8 of their most popular donuts including the one with bacon. The donuts were good but NOT worth standing in line for so long. And definitely not worth $2.50 a piece. 

Additionally, the bakery and premises were absolutely filthy. The employees were filthy. None of them were wearing hairnets or gloves. The girl who served us looked like she hadn't bathed in days.

No FDA food codes were posted. And they do not accept credit cards.

Additional scores: 

Donuts : 3/5

Customer Service : 1/5

Convenience: 1/5

I went to the one in Portland that doesn't have a mile-long line out the door.  The donut I had was tasty but had been there too long so it was bone dry.  Staff are friendly, huge selection.  I'll try to go when the donuts are fresh.

Long line, extremely horribly rude service, the donut wasnt anything special or better than a Super market donut. The only plus side is How many vegan donuts they offer, otherwise there is no reason to bother with it. Glad I tried it, because of all the hype, but I won't bother waiting 20 min in a line for a donut here ever again.

They are good dougnuts. Nothing special, I get it they are penis shaped and little death men shaped but they are just dounughts. Oh just an FYI i live in portland so the allure of the VOODOO doughnut doesnt work on me. if you want them go get them, it is a fun expirience for first timers but there are better doughnuts in portland.

Voodoo Doughnuts is a must see when visiting Portland. And when I say must see, I mean must see once, one time. I got in line at 10:30 on a Monday and the wait was about 20 minutes. The line is outside, thankfully it was not raining! You are allowed inside when it is your turn to order, the doughnuts are on a menu board on the wall, behind the counter. There is a rotating glass case showcasing the doughnut offerings. Unfortunately, because the line is so long and I could see the menu until it was time to order, I felt great pressure and wasn't able to really see what the shop had to offer. I ordered what I knew, a chocolate bar, bacon maple bar and couple of glazed doughnuts. 

Because we just finished breakfast and were headed back to Seattle, we waited until we got home to eat our treats. The doughnuts were good although I wouldn't say anything special, I have had better. I am a fan of Frost Doughnuts in Mill Creek, north of Seattle. The glazed doughnuts were a loss as they were wrapped in wax paper, which stuck to the doughnuts and was impossible to completely remove.

If I were to visit Voodoo again, I would check the menu online first, as one will not have time to make a decision without annoying everyone in line as well as the staff. I would also only order what could be eaten right then and there, the doughnuts I had just didn't seem to hold up great, maybe they are better eaten immediately. 

Don't forget, cash only! Don't bring too much cash though, this corner seems kind of sketchy, even during the day time.

I kind of already knew this was going to be just another tourist trap. To be honest I'm not really sure what's so weird about Portland to begin with. I've seen and experienced more weird S#!% here in San Diego so I guess coming here was so similar that I didn't get all the "keep it weird" comments. Now to get to the supposedly weird concoctions of this establishment..hmmmm..maybe it's cuz the whole weird concoction thing has been played out here in San Diego that I didn't get it either. Maple bacon doughnut? Yup we've got that here in San Diego too at a place called Donut bar, which attracts just as much patrons as VooDoo. Well anyways I guess every city has to have their one tourist trap and if you want to go just to say you went, then I guess by all means, but I would definitely try a different establishment. Oh and to actually review their doughnuts. My boyfriend had some fritter-peanut butter thing which he liked but he likes anything with peanut butter. He could only eat a quarter of it because he said it was too sweet. My son had a peanut butter-oreo-chocolate glazed raised donut concoction and he said it was way too sweet as well. My daughter had the classic powdered sugar cake donuts and she said it didn't taste nothing special and would go to Krispy Kreme instead. Haha I think that place is overrated as well. I had a voodoo donut. Not very tasty, could eat only the arms and head and couldn't get to the body as it was way too sweet as well. I like my donuts slightly warm too and these donuts are made so far in advance I think due to the amount of customers that they did not taste fresh at all. One good thing though is that my bf got a sticker from there that read "I got VD in Portland." The young probably don't understand but its a good one. Oh and the line wasn't too bad. Took about 10-15 min tops to get to the front.
I don't know what these guys do except maybe really effective marketing. The donuts are overly sweet and pretty average. I would not waste time waiting in line for these frosting laden sugar bombs.

Come for the quirky donuts and touristy vibe, and leave slightly disappointed.

Naturally, as a first time visitor to Portland, I came here. Some of these donuts are interesting concepts like the cereal covered donuts or the ones with alcohol-infused fillings, but overall they're not anything special. I bought two donuts but only ended up finishing one because I didn't really think they were that good. 

There are a lot of really good donut places in Portland. Voodoo just happens to be on everyone's lists because of how quirky a lot of the flavors are. But if I'm going to be perfectly honest, some of the toppings are so overwhelming (like having candy or really sweet cereal on top) that it actually stops you from enjoying what the donut is. Also, no amount of coffee or beverage will be able to save you from how sweet these donuts are.

Keep in mind that this place is cash only (there's an ATM inside the store but it charges convenience fees, as expected). If it's your first time in Portland, come once, then you can probably get by with never coming again.

So I only went here one night with my cousin when the line was surprisingly short, and only because so many people had told us to.  We didn't quite know what everything was, so we blindly ordered several doughnuts.  Most of the offerings are way too sweet for me (and I should say I'm not a big doughnut eater at all), but I did like the basic crullers.  My cousin loved the crullers and was thrilled to learn that a Voodoo is being opened in her home town of Denver.

They've revamped! The last time I was at the downtown location, the entrance was somewhere else, closer to the sex theater next door. 

Anyway, the "sales associate" was in an awful mood and was even witnessed by myself and others yelling, "GOD I'M SO TIRED!" She wasn't really excited or enthused about her job. I love seeing people at work who love their job. But sometimes the opposite is just as entertaining. 

Anyway ,my donuts were fine, as always, but not life changing, as always. 

Donuts run anywhere from $1-2 each. They're cash only. Expect a line, any time you go.

For my money, I prefer Annie's. But I get that Voodoo is an experience.

Only go if your ready for a sugar overload. They recently got rid of my favorite doughnut, the Miami Vice, and so I won't be going as much anymore. Has its time and place but not for all the time. However, if you are traveling to Portland you have never been, DO IT!

Not worth the hype.  I ordered the voodoo dozen where they choose for you. The woman behind the counter was friendly and gave us a good variety of doughnuts including a few cereal ones. Unfortunately all the cereal was stale. I was expecting a lot more.

Visited this place during our trip to Portland. Since the place was highly recommended, me and the mrs walked 15min from Powell's on a rainy day. 

Got a box of doughnuts to go. Requested a bag for the box as it was raining. She gave us a single doughnut doggy bag, a disgusted look and a snarky comment "You asked for a bag, this is the only bag we have". 

Long story short, If you like decent doughnuts with a big side of pathetic and obnoxious Customer Service, do visit.

Would have given it negative stars for the customer service, but Yelp won't let me.

I wanted so much to like the donuts because everyone is carrying their pink voodoo box. The hype is basically for their fun and Portland weird concept of a donut shaped liked a voodoo with cute designs on them. They have a nice variety of top filled donuts- like cereal, coconuts and bacon on them. Sadly every donut shop does these toppings nowadays so I wanted to compare the dough and get newer toppings. The dough was thick but soft. The fillings were minimal did not goo out of my donut. So could use more filling. 

Love their fun concept and their fun atmosphere. Got my fill on this trip.

I've been here twice and the final verdict: "meh". I consider myself a regular donut eater and while this place may top their donuts with the unordinary, the taste is pretty ordinary. There was a wedding going on in the shop which was definitely a new experience. I went for the hype but the long line and the mediocre donuts won't keep me coming back for more.

it's neat to be able to say i've had a "real voodoo doughnut experience". but yeah. that's all i need, just one. 
the doughnuts are quirky in ingredients and names alike, and i have to admit it was funny to say "cock and balls" with a semi-straight face (that's the name of a doughnut, people. IM NOT THAT RANDOM. haha) but they are not the best doughnut i've ever had. not a "wait in line for 30 minutes", that's for sure. 

do it to say you did, then move on with yourself.

The wait was around 40 minutes and when I finally got to try the donuts.... it just tasted like any other donuts.... not so sure what is so special about Voodoo donuts. It might be just me, but I was much disappointed

Another late review, but as the old saying goes "Better late than never". Came here while visiting a friend, we waited in line for 45min, I was excited to try this place. Ordered 3 donuts a voodoo man (pretty good) a Mexican chocolate donut (yuck) and a vegan glaze (yum). It was a good experience, I'm glad I was able to do it. If you are a first timer in Portland I do recommend you try it at least once.

Showed  up around 11 am and waited in in line about a half hour .  I ordered the cock and balls and at the suggestion of the worker taking our order  the dirty old man     and a few more...    the cock and ball was ok  the dirty old man I did not like.   Glad I went but wont be back... was a bit expensive and the donuts while ok were not enough to bring me back .

This place is overrated. It's definitely a fun experience because of its location and they're fun donuts. If you're looking for a real tasty donut that is unique I recommend Bluestar donuts. But other than that I don't really recommend this for locals. It taste like your typical Safeway or Fred Meyer's donuts.

This is a donut shop you visit when you don't live in Portland, you do BS's over this place, they have a couple descent donuts but overall a kids, wanna be hip joint with a line of homeless and some of Portland's weirdo's sweating you for a donut, don't walk out with a box, your the one being the most selfish...that's why you buy one and bounce, if you make that trip...go a lil father into NW Alphabet District to BS 's! Better choices and fits a lot of the snowflake choices they seem to flock to...you will thank me later, Voodoo is just played out, like most cool startups do over time in OR!

Remodeling looks good and handles the crowd much more efficiently.

But they should have a "what's hot" sign over what is hot. I just ate an apple fritter from yesterday, or whenever; it just was. And it was too sugary, but that is an eye of the beholder thing, isn't it?

I went to Portland for my birthday with my best friend and of course this was on my list to try, so we went on Saturday afternoon and waited about 25 minutes to get in. I think with all the hype that is exactly what it is, hype. We got four doughnuts in total and I think the names are cute, but the doughnuts were pretty basic and basically nothing to write home about. The people were nice and accommodating and waiting in line was fun just talking to different people, but I am from California and I think Donut Man is much better and their two specialities are above par then Voodoo Doughnuts. Overall the atmosphere was much better then the doughnuts.

I am going to say right from the start...the love and obsession with Voodoo Doughnuts is lost on me. And don't get me wrong...I love doughnuts. I've eaten a lot of them over the years, as my waistline will attest. I've also eaten them in multiple states and in multiple countries. But...I am a Portlander...born and raised. Alas I never discovered Voodoo when it was a little, small bakery. I found it after the behemoth it has become today. Maybe, as some have attested, it was a great shop back in the day. I can only judge it by the experience I had now.

I come from doughnut loving parents. I, for a time, lived next to a donut shop owned by a little old lady from Guam. It was a little hole in the wall, but her donut bakery made some amazing old school donuts. He would allow me to pop in just after he filled the case and grab a few. Oh those maple bars, old fashioned...the list goes on. Yummy. They were so good they even survived a Krispy Kreme opening literally across the street. 

One night my parents and I decided to venture downtown, late, and try Voodoo. The line wasn't too bad...and we ordered up a pink box filled with a dozen of the various kinds they had so we could sample all the creatively topped treats. The first thing that burned in my memory of my first experience there...the staff were less than friendly. Now perhaps this is part of the whole "punk" vibe the place goes for...but honestly...there is no place for unfriendly or poor customer service E V E R in a public facing business. This attitude extended to even the person's placement of our donuts in the box. Normally one carefully arranged and places the donuts so they don't get mashed or messed up. You'd think this would be even more so important for a place known for his toppings. Well our donuts were basically just tossed in the box....so much so they were a damn mess when we got them home. And no, I was careful with the box...they are donuts, its sacrilege not to be. ;-)

Once home we went into sampling what we got. Now, like most situations, when something is great it can overshadow waiting or poor service or many things. But when you venture through all that and the end result makes you go "WTF?" It really makes the whole thing sink. First, I have to say...before you go all nuts on your toppings, designs, etc....you have to have a solid foundation...in this case a solid donut. To me Voodoo fails at this necessary principle. The donuts themselves were old and stale. Like we were subjected to day or two old donuts. No amount of toppings were going to change that. Out of 12 offerings I cannot tell you a single one that was memorable. Not 1. And everyone involved in this adventure felt the exact same way. The toppings should be enhancing an already great donut. Yet in this case, it seems it's all novelty and no substance. In some ways it felt like the toppings were masking a lousy donut. 

Fortunately I discovered a true gem of the area long after my unpleasant experience at Voodoo. A true NW hole in the wall donut shop in Vancouver called Donut Nook. The place looks like you have time travelled when you walk in...but it's funky and inviting. The staff warm and friendly. And the donuts? Well that's the best part. While you won't get Captain Crunch mashed on them or one shaped like a penis with cough syrup drenched on top....you will get some fresh...amazingly flavor-filled donuts here. Ones we easily go back to and talk about all the time.

Skip the line...there are much better donuts to be had than Voodo

Somewhat overrated and extremely touristy yet still a fixture for our birthday breakfasts. Worth a visit if you haven't been. Also wish they accepted credit/debit cards instead of "cash only". It is an established enough Portland institution that customers should not have to be charged an additional $3 at their ATM if they didn't realize that in 2016 big popular cash only places still existed...

Voodoo Doughnuts is one of those places I hear my friends raving about it for quite a bit and has been told by many it's a must try experience. I find Voodoo Doughnuts to be good but not exceptionally mind-blowing. I mean it's doughnuts, you can't really go wrong with doughnuts. 

I would recommend it if you're visiting Portland or you've never tried it and it so happens you caught them on a day where there is no line. 

However, I personally would not queue an hour for doughnuts.

Very creative donuts, and the store is a really fun environment.  

But the donuts were just ok. Nothing spectacular about them. You're getting Cap'n Crunch or grape jello mix sprinkled on top of what are basically grocery store donuts. 

Come here and enjoy the wacky atmosphere, the long wait, and the hyped aura that is Voodoo. Just don't expect incredible donuts.

Do you know what is better than a Voodoo donut? Literally every other donut on earth. Their cake donuts are the same quality as those packaged Hostess or Little Debbie donuts that have been sitting on the shelf of your local grocery store for god-knows-how-long. The raised donuts are nothing at all to write home about. Crazy toppings? Save yourself the time and hit your local 7-11, take some of their donuts home, and dump your kitchen cabinet on the donut. 

Don't believe the hype. The only time anyone could possibly enjoy this "experience" is if they are drunk, stoned, or just so bought into the fairy tale that they won't admit this place is bogus.
Nothing special about their donuts. I don't know why they are famous! We stood in the line for 20 mins and was not worth it AT ALL!
I thought this place was ok... I think its more about the hype than anything but worth the experience.

The line to get VD wasn't long and/or painful as a few have mentioned when we happened to swing by. But we had to run to refill the meter since we underestimated the wait with all the wishy washy ordering that was going on up front. 

Cash only. Imagine how annoying it would be watching people bust out their debit card for $2.99. (BTW I love that there is no sales tax in this state but PDX sure is aggressive and strict with street parking)

They have a huge variety of donuts from the Froot Loop'd topped to the basic cruller. As far as the donuts we purchased, taste-wise, not bad but nothing special here.

Long line to get in and order. Cloyingly sweet doughnuts with little nuance.  The claim to fame is the toppings (ranging from breakfast cereal to Tang) and the irreverent sense of humor applied in the making and naming of the doughnuts.  It has a rightful place in Portland and can be fun to visit with out-of-towners but there are plenty of other local doughnut shops that offer a better tasting product and much less of a wait.

No idea why people wait in line at this place for a donut. They wait for hours for the same donut you can get from Safeway. If you don't see a line....maybe, but if there is, skip it. You wont miss much.

You know the hype and when in Portland, you got to go to Voodoo's. Honestly, people probably only go for the Instagram pictures because I was not impressed by anything here at Voodoo. The only reason we even STOPPED here was we were looking for Chinatown (which was a dud) and voodoo was right there in front of us. 

The line was short, so the Jen W. and I decided to beeline for it. Standing there, it reminded me of a chinese bakery where the fruitcakes just sit in the center of the store between the cashiers and spin in circles. The donuts were doing the exactly same thing, on a platter spinning and spinning. The decor was pink inside that screamed look at me and give yourself a headache. 

I was really thrown off by the LACK of service here. There were no signs as to what they offered, or what each of the donuts on display was. The girl helping us was in no mood to and we were just trying to find out what's good in the hood. We asked for their "famous" donut and she suggested the Maple Bacon- and so we did. Not impressed because I don't care for donuts like that, bacon was dried and fried to an ashy crisp, and the donut wasn't even fluffy on the inside. 

The hype lacked realness and it's really for the pictures. I mean they looked better than they tasted. I wouldn't waste my time through TSA to bring you back VD's. But there was a good amount of outdoor seating in this alley way right next to the store. Great for hanging out on a nice day. Good try Portland.

I ordered their popular ODB and Bacon Maple Bar. The doughnuts were enormous for roughly $3. Both were surprisingly good, especially the Bacon Maple Bar. However, I did not finish them because I started feeling guilty when I thought about the calorie content. 

I came here around 9 p.m. on a weekday and the line was crazy long and I waited for about 25 minutes. It was my first time there so I did not mind the wait, but going forward, I probably won't do that again. Additionally, the store inside is very, very small and dark and it did not seem very clean.

Overall, its an interesting concept they have here and they are definitely creative, but I would not crave for their doughnuts on a regular basis.

Overhyped donuts that are not worth the wait in line. Most of the donuts, which we ordered one of each, are overly sweet and overly priced. As my friend said, "Looks as though a kid went down the candy aisle and dumped them all on top of donuts. We were looking forward to having. Great creative donuts and were very disappointed and let down. Never coming here ever again, and will not recommend! If possible I would put no stars at all...

A touristy spot with some unique appeal, but certainly doesn't live up to the hype.

We had no line at all on a Mon morning, which from other reviews sounds like we totally lucked out. If I had stood in a 30 min line I would have been extremely disappointed with the results. As it was the donuts were fine, but nothing special as dar as taste or quality. They get high marks for creativity and the kids had fun checking out all the wacky combinations. Staff was pleasant and helpful.

Overall it's a good spot to go once as a tourist, but I wouldn't bother going back. The donuts just weren't that good.

This place has some crazy eccentric decor and long lines.  I got myself a voodoo doll donut because I couldn't help myself but to visit this Portland Icon.  The donut tasted just like any other ordinary donut from any old donut shop. Make your way over to Blue Star Donuts if you're looking for something more unique and tastier.
Dont really understand the lines. These donuts are disgusting.

Very overrated.  Maybe my expectations were too high, but I've visited several times over the last couple decades and all 3 locations including Eugene, and every time they've all been meh.  If you are visiting Portland and 'must do the Voodoo Doughnut Experience' because that's what you heard- try it early in the morning like between 1-2 am (before the bars close) or 3:30-6:00 am.  And expect a line at anytime.  If you don't have the patience to wait in line an average of 45 mins for a mediocre doughnut, try donut byte labs only a block away.  They're the blue food truck amongst many other food trucks, and they're half the price and way better imo.  They taste fresher!  Only negative is that they're only open to midnight.  But really who needs doughnuts after midnight?

Methinks not, indeed. I was curious and popped in when I noticed there wasn't a queue. I got their signature Voodoo Doll donut, as well as the Bacon Maple Bar donut and was so glad I did not order more. Both were way too sweet, almost as if I could feel my teeth rotting from all the sugar. Neither donut lived up to the hype. The donut flavours are creative but that's about it.

The doughnuts are good, however the employees were unkept and the place was filthy, the fingerprints all over the glass and trash all over the floor made me not even want to take a bite... The novelty is there but c'mon folks, pick up a broom and windex now and then, you serve food!!!

Looks over flavour, for sure. The donuts have fun decoration for when you snap selfies, but the taste is extremely average. If you've been to Canada you'll understand when I say they are essentially Tim Hortons quality.

Staff was very friendly, but this place usually has a huge line, and it's cash-only. Over, I'd give it a pass...

Line was long, doughnuts looked good but maybe you should have a sign outside that says cash only. Waiting in line and getting to the front only find out that cash is the only form of payment accepted is ridiculous. We are in 2015, who doesn't take cards! Will never go back!

Of course during our trip to Portlandia we HAD to try Voodoo!!! My boyfriend is the fan of donuts and he was not really impressed. I got a traditional old fashion and it was good, not worth an hour line, but good. Yes you should experience voodoo donuts but don't expect the donuts to be great!

Disappointing.  Not only did we have to stand in line for more than 30 minutes, but were they out of the famed maple-bacon donut!  We opted for the Ol' Dirty Bastard (ODB) and the signature VooDoo donut, both of which were gross.  I found them chewy and not soft, and much too artificial and sugary to eat.

A couple stars for creativity, though.  They do put a lot of thought into how their donuts appear, if not so much thought into how they taste.
TBH not a fan. The iconic voodoo donut was appealing to the eye, but the garnishments and chocolate tasted like plastic. Also my hot chocolate was completely watered down. Disappointed.

We had a big assortment, and honestly...they are just doughnuts. I give them props for different/unique flavors.

The blueberry doughnut was really good, but other than that, nothing out of the ordinary. I wouldn't come back if I visited Portland again.
I do lile the maple bacon doughnuts, but I prefer the Blue Star doughnuts if I'm going to wait in line for some fried dough :)

Total tourist trap complete with long line and random "DJ" hawking bottled water outside, but when hosting folks from out of town, they always ask to go to Voodoo Doughnut ‍

Service is quick and they are cash only. While I generally prefer other donut places in PDX, Voodoo's bacon maple bar is delicious. 

We also got the voodoo doll and the Memphis mafia, but they were way overkill for me.

Minus stars for annoying "entertainment" and people who are indecisive once they get to the counter!
Super long line, it's a must see for anyone visiting Portland, but the donuts taste a bit average. Great decor inside and out !

Visitors to Portland, please don't come here. I made the mistake of bringing my mother and great aunt here when I first moved here. It was dirty and the place was surrounded by homeless people. 

The donuts are interesting, but if you have any food allergies, this isn't the place for you. The way the donuts are stored make food contamination almost impossible to avoid.

Visited this famous doughnut chain on a quiet Friday afternoon. There was a short line out the front but it took us only ten or so minutes to get inside. 

The interior is very doughnut themed kitschy, filled with branded (and somewhat overpriced) merchandise and, of course, doughnuts. 

We were buying for ourselves and friends so we opted for two dozen mixed (their pick). Our server gave us a good combination (though mainly the cheaper options, as I suppose is to be expected). They were very tasty and stylish - with interesting options that offer a nice bite. Would I say that they blew my mind? No. I'd probably prefer a Krispy Kreme, to be frank. But my boyfriend loved them and thoroughly enjoyed the crazy flavour combinations. 

Overall a mixed bag in my mind. Not great. Nor particularly up to the standards I expected. But still... A good snack for a chill Friday afternoon.

I waited 45 minutes to get a couple donuts.  I was warned this place was crowded and I believe i was there at peak tourist season, but still 45 minutes....for donuts????

I tried the Maple Bacon Bar, the glazed raised, and the Lemon Chiffon Creuller (spelling?).  They were all delicious, but not so amazing I wanted to go back during my visit.

One issue there, is they don't have the menu available when you're waiting outside  It's so slow because you can only think about what you want to order when you're basically at the counter.  Even then, on the menu they don't tell you what all the donuts are.  I went ahead and read the menu online before my visit to see what they had, but not everyone does this.  So I can see why it takes so long to order here.

I really wanted to see how they fit up against Psycho Donuts which has been a favorite place of mine to visit on the west coast.  They also have weird donuts, weird people, and weird crap for sale inside.

I mean, it's okay. Not super good, not super bad... just a little overrated. My partner and I were unable to finish our cereal donut orders just because we had a sweetness overload. I did like looking at the Voodoo creme-filled donut! (Alas, I'm not a creme-filling person, so I didn't order it.) Pretty cool decked out place, though! Liked the ambiance. Might not come again as it just strikes me as similar to DK's donuts or something.

When in Portland, eat as the Portlandians eat.

Voodoo Doughnut as most know is a Portland staple, a must see, must try. So, that is what we did. A long line in a cold December morning did 
not deter us, and should not deter you. Just be ready to wait, they do go relatively quick for how packed it is.     

I got the traditional Voodoo Doll filled with Raspberry Jelly. It was good, but didn't really excite me. It seemed hard, not totally fresh. My boyfriend got the Old Dirty Bastard. It was a tasty mouthful. 

Overall, I'd recommend going to see what the hype is all about , but I would not go back.

Stopped here on our last morning in Portland because there was no line, unlike the rest of the weekend. Good donuts, but nothing special...pretty much just ordinary donuts with lots of icing. Very touristy, long lines on the weekends. Would not go out of my way to try them.

Doesn't rate the hype from the Food Network.  The downtown location has zero available parking, yet lines that are blocks long while the second Portland location has plenty of available parking.  Longish line inside the second location didn't take too long.  Maple bacon doughnut was tasty, but not orgasmic as it is hyped.  I've had better elsewhere.  Rap music was loud and off-putting.  I will say that the place fits the neighborhood.  Got a t-shirt as proof I'd been there ...

Review in one word: Overrated. I'm not sure how this place ever became such a staple in the city of Portland, but these doughnuts are average at best. The creativity boarders "lame" as they take normal doughnuts (that aren't even that good) and dip them in chocolate before sprinkling cereal (Captain Crunch, Coco Puffs, Fruit Loops, etc) on to them. Why is there always a (deceptively long) line? Because their store is tiny. They also only accept cash, which draws tons of Portland's homeless to linger outside because they KNOW you have cash if you just came out of there. Let's also talk about the prices... $3.00 for a bacon maple bar with bacon that looks like it came from an airplane breakfast? Pass. On a positive note, the staff was nice and cheerful. Unfortunately, the final verdict is that it's a waste of time and money.

Note: I've been informed that Voodoo was one of the first doughnut places to start doing creative toppings on doughnuts, is a shame that there are now places that do it better. Props though, for the original creativity.
I'm not standing in that redic line ever for this. Just go the one on Sandy if your from here and let the tourist wait an hour

Donuts are very sweet and too much to handle. Not the best donuts in the world. 3/5 for donuts. Butttt the hype is there. And it's unique. Worth getting as gift for donut lovers back home. Expensive donuts. I like captain crunch and the Oreo one. 

Careful the area around is ghetto. 

Place accepts only cash. They have atm in store.

They stopped making curly doughnuts... those are my favorite. This is a very well known place to take friends from out of town. I would say it is great for the experience. but for taste go to blue star doughnuts. The cereal on the doughnuts tasted stale...

Not a big donut person but did it for novelty. Long lines. Quick service. Donuts didnt seem fresh, not stale but almost cold as if they dont have a heater in this joint. Bacon Maple donut was solid. Captain Crunch Donut is a must. Do try to avoid the Grape sprinkled donut though. Looks pretty. Sounds good. Tastes like dishwasher fluid.

It's overhyped. Really cool scene and helpful staff, but I think the doughnuts are uninspired. Not terrible, and they come in humorous and creative shapes, but nothing special in the taste department.

I am a New Orleanian and felt right back at home when visiting Voodoo Doughnut it downtown Portland. 

New Orleans is known for great food, correct? Doughnuts are no exception - we have fantastic ones! But this review is not about how visiting Voodoo Doughnut transported me back home due to it's fantastic product, nah. This is how visiting Voodoo made me feel right at home due to:
-A strip club located next door
-Crowds of homeless begging for money steps from the entrance
-Cash only accepted 

Cash only is fine by me. I am used to that craziness. 

But, can I munch on a doughnut and cup of coffee without being asked for money & having my offering of food turned down by the homeless (it was excessive)? Or having them scream at customers through the windows? 

The  trip club next door - watching the women arrive for work - that was just amusing. 

So the doughnut...I give the Voodoo 3 stars for product creativity and 1 star for product quality. It was just...not good.

WOW! people actually wait an hour for a Doughnut got a few and it was OK It was creative Doughnut but I went home to Hollywood and told our local Doughnut guy to make them and he did....Not impressed at all its just a over the the top Doughnut not at all worth the wait.. stop by look in and the local porkland locals and just keep walking and go home and have a Doughnut at home from your local place it will be just as good..

Voodoo make u doo doo...I had to have a taste of the doughnut hype seeing as how my boyfriend and I are here in Portland and every thing you eat tastes like heaven here! We stopped in today....the line wasn't as bad as we had anticipated, so that was cool. However, the employee working the register that takes !CASH ONLY! was handling our doughnuts with his bare mitts...and as if that's not bad enough...he wasn't putting them into that cool little pink box....He was setting them on the dirty counter in front of us! Anyhow, we ate the funky fun treats and too say the least they were good doughnuts....but immediately after my boyfriend and I both got a voo doo curse in our guts. We both feel sick and have diarrhea....thanx voodoodoo!

Everyone said this is a must-go place so we just joined the line when randomly found that it is just at the corner. Waited for 30 minutes and got a chocolate old-fashioned. Delicious at first but when I was trying to finish it, it started getting too sweet. If I have no solid plan and just feel bored I think I wouldn't mind waiting in line and get a doughnut next time visiting Portland.

It's a very good gimmick ; the donuts are really cool to look at, they all have hilarious names, and the atmosphere is very relaxed and casual. Taste wise though, they're decent. Nothing extraordinary about the actual quality, but a fun place to meet up with friends for decent donuts and an instagram photo.

After getting lost and working up an appetite by walking the maze at Powell Bookstore, we headed out for Voodoo doughnuts. Supposedly this is the spot where out of town visitors HAVE to check out before they leave Portland. From what I hear, Voodoo Doughnut is splattered all over the Food Network on various shows. 

The line was about a solid 20-25 minute to just get into the store. Keep in mind that there is a line inside the store but isn't long because the store itself is quite small. Does anyone notice the XXX raunchy theatre next door? I was just standing there in line, trying to find some shade when I look up and the sign reads, "Hentai" on such and such days/times. Funny, I didn't over hear anyone else in line say a thing about this theatre. I even saw some dude come out of there and he had the "You didn't see me!" look on his face.

Eventually, we finally got into the place and it's only about 1-2pm now. At this point of time, I tell my friend to get me the maple bacon bar since that's what everyone raves about. I had to rush out to the car because our parking time limit was running out. The parking nazi was walking around and handing out tickets with a smirk. "I gotta go check that biznatch! Maple bacon bar please! See you at the car." and so I jam.

My friend comes out with that noticeable pink doughnut box but I noticed her grim face right away. The words I didn't want to hear was spoken, "They ran out of the maple bacon bar." WTF??? It's only 2pm and you're out of it already! Granted, it's damn popular but that sucks. I settled with the powdered rasberry filled doughnut that tasted like any other Cambodian doughnut shop in So Cali. She got the c*ck & balls doughnut for her friend which was for her bday. That's always a good laugh (picture to come). Had to be a huge chocolate one too.

Anyway, I'm not sure if it was worth the wait. Honestly, I'm like whatevers. They didn't have what they're known for so that was a bust. As a tourist, I can say I've been there but that is that.

CASH ONLY.

If Portland was reincarnated into a doughnut shop, it would look exactly like Voodoo Doughnuts.  Let's face it, Voodoo Doughnuts would not be what it is if it was placed in any other city.  That being said, I ONLY go to Voodoo if I am with an out of town guest.  

While I am not a doughnut fan to begin with, Voodoo just doesn't do it for me.  Big props on pushing the envelope with creative and quirky flavor combos (with names to match) - NOTE: bacon on a doughnut should be a standard around the country.  But when it comes overall eating pleasure, I find myself disgusted after my second bite.  Sugary and overly rich, eating these doughnuts for me becomes more of a chore than a choice.  

From the visitors perspective, I get it.  National media attention, late night hours, outrageous offerings,  one-of-a-kind doughnuts, etc.  However, eating as a tourist is much different from eating in your hometown.  For goodness sake, I am the guy that ate fugu semen while on vacation!  What I mean is that we are all looking for that singular, foreign experience - and Voodoo provides just that.

If Voodoo is your thing, more power to you!  We all need to do our share to "Keep Portland Weird".  If it wasn't for the superbly strange, the OMG outlandish, and the frighteningly funky, Portland just wouldn't be Portland.  THEN who would we be....Seattle????

I gotta be honest...

After waiting in line for 45 minutes...and after all the hype...I was expecting my Portland Cream (cream filled, chocolate glazed) to be oozing with homemade cream and frosted with homemade glaze- the filling tasted like canned vanilla pudding and the chocolate like a cheap can of Hershey syrup. And the bacon maple bar...I would expect the maple glaze to be above the ordinary, and crumbled bacon would have been much nicer than two strips.

We also ordered the old-fashioned cake, and a french glazed cruller. While these were good, I couldn't say that they were amazing.

Don't get me wrong, VooDoo makes amazing 'average' doughnuts...but they left me wanting more.

But I will give VooDoo props for the funky unique decor and cool doughnut names.

I'll keep it simple: go here for the experience of the wild crazy experimental choices, but go to Blue Star for divine quality donuts. Still come to Voodoo for sure, but grab one donut, eat it, and then for the rest of your life go to Blue Star. Very big difference between the two.

After a few trips to Portland and avoiding the long wait, I broke down and finally tried Voodoo. Once you finally make it inside take some time and absorb the environment, its a trip, but also check out the menu. There is a case with every dough nut on display so if you are having trouble picking, just take your time and ask when you get to the counter. The selection is overwhelming but the couple we got were generally good. Sugar is used liberally so hopefully you have a sweet tooth.  I think the account for 50% of Pixie Stick's yearly sales.....

I would definitely have a maple bacon bar again, just not sure the wait was worth it.

Of course I was expecting to be blown away by the doughnuts here, but unless you have a ridiculously intense sweet tooth, prepare for some overly sugary doughnuts. I tried the gay bar, and while tasty, the fruit loops on top has gone entirely stale. Despite waiting in line for 15 minutes at 3 PM, I would say I wasn't overly impressed with the food. That said, this place is a Portland institution. A world of kitsch and counter culture. So you should go. Eat a doughnut with a slightly vulgar and/or offensive name, and enjoy it for what it is :)

Gimmick. Weird. Not a great doughnut to start and then loaded with weird. 
They serve pretty incredibly stale product. 
I had to give my chocolate bar back and ask for another doughnut because the outside was literally hard. 
Whatever.

I visited portland from seattle and brought back 2 dozen doughnuts for my co-workers at a restaurant. While they were definitely delish (and I basically got whatever I wanted for the rest of the night), I'm not sure they were worth the hour long wait. I appreciate the creativity with different flavors (orange sherbet was a great one) and they did basics well too (maple bars are my hands down favorite and they did it justice) but this place is all about hype. I think if I had gone in with lower expectations, then I might have loved it more, but I was sort of expecting  - as was the entire line of people - to be awed...and I wasn't really :(

This joint has become a novelty for me.

To be in line for hour in a cold rainy day while being stared/begged by transients to give them money/donut is pretty crazy.

As for the actual pastry, it is pretty good, but being deadly honest I would not wait 10 minutes for these donut.  There are very nice bakerys around in the city of Portland I would go to rathger then wait here.  

This joint is more of a tourist spot for me.  I would bring my out of state friend here and enjoy the wacky donut that PDX has to offer.

My friends get a good kick out of the donut design and the naming and all.  They get shocked to see that infamous bacon maple bar.

BUT!  

The bacon maple bar is good though...*gasp*(shame on me yeah I know! lol)

If I see no line, I would go here.  There are some time frames that exists where lines are not there.  That would be your best bet to enjoy this wacky voodoo cursed pastry.

trash. 

they give glamour doughnuts a bad rep. tell me if this sounds appealing -- throw random bits of cereal, sprinkles, chocolate kisses, and/or slap a piece of bacon and smother with frosting to make a decorative doughnut (i.e., voodoo doll, bacon maple doughnut). this place is nothing, but hype. maple bacon doughnuts should be bacon infused sugary glaze, not a crispy bacon slab. 

save yourself the near-"not worth it"- heart attack and just go to NYC doughnut plant. 

outcome? murderous rage.

Unfortunately, these donuts are hugely overrated. I had the viscous hibiscus donut and the 'viscous hibiscus' coating tasted distinctly artificial / chemically while the donut itself tasted chalky. However, I was impressed at how quickly the line moved and how friendly the staff were. They've also got some fun flavors and interesting-looking donuts -- wish they tasted high quality.
Stand in a  v e r y   l o n g   l i n e    to eat overpriced sugar and fat?  no thanks,

You wait in line forever because everyone say "you like haaaaave to go to Voodoo Doughnut derp da derp derp derp."

I had the maple bacon doughnut with old tiny bacon, artificial flavoring,  overly rich sugaration. It's a doughnut so it's supposed to be sweet...I get it.  This was overkill.

Some of the other selections included such choice ingredients as cartoon breakfast cereals from the 80's thrown on top, so mine was rather high-brow in comparison.

Here's the thing: it wasn't fresh, it was way too sugary, and all in all it was just a crappy doughnut.

I was really excited to visit this place but when I came, they said cash only, the total was 10.35,  i paid in cash 10 dollar bill with the exact change. They said they couldn't take the coins because they don't accept pennies. They should state that somewhere in the establishment. Its not like I was trying to pay in ALL Pennies,  i only tried giving her 5. I'll never come here again! Voodoo doughnuts is all hype!

Long lines so it must be good right?

Note: cash only!

These doughnuts are difficult to get to. Parking is a real problem here. We had to drive around for about 10 minutes before we found parking. We also had to pay for parking. So you might want to think about that if you're wanting to drive out to this place.

The doughnuts have an interesting Voodoo twist. There are a lot of great choices that you won't normally get from a doughnut shop, like the Memphis Mafia Doughnut that has peanut butter and is on a banana fritter.

The kids got a sprinkle doughnut and the m&m doughnut. My oldest kid finished her sprinkle doughnut. But my younger ones didn't really like theirs and only ate a few bites.  My wife got the maple bacon doughnut and thought it was really good.

I really liked the voodoo theme, but the taste of the Doughnuts was nothing special. 

The line for his shop was insane! We waited for about 15 minutes to order. But once you order, you get your doughnuts almost immediately.

The atmosphere was kind of adult. Not rated R, but close.

Great novelty place to stop by and get your sugar fix.  There can be a long wait but we scored when we went after dinner at about 7:00PM.  We had front row parking, had we not we would have kept on driving.  There was still a line but went pretty fast and we only had to wait maybe 15 mins.  The area itself is not the nicest, there are many homeless people in the area or waiting right by the front of the line which was sad.  It is next door to an adult theater.

The selection of doughnuts were fun and varied. There are a large assortment of t shirts, mugs, sunglasses, stickers etc that you can purchase in addition to your doughnuts.

The doughnuts themselves are good, not the best an if you get the variety of flavor really sweet. We're still glad we stopped by and tried them and if we lived in town would probably still pick them up for a party... Who doesn't like sugar!  We ordered, the pot hole, cruel las, old fashion, Texas, cocks n balls, dirty old bastard, the fruit loop one, the coffee one, Reese's one, sorry forgot all the names!

A must try at least once for the experience!

Overpriced and underwhelming. Peach fritter had peach COLORED icing on it. Zero peach flavor. Bacon maple bar was horribly overcooked (to my liking) Other items are either just gimmicky or dumb.

Not worth going out of your way.

It all started with the Voodoo Doughnut Maple Bacon beer. All the hoopla about the beer made it mandatory for us to visit the actual store during our visit to Portland. The maple bacon bars are novel and delicious, and so were the maple and chocolate cream-filled doughnuts. I'm allergic to peanuts, so half the menu was off-limits for me, but my fiance tried the Memphis Mafia. For a doughnut that was almost $5, he said it was definitely filling and very rich. I'm going to take his word for it.

We also got the cocoa-puff covered chocolate cake doughnut. Sadly, I have to say that my love for Voodoo right about died right there. The cocoa puffs were extremely stale, and the cake doughnut was extremely sub-par. We ended up throwing it away.

Next time, I'm going to take my aunt's advice and try Dizzy Dean's in Eugene, instead of trekking over to Voodoo, running around downtown Portland to find an ATM for cash, and waiting in line for sub-par doughnuts. Sorry, Voodoo, you were good, but you were too disappointing to be worth it.

The line is sooooo long. The wait is sooooo long. The donut are expensive. But the flavor is just whatever. A little disappointed. But glad we could take this place off our checklist. Voodoo donut is so popular! Maybe they use Voodoo...

They don't have anyone standing outside giving out menus. So we didn't know what to order, being first timers. So we panicked and went to their website to look for the menu. Because we noticed once you're inside the line is short and it didn't leave you much time to look at the donut selection. 

They have unique shaped donut. People's favorite are probably the Voodoo shaped donut. My personal favorite is the penis shaped! It was funny. It's like a Boston cream donut, but in a different shape. It is the most expensive of the donut that we got. It was the biggest one. 

One of our friend that lives there told us that he sometimes come here after it closes or before it opens (I can't remember). They'll give you a full bucket of old donut from yesterday and you'll only have to pay 10 dollars.

HONESTLY GUYS! It's just a donut. I'm really not sure what the hype is about this place. The line is long, but it goes by quickly. There are a million different donut variations to choose from, and I'll definitely give them props for being so creative. You are bound to find one that speaks to you. 

My boyfriend and I ordered the tropical one with coconut flakes on top. There was a custard inside, as well as some fruit jam. Honestly, it tasted just as I thought it would be like: a donut. I could get donuts at Ralph's. Come here for the hype, I guess?

Yup...its a donut shop.  If you are looking for a great donut just stop by take pictures and keep walking.  We went in because at 9am there was no line.  The workers were friendly and welcoming, but the donuts were not very good.
Not a huge fan of the hype donuts, but their French cruller is pretty darn good.

Should you at least go to the downtown location once?  Yes.
Is there a reason to return?  Not really.  
If someone hands me a tang donut from here I will gladly eat it but I will not wait in line or go out of my way to get one.
I do have a better recommendation for you- Sesame Donuts located in SW Portland.  Corner of Oleson and Beaverton Hillsdale Hwy.  Mmm yummy and fresh goodness!
Overrated. Don't stand in line for a pink box.
Just, gross. A tourist attraction that gives the Portland food scene a bad reputation.

How is this what my city is famous for?  Is it that impossible in other cities to find a mediocre doughnut with a bunch of shit stuck to it?  Can't anyone dump a box of coco puffs or a wad of bacon on a completely average doughnut?  
For anyone who isn't already aware, the doughnuts are in all those disguises to hide the fact that they taste like shit!
There are such better doughnuts out there and you don't even have to wait in line for them.  
Voodoo grew an amazing reputation thanks to all the super trashed folks looking for  midnight snacks and has been coasting ever since without having to produce anything that actually tastes good.
Good for Voodoo, but as a local I would never go back there.

I had a lot of fun at this place mainly taking pictures of the donuts. I got the classic voodoo doll donut and it was probably the coolest looking donut I've gotten. It did however taste a little generic.It was filled with raspberry jelly which was pretty good but srill kind of like a typical donut with chocolate frosting that you could find at any donut store. I was expecting the taste to be a little more impressive but the experience was very cool

I get why every tourist goes here, word of mouth can take a long time to die. They were once a unique and Portlandly experience, but now they have locations outside of Oregon and its all about brand image and the gimmicks. Honestly, these are some of the worst donuts I have ever tasted and the service is barely passable every time. There are lines every where in Portland, but this line is not worth waiting in. If you are a tourist and want a unique and delicious donut experience I suggest Pips or Blue Star any day.
Yes, it is a tourist trap. Yes, the lines are terrible. But the donuts are good, and have been for quite some time.

As they say, "when in Rome..." Well since we were in Portland we decided to try Voodoo, of course! However I was pretty disappointed by the actual donuts. They weren't really anything special other than some having weird decorations/shapes. I felt that the donut I ordered (Portland cream) was really sweet both inside and out. The dough itself to me tasted very similar to that of a donut you can find in a grocery store bakery, and I felt the cream was pretty much just sugar. I felt donuts we got at other places (Blue Star and Pip's) were way better and had shorter lines. The only thing this place has going for it is brand name recognition, sadly.

Can't go to Portland without trying the famous Voodoo Doughnut. Honestly I think this place is overrated - very hyped up. With the long lines and wait times (we waited in the rain for about an hour), I just lost the special anticipation I had for Voodoo.

Donuts were decent. My friends and I ordered 8 donuts total - forgot what they ordered, but I got the Dirt Doughnut and the Lemon Chiffon Crueller Donut. I would advise to eat your donuts within 24 hours as they became too soft and a little too squishy the second day :/
I brought my cousin from Cali here and when we opened the door a staff member yelled, "close the door"!!! There was like 10 of us and I was embarrassed. I wanted to love you

I am not sure what the hype is about. Yeah the donuts are cute looking (voodoo man) or hilarious (they have one that looks like a big dick) but overall taste wise it is just whatever. I would much rather have a Krispy Kreme original glazed over this overpriced gimmick. 

The line is long and there are tons of hippy buns outside who actually look down on you.

Voodoo doughnuts was a minor disappointment to me, I had heard so much about it that i really was looking forward to get some crazy ass delicious doughnuts. 1st of all its a little hard to find , maybe not to a native portlander...portlandite? but to a visitor of your fine city I walked by its intersection twice , maybe they need a bigger sign maybe i need better glasses but whatever , my anticipation was at an all time high as we waded though the sea of  begging vagrants ("back off" I  yelled "my loose change is for some doughy goodness") and into the small 10ft by 10ft enclosure that is voodoo . My eyes widened at the sight, dozens of doughnuts on hundreds of trays stacked on their racks like little skyskrapers and I my friend was going to the penthouse. There was a long line so I used the time wisely to narrow down my decision , should I get the maple bacon bar....nah dont want meat on my treat , the cock doughnut ....nah, its my week for girls.... and then i saw it The chocolate peanut butter oreo doughnut, that would be the one for me. After what felt like hours (real time 10 minutes) i finally got up to the front and made my order,either the cashier dude was deaf ,foreign or just plain stupid because he handed me a vanilla frosted doughnut, and im like hmmm I said chocolate peanut butter oreo , he said oh and then handed me another one with sprinkles. I was like buddy i wanted that one (pointing to the CPB&O) and he said oh the one with oreo , I said you got it sparky. My cell then rang i answered it gave my GF the money to pay him and took the call outside. she got our doughnuts boxed and we headed off to someplace less bummy, and when i opened the box ...surprise vanilla frosted with oreos(at least) . I was too hungry to walk all the way back so i said fuck it and ate it anyway. It was great but i could only imagine how my real choice would have tasted. Maybe next time voodoo maybe next time.....oh yea this place was cash only if anybody wanted to know

I was excited to try this Donut place bec of its reviews.  Sad to say it's overrated.  Donuts are overly sweet, I guess it's not for me. Even Anthony and Joe who loves their sweets are not impressed by them.  We would much rather stick with my plain old donut at Krispy Kreme.  

Thankfully there was no line when we got there, otherwise it would've been a complete waste of my time.

We purchased 4 different donuts - and I found all four to be way too sweet.  (I generally love any sweets.). If you're in the neighborhood, and don't mind the long line, then try it.....but don't go out of your way.

Voodoo is neither a must-do for Portland visitors nor are the donuts very good. They are kooky, but very mediocre donuts at best. I tried them a couple times back before 2010 and again last night, when there was no line. I still don't really understand why people still line up for this place or take boxes on the plane, when we have such great donut places competing (especially Blue Star with a downtown location and Tonalli's on Alberta). The donuts are way too sugary and the custard is terrible. Sure, go in if there is no line and you want a donut late at night, since they are open 24/7, but it's definitely not worth waiting for.

The first time I heard about this place I was SO excited to try it. We came by at 6am on our way out to the Columbia river gorge so thankfully there was very little wait. I got the Captain my captain which is a raised donut with vanilla frosting and captain crunch on top. The donut wasn't bad (says the non donut lover) but the cereal was stale which was disappointing. All in all its a funny unique spot to check out but not a whole lot more.

They are okay.  
Very unique, but not tasty for sure...
I miss Bob's in SF...

This review is coming in super late, but I wanted to write down my thoughts now that they've come back to me. The specialty donuts here have a pretty nice flavor to them. The selection of donuts is really varied as well, both in toppings and in the shape of the doughnuts. 

What I will say about some of the doughnuts though is that they can have a kind of staleness to the toppings. The cereal toppings in particular you can tell the cereal itself isn't exactly fresh. 

Through no fault of the restaurant also, the wait can be super long for donuts due to it being a Portland tourist attraction. I'd definitely recommend going just for the experience, but don't expect to be blown away.
The donuts are fun, no question, but they're not incredible in terms of taste ... it's more of a novelty thing than a delicious thing.

It's a freakin donunt. This place is popular because other people think it's popular. 

It has it's charm, no doubt. The atmosphere is nice, the glittery wall is entertaining. There's plenty of "weird" portland to look at while waiting 45+ minutes for some sugary bread.

The donuts are tasty and creative - but c'mon. It's not worth the wait after one visit.

I'm glad I saw it once; I'll never go back.

*** Cash only ***

Below are some of reasons why this place is REALLY hyped up:

* During the first couple of months when Voodoo Doughnut just started (2003), they actually sold NyQuil Glazed doughnut and Vanilla Pepto Crushed Tums doughnut. Well both doughnuts got FDA's attention and FDA told them to stop making doughnut filled with OTC drugs.

* Back in 2011, they made the World's Largest Box of Doughnuts (http://voodoodoughnut.com/blogging/voodoo-doughnut-makes-worlds-largest-box-of-doughnuts/).

* Voodoo Doughnut appeared in Anthony Bourdain's "No Reservations" & Season 1 of "Man vs Food".

* You can also cater and request for a legal wedding ceremony at the selective Voodoo Doughnut locations (host up to 9 people at this original Voodoo location for $300).

* Weird doughnuts (e.g. doughnut shaped like a vodoo doll [Voodoo Doll doughnut], doughnut shaped like a certain organ of the male reproductive system [Cock-N-Balls doughnut], etc).

I came here pretty early and there was already a line formed at 7:30 AM. This is pretty much a grab-and-go doughnut shop with few picnic tables located just outside of the shop. If you really like this place and want to buy some gifts, then they also sell souvenirs like baseball tees, water bottles, hoodies, baseball caps, beanies, and panties. Yes I said it ... panties.

***

Captain My Captain ($1.75): Basically a Cap'n Crunch cereal donut ... most specifically, a cold donut covered with a fairly sweet layer of white sugar coating. Too sweet for my taste. (2/5)

Bacon maple bar ($3): This donut is their best seller. Just like Captain My Captain, it also tasted cold ... just think of a maple bar slapped with two pieces of cold bacon. Still tasted slightly sweet, but bacon maple bar was slightly better than Captain My Captain. Cold donuts just don't taste good. (2.5/5)


***

Count me out ... I am not a fan of Voodoo Doughnut and I personally like Blue Star Donuts a bit better (most Blue Star Donuts are not as sweet as Voodoo's).

P.S. - Soon Voodoo Doughnut will be opening up their first LA shop located in the Universal CityWalk (http://www.latimes.com/food/dailydish/la-dd-voodoo-doughnuts-bierbeisl-cleo-20160516-snap-story.html).

OK - I think a 5 star review is overboard. 

While visiting Portland I knew I had to stop in and check this place out. I heard amazing things.. did they ring true? For the most part.

Here's what I knew to expect:
The place was covered with strange art, visited by tourists from all over, and most importantly, the donuts were "weird".  (Thanks Food Network!)

Here's what I found upon going there:
Most people ARE tourists. This place isn't quite special enough to warrant a return visit unless you're bringing a Voodoo Doughnut virgin. The line is long and when you finally get up to order you can't decide what you want. NOT because everything looks delicious though. Much to my dismay, I thought a lot of the choices were too weird.. almost weird JUST to get attention. (This is coming from someone who eats bull penis, alligator, bone marrow, frog's legs, you name it..I'll eat it!). But c'mon... TANG sprinkled on a donut? Some of the ideas are original.. some are just stupid and barely edible. 

In summation I recommend you visit this place if you're visiting Portland. It's a Top 10 "must-see" but don't expect to get the best donut of your life. (You can get THAT in Seattle at Top Pot). The donuts are odd and funny to take photos of but it pretty much ends there. If I lived a block away from it I'd still probably make it over there once a year when someone was visiting and I had to take them to the touristy spots. Other than that.... yeah - total miss. I was disappointed.

Voodoo? Or boohoo? I honestly don't get the hype! Maybe because it's pink and attractive from a distance? The doughnuts are bleh. No unique taste to them...The presentation of their doughnuts could use some help too...and I hate how they packaged the doughnuts! Sloppy and messy...I now understand why locals don't even recommend going...we went at an odd hour...no lines! Thank goodness...just a bunch of hungover individuals chillin' outside.

OK so this is a tourist trap. Anyone who is going here for the donuts that lives here is bringing an out of town friend that just wanted to try it. I know that's why we went when we first moved here :) It's a quirky, cool place which should definitely been tried at least once. If you are looking delight your palate, there are many other choices.

The whole process of ordering is crazy since you have no idea which donut is which based on the name or what's in the case. The prices are reasonable, staff a little harried which is acceptable based on the crowds.

Cash only.

I happened to see Voodoo come up here and had to comment.   This place has some kind of curse on it for sure.  I recall walking into this tiny hole in the wall dump next to an equally dumpy adult only theater about five or six years ago and there was maybe two people in the joint.  One of my son's said he heard they had a maple bar with bacon on it and I thought why in the hell on earth would I want to put something like that into my mouth?  I ordered something I could relate to, he had the sugared pork.  

I may have been back one time since as frankly it's a doughnut shop for god sake; it's not some ancient monument like Stonehenge or the Pyramid of Giza, but passing by there today you will see lines of people longer than what you will ever see at the Museum.

I travel a bit and it is not uncommon to see people at the airport waiting at the gate holding a box of Voodoo doughnuts to take thousands of miles away!   I tell you the owners must practice Voodoo and they turn people into zombies who eat only doughnuts or something.  I want to learn how to market a product that has lost all of its appeal from decades of "it's time to make the doughnuts" to driving people to come from every continent to stand in line for the same boiled in oil, sugar coated dough ball that is available in every city in America sans Bacon.

Anyway, I don't mean in any way to take a doughnut from your mouth or a buck from Voodoo, but please at least eat them fresh.  I love NY/NJ pizza more than doughnuts and you won't find me carrying pizza across country; now maybe if it was a Voodoo pizza---hmmm.

Eh, it's basically a stop for tourists to come and take a food-selfie. The lines are often completely ridiculous and no where near worth it for the quality of the donuts they have. Granted a couple of them are fairly decent quality and taste-wise, but a majority of them are more for entertainment or novelty purposes rather than for flavor. I would rather go to a place that has really good donuts than to wait in line for an hour to get a penis shaped donut or a donut covered in stale fruit loops.

This is apparently a "must visit" in Portland. Thankfully the hubby and I went on Monday morning right before the rush (10am). I had the Captain My Captain (Captain Crunch cereal doughnut) and he had the Dirty Bastard (Oreo peanut butter doughnut). They were both delicious, but my enjoyment certainly would have been much much lower if I'd had to wait in a long line. I highly recommend timing your visit to skip the rush.

Prices were not bad - we paid $4.50 for two doughnuts and a small milk. 

Tip - this place does NOT take credit cards. CASH ONLY!
Didn't get a chance to eat any of the donuts because it was a 25+ minute long line but all the locals we talked to said to go to Blue Star Donuts instead!

I saw them on the Travel Channels in those food shows. It looked like a fun place and the doughnuts look very creative. So I went to their downtown location when I was visiting Portland and couldn't believe I was in line for almost 30 minutes. Finally got in and to my dismay, they only accept cash! I was very embarressed and upset, since I didn't have any with me. Still curious about their doughnuts, I went to their other location and this time got cash. It was ok. More of a novelty. But I did like the fact that they carry vegan doughnuts for my lactose intolerant boyfriend and family. My only suggestion to the owners...Get a credit card machine!!!

First of all I have to be fair I'm not a huge donut person so I wasn't expecting much...and I didn't get it. All the donuts we got were so sickly sweet they hurt my teeth. They definitely had creative and different flavors that you won't find anywhere but like captain crunch. This place just wasn't my thing. The place it's self is  quirky and cute and the stuff was friendly and helpful. Maybe their other locations are better.
go to delicious donuts on grand, unless you want to show off the pink box or need a phallic shaped donut.

Probably wouldn't come back to this tourist spot. The hugely popular Voodoo Doughnut was crowded and a bit dirty. There are better donut shops in Portland. Give them all a try. No need to buy a dozen at each stop.

Note: I felt like my Voodoo Doll donut may have had traces of nuts. I had a slight reaction after a small bite.

Donuts are good and the staff are knowledgeable. When I went in the music was so loud I can barely think. Aloud alternative grunge type music I think everyone can enjoy a good donut however I think their marketing to a very narrow group of people. Otherwise the music would be a little bit more broad spectrum and at a comfortable listening volume. They are cash only so not really convenient to modern transactions. It was okay but definitely did not live up to the hype. Everyone should go just so they could say they went, but honestly I don't get it.

Very much something that you have to do when in Portland, but just once. 

One of those places that transcends the actual food served there. Standing in line is an event! Getting inside is an event! The hip divey pizza parlor vibe is something you have to behold! The employees who are infinitely cooler than you will ever be, but still very nice, given the number of people they have to deal with in a given day are awesome! The donuts are.....ok. I liked the maple bacon donut the best since it's a classic combination, the others seemed like forced novelty. 

Breakfast cereal on a donut sounds like a good idea, but is there anyone who can eat cap'n crunch without letting it soften in milk at least a little first? I was terrified for the roof of my mouth and my teeth. Some of them, like the cock and balls are funny renditions on classic donuts, but the thing is that they're mostly very sweet and if I'm willing to do without some novelty I can stop at nearly any other donut place on the west coast, (yeah, I had to specify west coast, I don't think NYC would know a decent donut if it slashed their tires), preferably run by vietnamese people and get something better, without standing in line.

So yeah, worth it once, for the novelty, and maybe if you're in the area and want a snack and there's no line then it might also be worth a stop. I think if I lived PDX it would be one of those places that would kind of piss me off because I know that every visiting friend and relative is going to want to go there and then I'd have to act excited to stand in the line again, for an inferior donut.

I don't get it. worst raised donuts I have had. Old fashion ok...The donut with rice krispies was not bad but I have had much better donuts. They were out of the maple bacon donut ...that sounded pretty good. Huge line of stoners each time i passed by. I wish I would of read the previous reviews before I ate here !!

Tourist trap. 

In all honesty these donuts just aren't all that great. It seems like they're a big fan of just putting various kinds of cereal on donuts. 

The bacon maple bar is good.

I went for a night run to Voodoo, and I had no idea how "shady" the block was. It was only about 9pm, but I was kinda scared to get out of my car. At that time of night, there was no wait and I was the only person in the store. So It could be a good time to go. But just be weary of the homeless and drunk kids lounging all around outside.

For a tawdry post-apocolyptic punk-rock sugar buzz, this is probably the best place in the world.  VD offers an array of goofy choices (including the "cock and balls doughnut," which my server thoughtfully described as "a doughnut that looks like a cock and balls") I've never seen anywhere else.  I even saw a few cockroaches on the coffee table thingie where you fix your drinks.  Nice.  We went in the afternoon to avoid the long lines.  I had a maple bacon eclair.  Delish!
It's great for a tourist visit but the actually quality is average.

Voodoo Doughnut...I had high expectations! All I can say is, Eh...

I heard this was the place to go when in Portland, so I decided to check it out. I did my research too--made sure to get cash (who carries cash nowadays??) and was prepared to stand in a ridiculously long line.

After being accosted by several homeless people (probably because they knew you had to have cash on you to go to Voodoo), I arrived at the historic site. Luckily, there was barely a line and only had to wait a few minutes...inside (it was raining, so I was grateful for that). The variety can be overwhelming; I didn't know which one to choose. But as a sucker for anything with peanut butter, I opted for one with peanut butter drizzled on top.
