I was super excited as I sat down to eat outside the shop (again, approached by more homeless people). I have to say that the doughnut did not taste fresh or warm...it was hard to get down. I was expecting a melt-in-your-mouth moment, and it just wasn't there. Maybe it was just the day or my choice, but I wasn't impressed.

I will give it kudos for having vegan options...it allowed my brother to partake in the experience.

I heard that the locals go to a different doughnut shop, I just didn't catch the name. Maybe next time!

They're okay. But nothing special. Highly overrated, which means they do a great job of advertising and promoting themselves. 

Got the famous donuts including the bacon maple, and the voodoo one. Both were pretty standard donuts.

Ok, we went here because of the enormous amount of reviews. The location is downtown near the waterfront and chinatown, the titles of the doughnuts are catchy but the flavors mask the doughnut taste. If you have ever had a malasada, voodoo doughnuts are no match. You should try it to blend in with everyone else or to be the favor of a party but not try it because you are a cop and want to taste the best donut Portland has to offer.
diferent but not that great.....more of a novelty then quality food
Interestingly overrated and not worth a long wait... But great to pop into before 7am to get a mixed box on the way to work. Actually pretty good value for money. Don't forget they only take cash!

I have tried voodoo both times I've been to Portland, there's always a long line but it moves pretty fast. Things are little crazy in there so both times I've asked for a dozen that they pick. The second time the girl at the counter was not friendly, I asked for an extra maple bacon, and she gave me one, then she have me about eight donuts that are essentially the same just with different stale cereal toppings. Stale sugar doughnuts with fruit loops, Oreos, fruity pebbles, sprinkles, all stale. They make a decent cake doughnut, try blueberry if that's your thing, and they have pretty good vegan doughnuts. Otter than that I don't think I'll be back.

I had to see what all the hype was about. The line was out the door but it went fairly quickly. After reading all the reviews about the rude employees that don't seem to like customers who ask questions, I felt a little intimidated.  If they don't like the questions, I'm not sure why they don't post menus explaining each donut and what they contain. Seems like if you're going to have customers waiting in a long line out  the door, you would post a descriptive menu on the window to read while you wait. I took my chances and just ordered 3 varieties. The Portland cream, plain glaze, and another one that had rice crispees and peanut butter on top. Sound gross but I asked her for something with peanut butter and that's what I got. The Portland cream was definitely the favorite and very good. The rest were just ok. I will take a hot crispy cream glaze donut any day over these. I'm glad I tried them but I don't need to go back!   
BTW I didn't feel the employees were rude, not overly friendly or welcoming but then again, I don't think I would either dealing with nonstop crowds!

Definitely have to go just for the experience of Voodoo but the doughnuts aren't the best I have ever had and you will wait in line forever! But once you get through the line you will have your pink box and a one of a kind Portland experience. - Make sure to bring cash!!! they don't accept CCs. 
** if you can get the doughnut fresh out of the oven when they are still just a bit warm they are much better!

Boy are these guys great at marketing. You've got to hand it to them -- they nail pop culture. As any PDXer know, the donuts aren't that good. But, the concept is zingy and kids and tourists love them.

This place has huge hype. 

I'm not terribly big on sweets, and as doughnuts go... these are okay...  just okay though. The creativity that goes into making some of the combinations is awesome, I loved the fruit loops on the one I had, and the piece of actual bacon on the other one. But the doughnut itself, minus the toppings, are pretty average. 

I'd say its cool to go, to say you've gone... but don't expect the doughnut to really blow your mind.... the combinations and creativity though are top notch.

Service is key, and this isn't where you want to go. The doughnuts aren't bad, but the service kills the experience. Everyone is extremely rude. When you work at a place that is this popular, you are going to have tourists with questions. It would be nice if you didn't roll your eyes when your customers have questions. Also, don't you dare ask for an extra box for your leftover doughnuts because they will tell you that you need to pay. Go to other doughnut shops if you want friendly service that is actually worth the wait.
I had a bite of the bacon donut after it spent a day on the floor of my friend's car and I still enjoyed it.

Passed through Portland and me and my friends had to stop to get some donuts. I was planning on getting a dozen but I felt totally rushed even tho it wasn't busy at all. The donuts are in a spinning case with no labels so you just gotta guess. The bathroom door had a sign that said 'out of order' but I saw a girl coming out of it so maybe it was just a lie? I asked the cashiers where the closest bathroom was and they replied 'I don't know I'm not from around here.' I couldn't tell if they were messing with me but I had to PEE. anyways when entering I had to step over a homeless junkie who was obviously having withdrawals. The donut was okay I guess. I've been to psycho donuts in San Jose and those are waaaay better and they don't rush you.

It's a donut.

Typically extremely long lines.

Eh. I mean it was a must-see spot in Portland, so it gets three stars (well, 2.5) for a fun, one-time experience. The line was about half an hour on Sunday afternoon. The donuts themselves aren't that noteworthy. Suuuuper sweet. Buy 2 milk cartons per person.

I give it a 4 simply because of the hype factor. I hadn't been to voodoo in a long long time and wasn't impressed the first time around so I figured why not check it out. Fact is EVERYONE seems to be all about voodoo doughnuts. I was with my family, 3 small children my SO and myself and my SO just had to go and check it out and buy a doughnut. Well we got a doughnut each, I got a lemon filled doughnut, my kids got the most sugary eye catching ones they could find and my SO got 2 one bacon something and one I can't remember. I am not a sweets person as it is so when I do get a doughnut it's usually one of three types for me le.on, Apple fritter, or a twist, and mostly my choice depends on how much sweet I think I can handle at the moment. This day it was a lemon filled and it was ok. Not the best I'd ever had but acceptable as far as lemon filled doughnuts go. Would I run all the way downtown fighting ridiculous traffic and paying to park in some lot or on the street for it? NO. My daughter got a bubblegum doughnut because well it was pink AND had a piece of pink bubblegum plopped in the center. I tried to talk he out of it knowing color and a piece of what resembled the kind of gum you get from a pinãta don't necessarily mean a yummy doughnut but trying to reason with a 4yr old isn't exactly an easy feat when gum and the favorite color are involved. She barely ate half and threw the rest at a pigeon saying it was to sweet and yucky. My other 2 LO's got cake doughnuts one cereal and one with sprinkles and neither made it through the doughnuts both saying it's to sweet mom. (man those pigeons are Good that day) My SO ate half of each of his and saved the rest for later. All in all Id say the place is over priced and doughnuts are just ok knowing from what I saw there I could get for half their price, or less, at any doughnut place. Not good enough to win my business or make me think all the effort is worth it.

presentation...yes (this is where the two stars come in). actual quality and taste....no. completely over rated. have been twice. both times the help behind the counter were rude and i got sick within a couple of hours of eating the donuts. not worth it! if you are visiting Portland then you have to go at least once. otherwise, do your self a favor and take the 20 minute drive to krispy kreme.
Decent place.  Not worth the wait.   The donuts are good and tasty, but I think they are riding more on the history / name than truly being innovative and seeking exceptional quality.

I came, I waited (over an hour), I saw... The sight of the little revolving case was enough to fill me. Most of the treats looked tasty but by looking at them you really didn't get an idea of what the filling is or what flavor they are.... The menu board was absolutely no help and there were no little menus to further elaborate. I got to the counter and asked a few questions... got a few one answer responses... and blindly picked a few of the creations.. Overall not impressed. I got the Peanut butter and Oreo.. I waited over an hour for nothing more then a krispy creme donut on crack. I wanted to love it... I really did! I am not from Portland and was hoping to add this place to my arsenal of fav. hole in the walls... but to no avail...I am however from Seattle... and I recommend Top Pot.

All hype.  The donuts are good, but not amazing.  Definitely not worth the price they charge for the donuts or the ridiculous wait times.  As a tourist, we went just to say we went and I don't think I will ever be back.

We had the marshall mathers, triple chocolate penetration, maple blazer blunt, the portland cream, and the vegan cocknballs.

The marshall mathers was OK, I didn't particuarly care for the frosting.

The triple penetration was good, but the cocoa puffs on the outside were stale.

The maple blazer blunt was good.  It was like a churro dipped in maple frosting.

The vegan cocknballs was good.  Its cool that the vegan donut was pretty close to a normal donut, just a little dense and dry.  But if I didn't know, I would just think it was a dry donut.  The cream inside the balls is delicious.  Get the normal cocknballs if you arent vegan.

The portland cream was my favorite.  Simple and the cream is straight up good.

If voodoo was a little bit cheaper and the wait was not as long, I would like it more.  As it is, its strictly novelty and something to do just to say you did.

Hyped up doughnut place so I had to try it when visiting Portland! There was a line but it was a quick 10-ish minute wait. This place has the most unique doughnuts I've ever seen, and the decor was pretty awesome as well. 
I got the Old Dirty Bastard and the Portland Cream. They were good, but I got sick of them after a few bites because of how sweet they were. So do not get the crazy topping ones unless you can eat lots of sweetness and cream without trouble! I probably would have been better off getting original glazed.
No doughnut with any topping will beat a plain old glazed doughnut fresh out of the fryer! 
Definitely worth a try when you are in the area, but I wouldn't go back for seconds.

Good for instagram pictures, not as much for people that actually like food.  Not a bad price, and nice to find some more unique flavors... but most are just variations on junkfood-topped-doughnuts that are just soooo sweet.  The kind of food you need a nap after.  In general, no complaints... but it's really just a doughnut shop with good advertising/gimmicks.  Kind of disappointed I took time out of my visit for this 'Portland must-try'
Too much hype. Donuts weren't good at all and the restroom smelled like no one cleaned it in years. One whiff and I almost died :( the line looks long but it moves pretty fast

Bacon Maple Bar is delicious if they don't burn the bacon. Classic Portlandia style staff and plaid-drenched line outside the door. Donuts are donuts, and other than some very creative donut deliveries, I wouldn't make a habit of visiting this place too often. I remain to be "WOWed" by anything I've tried here, but the donuts are good enough.

If you want a donut and there's no line, give it a go.

I had one day in Portland, so we decided to stop by Voodoo.  Look, they're good donuts.  But I really enjoyed the regular donuts over most of the creative/weird ones.  Grape Ape?  Disgusting.  No one in my family wanted to finish that thing.

The wait wasn't really that bad.  We had done the research; we knew it was going to be busy.  It was maybe only 20 minutes for us.

Definitely just went to try it, but I've had better donuts.  I don't regret the visit though; definitely interesting.

I used to love voodoo doughnuts when I was 18-19, lived downtown and couldn't go to many places that were open after midnight.  This was more of a love out of necessity than quality though.  Honestly, the doughnuts aren't bad, they're decent, but that's about it.  Now, I only go here when family from California visits, because they saw it on the food network and are DYING to check it out.  Every time I have to go I am forced to wait in a long line for mediocre donuts, which has really made my love for voodoo go downhill.
Also, can you just get a credit card machine now?  Cash only for a restaurant as famous and popular as yours seems silly.

Blecch. If you're looking to stand in line like a moron and/or get a bellyache, try one of these completely overrated confections. "It's a doughnut...with Cap'n Crunch on it!!! Holy sh*t! Book a flight to Portland!!!" The too-cool vibe in this place is so palpable it feels like it clings to you like a hot beer fart trapped in your shorts. Save yrself the trouble: go to Safeway, buy a glazed, frosted doughnut & a pack of Lik-M-Aid Fun Dip and avoid standing in line like cattle with the tourists wondering if everyone who walks by is Fred Armisen.

This place is way too hyped up. I came here b/c it's apparently what you do when you're in Portland. Luckily, it was early enough in the morning that the line was short and I barely waited 5 min. Downside is that it is still so super busy and the rush made it hard to choose a doughnut. Went with the Portland cream or something but it really wasn't special. Taste was Dunkin Donut equivalent w/ fun shapes. Pretty disappointing for meee but at least I didn't have to wait!

This place is fun to go to because of its creative varieties, but the doughnut itself may disappoint.  I got the Triple Chocolate Penetration, which was too salty and not chocolatey enough.  To avoid holding up the line, do your homework first and look at the website to narrow down your choices.  They'll have just about everything available.
The service is usually brash and the line takes forever but this is a fun place to head after a day or night downtown as long as you have cash left on your person.

First time was great, I even assembled a list of favorites based on that first visit:  Maple Bacon Bar, Mango Tango (where else can you find a doughnut filled with MANGO jelly?), the Memphis Mafia fritter, and the Dirty Ol' Bastard.  Inside of the place was cool and there was a hot, gothy broody chick working in back.  My only gripe at the time was they didn't accept debit cards; not nuts about walking around in that part of downtown with cash, y'see
The second time was like a totally different place; they were extremely rude, I had to wait forever in line (this is to be expected, I've found), just to get my dessert nads kicked:  they were OUT of ALL FOUR of my favorites.  When did they plan to make more?  "Not anytime soon," was the response.  Bollocks.  I was with a friend who was willing to drive my to the other location up near Sandy or wherever it is, and they were out of everything I wanted as well.  At least I didn't have to wait in line at that location; it was pretty deserted.
Not a risk I'm willing to take again, but I miss that mango jelly...

To me, voodoo doughnuts is a novelty store. Once the "weird" factor gets used to, their doughnuts are only mediocre at best. Their marketing is what makes this store, but if you are into taste and not the "Weird" factor, then go someplace else. Plus most of the time, their store on the east side of the river doesn't have a working ATM, so be sure to bring cash because for whatever reason these guys want to stay in the dark ages and not take debit cards.
Recommend going to Blue Star donuts or Coco. Voodoo's are just very dry....

Go to Safeway, grab a doughnut, grab some cereal, grab some bacon, check out, make a weird doughnut sandwich out of random ingredients, and avoid the longass tourist line.  No one that lives in this city cares about voodoo enough to stand in that ridiculous line, just to take photographs outside of the building and buy a doughnut that has a pretzel stick sticking out of it.  They have pretzels at Safeway too, don't worry.  You will find visitors and oversized Nikons here, and that's about it.  The doughnuts aren't bad, they're just not amazing.  You want an amazing doughnut?  Go to Coco.

We were so excited to try the doughnuts, but when we got here we were too scared to get out of the car. Not only was it located next to the adult film theater, homeless people were sleeping near the shop. Their were bars all around this location and we didnt feel comftarble in this area so we ended up going to Voodoo Doughnuts Too! Still impressed :)

The obligatory Voodoo visit for all Portland tourists: of course it's hype! But the portions definitely are not.

The donuts, while leaning on the pricy side, can be ginormous!

Bacon maple: good bacon, sweeeeeet maple, and lots of it. Not the best bacon maple I've had, but not the worst and it was pretty tasty.

Memphis mafia: described as "fried dough with banana chunks and cinnamon covered in a glaze with chocolate frosting, peanut butter, peanuts and chocolate chips on top", it was tasty! But also waaaay too big! I tried. I really did. I managed to finish half of it without the help of my bf, but the rest went to the trash :(

All in all, a good place to stop by to say you've, well, stopped by. You just won't find me back here again, given the numerous other donut spots scattered around Portland.
They're OK.  Nothing great.  The different topping on the donuts are pretty interesting.  Just not too appealing to me.

We came to Portland and were told by many to try this donut place so we did. Ended up waiting in a very long line and while the donuts were quirky, they were nothing special. The donut shop across my house makes much better donuts. I also felt like the menu was convoluted and difficult to choose from. Not the greatest overall experience and a very average product. All hype

Man...this place is hyped! I have had dozens and dozens of people tell me that Voodoo is amazing, and have seen the pink boxes around town. Hell, I even saw people on the plane coming from Portland with boxes! It is on television, celebrities have endorsed it...sheesh, how else could this place be advertised? Jesus coming down from heaven and personally blessing the place? Jokes aside, I decided to see what the hype was about...and found out that it's just that, hype. 

After waiting over fifteen minutes (only three people in front of me. But the hipster clerk wouldn't let anyone else pay until a customer used the ATM to get cash), I finally ordered my two doughnuts (bacon maple bar, and regular maple bar), and payed almost five bucks(!) for the two. Now that should have payed for two doughnuts, plus coffee at any other place, but I figured that the doughnuts should be good enough, right? Not quite.

Simply put, the doughnuts were nasty. The bacon tasted old, and the icing was way, way too sweet. To the point where I felt like vomiting afterwards. I couldn't even finish the second doughnut, because the sweetness was just killer. Some of you may think I am a wuss...but come on, try it yourself and see. I'd like to see you choke down two of the maple bars. And if you do...join the forces of Wilford Brimley in fighting diabeetus. 

As mentioned earlier, the smarmy hipster clerk just pissed me off. She had this air of superiority around her, like if she didn't exist, the whole place would fall apart. There was another hipster behind the counter, who did not open up a second register to help out the long line, and seemed to just sit and stare into space. What was his job? I honestly don't know. 

I don't understand the shit-craze everybody has for Voodoo. Everyone makes it sound like it's super original and trendy, but in all truth the doughnuts are sub-par and pricey. Clerks are super rude, they only take cash, the lines are long...and just the simple fact that it's overrated. It is just like those cupcake places that have sprung up in every metropolitan area. It is cool for the moment, but eventually it will collapse when something else "cool" comes around.

Crazy donuts as you all know. Fun to see all the droves of people in lines for the Pink Boxes. You feel part of the fun crazy waiting in a line for a donut and you don't know why. It's a Portland thing... I'd never do if I was not a tourist... 

No where to sit inside to eat the donuts is my biggest issue with this location. With the money they must make they could expand the space for some tables???

Donuts are still better than cupcakes at least... and a cheaper fun treat! ;)

TIP: Voodoo II is a better stop for this tradition, friendly service and has inside benches!

Long line + cold weather = donuts MUST be delicious!

Tried the grape (good, really sweet, but pretty awesome...mostly b/c it's so diff. from "normal" donuts), maple bacon (because everyone talks about it! it tastes exactly like what it is..i like the combo so to me, it was quite tasty) and the arnold palmer (in my opinion, someone who LOVES arnold palmers....this was NOT good....i did not enjoy the flavors on a donut at all)

Wish i lived closer so i could try more...but alas, tasty and worth waiting in line if you have the time and curiosity. :)
Not bad, had better. :) definitely come for the touristy-ness and the funky shapes!!!

Got 2 donuts: lemon crueler and portland donut. They were okay.  
The donuts are cheap because the ingredients are cheap and have cheap flavored cereal. One small step up from DD because at least they're fresher than DD. 

What bothers me more than the inferior ingredients:
1) location: the blocks leading up it are dingy and smell like urine (a lot homeless people). 
2) bakery operations: after eating the donuts walking past the side of the shop, I see the 6 ft tall racks of unfrosted donuts in the tall OPEN window - open to the street!! Dust, dirt, car emissions! YUCK!!!!  Does that mean the inside of the shop is dirty? I wished I had looked first before ordering

Surprisingly, the line wasn't as long as we thought it would have been, but there was definitely a line. It moves pretty quick though. Heads up, CASH ONLY!! The night we came, the ATM machine inside by the bathroom was broken. The donuts are pretty good and fresh but I don't know if I would stand in that line for them again. Our cashier was super friendly and they have Vegan donuts too!

The Food Network effect is going on strong with this place.  It is funny to see all of the tourists wait in line for hours to get a donut that isn't even on par with Dunkin.  If you are visiting PDX.  Let me save you some time: Do not waste an afternoon to get a mediocre donut with some stale cereal on it.  No one who actually lives in Portland goes there.  That should tell you something.

I couldn't wait to visit Voodoo Doughnut after hearing so many things about the place. I can't say it was amazing but it also wasn't terrible. Had the Diablo Hex doughnut; definitely good but nothing spectacular.  My boyfriend had the Fruit Loops one and it was completely stale.  :(  The service was completely awful.  I heard rumors that the staff is told to be unfriendly as to speed the customers through.  (?!) If this is the case I have never heard of anything more ridiculous.  

Overall, I wouldn't call it a "MUST SEE" for  Portland.  Cute names for basic doughnuts with stale cereal sprinkled on top served with a side of bitchiness? ill stick with my local doughnut shop.

I had been hearing about Voodoo Doughnut for ages and finally got to try it recently. We tried to stop by on the weekend--no dice. The line was around the block (and the shop is tiny!). We went back during the week and there were only a couple people around. The menu above the counter is overwhelming, but they don't have every doughnut available every day, so the glass case to the left is your best indicator of what they've got that day.

As far as freshness goes, these were great. We bought them in the afternoon; they were great that night, and they were still great the next morning. 

Voodoo Doll: The only complaint I heard about this one was that there was jelly in only 1/3 of it. 
Captain My Captain (Cap'n Crunch): A no-repeater; the cereal gets sort of soft and pliable from absorbing the doughnut's icing. (I would assume the same for the ones with Cocoa Puffs and Fruit Loops on top.)
Mexican Hot Chocolate: A chocolate doughnut dusted in cinnamon, sugar and cayenne pepper. I like chocolate with a little cayenne, but this was more than a little cayenne. I couldn't eat it.
Butterfingerling: Topped with crushed Butterfingers. Love. This was awesome.
Maple Bacon Bar: Loved even more. This one is the reason to go. But in the future, I will probably just buy a maple bar at Albertson's and put bacon on it myself.

I would go back to try other variations, but more for the novelty than because the doughnuts are that worth it. They're good; they're not magic.

Voodoo Doughnut was a long drive for me. I live in Washington. Personally, I thought  the donuts were not really worth it. They were too sweet, the lines were long, and the street that they are located on is a street tumbling with homeless people and drug dealers. I was scared while I was waiting. The bacon maple donut is the only donut that i liked, because of the bacon. Only go if you are craving sugary sweet donuts and willing to stand in a two hour line.
They are way too sweet. Not really that awesome for the product, but they are interesting to look at, as they're so different from any place else, so variety is going for them.
Hippies and weirdos enjoy donuts between tweek binges. Just off sandy and 24 hours at that. If your new to town you'll thinks its cool. Otherwise just gaze at the sea of losers

I dont get it ....  fred meyer donuts are equal or better ... commercial dough mix ... I watched the truck unload the bags .... long line with begging  bums hounding you ....do you basically get bisquick donuts and quality time with bums ?????
Rude service, mediocre donut. Overhyped

It's nice that Voodoo is open 24 hours. We came by around midnight and there was no wait. Had there been one, I'd likely rate it lower. While we had heard from numerous sources that Voodoo is overhyped and not worth it, we still had to try for ourselves. Everyone else is right. The donuts are alright...I guess. They were dry, lackluster, and overly sweet. We did it because we had to, as first timers to Portland, but I doubt I'll ever return.

The shop is unique and the donut flavors are different but it's not actually that good. Taste like a supermarket donut. Frosting taste like it's out of a pillsbury tub. Nothing tasted home made. Gave 2 stars for the presentation

At about 1:30am the line wasn't too long. The doughnuts are ok, but cool place to stop by and check out, with all the weirdo doughnut names and designs. My friend's thought this place was kind of similar Psycho Doughnuts in San Jose, CA. Ca$h only.

Bold statement: I'm not a fan of Voodoo.

The actual donuts (or is it doughnut?) aren't anything special. And the endless onslaught of icings and toppings are just a sugary overload for my tastebuds. I see lines outside VD everyday of the week and can't figure out why... I'd consider it to be a tourist attraction instead of a place for Portlanders to get their doughy fix. 

I do like the names and presentation, though! I'm just not in love with the flavors. I'm sure, at some point, someone will attempt some voodoo on me and get me to fall in love with their colorful creations.

I think I came here with expectations that were a bit too high...it's a donut shop-nothing more, nothing less.  The donuts were decent, but when you start to get into the crazy flavors with crap piled high on top, it gets to be too much.  Stick to the basics and maybe share a crazy flavored donut with a couple friends.  And, DON'T order their coffee...it was gross!

This place has fallen on it's own sword, in my opinion...if only Al Roker and the rest hadn 't discovered it, it would still be high quality. Sadly, I only come here now when I have company in from out of town....love to see their faces when they see the revolving donut display.... Not worth the typical 45 minute wait, IMHO.

But, the maple bar, and the banana fritters ARE good....but I have had better.

Voodoo Doughnut is a bit of a star in Portland - but their donuts are not **that** amazing. Go during early morning (before 10am) or later at night (past 10pm) to avoid any touristy line. I love their vegan chocolate coconut and will def. partake in any pink box contents, but they are not my favorite donut of all time. Three stars for fun, creativity, good donuts and low cost

I'm not a huge fan of sweets, but curiosity got the best of me and I had to see what this was all about.  I mean...how can you come to Portland and not try Voodoo Donuts?  That would be like coming to SF and not going to...well...shoot I don't have a close competitor.  Anyway...I endured the summer heat of Portland and stood in line for about 30 mins.  Finally, the time came to choose...the gf and I got the maple bacon and the voodoo donuts.  After a few seconds of being a tourist and taking pictures with my phone...I took my first bite of the maple bacon donut.

My first immediate reaction..."holy f@#!ing $hit...this is way too sweet".  Second bite (from the voodoo donut this time)...same reaction.  I'll give it that...the donut itself was very fresh...dense and fluffy at the same time...too sweet for me though.  I'll take Krispy Kreme over this any day.
I would never wait 20 minutes in the rain for  donuts again.  they make some very strnage ones.
Decent enough donuts, especially for like 2am. Line was a bit long though. The bacon maple bars were different to say the least.  Don't know if it's really worth the wait.

Honestly, the donuts are just okay to me, but of course being a visitor I had to drop by. This place is all HYPE but I still support it as a quintessential piece of Portland. I would gladly drop by again just to take pictures and be apart of the experience but I wouldn't necessarily order a donut - maybe just one.

Rude staff because they know that even if you don't buy anything someone else will. They only take cash because who has time for technology? 

Took my stepdaughter there when she visited from California, stood in line and everything just to get the full experience. Bought a couple meh doughnuts for ourselves and brought some home for extended family who doesn't have time to navigate downtown and wait outside in the rain. Dealt with the consequences later when everyone who ate a doughnut got sick and had to wait for the one bathroom in the house.

Voodoo Doughnuts are a Portland classic, so the line is always filled with tourists who want to cross it off their bucket lists. My friends and I didn't intend on visiting here... but we noticed that the line was super short since it was raining, and we were just like, why not?

There's a wide selection of doughnuts to choose from, but I decided to limit myself to one because I was full from eating earlier and donuts are usually super filling. I decided on getting the bacon maple bar doughnut ($2.50). In all honesty, it was ok. The bacon strip on top was crispy, but I wish it was crumbled and evenly distributed on the surface so that every bite had bacon.

One interesting thing about Voodoo is that they have a sign that states that guests ONLY have 5 minutes to use the restrooms. This was funny to us because we were like... what if it was an emergency? But I'm sure that the workers are too busy handling orders to actually time your business.

Overall, I would suggest visiting here only if the line is short. If it wasn't raining that day, then it would have probably taken an 30 minutes to an hour to make an order.
My mom is lactose intolerant so I get her a vegan donut from voodoo occasionaly and they are pretty good.

The old place was striking, not for the quality but for the ambience... It was SO Portland!
The new place lost all that charm, and turned to be just a cool place where to have a decent cheap dessert.
Clever names and donut designs, tastes like your run-of-the-mill donuts.

I would recommend Voodoo to a first-timer, or somebody looking for a good experience, but not much for the doughnuts. I used to love Voodoo; of course, I've noticed a diminishment in quality and service the last couple years.

If you're looking for good doughnuts, I recommend Blue Star or Annie's. Blue Star is great for artisan, gourmet doughnuts whereas Annie's is inexpensive and very reliable.

So I like vodoo donuts but they seriously have a problem with roaches.  I was there last night and I watch roaches come out of the wax paper boxes that they use to grab the donut with.  Seriously a place like this that draws lots and lots of people need to seriously get some pest control before they decide to serve any more people.  I would go back if they get their roach infestation under control.

Taste-wise, the doughnuts themselves are nothing better than what you can get in the case at Safeway, but it is still a fun experience when entertaining out-of-town guests. The way the doughnuts are decorated is obviously unique and the novelty of the atmosphere and bright pink boxes is fun. Personally I don't want a bunch of crunchy cereal on my doughnut. Go for the Portland Cream!

Overrated!! This place sucks. There are plenty of other donuts shops that have better donuts this trash. Anyone who said that this is the best donuts place is probably because it is the only donuts place they've been to. I can't believe I waited 45 min for this place.
What do you have to do to get a doughnut ! ......couldnt see the end of the queue ! So go on a day early in week before or after lunch definate not weekend unless you like queing
Meh. the sheeple love it, but if you want to buy a good doughnut try bluestar

Great donuts as always, BUT... I bought Rogue's 22 oz bottle of Maple Bacon Ale which a rep was selling at Voodoo Donut. It was $13 which is well above what anyone should ever pay for 22 ounces of beer but I took a chance - key word... "chance". I understand now why they weren't tasting the beer and force people to make a blind purchase - it was H-O-R-R-I-B-L-E. I brought it to a party with a bunch of friends - quite a few beer connoisseurs - none could finish the 2 oz sample I poured. I tried to give it chance - came back to it a couple of times - no luck. I feel robbed. At least I have a story to tell. Find a way to get a sample before you buy - if all else fails, call me - I have quite a bit left. Rogue - pretty bottle, but you can do MUCH better.

Would any parent enjoy hearing there 12 year old daughter make an order for the cock and balls doughnut?? Probably not... As a native I walked in and took one look and walked out. Over priced donuts that look like someone threw back up from a heavy night of drinking.. Pretty comical watching tourists wait in line for an hour for something that I'm sure tastes like shit.. And the fact that this place is just a hole in the wall in the worst part of the city.....

A friend and I recently took a trip to Portland and had to try this place. It came soooo recommended by my coworkers and different friends. After walking around downtown, our last stop for the day was Voodoo. The line seemed the same as it was a few hours ago so we figured might as well wait, it did go by pretty quickly. The insides was kinda hot and really crowded, honestly I just wanted to leave. I got the loop and my friend got the Portland cream. I mean it wasn't bad, it just wasn't that good either. It struck me as more of a "do it for the gram" type thing. Another thing to mention is that it's cash only.

Don't waste your time. Subpar donuts. Inefficient business model. Went on Saturday night and to be honest, my friends and I were uneasy in this hood, super sketchy crowd. Rude staff. Overrated! Go to Bluestar Donuts near Pearl District, super darling and looks yummy. Next time we will use our calories there! But...fascinating to finally see it after all the hype. Won't go back.
A lot of hype and long lines but definitely good doughnuts!

This place is cute and the schtick is cool, but I wasn't a big fan of the specialty doughnuts here: they were way too sweet for me.

Take this review with the understanding that Krispy Kreme Doughnuts actually hurt my teeth. Also understand that I have a major sweet tooth, so for something to be too sweet, I feel that it has to be 110% sugar. Because that percentage is possible in the realm of my reviews.

I didn't try the bacon one and maybe I should have. Bacon equals heaven. The voodoo man doughnut was actually the perfect amount of sweetness, but the jelly filling was too much a giant glob of jam in my mouth all at once. I would have enjoyed it much much more had the filling been spread throughout the whole of the doughnut rather than just in the "butt."

I made the mistake of buying a huge pink box full of these things and wound up giving them away to someone else who wound up not being a fan. Frowny face.

The non-voodoo style doughnuts here are more up my alley though.
They touch every single donut with their hands after touching money because it's a cash only place. No gloves. Disgusting.
Not  my kind. I don't like artificial flavors.Donuts are very ordinary and nothing special about them. Safeway have comparable donuts like them!!

I think i had the horrible experience...
I like to take the kids to new places here and there. It was a highly recommended spot so i went smiles there smiles when eating our doughnuts... few hours kicked in i and the kids had food poisoning. IT WAS HELL first time getting food poisoning and i felt like i was dying i could only imagine on my kids. My father laughed because he refused to eat the doughnuts in the first place but he was very upset And for customer service...with the new technology service the girl that handed us the doughnuts was texting and using her phone. WAY TOO MUCH SUGAR. This is the spot to get diagnose with diabetes and become obese.

Just ok. Donut was dry... the fruit loops were what saved it! It's a place to go to, so you can say you went and experienced Portland being weird. 

We preferred blue star more!

I'll just be blunt. These donuts are no more tasty than almost any other donut I've had in Portland. Heck, even some of Krispy Kreme's donuts are higher in quality.

The only reason this place remains popular is because of their unique flavors and the emergence of modern social media. While most won't admit it, going to Voodoo focuses on taking pictures and spreading them on social media, rather than judging the quality and flavor of the donuts.

This place is very nearly the equivalent of an edible museum. Have you ever wondered what the Mona Lisa painting tasted like? No, and you shouldn't, because that's weird. Some of their flavors are unique, and maybe one out of 30 actually tastes good. But to compare their basic flavors to other places, I'm underwhelmed. 

Don't be fooled by the fad. Eat the donuts for what they are, and judge accordingly. Once you've done so, I think you'll agree that this place is overrated. In all honesty, this place is average, and probably deserves a 3-star rating. But to compensate for the influx of misleading high reviews, I'm obliged to give a 1-star rating.

On a side note, I wouldn't consider this place family friendly. Some of their creations can be dark and sexual in nature. Just a heads up.

This place is just so awesomely annoying. Wait, that doesn't make sense. Well, actually it does; let me explain. Why is it that people are willing to wait in line for 30 minutes to an hour for a donut shaped like a ghost with some creative frosting and a humorously placed pretzel stick? I don't know, but dammit I did it and I don't regret it. I don't even like donuts that much, but someone about that voodoo donut pulled me in. I waited in line for half on hour, took a crazy amount of pictures of the sign outside, the glittery wall, the musicians playing on the corner, the "Keep Portland Weird" mural across the street... As for the donut, it's ok. It's just a donut, nothing fancy. I was a little disappointed in the design, it didn't look like the one in the pictures and the sign outside, but they did draw a nice fetus on it which made me happy. The girl taking my order was a little rude. I was wondering if they had a donut design similar to one in the display cause, and she looked at me like I was speaking in Piglatin. Whatever, I took my Voodoo man, and a Portland Creme, and hightailed it out of there for some fresh air (and to take perfect pics of these donuts). I wouldn't go back, but I understand the need to go there.

Oh Voodoo, you are sitting in the back counting your green going SUCKERS!! I am a Chicago donut connoisseur!  You are par with Dunkin, but you market and have made a niche for yourself. Brilliant!!! I laugh when i drive bye and see the hundreds of tourist waiting in line for your big pink box. Suckers!!!! Donut on!

Review #1,001 of this place.  This means that it will be buried by 10 newer reviews within a day or two, I'm sure.  Consequently, this means you won't be reading this.  Yes, you.  The one reading this.  You're not reading this.

I can't say I see the hype over this place.  Yes, hee hee, they make dirty looking doughnuts.  And yes, ooooooo, they put bacon on top of some of them.  So?  The quality of the thing you're going there for isn't anything special.  It's an okay doughnut with different things on top.  Half the time, the things I get on top of them are stale.  Nothing worse on a doughnut than cereal or Oreos that taste like they've been sitting out on the counter all day (because they have?).

Then you add the service to it.  Actually, the last time wasn't bad, but overall the staff acts like they could spit on your doughnut and you'd still be happy to take it because it's Voodoo Doughnuts and they are gods and we are but peons.  This continues because Portlanders continue to think it's true.

When it comes down to it, it's a doughnut shop.  It's average.  It's fine.  It's kind of expensive.  There's a line.  Always.  If you have another option, pick it.  If not, it will do.

Voodoo doughnuts is a photo op. The decor is interesting and you have plenty of things to look at when you are in line. When you receive the doughnut, you just want a good laugh about it. It's so "cute." However, it's just a plain old cream doughnut, so don't expect too much.

Ok so the Doughnuts were good. But were they waiting in line for 45 min good?  Def not. We ended up getting a dozen and the dude threw us a extra one for free maybe due to the long wait.  I can't even remember the names because they are all super crazy.

I give a 3 star because the doughnuts were good and the atmosphere was fun. Good vibes there. 

Overall I would say it was a good experience and I am glad I went. I would def go again as long as there is no line. 

So if you are in the area and haven't experienced Voodoo you should go for it.
much improvement needed in terms of taste...i find the donuts very buttery and overtly sweet

I've never waited in the three-hour line, and now I don't plan to.  The staff with the mobile truck were rude and uncooperative at a community event.  For a company with a reputation of being philantropic I was severely disappointed by their greed.

So, thank you but no thank you, you've lost a customer.

Wow. I can't imagine thinking that just working for a place that sells pretty ok and gimmicky donuts makes me somehow above being nice, friendly or helpful even though I work in the food service industry. Donuts are good if overpriced and the people who work here are rude and actually roll their eyes if you don't know exactly what you want to order when you get to the counter.  It doesn't help that there isn't really a menu, only a revolving glass case of their tacky donuts, which is a bit overwhelming for kids. Grab a coffee down the street and enjoy the nicer folks of Portland. Save your money.  Skip the Voodoo.
Why do people stand in line for these doughnuts?  Just to get the pink box? Mediocre and not worth the hype. Check out coco's -- now that's a real doughnut.

I'm here for the long weekend and like any good tourist had to check this place out.  

The GOOD news:  the doghnuts are above par with interesting combinations.  The long line moved fairly fast.  Their tshirt designs are pretty cool.

The BAD news:   the frostings are a bit too sweet - frosting with additional sugars atop, almost put me into a diabetic coma after one doughnut.  The place is filthy, clean it up a bit boys, dust everywhere is gross and give the impression that the kitchen may be overrun with gawd knows what.  American Apparel shirts run pretty small so even though you might be able to eat a TexAss, you won't be able to fit into an XL.

I'd come back but maybe to the second location because it's probably (HOPEFULLY) a bit cleaner.  Swiffer dusters, check 'em out!
The atmosphere is fun but the quality of doughnuts isnt the best. I'd bring non-portlanders or non-eugene people here but not my go-to doughnut shop.

I've lived in the Portland Metro for almost 30 years.  Today was the first time I went to try Voodoo Doughnut.  I will not make a special trip to go back.  Here are the positives.  It is a donut shop and they make pretty good doughnuts overall.  The selection is "obscene" in more ways than one!  Who needs such a selection?  Tourists, I suppose.  Serious donut eaters do not need this kind of place.  The service is good!  Every cash register was open, and although there was a line, people were be being served quickly, efficiently, and by people who were seemed knowledgable.  That's it for the positives.  Here are the negatives:  1. Severely over priced.  Their maple/bacon bar, a legend for them, is $3 each!.  Most donuts are above $1 each and I'd say the average price is about $2 each.  We bought 4 donuts and it cost us $7.15.  2.  No parking.  This place is in an urban area so parking is sparse.  We lucked out and found one nearby, but we had to put money in a meter to pay for the space, so no bargain there.  3.  Homeless person begging at the front door is a nuisance.  We gave him money, but come on, do we really need this at the front entrance?  4. No tables inside.  The only tables are outside (it was raining, as usual this time of year) and they are surrounded by homeless types, etc.  So, in summary, if you are a local, pass this place up.  The doughnuts are not so good that you need to go through the hassle at this cramped location in a less than desirable spot in downtown Portland.  If you are a tourist and saw this on some cable TV food specialty program and want to try it..... go ahead and waste your money so you can get the pretty pink box to show off to your friends and relatives, I suppose.

I always see all these TV shows that tell travelers to come to Voodoo Doughnuts. I've lived here my entire life and I just do NOT get all the hype that surrounds the! For one, I refuse to wait in a long azz line for a doughnut. Two, their doughnuts are extremely heavy and dense, and that just isn't my preferred type of doughnut. Even on a really drunken night when I stagger over and wait in the two-hour long line, I can't handle them. 
I did meet Tom Green at Voodoo Doughnuts like 7 years ago though, so I'll give an extra star for that. Oh...and for creativity.

Like being mouth-raped by a unicorn, Voodoo doughnuts is a serious injection of sweet.

I went on a Tuesday morning, around 9am - very short line, guess that's a good time to go. Parking was open, too.

Obviously the maple bacon donut was going to be purchased for my group of buddies but the question was which other ones to get. After some help from one of the friendly, not condescending, staff members, I made my selection:

-Maple Bacon Doughnut - coming from LA, the land of two very good maple bacon doughnuts (Huckleberry & Nickel Diner), I had high expectations for this. Unlike the aforementioned eateries, Voodoo's doughnut has two WHOLE strips of bacon on it's long, maple-coated eclair shaped doughnut. No hole in this guy. The bacon was sweet and the maple frosting was a good accompaniment. But this was a big mamma-jamma, and I had to split it with friends

-Chocolate peanut butter donut - this was great, for a bite. I don't know how anyone can finish one of these unless they are on an MDMA rush and haven't eaten in weeks. It was super sweet, yet super decadent. A chocolate fantasy - that you can't turn off.

-Cotton Candy doughnut - this was the true mouth rappage of them all. The doughnut tasted like cotton candy (I believe it was coated in cotton candy granulated sugars), and was the most fluorescent blue you will ever see while not on a hallucinogen.  But MAN was it SWEET! It was like getting your cavity filled with sucrose.

A fun, and novel place but beware of the sugar rush!

*CASH ONLY, TOO!*

Overrated!

The toppings and some of the doughnuts are creative, but the actual doughnuts themselves are mediocre and that colors the whole experience.  The last time I went, it was too late to try some of the more well-known doughnuts.  The line was a bit long when I went.  It's not bad for a try, especially since it's talked about so much, but overall it's not really worth the wait.  The ambiance and decorations in the store are cool though.

Voodoo you used to be a ever present go to... you have let the taste slide and the customer service is not at all what it used to be...  Here's to figuring out how to have a VOODOO PREMIUM WINDOW accessible to the street without a line of people that just want a fast pack of dozen doughnuts for a premium price... I would rather pay $15 for a dozen fancy pack from a window that only took credit card and it was a swipe and run then stand in a line for the next 30 min and count how many people in front of me just wanted to gawk at the doughnuts in the case and gigggle like school girls... damn it... for some of us this place is medicinal... get out of the way... I have more money than time!
I've been here about 5 times. The donuts are very creative! The lines are not so great and the service is really just okay.

Ive lived in Portland 25 years and just had my first taste of voodoo in the past 6 months via an office gathering. Im not a doughnut fan but I dont hate them either. These are just doughnuts folks. A lot of them are even a little over the top which I hear is a selling point for a lot of people but there are tastier ways to elevate your A1C as far as Im concerned. If you love doughnuts go to pretty much any doughnut shop in town. If you love long lines, people rudely blocking your path in their selfie taking oblivion and despondent "over it" staff ordering your dozen for you because your just too slow. Go to voodoo.

Don't kill me for not going four or five star, but the doughnuts were just ok for me. So, they found different ways to make them fun. For one thing, I waited in line in the sun in 100 degree weather for 30 minutes. You would think they would put a cover over the sidewalk area for the sun as well as the rain. They don't take credit cards either. The young lady that took our order was very kind and quick. My partner promised colleagues that he would bring them Voodoo doughnuts. I tried the maple bacon. It was much better when I removed the bacon. He thought the couple that he tried were OK. His colleagues raved over them though. He took two dozen in to work and there were none left at the end of the day. They sliced them so that they could try different ones. I'd eat a WInchell's anytime over a Voodoo.
Visiting this weekend and decided to try an Apple fritter. Very disappointing. Just lumps of dough with tiny pieces of canned Apple. Not sure what the rave on this store is about

Is it worth checking out Voodoo Doughnuts?  Sure; if there isn't a line.  Otherwise you're stuck standing there waiting for doughnuts that you can probably get elsewhere.  My understanding is that Voodoo started the whole crazy doughnut topping craze (maple bacon donuts, anyone?), but by now it seems that you can get these specialty topped doughnuts at many other shops.  I'm in no way a doughnut connoisseur, or even an enthusiast, but their doughnuts tasted like any other.  Fun to see, but again, not really worth the wait if there is a line.

Really overrated novelty donuts. If you want a donut covered in cereal, or shaped like genitalia, this is your spot. Its not hard to find fresher, more tasty donuts other places in portland. Voodoo isn't bad, but it's a wait in line for an average donut covered in stuff.

Creative donuts but not worth the hype. Lines are very long for ok to  good donuts that you can get just about anywhere. Not worth an hour wait. Not family friendly (images, names of donuts). Would not bring young children here.

Perhaps the donuts aren't the best tasting, but the flavors were very creative and the vibe of the store was quirky and fun. It was cool to see all kinds of people stopping by Voodoo Doughnut in the middle of the day to get their sugar fix (men and women in business suits on their lunch breaks, a biking family, tourists/Portlandia fans like myself). 

There isn't much street parking available but there are cheap lots all around the area.

Voodoo Doughnut is also conveniently located across from the "Keep Portland Weird" sign!

I don't think I'm in their demographic. The flavors are not constructed well. The doughnut dough is very average and the wait is unwarranted. But everyday you see sun tanned people carrying pink voodoo boxes all around town, so someone likes them.
I tried these donuts yesterday .. the place was a bit crowded and luckily I had cash .. dint feel it was out of the world .. but definitely yummy!

The stars must have been aligned when we came here because we had absolutely no wait. In fact, we were the only ones in the place on a Tuesday afternoon. We picked out the ODB, chocolate glazed, and voodoo donut. The boring chocolate glaze was actually my favorite. The donut was moist, soft, and had a thick, delicious chocolate icing. The voodoo donut was cute to look at as I ate his arms off and bled raspberry filling, and a bite of the ODB sent me into a sugar coma with it's oreo and peanut butter topping. Overall, they have pretty interesting combinations but the donuts are a  bit too sweet and over the top for my taste. Good to try at least once. 3 donuts were under $5. Cash only.

After hearing so much about this doughnut mecca when I was driving through Portland I had to stop here, bought a dozen mixed doughnuts and sat outside on the benches to enjoy. After trying a few of the different ones I felt disappointed by all of the hype. They were smothered in a thick cake like icing and were very sweet. The different toppings were good but some like the cereal tasted stale while others like the m&m and butterfinger were amazing and loaded with goodies but I kept coming back to that icing. It was too sweet and did not seem to have a flavor other than sugar which downgraded the whole doughnut for me. The best ones were the ones with a glaze, chocolate, or the filled ones. The doughnut itself was a thick, dense, and very filling the base is a good decent doughnut but without the fantaboulous toppings it would be just okay. It was a fun experience visiting Voodoo Doughnut but would I go again probably not.
This is fun, but not a daily donut shop for us.  The quality has gone down over the years in my opinion.  They are novelty not mouth watering.  But hey, we all love the pink box. :)

A must-see spot in Portland? Yes. 

Should you expect delicious donuts? Not really. 

Besides the unique designs and flavors, I found the donuts to be fairly bland and too sweet (in addition to over-priced). They also don't hold up too well. It's a novelty in the area so the line is always long. There's no free parking close-by so expect to pay either in a lot or street meters.
Fun, unique but only worth waiting in line for if your entertaining guests from out of town.

The donuts are pretty good, but the whole thing has become more of a nuisance than an experience.  Since the expansion, I've visited twice: once at peak time and once at a slack time - in both cases, they only had one cashier on duty, even though they have 4 cash registers at the counter.  When the line is caused more by indifferent service than any real demand, I'm not inclined to spend any more time there.
when i was new to Portland I thought it was amazing. Now that I have been here a little while it's not as appealing. Just a grungy donut shop with unique flavors.
Novelty doughnuts that don't taste very good. Go to Blue Star instead.

I stopped by here with my wife whenever we were in Portland.  It seems like everyone has heard of Voodoo doughnuts and wants to give them a try.  So it wasn't surprising that there was a huge line outside the shop whenever we go there.  Thankfully that long line doesn't take too long to get through.  Whenever you finally make it into the shop you are able to see a pretty nice space.  It was brightly colored with lots of photos on the wall and had a cool chandelier type light.  By the time we got up to the spot to order we had already made our selections long before.  So it was with great sadness that they told me that they were out of the lemon chiffon that I wanted.  As a quick backup selection I ended up ordering the maple bacon bar.  We then made it to the register and paid our cash (it's a cash only place) before heading outside to sit at one of their tables.  The doughnut portion of my bar ended up being fresh and really good while I also enjoyed the bacon.  What I didn't enjoy as much was the maple frosting which i found to be a bit too sweet for me.

The bottom line for me is that I would head back here again in the future.  Hopefully the next time they will have the lemon chiffon and I can leave a bit more impressed.

It's something you have to experience at least once.... but once is enough.

When I first moved to Portland, I had no idea what I was standing in line for- just that the line went around the block, it was booming awesome music, and normal looking people were in line (good cue letting me know it wasn't a crack house or X-rated), so I figure, 'I got some time, why not?'

Once in, I thought the interiors were fun, the workers seemed a bit bored, but friendly enough. The selection of donuts and their donut decor was also fun, but the taste is honestly like any other friend ball of dough you would find at a generic donut shop... with a ton of frosting and other goodies on top.

After having it, you'll be tempted to grab a box of cereal and some frosting to make your own. And you might as well. Safeway, Fred Meyers, and all the other grocers in town are doing it too. 

Since that first experience, i've stopped in once for a couple of donuts, but always found that 1 or 2 bites was enough before my head exploded from the sugar. 

Seriously, once is enough.

Okay, I've heard SO MUCH about voodoo doughnuts. When I was visiting Portland everyone was telling me to try this place because it had the best donuts ever. I was little skeptical because I'm from LA and NOTHING beats the food or desserts out there. 

So after dinner, we decided to walk over to this joint located near Chinatown. This place is CASH ONLY. I'm not sure if the other place is cash only as well, but the voodoo doughnuts in Chinatown was so that was a bummer. They have an ATM machine inside so you're in luck if you don't have cash. 

The venue is SMALL, and dirty as hell. Actually, the surrounding area of the venue seemed like your typical LA skid row type of area so if you're feeling something nicer, maybe you should head to the other one somewhere in Portland. 

We ordered half a dozen donuts, and it came out to be 10 bucks? It's pretty pricey for donuts but since it's a popular joint I guess they can hike up the dollar amount. They're also popular for their vegan options but we didn't have any of that. 

In all honesty, this place is all hype. I'm not sure where the hype stemmed from but gotta give it up to their marketing skills. It tastes like any other donut joint but more expensive. 

But when in Portland, it's always good to visit their most famed donut shop at least once. Probably won't come here again if I head up to Portland again. 

California donut shops are better. Actually, any generic donut shop is probably worth your money more but if you love HYPE, then go for it.

Regardless what time you go to this place, there will always be a line and the average wait time to get to the counter is about 20 minutes to an hour depending on the customers that come in and can't make up their mind on what to get.  Don't expect anything amazing about these donuts, they are just the same as any other doughnut joint. If this is your first time to line up at Voodoo doughnuts I would say check it out because the fun part about being in line is the people you run into which is an experience in itself, Portland people are weird....trust me it is entertaining to watch weird Portland'rs roam around the streets.  Other than that, just make sure you try the doughnut shaped like a Voodoo doll.  The only reason why my wife and I checked out this place was because of Anthony Bourdain and his love for the maple bar with bacon on it which wasn't bad.....so first timers I wish you an experience while you are in line and hope you enjoy those regular doughnuts!  Happy eats!

Danny's Yelp 2016.

2 words about Voodoo = Overrated & Hype. Voodoo is a "must" for anyone that's visiting Portland but it ain't the best donut in town. GO TO BLUE STAR! I only came here so I can cross this out of my Portland list.

They sell a variety of donuts thats huge and has crazy toppings, which is the reason why it attracts so many people to visit here. Oh yeah, and people are crazy about their pink box which isn't anything special. The donuts was very overwhelmingly sweet and I like sweets too but it was way too sweet for my liking. 

Tips/PS:
+ Cash ONLY! So don't forget to bring cash.
+ There isn't any line after 10pm.
+ It's opened 24 hours.
+ Cheap donuts. $1.50 - $3 each

Conclusion: I wouldn't come back. I rather go to Blue Stars.
It's a good donut but not the best. It's a Portland novelty and now that I have done it, I dont feel the need to do so again. It's Cash only and the line can get a little crazy. Staff was pleasant.

First off, I'm not a contrarian who doesn't like things just for the sake of not liking them. I genuinely don't fawn over Voodoo. 

My reasons:
1.) The staff has never been nice to me.
2.) They only accept cash. Just because they can.
3.) Their donuts aren't that good.
4.) Previously charming gimmicks are overplayed now.

Don't get me wrong, Voodoo is worth a trip if you've never been there. It has a unique, fun atmosphere for a donut shop. If you're looking for an everyday donut spot, it's probably not the place for you though.

As more of a foodie and less of a dessert person, my review could be biased.

After seeing all the reviews and instagrams about this place, I had to check it out while in Portland. I was overwhelmed by the names and types of doughnuts and quite honestly didn't know what I wanted except to try the voodoo doughnut for sure. However, the guy at the register was extremely helpful in answering all our questions and explaining the different doughnuts. They have regular doughnuts as well if you're not into the crazy menu items. 

VERDICT: The doughnuts were pretty good (taste, texture). The voodoo doughnut was pretty good with the jelly filled center and the oreo encrusted one was pretty good too. I just had a bite from each and the sugar was enough for me. However, if sweets are your thing (cereal encrusted frosting), you should definitely try it and decide for yourself. I'm happy I tried it and would come back when in the mood for doughnuts.

I don't know man... this I think is just a hype. 

The creativity was nice to see, and the different variations of doughnut designs were displayed as your 'menu' visuals. With tourists visiting this spot because of it being a 'Portland' thing to visit is what brings the crowds in. 

To me personally, their doughnuts taste like that of any other doughnut shop. The first time I visited this place I was so hyped, but visiting this a second time, I was whatever about it. 

There's a location in California now near Universal Studios incase you guys didn't know. 

All I can say is this is a great spot to go to late at night if you're craving something sweet.
Played out. Honestly the donuts are/never were all that good. All show, no go.

Haven't been here much other then whenever friends that visit and needed to get a box of voodoo doughnuts back to their respective places. Extremely crowded I most days. Pretty cool looking donuts but also really really sweet. Not my cup of tea but lots of my friends love it as it's a PDX thing. Drop by get one and try it out yourself!

This place is overrated. Not to say the doughnuts were bad, they werent, but they werent great either. I guess the draw is the weird collection of doughnuts but that doesnt make the shop live up to the insane hype.

Great place for something different or to put a check on the bucket list. Other than that no reason to come here. The doughnuts really are not that good. 
Lot of hype but no substance. Long lines to get an average doughnut with stale cereal on it. No thanks. 7-11 has much better to offer.

I've been wanting to come here since I read about it in the rough guide and saw it on the food network. In my first week of moving here, I went on a late Saturday evening only to find a HUGE line out and around he corner for this little hole in the wall. I decided to do the wait because I was in good company so the wait didn't seem that bad, and I figured there MUST be a reason this line is so big. 

I thought the place was really quirky and funky. The menu was hilarious and made ordering the donuts that much fun. We selected a random assortment of donuts so that we could try a bunch of things. Our total for a dozen mix of these random donuts cam to about $18...a bit pricy for a doen donuts, but I didn't mind since the topping were quite unique. 

Unfortunately I was a bit disappointed that they didn't have their famous bacon maple bar and their cock-n-balls (which I really wanted to try). So out of the ones we did try (cereal topped, cookie topped, filled, and more!), my FAVORITE was the creme filled one...mmmmm...But although it was delicious, it didn't WOW me...so I'll give the place 3 stars. Maybe I'll give it more stars once I try the bacon maple bar...but they need to make sure to have it next time ;-)

"Good things come in pink boxes" is their tag line; for us it was "overrated but interesting donuts designed to entice children and tide them over between meals come in pink boxes."

As native Oregonians and longtime Portland area residents, we've somehow avoided this place, but we were tooling around downtown Portland one Friday and couldn't resist. We even endured a long (but fast moving) line in the hot hot afternoon sun on an 80 degree day. It's fun to mix it up with tourists talking and geocaching and generally buzzing about their Portland visit.

Make sure you have cash on hand. We paid $17 for a "voodoo dozen" which means they choose twelve donuts and put them in an iconic box for you. I asked for silverware to cut up the donuts (there were six of us and obv we wanted to sample each one) and the guy behind the counter simply replied "no knives."  i was like "what about forks?" And he didn't laugh. Or smile. (I'm used to the rude, smug service in Portland but that doesn't mean I have to like it.) In the end, They did a good job choosing our assortment and the kids loved it. 

I mean, I wouldn't come here on a date, but I would bring visitors back here because it's in an area of town proximate to the water and lots of other things to do.

Eh, I guess I don't get it. The donuts were good, but this place is overrated, I think. Plus the staff had that hipster cooler-than-you attitude that I could do without. 3 stars though for serving a pastry with bacon on it, and the butterfinger donut is pretty good too.

First time to Portland and I had to come try Voodoo.

Tried the maple bacon bar and it's the business.  My only gripe is that it cost $40 for a dozen of their specialty donuts?  Donuts are good, but not that good to where I should be dropping that much for them.

If it's your frist time to Portland, give it a go.  If you're going back, skip it.
If you're in Portland go try voodoo, get it out of your system. This place is extremely hyped! Blue Star by far has superior donuts!
Didn't hate or love it, I didn't even finish my donut. I got the bubble gum one, the glaze didn't really taste like bubble gum. I was expecting more hype

Maybe I came here too late-it was midnight after all. three of the donuts i wanted to try were already sold out so i got the oreo, chocolate ring, and portland cream. Oreo was the best since there seemed to be a peanut butter glaze thing ontop of everything.

I'm not a huge doughnut fan, but this place is "you have to go to Voodoo when you're in Portland" kind of place.  It's got an edgy soupkitchen-turned-midnight-street-cafe feel. You may encounter some interesting characters on your way in, and even more inside the shop. They sell underwear with their logo on it. So why go? For the experience. We went late at night, got a box, and tried a little bit of everything. They're doughnuts alright. Some of them have funky toppings. Others have awesomely inappropriate names. It's about the vibe and the experience, to me. These are not the best doughnuts I've had. But, Voodoo is an unforgettable doughnut for sure.

Dear Voodoo Doughnut,

I've heard the story so many times. Your founders got high and walked around a grocery store and came up with your doughnut ideas. They then found a piece of commercial real estate in the once-defunct Old Town district next to a hentai theater in the 90's and got really lucky with the way that PDX decided to expand. Their silly little doughnut shop now lives at the heart of Portland's tourism industry. A cheap product that can be made in mass and delivered to a cheap consumer. The McDonald's of bakeries. It's a win-win situation for anyone hoping to consume 500 calories for under $1.

But oh, Voodoo, oh how I despise you. I hate your long lines regardless of the day or season. I hate the way that everyone who visits me in this city insists on going to Voodoo while they're in town, and how I have to stand there with my rolling eyes and crossed arms and pretend to be happy to take them to your establishment. I hate your tired "pink boxes" jokes. I hate the way you've made "maple bacon" a thing now. I just hate you, and you don't deserve it, but I still hate you.

You get two stars, though, for having an excellent reputation as an employer. You provide those who work for you with a livable wage and health care options. Even though it's one of the busiest food spots in town, your employees always seem to be happy to call Voodoo Doughnuts their place of work. Serious high fives for you.

But your doughnuts are still worse than the ones at Safeway. 

Sincerely,
Sara

I am just wondering, when all these "fun" doughnuts the TV shows talk about will be available to people who don't wake up at the Butt Crack of dawn, and stand in line for hours, only to get to the little window, just to find out all they have are nasty, cold, half burned Apple fritters.

Been living here for 7 years, and not one time was able to buy a decent doughnut from Voodoo.

Woman cannot live on a nasty Applefritter alone

Overhyped donut spot... The atmosphere and decor on the donuts were great, friendly service, however, the most important thing to me was the taste/quality of the donuts themselves. I got a box of 4-5 various ones - all too dry and pretty standard. Kind of sad about it.

There are 4 quarters of Portland and VD has the doughnut market cornered in 2 of them.

Like every other foodie pilgrim/ tourist this is one of those places which has to be visited, whether you like it or not.

Got there @ 10:30 and had to wait in a line for about 15 minutes. If it doubles back on itself count on 30. 

While waiting, you can QR a copy of the menu where you can check out the selection.

CASH ONLY. But you shouldn't be spending more than $30 here anyway or you have a donut problem of Homerian scale.

Inside there's a gorgeous wavy chandelier and the menu with pricing on the wall. Best deal is the cashiers selection of 12 donuts, where they pick 12 random ones for you for $17. 

But if you ask if they picked a specific one for you they will look at you with a glazed look and say "I'm not sure".

Just saved you 5 minutes of haggling and you can't be bothered to tell me if you picked a Portland cream? Bought a cream just to find he had picked one.

Save your coffee money and buy at the too cool for school Stumptown branch 3 doors away. Theirs was just not well made. Kids threw theirs away as too acidic.

Nice seating area outside if you are lucky enough to get a table.

They are good doughnuts. Fancy names, fillings, toppings but in the end there's no big revelation apart from a sugar high. And the Portland cream was the best.

The doughnuts are 5 stars delicious, the line is intolerable. 

If you see that there isn't a line, get doughnuts. If there is that abominable line, skip it.

It's a novelty. People either seem to be addictedly crazed to this place, or like me, kind of like meh after you've tried it.

I had the maple bacon donut. There wasn't a balance at all. There's no subtle flavor or gourmetness to this at all. It's a super sweet maple donut with two simple strips of oily bacon on top. It is what it is, and if you were expecting any level of culinary action to this, there is none.

Not that I'm complaining, it fits the niche and its fanbase entirely. Candy covered, cereal covered, it's like cavity central here while being served by hipsters wearing million gauge earrings while a mix of death metal, punk, and hardcore are being blasted through the stereo speakers. Oh, and interesting names of the various doughnuts.

It's worth the touristy visit, but don't expect anything mind blowing unless you love sugar. And lots of it.
Meh doughnuts... a tourist trap.  Fun ideas though, wish they tasted better.
...gimmicky donuts.  hipster scene.   there's much better tasting donuts other spots but this has turned into one of those places friends/family from out of town want to check it out.

As a comparison, this is UNLIKE going to Cafe Dumond in New Orleans where the food and flavors live up to the hype.  Voodoo is just marketing hype encapsulated in an average donut.

I probably wouldn't be as cross if we didn't wait in line for 30 minutes, only to be rushed during the order process.  Not that it matters much in the end.  The donuts and flavors are standard and only stood up by the marketing of kitschy ideas like a human shaped donut Voodoo doll bleeding jelly.  Is that even appealing?  Tourist trap for sure.  Much better donut options in Portland, use the app :)

I had the dirt. Too sweet. However perrrrrrfect with milk.
This location is not bad but  it feels a little awkward when you have people asking you for money right outside of it.

CASH only. This location is smaller than the one on davis.

I know it's touristy, but a cock & balls doughnut?! Come on..that's just plain funny! This place is worth a visit, but go on a Friday afternoon at 2pm like we did - only had to wait in line for a few minutes before we had giant doughnuts in our hot little hands. Not the best doughnut I've ever had, but not too shabby either!

There's a lot of hype, and I felt like blue star donuts is a better option.  Although these donuts are cheaper and have creative toppings, it was overly sweet and not as fluffy as a fresh baked donut should be.  I got the old dirty b, the voodoo man, and the captain crunch with berries (forget the name).  The ODB was good but the Oreos lost their crunch, tasted a bit stale.  And the voodoo man was like a regular donut but made into a funny shape. Captain crunch was nice, but overly sweet like the rest.  A fun stop but not quality ingredients like blue star.

With donut names like "cock and balls" and "voodoo doll", you have to visit this place for the creative ways they bring Homer Simpson's favorite food to a new level.   In the end they taste like slightly above average donuts, but unless it is just really stale or covered with hair and dirt, when does any donut fail to deliver?   Go for the quirkiness of the place, and for the surroundings.   Bonus points for the vegan options.
If you are a tourist and want to say you have been there, go and wait in the stupidly long line and put up with the rude service.  If you want a good donut, there are much better places to go.

Note: If you are going here for vegan doughnuts on a weekend, don't bother. Head over to Sweet Pea Bakery. Support an all vegan bakery with better tasting doughnuts. 

Who do they think they are? The Doughnut Nazi's? Only reason we tried this the first time is because I wanted a vegan doughnut while we were visiting. My husband went to pick them up and when he came back he was a little annoyed. The guy behind the counter was super rude and the line was long. I was surprised that my doughnuts weren't that good and he said neither were his non vegan ones. 

We moved to the Portland area and went again recently after a day walking around town and eating Delicious Thai Cart Food (with awesome service). After waiting in a line for about 30 minutes we get up there and there is only one guy doing the cash register and getting the doughnuts. He's got an attitude like he wishes he wasn't there and he's doing us a favor. We order our doughnuts and I have to scrape the frosting off of mine because it is unbearably sweet. 

Then just today I went down there to get three dozen for my daughters bday tomorrow in class. Line was only about three people out the door. Once I got up to the front there I got a blank stare from a skinny chick that could double as a meth head ( I know I'm being mean). I told her I needed three dozen and I swear she rolled her eyes and sighed. I asked if she had a dozen chocolate glazed vegan doughnuts and she looks at me so perturbed and says "no". So I said, OK, how much you got. She actually starts getting them and then realizes that she does have them. Then I point to above them and say and ask for a dozen of the plain glazed. She snaps at me "are they vegan? If they are, you have to tell me or I'm gonna give you non vegan!" Again, maybe too much meth? It didn't get much better as I picked the remaining.
