She took my money when I was done and her "thanks" was very phony. I walked out of there and swore they would never get any of my money ever again. 

Now I can imagine if their doughnuts were the best around but they are not. My husband gets the non vegan ones and says Krispy Kreme is much better. The vegan ones aren't that great either. Especially the powder. Made me ill. And I just get the feeling that if they are going to treat me that bad when I'm ordering maybe the doughnuts aren't even vegan. Next time I need vegan doughnuts during the week I'm calling a vegan baker and seeing if they can make them for me. Otherwise, if I really want a doughnut I'll wait for Saturday and go to Sweet Pea.

No matter what I put here your gonna go anyway but here it is...

The best thing about this place isn't the doughnuts, its the crazy names and funny shapes. It is my opinion that I have had WAY better doughnuts back at home with no line around the block waiting for me. The doughnuts are not bad but they are in no way the best. A line around the block represents the best... The staff is cool enough, the prices aren't bad and it's a neat little place. However if you have done it once then you know what i'm talking about. Unfortunately I have done it twice. Well played Voodoo...

I'm sad to have to agree with the majority of reviews here...Voodoo didn't live up to the hype.  We have better donuts here in Lehi, Utah.  Sure, they throw a lot of sugar, cereal, oreos, what ever on top, and they might even be the ones that made doing so popular, but others have run with it and improved it vastly.  I think my main issue was the core underlying donut just not being that great.

The one thing I noticed was that everyone in line seemed to be a tourist.  I don't think any of the locals actually come here...makes me wonder if they know of a better place.

Sad visit, still worth a shot, you might like it more than I did.

I have to say I was so excited to be able to go here, after all it was one of the first things that came up when I googled Portland.  Apparently I should have took the time to read some reviews first.  After waiting in line for 25 minutes on a weekday afternoon to get a doughnut, the ordering process was bad, I had no idea what any of them actually were because of the crazy names so had to ask a ton of questions, when all was said and done I walked out with a dozen priced at $24.75 and was ready to experience pure bliss in a pastry, it only took me one bite to realize that the only reason they were popular was the crazy names and the voodoo doughnut.  I got the apple fritter and my mouth was so coated in grease I had to go get a drink to stop from feeling sick.  

In short Save your money and your time, because Krispy Kreme is WAY better.
tourist doughnuts ! great for getting pan handled inline
Stale doughnuts and obnoxious employees. If you want to wait in line for forty five minutes to get doughnuts that have been sitting out all day, then stop by.
Creative, they are donuts. Way overhyped but a nice sugar rush.

I love the interior of this place. With so many great doughnut places out there though, the line is always the biggest turnoff  to me. I do enjoy the Portland Creme, the voodoo, and the Elvis fritter thingy. It's always a treat when someone is visiting town. Don't forget cash!

Eh, it's better than a chain. Donuts are fresh and the chocolate icing is pretty tasty, but when you need a taser or can of pepper spray just to feel safe at their downtown location, well that pretty much sums up how the overall experience is going to go.

The cap'n was the best.  Very marshmallow-ey.

Too much cream in the cock n balls.

The anarchy star one was good -- like a cake.

Looking over what I just wrote, I actually can't believe I went to a donut shop.  I honestly cant rave about the actual donuts, thought, but the creativity factor was pretty cool.  The service was lacking, though.
Bleh . Bland. Dry. Don't go because of all the hype. Go and support other small business donut shops in Portland. Don't wait in line to be disappointed.

I've seen / heard about VooDoo doughnuts literally everywhere - especially Instagram. So when I was visiting my grandma I knew I had to do this while I was in town visiting. The store is really cute and the doughnuts are the cutest thing I've ever seen, but they are SO SWEET AND RICH. If you're really into rich, doughy treats then you'll love this place. It was a little too sweet for me (which is nuts because I'm a huge sugar / sweets eater) but I couldn't even finish one doughnut. Not knowing how sweet they were, my mom and I bought a box of 24 to take back home to give to people and we ended up giving away all of them saving none for ourselves because they were just way too much for us. I think this place is mostly just for looks and to take pics of the doughnuts and if you're going, just buy one to eat there. Other than that, cute place & if you're in Portland, stop by to check out all the hype!

I've been to VD a few times and it's a nice touristy experience, but there's better things to do in PDX.  Donuts are good, and the creativity is a lot of fun (I like creative food) and a dozen specialty donuts are still cheaper than a dozen donuts at Top Pot in Seattle, but that doesn't necessarily translate to being a good deal.  Still - something worth going to once or twice.

Also - I saw a lot of people there with small kids.  A note to parents: you might want to review the donuts (both the names and the appearance of them) before taking a four or five year-old into the shop... unless you're really ready to explain some terms...

Honestly this is the most over rated place. The lines are definitely all for the gram which I get because who doesn't want a colorful donut post to prove that you were in pdx?! But in terms of the taste department I have to say it's like they took a Krispy kreme put some crappy frosting on it, dunked it in breakfast cereal and called it a day. Was underwhelming but who knows, maybe I just got a bad flavor- but my two friends also felt that way. The one bright side it's only two bucks so who really cares. As long as u get the gram.

I love the donuts here. Hands down, they are just the best. They are consistently good every time I've gone over the years. What I don't like is that the last time I went in there, there were some street kids sitting on the floor inside, just hanging out, with their pitbull. Then a guy walks in carrying his small dog, and stands quietly in line behind us. Out of nowhere, the pitbull lunges at the man and the small dog, snarling and trying to attack it as the owner is holding it. It scared everyone in there to the point where no one said anything, just stared with their mouths open. The street kids started yelling at the customer, saying he shouldn't bring his dog in there, and theirs was a service dog. The man holding the small dog didn't say anything, just pulled out a lanyard he had around his neck to show that actually, HIS was the service dog. I really doubt the street kids' pitbull was a service dog that just randomly viciously attacks other people's dogs. The worst part? The girl ringing us up didn't even glance over there or blink an eye. How about you keep crazy animals out of there and don't let street kids camp out- that makes me not want to go back.

I did not intend on going here because I don't eat deep fried food, but it was actually only a few blocks away from my hotel and they had some vegan donuts. 

I tried a few of the donuts here to get an idea. You don't really want to eat a lot of them, so I shared them and they lasted a few days. 

The best vegan one I had (which is obviously not healthy) is the one with chocolate icing, oreo cookies and drizzled with peanut butter. It is good, but you probably would only want to eat half of it to avoid the sugar headache! 

I also tried some of the vegan apple fritter, tasted pretty much like an apple fritter. 

I also got a chocolate cake donut and a white cake donut with maple icing. These were ok, they were a little dry and did not taste very fresh. Perhaps fresh would be better. 

I also got a chocolate one filled with vegan vanilla pudding another day, it was pretty good too. 

I went at 11 pm on a Thursday night and it took me about 25 minutes before I could order.

Friday night we went around the same time and it only took a few minutes to get in. 

It's super chaotic there and not very easy to order vegan donuts as you can't see all that they have available, and there are no names. So I had to like describe what kind of donut I was looking for and they quickly try to find what you want. 

Basically don't go expecting any particular donut if you're vegan, it's a random mishmash of what they have, and the later it gets, the less vegan ones they have in stock.

If the place wasn't so dirty and chaotic I would give it more stars. It just isn't a pleasant experience buying from them and not being able to see all of the options and get what you want. 

I'm sure vegans won't mind that the donuts basically would taste the name as the non vegan ones. I doubt I'd be able to taste the difference.

The coolest, funkiest place for donuts I've ever seen. It is certainly a staple of Portland. I was amazed at the selection - very creative with their donuts. Donuts didn't taste much different than any regular donut you would order - had the original Voodoo donut. Very cleaver creations!

Portland Trip - Snack #1 
Objective - A doughnut with a side of voodoo

Pro: Solid doughnuts.  Lots of variety.  What can you say?  The voodoo doughnut is just plain fun.

Con: Employees seemed like they wanted nothing more than to be out of the store.  Unhelpful and unpleasant--at least the customer-facing employees were.

Overall: Would recommend to the "have to try it once because I'm a tourist" friend.  Be prepared to wait awhile outside.

My Experience: The line doubled back outside of the front door.  After waiting an hour to get inside, we were excited to finally get to the cashier and start picking out some doughnuts.  Here's how our dialogue went:

Us:  "Hi!"  *smile*  "How much is the voodoo doll doughnut?"
Them:  *bored, sarcastic, unpleasant* "It's priced what it is."
Us:  "Oh okay, sorry this is our first time here."
Them:  "..."
Us:  "For the voodoo dozen do we get to pick the doughnuts in the dozen?"  
Them:  "You can pick whatever you want to be in the dozen, but you'll pay for each one of them individually."
Us:  "Oh, okay.  So, what's in the dozen then?"
Them:  "There's some cake, there's some special, there's some normal."
Us:  "...Okay, we'll just take a dozen."
Them:  *proceeds to grab random doughnuts*
Us:  "Does a voodoo doll doughnut come with the voodoo dozen?"
Them:  "Yeah.  We can add it on top and you can pay for it."
Us:  "Alright.  Let's add one then.  And add a maple bacon too."

We left far less than satisfied with their customer service.  It felt like they thought we were idiots and were doing us a huge favor.  I guess it's hard to maintain quality when you have employees with a "I don't care about you at all because I have another hundred customers waiting right behind you" mentality.

Absolutely pathetic.

After waiting in line for 30+ minutes, we ordered a dozen donuts for our family, including two voodoo donuts (apparently their specialty) and a Froot Loops doughnut for our 3-year-old.  After finally ordering our doughnuts (which totaled a, frankly ridiculous, $23), we were pushed on by staff, not giving me a chance to check that the box actually contained what we ordered, which is something I usually make a point of doing.  Upon reaching home, we opened the box to find that the aforementioned three donuts were missing entirely (in spite of us being charged for them).  In addition, the doughnuts we *did* get were dry and boring, in spite of their attractive descriptions on their menu.

Pros: None.  An absolute waste of time and money.  Dunkin' Donuts doesn't exactly peddle high-quality doughnuts, but at least you know what you're getting.  I'd spend $20 at DD before I spent another cent at Voodoo.  Heading to Krispy Kreme tomorrow to get some fairly priced and consistently tasty doughnuts from people who know how to count.

In summation: avoid Voodoo Doughnuts at all costs.  You'd be better off just eating your money, it'd certainly be less dry.

I have to say, the donuts here are not my favorite. I tried the Maple Bacon Bar and VooDoo Doll, and they were both just mediocre at most. I loved the decoration and the service is friendly, but my donuts were not as soft and tasty as I imagined it to be. A bit disappointed, but definitely still worth a visit if you ever find yourself in Portland.

Their service was very unfriendly and I almost retracted my order after being assisted by one of their workers. I asked for the different types and she seemed to want to rush me and was distracted/looking elsewhere when I was asking what type of doughnut contained what ingredients or flavors. Are you hiring people with no personalities or people who just hate their jobs? I ordered the orange tang powder doughnut with mango jelly and a cocoa puffs doughnut. Hrmm..let's see how the donuts fare since the service sucks. 

My orange donut was way too sweet. I felt like I was eating diabetes if that were possible. I was dissatisfied and disgruntled and dis-everything after biting in my doughnut several times. Then I tried the cocoa puffs doughnut...and yum! It was much better and I then though....why did I decide to venture off form the norm. I LOVE chocolate. What made me think I would enjoy a foreign mango jelly and orange tang doughnut???

I didn't try the maple bacon regardless of how many people rant about the thing. it's just a maple doughnut with...bacon on it. wth?

Anyways, once was enough and I went for the novelty experience (which I highly recommend). But it's definitely nothing to rant about....

ps: I went mid-day on a weekday and there were only approximately 5 customers ahead of me...apparently this place gets crazy packed and lines go out the door...and I haven't the faintest clue why....

Fun place to go out with friends, pretty good doughnuts. But I think the reason everybody likes it is obviously for the novelty. The doughnuts them selves, at least to be, are average, pretty all right doughnuts. But You don't go for the taste, you go for the bacon flavored maple bar, or the penis doughnuts. In reality, I would much rather go to Krispy Kreme any day, but also love the creative designs and flavors. There is always a huge line, especially late at night. I always get the Miami Vice, boring looking, but super yummy.

The Burnside location line is too long, but it is a great photo op moment.  Try their Sandy location instead, same thing but with much less of a wait.  As for the quality, umm, it's okay.  As for the creativity, it's definitely a go try it place.

The line is always way too long. They may want to consider getting a larger store and hire more people  to accommodate the crowd. People don't generally want to wait in line for an hour and a half for a damn doughnut! I am not a big fan of their doughnuts. Yes, they have interesting types, but the flavor isn't there.

Overhyped and underwhelming but definitely part of the "Portland experience." I happened to be walking by at a low traffic hour so I stopped by to grab a bacon maple bar donut. It was tasty but sort of looked and felt like it had been sitting there in the case for a while. Nevertheless I dutifully consumed it in just a few minutes. Later in the weekend I went for the true gold nearby at Blue Star - if you can only afford one (via time, dollars, or calories), I highly recommend Blue Star over Voodoo any day.

It's a donut shop folks.  Yes, I stood in line, late at night, ironically on National Donut Day.  Cute & kitschy, for what it is, it's not a bad donut.  One of those touristy things you think you should do in Portland.  Do or don't!

Can someone say, DIABETES?  I CAN!  DIABETES GALORE!  I don't understand what all the hype is about!  The doughnut batter/base itself wasn't a favorable texture or flavor - neither fluffy or buttery.  Maybe just, doughy or overcooked.  I've definitely had better.

The only thing people rave about are the unique and interesting toppings... but that doesn't mean it tastes all that great.  And that doesn't make a good doughnut - good.  It's OK.  It didn't blow my mind.  No, wait - I take it back.  The fact that their doughnuts was so friggin' sweet, blew my mind.  Maybe a few blood vessels too.  They were tasty, but definitely overwhelmingly sweet.  Even though I bought a Voodoo Dozen (a dozen of their selection), I can't bring myself to eat taste another.  Yes, I tried their infamous Bacon Maple and I thought the Bacon was good, like pancakes and bacon explosion in your mouth.  It was a innovative doughnut but can be executed better. 

I am also impressed that they have vegan donuts.  I tried the Voodoo doll, and it was equally as sweet as the Bacon Maple.  However, the texture was pretty good considering how difficult making delicious vegan pastries can be.

Worth the visit.... I GUESS.

I'm going to agree with what seems to be the general consensus: worth it once for the experience, but not necessarily worth returning.

I waited for about an hour on Sunday afternoon, which wasn't too terrible. A girl in sweats with bright hair was singing to those in line, trying to put her name out there. Just to warn you if she comes back again, she's definitely not as good as she thinks she is...but it made the wait a little more interesting.

When I finally made it in, I ordered 3 doughnuts:
Bacon Maple Bar ($3): arguably the doughnut Voodoo is most famous for. It was delicious, but at the same time, I could have bought a maple doughnut almost anywhere and put a couple of strips of bacon on it and it would have been the same.

Portland Cream ($1.75): I got this since the menu described it as "Portland's Official Doughnut." I didn't discern any difference from a Boston Kreme, really. The cream was light and delicious, but the chocolate layer on top proved to be too sweet for me. I had to scrape it off to finish.

Lemon Chantilly Cruller ($1.40): the crullers here are really good. This one was also covered in frosting, but since I saved it for later, most of the frosting came off on the paper I'd wrapped it in. Only then did I think I was good. The actual cruller was light with a perfect texture.

Prices are fair. Not cheap, but not overly expensive.

Overall, I think the doughnuts here have too much frosting. I have a sweet tooth, but even I can't handle it! The doughnuts are good, but not amazing. For the line you wait in, I would like something better. It's considered a Portland institution though, and you can easily tell it's a tourist destination from all the souvenirs they sell inside. If you haven't been before, go for the experience, but know that you can find equal or better doughnuts without the wait.

The donuts are good, but I find better pastries at Winco. The lines are crazy sometimes and it's really not worth the wait.
Overrated doughnut shop, but still one of the best.

CASH ONLY PLACE, THEY DON'T TAKE PLASTIC AT ALL, WTF??

Okay, I guess I'm not all that impressed with the whole Voodoo Doughnut thing on several levels.  I waited in the long line for almost an hour to get a dozen cuz I've never been to Portland before & this is sort of a Portland institution.  I ordered the 'Voodoo Dozen' which means the cashier pics them out.  Some of them are unusual, i.e. a doughnut with oreos sprinkled on it, another with fruitloops on it, etc., but then some of the ones she gave me were just as ordinary as ordinary can be, like a maple bar, and a plain old chocolate covered, plus a few others.  Those weren't 'Voodoo' at all from what I could tell.  One I was hoping the woman would include was the maple bar with bacon strips because I'd read about that one before coming here, but for some odd reason she left that one out in favor of some more ordinary nothing-special doughnuts instead.  I asked her if she could swap one of the ordinary doughnut for it -- she said no, but I could buy it for an additional $2.25, which I did, even though I felt like that was sort of a ripoff.  The doughnuts themselves taste okay as far as doughnuts go, but I wouldn't say they are  anything all that special or spectacular as all the hype & vibe of this place would lead you to believe they are.  They're just doughnuts, some of which have an interesting, unique visual flair.  That said, I was really surprised when she told me they don't take plastic!  This makes NO sense, this is a very popular booming business, it's not like they can't afford the fees of taking plastic (A LOT of other less popular businesses in this area DO take plastic).  She told me I could use their ATM, but I'm sure the fees I get charged for that wouldn't be worth it, however, luckily I had enough cash to pay for them.  Come on Voodoo, this is ridiculous, don't be so damn cheap, take plastic you morons!  IMHO this place is way over hyped for what it is.  I can see how this would be fun for little kids to get some of the unusual doughnuts with cereal or cookies sprinkled on them, so that might be worthwhile under those circumstances, but otherwise Voodoo Doughnuts  really isn't anything all that great.
Sorry to say the taste just didn't meet the hype.  Too many rules, signs and restrictions for a donut that didn't even taste fresh.
Love the place and the atmosphere but my doughnut was not very good this time. It was hard :( never had that experience here before.

I was told I had to go to Voodoo while I was in Portland, so I made it a must on my travel list.  Me and group went (in the rain, no less) around 10pm and waited only around half an hour, though the line quickly tripled behind us! Remember that it's cash only and you can ogle the window for the menu (or look on Yelp).  

The overall experience (funky decor, bright pink boxes, tongue-in-cheek names, gluten-free friendly) is super cool - I think people are right in saying you have to go at least once to get the vibe of it.  That being said, I don't think the donuts are the best - they're really only good because they're big and they're loaded with toppings.  As far as the donut itself goes, it's good but not THAT good.  

I had the Apple Fritter, the Blueberry Cake Donut, the Dirt Donut, and the classic Glazed donut.  Don't worry, I didn't eat it all at once - four donuts lasted me an entire weekend because they were fairly large (except for the cake donuts, which are normal sized) - but it didn't feel like any of them were revelations or the best donut I've ever had. 

Overall I'd go again if someone asked me to, but I wouldn't go out of my own on my own or wait in a line longer than 15-20 minutes.
Creative doughnuts, somewhat tasteless. Employes are arrogant and my main reason for not rating higher.

No idea what the hype is about. Yes, it's a quirky Portland place. The donuts are "meh" but they are shaped like some pretty interesting stuff. The line is pretty long, ~2+ hours, but there's always a random street musician singing and strumming while you wait. Tip that dude - it's by far the best experience of the place. Service sucks and you better know what you want when you're up. Yes, everyone should go there at least once if you live here. No, I don't take people here if they're visiting me from out of town. Good luck. :)

Good donuts but not the best I've had. I prefer mom and pop shops but this place has a very touristy and gimmicky.

I like their regular options like buttermilk and the chocolate bar but anything more creative struck me as creative for the sake of being creative instead of truly imagining and creating something original. For instance, lemon dream one just had mini marshmallows thrown into a yellow glaze. I guess it was a dream because it had marshmallows?
it tastes just like donuts! but in fun shapes i guess. don't be afraid of the line, it moves fast. they also have a bathroom!

Not the freshest donuts. Stale Captain Crunch. 

But props for the glittered wall and eccentric donut creations.

The jam in the voodoo doll donut is good. Doesn't taste like the artificial stuff.

No matter how much hype the locals or television food shows give this place, I thought the donuts were way too sweet. The maple bacon donut was pretty unique, and tasted delicious. 

However the basic voodoo style guy stuffed with raspberry jelly put me into diabetic shock. I don't think anyone needs to have that much sugar in a couple mouthfuls.

Voodoo is a place to go the first time you are in Portland...and then never again. The donuts are average. I would recommend trying the 'weirdest' donut that sounds appetizing to you, the more 'normal' donuts are not of high quality.

The midnight bucket of donuts is a good deal if you are a poor college student or intoxicated with a huge sugar craving.
Awesome donuts, but the line is too long to wait for. I rather go to the SE location if I am really craving Voodoo.  I wish they would relocate the downtown location to a bigger place.

Voodoo Doughnut is a Portland novelty, not a good doughnut bakery.  I would say go at lease once, just to say you have. Luckily we hit it at the right time and did not wait in line at all.  The doughnuts are very dry and not good at all.  My daughters thought they were literally the worst doughnuts they have ever had.  We will not go back.  If you're looking for a good doughnut, Voodoo is not the place, do not waste your time.

Not sure what the entire hype is... Waited in line for about 20 min.... Got several different items all over priced..... Bacon maple was good but I think Top pot makes it better.... Hipster place fun to see for sure

Voodoo Doughnuts is one of those experiences that you must check off your list of places to go while in PDX.  Stand in line and debate with your friends and family which doughnut you should get. Hum, the maple bacon bar, one of the many rare doughnut combinations that Voodoo has to offer, or the cock n' balls (three Boston Creme doughnuts in the shape of eh hem)... Like that was a hard decision. Don't be put off by the crowd that frequents Voodoo's stoop, they may hit you up for some spare change but more likely they will want a doughnut. Disclaimer: I am not a big fan of doughnuts, have had better ones, but after giving Voodoo only two stars I still recommend going there.

Voodoo donut is a tourist trap but is very good, the one thing I didn't like about the my trip that I made today after driving up from Reno Nv was the staff was very rude and too cool! If your gonna be rude and act like I don't matter and be bothered by me ordering than I'll never be back.

I don't really need to say much about this place: Just read the other reviews for that stuff! What I can say is that yes, the place running out of Voodoo Doughnuts was VERY common. I almost never saw them there! But now, they've invented a new doughnut, from what I can tell, and it's basically the same flavors as the original voodoo but without all of the hype and stigma of being 'the doughnut'. So now, if you're a local in there for a doughnut, you're good to go, and if you're a tourist there for a bit of an edible, sadistic souvenir and bragging rights, go on ahead. Everyone is happy. Another thing is that the people who work here are so very, very rude. So extremely rude. Giant gutter punk brutes who just glare and hand you your doughnuts. I'm no posh princess or anything, I dye my hair and get down with all of that crap, but do not treat me like trash just because you work at such an esteemed location! If I make a joke or say something nice, RETURN THE FAVOR OR QUIT THE JOB!

In any case.....I highly recommend the mango filled. And the Grape Ape. Nomnomnom.

After seeing Voodoo Doughnut on 'No Reservations', I super excited to try it.  I came to Voodoo at 2pm on a Wednesday and was surprised to see a long line.  Don't people in Portland have to work?  I ended up waiting about 40 minutes to get in the door.  

I always judge donuts shops on their ability to make a simple raised donut and cake donut.  So I ordered a glazed raised donut, a blueberry cake donut, and one of their cherry-filled, voodoo doll-shaped donuts.  I honestly felt like I should have ordered more after the long wait but alas I knew that 3 would be my limit.  

After stopping off to pick up a quart of milk to wash them down, I headed back to my hotel to tear into my much awaited donuts.  Unfortunately, I was pretty disappointed with every one of them.  I've had a hell of lot better glazed and blueberry donuts in my life so I'd rate these 2.5 stars.  The voodoo doll donut didn't taste any better and wasn't even that nicely decorated like the ones I saw on TV (more like a bloated doll with stubby arms and crap frosting job).  Definitely not worth the long wait.  Perhaps I should have gotten the bacon maple bar instead? 

The donuts are worthy of 3-stars but I'm docking a star for the excessively long waiting line.  I'd only come back here again if the line was less than a 10-minute wait.

I want to say I have never tasted the donuts but they all look so interesting and artistic.  I've heard the donuts were average but the waiting line says otherwise.  A true Portland tourist destination.

Oh, Voodoo. You broke my heart. How I wanted to like you.

We came here on a ridiculously steamy Friday night (88 degrees at 10:30 pm ... in Portland?) to pay tribute. We waded through what appears to be Portland's version of what every city has ... an obnoxious club district. It was very Portland-style, though, and I leave you to interpret that in your own way.

We got the Voodoo Dozen and brought the box back to our gracious hostess. We all agreed that the novelty far outstripped the flavor. These babies just ain't fresh. No amount of Butterfinger, bubble-gum flavor, or M & Ms can hide that. Not to mention the fact that I wanted to clock all the little club bitches teetering on their tiny heels. (Isn't this supposed to be the Northwest? Get out your Timberlands, ladies, even on a crazy-hot night like tonight! Represent, damn you!)

Two stars for sheer originality. I would still get married here. But I am already married. Signed, Crazy From the Heat.

OVERRATED

Way too sugary and too much.  The only reason I would recommend going is for the "experience".  Where else can you find the most random donuts... ever??

We sampled a few.  We just asked the lady working to pick us 4.  We sampled one with peanut butter and Oreos, coco puffs, mini M&M's and lastly, one with captain crunch.  I prefer my cookies and cereal with milk and definitely NOT on a donut with way too much frosting.

I was on a sugar high for like a week after this (OK exaggerating a little), and will never be back.

This definitely is a tourist attraction and I'm sure they'd probably not like to be called that but it is what it is. We paid for the 90 min parking because you obviously need it since there is obviously a line that you can normally see from the street. Suprisingly it's not chaotic standing in line. You don't have to scrunch over to the side to let passersby squeeze by. It almost seems like no one uses the sidewalk down there maybe because they know several silly gooses are waiting out on the street to get a taste of the voodoo. 

There is live entertainment while you wait from the hoards of wayward, homeless, or vagrant "residents" of the downtown area. We were treated to the unsmooth sounds of a couple covering the latest hits of the 80's, 90's, and today. Rather unpleasant, but people gotta do what they gotta do to make a dollar. God bless 'em. 

What I did find nice is that they have a small laminated menu that you can pass around the line so that people have an idea as to what they might want to order before they get inside the doors. I kind of makes you feel like you have to be ready when you get inside the door or feel the wrath of a "Soup Nazi" type experience. "No doughnut for you!" as they snatch the doughy confection from your ever-waiting hands. Only kidding. There is also a person that works for Voodoo outside who keeps you informed about the doughnuts and tells you interesting things about the selections. He also said the menu is online which helped since the menu didn't seem to make it to us before we were almost next in line. The menu can be found on your smartphone or "dumbphone" prior to entering the building at voodoodonuts.com.

Cash only as many people have said. The doughnuts are really inexpensive though, so scrape some change off the floor of your car and got get a doughnut. 

Now the doughnuts themselves I didn't find anything spectacular about them but they were good and not dry by any means. It's more of an experience then a go-to place to eat because obviously you could get a doughnut elsewhere with less of a wait and the same quality for the same price. Just being honest. Mad props to the people that work there though for standing at a register on rotating shifts 24 hours a day 7 days a week exchanging doughnuts for cash. The frowny faces are free with purchase.
Doughnut tastes great, but it'd be better if that's not cash only. The worst part is their restroom. I had to use it after a long drive, but man that is disgusting!

Really sorry to right such a bad review but i fell the need to warn everyone - 
A lot of hipe and beautiful colors, but It's not testy at all! Felt like eating plastic. Gave most of what we bought to a homeless. Skip the line and go somewhere else.

well. so i came here since SOMEBODY is a huge anthony bourdain fan and had to try this place since it was featured on his show. i thought it was a cool name for a doughnut place, so we waited in line (freakin long) and waited our turn. 

obviously, we were expecting really delicious doughnuts, but were totally completely disappointed. i ordered the mexican hot chocolate doughnut, the buttermilk bar, and a couple of cream filled doughnuts, to get a variety. they were out of the gay bar, which i was tremendously saddened by. my anthony-bourdain-fan-fiance got the bacon maple bar (the one he HAD to try), the ODB, and the miami vice something or other. 

i took one bite out of each doughnut, and i was sick to my stomach! it was way too sweet, and it made me crave those hashbrowns we passed at the diner on the way to the park. anyway, we were both disappointed. the pink box was overrated.

kudos, though, for having vegan options!

I'm glad they have vegan donuts, but their always dry, and I can find better donuts elsewhere.  Its always too busy, loud, and crowded. The sales people have always been rude to me as well, so I just stay away. Only good to go if you're a tourist who can't find anywhere else to go (even though there is a wonderful thing called google).

CASH ONLY.

Voodoo Doughnut is worth visiting when you are in Portland for the experience, but just once. I see it as just another establishment that keeps Portland weird ;) I had the Voodoo Doll which basically is a raspberry jelly filled doughnut topped with chocolate frosting and pretzel stakes. Though I do not find the taste of the doughnuts extraordinary, I do find the different designs on the Voodoo Dolls interesting. Each Voodoo Doll has its own unique features which I thought was pretty cool... 

Other than the special decorations and the weirdness, it is no different that any other donuts. Does it worth the wait? Maybe not...

Came here for the hype, 
got the vegan pb&j donut
taste was good, but the texture was like a pb&j sandwich
A little pricey for donuts, I didn't really like it overall, but I'm not really a huge donut person either. I would say they're pretty tasty

There's the appeal that it's a part of Portland culture, but the donuts just aren't that great. They are overly sweet and move on the novelty side. They're fun, and if you've never had 'em I think you should definitely try them. If you love them, knock yourself out. 

You can even get married at VooDoo if you so please!

As for me, I'd rather go to Blue Star or Pip's.

I never trust anything that is overly hyped and this is no exception. Good donuts but nothing that I haven't eaten before. The popularity rises from the perfect gimmick, great naming convention, and freakish appeal. Great place to visit if the line isn't too long, but nothing to camp out for. The girls and I had the Bacon maple bar, Vudoo Donut Doll and the Butterfingering. All good and hit the spot. They offer some pretty cool creations and they are open late, but I prefer my donuts from little mom and pop shops. They always seem to much better...with no gimmicks attached.

Donuts: OK.
Toppings: Eccentric but not exactly tasty.
Decor: Awesome.
Hype: Through the ROOF! Who the f*ck would wait in line an hour for this?

I had such high hopes. But Voodoo will definitely NOT be making my Top Donuts list. :-(
They have something called a Portland cream donut. It's a Boston cream donut. guess Asa Lovejoy won...

Happened to get in at one of the rare times when there is a wait less than 20 minutes. For that, it was worth it just for the experience. Fun times fun photos, good donuts. Nothing crazy though other than the flavor concotions!

Overhyped?  Of course.  But at this point it has moved into the realm of must try destinations in Portland and honestly I am not disappointed at all I went and would even go back. I dont get the "pricey" critisism.  Yeah, its not winchells where you can get donuts for $1-2, but we got a Capt Crunch, a Pothole, and a "large" coffee for under $6 so I was actually surprised at how affordable it was.  We hit it up around 8AM on a Friday and there were only 4 or 5 people in front of us.  The donuts are in two separate display cases and the menu above doesnt list what is in all of them (or else I didnt notice as the place is trippy) so I wish they had menus.  I can see being really stressed if there are 45 people behind you and after 30 minutes in line you just wanna make sure and order something good and have a few questions.  The capt crunch was tasty...simple but tasty.  I got the pothole so I could try their famous bavarian cream, which was pretty good once I got to it but cream occupied MAYBE 20% of the inside which was severely disappointing.  Speaking of head scratchers, being a DONUT place...in raining PORTLAND no less...can I please get a LARGE cup of coffee?  It wasnt that good either and the coffee station was out of most everything.  Act like you been there before and station one person in line while the other gets coffee across the alley, on the other side of the patioo seating. :) One size which was a standard small-medium cup and as the line built up I wasnt waiting in line for a refill. Anyways, donuts were tasty but nothing earth shattering.  They do use yeast so you get a thick, more hearty donut which personally I enjoyed. A few notes...parking is street.  Avoid the lot across the street if possible.  My total was $2.50 and dude didnt have ANY coin change.  I had 40 cents, so $2.40 and he wouldnt take it. He refused to give me my keys until I went somewhere to get coins...or overpaid.  Shrugged at me like "hey, what are you going to do clown, I got your keys." UNREAL.  Speaking of cash, cash only at Voodoo.  They do have an ATM in there but you will get charged $2.75 or so by your bank to use it.  Overall, I'd hit it.  It is a destination, it is reasonably priced, there is always some kind of scene over there, and it was FUN.  That's the name of the game...FUN.  Everything doesn't have to be a gourmet experience. :)

When visiting Portland Voodoo donuts is a must visit once donut shop.  They have a wide selection from your common donut right up to the exotic  XXX donuts.  My suggestion is to look at the donut selections and make your choices before you reach the counter because once there the counter people push you to order very fast.  The donuts are really good but not great. The donuts are expensive but the whole experience makes it worthwhile.   I would have given it 5 stars if not for the location.  While you are waiting in line to get into voodoo donuts you are constantly accosted by the street people wanting money.  They can be very aggressive and become very vocal if you don't give them money.

Sigh. This place is iconic to Portland and if I had a dollar every time I heard someone say that they should go to Voodoo when they're here I'd have enough to buy several dozen far superior doughnuts. This place is overrated, period. I have several gripes, concerning both locations, starting with the most obvious one- GET ANOTHER CASHIER. Seriously, waiting in line for 30-60 minutes for mediocre doughnuts is just not the business. If you're at the downtown location anytime at night, expect a throng of drunk people trying like hell to figure what they're going to order, which only slows down the process. Sure, while you wait you can stare at the totally, like, kitschy gaudy decoration and marvel how quirky this doughnut shop is but then after the first 20 minutes of waiting you realize you could be doing much better things with your life like making a sandwich, watching E! News Network or I dunno, getting a doughnut somewhere else. Just some ideas. The doughnuts themselves? Not even that good. They've never tasted fresh and they are definitely NOT worth the wait. If you want to do a typical thing while visiting or living in Portland, sure go here. Knock yourself out. You're basically paying for the Voodoo brand and there's a whole bevy of great pastry and doughnut shops here.

Not sure what the hype is about this is pretty standard fair. Went late night to miss the line, glad we did as the overall experience was disappointing given all the hype. None the less, the donut is a good donut and they add a flair of out of the ordinary toppings.

When does a doughnut cross the line and become a cupcake?  Our house is enamored with both, but they both have to be good.  Top Pot is a stone's throw from our house so the bar is set high for doughnuts.  I'm just not a big fan of doughnuts or cupcakes that are covered with breakfast cereal or mini marshmallows.  Save that for cupcakes or cakes.

Admittedly, I did like the consistency of the devil's food cake doughnut I had.  It was rich and chocolatey.  Definitely not inedible but I didn't think that it needed all that excessive frosting.  We did split a plain cake doughnut but Voodoo's version was just ok.  Not Top Pot.  We routinely do plain cake and plain old fashioned from TP because they are just right.

Maybe what turned me off was the huge buckets of day-old doughnuts set up near the sole table in VD.  Sure, we could have gotten one and tried most of the menu, but ugh. I really rather not think of the aforementioned excessive frosting, yet there the buckets are.  Buckets that used to house all that crazy frosting, staring me in the face.  Yikes.

I visited Voodoo Donuts yesterday for the first time. There I waited in a lengthy line for about half an hour. When I finally got inside the building I noticed some pretty eccentric decor, music and donuts! I ordered a Homer Simpson, Grape Ape and a Old Dirty Bastard donut. The donuts were definitely fresh and not stale. Also extremely filling. However...while the donuts do have an appealing and different LOOK, there is nothing special about the TASTE. These donuts weren't "amazing" unfortunately. I have definitely had better. It was worth a try and I can see why they get so much hype! But I honestly felt like I was eating a donut from the grocery store bakery! If your visiting Portland give it a try. Why not? It's the touristy thing to do. But don't visit having high expectations!

Hype! Hype! Hype! Being from out of town, this was naturally on our to do list. I so wish it was worth it. The place is cool with weird decor and such with also a long line. When you get in and see the display of donuts you think omg yum! There are all types of different shapes and colors to choose from. When we got our bag of yummies, we were so disappointed, we had 3 different donuts that had cereal on them and they all tasted stale and old, it was a sad day. We preferred blue star donut!

Just an average donut shop. Actually, I think they are overrated.

The last time I went there I ordered a raspberry filled donut and it was only full of air, unfortunately!

I prefer Krispy Kreme after 9 at night, when you can get a really good deal on a dozen.

i love donuts!  i've been to portland multiple of times but this was my first visit to voodoo donuts.  i really wanted to order a variety of donuts but i'm in running shape so i limited myself to one m & m cake donut.  it was very underwhelming.  i know i should have tried other donuts too.  maybe on another trip.  i guess i missed out on the "cok and balls" donut.

i went on a monday morning and there was a 5 minute wait.  oh they take cash only.
The donuts are good but not great.  Certainly not worth waiting in line for an hour.

I obviously didn't do my homework, because I managed to eat two very BLAH donuts in the two times I went here. 

The maple joint was a sad blob of dough with hardly any maple flavor and some creepy red sprinkles, while the orangatang was another sad blob of dough with a horrible artificial orange flavor. 

Would definitely give them another try...I don't think I could do worse than  I already have!

Definitely over-hyped, but still worth the visit. The locals prefer Blue Star (apparently), but the tourists only know about Voodoo. At least the doughnuts here are really cheap! This location is open 24 hours, and it's smack in the middle of DT, so I'm sure it gets busy at night time. It also has a grungy look on the inside, but it fits the store name. We tried the bacon maple bar doughnut and old dirty bastard doughnut. These are pretty filling so it's hard to eat too many in one sitting. They tasted like... sweet... doughnuts. The bacon on the maple bar was an interesting combination. I definitely liked the old dirty bastard doughnut better, probably bc I'm a chocolate fan. It has chocolate, Oreos, and peanut butter.
Worst place ever. Rude personnel. And the doughnuts aren't even worth the price.  Doughnuts from Safeway taste way better.

Living in Seattle I've ventured off to Oregon about 6 times in the past 3 years.  Of those four times, a trip to VooDoo was never passed up.  

First hearing about it from Anothony Bourdain and his encounter with the "Maple Bacon Bar", I made that my doughnut of choice.  It was a little to sweet for my liking and I could have done without the bacon but I still enjoyed it.  The doughnut itself was soft and moist, not doughy.  My friend had the "No Name".  I loved it, it was like a different take on a s'more.

I have tried just about every doughnut on the menu and can narrow it down to a top three: The Memphis Mafia, Miami Vice and McMinnville Cream.

VooDoo wins for fun and comfort.

I am not a fan of the super sweet frosting and topping overload but it keeps me from overeating!  These doughnuts are soft, moist and made fresh.  A plus in my book! They also provide a vegan selection.

A must when traveling with young adults and the young at heart!

TIPS:
- Open 24 Hours
- Street Parking
- Cash Only (ATM inside)
- Long Lines
- Selection is limited in the evenings.
- Bring a Camera

We waited a really long time in line. Definitely a tourist destination. The donuts are unique, but pale in comparison to the taste of Blue Star donuts (a local favorite). I did enjoy my "Old Dirty Bastard" donut, with chocolate frosting, Oreo cookies, and peanut butter.

All I heard from friends when I told them I was visiting Portland was "go to Voodoo Doughnut!" so I did.  I didn't mind waiting in line because there's always something interesting to look at in Portland, the "Keep Portland Weird" sign painted on the building across from Voodoo, the glitter painted on the walls of the building, the signage for Voodoo (which showed their signature doughnut with a pretzel sticking out of it).  Great!

The girl behind the counter was fairly lack-luster.  I mean, realize that you work at THE Voodoo Doughnut... you're kind of a big deal... people come from all over and wait in line for upwards of an hour to obtain your product.  So have a little enthusiasm please?  Voodoo is not just about doughnuts, it about the experience, the kitschy vibe, the decor, the fun doughnut names etc.  The staff should reflect this.

All the doughnuts in the case looked amazing, but I opted for the original (when in Rome, right?).  It was good, not AMAZING, but good and given the overall experience put together with the good doughnut I can see why so many people recommend this spot.

Long lines as in wowzers long lines and sarcastic a$$ employee (Dood with the dollar coin sized earring). I asked politely for some napkins and said to me "ohhhh sorry" and just stared at me, so i asked again and again he said the same damn thing. I went to the next cashier and found napkins. What would have been a 3 is now 2z maybe i dis jot get the lingo or maybe this is a portland thing but thats that. The donuts were tooo sweet for me and could not see what the fuss is all abt. I am glad i tried it since its an must try in these parts of the country.

I want to like you more than just 3 stars Voodoo, really....but your cereal donuts can be very stale, your regular cake doughnuts are really sweet...too sweet, all I can taste is sugar and not anything else. 

I'll come back and try again...but I'm disappointed that you didn't live up to all the hype.
Not sure what I'm missing here or what's the big deal. Stale cereal on a doughnut isn't cutting it. Overly sweet for my taste. To each his own.

Most over-rated cap I have ever eaten. Served by exceedingly rude hipsters.
Hours later I can still feel the layer of grease in my mouth.
I am assuming these positive reviews are from tourists who felt obligated to give a good review after waiting in line so long for this garbage.
Came here for the hype, because thats what all tourists do! The guy that served me was really rude, I should have gotten his name. The donuts are average.
Meh.  It's nice that they have vegan options but the taste fails to live up to the hype.  Save your time and calories for something else.  The staff is kind, though.

When I saw the line I thought these must be the best donuts in the world.   I got a cream filled doughnut with eyeballs on it.  I cannot even remember the flavor because it was sooo sweet. It could have been chocolate it could have been maple all I can remember is the sickening sweet gooey stuff in my mouth that I wanted to spit out.  I took a second bite to get to the cream and wish I hadn't . As the realization of the taste of the cream filling shot from my taste buds to my brain my enthusiasm for my donut sank.  Could this be the worst donut I have ever eaten?  My donut eating life flashed before my eyes. Cream filled donuts in Germany with cream filling so good if it dripped onto the floor of "The toilet in Scotland" you would probably scoop it up and still eat it.  Or the Curry donuts in Japan so good you would buy a box in the morning and travel with a dozen of them all day only to find they were all gone by night fall.  Or the Italian fried bread fried while you wait and lightly dusted with sugar.  Yes, Just as Renton had found the worst bathroom in Scotland I had found the worst donut in Portland.

Overrated! Yeah, the menu choices were unique, but the donut itself was whatever. I got the Mango Tango and Maple Bacon donut. The frosting on the Mango Tango was pretty good, but the full inch of mango jelly inside is just ridiculous. It was thicker than the actual donut pastry itself! Waaay too sweet. The Maple Bacon was a cool concept, but again too sweet. They need to cut back on that maple coating. But aside from the toppings, the donuts themselves were too dry, even almost tough to chew. Sorry, but I'd rather have Krispy Kreme any day. Thank goodness we didn't have to wait in too long of a line, though it grew substantially after we got there at 7am.

Their brand is definitely the coolest part of this place. The doughnuts are made of corn syrup and GMO flour, standard yeast, definitely not the Portland ethos. That being said: Kids love it despite the irony of 7-year old girls wearing tiny pink "the magic is in the hole" t-shirts. Parents! Stop buying your girls pedophile enticements. Lines are long, variety of doughnut is awesome, despite quality and ambiance is definitely unique. Worth a trip if you're in the area.
Longest line and not really worth the hype. It was pretty basic! Save yourself the wait and go to Blue Star donuts.

This place is such a fun Portland standard.  I don't find myself needing to eat doughnuts often, but my mom was in town for Thanksgiving and she had heard all the hype.  We stopped in on the way to hiking (LOL) and there was already a line of 20 people at 10am on a Wednesday morning.  We chose the Mexican chocolate (sadly this was plain and a bit dry) and the chocolate with peanuts (soft, chewy and exactly what a doughnut should be).  Washed it down with a cup of Stumptown coffee - what a yummy morning :)  Great prices and a classic vibe - go enjoy!

Doughnuts here are just OK, no better than your run-of-the-mill grocery store bakery doughnut. The length of that line is not worth it. You're better off going to Blue Star or Pip's for a good doughnut.

a place famous for doughnuts. But employees are unkind. When I asked to recommend a popular doughnut, she hust said, "I don't know". 

I don't think everyone does not know every doghnut taste. I look forward to a more kind reception like an old history.


 ,   , .

The line was way too long, and it is located where many hoodlums would come up to you and ask for money (or donuts haha). I love how the donuts come in a pink box. The donuts taste like any other donuts though honestly, but I give it props for the unique names as well as donut designs! The donut texture are very soft, I recommend eating it within the day.
Overrated, who wants to wait in line for 15 mins or more for mediocre donuts? Also its cash only! If your drunk and desperate go for it.

Unfortunately, I was disappointed.  The line was too long (as a tourist, you can't help but have to go on a saturday!) and the donuts didn't live up to the expectations.  Additionally, I only did a few minutes worth of preliminary research on the website to determine what was in each donut, and with a 30 minute wait, I wasn't about to be that girl who asked what every donut was with 100 people behind me.  So I would say, if you are going in for the first time, study the website carefully before and go at an off time if you can!  OR just skip it, cuz frankly, when it comes down to it, they're just donuts!!  You could go to dunkins and taste something similar, sorry.

EXTREMELY CREATIVE IDEAS here for design and motif of donuts and quasi-donuts, well worth stopping by and looking them over.  I've tried maybe 10 different ones over the last 5 years, and they uniformly leave a waxy coating all over my lips and mouth.  The flavor and texture are good, but that waxiness, well, it ruined Voodoo for me.
Why would you wait over an hour for overhyped and mediocre doughnuts? Pass.

boo. stand in long lines only to be disappointed by the ridiculously small space and zero time to scope out the doughnuts or decide on the huge menu. When I got to a coffee shop, I found the doughnuts were stale and not spectacular. The old style doughnuts were best - no old fashioned ones though. :(
Worth the line if you like the novelty of doughnuts with cereal on top.

Voodoo Doughnuts unfortunately did not woo me! I have tried better doughnut places, however when in Portland do as the Portlanders do! I'm glad I went for the experience! 

Pros:
Parking lot available for $5-10
Close to different coffee shops

Cons:
Donuts were okay
Long line

I never heard of this place until i was headed to Portland, then all my friends freaked out about Voodoo Doughnuts. We waited in line for like 10 mins, got a maple, a cream filled, and a devils food with cocoa puffs. They are all awesome ideas, the donuts are eh, just like any other doughnut place. But it was a cool experience, they had a c*ck and ba!!s one that was huge and funny haha you cant really eat them out front without being harassed by a bum with doo doo stains.

On a Sunday morning I step out of the hotel and into the freezing wind that's blowing all around the city. I just wanted two doughnuts and Voodoo doughnuts is 4 blocks away... this shouldn't take more than 15 minutes right?

Not quite. The only way the number 15 was accurate was that I had predicted the number of people lined up outside the store. It was freezing and I had forgot a jacket, but I waited. It took probably 20 minutes just to get inside and wait more. Once inside it was at least warm, I could hear the Velvet Underground (and the employee up front singing along... sadly his voice paled in comparison to Lou Reed) and smell the deep fryer. 

Finally got the doughnuts and left. They're real tasty, real gimmicky, and given the same situation, I'll probably go again. But couldn't they just go ahead and put a second person up front to grab people's doughnuts... on weekend mornings at least? I'll bet they could justify it by adding someone to sing Nico's part...
The place was really cool, the donuts were cool. Must see when visiting the city. Probably don't need to wait in line again :)

This is a pretty cool donut spot. They have been here for a long long time and you mosdef have a ton of choices. The staff is really cool. I believe they are family owned. There is always lots of people hanging out enjoying the atmosphere. The coffee is fresh and you never have to wait long. The only thing is-The Donuts are completely dry and it makes me so sad cause this place seems so cool. I've been here numerous times in the last couple months or so and have been disappointed each time. Donuts are stale and way to sweet....not at all gooey but just hard with hard over sugared toppings...SAD!

The doughnuts are very mediocre. I feel like people should be warned before they go into this place. If you have never eaten here before, there are many better options.

What to expect? Waiting for possibly an hour+ while having homeless people yell at you. Once you finally get in, you'll probably be surprised to find that the store is actually not so jolly and nice. It's very dirty, the doughnut you're wanting is probably not fresh, and you'll get yelled at if you don't order immediately when it's your turn. Don't expect to pay by card either. You'll then leave the store, post your doughnut selfie, and then get comments on your photo like "Shoulda gone to Blue Star" or "Pips is where it's at". 

Have fun.

This place is so overhyped! The donuts are meh at best yet I give it credit for knowing how to build a buzz, even when there's no substance behind it. I'd be embarrassed being seen carrying a box of these anywhere. If you want awesome donuts served to you by people who aren't pierced and tattooed on every part of their body, in a setting that is clean and genuine, go to Tonallis over on NE 28th and Alberta. There you can enjoy strolling through the Alberta Arts District and getting non-overpriced ice cream and donuts at Tonallis, a family run business that makes out of this world donuts!

Had to try the doughnuts while we were in PDX over the weekend. I have to say I'm a little dissapointed.
Their sign listing all their choices was overwhelming! There was a line so I felt rushed, and one of the donuts I took home was pretty gross. I had to scrape off more than a handful of frosting just for it to be eatable!
I did enjoy the maple bacon bar and the donut with chocolate frosting, oreo and peanut butter. But I would stear clear of the peach friter.

I might be willing to try again, but I won't say it's the best, I'd just say it's original :)

When we moved to PDX 6 yrs ago, we tried it a couple times... in 2 of their locations.  And yes, we do bring visiting friends & family to here per their request.  HOWEVER, we dislike their doughnuts very much. It's overly sweet, sugary, and stale.  Their doughnuts are definitely showy & colorful, if you like that kind of things. But personally, I would rather NOT have doughnuts than have them from Voodoo

This my friends happens when food hype meets unfulfilled reality.

We were heading back home from a mini vacation but wanted to stop to taste what it seems Yelpers and the Food Network celebrities have said is one of the best doughnuts or as one person said comically the best thing she's put in her mouth. So armed with great expectations and a sweet tooth that make Yogi Bear proud my friend and I buy into it and wait in the long line. 20 minutes later we bought several doughnuts including voodoo, peach fritter, fruit loop, ODB, bacon maple, maple custard, and oreo so we could be fair that if there was one we didn't like there were other options. First, the counter service girl had the personality of a wall. Not friendly, no smile, no personality, and act like we should be honored to have her wait on us. This seems to happen a lot when employees work at a "tourist hot spot" and think they are rockstars and service never gets better since they know people will still show up. Second, the actual product... overrated. Voodoo filling was subpar, frosting had a weird flavor, and seemed too doughy. Bacon maple to me had a burnt piece of bacon which took away from the flavor although in concept it should have worked. This was probably my friends best doughnut out of the bunch since she said she likes more crispy bacon, which I countered no there is "creole" and there is burnt. Fruit loop was disgusting. Imagine leaving fruit loops out on the counter for 2 weeks then put  on a doughnut with frosting and letting them get soggy. Peach fritter in my opinion had the most potential but had so much frosting it became gross to eat. You had to scrap off 90% just for it to be eatable but once you do it was probably the only doughnut that was decent to me. Maple custard was "ok" but not worth the hype. After eating just those doughnuts we had enough and tossed the rest in the trash. 

Overall, this place is not going anywhere since its a tourist place and has some devoted fans but in my opinion this place calling card is more about being weird and a "i've been there" kind of place and not so much for quality of doughnuts. I would never come back since I've had better doughnuts without the hype or the weird combinations that with us at least failed on a massive scale. End result... we tossed about $20 worth of doughnuts in the trash and actually all agreed that there are several lesser hyped places heck even Krispy Kreme that make better quality doughnuts without having to be weird just to "keep portland weird".

First let me say the donuts tasted good and came in fun shapes.

We had a Portland stop scheduled on our Northwest road trip. This was going to be our first time to the city and this place always came up in search engines for the best  thing to do. Side note: It made me nervous that the biggest highlight of Portland was a donut shop. 

A Saturday was spent mostly trying to avoid beggars and hobos and VooDoo is a hot spot for them. Oh and people were actually willing to wait in line an hour for this stuff. We begged off that day. Tried back Monday morning before driving to Seattle, and it was a 5 minute wait and the hobos were sleeping in. Fun but definitely only worth a short  wait. They make me laugh too, because me and my husband only bought two doughnuts and they offered to give us a fancy box for them instead of a paper bag. I guess that's what all the crazy tourists want and expect after their hour wait so they can post proof on facebook that they actually ate donuts from this place. Of course you need a fancy VooDoo box for that. We took our paper bag and went outside to eat and watch everyone else photograph their doughnut boxes.

PS. Sadly this is actually one of the few tourist highlights of the downtown. However I preferred the craft breweries and food trucks.

I love voodoo, the three stars isn't for the donuts. With this location there's usually an atrocious wait, the people are usually rude and the outside environment sucks at night. I have been to their other Sandy location and Eugene location which were way better and have fresher tasting products.

Disclaimer... I am not a doughnut fan.  I decided to try this place after watching a clip about it on TV and then being witness to lines around the block day after day.   I tried several doughnuts with a friend of mine and a couple were tasty... and I guess I might have said AMAZING if I liked doughnuts.   The Grape Ape was actually my favorite.  It had a taste that surprised me.  Fun and tasty treat.  The doughnut that looked like a person being stabbed was down right pedestrian... I took one bite and spit it out... yuck... tasted like something you might get at the corner grocery store.  The other two I tried had Oreos on them... they were similar except one had peanut butter... again might have been amazing if I liked doughnuts... they were ok but nothing to wait for in a line.  If you like doughnuts you might like it... if you do not... its a waste of time... nothing so amazing that it will change your opinion of doughnuts.

Yak Yak Yak!  Holy Sweet!  Yeah so you come to Portland you gotta stand in line for a VOODOO donut.  NO YOU DON'T!   They are sickly sweet and that's about it.  Run across town to a real donut shop.  Sesame Donuts!

I don't get all the hype... I really don't. I went early on a Sunday morning to avoid all the lines. The music was blaring for being so early, and the guy behind the counter didn't seem really friendly. I ordered only the raised donuts in glazed, maple bacon bar, hibiscus, and the portland cream. The best one was the maple bacon bar and the portland cream. The prices were reasonable since each donut was fairly large. I just felt like they were a little dry and overly sweet. It was a good donut, but not something I would ever wait in line for or crave. Just an okay donut...

I have to preface this review by saying that I visited Portland during its "Great Storm" of January 2017 (where apparently the city was shutdown due to snow fall).

I'm sure I witness a miracle and wandered into Voodoo Doughnuts TWICE with little-to-no line.  I was in and out in less than 10 minutes.  Their staff, clearly accustomed to throngs of people, were quick and recommended doughnuts based on whatever arbitrary criteria we stated.  Out of both visits and 6 different doughnuts, I thought that each one was way too sweet.  The glaze, even if infused with rosemary, kicked you in the gut with sugar.  The filling, no matter how much it added to the theme of the doughnut (like the Voodoo doughnut), slaps you in the face with sugar.  Even when paired with Stumptown coffee (which is located a few doors down), I felt myself falling into diabetic ketoacidosis as I slowly consumed the doughnut.
After seeing the TV reviews and hearing the hype, it's so sad when you bound into a spot only to be greeted by an employee that makes you feel like you're not welcomed. =(

There are varied types of Donuts that they serve.   Somehow I prefer a hot donut served at Krispy Kreme over Voodoo.  If I did not wait for 30minutes in line to have this, I wouldn't have been as disappointed.
It's a scene. Blue Star has better quality doughnuts but if you want the scene, have a doughnut at Voodoo.
kinda over rated donuts and they are pricey. i don't even think locals come here...most of the customers are out of towners wanting to find out what the hype is all about.

I'm glad they only accept cash.  I can't count the number of nights I have waiting in their long lines, trying to convince myself that I don't need the sugar,  and then remembering once I get closer to the front that I don't have cash me. It's strange that this establishment only accepts cash. In this technological age I'm shocked that cash-only places still exist. It's the only cash-only place I have known about in the past 10 years.  Anyway, I only use my credit cards, so I'm always glad to have to get out of line and leave.    Besides, if I was want captain crunch on a donut, I can buy a donut at the 7-Eleven on my way home and put captain crunch, or peanut butter or a slice of bacon on it when I get home. Anyone can do that- and people wait in line for it?

Not worth the line! If you're a tourist go take a pic out front just to say that you've been there. Or just cut to the front of the line and take a peak at the donuts spinning around in the display case. Make sure you take a picture of the maple bar with the slice of bacon on it. That's what all the hype is about. Doesn't taste good. If you want good donuts I heard you should go to blue star.

$3 for a doughnut? I consider this an IQ test of sorts. 

Fun? Sure! Interesting? Definitely! But highly overrated. Nothing of any nutritional value. And even if you're thinking about getting a lasting souvenir, those are very overpriced as well. 

Just walk by and take a couple photos. If you're in a large group, get one donut to share.
Too much sweet donut and too many people there, but if you come to portland this is the landmark you should come. For me, just one time 555.

The first time I saw Voodoo Donuts on Man vs Food, the donuts looked so mouth watering good. The way they described how they cooked the Apple Fritters had me wanting to hop on a flight to Portland right then and there to get one. So in September, it just so happened my husband had to go to Portland on business, so of course I had to get up there asap to visit Voodoo Donuts.  We grabbed a taxi and headed to the what I thought was going to be a wonderful donut eating experience, until I saw the line going down the street. Ok, I thought the donuts must be good if people are willing to wait in a long line for them....right?? NOT!!!! That place is so over rated it's ridiculous! I waited in line for 30 minutes to get what I thought was going to be my dream Apple Fritter and was disappointed beyond words. The Apple Fritter didn't look ANYTHING like what they showed on tv. It was a big blob of fried dough with very few apples. I could have gotten a better Apple Fritter at the local Royal Jelly donuts for less money. Don't believe the hype you see on tv.

We had to try it based on what folks told us, so we picked up a few doughnuts. We got a variety, the line was long because of it's popularity, which is understandable. However, I can only give this 3 stars as there really was nothing special about the doughnuts for all the hype. Though their fritters, the Apple and the Memphis were fantastic. Just wish I could say that about the rest.

I had high expectations for this place after seeing it on Diners, Drive-ins and Dives. We came here on a fall trip to Portland and even though it was pretty cold outside, people lined up outside to get V.D. The queue moves quickly, but as I neared the till I almost felt a building anxiety to quickly decide on what to order because we could NOT hold up the line. You don't get much of a chance to be a tourist and take pictures at this landmark because you basically move like an assembly line: order-pay-leave with your pink box. The selection of doughnuts goes around two rotating display cases with very dull looking glass, so if you're not quick enough to see through a coke bottle at doughnuts turning in a circle in front of you, you'll miss the bacon maple or penis shaped doughnuts. Not the kind of place where you can stand at the counter in an indecisive "Umm... Maybe one of those?" state. There is no place to sit and eat a doughnut or think about what you'd like to try. Come to think of it, I don't think there was a place to sit - period. This might as well have been a drive-through.

The doughnuts were not great. The one with fruit loops looks interesting but the fruit loops were so stale it was hard to eat it. Then there were a couple of "fruity" glazes which were so sickeningly sweet it was hard to enjoy. The doughnut itself before the glaze was no big deal, even dry, really, if I had to describe it. The best ones we tried were the oreo doughnut and the classic old fashioned glazed. The infamous maple bacon tasted good - if you like congealed bacon on a maple glazed doughnut. I think we paid more for the novelty of the place, with its quirky bumper stickers and tacky decor.

This place is a old Portland food landmark.  Be willing to wait in line a little while 20-30 minutes.  Overall the doughnuts are very rich and on the sweet side.  The limited time James and the Giant Peach doughnut was the best out of the four doughnuts we bought. This doughnut had diced peaches inside.  And the icing on the top had a nice peach flavoring.

VOODOO donuts...a MUST place to visit while in Portland, OR.  So I was told by a lot of people...and so we did.

On a rainy Thursday morning a few weeks ago we took the trek from the Westin Hotel to Voodoo Donuts.  Glad we missed the line which started getting longer soon as we got there.  As newbies we ordered just about everything in sight.  Be careful when u have kids with u (those that can read) because some of the donuts' flavors/names are totally inappropriate and crude.  The donuts were good but not great.  It tasted just like any regular donuts except for those that have added flavors like grapes, etc.  Bottom line...they were all too sweet.  The colorful ones were beautiful but after taking a few bites of each flavors they all started tasting the same.

I recommend this place to try just so u guys can see what the hype is all about.

Having lived in OR for the last 15 years, I havent gotten the hype surrounding this place. Ive been probably a dozen times ( both the downtown and ne locales) and the donuts are always, ok. The lines for said doughnuts... inexcusable. There are plenty of small donut shops in this city that are more than happy to get my business.

These donuts are so beautiful and fun. But they taste like.... hotdog buns with frosting and toppings. Seriously. Meh. We were so let down! Thankfully, we didn't have to wait very long. Though I imagine the line gets ridiculous. Honestly... if you're looking for a good donut don't waste your time. If you're looking for a photogenic donut, though, this is your place.

The donuts are good from this voodoo. WAY better than the ones from Eugene. BUT the location is HORRID! You can't go there without having to pay to park. We paid for 20 minutes as we were just passing through town. By the time that we walked to Voodoo, waited in line and walked back we were already 6 min past the meter. Not only that there are a BUNCH and when I say a bunch I mean a BUNCH of sketchy homeless people lining the streets. Making drug deals, saying nasty things to passers, sleeping in their puke on the sidewalk and just down right cracked out. Not Voodoo's fault by any of this. But I hope that they will be able to find another location because this doesn't make tourists want to come back.

The donuts are average if you like old cereal on your food their probably great for you. I personally order the old dirty bastard if i am forced here by a family member visiting portland. The hype of the shop co.es from the names and the look of the building. I don't mind this place when there is no line but I don't like standing in a long line for an average donut with old cereal on it. There are better donuts in portland there are even better donuts downtown.

This was my first stop in Portland! It's a tiny place downtown with a line going out the door. Read lots about the maple bacon bar but when we got to the front of the line, they told us they were out! Boo. 

We decided to get a dozen of assorted donuts. There were lots to choose from with interesting toppings and flavors. Most were covered with a thick sugar frosting and way too sweet. We ended up cutting the donuts into little pieces to try. My favorite was the old dirty bastard with oreos and drizzled with peanut butter.

At the end of Secrets of Portlandia tour, we ended up here and decided it was only fitting to try Voodoo Doughnuts. I am not sure if anyone actually goes here to get doughnuts for work or for a meal. I think the clientele is solely thinking that Voodoo Doughnuts is a classic fixture of Portland and therefore they must try them. 

The lines was very long, which is apparently typical and filled with anxious tourists. 

They only accept cash, which is a bit annoying, however, it make sense considering the sheer volume of people they have to service. 

The inside of the business is fun with all the decor and you are able to see some of the doughnuts available for purchase.

The doughnuts are reasonably priced and there is a wide variety. I went with 4 people and we all got a few doughnuts each intending to share. The doughnuts were average. I had a chocolate doughnut, with chocolate frosting and cocoa pebbles and it was nothing spectacular. The raspberry doughnut was like anything I could get at a convenience store. The voodoo doughnut was probably the best of the lot. 

Overall: quite a bit of hype for some unknown reason and the doughnuts themselves did not deliver what I was hoping for.

Cute & Quirky Decor - Store is bright pink.. you can't miss it! 

Lines are pretty long... luckily, we went on a Monday morning at around 10am and only had to wait about 20 minutes :) There are SEVERAL flavors to choose from, which is awesome, but in my opinion, it tastes like any other donut to me. I wouldn't necessarily wait hours & hours in the heat for it. 

Here's what we ordered:

Classic Glazed Donut - tasted like any regular glazed donut 
Fruit Loops Donut - I like the concept, but fruit loops were stale
Dirty Old Bastard  - haven't tried yet, but looks like a sugar rush waiting to happen!
Viscous Hibiscus - Pretty purple color, haven't tried yet! 

Keep in mind: CASH ONLY

I feel like a horrible Portlander when I say this, but Voodoo Doughnut is horribly overrated and more of a novelty than anything else.  Yes, you can get doughnuts in funny shapes.  Yes, you can get doughnuts that have unique toppings.  And yes, you can get doughnuts that aren't very good.  On a lot of them, the icing is way too sweet (and that's a lot coming from me), and while the doughnut itself is better than something you'd get at Safeway, it's really not by much.

I hate to be the guy that recommends an out-of-town chain over a local favorite, but Krispy Kreme really is way better.  I'd take something simple and non-gimicky from them over an overloaded, too-dense Voodoo Doughnut any day.

Nothing great about these donuts. Don't recommend and wouldn't go again. They're not bad, there's just so many other better donut places in Portland why go get mediocre ones? Go to Pips! Or Blue Star.

I went for the famous bacon maple donut, expecting great things since I do love both bacon and maple syrup. Voodoo came up short. I admit it was a large donut for what I paid (think 3x5 rectangle), but there was way too much sugar in the maple frosting and not enough bacon. It was the thin stuff, overcooked to a crisp. I gave up half way through because of the overpowering sweetness and pulled the bacon off and trashed the rest.

Thoroughly disappointed. This could have been better executed, and for the price I expected far more.
