Unfortunately, not a great experience. The three donuts I had, were stale.  Ingredients were very low quality. Place was junky looking and not clean. Living off their​reputation​.
This place is just all about the experience & to say you came! Long lines, however moves fast. Doughnuts are fun & over the top but taste like every other doughnut spot.

We had to go here because it's one of those tourist things we were told everyone has to do. There was a line outside the bldg, and you could smell the donuts when you walked up. We went at about 5:30pm. Still busy. I don't think it's ever not busy. I had my heart set on a voodoo doll donut. They had run out but just finished baking more. They decorated one quick for me. I was happy! The donuts are good but I don't think they are worth the hype. I liked blue star better. But these folks had great customer service. They also have an ATM inside the store. They only take cash. Oh and there are a bunch of druggies and bums that hang out outside... that was gross.

I've only been here once when I was visiting Portland but I have to share the experience I had on that one visit.

Okay I'll cut right to the chase...there was a COCKROACH in the doughnut case!!! Ok this is back in 2012 so I hope they're cleanliness standards have improved since. It was in the showcase of the doughnuts crawling all over the doughnuts! I took a picture of the cockroach in the case but I can't find it 3 years later.

I still ended up getting a doughnut, I believe it was the maple blunt. It was good and they had a variety of interesting doughnuts like the bacon maple bar. Overall, its probably a good place there just happened to be a cockroach in the case which I informed the employee of its' presence.

Overhyped donut store. The line wasn't long, but maybe because it's a Monday morning?
The Bacon maple bar was good given that I've never tried one before. Other than that, their donuts are not fresh at all. Their wacky designs and clever in your face names are enjoyable for those who like to eat with their eyes. I wouldn't wait in line for these donuts. Ever.

I admit it-- I was a tourist! I went to Voodoo Donut to wait in line to get the bacon and maple bar everyone told me I needed on my trip to Portland.

Yum- the end!

Had 7 of my students in Portland for a team competition and decided that we would explore Portland a bit. 

I asked if they had heard of Voodoo Donuts and would they like to try them. I got a resounding YES! Only one of my students had been there previously.

Found a parking space right away, plugged the meter and down the block we went to wait in line for what amounted to about 45 minutes. The street entertainment was mostly palatable although I wondered what my wide eyed students from a small town in Oregon where really thinking.

We managed to all fit inside the postage stamp of a donut shop and looked at the offerings. I can honestly say that I was underwhelmed by the visuals but having heard that these donuts were beyond belief we ordered our 8 donuts and were on our way. 

After we had all eaten our donuts I asked if it was me or was anyone in agreement that these were possibly some of the most mediocre donuts we had ever had. Everyone without except agreed that they had better at the grocery store.

I thought they were mostly dry and flavorless. Anyone can dip a donut in icing then in cereal. I didn't get the cereal thing as it didn't add anything to the taste of the donut. That wasn't the only type we had, but all agreed the various donuts were not very good.

Unfortunately, I won't be back nor will I ever suggest to someone to spend their hard earned money there, if just wasn't special at all.

Not sure what all the excitement is about this place.  Sure they have a variety of donuts (more than any donut shop i have been to.  I must admit, the donuts looked very creative and unique.  I asked for their signature donut, a maple bar with bacon donut.  Ate it and it was good but certainly not worth any kind of wait.  This place is way overhyped.

I tried 4 different kinds over the course of a few days.
-the original portland cream
-the voodoo doll
-the arnold palmer
-the old dirty bastard

Love the choc, PB, and Oreo combo of the old dirty bastard but preferred the Portland Cream overall.  It was a good sized doughnut with a great texture to the filling.  DO NOT think this is anything like a Boston Cream, it has a totally different flavor to the filling.  Reminded me of white cake batter in the center.  

Cool little location with a few picnic tables outside. 

WARNING*******Cash ONLY but the do have an ATM right inside.

All hyped. 

I do love their unique branding but their doughnuts a big disappointment! They're not amazing. I told myself not to have high expectations, but they're horrible. It's just a regular donut shop to me. Thankfully, there was no line when​ we went in the morning. 

On the bright side, the workers are super friendly and cheerful!!

Portland native here. The donuts have always sucked, the employees are rude, the line is extremely long, sometimes hours. I've only gone here to entertain visiting friends who have it on their to-do list. This is a tourist trap and you'll be disappointed by the lack of quality. Plus your donut's going to be shaped like a penis and it'll probably have tang and bacon on it, or some other endearing combination of ingredients that should never be mixed.

I SO wanted to like this place.  I think it's a mad genius who came up with "fried bacon on maple bar".  But my bar was so sweet that I nearly fainted after the second bite.  And I am a girl who doesn't shy away from sugar, or fat, or fry, or, you know, flaming hot cheetos with a root beer float chaser.  

I am giving the place 3 stars for thwarting my rampant desire to like it, because I had to Throw Away half my donut.  Or else I was going to freak out  at my morning meeting, from a sugar fit.

But to be fair, the 2 dozen donuts I brought in the office to make friends with disappeared under 30 minutes.  So these guys must be doing something right.

Not so coocoo for Voodoo!  My pals and I felt Voodoo failed to meet its expectations.  Yes, the selection appeared artistic, original, and tasty, but all you get is a mouthful of disappointment.  Stale disappointment =(.  I had the bacon maple bar where not only the donut was stale, but the bacon was too.   I guess next time we should visit in the middle of the day when they're not stale?!

Oh, enjoyed the interior décor consisting of random and artsy debris.

Tourist trap. The donuts are cold and not worth whatever you spend on them. Where I'm from (east coast), when you get donuts from the shop, they come out warm and freshly made. These were a disappointment for the price. Several people recommended it, and it was a waste of money and calories. Don't bother. I've heard blue star is way better, so if you want better cold donuts, go there instead.

Definitely, overly hyped. Everyone was recommending us to stop by Voodoo Doughnut, when in Portland. Sadly, to say... I'll probably be recommending EVERYONE NOT TO GO TO Voodoo Doughnut. Sum it all up, the doughnuts were definitely stale. 24/7 Doughnut, and we got a stale one, multiple ones, actually! Not to fond of their crazy unique toppings. You're better off buying a regular donut and separate toppings. Thanked god we didn't have to wait in that horrendous long line everyone speak of, I would've hate myself for it! Not going back that's for sure...

Very touristy, kinda gimmicky. Tried voodoo donuts & blue star donuts and blue star was better in quality. Voodoo is cool to pop in and check out because it's so famous.. Not sure if it's worth the long lines though. Luckily we came in the middle of the day so it wasn't too bad of a wait for us.

Don't know what the fuss was all about.. the donuts are just OK. Maybe the concept and the different flavors/shapes available is unique and i give points for that.. But after waiting in the line for almost 30min and ordering 3 donuts, I was not too impressed with them..
The voodoo doll donut was cute and unique concept and loved the idea behind it.. but all donuts were dry. it could be that they were not fresh as I went there in evening, but you would think with all the crowds, the turnover would be pretty good..
Anywhoo, just checked off one more 'must-do' thing from Portland list. :)

-cheaper than blue star
-Fun shapes
-Nice variety
-Good location. Plenty of other food around


-Long line
-Cash only

Unpopular opinion time. 
So I love Voodoo and I'm totally on the bandwagon with how awesome, funny, and unique it is. However being born and raised in Portland I also have an honest opinion of the place.

The lines are long. Like really long. If you want to stand in line for about an hour in order to receive just an OKAY pastry, this is just your cup of tea. It's funny because the lines never seem to die down. No matter the time. I've been to Voodoo at 2am and I still found myself waiting with a flock to retrieve the almighty sugar bread.

The doughnuts themselves are not the best doughnuts I've ever had. The dough is kind of stale and crunchy, the frosting and fillings hard and cracking. Obviously they have a lot of customers to serve, and thus doughnuts spend a long time out on the shelf during the day. But if I'm going to be waiting in a line for six days, I would like to shove the best doughnut of my life in my gob. You'd just think with all the DOUGH they rake in every day they'd be able to get the doughnut game right.

Tourists are fantastic. They bring a lot of revenue into the city and I appreciate their existence...just not in my vicinity. They are anxious, loud, and crowding up the place, and they're all apparently at Voodoo. 

Cash only. They have an ATM inside if you want to be charged five extra bucks to withdraw cash. 

Parking is a nightmare and to be expected because it's right in the middle of downtown. I recommend just getting to one of the many pay to park parking lots in the area. Or you could drive around the block eight times before finding street parking...to also pay for.

HOWEVER, all that being said, I do recommend you go there at least once if you've never been. It's a cool experience with friendly staff and a very Portland vibe- just be aware of what you're getting into so you're not gravely disappointed. I would also recommend going over to Voodoo Doughnuts Too, because it tends to be a little less crowded and more accessible.

Voodoo Doughnut is definitely a famous Portland institution. I think it is a bit hyped up though. The location downtown is small and cramped although it is in the heart of the action in downtown. The east side location is much bigger and has cool music and pinball so I tend to go to that one when I do go to Voodoo. I like their flair and humor, especially their cocoa puff doughnut which is definitely my fave, but their donuts taste stale sometimes and I've heard from some of the employees that the management isn't too nice to their employees. Definitely check the place out at least once if you're from out of town but otherwise there are better doughnut places in town.

The donuts are good, but not amazing. After all, they're just donuts. The bacon maple donut was a nice mix of sweet and savory which I always enjoy, but I can fry up a bacon and eat it with a better tasting maple donut for less money. The maple bar at Voodoo's was not very maple-y, but more sweet than anything. 

The best donuts out of the 2 dozen I ordered were the oreo and blueberry ones. I paid $50 for 2 dozen of which half of them melted within half a day. 

I was so stoked to come here- walked in the rain with my iphone gps at 6:30am, got lost, & freaked the hell out because of the homeless druggies on the street, but was sadly disappointed in how unspectacular these donuts were. Note to early birds, there was absolutely no line Sat morning at 7am. Do it!
Mediocre tasting, albeit incredibly creative, donuts.  Not responsibly sourced ingredients, generally rude employees.

I don't get it. I mean, donuts are good, but come on, worthy of a line around the block in 90 degree heat? Having never been there during daylight hours, I convinced my friends it was a better idea to come back around midnight for a snack. Even at midnight the line was borderline ridiculous. 

Yes the bacon maple was good, yes, the custard filled was good, yes the captain crunch and cocoa puff covered were both good. But it still boils down to fried dough. 

I've spied the pink boxes being transported from PDX and also saw a person toting a box at LAX a few years back. Yes, it's definitely a thing, but I still don't get it.
I only take friends from out of town here for the "Wow!" factor. Other than that, I would never visit VD. If someone surprised me at work and brought me a donut, I wouldn't say "no," though.

Donut sucks. Service Sucks. Touristy. Pass & go to spend your money at Blue Star instead. 

I am so glad there wasn't a line when we came because I would have be pissed. Service was horrible, they were really rude and seemed so unhappy. We got a box of donuts and it was disappointing. Tourist trap.

surely a cool place to start off the day.  The maple donut is good, but not all that.  The captain crunch would be good if the captain crunch part was fresh, and they do have this challenge that if you eat this donut, a large one in so many seconds, I think 80 or 90, you get to be famous there.  I would just by the donut.
If you like stale doughnuts, gimicks and cockroaches - you'll like this place...

I love the designs of the Voodoo Donut line up but as a Portlander I know the truth is their are much better donut shops in town. Also the experience of waiting in line for a long time just for a donut is a turn off for anyone but the tourist seeking their first Cock and Balls donut.

Add in the poor location where drug addicts and transients circle trying to exploit tourists and its just not worth the trip.

Nothing to brag about here.
The hype doesnt live up to it.
The line is about 45 minutes long? 
Cash only.
The doughnuts didnt stand out to me at all. Very sweet. Way too sweet for my liking.
I can get the same donut somewhere else without waiting in line

Screw the lines!!! I love this place, but it's not worth the wait. The only time I go is when I stumble out of Dantes late night and there's no line. The Oreo doughnuts are my favorite (the Old Dirty Bastard and the Dirt Doughnut). Whatever you fancy, all their ridiculous varieties are delicious....just not worth a 45 min wait.

Honestly it's A-OK 

Blueberry donut, maple bacon donut, raspberry romeo, or apple fritter: thinking about this .. they all can look so different but honestly they taste all the same except with slight variations to taste or texture. Apple fritter? Plain donut with an extra crisp on the exterior, flakier interior, and cinnamon apple notes. Blueberry? Cakey, with an even amount of blueberry flavor to balance out (and my favorite to be honest.) Raspberry romeo? Plain donut with a semi-sweet raspberry jelly filling inside. Maple bacon bar? Plain donut with bacon and maple glaze on top. 

There are trays of donuts just sitting out and for some odd reason none of them are fresh; they don't melt in your mouth so they end up being a softer, or cakier, fancy version of Krispy Kreme donuts. 

I'd rather go to Tasty & Alder to get fresh donut bites instead honestly..

Fun little experience while you're in Portland.  There's typically hour-long waits, but if you go early in the morning or late night (it's open 24 hours) then usually you can enter the small space within 5 minutes.  The menu is confusing, it took me a bit to puzzle out what the selections were.  I ended up with their bacon maple donut, the Portland cream donut, and an Oreo one.

They're unique and tasty, but after a few bites it's overkill.  It's definitely fun food; I don't know how much thought went into seeing whether this flavor complements another flavor well (or even as a donut), but it's enjoyable to taste all these sugar & topping combinations.

It's cheap, which is rare for a tourist attraction, so join in the fun and get a donut!

If you're here for the experience of Voodoo Doughnuts then have at it. These donuts are for food blogs, the experience of eating a doughnut in the shape of a penis and being served by a tattooed super pierced lady behind an old counter. Otherwise, just buy a supermarket doughnut and slap on a strip of bacon on it and you will replicate (actually, it will even be a better version) their best tasting doughnut. Don't fall for the hype!
this place is ok, great donuts. The place just seems dirty and is always overcrowded when I visit. wish they had a bigger place, with more room, to sit down and enjoy your donuts.

Nestled between the rows of bars, there's a place to get a starchy solution to your alcohol insolubility problem. Voodoo doughnuts fills a much needed place among night time haunts in PDX. Its curious, sometimes dubious flavors beckon the wayward adventurer to partake of something out of the ordinary. 

Unfortunately for us, many of the most abnormal doughnut concoctions were deemed unfit by our health authority. These tasty pastries included the Nyquill jelly filled and Pepto-Bismol filled doughnuts.

My favorites are the bacon maple bar (of course) and the Butterfinger/chocolate. The former must be had by any visitor looking for an element of Portland life. We're proud of the bacon maple bar. 

Quality isn't priority number one, here. It's all about the novelty. The doughnuts, for instance, are often rather dry. But, this isn't a problem for their main constituents. Drop by when you're drunk and hungry: you won't be disappointed.

Honestly, sometimes you just need a delicious doughnut to turn your day around. I recommend the Maple Bavarian Cream filled one. AMAZING!!

They have a cart in Pioneer Square during Noon Tunes on Tues and Thurs during the summer. Lines are short :)
Good doughnuts. But nothing so special. Definitely not worth the long lines. I guess it's one of those thing that tourists tell other tourists to do. I did like the costumes of the staff.
They have a few doughnuts that were good but nothing that blew my mind. The coffee was weak as well as the hot chocolate

TBH, I'm not much for doughnuts, but I really wanted to give this place a try. 
I can say that I'm still not much for doughnuts, but I'm glad I tried this place.
There was a queue out the door. It was hot. But I lived. I made it inside, and I was able to buy doughnuts. We got the "Voodoo Dozen" where the employee picks the dozen for you. We ended up with a variety - including one with fruit loops, one with cocoa puffs, one with Oreos, a glazed, an M&Ms, a cream filled, a bubble gum, and ones that I don't even know what they were. They were definitely jammed packed with TONS of sugar, though.
Anyway, I applaud them on their creativity. Also, their ability to take something you can buy almost anywhere and STILL make people want to come to your place instead is amazing. They definitely run a good business.
I wasn't fond of the incredibly loud an obnoxious music that was playing when we were there. I could barely hear anything.
Other than that, the doughnuts? They tasted like doughnuts to me...
I reaaalllly don't get the hype. This is for tourists, not locals. The donuts are about supermarket quality.
I can't actually review this because I didn't eat here. The line wrapped around the building and was probably an hour long. Not worth it for a donut, honestly.

It is a doughnut, nothing special, I tried to vegan cock and balls one and it tested alright. I tried to go there on the weekend and the link was crazy so I tried during the week around 11am and was able to get to the store without waiting. If I would live in Portland I would not been returning there, I am glad that I had the hoopla experience tho.

seriously, it's just a doughnut. there are some crazy concoctions though. this is what i would consider one of those "must visit" places just to see what people will do to taste the hype.

if you're sick and tired of the super-friendliness that is portland, go to voodoo. you'll get the experience of the stereotyped NYCer -- rude, pushy, demanding, impatient. the line alone will probably deter you if you're not set on tasting a gourmet doughnut served by misanthropic (okay, not all were that bad) counter clerks with cute little tip jars. get your coffee, get your doughnut, get out. water costs .10 for a cup.

back to what i was saying about the line, it goes out the door and down the side of the building. when you are near the door, do not try to rush in. they want that door closed. they also want you not blocking the entrance or exit through that door. stay patient. wait until the people in front of you provide enough clearance for you to scoot your butt in -- or get yelled at (experience talking). your choice.

i won't lie. their doughnuts are yummy. i prefer starting with a plain ol' glazed doughnut. it's like sampling a cheese pizza to determine if an establishment really makes pizza well. well, they do doughnuts pretty dang well. back home, i get the same kind of stuff at a place called dutchmonkey so the experience is not unique to portland.

detractions -- long lines, rude service, lack of seating (except outdoor picnic tables -- did i mention it rains a lot in portland?), water that costs .10, ingress/egress system designed by industrial engineering flunkies...

Sometimes you crave a VooDoo Doughnut, like when you're working a 12 hour shift in the ICU on a weekend when you could be spending time with your kids. In recent years, VooDoo seems to have become a tourist trap with long lines. For me, the sugary treat isn't worth the difficult parking or the long line.

Voodoo Doughnut is a must-do when in Portland.  It's open 24 hours and the lines can get crazy.  It's also CASH ONLY.  There is an ATM machine inside (it wasn't working when we went, but there is also an ATM across the street).  

The doughnuts are good, but it's more about the experience.  The lines goes pretty quickly.  There is a hug selection of doughnuts.  We had teh maple bacon (Raised yeast doughnut with maple frosting and bacon on top), Portland cream (Raised yeast shell filled with Bavarian cream and topped with chocolate and two eyeballs, representing the vision of the great city of Portland), glazed (Raised yeast doughnut with glaze) and sprinkle cake (Plain cake doughnut with frosting and sprinkles).  Each one was delicious and fresh.
I don't understand what the fuss is about. Rather go to Krispy Kreme
Tourist trap with doughnuts that aren't even freshly baked or warm. Hard to match up the name in the doughnut to what you see in the revolving glass case so hard to know what you're ordering.

*Maple Bacon 

VooDoo! Been there done that is all I can say. This is a stoners dream come true. (Un)Fortunately I haven't toked the cron in years.  So my taste buds are much finickier. Tried the Mexican spicy doughnut, I don't know why but Im a sucker for spicy anything its the paisa in me sad to say picanté pastries probably wont be the next big thing. The fruit loops doughnut was sad as well along with all the rest. High priced and not worth the the long line. I beat the lines by dropping by at two am which made me glad Oregon is an open carry state :) I must say the bacon maple was delicious and as American as it gets. I would recommend it for the experience but wouldn't stand in any kind of line for one.

The lines are long but move fairly quickly because of the efficient staff.  Not so good is the rude customers who ignore the sign that tells them not to block the exit door.  The "Too" location is better laid out so you can actually escape with your doughnuts without having to push past others.  Tried the Voodoo Doll (neat to look at but only ok tasting) and the Grape Ape (as good as the first time, from Too).

When in portland...eat voodoo donuts! Had to try it at least once....so we bought a box of 9 donuts for 4 people. Luckily, we picked up a box friday morning around 8am and there was no line! No line at all! We passed by on sunday looking for coffee and the line was wrapped along the building like Disneyland. 

Standouts: 
Nepal donut, not so sweet, delicious creme filling, my favorite!
Voodoo doughnut, good! i like the jelly cream too.
Bluebeery, or grape?? with sprinkles. 

Everything else...way too sweet. Too much frosting..shouldn't have gotten so much donuts! Also, eat the cereal ones right away cause a couple days later it's super stale. Same with the bacon.

Went here on a recent trip to Portland, because of the hype. Unfortunately, that's all it was. Maybe we have a higher standard for donuts in the SF Bay Area, maybe it was an "off" day. I'm not sure, but these seemed like your average grocery store donuts with gimmicky toppings and decor.

We tried 6 different varieties - maple bacon, mango tango, Portland creme, dirt, McMinnville and bubble gum. The donut itself was pretty indistinguishable. The toppings were almost all too sweet...possibly to overcome the plainness of the cake. The only two worth eating again are the maple bacon (I believe this is their signature donut and what put them on the map) and the bubble gum, which was surprisingly good even though we bought it solely out of  curiosity.
The hype! Donuts were overly sweet for me. Didn't taste fresh. Donuts just look astheticly pleasing. It's a trap!

Fame is fame people, and no matter how sh*tty you are, people will still love you (ask Justin Bieber).
They surely got their popularity  by doing a hard and honest work, no doubt. With that said, I really don't see anything impressive  about them, but their endless lines. As soon as I arrived in Portland, somebody told me that having donuts from the place was almost like an "initiation ritual", and those who didn't, would suffer for eternity. So I did. You don't get to choose your own donuts which could be a fairly acceptable excuse for an International diplomatic incident or even military intervention. The lines are just surreal, and have people stabbing one another for the pleasure of standing for hours.I've been living in Portland for almost two years now, and have NEVER seen that place with less than, at least, 50 people in line.
Ok I will give you that, the donuts are oddly interesting and very creative.The place is funky and lives up for the "Keep Portland Weird"  atmosphere, which I love.Other than that, I ain't joking when I say it, chocolate & cinnamon´s  Safeway's donuts kick the heck out of this voodoo!
Mostly hype and posercool.  Long wait for unhealthy food. Makes high fructose corn syrup look likes a super food.
I only ever go here when out of town friends or family ask me to take them...otherwise there are many other places with better doughnuts, ambiance & service in the PDX/Metro area.

So evil it's good! I had the voodoo doll and we got a bunch of other stuff including hte bacon maple bar! I have to admit that we planned ahead and got there early and it was well worth it! There's nowhere to sit but we brought our wares back to the lobby at ACE and they didn't seem to mind. Besides the walk did us good! Love the vibe here and the specialty options! xoxo Portland!
They have doughnuts. They are hip and cool. There are definitely better doughnuts in town, and you don't have to stand in line waiting to be seen by all the other hip, cool people standing in line.

Voodoo is an appropriate name. What sort of magic and/or crack do you put in these doughnuts that keep bringing HOARDS of people?! The lines are just insane - I want to drive by and yell "Sheeeeople!" to everyone waiting 30 + minutes for mediocre doughnuts. That said, it does have it's charm. Give me a glitter brick wall and a doughnut shaped like genitalia and you'll see a smile. In my opinion, Blue Star Doughnuts far surpasses the quality of VooDoo. One thing to note: this place is *cash only* but they do have an ATM inside. Also, they're open 24 hours a day. After a night of questionable decisions, perhaps a maple bacon bar is just what you need.

Yum! Late night yummy doughnuts next door to a hentai bar. Awesome! What would've made this experience perfect? Maybe a cleaner shop, and definitely an employee that didn't have that terrible "cooler-than-you" attitude. Seriously, they're "just doughnuts" ;)

Wouldn't be great if Portland had a REALLY GOOD doughnut shop?  I'm a native and I really, really do not like the doughnuts at Voodoo.  I really wish they were good and I also really wish I was treated well by the staff when I went there, but no such luck.  Being shaped like a penis does not make a pastry taste better.  Sorry.  And just because a place is way popular does not mean that it should stop giving good service.  I was "over it" practically before it was discovered and it's only gotten worse.  I agree with the review that points out - don't you have enough money by now to start making a decent product???

The donuts are cute. 

I waited in line for over an hour. I get to the front and it says CASH ONLY! What is this? A freaking Vietnamese restaurant?! Seriously! 

I didn't have any cash. I didn't get a MF donut.

And why aren't there two people working the counter?
Perhaps more for the tourist than the local. Not bad donuts, but there are better donuts in the area
Worst donut ever. It's actully taste really really really bad. Like that sell donuts that a week ago, cold and dry.
Meh. Over-hyped gimmickey joint.

Crappy, overpriced, overhyped, oddly shaped, cheaply made, overly sweet, safeway quality. I have just fully described your donuts Voodoo. 

Now that Blue Star is here, I hope you begin to revamp your entire bakery and decide to actually put in effort and skill into making your poopoo donuts. 

I'm tired of visiting with my friends at 1 AM and eating safeway donuts with cereal on top. Just cause you colorfully decorate donuts, doesn't make them good LOL. 
So please Voodoo, do yourself a favor and just stop what you're doing. 

P.S. You opened a Voodoo on the east coast and that's just f*cking stupid. Bye.

One of the most overrated food places in Portland along with Pok Pok. I laugh when I see  people carrying boxes of Voodoo doughnuts at the airport.  While, the doughnuts are good they are overpriced and not worth long lines.  If your a sheep that follows that hype and doesn't think for yourself  You will love this place because your told it's hip,(and they have cool doughnuts that are shaped like a blunt,and imagine just how wild and crazy they are to combine maple with bacon). Who could ever think of such an outrageous idea?LOL.  These owners are laughing themselves to the bank at all the stupid sheep that buy into the hype!!!  It's Portlandia and everybody is really cutting edge if they buy a doughnut at Voodoo.(NOT)
I don't see what the big deal is about. When I went there, the doughnuts were not fresh. I think Krispy Kreme and Heavenly Dougnuts are way better and fresh.

the doughnuts were decent but not worth waiting in a long line for (luckily we didn't). the oreo peanut butter was good but the blueberry cake doughnut tasted artificial. I'm glad we went but don't think we'd seek it out if we're ever in Portland again. in the Bay Area we have psycho donuts which I feel is comparable, if not better than voodoo.
Ok at the best. It is super fun to see what flavor they have and created but beside that it isn't a very big deal!! Check off my list to do :)

I don't understand what all the hype is about. We were visiting from Seattle. This was not the best donuts I have ever tasted. My donut did not taste fresh. It tasted like it had been sitting out for a while...which they had because they picked them from a pre-made rack. I was so disappointed when I bit into my "The Loop" donut and the Fruit Loops we stale from sitting out too long. My mom stated the filling inside her coconut donut didn't taste fresh as well. I've had better. I will not be returning.
What was once a great gem of Portland has turned into a snobby tourist trap.  No way is waiting in line for 2hrs to get stale donuts worth it.  Would rather stop by heavenly or blue star.
Had some really high expectations for this place. Unfortunately it wasnt anything near as amazing as I thought it was going to be and the service was terrible. Definitely disappointed.
Not bad donuts, not good donuts. Just OK. If they made new dough recipe id be back.
Important stop if you're a tourist.  If you're in search of great baked goods, not.

Used to be the best, before it got all of the publicity... The doughnuts are still decent, but it feels like they are riding on fame and not working as hard to improve the experience.
It's okay though! Plenty of other portland gems to take my business to.

Trust me I totally bought the hype that Voodoo was the Mecca of doughnuts like Franklins is to BBQ but in the end it sadly is just a above average doughnut place. I love my donuts you can double check with my fat gut so I know a good donut and voodoo is nothing special. They just have donuts with tons of shit on them like cereal and crap. In the end it's just a normal doughnut. As I am writing this I am getting more and more disappointed in the uninspired shit I just ate.

We usually make it a point to visit businesses featured on television. 

We've experienced better bakeries and doughnuts, but, this establishment is still worth putting on your bucket list of things to do while in the Portland, Oregon area. 

Suggestion: Buy the huge glazed doughnut, then take a photo in front of the building & sign to add to your photo treasures! Makes a wonderful photo for your scrapbook!

Long lines, not personable, cash only... they are just donuts. My kids HAD to visit Voodoo Donuts on our trip to Portland. We did just that. Sunday afternoon and 100 degrees, and we still had a 45 minute wait in line. 
The eclectic location makes this a fun experience. This is Portland so you have to be prepared for the adult humor surrounding you, even with cock and balls creme filled donuts in their spinning case. 
Really the biggest con, the cash only and the fact that they have to push you through like cattle in order to serve everyone!  
Why not spin in for a little bucket list visit and enjoy a donut... they are just donuts but it's a fun time regardless.

Honestly, just awful donuts... Worse than the typical donut... I would give it one star, but I understand the appeal of the cute voodoo shapes and funny names... But I would just go to enjoy those and not actually purchase a donut for consuming. I got the voodoo doll donut and the jelly inside was absolutely disgusting. I got another donut too, but my two friends and I ate 1/4 of each donut and threw the rest away... not worth. At all.
It is what it is. Good donuts, not great, but it's really hard to mess up something that is deep fried and then coated with sugar. The lines are horrible. Service is hit and miss.

Everyone are crazy about this place and you can see 50 people line waiting outside under rain. Does it worth it??? For me ... I will say just okay only! If you are into creative food, this donut is for you. The Maple Bacon bar, some people like it some don't, it really is on the sweet side.

I was really unimpressed with this place, we had heard such great things and were sadly disappointed.  We were in Portland for the weekend and decided to walk over to Voo Doo doughnut on Sunday morning.  The line to get into the place was about a half block long but the girl in front of us said it goes pretty fast, so we waited.  Well after waiting about 40 minutes on a transient infested block that smelt absolutely awful we made it to the front door.  The place is tiny inside and pretty dirty.  We finally made it up to the counter and thought we better make that wait worth while so we ordered several different doughnuts - Maple with Bacon, Voo Doo doll, Memphis mafia, triple chocolate.  There's no place to eat at the doughnut shop so we headed back to our hotel, I have to tell you it really was not worth the wait, I would have been much happier going to a grocery store bakery for what we received.  It was pretty mediocre.  I would never return or recommend to any of my friends to visit this establishment - its all hype.

When in Portland, do as the Portlanders do. Or maybe people from Portland don't even go here because it's so touristy.

Anyway, I mean it's Voodoo Doughnuts--you should obviously come check this out because it's the thing to do while being a visitor in the City of Roses. However, you won't get the best donut ever here. What you will get is a cool time for a photo op and a check in a box of your trip list of things to do. It will also generate some social media responses if you're one to post ("bring me back some donuts!" said your random friend you don't really talk to that much).

People talk about the Old Dirty Bastard and the Memphis Mafia donuts, which are decent, but nothing you're missing out on if you don't get a taste. I think the presentation is greater than the actual eating experience.

Come for pics, try 1 donut, then go to Blue Star for the gourmet stuff!

Very much a tourist spot.  As I was, in fact, a tourist here in PDX, I had to go!  Even on a rainy Sunday, the line wrapped around itself twice.  Still, it was shorter than the line we saw the day before so we decided to go for it, just for tourist's sake.  

The novelty of it was definitely awesome... all the puns, glittery walls, even waiting in line -- all a part of the experience.  The donuts, though... meh.  

The Cock-N-Balls is, of course, shaped like a cock... and balls.  It's cream filled (ha!), but just barely.  It's mostly dough and very little cream in the center.  The chocolate frosting on top is lackluster and mostly just really sugary.  Not to mention the awkwardness of eating this in public... God forbid a little kid see and I'm suddenly registered as a sex offender.  The Captain my Captain is, honestly, kind of atrocious.  The Cap'n Crunch bits on top are simultaneously stale and soggy.  Old Dirty Bastard met with a similar fate.  The saving grace was the Bacon Maple Bar, which my fiance actually really liked.  

Kind of disappointing.  I haven't had a good donut in quite a while and, with all the good reviews and giant line out the door, I thought this might be the place to break the spell.  But I guess not.

They are very creative and offer a lot of fun options to choose from. The quality, however, is pretty mediocre. Most of the doughnuts I've had were too sugary and weren't any better than I've had from a grocery store bakery. I've never had one yet that was worth coming back for. It's worth going once for the experience, but that's about it. Also, the atmosphere is not exactly rated G, so keep that in mind if bringing your kids.

This place is gimmicky for those who want average quality donuts topped with cereal or a happy face. If you're not much of a donut conneissuer, you'll probably enjoy this. If you're a serious donut eater, be warned.

I was really hoping this would be the best doughnut ever, but I was saddened by the dryness of it. I think the hype around it is a novelty. A fun novelty though. A place where you feel like youve slipped down the rabbit hole into another place any time of the day...for me that was at 2 am in the morning after a cross country flight. I would still take people here just for the fun atmosphere, but I wouldn't claim that their doughnut was anything amazing!
We bought 3 doughnuts and none of us thought it was good enough to be worth the calories. Totally did not live up to the hype.

I thought the donuts were just okay for the most part. We tried several, including the maple bacon & the fruit loop donut. The fruit loop one was the only that was anything special, and I would recommend that one. Loved the ambiance and the service. Fun experience, but won't be going again.

Fucking joke! We heard everyone talking about this place, so figured we'd give it a shot. Managed to find a time when there was pretty much no line, so we jumped in with anticipation. We get inside the building, and my wife walks around the edge of the line to see if she can eye the donuts, and the  hipster "donut bouncer" basically screams at her that she needs to get back in line.

We should have just left then, but persisted since we were already there. Got a few donuts including the bacon topped one, and will just say they were quite underwhelming. Top pot in Seattle is way superior , and isn't stocked with assholes. Avoid the line, it's not worth your time.

Voodoo's is a fun experience with decent donuts. My wife and I went here on our way up the pacific coast. She had gone before in Denver and was excited to take me there. When we got there, there was a bit of a line, but it moved quickly and only took us 15 minutes to get to the counter. The variety to choose from is overwhelming and there are tons of crazy flavors to choose from, which was a lot of fun. We ended up getting the voodoo dozen, which is a dozen donuts selected for you by the employee. She gave us a really good spread--we got some coco puff and Oreo ones, as well as more traditional ones likes buttermilk. Our favorites were the butterfingers, Oreo, old fashioned buttermilk, and s'mores.

The donuts are not that fantastic--they weren't hot at all, which kind of kills it for me.  It's mostly just fun to get all the different kinds and try them. If you're looking for really quality donuts, head to Randy's in Los Angeles and get the wheat and honey right as they come out of the oven at 12:30 AM.
better doughnuts in town, just a tourist trap now.

This place is clearly overrated. All the hype from TV was all fluff. I am so glad we only bought 4 donuts in the end
I had the custard with chocolate, the Oreo cookie, split the sourdough and tried the grape ape. The donut was too doughy, the custard was flat and boring, the Oreos were stale and the sour in the sourdough had no punch and lacked the melt in your mouth goodness. I am glad I tried at, now I know not to return. If you can ever make it Detroit, come and try the famous 64+ year running best donuts I have ever had the pleasure to eat in my decades of eating the holey deliciousness at Dutch Girl Donuts. On top of the less than stellar donuts, the one cashier with the two colored eyebrows seemed rude and annoyed at the customers, perhaps she should quit and the donuts are way over priced for donuts that aren't as good as Dunkin donuts. Enough said.

The shop is fun, and they have some very unusual flavors, and the doughnuts sure are pretty and bright.

I'm not a huge doughnut fan, so tastewise, Voodoo was nothing special for me.  I got the chocolate-covered, raspberry-filled, prezel-stabbed voodoo doll and a Mexican chocolate.  I defininetly would not get the Mexican chocolate again- it was bland and not chocolatey at all.  The voodoo doughnut was tasty but not more so than from any other decent bakery.  My coworker got a mango flavored one (in addition to a few others), and she liked it.

I don't really eat doughnuts except for those mini ones you get from the vendors in Seaside but it's a Portland institution so I figured I should check it out at least once. Waited in line with the tourists, picked out a dozen from the many original and funky options, got some stumptown coffee down the street and dove in. Pretty good but nothing amazing. Staff was chill, decor was interesting. Probably won't go back anytime soon though.

Donuts were really good but not worth the wait and the dodgy area surrounding the store. Many homeless people walking around disturbing guests. I think they need to hire security if they want to preserve some sort of image. We were there at 9:30pm/10pm. However, I do admit that the donuts were really good and they had many creative flavors. We got the chocolate and cinnamon flavors. Fantastic. Wouldn't come again though. Bluestar just as good and little/no security issue.

So much hype and the doughnuts are terrible in taste. I e never purchased a doughnut my children won't eat until we went here. 

The location is fun and a good place to just say you have been, snap a couple novelty photos. Doughnuts are decorated well just taste horrible.

I came here because I'd heard this was a necessary stop when in Portland. The pastries are unique and fun, but I wasn't that impressed by the quality of the food, the service (my cashier didn't seem thrilled to be there at all, but the girl next to her was more peppy), or the cleanliness of the space. I enjoyed the donuts and the hot apple cider, but I wouldn't say you'd be missing much if you didn't go to Voodoo Doughnuts when you're in PDX.

I was so looking forward to this experience but between the long lines and wait times, the experience became lackluster for me. I felt like wrangled cattle going through the line only to get to the front and give them your order and walk out within minutes...it happens in a blink of an eye. You wait wait wait and then it's over. Just like that. Poof. Overrated... 

Save the time and walk over to Saturday Market if you're there on the weekend. 

I wasn't too impressed. Donuts were decent but between the long line and lacking customer service, I was over it.

Visited Portland and had to go check out Voodoo donuts to see what all the hype was about. The real voodoo is how this place is more renown then Blue Star Donuts. It's definitely a tourist spot and we were waiting in line for 30 minutes. The donuts are single handedly keeping Portland dentists in business with all the sugar they pack on these things. The maple bacon donut was by far the best one. I love Oreos and peanut butter, but as toppings on a donut it just didn't go very well.

I heard about Voodoo Donuts and a few friends, although they had other recommendations for donuts, just told me to try it anyways since it was native to Portland. Since I knew Voodoo was known for their crazy and unique flavor combinations, I decided to try their Captain Crunch. It was basically a donut with thick sugar frosting topped with Captain Crunch and Fruity Pebbles cereal. It was too sweet for my taste and the cereal was not as crunchy as a thought it would be.

I don't now what the hype is about unless you are into weird flavored donuts like Cereal and oreo. We got a dozen and regretted it. I have to say that the standard boston creme donut was really yummy, but nothing phenomenal. I would go back if the lines are not insanely long as they usually are. Grab a donut, some Vita coffee and take apicture under the "Keep Portland Weird" wall across the street :)

I stood in line for an hour just so I could try these doughnuts out - that is 55 minutes longer than anyone should stand in a line for doughnuts.  The 26 doughnuts I ordered looked interesting and I did enjoy the bacon maple bar but in all honesty I could just go buy a maple bar and some bacon from Safeway and achieve the same result.

If you go to Portland I suggest you visit the place and look at the pretty doughnuts and take some pictures then head down to Winchell's or Dunkin's.
Its a weird doughnut shop. For tourists, after going a couple times it gets old. Voodoo is definitely a good place to bring friends from out of town, but other than that. Not so much.

We made the trip to Portland and had to visit. We're donut fans and these were good and creative, but hardly worth the hype. We still don't get it. We came in Friday morning at 9 and there was no line but the presentation was hard to select from, and we were still rushed by the server who was also in space. Why do people wait in line for an hour for this?

ugh.  over rated. Cliche. not worth the wait at all.  I prefer either a truly great pastry, such as what I can get a Ken's in NW, or if I want a creative doughnut I prefer Blue Star, and for basic doughnuts I always hit up Coco Doughnuts.  Leave Voodoo for the hoards of tourists, maybe combined with the rain it will keep people from moving here.

I detest lines. I know that waiting in lines is inevitable in our society, and I'm willing to bear the pain of waiting in a line if the rewards warrant the agony, but DONUTS? I'm sorry, but even if you throw bacon on a maple bar, it's not worth waiting in line for 40 minutes. And the people in line are horrible. I'm not talking about the drunks or the teenagers. I'm talking about the honky-ass cutesy families and gleeful couples who are bursting with joy, taking group pictures and selfies and sending that shit out via the interwebs to all their cutesy honky friends and families. In fact, I think over 50% of the reason people even go to Voodoo Doughnut is so that they can take pictures of themselves standing in line at Voodoo Doughnut. Seriously, it's a fu*king donut shop people.
As a tourist coming from bay area we had to try the famous voodoo doughnuts! But did not like the taste at all. The doughnuts were a bit on drier side.

Fun. Different. Weird. Truth be told, the donuts, while unique and off the wall in appearance and presentation, aren't better tasting than other places around town. Go for the ambiance and the Portlandia vibe, but if you're looking for great tasting donuts, there are better choices.
Tourist trap and overrated. Stale tasting donuts with unique toppings. Yes, they have donuts you can't get anywhere else, but the actual donut is not that great.

I've been waiting over a year to stop in at VooDoo Doughnuts after seeing  a TV show about it on the Travel Channel. I waited in line outside for almost an hour, and people were packed inside like sardines. The menu was kind of confusing, it just had the names of the doughnuts without a description. I was very disappointed when I tried to order a tex-ass doughnut because the employee said they were out of them....but then my friend asked for one at the same time to a different employee, and she pulled out a whole tray of them. The doughnuts tasted like ordinary doughnuts; the only difference was that they had cool names, interesting shapes, and pretty colors. It was definitely not worth the wait.

Was told it wasn't worth the wait and the bother by several people, but decided we wanted to see for ourselves. In the 2 days we were in Portland, we went by this place about 8 times and each time the line seemed longer than the last. If I had heard heard amazing reviews of these donuts from friends that have tried them, I just may have sucked it up and waited on the line for an hour to try them. But for "well... they're okay." type reviews, we opted not to wait. Maybe on our next visit, if the line's not so long.....  Good luck!  With a line that long all weekend long, (even at 930pm sunday night!), ya figure they must be doing something right though:)

Everybody fawns over Voodoo doughnut, but to be honest, the doughnuts are just ok.  It is not the food you go for, you go here because of the culture and atmosphere.  Everybody that visits Portland has to go to Voodoo.  It has an edgy grunge phsyco-sexual mystique that just draws people to look.  So yah, you gotta go, but don't expect an exceptional doughnut.

Late night drunk crowds and donuts. Hard to beat the atmosphere. We did find out this evening though that if you order something they are out of they will pull it out of the display case and give it to you for free!!

This is a place for tourists, doughnuts are good but nothing out of the ordinary, and the time that you have to wait in line sometimes is just not worthed, since other local places have much better doughnuts than here, plus sometimes when you're in line you have to deal with homeless people asking for money, very bad smells, cold or hot weather, etc. 
Another bad thing is that they only accept cash, what kind of business doesn't accept credit cards this days, but the worst part are the employees, they rush you to order your doughnuts and don't even give you time to see what you want to order, and after being in line for a very long time doesn't look fair.
We'll be back but only if we don't have to be in line for a long time, cause the doughnuts are not bad, they're just not amazing, they're just regular doughnuts, but we think is probably a good place for tourists to visit.

I had heard so much about this place and was looking forward to it but I must admit they were mediocre at best. Too much hype and no substance and there are other shops equal ore better. They might have some unusual ones but lacking in flavor and quite expensive, they take NO plastic at all, just cash, that all that comes to mind in 2017 from a business not giving options to their customers is somebody must not want to declare all their income. Terrible tourist trap so skip this place and give the cash to the homeless that know you had to get cash and wait for you out front. They also have a disgusting bathroom.

A lot of hype built this place up in our heads.  We brought back about 3 dozen of the donuts for the group.

Gourmet donuts has popped up in Chicago and NYC and perhaps Voodoo was good back in the day, but they fall way behind by the new entrants into the donut market. 

Disappointed that this wasn't a better experience.

When you come to Portland for the first time as a tourist, not trying Voodoo donuts is like not seeing the leaning tower of Pisa in Pisa.  Putting it on the itinerary was a requirement and considering how many  times it has been featured on your favorite foodie TV shows like Anthony Bourdain No Reservations and Man v. Food....I knew I had to check out what the hype was all about.

Unfortunately...there was really no hype.  Its just your typical donut that you can get at any neighborhood donut shop.  Yes, the donuts here look pretty....Yes, the toppings are pretty neat and unusual... Yes, they are instagram-worthy in front of that VooDoo sign but really, the taste is not really something I would be jumping for joy over. 

At least I got a cool Instagram photo to document the memories of one of the most famous places to visit in Portland, so I was still a happy camper.

Ive been here about 5 times.  The donuts are good but they are expensive and definitely not worth waiting in line for.  I always go on a weeknight where the line is no more than 5 mins long.  If you go on the weekend be prepared to wait hours. 

The donuts are good but they arent spectacular by any means.  Yes they have all kinds of creative names and toppings but the overall quality of the donut is not the best.  My favorite is the chocolate glazed one, topped with rice crispies, and laced wiht peanut butter. 

I like the combination of chocolate, peanut butter, and the crunchy texture of the rice crispies.

-Five stars for the vegan donuts--vegan maple bar!

-NO STARS for the shitty service and piss-poor attitude of the staff (there was one time I had a nice cashier, every other time they seem like they want to strange you for even being there)

-NO STARS for the horrendous line . . .
Eh. They hype is just as high as the customers and the sugar in each donut.

I Like their doughnuts, and their selections of odd but good combinations of toppings.  Sometimes I get heartburn afterwards.  I like their $5 buckets of doughnuts to get late at night.  I Love that the are 100% Portlandia!

I enjoyed the voodoo we shared at the end of the tunnel tour I took with my folks. There was more authenticity in the flavor than most of the stories the tour guide had, but he was funny and made my dad smile in that not-very-innocent way that us kids liked. But his stories seemed false. Anyway, I have as any Portlander has I guess, eaten a few of their donuts. I have not, however, ever waited for them. Hey, they are... well, donuts.

When I was young they had a good deal on coffee but the actual product had always been sitting around so long.... I don't know, maybe Nyquil has some kind of preserving power. They appear to be much fresher now. They are an institution and all. I had a friend get married there, they are still very happy! So in the least Voodoo helps facilitate happy wedding times and can be a bright spot on a tour where the guy makes your dad smile funny. Capiche?

Totally overrated. Aside from the absurdly unjustified long line, the donuts themselves are quite disappointing. The flavors are so-so but the worst thing is that they're just diabetes-inducing sugar bombs. Skip the hype and go for Blue Star Donuts. They're the best in town.

Not bad, kitchy.  Standard donuts (maple bars, old fashions, etc) are fair. The real treats are the specialty donuts( mexican hot chocolate). The staff is sorta friendly, granted I'm sure it's annoying dealing with tourists all day. Yep, it's a total tourist spot! They know how to keep the line moving so don't be deterred if it's out the door. More expensive then a regular donut shop but you're paying for the experience.

So I know this place is a staple of Portland - but I really was not a super fan. After waiting in line for 10 - 15 minutes I chose a lemon lime donut with nerds sprinkled on top. Bad choice and it made me sick. It is a must to go if you are in Portland for the first time but I won't be back.

Prior to moving to Portland, I often heard "you must try VooDoo." In one word, VooDoo Doughnuts is alright. Very creative doughnut names and flavors, yet they lack a "delicious aspect"; that is unless you've had a late night at the clubs, then they're truly magical. 

Pro-tip: skip the line and head over to VooDoo Too on Sandy and 16th in Northeast where there is never a line. They're doughnuts for crying out loud...you shouldn't wait in a line of 100 people.

I love the concept of Voodoo Doughnut. The shop it absolutely entertaining and some of their doughnut silhouettes were humoring. Just look for the big black "T" shaped doughnut next time. Let me know what it reminds you of. Anyways, this review is just for the maple bacon bar. The maple bacon bar had the right amount of sweetness from the maple glaze and saltiness from the bacon. The texture of the doughnut was soft and with a good amount of chewiness. It was a good doughnut with strips of bacon. Good but nothing over the top. If you're ever in Los Angeles try the bacon doughnut from Nickel Diner. I think it's much better but this particular doughnut was good for Portland.

Well, this place definitely gets cool points for it's Portland history. The flavors are pretty clever and it was definitely a "must do" on my 1st trip to Portland. Now that I live here though, I doubt I will make more than 1-2 trips a year. 

I stopped by today to give them another shot since I was getting my hair done close by in the Pearl. The doughnuts are pretty average in my opinion, nothing to go crazy over but something to definitely try once. 

The wait is usually at least 10 minutes and they only take cash. The music is eclectic and always too loud. I get the gimmick but it's too overpriced for my tastes. 

If you haven't had it, give it a shot and form your own opinion. (then come back and post on yelp!)
Don't believe the hype. There is a donut food cart about a block away with better nuts n coffee. Super dry covered in candy, if you wanna wait in line for that, go for it.

Two stars docked for foul language--'the old dirty b******?' This place needs its sanitation license checked, because its menu is DIRTY. I brought my wife here, for pete's sake. Thank goodness there weren't any kids around, not that I would have been there if there had been. Anyways, besides the foul mouth on this franchise, the donuts were A-100. Nice to see a place live up to its name. Doesn't happen much these days, you know? --Bigger, A. "The Traveling Professional"

I do not know why this place attracts the crowds it does.  The wait is always long, even if you're there at 7am and there's only 3 people in front of you in line.  The service is just SLOW.  And the donuts aren't even that good.  Sure, maybe they were one of the first to do unusual donut flavors in Portland, but now lots of places do that.  And some of their creations are just ???.  One has wrapped pieces of bubble gum on it.  Who wants that?  The ones with cereal on top are fine if you eat them immediately, but if they sit in a box for even 15 minutes, the cereal gets soggy and gross.

Expensive disgusting donuts that you have to wait forever to buy in a location that smells like weed, urine, and the great unwashed.

I might have missed something. The doughnuts were good, not exceedingly good, and certainly not "wait in a huge line and make sure you have cash" good. It's a neat spot, and the venue's got a lot of variety to it. I'll stick with a regular spot next time though.

If you're going to go anyway, the fruit loops covered raised glazed was a tasty play on your usual doughnut. Maybe I should have tried one of those giant, oddly shaped doughnuts too?

The doughnuts are not great but you have to go for the general theme and concept.  

We went around 10am on a Thursday or Wednesday and the line was very small. We were able to pick from a wide selection of doughnuts and sit outside on the pink benches to eat.  

I love the quirky decor inside. Upside down doughnuts hanging from the celing and voodoo skeleton men. 

The raised doughnuts are underwhelming even with all the unique flavors they offer. They were dry and old tasting. The lemon cruller I got was very tasty however.  

There was a homeless woman who kept disturbing the tables outside and that took a little bit away from the experience.

I waited in a long line to see what the hype about this place was. Unfortunately, for my experience, it was all hype. I waited in this line, got in, saw the GIANT BOARD OF WORDS, saw the display and I had NO CLUE which menu item matched which donut being displayed. I was confused. Sigh. I ended up pointing to a round donut that was glazed with maple and had a custard filling. The donut was unbelievably sweet and I ended up throwing half of it away. The winner is the homeless guy who picked my donut out of the trash and had a feast. There's quite a few homeless people waiting in the picnic table area next to Voodoo, waiting for your discarded sugar bombs. If these were so sugar packed I would eat many many more. Now I want a maple donut from Tim Hortons..

Very disappointing after all the hype. We didn't find Voodoo donuts to be any different than your garden variety Dunkin Donuts, other than the fact they have wackier flavors and are prettier. They're greasy and heavy and definitely not worth the wait. Go to Blue Star instead!

I heard of Voodoo back East, before I moved out here.  I expected the holy grail of donuts. Turns out, it isn't that at all.  Great marketing for sure, and that can't be denied.  There are better donut shops in town, where hipster kids don't act like you're putting them out.  The donuts aren't bad, but they aren't great, either!!

First things first.  Voodoo Doughnut is a tourist trap.  Expect to wait in a line of gawking idiots before ordering.

     Second, the doughnuts are not that good.  Maybe you should just go to Safeway. 
     
I've heard they use Dunkin Donuts mix and that doesn't explain why Dunkin Donuts are a superior product.
    
 The good doughnuts are found at Blue Star, Tonallis, Hellen Bernhards and other smaller producers.

"[My] Next Review Awaits," eh?  Yelp invites me to contribute to the community's understanding of Voodoo Doughnut, undoubtedly because it figures there's like a 90% chance I've been there.  Well...  YES.  That bait, I'll take it.

Ok, whatever.  If you're going to go to Voodoo then you already know that you're going to go there because it's on your travel itinerary or whatever.  And if you like Voodoo, then you've already convinced yourself that you like it, and I'll acknowledge that quirkiness/attitude/whatever it is that Voodoo has to offer has some kind of value.

Just don't get confused and think that you're going there to experience a doughnut product that tastes in any way special/better than Safeway.

(Also, when I bake a bunch of cookies and I package them in adorable COMPLETELY STANDARD PINK BAKERY BOXES that I got at The Decorette Shop, don't say, "Oh, you got Voodoo??!!?"  No.  Voodoo does not own the rights to the pink box.  Please.)

If you would like to try a doughnut that has the weird ingredient combos down (minus the occasional phallic inspiration) and is also a well-made doughnut, try Blue Star.  It's expensive, for doughnuts.

If you would like to experience the ultimate doughnut without getting crazy (particularly the doughnut holes, OH MY THE HOLES), head out to Tulip Pastry Shop in St. Johns.  Doughnuts are supposed to have an ultrathin exterior of crisp caramelization, remember?  If you don't remember and can't be bothered to go out to Tulip, then that's on you, but don't complain about how Voodoo was supposed to be the best and failed you, because no.  That is wrong.  You've been warned.

I'd like to send my readers off with an anecdote.  This dialogue comes from an interaction fellow would-be customers and I had with the good people at Voodoo Too, circa 2009:

***
Customers: [patiently gathering at counter, politely staring at rotating display, don't want to impose]

Voodoo person in back: [indistinguishable bellowing to Voodoo person in front]

Voodoo person in front: JUST A SECOND!  I GOTTA DEAL WITH SOME PEOPLE OUT HERE!
***

Terrible doughnuts. Terrible service. The whole place reeks of urine and old grease. The interior is filthy. So many places make better doughnuts and have better service...why waste time with these stale, dry, nasty gut-bombs? My money is on Joe's Donuts in Sandy.

Nothing factual to add here that hasn't already been said, so I'll just give my $0.02 on the donuts themselves:

Penis one (don't remember the name): Huge with a Boston cream pie thing going on. You know what that means. It oozes white cream. Yum!

Voodoo Man: Tasty. Is it bad that I enjoy devouring a donut shaped like a screaming, helpless person?

Maple Bacon: As a Canadian, I know maple and I know bacon. They're great on their own and they work really well together. Example: this donut

Mango Tango: Very refreshing change from all the chocolates and creams. Mango-flavored on the outside, zesty orange on the inside

Cocoa Puff Chocolate: Looks cool but tastes like cardboard. The Cocoa Puffs were really dry and clearly not fresh anymore, and the actual donut was also dry and tasteless. Skip.

Plain cake donut with powdered sugar: A classic but a goodie

I just can't give more than 3 stars though because the service here sucks. They know they're famous, they know people will line up in droves at all hours of the day, they know tourists will pay money up the wahzoo to try all the flavors, and so they don't put any effort into being nice or friendly. The store is kitschy and quirky. But no amount of decor can make up for a shitty attitude after you just spent 45 minutes waiting under a 95-degree sun to pay inflated prices for a pastry you could easily fry yourself in less than 10 minutes.

The place is fun, but gimmicky. You definitely go for the atmosphere and the clever copywriting. But the donuts are so-so, and more suitable for display than actual eating. I'm sure they would taste better after drinking at one of the nearby dive bars, so keep that in mind if you plan to visit.

I don't want to rate them low just because they are over-hyped. They make a great doughnut and they are unique. I just don't think it's as mind blowing as everyone else seems to--so I wouldn't wait in a line for it.

Ok well I'm originally from California which I never been to Voodoo Doughnuts before. I came to Portland last year, never been able to stop by this place. Therefore, I come in after eating at sube restaurant (a sushi place right across from voodoo doughnuts). There was no line which was great because I hear the lines can basically wrap around the building practically. So once I'm inside I look at the great looking donuts circling in the glass and begin to figure out what I would like to order. As I am about to approach the counter and greet the individual (which was a bearded man with a net wrapped around his beard), walks away from the counter softly saying "I'm on break." Then he asks (outloud) to a co-worker "am I on break?" I understand every employee deserves a break, but he made it seem like he didn't even want to assist me. There's one issue. The other issue was due to my inexperience of ordering donuts at Voodoo. First thing i explained to the individual was " So how does this work?" Stating the obvious that i have never been there before. He explained they way you could order donuts kind of low mannered and with the same attitude as if he just wanted to get off and go home, which i dont blame him coming from an employee standpoint. Idk if it was just the loud environment, lack of explanation, or my comprehensive undstanding that didnt give me the greatest experience. Therefore I ordered a classic order of donuts, not realizing that classic was literally donuts you could of ordered anywhere at any Joe shmo donut place. To my understanding, I thought classic was considered signature classic voodoo donuts that they have made before since they began, unlike their daily creative donuts. In my opinion, if I have a customer that doesn't understand how things work, I would explain my best to make sure I know what the customer is coming for, and trying to order. Therefore, I am giving this a 2 star rating. The donuts were good, but the service could step up for being one of the best donut places in town.

Before my visit to Portland, I had many friends tell me that I NEEDED to go to Voodoo Doughnut so that I could tell them what it was like.

So, here it is: it's fine. It's a donut shop. Deep-fried dough with icing is almost always delicious. It's inexpensive, at least for the normal donuts I bought.

I love that they have a whole line of vegan donuts, I love the rotating display case, I like the imagination that went in to some of the donuts.

I tried the Boston Cream and the chocolate covered crueller. Both good. My friend tried the maple bacon and she said she liked it, that it was a good balance of bacon and sweet. 

I do wish I tried a vegan donut but I guess that will be the goal for next time.
The bacon maple bar is the ONLY and I mean ONLY doughnut worth buying, and even then, not worth standing in line for. The other doughnuts are really just mediocre.

Two stars because I came here specifically for the friggin' bacon maple doughnut I saw Bourdain with on his show....but then couldn't have one because they didn't have any made.  When we asked when/how often they make them, the boy behind the counter answered, "we make doughnuts all day."  This was not helpful.

I settled for Triple Chocolate Penetration - heh, yeah.  I didn't even know it was called that until I went to their web site while writing this review!  It's a chocolate doughnut with chocolate glaze, topped with cocoa puffs.  It was pretty good and spun me out on a sugar high for the rest of the afternoon.  My girlfriend had some not great and not interesting standard doughnut fare, and was licking her "they don't have maple bacon doughnut" wounds for days after that.

Total bummer.  Lesson learned = do not come here in the middle of the day expecting them to have all their interesting doughnuts made.

Fun Flavors and atmosphere, but a bit over-rated and over-priced.

However if you've never been I'd say it's a must go just because it's such a Portland attraction.  I liked the Bacon Maple bar the best.

The donuts themselves are not bad. They are by no means amazing however. The thing that gives this such a low rating is the ridiculous wait. Rain or shine, every day of the week there is a line around the block and the service is not even that great. Over-rated.

They are donuts.   I can't believe I fell for this tourist trap.  The glazed donuts were good but they were not different than Dunkin Donuts or Krispy Kreme.  Skip the line and go to a chain donut store that can serve you in 5 mins or less.

Came here early on a Monday morning, so there were only a few people in line. Very quirky place, loud colorful art and decor, even the donuts were displayed lavishly. Was choosing between the voodoo doll and the bacon maple, went with the latter. Crunchy bacon, I thought it should have been saltier to complement the immense sweetness. It was so strong and sweet, I couldn't finish it. My cousin would love this place.

Check it out for the novelty of it, but if there's a crazy long line (and I did see the line several times!) I say just skip it.
went with the kids on a rainy afternoon- not quite sure what all of the fuss is about. Interesting, yes, ecclectic-yes. Worthy of all the notoriety? Meh.

Okay. This was a conflicting experience, and I did not read the Yelp reviews beforehand because I wanted to experience it myself. My husband and I went to this voodoo doughnuts at about 11PM on a Saturday because we wanted to skip the lines--and we did! But this location is surrounded by druggies, homeless, and god knows what else. Maybe it was the time of night? I don't know because the rest of the city was fine at night. But we walked out with our doughnuts to sit at a table outside the store and we were approached by a homeless woman who wanted us to show her our doughnuts. She literally said "I don't get to see the doughnuts they make, can I just see what they look like?" Uh..NO! We told her to go look at the rotating display in the store. Then I saw someone shooting up when we turned in the other direction leaning against a fence in front of the store. We GTFO. While the actual experience was horrifying, the doughnuts were DELICIOUS, as expected, but def not sure I'll be going back. I'll go to either a different location or Blue Star next time. Or any other place that has good doughnuts since there's no end to good doughnuts in Portland. This was a one time deal for sure...

I came here because I thought it was a must while visiting Portland but I was kind of disappointed. 

The line wasn't terribly long since it was raining so we probably wait around 15 minutes which I've heard isn't that bad.

The donuts themselves were really nothing special. I definitely had higher expectations. There's a lot going on with these flavors too and it was almost too sweet. I ended up not even finishing my donut. Crossed it off my Portland bucket list but wouldn't come back.

I do not understand the hype of this place.  The line going down along the street seemed to indicate something special, and it seems like everyone I know has been there.  

But, I was definitely not impressed.  The donut was not fresh, it had clearly been sitting out quite a while.  It had a lot of potential, I got the old dirty bastard, but it just lacked that fresh donut taste.  The music was also just kind of creepy (I know I know Voodoo Donuts what do you expect) but it just didn't seem like a very fun place to be.  

Just walk by, see the place, and walk away.  Go get your donuts someplace else.
Worth the stop so you can check it off the list but donuts were just okay and there's no where to sit inside so keep a lookout for ppl coming up to you asking for money.

We stumbled across this place because there was a huge line out of the door at 9am in the morning as we walked pass to a restaurant nearby.  We decided to try it to see what's the fuss about.

Quite frankly, this place is more gimmicky than taste... just interesting names and designs.  The doughnut by itself is no more than mediocre. We tried 3:

(1) Mango Tango - it's way too sweet for my taste... 
(2) Maple Bacon Bar - a bar with maple frosting and 2 small strips of bacon on top. It's something that you can probably assemble yourself and not have to pay $2.75 for it.  anyways, the taste was quite nice... sweet and salty at the same time.. not bad
(3) Voodoo Doll - This is definitely more gimmicky than anything.  The doughnut is in the shape of a doll and filled.  Nothing more.  

One of the touristy things to check off your list.  Otherwise, don't bother waiting in line.

====================

Review #150

If you like waiting long lines for overrated, overhyped donuts, go for it. If you want some mindblowing ones, go to bluestar. That being said, this place is well featured (on tv, yelp, online, etc.) it makes sense. Anyone who ever visits Portland will be told to go check out Voodoo. They been in business for a while, so they're doing something right. I just feel that Blue star is lightyears better. Every non-native should try it once though. Good luck, have fun.

Everyone's gotta go to Voodoo at least once in their life; it's totally a Portland tourist destination. The line wrapped around the front of the shop and went down the street, but it moved pretty quick. We spent about 40 minutes from end of the line to check out. The doughnuts seemed pretty average quality, but the toppings and flavors they pulled off were pretty entertaining and impressive. They could probably have a better ordering/check out system because once you're inside, you feel kind of rushed and everyone's talking over each other in the small space just to be heard by the person taking your order.
LINESSSS = No Fun. Also, the donuts are not so much good as they are an experience. I would recommend if you are a donut lover, then to go to another PDX place.
locals dont really go here. The lines are not worth the calories.However if your thin like me you dont care and will wait. Actually very cheap.
Very cute place. Really cool atmosphere. Cool ideas behind the doughnuts but really not impressed with the taste.

I'd heard rave reviews about the quality of the donuts here, so on my last trip to Portland I headed over as soon as I left the airport.

Honestly, I'm disappointed.  Word of mouth made me believe that they served up gourmet donuts, so I was expecting something akin to Dynamo in San Francisco-- creative, flavorful, intriguing, and exquisitely crafted.  What I actually got was stunt donuts of average quality.

If you're looking for gimmick and kitsch, I guess they're good.  If you're looking for high-quality donuts, not so much.

There is the show of Voodoo donut, and then there is the culinary quality of it. The show is a 10, replete with Disney-length lines on the weekends, the pink boxes, and the huge side-show menu of donut oddities.  A box of a dozen weighs like six boxes of Krispy Kremes, and, to say the least, they are festive.  On a taste level?  They're a mixed bag. 

The lemon filled donuts covered with blue icing, the special, were filled too rapidly and unevenly. Too much bread on one side, too much filling on the other. The filling itself was made hastily, and had a bad gelatin quality to it rather than a gooey lemony wonderfulness for which I think they were shooting. 

The Memphis fritters were overcooked to dry hardness, but the toppings were tasty. It just lacked interior softness to go with the snap of the outside of the fritter. 

The coconut topped donut with the peanut butter in the middle wasn't inherently sweet, so the dollop of unsweetened peanut butter in the middle gave it a doughy peanutty quality that wasn't taste or particularly fun to swallow.  

I'm sure, somewhere back in its foundation, Voodoo executed at five star quality, and the donuts have the potential to be that good again BUT... 

Right now, they're big on attitude and low on quality preparation, so, fun as the 30 minute line to get it was, they were not worth the wait, although we can always hope that someone in the kitchen gives a damn enough to produce quantity AND quality once again.
