It's a doughnut with a lot of good PR. I need to admit I'm not big on doughnuts in the first place, so my expectations weren't high. I went, I ate,  doubt I'll be back. It seems people were more into walking around with the Voodoo Doughnut boxes in their hands than anything else. Kind of like a status symbol. I guess for the converted this place is its own kind of Mecca. For me it was a greasy doughnut. Enjoy.

Kinda like Powell's books, it's a cool novelty that Portland has to offer but really only the first visit is exciting.  Then you go back and realize if you get anything with cereal on it, it's stale.  Everything is priced fine, but I'm not really the kind of person who likes to line up for an hour for just a donut.  You'd think someone famous was signing autographs the way people flock like sheep and wait for hours for donuts that taste already stale the same day you get them.

ODB ODB ODB!:) Voodoo is just right. Prices are fair some items are amazing and some are just weird. The staff is pretentious and it is about them NOT you, but alas that is part of it's step child charm!:)

Okay. I know that this is one of those Portland staples everyone talks about, but you're paying for novelty and reputation-- not quality doughnuts. They're okay and fairly entertaining, but often overly sweet. Not something I would actively wait in life for, but I would at least take out of town visitors by to peek through the windows.

They claim to be the home of the "original" maple bacon bar but that's a lie. I know of a bakery in New York that was making a maple bacon bar before Voodoo was even open. Totally not worth it. $3 for a gross donut! You can go to Safeway and get a better tasting one for .50 cents. No line at Safeway either!

Made an obligatory stop at Voodoo Doughnut while visiting Portland.  It's located in Chinatown so there's unfortunately a lot of homeless roaming around and asking for money. 

There was only one person in line when we walked in so there was really no wait for us. I couldn't believe it, especially with all the reviews that mention how there is usually a line that circles back and forth. 

The doughnuts themselves were alright. I didn't think they were amazing but they have some good solid doughnuts here. The names of these doughnuts are definitely fun and part of the charm. 

Some of the options they have can run up to $5+/doughnut but they have more than enough options in the $2+ range. All of the doughnuts we got were all very reasonably priced and considering the amount of toppings they put on each one, I expected them to be much more. 

The ODB (chocolate frosting, oreos and peanut butter), No Name (chocolate frosting, rice krispies and peanut butter), Dirt Doughnut Doughnut (vanilla frosting with oreos) and the Portland Cream (chocolate frosting and bavarian cream) were all good but waay too sweet to finish one whole one by yourself. 

I wouldn't wait 30+ minutes in line for one of these doughnuts but it's an experience that I think is worth checking out.  Cash Only!

SERIOUSLY GUY. I DONT GET IT. 
DOUGHNUTS are DOUGHNUTS. 
I came here expecting a great doughnut. Ordered couple of favorites (bacon maple glaze) and ate them. 
I guess for some reason, maybe the length of the line or the hundred of reviews, I very much expected this doughnut to give my mouth an orgasm. 
To tell you the truth, my mouth couldnt even fake one. I guess its shame on me for expecting a doughnut to taste like magic. 
I mean...go...get one. Eat it. But, dont be like me and expect the doughnut to dance and do magic tricks for you. It is, in the end, just a lousy doughnut.

Stopped by Voodoo doughnuts because it's an icon in Portland. I came on a Wednesday morning around 8 am, and there were only a couple people in line. Ordered the voodoo doll, topped in chocolate and filled with raspberry jelly. Also got the portland cream doughnut, filled with bavarian cream which tastes like a custard and topped with chocolate. Both doughnuts were good, but nothing over the top.

"Keep Portland Weird," reads the wall across the street from Voodoo Doughnut, the eccentric and beloved doughnut shop in Portland, Oregon. Judging from the dreadlocked ginger, dirty hippie girl with ring worm (seriously), obese monstrosities, various speed geekers, aging hipsters, and other creatures occupying the block-long line to get a doughnut at 3:00 p.m. on a Tuesday afternoon, weird is exactly what they're keeping it.

Among the weird was I. I'll admit it, I waited in the ten-plus minute line to try what authors Chuck Palahniuk and Anthony Bourdain once swooned over. It wasn't my choice to go or wait; nevertheless, I was there and I was intrigued. I'm not a big "sweets guy" (excuse me while I throw up in my mouth for saying that), but I'm all for decadence, and decadence is definitely what the people at Voodoo Doughnut are doing. Along with weird.

I tried four doughnuts: The bacon maple bar (maple frosting and bacon), the dirt doughnut (vanilla frosting and Oreos), the sprinkle doughnut (vanilla frosting and sprinkles), and an Old Dirty Bastard (chocolate frosting, Oreos, and peanut butter), the last two which were vegan. I only took a bite of each, and every one, even the vegans, proved too rich for me. As comedian Robert Kelly would say, "What the fuck does that mean, it's too awesome? You diabetic boring ass face."

I may not be diabetic, but I guess I'm a boring ass face. I just couldn't eat them; they were too rich. I'd rather trek the mile over to BUNK and eat a pork belly cubano with a side of bacon and egg potato salad and a "Mexican" Coke instead. (Like I said, I'm all for decadence, it just depends on what kind.)

Something that pleasantly surprised me was how supple and moist the vegan dough was. I've had vegan doughnuts in the past and they were abominations. Like eating chalk. Why bother? It was nice to see people doing vegan right when there is so much wrong in the world.

Ultimately, Voodoo Doughnuts is not a great place, nor is it a bad place. Simply, it's proof that if you deep fry it and put Oreos, Cap'n Crunch, or actual strips of bacon on it, curious people will come. So will weird people and, evidently, so will I, even though I'd rather be eating my pig with vinegary red peppers on toasted, gluten-full bread, not a maple bar.

Meh.. Novelty, that's all it is. It's some place you need to go once, just to say you've been there. I've always wanted to go since I watched their special on the food network. Of course I had to get the voodoo doughnut, so cute with a pretzel thru its heart. Extremely sweet, but interesting with the jelly filling. I guess this is not my type of doughnut, I prefer traditional. But I have to say you gotta try once. the prices are pretty reasonable too.

What else can you say about sugary crack in a pink box.... They're donuts... I do prefer fresher bacon on my Bacon Maple bars though... Hard and crisp bacon, not so much. The Dirty Ol bastard though put me into Diabetic Ketoacidosis only half way through... A stoners delight, which it happened to be the green festival when we happened to be down there for a day trip... 

Probably be back

Look. I get it. It's Cool. Captain Crunch Cereal on a donut.... Donuts shaped like man parts... ha ha. 

But in reality the donuts are hella sweet and don't taste great. I've had coco donuts and sesame donuts which taste much better and actually taste like something other than sugar. 

When I bit into my chocolate glazed chocolate... not only did the chocolate donut NOT taste like anything, but my teeth literally hurt from how sweet the glaze was. Bleh. Their custard is also PURE SUGAR. 

I get it, donuts are sweet. But there is a difference between a yummy sweet donut and PURE SUGAR in donut form. 

I really don't get why people stand in line for hours to get donuts. It's so NOT worth it. Go to Coco Donuts. Go to Sesame Donuts. They won't have a line and will taste SO MUCH BETTER!!
Really nothing too special about the donuts or the decor.

It's donuts that any local, non-chain can do well. They just add gimmicky toppings that make it more fun. The line is not worth it and it just seems so stupid when I see it. Poor souls. I don't know whether they're tourists or whether they're Portlanders who want to feel more, Portland-y.

Also, it's next door to a grimey porn theater...same building...so, which line are you really in? Better check twice (but only if nobody's looking!).

Anyway, if you can get in here with a line that is less than 10 people and not waste your day to get fried dough with cereal on top, then it's worth going. Otherwise, don't wait too long or you'll be cosmically punished by your disappointment. Then you'll wake up and realize: oh wait, I just did that for doughnuts in a pink box.

With all of the amazing doughnut shops these days, I would rate Voodoo as 'okay.' It's not bad but it isn't any better than other local run of the mill mom and pop places that serve basic doughnuts. The only one that I would say jumped out at me is the Oreo with Peanut Butter. 

Some other things to keep in mind:

It's very busy and you will feel rushed. 

They will be sold out of some of the more popular doughnuts, so don't get your hopes up. 

Don't expect to sit and enjoy a doughnut. They get you in and out as quickly as possible. There is  a 'to go' atmosphere.
Why they do me like this???  I had them pic it for me. Hoping for a surprise. Ain't no suprise. I could have got these donuts at home. Drove two hrs plus for this. Smh. Never again.

I find these doughnuts to be fun. If you are coming to Portland, go ahead and give them a try. However, every time I drive by, at whatever time of day/night, there is a ridiculous line that is not worth standing in. The donuts are extremely expensive, and every time I have had them (maybe 3/4 times) they have been dry and stale. I don't know what it is, but these are mediocre donuts disguised in pretty colors and toppings.  Go once, but not worth returning.

So yes, I know that when people come to Portland they say you HAVE to get Voodoo. And I've also heard a lot of people say, don't waste your time on Voodoo. Since I suffer from FOMO a lot, I had to try it just to come up with my own opinion. With that being said, DON'T GO! (but I understand if you still do).

The line can get pretty crazy, but it moves relatively quickly. The doughnuts are funky and creative. You can get some fun stuff here. However, I do have a few complaints. First, it's difficult to go in there your first time because there's a big board on the wall with names of doughnuts, but no descriptions. So you aren't really sure what you're ordering . . . unless you try to point to a doughnut that's spinning around in their little case (in which there are no names to label the doughnuts). Good luck with that. Secondly, it is a lot of pressure to go up and say what you want since there's a long ass line behind you. If you are indecisive, this is not the place for you. Third of all, the doughnuts just aren't that good. Yes, they are creative. Yes, they look cool. Yes, I love the pink box. However, the underlying doughnut is meh. The husband got the Voodoo donut and it was waaaaaaay too sweet. I got the maple bar with bacon and it was too heavy on the maple. Go to Blue Star for some quality doughnuts instead.

Buuuuuuuut, if you're in town and you want the instagram photo you have to determine whether the line is worth it for you. I totally understand and do not judge you.

I didn't dislike the place, but I found it to be just average. Something more for visitors I suppose.

The donuts were good, but none of them really stood out to me. They're really big though, I'd say one donut for two people is plenty. Everything is on the sweeter side though, so be prepared. Lines look long, but they move pretty fast.

Let's just say that I've had better donuts.

After hearing about this place, watching this place on TV, and looking at other peoples' pictures, I decided that going to Voodoo doughnuts was the ONLY thing I absolutely had to do when I was in Portland.

Excited me got 3 donuts all for myself...couldn't even finish 1. Hah.
Captain crunch/fruit loops donut was overly sweet. The cereal was getting kind of stale when I ate my donut.
Maple bacon bar was okay. I guess if you're into sweet+salty you'd like this.
The roadkill was probably my favorite one out of all of the ones I tried. Oreos, creme filling, and chocolate glaze. Can't go wrong.

Their dough is pretty soft, but it was something about the frosting/glaze. I felt like I was developing cavities with every bite. The glaze was extremely thick and it was hard to taste everything else because it was so overpowering.

Go here for the experience.

Creative, fun, great shapes, unheard of flavors. Unique and a landmark. You have to visit them and try them, because it's a most. It's a tourist spot, it's a fun experience, it's cool. Will you call these the best doughnuts you've had in your life, no. But will you remember the experience and enjoy the flavors? Yes. 
Go!

On our last day in Portland I got myself up early, despite the looming hangover so I could finally grab some voodoo doughnuts. 

The line wasn't long but it definitely took a while. Way too many options so eyes get hungrier than the belly.

Note this joint is cash only.  donuts are in the $2-$5 range

Got a dozen of mixed items, all of which I was excited to try. We made the seemingly long trek back to the hotel (it wasn't even a mile) , entered our room and started nibbling on each one.

Unfortunately, they weren't anything of intrigue. No not even the bacon one.  In fact, DK donuts back home is much less crowded and pricey--for a better donut.

That aside, voodoo what a must see and I'm glad I saw (and ate)

One of the places that need to be visited when in Portland. Came here on a Thursday night, line wasn't too long. They had pretty funny names (x-rated) for their doughnuts. I wasn't too impressed by the taste of their doughnuts, some lacked sweetness and some were overly sweet. The most important part of the doughnut is the breading! Would recommend going to blue star instead. 

Shortly after getting my doughnuts, I almost go into a fight wth a disrespectful drunk homeless man outside, wouldn't recommend coming here at the darker hours... not worth going to jail in a state that i don't even live in.

Donuts were okay, honestly the best I tried was the old fashioned. The location was less than ideal and had a lot of staring people as you waiting in line. I was asked a few times if I had money on the way to the donut shop and there was a dj/security there that seemed to keep most away. Over all I understood the hype with the wide variety of donuts, but I don't think I'd make a special trip for it.

I like that they have a variety here, but I did not feel like it was worth waiting in line for half an hour. We did the tourist thing and tried and but I don't have to come back here again. 
The donuts here are HUGE and we mistakenly bought a dozen which is the equivalent of 30 donuts. We ordered a variety of flavors but I felt overwhelmed by the speciality donuts. Too sugary for my tastebuds. I honestly enjoyed the simple chocolate glazed and plain glazed the best. 
This is a place to try once when you're in town and get it out of your system.

The only people who go to Voodoo Donut are tourists and suckers who have actually bought into the whole schtick of this place.  As if they're selling some secret, special pastry that only Portland has.  IT'S A DONUT, PEOPLE - get over yourselves.  There's nothing adventurous about getting an average donut with a wacky name served in a wacky way.  If you actually stand in line for one of these things: you definitely need to get out more.

Driving through Portland, figured I'd stop and see what all the hype was about.  Doughnuts where good, womans attitude behind the counter sucked!  If I never go back, she'll be the reason.  The whole experience was not what I expected nor was the service.  I was there for all of 3 minutes and walked out with 6 doughnuts costing $10.  I would say if your in the area check it out but don't make a special trip.

Number one: Expect long lines out the door always - no matter what time of day. Doughnuts are very eccentric as far as presentation. They taste as yummy as your best doughnut shop in your own town. I think the name is what makes it so popular. Just a fun thing to do in Portland - if you have the patience to wait in line.

LOL. First off, I do NOT understand the hype about this locally owned business. I'm all about supporting local businesses but when people hype up Voodoo doughnuts to be something of a Godly treat, that's stretching it out of proportion. Voodoo doughnuts is average at best. 

Sure, you get the infamous maple bar with bacon that has captured the taste buds of many, but other than that, the quality is just about the same as Safeway doughnuts. 

I really miss Dunkin Doughnuts :(...They really should bring a few locations back to Oregon.

I grew up in Portland. Sometimes it's still hard for me to process just how dramatically this city has changed. To put it in perspective, the popularity of a place like Voodoo Doughnut would have seemed all but impossible 15 years ago. But in 2019, it's not unusual to drive by this place at any given hour of the day, and see a line far out the door. I'm honestly astonished at how this establishment has remained relevant for YEARS now. 

The doughnuts are really quite good, and creative to boot. Why then 3 stars? It really comes down to the location and the hordes of people. Additionally, I can respect that this place started off very grassroots, but now they are in basically every "trending city" in the USA; Austin, Denver, Portland, LA. At this juncture, your success is undeniable, and being cash only is becoming a greater inconvenience by the day.

If you want to come here for the experience, and to get that perfect insta photo, I'm really not going to knock you. It's fun, and I'm not here to rain on the parade of those who wish to see *the* Voodoo Doughnut. At the same time, if you're like me and basically have the "fuck a crowd" mentality, there is another Voodoo shop over on Davis, roughly a mile away. 1/3 of the people, for the exact same doughnut? Worth it, 100 times, worth it.

Simple and Sweet

Probably the most well known place in Portland due to TV coverage and a tourist's destination, they serve doughnuts in a very Portland way: keeping it weird. One great thing about Voodoo is that they sell Stumptown Coffee to go along with your sweet treats. You also get to cross off 2 foodie locations in one go! The most well known is the Voodoo doll doughnut which is shaped like (you guessed it!) a voodoo doll. It is filled with raspberry jelly to emulate the blood. The doughnuts itself are yeast based and each doughnut is well decorated. I tried the voodoo and the Portland cream and they were just alright. The doughnuts itself are good but the glaze on top is too sweet for my taste. I also thought the Portland cream doughnut could use more cream. It felt like i got one bite of cream and that was it. 

The decor of the place is extremely pink and really matches the name. There are some skulls, coffins, etc that really make this place what it is. Staff here are super friendly and really open to talk and see how you're doing. If you've never been, it's definitely worth checking out but just don't go in expecting the world's best doughnuts.

P.S. go during an off hour so that you only wait 10 minutes compared to an hour or two.

I am reminded that I need to write my review for VD donuts. Let me start off by saying I've always wanted to grab and indulge myself into one of the famous VooDoo doughnuts. Even though I'm not a huge doughnut fan, I still wanted to partake of the experience. They look great. They smell great and are reasonably priced for being celebrity status. The place itself is quite small, so the line builds up fast. It's outdated and yes I understand that it's he first of its kind, but with the income it brings, a facelift wouldn't hurt. I mean it's a business tale that you're supposed to upgrade every 10 years for good luck, but what do I know about luck? 

Anywho, the doughnuts. This is the kind of place where looks are deceiving. Not one did I enjoy, Not one.....and we purchased a dozen. So, sadly we threw almost all of them away because they were difficult to eat. I'm wondering if the makers even taste these things or if they just dish them out because visitors are going to buy them anyway?? Whatever the case may be, I won't be returning. You really broke my heart VD. :(
Really cool and interesting flavors but they seem a bit too sweet and old. Some solid ones but nothing crazy. More of a touristy thing to do than anything.

I've had this place on my list for a while as I prepped for my trip to Portland, but I gotta admit that it was a bit overrated. We came around 11PM on a Friday night and there was hardly any line so that was the big plus. We passed by the place multiple times before 8PM-12AM and the lines were out the door and seemed to be 1hr+. 

Once you get in the door though, you'll see a photo booth to the side and tons of donuts rotating in their cases as you get closer to the register. They seem to have a lot of apparel/items you can get as a gift as well. 

The dish: Captain crunch, Maple/Bacon, and Oreo.

The maple/bacon has legit bacon slices, and not bits on the top which was a nice change. The cereal based donuts had a great texture contrast but honestly it became too much and we couldn't finish the 4 donuts we got to split between 4 people since you can def taste the sugar rush after each bite. 

Advice: If you want to try this place just to try it, I suggest coming during their off hours because I don't believe waiting 30+ mins for this place is worth it. 

***CASH ONLY

I haven't gone back since the last time I lived here, but the quality of their donuts is nothing to write home about. The cereal is stale and I feel like the only reason this place is so popular is because it's just something you have to try when you move here. I'm not sure that anyone else in Portland makes "unique" donuts, but I'd imagine that's changed since it's becoming popular in other states. I'm just saying this place isn't where you go for the eyes roll into the back of your head because it's so damn good experience. Nothing against what they're about... I'm just not impressed.

Just to clarify things.  I am a Portland local myself and I do think their donuts are amazing.  I only rated it two stars because of the soup line depressed workers and the incredibly slow lines.  Those are the only problems with this place.  Go here and you'll likely be in line with a few hundred other tourists.  They're only aware of this place because they saw it on tv and that's why this place is always cramped.  Instead of going here, go to Voodoo Doughnut Too on NE Davis instead.  You have places to sit, the employees are much nicer, and there are rarely ever lines here.  In my opinion this is the best donut I have had in all 7 countries I've been to hands down.

They doughnut is OKAY. The fashion/style of doughnut is what makes it "Special," but this isn't for me and not worth any long drive. The doughnut itself reminds me of Dunking Doughnut. Go to your local Krispie Kream it'lvl taste better overall.

This place is so so cute. I loved the decor in the shop and how they displayed the different doughnuts. I wanted to try this place because it seemed to be one of the places that Oregon is known for. Althought the doughnuts were very pretty and the actual shop was nice, the doughnut itself was nothing special. I usually get just a plain glazed doughnut, but since I was here I decided to try the cap n' crunch doughnut. It was bigger than a regular doughnut and very sweet. I wouldn't come back to this place, but I am glad I visited k

I was visiting from LA. Wanted to try these famous donuts. The bad reviews for this place are true. The donut are average for a high price it's at least $2.25 for a decent donut here. Thankfully the line was not bad on a Friday noon that's why it's getting 2 stars. The staff are not friendly. I personally like Krispy cream donuts a lot but this donut was overly sweet and not fluffy. Definitely not worth it. I'd find another donut shop if I were you. Unfortunately the other place I found (delicious donuts) was sold out at the time so I couldn't go.
voo doo donuts is OK over hyped and too sweet but the bread is excellent. i just have had better donuts at the lil asian spots

Go here for the nostalgia, but realize their doughnuts taste the same as every other doughnut.  It's cash only and there can be a line, so be prepared for that.  Also when you're in line make sure to know what you want, because they want you out of there once you get your stuff if you're not sitting at maybe the two tables in there.  Workers are friendly and nice.

This is one of those "city institutions" that's coasting on word of mouth. But if you peel away the PR "mystification," it's just a mediocre donut shop. There was nothing special about the ingredients, and to be honest, most of the stuff at Dunkin Donuts tastes way better. Voodoo's claim to fame is molding their donuts into "adult-themed" shapes, but you can derive all the amusement one can from this by just looking at photos on the website. 

There is also an unpleasant cattle herding feel to the whole place, and this Willamette Week piece breaks it all down: http://www.wweek.com/portland/article-21767-the_hole_story.html

Expect to stand in a long line - at least half an hour and even longer on nicer days.  Your best bet at avoiding a line is to go when it's pouring out.  Expect people in line to be taking all kinds of pictures and the homeless to be vying for your attention (in case that phases you). 

Expect to make a rather quick decision once you do get inside.  There are tons of options and looking them up online just isn't the same.  I will be bold enough to say though that 75% of the patrons either get a mixed random dozen or the maple bacon donut.  Being a tiny vegetarian, I did not do either, so options were a lot harder for me to deal with.

Expect to get a tasty but not a mind blowing donut.  I opted for the maple cream filled, which was very heavy (as expected) but tasty.  It did leave me feeling a little sick afterwards, but I'm not used to consuming 1000 calorie complex carbohydrates in 15 seconds :-). 

Not worth the wait. Over-hyped. I'm glad I tried it at least ounce though.
I know Voodoo Donuts is a Portland icon, but honestly, it's just meh. Glad I came for the experience, but their donuts are just as good as a local mom and pop shop on your corner.

I am not sure why people are willing to wait in line here.  A few years ago I could understand it because I feel the donuts were made with more care then (like their trademark VooDoo doll donut. Now, they seem to be mass produced without as much care.  While less artful, their donuts still provide a creative mix of ingredients and toppings. I wish they would go back to the days when their offerings didn't look so thrown together.

One star for creativity with the names and flavors, but they are some unimpressive donuts.
It just seems like something you HAVE to do when you come to Portland because it's a local thing but they are some serious below average donuts. Maybe they're amazing when they're fresh. . .

Also, customer service was terrible from the Asian girl who helped us. Before she took our money, she was friendly. After she took our money, she straight up ignored our presence when we audibly returned with a question about our change. It wasn't until we got into her personal bubble that she acknowledged us with attitude and rudely "assisted" us.

Just take a picture outside of the place and then go across the street to the "Keep Portland Weird" wall. . .

Such a devilish doll!

I had Voodoo in Denver and already knew the donuts were nothing special but I still had to come to check out this location.

Parking is meters. They are open 24/7. It was empty at 4 am when I came before I flew out. I know the line can get crazy.

Outside is pretty sketchy at night. Be careful when you go!

Cash only!

Voodoo Doll - $2.50 - Basic donut with chocolate stuffed with berry jam. I hate that they wrap the doll in wax paper, it smeared the doll!!! ARG!

Sprinkle Donut - $.95 - Good, typical sprinkle donut.

Glazed Crueller - $1.50 - Donut was light and fluffy. Glaze was nice and sweet.

I knew it would be semi pricey donuts and over hyped but still worth the visit!

Like many reviews, the doughnuts (donuts) are not that great, maybe even bad depending on your standards. The shop and the vibe are 5* and very cool but the actual donuts are not really that good. Go for the experience and maybe order one donut. Enjoy the atmosphere. I'm sure Portland ha better donuts to offer.

If people are honest about the taste of these donuts, the reviews would be more realistic. This is about how the donuts look. The day I tasted a donut with cereal on top was the last day I tasted a donut with cereal on top. Bravo to Voodoo for great marketing, but this is the Portland of non Portland dreams. It's a tourist spot and novelty shop.

The customer service is absolutely terrible and unprofessional. I simply asked the worker for recommendations and he rudely said " No! I don't do that , I never do that shit." It made things extremely awkward and shocking that someone would employ someone that had no sense of professionalism or care for customer service. It was my first time there with my friends from out of state and it just ruined the experience . We all felt uncomfortable and rushed to leave even though there was barely any other customers. We came there on November 4, at 9:30pm. I tried calling multiple times and was hung up on. I want management to know that this worker is honestly a pathetic excuse of a cashier, he did not want to help us at all. I did not get his name but he was a white male with ear piercings, tattoos, grey shirt, and not to be mean but a missing ear lobe. I hope this will help the business employ better workers that actually seem like they want to work there. I have never in my life wrote a review but my experience with this worker was extremely rude and aggressively adamant about not wanting to help us and made it absolutely clear by saying so. That is why I felt the need to write this because I've never experienced such horrible customer service. I will definitely never come back to this establishment because obviously they don't know how to enforce proper customer service standards.

I was pretty excited to finally try Voodoo Doughnut and to see what the hype's all about. I was recommended their Voodoo Man donut which was basically a chocolate donut in the shape of a man with frostings on top for the eyes, mouth, etc. The donut was stuffed with raspberry filling inside which together with the frosting and chocolate, put the donut over the edge of sweetness for me. 

Overall, I'm disappointed to say, this is just a hype. I get it's suppose to outline the weirdness of Portland but if unique flavor and intricate design is more your speed, Bluestar Donut is definitely the winner.
Long lines, mediocre donuts, and overrated.

This place is way too overhyped. The donuts are super ig-worthy but unfortunately look better than they taste. They're extremely dense and packed with sugar.  After a couple bites, I felt sick from how sweet it was.

I FINALLY made it to Portland and my first stop was Voodoo donuts for breakfast. This place is a must for tourists because this place has been hyped up for its fun donuts. The donuts are fun but by that I mean that they are shaped like voodoo dolls, and penises, in addition to regular donut holes. Also some of them are topped with cereal, crushed cookies, filled with cream or topped with bacon. Yes the donuts are fun but to me, they are overly sweet (like quadruple dipped in sugar) and the dough is simply ok. I think I got diabetes after I finished mine, I definitely crashed from the sugar. 

The line at voodoo is long but it does go by fast and the donuts are pricey. It was about a 20-25 minute wait. If I were a local I wouldn't bother to come here because of the price point and the wait. I'd definitely bring my out of town friends here though. Cash only. Coffee is good.

There are so many different flavors of doughnuts here! There was a line when we went after lunch on a Sunday, but it goes by pretty quickly. The price of the doughnuts here are cheaper than Blue Star's, but still prefer Blue Star. 

I think that the doughnuts here are way too sweet. I couldn't even finish one! It's easy to get carried away here and order more doughnuts than you need, so I'd say to just pick a few. It's also CASH ONLY, so make sure to bring cash so you don't need to stop by the ATM. 

Overall, an interesting experience to try, but if there's a long line, I think that it's okay to come back later since they are open 24/7. If I had to choose, I'd choose Blue Star, though, because their doughnuts seem higher quality and not as sweet.

Honestly, I don't think you can visit Portland without getting doughnuts at Voodoo! Yes, it is a very touristy thing to do and yes, you will wait in line at almost all times of the night and day.  And without a doubt the doughnuts are just as unhealthy as any you will find at Dunkin or Krispy. There are several bakeries in town that offer vegan, gluten free, and cleaner ingredients. I will soon be reviewing a few of those too. But as a vegan, I have not been able to bite into a yummy raised donut in YEARS. So I was very excited that they offer vegan options and I enjoyed every last bite. Thank goodness I can only eat these things when I visit Portland. I had the delicious Gay Bar - a cream filled long john with froot loops (I did pick those off). The only draw back was it left a weird film on the roof of my mouth. I tried not to think about that too much at the time! And the next morning ate my Dirty Old Bastard - a yeast raised donut with chocolate icing and a pile of oreo cookie pieces with a drizzle of caramel. I don't know if I will ever go back again but I have no regrets that I tried it!

Voodoo's fun and strange atmosphere is reason only to visit if not for all the notoriety they have received nationally as a must visit when in Portland. 

While I enjoy a voodoo donut from time to time, I personally do not think they are the best in Portland and that there are a few other spots to try. 

Nonetheless give this place a try if it's your first time in Portland and they will transport you back to when you were little wanting a donut from the grocery store case.

I didn't expect this place to live up to the hype but with 6k+ reviews and counting, I had to check it out. I came on a Saturday at around 1PM and the line wasn't as horrendous and yelpers make it out to be. I was probably in line for 20 minutes before I had an Old Dirty Bastard and Bacon Maple doughnut in hand. 

Old Dirty Bastard - Chocolate glazed donut topped with Oreo pieces and drizzled with peanut butter. It was good, but not mindblowing. It tasted exactly how I expected it to.

Bacon Maple doughnut- Again, nothing out of the ordinary. Met my expectations but didn't exceed them.

I wouldn't go out of my way for Voodoo again. If you're serious about the donut game, go to Blue Star!

[CASH ONLY]

The Bottom Line:
* take a moment before you get there or while you're in line to investigate the menu and see what comes in each donut because the menu does not have an ingredient list/description
* There are better donuts to be eaten in Portland, don't be disappointed if you don't make it here

Pros:
* unique donut flavors with funny and creative names
* fun decor and atmosphere
* takes debit and credit cards (in the past was cash only)

Cons:
* the donuts were good but I have had better
* the person serving us was a little rude and bothered that we had a few questions about what was in the different donuts

Their donuts aren't very good. Sure there's a lot of variety, but they taste like they're a day old. This place is a tourist trap and they might have had good donuts one day but not anymore. Pass on this place if you're expecting something special.

I was lucky when I hit this place up and found that there was NO line. seriously no one in line. interesting.... Thank goodness though. Had there been a line, I would've been super upset that I waited for these. Voodoo doughnuts are super overrated. WHAT ARE YOU GUYS THINKING!? Who can SERIOUSLY tell me they love these doughnuts? I had way higher expectations because of all the good reviews and from what I've heard via Word of Mouth, but I definitely wouldn't come back for these wayyyy too sweet, almost stale tasting doughnuts. yuck. Staff was friendly though. :/ That's where they get the extra star. But realistically it was more like a 1.5 star experience in my books.

SADLY, we waited for 1-HOUR in 90 DEGREE temperature because of AWFUL service. After ordering the cashier turned around and casually chatted with a co-worker for about a minute (not because he HAD to wait for anything to get our donuts....he just DIDN'T CARE) and was so SLOW he wasted about another 1 min. May not seem like a lot of time to one person...but there were 75-100 people in line. it dawned on me why I had to wait that long. Voodoo puts the appearance of a line as a higher priority than the customer's time. I'll never go back.

Highly Over Rated!
Yes, the name is cool, the place is funky, the staff is helpful. But, for waiting in line for 30 minutes, I was expecting the donuts to be at least tasty.  The dough they use is very bland.  Sure, the donuts look great but come on, put some flavor in those bad boys!  We spent close to $30 and tried the most popular donuts. Not worth the hype or the wait.

I was excited to finally try this place and was really let down by the customer service. The guy at the counter had a bad attitude and was just not pleasant, was being quite short with me and a friend. Giving it three starts because the donuts were good and moderately priced.

I refuse to eat here. I just don't want to be part of it. I don't like hype. Dare I say, I don't like cereal. 

I'm a decent friend though, so when my out-of-town friend wanted to go, I went along with her and 3 other people. They all ordered doughnuts; I didn't. No one bothered to eat more than a bite or 2. Partially-eaten doughnuts were glaring at us for the rest of our chat. 

I did try a bite--there's nothing wrong, but also nothing special.

Obviously this place has a lot of hype. The decor is super cute, and the whole vibe of the place is cool af. I suppose the prices are higher because they can afford it, but it is a little pricy (paid $14 for 5 donuts). Their fruity donuts (cherry and mango) are honestly the way to go- the donuts are soft and fluffy and the flavors are nice and subtle. The ones with cereal or cookies on top are a little stale and overly sweet, which I suppose is good if you're into sweets. It's nice to say that I've tried it but I don't think I would go out of my way to go back. The cherry donut fundraiser they're doing is a really great idea though, would definitely go back to support that and get the donut.

What's so special about Voodo Doughnut? Did I missed out on something? I think there's nothing special about it, the flavors are just meh . I guess I just don't get the hype. The lines are also long and I had to wait 15 minutes in line. I have to admit though, the customer service is super friendly. So therefore I'm giving it 3 stars.
Just ok. The donuts didn't appear to be very fresh. I was there around 11 am and the donuts I received were just ok. I've had better.
We originally did not plan on coming here, but changed our minds once we saw the long lines. The donuts were a little bland and not that fresh. They were really cute though!

Firstly you must brave the location. Walking in here with 2 kids was oddly disgusting. You park in front of a strip joint with "XXX" and "Nude Girls Performing Sex Acts" written all over the place... Come on. I hear the other location is no better. So what's with that?

We went in, waited in line. Did not know what the heck was what. You just point to what looks good on the spinning tray in a tall tube and say, "that one". They pack it up in their cutey little pink box with their logo, you pay, and you escape to the car... But not before being harassed by pimps who just want a donut. Yeah... Your grill alone could buy you the building, but you're panhandling for spare change, so you can get a donut?

Sick and wrong. If you like GMOs. Eat here. I did splurge and get a fruit loop coated donut. The fruit loops were stale. The frosting was sickly sweet. And the donut was a pathetic excuse for a raised donut... and I only ate 1/4 of it. I am normally a donut fiend and can eat a dozen at a time if allowed.

I can say I've been there... and I can say I will never return.

I swear to Holy Hades, one thing that consistently makes me want to scream when I see it is the line the crawls out of the doors. It's a tourist trap*! Fleeeeeeeeeee for your lives!!

Basically, when it comes to brass tacks, these are all schlocky silliness and just not that good. I mean, they teamed up with Rogue (also no longer good or creative for beer) to make donut-flavoured beer.

 And with the no credit cards thing (hi, welcome to 2015 - stop being so $#*& cheap Voodoo owners) and surly attitudes (thanks for deignign to notice your massive line of customers) it's a NOPE. 

You're better off getting donuts from
- Blue Star
- Tonallii's
- Fred Meyers
- Krispy Kreme - yeah, I said it
- just deciding to not eat a donut

Blech. 

*Caveat, I generally enjoy tourist traps.

Voodoo Doughnut is a cult favorite here in Portland and they pull it off in fine style. The decor is funky and fun...and the amazing variety of doughnuts will certainly keep you entertained and on a sugar high. However, the offerings for me just didn't live up to the hype on the taste scale. Now, don't get me wrong, as a loyal Yelper, I am willing to sacrifice for the team and get back in here and try a few more in hopes of finding that perfect pastry!
Regular tasting donuts with some captain crunch.  :). Voodoo is a local icon and visitors enjoy going.  Locals stay away...

The doughnuts are O.K. but not worth the hype at all. The line is long, but moves pretty quick. The customer service is shitty, the employees are tatted up and faced pierced entitled Porkland millennial trash. We got a "bucket" of doughnuts for a VERY reasonable price, but they were mostly stale (especially the ones with cereal toppings). There is NO parking at all except for the street and of course the street meters. All in all I will never go here again.

Oh yeah, as an aside, you will probably get hit up for smokes or money from the enormous homeless population that have kelp enwalled this area of Porkland.
Why is there any hype around this place? Not worth going! Mom and pop donut shops are a thousand times better.. Super dry.. Super dense.. Save your money and time
Over rated but I do love the theme and décor. Cool place to take kids. The donuts are just too sweet for me. I'm more of a glaze and crub donut type of person. lol

Upon the recommendation from my co-worker and hearing about this place from others, I decided that I absolutely had try and go to Voodoo Doughnut.  As a first time visitor to Portland, I did not realize that the surrounding location would be sketchy.  I was with someone who walked with a cane so we decided to ride the MAX from Pioneer Place Mall (very short ride).  At the stop, we noticed that there were a few homeless people settling in for the night (we were there a bit after 7pm), as well as a few walking around and huddling in their oversized blankets.  If I had known beforehand about this neighborhood, I probably would not have attempted to come at night (none of this is the fault of the store).
The store itself had an old-school feel to it.  There was a big board that lists the names of the donuts they had, as well as a revolving window that showcases the donuts with their names.  I had studied the menu beforehand and knew which one I wanted to try (Chuckles), but I did wish that there was a bit more description next to some of the donuts.  I also realized that it was a cash only store.
We didn't get to have a chance to try the donuts until two days later.  However, I was a bit disappointed in the taste.  When comparing it to another donut place in Portland, it somehow didn't taste as good (those were eaten at a later date too).  The flavoring was a-ok, but not something I would want to come back again.
I have to admit that our Voodoo doughnut run was probably the most exciting adventure we had in Portland (while trying to get back to our hotel, we ran into someone asking for a doughnut-which we definitely weren't giving out; and it took us 30 minutes to walk back to downtown because we took the long way around trying to find the MAX station).  So, we have a great story to tell about this place, but sadly our taste expectations were sadly dashed.

I'm sorry but this place is a tourist trap and they have the worst donuts I've ever seen. Whenever I see people walking around with those pink boxes, I always roll my eyes. If you wanna donut go get a great donut!

Two words: Tourist Trap. 
I passed in front of this place a bunch of times before deciding to come in. There was always a ridiculous line outside! Finally, on a sunday afternoon the line was almost gone and it seemed like the perfect time to partake in the ultimate tourist activity. 
The doughnuts are a-okay, nothing spectacular about them, and a wee-bit overpriced. I got a "voodoo dozen" which contained a bunch of signature doughnuts. After eating most of them I got a pretty fair idea of their taste, there were some better than others... but the general impression I had of the place is that they taste like your standard grocery store doughnut with a prettier design. 

Try it if you've never had them! but keep your expectations low

Too sweet and not much quality.  My friends were from out of town and were so excited about this place that they bought 24 donuts after lining up and they only took 2 bites and left all the donuts at my place.

Well it was somewhat ok after standing out in the cold to get a doughnut with some family who was visiting.  I too am new to the area so it was an experience for all of us.    I'm not a doughnut person anyway but most disgusting donuts plus I had a giant hair baked into the donut and I couldn't even continue.   Even after saying this they just grab another as if I wanted to eat more of their dry ass donuts.

Voodoo is the most well known and frequented donut spot in Portland amongst tourists and I can see the appeal since it's a very unique design. It's definitely got a cool style but they aren't the best donuts in terms of taste. Decent prices though, I got the Voodoo doll which was only $3. It was a pretty average tasting donut. The chocolate frosting on top was too much like a spread and I didn't really care for the raspberry jelly filling. Superb job on the food styling though if you want that Instagram shot.

Food: 3.25/5
Value: 3.5/5
Service: 3.75/5
Overall: 3.5/5

Okay... I've gotta confess I don't understand what all the hoopla was all about.  I waited in line for 30 minutes while a hobo serenaded me on his flute, but given the entertainment I really did not mind the wait.  Finally got to the counter and ordered some doughnuts to share.  Anticipated that my mind would be blown by doughnuty goodness but instead I was sadly underwhelmed.  The mango-tango was downright  gross - sickly sweet and just ick.  The maple bacon doughnut and the lemon cruller were admittedly better, but really nothing incredibly special.  I've had much better doughnuts in Vancouver and San Francisco, at comparable prices minus the line-ups... definitely wouldn't bother doing this again!

Obligatory was in Portland and dropped into Voodoo Donuts at 1 AM post.

Ordered the Pothole and the No-Name Doughnut. Both donuts were just average if not sub-par to the average donuts I have received from any random doughnut shop since the dawn of time. I do not understand the hype on this one at all. I prefer fresh donuts from any random no-name doughnut place hands down.

Overhyped!!! The taste is ok borderline bad. The wait times are unreasonable. Cash only.... mmm ok. 

Also, ordered 150 donuts for an event two weeks prior to pick up date. Upon arriving to pick them up (paying cash) m I was told I still need to wait in line, for 20 minutes. Once I got to the front of the line they realized the employee I spoke with placed the order for next month. So now they scrambled for another 20 minutes to figure out what they have the most of and provided me with an assortment of 150 donuts... not exactly the experience I was hoping for on a organized bulk order. 

Going here one time to take a picture is ok, other than that don't waste your time waiting in line.

Been wanting to try this place out forever with all the hype and all. Went around 7pm and the line was barely out the door and the spinning cases full of donuts. Don't know if that was a good or bad sign of fresh donuts but I went with it.
Tried the blue moon pie (I think that's what it's called.. It had blue marshmallow filling and chocolate frosting with Cinnamon Toast Crunch on the top) and the Portland cream. The blue moon was amazingly sweet - too sweet. I couldn't get past 3 bites because the frosting was way too much with the filling. The Portland cream was just as sweet, but I could eat it since the custard helped balance everything.
It just seems like this place is all the hype and it's just overly sweet donuts.

Anthony Bourdain had a great chapter in his new book about an island in the Caribbean populated entirely by rich vacationers, and how a few enterprising restauranteurs figure out that they can serve seriously crappy food - we're talking boiled lentils on a plate - and get away with it. The idea is that rich playboys/heiresses are so concerned with eating at the new "in" place that they don't even notice that they're being served crap by someone who's probably laughing all the way to the bank.

Replace Caribbean with Portland, "rich" with trend-conscious yuppies, and boiled lentils with stale doughnuts, and you have Voodoo Doughnut.

I felt sad when I saw no fewer than 3 people carrying Voodoo boxes on my flight back to SF.

Long line which moved quickly.  We ordered an assortment of donuts, some were on the SUPER sweet side, but I liked how these donuts were more of the traditional flavors.  If you wanted lavender jalapeno pb&j, you'd have to go elsewhere. At one point, an older gentleman came out and started yelling at a panhandler standing in front of the shop, loudly. And it was totally disturbing.  The homeless guy hobbled away but I was left mortified at the conduct of this employee (manager? owner?). I'm sure they deal with homeless and transients constantly because there are a lot in the area but there are just better ways to deal with the situation than yelling in front of all your customers.

TL;DR - Donuts are ok, but way overhyped.  Voodoo has fun toppings, but the donuts themselves are unremarkable.  Go to Blue Star if you actually want high quality donuts.

We ordered about 8 donuts to share the Old Dirty Bastard, Portland Cream, Captain my Captain, Double Chocolate, Glazed Old Fashioned, The Loop, and Bacon Maple Bar. 
-Old Dirty Bastard: Oreos themselves were stale.  Donut itself wasn't great. 
-Portland Cream: Good. Standard cream donut
-Captain, my Captain: Same issues as ODB.
-Double Chocolate: Little stale
-Glazed Old Fashioned: Good.  Only donut where the donut itself was good.
-The Loop: Same issues as ODB and Captain
-Bacon Maple Bar: Only good part was the bacon
Only tourists go here. You will be in line with 30 other people here. You think I'm kidding but I'm not. You also think this is the original Voodoo but it isn't. I can prove it

This place is over hyped.  The donuts even though creative are not fresh tasting and you could easily be left feeling nauseous after eating a sugar block of a donut.  As a visitor I don't enjoy smelling bums lying around outside on the sidewalks near a food establishment either.  This was a turn off.  The lines are expectedly long given that out of towners want to say "they've been there".  I can't foresee locals eating at this place.  There are far better donut shops in Portland.

so..... you either like it or hate it!
definitely not as good as blue donuts or peeps, i call it  tourist trap. but thats me...
Eh, line was ridiculously long. Donuts kinda overrated, ppl just wanting that Instagram shot. Saw someone else take a bite, frown then throw it away.

IN A NUTSHELL: ok donuts, trendy donut place, voodoo donut (a donut shaped like a voodoo doll)

VERDICT: NOT APPROVED 

RUN-DOWN: I think that the hype for this donut place was too much. Yes, they make cool voodoo donuts but the actual taste of the donut was not that great. They do have some non typical donuts but their classic donuts were just eh to me. Most people come here for the hype and I can see why. But if you're looking for a delicious donut, I wouldn't recommend it. But you should check it out if you are into the trends.

SCORE & ORDER: 2.83/5 
* Guava Colada - $3.25 (3/5) 
 -This was an interesting flavor for a donut. This was a coconut topped donut with a guava jelly filling. This was an interesting donut because I have never had a guava filled donut and this was not bad. I am not a fan of guava and coconut but my dad said it was delicious. 
* Dirt - $2.25 (2.5/5) 
 -The first, for me was too sweet. Yes, donuts are supposed to be sweet, but this one was  little too much for me. The oreo was a great touch but when it came to the donut, it almost tasted like it was filled with sugar.
* Voodoo Doll - $3.50 (3/5) 
 -The classic donut that most people get for the picture. This donut was  chocolate donut with a jelly filling inside. It wasn't the best donut. Mine was a little deflated and the chocolate melted way too easily. It also tasted a little chalky for me. 

SERVICE & ATMOSPHERE
(not reflected upon review score): 
There is a long line (usually). When I went, there wasn't that long of a line. They have ll the donuts on display for you to see. The atmosphere is pretty different. There is a lot of pink and it's a pretty small shop that they lines usually reach out the door. Service was great. The get got out donut real quick and we were out which was fast.

TIME STAMP: Tuesday - 9:45 PM [JUNE 25]

The donuts were unique and tasty, the designs are a work of art. I visited the 3rd Ave location twice, the first time the people were very friendly and nice, so I went back for more donuts to take home. The person who help me the second time needs to work on customer service, he practically threw my donuts into a box smashing one. He did give me a new donut, because it was obvious he smashed it.  My advice, if you don't like helping customers, don't. Just make the donuts. The three star rating is for the second customer service experience.

I don't understand how Voodoo achieved the level of notoriety that it has. Perhaps they were early pioneers in the "let's dump breakfast cereal on top of a donut" innovation, but the donuts themselves are just adequate, and although you might find some donuts with fun, edgy names, the donuts themselves are not pushing the envelope.

And don't get me wrong, I'm not knocking the fact that the donuts are typically following a pretty traditional recipe (minus the eccentric toppings and appearances); I've been to a lot of small donut shops that do this as well and their donuts are amazing and delicious, but the donuts I ate at Voodoo didn't even taste particularly fresh; an impressive feat given the long line I waited in for these donuts. 

Voodoo? I say Voodon't.

Was it worth the wait?  Not really.  However, it was quite interesting to see what all the pazzaz was about.  No matter what time you go, there's always a line out the wazoo for these doughnuts.  Got there at about 11pm - saw the line from afar and thought it was a line to get into a bar or something.  Nope, just for Voodoo Doughnuts.  

Although I must say, the flavors and novelty of the items are quite interesting.  Of course, we had to get the infamous voodoo doughnut with raspberry filling.  Not really my favorite, but at least I can say I've been there and done that.  I also got a Bavarian Cream doughnut.  Can't wait in line for that long and only get one doughnut right?  

I will admit, the doughnuts are super fluffy and soft.  Couldn't finish our little voodoo friend, so we left him out overnight.  Woke up the next morning, bit off his little voodoo head and it was still nice and soft.  Nom nom nom..

Small shop. Cash only. Cock-and-balls doughnut - woah that's a big one.  

Eh..

Soooo overrated. If the place had a semblance of hygiene standards it would get at least 2 stars. But the doughnuts are just ok, and the few times friends have wanted to go so I've tagged along, I always leave feeling dirty.

Yes, I get it - it's world famous, but only because the featured edibles are so audacious.  C'mon - doughnuts covered in Cap'n Crunch?  Ick.

But it is fun, if not culinary genius.  

My grandkids visited from Indiana, and I was shocked to hear their response to the question "So what would you like to visit?"  The answer: Voodoo, of course!

After a spontaneous road trip to Portland to see a show, my female companions and I decided to add to the impulse by picking up an order of Voodoo before heading back to Seattle.  Donuts at midnight?  Yes, please!  

Voodoo donuts are a novelty.  All those crazy flavors and toppings are alluring, and there is a dirty kitsch appeal to the place.  Thankfully, we got in before the line was too long, but found ourselves holding our purses close, as the street was littered with nightlife that seemed more criminal than cool.  

Hubby really liked the bacon maple bar I brought home for him.  I quite liked my "Dirty Snowball" and ordering the "Old Dirty Bastard" was a good time.

Who doesn't know Voodoo donuts even if you do not live in Portland? It is such a well know donuts chain and I was very exciting to taste their donuts. Very cute little store with eye catching glitter wall and original/funny donut names. But the fanciness of their donuts is just about the name. I had the portland cream and it was overly sweet. The vanilla custard was only filling 1/4 of the donut and it doesn't seem that they use real vanilla beans to make their custard. I have had much better donuts in less famous places.

Please STOP patronizing Voodoo Doughnuts in Portland, Oregon. The owner Tres is a complete jerk!  He called my brother (who has a cognitive disability) a "retard," after my brother complimented him/his business, while at a local karaoke bar. To use that word and to make fun of those with disabilities is disgusting and unacceptable. I will NEVER support a business like this.

The kids really enjoyed the Voodoo donuts.  They are fun, and unique from what they usually eat.  We walked there late at night since they were opened 24 hours.  Close enough to our hotel.  Too many choices for our hungry eyes, so we did pick up a lot so the kids had variety.  Great place for donuts.

this place wouldnt be so popular if it wasnt for the travel channel.

they have a variety of weird donuts but honestly, it's not anything unusual from what i've seen already. on thursday, they have jelly donut specials and on the day we went, they had the habanero jelly donut which the BF had and i hate to admit it....it was REALLY good. i, on the other hand went with cuteness and had the voodoo doll shaped donut with raspberry filling. the donuts are are $1-2 each (not cheap) but i guess you can charge that much if Anthony Bourdain has eaten here.

there was a line out the door when we came on a thursday AFTERNOON...yes, afternoon. who woulda thought donut was considered an afternoon snack. the good thing about this location is that it's downtown near the food trucks and a coffee shop next door. so you can always get some grub at the food trucks then swing by to have a donut for dessert.

oh btw, the cock and balls sounds great and enticing but its just novalty. doesnt hurt to take a look though :)

Doughnuts are my 3rd favorite food (1. Sushi, 2. Guacamole, 3. Doughnuts)... so to say I was slightly disappointed in Voodoo really hurts my soul. For as long as I can remember, Voodoo has been the esteemed doughnut that all other doughnuts strive to be. I also am not exaggerating when I say we planned this trip to Portland to 1. eat doughtnuts and 2. drink beer. And we did a lot of both.
The trick to eating at Voodoo is apparently to come in the morning... you know.. breakfast time.. when most people eat doughnuts. There was barely a line. When we walked past later around 3pm and again at 8pm, the line was wrapped outside. Yikes!
Now.. don't get me wrong. Voodoo was good. The doughnuts were very solid, fresh-tasting, and the chocolate frosting was fantastic. My favorite was the maple bacon bar, followed by the traditional voodoo doughnut with jelly. We also got a peanut butter with oreo topping, and a Portland Cream. However, there wasn't anything GREAT or unique about them. They were just... good doughnuts? And I've had good doughnuts from a lot of gas stations too. Did we order wrong? We covered what seemed to be their go-to orders? Anyway, for all the hype that we had heard, the end result was a bit disappointing. They tasted great, but I'll never in my life utter the words "You know what I'm CRAVING right now? Voodoo Doughnut".. because they just don't offer something that I can't get somewhere else.
The only things that make this place get two stars instead of one is its open late and not too expensive. If you want good donuts go someplace else, they only serve sugar bombs here.

No one really goes to Voodoo Doughnut, at least no one who lives within a 100 mile radius of Portland.

This place is like what would happen if a seven year old had a chance to make a business. "oooh... we put Cocoa Puffs on a doughnut!" Wheeeeee. Thanks for keeping Portland "weird." 

There's a reason why everyone on a plane departing Portland is rolling their eyes at you when you get on board with one of those pink doughnut boxes. This place sucks like a muggy day in a mosquito-ridden campsite sucks.

The main positive of this place is that it's a honeypot to keep your annoying relatives from the midwest standing in line for several hours rather than cluttering up some of the prettier and less touristy areas of the city.

Don't see what the hype is about. Just about every donut I have ever had there has tasted dried out and little stale. If you get a donut with cereal on top, expect that to be really stale as well. I have been to two locations (about 8 times total) and both were the same. The people are usually really friendly though! I gave them an extra star for their creativity with their donuts - wow, some really interesting stuff there.  

I AM HAPPY that they have brought a lot of publicity to Portland (and our eccentricities)!

TL;DR: there are much better doughnuts to be had for much less of a wait.

We got there around midnight on a Saturday, and waited in line for about an hour.

(Side note: while waiting in line, a grumpy man walked past us shouting, "It's just doughnuts, people! Where are your priorities?!" I mean yeah, it is just doughnuts, and turns out they weren't even that great, but it's still our time and money to spend how we choose. Why the judgement? It's Saturday night and we're hankering for something sweet. It's not like we would have been volunteering at a soup kitchen feeding the homeless or working overtime discovering a cure to cancer, IF ONLY we got our priorities straight and didn't waste our precious time on doughnuts instead!)

So anyway, doughnuts! We got a Voodoo dozen, which is server's choice, a combination of raised (with toppings like crushed oreo, cocoa puffs, etc), filled (with cream, custard, etc), and classic. I asked if one of them could be the iconic Voodoo doll doughnut, and was denied. Fair enough as it's more expensive.

I ate at least 5 doughnuts and took sampling bites out of more. (This is a safe space for such confessions, right? You guys aren't judging me?) My favorites were the Boston cream, the "Homer Simpson", and the maple glazed, as they had the most flavor and best texture. A lot of the other promising ones like crushed Oreo turned out to be disappointingly dry and bland.

Overall these were far from the best doughnuts I've had.

I'm pretty simple and although I love the variety, some of the doughnuts are too sugary. I loved the Boston creme. Freshest doughnuts I've tasted, but way too much variety. I get that it wants to cater to everyone, which is awesome, but makes deciding a little more difficult.

The line was super long! Waited about 30 minutes to get in. The place has a really nice vibe to it and the atmosphere was really fun! They have really cool shaped donuts (however if you are bringing kids be aware they have adult shaped donuts). I ordered the cake donut and it tasted as if it had been sitting on the shelf for a while.

Not really sure why everyone hypes up this place so much. Their donuts are super dry, but the 5$ bucket of donuts are a nice deal. I like how they have unique variety of donuts. Maple and bacon is the best or the classic voodoo. If you want moist donuts this isn't the place maybe try Krishy Kreams.

I honestly can't believe so many people are willing to stand in line for these donuts, at this ugly place.  My husband is a donut fanatic, and I just like a bite or two.  We fell for the "you gotta go" hype and went during a weekend getaway in PDX... Im telling you, ITS NOT WORTH IT! I have never in our 24 years seen my husband throw a donut in the trash, but he threw these away! After a bite! Such a waste of time and money and NOT worth the calories... If you want a decent donut go to the original Blue Star where you can get their fresh and very unique flavors that are actually worth it.  TOURIST TRAP don't fall for it...!

I'm European, so donuts are not really my thing. Having said that, I've tasted some delicious donuts and this place did not serve them. These donuts are serious sugar overload that will make your teeth hurt. Disgusting. The icing was gross. So damn sweet. I took one bite of my guava colada and was done. My family got the one with the Bavarian cream filling and chocolate glaze, the Homer, and the Bubble Gum one. My 2 and 4 year old ate about 1/3 of theirs and we threw the rest away. My husband, however, finished his Bavarian cream one. I would not eat their donuts again. The place was popular, the line super long, the inside was decorated in traditional Portland weird vibe, which I can appreciate, but the donuts did not hit spot. At all.

Over-rated tourist trap. Whoever marketed Voodoo Doughnut, to where it is now... an iconic-bane of Old Town and SE Portland... that person must be an evil-genius. Be prepared to wait in line for around an hour; if it's summertime... be prepared to be hit in the face with overwhelming, wafting whiffs of sewer-stink... emanating from the rickety, old-school, old-town plumbing-venting... seriously... it might be the homeless folks as well... but at this point... they are iconic of Portland too. Just be prepared to receive an iconically forgettable doughnut.

The donuts are tasteless. All you are paying is for the topping. I heard so much about Voodoo Donuts, even saw it on TV. I was super disappointed. And a plus side, I tried it, hated it and will check it off my bucket list. Will not be going back

Do I like donuts? Yes. Have I needed a donut at 11 pm? Oh yes. Is this in a great spot if you are at Saturday market or drinking downtown? Totes. 

So voodoo, I will be nice about this, they are normal donuts you can get anywhere. Places in Portland often will have donuts with cereal on them or bacon. If you are visiting Portland, yeah you should get the pink box at least once, but if you are looking for unique PORTLAND donuts there are other places. 

Make sure to bring cash and have some idea of what you want, especially if there is a line. It's very go go go.

I've visited Portland at least a dozen times in the past 2 years and have always been tempted to try the famous Voodoo Donuts, but every time I would drive by and see that long line of people waiting, wrapped all the way around the corner and down the side street... I don't think any donut is worth that wait... But this last trip to Portland I finally figured out a loophole: going in the middle of the night. Seriously. Voodoo is open 24 hours and after a long night of pub crawling, we decided to attempt getting a Voodoo donut. Success! No line at 1 am. In the end, the donut (I got maple bacon bar) was just okay; nothing that I'll go back for. But I'm glad I can finally cross that off the Portland bucket list.

Not so impressed... live with a donut aficionado and we have experienced donuts around the world:  always going to the reclmended place. The vibe is great...Halloween all year round, buy, the donuts sre just ok. In Portland Maine there is a donut shop that would kick their ass. And I. Amherst Massachusetts whole donuts would leave them at the starting gate. Fresh is key and they do not have the fresher off the oven understanding.

Perhaps it's the weird part of town that made this yuppie gal nervous? Nah, that's not it. Perhaps it's the small, interior? Nope, that's not it either. Perhaps it's the not-worth-your-time doughnuts? DING DING DING! You got it! 

Look, hailing from San Francisco (where they have outstanding doughnuts) has clearly spoiled me. I'm used to light, fluffy ones, not dense, cake-y lumps of cake. Plus, the cocoa puffs on top of my chocolate donut were SO STALE. 

I know lots of people looooove this place, and I have to agree the kitschy interior and awesome heavy metal music adds to a cool vibe, but *shrug* I wasn't blown away. 

Sorry Voodoo, I really, really wanted to like you! :-(

I'm going to be honest...the donuts here are absolutely okay. The most spectacular attribute: the creative ideas that inspire each donut and the hilarious names.

More hype than actual oomph behind the flavor combinations. It is a fun place to visit (as long as it's not raining and you're waiting in that looong line outside).

It's open 24/7, which is perfect for your late night munchies.

You go to Voodoo for the novelty, the vibe, and hilarous out of the box thinking that goes into what they craft as donuts.  You don't really go for the amazing culinary flavors. It's straightforward. They taste like average donuts but average donuts that have quirkiness. So more fun than the usual donut place. 

I recommend going for the experience at least once. 

To avoid waiting in a long line, I recommend going late at night. We came at around 10pm and that was perfect.  People, this place open 24 HOURS. You can go at any time. Save waiting in line for something worth it that can't be avoided. 

Tried the following raised yeast doughnuts that are recommendable:

Voodoo Doll (this would be the quintessential one to get) -- filled with raspberry jelly, topped with chocolate glaze, staked in its little heart with a pretzel stick; each one is slightly different; can you imagine the fun that the staff must have making each one?

Cock-N-Balls -- how can you not? Shaped as it sounds, filled with Bavarian cream and glazed with chocolate. 

McMinnville Cream -- topped with a maple glaze, filled with Bavarian cream; couldn't resist its cute beady eyes and curly mustache

If you want to save time ordering, look up the flavors beforehand on their website.

Slightly better than a Safeway doughnut as afar as the actual pastry is concerned. The toppings are quirky and good. The atmosphere is fun as well. I felt like I waited forever for an average to mediocre doughnut. If I had walked in and pick some up no problem then maybe 3 stars... maybe.

Without a doubt, this is a pit stop for any out of towner. You'll for sure see one or two pink voodoo boxes in the airport. Frankly, I don't understand the craze. It's weird and quirky and has the Portland charm to the shops, but that's all that I can really say is going for the store. I've seen insane lines that go down the block, I must admit that I've been guilty of waiting in those lines.

The decorations are fun and they take donuts to the next level by adding all these cereals and cookies to them. It's whats underneath all that make up that counts.. I mean frosting. You can dress it up as much as you want but at the end of the day the donuts are dry and virtually flavorless. Yeah, the donuts taste like instant diabetes but thats all from whatever is covering the donut. I've never wanted to dunk a donut in milk, but I absolutely feel that it is necessary. I know some people actually enjoy their donuts but for me, I can't get passed how dry it is and dense. Portland cream, dirty donut, voodoo doll, and dirty old bastard are on top of my list when I'm here.

Be prepared for a long line and come with cash.

I recently broke one of my personal Cardinal Rules when, after someone brought in a box of VooDoo Doughnuts to work, I accepted one (this time coated in Cocoa Puffs or some such) and without thinking, bit in. 

To describe the sensation of eating one of those cereal-topped abortions, one must look for metaphors that stray far from any notion of edibility. As my teeth sank into the stale, almost rubbery toppings, my mind raced backwards, much as a person's mind might whilst watching her/his life flashing before their eyes: I was younger, it was Christmas morning, and we had just gotten a brand new Nintendo Entertainment System...it was also my first time experiencing the ear-rending squeal of thick Styrofoam against cardboard as it slid from within its boxy restraints. 

Flash to present, and there is no video game system, encased in environmentally caustic Styrofoam, but a doughnut... 

...yes, eating this doughnut was like biting into sugar-covered packing materials. I only wish I were exaggerating. 

Humans are odd creatures...they congregate around the most unexplainable monoliths as if desperate to forge an identity - any identity - and in the inexplicable vortex of Portland's cultural stew, VooDoo Doughnut has somehow amassed a following. 

I remain baffled to this day...respectful of the choices made, but baffled nonetheless.

**I fear this review may send a bunch of people in tight jeans and hipster glasses my way for a flogging**

But seriously people, whats with this place? I have to stay true to my fellow Yelp followers. The donuts taste like someone dropped their Safeway doughnut in box of cereal and out came a donut with Capn Crunch on it. The donuts do not taste good, cool concept? I guess, but if I want a doughnut I want it to taste good, I do not care if if looks like it got dragged in a hipsters food pantry. Oh, wait, did you say bacon?! Sorry guys, bacon is amazing but it cannot make up for all sins. Try taking bacon with you on your next blind date, if they end up being an ugo guess what, that bacon wont make them any more attractive if you put it on their head.... Trust me, I've tried.

I lived in Portland for several years and had the daunting task of taking visitors here because they just had to check it out. They all said the same thing.."they had really cool looking doughnuts, and funny names, but did not taste that good". I say try the place out yourself, the doughnuts wont kill you or anything, just don't buy into the hype. It's OK to not like a place that all the "cool" kids like.

I will say, they have great choice and great video games to play. Oh, and if you are into phallic fried dough this might just be your place. Portland, you go ahead and stay weird, but please be unique.
Why do people bother! The donuts are overpriced and nothing special at all! Amazing how many people go there! Tourist trap only!  Try coco donuts!

So on my first trip to portland i insisted on visiting VooDoo Doughnuts because it is a touristy thing to do. So i did. My experience was relegated to horrible. 

The first thing you notice when walking in is that this place is old and dungy. It doesn't look clean and the lighting is horrible. The customer service there is horrendous. They yelled at our group for standing in front of the door. If they don't want people standing in front of the door of a cramped 
 and overcrowded area they should set up line barriers to prevent this from happening. Yelling at customers doesn't really make the experience enjoyable. 

When we were called up to make our order we were met by a guy that was dressed very funky and was tattooed all over. I mean on his face, arms, and anything that was visible. I honestly was intrigued by all his tattooes. He had these knuckles tattoos with a line in between each knuckle followed by dots between the other knuckles on each finger. I had never seen that before so i asked what it meant. He looked at me and said "you don't know!?" to which i shook my head to indicate that i did not. He then said very rudely, "if you don't know then you will never know!" and walked away in disgust. He said it with such anger i was left there staring at the ugly pink walls of the shop in disbelief of what just happened. It was an eerie feeling being there to begin with and now it was a bad experience that kept turning worse. 

Now, i was hoping the doughnuts would redeem the bad experience. I tried the bacon maple doughnut. The doughnut tasted old and the bacon was dry and lacked flavor. To top it all off it wasn't reasonably priced either. 

Then what sealed the deal was that our group decided to eat our doughnuts a block away from the shop standing on the sidewalk. While eating them,  there was a man in his late 20s or early 30s standing about 5 feet away from us. We didn't think anything of it. He tried to make small talk with us but we kept to ourselves. A minute later we see him shooting up some heroin right in front of us. This was in the late afternoon and in public. 

Overall, I would give this entire experience 0 stars if it were possible. I will never step foot inside a VooDoo Doughnut shop again. Bad customer service, bad product, and it's located in area with junkies.
Great selection of off the wall donut "flavors".   Taste just average. Overrated IMHO.
so over rated its awesome. The idea that this place has good donuts is silly but tourist love it.

My god, the most overrated donut shop I have ever experienced. Even my friends who actually LIVE in Portland agree with me, but I had to try this place once...

So what's so special about Voodoo Doughnut. Like a lot of the places in this hipster-esque city, Voodoo Doughnut is a shop that experiments in a lot of unique types of doughnut combinations. For example, their Yelp business picture is a photo of the Maple Bacon doughnut. Literally, you have slices of bacon on a doughnut...

But still, sometimes popularity is justified right? We came in on a Friday morning at about 8am and there was already a long line going. Note, before you come, know that you will 1. have to wait a bit and 2. you need to pay in cash.
