You'll notice when you walk in that you are in a different world, transported into the Voodoo universe. There are interesting decorations on the wall, capped off by the unique combinations of doughnuts that they have. Don't be fooled though, they're just doughnuts...

I wanted to save my stomach and so I opted to try the Great Ape (it's like a normal glazed doughnut with purple sprinkles). Just my luck because they ran out... AT 8AM. So I ended up getting the captain doughnut.

What a mistake because it was literally a glazed doughnut with fruity captain crunch and frosting. It tasted like something I could make myself and I realized that I preferred and even craved Krispy Kreme Doughnuts after that. My friends also echoed my sentiments, saying that this place was a tad too overhyped.

I understand that Voodoo doughnuts is out there to experiment with different combinations, but I'd love it a lot more if the doughnuts actually tasted decent. 

Eat well and prosper folks,

The doughnuts are too dense & way too sweet. I know, you're going to appease the sweet tooth, but dang. Not only that, but the tattoo-faced cashier was just rude. I'm an alternative girl & was happy to see fellow alt folks working there. To be completely ignored isn't ok. I complemented his necklace... ignored. Finally says "Sorry, I had to count your change". Seriously? I've been bartending for 16 years! I can carry on multiple conversations whilst making change, plus running CC's! No excuse. They need to concentrate on making good doughnuts as opposed to beautifully odd ones. Hiring friendlies would help too.

Tastes pretty good considering places in LA have knockoffs. Voodoo taste is more refined and we'll developed for sure. The coconut guava is ill, as is the maple bacon and the hibiscus one. The line is insane. Even late afternoon.  I have a kiddo, and it's a bit more sexual than is necessary - for donuts.  Between that and the line, it's a drawback.
Not a fan. The wait was definitely not worth it. I felt the donuts were over-hyped. I'll give it a star for the creativity but it's useless if the donuts itself were average.

over rated
over rated
OVER RATED .... if these are superior donuts, I am Marie of Romania.  I'm not sure a doughnut can really be BAD, er good, uh bad, well, you know what I mean ... broccoli donuts? OKAY! Now that's Portland hip. 
Go to Annie's Donuts on N.E. Sandy Blvd. then somewhere for a Burnt Weeny Sandwich with Roy Estrada and Jimmie Carl Black.
Quit faux doughnuts!

My brother bought some Voodoo doughnuts back for me and I must say I am seriously not impressed....$27 for a box of donuts that I could easily get here for half the price and taste better....its all a hype, just because they were featured on tv  they jack up their prices. None of the donuts I had stood out or made an impression on me.

"Voodoo Main" is dropping.  Why so?  You drive by there and (1) it has a long line, so you don't want to stop, or (2) there is minimal to no line, and you still don't want to stop.

I could have used a formula to come up with 4 stars - that is, you could eat the donut of your choice, in my case the chocolate-peanut butter "Old Dirty Bastard," once quarterly, thus 4 times a year and call it a 4 star event. Since I've been slipping from adhering to this arbitrary schedule, I'll say it's a 3 star event, as in a-ok.

Mind you, I do like the "Old Dirty Bastard" donut quite a bit, and even the Neapolitan, but some of the other donuts in the glass case look overworked, and even a little gross.  However, I'll just say that the few donuts I like are good, even very good, in my opinion, but jumping through the hoops to get them has become somewhat of a yawn, especially since I live in the metro area and could go elsewhere to get some donuts, and practice my Spanish at the same time, instead of dealing with tourist weary hipsters.

If you're looking for a (pink) box of cute and aesthetic donuts for your instagram, this is the place for you. However, if you're looking for a deliciously decadent donut, I would suggest you try out another donut shop. As much as I wanted to love this place, the donuts that I tried (Voodoo bubblegum and raspberry) were just alright. The dough felt super heavy, and the sweetness was extremely overpowering. I came here after seeing thousands of reviews on this place, and wanted to try it for myself. Unfortunately, this place just doesn't do it for me. Just a heads up -- since this shop is located downtown, finding parking is rather difficult. Also, please note their hours before coming here since they are constantly changing due to the pandemic. If you're looking for a quick and easy bite to satisfy your sweet tooth, this is the place for you!

In my honest opinion, this place is over-hyped BUT you just gotta check it out at least once. There will be an absurd amount of people waiting in line and sure, the donut you waited 30 minutes for can potentially be sold out but that's part of the Voodoo experience. The donuts was too sweet and it wasn't good the next morning. Parking was a struggle as usual since it's downtown. At least the workers were fast!

If you ever want to eat the pink donut from the Simpsons, they have the Homer which is their take on it. I heard the Dirty Old Bastard was pretty good too.

It's not worth the trip, the hassle to park, or the BS policies.  It's all hype and no substance.  Furthermore, they are in the skid row section of DT PDX.  The Salvation Army and Missions are literally around the block.  Go to Krispy Kreme.  They are quicker, fresher, safer, and nicer.

Maybe I was anticipating it too much, but after waiting in line to get these, I'm underwhelmed.  The bacon maple bar was just okay, and the Portland cream was bad-- too much cheap chocolate icing on top.  Seems like a tourist trap--I can get better doughnuts elsewhere.

Over-hyped and over-rated.  Lots of humor and being out there but the basic doughnut is only average.  For the giggle factor they win, for drawing attention they win, but for the actually eating experience they lose.

Reviewer no. 7,639.. whoa! 
My measly review no. 362. 

I feel kinda bad about my 3 stars because of the cultural icon of Voodoo Doughnuts, but to me, the hype is much more than the genuine quality. I've been to two of their Portland locations. This particular one is in the heart of downtown and I've only been to twice. 

It's super busy and has a basic albeit awesomely creepy ambiance to it. I mean you can get married here in a coffin if you wanted-- They have creative doughnuts like the voodoo doll and a "cock and balls" (it's their menu...not mine). CASH ONLY! 

The doughnuts to me aren't special at all. With that being said, I haven't had many doughnuts to compare and I'm not a doughnut guy. I do buy the $10 bucket of day-old doughnuts sometimes. The leftovers go to charity for the most part, but you can get your hands on a bucket for super cheap and share them out. They come in a big frosting bucket and must have 20 doughnuts in it. Since I only live 6 hours away and my mom lives in the middle of that drive, there is a doughnut for all!  

All-in-all the cultural Portland vibe and the popularity is indeed worth the visit. If you're going downtown just for this, I suggest you visit their other location because it's not in the hustle and bustle of drunkenness, but rather somewhere with ample parking and seating. Bring cash... :)

Yikes it was the only place I didn't like during my first Portland trip. $1 tip was set as a default and I did not realize until I signed...i mean what is that and who does that? For picking 3 doughnuts and putting in a box? 

Ok and doughnuts....
I got the 3 doughnuts and i did not finish ANY of them...yikes toooooo sweet and too soggy (the loops and cookies) 

What can i say ‍ i wasted $8.xx


Update: I tried to finish the doughnuts, ugh i seriously cannot

Don't, just don't.... If your out of town visitors insist on going, do it for them...the thrill of standing on line, the fun of chatting with everyone else there from somewhere not Portland (hence 2 stars), being accosted by the best of Portland's houseless, then when you finally make it in the door, being rushed through the process of picking out which practically tasteless piece of fried dough you are going to shell out way too much money for.. then go ahead and go. Just know that for the cost of one voodoo donut, you can get a dozen at Fred Meyer that will taste just as good. Give you visitors a day to get over the thrill going to Voodoo,  take them to Blue Star for a truly great doughnut.

I've visited Voodoo Doughnuts a number of times - mostly with out of town guests so they can have the experience. I'm not a huge doughnut eater but the novelty factor is definitely there ... the place is pretty much always packed (at least when I've been there) and the service is OK - not overly great but not terrible either and completely understandable with the volume they are doing.

Why the hype? They are doughnuts. I can't believe people line up for these denizens of sugared pastry confection. I get the draw, the toppings are creative and unusual, that is the key. Not being a sweet focused guy, I am less than excited, but if you are a doughnuts aficionado, then this is your nirvana
I like the Homer Doughnuts . I have had their traditional glaze and Apple Fritter a long time ago... years ago... so not sure what they have now.

If you know me, you know my obsession with Bourdain and you know that of course I watched his Pacific NW episode again before taking off to Portland. So, Voodoo was somewhere around the middle of my list of things to see.

My friends and I went to Powell's and then decided to grab the donuts before we headed back to SE Portland. There of course, was a line and some bums hanging around but they didn't bother us.

When we got inside, the crap all over the walls made me cringe a bit because I was thinking of all the dust that settles on the frames and old pink boxes.. (shudder) I'm a germ freak I guess.

We decided to get a half dozen of goodness until we went to the counter and the girl told us that they only had what was spinning around in the display. TOTAL DISAPPOINTMENT! No bacon maple, no bloody voodoo, no EXCITING donuts! We settled on a chocolate cocoa puff donut, a pink coconut peanut butter donut and a regular donut with chocolate frosting, rice krispies and peanut butter drizzle (my favourite of the three). 

I'd totally go back if I was in town to see if I can get the bacon maple, but for the price and the uncertainty of what you'll get.. it's sort of like meh.. whatevs.

I'm sorry to say but I didn't love this Portland institution. It's certainly creative and kitschy and a good value (doughnuts are huge and surely shareable).

There are many flavors and fillings. The doughnuts kind of rotate in the glass cases which in itself is kind of odd because you have no idea how fresh they are. We were a group of girls in from nyc and came around the afternoon on a Thursday. Maybe it's better in the morning. 

I also got the plain glazed. As I normally do when trying places. It was yeast, dough y and fluffy. Not too sweet but I've had better even at nyc our home shop of Dough. 

Idk the doughnut didn't taste fresh. And while they do have nice seating outside, the area smelled like sewage which didn't really help their cause. 

Since we were a bachelorette party we ordered the "cock and balls" doughnut for our friend which I think was the Portland creme with a chocolate frosting atop. I didn't try this but the girls seemed to think it was alright, and definitely huge to feed an army. 

I suppose take your own spin on it but not worth waiting in a line for (we didnt) and note it's in a grimier part of town.
Tourist trap. Mediocre doughnuts in funny shapes. Wait in line for an hour to get your trendy pink box. Go to Delicious Doughnuts on Grand or Bluestar. Save your time, get a better value.

Great visual creativity with the artistic aspect of the donuts but they are so darn sweet that I don't taste any creativity!  Really cool looking donuts!  Wasn't thrilled about the taste unfortunately.  Sorry!

Perfect example of how in this country, gimmick = marketing = success.  To replicate the taste you get here, simply get

2 slices of out of date wonder bread
9 tablespoons of sugar

Place sugar between the two slices of bread and enjoy!

Only difference is that in portland, anti-corporate gimmick/image = marketing = success, so I wouldn't even be surprised if Voodoo Doughnut were to be revealed as actually owned by McDonald's.

Seriously the worst donuts I have ever had.  Dry and stale, way too much sugar frosting and a ridiculous price tag.  I guess thats why Portlanders don't bother.  Voodoo is for out of towners.  Gross:(

They have a lot of different doughnuts here, both cute and scary ones. We ordered the guava one, a voodoo doll, a bacon maple donut, and a mango tango. Pretty tasty overall, just WAY too sweet. 
The decor in the shop is pretty unique, really emo. One downside is that the shop is too hot, I guess maybe that's the "oven -like" environment they want to create??? Nice shop if you want to take aesthetic photos.

Well wasn't sure what to expect because of the hype. But this place was following all social distancing guidelines. To get the place in downtown, is a little dirty with the roads, but well it is downtown.

There were only a handful of people in line, and ordered the voodoo donut, maple and captain crunch. The maple one was def my fav! The sweetness and apple flavor of it was delish. The crispiness and freshness of it was great. The captain crunch one was great for the first two bites, but after you kind of get sick.

These donuts need to be shared they are huge!

Voodoo was awesome back in the day, like before it was cool. Now, the donuts are stale, made with hate and the homeless live inside the building. I seriously feel for the employees (you should too). Cool if you're from out of town to experience Voodoo/for bragging rights of "touristy things I did in Portland" but there are MUCH BETTER quality donuts around. Look for a hole in the wall. People say Blue Star, I say BOO. Explore dudes!

Overrated! Went to Portland a few years ago and we didn't go cause the line was ridiculous. Went again this past weekend, line was still ridiculous but we wanted to try it so we waited. Was about a 10 minute wait. Cash only! 

They have a good variety, fun flavors but overpriced! Maybe it's just me but I prefer the Mom and Pop shops with the pink boxes!

Underwhelming, cold doughnuts that weren't fresh. 
The best doughnut I've ever had probably is at Randy's in LA. This place is a tourist trap, unfortunately.
Ehh, nothing special here.  I really don't get what all the hype is about!  I'd rather go to Blue Star Donuts any day.

every time I go to voodoo... the place is extremely dirty inside. I have worked in the restaurant industry for almost 10 years and everyone knows that the lobby is what needs to look nice. Yes, the doughnuts are good, but not good enough to stand in line for 30 minutes. maybe during the rush times, they should have more than one person working counter. also... bust out the windex and mop. it would do wonders.

Five stars just for the touristy experience of sayingyou went, which we did. Two stars for the quality of the doughnuts.

Sorry Voodoo, what we walked away with were no better in quality than your average Dunken Donuts at 5pm on a Sunday afternoon. A bit too stiff to call fresh, not 100% stale, just blandly unappealing but fun to look at.

Staff seems friendly enough if you can get them to engage you but yeah, it's a tourist trap, and hailing from a tourist trap area myself (New Orleans, the actual land of American Voodoo), I understand its importance.

Expect long lines and a wait for unremarkable but must-have treats. Expecting anything else is just bad JuJu.

I heard so much fame about this place that I had to try it out. We got a dozen of donuts and tried a variety. The donuts themselves are really creative and cool. The have a cute lil photo booth inside which is cool. The line is usually long but it does go by quick. As for flavor there was nothing special about it. I would say its definitely more of an experience thing.
Actually, I have had better donuts than that in New York, but still, the voodoo doughnut is okay with me

Unfortunately, this place is just another hyped up place for me. But like everyone else, I had to try it since during that time it was only in Portland! Lines can get really long! Their donuts are really too sweet and there's really nothing special about them taste wise, but I do have to give it to them for their creativeness and decorations!

Voodoo doughnuts to me was more of a touristy thing to do in Portland and cross off my bucket list more than anything else.

My very first trip to Portland we tried to come here but the line was around the corner. Waiting and waiting for a box of doughnuts just didn't seem worth it to me at the time, so we skipped it.

Round 2 the following year was a success only because we came around midnight and hardly no line. I remember browsing the doughnuts which seemed the majority were more about the shape and character. In fact, it seemed that many doughnuts available at the time didn't really excite me. 

I ended up ordering a doughnut with fruit loops which tasted exactly like it sounds. Wasn't bad, but didn't wow me either. I think the majority of these doughnuts are more about the design than taste.

Between the three of us, we had a box of doughnuts to go. By the morning, nobody wanted to eat any of them which resulted in the trash a few days later. I do appreciate the unique style that this place has, but I just don't see myself being that excited to go back now that I've been there and done that.

I don't really understand the appeal. Granted I like sweets but not love them. This seems like a overloaded donut just to be able to make them unique. Great concept but I just think it's extreme amounts of sugar. We split the homer 3 ways and the staff said it's the first time she's heard anyone asking for a donut to be cut . Glad we did because I felt it was just too much. Our 12yo enjoyed it. I hear another establishment is a bit better with the variety and styles they have. But I haven't been. I guess it's a great social media picture place.

I came here with such high hopes. They all came crashing down when:

1. They were out of not one, not two, but three of the doughnuts I came for. I settled for something way different than I was craving.

2. The service was so bad. I felt like I was totally putting them out by being there, I get its part of their schtick but come on guys, take it easy. 

3. I will not go back, no matter how good I hear they are. Some things should just stay a mystery.

look wierd?=yes
want to seem cooler because everyone else does it?=yes
taste good?=NO

I'm glad we came here as first timer in Portland but I should say I've had better doughnut before.

We came here on Friday afternoon and line wasn't too bad, we waited about 10min or less. The decor inside was cute and unique. There are so many different tastes to try but we tried one recommended by our cab driver, maple bacon doughnut. It was ok, Who doesn't like sweet and bacon combination but that was about it.
Waited for over an hour in the line to get in. The experience is fun, but the doughnuts are very mediocre. Too sweet for my tastebuds too. Isn't worth the wait unless you just want the experience.
Tried once and never again. Overhyped and average taste. The shop is small with a couple of displays of donuts that don't even look enticing. Creative decorations? I think not!

Voodoo is an average place, nothing special about the donuts. They're only popular because of the boxes and the image they have online. These donuts aren't extravagant or worth waiting an hour in line for, there's better places around.

Oh for the love of Pete....total gimmick! LOL Give me a break. Long line waiting out the door, fun pink building, fun sign, fun decor. But honestly, I'd rather eat in a boring dive if the donuts tasted out of this world, and sadly...Voodoo does not deliver on taste. Incredibly boring taste like the donuts I can buy any time at my local Safeway bakery. The chocolate coating had that sticky cloying overly sweet and not that good flavor of grocery store donuts. Also super expensive, we paid about 13 bucks for 5 donuts.

Meh, I guess I can check this off my list of things to do in Portland. But as I drove around town I noticed a donut shop on literally almost every corner. This here city loves their donuts!!! Hahahaha, how are they so thin? Next time I visit Portland I will try one of their bazillion other donut shops.

The cashier cursed out me and my friends. When the customer before us asked him what his favorite donuts were, he said, and I quote " I don't have a favorite donut. I'm suck of donuts and I'm sick of people, I'd rather be in the back staring at dough." He called me and my friends a dumbass for not knowing the difference between a voodoo dozen and a classic dozen. Very rude but a funny unforgettable memory

Definitely worth the experience and we are now able to cross this off our bucket list!

However we were not really impressed with the taste of the donuts at all (we went there at 11pm ) so maybe we were getting near day old product. Visually they were very cool to look at and they had a very wide variety! Staff was very friendly and helpful and the line moved quickly!

Admittedly I'm not the biggest fan. But... I do like balanced, flavorful donuts. 

Voodoo IMO: They're greasy, heavy, over-hyped, sugary and not very flavorful.

I get the spectacle part of Voodoo Donuts so I may bring people from out of town here at times, but I prefer to take them during less busy hours or go to the East side location.

Bad management practices translate into bad attitudes and rude service by employees. These are mediocre donuts with odd names and hyped marketing aimed at the tourist trade and people who get a donut craving at 2 AM. Once was enough for me, never to return. The Donut Queen on SE 58th & Burnside makes better donuts for locals at half the price. And Pip's has it all over DooDoo.

Honestly, Voodoo is seriously over hyped thanks to places like Food Network. I tried two separate donuts there. The first time I went, I got the Voodoo doll donut. It tasted like a plain jelly donut with chocolate on top. It wasn't bad, but lacked any kind of special aspect to it. The second time I went, I got the Homer. It was slightly better than the first, but overall the donuts are really dense and aren't that appealing. I still recommend going because they're a big deal in Portland, but Blue Star Donuts is definitely better quality. There is also no indoor seating, so I would either go on a clear day with no rain, or take it to go.

Agh - to be honest I don't think I'd come back here.  YES - the ambiance is fun and unique and the donuts also reflect that personality.  If you want to get that pink box that everyone's carrying around - this is where you've got to go.

However I do think donuts elsewhere in portland (and other cities) are better.  So if you're here for the photos, hype and personality - that is definitely served up, and you'll have to wait in a line for it (it is fast-moving though).  We've also been to voodoo in austin - same kind of thing.  It's fun to go to the Voodoo in portland but I wouldn't recommend it if you're already been somewhere else.

There are so many donuts in portland that in order to try them all you've got to pick and choose!  Overall we liked the homer, portland cream, and the hibiscus.  We ordered 3 and they lasted 4 of us 2 mornings.

1 Star off for the staff I dealt with who seemed exasperated that I couldn't figure out what I wanted as a newcomer and  cLearly couldn't read the turntable of donuts fast enough! Smdh... The donut I got was ODB (Old Dirty Bastard) and Hibiscus Green Tea. I love chocolate BUT I really liked the HibiScus with the white and pink coloring. The ODB has Oreo drizzled with peanut butter. I ate both and liked both. I will have to compare this place with that "Blue something ..." establishment. Expect lines and lines of people and it is loud. Patience is a virtue here. Over by Mother's Bistro and Bijou Cafe.

I gave into the pressure to visit this local landmark while in Portland. The verdict? Neat, but bottom line is that the donuts were average at best.

We waited about 20 minutes on a late Thursday morning. By the time we made it inside our eyes lit up at the variety of options, such as cereal topped frosted. I decided to keep it simple and go with my fav- maple glazed. This was prepared as a "bar" instead of the traditional "O"'shape. The frosting was tasty, but the donut itself was cold and slightly dry.

The experience was pretty neat, just feeling the energy and enthusiasm of the crowds waiting to try. Unfortunately we weren't able to spend much time at the outside picnic tables as we were harassed by a homeless dude. Still happy to say I've experienced Voodoo donuts!

Voodoo Doughnut was the only disappointment I had during my three-day stay in Portland. My boyfriend and I planned the trip using Yelp reviews and responses in talk threads and, for some reason, y'all are Voodoo Doughnut fanatics!

We were in this part of town around 11 pm on a Saturday night and eagerly got in line. The wait wasn't *that* bad (maybe 30-45 minutes) and the Voodoo Doughnut crowd was even bouncing beach balls around, which made waiting in line that much more enjoyable. Once we got to the front, they were out of all the doughnuts we wanted and the ones we got (1) The one with Oreos on top, 2) the chocolate cake doughnut with Cocoa Puffs on top, 3) the custard filled one with the little moustache icing face) were absolutely mediocre! The icing was nothing special, the doughnut was not-so-moist, and the attitude from the perpetually-annoyed employee was not so pleasant either. 

I'll save myself the trip to Portland and just sit over here in Seattle eating my Mighty-O's and Top Pot doughnuts, thankyouverymuch. Hrmph. (God, I'm so bitter.)

Come on, people. If you're there for like, a gourmet donut, you've made a wrong turn. You meant to go to Blue Star or Staccato Gelato. But of course, if you need that big pink box that reminds you that "good things come in pink boxes" (well, they do), or you're drunk and need a Pepto-Bismol donut, or you want a place to get married that will make your parents really uncomfortable (they do weddings for $5,000 last I checked), then this is a  must. Otherwise, skip it. And if you must go anyway, please don't try the coffee. It appears to be--and tastes like--dirty water. 

+open late
+very fast service
+always good music
+tourist pleasing

So everyone and everyone's grandma comes here to get a WORLDS famous doughnut. 
The line is always incredible..never ending.  I stand in line thinking is it really worth it?

 As homeless man holds a sign that says, "Broke, Hungry and UNSTONED".
Poor guy. Living in Portland without weed. The irony.

  Another pan handler around the corner asking for a few bucks. I guess it is a great place to make an little extra cash from the visitors who come to Voodoo doughnut.

So once inside, it's a bit crazy. People pushing to get a closer look of the funky doughnuts.  
I'm thinking...I could make these at home. It's the name that sells them however.
 Order fast, pay and get out.  The party is over and your left standing outside with a bag full of gooey filled and sugar topped dough. How much fun was that?
 Not much. Next.

This place is a joke, and if you're not in on it, you might as well not even come in. Stop taking this place so fucking seriously. If yr gonna get a donut with froot loops on it, quit expecting gold.

Strong 2 outta 5.

Maybe this is just because I'm not the biggest fan of doughnuts, I'm more of a cake person really, but Voodoo doughnuts though hip, cute, and oh so cool wasn't anything special. Can a gimmick such as crazy names and bouncy colors really make something taste better? In my opinion no. Voodoo Doughnuts though is friggin famous. I only know because I decided to bring some home to my family back in California and transporting a dozen doughnuts from downtown to the airport caught a lot of attention. Was it the vibrant pink box? No. It was the doughnuts! Everybody on the bus, train, and in the airport asked if the things in the box were -specifically- Voodoo Doughnuts. It was astounding! I actually started to get paranoid that someone was going to try and STEAL the doughnuts from me as I was taking it en route to California! 

Anyway, this is a famous place. Go here. But, in terms of taste, nothing special. Good, but not attention-grabbing, jaw-dropping good. Just good.

So my crew tried several doughnut places around Portland and we gave a fair shot to Voodoo, thinking that people were being unfairly critical because of its popularity.

We ended up agreeing with the masses! While they have some cool flavors, at the end of the day we thought the quality of the doughnuts themselves were little better than others we've come across.
7-11 has better glazed donughts. More like the cool place to be than the right [place to be!
There is too much hype in this place. Not the best donuts but cool voodoo designs. The line is way to long so come early but even then it's long

I waited in line for an average doughnut. 

I ordered a glazed doughnut - it was okay. 

One friend ordered the bubble gum doughnut - fabulous presentation, average tasting. 

Another friend ordered a chocolate glazed - it was okay. 

I can see why people are drawn to Voodoo doughnuts, because how creative their doughnuts are. However, I would not wait in line again.

Seriously, Portlandia!!!!  Get real.  You are so hard up to be weird and novel that you forsake making even the lowly donut palatable!!!!  By Seattle standards these donuts are barely mediocre, particularly the simple, old fashion.  What's the attraction?  Boredom?  I could get better donuts from a sack in a dumpster.

Voodoo doughnuts is definitely a must-try when in Portland, unfortunately there is often a wait time that takes 30 minutes or more especially during the weekends. If you're looking for interesting and unique doughnut shapes and flavors, this is the place for you; but there are certainly other amazing doughnut places scattered around Portland. The sheer selection can be a little overwhelming, but there's always something for everyone. I personally gravitate towards the fruitier flavors, and have never been disappointed by Grapve Ave, Mango Tango, Raspberry Romeo, or The Vice. However if you're there for a one-time deal, I would recommend trying their specialties like the Voodoo Doll or Maple blazer blunt. 

At the end of the day they are amazing doughnuts but the wait times often makes me question the worth of it all; as there are many other doughnut places. However if you go close enough to closing you can always pick up a bucket of doughnuts to bring back for your all your friends and family to enjoy

Fun Portland tourist experience! Lines are long, but move quickly. The names and shapes for the doughnuts are  clever. To be honest, we found the actual doughnuts to be just so-so, kind of dry and overly sweet. But we'd heard lots about Voodoo Doughnut and it was cool to check it out while we were in Portland.

Maple bacon bar will always be my favorite. I've gone to Voodoo for years and loved it. Still like them, but I can NOT constitute standing in line for an hour sometimes for a doughnut that isn't fresh. I'll be damned though if  they are somewhere I am and I don't hammer down on a Maple Bacon Bar.

Overall, wasn't impressed. Just a donut shop with cool toppings, with a funky atmosphere. The line was long, took forever, so I was expecting to be blown away, but honestly, I could get the same thing at my local grocery store. Prices are pretty reasonable too, a little higher than the grocery store but not too bad, and donuts come in a cute pink box.
Tourist trap with gimmicky sugar-bomb donuts. If you actually want a good donut, I'd recommend Blue Star instead.

A doughnut is a doughnut. If this place has anything, it was good timing. Someone recognized it as being unique, they got put on some traveling food shows, and now everyone who visits Portland wants to come here and pay for an overpriced doughnut in the shape of a penis. Over $16 for seven doughnuts, rip off. I've lived in Portland 18 years and come back every once in a while and I've only eaten here once. Not to mention, the "keep Portland weird" people working there, who probably aren't even from here, have a shitstink attitude. Dude, you put doughnuts in a pink box for a living, chill out..

If there's one thing that Portland and Voodoo Doughnut have in common it's that both their reputations exceed them. Rather than being known for its confectionary quality it is more known for its peculiarity. Nevertheless, these donuts will impress one way or another, so make sure you stop by. 

The establishment is located on the outskirts of the city with the homeless and peripatetics walking every which way. These unbecoming factors create an unwanted discomfit. The inside however is another story. The walls are covered in miscellaneous knick-knacks with two carousal display cases that feature their renowned confections. One of the sales associates was just as much a novelty as the bizarre things inside if not more so. 

Our sales associate was, quite frankly, a dick. He corralled us through the line with a persistent "NEXT"! His eye rolls and uncouth behavior tainted our visit most of all. Thank goodness the donuts left us on a high note with their generous size and comforting taste.

It's been a couple years since my last visit and a group of friends wanted to go. We went at 10 pm on a Friday and didn't have to wait very long in line, which was nice. My pick was the worst, a maple old-fashioned. It was dry. I was surprised that the fritter and cocknballs were pretty good. The crumb had a good texture but were overly sweet. Moral of the story: skip the cake donuts!
Long lines. Bad donuts. All hype.

The wait in line and the getting screamed at by a vagrant (because I wouldn't let my young daughter give her all her money) didn't make the donuts worth it. I can raise compassionate children without raising compassionate suckers.

But anyway: the donuts were enormous, I'll give them that, but they were pretty standard-issue. Most definitely not worth the almost $30.00, but it's close to bars and drunk people aren't exactly discerning.

The person that helped up at the counter was an absolute cranky beast--she shoved the box across the counter to us to let us know she was done with us.

One star because I didn't get food poisoning, and one star for the shop staff lady not spitting on our donuts before she shoved them to us.

You wait in line (a long long time!) for terribly overrated and underwhelming donuts. Do yourself a favor and go to Blue Star or Pips, much yummier and quite honestly, better atmosphere and service. 

We came to be touristy and see what the fuss was about, but it's just a simple marketing advantage over the other various (and better) donut shops around the Portland area. 

One plus side, the Homer donut looks really adorable.

After hearing about Voodoo donuts for several years now, we were excited to try it out. To be honest we were pretty disappointed.  Maybe when they started,  specialty donuts were not common so they stood out, but now there are tons of donut shops that have more creative and better tasting donuts. We got the Portland Cream, Voodoo Bubble and the maple bacon.  None were any different from similar donuts found at other shops. Nothing worth waiting in line to get. Plus $3 for a half pint of milk was pretty ridiculous.
Over-priced and wayyyyy over-hyped. The only reason to come here is to gawk at the poor tourists falling over themselves buying these mediocre to bad doughnuts who don't know any better. Suckers!!

Super long lines for perfectly average grocery style donuts that have been topped and sprinkled by overly sweet cereal toppings. Super colorful sugar bombs make them #foodporn and #tourist trap hashtag worthy. One and done.

trendy? check.
overpriced? check
Portland hipster attitude? check
overtly sexual shock value? check
mediocre doughnuts? check

1 star

Good doughnuts but long lines and high prices. The voodoo doll was cute and a good doughnut cake but the jam was too sweet and made the pretzel was soggy. The PB&Oreo was good tho. Coffee was gas station quality at best. Overall a cool place to see but a bit of a tourist trap

Honestly, it just is what it is. They've created a huge business with their edgy quirk and borderline abusive customer service. Its a perfect spot for masochists. The donuts are pretty good. The vegan donuts are REALLY good. Is it deserving of the hype or waiting in long ass lines to get treated like annoying dirt? No.
I can certainly understand the fun with the novelties around these dougnuts.  But when you get down to it, they tasted just OK.  I think of this place as an amped up Dunkin' Donuts.

Ok, we were walking by and believe it or not there was no line. I know usually it is not uncommon for people to stand in line for an hour or more. I think people do it because, we'll I'm not sure why anyone would spend that much time of their life and vacation for a doughnut. I guess if you see people doing it and everyone says "dude you have to get voodoo doughnuts, well I guess it's a peer pressure thing. But I'll tell you, when you finally get called to the counter and you get your doughnuts, well, all you'll have is doughnuts. There not bad doughnuts, but definitely not amazing oh my god doughnuts. So my three stars ratios more of a commentary on all the hype. So my recommendation is, if you're walking by, and there is no line, sure go get a doughnut, take a pic, so you can say you did it. But if there's an hour line, take a pic of all them fools and just move on. You really didn't miss anything, and you saved an hour of your lie you otherwise would never get back.

Better than we remember. #IsItRememberOrRemembered? #GoodThingsComeInPinkBoxes #PDX #DonutExtravaganzaWeekend #PacificNorthWest
*
*
#VoodooDoll vs. #GrapeApe (Grape Kool Aid)() Shop 6 - Voodoo Doughnut in Portland, OR
*
*
#DonutShopSix #52DonutChallenge #WeJustDonutGiveADamn #DontWorryEatDonuts #GringoAndAChina #Donuts #Doughnuts @DavidJohnSouza

I am deeply disappointed in this place. It was recommended for my family to come here. We found the doughnuts less than amazing. More importantly, the 3 punks serving at the counter were rude and pushy and even yelled at our family to "close the door" when we were assisting someone trying to get in. My two kids were shamed and embarrassed in front of all the other customers. Unfortunately, it was after they got our money and we got some pretty poor eats. I will always remember this place for their disgusting customer service!

Overpriced and overhyped.   Another tourist trap.  We will stick to our mom and pop shops back home where dozen still costs $7.  Neighboorhood seedy to so if you go watch your back.  Be safe get a dozen at fred meyer if you really need a sugar fix

The hype is was overrated here. I see no difference in taste from Dunkin Donuts or some of the other donut shops in the Northeast. Locals who worked at my hotel literally rolled their eyes at me when I walked in carrying the big, pink box.

I have to give Voodoo credit for creating a brand and also getting creative with their donuts. A decade ago when they opened (before the 'foodie revolution' which brought pho, cronuts and street tacos to every suburban town in America) they were cutting edge. Nobody was putting Captain Crunch cereal or bacon on donuts. To do so was literally like the invention of smartphones ... unheard of by anyone, but loved by all.

Over the years they have stayed in the news by having the FDA stop them from making donuts with a shot of Nyquil or pepto bismo in the center, etc. Naming donuts The Old Dirty Bastard or Marshal Mathers has given them hipster street cred. But honestly, they didn't taste any different from donuts you could get at Wegmans or Dunkin. Maybe a bit more 'sugar bling' ...

My favorite of all was the maple bacon log. I also tried the original voodoo which beyond the cute doll shape was pretty much a standard Boston Cream donut shell with jelly inside. Nothing special beyond the likes it will get on instagram. The Memphis Mafia fritter was way too dense. After a few bites, I was over-sugared and full. Way too much going on here ... maybe it would have been better with a glass of milk.

They were out of the cake donuts when I went, around midnight, probably because they were the cheapest donuts at about a buck each. The other donuts were around $3 and the fritters like ODB, Memphis Mafia and Marshall Mathers, were $5 which was a complete rip off.

The line was about 10 minutes long. I was drunk and didn't mind waiting as the people watching was good. (its right next to two dance clubs) However, they don't really need the line ... it's just that they have 2 people working the counter (slowly) so I think the line pretty much just adds to the 'mystique' of the place. "If people are willing to wait outside for 10 minutes, this must be legit!'

Glad I tried it. It didn't suck. But it wasn't really anything all that special. Maybe it would have been 5 stars in 2003 when it was impossible to find creative donuts anywhere. Oh yeah ... cash only. At least that hasn't changed since 2003.

They had some pretty unique combinations, however for me the taste wasn't there.  I found it to be more of an experience than anything.

This location was in a pretty trashy area of town, long lines, and would not visit again.

Maple             B+
Voodoo Doll   C
Grape Ape     D (this was the most unique, but not good)
Snickers         C (sugar bomb)

Cash only donut shop that has delicious designer / gourmet donuts. I recommend coming at night or during off hours. Just be prepared to walk by or around 9 to 12 homeless pan handlers. One pan handler even came into the shop, asking customers for cash. The staff said nothing, did nothing and acted like nothing happened. Must happen a lot. The least they could do is hire a security guard with all the extra, unreported cash they're making... but no. What a joke.

We got the voodoo donut here and honestly can't see why this place was so popular.

It was basically a chocolate covered donut with like a raspberry jelly inside and I thought it wasn't all that good. It didn't even taste all that fresh and more like that it had been sitting around for a long time.

It was cute though with the pretzel stick in it but that's pretty much where all the coolness ended.
If you like waiting in a really long line with rude hipsters for stale donuts with inappropriate toppings at twice the cost of other donuts, then this is the place for you!

I am a fan of Doughnuts. Knowing that Voodoo is highly popular on TV, online, in magazines, etc- I knew that when I was in Portland I needed to try it. I was pretty excited, but it didn't really blow me away. The variety of doughnuts is large, which is nice, but the doughnuts themselves are pretty average. I ordered the voodoo doll and the mango. Both delicious, but still tasted like an average doughnut. I come from a big foodie city and these just didn't really "wow" me. 

I think the long line was due to the popularity of it and most people were tourists in the city. (We spoke to a good amount of people in our half hour of waiting) This is a cash only place. There are signs EVERYWHERE that say that. Please don't be the guy who can't read and is confused on why they can't take a card (*ahem*...guy in front me in line) I had to wait longer because he had to run to the ATM. 

I'd recommend it if you are in the area, touring, and feel the need to hit up a "famous spot" but I wouldn't go too terribly out of your way.

A bit overrated.  We went around 10am on a Saturday morning and there was hardly a line.  Got up and ordered the Oreo covered doughnut but it was stale.  All the Oreos tasted really old as I'm sure they make them in batches and leave them out.  Also, stumptown is just down the road so you could get a doughnut and have a coffee. 

Ended up walking by the place again later in the afternoon and the line was super long.  Not with it in my opinion.

Over rated. They have a few interesting items, but by and large it's pretty gimmicky.

If you enjoy standing in line for medicore donuts this is the place.
Really good donuts, but not a fan of the long lines.

Sorry, you did not wow me. BUT, I did check one off my bucket list. So therefore, you still win Voodoo. 

I'm sure wherever and however you heard, Voodoo Doughnuts is a must in Portland. Tsk tsk if you don't make time for it. Anyways, love the 24/7!!!! Comes in handy when you want a midnight snack.

Whatever angle you wish to take a picture, the essence of Voodoo will be there. The place is weird, but so is Portland. I guess Voodoo Doughnuts and Portland are meant to be.

I had the Homer Simpson's Doughnut.
He had the Voodoo Doll Doughnut. 

Like what I first said, I wasn't wow'ed. Too sweet and doughnut was slightly too dense for me. I'll have a few bites, but probably can't finish the whole. I'll probably go again.... because I like taking pictures. Pictures of their quirky doughnuts.
TOURIST TRAP! Go to the kit kat club next door and save yourself an hour wait.

This place is just meh!
its just a tourist spot...in regards to the doughnut, its not that great...its not fresh, and has been sitting on the trays all day...prices are cheap, but the taste is not good...its just a regular doughnut from the supermarket with fancy toppings.

theres always a line here, but i'd skip. 
Dunkin donuts is wayyyyyy bettterrrr!!!!!!!

I was compelled to visit Voodoo during our spring break trip to Portland last week, simply because I'd read so much about it on Yelp and other sites (the place gets lots of publicity; it was even on the Travel Channel!).  I have to say it's not for everyone.  I think the doughnuts are more for shock value than taste, because we tried several, and they were just mediocre.  I had triple chocolate penetration, and it was OK, but it definitely wasn't the freshest doughnut (could be because of the time of day we were there - late afternoon).  We also tried the infamous jelly-filled voodoo doughnut, my son and friend tried the maple bacon, and we tried various others that I can't remember.  I wouldn't call it a scuzzy place like the last reviewer; it's just more for the Portland counter culture (the gal working at the time we went had multiple piercings on her lips/mouth alone).  We were staying at the Embassy Suites across the street, and several nights in a row, I looked out the window around midnight to see a line of people at Voodoo, so that's definitely a popular time to go.

Came to Voodoo Donuts earlier this morning. There was a long line on a Sunday morning but it went by fast. We were greeted by stinky homeless poop while we were waiting in line. It was pretty gross and kinda ruined my appetite.

We ordered No Name, Butterfinger, Captain Crunch, and Voodoo Donuts. It was alright. I wasn't too amazing or memorable. This was just a to do list that was part of our itinerary. 

Overall, the wait was definitely not worth it as the donuts were just alright.
This place is so ridiculously overrated. Their donuts aren't that great they're just silly and got too popular for their flavors. Nothing special.

The best thing about Voodoo Doughnuts is their name.  In fact, their marketing is probably the only reason it is so popular.

After you wait in line for (at least) a half hour, you are greeted with a spinning case of donuts. There is a menu on the wall, but without descriptions you have no idea what anything is (what the hell is an Old Dirty Bastard doughnut?) Since we had no idea, we ordered a dozen. Even that was a problem, because if  you choose what you want in the dozen they charge extra, so we allowed them to pick.  

All the donuts were incredibly dry with the exception of one that was completely undercooked and doughy. 10 out of the 12 donuts were just a dry plain doughnut with white frosting and some cereal on top. Everything looked sloppy, and I was very underwhelmed with the "creativity." Krispy Kreme may not have stale crap on top of their donuts, but they're too busy making their base product good.

Voodoo needs to take example from the best doughnut place I've ever encountered: Fractured Prune in Maryland.  They have a terrible name (which is probably why they haven't done as well), but they serve made to order, warm donuts with actually creative and delicious toppings.

THERE IS SOME VOODOO MAGIC GOING ON AT VOODOO DOUGHNUTS... 

They really aren't that great, lines are always long, and the donuts are expensive. There is someone out there placing spells on everyone that visits Portland that makes us visit VooDoo Doughnuts -- we just don't want to believe it.

They do offer quirky donut designs, and unique flavors, but they may be overdoing it a bit. It's like when I go to to FroYo Shop, and majority of my FroYo is toppings vs actual FroYo. And what is up with all this blow-me, cock-n-ball, penis shaped donuts? It's like I am in a porn shop for donuts.

The service is a little lacking as well. The people behind the counter seemed bored and uninterested. I don't know if that's how people are in Portland (not my first occurrence), but for such a touristy spot... they should at least try to care. Be happy, and sell us donuts with pride! lol

The donuts are not terrible, but I don't think they are necessarily worth the 30+ minute wait and price. We have our own specialty donut place in San Diego called Donut Bar, and although they do not have voodoo and penis designs (thank goodness!), they do have unique flavors and designs as well. I think our donut joint taste better, is safe for all ages and we don't believe in all that voodoo magic stuff. lol.

TIPS
-- They are open 24/7, so don't stop by during the rush hour
-- Cash only. There are nearby ATMs.
-- If you buy any cereal donuts, don't wait too long before you eat it because they will get stale.
-- I read on someone else's Yelp that they offer a bucket of "Day Old Donuts" for $10. I may look into that if I ever stop by Voodoo Doughnuts again. I just hope they are all family-friendly items. I can't imagine bringing home a bucket of donut shaped wieners. lol.

I am going to say right from the start...the love and obsession with Voodoo Doughnuts is lost on me. And don't get me wrong...I love doughnuts. I've eaten a lot of them over the years, as my waistline will attest. I've also eaten them in multiple states and in multiple countries. But...I am a Portlander...born and raised. Alas I never discovered Voodoo when it was a little, small bakery. I found it after the behemoth it has become today. Maybe, as some have attested, it was a great shop back in the day. I can only judge it by the experience I had now.

I come from doughnut loving parents. I, for a time, lived next to a donut shop owned by a little old lady from Guam. It was a little hole in the wall, but her donut bakery made some amazing old school donuts. He would allow me to pop in just after he filled the case and grab a few. Oh those maple bars, old fashioned...the list goes on. Yummy. They were so good they even survived a Krispy Kreme opening literally across the street. 

One night my parents and I decided to venture downtown, late, and try Voodoo. The line wasn't too bad...and we ordered up a pink box filled with a dozen of the various kinds they had so we could sample all the creatively topped treats. The first thing that burned in my memory of my first experience there...the staff were less than friendly. Now perhaps this is part of the whole "punk" vibe the place goes for...but honestly...there is no place for unfriendly or poor customer service E V E R in a public facing business. This attitude extended to even the person's placement of our donuts in the box. Normally one carefully arranged and places the donuts so they don't get mashed or messed up. You'd think this would be even more so important for a place known for his toppings. Well our donuts were basically just tossed in the box....so much so they were a damn mess when we got them home. And no, I was careful with the box...they are donuts, its sacrilege not to be. ;-)

Once home we went into sampling what we got. Now, like most situations, when something is great it can overshadow waiting or poor service or many things. But when you venture through all that and the end result makes you go "WTF?" It really makes the whole thing sink. First, I have to say...before you go all nuts on your toppings, designs, etc....you have to have a solid foundation...in this case a solid donut. To me Voodoo fails at this necessary principle. The donuts themselves were old and stale. Like we were subjected to day or two old donuts. No amount of toppings were going to change that. Out of 12 offerings I cannot tell you a single one that was memorable. Not 1. And everyone involved in this adventure felt the exact same way. The toppings should be enhancing an already great donut. Yet in this case, it seems it's all novelty and no substance. In some ways it felt like the toppings were masking a lousy donut. 

Fortunately I discovered a true gem of the area long after my unpleasant experience at Voodoo. A true NW hole in the wall donut shop in Vancouver called Donut Nook. The place looks like you have time travelled when you walk in...but it's funky and inviting. The staff warm and friendly. And the donuts? Well that's the best part. While you won't get Captain Crunch mashed on them or one shaped like a penis with cough syrup drenched on top....you will get some fresh...amazingly flavor-filled donuts here. Ones we easily go back to and talk about all the time.

Skip the line...there are much better donuts to be had than Voodoo.

This place is a tourist trap that sells gross, often stale, donuts with dumb gimmicks like covering them in cereal or making them shaped like genitalia. If all you care about is having a cooky looking donut regardless of how it tastes then I guess this is the place for you. Otherwise you're better off going to any other donut shop or even some supermarket bakeries.

A sweet pitstop in Downtown Portland.  No more, no less.

We reached Voodoo's pretty early in the morning as a pre-game for an early hike.  It was a short wait, and we had the added benefit of seeing the city of Portland awake before our eyes (complete with a street resident emerging from a tipped newspaper dispenser).  When we stepped inside, we were impressed by the multi-colored decorations about the store and the trays upon trays of donuts behind the counter.  It is definitely a festive environment.

One thing that I can really vouch for Voodoo is the variety of donuts.  Each type of donut looks completely different from one another, so when you choose, there's a feeling that you could be missing out on a potentially tasty gold mine.  We ended up going for the voodoo dozen, (a cheaper alternative to selecting a dozen yourself), and set out on our day.  

Now here's the kicker: while it was fun to pick from the box throughout the day, I can't say there was a time when we would rave about Voodoo after eating a donut.  They taste like what they look like: donuts with some added pizzazz.  Their components taste great on their own.  Together? Enjoyable...but not life-changing.

The Voodoo experience is much like the food they are selling.  It's fun, decadent, and over fairly quickly.  There are more memorable places to eat in Portland.

Essentially an overrated tourist attraction. Famous for being one of the first hip, independent donut shops and for their wacky decor and donuts. The reality is long lines and mediocre  donuts. Perhaps they should focus more on quality and less on novelty. Though there's likely no incentive given they're always busy and have more than 5,500 reviews! 

With so many amazing food options in Portland, don't waste your time on Voodoo!

Bad customer service. For someone coming here for the first time and not knowing much about the type of donuts they have. I expected the lady behind the desk to be understanding and have patient. She snapped, yelled and   Made me felt embarrassed. I felt so bad that I had to call the manager on getting back to my hotel. I honestly do not feel the donut is all that. I mean with that kind of bad customer service. I will never go back there next time I'm in Portland. Was there today Sunday 20, 2019. At around 8am.

The hype is hype. Rude employees, okay tasting doughnuts, long line, grungy store. 

Let's start with the line: wrapped around the outside of the building on the sidewalk, builds expectations for something good and worth waiting for. 

The store: grungy and unclean, flies IN the display case, and most of the doughnuts were sitting uncovered in racks anyway. The store is dusty and dirty and I know they are trying to build an atmosphere, but come on, the GROUND  and walls don't need piles of dirt and grime. I know this store makes bank, but they obviously aren't investing it back into the upkeep of the store. 

Finally make it up to the counter, the employee was super impatient, while I struggled to identify which doughnuts matched in the display case to the menu board (the display case is unlabeled). After ringing me up with an air of distain, he went and THREW my doughnuts down in the box! Like, slammed them in!!! I kinda just looked at him like 'really'? And asked him if he had had a long night. He answered "no more like long life". And I took my doughnuts and left in satisfied with the service. 

Now. To the taste. First doughnut was the Butterfingers. Dry. Pretty oily and tasteless. Gross. The peanutbutter drizzled Oreo was pretty good, as was the maple bacon. 

I like the variety and creativity of the doughnuts so that, and the taste of those two doughnuts are why this has place earns 2 stars.

Voodoo Doughnut is a Portland classic for tourists, however their donuts are insanely overhyped for what it is. We passed by the store in the late afternoon, but gave up after seeing the lineup around the block. We returned close to midnight to a more reasonable line, and got served relatively quickly. Our group went for their dozen box (you don't get to choose the flavors) to try, however I couldn't get past the 5th bite. Each donut was covered with an insane amount of sugar, and some tasted a bit stale (likely from sitting into the night). Most of the flavors were too weak to taste, just completely overwhelmed by the sweetness. Please save yourselves some time and money, and skip this tourist trap.

Outside of this being a creative idea with fun and unusual doughnut designs and doughnut names, the long lines, funky, yet touristy atmosphere, and expensive, dry doughnuts are really much more hyped up than they deserve to be. I'd say find a little corner doughnut shop down the street and give them some business instead.

Came here because, well, I guess that's what tourists do in Portland.  It was raining, so the line was only about 30 minutes long (wrapped around twice).  Prices are good, and the donuts are average.  Got the maple bacon one, which tastes pretty much like any maple bacon I've had here in S. CA - bacon was nice and crisp here.  Also got the one with Rice Krispies - like other reviewers said, the Rice Krispies were soggy.  Not sure if it was bc they were stale or bc of the chocolate they were sprinkled on, but either way, it was no bueno.  Also got the bear claw with peanut butter and chocolate chips - this was huge - flavor was okay.  Finally, got a regular blueberry cake donut for $1 - this one was pretty good but also standard.  The four donuts I had came out to $10.  No need to go back.

3.5-4! I've heard meh things about Voodoo, so I wasn't that excited. However, still have to try out this iconic spot!

Pro tip 1: the "Keep Portland Weird" mural is right across the street from here!
Pro tip 2: CASH ONLY! 
Pro tip 3: Benches right outside that you can sit at! However, the area is borderline Chinatown which isn't too safe if you stay late. 

Allen and I went with the classics:
1) Chocolate frosting raised donut ($1.05) // Oh wow! I give this a 5/5.
+1 I was impressed by how yeasty this was. You take a bite, and you see it bounce back!
+1 Chocolate on here is really good! It's not your typical milk chocolate (80% sugar) and actually tastes like good quality chocolate.
+1 Pretty good for the price and size!

2) Voodoo doll ($3) // MEHHHH 3.25!
-1 A bit too dry...
+1 Cute shape but not really functional to eat.
-1 The jelly inside was mehhhh. 

Quick service, lots of options, definitely a more Sunday-morning-in-sweatpants type of place. Would recommend trying their other crazy donuts!

Not worth waiting for. The doughnuts are just above average, and they're a bit TOO odd for my taste. The lines are tremendous in a kind of dirty/bad part of town, surrounded by strip clubs and dirt. I'd definitely say get them when you can, but don't go yourself.

Okay I'll admit I did the touristy thing and stood in line 30 minutes for a "WEIRD" donut, it was late and we needed munchies.... That being said the donuts are just donuts nothing special other then there funky shapes and flavor combos, and I do not believe my wait in line was justified, but hey if your into voodoo doll shaped donuts and donut chapel weddings you've found your spot.Me on the other hand will stick to catching the food truck location down the street if the urge for a bacon maple donut hits me,LINE FREE :)

Greasy tourist gut bomb.  Literally that sums it up.
Sure you can wait in line but wait for the last day of your visit, as there are no locals going here, because your going to have some GI tract issues later.
Sure there are some cutesy donuts but it's all gimmick.   No one goes here to just get a good donut to eat with coffee.
Cool place, but their donuts are a little kitschy.

I honestly felt like voodoo was super overrated after hearing all the hype and standing in line for far too long. We bought three donuts and one of them was good----the grape flavor, strangely enough. If youre looking for a great donut, head towards blue star.

Hype. hype. hype. Honestly, it's just a regular donut with candy/cereal/syrup on top. There's no unique flavors and no creative twists other than the names of the donuts. BUT, if you MUST get something, the maple bacon and the voodoo are the way to go. The line is absurdly long for what it is but at least there were some Portland homeless musicians to entertain us.

Fun unique experience, do I need to go again? No - reason being if you typically don't indulge in raised doughnuts, this is Voodoo's speciality. I'm more of an old fashioned doughnut gal myself.
Lots of variety with crazy combinations. I'm not sure how many doughnuts you need to buy to get the coveted pink box, but it seemed like most people leaving the store were proudly touting the pink box. I appreciate that this place is as organized at it is, with efficient line control - as there were a lot of people were anxious for the prized doughnuts. There is seating outside, unfortunately it is in a bit of a rough neighborhood, and some of the homeless are a bit aggressive in this neighborhood, which put a damper on the experience.

Visited this place when we were strolling through Portland and saw a long queue standing outside the shop. The line moves quickly. There is a large variety of donuts available to try, and could get overwhelming. We tried couple of old fashioned glazed donuts, shaved coconut and dark chocolate. The donuts were fresh and delicate. I liked glazed donuts the best. Toasted coconut was a bit too dry for me. Overall a descent experience. I would not say a must try for any Portland tourist and succumb to the hype, but if you have the time you can stop by and grab a quick bite late at night.

They have very unique donuts but I wouldn't say they're all very good. Most of the time they are stale because of how long they've been sitting there. Not sure how often they rotate them and dispose of them. For example, the donut with the maple bacon on top, dry, cold and stale. The place is very small and it can get very busy. Long lines but they usually go by quickly. Nowadays, there are other shops that serve better donuts. It is cool that they're open 24/7. Keep in mind, they only accept cash, there is an ATM inside.

My boyfriend and I patiently waited in a ridiculous line for 30 minutes at about 1:45 PM on a Friday afternoon because apparently you MUST GET Voodoo Donuts when in Oregon. I carefully decided which ones to get: the original voodoo doll, the giant phallic-looking one, old dirty bag, and a Portland cream. Since I was saving the donuts for later consumption, I regrettably didn't look inside the gaudy pink box. The lady who took my order only gave me 2 of the ones I asked for. I didn't even receive the voodoo doll which is the one I wanted most. ): She even charged me for it. I asked for 4 different donuts, but was charged for 3, and she totally didn't even give me one of the donuts she charge me for..

Sorry, Portland. Too hype for me.

I think voodoo donuts is a little overhyped. Donuts are overpriced and way too sweet. I ordered the bacon maple bar which is one of their specialties and was underwhelmed. I definitely recommend Blue Star donuts where the flavors are much more unique and tastes a lot better.

Admittedly I walked here in the rain, but when I opened the door I got a face full of humid oily air. The line wasn't too bad, and I love the turning display cases which make it easy to see what's available.

$1.05 for a cake chocolate glazed was east coast pricing. The donut was good - but deeply fried. Frosting was dark not milk chocolate which I like. Sweet but not cloying.

The kitsch of the place is a bit much. Blaring classic rock is fine by me. Big pink boxes stacked up, not a problem. Crowds in a small space can't be helped. All together, it doesn't add up to the vest experience though - especially since the displays and floors don't look spotlessly clean.

Still my donut was good. Not sure why the hype is so intense, though.

You remind me of a man. 
What man?
A man with a power. 
What power?
The power of voodoo. 
Who do?
You do. 
Do what?
Remind me of a man...

That's the most interesting thing about voodoo donuts, in my opinion: a really old ditty that has nothing to do with fried dough. I came here because everyone was all, "Voodoo donuts! Gotta go!" and whilest standing in line looking at the 90's-ish photo of donuts on the outside wall, I realized nothing looked truly appealing. That's impressive, actually, for me to think such sacrilegious thoughts. 

 The enormous line moved quickly enough, and I have to hand it to the waitstaff: they were generously good humored and kind, which I would not have been if I were in their shoes. I ordered the vicious hibiscus; my friend got one with bubble gum on it, and my other friend got an old fashioned with chocolate. 

I will say: I liked the taste of the dough itself much better than I expected. The bubble gum one tasted like a peep on a donut, which was better than it looked. The old fashioned dipped in fudge was nauseatingly sweet and just NO. Don't do it. Homeless men hovered and told us our donuts looked good, and I wish I would have just given ours to them. I felt full, and a little sick, for several hours after that. 

Save your money for Blue Star, IMHO.
Too much sugar. I prefer gluten-free, stevia dognuts.

My friend traveled from Colorado Springs to try their vegan donuts. She wanted to make sure several times before leaving the shop up make sure her donuts were vegan, to get home to find bacon maple donuts all the way at the bottom of her box. She's now sick. I can't believe the carelessness in this matter, especially if this was an allergy or religious situation. The fact that she reiterated how important it was to get vegan donuts and to find them all the way at the bottom sounds fishy to me.

Oh VooDoo Donuts, It's a love hate relationship. (Not talking about the calories). They have three shops, I have been to all three. They are all very aesthetically cute. VooDoo Donuts Supports many charities and organizations including many local events, which I truly appreciate in a company. Many of the donuts I do enjoy including; Bacon maple bar, Maple Blazer Blunt (not a stoner) & there Memphis Mafia. 
However I find many of the donuts to be extremely sickly sweet, mainly the fruit and cereal inspired ones. I love the idea of Kelly Jelly's and vegan donuts but I cannot give them high reviews. Also I feel there Is some serious wasted potential in the creativity process of inventing donuts. Last bit about the donuts specifically, there not of very good quality no more better than the grocery store brand which is a bit disappointing. 
As for the rest of the review, I cannot deny that I have multiple times had very bad customer service. Some of the employees there are very nice however I have been shown rudeness more times than not. And the girl that  just transferred from eugene I find to be unbearable, Out of respect I will not mention her name however it is completely inappropriate to call your customers stupid. 
Lastly I will say it is lip-service Marketing for tourist, but if your a local and support the "keep Portland weird" culture, I would say go here as I do.
lines very long , nothing extremely outstanding about donuts except large selection noted

Voodoo Doughnuts are decent. They are cute - different -- interesting flavors - shapes and names. They have gotten a lot of press coverage and gained in popularity.  I understand why so many people like them or want to try them.
I have been several times...and always have the same meh --they are ok feeling ---- plus the line is ridiculous---so, if you stand in line for 40 mins to have an ok doughnut -it's not really worth it to me. 
However, when people come to visit and want to go to Voodoo, I always take them for their doughnut.
Not sure what the fuss is about really.  The donuts are not bad but nothing super special.  I guess it is a thing to do in Portland

Voodoo seems way overrated, and it is not worth the wait. If I wanted a doughnut in Portland, I would go to Blue Star.

I would only suggest going here if you feel like you would miss out on part of the Portland experience without visiting. Or, if you are really, really craving sugar.

The doughnuts aren't special.  The owners were creative enough to come up with the multimillion dollar name and theme.  Sheer genius as far as the original creativity goes.  But the doughnuts are doughy, very sweet, and not worth the hype.  A good doughnut dough is refrigerated overnight before made into doughnuts for yeast flavor development.  Their cooked doughnut is one dimensional in flavor.  The fillings in the filled doughnuts taste like the premade stuff from the Sysco, Cash & Carry, or the Decorette Shop.  The Cocoa Puffs on that doughnut were stale.  Tourist trap extraordinaire.  And it works.  Kudos for that.

There are way better doughnuts in Portland, go to Pips or Blue Star and save yourself a rough experience. The doughnuts aren't anything special and are often stale, the draw is the weird toppings and not the actual doughnut.

This location is in the WORST part of town and there is always sketch shenanigans happening outside. My most recent visit included a man throwing literal salad out of a bag while screaming at no one. I realize this isn't necessarily the fault of the business but I definitely think the voodoo tourism contributes to the area.

Also, just a side note but the cash only policy is beyond outdated. Any business of this scale that doesn't take card in 2019 doesn't deserve business.
Not the greatest donuts in the world but definitely a tourist spot. Fun donuts sometimes long wait times and cash only !!!  When in Portland try a voodoo doll.

The line definitely makes this location a little disappointing. It seems to not steadily move along. I enjoyed the donuts themselves and am glad to have them near home. 

I think my biggest problem is the location, and donuts end up costing $$$, parking included. 

I would certainly not ever turn down a Voodoo Doughnut, I just never visit this location
Long lines (always), lots of hype, mediocre donuts.  They are just donuts and don't deserve a wait.

Look I know this is like a Portland institution at this point but if you're not drunk late at night, you'll usually notice the slightly stale, dry texture of most of the donuts.  It's got the whole hipster vibe going on but honestly there are many more quality donuts in the city.  Also, cash only?  Really?  Even food carts take cards at this point.
Many times I've bought donuts from here was for hype. Many times I tried to give the benefit of the doubt and still do not like it. Donuts taste stale or overly sweet. Just did it for the gram tbh

Voodoo Doughnut serves unique picturesque donuts. Many people have raved about their donuts but I think Voodoo's reputation exceeds expectations. Some donuts are better than others but most have a heavy oily taste and were exceedingly sweet. Maybe I don't like this type of donuts. 

I've heard about Voodoo donuts for years but didn't get a chance to visit last time I visited Portland. So when we were in town, our out-of-town friend suggested to try this place. Why not?

This location is open 24 hours. We waited in line for 30 minutes. The smell was heavenly (oil, fried bread) at 09:30. The line was filled with locals and tourists. My friend and I were super excited! So many flavors! They offer a coffin filled with donuts for $130. My friend joked about wanting to go out in a coffin full of donuts.

So we ordered: maple bacon donut, lemon chiffon crueller, captain my captain (captain crunch donut), hibiscus donut, the summer dream (marionberry filling with lemon frosting). 
The best donut was the the maple bacon donut. The bacon was savory smoked and crispy. Unfortunately, the frosting didn't gel with the bacon. 

The summer dream wasn't bad and I liked the sound of the marionberry filling. The filling was ok but the frosting but a little too sweet for me, it tasted like a fondant. The best texture was the lemon chiffon crueller. It was a crispy and cakey but the marshmallows were unnecessary. 

The service was curt and quick. Like NYC. So all in all, Voodoo Doughnut was fun to look, take pictures but the donuts were a little disappointing.

I was disappointed, these are not good donuts--I'm really puzzled why these are so popular. They taste like grocery store donuts that have been jazzed up with extra toppings. It's definitely not worth the 30 minute wait. After trying several other PDX donut joints, I found Voodoo to be the worst. I won't be back.

I've been here a couple of times and frankly, I just don't understand.  Everyone told me I had to try it.  "Voodoo is amazing!"  "Magical!"  "Best thing that's ever entered my mouth!"

So I did.  Waited in line for 40 minutes.  And guess what!  It was just a goddamn doughnut.

Does this diminish my Portland cred?  I mean... they're doughnuts.  Some have bacon.  Some have zombie faces.  Some are topped with stale breakfast cereal.  Some have funny names based on rappers.  But essentially, we're just talking about doughnuts, right?  You wouldn't wait in line for 40 minutes for a lump of sugary dough at Heavenly or Dunkin'.  Or for a box of cereal at Safeway.  So why are you waiting in a line that stretches around the corner for a chocolate doughnut topped with Captain Crunch, served by a kid who hates you and hopes you choke?  

Are you all stoned?

Would I wait an hour for one? No.
Did I once? Yes.

They make all kinds of tasty donuts. The Maple Bacon bar... well it's got bacon so yeah, it's awesome.

Apparently there's another location that is never as busy. I hear the trick is drive by this one, if there's a line, move on. 

Oh and they only take cash (minus 2 stars). That's retarded, and lame, and the only reason is it makes it easy to report less sales than actual. So also shady.

Because of the popularity of Voodoo Doughnut, there's always a super long line. I can understand an hour wait during the daytime, but even at 11:30pm, we had to wait 40 minutes! Not cool, bruh. One of the employees mentioned that 75% of the people that wait for in line are people who are visiting Portland. Hm...

Sure, their donuts are *different*, but I didn't think they were amazing. Six special donuts turned out to be a little over $12. Personally, I felt like some of the items were just thrown onto or into the donut to make it different. But hey, whatever floats your boat! 

The cashiers here are pretty hit or miss. I was unlucky and got one of the girls who had a b-tch face the entire time we were talking. Come on, you're supposed to smile and put some lovin' into my pink box! This place is definitely more hype than anything.

CASH ONLY! So get your dolla dolla bills y'all!

I've tried these donuts on a couple occasions, and I have to admit...I'm not a fan of them.  They're overpriced, too damn sugary, and to be blunt...over-rated.  I prefer plain donuts with no fillings and minimal toppings if any, so this could be a bias, but they just don't cut it for me.  

I most recently tried some longer bar-looking glazed donut, which I found to be too dense and too sweet, as well as a Fruit Loops donut and a Captain Crunch donut, both of which were too sweet and way too sugar.  The sweet frosting was quite unnecessary considering we all are aware that kid cereals are packed with too much sugar as it is- and these are cereals I grew up eating and loving!  On donuts, however, they're not as good.  

I love donuts, but daaaamn...these were WAY too sweet - even for me.  If you're into kiddy cereals, overpriced and over-hyped donuts, here's your place.  Otherwise, stick to the mom and pop shops that don't need to pour a whole bag of sugar on their donuts to get people loaded.

Whoa...

The donuts seem to have dropped in quality a bunch since the olden days when I would walk blocks across town for a pink box filled with doughy goodness. It's been a few years since I've had a VooDoo donut, and things seem to have changed. 

For the most part, the donuts here are a step above your average grocery store donut. What really still drives VooDoo is the gimmickry and awesomeness of their designs. The Tex-ass is still impressive, the cock n balls is hard to beat, and anything with crushed up oreos on it rules. As much as people like to hate on the disaffected staff, I still find it kind of endearing. It all combines to create a simply ridiculous atmosphere in which to purchase ridiculous donut creations. 

Now I should say, I still prefer cakey donuts to airy, fluffy ones, so IMHO, places like Krispy Kreme don't hold a candle to Voodoo. But having tried other place like Annie's and Joes, both of which produce par-for-the-course grocery store quality donuts, I still stand by my assessment that Voodoo makes some of the best donuts Portland has to offer. 

Also, I still stand by my warning - while cereal on donuts is clever, it gets stale real quick.
