The donuts are fine, but not quite worth the hype. We initially weren't going to come here during our Portland trip because we heard about the hour-long lines, but when we passed by the place on a cold, windy Tuesday evening it was practically empty so we decided to try it out. We shared the Grape Ape, Portland Cream, and Peanut Cake. They definitely have a large variety and they're very creative when designing the flavors, but the actual taste isn't actually that distinctive compared to your average donut shop.

Not sure what the hype is all about... mainly for the unique looks. Donuts really isn't all that great and theres always a line out the door. If you're visiting I guess it's a must do but don't get your hopes up.

Went mostly to say we did. Short line, donut tasted like it should, but felt like they were sort of just on autopilot. 

Seems like they've had the same selection since they opened and meant mostly for tourists, but there's nothing wrong with it at all. 

Cash only, but they have an ATM.

The location is packed with party go-ers, near Chinatown and the bars. Maybe it is a good spot to hit after a night out. We got the top 3 donuts and a couple others. Nothing special. I'm not sure how or why it got so popular, maybe the concept of cereal on donuts? If you are visiting from Orange County or SoCal, I suggest you skip this place. For a similar concept, but good, visit Cafe Dulce (Little Tokyo, LA). Donuttery and DK's, both in OC taste better, in my opinion. The donuts just don't taste fresh at all. If you do try Voodoo, I suggest getting the oreo on top.

I am visiting Portland and decided to give Voodoo a try due to all the hype. Good maple bacon doughnut(not great), but the WORSE customer service. The employee behind the counter was extremely rude. He looked at me as if I had three heads. Regardless of how GREAT your doughnuts may be, I will not come back when treated like I'm inconveniencing you. Go to "Blue Star doughnuts".

The donuts were good, but not great. What I did like was that they had a good amount of variety and there is just about something for everyone. What caught be of guard was that they didnt ear gloves. Which is hard for me because you take money and cards from people and the. Turn around and pick up the donuts with you hands and a paper that beerly covers the surface of their hand.

Came here because this is one of the few places in Oregon that have more than 100 reviews on yelp. (Where y'all Porlandian-yelpers??!) 

I was here at around 7pm on after a long weekday and was greeted by line that snaked all around the side walk. Although the outside decor was somewhat funky and distracted me and my friend for a couple minutes; but the decor won't be able to hold up your attention for an over-1-hour wait. And I like to think that I'm pretty easily amused. 
I ended up taking so many touristy pictures of this one place (there was this mural (?) across the street that just said, KEEP PORTLAND WEIRD!!) just because I ran out of text messages to check / reply. must've taken more than 50 pictures- of the same things

The donuts had pretty creative names, reminiscent of the names for sandwiches from Ike's place if you are a fellow Franciscan. Unique toppings: like fruit loops and crushed oreos atop chocolate glazed donuts. Which looked pretty good, and... jack pot!! It tastes just like Fruit Loops and crushed Oreos atop a chocolate glazed donuts! 

Too sweet; ended up throwing away the two Voodoo-doll shaped donuts we bought the next day.

if you're going to keep me waiting, make me feel like it was worth my wait!

Just A-ok for me. It is better than Psycho donuts here in the bay. I waited in line for over an hour because everyone said it was so good. Service wasn't that great. I felt like they wanted me to hurry up. I tried looking at their rotating display of what they had but nothing looked great. Taste-wise...you can make it yourself. Grab a bag of lays and crush it on top of a chocolate donut. Done. Get a chocolate filled rasberry dounut and stick a pretzel stick in the middle of it. Done. 

Nothing unique when it comes to taste. But weirdness of what's on the donut is what makes it appealing which I believe is why it attracts so many tourists.

2 words. OVER RATED.

2 words. OVER PRICED.

2 words. NOT FRIENDLY

2 works. NOT AGAIN.


and a bunch of words. 
I was really excited to go here because of the reviews, and seeing them on TV 2 times.. But I was disapointed the moment I walked in. Now if I was drunk, and could care less paying a 4bucks for a sugar rush,  and dealing with a less then friendly staff person. I guess I'd rather be drunk because I won't be back unless I am.

Donuts taste good but nothing extraordinary. When I think of Portland, I think of rain, donuts, food trucks, and coffee. There are donut restaurants throughout the city and NOLA Donuts is my favorite!

Don't bother reading this review. You already know you're going to climb back on the airplane with a pink box -like all the other tourists.  Voodoo gets five stars for brilliant marketing.  They get approximately 1/5 of a star for the actual donuts.  Lots of good choices in Portland.  Keep looking.

Very Portland if you're not actually from Portland.... GMO cereal covered donuts, that lack real donut taste. 

Fun experience, if you don't mind waiting in line for something you might regret eating, I advise you take some tums.

I truly love donuts, and I always pass on an opportunity to eat one of these.

ITINERARY: SUNDAY late night (since Voodoo is open 24 hours!)

Why do people flock to Voodoo Doughnuts?

Must be whatever voodoo they sprinkle on their stuff.

Although it's a cute place with crazy looking donuts and a long line, the bottom line for me was that the donuts were not good.

Period.

It's a tourist attraction most definitely. 

Maybe pass by, buy a donut or two or take some photos but it baffles me why anybody would want to buy boxes and boxes of this stuff and take it home. The dough was rubbery and dry and the toppings like the chocolate and cream tasted old and overly sweet.

Whenever you watch a food show about Portland, Voodoo Donuts is always mentioned. Since it's always highlighted as a must go to destination in Portland, I knew I had to be lured into this tourist trap. Fortunately, we came when it wasn't busy, so no ridiculously long lines for us. I ended up going for the Voodoo doll donut and cock and balls filled with custard. The best part of the spot was their signature pink box, other than that I was majorly let down. Both donuts tasted stale and overly sweet. I love their concept and wish their donuts weren't disappointing. Overall, this place is strictly hype and food television shows need to steer away from promoting such lackluster donuts. Save your money and calories and go to Blue Star Donuts instead.

I went to Voodoo donuts on Sandy Blvd to surprise my husband. We had never had Voodoo doughnuts before. I told the gentleman behind the counter that I was going to get a dozen and I proceeded to point them out when I was told that he would be the one picking the flavors out. I said what if I don't like cereal on my donut and he told me I had no choice. I also wanted to have the famous maple bar with bacon and again I was told that they were not part of the selection and I would have to purchase them separately. OK, fine, but when I pullout my debt card he said cash only. I told him to keep his doughnuts and left. I've never gone back, that was about a year ago.

With all of the amazing doughnut shops these days, I would rate Voodoo as just okay. It's not bad but it isn't really any better than any other local run of the mill mom and pop place that serves basic doughnuts. The only one that I would say jumped out at me is the Oreo with Peanut Butter. 

Some other things to keep in mind:

It's very busy and you will feel rushed. 

They will be sold out of some of the more popular doughnuts so don't get your hopes up. 

Don't expect to sit and enjoy a doughnut. They get you in and out as quickly as possible. This is more a 'to go' atmosphere

Thought the doughnuts are fun and delicious but the workers were overall pretty rude... I understand it was super busy and crazy, but they handled it by taking it out on us by ignoring us and being pretty blunt.

SOUTHWEST - PORTLAND, OR 11/20/19 BREAKFAST

+The cake donut is a bit dense and for some reason I like it that way.  It almost reminded me of a pound cake.  I could've been hungry though.
+The toppings and unique flavors are cool.
+These donuts are pretty dope.

-There is a slight grease flavor.

I definitely want to try the other popular donut shops in Portland.  But this is an iconic spot.  Gotta check them out!

P.S., I'm reviewer #9,000.

Like most other people visiting Portland for the first time, I was looking forward to trying Voodoo Doughnut because I had heard so much about it. I waited in line for about 20 minutes. However, like many others, I was disappointed. I had the "Old Dirty Bastard," which was a pretty large donut with chocolate frosting, Oreos, and peanut butter. Unfortunately, the Oreos were stale and I've had much better donuts. I may have gotten unlucky with my donut, but still glad I tried it!
Eh, three stars. Not even really worth writing too much. I'm no donut expert, but I'm not sure why this place is as popular as it is. To me, the best thing to get here is their beautiful box.
Overrated. Mostly hype. Doughnuts are only average.

I'm pretty sure these guys are loaded on sugar.   It not a donut for a adult to enjoy, but for tourists and first timers.  Employees are friendly and polite, probably since they are sticking you for a $4.00 donut.
Greasy, heavy and highly overrated. They don't taste that great either.

Voodoo Doughnuts has such a magically overpowering and all-consuming allure it almost made me consider becoming a Republican... Almost.

25 - The number of minutes it took me to walk from Voodoo Donuts to my hotel.
30 - The number of total strangers who had no shame in shouting out to me, "Hey, buddy! Can I have one of your doughnuts?"

Seriously. That is no exaggeration. More than 1 completely unknown stranger (mind you, these were NOT the homeless people who harass patrons lining up outside an establishment well known as "Cash Only") would ask me every few yards whether I could spare a donut from the box (less than half a dozen) I was carrying. For half an hour I felt what the folks featured on Fox News must feel about the 47%... I kid. Well, sort of... for I do take my (just) desserts very personally.

Voodoo Doughnuts (VD) is a Portland institution, with their Portland Cream (essentially Boston Cream with two eyeballs) actually being recognized in 2008 by the Mayor of Portland as the official doughnut of the city... Open 24 hours, VD adds kitsch, convenience, and reliability that stands it apart from the plethora of "Stoner food" destinations in Portland.

I'm reluctant to call VD a PR gimmick or a tourist trap for every now and then you'll be surprised by the merits of a doughnut. Then again, I don't know which 24 hour establishments across this great country would truly rank as great, at least when sober. I think it would be fair to sum them up based on the website's version of the VD story: "stunningly brilliant business sense" for "two people who had never made a doughnut before".  One manifestation of their genius was to come up with the (now outlawed by the Health Dept.) Vanilla Pepto Crushed Tums Doughnut for "that shot of tequila at 2 am...you got sugar, bread, Pepto, and Tums, you'd either feel better or puke your ass off and then feel better because you got it out of your system ". But, they've still got pink boxes, voodoo dolls, old dirty bastards, and cock and balls... that stuff will always have a market, much like the American Pie movie franchise.

1. I'm a southern Californian born in Taiwan.
2. I've lived in north Orange County, southern CA all my life minus the four years I spent in UT for college.
3. I love to eat, and refuse to eat anything I don't think taste good.  REFUSE.
4. I don't mind spending money to eat well.
5. My parents owned two sandwich shops while I was growing up.  I worked there as a kid, through college and beyond, so I'm a big fan of mom and pop shops.

Where do I begin?  Just SKIP IT.

I love donuts/doughnuts.  I mean, who doesn't? I love it when they're fresh and fried up right in front of you.

There's no shortage of great donuts even in healthy southern CA.  So when I was visiting Portland staying for two nights, you gotta go where everyone is raving.

WOW.  TALK ABOUT VICTIM OF DISAPPOINTMENT.

First of all, the place STINKS. It's in a horrible area where there is a ton of transient folks and let's just say, it's not pleasant smelling.

Of course the line is line, which I don't mind because good food cost a lot and takes awhile.

But.....

after waiting for 45 minutes and getting our two boxes of donuts, I thought to myself, REALLY???  This is what has gotten the tourists nuts about this place?

Their service STUNK.  Yeah, they were fast (too fast) but there was an arrogance to their attitude. Like, "Oh yeah, we're hot stuff and we know it.  Look at our Yelp reviews and all the different shows that feature us."

NEXT!!!!!

So not impressed.

Then there was the actual sugary snacks - which wasn't any better than the good stuff I've had across this country.  Seriously?  This is the best Portland has to offer.

Do yourself a favor - there are PLENTY of good eats in Portland where the servers have senses of humor and serve you with courtesy instead of attitudes of entitlement - TRY ***THOSE*** PLACES OUT.

I will not come back. I will not recommend this place to ANYONE, even if I don't like you. I don't even know why I'm bothering with this review because I'm not sure anyone will read it.  But there it is. =)

I would give them a 10 out of 10 for Uniqueness and art work. But as far as there donuts go for taste not a fan. So, great place to visit 1 time,  but best donuts are Sesame Donuts, and Blue Star Donuts.

Creative & yummy, but not the best I've ever had. I do appreciate that they are open 24/7. 

$8 for:
+ Portland Cream (my fav! creamy inside)
+ Mango Tango (thick frosting and nice cream filling)
+ Old Dirty Bastard (oreo crumbs were a bit chewy)
I think it's pretty overrated and expensive.  My kids liked it though.  Not bad I guess if you're into donuts.  The servers aren't super friendly I have to say.

I came here very late at night and there was thankfully zero line. I really enjoyed the decor and I can't help but love the whole pink aesthetic since it's my most favorite color in the world. Donuts, however, were just alright. My favorite that I ordered was the Portland Cream. It was basic chocolate glaze with cream filling, but definitely not a donut I was crying happy tears over, especially considering how pricey they are (keep in mind this place is cash only). Will only come back if someone else suggests it.

Okay so the donuts are definitely original. The ambiance is fun too. I always take Portland visitors there so that they can check it out but i personally don't buy the donuts. They really aren't very good and certainly not worth the cost.

All novelty, no substance. It's all for show and social media. So yeah, overrated. They have a fun theme for donuts and the mocha donut of the day was good, but that's about it. It's like dating one of the popular people, pretty to have with you, but purely saccharin. Visit Voodoo for your fakebook posts, but then go to Blue Star Donuts to warm your soul.  Seriously, go to Blue Star (1155 SW Morrison St) if you want excellence.

One of the worst pastries I've ever tried... too sweet, not fresh and 10,000+ calories.
U get what you pay for it's cheap and shitty...

Really sweet over the top donuts. I took a few bites of each donut to try and I just couldn't finish it bc it was ridiculously sweet. 

Long lines during the day, but by night time there was no wait. This place is open 247. They have crazy mix of donuts with pre-fixed toppings, so I couldn't modify the toppings. Its def not my fav and I wouldn't go back.

TLDR: This place was disappointing. It's also cash only.

After visiting Philly and trying the amazing Federal Donuts, I was really excited to see what Portland had to offer in terms of donuts. I had heard good things about donuts in Portland, but we made the mistake of trying Voodoo Doughnut instead of other places (next time I want to try Blue Star Donuts).

We arrived on a Sunday morning and waited in a 20-minute line before ordering. The shop was very pink, cool, and unique. However, after we ordered around 6 different flavors and ate our donuts, we were all disappointed. I tried the Bacon Maple Bar (yeast donut) and the Marshall Mathers (cake donut), which were both too sweet and didn't taste that much different than a typical donut.

I know it seems like a fun touristy thing to do, but I wouldn't recommend visiting Voodoo Doughnut. There's usually a long line outside that moves slowly, you have to pay 10 cents for a water cup (which feels greedy and also ruins the point of cash-only in no-sales-tax-Oregon because you're going to get change!), and the donuts, while unique and arguably creative, just aren't good.

This donut shop came highly recommended by almost everyone that heard I was visiting Oregon. Sadly, I felt that it didn't live up to the hype.

Regardless, they did offer unique donut choices (flavors and shapes). They had cute ones such as voodoo dolls and cereal covered ones Or they had a little more funny ones such as Cock and balls donut (which is shaped exactly how it sounds like it would be lol).

Other than that, the quality isn't the best and the taste was slacking for me. I'd probably skip on Voodoo and head over to Blue Star donuts if you want a great donut!

Perhaps the worst donuts I have ever had. I'm not sure how they became so popular.

The donuts were permeated with ridiculously stale cereal. The voodoo doll jelly donut was not special at all...even the pretzel was stale!

Long line. Forgettable food.

Well, Voodoo is good. They have a good selection and its different there. It is a must stop and see if you have never been before or if you are visiting from out of town. Just walking in the door is an experience in its self. However if you are just looking for best darn maple bar you have ever had, your much better off just going down the road to Annie's Donuts. And for every other kind of doughnut I would go to Heavenly Donuts. For me, the hand full of times I have been have been to Voodoo have been enough. I will go back, but only to take friends when they are visiting from out of town so they can have the experience for themselves.
Cheap, fun looking donuts. Did i like them - nope! Would i recommend trying them - nope. Maybe i just don't like donuts

Clueless tourists only go here. Doughnuts are below average - fat better available at Blue Star and many others (Pips!). Long lines and the area around is basically skid row - drug addicts and camp sites on the streets - area needs a massive clean up and these people need more help and better services. It is killing retail in the neighborhood.
Mostly for the kids because there's just nothing like Shipley's back home in Houston  ;o)

Considered a must-see stop for tourists to Portland, Voodoo was featured off course on several shows on Food Network and Travel Channel. I love their unique selections and eclectic decor. It almost a tattoo shop feel to it. And while the donuts are unique and one-of-a-kind, it's a bit of a tourist trap...similar to New York, going to Katz or Carnegie Deli to get a sandwich just to say you were there. The donuts are super sweet, better for dessert than breakfast, but take away the toppings, and their donuts are okay. The texture is okay, flavor is okay; doesn't quite have the fluffiness and savoriness in the dough as other places i've been to. The attraction is definitely the flavors than the doughnut itself.

I heard that coming to Voodoo donuts while in Portland is a must. You always want to try the original location! It was my first time trying it out and I was super excited. The line was crazy out the door, but it helps that they have a menu of their donuts that you can see while in line. Once getting to the counter, I felt very rushed by the workers. I ended up only ordering one thing. Everyone in my party ordered something different so we ended up trying a little bit of everything. Overall, the donuts here are just for show. They're cute and instagram worthy, but there's nothing special about the donuts here.

They may have excellent donuts, but since they can't come up with GLUTEN-FREE, I wouldn't know!!!
Too bad. Vegan ain't good enough, I can't have gluten, AS MANY THOUSANDS IN PORTLAND CAN'T!!!

I've been a long time lover for all the sweet tooth places in town, I like to try as many as I can get, this was a good place, donuts are tasty but the service is not that great, I will give them some second and third chance to make sure if I'm going to become regular or not!

What I like about this doughnut place (apart from the very friendly staff) is the unique variety of flavors. So much to choose from! But given that I'm not that much of a sweet tooth, I decided to try only the maple bacon and voodoo doughnut, which are two of their famous doughnuts. It was a good experience but it's not something I would come back for. It was too sweet for me. I give them props though for the creativity!

The long line you always have to wait in, is not worth it. Trust me. It's all just a hype and tourist trap.  Yeah they have different toppings but the donut itself is not good. But it is the only place you can get a big penis sized cream filled donut. P.S. Cash only!

This place is too hyped. 

It does have a lots of varieties and comes in different shapes, but average taste.
If you're looking for a post, this is the place. If you want a good donut, there are plenty of better places around.

Voodoo Doughnut is always exciting regardless of the taste. The bright pink, the crazy doughnuts, the glitter on the bricks, the anticipation waiting in line... Once Helena H brought me a box of Voodoo Doughnuts from Denver and that was so nice. Going there in person in Portland was just as sweet. 

We chose the Mango Tango, Diablo Rex (for the design), Guava Colada, and of course Voodoo Doll (again for the design). I didn't care for the Diablo Rex (bland). The filling of the Mango Tango was way too much and way too sweet. Guava Colada was just right. The subdued guava filling and coconut frosting was a great combination. The Voodoo Doll was the classic chocolate yeast doughnut and more of what you'd expect when eating doughnuts for breakfast. Overall, way too much doughnut for four people and it took us two days to finish them. 

I've had better doughnuts at a myriad of places but Voodoo Donuts is a fun experience. Definitely try it once and also if you are in the area. Otherwise go to Blue Star for repeat visits.

When I order a cock and balls I expect better cream filling and darker brown frosting. 
Plus all the dognuts basically all taste like fancy hip portland trash. The staff on the other hand is amazing. I have never met more entitled 20 somethings in my life. They thinking working there makes them gods. It's impressive.
Plus they wouldn't let me return my dog nuts after I puked them up. Wtf

guh GARBAGE. Hey, if you want to drag that pink box around town and alert every single person that you're a tourist, go for it. By the time you get 'home' the stuff in the box will be more stale than it was when you bought it! 

There are times when you can visit without standing in a line for an hour+, but most people decide to go mid-afternoon on a weekend day when it's nice out so expect to wind your way through Disneyland-style person barricades with about 200 other clueless people as you dodge panhandlers and e-scooters. 

Look, its an experience that you'll only get in downtown Portland, and I can't blame people for going down there (I did, once) but it's overrated at best. The staff, when you get to the part where you can order, are overworked and carry the kind of 'tude that stems from direct hatred of humankind. They've got to deal with agitated customers and a whole host of other problems (aforementioned panhandlers) so you can't really blame them. You can just avoid the situation entirely. If you're really down for a decent donut, hit Blue Star (overpriced, yes, but still better than the contents of that pink box). If you just want to soak up the Portland vibe, head to the strip clubs nearby. You'll be happier spending your money there, trust me.
Cool fun choices but the donuts themselves were like any other. Sorry! And not work a long wait..

I like donuts, but these are not the best out there.  I'm a Winchell's man myself.  All the fancy flavors and designs don't get my money after the first one.  Also I should mention that the line is very long almost 2 hour wait.  We missed the opening of Avengers Endgame for this?!  Well we did.  In my day you used to wait in line to watch movies - now you wait for donuts in the afternoon.  My grandkids loved the donuts, though.  We will be back!
Not sure why everyone is excited about this place. It was a donut shop donuts were okay.   Cash only... that makes you wonder.    Would not have waited in line --so good thing there was no line!

Donuts here are average but the sense of humor and touristy vibe make it fun. Go super early in the AM during the week (never go on weekends) if you're not into the Portland line game.

Cash only but there's an ATM inside. The folks who work there have zero chill, so be ready to order when you hit the counter.

A must see, must visit for all Portland visitors. It's an icon :)
This place is more fun and interesting than having truly good donuts. Though the dirty bastard is pretty good. Voodoo is more of an experience, but Blue Star is where it's at for quality.

I honestly think this place is super overrated for mediocre doughnuts. I think they're nicely decorated but I wouldn't want to wait an hour for them. The line here is ridiculously long. Sometimes they wrap around the building. I ordered their infamous voodoo doughnut and actually didn't even finish it. It's definitely a touristy thing and I'd still recommend to a friend who is visiting, but I wouldn't come back for more

The lines are so long and not worth it.  Yes they have crazy toppings and interesting ideas for donuts.  At the end of the day, they are just ok donuts.  I'd go to the many other delicious donut shops in town instead.

Line moves pretty quickly. We got 5 specialty donuts for $10.65. A little on the pricey side, but when you're in Portland, you have to check this place out. Enjoy it as dessert after eating at Pine Street. I LOVED how fluffy the donuts were. I took a bite and it would literally bounce back.

Be careful walking in this area of PortlanD though... One block in the wrong direction and you're in "Skidmore." Yes, it's exactly like "Skid Row" in LA. Other than that, friendly service, fluffy donuts and quick lines. Can't get better than that!
More hype than tasty.  They are of course a tourist attraction in Portland but, far from best doughnuts in city.

If you are visiting Portland then Voodoo's is a must. Their donuts are fun but be prepared for long lines. They also only accept cash. 

However, if you are a local then you know that there are WAY better donut shops in town and this should be the last on your list.

NO! NO! NO! It's WWAAAYYY to sweet! I walked away with a tooth ache (litteraly!) And they are pretty expesive to boot. Yeah they DO have fun shapes and if you don't mind walking past all the homeless people or the kids laying on the sideays getting high then you might be okay. 
Oh and taking my 9 year old son? AWESOME!

Of course if you visit Portland everyone tells you Voodoo doughnut is the place to go! So we took everyone's advice and decided to stop by on a recent trip to Portland. 

It's pretty crazy to see long lines at almost any hour. When we arrived we had to wait in a line that took about 10-15 min to get to the front. I've heard it can some time take up to 30 mins of wait time to get to the front so I guess it just depends on the rush hour times. 

They have a huge selection of doughnuts that are displayed on a revolving display case towards the front of the cashier area. 

We decided to pick random ones that look cute or somewhat appetizing. 

I would say that their doughnuts lean more towards the doughy side. If your into fluffy light donuts like Krispy Kreme I would suggest Blue Star doughnut. 

I would probably pick Blue Star doughnut over Voodoo doughnut because I felt like the donuts at Voodoo are over hyped because of it's crazier designs and look over the normal traditional donut.

Not gonna lie, thought the doughnuts would be a bit more unique in style and flavor. They're big and fresh, but I was looking for a bit more variety. They apparently have several locations. The line here looked long, but moved efficiently. The guy managing the door was good about only letting a few people in at a time. Friendly cashier. Was also hoping to find a cronut here but sadly, none on the menu. Glad I tried the place though so I could see what the hype was about...a bit overly hyped in my opinion.
I know this isn't going to be popular but I don't get the hype. Minus that the selections are weird. I'm sorry I just don't get it.

The donuts here are good and pretty big. The combinations they have are pretty cool and delicious. But tbh it is not worth the wait. This place is hyped up way too much. Maybe if you are visiting the area, definitely try it but if you are just craving donuts go somewhere else.

Trash. In fact, so bad that it made me and my boyfriend get in a fight as soon as we took the first bite. I've never had such a dry, sad donut before. Instantly put the bad vibes in us and some voodoo in our relationship. And not the good. Get some Blue Star donut instead and don't ruin your day.

We arrived bright and early around 7am on a Saturday to try this place out and there were still a few people in line! We tried: the Voodoo Doll, Portland Cream and old fashioned glazed doughnuts. 

All the donuts were too sweet and not fluffy like I was hoping. They didn't taste fresh and I'm glad we didn't have to wait in a long line (we passed by later in the day and there was a line around the building and it was raining).

Too much hype for expensive donuts that only taste mediocre at best.

Talk about the voodoo that causes this place to be so hype. These poor souls have not been blessed by the other certain -colored celestial object- donut shop that is present in Portland. Sure, you get some fancy flavors here but for the price and wait time- take a pass!

That being said, I guess if you're in Portland for the first time, I'd give it a try. THEN go to Blue Star and see what a real quality donut is like. I'll give them perks for being open 24/7 though! Voodoo has a very fun and pink aesthetic that makes them so special. Are you really a tourist if you don't get a pink box to take a pic of? There's outdoor seating for you to set up the perfect scene right outside their shop.

Anyways about the donuts- what you actually came here for right? They are alright lol. I did enjoy the maple bacon and the Old Dirty Bastard (peanut butter and oreos), but was whatever about the hibiscus and Homer Simpson donut. Their glaze didn't give me this high quality feel for the high quality price I was supposedly paying for. I'm glad I only waited in line for like 15-20 minutes, and this was on a Monday afternoon. I can't even imagine how long a weekend line takes and I've seen it- poor people waiting in the sun. However once you're in there, it seemed to move pretty fast. They are efficient with taking orders and they have donuts on a rotating display so you can choose donuts based on how they look (which is really what you're here for).

But yah I won't be back here when I know there are better quality donuts elsewhere in Portland.

4.17.16: If there was a 3.5 that would be the rating. I'm not sure if it's worth the wait. I do think their donuts are good, but I really don't like waiting in the heat It is something to try if you haven't tried before just to see if you agree with other people's hype.

There are so many flavors, we ended up getting two dense ones and two fluffy ones. It was sweet like donuts and I'm not sure what else to say about them. 

It was actually a quick process if you already know what you want. Once you order it's like bam you get it right away. The cashier was very patient even though it was so busy. So that's a plus. As others have mentioned this place is cash only. 

If you don't mind waiting in line then it's worth it.
Typical donuts nothing special tasting.. but the price point is low and the box you just have to take home!

It's not the best location but walkable to get there. There was small line starting around the door but it moves fast. 

I ordered the basic voodoo doll donut and it's cute but it was only worth it for the gram haha.

Since the last time we were here, a couple things have changed. 1st, they now accept credit cards. 2nd, the female begging outside the door has now been replaced by 2 men. Doughnut wise, the  Homer was still good, so was the voodoo doll. Tried the mango tango, I liked the filling but it was too sweet to be eaten with the topping. The maple bar is still too sweet but the kiddo liked it. 

I didn't feel as safe this time around even though it was still bright and there were still plenty of people out and about. It's like the area has gone downhill since February. The short (brisk) walk back to our hotel felt like an eternity. Don't think I'll venture back here even if my kid begs me to unless I have a big guy with me.
Literally, was not all that. Brought 5 donuts, but only ate 1. Too sweet. More for looks than anything else. Line was long. Location was small.

The World According to Noelle
Allergic Girl's Guide to Life

"Just say no to Voodoo Doughnuts." Noelle W.

On our long road trip Voodoo Doughnuts was definitely on our list of places to try. We parked around the corner which was a short 5 minute walk to the doughnut shop. Passing the dive bars and restaurants my senses were offended by the smoke from the local patrons.

We stood in a rather long line. Most of this line was comprised of locals and a few tourists. The people in front were definitely hippie like and had the worst body odor ever. I was not going to be deterred. I was on a mission. That mission- to get a dozen of these Voodoo Doughnuts. We finally were ready to order. I picked three Portland Creams, three cinnamon sugar, two Voodoo Dolls, two Bacon Maple Bars and two Neapolitan. The only doughnut that tasted decent was the Portland Creams- delicious chocolate frosting and amazing Bavarian Cream. I saw the customer service person take our doughnuts from the racks and they seemed fresh. The doughnuts were extremely dry almost to the point of stale. 

CONS
~The flies flying above in the foyer.
~The dirty and smelly foyer.
~The fact the customer service person told me while picking my doughnuts, "You don't have to order one dozen." Whereby I replied, "I want to order one dozen of your doughnuts."
~When I inquired about purchasing a t-shirt the disgruntled employee rolled their eyes, quickly walked away and quickly came back to say, "No we don't have any more."
~The dry and staleness of the doughnuts.
~Cash Only.

PROS
~If you've never been here and are lucky to read my review- save your money and taste buds, just skip it.

Noelle's Notes
There's got to be better doughnuts in Portland.
Voodoo donuts is popular and before my trip I kept hearing great things about the donuts shop. I don't think the donuts were magnificent or special in any way. The customer service was horrible.

Voodoo Doughnuts are a little over hyped.  I imagine this place is more for the novelty and Instagram pictures than for the doughnuts themselves. The doughnuts were not fresh, and for having so many doughnut options ready to order I can't imagine how they could be. I tried a cake doughnut and a rised doughnut and both did not have the rich texture I would expect out of a fresh doughnut. The flavors were also sort of bland. The cake doughnut was dry. Do not go here if you want a real crafted good quality doughnut, go here if you want a novelty picture, then throw the doughnut away. 

On the bright side the line did move fast.

Voodoo is, I think, exactly as you would expect. It is quintessential Portland and I would never discourage a tourist from going there for the first time - but, I would suggest that once you've had voodoo, there is no reason to go back. 

First, the sheer popularity of it is enough to discourse me to Blue Star or Coco's or.. dare I say? The Fred Meyer bakery. It sits in the worst neighborhood, both for parking and heckling, and the line to get in zigzags between metal gates as if a Disneyland scale roller coaster awaits you at the end. Nope, alas, just mediocre donuts. 

They are fun shapes, unique flavors, etc. so they are perfect for getting a selfie with a novelty donut in a pink box so everyone knows you went to Portland and didn't explore anything cool. 

I am not unhappy with my overall experience, but unless it's 4am and I'm leaving Kit Kat, I do not see any reason to return.

hyped ass garbage i feel bad for the sheep that waited in that ridiculous line out the door in 40 degree rain. the donuts with cereal is fuckin stale.. avoid this shit place at all costs and hit up blue star donuts that's quality you can taste!

Had these donuts a few times simply because of the unique designs that would entice any person to try one...at least one donut. Other than a creative display of sugar induced toppings added to a donut, the base itself, the donut, has to be the worst I have ever had. Extremely dry, consistent as a two day old donut. The taste is nothing worth standing in line for. But if you must, go ahead and judge for yourself.

Voodoo is great for the experience, but their donuts are not good anymore. Unless you're really drunk. Maybe there is just too much demand, and therefore it's hard to keep them fresh? I have no idea. I'll say this. It's one of those places you have to go to at least once. If you're a tourist, go ahead and experience the line and get your self a penis donut. Enjoy! If you're a local...go to Blue Star. They'll knock your socks off!

The donuts are a step above dunkin donuts but aren't anything to write home about. We tried the voodoo donut (a jelly donut shaped like a voodoo doll) and the Portland creme (it's a Boston Creme). They were OK at best but nothing special. The wait was 30-45 mins and the line wrapped around the outside. The wait definitely wasn't worth it and the atmosphere outside is odd and really shows the paradox of a city like Portland. Seeing people who are homeless sleeping on the sidewalk and begging for a food is such a contrast towards those of us who are privileged to be standing in line to wait for overpriced donuts. Definitely wouldn't visit Voodoo donuts again nor would I recommend them.

+ donuts are creatively decorated

- ridiculously long lines
- donuts aren't good. Made to induce a heart attack or at least a sugar attack

Well I'm probably going to be ostracized for this review, and hoards of Portlanders will hunt me down and / or create a voodoo doll and have their way with me vis a vis pin sticking, but so be it.  What is all the hype?  The place was dirty!  I mean, dusty and grimy!  COME ON, IT'S FAMOUS ALL OVER - can't you get a crew in there and make it so I'm not scared to touch the walls?  But hey, if that's the cool way to be, okay I won't touch anything.  But the donuts?  Do you EVER change the oil?  You can't rest on the uniqueness of the names and shapes of the donuts forever.  Someday, people are going to want QUALITY over uniqueness, and that is how it should be.  I could not eat my donut.  I had to throw it away.  It was rancid with old oil.  The people serving me were either hungover or gasp still in the grips of a party the night before.  I felt like I was on acid in the 60s, something I used to do often.  Perhaps I wandered into a fugue state and wasn't even in Voodoo Donuts at all.  I don't know.  I was so disappointed.  We made a special trip as newbies to Portland just to try them out.  We saw them on t.v.  Helloooooo (echo coming back to me) WHAT IS ALL THE HYPE?????

HORRIBLE! I brought my brother who was visiting from AZ in for a "famous" voodoo Doughnut and I'm sad to say it was a horrible HORRIBLE doughnut! It was old tasting, stale dough that started to crust on the outside, the glaze was gritty, the crushed oreos were soft and crumbly (not in a good way) There was hardly any peanut butter sauce on the dirty bastard, the peanut butter and jelly that was my moms favorite PB &J the first time we went in, which was an okay experience, was now just a disappointment, it too was stale, hardly any jelly and much smaller than the last, honestly I'm never going back, each time fails to hold up to it's reputation, STOP getting overpaid for crappy dough... Go to "Fresh Roll" instead, I have nothing bad to say about that place! It may not be a donut shop or a place to get a sugar high but the food is amazing and the service impeccable, unlike Voodoo.

So i guess this spot was on our list of to-go places while visiting Portland, and surprisingly, there was a long line by 11am.

Pros:
- The cool slow-spinning tray of doughnuts available near the cashier. You can definitely see which ones you'd WANT to add into the pre-selected box they provide you. These boxes normally contain the popular selections but if you want to add extras, you can, but you have to pay extra.
- Aside from the doughnuts, they also sell some cool merch like shirts and mugs.
- Despite the line, the service is pretty fast.
- Open 24 hrs for those who get hungers at 3am.
- Their doughnuts have some unique names and concepts, like the maple blazer blunt, mango tango, and dirt... literally.

Cons:
- The hype was real but the taste wasn't the deal. Pretty much your standard doughnuts, but not as great as mom-and-pop doughnut stores.
- Parking is available on the street or garages if they're actually available.

The doughnuts are good, but not the most amazing that I've tasted. Take the pictures to say that you've been here! But honestly dont think I'd want to come back to wait in line again for average doughnuts.

After just a bite of their donut it was enough for me. A lot of people seem to like this place but I see nothing special. However, I do sense something dark and sinister, As if this place has been cast with Voodoos. I wonder how many kids come here to eat and play?
Have tried their donuts every now and then since they opened and they SUCK. Hands down worst donuts ever.

Meh. That's all I have to say about these donuts. I went around lunch time on a Thursday and there was no line. That was about the only good thing. I got the voodoo man donut, butterfinger, Portland cream, and dirty snowball. All the donuts were cold and they tasted like old oil--you know, the taste of oil when it's been reused over and over again and then left out to sit. It left a bad taste in my mouth. The two chocolate based donuts were absolutely flavorless. I wouldn't have know what I was eating if it weren't for the toppings. The dirty snowball had a dollop of peanut butter and that was all you can taste. The (Bavarian) cream donut was ok. And the voodoo was ok but a bit dry/hard like it had been sitting out all day. 

I have it 2 stars bec it's an interesting place and there is a huge variety. It is more a treat for the eye than a treat for the tastebuds.

Everyone warned me Voodoo was a total tourist trap but, since we were in Portland for a few days, we figured we should go anyway. Our first evening, we stopped by around 5:00 p.m. but the line was out the door and down the sidewalk, so we tried again two days later around 7:00 a.m. We got the bacon maple, along with some other doughnut that the employee recommended, and we were underwhelmed. My wife and I agreed the doughnuts at Blue Star were significantly superior.

Voodoo has many donut selections to choose from. The price is cheaper than many other donut places.

We picked out a few to try. It was good but nothing so special in terms of the taste. I actually prefer Blue Star Donuts. Having said that, it is like a tourist attraction (must try) at least once when you are in Portland. 

The line is long ...

I read through some reviews of this place and it seems that most people are saying the doughnuts are just average. However, in my time in Portland, I HAD to spot by this famous landmark that everyone raves about!

Surprisingly the line was not bad for a Sunday afternoon but it still took about 25 minutes to get in. Once we got in though, I felt like I was taken to another dimension! I loved the unique interior and the employees were extremely nice. We ordered the voodoo doll, hibiscus, portland, and one other thing that I can't remember (must not have been memorable). 

Overall, the first bite is SO DELICIOUS but it's major sweetness overload. However, after attempting to finish one, I had to stop. There was nothing that really stood out to me about the dough or the frosting. I would have to say that it was just OK. 

The place is pretty pricey but it's understandable since they make crazy designs and names. Would I come back? I wouldn't go out of my way but if I am in the area, I would probably just stop by (as long as the line isn't long). I am glad I got to visit this place as I always see pictures on social media!

Long wait (45 minute line wrapped around the building) for OK donuts, but I wouldn't say they were anything to rave about. We got a wide variety. Any of the donuts with cereal on top were not appetizing. The cereal was stale and gross. The voodoo donut was the best with this yummy raspberry filling. I also had this really chocolatey donut that was good and super rich (it's been awhile so I don't remember much about it besides at the time I really wished I had something to drink with it)
Overrated and snobby staff. Blue Star is way cleaner, better part of town and tastier donuts.

In my opinion, the donuts here are below average or mediocre at best-- way too sweet, and also very, very crowded. Not sure why this place is recommended for tourists, but it's definitely not something I would recommend if you were searching for a nice donut shop.

Voodoo Doughnut is the dive bar of doughnut shops...

Dirty, cheap, nowhere to sit, doughnut-tender handles items with bare, dirty hands, nothing to drink but milk, questionable all around...

But you keep going...

Please eat a bacon maple bar.  Whoever came up with this deserves a high-five, though I'm sure they'd frown upon that at Voodoo.  Also, I enjoyed the grape ape...like grape soda in chewable form!

Do like the Voodoo do...eat their doughnuts.

Just try not to think about how they're made...

My first time in Portland trying voodoo donuts and it was quite overrated to say the least. The doughnuts themselves were unbearably sweet with all the toppings and candy. I tried the dirty bastard and butterfingering. The regular donut is definitely better than the cake donut which is dense and dry. However the donut itself is full of sugar as well as the chocolate/ vanilla glaze. I prefer donuts that are less sweet if they are going to have Oreo cookies and butterfinger bits on top. The location was very kitschy and cute and plenty of seating outside with protection from the wind and rain. However this place is just novelty and not worth coming to unless you want an Instagram post.

Not bad, it's just supermarket quality donuts with cheep funky toppings and tripped price. It's such a shame that this is more famous than blue star, NOLA, or Pip's. 
And wow this area is really ghetto. Don't go there alone, homeless people wouldn't let you enjoy donut time, seriously. I had a scary experience.

Meh...Voodoo makes mediocre doughnuts that are unbearably sweet, but it's a novelty in Portland so everyone feels like they need to check it of their list. I did try hibiscus glaze for the first time so it was interesting, but I wouldn't seek it out again.
Perhaps the most iconic donut shop in Portland, but certainly not the best. Is it worth your time to wait in the disneyesk lines? Id say not, unless you have a a few bright eyed children in toe.

It was okay, we got the grape ape, voodoo bubble, diablo one and the key lime crush and they weren't bad but they were all too sweet to the point that it was honestly too hard to finish. good place to try out though for one time, the only thing i was not satisfied with at all was the customer service. they were not of help at all, we waited as the guy guarding the door saw us waiting after the family who came in after us got help and the guard acted like he didn't let us in and was like what are you guys waiting for, did you come in when i wasnt looking? my bf and i said no, you let us in... and he realized his mistake and apologized. the worker also ignored us at the register so that is why we were confused where to order. not a great experience.... oh and they also got his donut wrong and no we were not there during a busy time

First off... they aren't good doughnuts. Let's be honest. You're going to voodoo for the "creative" choices and the photo for social media. If you live here in portland you're going to pips or if you just want to be different and only have one overpriced donut, Nola or Blue Star. Not even going to start with the location.

Okay, I've written a four star for this Voodoo Doughnut site before.  It's one star now.  I drive 40 mins. to get a Voodoo dozen, a voodoo man and a Texas Mafia or TexAss doughnut.

The last five times I've waited up to an hour in line and when I try to order all their specialty donuts are gone.  GONE.   FIVE TIMES.

I get their Voodoo Dozen and they're all the crummy, left over ones.

Get your act together, VD.  Tonight, my birthday, was the last straw.  What a disappointment after the hard time finding parking, driving all that distance and then getting some frickin' purple hard candy donut and other unedibles.

I give up.
A Portland staple, as a doughnut neutral individual, I come exclusively for the spectacle! Pink boxes! Epic lines! Coffins! Genital doughnuts! Oregon in a nutshell.

Voodoo Doughnut is one of those places with a cult following. So make it there early or wait in a long line just to get in. 
That being said, I made it there early enough to get in pretty fast, but I noticed a lengthy line later that afternoon while passing by. 
Voodoo has so many doughnut options that it's hard to choose what to take. Their options are extensive and have playful names; some even sexual in nature. My girlfriend and I just stopped by to get two each, just so we can say we tried them. Ended up choosing the Raspberry Romeo with peanut butter glaze, a Maple Blazer Blunt, Lemon Chiffon Cruelter, and a Grape Ape.  
All in all, good doughnuts but nothing to go crazy about. Voodoo is definitely worth a stop if you're not from around the area. Just make sure to get there early and take cash because they don't take credit card.

Stopped here on my road trip up to Vancouver in 2014 since I had heard so much about it. I was expecting more from a doughnut shop with so many reviews and so hyped. They're really creative with the doughnuts but that doesn't necessarily mean they're going to be good. It's one of those places you stop by just to see what all the talk is about then get left somewhat disappointed because it was overhyped.
I don't know what all the buzz is but this place is just OK. Yes, their doughnuts look cool BUT I have tasted better. Don't waste your time in line.

My experience with the infamous Voodoo doughnuts was pretty similar to how I felt about trying the ramen burger back when that was still trending, and can be best summed up with 'lol'. Not as in they were so terrible that they were a joke, but as in "Well...I guess that's another buzz food to check off the list. Ha ha." 

Voodoo makes very solidly average doughnuts in terms of taste, but its personality and sense of humor are awesome. The doughnuts themselves aren't very special - too heavy and sticky and cloying for my tastes; I'll take Shipley's any day - and it's definitely the eye-catching novelty of their decorations that do the legwork. I mean, where else do you find doughnuts topped off with Fruit Loops and chocolate-drizzled Oreo chunks? Once you get past the initial giddiness most of them are actually kind of disappointing though. The Voodoo Doll, for instance, while cutely decorated, is really just a normal raspberry jam doughnut underneath. The Diablos Rex, under the guise of such a badass name, is just a chocolate doughnut with red and white icing/sprinkles piped around in a gimmicky pattern. The pretty purple doughnut, upon further inspection, is a plain doughnut with purple glaze and purple sprinkles. The supposed lavender and grape flavors weren't very strong. The one doughnut I did really like was the bacon maple. Because BACON MAPLE.

Maybe I just had the wrong expectations coming in or was unlucky enough to choose all 'boring' doughnuts, but I thought the doughnuts would just be more interesting. Like what if the Diablos Rex were made of Mexican dark chocolate, or the purple doughnut were actually lavender flavored? Now that would be cool.

tl;dr: YOUR MOMMA WAS RIGHT, LOOKS ARE DECEIVING. Average tasting doughnuts that don't have much substance under all the flashy deco. You still walk away vaguely happy with their sense of humor though.

There were probably about 80 people in line ahead of us Saturday afternoon.. but the wait was not bad at all. Lots of people watching, crazy unique donuts to choose from and a pretty glitter brick wall to look at. But other than that, the donuts were just donuts. I didn't get any for myself, but I snuck a bite and a Snap of my bf's donuts. They don't taste very good but I gotta give them points for creativity and marketing. Everyone recognizes their pink box and the voodoo doll donut! So basically that's all you're getting.. a nice Instagram, Snapchat or Yelp worthy pic!

Worst tasting donuts I have ever had. Tasted like they were 3 days old. The employees look sick and not fit to serve food. The place is dirty and the neighborhood is full of tweakers and drunks. Good luck if you park a car and leave anything in it! Disgusting!

I didn't really find any difference between Voodoo and other doughnut shops. I drove down with my family from Seattle and going to Voodoo was on the top of our bucket list. After waiting for about 30 minutes in line and excitedly discussing which flavored doughnuts we were all getting, I was about to experience one of the biggest foodie let downs. The doughnuts were not warm and the taste was average. 

The doughnut flavors are pretty creative-- we got the guava, chuckles, ODB, and dirt doughnuts. I thought the guava doughnut was the best. Very fresh and great center guava ganache filling. However the other three were nothing special. The dirt doughnut was too sweet, with icing and oreo, and the ODB was basically the dirt with peanut butter drizzle. I would prefer Krispie Kreme or Top Pot doughnuts over these.

I liked the vibe of Voodoo, it seemed very trendy and Portland-y. I also think maybe Voodoo has created its own hype? The employees worked incredibly slowly at the cash register, hence the long lines. 

Also random side note-- they didn't have knives to cut the doughnuts. How were we supposed to share??

I'll give them the benefit of the doubt-- maybe it was a busy day or the rain got to them. Who knows.

I really done understand why this place is so famous!! We stood in line for line 30 minutes. If the line doesn't move fast enough they have a loud horn they will call within less that 10 seconds when your inside. The donuts inside weren't labeled, only a few of them were. The employees were actually very nice though. They helped us decide on which donuts to get depending on our preferences. 
The donuts may seem unique, but they taste disgusting. 
The loop donut is just a really bad mix of flavors, I don't even think a child would like it. The Marshall Mather donut would have been okay but the frosting tastes gross. The Neapolitan donut also had a strange blend of flavors, but it was the old one with soft dough. Again, the homer donut also had bad frosting and the dough tasted kind of stale. The peanut donut was the only one I felt was kind of decent. Just being honest here, these donuts are pretty overrated and overpriced. Don't bother getting a dozen or half a dozen.

OVERHYPED but if you're in Portland, you're probably thinking that you have to try Voodoo at least once! Soo if you must, I recommend the Bacon Maple Bar doughnut!! The perfect combination of maple frosting and bacon yummm... This was the real winner out of all the donuts we tried. And we took two trips to this location in our weekend getaway so we tried quite a few donuts!! The bacon on top had the perfect balance between crunch, salt, and sweetness. What isn't delicious with bacon on top?!?!

Other than that, everything else was pretty average. Good donuts but nothing else that I felt was really worth the calories LOL. If you really need to try a selection of donuts besides just the bacon maple bar, try to stick to donuts with filling. It tastes so much better with a bite of custard or jelly rather than just donut alone.

Stay away from donuts with cereal on top! They look so cute but it turns out way too sweet and the cereal gets soggy if you don't eat the whole donut right away!!

Most of the donuts taste like regular donuts but they're not bad at all. I like that there are so many unique flavors and names. Some of them get pricy like the Cock N Balls is around $6 but the pricier ones are HUGE so you get your money's worth. They are all adorably decorated and instagram worthy so I get the appeal but when you taste it, you realize it's really nothing special. It's your average donut disguised beautifully.

My friend and I went here for the first time on Saturday morning (Aug 15). The line was out the door and the wait was about 40 minutes. They only accept cash. We were visiting from out of town and read that this is one of the popular tourist spots to see. It's nice that they had a lot of different options to choose from. Everything looked so good. I got the 'Captain my Captain' doughnut and my friend got the 'Triple Chocolate Penetration.' We each thought that the doughnuts were just okay, nothing special other than the fact that they had cereal on top of it. For the wait, price, and quality of the food, I don't think it was worth it.
This place died when health officials took away the NyQuil doughnut. That was old Portland.

Made a trip to Voodoo Doughnut on Sunday afternoon. Was lucky to avoid a long wait and enjoyed two unique and tasty doughnuts.

Quality: I was happy with both doughnuts I tried. I don't know if they deserve the iconic status they have reached, but both doughnuts I tried were good. I thought the Bacon Maple Bar was the better of the two, but there is something cool about the Voodoo Doll. I have a feeling though that the real highlights are the less attractive looking options
Quantity: Large doughnuts that can easily be shared.
Value: $3.00 for the Voodoo Doll. $3.50 for the Bacon Maple Bar.
Ambiance: Voodoo Doughnut has a few locations, but I visited the one just north of Downtown Portland. It sits on the corner of a small strip of bars and restaurants. Outside they have pink barriers setup for long lines, but luckily it wasn't needed on this day. Outside they also have some tables and umbrellas, but with a downpour, it is was not a feasible option. Inside the shop is small, with just enough space for the line to wriggle one last time before the register. You will find memorabilia, gear, and of course, rotating doughnuts.
Crowd: On a miserable rainy day, the line was not what I was told to expect. It took less than 10 minutes to make it to the front and grab my treats. I assume that is a rarity on the weekend.
Service: The line moves fast. I assume they were prepared for a bigger crowd.
Parking: Limited street parking in the area.

Being that this place is an iconic spot for many visitors to ensure they stop over.  At first I was so happy to be at such a magnificent place (who doesn't get happy, when there are treats).  

After we made our choices in our head, we stood in line. We were helped by the a female with purple and red dyed hair.  She was very rude and impatient, I understand that you are trying to push as much customers through but really it wasn't even busy.  She needs to understand that most people are coming in are tourists and they aren't going to know exactly what they want.  So we started to give out order and she started to toss our donuts into a box.   Remind you we are from Hawaii and we wanted to fill the box as much as possible to prevent the doughnuts from sliding around.  Well our initial request of donuts didn't fill the box so we wanted to request more donuts.  She got upset because we had to start another transaction.  

So after dealing with her bitchy ass, she doesn't hand me our receipt but throws it in the box and now I have a receipt with chocolate all over it. 

Well after all that she didn't even offer a bag or anything so I just left.  Glad I went and now can knock going to voodoo donuts off my checklist of things to do in Portland.  Screw her and hope she gets fired.  Don't make sense to work in a customer service business and you suck at it!!

This place has changed. I remember when it was a little room the size of a closet. Now it is like a mini-restaurant. And every one and their cousin in law is standing outside in a line extending down the block. I remember they use to do weddings there and had ouija boards on the walls. I don't know what has happen to Portland in general. I leave for a few years and come back to this preppy trendy over populated city, or town. There never was a line when I came to this place. Nobody really cared about voodoo donuts around 2007. Nobody was ever in that restaurant Nicholas's, I went to that place also and it is packed with lines down the street. Every time I went there in the past, there was maybe 1 person in there. Portland is not cool anymore. It got sold out or taken over. Blame the tv show portlandia.

The other 7,000+ reviews got it right. A great local flair that is highlighted in many television shows. Not necessarily a must-go for great donuts, but a nice spot to visit and try interesting flavors. We came on a Saturday after visiting the Saturday market nearby. The line wrapped around just once, but moved along.

We ordered:
- Grape Ape
- Voodoo Doll
- Cock-n-balls
- Marshall Mathers

We all took a bite of each and nothing stood out to be delicious. It was extremely sweet and photo worthy, but nothing really else.

The donuts are OK. Nothing too special. I have been here multiple times and here are the ones I like: 

Maple bacon: tastes good, if you are into things like that 
Voodoo doll:is a good one for people who like raspberry filling
Triple chocolate penetration: for the chocolate lovers
Cock-n-balls: which is and should be used for bachelor and bachelorette parties alike

Overall it is a predictable place which is part of the external image of Portland, so is usually part of the food pilgrimage that people make to Portland, and there is nothin bad about it. I just think that there are better donut places that are doing some nice experiments with donuts that seem more attractive and fun to me. 

All said and done. This is the place to be at 2:30am after you are done partying and drinking, and now want to eat something. These donuts taste heavenly then ;)

What can I say - Voodoo donuts are good - and worth a visit while you are in Porltand.  Are they the best thing I've had, not really - but a good option nonetheless.  The Bacon Maple Bar,  Dirt & Old Dirty Bastard are all good to try -  sweet as hell - but definitely worthy taste testers (Tip: I'd split a nut with a friend - as they might be a little too much to handle all at once)  The signature voodoo donut man complete with a pretzel needle stabbed to the heart is freakin awesome!  I'd make a pit stop to stumptown down the street for a nice cup of Joe to complete your experience.  The one thing i do wish for is some freshly baked (hot donuts..) I wish they had some of this --  most of their options have a ton of frosting and toppings that you can't really have it hot out of the oven)  Either way, Voodoo has such a Portland vibe that you HAVE to come here when you are in town...

Look at all my reviews, I rarely give bad reviews... but this one is bad. I agree that this place is just hype. I imagine that they used to be the leading innovating imagineers of the donut industry, but everyone caught up and they're still hanging back. I don't imagine that this review could even do any harm though because the name 'Voodoo Doughnut' is already closely associated with anything Portland. There's a whole bunch of spinning donuts in the glass case and it can get overwhelming, but i think the best one I got was the pink donut and the blueberry filled one. These ones were the only ones of the 6 that were somewhat moist (well.... one of them had filling, so does that one even count?). Anywayssssss, I've had way better donuts back home that costed 1/2 the price of these. These donuts are super dry, I don't know what the hype is.

This place is  a DIVE. I've never said that about a bakery before but that's exactly what it is. However...  Puffy, delicious, gooey pastry? Check! Mediocre service? Check! Conveniently located? Check! Will I come back? Check!

Used to love this place. What's good? The doughnuts of course! The selection is really great and the flavors are really good. I always get the ODB or the bacon maple bar. My issue? Omg it's so busy (the location on Davis is better), and the employees are kind of jerks. Went there with my 5 year old. She was having a hard time choosing with all the different kinds and one of the employees told me to hurry up. Haven't been back since.

"You must go to Voodoo Doughnuts when in Portland"!    

"Voodoo Donuts are amazing"

That's what I heard from a few people, aside from all the reviews I've read.   
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/voodoo-doughnut-portland?select=fsdnsh5IiFJHxYT0nVOUjQ#fxuRMqqGiJdg2lH6-8fKxA

Well... I drive by and once I saw the 50 or so people waiting in line outside the door, I said "Oh, hell no!"    

I decided to park anyway and walk across the street, just to take a quick look inside the door, "since I was there".  I then got back in my car and drove to their other location, Voodoo Doughnut Too.   http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/voodoo-doughnut-portland?select=fsdnsh5IiFJHxYT0nVOUjQ#HXXZ-EzxFpUtR9ER2YcePA  and 

Please see my review for # too.....
http://www.yelp.com/biz/voodoo-doughnut-too-portland

I went to Voodoo because of the hype, since it's our first time in Portland I decided to try it.  We got a dozen that we picked on our own and it came out $26.  There is four of us so each one of us got to try a quarter or each type of donuts.  They are so much icing and it is SO sweet.  I tried 5 pieces and I can not say those are good donuts.  

On the other hand I tried Blue Star Donuts, they are SO GOOD....save your money and go there instead.

Come on.  This place is really what Portland is putting out to the world?  Sure, a donut in the shape of a voodoo doll, another in the shape of a penis, yeah those are all fun.  But worth an hour standing in line in one of the worst neighborhoods in Portland, right next to a porn theater and a strip club and across Burnside from a lot of transient hotels, shelters, and halfway houses?  

I continually fail to see the appeal.  

And don't get me started on the eastside location.  They took a fast food joint, threw a bunch of half-broken chairs at it, and failed to clean the floors forever.  That's a place where I want to spend a bunch of time.  

There are better donuts in Portland, tourists.  Go find them.

I've had wayyyyyyy better donuts but like to swing by here whenever I have someone new in town to show them the "weird" part of Keeping Portland Weird!

The donut itself, it's the whimsical toppings that make it worth visiting & buying some cool paraphernalia. The taste and the lightness of the donut, meh, leaves much to be desired!

Definitely a must do as a Portland institution, more for the ambience than for the flavors! But you gotta grab yourself a Pink Box, when you're in PDX!

I was really excited to eat Voodo Doughnuts as I've heard so much about it (good and bad) before coming to Portland. Sadly, I left a little disappointed and with a sugar coated throat. I came at around 8pm on a weekend and there was a long line out the door. Although there's a lot of people in front of you, it moves fast. 

The decor outside and in is very unique. I really enjoyed how the walls are sparkly haha! The interior is quite loud in decor and sound. It honestly gave me a little headache. I ordered the voodoo doll and this nutty one that I forget the name of. In appearance, both donuts are really cute and instagram worthy! The taste however, were both mediocre. The first two bits were very good but after a while, they were all overly sweet. Also I didn't particularly like the jam in the voodoo donut but I'm also not a huge jam fan. 

Voodo Doughnuts was okay but I don't think I'll be back.

3 1/2 stars. I would actually probably round up 4 stars for my personal experience- we went a little after 1 am and the line wasn't insane which made the experience better sure. I don't think waiting longer than 30-40 minutes would be worth it though (in my opinion-I'm side people would disagree). 

The donuts are actually super reasonably priced which was a pleasant surprise given the hype. Taste wise I was a bit disappointed as a lot of them, especially the fruit ones, tasted artificial and overly sweet. They definitely had some interesting options but I have had better donuts at many other places. The best donut I had was probably the maple bacon donut but overall, these were crazy sweet (in an artificial/not good way) and just okay. If you wait for 15 minutes or less, maybe it is worth coming here just to say you did. But anything longer is definitely not worth it.
Had to stop and get our doughnuts for dessert.  Fresh and tasty!  Line to order was not long in the afternoon when we visited.

We heard we had to try Voodo on our short trip to Portland. So, we went on Saturday afternoon. The line was long, but moved quickly. The donuts were nothing special AT ALL. If I had to pick my favorite of the ones I tried it would be the Portland Cream. I much prefer other donuts even Krispy Kreme's are better. 
We won't be going back.

A Haiku Review of Voodoo Donut:

Lets all stand in line. 
For a phallic shaped donut. 
A place for tourists.
Donuts were ok. They didn't live up to the hype. If anyone is visiting So Cal I would recommend Peterson Donuts in Escondido.

Hey, it's riddle time! "How can you spot a tourist leaving Portland at PDX?"
Answer: "He's the one holding the pink box!" (Insert rimshot here)

Ok, maybe that's not so funny (especially if you the one holding the pink box) but we've all seen it right? Those poor souls who were somehow convinced by friends or family that the donuts at Voodoo were so transcendent that they just HAD to bring one of those cumbersome boxes home as one of their carry-ons. 

I get it - the first time you go there, there is some general amusement over their playfully-named     (crass?) risque confections. But that amusement wears off in far less time than it took standing in line. Because once you bite into the donut, you realize: "Huh, that's it?" Yes, they get points for creativity on presentation, but they fall short in where it really matters: how their donuts actually taste. At best, they are just ok, and at worst they taste stale and old - as if someone spent took a lot of time decorating the donuts and they don't want them to go to waste. 

If you are in Portland for the first time and want to check the box on a "quintessential Portland experience," (Don't forget to post your pics on Facebook!!) then go ahead and wait in line at Voodoo. If you actually want to eat an amazing donut, then skip this tourist joint and head over to Blue Star.

(No, I don't work at Blue Star. I just really like donuts. I have a belly to prove it.)

Enjoy!!
Was disapoointed.  Most choices sokd out by the time i got there.  Guess thats a good problem to have?

If you want interesting looking donuts, Voodoo might be worth checking out.. especially the original location in Portland.
But if you want to eat GOOD donuts, I would skip.

We came here to get a couple donuts, including the 'cock and balls' donut, for my sister's bachelorette. Let's just say, it was fun for the 'gram (and boomerangs) but we didn't even end up eating the entire thing (it's HUGE). We got some others- the hibiscus, graham slam, bacon maple bar, old dirty bastard... all in all, they just tasted like regular donuts but SUPER sweet. Maybe I also didn't enjoy them because in general, I like cake doughnuts better? We didn't even end up eating them all.

I definitely liked Blue Star and Pip's better, but now I can finally say I've been to Voo doo and confirm that it's overrated.
I don't understand all the hype. NOT the greatest doughnuts in town by far. Some are just disgusting. Building in NE seems quite run down and dirty inside.

3.5 stars ... this is one of several locations of the famed donut shop in Portland with a selection of hilariously named cake or yeast raised donuts.

We had to pass a couple of strip bars and Pizza Slut before we saw the bright pink neon sign which had attracted long lines even in the cold rain.

Once inside, the shop is pretty small with memorabilia decorating the walls. The donuts slowly turn in their glass cases while everyone ogled their colorful shapes and names.

The wait staff were busy as heck since the shop is 24/7, but they still were friendly and nice. That made the experience since it's overwhelming to be faced with so many donut choices.

To make it easier, there is a laminated menu at checkout so you can pick while the staff run to get the donuts.

I ordered 5 donuts for about $14. The donuts were placed in the iconic pink box which I saw a lot of people bring back on my returning flight. 

Is it better than any other donut? It was good but I think flavor profiles were fairly common with other donut shops, though the clever names were what made them distinctive. 

Must say that the donuts stayed pretty good without refrigeration for 2 days. Maybe because Portland is so cold? I dunno but they held up well. Check em out!
I think it's more a destination than a good donut place. There are many other doughnut places in Portland that sell way better doughnuts, but they are not Voodoo.
Overpriced, overhyped, stale donuts served by rude employees.  No thanks!

DO Come if:
1. It's your first time to Portland 
2. You want to be at an iconic place/landmark in Portland and get a proper Portland experience
3. You want to see what the hype is all about
4. You want to see interesting looking, cheap but so-so donuts (most donuts I tried there were simply sweet  and taste one dimensional somehow)

DON'T come if:
1. It's your second time or 253rd time visiting Portland
2. You are tired of the hype 
3. You have slight aversion waiting in line (although the line is quick)
4. You value quality over anything else. Do yourself a favor and visit nearby Blue Star Donuts instead
5. You do not want to transact in Cash. CASH ONLY!

my donut was dry and gave me a stomach ache.  

go ahead and follow other yelpers' insistence that you go to this place for the experience. you know, the experience of waiting in line  for 15 mins outside of a shop the size of shoebox for mediocre, overpriced donuts.

This is a great tourist attraction. The doughnuts are fun and funny and embody the Portland spirit. If you go be prepared to wait in line. They work fast but it's still very popular. If you are going just becuse you want good tasting doughnuts this isn't the BEST FLAVOR around. You go for the experience and the flair. Not for the actual food.

There's no way this horrible company could make a donut good enough to justify treating their employees like garbage. I guarantee you can find better mom and pop donut shops around town to find your tasty treats.

For all the hype around voodoo donuts, I was a little disappointed. The donuts were all really sugary and made me feel a little sick after. I guess you could say that's what a donut is supposed to be, but I didn't think there was a ton of creativity in the donuts. 

The location was right near the waterfront, but there wasn't really anything else going on in the few blocks surrounding it. The line was about 10 minutes long to order. They took credit cards for the one donut I ordered. Definitely a big tourist thing. Glad to have said I went.

If the length is daunting, see the "Too Long; Didn't Read" segment below :3 

I hate feeling like a tourist when I visit new cities. Everyone knows about Voodoo Doughnuts, and the only reason we actually stopped in was because: 
A. We ended up right down the street,   
B. The line was unusually short, and 
C. To say that we did it, and tried it. 

I wouldn't say I'm a donut person. I have about 1.25 every year or so. So I thought this would be the perfect time to get that "1" part of the donut in, to almost reach my quota for the year. 

Here are my thoughts about voodoo:

-The line is apparently very long, and it's only once you reach the front door that you see the sign that they take "Cash Only". Maybe this is a well known thing, but it was unknown to my friend and me, so thankfully he had some cash to pay. I feel like this is something that could be advertised, or said earlier.... while you're waiting in line. 

-I feel like it would be beneficial if there were a menu along the side of the building where everyone has to stand at one point.  There is not nearly enough time to get in through the door, and look at the menu to decide what you want before you're at the register.    Make the infamous long line exciting! Like a Disneyland ride! Give me stuff to read and look at, and pictures/sayings/insights to enhance my cravings for donuts!   Otherwise, once you make it to the inside of the building, it's extremely overwhelming trying to look at the very clustered menu, or the endlessly spinning racks of donuts... I suggest not even trying to understand the menu. Get an idea of a donut you want from the spinning racks. 

-The donuts are a lot cheaper than you imagine!! I was seriously thinking one would be close to $5 or so, but the majority are in the 1-2 $ range, with even some .95 ones. That's awesome! But don't get too crazy with buying a dozen donuts until you read my next point...

-These donuts are [underlined, bolded and italicized:] EXTREMELY SWEET. We decided to get 2 of them to try different options [We got the Chuckles, and the Dirty Ol' Bastard], and we pulled them into halves. I couldn't even finish mine. I was so sugar shocked it wasn't funny.
