I felt the sugar all day in my back and my kidneys, and vowed never to consume sugars again [ha, like that lasted.] I suggest getting 1 donut and splitting it with a loved one. Or even someone you don't like. Feel good knowing that they will be just as uncomfortable and zapped with sugar as you are. 

-Voodoo is apparently open 24 hours a day... but it sounds like it's NOT a place you want to be around when it gets dark. When we asked the cashier if they had a plastic knife to cut our donuts in half, she replied saying that they do have have anything that can be made into a weapon, because it's a sketchy/dangerous part of town at night. So keep that in mind, wary travelers! Do not make late night donut runs, Portland stoners!

Overall, at the end of the day, a donut is a doughnut. [Doughnut is a donut]. They had some creative and fun looking ones, but I do not think this will ever be a place I visit again. It was yummy, but it left me feeling so icky inside. I WAS sugar.  I mean, do it to do it. Because really... who can say no to a nicely priced donut?

TL;DR:
Voodoo Doughnuts is known for their creative donuts and infamously long lines. Make sure you have cash in yo' wallet if you're hoping to get anything once you make it through the threshold. Decide what you want by looking at the spinning racks - don't waste your precious time with the very clustered, but fun-donut name menu.  The donuts will course so much sugar in your veins you'll wonder if you'll ever feel human again. Split one with someone, unless you really believe you can handle it, or if you get off on sugar shock. You do you, but you've been warned. Visit during daylight hours. No plastic knives. The pigeons don't like the donut icing. This place is probs better suited for NOLA.

If I could give them 0 stars I would.

I can't believe that they can stay in business when their products are crap, their location smells of urine and warm beer, and their staff is not actually there to serve the public.

What, I ask, is the attraction?

I could look past the obvious things like toilet bowl flavored flooring, and staff that would prefer I go away, if the food product was worth discussing.

Show me a passionate person making passionate food and I'll beat a path to their door.  This place does not qualify.

This place is just a novelty that caters to a part of the brain that I don't seem to have :(

Nasty...

Ostensibly this place is a landmark that is not to be missed.

Went there at about 6:15 one Saturday morning in July. Yes, they have some interesting selections, but not much else to recommend. The area around it is, how should I put it? Dicey. Definitely a place you want to go in knowing what you want, and not to hang around in.

On the other hand, it is a spot to go to in what is something of a culinary desert, although you really don't have to go too far to find an array of better options.

I came here twice on a trip to Portland. The entire 8 days I was in town there was always a line for this place... after being there two times I can tell you that the lines are not worth it. The first time I went, we got a variety box, and that was actually pretty decent, but nothing over the top. But there was some cool donuts in there like cookies and cream, and ones with fruit loops, and M&Ms. The second time we went back was because we wanted to try the maple bacon bar. I have to say this was really disappointing. It was a bar shaped doughnut with a maple glaze and one strip of bacon just slapped on top. Since having this doughnut, I have had at least 4 different maple bacon donuts and all of those donuts blew this one out of the water. Badly. They really should have at least chopped the bacon into pieces to spread out the saltiness. So that each bite you'd be getting the contrast of the sweet glaze and the salty bacon. I still say if you are in town you should go here for novelties sake, but it's not as great as you'd expect.

Horrible service , it's just a tourist thing , doughnuts aren't good , they look cool but they don't taste good at all, after being in line for 40 minutes and spending more than $80.00 i took a few steps forward then turned around and ask if if I could get a coffee they said " you need to go back to the line , excuse me  can you please move with your boxes out of my way" that was the worst experience ever !!!

The problems lie in the fact that they rely too much on gimmicks and cheap ingredients (artificial flavors, artificial colors, etc). The jam in the voodoo donut tastes like smucker's jam or some other generic cheap jelly. The same can be said about all the flavors, frostings, fillings, etc. Sometimes it works, sometimes it doesn't. Don't get me wrong though, it's fresh, yummy and well made. But it's just not worth the price, wait time, and the hype. Do not eat these donuts if you dislike artificial flavors. I don't think they use real food ingredients (fruits, etc) in their flavorings. If they do, I can't even tell. I guess this is something kids would enjoy more than adults!

Out of the dozen, I did enjoy grape ape, captain crunch and the homer (for the nostalgic old school strawberry milkshake flavor). Personally it was worth trying once and never again!

Atmosphere was cute. My school days donut was given to me free of charge because it was the last one which was nice. It had no flavor and I tossed it after 2 bites. Not good at all.
Oh well.

Edited to say I don't wanna knock the place or anything. Just not my preference on donuts!

Since I was in Portland, I just had to see what the big Voodoo donut fuss was all about. In a nutshell: colorful fun shaped and cleverly topped donuts, glittered bricks, neon lights, fun adornments here and there, and a long line waiting to get in. The taste and texture of the donuts were not notable. To me it was a been there, done that, and probably won't do it again kind of thing.
Pretty over-rated as far as "why would I stand in line for hours to get donuts?" . . . but good donuts!

Cool vibes. Long line. Pretty meh doughnuts.
Basically it's a middle of the road kind of doughnut, but let's be real: we're not here for the doughnuts. 

We go because they're on the foodie map now, the name is recognized by most people you know & it looks cool. Overall we're mainly here for the gram whilst getting a pretty okay doughnut or two. 

This is in no way a complaint, just being honest. Plus, the idea behind the Voodoo Doughnut and the shop itself is neat.

But if you're here to get an amazing tasting doughnut that'll blow your mind, your waiting in the wrong line here.

This is a standard donut shop here in Portland.  Its marketed as a must see but it is definitely overhyped.  Donuts taste like any other regular donut and overpriced.  The voodoo doll donut has a nasty raspberry filling in it FYI.  Blue Star Donuts were way better.

Satanic music plays in there, and there are 'evil spirits' present in those tacky, frightening photographs and paintings on the walls above the serving area.

Avoid this place - " Voodoo" is not a joke - the name itself  refers to a "Satanic Religious Practice" done in Haiti and Africa.

And here, in "everything goes and who doesn't really believe in ANYTHING ANYMORE AMERICA", we make "voodoo" into a BIG JOKE  . . . down to the point of a nowhere "donut shop" in a poor and rundown neighborhood (being gentrified to the point where this outlet will undoubtly be closed down . . . to make way for more offices and trendy restaurants . . . perhaps yet another Starbuck's. Just wait).

This place has 'evil in it'.  Trust me.  The loud music alone tells you "something is very wrong in there ".

Had to visit the infamous Voodoo Doughnut while in Portland. Went on a Sunday night and the line was still out the door. Parking there was nonexistent..haha so 2 of us hopped out while the other two drove in search of the closest parking spot. 

While the line was out the door, the door is to remain closed until you and your party can fit inside voodoo...understand? Oh and just a head's up, you may also come across some random homeless people in the vicinity. Now that the formalities have been said..off to the good stuff...them donuts, son!

Tried a few:
Bacon Maple Bar - My fave of the bunch! Was a bit skeptical bc the 2 strips of bacon were just slapped on there...but my oh my - the tasty bacon + the maple glaze = complete and utter foodgasm! THE perfect blend of sweet & salty. While the maple bacon doughnut over at Blue Star was far more appealing to the eye, the Bacon Maple Bar from Voodoo was by far much tastier. 

Old Dirty Bastard - had to get it out of respect for it's namesake! A few bites were quite tasty..but after awhile too sweet for this fan.

Captain my Captain - aka the Captain Crunch doughnut. Thought this would be way to sweet..but mmm delicious. Loved the crunch from the cereal. Perfect with a nice cup of coffee!

Triple Chocolate Penetration - aka the Cocoa Puffs doughnut. Ehhh..maybe we had a bad batch..but the cocoa puffs tasted a bit stale on ours. Pass.

Portland Cream - yum! Is it blasphemy to say this is just like a Boston Cream doughnut? Hehe whatever you want to call it, loved the bavarian cream filling!

There's a little revolving case that shows most of the doughnuts available if you haven't seen all the gazillion pics on Yelp. Oh and the most important thing to note: CASH ONLY folks! In order to taste that ever so delectable Bacon Maple Bar, bring that cash with ya!!

Way over hyped

**CASH ONLY** 

I should have listen to the reviews and not come here, but I wanted to come just because I wanted to visited the iconic shops in Portland and see if this place is really that bad...it was :( 

Came here on a Friday afternoon, no line (score!). Although it made us have to think fast on what kind of donuts we should get though. Also our server was a bit rude and unfriendly which made the whole experience at Voodoo suck. Other than the service, the donuts was just as bad. 

Ordered the Old Dirty Bastard, Voodoo Doll, Portland Cream, and Maple Bacon Donuts. 
-Old Dirty Bastard: Too much going on in one donut. The Oreos were a bit stale, might have been out for a while
-Voodoo Doll: Also stale and wasn't a big fan on their berry filling 
-Portland Cream: Probably my favorite one, you can't mess up on a cream donut 
-Maple Bacon: Also a bit stale, only good part was the bacon 

If you are going to be one of the iconic donut shops in Portland, at least keep the donuts fresh.

I think this place was extremely overrated. 
We were told this is a place to go when in Portland, hence the trip all the way to this place after fiasco of finding a safe place to park our car. 
As expected at any sort of touristy/advertised site, there was a pretty long line up but i wouldn't say it took that long for us to actually get to the cashier, but given how disappointed we were after all, this kind of wait is not worth it - i'd rather save my time and get better donuts and go to krispy kreme. 

Three of us got four donuts - we tried to pick special ones that were not likely to be found at other typical donut places : voodoo doll, portland creme, dirt donut and m&m donut

First of all, portland creme donut, was nothing different from typical boston creme donut. 
Voodoo doll, was supposed to look like a voodoo doll but we wouldn't have guessed it looks like a voodoo doll if it wasn't named as that. We didn't even get to finish the other two, because the they had no flavour but just sugar sugar sugar. 
On top of these, the aesthetics of these donuts weren't even good. They all looked messy and honestly the place just looked like a hot mess with tourist trap decos. 

Maybe other flavoured donuts are better and more special, but based on my experience during this visit, i have no reason to return and probably won't go back.

Ok so not that impressed. This is more a slick pull-end marketing ploy than actual quality product. Acquaintance raved about it so I decided to give it a try and ordered a bunch from the selection. While the cutesy (slick) shtick factor was there (donuts in all shapes and colors etc etc), when it came to the quality of the product, there was nothing to rave about. Chocolate (covered or otherwise) didn't taste chocolaety enough, too much sugar to compensate for the lack of taste. Kind of like the horror of supermarket, pre-packaged, big-food conglomerate offerings.  I'd avoid it, unless you really have a hankering to take an instagram of a phallic shaped donuts in your mouth etc etc. Been there , done that .. too "2000 and late" in my opinion

One star, because they are open and catering to the public during pandemic with safety procedures in place. Minus 2 stars because they didn't have any gluten-free options in the store when I went to and they claim to have gluten-free donuts. I really wanted to try them.
The place is neat and it was fun to go see it but I got a maple bar with bacon and it tasted really stale...nothing special these donuts except the place is different from you everyday place

Portland eclectic and I'm giving them 3 stars for ambiance and the staff.  The donut we purchased was hardly a 1 star...it was the most stale and flavorless donut I have ever eaten.  It was an old fashioned maple glazed donut.  The line was long but moved quickly.  I likely wouldn't return. This is my second visit, and the first visit was incredibly slow but had much better quality of donuts.  Pass unless you simply want Portland keeping it weird.

Voodoo donuts.  I applaud Voodoo donuts for being the first "Instagram-pretty" donut place. But like other donut places which are all looks, they have zero taste & flavor.

I was extremely disappointed in my experience here.  I had the maple bacon, captian crunch, and oreo donut.  They all tasted OK.  The maple bacon was OK but the remaining 2 were awful; I took a few bites and didn't even eat the rest. The base of the glazed donut was really lacking in flavor.  In addition, I tried eating the donuts the next day and they tasted awful.  I've had donuts in California and they taste good for a few days; I know that's not something to brag about but it's something to consider.

Maybe I'm spoiled but California donuts near my house were 10x better.

PROS:
-Beautiful presentation.  Instagram worthy pictures.

CONS:
-Prices are actually decent; most donuts run $1.50-$2 each.   I was expecting "California Instagram" donuts at $3 each.
-Donuts taste pretty bad.  They also don't survive the "test of time" and taste disgusting the next day.
-Menu is confusing and not detailed at all.  They list the donut name (which is usually something cool/witty) but they don't tell you what it is / what's inside it.  
-Expect long wait times.
-Lots of homeless around the area.


TIPS:
-Cash only.

Got to the front of the line and found out it was cash only ATM inside was broken ATM across the street is broken went into a gas station no cash back and their ATM was broken... are you serious.

Update: they now have card machines! Donuts were alright but I still don't know what the hype is about!
Donuts are good, but not anything overly special.  Worth a stop for the novelty one time, but not if the line is long.

Dare I say it? Even within Portland, there are better doughnuts to be had... DDOH! NUTS!!!

I may be bringing down some bad juju on me for saying this, but Voodoo Doughnuts is an overhyped tourist trap. Yes, the donuts look creative and cute, but taste-wise, there is nothing special here that your local Southeast-Asian-owned doughnut shop most likely named Happy Donut cannot duplicate.

The original location is in what was the old Chinatown, steps from the waterfront and the Willamette River. After stopping by the Portland Saturday Market a block over, we noticed tourist after tourist carrying around those Pepto Bismol pink boxes. So, the wife and I finally caved and reluctantly decided to try Voodoo. 

Surprisingly, the line moves pretty quickly and the inside of the store is decorated with a ton of cool stuff. Also, the workers were really nice. Sadly, that is where the positive experiences ended. 

We got the Voodoo Doll, The Homer, and the Bacon Maple Bar. The Voodoo Doll is definitely Insta-worthy. However, the raspberry jelly was way too sweet and is probably what is going to kill you more than the pretzel stake. The Homer, named after Homer Simpson, is a doughnut with strawberry frosting and sprinkles that was alright. And, the Bacon Maple Bar was good, but it's something that I've had at other doughnut shops. 

After sharing three diabetes-inducing donuts, the wife and I immediately had to eat the yuzu ramen next door even though we weren't even hungry. You see, we needed to balance all that sugar with some soup. 

At the end of the day, Voodoo appears to be magical for some since they have expanded across America from Hollywood to Austin, Denver to Orlando. But for me, I prefer doughnuts that are not so sugary.

You come here for the cute designs on the donuts but not necessarily for the taste of the donuts. My friend said their famous donut was the voodoo person donut with the raspberry jelly inside. We got one and it was gross. Also got the old dirty bastard with oreos and peanut butter.. meh. I think it's only worth coming back here if you have kids and they want to ooh and ahhh over all the cool and fun designs and flavors moving in the cool glass cylinder display. Kids won't know that they taste bad.. will they? Otherwise, just come here and take cute pics of the cute donuts and you're done. Don't waste your calories.
Plus while waiting in line, you get to hang out with the homeless/travelers/lazy people.

This is what happens when a local business blows up nationally :( I remember Voodoo a while ago before they were a big chain.  It's now just the variety and convenience that people flock to.  There's nothing special about this place anymore :( 

Entirely too sweet, and the actual doughnut tastes flat. 

Blue Star doughnuts is a lot better!  Trust me, save your time waiting in a long crazy line....skip this place!

OVERRATTED! The only thing this place has going for itself is that they've created something different and weird compared to the typical donut. So if you want a dry rough donut this would be the place to go. My family and I are major donut lovers! And I'd have to say Heavenly Donuts are 100x's better!
Fun place, fun experience.  The donuts were good but not exceptional.  I think everyone should do it at least once

Their donuts are interesting to look at but I don't care for the taste of their donuts. The reason I give three stars though is because they have awesome fritters!!!!! It's like an unknown secret LOL! I love the Memphis mafia fritter and the "ain't that a peach fritter.

I just don't understand the hype behind this place. The lines are usually long, the donuts are just too sugary sweet, and the dough itself... meh.

it's one of those places where it's a neat idea to have a "Dirty old bastard" but i won't go outta my way for one. There are better donuts places in Portland. (Pip's, Blue star, Byte Labs when it was around, etc)

If someone offered me a donut, I wouldnt turn it down but i just don't understand the hype, and I think most Locals would agree with me. It's just a tourist trap..
The best part is the people watching and the nice workers.. the doughnuts are not that great really.. below average but it's worth checking out this strange cultural phenomena

I love the layout of this place. They've got stained glass adorning the windows, donut light fixtures, and brightly painted walls. 

The prep area is filled with donuts waiting to be bagged and the display cases are  merry-go-rounds of funky doughnuts.there are at least two people taking orders so the wrap-around-the-building line moves at a steady pace. 

Ordered the bacon maple glazed bar and was nicely surprised by the fluffy yet dense texture of the dough. The bacon added a nice salty bite to the maple glaze. I was fearful of a syrupy flavor but the maple  was just a richer version of the original glaze.

Worst experience of my life and terrible service. I was pretty sure they didn't have gluten free donuts when I asked the cashier to confirm they told us the bottom row (which clearly says VEGAN) was gluten free. I asked THREE times and the woman continued to say that yes, those were gluten free (which is not the same thing as vegan).

I have an allergy and was up vomiting...when I checked the website and then called the manager I was disappointed with their response. He said that some of the new cashiers were new and in training and that he would let her know. He apologized but I expected at least a refund.

NEVER going there again and will advise all other guests and out of towners to never go there.

I'll also add - way over-hyped, too long of a line and the taste is not even that great! Kyra's are a million times better.

Multiple people recommended VooDoo on my first trip out to Portland, but I have to say I wasn't the biggest fan. I had the the Oreo donut and it just tasted kinda like a basic donut? Definitely get a different flavor (no fruit loops or Oreo donuts) when you come and maybe you'll have a better experience than I ddI.
Overrated.  We stopped on Friday morning, only a few people in line.  Staff was great but the donuts are nothing special.

Donuts are mediocre at best.  Way too sweet and just not very good.

Nice for them that they got on TV and found success as a tourist trap, but a crappy donut is still a crappy donut, regardless of how it's shaped, what gets dumped on top of it, or what color the box is.

Highlights:
- Open 24 hours, but still frequently a line
- Show off to all your friends on social media where you're at and what you're up to
- The donuts are no good...

I get it, I get it. It's a Portland staple that's known for their more edgy donuts and decor. They put things on it that you wouldn't typically expect... at least back in 2012. These days, even Krispy Kreme is putting oreos on their donuts, and boy does Voodoo pale in comparison to even the most basic of chains.

The donut quality is incredibly mediocre. If you are coming for a snack, for a dessert, you will be disappointed if you've ever had a good, fresh donut. Come take your pictures with or without a donut and that's the entire extent to which this place provides value.

A word to the wise: don't visit Voodoo Doughnuts well past midnight after you left the raucous wedding reception you were at. Your tastebuds will not thank you necessarily for the remnants for sale at the shop, waiting to be packed into a bright pink box with Baron Samedi striding about in all his inky glory. I should've sacrificed a Timbit to him first, shouldn't I? 

I joined a queue headed out the door on a rainy Portland night, which I'm no stranger to being from "big" Vancouver, Canada. February so often brings these drizzly nights where streetlights smear into a mash of neon orange on anthracite facades. I dutifully fed the ATM and received cash to cover a box of doughnuts, rather than pick just two or three. Excess is the rule here, not the exception. Considering I was flying out in seven hours, I suppose the doughnuts were intended to tide me over to the airport and through my flight back to Chicago. My perceptions were clouded by the multiple recommendations to get a maple bacon doughnut, because of its sinful excellence and the fact I am, as forementioned, Canadian. I don't care for bacon much but there is a degree of cultural expectation I have to live up to.

The shuffling line of zombies seeking sugary sustenance proceeded forward under laughing eyes of dim spectres. The shop plays up its vodoun origins to the hilt, and peeling photographs and magazine articles add just a lurid touch. You are entering an institution and you will not put a bird on it, you will wring a bird for it, if you must. I was eagerly anticipating a host of changing flavours, often predicated upon how bizarre the combination might be -- let's put tang with fruit loops on a chocolate doughnut; a kruller with hot sauce, chipotle, ground up Oreos, and simple syrup anyone? By the time I got through the queue, I was half-dead myself and ready to eat the suppurating tattooed arm of a hipster, if it came to it.

I did get my maple bacon. The list of twenty some-odd flavours I wanted to try were gone. Each successive person ambling to the counter depleted the remnants and left me with the day's less desirable choices. Gone was ODB. Gone was a Dubble Bubble. One Memphis Mafia remained, one Captain my Captain, and NO Voodoo Dolls. I could've slapped down the two people in front of me who grabbed the last cock and balls, and proceeded to order thirty doughnuts from the stock. You could hear the sighs and growls in a chorus, damning their rudeness. People, it's late, they're not making any more, and the rest of us are waiting in the cold, cloying showers for our chance at a doughnut opportunity. Stop being a complete, self-interested douche. If you live here, you can come back tomorrow. Some of us can't. May Legba curse you with baggy jeans and cardigans! 

The dozen doughnuts I had were as much candy as they were pastry products. Friends and I departing on the outbound flight in the morning decided to pick and choose with some assistance from the menu guide and the employee, and we ended up snarfing pieces from each at our liberty like kids set loose in Willy Wonka's labs. Fruit loops on blue tang frosting, orange shot Rice Krispie treat jumble? First rotted my teeth, the second redeemed my tongue. There wasn't one except for the maple bacon bar, which I scored one of the second to last of, that I consumed in full because post-wedding reception isn't the best time to be Voodooing it up. For large part, they're incredibly sweet or very cakey, and best to appeal to people with a sweet tooth. I am not the sort who purrs at the sound of chocolate. 

Mistaken information from Portland International Airport suggested that we wouldn't be able to take our doughnuts with us on the plane, so I and my friend scarfed as many as we could and cursed fate. We abandoned our doughnuts in the trash, only to see at least four boxes on the flight back to Chicago. Needless to say, I was not impressed by that.

Voodoo's drawbacks are obvious. Long lines and limited stock reap havoc for when you show up at peak hours, as I apparently did. Spending thirty minutes or more in a slow-moving line while taunted by the chalkboard menu knowing you aren't going to get to see at least half of them doesn't earn a five star rating from me. Combinations of flavours get downright nauseating for how sweet some of them are; avoid the ones with breakfast cereals and powdered juice mixes where possible. I also wish some of their sizes were smaller because this is too much doughnut for a sitting, though I suspect the price makes them meant to be shared.
Cute but for tourists, over priced and super long lines.  Lots of hype and for what?  A maple bar with bacon on it.  A local resident!

We stopped in at Voodoo in Old Town because we were in Portland for vacation and it's just one of the things you do in PDX. Immediately in the door we weren't greeted at all, but we're instead told to "get out of the way" by the gruff tall goth lady behind the counter. After scooting over a bit we made our best attempt at figuring out what made each donut different, but with no descriptions and no help from the staff, we had to basically make blind decisions based solely on the visuals and the names of the donuts. The guy at our register was nice enough but the goth lady was so gruff and impatient that it ruined the whole experience. And to top it all off, the donuts were nothing special, relying more on shock and awe with their decorations than actually interesting and inventive dough ingredients and flavors.

I wish Hermione Granger, actually Emma Watson, would cast a love spell on me. However, for some reason Voodoo Doughnut conjured up something in her stead. Their bewitching fried dough are hauntingly beautiful and mad-scientist creative. Delicious and sweet on your lips but devastating to your hips. 

My friends and I tried a smorgasbord of their pastries. Although we enjoyed a few bites of each doughnut, the sweet and heavy tastes weighed too much on our buds and butts. I would suggest ordering different items and then share them with your friends, family style. We went on an off peak breakfast hour, so we did not have to wait in line.

Recently moved to the area, my baby sister and her boyfriend came to visit, with so many places closed due to the pandemic and the election we were happy to see Voodoo was open. Myself and my sisters boyfriend had both been before, but it had been a few years for both of us so we didn't really know the low down or how things worked! We waited in a pretty short line and then were directed to window 3. We walked in and were half ass greeted by the cashier. My sisters boyfriend knew he wanted the cock and balls so that was our first pick. I let the girl know we would be getting a dozen as I noticed a small sign in the register that showed pics of the donuts and had a price of $20 and $15! So we started picking out donuts we wanted to try and asked questions about them, never once did the girl explain how the dozens/prices for the dozens worked! She heard me several times say, keep going we're trying to get to 13 donuts! As we got to about 9 it seemed like we had a lot of donuts, so I asked her we're trying to get to 13 right, at that point she says "yeah only if your getting the ones shown on the picture"! Oh well besides the cock one we pretty much were, but she was ringing them up individually!! So at that point we decided to stop picking out donuts and get a total...$37 for a couple donuts!?!? Are you kidding me!?!? I would've definitely loved an explanation on how they sold the dozens and would've paid for the cock one separate from the dozen and would've gotten all of the donuts we picked out and more!! I think the cashiers should have to explain the dozens especially since it is such a touristy place to go! Not everyone has been there before and knows how it works!! I also got charged for a donut she didn't even put in our box! I remember seeing her ring it up though!! The donuts were good and fun, but I will not be bringing anyone back there knowing that they would just let you spend so much and never even explain or suggest the pre picked dozens!!

Not so hot...I was really excited to come here having seen Voodoo Doughnuts on TV and read about them online. Unfortunately the doughnuts were average at best. Definitely not worthy of national praise. The doughnuts themselves were indistinguishable from your standard Dunkin with some interesting toppings. I am not sure if they were the innovator of these toppings but at this point they are no longer unique since I have seen the same doughnuts at a dozen or so joints. The doughnuts themselves were heavy and ridiculously over sweet. They should be light and fluffy and should melt in your mouth. If you're a visitor to Portland as I was, I would definitely put this joint in the "skip" category. Locals seemed to agree when I told them my thoughts.

Typical donuts in funny shapes. That's about all that can be said about Voodoo Doughnuts. They were good, not great and I'll admit the different types were cute and definitely fun. Worth a visit but try to come by when it's not too busy. I refuse to stand in an excessively long line for these donuts.

Somehow, despite being pimped out by Chuck Pahlaniuk, Tony Bourdain, and every other pop culture maverick with a publisher or a TV show, VooDoo Doughnut maintains its indie cred.

From its location next to a seedy theatre to its in-your-face customers and employees, this isn't your cookie-cutter hipster joint outta Williamsburg or Silverlake or The Mission. This is the real deal.  Personified as a hipster, VooDoo Doughnut is a Pacific Northwest original, coming right at you with face tattoos, loud music, and maybe a little heroin problem.  It's brash, it's in your face, and all the while a bit cheeky and playful.

Take, for example, the Tex-Ass.  A "Texas-sized" doughnut reminiscent of...  a hemorrhoid donut.  Or the famous Cock n' Balls, shaped like -- well, DUH. Then you have the infamous VooDoo doll donut being pierced by pretzel sticks and bleeding jelly filling, followed by some Froot Loop covered monstrosity. And, of course, the piece de resistance, the doughnut that put Portland on the cable TV travel show radar:  The bacon maple bar.

This modern-day legend has earned its hipper-than-thou status on its don't-give-a-fuck creativity and attitude, the same attitude I'll express when I tell you this:

THESE. DOUGHNUTS. SUCK.

You can get as creative as you want. You can crumble up Oreos and drizzle on caramel and call it an Ol' Dirty Bastard. You can get yourself featured on TV shows on both the Food Network and the Travel Channel.  But you can't call yourself a goddamn doughnut shop if the base product isn't worth the bag it's served in.

Bless you for not being Krispy Kreme. Bless you for not being Dunkin' Donuts. But please, for the love of god, you should fry a better lump of pastry before you go apeshit customizing it.

If you like taking pictures of your food, trying anything at least once, extremely sweet desserts, and super soft (versus cakey) donuts, it's worth a visit.

Otherwise... eh.

We didn't wait that long (10-15 minutes, early afternoon on a rainy Monday). Service was fast and friendly, which is always a plus, and they now accept credit/debit.

Full disclosure: I don't have a huge sweet tooth, so this might be a preference thing. That being said, both donuts we ordered (Bacon Maple Bar + Oh Captain My Captain) were sickly sweet to the point where we didn't finish either one.

The Bacon Maple Bar was the better of the two. Despite being cold, the bacon was still relatively crispy. Its smokey and salty flavors also balanced out the otherwise overpowering maple frosting. Would have liked a better bacon-to-donut ratio, since the current layout covers ~2/3rds of the pastry.

On the other hand, the Oh Captain My Captain is pure sugar. Not the easiest to eat either... get ready to stab the roof of your mouth with cereal.

It's probably worth going once for the novelty, so try to go during off-hours and take some good pictures.

Come here for the experience (long lines, flashy signs, colorful sprinkles and cereal on deep fried dough with outlandish names). Gotta hand it to them for making a name for themselves and attracting hundreds and thousands of people over funky, but gross stale donuts.

That's all there is to this place. An attraction. Nothing more to it. At least I can say I checked this off our Portland list.
I don't get it. Mediocre donuts from a not-very-clean place served by not-very-clean people.  Don't see what all the hype is about.  The epitome of Portland hipsternism.

Nothing special. These donut places with all the cereal/cookie etc toppings are fun to go to but u take one bite and keel over in diabetic shot but hey-we all "do it for the gram" 

Yes come and experience it, have a good laugh, take your photo and mark it off the Portland must see list. 

The actual donut taste is lost on all the super rich extras and the staff was pretty rude but again, it's an experience so stop by but don't expect foodie orgasm here.
Poor customer service! Lately their donuts have been stale when we picked them up which makes no sense since they have so much traffic. Sadly disappointed with the service we received last few times.

My flight leaving Portland was at 4pm.

At 1pm I looked at my phone and made the hardest decision of my life -- make sure I get to the airport on time and miss out on the famous Voodoo doughnuts, or wait in the long line wrapping around the building at Voodoo and MAYBE be late for my flight.

Obviously I chose the doughnuts and got the Rapper's Delight (Eminem, Ol' Dirty Bastard, and the Maple Blazer Blunt) and a Captain My Captain. 

Oh my god. First off, I for some reason thought that the Rapper's Delight was ONE doughnut, not three. I ended up gorging myself on delicious doughnuts and boarding my plane (yes, I made it on time) in a delirious sugar high.

Like most famous "you've got to try it" places in big cities, I thought this place was a bit overrated. I've had better donuts at other places, maybe not with the same creative recipes and names, but still. Of all the donuts, I liked the Captain Crunch one the best. The maple donut was very plain, and the other two were far too sweet for me.

I'm glad I was able to check it out, but I probably won't be back.
Definitely try Voodoo at least once if you haven't already. They do have good donuts, but your mostly going for the novelty rather than out of this world donuts.
Very bad service; the staff are incredibly rude! The donuts are good but not THAT good. I think I'll just stick to the traditional mom and pop donut shops. Oh! And this place is not very clean!!

The a absolutely most vile and disgusting donuts anywhere. Lines outside waiting to get into a dirty interior where , clearly, the Cookie Monster vomited candy and god knows what else all over their baked goods. Why this place is so iconic is beyond me. I'm for BLUE STAR all the way.

I might not have gotten the right donut, I'll admit. I think I just got a basic raspberry filled donut I forget what it was called. But there was absolutely nothing special about it. If I was given the donut in a taste test I couldn't tell it from a donut from Walmart, a gas station, Voodoo donuts or any other nondescript donut. Maybe theres a certain donut you are supposed to get, but dont go here for high quality.  I will say that location on 3rd avenue is fun though, and the inside had some cool music and such so I def enjoyed myself late on a Friday night visiting Portland.

This place is down right nasty. It is literally a hole in the wall with a huge following of loyal customers. We recently visited Portland for the first time and intended on enjoying a donut here after reading about it in tourist mags. It was so dark and dingy and TINY with NO seating we walked out. It is a mystery why anyone comes here. The donuts must be great because the place is a DIVE.

The area this is located is so skeezy and the employees do not care about you. They seemed so bothered to be serving lowly tourists. I was so excited to get some donuts and get a cute pic from my vacation but we were basically shoed out of the store and when we were outside we were harassed by sketchy people hovering around the area. It's clear there was no thought in upper management to put this location, and were cashing in on the name. The area is so bad. If your are a tourist go to the other location in Portland or Colorado or just go to blue star donuts. So disappointed after a long walk and $15 to get a few good but not mind blowing donuts, and have a poor customer service experience. You are a TOURIST destination. Please work on making it as magical as all the blogs say it is.

As a big fan of the independent doughnut shop, I love love loved the concept of Voodoo and wanted to visit here for months and months before I actually did.  My friend's apple fritter was great, but sadly the Cap'n Crunch on my doughnut was kind of stale.  I was disappointed, but I think the awesomeness of the creations here makes up for one stale 'nut.  After all who can say no to Triple Chocolate Penetration, Maple Bacon Doughnuts, or the cream-filled Cock-n-Balls doughnut?  Not me.  I'll be back in May to give it another go.

Extra props for vegan doughnuts and the ability to officiate weddings in-store.  Not sure who'd be crazy enough, or crazy in love enough to do that, but it's still awesome.

When people talk about Portland they talk about Voodoo Donuts... "you gotta go!"  Each time I walked by the location I saw a line of people that extended down the sidewalk and around the corner and down that sidewalk...  one day, finally, I walk by and there's no line!  Hallelujah!  I head in and order 6 donuts... as a test... to see if they really know how to make a donut I order a plain cake donut, a double chocolate donut, and 4 wild and crazy creations.  The plain cake donut sucked - it was unevenly cooked and the exterior was not at all crisp.  Ditto for the double chocolate donut.  Now... the wild and crazy creations - if it had cereal on it, it was stale.  Think about it.  You're putting cereal on unremarkable frosting... the frosting's moisture destroys the cereal.  The magic is in the hole?  I think not.  The magic is in the remarkable job they've done with advertising.  The magic is in how unrefined the American pallet has become.

Grandma sure likes her sweets. Doughnuts. Ice cream. Butterscotch hard candies. The strawberry hard candies. 

Unfortunately, what this place lacks in taste, texture, and quality, they do not make make up for in creativity. 

I don't understand why the line is so long. I walk by and people and lined up. Also, the business is cash only - which just screams illegal food or other monkey business activity. But I don't judge, the economy is bad for people who don't have money. 

One thing I did appreciate was the chocolate milk. Brought me back to when I worked as a lunch lady. I would deliver alpenrose tiny milks to kindergartens classroom. 

My stupid grandson Steven got the cock in balls. Absolutely disgusting. Can't believe he paid money to eat a doughnut shaped like a *enis. It's okay because we accept him for who he is. Even though I grew up in a different time, I still have to adapt to the current times. Now, if only we could get those wild turkeys in congress follow suit. 

Goodnight.

~GRAM GRAMS 3rd~

Edit: here is a photo from about 6 years ago my stupid grandson sent me when he saw my review.

My daughter wanted only one thing from my trip to Portland - doughnuts from Voodoo Doughnuts. We luckily got there early enough in the morning that we only had to wait 30 minutes in line - by the time we left, it was at least 4 times as long. She LOVES doughnuts. Her review from bites of the 6 different kinds that we got was, "tastes like donuts" and "nothing extraordinary". We got a variety of the very popular ones. I don't eat sweets, so I can't comment, but both she and my son love sweets and both of them thought they were just OK. (And they were fresh when they got them - not much later.)

In the heart of downtown, everyone has heard about VooDoo Doughnuts. Let's face it, you have to go here to get the Portland experience. However, any true Portlander will tell you that for quality, Blue Star donuts is where the culinary donut exists. VooDoo is great for the ambience, with the glitter brick wall, bubblegum pink decor, and odd donuts with even odder toppings. Taste wise, we ordered 4, took bites out of each of them and then threw the rest away. Fluffy bread with heavy, sugary toppings. But when we went to Blue Star, we ordered 10! Just because the flavors sounded amazing and we were not disappointed. Not a single one went to waste. So keep this in mind when you go. VooDoo is for the experience, but I wouldn't really recommend the donuts on a normal basis.

Not as amazing as I hoped for all the hype. Blue star and tonalli's are both better in my opinion.  Service was pretty decent.  I'm sure it is probably somewhat annoying to deal with masses of tourists all day. I feel for them there...

Voodoo Doughnut is a Portland icon. When I tell my friends that I'll visit Portland, they would always ask me to grab some pastries at Voodoo Doughnut. The business was founded in 2003 by Kenneth "Cat Daddy" Pogson and Richard "Tres" Shannon, both Portland natives. The idea of starting their own doughnut shop came up when the two friends were tubing down the Sandy River one fateful day. At the time, there were only five doughnut shops in Portland. They weren't familiar with the doughnut industry, and so they had to travel to California to learn from doughnut masters who had about 100 years of doughnut-making experience. Fast forward to today, Voodoo Doughnut has become synonymous with Portland. The business knows how to keep Portland weird through its creative doughnut flavors. Voodoo also has locations in Eugene, Denver, Austin, and LA.

I don't have a strong opinion on whether or not it is worth the hype. The donuts aren't too shabby. In fact, I think their yeast donuts are fluffier and tastier than the average American doughnut. Definitely fresh. However, they are on the expensive side. I ordered the voodoo doll (raised yeast doughnut filled with raspberry jelly and topped with chocolate frosting and a pretzel stake). Lots of flavors to choose from (over 50)! For example, bacon maple bar, old dirty bastard, voodoo bubble, mango tango, etc.

A few other notes... Yes, you can pay using debit/credit cards. Nope, no gluten-free doughnuts. And yes, they have vegan options.

It basically is a tourist spot, so lines can get long. However, it goes by quickly. Will I come back? I think so! Gotta try the other flavors.
Overrated donuts for us tourists. Donuts were good, not the best. Not worth the long line in my opinion.

When the line goes to the corner, that is a ONE HOUR wait. We had a crying toddler and had to leave after a half hour. No doughnut could be worth this. Never again  until they get serious about selling food.

My wife dragged me down to Voodoo Donut. There modo is the "Magic Is In the Hole" It is here because of the novelty of this place. Apparently it's hyped up pretty good,. It is not in a good part of downtown, in fact it is down right seedy and there are a lot of homeless, beggars, hypes, drug addicts and basically dregs on the streets out here. Upon getting here which was around 8:00 PM there was a huge line down the block just to get in. There is no way I'm going to wait around in line out here for a donut, no matter how good or weird the donut. I have better things to do. The area has other bars and restaurants nearby but I would not hang out here for long.

This may be a misleading rating as it doesn't reflect my experience with my donut. I had the Dirt donut and it was delicious! Had it a second time later in the week. The lower rating is for the atmosphere and long line. The music was extremely loud and was screamo heavy metal, making it unpleasant to stand in line. The store embodies the "Keep Portland Weird" slogan in all aspects...not my scene. There is also a Dick and Balls donut that is inappropriate and should not be on the menu. The lines are not worth the donuts. If you can make it in the middle of the week, the lines are doable.

The Hard Rock Cafe of doughnut places.. you hear gobs about it and feel the need to check it out, only to be disappointed by the food inside. I do have to give them props for having a 'cock and balls' doughnut in a cock n balls shape though.
A+ for creativity. Incredible selection. But the one I had didn't really seem fresh. Coming here once was probably enough!

This review is very overdue but here it goes. I was visiting Portland and this is obviously a must. My family and I went during the week in summer and the wait was probably about 15-20 minutes. The doughnuts are captivating in appearance but don't let that fool you. 

The doughnuts look appealing physically but they aren't the greatest I've ever had by any means. They just don't taste very fresh but major props for being unique! Everything is well organized and the staff is friendly. If you're in Portland, stop by. You gotta see the doughnuts even if they don't taste amazing!
Extremely sugary donuts and poor service. Check out another artisan donut shop in town if you want something good!

Wow WAYYY TOO MUCH SUGAR. These donuts will you give you diabetes. They are so sweet that we could only take a few bites before tossing them in the trash. Not worth the hype or the line (but at least the line moves quickly). Cash only. I'd skip this place.

I was excited to finally tried voodoo donuts during my Portland trip. It was a fun experience, there was a line but it went quickly. The donuts are good, but they are a little too sweet for me. None the less, I'm glad I got to try it!
Went here because of the Photo OP and because my SO is another one of those "touristas" and needed to check it out. I thought their doughnuts are average at best but this place is always busy.

I'm sorry, but this place definitely did not live up to all that hype. Absolutely not worth waiting in line for 45 minutes in the sun. Maybe we got the wrong thing (since the menu wasn't exactly descriptive, and since they were out of bacon maple) or maybe I was just extra cranky after the wait in the blazing sun, but I'm pretty sure I could have poured a pixie stick on a grocery store doughnut and it would have tasted exactly the same. This disappointing trip plus the fact that I'm lukewarm on doughnuts in general means I won't be back. One star for the ATM and the water, which pretty much made my day.

I've lived in Portland since 1991. Can you remember that far back? That's before PC's and cellphones, MP3's and Facebook. Yup - BEFORE FACEBOOK. And since 1991 I've been to Voodoo Doughnut twice. That's all it took. Twice. Once at the location on 3rd and the other one in N.E.. Nice pepto-bismol paint job, guys. Seriously.

The doughnuts are nothing special. Think doughnuts from anywhere and drop them in the self serve cereal bins at WinCo. Mmmmm - sugary stale cereal coated fried globs of white flour. That's about as original as trying to drive your truck up the bike lane on the new Sellwood Bridge. Oh, wait - that recently really happened - sorry lady. Or how about sticking a pretzel in a maple bar - famous! 

The only fun thing about Voodoo Doughnuts is suggesting to your prude grandparents to ask the staff about the pink boxes. Stand back, wait and then laugh at the look on their faces when they get their answer. 

I just hope their mojo doesn't come back to bite me in the butt - unlike their doughnuts the last time I had one.

Update: I just heard in the news apparently the donuts can accidentally kill you. Just ask Travis Malouff, I guess he bit off more than he could chew. Sad, very sad.

Ok-trekking with kids who are 6 and 3 walking by a multitude of people that require having certain conversations that kids this age should not need, porn shops, strip clubs and what we believe was a porn theatre just to go to a place that will put ANYTHING on a doughnut to make it unique was NOT WORTH IT. Doughnuts are sweet indulgent treats, no need to pour crap all over them for notoriety, but seems the marketing gimmick worked for them.

Unique.  If your looking for a light, Dunkin-like doughnut, you won't find it here.  Voodoo is a big change - cakey not greasy, heavy and filling.  Interesting flavor combos and whacky names.  I had the dirty old bastard (I love peanut butter) and had to give half to my kids who readily gobbled it up.  Worth the trip.

I've been putting off reviewing this place until I gave them another chance. Well, I have, and I can't say I have a better opinion now than I did before. 

I'd give this place 2.5 stars if I could, but since I can't I'm demoting it to 2 since the hype raises your expectations. Also: the area can be kinda sketchy at night. 

You often see people carrying their pink voodoo boxes in the airport or while roaming around local hotspots. It's one of those touristy things that makes you wanna join in on the fun! 

But you show up, feel excited by the pink lit up sign, smirk at the clever-sounding names for the donuts and wait in line (hopefully no longer than 15 min) only to be met with the dry texture of a decorative donut with the flavor complexity of standard cake fondant and the equally bland personality of a cashier that has maybe worked too many busy shifts. 

I've ordered the following: 
- mango tango (probably my favorite of the bunch. Wasn't stale, tasted like mango)
- oh captain my captain (stale. Very, very stale)
- viscous hibiscus (very excited for this, but I couldn't much tell the flavor)
- others ordered by family members that I can't quite remember (didn't make a lasting impression)

I'm left with the impression that the titles are trying  too hard to be trendy, and now I know that the cute bits of cereal, icing, and other decorate edible items on the donut are the equivalent of spraying scented febreze after someone took a dump in the bathroom - your senses are initially fooled, but very quickly you encounter the crap just beneath the surface.
I cut my donut in half and out came a long hair. Yuck

Overrated? Yes. Worth checking out if you happened to go to Portland? Sure. They only take cash, though, so come prepared or be willing to use their ATM and pay the fees. (My credit union refunds ATM fees though, so IDGAF!) :D

I had a donut with cocoa puffs on it. It tasted....like a 7-11 donut with cocoa puffs on top. Definitely a unique idea which probably helped in part to spur the whole wacky donuts-with-random-shit-on-top craze which is just now making its way to St. Louis (with Strange Donuts opening.) 

Like I said, worth a trip just for the experience but I am sure the locals would attest to much better donut joints around town. These were just "okay" and I felt like I needed insulin afterwards. Thankfully the line wasn't too long because my coworker and I got there early enough. It was warm enough to sit outside at one of their nifty purple tables!

I would not bother to go to this Voodoo location again.  Why?  Too much of a pain in the ass for donuts that only serve to further Portland's "weird" (lazy, really) niche.

The donuts were not bad, not good.....just a sugar rush.  I had a hard time just finding a regular donut (don't much care for fruit loops or bacon on my donuts) so I gave up and asked my husband to just pick something for me (in other words, I gave up - that is never a good sign).  It was stressful enough finding a parking spot, getting across the street, having it be 11pm-12pm downtown next to some strip club, homeless all over the place, being hit up for money in line when outside the building, then being inside in the amusement park line -- only to be met by staff with attitude.

CASH ONLY.  Parking is hard, then you need to cross the street, felt like I had to memorize what I wanted so I did not make others have to wait in line longer.  There is no seating so you have to leave right after and get back to the car, or stand outside with who knows who.   

Not "good memorable" in any way, except that my in-laws got to see this part of town.  I doubt they would go back.

The above is the ultimate Portland experience.  Tired of the lazy "we are so weird its cool" theme.  It is not creative at all to go to Hippo Hardware and pick out weird stuff, throw it up on the wall, then be rude.  I guess it is their niche, but it is a stupid one.

Yes, it's overhyped, and no, I don't think it's worth waiting in a line more than 30minutes, but it really is a Portland institution, and a box of Voodoo doughnuts is an obligatory accessory when in Portland for the first time.

Would I go back?  No, but I'm glad I went at least once.  

If you get there early and there is no line, definitely get the peanut butter donut or the caramel one.  There are so many choices it's a little mind-boggling, but everything about it is entertaining, unique, and special.  

Service is non-existent, and the person working the cashier seemed tired and uninterested, but the interior is cool and you gotta love that pink box!  A conversation starter among tourists too, with many people asking if we'd been to Voodoo Doughnuts yet.  Now I can say "yes, definitely!"

When I went to voodo doughnuts I thought that the doughnuts there were a little to much. The line is way to long just for doughnuts and they don't have that many drinks to choose from. They put cereal and other stuff on the doughnuts that you would normally have for a ordinary breakfast, I don't suggest going to voodo doughnuts.

They may make a voodoo doll out of me that they'll want to poke with a needle after this review but I thought Voodoo Doughnut wasn't all that crazy fantastic as people hyped up to be.

They are still pretty good doughnuts with wild and inventive creations that make you feel as if you've walked into a new franchise brought to you by Willy Wonka and his chocolate factory. 

As far as first impressions go, walking into Voodoo is a trip and you almost do feel like someone put a spell over you. The displays of various brightly colored and creatively concocted doughnuts are so fun to look at and for taking photos. You definitely feel like a kid again which is always a good thing.

But I must've inherited donut snobbery having grown up on a steady diet of donuts. Also, since becoming a Yelper I've been on a never-ending journey for good donuts. 

PROS:
- Maple Bacon Donut - possibly one of the best bacon donuts I've had. Proper execution of sweet meets savory and neither overpowers the other. Plus full strips of bacon!
- Voodoo Doll and Cock N' Balls donuts are something else to behold. I wasn't so much impressed with how they tasted (very, very sweet) but the level of intricacy that they go into the appearance/theme is very cool.

CONS:
- Ordering the Cock N' Balls. Just a different experience asking the male cashier, "hey, can I have the Cock N' Balls please?"  
- Getting a box of donuts is sugar overload. I would recommend trying one first that you are really interested in so that you get the experience of having visited Voodoo and can check it off your list.
- The donuts are room temperature which makes sense considering if they were hot, there would be no way to maintain those cool designs. But, I like my donuts warm or hot and that does affect how it tastes.

Overall, I recommend trying Voodoo because as a tourist it is totally worth checking out to see donuts you probably won't find elsewhere. Its a spectacle for sure in both appearance and taste but it wasn't quite as tasty as I would've hoped. 

Tips: take your donuts around the corner to Stumptown Coffee Roasters where you can sit, order a latte, and enjoy your donuts indoors away from the cold.

I had a terrible experience. As I was standing in line, one of their employees flew out of the store & started yelling at a man standing near the seating area. The man was not bothering anyone but the employee proceeded to yell at the man & tell him he needed to leave. It appeared that the man was experiencing homelessness but I repeat, he was NOT bothering anyone. He was not asking anyone for anything, just standing & waiting to cross the street. The employee continues to yell & berate this man. I was so disgusted by this display of utter disrespect and callousness that I didn't even buy anything. I refuse to patron a place in which the dignity & integrity of all human beings is not validated & respected.

I understand the novelty of them but these were basic at best and we should've just had one each instead of being tourists and getting a baker's choice box. We were stuck with cold, dense doughnuts. Nope, no thanks. The flavors, however, were very inventive. I just prefer a lighter doughnut and this wasn't that at all. They definitely draw a crowd though! The line for this place was out the door and we waited in it. It's in a convenient location near the market and the line was moving pretty quickly.

My review is one of 7k at this point so it won't make waves, but I thought Voodoo was just ok. I have respect for them as one of the originators of the gourmet donut craze. 

Their yeast donuts are tasty. The flavors are nothing too special- your usual suspects of chocolate, berry, sprinkles, etc. we had the voodoo, pink lemonade, hibiscus (which was my fave) and maple bacon. 

I get that their shtick is sex, donuts and rock n roll but it gets old after awhile. I don't regret going but didn't finish them.

I don't see what the big hype about this place it.  The line is always super long.  The first time I had this place was when a friend brought it to us in Seattle.  This time I just need to try it for myself at the place of.  Still, I thought the same... nothing special and overly sweet donuts.

Overall, its not worth the hype or the wait time.  I guess you just gotta try for yourself and see what it is all about.

As a tourist (me and you), this is an establishment you go to just to say you've been. Going on July 4th weekend amidst the pandemic, there was a line but it wasn't horribly long. The wait itself isn't bad either. The donut itself tastes like your average donut, but their selling point is the variety of quickly flavors you typically won't find elsewhere. I was a bit sad they no longer have the fruit loops donut, but tried the Cap'n Crunch instead. And, as expected, it tasted just like the cereal on top of a bed of dough (which was good!). The hibiscus sounded very interesting to me since I do like that flavor (typically in a tea), but would not recommend the donut. The chocolate peanut butter donut tastes just as it looks as well. If you aren't holding this pink box all around downtown, are you even a Portland tourist?

This place is unique because of the donuts they make and decorate. Though it actually reminds me of Psycho Donuts in the San Jose area in California. The claim to fame is the MAPLE BACON DONUTt, which has (2) 1/2 strips of bacon on top of the maple bar. The donut itself is nothing different than other places. I also got a RASPBERRY FILLED DONUT that is decorated with tons of frosting to mimic a Voodoo doll because there is a pretzel stick through it. The APPLE FRITTER was HUGE. It was also very sweet with all the glazed sugar. OREO DONUT wasn't anything special other than crumbs of Oreos on top of the donut. ALL the donuts are INCREDIBLY SWEET. Seriously could get diabetes from this. So basically the LONG line of people who wait for this, (indirectly) WANT diabetes. The wait for diabetes was about 30 minutes around Saturday at noon.

Overall, not the best donut shop but it's still very attractive.  It truly is a Portland landmark that makes a ridiculous amount of revenue. I guess the innovative thought is reaps a lot. I wouldn't come backa again, but because it's a Portland landmark, now I can say I have been there with no regrets. If I wanted diabetic donuts, I'll stick to Krispy Kremes.

Have you ever ate a handful of wet sugar? If you haven't you'll soon be doing that here at Voodoo. 

"A must try in Portland" Who ever even came up with that? VD is definitely all hype and doesn't live up to it's name. We waited 50 minutes, 50 MINUTES for this nasty donut place because people said "a must try" and we fell for their voodoo...

So were expecting it to be at least decent because it can't surely be good if it's just spitting out thousands of donuts a day for the big crowd. We got 6 donuts: maple bacon, voodoo, portland creme, dick and balls, lemon filling one, and a glazed with raspberry filling. My god, these were all horrible! The only thing we found decent was the plain glazed with raspberry filling, because it wasn't drench in all nasty frosting! The dick and balls were a waste, nothing special, not even decorative. Literally just a molding of a dick and balls. The maple bacon was drenched in maple frosting that literally overwhelmed the bacon slice on there. The lemon filling donut was okay... nothing great. And the voodoo special one was just plain nasty. That was a handful of wet sugar. The portland creme donut was the grossest thing ever. The creme tasted like some other "creme" it had a nasty flavor to it. Also the guy gave us a small box for 6 big donuts and everything got a little of everything on it. Seriously dude? The donuts look like it was sitting for awhile...that probably explains why it was also dry inside. Eating the donuts between 3 people, we felt sick to our stomach. The sweetness was just too much. And me, I LOVE SUGAR but they just overdo it. 

I had MUCH better donuts in LA. Heck, I think Krispy Kreme makes better glazed ones! It's not soaking in frosting. It was so disgusting. We will never ever wait 50 minutes for a handful of wet sugar again. 

Somebody cursed us that day we thought of VD.

As with any trip I talked to the locals and asked for the hot spots in town. Voodoo donuts was definitely mentioned multiple times. Here's what I though:

Pros
Nice interior and outside decor
A lot of interesting choices
Good size


Cons
Cashier wasn't all too happy answering questions.
Huge lines

Overall my opinion is mixed. I think this place is over hyped and you're expecting amazing donuts and not that they aren't, but they aren't spectacular. 

I'm also not a huge fan of sweets but I didn't think it was anything special.

Doughnuts were ok. Lots of hype! Fun to visit. To say I've there BUT I probably would spend the time I spent waiting in line for an over priced mediocre doughnut better spent elsewhere on something else more meaningful.

Voo Doo Donuts Portland. The store is cute, colorful and fun. The people are wonderfully delightful, enthusiastic and inspiringly cheerful with impeccable customer service. Thank you all for an amazing customer service experience. Now for the Donuts. Unfortunately the eating experience was less than anticipated. Dense, Dry and Flavorless. I have personally tasted better Donuts at Safeway. Take away all the multiple of toppings and creative designs, your left with a Dense, Dry, and Flavorless pastry not worthy of going back for seconds. If you don't believe or trust my opinion, please buy donuts absolutely anywhere else and take an honest blind taste test. Please let me know what you think.

Iconic and well-hyped business embraced by those that love Portland's moto ;)   As far as taste, they are just wildly crafted donuts people...and highly-priced.    But if you want to go stand in line a LONG while to say you've seen/tasted a weird donut, this is your place!

When we moved to Portland I was prepared to break my no-sugar diet to try some of the pdx staples.  Voodoo doughnuts was one of those places that we were eager to try based on the rave reviews we heard from friends and family.

First of all the queue was really long and hot (you have to wait in the huge line that wraps outside, and when it is 90 degrees with no shade, 20 minutes can seem like a long time.  When you finally reach the door, the people behind the counter are yelling at the people in line to leave enough room for the people who just purchased to get out (seems like poor planning on their part when there was plenty of room to wrap the line the other way and not have this door issue.)

Because the inside is so small, you have approximately 2 minutes to look over dozens of flavors and decide what you want before a horn goes off at the counter and you are expected to come with your order ready. (There is also no AC inside which is kind of disgusting when you realize all the doughnuts are sitting there in the heat all day)

In spite of all this, we were still eager to try it and ordered 4 different kinds.  All of the doughnuts were just short of "Blah" and not just in my opinion (I know I am a little skewed by admitting that I don't eat sugar) but also from my husband who eats enough on a consistent basis for both of us (plus a little extra for good measure.)

After all this, I would say skip this tourist trap and try some of the much better doughnut options in downtown Portland (Blue Star) or do what we did and have a mini doughnut tour and test them all out for yourself.

TOURIST TRAP! GIMMICK! BLASPHEMY! RUN FOR THE HILLS OR THE NEAREST BLUE STAR DONUTS!!

The most artificial tasting donuts I've ever had. 

Who thinks a donut covered in Tang or mango powder would be good?! I did and I was completely wrong. Don't give them any of your money. You'll regret it!
Over rated, snobby counter help, too much sugar atop so so donuts.

Eh. When I told people I was going to Portland they all told me "you have to go to VooDoo Doughnut!" I really didn't want to, but when I walked past the brightly colored shop I figured, what the hell, when will I go to Portland again? I dragged my boyfriend in and we stood in line. It moved fairly quickly but the door is so small that if your place in line is right a the door, you will be shuffling around for the people exiting. Sad to say that the BACON on top of the Maple Bacon bar was the best tasting thing about this place. We got the: 

Voodoo doll - I knew I wouldn't enjoy it as I never get jelly filled donuts but I just wanted a cute picture ok?!?! It was ok. Had a lot going on. Instagram able? Yes.

Old fashioned chocolate donut - my boyfriend wasn't impressed. He didn't even like the chocolate that was on it.

Maple bacon bar - surprising the best one. It was good but not out of this world. The bacon was so perfectly crispy and literally the best thing about this whole establishment.

Needless to say customer service was gruff. Did not seem like the guy was in a good mood. Donuts not really fresh. Wouldn't come here again. We have something similar back in the Bay Area and I still don't go there either.

So, they have unique doughnuts but the quality is just "OK". Honest don't understand the hype. Over the weekend there was a line out the door, I mean, out the door. At least two dozen people outside. At least it wasn't raining. Cool flavors and combinations but the actual doughnut was so-so. Next trip to Portland will NOT include a visit to Voodoo. Do your self a favor, check out Blue Star for a delicious doughnut.

Overrated. Voodoo is just for the tourists. The doughnuts are not special, they taste like regular old doughnuts you can get from a basic doughnut shop. If you want incredibly delicious doughnuts, go to Pips!!!

Overrated doughnuts, but I felt like I had to try one since I'm from out of town.

I had the powdered, regular glazed, Oreo, and KoolAid doughnuts. It's a LOT of sugar on top of sugar. The doughnut cake itself isn't great, either. I guess the idea of putting cereal and other cool stuff on doughnuts is kind of appealing. However.. Sacramento has tastier doughnuts.

gaaarrr.  must reach door.  cannot move...food coma.  [whump.]

stupid iphone.  cannot write review to warn yeeps of fat, sugar, & more fat hoodoo doughnuts.  must find more alcohol to deglaze my intestines.  [glug. glug-glug.]

ahhhh.  now i understand why this place is so popular in the wee hours of the morning.  it's the perfect antidote to a night of unadulterated carousing.  next time i'll fortify myself with some macallan's before tackling the memphis mafia (mmm.  choco-banana-peanut buttah).

Fun spot to go to late night, one of the more popular places in Portland and it's different. They have a lot of crazy combos and it's worth checking out if you haven't been. 

I think the doughnuts are okay, not my favorite and I think there are better options elsewhere in the area. 

But if you haven't been before and you are visiting Portland, check them out, try the different doughnuts, and get yourself one of the pink boxes!

I went to the 82nd Street location in Cartlandia. Really, just terribly disappointing.  I came here from Chicago, and let just say that Chicago has better donuts than Voodoo.
I had the bacon-maple glazed donut.  It was fine, but not great.  I also had the children's cereal all over the doughnut; blah.  This was recommended to me by the attendant, and she was off her mark.
I was glad that I could easily park, so that was great.  However, the service attendant just had an attitude.  I'm feeling kind of generous, or it would have been a 2-star review.  I just don't know how they stay in business.  It's a tourist trap.
I'll go for Blue Star Doughnuts, or Pips, or anyone else before returning to Voodoo.

Voodoo Doughnut is an iconic Portland location, and I wish I could love it more than I don't, but I'm not exactly smitten. I love the Diablo Rex, a double chocolate Satanic donut, but for its awesome decorative look, chewing and swallowing feels like an obligation instead of something I enjoy. Even when fresh, the density and taste reminds me too much of Dunkin Donuts, which is everything you're trying to avoid when shopping local.

The place is tiny for how long the line can get and I don't know how they still don't take credit cards, when most other small businesses in Portland have a Square. Even more aggravating are how many panhandlers and drug addicts surround the store's tiny entrance, leaving traffic direction up to the patrons. Maybe I'm just getting older and veering more towards healthier options, or maybe the bizarre cereal toppings don't turn me on anymore, but in an age when you can do so much with pastries, I don't know why a Voodoo Donut of all things should be so limited.

To the store's credit, prices are extremely reasonable for the area, vegan options are available, and of the limited 24 hour places in the city, it's a reliable place to stop in for a late night snack, but sometimes it's better just to go home.
Fun to look at but really nothing amazing. If you go at the wrong time all the doughnuts Are stale as shit. Much better options that have fresh doughnuts

Did you ever really go to Portland if you didn't go to Voodoo Doughnuts though?

Hate to break it to you, but this place is alright at best. Donuts are entirely way too sweet, and I found that the only donuts that were decent were the plain blueberry old fashioned and chocolate old fashioned donuts. Everything else was doused in sugar. And don't get me started on anything with cereal on it, beware of the stale. Unless you choose to eat that right away, the cereal get stale quick. The donut flavors and designs were pretty creative though, so props for that.

The space is quirky, kind of like a mix of a fun house, arcade, and pepto bismol all in one. Lines can be pretty long too, and if the line is long, honestly just skip this place and go somewhere else. The novelty is fun, but not if you're waiting in line for longer than 15-20 minutes. Note, it's also a cash only establishment, so keep that in mind, but they do have an ATM for your convenience. I will say though that the service is really good, and kind of makes up for the fact that this place is way over hyped. As this was my first time here, I did not once feel that I was being rushed when placing my order, even if I had questions about some items. Not one person ahead of me was rushed either, which I thought was amazing, just due to the sheer volume of customers they get.

If you happen to pass by Voodoo and the line isn't crazy long, then by all means, I suggest you stop by just to experience it, just don't come in thinking you're getting anything other than an extremely sweet but otherwise fun cool looking donut.

"Keep Portland Weird" - Voodoo Doughnuts is doing just that and adding an R rating while they're at it... Read on:

Most items on the menu incorporate sexual connotation. Their moto "Good things come in pink boxes" or "The magic is in the hole" really keep things pretty strange and in line with the sexual theme. I'm not sure about you, but sex and doughnuts aren't really that appealing. When I think of doughnuts I think of feeling sick after devouring that many grams of fat and sugar, but hey, that's just me.  

The lines are ridiculous! While they are open 24 hours, I suggest going early in the morning - around 8 as the line seems to be smallest then. The staff do their best to move people along quickly, but the patrons get excited and want to talk incessantly about nothing. 

I have to admit, I didn't try a doughnut, but my husband did. He sampled the Memphis Mafia. Good lord, this is indulgence at it's finest. He gave the doughnut itself 5 stars, but complained that the staff touched his doughnut after handling cash. They use these parchment paper tissue things to grab your doughnut off the trays, but when they go to set it down on the counter, they touch it with their bare hands. I don't know about you, but handling cash and food in the same sentence is pretty fucking disgusting - weird city or not. So for that, I downgrade to 3 stars.

Great Little place to visit, they have quite a following.
The ambiance, so many different Donuts, decorated in weird ways.
The truth is the taste and quality of the donuts are average at best and they are very over priced. Sorry just telling it like it is!

The thrill of it all was "Yea! I finally made it to Voodoo Doughnuts." Boy, was I disappointed! Did i mentioned that I waited in line, SUN beaming down my back, SWEAT  masking my face. Got a visual....
 I had the doughnut with Chcolate frosting,  Rice Kripsies and Peanut Butter, although the topping was good, the doughnut was stale. I really would have liked to bite down to some softness but instead I bit into the Sahara and  didn't have a drink to quinch my thirst. So I just ate the topping and tossed the rest.  VOODOO was a BOO HOO for me!

It's a donut. Looks like a donut. Tastes like a donut. So what's with the hype. Not sure. Hype for the hype of it, I imagine.
They are so cloying and sweet, so not my favorite. I won't be going back. My advice, do not get any of the choices with cereal on them. They are soggy and stale tasting.
I am curious about this Blue Star donut I've heard about.

I honest to God don't understand the hype surrounding this. Most of the donut bases taste the same as Krispy Kreme. Yes they have some unique flavors, and the best one that will keep me coming back is the maple flavored old fashion donut, and they do have really cool decor inside and a whole gothic vibe going for them, but this is a case of a spot that unfortunately was overhyped and didn't live up to the expectations set. There was a line when I went but it does move pretty quickly. They also had signs up saying they now accept credit cards. No where to use a bathroom that we saw at this location.

Beyond overrated. The staff really couldn't be any more rude and careless. At this point in time, any donut shop can throw some bacon on a maple bar. You're better off going elsewhere. Don't waste your money!

I was so excited to try the donuts here because of all the hype but it really disappointed me. I'm a huge person on sweets and donuts but the donuts here are not worth the price. Although I do give them credits for the nice design on the donuts but it really taste similar to something you can grab at a gas station.. 

The overly sweet is not a good combo with the frosting and all the sugar they put on some of the donuts. The price is a little bit much... 

I do have to say that their customer service is very genuine. They have very great energy and the one who took our order was so nice. 

Do have to warn that the line gets pretty crazy... but I wouldn't come back unless I have to... Sorry Voodoo..

The doughnuts are beautifully decorate. If you like stale & dry, then this is your place. Two of the six were eaten the rest was tossed.

The staff isn't too friendly. They make you feel rushed. And, Yes there is a long line to get in.

If you go on the weekends, the line could usually take up to 20-30 minutes before you can walk in.
It's good, but not worth the wait

Don't give into the hype like I did!

Donuts are less than mediocre, but they do get points for creativity. The bacon maple that everyone raves about... Well, there is nothing to rave about.

Lines are long, especially at night when all the drunkards are done partying. The prices here are more than your average donut shop too, so SKIP IT.

~ Cash only
~ Open into the wee hours
~ Street parking only
