Tourist trap. Avoid at all costs. No one local eats here. It's just a tourist spot, mainly because no one returns!

if it wasn't so bad for you, i'd probably eat donuts everyday but not these donuts. i went there on a saturday in the late morning and there were about 10 people in front of me. the guy at the front of the line was buying something like 100 donuts (no joke) so the wait took quite a while. that was okay because the people watching in there was priceless. quite a collection of characters, most of whom appeared to be tourists. the decor is also quite interesting. anyway, i ordered a glazed donut which is what i use as a benchmark to judge how good a donut place is-- if they can't do a plain glazed well, how good can the place be? well, this completely disappointed. the donut tasted like it was underbaked and the glaze was sort of flavorless but i guess that's good in way because i also hate overly sweet donuts. all in all, a big letdown. yuck.

Who hasn't heard of Voodoo?. 
A Portlandian iconic experience. 

This place sums up everything Portland pretty much. The Hipsterish vibe and all. 

I like donuts obviously. Who doesn't?. I don't trust anyone who hates donuts. A good donut with coffee... Although, if you come here thinking you'd sit down eat a nice creative donut with coffee sips, sorry you'd be disappointed. 

It's a tourist attraction (Trap?)lol... either way, it's a cute place and the donuts in display look just ... donutilicious lovely. 

I have been here few times and tried several crazy offerings.

Old Dirty Bastard... ah, sorry I wasn't cussing I promise. That's actually the name of a donut :)
This one is actually my least favorite. Too much going on and a bit dry. It missed the mark. 

Raspberry Donut - my favorite here so far. always fresh, soft fluffy and adequately filled with goodies. 

Dipped donuts are good too. They have several kinds.

I think the best experience, especially if you are not staying in town too long, and only have a chance to make one stop, is to sample and get a box to go. 

Line can get really long (mostly tourists, visitors, or college kids). 

Not a fan of the way they do the check-out. Often they'd have a third cash register open all the way at the end of the room with a person there yelling at customers to grab their attention or waving them down. How about make them closer together or add proper signage to help people notice the 3rd cash register instead of frantically yelling every time a slot opens up?. It makes for a better and friendlier experience. 

If you happen to be in Portlandia, it's worth checking out if you happen to be an avid donut fan. If you don't care about sugarly creativity then I'd skip it due to logistics that come with it - being downtown, crowd, lines, etc. 

I did notice off peak hours where there's no line at all, might be evenings/nights on weekdays. Weekends are busier. Enjoy!
Even though I prefer Blue Star donuts, Voodoo makes a really good raspberry filled one that's simple yet delicious. They also have a good maple one.
A must experience when in Portland! And they have crazy weird flavors and are fun to look at and try but NOT my favorite tasting donuts in Portland. It's a one and done for me!

There was a long line to get into Voodoo Doughnuts that moved fairly quick. Once inside you are instructed to go to whatever cashier is available. If the cashier is not near the donut display in the center of the room you have to choose your donuts from a photo chart. The photo chart is not as enjoyable as being able to see the actual donuts. Their donuts are decorated in fun patterns and have wacky colorful toppings. 

My daughter and I decided to try one donut to see if we liked it. We were not overly impressed with the Voodoo Doughnuts in Orlando and did not want to get stuck with a dozen average donuts while on vacation. It was a good decision on our part because the chocolate coconut donut was shamefully bland. On the plus side it was moist but it lacked flavor in the worst way.

I am a local and not sure why everyone cries over voodoo donuts. There are much better shops in PDX. Dough is often dry and flavorless with toppings stale. Employees are always busy and their customer service is nothing special. I do not reccomend voodoo to friends or visitors.

Long lines + mediocre doughnuts = not worth it. 

Good to try just to see the hype but don't order too many and just skip it if the lines too long. 

Trust me you're not missing out.

Sorry, I don't know what the big deal about this place is. Donuts tasted super average and our service was super rude. The lady didn't even look at us so we just ordered our three donuts and she didn't say anything to us the whole time. I put in my card when I thought I should and I took my receipt when I thought I should because she didn't even do any of this for me. Would never go back. I heard from locals that there are other donut shops that taste way better.

Came here on a Sunday afternoon and the line was only a 20 minute wait. The decor inside the store is very hip and cool. There are so many donut flavors to choose from, you just can't get everything.  Everybody leaves this place with a huge pink box. 

We ordered the donuts with coco puffs, oreo cookies and peanut butter, vanilla with coconut shreds and they were okay. I think people are just all excited about the different flavors they make. The donut just  tastes like any other donuts you order in a regular donut place. The uniqueness of the donut design is very cool but the flavor is just okay. It doesn't really live up to its hype. 

Remember, this joint is CASH only.

I honestly don't understand what all the hype is about regarding this place. Doughnut are no different than your typical doughnut places other than the variety of toppings from bacon to fruit loop and anything else in between. They are cash only. The line to order is always long. The interior is sadly lacking and I have nothing to say of the bizarre pink exterior color.

All the hype ...  bazaar and wacky flavors ... long lines  ... got a sweet tooth ... don't mind massive calories ... how about a little insulin shock ... love is sweeter with a box of Voodoo doughnuts for your sweetheart on Valentines Day ... consume too many doughnuts and watch your Valentine grow!

Fat Love

My Valentine sweetheart,
My toasty cinnamon pop up tart,
My sugar plum pie,
If love be counted in calories,
Ours far exceeds ten times more,
More than any Voodoo doughnut,
a Bacon Maple Bar, Portland Cream, Diablos Rex, Mango Tango, Grape Ape, Maple Blazer, Memphis Mafia, Dirt, Old Dirty Bastard, Rapper's Delight, Cinnamon sugar, Tex-Ass Challenge or "da" Voodoo Doll doughnut,
Fat love, more than ten times the calories,
If our love was calories counted like that,
Our love would be really really fat!!!!!!!!!!

Voodoo doughnuts come in many shapes and sizes. Inside lots of tasty surprises. In the long line outside, down the street and around the corner, you'll bump into many PDX'ers -- and folk around the country and world -- all hyped-up over a small fried cake of sweetened dough in the shape of a ball, ring or doll!

I do not know if Voodoo ingredients are GMO free. The only organic ingredient they use is Zulka Morena Sugar in their vegan cake doughnuts. Voodoo Doughnut's cups, lids, straws, paper items, and doughnut boxes are all compostable -- impressive! They also support good causes, i.e. Street Roots and more!

You like doughnuts? No doubt, you love Voodoo! Me, I am not a doughnut junkie. I admit, I am chocolate crazy! I'll spend my calories on organic dark chocolate (many known healthful benefits too). OK! I cannot live in PDX without "One Old Fashion Glaze." 

Dough-nothing special!

THEY'RE.  JUST.  DONUTS!

Let me break down what happened with this place.  While there is good food to be had in Portland, Portland isn't really known for its good food.  And since there was nothing SUPER special to be had, the first thing to really stand out gets a lot of hype around it, whether deserved or not.

Voodoo Doughnut is one of the first places to make "novelty" donuts before that was more of a thing.  Are they good donuts?  Yes, they're fine.  They're serviceable, if a bit too sweet at times.  But you're going to be waiting in line for too long just because "you have to while you're here".

That's all there is to it.  They didn't get famous because they happened to have a killer recipe for donuts.  They got famous because they made a penis-shaped donut.  So scandalous.

Oh, and by the way to all the Portland natives who are annoyed by all the tourists (and locals) who wait in line for this?  I come from SoCal.  We have this shit ALL OVER THE PLACE in LA!  Over-hyped, underperforming, with lines around the block.

Also the girl who rang us up was an asshole.  I don't blame her, but she absolutely was.

Also also, yes, I am spelling it donut and not doughnut. If this bothers you, congratulations on having literally nothing to worry about in your life.

Better doughnuts then expected. The hype is pretty funny but not worth waiting in a long line if that's the situation. We got an assortment to test out the goods. Surprisingly I enjoyed the one I dissed the most hahaha. Cap'n Crunch donut. Yum!

*******************KRISPY KREME IS BETTER***************

So, after a disastrous experience at Bunk Sandwiches (hated them!!) the hubby just had to have Voodoo Doughnuts because as with Bunk he had seen them featured on TV; so off we went. 

Not being used to the many one way streets we literally drove around in circles before turning down the correct street and luckily we found parking right in front of the shop. 

Once we arrive we were surprised to see a line wrapped around the building and though "these donuts must rock!"  We eagerly and happily awaited our turn to go inside. 

Once inside we expected the warm and pleasant smell of fried deliciousness but not so much.  I won't go into the decor because I'm sure by know everyone has seen plenty of pictures and know what to expect inside at least visually. 

We ordered the little voodoo guy, a maple bacon donut and coffee...and the verdict is....drumroll please:

Coffee:  Holy willykers batman! It seriously tasted like they used the year old sock of an unbathed transient (which there happens to be plenty in the area) to filter the coffee.  It was bitter, acidic and talk about after taste...just putrid! 

Donuts:  Save your pennies and go to your local Krispy Kreme or anywhere else.  My little voodoo guy had no taste as far as the dough went.  The frosting I just about went into diabetic shock it was like taking a shot of sugar dressed with powdered sugar topped with brown sugar with a sprinkle of splenda.   

I was really hoping to be WOWed, it didn't happen :(

If we are being brutally honest- it's not worth it. We got a half dozen box. We got different ones to try out. Grape ape is just super sweet with dry doughnut dough. Gay bar literally  was just custard filled bar  with 4 fruit loops. Doughnuts  were very dry, too  sweet, overpriced and it was just something that shouldn't be so popular. It's whatever

I'm not sure what all the hype is about with this place, but I wasn't too happy with the doughnut. We got the captain crunch doughnut and it tasted like it had been sitting there for a few hours. It definitely wasn't fresh. Luckily, we went later in the day (around 1:30pm) so we didn't have to wait in a massive line. I'd say go here if you're a tourist and want to experience it, but you're definitely not missing out on anything.
Rude workers all the hype super disappointed will not return the girls working were absolutely rude and treated costumers in front of me horrible . Drove from Washington state super lame .
Tourist trap with over-expensive doughnuts. Better than a grocery store, but not much.

Yes it's famous, yes it has unique donuts, but no, it's not the best tasting donuts.

Here's why I kept going back:
1. Out of town visitors get a kick of it
2. It opens 24 hours
3. Cock'n'Balls donut is the best gag gift

Maple bacon bar is the best tasting one, anything that has crunchy stuff on top (ex: fruit loops, oreos, etc) are not good because most of the time, they're not crunchy anymore.

This place knows they can treat the customer however they wish too.. And they do JUST THAT. My family owns a business and we pride just as most business do ourselves on great customer service. Our family drives up to Washington every year and this year we decided to stop by VooDoo on the way. It's been on the food net work and sounded pretty cool.. You wait in line outside for about 20 minutes. Once inside you can sort of see what there is to choose from, although nothing is labeled with prices making it very hard to decide how you want your dozen or single donut. 

We'll it's our turn in line and we are greeted by a not so friendly employee of VooDoo who clearly hates customers, and does not want to answer any of our questions. It appears from other comments that they frequently get complaints on customer service. 

Donuts weren't the best.. But here's the problem. We took our box outside to enjoy our donuts and they were all squished, my kids.. So exited to see the donuts they just picked out.. All squished together. To me, that is flat out rude.

I understand they are over priced most likely because they have been on TV how ever, ended up spending 19.55 on a box of one dozen donuts... Which we had to pay CASH ONLY for unexpectedly. Not friendly at all.. Very weird environment and workers.. also very dirty. I would never go back and will not recommend it to any one simply because of the experience.

If you are going make sure to have cash and don't be expecting any type of customer service, smiles or reasonable donut prices.. The owner clearly does not care how his business is perceived through his employees, they all had the exact same attitude. Can't believe this place made it on TV!

Disgusting donuts and bad service (cashier lady dropped our box on the floor and still gave it to us - so gross). Even on a random Monday night at 11pm, there was still a line. Don't waste your time coming here.
Major tourist stop, and it's not for the quality of their doughnuts.
Bleh. Overrated. Bacon maple bar is pretty good though.

I'm not a huge donut fan but I'm told that if you go to Portland, you go to Voodoo so we did.  There was a line, completely expected but what was weird was that there was a line because only three customers were allowed in at a time.  This made selecting a donut kinda stressful, since I didn't know the menu until the pressure was on and we were inside.  

The selection is insanely large so there is definitely something for everyone. I ordered a Portland creme (the official creme donut of Portland so the sign says) and one glazed with chocolate and covered in peanuts. 

I was anticipating some huge moment of realization where I would discover that these donuts hold the answers to life, drooling and begging for more.  That didn't happen, not even close.  The creme was just fine, I've had more attachment to Dunkin Donuts.  

However, the next morning I savored every inch of my day old peanut donut.  It was pretty damn good and worth carrying around for 24 hours.  

Go if you are in Portland?  Absolutely- you have to.  Will it change your life? No of course not, its just a donut.

This place has definitely been hyped up, perhaps by some of its bold donut names *cough*
Hey, a donut is a donut is just a donut.

I tried a few different donuts, and the first thing that struck me was the sweetness.
Worst....the Lemon w/ powdered sugar was not a hit. The curd was so sweet, and the powdered sugar had an aftertaste to it.

The line was long, and this was around 10am. As I was leaving around 11am, the line was going all thru the other side of the street.
And service.. was not so great. First off, their menu is a mess. It doesn't clearly explain the content of the donuts and it would probably not be appreciated if you asked about each and every donut they have on the menu.
I don't really understand what the "Voodoo" experience is about. There is no "experience" going to this place, other that waiting in a long line and getting a few overpriced donuts in a pink oversized box (even if you get 2-3-4-5 donuts.

It's CASH ONLY, and NO PENNIES (as it clearly says on the window).
Over rated and vulgar donuts. Not even that good. It's design is the main selling point. Definitely not the taste.

Let's be honest, if you are in Portland you are going to check this place out...buy a donut, take some photos, and cross it off your list.

There's nothing special about the donuts here....they have some crazy flavors but crazy doesn't mean good.... it usually just means different.

Like I said if you are visiting Portland you are going to check this place out...but i can't imagine ever wanting to go here if i was a local.

Voodoo Doughnut is definitely a tourist trap; go for the experience, not for the donuts. The line was long but I highly enjoyed the atmosphere inside. With groovy, strange music and spiritual folk decorations, the place definitely creates a voodoo culture feel. 

They have glass displays of their donuts in merry-go-round carousels, which was a cool touch. I always like when you get to see what you're potentially ordering. The place only takes cash, though, and most of the donuts (for a single donut) range from $1.50-$3.50. I ordered the Chuckles doughnut based on the staff's personal recommendation.

The doughnut tastes like a Nestle Drumstick with its peanuts, chocolate, and caramel, but in doughnut form. It's a pretty delicious concept but poorly executed. The donut was rather dry and it seemed like the toppings weren't really fused with the donut but instead in its own crusted layer sitting on top. The donut also wasn't warm which made it taste even sadder. I will say I love their Voodoo Doughnut box packaging; the pink really stands out. 

But would I ever buy a dozen for the box? Never. I've had better donuts at Dunkin.

Visit VooDoo once for the novelty of it all but no need to return. I was tempted to book a visit with my dentist afterward, these donuts can seriously cause some cavities in one bite. I'm just thankful the line was not long when I went because I would have been sorely disappointed otherwise. I'm also thankful that my friend knows one of the girls that works there because we got a box of VooDoo dozen and a maple bar for FREE! That alone made it a 5 star experience BUT the donuts themselves did not. 

The maple bacon bar was delicious, I'm a fan! The rest of the donuts were waaaayyyy too sugary and rich. Yes they are unique but not necessarily good. I'd rather eat a bowl of cereal than eat any of their cereal coated donuts. If not eaten fresh they do not hold up well for the next day...or even a few hours later. 

Like I said, go once to say you've tried it but check out Blue Star donuts too...they've got some creative choices as well, and better tasting in my experience!

If a two star is, I've had better, this much is true.
I absolutely love cake doughnuts so I got one here and maybe... Voodoo is just not great at cake doughnuts or maybe this was more a cake in the form of a doughnut??? I got the Triple Chocolate Penetration which is far from my usual fare of fruity cake doughnuts or a simple old fashioned... And maybe that's where it all went wrong.

ANYWAY.
The Cocoa Puffs were stale and the doughnut was, as I said, more cake... Very light and fluffy cake than a cake doughnut. And the frosting was pretty unremarkable. The place is cool, maybe worth a trip to see the decor, but if you want doughnuts... I'd book a plane ticket to Chicago.

P.S. Cash only. Don't be like the family before me in line who waited only to leave at the door because they had no cash.

Every time I see a visitor to Portland rave about Voodoo Doughnut I cringe a little.  Every time I hear about someone coming here I want to scream "Don't go to Voodoo!"

I'm the hype killer, so I hafta go after this place.  These donuts are merely okay. They're no better than Safeway or Freddy's donuts.  Those places also sell bacon if you must cross your sweet and savory streams.  It'll take about as long to fry the bacon as it will to churn through the line of suburbanites and tourists in this closet of hipster sneerdom.

I want to find whoever put this place on the list of touristy stuff to do in town and kick them in the shins repeatedly.
If your a tourist, go check it out, its worth experiencing at least once. However not the best donut in town.

Voodoo Doughnut certainly has a reputation that precedes itself, so being in the city for just a handful of days, it would have almost been a sin not to stop in for a light, deep fried breakfast. 

Upon strolling through the front door, it quickly occurred to me that it's one of those places that's more of a show than it is a superior eatery. There's tons of cool stuff to look at on the walls, including a giant donut that's apparently been stolen on more than a few occasions. The music that happened to be blaring through the speakers during my 5-10 minute jaunt was some kind of cacophonous mess with thrashing guitars and Darth Vader on vocals, and the kids working behind the counter were so detached and disinterested, it was almost a joke. But hey - it's pretty much exactly what I expected. Apparently, every employee there is an ordained minister, and if you feel like getting married at the doughnut shop - you can! And within just moments, too!

The downside is that the doughnuts themselves leave a lot to be desired. Most of them taste like your standard grocery store doughnut, only with odd ball ingredients piled on top like stale cereal and Oreo cookies. They do get creative and their doughnuts will give you a bit of a rise, but that's about all. The penis shaped doughnut and the "Blazer Blunt" which resembles lit joint are just a couple of the comical creations that are undoubtedly fun to look at... but not as fun to eat.

Being that bacon is my weakness, I devoured their bacon maple bar... which is pretty much exactly what it sounds like. A maple bar with two slices of cooked, crispy bacon on top. It's no match for the bacon maple doughnut at Dynamo in SF, but really, what is? 

Definitely glad I was able to squeeze this into my travel plans, but I did expect a little more from the doughnuts themselves, due to the massive amount of national attention this place receives.

I know, I know... "Haters gonna hate" but I really, REALLY wanted to like this place!!  I seriously did!!!  The doughnuts tasted old and the long wait just underlines my distaste for the hipster-fueled  "all hype and no service" failures on delivery.   Bummer...

It's a piss poor excuse of an novelty doughnut shop. It's embarrassing when people come to Portland and this is the place we tell them to go to. It lacks originality and is just pathetically underwhelming in every conceivable aspect of anything remotely qualifying as a culinary experience. "Right, but it's a doughnut shop" you might say. If that's the case, save yourself the trouble of taking out cash and time wasted waiting in line and go to 7-11 or Krispy Kreme. 

"Oh but it's uniquely Portland, right?" go fuck a over priced doughnut with food coloring because Portland deserves to be much better than your limited aspiration. 

This armpit of culture doughnut shop just needs to close. And how much effing sugar do you people need? This country is literally rotting to death on cholesterol and sugar. Plus Blue Star down the street is x100 more authentic.
I am so puzzled why this place is so popular. It is trashy looking and the doughnut was not so fresh.

Meh.   The pro, no line on a Saturday morning, a good assortment offered and the price. 
 
The bad, unfriendly service and the actual doughnuts.  They were okay/good, but definitely did not blow me away.  For us, this was supposed to be the Mecca for doughnuts.   We left in search for a higher being in the doughnut world.

You know how you hear about a place that everyone likes. you have high expectations, right? This was Voodoo Doughnuts for me, except I've learned that it's not something to get excited about. Voodoo Doughnut's building has graffiti and homeless men dancing to the weird music that's blasting so loudly it will damage your ears. They only accept cash so my mom had to push her way through the line to use the ATM, which charged a three dollar fee to use. The service was terrible, they yelled at us and they were out of the doughnuts we wanted. The wait was insanely long. It also felt extremely grimy. It had trash EVERYWHERE, the walls were dirty, and there were people smoking right outside the door. And finally, the doughnuts were expensive and after knowing where they came from, they seemed gross to me. I don't suggest going to Voodoo Doughnuts ever, unless wasting money, herds of wild humans, and filth are your thing.

Long lines. The things people will put into their bodies is astonishing to me. This place is just too much. The donuts are big and filling, more than enough. If you're big on sweets and love to throw the most un-healthiest of things together to eat, you'll be in heaven. It's certainly an experience to have.

Very terrible service here!!! Avoid at all cost! I will never return here even though I like their doughnuts. First of all they have quite a bit of a homeless problem here as there are people begging for money while you are waiting in line. One older lady was going around each and every person asking for money. I also saw many homeless pushing shopping carts around with only their belongings.

My main reason why one bad customer service experience can alter your thoughts of ever returning to the place of business. I had bought a few doughnuts and the cashier overcharged me a doughnut I never bought. When I returned after I left the store, I brought this to the cashier's attention. He was not apologetic at all and even had the gall to just give me the doughnut he had incorrectly rung up without asking to take the price off. I didn't want a $5 doughnut that I had no interest in getting. After having the manager come over and change the price the cashier never closed our box of doughnuts after we showed them we got charged wrong. He just stood there like an idiot waiting for me to close the box! No apologies whatsoever and just a plain ass! I know the lines are endless here, but if you keep treating your customers like that, you won't have many returning. I can gladly say that they have lost a customer for life as I will never set foot again at this lousy establishment!

OK, I love this place and would go there now for a Maple Bacon Bar (yes real fried bacon on top of a maple bar) but I know the SOUND of it is MUCH better than the TASTE of it. 

In fact that's the point of this review; If you want pastries that LOOK delectable and often SOUND yummy Voodoo is your best destination.

However, if you want donuts that actually TASTE good then head for the nearest Krispy-Kreme  and WAIT for fresh donuts.

I've been to Voodo Doughnuts multiple times during daytime and nighttime and I would prefer to go during nighttime. At nighttime there is more parking that is available and also there isn't a huge line to get a doughnut. Although this place is a very touristy spot in my hometown I would say that it is overrated. Maybe I believe that because whenever I go it's nighttime and the toppings are always stale but I've had better donuts from even a grocery store. I will say that they do have a lot of unique donuts that you can't get anywhere else and that the price is very inexpensive but I don't think I would recommend this place to a tourist. I will say that the inside of the restaurant is decorated very uniquely and I've never seen a place decorated like that before though. Overall I wouldn't recommend this place.

Voodoo Doughnut is a must visit for out-of-towners for the novelty but it ain't the best donut place in town.

Pros: opened 24 hours, there was no line at 11pm on Thursday night, fast service, unique donut options
Cons: donuts are super sweet, cash only

We had fun stopping by in the middle of the night for donuts and eating them outside on the nearby tables, but the donuts were all overwhelmingly sweet.  I got the Dirt Doughnut, which has crushed oreos on top, and it was pretty good but maybe I should have gotten another option.  

Nothing sensational but we can now check this place off our list.

Honestly I was disappointed. Not with the experience but with the actual dang donut! The experience is fun, you get to look at all the creatively named and quirky flavored donuts, you can chat in line with other donut lovers, and you can fulfill your Portland bucketlist. But the donuts are overly sugary sweet and the flavors were ok. Def like other places like Bluestar in terms of flavor much better. Overall fun experience.

Yes.   Portland and Eugene's icon when it comes to donuts (or at least, so I've been told). 
I've had my share of donuts at voodoo; to me it's more about the different shapes and named that makes this a fun place. 

Not even the flavor and quality. 
For those I have to go to a different donut store in town. 

But I will always go inside when I'm in the mood for a sugar fix and order one of your goodies.

Nahh, just naaaaaaaah. I know, I know. I, too, got sucked into the hype and HAD to make this a destination when we visited Portland last year. Surprisingly, there was no one in the store (it must have been a weekday) when we stopped by so we didn't wait long. I can't even remember what we got - probably something with raspberry jelly and some chocolate one, I think. Anyway, besides having fun names and some interesting toppings, this is nothing to write home about. It's your typical, saccharine donut. Nothing super creative or gourmet about it.

Last weekend I walked by to see a HUGE line that went out the door, did an S, and went down the block. They're so popular they have to use pink barriers to herd the line. All I could think was, "suckers."

Noticed this was a "must go-to" place when I researched Portland. 

Fortunately, the line was not crazy my first night in the city! Cool place for being open 24 hours! I appreciate the store's character, yet the quality of donuts are overwhelming. Not the place to go if you want a simple donut. 

I ordered the Voodoo and Hibiscus donuts. Way too overwhelming! I was shook by the jelly inside the Voodoo to the  point I did not  finish it.

Open late, overpriced, but great place to visit once as a tourist (for photos).
if you like really heavy donuts then this place will definitely be your thing I just would not say it's worth the wait.

Terrible tourist trap.  Donuts that you get look old and dry definitely better go to blue star or pips to get donuts. Most people think voodoo is some kind of special landmark when it's actually a chain that just typically has one in a few cities.  Always a long line for absolutely no reason. Only positive is the staff are nice. Save your money and get some real donuts.

I stopped by on my way to the airport to pick up donuts for my staff in Seattle. It was $60 worth of donuts that each person picked out, The guy working there said he could fit all of them in the larger box. I gave him the cash and he started helping someone else. I did not receive a receipt, and honestly don't remember him opening a cash drawer. He was reading the donuts off the screen, yet somehow missed almost half. When I got to the office, I didn't have enough donuts for some of the staff, which was sad. I called and spoke to the manager, who described the person who helped me and that "he has had a couple issues in the past", but without a receipt there was nothing he could do. I told him that I wasn't given a receipt and I asked him to pull my transaction. He said he isn't able to and all he can do is have a conversation with him about not doing it again. I told him that I was very disappointed and that I don't care if he gives me a refund, but maybe allow my kids to come by for some donuts. His response was "not without a receipt" the customer service is horrible. I know the manager was there and remembered me because I clearly needed assistance picking some of the donuts out and ordered a lot. I believe they forgot to give me donuts and know it. Or they did it on purpose and kept my cash. Either way, I feel they have horrible customer service and clearly don't value customers. It's just a donut to them, but 8 people who didn't receive what they ordered after I made a special trip before I flew to see them. Will not go again and plan to share my concerns as many times as I can. The owner should be embarrassed. NO STARS

Overrated. Don't be fazed by the lines. We looked up Yelp reviews and decided this is pretty standard fare albeit with fancy toppings etc. But when we passed it there was a huge line( Probably non locals like us) and in my food brain big line = good food , so we got in line. 
For me a doughnut is all about the dough not the toppings. It should be light and not feel like eating bread. And trust me this is no Krispy Kreme. The doughnuts are more of the Dunkin genre. If you like that then this place might be for you.

Some tips: 
Open 24 hours.
Cash only.

Recommend for tourists. But it's definitely not a regular basis type of place. I've probably been here twice in my six years of living here. Both of which were in my first year! I just don't get the hype.
Stale donuts, long lines, rude and unenthusiastic employees, and loaded with Californians.

this place has been reviewed a few hundred times so i'll make this quick. the donut bread part has a nice consistency. it's soft and chewy but the frosting/icing on top is waaaaay too sweet. it made my mouth pucker.

we got the peanut butter, oreo, chocolate donut and of course "THE" bacon maple bar. it was so rich and big that the donuts lasted us two days. we nibbled on them when we got hungry throughout the weekend. it actually tasted better 2nd day. 

voodoo is a place you have to try once but not necessarily twice. luckily, we went on a friday afternoon b/c the long line was outside the door on saturday.

it's cash only too!

I was so upset.

We checked the website.
We called.
No voice message.
also no answer...

We drove by, it was New Years Day and they were closed. 

We had even spent 30 minutes in a new city finding a bank, to make sure we had cash on hand..

We were coming through and made a particular detour here in search of a large amount of doughnuts for a birthday extravaganza surprise...

Oh VooDoo please update your website so this doesn't happen again.

Update: I e-mailed them and this was their response. *shrug*

Karen,
We are sorry that you missed out on our doughnuts!  Our website is
currently getting re vamped and we will consider adding your suggestion.

Thanks for feeling the Mojo!!!
-Voodoo



....apparently they didn't understand I wasn't "feeling the Mojo!"

Here's my 5...

1. I definitely recommend people to come here for two reasons: the ambience makes you truely feel the Portland Weird vibe.  It's open 24 hours so it seems like the perfect stop after the bars. 

2. The donuts in terms of taste and quality seemed standard. It took some time for us to find a donut that we wanted but nothing stood out. It seems like a standard donut place with very cool ambience and people. 

3. Open 24 hours a day. That sounds nice!

4. Very creative donuts. Cock and Balls looks...cool.

5. Prime location near Chinatown and other cool stops!

Voodoo Donuts is a Portland staple, yet there leaves a lot to be desired. Luckily, we were staying across the street at Embassy Suites so we had a good view of the line. My husband went and brought back a variety of donuts. Two dozen worth of donut goodness....so we thought. The creativity in the donut types and toppings are quite interesting. The cereal toppings on some of the donuts were actually stale. Don't understand the hype, but glad I was able to try these so called novelty donuts...

Check it out when the line is short. Unless you have a desire for dry and non-fluffy donuts, then you might enjoy. Personally, the freshness at other neighborhood donut shops take the cake. Maple bar and/or glaze for me please... 

Notes:

Cash is only form of payment accepted 
Open 24/7
They say in Portland voodoo doughnuts is a must but it was ok. The box was nicer than the doughnuts.

We happened to find ourselves within walking distance of Voodoo Doughnuts around 8pm so we made out way over. There was no line at all! We went with the Voodoo Choice Box (I just made this name up cause I can't remember what it's actually called) where they select a dozen for you. We took our box, stood outside, and the 5 of us went all in. From an outsider's perspectives, we probably looked like monsters! Each of us taking bites and exclaiming our opinion then putting it back in and reaching for another. Can you guess we may have had a drink or two at dinner?

When we looked at our box the next day, it was like a doughnut grave yard, half bitten and left to rot.

We tried Blue Star the day after and all of us agreed it was better. Sorry Voodoo! I'm glad we didn't have to wait long to try you!

Seriously??? 4-5 stars for this place??? I stood in line 30 minutes in 97 degree weather for this??? Yuck!!! The rest of the reviewers need to discover Krispy Kreme... And, if you really want to stand in line 30 minutes for genital-shaped donuts and other stale pastries, knock yourself out. I won't be there with you.

Walked a long way to get here as I had been told I had to visit. Was not impressed. My wife said it looked like they set a bunch of food on the table and told toddlers to come up with different donuts. Fruit loops on a donut? Not interested and didn't buy anything. Guess it was an experience kind of thing.

You can get away with eating there once and calling it a day. Doughnuts shoved into broken cookies. Oooo
Original. I mean they're good after smoking a blunt and have the munchies. But it's even to sweet for my kid. The lines are long. You're forced to carry around the punk box. People actually get married there too. They don't even sell good coffee. I don't think they sell coffee at all. I'm going to a different place.
With the best simple sugar doughnuts and good coffee.

This doughnut shop has been bookmarked for a good two years and vowed to myself if I ever go to Portland, I have to hit this place up. So, I finally had the chance to pick up a box of Voodoo Doughnuts & it waassss... pretty good but our experience was soooo weirdddd. 

On our walk to Voodoo, I already had strange vibes. I now understand the phrase, "Keep Portland Wierd" because dammit, Portland was sooooo wierd. We waited in line for I think 40 minutes which felt like forever. The whole time we were in line, we encountered 6 different strange, homeless, or crazy people. One guy was literally shaking the divider for the line, another one was begging for money, a few minutes later you see a guy starting to scream random things, and a few more people just doing weird shit. At this point I've stopped counting and was just terrified. I just wanted to get my doughnuts and get the hell out of Portland. 40 minutes later, I was finally in the shop deciding which doughnuts to get. My bf was simply not in the mood for anything at this point. So I ordered the iconic voodoo doughnut, Captain Crunch, basic glazed donut, the devils food doughnut, blueberry doughnut, and oreo doughnut. Honestly, not going to lie, it was really good however, I really think I can get the same thing in LA minus the whole crazy encounters. 

Also, the service was meh, I felt rushed and the workers attitude was kinda "whatever you like". It's busy so I guess I kinda understand. Overall, loved the voodoo doughtnut!

This place is soooooo much hype. I think the donuts just might be regionally better than most other places. I was super excited to try Voodoo but it was pretty generic and... blegh...?? It's cash only so make sure to bring the Washingtons. But we came on their anniversary so we got a free maple and bacon donut which was cool!

I mean, we came here because it's pretty well known in Portland. The cool designed donuts. The crazy decor. You know we had to stop by. 

We got some donuts Togo but there isn't anything special about them but how crazy they are designed. I think it was more meant for taking pictures with it rather than the actual taste of it. 

Stop by because it's known in Portland. But for taste, I've tried much better. I would recommend blue star donuts over this for sure!

Not to be a voodoo downer, but I have to be honest. I don't get it. You go and stand in a long line in the hot sun on a grungy street, wind your way through roped off disney-esque lines once inside, try to guess what the hell the menu is trying to tell you, and then pay for a harried server to hand you a box of donuts that you could've got at just about any donut place in the country. Admittedly, the logo is cute.

This place is definitely way more about the experience. I would recommend going once. It's a trendy thing to do in the morning before walking around downtown. They have really fun donuts but certainly not my favorite donut place ever. The apple fritter was the best one I tried. There will be a super long line but it moves quick. Have your order ready!!

The donuts are average, not the best in Portland but I definitely recommend trying it out because they have funky fun flavors that you will not find anywhere else. It is for sure a "must try" for tourists coming to Portland!

The lines are ridiculously long.

The donuts are pretty meh.

Creative, but the taste was just ok. I waited in line for 1/16 of the time at another donut shop and was blown away. 

Went once, won't go back.

Worth the stop because it is a Portland institution

This location (located in Old Town Chinatown) was where it all started and became an international tourist attraction. This was actually part of the walking tour we signed up with and our tour guide gave us the lowdown on some of their unconventional doughnuts. I didn't purchase any donuts from here because the lines were always crazy long looping around the pink dividers but our tour guide hooked us up and brought back a dozen of an assorted mix including their popular Voodoo Doll doughnut. 

We heard stories about their two doughnuts that are no longer available because of violations from the health officials: the NyQuil glazed donut and the Vanilla Pepto Crushed Tums donut. Imagine these ingredients in their donuts... whoa! LoL! You can still have the Cock-N-Balls donut (it has cream filled "balls"). I had the DIRT donut (raised yeast doughnut with vanilla frosting and Oreo cookies). I couldn't finish it, too much Oreo crumbs... it was a little too much for me, like eating dirt. 

This wasn't our first taste of Voodoo Doughnuts, we've had them at the Universal CityWalk Hollywood (SoCal) and a location not too far from this on NE Davis Street (less lines). I just think that they are great donuts but not worth the long wait. If you haven't tried their donuts it's worth it just for the unique experience. It's a known "must do."

Review #1398

The only thing that lived up to the hype about Voodoo Doughnut is their reputation of having a long line at all times of day. The donuts, however, were quite unremarkable and overpriced.

We arrived at 2pm on a weekday and we waited in quite a line. There are 3 counters total that take your order. They're cash only but there's an ATM inside if you're desperate. We waited about 20 minutes before getting to the front of the line.

The donuts are dry and stale. We had the voodoo doll, the grape ape, the Homer, Portland cream, and mable bacon bar. I was impressed with 0 of them. The voodoo doll was super dry that we ended up throwing most of the edge pieces out. The fillings were also not very evenly distributed on the voodoo, which has jelly inside, and the portland cream.

Overall, I woud say that if you're in Portland, visit once to say you've been and take some pictures. I definitely won't go back again for the 2nd time though.

I had a maple bacon donut. It was ok, but seriously overpriced at over $3. Nobody in my group thought the flavor of the donuts was anything special and we all agreed they are overpriced. Sorry. Don't recommend.

wow. 
over priced dough nuts served by smelly hipster defuses with bad attitudes.
wait, i found a hair ! YAY ! is this a contest? i found the pubic hair...what do I win?? 
will not be going back.     :'  (
esp. now that Safeway by Lloyd Center is making dough nuts with 
similar crazy toppings @ $.85 a pop... 

I can appreciate why people like this place so much... but after LOTS of trips there - i can safely say I'm over the lines, the crappy attitudes & overpriced product. 

but they were the first to overprice & assemble interesting doughnut combos so good for them... i guess.

Ok a solid 3.5. We came because we were visiting Portland and had to try Voodoo. I feel like Voodoo is such a landmark that even if you're one of those people that hates everything that's popular you have to try Voodoo just for the experience.

First of all, there's a line. I know some people are probably thinking, "oh my gosh, a line?" Yes, there's a line. You'll be fine. I promise. Second, they don't take card. "Oh my gosh I have to get cash?" Yes, you'll have to get cash. 

I ordered the standard maple bar. I know that sounds ridiculous to order a regular donut that I can get at any donut shop but I wanted to compare apples to apples. Anyone can be fooled by bells and whistles. I needed to get down to brass tax. The maple bar was good, but I've probably had better at little hole in the wall donut shops with the white greasy bags. My bf had the maple bacon bar and exclaimed it was the best donut he's ever had. It looked good but I didn't have any. I appreciated that there were whole bacon strips on top. None of that artificial flavoring business.

The service is ok but I don't think you go here for the amazing service. It's a doughnut shop. If it's your first time in Portland try Voodoo.

What's with the racist voodoo theme, y'all? Why are there problematic caricatures of tribal people on the box? Also, there's always a line that you feel you're about to get stabbed in, there's no bathroom and the donuts are too sweet. And Yelp does this thing where it will hide my good reviews if I don't have enough bad reviews to balance it out. I do genuinely hate this place tho. 

The staff is nice.

Highly overated. Super sketchy location. Homeless people EVERYWHERE! Donuts are good but no better than everywhere else. Seriously just regular donuts with funny names. Lines are super long atleast 30 to 45 min wait for a 5 dollar donuts. I have to admit the hype is why i came and because  it wasnt that special my rating is low. But it really is  just a average donut shop with a huge cult following.

2.5 stars, but since yelp doesn't allow us to give half stars, boosting to 3 stars for originality and aesthetics.

When visiting Portland, a common recommendation is to hit up Voodoo Doughnut.  Evidently, word has spread that this is a spot to hit up and the proof is in the daily long lines outside the door.  Curious passersby likely get reeled in to check out what all the hype is about...

Expect to continue to wait in queue once you get inside the bakery.  No worries, though - time will fly by as you will be amused by the interior decor.  Bright yellow and pink walls are covered nearly from ceiling to floor with framed merchandise for sale, stained glass depictions of their popular sweets, kitschy doughnut and coffin art, paintings of caricatures, etc.  Totally fun & hip vibe with a motley of punk rock, goth, emo scheme.

The myriad of doughnut offerings is just as quirky as the venue.  They definitely earn an A+ for uniqueness.  Many of the pastries are art pieces themselves, almost too cute to eat.  In fact, they do, indeed, look much better than they taste.  We ordered about a half dozen of different selections and they all shared a common trait - gross sweetness.  Crazy sugar overload here, no joke.  Diabetics mos def should stay away from this place as I imagine going into toxic sugar shock/poisoning from eating a whole doughnut, if you dare.  I don't recommend doing so.

In sum, this is a one-of-a-kind donut shop - cool to visit as a tourist site, but skip the food...unless you need a sugar boost for a bout of hypoglycemia.

The worst donuts I've ever eaten in my life. I thought this place was going to be cool but it was not. Disgusting in fact. The people behind the counter were head banging and took at least 2 minutes to acknowledge me. THIS IS A TOURIST TRAP!!!!

Not sure about the hype. 
Its a little too sweet in my opinion (tried the bacon and captain crunch). 
Would not highly recommend it. 

The place is located in a pretty ghetto area. Not good to go late at night, unless accompanied by friends.

Lines!!!! I have been a long time fan of Voodoo, but I've just about had it. I don't care how good your doughnuts are, or how unique the overall experience is, NOBODY likes waiting in line for 30 minutes (or longer) to get some god damn sustenance. Frankly, most people put up with this shit without thinking because they're drunk or have someone to talk to in line, but anyone will agree that if there was an option for faster service, it would be much better. Do the owners simply not care that their operation runs so inefficiently, or do they actually take some sort of pride in the length of the lines? You've got seven people in the back either baking or simply hanging out, while one -- ONE -- person works the register. Figure it out, and I will start coming back again. 

Also, almost every review here mentions the line as a negative factor in their review, but very few reflect that in their star rating, which simply insures that the owners will never change anything. *Confused*

Was in Portland for a wedding and heard rave reviews about this place. I don't get it. It's just OK. I had the maple bacon bar after traversing through a 45-minute line. Nothing remarkable about this place.

Waiting in line for a doughnut, especially a doughnut that isn't spectacular, isn't my cup of tea. Couple this with people giving you attitude about doughnuts...to put it succinctly the experience harshed my mellow.

If you must go, they have a variety of mediocre donuts that are topped with breakfast cereals, filled with canned fruit filling, and doughnuts shaped like male genitalia.

What's even more ridiculous are the gutter punks who ask "Can you spare a doughnut?"

There are much better doughnut shops in Portland, albeit the doughnut shapes are orthodox but the flavor and crumb is much better.

Definitely a cool experience for a first time visitor, but outside of the wide variety of flavors, I was unimpressed with the texture, consistency, and "fluffiness" of the donuts. There were definitely a lot of flavors I have never seen before, accompanied by some very puny titles. That was very impressive and fun to read through!

Grandma sure likes her sweets. Doughnuts. Ice cream. Butterscotch hard candies. The strawberry hard candies. 

Unfortunately, what this place lacks in taste, texture, and quality, they do not make make up for in creativity. 

I don't understand why the line is so long. I walk by and people and lined up. Also, the business is cash only - which just screams illegal food or other monkey business activity. But I don't judge, the economy is bad for people who don't have money. 

One thing I did appreciate was the chocolate milk. Brought me back to when I worked as a lunch lady. I would deliver alpenrose tiny milks to kindergartens classroom. 

My stupid grandson Steven got the cock in balls. Absolutely disgusting. Can't believe he paid money to eat a doughnut shaped like a *enis. It's okay because we accept him for who he is. Even though I grew up in a different time, I still have to adapt to the current times. Now, if only we could get those wild turkeys in congress to "adapt". 

In my opinion, head a block south and grab a coffee and pastry from the coffee place that serves stumptown.

Goodnight.

Ezekiel 23:19-20
~Granma McCray

We heard that Voodoo Doughnut is the go-to donut shop in town, so of course we had to check it out while on vacation. Unfortunately, we weren't too thrilled with our experience. We waited about an hour (if not longer) in line for a donut. Obviously we weren't the only ones waiting!

Since the name of the donut shop is Voodoo, I couldn't help but getting the Voodoo doll donut. My husband got the Pot Hole donut. Honestly, neither were super impressive, just really sweet. If I had to pick one out of the two, I'd go with the Pot Hole, only because it had the Bavarian cream filling and oreo topping, making the donut a little bit more interesting.

If you're looking for a popular spot to go to while in town, you have found it. This would definitely not be on my list of recommendations in Portland, however.

Honestly a big hype. I can probably understand why it would be because of all the cute donuts & crazy toppings they have, but is the donut actually good or is it just IG worthy? I honestly believe the donut is just IG worthy, cute pics to take pics of but the taste of each donut is just like any other ordinary donut you'd find at a mom & pop shop. There is no distinct taste or anything special about it. The donuts are quite pricey ranging from $4 & up, when in reality you have the same exact donut for $1-2 at a hole in a wall shop. I'd also say if you're coming from another city or town that don't have these kind of funky cute donuts, then yes it would taste good & be out of the ordinary for you. Krispy Kreme taste better tbh. If you really want good donuts in Portland, Blue star or Original Pip's is a lot better.
Portland tradition but NOT the best doughnut in town. So many other options in Portland. Locals do not visit Voodoo Doughnuts, only tourists. This is not where locals frequent.

got a lot of suggestions to visit this place (not from OR). not a huge donut person and felt this place was super hyped for what it is. at the end of the day, it was just donuts. staff was nice. they have a variety of different options and lots of toppings. cash only (when i went).

Interesting donut designs that fit the Portland eccentric character. However, the flavor literally is indistinguishable from the fifty cents donuts you can pick up on the Safeway discount rack. 

I don't blame them though, quality donuts usually stand out when served freshly made and warm. The donuts here have been sitting for who knows how long.

Well...its aiite.

Listen, they are soft and hearty but at the end of the day, they are like any other donut shop out there. 

Do I wanna pay $3.50 for the voodoo donut? Did it once, that's it. The donut is heavy due to TOO MUCH JELLY inside. It really is overloaded with it and I had to scrape most of it off. 

Only came to see the KEEP PORTLAND WEIRD sign.

I thought the donuts were okay. A bit overrated for me. But I'm a fan of Dunkin and Krispy Kreme. I would say KK is light, fluffy, moist, melts/dissolves in your mouth and very sweet. DD is more firm, more cake like and the Boston cream is my favorite. Voodoo is the next step towards a cake/bread like consistency. More doughy, firm, a bit chewy and a bit dry. I shared 5 different kinds with friends (bought 2 of them). Also, one needed more bacon to balance out the donut. 

But.... they were fresh, the staff was friendly and very patient. I actually enjoyed the fact that they werent very sweet since they were pretty large. The decor was pretty cool. But overall they were uneventful and not really worth the 25 minute wait.

I just don't get it. Sure, they have wacky flavor combinations, but in the end, they're just mediocre donuts. They don't deliver on all of their promise. There are much, much better donuts to be had (and in MUCH nicer places). For my money, I'll head to Seattle and have a Top Pot Donut!

Tip: No line at 2am. (Thumbs up!)  Place smells like piss and vomit at 2am.  (Thumbs down!)

I'll throw in my 2 cents/stars that nobody but my friends will see in the sea of thousands of reviews of this place.  Portland doesn't have any amusement parks, so instead we stand in long lines for food places downtown or for ice cream at cheese factories.

I've had their donuts before when co-workers would bring in boxes.  Not a fan at all.  The way some people talk about this place you'd think the donuts were frosted with Ambrosia and sprinkled with the crushed wings of angels.

I can pick up the same things at Krispy Kreme and smash some Cap'n Crunch or crumbled Oreos on top and there ya go.  Except mine will still be fresh and crunchy and I got to buy them with a credit card without the long wait.

The silver lining in all this is that every sucker that's standing in this line is one less potential person standing in line in front of me for something good.

Food: 2
Service: 4
Ambiance: 1
Value: 2
TL;DR: I warned you.

Mediocre. Over-rated. Terrible service.
I am 100% certain they tell the employees to serve customers as slowly as possible so that they ALWAYS have a line out front... and it totally works, people are like "oh wow that place must be good, it has a huge line..." FALSE... ok, i mean its doughnuts, they are tasty. But  Voodoo being a PDX tourist destination??? please...
the vibe this place gave me made me lose my appetite and walk right out the door. If you're woke you'd know that this place ain't it. satanic vibes... sorry not sorry I had to take it that far

If you love doughnuts then obviously my review isn't gonna tickle your fancy.  I'm, personally, not very fond of them but my husband insisted on getting VD doughnuts.  He was bewitched by their turning displays of donuts that he ordered a large box full of every donut which was a mistake cause he's struggling to eat the last five (on him for ordering too much for one person).  But I just can't get over the whole donuts with poulds of sugur, layered with additional sugar to have even MORE toppings placed on TOP of the donuts.  

Meh... cash only, limited street parking, and potential for standing in line.

Super slow service for interesting, but just okay donuts.

I gave this place two tries before writing it off.  First try was worth it just to try some funky ingredients on donuts, but I wouldn't bother after that.  There is little organization or effort to move the line along, and many people just walked away from the 20-30 minute wait.  

Serving up coffee and donuts is a time honored tradition, but if you are a police officer seeking the classic snack you better have the day off from fighting crime because you'll need it to get through that line.

Voodoo is another Portland hipster trend like Pabst (the king of $&!T) and fixed gear bikes.  People will try to explain the virtues of these but in the end they fail.

  Voodoo Donuts are the taste equivalent of any grocery store donuts but they add wacky things to the top.  Mostly the things they add to the top are things no customer would eat in real life (captain crunch and other sugary crap cereals and 3 day old bacon.)  Let me know which out there amongst you keep your cooked bacon on a shelf for 24 hours or more.

The donuts are way too sweet, way too expensive and take way to long to get.  Expect a 10-30 minute wait and to be treated with the Portland holier than thou barista attitude.  The servers look at you as another bovine consumer to be ignored and then pushed through line as quickly as possible.  I get treated better at a Wall Mart.

If you want a great pastry god to any small Mexican shop or an Asian market. The pastries are not loaded with crap, they don't cost 4 bucks and they are unique and different.  They usually cost about 50 - 60 cents and the staff treat you with respect.

Voodoo, like Pabst, fixed gear bikes and really tight jeans over misshapen asses is a Portland tread based on the "cool" factor not on the actual product.  I'm sure if you enjoy being really hip and cool, drink Pabst smear and harbor a misshapen blob under your gray jeans you will enjoy Voodoo.
If not save your money and soul and get something that is truly different and delicious

Similar to a place in my hometown, Voodo Doughnuts is a specialty doughnut shop that provides doughnuts which are out of the ordinary. It is open 24/7 and definitely a fun place to stop by when you're from out of town. Typically when I come in with friends, we stop by around midnight or so where there is usually a crowd. There are lots of food trucks near this location as well (in case your friends want doughnuts but you want something else). It's a popular tourist spot, THIS IS BETTER THAN BLUE STAR DOUGHNUT which people also recommend "when in Portland". It's a fun place to go when you're in town. I normally get the ODB (Ol' Dirty Bastard) which is Oreos and a Peanut bitter drizzle on top of a fudge icing on the doughnut. It is delicious! The doughnuts are rather large so I definitely recommended sharing them with a friend. Also, note that because this is a specialty place you'll be paying a higher price than a regular doughnut. Stop by and try it out once if you haven't!

I'd say this is a must as a tourist attraction but not a culinary must. It's fun to check this place out, see the doughnut names and variations... But other than the maple bacon bar I don't love the doughnuts. They always seem a bit stale to me and definitely aren't worth the enormous line that usually awaits you. For my doughnut fix I prefer Blue Star doughnuts.

After hearing about this place for years, what a let down. Overhyped. There was no line when I went but I went at an odd hour. This place is all about the weird flavors, naughty shaped, and crazy add ons, not necessarily the fact the actual donuts are high quality fluffs of sweet heavenly dough. 

Portand has to die for bakeries with award winning chefs and bakers so not sure the hype surrounding this place. I am sure it is just a fun tourist trap kind of place that every city has. Decor is cool though! And I am guessing it is fun to come in and get a phallic shaped donut especially if you are drunk after-hours. ( Voodoo is open 24 hours) 

I chose two donuts on my visit. On the first one I could not taste the donut itself because there was too much stuff and extra flavorings on it. It was also kind of stale/ hard. This was the, "Dirty Bastard" flavored donut. The verdict was that it was good but it was like a 5 year old's birthday cake, just too much going on. Sometimes less is more, ya know? 

However, i also got a Guava Colada and that one was tasty and came with an umbrella. Haha!  I loved the coconut and the filling. ( who knew) However, yet again, the cake part was nothing special.

Get in line, folks, read neat historical facts on posters, watch the WINNERS come out the exit with their championship pink boxes!! Running through town are many winners just like you who braved the rain, fought off the homeless, and triumphed over numerous obstacles to PAY FOR DONUTS. They are good donuts, they are famous donuts, they are at times, weird donuts. Yet, they are donuts, you will eat them, they will be gone, and all you have left is a story about how you GOT THEM. It's an experience. A Portland must-do, unfortunately.

So, there has never been a time in my eating experience which has moved me so much so that I must sign up for yelp and write a negative review, until now...

This is and will be forever more my first and last visit to voo doo donuts, in downtown Portland; it was definitely a unique experience, for one, I won't be returning. My reasons mainly include: rude service, nothing-special-doughnut, and a hype which I don't really understand or wish to share with all the eager late night doughnut mongers. 

The counter help was rude, and had no energy to work up any amount of customer service. My advice would be, don't work there if you are miserable and miserable looking. The counter person asked me if I wanted a bag for my donuts, I said yes, and they reached for a bag and left if on the counter next to my donuts. I waited and realized the counter person wasn't going to bag it. Here I am reaching over the counter bagging my own doughnut holding up the line wondering what went wrong. Then realized I must have offended the person with my faux fur trimmed coat, this person had "vegan" tattooed across the front neck. This is the first time I wanted to take my money out of the tip jar.

Besides the rude service, their doughnuts were cold, stale and too sweet. My guess if you're not going to get some outrageous bacon cheese doughnut, just go somewhere like Krispy Kreme. You'll probably get something more fresh and soft. 

The hype, which is bogus, is generated with eclectic and obscure underground music, rugged interior decorations, night creatures, and hand stamped pink doughnut boxes to make people feel ultra sassy, artsy fartsy, and liberated by other "plain" doughnut companies. Like a freak show experience, I can see how this can be a novel experience for sheltered folks. 

So folks, this place is more for fast food junkies with no taste, especially with donuts. The place caters to hipsters, wannabe hipsters or idealistic vegan hipsters. 

Don't go there looking for something magical, the magic is definitely NOT in this hole.
The donuts are gross. Period. I suppose they would be fun for a toddler because of the crazy colors? The smell of these things makes my mouth salivate with nausea.

Although this is a popular tourist destination when visiting Portland, I had no interest in going to this donut shop. A lot of friend told me the donuts here are not very good and is just hype. During my trip to Portland, I was downtown and accidentally walked passed this place. The line was short so I decided to just go in and try. The decor is very fun and the employees look like they are having a good time.  I waited probably about 10 minutes and the line moved very quickly. The line was even more enjoyable with 80's music playing. I got the DIRT (Oreo donut) and Voodoo donut. I actually enjoyed both donuts more than the donuts I tried at Blue Star Donuts. After eating the donuts, I got a probably non-coincidental stomach ache. Overall, I did enjoy the donuts more than I thought I would, the line at this place although may seem long, moves very fast, but I did feel I got a stomach ache from the donuts here.

I remember Voodoo Doughnut from almost a decade ago when my brother brought back a box from his trip to Portland. He raved about how cool and popular it was. Sure, they looked extraordinary but I wasn't impressed with how they tasted. Maybe because they weren't fresh? Fast forward to my recent trip which was well after the donut craze that hit up SoCal, NY, and what have you, I decided to pay them a visit and check out what voodoo magic they had under these donuts.

The store was eccentric to say the least. They say a line is normally expected but apparently not on a Tuesday morning when I went. After a few IG worthy shots from every corner of the store, I finally reached the front of the line with no clue what to get. The lady helped me out in getting a dozen various donuts. They were truly all sorts of weird and wonderful in a box, similar to how I would describe this city. I loved the creativity and the colors but they were overly sweet for me. 

My top three would have to be:
*Bacon Maple Bar ($3.50) - Anything with bacon is fab but two long crispy strips? Winner! 
*Neopolitan ($1.65) - Chocolate cake donut covered in strawberry and vanilla frosting with marshmallows. Looks really pretty, too. 
*Mango Tango ($2.45) - Mango jelly filled donut topped with orange frosting. The flavor combo was superb especially since I love orange flavored anything.

All these were again, very sweet but if taken in small doses, they can be a treat. Voodoo Doughnut may be the OG when it comes to gourmet donuts but the competition they have now is far more superior in taste and quality. Come for the novelty but that's it. Cash only!

I am so not a fan.  Mediocre donuts covered in Fruit Loops or Captain Crunch cereal.  This is not haute cuisine of donutdom.  It's not even good at 2:00 am.  It just brings the vomit up faster if that's your goal.  Last time I went I ended up giving my half eaten donut to a hungry homeless kid.  It was THAT good.  It still made me sick.  Ugh.  Do yourself a favor and skip this Portland institution.  Just because that guy on Food Network liked the maple bacon, doesn't mean you have to become a sheeple and like it, too.  Hell, just go to Freddy's and get a day old donut and a box of ceral.  It'll taste better and save you a 45 minute wait in line with the great unwashed.  You'll thank me later.

I may get shot by the local fans of this place and maybe my review might be a little premature as I've only been living in Portland for a week but I thought that these doughnuts deserved 3 stars not a star more. I'm no doughnut snob either. I just thought these tasted pretty average as far as doughnuts go. I tried the famous bacon maple bar (delish but just a little too sweet and I wish it  had more bacon!), the buttermilk bar (nice and dense) and the chocolate one with the cocoa puffs. I made the mistake of eating the cocoa puffs doughnut a day too late so it was a little stale though I knew it would've tasted a lot better had I eaten it the same day. 

I do like the novelty aspect of it (voodoo's dozen being 13, not 12) and the crazy flavors and shapes but since I'm now living here, I know that my visit wouldn't be the last one.

The only reason you should go to Voodoo is because it's a Portland staple. It's iconic. It's mentioned whenever people talk about things to do there. 

Is it worth the line and wait? No. Does the interior look cool? Yes. Yes it does. It's a fun place to visit, you can buy a tee shirt saying you were there, and you can also eat outside. 

They have so many different doughnut flavors, I struggled to pick just one. I finally settled on the Voodoo Doll--I figured it was like their namesake or something. It was okay at first, until I reached the jelly filling. 

ALSO they accept credit cards now! Overall, you should come for the pictures and to say you've been to Voodoo, but go at an off-time. I do not think it is worth the wait when you could walk ~20 minutes to Blue Star for something similar (says someone who doesn't usually eat many doughnuts and had more in two days in Portland than all of last year.)

I am making a trip to Washington from California and just had to try voodoo doughnuts! I placed my order online for fast and easy pickup. The doughnuts are delicious, but not anything to rave about. The hype is more about the special flavors and cute decorations. Still a cool place to stop by at least once in your life.

I would rather be diagnosed with a VD than have to eat another donut from VD...yes, I said it...they're that bad. 

If you enjoy eating fancily decorated peanut butter coated sponges and rubbery cereal then this is your nirvana. I love sweets, so donuts are no exception, but hated each and every one of these. 

I purchased 5 donuts in total, 3 of the yeast variety and 2 cake. Two of my selections had peanut butter, cant go wrong there, and the others were sprinkles and fruit loops . The dough was old, cold and stale...it was like eating a sponge. The raspberry filling was the only thing that made this donut 'sweet.' The cereal on the fruit loops was like rubber, very old as well and chewy. All eventually went in the trash after I grew tired of looking at them on the counter of the room in my hotel. 

The store is super small and gets cramped quickly with tourists like myself who are under VooDoo's spell. They even have a time limit posted on their bathroom door of 3 minutes. Employees are even more cold and soulless than the donuts that they are serving. 

When I get home, the first order of business will be to stop by my nearest crafting store and make VooDoo dolls of the employees and make them eat the donuts that they serve.
Eh. It's ok. The location isn't the greatest. Their other location on the east side is more comfortable.

We read the reviews for this place and saw that a lot of people were saying how sickly sweet these doughnuts are. And still, we had to try it once to see why people are lined up outside Voodoo 24/7 and sometimes walking away with home depot buckets full of them (I'm NOT joking). Also, I love sweets more than anyone I know, so I thought people must be crazy to say a doughnut was "too sweet". 

I have to say that everyone was right. The icing was so thick on these that they left a sticky burn of sweetness in the back of my throat. I powered through the maple bacon bar because mama didn't raise a quitter, but was ultimately left disappointed. Also, it is NOT maple. It's pancake syrup icing. Of which there was so much of that icing oozed out as I bit into the doughnut.

We also tried the glazed, which I found to be a delicious and well balanced doughnut, unlike it's voodoo brethren. The stars are for that doughnut. We'll pass on this place in the future.

Finally had their bacon maple donut and it wasn't the best. The fruit loop donut was also lacking flavor. Maybe if the donuts were nicely warm it would be different. I had such high hopes for this place. I love the atmosphere and vibes. Their donuts are really creative which I love. I think to a young kid they would really love this place, but I was wanting a nice warm delicious donut. The prices are reasonable. I heard the line can get pretty long, but luckily I was able to walk right up. I think next time I would just stick to a plain donut and warm it up at home. Otherwise, I am glad I was able to visit a Portland staple. 

Pros:
-Wide variety of donuts
-Merch/souvenirs available 

Cons:
-Parking
-Line could be long
-Lack of flavor 

BONUS TIP- Yes, you can buy a box of donuts and take it with you on the plane! Also, they make great IG photos!

-One of all and one for Yelp!

I'm not a huge fan of donuts so my review may be bias but this place was more of an attraction/hype to me. We were recommended by locals to check this place out so we had to. We came here late at night after a night on the town and there was still a line out the door! It moves quickly though. Ordered a bunch of different kinds of donuts to try and they were all just mediocre to me. Definitely go check it out for yourself though. At least we got that checked off our list of things to try in Portland.

THE GOOD: No line and very friendly employees. They could probably benefit from a little extra training as there was some confusion and mix-ups. Even so, the service was super friendly and nice! 

THE GREAT: the Portland cream was so fricking delicious!!!!!! I need to get like 10 more and take them back home with me or I might have withdrawals. The Dirt was also very delicious. 

THE NOT-SO-GOOD: the server gave us a voodoo dozen even if we hadn't asked for it and we felt bad so had to take it. We were allowed to swap out some, but could have benefitted from more clarity and it felt kind of pressured ($20 is a lot for a dozen - especially when som  of it is stuff we didn't really want). It was my bday so we decided to just get them all and then we could leave. The Homer was not tasty. There are no seats outside right now (covid) and that is very understandable, but most places also around kept theirs open and it just made it less of a nice experience. 

PRO TIP: decide on a place to eat donuts before purchasing and make sure you know what you want! 

The VOODO DOLL - not delicious per my husband. He couldn't eat it.

These doughnuts are not worth waiting for. They don't melt in your mouth, they taste stale and the staff is pretty annoyed by the time you get to the counter. It's a cool shop and obviously a Portland institution, but their doughnuts are not worth the calories nor the ridiculous wait in line.

Greasy, oily doughnuts that are jam packed full of empty surgery toppings.....yuck!!!! The location of this place is also not one of Portland's better places, known to have mice and insect problems in this area. Caution!!!!!!

I've had a lot of specialty doughnuts in my days, this place was good, don't get me wrong. However, I feel the name and hype behind it isn't quite worth the price. A little overpriced and a good bit of a line for what you get. Definitely worth trying, but doesn't stand out compared to other similar competitors I've had in the past. Taste+price+wait= 3 starts

Came for the hype and that's really about it. They had a 13 for $13 deal going on, so we didn't get to choose the doughnuts we got. The assortment they provided us wasn't too unique and out of the 13 doughnuts, I think there were only 2-3 that I really liked. The rest were good but nothing special and nothing that I couldn't find back home.

I personally liked the ones with Oreos and cereal (the rainbow one) on it.

Will I come back again? If the line wasn't 5 miles long, I'd think about it... but honestly, for such a long line, I think this store did an amazing job with getting people in and out.

A month later I still can't decide if that was worth an hour wait in the rain. Yes, the place is funky, edgy, and the voodoo doll donuts are freakin hilarious (and, might I add, delicious), but these aren't the best doughnuts I've ever had. 

Still, the outrageous flavor combinations are much appreciated and I happily took a box home - the voodoo doll, Maple Blazer Blunt doughnut (yes it looks like a blunt), some peanut butter chocolate oreo amalgamation (oh wait, that's right, it's called the Olde Dirty Bastard), and a lemon chiffon cruller. The hour plus wait is pure madness but that's really the only negative thing I can think of - and yes, negative only to cranky customers like myself but props to Voodoo for their growing popularity!

Portland institution? Perhaps. But 3 chances and each time the donuts have been consistently unsatisfactory.

Perhaps each time I've been unlucky and gotten donuts from an old batch, but that isn't really acceptable either.

The glazes are overly sweet, the cereal stale and the donuts taste of old oil and leave a greasy film in my mouth. Strangely, there's an unpleasant burning sensation left in the back of my throat after each swallow.

There are plenty of superior alternatives so I'd definitely skip unless you're dying to bask in the juvenile sexual innuendo permeating every aspect of their marketing which is about as subtle as the flavor of their donuts.

Also, the pretzel in the voodoo doll was stale too.

In Portland?  Never been to Voodoo Doughnut?  Then you must go.  But perhaps just walk by and bask in the splendor of its Voodoo; no real need to get a donut unless you have time, cash (only) and a SERIOUS craving for donuts.

They have some wacky donuts - and I support wacky things.  We got three donuts and they lasted us two days.  They're big.  I got an Apple Fritter - but when we got back to where we were staying it turned out to be a Banana Fritter.  I guess I'm OK with that, but what if I was allergic to bananas?   Oof.  Also went for the Portland Cream with 2 eyes on it.  The eyes make it Portland Weird.  Also got a mango filled coconut donut that isn't on their internet menu.  Very very sweet.
