Anyhow, now that I've been to Voodoo, I don't have to go again unless I'm with another tourist who hasn't been there.  I will give them points for weirdness and fun.

The hype about the must see spots will always get any yelper to go see and experience themselves what it's all about.  The amount of attention the donut industry has received within the last few years is amazing.  It's so mainstream now as everyone's go to dessert or to fulfill our sweet tooth or cravings for sweets, it brought Chel here. 

On my northwest vacation earlier this year,  I knew I was going to drop by here no matter what.   It was definitely in my bookmark.  Located in downtown Portland, street parking wasn't too bad midweek right before lunch hour.  A short walk led us to a short line that took about 20 mins to get inside the building. 

So wow.  The first thing that I noticed was that Huge donut artifact on top of the ceiling.   Very eclectic decor indeed from one wall to another,  then you have the several glass cases, rotating ones too, with displays of their unique donut creations.

What to get? Hhmmm...this and that but the bacon maple bar was definitely first on my list.  The oblong shape maple donut with two strips of bacon on top can make anyone drool just by looking at it as it did Chel.  Although   I'm not too much of a donut fan, that balanced taste of salt and sweet just screams, "eat me, eat me Chel!" So she did gracefully only to wash it down with a cup of Stumptown coffee (ty Ninong Joseph A. for reminding me). But I wish it was warm, and the maple still slightly wet, and the bacon freshly made and more crispy so when you bite into it the entire bacon doesn't come off the donut.  That's just my idea of an awesome,  honest to goodness, BOMB azz bacon maple donut!

Soft.  Tasty.  Teaser.   Unique.  Sweet.  Yup.  Creativity at its best but nothing I would tell anyone that you HAVE to go and have a Voo Doo donut because they would be missing out on something incredible.  No.  It's a tourist spot for us yelpers to see for ourselves and be wowed but eh...   after this trip to Voo Doo,  I did find a spot that I can totally recommend to anyone to go to for some bomb azz maple bacon donuts!

Ty Portland for the VooDoo experience!

So I moved, but I lived in Portland and had to do the voodoo experience once! I waited in line with all the tourists, downtown where I never go bc of parking. Anyways, I wait in line, get to the woman and she was hella rude! Like, why? Then I order 3 donuts. I was so hungry because I waited in line for donuts, so I went to bite in and... stale. Like, I need water please stale. I just wasn't a fan. I stopped at Safeway on my way home and forgot I had brought my dog so she ate the rest while I was in the store.
They might have remodeled to add more cash registers, but they still only have two people behind the counter, and the wait is over an hour.

The store space is very small and dark. The donut was okay. The bathroom was not. It is coed, single bathroom. The donut was very sweet for me, and I tried a few different ones. So many great reviews but I thought it was maybe okay.

I have to say it is over rating. I don't see the donuts have any different than others. We came here out of curiosity as everyone said We have to pay tribute If we are around Portland area. It was not super busy may be because of Sunday? However we still had to wait for 20 mins before placing order. Unlike others who ordered boxes after boxes, we just got 2 regular donuts - Homer and Daisy. If the line is too long I would not recommend for the wait. It is not worthy.

Caved in and lined up for their doughnuts today; just wanted to try it out for myself. The line actually wasn't too bad, if it wasn't for the blazing sun. 

We got the Memphis Mafia which is a banana fritter drowsed with chocolate and peanut butter chips and sauces on top; it was montrous. We also tried the Buttermilk Bar that was much more managable, size-wise.

To my surprise, the doughnuts weren't as sweet as I thought they'd be! Although the Buttermilk Bar looked bland on the outside, it has a velvety, buttery taste. The glaze on the outside was crispy and kept the moisture within the bar, giving it a good, soft texture. 

The Memohis Mafia was also rather nice; I've never tried a banana fritter before. The banana chunks went really well with the chocolate and peanut butter chips/sauces. 

The doughnuts were not stellar, but they're totally fun to try and, definitely, share with A LOT of people. Perhaps, more of a spot for the experience rather than good doughnuts :)

I stopped by Voodoo during my visit to Portland this past week. It wasn't at the top of my list because there's a donut shop with a similar concept back in my hometown (psycho donuts in SJ). But once you see everyone walking around with pink boxes, you're motivated to see what the hype is all about. 

The line was out the door when we came on a Thursday around 3pm as expected. The total wait was about 25-30 minutes. And the wait was not worth it...sorry, Voodoo! Your pink and purple colors and creepy music provided a fun atmosphere though.

All the donuts I got were consistently dry. The donuts are large, topped with frosting, cereal, oreo crumbs, and basically all of your usual ice cream sundae toppings. It's a sugar overload with every bite, but the batter itself isn't anything to rave about. It's a fun experience, especially for kids! 

Still, if you want good donuts in Portland, people recommend Blue Star. I would recommend Pips!

Well if you're visiting Portland I guess you have to go to Voodoo, but I found it pretty gimmicky.  Donuts were good, but this is not much more than a tourist place.  Since it is near the Keep Portland Weird sign, I guess it's kind of an obligatory stop, but once was enough for me.

This location is in kind of a weird part of town next to Chinatown and the waterfront. I think it's part of a new revitalization that some building are abandoned but there might be a new coffee shop right next to it. 

When it's not raining there is no reason you can't wait in line for the donuts and coffee but in the rain I can't imagine it at all. 

I do like that they have a list of the donuts on the wall outside the building and also inside there is a big menu and a two cases swirling with the donuts.. there is no reason you shouldn't know what you want when you get to the cashier. 

They only accept cash but have an ATM inside which is only helpful if you have a debit card with you. 

While the donuts are cute and fun.... I'll say this .. they are not that good. It is more of the PdX culture than anything else. It is great that prices are low (2 donuts and 2 coffees were $6.20). I'll be honest, my donut was dry and I could taste the grease a little too much.

Not worth the hype. Donuts are a bit dry and they definitely don't taste or look fresh. Interesting assortment of flavors though (maple log is better than expected) and cheap prices. 

I wouldn't wait in line longer than 15 minutes or order more than 2 donuts.

Tourists trap, but still worth going and "check-in" if you are the tourist. If you want to get some real good donuts, go to blue star or just some random bakeries in Portland, they are all way better than voodoo. 
The voodoo dolls is extremely sweet and full of artificial flavoring stuffs. I'm not a fan of the jam inside the dough at all. Memphis mafia, giant and super sweet, full of cheap ingredients. 
You need this once in a life time experience waiting in the line and checking the store, but I certainly would not come back for donuts again.

We waited to visit Voodoo Donut for years. Very disappointed! The donuts were run-of-the-mill, and the workers couldn't have been more rude. Ridiculously rude. I suppose at one time this place was on the cutting edge, but fruit loops on donuts is overrated. Did I mention how rude the staff was? Very rude.

What a let down.  This is nothing than a Winchells doughnut with stale cereal dropped on it.  Yeah, they have cool names for the doughnuts, like cock and balls. (love me some of both).  In reality its a room that barley hold 6 fat guys and a staff of nasty people that appear to be unhappy with life.  After you climb over the filthy pan handlers, make sure you have cash, they dont accept cards.

I mean, it's a donut. It can't be that bad, right? Sure, their offerings taste perfectly fine. But for all of the BS that you have to go through to actually get a Voodoo Donut, they should be just astounding. And they're not.

Voodoo subscribes to the "more is more" philosophy, making ridiculous donuts. Some are shaped like genitals. others are topped with breakfast cereal. Others are made to resemble blunts. From my perspective, it's all so painfully calculated to be in the "Keep Portland Weird" vein that it's a turn-off. If I want a donut, I just want it to be good. It doesn't have to be wacky.

That being said, to each his own. Some people obviously like Voodoo. In fact a ton of people do, as evidenced by the horrendous line that congregates seemingly 24/7. To their credit, they keep the line moving fairly quickly. This might be part of their reasoning for being cash only. 

Basically, I'm a dude that likes good but less flashy donuts, who doesn't like waiting in massive lines for them, and wants to pay using a card. Voodoo is clearly not for me.
way overrated  pastry stop......would you really stand in line......makes me nostalgic for the superlative Blue Star.....sad passing????

With one morning to spare in Portland and a child eager for sugar, we had to stop at Voodoo. It fulfilled our desire to hit up an iconic PDX spot and receive ample calories for a morning of walking around, but the actual doughnuts were underwhelming and the coffee was bad. The bathroom was also "out of order" (whether it truly was or was a ruse to deter transients, I do not know). The themed decor, as always, was fun/morbid, which made for a more worthwhile experience altogether, and the employees were nice and playing good music.

*2.5 Stars*


Voodoo donuts... yeah, you sure did put some voodoo on me... but not the good kind. I have a soft spot in my heart for donuts, especially those warm and fluffy ones. Welp, I'm sad to report that Voodoo's donuts were neither fluffy nor warm. In fact, they were more on the stale side and they definitely didn't taste fresh. I guess I should also add that one of the workers left a real bad taste in my mouth. His attitude really threw me off, but luckily the gentleman at the register was much more pleasant to deal with.
 
One of the biggest turn offs about this place is that they are cash only! Ugh... I hate it. However, I did come prepared since I was traveling, so that cash got spent. I got here at 10:00 am on a Saturday and was able to beat the line. I can't lie... these donuts are definitely esthetically pleasing! If they were in a best looking donuts contest, they would probably win hands down. But, you have to have the taste to really back it up, and these donuts just didn't have that.
 
I ended up getting three donuts: the Captain my captain, Butterfingering, and their seasonal gingerbread donut. The Captain my captain is topped with icing that has Captain Crunch cereal on top. The donut tasted okay, but the cereal tasted very stale. The Butterfingering was probably my least favorite because it was extremely dry. The Butterfinger topping and outside coating was moist, but the inside of the donut was still dry. My favorite one was their seasonal gingerbread donut! The frosting had a wonderful gingerbread taste but the donut still tasted pretty stale.
 
I can understand donuts being a bit stale if I was getting them late at night. But if it's 10 am in the morning, there is absolutely no reason why they should taste like they've been sitting out all day! This coupled with the bad attitude of the employee who was pushing the bucket made me feel like I had chosen the wrong donut shop to go to. Maybe it's harder to make fresh and fluffy donuts with all of those crazy ingredients on top of them, but I'd rather have a fresh plain donut than a fancy stale one. Overhyped? Hell yes! Would I come back? It's up in the air right now, but I would probably try Blue Star donuts before heading back over to this place.

Donuts were good, went during covid so wasn't allowed in the store. First time to Oregon, wasn't really impressed or wowed.. design of the donuts are totally funny. We bought a mug which was pretty cool felt like the donuts were a little overpriced

I've been to two locations in Portland, and have picked up voodoo donuts at a few other retailers. The donuts are OK, but you don't go there for the quality food, you go there for the uniqueness of the brand and the product, which they have down pat. 

The donuts are R rated, so I definitely wouldn't take someone under 13. The flavors are definitely creative. Full of lots of artificial colors and such. They aren't cheap either, but if you want a deal on them you can pick up a bucket of the day old ones for a real bargain.

Voodoo Doughnuts is an insulting joke.

Parked across the street is a building with the self-indulgent cliche, "Keep Portland Weird". And that, apparently, is what Voodoo thinks it is doing. At least, that is what its patrons seem to be celebrating.

But don't fall for it.

Voodoo Doughnuts isn't weird. It's just a sub-par, hyper-commercialized, offensively expensive donut place full of empty promises of creativity and memorable experience.

The donuts are nothing to speak of. They are decidedly "not bad". But you won't be paying "not bad" prices -- no, you'll be paying the Portland-promotion-premium. That apple fritter you want? That plain cruller you're eyeing? Yeah, check the price on that before you buy.

"BUT", you say, "you're paying for the experience!" Let's talk about the experience. You wait in a long line (probably an hour wait on average, and certainly longer at peak times). The line is poorly managed and ends up making traffic in and out of the store congested and bothersome. As you wait, you'll no doubt be surrounded by tourists and "OMG I LOVE PORTLAND IT'S SOOOO WEIRD!!!" natives talking about the very donut store they are now patronizing.

Once inside, you'll be bombarded by merchandise -- including slutty underwear -- brandishing the Voodoo Doughnuts logo. Overpriced merchandise. Everywhere. As you slowly work your way through the packed-in crowd, you'll find a disturbing lack of explanation of the various donut varieties. What exactly is a "Maple Blazer Blunt", you might ask. And as you notice the price, you'll wonder what magic they've worked beneath the surface to make it such an extraordinary specimen. If you take the dive, you'll discover that you spent way too much money on what is essentially just a donut with maple frosting and red sprinkles.

So the lack of donut descriptions isn't really a problem. They're just normal donuts with perhaps a strange topping and an unusual name.

And therein lies the kicker. This whole "experience" that people speak of? It's entirely empty. Like standing at the corner of Hollywood and Vine, it's only an "experience" in that you can say that you've done it. But it's not particularly unique or enjoyable, and you certainly wouldn't care for it at all had the very successful marketing campaign not convinced you to somehow brave Portland drivers in the rain in order to spend way too much money on decidedly "not bad" donuts. The creativity of the donuts is...well, you tell me: Is it "creative" to put Fruit Loops on top of a donut? If you think so, then heck, I guess you'll love this place.

You want real creativity? How about a "Cock-N-Balls". It's chocolate-covered, cream-filled donut. In the vague shape of a crudely-drawn penis. If that's the amazing experience and creative one-of-a-kind weirdness that you want to have as part of your Portland experience, then go for it.

But let's not pretend that it's anything other than a normal donut with a slightly different shape and a name that is nothing more than a cheap marketing gimmick.

And let's not pretend that you're really helping the local community when you buy from Voodoo. Voodoo is ripping off natives and tourists alike, offering nothing special in exchange. You're not supporting Portland; you're supporting Voodoo. But I guess that's what Portland is -- a whole bunch of people wanting really badly to believe that they're creative and weird, but they're really just an audience easily marketed towards (see Obama's record-breaking crowd in the same city).

On the plus side, the donuts are by no means bad. And the variety, while mostly stupid and just a repackaging of your typical variety, does have some gems. The peach fritter, for instance, is a rare find. The Mexican hot chocolate donut is another enjoyable varietal that you're unlikely to encounter elsewhere. Still, the prices are exorbitant and you can just as easily have an apple fritter as a peach fritter. Likewise, a chocolate donut won't suddenly pale in comparison the Mexican hot chocolate donut.

Bottom line: Voodoo donuts are pretty good donuts. But they're not amazing, they're not creative, they're not worth the price, they're not worth the wait, and you're better off going to any other "pretty good" donut place.

I've now been to Voodoo twice. Once when a friend was visiting and wanted to try their vegan doughnuts, and another when a group of friends and I decided to try it on a weeknight. The line here is also super long, and I personally wouldn't wait longer than 30 min. They used to be cash-only but they accept card now, which is great! I like tart, fruity flavors so I've tried the mango tango and the pina colada. This place is definitely super popular with tourists, but most of the people I know prefer Blue Star. Overall, if you're willing to wait in line for some fun, wacky-looking doughnuts, then come here. It's not a must, but it's an experience.

Got to the front of the line and found out it was cash only ATM inside was broken ATM across the street is broken went into a gas station no cash back and their ATM was broken... are you serious. Really disappointed will not be back.

I'm rewriting my review of voodoo. I ordered their memphis mafia which used to be my favorite item, but this time it was very dry and flavorless. My other favorite fritter has been removed from their menu. Those were the only 2 things I've ordered and liked from them.

First time in Portland and had heard the hype about this place. Afterwards, I can't see what the craze is all about.

It's located in what seemed like a pretty seedy neighborhood. There were homeless people at almost every corner and questionable folk walking around. It's right next to the "Keep Portland Weird" sign, a photo op location so that was a plus. We got there late afternoon on a weekday and the line wasn't that long - maybe a 10 minute wait, so that was also a plus. 

The actual donuts themselves didn't taste that good. Didn't taste fresh, and the one I had was pretty dry (oreos and peanut butter drizzle). The price was decent but it's cash only. 

I guess I'd recommend coming here for the intrigue and Portland factor, but don't expect amazing tasting donuts.
Dunkin' Donuts is much better- they don't include complimentary hairs in their donuts.

No line on a Tuesday at 2 pm! I tried pips before this spot and although there were a lot of flavors and options here, the fresh mini Pip donuts were much tastier. I found these to be too sweet but I do like the idea of bringing these to people for the fun factor. I wouldn't stay in line for these or go out of my way to carry these home, but I would buy them again for all the interesting flavors and presentation.
Not sure if the wait is worth the donuts. They are too sweet, but it was alright to try out at least once.
